title: A Liberal Hollywood Actor Who Speaks Up for Bush
description: The actor Ron Silver was leaving a cocktail party at the Four Seasons restaurant on Monday evening, headed for Madison Square Garden, when he ran into Henry A. Kissinger, whom he once played in a made-for-television movie. They greeted each other warmly, but as they shook hands, Mr. Kissinger raised a quizzical eyebrow and said, in his distinctive, German-tinted rasp, "What are you doing being a Republican?"

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 20, 2003, about Sergio Vieira de Mello, the high commissioner for human rights who was the United Nations' top official in Iraq when he was killed in a bombing in Baghdad, omitted a survivor. She was his partner, Carolina Larriera, with whom he lived in Paris. The omission was pointed out in a recent letter from his family.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Defendant To Stand Trial In Elizabeth Smart Kidnapping
description: Brian David Mitchell, who is accused of kidnapping Elizabeth Smart, was declared mentally competent to stand trial. Mr. Mitchell was a homeless man who had done some repair work at the Salt Lake City home of Ms. Smart, who was a teenager, before she was taken from her bedroom at knifepoint in June 2002. Mr. Mitchell and his wife, Wanda Barzee, have been in custody since March 2003, when they were found walking down a Utah street with Ms. Smart. Mr. Mitchell is said to suffer narcissistic delusions, and his wife has been found mentally incompetent to stand trial. No trial date has been set yet. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHMANN, FRITZ P.
description: LEHMANN--Fritz P. On August 30, 2004. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. All who knew him loved and respected him as a person of modesty, humility & dignity.

title: Trying to Stay Competitive, Cambodia Joins W.T.O.
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 31 - Cambodia's legislature voted Tuesday to approve the nation's entry into the World Trade Organization, a step forced by new rules for international textile and apparel trade that could otherwise have smothered the country's garment industry.

title: Sea Salts With a Special Touch
description: Most of the natural sea salts introduced in the last few years have about the same effect on your food. But texture is a factor and can influence the amount you use. The latest exotic salts are from Asia: Bali, Bangladesh and the Himalayas, from ancient marine deposits left in the foothills.

title: Hostage Crisis Unfolds in Russia as Guerrillas Seize School
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1  Heavily armed insurgents, some with explosives strapped to their bodies, seized a school in southern Russia today, herded scores of schoolchildren, parents and teachers into its gymnasium and threatened to kill them.

title: Is It Time to Scrap the Electoral College?

title: Beneath Putin's Pedestal, the Ground Keeps Shaking
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31 - If there has been a consensus on Vladimir V. Putin's presidency, it is about stability. He has brought stability, the consensus goes, to Russia's economy, its foreign policy, to its politics. If the cost of stability has been aspects of authoritarianism, then that is a price most, here and abroad, have been willing to pay.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hollinger Report Says Ex-Officials Diverted Cash A special committee of the publishing company Hollinger International concluded in a report that the former officials Conrad M. Black and F. David Radler ran a "corporate kleptocracy," diverting to themselves virtually all the company's $400 million in earnings over seven years. The report also criticized certain directors for being "ineffective and careless" in stopping the "systematic looting" of the company.

title: Venice perfects its American accent
When Pest Killers Make Mistakes
description: Correction Appended

title: British Grid Operator to Sell 4 Gas Networks
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 - National Grid Transco, the owner of Britain's power and natural gas grids, agreed on Tuesday to sell half of its gas-distribution networks for 5.8 billion ($10 billion), a move that would help the company cut debt and prepare for possible expansion in the United States.

title: Country Laurels
description: In Nashville the Country Music Association has announced that the singer, songwriter and actor Kris Kristofferson, above right, and the former music executive Jim Foglesong have been elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame. They will be inducted during the association's awards show in November. Mr. Kristofferson, 68, wrote country classics like "Help Me Make It Through the Night" and "For the Good Times" and has appeared in more than 50 movies. Mr. Foglesong, 82, ran the Nashville operations of Dot Records, MCA Records and Capitol Records during the 1970's and 80's and played a key role in the development of stars like Roy Clark, George Strait and Garth Brooks. Meanwhile Alan Jackson led the way with seven nominations for awards. Toby Keith received six, while Kenny Chesney, Alison Krauss and the newcomer Gretchen Wilson each got five. The duo Brooks & Dunn will replace Vince Gill, who has been host of the awards ceremony for 12 years. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: I.M.F. Accepts Standstill to Let Argentina Work on Debt
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31 - The International Monetary Fund sought to mend fences with Argentina on Tuesday, agreeing with the country to put aside an I.M.F. loan program while the government seeks to work out one of the largest sovereign debt restructurings in history.

title: 1904:Partridge Shooting : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Hollinger Files Stinging Report on Ex-Officials
description: In a 513-page report shot through with sarcasm and disgust, a special committee of the publishing company Hollinger International Inc. concluded that the former officials Conrad M. Black and F. David Radler ran a "corporate kleptocracy," diverting to themselves virtually all the company's $400 million in earnings over seven years.

Paid Notice: Memorials   JASON, EDITH ''NANU''
description: JASON--Edith "Nanu". Better late than never. August 25. The love is still here. Love, Bernie

title: Delegates Mock Kerry's Wounds, Angering Veterans
description: When speakers at the Republican convention discuss Senator John Kerry's service in Vietnam, they use words like "respect," as Rudolph W. Giuliani did on Monday, giving nary a hint of the unsubstantiated charges by a veteran's group that Mr. Kerry lied to get his war medals, which dominated the campaign for two weeks before the convention began.

title: Mexico's Leader to Pursue Genocide Case
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 - President Vicente Fox said in an interview on Tuesday that if Mexico's Supreme Court would not hear the genocide charges his government had filed against former President Luis Echeverra, he would call for the creation of a truth commission to investigate abuses committed by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which used fraud and corruption to rule the country for more than seven decades.

title: Three cheers for Sweeney
Vonage Starter Kit Deal
description: Vonage, the New Jersey provider of Internet-based telephone service, has reached a deal to sell its starter kits at 700 Office Depot stores, the companies plan to announce today.

title: Democrat by Association
description: The people scheduling the campaign appearances of Senator John Edwards, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, seemed to be out of their minds. Why else would they have him stop in Oklahoma City on his way to New Mexico the evening of Aug. 25, given that Oklahoma went for George Bush by a landslide four years ago?

title: World's first Internet caf hoists a latte to celebrate 10 years
'Food Talk' Host Departs Amid Some Talk of Static
description: THE line between sales and editorial had always been thin on Arthur Schwartz's radio program about food. In addition to recipes, restaurant reviews and gossip of the New York food world, he read many of the food-oriented commercials that supported his daily show on WOR, at least implying his endorsement of those products.

title: Governor Pataki's Moment
description: Gov. George Pataki will have a tryout on the national stage tomorrow, when he introduces George W. Bush at the Republican convention. Mr. Pataki has been in office for nearly 10 years, and he has toyed with presidential ambitions in the past. But if he actually hopes to turn tomorrow's prime-time moment into a step toward higher office, he has to start by cleaning up his own backyard.

title: World's Caviar Faces a Ban
description: THE United Nations agency that controls trade in endangered species has halted exports of caviar until the countries where it is produced comply with an agreement to protect sturgeon, an official of the agency said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about negotiations between US Airways and its pilots' union over concessions misstated the total annual cost reduction the airline is seeking. It is $1.5 billion, not $1.5 million.

title: Becky Sharp Again Weaves Her Wily Web
description: Her eyes snapping like tiny firecrackers and jutting her chin, Reese Witherspoon makes an appealingly crafty Becky Sharp in Mira Nair's bland but color-drenched adaptation of William Makepeace Thackeray's 1848 novel, "Vanity Fair." Ms. Witherspoon, as usual, conveys a bristly, determined spunk. But if her performance emits enough sparks to hold the screen, it never ignites a dramatic brush fire. Despite her make-do British accent, she is quintessentially American in attitude and body language, even more a fish out of water in "Vanity Fair" than she seemed in "The Importance of Being Earnest."

title: Mall Where Brooks Brothers and Home Depot Share Space
description: It's not easy finding a shopping center where stores like Brooks Brothers and Williams-Sonoma share a roof with Home Depot, B.J.'s Wholesale Club and a 68-foot Ferris wheel, but that has long been the point at the Palisades Center mall in West Nyack, N.Y.

title: It's 1968 in Kentucky: Two Days of Political Theater in the Original Settings
description: WHITESBURG, Ky. - When John Malpede, a performance artist from Los Angeles, asked a small-town Kentucky lawyer named Jack Faust to play the lead role in his latest project, "RFK in EKY," Mr. Faust was flattered but perplexed.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Best Buy To Require Radio ID Tags
description: Best Buy said yesterday that it expected major suppliers to begin attaching radio identification tags to cartons and pallets of goods shipped to it, starting Jan. 2, 2006. It expects all such shipments from the suppliers to be tagged by May 2007. Best Buy, a 750-store electronics and entertainment products chain based in Minneapolis, said its radio identification system would use E.P.C. standards, a form of the technology that Wal-Mart and the Department of Defense have already specified for suppliers. The company said it planned tests in stores and distribution centers before the introduction. Best Buy indicated that its short-term goals were to speed products through its supply chain and reduce instances of products that customers want being out of stock. But the company said it was also interested in the technology's potential to help with tasks like processing warranty claims and returns, which would require leaving the radio tags on products when they are sold. That use of the technology is strongly opposed by consumer privacy advocates. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: A Bush Family Reunion, Including the Asterisks
description: The quadrennial Bush family reunion known as the Republican National Convention is on again, and my how they've grown.

title: American Made: New White House Pastry Chef
description: Correction Appended

title: After 2 Nights of Sizzle, the Regulars Take the Stage
description: Tonight it's back to basics.

title: SOCCER : Newcastle kicks up coal dust to block bleak view
Giambi Returns to the Stadium as Only an Anxious Spectator
description: Jason Giambi was so relieved and so excited about being back at Yankee Stadium yesterday that he hugged one of the batboys. A few feet from his locker, Giambi wrapped his arms around the young man as gleefully as if he were easing into the leather seats of a new sports car.

title: Doing Business : Old charm and new money in Bucharest
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: U.S. Appeals In Broadband Cable Case
description: The federal government is appealing a crucial appellate court decision over regulation of cable broadband services. The decision to appeal before the United States Supreme Court is good news for the cable industry, upset by a ruling by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that cable modem services should be regulated more like telecommunications services, which are heavily regulated by the Federal Communications Commission. The solicitor general's office filed the appeal Friday night, ahead of a Monday deadline applicable to this case. Although the cable industry had already planned its appeal, industry officials hope the government's involvement will increase the chance of Supreme Court intervention. The Ninth Circuit, based in San Francisco, ruled last October that F.C.C. regulation of broadband cable services as unregulated "information services" was incorrect. The decision came from a lawsuit by a small Internet service provider, filed after the F.C.C. developed rules that lightly regulated cable broadband. Although the cable industry has been nervous about the Ninth Circuit decision, the court ruling does not necessarily force the F.C.C. to change the way it treats cable broadband services. Still, the industry believes that the appeals ruling could make it easier for the F.C.C. to change its mind in the future. Telephone-line-based Internet service providers, like EarthLink Inc., have pressed to have cable broadband services regulated like telecommunications services. One outcome could be regulations requiring cable companies to let other service providers sell Internet access over their cable lines. The underlying lawsuit was filed in 2002 by Brand X Internet Services, a small company based in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court To Let In Cameras As A Test
description: With Victorian formality, judges and barristers still wear wigs to court in Britain, so it was quite a nod to modernity when Lord Falconer, the lord chancellor, announced that British justice would open the door, just a crack and on a pilot basis, to allow television coverage of some proceedings. The heavily conditioned experiment will go forward, Lord Falconer said, because "justice should be seen to be done." Criminal trials for now would not be subject to television coverage. "We don't want our courts turned into U.S.-style media circuses," Lord Falconer said, referring to the O.J. Simpson trial. But in the next few months, cameras will be allowed to film appellate court arguments with the film seen only by judges and lawyers to review. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Remarks Made by Senator Zell Miller
description: The following is the full text of remarks made by Senator Zell Miller, as prepared for delivery.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Steady At Bayer
description: The chemicals and drug company Bayer said its second-quarter sales and operating profit rose, compared with a year ago. Sales rose 4.5 percent, to 7.6 billion euros ($9.2 billion) from the second quarter in 2003, and operating profit jumped 44 percent, to 660 million euros ($795 million), above market expectations. Bayer said performance improved at all operations except the health care unit. Diminished by 136 million euros in one-time items, Bayer's net earnings were flat at 128 million euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Lawyer Named by Rowland May Not Have to Testify
description: The investigation of John G. Rowland, the former governor of Connecticut, hit a roadblock this week when a federal appeals court ruled that a state-appointed lawyer could not be compelled to appear before the grand jury that is investigating Mr. Rowland and people who were connected to his administration for corruption.

title: U.S. Clears Stent Sales by Guidant
description: Guidant received approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to sell stents that are inserted into the main neck artery to reduce the risk of strokes, making the company the first manufacturer cleared to sell that version of the device in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, SYLVIA L. (NEE LEVINSON)
description: VOGEL--Sylvia L. (nee Levinson), on Monday, August 30, 2004, age 96, wife of the late H. Leonard Vogel; mother of Dr. Robert (Sharyn) Vogel and the late Janet Vogel Dorfman; mother-in-law ofSharyn Vogel, Paul Dorfman, sister of Dr. Leonard (Irene) Levinson; also survived by five grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Funeral services and interment private. Sylvia was a masterful New York City school teacher for 35 years, world traveler and an independent spirit. She will be lovingly missed by her beloved family and friends. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the Chautauqua Foundation, P.O. Box 28, Chautaugua, NY 14722.

title: Carter Cramming to Learn Jets' Style
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 31 - Through his first week as a Jet, one of the toughest assignments facing quarterback Quincy Carter has been something that should be one of the easiest: getting the ball in his hands.

It's Up and He's Good: Giants Choose a Kicker
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 31 - Todd France became the Giants' place-kicker on Tuesday, with a simple mandate: keep kickoffs long and perhaps surprise with a 50-yard field goal.

title: PARMALAT UNIT GETS MORE TIME FOR BANKRUPTCY EXIT PLAN
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation and Citigroup Inc. gave the United States unit of Parmalat Finanziaria, Italy's biggest food company, an extra week to file a plan to exit bankruptcy and avoid defaulting on its financing agreements. Parmalat USA has until Sept. 9 to file a plan that is "acceptable to a majority in interest of the lenders," the company said in papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. The previous deadline was Sept. 2. The unit, which is based in New York, decided in May to reorganize as a stand-alone business after spending several months exploring a sale of its assets.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Paramount Buys Film Rights To Area 51 Game
description: Paramount Pictures, a unit of Viacom, has agreed to buy the film rights to Midway Games' Area 51 video game, in a collaboration between the film company controlled by Sumner M. Redstone and the electronic-game company in which he is the majority owner. Christine Peters, who produced the movie "How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days," will produce the film, a Midway spokesman, Reilly Brennan, said yesterday. It is the first film-rights sale between Midway and Paramount, he said. Paramount made last year's "Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life," based on Eidos's Lara Croft computer games. The film "Area 51," about a viral outbreak at a research center, will be released in March, Paramount said. Viacom has been pursuing possible transactions with Midway, like licensing agreements or a purchase of the company, and formed a committee of independent directors to evaluate the process, Mr. Redstone said in a regulatory filing. Shares of Viacom fell 44 cents, to $33.31. Midway shares rose 9 cents, to $12.07.

title: Behind Top Student's Heartbreak, Illegal Immigrants' Nightmare
description: ANGELA PEREZ looked up from her desk at International High School in Queens one morning last April to behold a most uncommon sight. Her best friend, Lydia, the one who shuffled into homeroom late every day, had scampered in ahead of the bell. "Guess what?" she called to Angela, and from her backpack she pulled a thick envelope. It held the letter admitting her to Tufts University.

title: Disaffected Democrat Who Is Now a G.O.P. Dream
description: Zig Zag Zell, his critics call him. Zellout. A traitor. An elephant in donkey's clothing. "They can call me anything they want," said Senator Zell Miller, the Georgia Democrat and leader of Democrats for Bush. "It's not anything new to me."

description: The Interpublic Group of Companies ended weeks of speculation yesterday by naming Tony Wright, a top executive at the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of the WPP Group, as president and chief executive at the large, struggling Interpublic agency Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York.

description: Bob Knight is no Buddy Hackett or Bill Cosby. He is not full of chuckles, mirth or guffaws.

title: Milosevic Opens His Defense Case by Going on the Offensive
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 31 - Now it was Slobodan Milosevic's turn to explain himself. After hearing the prosecution case for 24 months, the former Serbian leader began his defense on Tuesday against an extensive array of war crimes charges, including genocide, stemming from the Balkan conflicts of the 1990's.

description: DREYFUSS--Ralph F., on August 30, 2004. Beloved husband and best friend of Helen. Wonderful father to Michele Sherrill, Jamie Dreyfuss and Madeleine Schnell. Special Grandpapa to Philip, Teddy, Emily, Isaac, Jordana, Justin, Amanda and Casey. Services Wednesday 11:15 AM at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 31 - Florida's highest court on Tuesday scrutinized Gov. Jeb Bush's effort to keep a brain-damaged woman alive against her husband's wishes, sharply questioning how a special law that the Legislature passed to prolong her life did not violate the separation of powers that the state's Constitution assures.

description: Entering Washington Square Church for "The Republic in Ruins," a collaborative performance piece that opened last evening as an angry counterpoint to the Republican National Convention, a visitor passes two pillars of television monitors showing people of all ages and races reciting the Pledge of Allegiance, and banners with quotations about protest and citizenship by, among others, James Madison and Gnter Grass.

description: FUIKS--Lewis "Jack" J. 85, a resident of Dorset, VT and Vero Beach, FL. Formerly of Darien, CT. Died August 30. He was Vice President and Creative Supervisor at Interpublic Group Co's. Services are private. Memorial gifts may be made to Hospice VNA c/o Brewster Funeral Service, PO Box 885, Manchester, VT 05255. Email family at sheafuneralhomes.com

title: Cheney Functions as Icon as Well as Lightning Rod
description: Four years ago, Dick Cheney was the consummate Washington insider, offering reassurance to voters and gravitas to a Republican ticket headed by an untested governor from Texas. But the vice president who takes the stage at Madison Square Garden tonight is now not only a conservative icon, but also a campaign flashpoint, perhaps the most controversial running mate since Dan Quayle.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: BOBBY FLAY, right, has changed his mind. Instead of opening a Latin-theme restaurant in the Judson Grill space at 152 West 52nd Street, he plans to put a brasserie there called BAR AMERICAIN. With DAVID ROCKWELL doing the design, Mr. Flay has started working on regional American dishes like slow-smoked pork chops with green onion grits, and cedar-roasted wild king salmon with a sauce of Oregon pinot noir. "I decided that Latin was too limiting," he said. "I've traveled all over America, and I really know the food well."

title: UNITED AIRLINES PLANS $625 MILLION IN ADDITIONAL CUTS
description: United Airlines, which is trying to develop a restructuring plan to leave bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had identified $625 million in additional annual savings. The executive vice president, Peter D. McDonald, said the biggest savings, $200 million a year, would come from the maintenance department. United also wants to save $150 million a year on airport operations. Other savings will come from fuel, distribution, reservation centers and at the United Express regional carrier. United has said it will probably terminate its four employee pension plans and replace them with less-generous programs. United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, has warned employees to expect other cuts. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: A Call to 'Win This Culture War'
description: At a closed, invitation-only Bush campaign rally for Christian conservatives yesterday, Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas called for a broad social conservative agenda notably different from the televised presentations at the Republican convention, including adopting requirements that pregnant women considering abortions be offered anesthetics for their fetuses and loosening requirements on the separation of church and state.

title: After Ball Boy Faints, Two Players Play Doctor
description: Jiri Novak fought through his anger and did his best to concentrate on his first-round match at the United States Open on Monday. But even his victory over Radek Stepanek could not put him at ease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTLIEB, DR. CARLA
description: GOTTLIEB--Dr. Carla. July 16, 1912-July 28, 2004. Art historian and professor at Bryn Mawr, Sarah Lawrence, The New School, University of Ilinois at Urbana, Carleton University, Ottawa and Chair of the Art History Department at Ripon College, WI. An accomplished author of art history books & articles.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Cases Of Missing On The Rise
description: Amnesty International reported a "dramatic escalation" in the number of disappearances in Nepal, where a Maoist insurgency has claimed 10,000 lives. In the last year, the rights group received 378 reports of disappearances, more than in the last five years combined. It called on government security forces to halt the practice and to stop obstructing investigations into disappearances by Nepal's courts and the National Human Rights Commission. Since 1998, the group has received reports of 622 disappearances, hundreds of cases of extrajudicial executions and widespread torture by government security forces. It said it had received numerous reports of abductions, torture and killings by Maoists. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Working to End the Stories of Abuse and Neglect
description: JOHN B. MATTINGLY, New York City's new commissioner of children's services, is recalling when child welfare became his life's work. It began with outrage over a little boy who turned up chained to a bed, frozen to death in the middle of a Cleveland winter more than two decades ago.

title: For Yesterday's Children, Too
description: "Look and Cook" calls itself "A Cookbook for Children," but with illustrations that could have come from children's books of the 1940's and 50's, it is no doubt meant to appeal to adults, too. The book's author and illustrator, Tina Davis, presents classic recipes for breakfast, lunch and dinner, like macaroni and cheese, French toast, mashed potatoes and chocolate pudding. The book, published by Stewart, Tabori & Chang ($19.95) also gives kitchen safety tips, covers measurements and ends with instructions on setting a table.

title: Demonstrations Continue, but With Fewer Arrests So Far
description: Demonstrations against the Bush administration and its policies continued into the third day of the Republican National Convention, with thousands of demonstrators forming a symbolic unemployment line in Manhattan and a small group of protesters infiltrating the convention floor despite heavy security at the Midtown venue.

title: Pfizer Ends Drug Cards for Elderly
description: Pfizer, the nation's largest drug maker, ended its widely used discount card for the elderly yesterday, leaving several hundred thousand low-income Medicare beneficiaries at least temporarily without access to reduced prices for popular medicines like the cholesterol treatment Lipitor.

title: F.D.A. FAULTS SANOFI-AVENTIS ON VACCINE TESTING
description: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, failed to conduct required follow-up tests to ensure that vaccines produced at a plant in Lyon, France, were uncontaminated, United States regulators said. In a letter to Sanofi-Aventis, which is based in Paris, the Food and Drug Administration cited manufacturing flaws in production of the company's rabies vaccine. The F.D.A. also said Sanofi-Aventis did not follow up on defects in Thymoglobulin batches, the Genzyme Corporation's treatment to prevent kidney transplant rejection. The F.D.A. discovered the flaws during inspections in March and April.

title: Immigrant's Search for a Heart Is Frustrating
description: In an intensive care unit at Bellevue Hospital Center, Isidoro Jimenez drifts in and out of sleep as anguished relatives watch nervously at his bedside. Days earlier, his heart had started beating irregularly for several minutes, to the point where his life was in danger.

The latest exotic salts are from Asia: Bali, Bangladesh and the Himalayas, from ancient marine deposits left in the foothills.

title: The Deciding Voters
description: John McCain's presence onstage was powerful, and his no-apologies message went to the heart of the matter in this campaign: The war against terror is being fought for a noble cause and the candidate most likely to persevere in it is George W. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL, WILLIAM MALTBY
description: KIMBALL--William Maltby. Died peacefully in his sleep on Wednesday, August 25 at the age of 81. He was born in Atlanta, GA, on September 19, 1922, and grew up in Buffalo, NY. He graduated from Colgate University and then served in the U.S. Army Infantry in combat in Europe during WWII. He received a law degree from Harvard Law School in 1948 and was a practicing trial lawyer in New York City until the time of his death. He is survived by his former wife and lifelong friend, Dorothy F. Kimball, his three loving children and their spouses, Pamela Kimball Kenney and her husband David, William Fisher Kimball and his wife Alexandra and Susannah Kimball Rosato and her husband Ernest Jr. He is also survived by his eight beloved grandchildren, Sarah, Alice, Ernest III, Sophie, William, Colin, Lachlan and Aengus. His sister, Jean Hutchinson of Williamsville, NY, also survives him. The burial in Cutchogue, NY, on Tuesday, August 31 will be private. A memorial will be held at a later date in New York City. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Peconic Land Trust, Box 1776, Southampton, NY 11969

description: Correction Appended

title: Bush Campaign Files Suit to Stop 527 Groups
description: Hours before President Bush arrived in New York City tonight, a day before his appearance at the Republican National Convention, his campaign organization filed a lawsuit aimed at halting unrestricted spending by independent political groups.

title: Canada Sets Tone in World Cup Victory Over U.S.
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 31 - To open the World Cup of Hockey against the United States, Canada wore antique jerseys the color of mustard Tuesday night. And after the Americans lost, 2-1, United States Coach Ron Wilson cited music as a source of inspiration for Canada.

title: Thoughts Have Wings (and Voices)
description: Mel Gibson didn't invent the concept of a mind-reading character in "What Women Want," his 2000 film about a sexist bachelor who finds himself able to hear women's thoughts. That film's director, Nancy Meyers, didn't even succeed in turning the idea into a convincing romantic comedy. But at least the characters' inner dialogue sounded like real, uncensored thoughts. ("Oh my God, I looked at his crotch. Oh no, I looked at it again.")

title: Is It Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Safin Shows Frustration in Upset by Enqvist
description: Marat Safin sat courtside yesterday, plucking at the strings of his racket, staring disapprovingly at the instrument as if something were wrong with it. Perhaps something was.

title: Casting Europe as a Virtuous Upstart
description: THE EUROPEAN DREAM How Europe's Vision of the Future Is Quietly Eclipsing the American Dream By Jeremy Rifkin 435 pages. Jeremy P. Tarcher/Penguin $25.95

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Serving Canaps, Then Recalling the 107th Floor
description: To be a banquet worker is to be invisible. Do not engage customers in chitchat. Just collect the discarded shrimp tails, keep the cheese platters fresh and know how to pose simple questions -- "Hors d'oeuvre?" -- so unobtrusively that you might as well be a phantom.

title: Hollinger's Board: Most Irresponsible Ever?
description: Correction Appended

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Corrections
Sharon Speeds Up Schedule for Gaza Pullout
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 - A grumpy and combative Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, announced on Tuesday an accelerated timetable for a unilateral Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, telling his unhappy party that the plan "will be implemented, period."

title: Nader Plans Appeal After Pennsylvania Court Keeps Him Off Ballot
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31 - Ralph Nader said on Tuesday that he would appeal a court ruling keeping him off the presidential ballot in Pennsylvania, a state where Democrats have fiercely opposed his independent candidacy.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Antiterror Law Overturned
description: The country's highest court blocked a centerpiece of President lvaro Uribe's plans to pacify Colombia, an antiterrorist statute that would have given security forces broad powers to tap phones, conduct searches and make arrests in the government's war on Marxist guerrillas. The Constitutional Court struck down the law, approved by Congress last year, because of procedural errors in its lengthy approval process. The bill needed court approval to take effect. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Knowing Him as He Does, Torre Lets Sheffield Play
description: Sitting out last night's game was not a subject that Yankees Manager Joe Torre even attempted to broach with Gary Sheffield.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I didn't realize it was on my bus. I looked at myself and saw I was all right, but when I looked back at the passengers I saw such painful sights."

title: 1929:Yucatan Divorce Mill : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
At Least 900 Arrested in City as Protesters Clash With Police
description: A series of demonstrations rippled across Manhattan last night when protesters tried to converge on the Republican National Convention, as a day of planned civil disobedience erupted into clashes with police officers and led to the arrest of more than 900 people.

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11 (11 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Finicky Fruit Is Sweet When Coddled
description: MOISSAC, France - WHEN I was a child an ancient, solitary tree stood near the driveway of my family's home on Long Island. It was hard to tell that it was a plum tree, because it rarely fruited, but when it did, the small, greenish orbs filled the air with perfume. I would pluck as many as I could, and their syrupy sweetness inspired a rapture that has haunted me ever since, though the tree died long ago.

title: Jeffords Has Been There, Done That
description: Republicans have their angry Democrat in Senator Zell Miller of Georgia, but Democrats have an angry Republican of their own. Make that former Republican.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: The Food Pyramid Scheme
description: If your mother ever told you that eating sweets would spoil your dinner, she was right. The government should heed her wisdom -- and pay less attention to the sugar lobby -- when it issues revamped nutrition guidelines next year. The preponderance of scientific evidence, much of it cited in a report issued last week by the advisory committee on the new guidelines, shows that the more sugar you consume, generally in the form of "added" sugars like high-fructose corn syrup, the less likely you are to eat adequate amounts of nutritious food. The report also persuasively connects obesity to sugar, especially sugar-sweetened beverages.

title: Amid Ghosts of the Red Guard, The Avant-Garde Now Blooms
description: BEIJING, Aug. 31 - In his gray fleece jacket and pressed khaki pants, Xu Yong looks more like a department store manager than a maverick who is one of the most successful promoters of avant-garde art in China and a protector of its historic architecture. Standing in 798 Space, his contemporary art gallery in northeastern Beijing, next to a row of faded photographs of a woman firing a handgun, Mr. Xu carefully thanks the city government for supporting the Dashanzi International Art Festival, a collaboration among 74 galleries and private art studios in a refurbished 1950's-era weapons factory.

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Globalist : Bush's momentary shift on war against terror
Surf 'n' Sweet
description: NO one who cooks ever laments the coming of fall, but there is something about the soft, warm end of summer that can make even the greatest soup maker and stew lover feel wistful.

title: Corrections
description: A report from the Associated Press in the Arts Briefing column last Wednesday about Frank Conroy's plan to step down as director of the Writers' Workshop at the University of Iowa referred erroneously to alumni of the program among the last five United States poets laureate. While two of the five laureates, including the current one, Louise Glck, taught at the workshop, none (not four) are alumni.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WRENN, M. PATRICIA
description: WRENN--M. Patricia, on August 28. Patricia lost her courageous battle with cancer at age 69. She will be deeply missed by her friends and neighbors, particularly those at 221 E. 78th St., and by her new friends at the Mary Manning Walsh Home where her spunky spirit and candid charm delighted and touched the hearts of so many, especially Bill. An alumna of Western High School in Washington, D.C. Pat came to New York in 1957. She was an active volunteer with the Central Park Conservancy and a founding member of the 200 Block East 78th St. Association which will hold a tree planting memorial for her this fall. Rest in Peace, dear Pat, know that you have brought joy to many.

title: Armed Attackers Seize School in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1 A Heavily armed insurgents, some with explosives strapped to their bodies, seized a school in southern Russia today and herded scores of schoolchildren and others into its gymnasium.

title: Gray Kunz: Out of the Fire, Into the Frying Pan
description: GRAY KUNZ surveyed the most theatrical kitchen in the city. Sleek Molteni burners, ovens and cornflower-blue lava stone counters stretched more than 60 feet before a panorama of Central Park.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Trust Official Chosen
description: Eduardo Prez Motta a longtime trade official, has been appointed the new president of the Federal Competition Commission, Mexico's antimonopoly regulator. He succeeds Fernando Snchez Ugarte, whose 10-year term is expiring. Mexico's antimonopoly law and the commission that enforces it date only to 1994. During his term, Mr. Snchez Ugarte investigated several powerful companies, including the phone giant, Telfonos de Mxico; Coca-Cola; Wal-Mart's local subsidiary; the country's two breweries; and the world's third-largest cement producer, Cemex. His efforts to curb their power were often trapped in Mexico's tangled legal system or halted by a lack of support from other parts of the government. His successor, Mr. Prez Motta, who took over yesterday, was most recently Mexico's representative to the World Trade Organization. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: PARTNERSHIP SELLS CALIFORNIA COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT
description: The Mack-Cali Corporation, Highridge Partners and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. sold Pacific Plaza, an office and retail development in Daly City, Calif., to Rreef America for $143 million. A joint venture of Mack-Cali and Highridge owned 50 percent of Pacific Plaza, and Lehman held the rest. After paying debt and other costs related to the sale, Mack- Cali will receive about $12.7 million, the chief executive, Mitchell Hersh, said. Mack-Cali, based in Cranford, N.J., owns stakes in 268 properties. Highridge is based in Los Angeles.

title: A Show of Unity in France
description: Major French Islamic groups and the political opposition have rallied behind the government's defiance of Iraqi kidnappers who seized two French journalists last month and demanded that France revoke its ban on the wearing of Islamic head scarves in state schools. The display of unity was encouraging. The head-scarf ban may be ill conceived and discriminatory, but French education policy should not be set by terrorists. Islamic leaders in France are forcefully making that point, too.

title: F.B.I. Interviews 2 Suspected of Passing Secrets to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 - Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have conducted interviews with two officials at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee who are suspected of passing classified information from a Pentagon analyst to Israeli intelligence, government officials and a lawyer for the committee said on Tuesday.

title: Prosecutors Drop Sexual Assault Charge Against Bryant
description: The Kobe Bryant rape case was dismissed tonight in Eagle, Colo., after the prosecution said the woman who had accused Mr. Bryant of sexual assault would no longer cooperate, leaving the state no option but to drop the charges.

title: For a Wine That Lingers in Memory, a Reminiscent Dish
description: A GLASS of wine can have the madeleine effect for me, evoking a flood of memories. So it is with St.-Joseph.

title: As Anxiety Grows, So Does Field of Terror Study
description: On a summer evening in a TriBeCa classroom at Metropolitan College of New York, graduate students pored over spreadsheets, calculating how prepared the elderly residents of Harlem would be for a dirty-bomb attack. In a course titled "The Impact of Disaster on Communities," the students analyzed the catastrophic possibilities for New York City and its residents.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Monday with an article about National Public Radio and its relationship with local stations misspelled the surname of National Public Radio's president. He is Kevin Klose, not Close.

title: Hope on Iraq Extends Decline in Oil Prices
description: Crude oil futures prices declined yesterday amid signs of increased confidence in Iraqi oil exports. The decrease extended a decline that has cut more than $7 from the price in eight sessions.

title: Nets Would Welcome a Mourning Comeback
description: While Alonzo Mourning recently placed a damper on the speculation that he wants to return to the Nets, and his agent echoed those sentiments yesterday, the team is still wondering if Mourning will attempt another comeback when training camp opens in October.

title: Disastrous debt : Why the Philippines needs a financial crisis
Protester Who Nearly Reached Cheney Is Arraigned
description: Thomas Frampton, an antiwar protester who penetrated the security in Madison Square Garden on Monday night to shout slogans within 10 feet of Vice President Dick Cheney, was arraigned on Tuesday on two federal misdemeanor charges of obstructing and assaulting Secret Service agents.

title: A New Sports Radio Network
description: Sirius Satellite Radio and CSTV announced yesterday the creation of a college sports network that will carry games from 23 major universities, including Notre Dame, Auburn, Florida, Louisiana State, Nebraska and Ohio State. It will carry other programming as well.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Flat
description: Industrial production was unchanged in June from July as declines in output of semiconductors and cars offset increases in production of steel and paper. Still, the government said it expected factory output to rebound in the months ahead, forecasting that production would increase 1.5 percent in August and 0.6 percent in September. July's production figure is the latest of a string of data that points to a slowing of Japan's recovery. Last week, the government reported that the unemployment rate rose for the first time this year, increasing to 4.9 percent in July from 4.6 percent in June. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Queens Man Is Beaten to Death Over Refusal to Sell His Home
description: A 78-year-old man was beaten to death on a Queens street in broad daylight after he repeatedly refused to sell his house for far below its market value, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Guerrilla's Extradition To Chile Denied
description: President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva has rejected the Chilean government's request for the extradition of Mauricio Hernndez Norambuena, a member of a Chilean left-wing guerrilla group convicted in his homeland of the 1991 kidnapping and assassination of Senator Jaime Guzmn, a prominent supporter of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Mr. Hernndez Norambuena escaped from a Chilean prison by helicopter in 1996 and is one of six Latin American guerrillas serving 30-year sentences in Brazil for the 2001 kidnapping of a So Paulo advertising executive. The Brazilian Supreme Court had authorized the extradition, but Mr. da Silva, a leftist former labor leader who in the past has pleaded for leniency for other guerrillas involved in kidnappings in Brazil, decided Mr. Hernndez Norambuena should remain in a So Paulo prison until his sentence in Brazil has been served. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Twin Blasts Kill 16 in Israel; Hamas Claims Responsibility
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel, Aug. 31 - Six months of relative quiet in Israel ended in carnage on Tuesday, as two suicide bombers blew up two buses 100 yards apart in this southern desert town, killing at least 16 people, including a 4-year-old child, and wounding more than 100 others, many of them seriously.

title: NASA and the Hubble : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
U.N. Urges Quick Increase in Troops for Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 1 A Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that the government of Sudan had failed to keep commitments to rein in the militias terrorizing the country's Darfur region and that a large international force was required there as soon as possible.

title: RAILAMERICA TO SELL AUSTRALIAN UNIT TO PACIFIC NATIONAL
description: Railamerica Inc., a short-line and regional rail service provider, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Freight Australia railroad unit to a privately held rail operator, Pacific National, for $204 million to reduce debt. Proceeds from the sale will used to pay down $60 million in Railamerica debt securities, the company said. Railamerica, based in Boca Raton, Fla., operates 47 railroads in the United States and Canada. It purchased Freight Australia from the Victoria state government in 1999 for $103 million. Pacific National is one of Australia's largest private rail operators.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Post Office Reopens
description: Mail delivery on the East Side returned to normal yesterday after a machine that had contaminated a post office with radiation was removed from the building. The device, a radiography camera, malfunctioned on Sunday afternoon in the basement of the post office, on Third Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets, and began emitting a stream of low-level radiation. City health workers used lead shields to absorb most of the radiation and barred postal workers from the building. The police closed surrounding streets. After workers removed the camera Monday night,, officials said, radiation levels in the building quickly returned to normal. They said seven people who were exposed to radiation at close range received doses too small to cause harm. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: State Releases 569 Inmates Early
description: The State Correction Board authorized the early release of 569 inmates who were within 90 days of parole. Despite additional space for 716 prisoners in the last year, almost 900 prisoners in city and county jails await transfer to state custody. Prison officials said mandatory sentences for drug offenders would continue to swell the inmate population. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Kerry Needs to Sharpen His Attacks, Democrats Say
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 31 - Democrats say they fear that Senator John Kerry squandered the capital from the Democratic National Convention as he spent August reeling from a frontal assault on his character and Vietnam War record, with many urging him to immediately sharpen his attack on Mr. Bush and make a more persuasive case for change.
