Paid Notice: Deaths   ROCKMAKER, GORDON
description: ROCKMAKER--Gordon, 77, of Freehold Township, NJ, died Thursday, August 26, at home. He was born in Brooklyn and resided there before moving to Freehold 30 years ago. He worked as an editorin-chief for McGraw-Hill Publishing Company for 15 years, retiring in 1990. He was predeceased by his daughter Kathryn Rockmaker in 1998. Surviving are his wife of 40 years Ellen, a son Morris and daughter-in-law Kristen of Queens, two daughters Linda Rockmaker and son-in-law Michael of Somerset NJ and Marsha Rockmaker of Freehold and a sister Sally Cohen of Florida. Memorial contributions can be made to CentraState Healthcare Foundation, 916 Route 33, Suite 6, Freehold NJ 07728.

title: Suit Seeks Tighter Security at the Empire State Building
description: Two partners in a law firm in the Empire State Building have sued the building's operators, claiming that security is too lax at the 102-story Midtown landmark and that tenants are exposed to the "clear and present danger" of a terrorist attack.

title: Mets Are the Cure for Beckett
description: The last time Josh Beckett walked onto a mound in New York, he was carried off it.

title: Corrections
Bush Twins Get a Little Payback in Prime Time
description: Maybe girls do just want to have fun. The Bush girls, at least.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 9 at Moscow Subway Station
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 1 - A woman blew herself up outside a subway station in Moscow on Tuesday evening, killing at least 9 other people and wounding more than 50, officials said. The suicide bombing came exactly a week after bombs destroyed two passenger airliners over Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHOLMELEY, JONES, RICH ARD G., II.
description: CHOLMELEY - JONES -- Rich ard G., II. August 26, 2004 of Norwalk, CT. Husband of Marion Cholmeley-Jones. Memorial services Thursday, 11AM, Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Westport.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SOSLER, CAROLYN ATLAS
description: SOSLER--Carolyn Atlas. April 10, 1940-September 1, 1993. "The world breaks everyone, and afterward, many are strong at the broken places. But those that will not break, it kills. It kills the very good, and the very gentle, and the very brave." Hemingway. You are always with us, Pop, Neil, Andre

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Japanese Concerns Plan Flat-Panel Venture
description: Three large Japanese electronics companies announced plans to manufacture large liquid crystal displays jointly for flat-panel televisions from 2006. The three companies, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Toshiba Corporation and Hitachi, and a handful of smaller partners will invest 110 billion yen ($1 billion) to build a flat-panel plant in Chiba prefecture, east of Tokyo, capable of producing 2.5 million 32-inch television panels a year, the companies said in a joint statement. Hitachi will own half of the new company, and Toshiba and Matsushita will each take shares of 21 percent to 25 percent, the companies said. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACKS, DAVID G.
description: SACKS--David G. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the loss of David G. Sacks, a beloved leader and friend. Respected for his guidance and wisdom, David served as president of UJAFederation from 1989 to 1992. As a leader within our network of agencies, he was president of Westchester Jewish Community Services and a member of the board of the 92nd Street Y. David also served as chairman and president of the Jewish Outreach Institute, as well as on the board of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the Jewish Communal Fund. David's concern for humanitarian causes will undoubtedly live on in the continuing efforts of his family. David's devotion to the Jewish community was shared with his wife, Marcella Rosen, who like David, was committed to the development of future Jewish leaders. Through their involvement, they have strengthened our ability to serve those in need, making an enduring impact on the Jewish community and all New Yorkers. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marcella; to David's children: Jonathan, Deborah, Judith, and Joshua; and to the entire Sacks and Rosen families. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. SACKS--David G. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn with a heavy heart the passing of David Sacks, our long time Board member, and beloved husband of Marcella Rosen, also Board member of The 92nd Street Y. David's warmth, care and humanity will long be remembered. The entire Y family mourns the loss of David's deep devotion to the Jewish community and the world at large. David joined the 92nd Street Y Board in 1992 and greatly contributed intellecturally and spiritually to our Bronfman Center for Jewish Life. David also spent many years on the Board of Directors of the UJA-Federation serving as the President from 1989 to 1992. We extend our deepest sympathy to Marcella, and the entire Sacks and Rosen families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Michael Goldstein, President Matthew Bronfman, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director SACKS--David. On behalf of the entire Heschel School community we mourn the loss of our close friend and the husband of devoted trustee, Marcella Rosen Sacks. David was an esteemed and well known leader in the Jewish community when he took an interest in our school through Marcella's work. He was a man of passion and great integrity. We will miss him. We extend our sincere sympathies to Marcella, his children and grandchildren and the extended Sacks and Rosen families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

title: VISTEON TO HELP BUILD AUTO PARTS FACTORY IN CHINA
description: The Visteon Corporation, a maker of auto parts, plans to invest $80 million in a new joint venture factory in China to make vehicle heating and air-conditioning components and add business in Asia. The plant, to be built in Dalian, will employ about 600 people by next year, said Bob Pallash, vice president of Visteon's Asia-Pacific operations, in a conference call with reporters. The factory will be 60 percent owned by the Halla Climate Control Corporation, a South Korean company controlled by Visteon, he said. Visteon, a former unit of Ford, is based in Van Buren Township, Mich.

title: 3 Former Invesco Fund Executives Settle U.S. Case
description: Three former executives of the Invesco Funds Group were barred from the mutual fund industry and agreed to pay a combined $340,000 in fines to resolve accusations that they helped favored clients make about $58 billion in improper trades, regulators said yesterday.

title: A Liberal Hollywood Actor Who Speaks Up for Bush
description: The actor Ron Silver was leaving a cocktail party at the Four Seasons restaurant on Monday evening, headed for Madison Square Garden, when he ran into Henry A. Kissinger, whom he once played in a made-for-television movie. They greeted each other warmly, but as they shook hands, Mr. Kissinger raised a quizzical eyebrow and said, in his distinctive, German-tinted rasp, "What are you doing being a Republican?"

title: Drive-In Food Trumps Staged Politics
description: Correction Appended

title: Crowning Prince George
description: ASHLAND, Ore. - The most common literary allusion to President Bush is Shakespeare's Prince Hal, the hard-drinking, wild-living young man who sobers up, reforms and emerges as the great English warrior King Henry V.

title: Is It Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Muslim Patient Will See You Now, Doctor
description: PORTLAND, Me. - Until recently, Rahmah, a Muslim woman who moved here from Somalia in 1997, was embarrassed when she was told to disrobe for doctor's examinations at Maine Medical Center. The short hem and open back of the flimsy robe she was asked to put on affronted her religious belief that women should dress to preserve their modesty.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
description: First-half net profit at the drug maker Sanofi-Synthlabo climbed more than 20 percent, the company said. Despite raising research and development spending by 13 percent, it generated 1.14 billion euros ($1.37 billion) in first-half net income, up from the previous year's 944 million euros. The company merged with the French-German drug maker Aventis to form Sanofi-Aventis.

title: Too Scary for the Classroom?
description: GENEVA - Right now, I am supposed to be in South Bend, Ind., beginning my term as a professor of Islamic studies at the University of Notre Dame. After all, my petition for a work/residence visa in the United States was granted in May, after meticulous clearance procedures. But nine days before I was to move, I received an urgent message from the American Embassy: my visa had been revoked. If I wished to reapply, I was told, I was welcome to do so; but no reasons for the revocation were given. Classes have now begun at Notre Dame, while my wife and children and I wait here in a barren apartment.

title: U.S. Loses Trade Cases and Faces Penalties
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 31 - The World Trade Organization on Tuesday authorized the European Union and seven other leading American trading partners to impose more than $150 million in retaliatory sanctions on exports from the United States. The ruling comes after Congress refused for two years to repeal a tariff subsidy for American companies that the W.T.O. found to be in violation of global trade laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERLINGER, RHONIE HOFHEIMER
description: BERLINGER--Rhonie Hofheimer, peacefully at home on August 31, 2004 after 89 vigorous years. Loving and beloved wife of the late George F. Berlinger. Devoted mother of Nancy Klee Stone and Mary Ellen Klee. Admiring mother-in-law of Bob Stone. Dear sister of Marion H. Levy and the late Lt. Lester Hofheimer. Proud "Noni" of Peter and Betsy, Robert and Douglas Kempner; Jim and Janet, Ellen and Julia Kempner; Carrie and Matthew, Brian and Daniel Getz. Rhonie actively served as a VicePresident of the National Alzheimer's Association since her husband's death in 1986. Funeral private. A memorial service and celebration of her life will be held Sunday, September 12 at 4pm at the Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, NY, 914946-1660. In lieu of flowers the family would greatly appreciate contributions in Rhonie's memory to Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL, 60601; Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY, 10601 or a charity of your choice.

title: Interim Iraqi Government Convenes for First Time
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sep. 1 A The interim Iraqi national assembly convened for the first time today as Iraq took a small and tentative step toward representative government.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Officer To Interpublic Unit
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies ended weeks of speculation yesterday by naming Tony Wright, a top executive at the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of the WPP Group, as president and chief executive at the large, struggling Interpublic agency Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York.

title: Late Rally for Many Shares; Intel Limits Nasdaq's Rise
description: Stocks rose yesterday as a late rally lifted the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the fifth day in six.

title: Kidnapped Frenchmen worked closely together
Virtue, vice and my visa : What does America have to fear from me?
Corrections
description: An article on July 29 about the Sept. 11 commission's recommendation that the White House disclose the amount the government spends on intelligence misstated the name of one of 15 agencies covered by that budget. It is the National Reconnaissance Office, not Agency. A reader's e-mail message that day reported the error; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALIGOR, LEOPOLD AND JUDITH
description: CALIGOR--Leopold and Judith. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the sudden and untimely deaths of our esteemed graduate, Leopold Caligor, Ph.D. and our distinguished colleague, Judith Caligor, Ph.D. Dr. Leopold Caligor became a faculty member at White in 1959 and had sustained the Institute with his acumen, creativity and limitless vigor for 45 years. He wrote numerous papers and co-authored the book, "Dreams and Symbols" with Rollo May and "Clinical Prospectives on the Supervision of Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy" with Philip Bromberg and James Meltzer. Lee was currently Director of Psychoanalytic Curriculum to which he made the kinds of penetrating and innovative contributions that made him a much sought-after psychoanalyst, supervisor and teacher. He shared his knowledge with abundant generosity, and his profound warmth was always in evidence. Lee's robust investment in his areas of expertise was contagious and students were always eager for the courses on dreams that he taught at White and elsewhere. A pioneer in the field, Leopold Caligor co-founded and co-directed the Institute's Union Therapy Project 40 years ago, and participated significantly in the creation of the Tel Aviv University's program in psychoanalysis. Lee also directed his energies to founding the APA's Division of Psychoanalysis in which he continued to participate in essential roles. In the course of his long and devoted tenure at the Institute he touched the lives of many. He was an inspired and inspiring mentor for younger colleagues. He could be demanding but he always showed kindness and concern. He looked for excellence but was patient with process. He was an alive, keenly sensitive presence at meetings where one could count on his giving, sooner or later, a well reasoned but passionate comment. He was one to take a stand and didn't like to equivocate. With all his being he showed us that he loved the Institute. We shall miss him sorely. Our love and deep condolences to the Caligor's beloved family, and to their friends, colleagues and patients. Joerg Bose, M.D., Director White Institute Charles C. Harrington, Ph.D., President, Board of Trustees Gurmeet Kanwal, M.D., Pres. White Society

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Exports Fuel Growth
description: Canada's economy grew at a rate of 4.3 percent in the second quarter, fueled by a 21.6 percent increase in exports, the government statistics agency said. Strong exports offset growth of only 0.4 percent in domestic demand and 0.3 percent in consumer spending, the agency said in a report. The increase was short of many forecasts but heightened expectations that the Bank of Canada would increase interest rates at a meeting next week. It would be the first interest rate increase in 16 months. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPPAPORT, ROBERT G.
description: RAPPAPORT -- Robert G. Formerly of Long Beach, NY, died suddenly at home in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved son of Frances, loving brother of Mort (Karen), Steven (Judy) and Donald and adored uncle of Marcy, Mandy and Peter. His passing leaves a void in the hearts of all who knew him. He will be sorely missed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Sabre Holdings Corp., Southlake, Tex., owner of the Internet travel service Travelocity.com, bought All State Tours Inc., Las Vegas, for $25 million to expand its ability to sell tickets for shows and attractions.

title: Staying on Message With Delegates on the Circle Line
description: David Parker is not a politician. He is not a delegate. And so he speaks not from the podium at Madison Square Garden but over the public-address system on a Circle Line cruising vessel as it swings around the skyline of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, HAROLD
description: BERNSTEIN--Harold, 75, of Hillsdale, N.J. died Saturday, August 28, 2004. He is survived by his wife Ruth, son Clifford and his wife Shinee, daughter Nancy and three adored grandchildren Eli, Emma and Reuben. He was predeceased by his son Richard and daughter-in-law K.J. as well as his brother Milton and sister Honey. Harold worked as a physicist, being a graduate of MIT and Boston University. His passions included sailing, playing the violin, and later in life, the ukulele as well as participating in competitive bridge. His jokes were appreciated by some, but he will be greatly missed by all. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 3, 2004 at 10:45 A.M. at The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah in Paramus. N.J. (201) 262-1128. Donations may be made to: United Nations Foundation, Attn: Polio Eradication, 1225 Connecticut Ave., NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20036

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger Takes to Limelight Again
description: Valerie White had each fingernail carefully painted to resemble a tiny, shiny American flag. No detail was too small for the big night, the night she put on her sequined vest, and her husband, Lyn, his flag-decorated tie, so they could welcome Arnold Schwarzenegger to Madison Square Garden.

title: Ruling May Return Assets to Ex-Chief at Freddie Mac
description: The former chief executive of Freddie Mac, Leland C. Brendsel, may recover more than $50 million in compensation that the company's regulator froze during an investigation into a $5 billion profit restatement, a federal judge has ruled.

title: The Cookies That Simply Would Not Go for a Ride
description: IN Italy, buckwheat is used mostly in a hearty polenta or a cheese-filled pasta called pizzoccheri. But at the Cascina del Cornale, a small artisanal and agricultural cooperative market and restaurant in the Piedmont region outside Alba, buckwheat means cookie. "It's not traditional to use buckwheat flour in biscuits," said Elena Rovera, a founder of the co-op. "But we think it's very good."

title: EU to make euro-bloc deficit rules flexible
The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Howe May Not Survive Another Mets Slump
description: When Art Howe walked into Shea Stadium yesterday, the police had surrounded the ballpark as if it were a designated protest site. Delegates from the Republican National Convention were taking batting practice inside, so Howe appeared plenty protected, but not at all secure.

title: No Pepper Games or Comments Allowed
description: THERE is no crying in baseball. There is no freedom of speech, either. Alex Rodriguez and Joe Kennedy have learned that recently.

title: Young, Passionate, Republican: What Some Say About the Issues
description: Many delegates to the Republican convention are first timers, but for some, their vote to nominate President Bush will be the first ballot they have cast. Among the 4,853 delegates and alternates, 221, or almost 5 percent, are under 30. Here are what some of the young delegates had to say about why they are Republicans and what issues matter to them. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Lava and Oahu: Fighting Sin in Paradise
description: Correction Appended

title: North Korea recalls ambassador to protest handling of defections
Full Text of Remarks by Senator Rick Santorum
description: The following is the full text of remarks by Senator Rick Santorum on welfare reform, as prepared for delivery.

title: On the Grill, Standing Up
description: ONE of the greatest crowd-pleasers, assuming the crowd has plenty of carnivores, is the standing rib roast. This large cut is so easy to prepare, so close to foolproof, that one can see it nicely done even in second-rate restaurants and buffets.

title: Coffee Straight and Strong, Or With an Eye-Opener
description: Trudging around TriBeCa one steamy day, I wandered into Mocca Espresso Lounge, a bright, comfortable oasis at 78-82 Reade Street (Church Street). I ordered an iced double espresso, below, unaware that it was a house specialty. Out came a generous martini glass brimming with intense coffee, ice cold from being shaken like a cocktail, but served without ice, which would dilute it. Three coffee beans floated on top. The bar also whips up alcoholic espresso martinis among a collection of cocktails, including raspberry mojitos. The owners, Ori Raz and Shay Zohar, are in the coffee business in Israel. Mocca, which opens at 6 a.m. on weekdays and 7:30 on weekends and closes late at night, also serves well-made pastries, salads and sandwiches.

title: Giuliani Described Remark to Kerik Years Ago
description: The anecdote seemed almost too scripted, too on-message to be true. Rudolph W. Giuliani told the Republican National Convention on Monday night that, in a spontaneous moment, in the midst of the attacks on Sept. 11, he had grabbed the arm of his police commissioner and said, "Thank God George Bush is our president."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANES, ESTHER (CHESLER)
description: MANES -- Esther (Chesler). On August 29, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Mathew. Cherished sister of Sarah and the late David. Adored mother of Marthe (Bob), Cathy (Rob) and Laurie, and grandmother of Darcy (Jonathan), Lindy, Sarah (Darin) and David (Megan). Funeral private. Contributions in her memory to a charity of your choice.

title: Bush Promises in 2000: Some Fulfilled, Some Thwarted
description: Four years ago, when the nation still seemed in an era of boundless prosperity, George W. Bush accepted the Republican nomination with an expansive promise of "compassionate conservatism": big tax cuts, new drug benefits for the elderly, a major overhaul of Social Security and a new commitment to public education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOWDEN, PAMELA A.
description: BOWDEN--Pamela A. On August 30, 2004 of Garden City. Beloved daughter of the late Alfred and Emily Bowden. Cherished sister of Barbara, Juliana Schmitt and Emily. Dear aunt of James Schmitt, Amy Herman and Thomas Schmitt. Memorial visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, Friday 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Pamela's memory may be sent to, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, GIST Research, c/o Robert G. Maki, M.D., Ph.D., 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021.

title: Indian Larry, Motorcycle Builder and Stunt Rider, Dies at 55
description: Larry Desmedt, a New York-based custom motorcycle builder and biker better known nationally as Indian Larry, died on Monday in Charlotte, N.C., of injuries he suffered doing a stunt on Saturday at an appearance there. He was 55 and lived in the East Village.

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Slide to a NewLow Against Indians: 22-0
description: The Yankees could not help but watch the scoreboard last night. Their heads swiveled repeatedly toward the outfield as hit after hit for Cleveland sailed over or against the wall. And it was not only the eyes of the Yankees that were fixed to the scoreboard, but also those of a sold-out crowd and the team's impatient principal owner, George Steinbrenner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VONK, HANS
description: VONK--Hans. IMG Artists mourns the untimely passing of Hans Vonk, a man of superb artistry and uncompromising integrity, keen intellect, wit and devotion. Our thoughts are with his friends and family, especially his beloved and loving wife, Jessie. Barrett Wissman, Chairman Edna Landau, Managing Dir.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Excerpts From the Report by a Special Committee of the Hollinger Board
description: Following are excerpts from a report commissioned by a special committee of the board of Hollinger International. The report contends that the company's former chief executive, Conrad M. Black; its former chief operating officer, F. David Radler; and their private holding company, Ravelston, took steps to enrich themselves at the expense of shareholders. The report is also sharply critical of a number of Hollinger's directors, focusing particular attention on Richard N. Perle, the former head of the Defense Policy Board:

title: Is It Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Afghans Die in Strike Laid to U.S. Force
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 31 - At least five civilians were killed, including two children, and eight were wounded by American airstrikes in northeastern Afghanistan on Monday night, the local governor said Tuesday in a telephone interview.

title: Cheney and G.O.P. Mount Vigorous Assault on Kerry
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said yesterday that the nation's fundamental security was at stake in the presidential election, that Senator John Kerry had repeatedly "made the wrong call" on critical foreign policy challenges and that the Democratic challenger did not appreciate the severity of the threat the nation faced after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: 12 Hostages From Nepal Are Executed in Iraq, a Militant Group Claims
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 31 - In the single largest set of executions of foreign captives by Iraqi insurgents, an Islamic militant group announced on Tuesday that it had killed 12 Nepalese hostages.

title: Talks to Disarm RebelShiites Collapses in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 31 - Talks to disarm hundreds of insurgents in the roiling Sadr City ghetto in Baghdad collapsed Tuesday, after a tentative peace pact was abruptly canceled by Prime Minister Ayad Allawi.

title: With Scraggly Habitat Disappearing, So Is a Rabbit
description: DURHAM, N.H., Aug. 27 - Developers and farmers in the Northeast hoping to unload overgrown parcels of land may come to rue the day that John Litvaitis dropped his study of bears and took up with the New England cottontail.

title: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Calendar
description: Local Produce

title: Fay Jones, 83, Architect Influenced by Wright, Dies
description: E. Fay Jones, an architect whose organically sensitive designs for houses, chapels and churches drew on early training with his mentor Frank Lloyd Wright, died on Monday at his home in Fayetteville, Ark. He was 83. The cause was heart and lung failure, said his wife, Mary Elizabeth. He also had Parkinson's disease, she said.

title: Kerry Turns Up the Volume With Litany of Critiques for Bush
description: All too aware that his inner circle has pressed for a more aggressive campaign style, Senator John Kerry today heavily criticized George W. Bush for what he called the president's failures in handling the Iraq war and the wider war on terror, saying "I would have done almost everything differently."

title: Remarks by Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney
description: The following is the full text of the remarks of Gov. Mitt Romney, as prepared for delivery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDER, FREDERICK M. II.
description: LINDER--Frederick M. II. Of Eagan, MN, formerly of Bronxville on August 29th, 2004 at age 58. Husband of Mary and father of Max. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between 2-4 and 79pm Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday September 2nd at 10am.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SESKIS, ELEANOR
description: SESKIS--Eleanor. On August 31, 2004. Died peacefully at home after a long, valiant endurance of Alzheimers disease surrounded by her loving family and friends. Devoted wife of John Y. Loving mother of Jane Soudavar. Beloved grandmother of Annabelle Soudavar. Sister of the late Herbert Diamond. Daughter of the late Sadie and Max Diamond. Her love of fun and her always pragmatic loyal and positive approach to life has been an inspiration to all her family. She will be deeply missed forever. Service Wednesday September 1, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. SESKIS--Eleanor. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member Eleanor Seskis. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memories bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Robert A. Bernhard, Pres Herbert C. Bernard, Sec'y

title: New York 2004, and Other Tales From the Chronicles of Hostile Ground
description: By now, it must be obvious to everyone that President Bush and the Republicans are about as good a fit with New York as Joe Torre and the Yankees with Boston. Or a square peg in a round hole. Or a glove on a foot. Many prominent New Yorkers have simply left town for the duration; I know people who are spending convention week in Florida, Maine, Switzerland or Wyoming, or on Martha's Vineyard, among other places, and many are perfectly happy to portray their absences as political gestures even if they are really just holidays or flights from anticipated trouble in the streets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Aug. 24 about the proposed Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail in the Northwest credited the project erroneously with a first. The nation in fact has other trails with geological themes. The headline also misstated the trail's accessibility. It would be accessible mainly to drivers; it would not be walkable.

title: The Convention: A Night Entwined With 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review of the album "People Behave Like Ballads," by the singer Rebecca Martin, in the New CD's column on Aug. 23, included an erroneous credit for Ben Monder, the guitarist on the album. He did not play on Ms. Martin's album "Middlehope."

title: Barricades Help Officers Keep Crowds Controlled
description: The Police Department faced its biggest test of the Republican National Convention yesterday, confronting a series of large, unannounced and sometimes unruly demonstrations with a massive show of force. The police arrested more than 900 people and mobilized to block roving groups from massing and moving toward Madison Square Garden.

title: Mrs. Rell Starts to Shine as the Star of Her State
description: She had to step aside when former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York swept past. And the introduction she received before accepting an award at the Women's National Republican Club included at least one error.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLATER, JEROME
description: SLATER--Jerome. Age 85 of Longboat Key, FL died August 28, 2004 in Sarasota, FL. He was born in NY, NY and was a WWII veteran serving in the U.S. Army. He leaves his beloved wife Lynne, loving daughter Amy, son-in-law Mark and his adored and adoring grandson, Peter.

title: Tropical Storm Gaston Kills Five in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 31 - Battering wind and record-setting rain from Tropical Storm Gaston caused at least five deaths as a deluge washed away roads, flooded houses and businesses, and sent vehicles floating down the streets of Richmond. Five people were confirmed dead by late Tuesday, and several others were reported missing.

title: Floods Damage Roads and Homes in Orange and Sullivan Counties
description: A band of torrential rain that stalled over parts of Orange and Sullivan Counties in New York on Monday night caused severe flooding that washed out roads, damaged homes and left some residents stranded, emergency officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 20, 2003, about Sergio Vieira de Mello, the high commissioner for human rights who was the United Nations' top official in Iraq when he was killed in a bombing in Baghdad, omitted a survivor. She was his partner, Carolina Larriera, with whom he lived in Paris. The omission was pointed out in a recent letter from his family. (Go to Article)

title: Close to the Garden, a Boom Looks More Like a Bust
description: It is a central tenet of Republican political ideology that government interference is an important obstacle to economic growth. Yet the irony that Republicans were stunting the growth of his bottom line was lost on Amadou Mangassa, a manager at Mr. Joe, a shoe store on Eighth Avenue near 35th Street.

title: Relishes That Cut the Mustard
description: For the hot dogs and hamburgers at your Labor Day cookout, there are some unusual condiments made in South Africa. So!Go Relish (subtitled fruit chutney), above left, is a bright sweet-and-sour mixture that throws off a touch of heat. Sweet Chili, above right, has more serious Sichuan leanings, and Catch'Up tomato sauce, in the rear, is earthier than Heinz's. The cute seven-ounce frosted bottles are convenient enough to take on a picnic, which might even make sense for the company's olive oil and soy sauce. Prices are $6.29 to $6.99 at Grace's Marketplace, Garden of Eden and Zabar's.

title: World Briefings
description: AMERICAS

title: U.S. Acting to Block Syrian Meddling in Lebanon
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 31 - The United States and France decided Tuesday to rush forward a Security Council resolution calling on Syria to remove its troops from Lebanon and cease its intervention in that country's politics.

title: Televise the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Paradox of Photo-Op Politics
description: For all their 9/11 speechifying, Republican politicians are keeping to their vow to shun ground zero as a campaign backdrop during the convention. They are pursuing less inflammatory "compassion" photo-ops of delegates as they feed the homeless on the Bowery or pick up litter in Brooklyn in time for the 6 o'clock news. Hey, as our subway beggars say as they move on to the next car, all contributions appreciated, ladies and gentlemen.

title: Union to Give Nod to Bush at Meeting in Queens
description: President Bush will meet tonight in Queens with more than 50 New York City firefighters as well as the widows of several firefighters who died on Sept. 11 to show his appreciation of the firefighters' heroism, union leaders and city and campaign officials said yesterday.

title: J.P. Morgan Selects McGarry Bowen
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company has named McGarry Bowen in New York as its creative agency for consumer banking assignments like credit cards after a review prompted by J.P. Morgan's acquisition and absorption of the Bank One Corporation. Although spending has not been determined, trade publications estimated the potential budget at $150 million to $300 million.

title: Williams Dazzles and Hewitt Breezes by at U.S. Open
description: Serena Williams wore black hot pants, a studded black midriff vest and then a victorious smile today after beating Lindsay Lee-Waters, 6-4, 6-3, in the second round of the United States Open.

title: New iMac packs computer into flat screen
Justice Dept. Assails Way It Won Key Terror Case
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 A The Justice Department assailed its own legal strategy today in the case that brought its first courtroom victory in the war on terror.

title: Upbeat Republicans Revive Bush Theme of Compassion
description: Facing perhaps three times the television audience that saw its sharp-edged speakers on Monday, the Republican National Convention circled back last night to President Bush's winning 2000 campaign theme of "compassionate conservatism," portraying him as not only hardheaded but also bighearted enough to lead "the most historic struggle my generation has ever known," as his wife, Laura, put it in a prime-time speech.

title: France Pushes for Release of Hostages
description: PARIS, Aug. 31 - The government on Tuesday stepped up diplomatic efforts to win the release of two French journalists taken hostage in Iraq as the deadline set by their kidnappers passed with no word of the hostages' fate.

title: U.S. Asks for Dismissal of Terrorism Convictions
description: Correction Appended

title: KINDER MORGAN ENERGY BUYS OIL PIPELINE IN TEXAS
description: Kinder Morgan Energy, a pipeline partnership, bought the Kaston Pipeline Company from the closely held Western Refining for about $100 million in cash. The 450-mile pipeline can carry as much as 115,000 barrels of oil daily from fields in West Texas, Kinder Morgan said, adding that the purchase will increase cash available for the partnership's holders by about $18 million a year. The system includes loading and storage facilities. The chief executive, Richard Kinder, said in a statement that the company would invest $11 million over the next five years to upgrade the system.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 976 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Positively Sixth Street
description: MYTHS about dining out in New York are like those about the sea swallowing the sun: they help make sense of a world that seems too complex to comprehend.

title: In Retreat, Bush Says U.S. Will Win War on Terrorism
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 31 - President Bush moved to put out a political brush fire on Tuesday with a forceful declaration to the nation's largest veterans group that the United States will win the war on terrorism and that the country will never show "weakness or uncertainty" on his watch.

title: Excerpts From Address By Gov. Schwarzenegger
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's speech last night to the Republican National Convention, as recorded by The New York Times. The full transcript and video are online at nytimes.com/campaign.

title: Loves Dogs, Hates Kerry: A Two-Prong Campaign Tactic
description: With Rudolph W. Giuliani's pummeling of John Kerry on Monday and last night's softer tribute to President Bush by Laura Bush, the Bush campaign has laid out for the convention what White House aides said was the two-sided template of its election strategy.

title: Senator (Elizabeth) Dole, Back in the Spotlight
description: Senator Elizabeth Dole's appearance at the Republican National Convention Tuesday night provided a reminder of why the North Carolinian and former Cabinet secretary was once in line to be the first woman to be president.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Glaxo Begins Posting Drug Trial Results
description: GlaxoSmithKline is expected to begin posting online today the results of clinical trials on its drugs with the release of 65 tests about a diabetes medication, a company executive said yesterday.

title: Advertisers Join the 04 Campaign
description: MADISON AVENUE is following its own version of the dodgy Election Day advice, usually attributed to Chicago politicians, to "vote early and often."

title: THE WORKPLACE : In Europe, unity has its limits
New York Is Already Up to Speed for Olympics
description: ATHENS - THE stray dogs are finding their way back to Athens; the shady characters are coming back, too.

title: Fashion? A Subject They Already Know
description: In the Bronx, paint-splattered Pepe Jeans and Air Jordan sneakers were all the rage. In Brooklyn, it was all about preppy long-sleeved button-down shirts set off with earrings shaped like Jesus' face. And in Manhattan, tiny hands reached for Lacoste shirts in every color of the rainbow, and anything, but anything, made by Juicy Couture.

title: INSIDE
description: Suicide Bomber Kills 9 in Russia A suicide bomber killed 9 other people and wounded more than 50 outside a busy subway station in Moscow. A group linking itself to Al Qaeda and the conflict in Chechnya claimed responsibility for the attack , as it did for the terror bombings of two Russian airliners a week ago. President Vladimir V. Putin vowed not to bow to terrorists' demands. PAGE A3

title: Edwards, in Appalachia, Reaches Out to Working Families
description: BECKLEY, W.Va., Aug. 31 - Senator John Edwards brought the Democratic presidential campaign to Appalachia on Tuesday, using his two appearances to declare that the Bush administration had done little to help America's working families.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Mayor Convicted Of Seeking Bribes
description: A federal grand jury convicted Mayor Emmanuel Onunwor of East Cleveland of four charges related to pressuring contractors to pay him more than $50,000 in bribes for city projects. Mr. Onunwor, 46, ran for mayor in 1997 on a platform that promised to halt favoritism in awarding contracts. The authorities said Mr. Onunwor also failed to report additional income on his taxes, prompting an Internal Revenue Service investigation and tax charges. The jury convicted him of racketeering, extortion, mail fraud and tax fraud. The City Council was discussing whether to appoint a council member to temporarily run the city. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: France's 'republican monarchy' : When the president is treated like a king
Paid Notice: Deaths   MISHKIN, RUTH L.
description: MISHKIN--Ruth L. On August 30, 2004. Devoted companion of Allan Ash. Beloved cousin of Dr. Murray Goldberg, Marilyn Tassencourt, Franklin Reider and Mildred Goldberg. Services Thursday 1pm at Sutton Place Synagogue 225 East 51st Street, NYC.

title: Upstate Mayor and 2 Officials Are Indicted in Loan Scheme
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 31 - The mayor of Middletown, the city's economic development director and a city judge have been indicted on charges of conspiring to direct more than $140,000 in federal urban development loans to the mayor for his personal use.

title: New iMac Makes Debut a Bit Later Than Apple Hoped
description: Correction Appended

title: VANTAGE POINT : As Athens closes shop, the new label is 'Made in China'
Distinct Tastes of the Northern Rhone
description: PEOPLE in the wine business speak longingly about a sense of place. By this, they mean wines that through aroma and flavor convey the special combination of soil, climate and the human touch that are encompassed in the mystical French word terroir. A wine with a sense of place adds a new chapter in a story that continues, year after year. Some chapters are more fascinating than others, but they are all similar tales.

title: Campaign Notebook : In New York, the protesters may have more activities than the delegates
Ex-Bush Official Gains in Race for Senate
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 31 - Mel Martinez, former housing secretary under President Bush, easily won the Republican nomination in Florida's Senate race Tuesday, providing a potential boost to the president's effort to win coveted Cuban and other Hispanic votes in this swing state.

title: The First Lady's Influence Is Starting to Reveal Itself
description: There were times when Ronald Reagan's behind-the-scenes reliance on his wife, Nancy, spilled into public view, most memorably when television cameras caught him repeating her whispered cue, "We're doing everything we can."

title: St. Vincent's to Expand Trauma Unit for New Age
description: When the jets struck the World Trade Center, the flood of wounded survivors was far smaller than expected, but even so, hospital officials around New York City found that they were ill-prepared for the large number of casualties they could face in an age of terrorism.

title: Mr. Popular by All Counts, Is He Republican Enough?
description: Aglow from the adulation of Iowa Republicans who hung on his every word at a delegation breakfast, Rudolph W. Giuliani was back-slapping his way out of a Sheraton banquet room yesterday when he was brought to a halt by a delegate named Luana Stoltenberg.

title: Corrections
Ex-Housing Official Pleads Guilty to Lying About Use of Vehicle
description: Richard T. Roberts, former chairman of the New York City Housing Development Corporation, pleaded guilty in federal court yesterday to one count of making false statements to investigators about a vehicle bought with $38,000 in city funds that he used for personal purposes.

title: Vice President Dick Cheney's Remarks
description: The following is the full text of the remarks made by Vice President Dick Cheney, as prepared for delivery.

title: Israeli Intelligence Faulted for Failure to Halt Hamas
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 A Israeli intelligence came under careful criticism today for its failure to crack the Hamas cell in Hebron that carried out the twin suicide bombings in Beersheba on Tuesday in which 16 people died and more than 100 were wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOONIE, AILEEN (LEE)
description: LOONIE--Aileen (Lee), 84, of Knoxville, TN, and formerly Manhasset, NY on August 29. Adored wife of the late Robert J. Loonie, loving mother of Jean Macmillan and Robert J. Loonie, Jr. Adored mother-in-law of Tom Macmillan and Patty Arledge-Loonie. Her loving kindness lives on in her five grandchildren, Cora, Katie and Claire Macmillan and Parker and Tate Loonie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, SIDNEY J.
description: BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. On August 30 at 100 years of age. Husband of the late Anita M. Survived by his children Elaine, Paul and Anne. Daughter - in - law Barbara. Grandchildren Erika Bernstein-Kelble, Jeremy and Matthew Bernstein, Jeff Kelble, Julia Gruenewald-Bernstein. Born in Brooklyn in 1904 Mr. Bernstein attended Boys High and Columbia College, graduating in 1924. In 1925 he founded Sidney J. Bernstein Inc. in which he was active until age 95. He served in the 119th Batallion in the Pacific during WWII. He was Vice President of The Educational Foundation of FIT, Treasurer of The American Committee of Shenkar College in Israel. President of the Midtown Realty Association from 1960 to 1977. Raconteur, dancer, philosopher, Beethoven lover, loving and beloved friend, gentleman. Services will be held 11:45AM Friday September 3 at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Committee for Shenkar College, 855 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10001. BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. The American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel deeply mourns the passing of our Founding Board Member, Treasurer Emeritus, generous benefactor and spirited leader. Patron and Founder of the Sidney and Anita Bernstein Library on the campus in Ramat Gan, Israel, he was part of the creation of the Bennett and Pauline Rose Archives housing historical garments and textiles. Since the founding of the American Committee in 1971, Sidney J. Bernstein was committed to the upbuilding of the College adding to its importance in the educational picture of the State of Israel. Beloved by so many, he will be sorely missed by all who had the opportunity to know him. Heartfelt condolences to his daughters Anne L. Bernstein, our devoted Board Member, Elaine S. Bernstein, son Paul Bernstein (Barbara) and to their families. Bruce Pernick, President Charlotte Fainblatt, Exec. Dir. BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. Shenkar College of Engineering and Design, Ramat Gan, Israel, records with great sadness the passing of Sidney J. Bernstein, devoted friend, benefactor and Governor. He was beloved by faculty and students who knew him over the years on his many visits to the College. The Sidney and Anita Bernstein Library, a vital part of our campus, outstanding of its kind in Israel, is also used by industry and academic institutions. An Honorary Fellow of the College, his support and steadfast dedication provide a shining example for generations to come. Deepest condolences to Anne L. Bernstein, Governor, Elaine S. Bernstein, Paul Bernstein and their families. David Pernick, Chancellor R. Stephen Rubin, Chair Board of Governors Prof. Amotz Weinberg, Pres. Moshe Golos, Vice Chair BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. The Educational Foundation for the Fashion Industries mourns the loss and celebrates the life of Sidney J. Bernstein, the longest serving member of the Fashion Institute of Technology's Support Foundation. His legacy of 50 years of commitment and dedication to FIT is inspiration to us all. John J. Pomerantz, Chrmn Joyce F. Brown, CEO

title: Is It Time to Scrap the Electoral College?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Fretting and Red Sox Are Flying
description: With every ugly inning, every shockingly ugly inning, the Yankees had to feel a little more vulnerable. It was only one game, one sliver of the 162-game pie and one awful evening. That is how the Yankees had to view their 22-0 shellacking by the Cleveland Indians.

title: Washington Makes Downtown a Destination Again
description: WASHINGTON - With its eye-catching display windows, 35-foot-high ceilings, exposed pipes and a facade that echoes the Victorian row houses across the street, the new 12,500-square-foot Urban Outfitters store on Seventh and H Streets almost looks as if it had been scooped up from SoHo in Manhattan and replanted here.

title: The Dancers Are Ready. Where Are G.O.P. Laps?
description: When Eileen Shedroff writes her tell-all memoir of the life of a lap dancer, the chapter on the 2004 Republican National Convention is likely to be rather short.

title: Raiders, in a Blue State, See Red
description: NAPA, Calif. - The Pro Bowl quarterback was injured, the coach had called it the dumbest team in the United States and it was clear that the Oakland Raiders would suffer the ignominy of tumbling from the Super Bowl to a 4-12 record in less than 12 months. In the bleakest part of a tragicomic season, planning for a rebirth began last year, in the Raiders' locker room.

title: US Airways Sets Talks With Pilots on Further Cuts to Pension Plan
description: US Airways and its pilots' union were set to meet last night, amid resistance within the pilots' ranks to the airline's bid to shrink their already diminished pension plan, a casualty of the airline's previous bankruptcy filing.

title: Report on Abu Ghraib : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

description: It was no accident that the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, met with the New Hampshire delegation yesterday morning. Or that Senator Chuck Hagel was with those same delegates the evening before. And Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts made sure that Iowans were among those invited to his New England clambake on Monday.

title: 3 Planets Are Found Close in Size to Earth, Making Scientists Think 'Life'
description: The universe looked a little more familiar and friendlier yesterday.

title: A Hopeless Idea for a Film About Alexander Is Finally Successful
description: MUNICH - In the fall of 1987 Thomas Schhly found himself in producer's hell, otherwise known as the set of "The Adventures of Baron Munchausen." He was fighting with his director, Terry Gilliam, whose surreal tale of an 18th-century German fabulist had fallen behind schedule, run wildly over budget and was about to be shut down by its Hollywood paymasters.

description: ROTHBERG -- David Selig, Ph.D Loving husband of Ann Glatman Rothberg, father of Barry, son of Isadore and Paula, brother of Mimi, brother-in-law and uncle. Educator, Vice Principal of CIS 166x, Director of Graduate Education at Mercy College, Manhattan. Former member of Teaneck Board of Education (9 years). Ham radio operator, Volunteer Communications for Teaneck Emergency Management Team. Private services Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. Shiva at home until September 6, 2004. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering or American Cancer Society.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Contract For Actors' Union
description: The membership of Actors' Equity, the actors' and stage managers' union, has overwhelmingly approved a new four-year contract with Broadway's producers, union officials said yesterday. The deal, which was brokered in mid-July after several months of tense negotiations narrowly averted a strike, increases minimum salaries on Broadway. It also establishes a tiered system of payment for touring productions, which the union hopes will increase the number of jobs. The contract, which takes effect immediately, was approved by more than 96 percent of those who voted. Jesse McKinley (NYT)

description: When the Yankees stumbled out of Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night after the most one-sided loss in the franchise's history, they scattered to their homes. But they passed on the urge to watch a replay of the game or at least the highlights, the usual routine for many of them.

title: Hernndez's Line Is No Smiles and All Business
description: Orlando Hernndez dashed to scoop up Coco Crisp's dribbler near the first-base line in the third inning and moved into position to tag him. Crisp stopped running about 20 feet from first and backed away, so Hernndez swiped at him with his glove and missed.

title: For Weary Gardeners, a Late-Summer Bounty
description: I LOVE the voluptuous, almost wasted quality of our garden this time of year. A tall sunflower that crashed to the ground in the potato patch earlier this summer, breaking its thick stem so it was impossible to stake, simply turned its big flower head upward and bloomed on the ground. Now, its foot-wide yellow seed head is visited regularly by the goldfinches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUTLER, ROBERT B.
description: CUTLER--Robert B., 90, of Newtown, PA, died August 28, 2004 at St. Mary Medical Center. Retired Professor of Music and Chairman of the Music Department of Lehigh University. A member of the American Guild of Organists. Survived by many cousins including Carol Thompson, Henry Lewis and Ruth Prigge. Memorial services will be held at a later date to be announced. Memorial contributions may be made to the Cutler-Samets Choral Arts Endowed Scholarship Fund, C/O Lehigh University, Development Office, 27 Memorial Drive West, Bethleham, PA. 18015.

title: In Conclusion; Upward Bound
description: Tonight, at the Republican National Convention in New York, George W. Bush will step onto the podium and accept his party's nomination for president. Though conventions themselves have receded in importance, the acceptance speech has remained potent, offering the candidate -- even one who has been in the public eye for four years -- the chance to define himself. So what should the president say? The Op-Ed page asked speechwriters from six Republican administrations, including the current one, to propose a conclusion to President Bush's address -- one that sums up what they think the winning Republican campaign themes for 2004 should be.

title: King of Remotes, but Try to Grasp It
description: I AM not a collector. My possessions do not include Depression glassware, Art Deco matchbooks, vintage postcards or Hummel figurines. When I die, I will not bequeath any coins, stamps or rare editions.

description: TAKING THE OFFENSIVE -- Senator John Kerry, in a speech to the American Legion, rebuked President Bush for his handling of both the war on terror and the war in Iraq. PAGE P1

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Widens
description: Brazil posted a trade surplus of $3.43 billion in August, up from a surplus of $2.67 billion a year earlier, the trade ministry said. That brought the accumulated trade surplus so far this year to $21.95 billion, compared with $15.13 billion in the first eight months of 2003. Exports and imports continued to increase last month, totaling $9.1 billion and $5.6 billion, respectively. The strong export performance led the government to raise its year-end trade surplus forecast last month to $30 billion, from $28 billion. In 2003, Brazil, South America's largest economy, posted a record trade surplus of $24.8 billion. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPKA, MORRIS
description: LIPKA--Morris. On September 1 at 96 years of age in Tamarac, FL. Formerly of White Plains. Husband of the late Genesse Levine Lipka and the late Sara Weiss Lipka. Survived by his sons, Leonard of Alexandria, VA, Kenneth of Boca Raton, FL, and Robert of Weston, CT. Affectionately known as "Papa" to nine grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Born in Pultusk, Poland in 1908, Morris Lipka came to the United States in 1920. He joined Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers Union in 1929 and founded General Sheet Metal Works in 1943. He was vice president of the Sheet Metal Workers Owners Association for many years and earned the admiration and respect of his industry peers and business associates. Services will be held at 10:00 A.M. Friday, September 3, at Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Experts Said Slam Would Fail, But a Danish Teenager Made It
description: There is no objective way to identify the world's best teenage player, but Martin Schaltz of Denmark would be a strong candidate.

title: On Politics and Power, Ask the Bard (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: China's 2 Top Leaders Square Off in Contest to Run Policy
description: BEIJING, Sept. 1 - As China's leaders prepare to gather for a national planning session, the country's two top officials, Hu Jintao and Jiang Zemin, are engaged in an increasingly pointed power struggle that has begun to create cracks in the one-party system, Chinese officials and analysts say.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ex-G.I. To Surrender
description: Charles Robert Jenkins, the American accused of deserting the United States Army in 1965 and fleeing to North Korea, said in a statement that he would "very shortly" surrender himself to American military authorities at Camp Zama, near Tokyo, and "voluntarily face the charges that have been filed against me by the U.S. Army." Mr. Jenkins, 64, who has met with American officials since arriving in Japan in July and receiving medical treatment, is expected to make a plea bargain that could allow him to avoid imprisonment. An agreement would allow both American and Japanese officials to resolve a diplomatic problem while tending to domestic opinion. In the past, American officials said they planned to court martial him. But because Mr. Jenkins married a Japanese woman who had been kidnapped by North Koreans and who was then allowed to return to Japan in 2002, the case is a highly emotional one in Japan. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Not the Biggest Delegation, but Still Enjoying the Perks
description: As soon as she stepped off the West Virginia Coach bus at ground zero, Gayle Mason separated herself from her fellow delegates. She walked over to the fence and pressed her face against it.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Insanity Plea In Highway Shootings
description: Charles A. McCoy Jr., who is accused of killing a woman in highway sniper shootings that left Columbus drivers wary for months, changed his plea to not guilty by reason of insanity. Mr. McCoy, 29, left, faces an aggravated murder charge in the killing last November of Gail Knisley, 62, and other charges related to highway shootings. He pleaded not guilty last month to the charges. The Franklin County prosecuting attorney, Ron O'Brien, said he would seek a second examination. If Mr. McCoy is found not guilty by reason of insanity, he will most likely be sent to a psychiatric institution. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Scallop Restoration Planned
description: The Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, signed legislation yesterday authorizing a $1.8 million county-financed project to reseed the Peconic Bays on eastern Long Island with millions of scallops over the next four years. County officials said the program was the largest scallop restoration effort ever attempted in the United States. Native scallop populations were hurt beginning in 1985 by algae that became known as the Brown Tide. Half a million pounds of scallops were taken from the Peconic Bays in 1982, with a commercial value of $1.8 million. By 1996, county figures showed, the total had dropped to 53 pounds, with a value of $400. John Rather (NYT)

title: Wal-Mart and Productivity
description: ON this Labor Day, it is worth remembering how widely it was once argued that America's new economy would produce more democratic workplaces that depended on the advancing skills of workers. Old assembly-line mass production was dead, hierarchical management was a dinosaur, and the nation's productivity would be raised rapidly through the creation of interesting new jobs at higher pay and benefits.

title: The Jets Make a Magnanimous Gesture
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 1 - This is the time of year when dreams die for many young players in the National Football League. It is the season of roster cutdowns and getting caught up in numbers games and "Hey, man, Coach wants to see you."

title: Forget Boston. It Is the East vs. the West.
description: THE Yankees finished last night with a seven-game cushion over Anaheim in the American League playoff race, the only race that is truly meaningful in a sport whose last two champions did not win their measly four- and five-team divisions. Sometimes it is difficult to remember this around George Steinbrenner's Yankees, who often seem psychologically trapped in a universe of two.

title: Textile Industry to Request Limits on Chinese Goods
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - Officials of the United States textile industry said on Wednesday that they would petition the Bush administration this month to block the flood of Chinese imports that is expected next year after global quotas on textiles and apparel are lifted.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Cuts Prices On Some Computers
description: Sun Microsystems, the No.3 maker of computers that run corporate networks, cut prices on some models as much as 35 percent to reclaim market share from its rivals I.B.M. and Dell. The discounts on servers and workstations run through Nov. 30 and apply to computers using Linux or Microsoft Windows operating systems and running on semiconductors from either Sun or Advanced Micro Devices, Sun said yesterday.

title: Court Says Ex-I.R.S. Employee Deserves Whistle-Blower Status
description: A former Internal Revenue Service executive won a rare victory in court yesterday in a whistle-blower case in which he raised allegations of the existence of official favoritism to rich and politically connected California families and businesses that owe back taxes.

"Unfit for Command," an unflattering appraisal of Senator John Kerry's service in Vietnam, is the fastest-selling book in the country. Ronald Kessler's sympathetic behind-the-scenes account of the Bush White House, "A Matter of Character," also graces the national best-seller lists.

description: MIAMI, Sept. 1 - In an unexpected move that signals the political diversification of Cuban-Americans, the executive director of a prominent Cuban-American exile group here has left his post to join a Democratic advocacy organization.

description: The Kobe Bryant rape case was dismissed yesterday in Eagle, Colo., after prosecutors said the woman who had accused Mr. Bryant of sexual assault was unwilling to testify, leaving the state no option but to drop all charges.

title: Justice Is Blind, but a Court Surveillance System Sees All
description: IN a fluorescent-lit, slightly dingy room on the ground floor of the hulking courthouse at 111 Centre Street in downtown Manhattan, Sheng Guo was showing off. And for good reason. There were no windows in the room, but Mr. Guo, chief technology officer of the New York State court system, could see for miles.

title: The Governor's Confidant Shares the Light
description: ELIZABETH, N.J. - WHEN Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey announced last month that he was gay and would resign, he turned for support and advice, as he has so often in his political career, to a patron and confidant: State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak.

title: The Cheney World View, With a Focus on Danger and Boldness
description: Vice President Dick Cheney reverted last night to the simple, bold declarations of how America should exercise its power that were often heard in the first year after the Sept. 11 attacks, when Iraq had not yet been invaded, intelligence reports had not yet proved false, and 17 months of insurgency had not yet raised the question of whether George W. Bush had taken a wrong turn in the fight against terror.

title: For Serena Williams, Less Is Definitely More
description: She is one of the best tennis players in the world, but the talk surrounding her has nothing to do with aces or ground strokes. When it comes to Serena Williams, the discussion turns to clothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARSHAW, LUCILLE (BARUCH)
description: WARSHAW--Lucille (Baruch) died August 31, 2004. Beloved wife of Seymour (died 1995). Loving mother of Carol Frehm and Susan Warshaw (Mark Lerner). Devoted grandmother of Eric Frehm (Sarah Barmby) and Adam Frehm. Great-grandmother of Isla Frehm. Loving sister of Sanford Baruch and devoted aunt of Stephanie Frucht and Joshua Baruch. Services Thursday 2PM at "RiversideNassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment approx 3:15 PM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: I.B.M. to Share Technology and Designs for New Computer
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that it will share the designs and technology for a fast-growing line of computers known as blade servers. The move is an effort to enlarge I.B.M.'s lead in an emerging market by making it easier for other hardware and software companies to build products for the company's machines.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Acclaim Plans Liquidation
description: Acclaim Entertainment Inc., a maker of video games like Showdown: Legends of Wrestling, filed for bankruptcy yesterday and plans to liquidate its assets. The company, based in Glen Cove, N.Y., made video games for the Sony PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube and Microsoft Xbox systems. In July, Acclaim reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $25.4 million and said it would seek bankruptcy protection if it could not get a loan by Aug. 4. Acclaim said on Aug. 23 that its line of credit from GMAC Commercial Finance was terminated as of Aug. 20, after the term of the loan was extended twice. In court papers, the company listed up to $50 million in assets and more than $100 million in debts. Gerard Agoglia, the company's chief financial officer, and its bankruptcy lawyer, Jeff Friedman, did not immediately return calls seeking comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARMAROS, CHARLOTTE
description: MARMAROS--Charlotte, age 84, of Great Neck, New York on August 31, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Dear aunt of Bill and Ed Keller, Ellen Brotman, Bill and Barbara Sammath. Reposing at the Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St, Port Washington, New York. Visiting Friday 8:30 AM. Religious Service 9:30 AM. Interment Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Donations to North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System Foundation, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY 11030, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about Clear Channel Communications' decision to change to liberal programming on one of its radio stations in San Diego, a city known as a conservative bastion, referred incompletely to the legal case of Roger Hedgecock, a former San Diego mayor who is the host of a conservative program on a Clear Channel station there. While he did indeed resign from office and was convicted of violating campaign finance laws, all but one of the convictions were overturned, and a conviction for which he paid a fine and served probation was later expunged from his record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORAN, JOSEPH J.
description: MORAN--Joseph J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Joseph J. Moran, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Robert J. Reilly, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Pakistan Found to Aid Iran Nuclear Efforts
description: A new assessment of Iran's nuclear program by the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency says that, as early as 1995, Pakistan was providing Tehran with the designs for sophisticated centrifuges capable of making bomb-grade nuclear fuel. It also finds evidence that, as of the mid-August, Iran had assembled and tested the major components for 70 of the machines, which it showed to inspectors from the agency.

description: OSTROW--Elizabeth B. Died August 31, 2004 in her 81st birthday. Beloved wife for 60 years of Saul. Ethical, humane, courageous, strong, a true woman of valor, she will be sorely missed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 32 Years For Bosnian Serb
description: A former high-ranking Bosnian Serb politician, Radoslav Brdjanin, was sentenced to 32 years in prison. The judges at the war crimes tribunal said he had played an important role in a plan to create an ethnically pure region for Serbs only in northwestern Bosnia. As part of the strategy, thousands of Muslims and Croats were deported, many to notorious prison camps, and more than 1,600 civilians were killed. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pink Elephants column of the special Republican convention section yesterday about a breakfast for the Texas delegation at the Hilton Hotel misidentified the event's sponsor. (The error also occurred in a picture caption about arrests of protesters outside the hotel who wore pig snouts while demonstrating against Halliburton.) The breakfast sponsor was TXU, a Texas energy corporation, not Halliburton.

Arnold Schwarzenegger of California waxed ecstatic about the American dream and assured immigrants that they could realize theirs just as surely as he has realized his, about 100 men stood on Roosevelt Avenue in Queens, waiting. They waited not for a dream, but for a day job as a painter, a sander, a plasterer.

Rowland resigned amid questions about his relationships with people doing business with the state, a task force created by his successor has proposed an overhaul of contracting procedures that it found inconsistent and vulnerable to improper influence.

description: IT'S a prospect that nobody likes to think about: a laptop or hand-held computer left behind on a train or bus -- or worse, stolen.

title: Folding Up Flat: Tupperware Does Yoga
description: John-Michael Ekeblad, Tupperware's vice president for global design, decided what the world needed was a container that "when not in use, it's invisible." The result is a bowl that collapses like a spent accordion to a thickness of less than an inch. The design team drew inspiration from Chinese takeout containers and Ikea furniture, both of which store flat, said Mr. Ekeblad, a former creative director at Ikea. A set of three orange-lidded containers, each holding up to a quart, is $18.99; for sources, (888) 887-9273. After Oct. 1, sets with lime-green lids and three-cup capacities will be available at www.tupperware.com. An exhibition of Tupperware's 50-year history opens Sept. 9 at Parsons School of Design (www.parsons.edu).

title: Bright Lights and Protesters for Delegates From Missouri
description: Hopeless, helpless, hapless rubes who couldn't tell a bagel from a banjo: that's the average New Yorker's view of visitors from the part of the country where I grew up -- the middle part, flyover country, where the vowels are as flat as the landscape. Well, not always. Not this week, for instance, and not the 57 delegates from Missouri to the Republican National Convention.

Celebrating his 100th birthday this April 13th, he always believed in the goodness of a person. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Bernstein Real Estate
