description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Link for the Mac User Who Craves a BlackBerry
description: As the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device has grown into a full-fledged computer, it has left Macintosh users behind. The software provided by Research in Motion, BlackBerry's maker, for synchronizing address book and calendar data runs only on Windows-based computers.

title: Problems Printing? One Error Decoded
description: Q. What is Spool32? It often shows up in error messages when I try to print.

title: Opposition Offers Compromise in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Sept. 1 - In a break with other government opponents, Venezuela's largest and most influential business association said on Wednesday that it was prepared to embark on talks over the economy's future with President Hugo Chvez, but the offer was quickly rebuffed by the administration.

title: Inside
description: Convention news appears today in a separate section, The Republicans, Pages P1 to 16.

title: G.O.P., Last to Bat, Swings Freely for the Fences
description: In politics, as in baseball, it's better to be up last, and the Republicans have spent their convention in New York this week in a batter-by-batter rebuttal of almost everything the Democrats said and did in Boston last month -- a strategic twist on that old Broadway boast: "Anything You Can Do, I Can Do Better."

title: Letting Gamers Play God, and Now Themselves
description: THE first thing Peter Molyneux asks someone who has played Fable, his newest video game, is not whether they like it, but what kind of person they were when they played it. Were they kind or cruel? Had they married? If so, how many times? Had they courted fame or skulked in shadows?

title: Mistakes and Miscues Prove Too Much for Bryant's Accuser
description: FROM outside their Mayberry R.F.D. offices in Eagle County, Colo., prosecutors spared Kobe Bryant the embarrassment of having more dirty details of his dark side revealed in a looming rape trial when these local keepers of ineptitude dropped the case against him yesterday.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
In Western Sudan, Fear Is the Ever-Growing Enemy
description: SHIGEKARO, Sudan - The United Nations has issued the Arab-led government of Sudan a stark ultimatum: show evidence of improved security for the black African tribes of the vast western region called Darfur, or face the consequences -- among them, possibly economic sanctions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOWDEN, PAMELA A.
description: BOWDEN--Pamela A. On August 30, 2004 of Garden City. Beloved daughter of the late Alfred and Emily Bowden. Cherished sister of Barbara, Juliana Schmitt and Emily. Dear aunt of James Schmitt, Amy Herman and Thomas Schmitt. Memorial visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, Friday 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Pamela's memory may be sent to, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, GIST Research, c/o Robert G. Maki, M.D., Ph.D., 1275 York Ave, New York, NY 10021.

title: Steinbrenner's Message Delivered in Platitudes
description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner and self-appointed motivational master of the Yankees, went to work early yesterday to help his players cope with the aftermath of the worst loss in franchise history. Steinbrenner believed the best way to handle Tuesday night's 22-0 embarrassment against the Cleveland Indians would be simply by showing they are stronger.

title: National Briefings
description: WEST

title: Corporate Kleptocracy
description: White-collar crooks typically skim from the top, but Conrad Black stands accused of pocketing the whole top, the middle and much of the bottom of the barrel of his company's assets. An inquiry that was commissioned by the company, the Hollinger International newspaper publisher, and led by Richard Breeden, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, accuses Mr. Black and his chief operating officer, David Radler, of helping themselves to some $400 million of Hollinger funds from 1996 to 2003. That's roughly 95 percent of the company's net income for the period.

title: In Conclusion; A Strong Front
description: Tonight, at the Republican National Convention in New York, George W. Bush will step onto the podium and accept his party's nomination for president. Though conventions themselves have receded in importance, the acceptance speech has remained potent, offering the candidate -- even one who has been in the public eye for four years -- the chance to define himself. So what should the president say? The Op-Ed page asked speechwriters from six Republican administrations, including the current one, to propose a conclusion to President Bush's address -- one that sums up what they think the winning Republican campaign themes for 2004 should be.

title: The View From the Floor: Looking Good for the President, and Getting Better
description: Not that Pat Takasugi ever thought there was much of a chance that President Bush would lose, but the spectacle under way in Madison Square Garden has really convinced Mr. Takasugi, an Idaho onion farmer and first-time Republican delegate, that victory is in the air.

title: Israelis Fault Intelligence Agencies on Bombings by Hamas Cell
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 - Israeli intelligence agencies came under careful criticism on Wednesday for their failure to crack the Hamas cell in Hebron that carried out the twin suicide bombings in Beersheba on Tuesday, when 16 people died and more than 100 were wounded.

title: Despite risk and a government ban, Filipinos line up for Iraq jobs
As Convention Ends, Political Fistfight Begins
description: President Bush and his devoted Republicans backers wrapped up their Garden party Thursday night, and the next two months do not look like they are going to be any picnic.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Man Is Charged in Attack on Detective During Protest
description: Prosecutors drew up felony assault charges yesterday against a 20-year-old Manhattan man who the police said admitted to punching and kicking a plainclothes police detective who was knocked off his scooter after a largely peaceful protest march became unruly Monday night.

title: Pressing for Turkey and Ukraine to join : Poland's vision of EU
Yankees Take the Hints and Bounce Back After Drubbing
description: The Yankees arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday relieved to see that, yes, the sun had come out again. And as they took the field for batting practice, the scoreboard that had taunted them so cruelly on Tuesday night had wiped away the 22-0 pronouncement of the drubbing by the Cleveland Indians and replaced it with a message from the team's normally tempestuous principal owner, George Steinbrenner.

title: Cheney and G.O.P. Mount Vigorous Assault on Kerry
description: Declaring that the nation's fundamental security was at stake in the presidential election, Vice President Dick Cheney said yesterday that Senator John Kerry had repeatedly "made the wrong call" on critical foreign policy challenges and failed to appreciate the severity of the threat the nation faced after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Tuesday about a repairman killed while working in an elevator in a Queens building included an erroneous description of the circumstances from the police. The victim was electrocuted after accidentally crossing wires, and he fell to the floor. He did not fall down the shaft.

title: Citing Politics, Studio Cancels Documentary
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 - Warner Brothers has decided not to distribute the director David O. Russell's new antiwar documentary when it re-releases his 1999 Gulf War movie, "Three Kings," this fall, judging it "totally inappropriate" to do so in a political season, a studio spokeswoman said.

title: TENET GETS SUBPOENA IN CALIFORNIA FOR DOCUMENTS
description: Tenet Healthcare said it received a subpoena from the United States attorney's office in San Francisco for documents related to medical directorships. The company said it was cooperating with the subpoena. Prosecutors are seeking information about Tenet's relationships with doctors at the San Ramon Regional Medical Center, a hospital about 35 miles east of San Francisco, the company said. The subpoena is consistent with government reviews of agreements in other cities that the company had previously disclosed. It follows similar requests from prosecutors in St. Louis and New Orleans. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., announced the subpoena after markets closed.

title: Microsoft Challenges Rivals With New Online Music Service
description: Microsoft started selling music tracks yesterday on its MSN online service, taking on Apple Computer and a host of others in the fast-growing market for digital music.

title: REPUBLICANS IN NEW YORK / From moderates to conservatives : Convention delegates just love New Yorkers, especially the police
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Profit Rises
description: The China Telecom Corporation, the publicly traded unit of China's biggest fixed-line operator, said yesterday that its first-half profit rose 13 percent after it bought networks from its parent and expanded a service that competes for cellphone users. Profit rose to 14.71 billion yuan ($1.8 billion) from a revised 13.06 billion yuan a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose to 80.22 billion yuan from a revised 74.07 billion yuan. China Telecom, based in Beijing, said it signed up 17.5 million new subscribers in the first half.

title: PHILIP MORRIS TO BUY COLOMBIA'S BIGGEST TOBACCO COMPANY
description: Philip Morris International Inc., part of the Altria Group, has agreed to buy Cia. Colombiana de Tabaco S.A., Colombia's biggest tobacco company, for $310 million. Colombiana de Tabaco's majority shareholders would sell 51.8 percent for $4.88 a share, or 30 percent above Tuesday's closing price. Philip Morris has also offered to buy the remaining shares. Colombiana de Tabaco's majority holders are members of the Antioqueno Business Group, Colombia's largest conglomerate.

title: Floridians Brace for Another Hurricane
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 1 - A shaken Florida began bracing Wednesday for the possibility of its second major hurricane in less than a month, with people up and down the state's eastern coast lunging for emergency supplies even as it remained impossible to predict where the storm would strike.

title: A Hotel and Condos, Authored by Balazs And Partners
description: Andr Balazs, above, the hotelier who brought us the Mercer in 1996, has three new projects under way. One is a luxury condominium on Mercer Street (lower left), by the French architect Jean Nouvel; another is starter condos (as in starting at $1 million) designed by Richard Gluckman on Lafayette Street (left), set for 2005; and the third is a Standard hotel on Washington Street in the meatpacking district.

title: 'Compassionate Conservatism' and Its Discontents (10 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: At Penn Station, A Stalled Revival
description: As Republican notables gather in Madison Square Garden to celebrate the candidacy of President Bush, New Yorkers might point to a pressing concern across the street: how to jump-start the plan to create a stunning new Pennsylvania Station in the neo-Classical shell of the old James A. Farley post office building.

title: Corrections
The First Day of the Month, and the Mail Line Is Smooth
description: The man in the blue shirt must have been someone important. After checking his bags at a sidewalk table yesterday morning, he and the others in his group received a police escort across Ninth Avenue and into the frozen zone surrounding the Republican National Convention.

title: Jitters Over Al Qaeda
description: BERLIN, Sept. 1 - The leader of Germany's foreign intelligence agency warned Tuesday of an increased likelihood of a major terror attack by Al Qaeda in the weeks before the American elections.

title: Excerpts From President Bush's Speech to the Convention
description: he following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks to the 2004 Republican National Convention.

title: In Conclusion; What I Learned
description: Tonight, at the Republican National Convention in New York, George W. Bush will step onto the podium and accept his party's nomination for president. Though conventions themselves have receded in importance, the acceptance speech has remained potent, offering the candidate -- even one who has been in the public eye for four years -- the chance to define himself. So what should the president say? The Op-Ed page asked speechwriters from six Republican administrations, including the current one, to propose a conclusion to President Bush's address -- one that sums up what they think the winning Republican campaign themes for 2004 should be.

title: Carl Morris, Advocate for Black Journalists, Dies at 73
description: Carl E. Morris, a former newspaper reporter and editor who then held several influential posts as an advocate for hiring black journalists, died Friday at his home in Reston, Va. He was 73.

title: Federal Inquiry to Review Regulation of Railroad Grade Crossings
description: The inspector general of the Transportation Department announced yesterday that his office would open a sweeping investigation to determine whether federal regulators adequately oversee the safety of railroad grade crossings, where on average one person dies each day.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Admits Legal Flaws In Detroit Terror Case The Justice Department assailed its own legal strategy as it asked a federal judge to end the terror case against what it once called a sleeper combat cell in Detroit; instead prosecutors asked for a new trial on document fraud charges. Convictions in the case had been hailed as a victory in the war against terror. PAGE A14

title: US Airways Pilots Hint Deal Is Near on Cuts
description: The pilots' union at US Airways said yesterday that it might be close to reaching an agreement on wage and benefit cuts that the struggling airline contends are necessary to avoid another bankruptcy filing.

title: Red Cross Offering Survival Kits Online
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - The American Red Cross has begun selling emergency preparedness and first-aid kits over the Internet.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Challenger Wants Congressman Off Ballot
description: Jock Scott, a Republican from Alexandria who is running for Congress, has asked the State Supreme Court to take the incumbent off the ballot for the Nov. 2 election because he switched parties at the last minute. National Republican officials had encouraged Mr. Scott to run, said his lawyer, Michael Johnson, then abandoned him when Representative Rodney Alexander, who qualified two days earlier as a Democrat, switched to the Republican Party minutes before the qualifying period ended Aug. 6. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Frank Horton, Former Dean of House Delegation, Dies at 84
description: Frank Jefferson Horton, a Rockefeller Republican from Rochester and the former dean of New York's Congressional delegation, died on Monday at a hospital in Winchester, Va. He was 84 and lived in Bentonville, Va.

title: After a Spate of Bombings, Moscow's Full of Foreboding
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1 - Liliya Boyalova came to work on Wednesday resolved to be stoic. But as she sold lottery tickets inside the bustling Paveletskaya subway station here, she felt only anxiety and fear.

title: A Windows IPod Experience (Don't Forget the Tattoo)
description: It is not blue and they are not calling it the hPod, but Hewlett-Packard announced last week that it was finally releasing its answer to Apple Computer's iPod digital music player, originally promised earlier this year. Now known officially as the Apple iPod From HP, the music player will be available in early September at hpshopping.com and at Best Buy, CompUSA, Radio Shack and Costco.

title: A Leader Now Tested by Tragedy
description: Four years ago, George W. Bush arrived at the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia as a governor untested in foreign policy, best known as his father's son and caricatured as a princeling who would do the bidding of his older advisers. Tonight, Mr. Bush will stride into Madison Square Garden as a president of consequence, tested, altered and defined by the history that intervened on a crystalline September morning four miles south of the stage where he will accept his party's nomination for a second term.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Quantum To Cut Jobs
description: The Quantum Corporation, a maker of cartridges and disk drives that store computer data, said yesterday that it would cut an unspecified number of jobs by March, the end of its fiscal year, to reduce costs. Because of the action, Quantum will take charges of about $4 million to $5 million before the end of the fiscal year, the company, based in San Jose, Calif., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Shares of Quantum rose 8 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $2.43.

title: Excerpt From Keynote Speech
description: Following is an excerpt from Senator Zell Miller's address to the Republican National Convention last night, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript and video are on the Web at nytimes.com/campaign.

title: France Plans to Cut Phone Stake
description: PARIS - THE French government accelerated its privatization effort yesterday, saying that it would sell as much as 12.1 percent of France Tlcom, the former state monopoly, and take its stake below the symbolically important level of 50 percent.

title: Stent Maker Says Sales Lost After Recall Have Returned
description: Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had regained virtually all of the business it lost after a recall this summer of some of its heart stents.

title: 'Compassionate Conservatism' and Its Discontents
description: To the Editor:

title: In Conclusion; National Unity
description: Tonight, at the Republican National Convention in New York, George W. Bush will step onto the podium and accept his party's nomination for president. Though conventions themselves have receded in importance, the acceptance speech has remained potent, offering the candidate -- even one who has been in the public eye for four years -- the chance to define himself. So what should the president say? The Op-Ed page asked speechwriters from six Republican administrations, including the current one, to propose a conclusion to President Bush's address -- one that sums up what they think the winning Republican campaign themes for 2004 should be.

title: Cutups and Cutthroats
description: I always enjoy hearing about how a teenage Dick Cheney stood off to the side with buckets of water to put out Lynne's flaming batons.

title: Bush Appeals to Nation to Help Build a 'Safer World'
description: President Bush said today that the people of the United States have arrived at a defining moment in their history, and that he wants to lead them in building "a safer world and a more hopeful America."

title: Tools of Crowd Control: Scooters and Mesh Netting
description: With no permit but an agreement with police commanders to keep sidewalks clear and not block traffic, antiwar marchers on Tuesday afternoon stepped off the curb near ground zero for a march to Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Our Towns column yesterday, about the Red Rooster Drive-In, a roadside restaurant, omitted the dateline denoting the locale. The restaurant is in Brewster, N.Y.

title: Congress Puts Insurance Sales To Military Under Scrutiny
description: State and federal investigators and members of Congress are broadening their efforts to address problems in the sale of life insurance and mutual funds to young soldiers and other service members on military installations nationwide.

title: The Return of the Venture Capitalists
description: In the world of venture capital, it may not be the best of times. But it is sure not the worst, either.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: United Technologies Corp.'s Hamilton Sundstrand unit, Hartford, Conn., agreed to buy Haskel International Inc., Burbank, Calif., a maker of pneumatic pumps and valves, to add to its line of specialty industrial pumps.

title: Crime Levels Stay Low During Hectic Week
description: Though the police have been occupied by thousands of protesters in Manhattan over the last few days, crime has not surged elsewhere in the city, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Sorry, E.T., but Parcel Post May Beat Phoning Home
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEFFEN, ETHEL
description: GEFFEN--Ethel. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff of the Department of Radiology, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Ethel Geffen, beloved wife of our dear friend and colleague, Abraham Geffen, M.D., former Director of Radiology. To Dr. Geffen and the entire Geffen family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Thomas Killip, M.D. Interim President and CEO Michael Abiri, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Radiology Donald M. Kastenbaum, M.D. President, Medical Board

title: Home, Terrifying Home: The Not-So-Scenic Tour
description: "The Comfort and Safety of Your Own Home," a mood piece written and directed by Josh Fox, is not one of those plays in which you settle into your chair and passively let the actors take over for a few hours. Mr. Fox, one of the most adventurous impresarios of the New York avant-garde, keeps the audience moving through the entire show, constantly shifting the stage and the focus of the action.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Aug. 26 about the Greek sprinter Konstantinos Kenteris referred incorrectly to a report in The Mercury News of San Jose, Calif., linking Kenteris to people being investigated for the illegal distribution of steroids. The Mercury News reported that one of the men accused of illegal distribution, Victor Conte Jr., sent an e-mail message to an unidentified person, warning that the authorities may have become aware of a previously undetectable steroid. The paper said that in the e-mail message, Conte suggested warning Kenteris's coach, Christos Tsekos. The newspaper did not say the e-mail message was sent directly to Tsekos.

title: Mourning to Attempt Comeback With the Nets
description: The Nets announced last night that Alonzo Mourning, who announced his retirement last season to receive a kidney transplant, will attempt a comeback and will attend their training camp in October.

title: For a Night, Cheney Dons Charisma
description: There cannot be many people in the world who would confuse Dick Cheney with Elvis Presley, but all of them seemed to be in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: 24 Executives Named to Help Revamp Fiat Auto Unit
description: MILAN, Sept. 1 - Fiat named 24 executives to its money-losing auto division Wednesday in an attempt to streamline decision making, cut costs and nurse the car unit back to profitability.

title: Did Namath Have Fun? Yes. But He Also Paid.
description: NAMATH A Biography By Mark Kriegel 512 pages. Viking. $27.95.

title: On Politics and Power, Ask the Bard
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Davenport In, Myskina Out, as a Shaky Day Shocks the Open
description: A slender Russian with long blond hair created a stir today at the United States Open A and it was not Maria Sharapova.

title: 1929:Customs Overcharges : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Another Try
description: At the start of political talks in Belfast aimed at restarting a joint Catholic-Protestant legislature, Protestant parties insisted negotiations were pointless unless the Irish Republican Army fully disarmed. The sides are to meet with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, in two weeks. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Mr. Bush and the Truth About Terror
description: While Republican delegates have been meeting in New York City, terrorist bombs have been exploding in the rest of the world. The horrific pictures of victims on an Israeli bus and slain airplane and subway passengers, as well as of a school held hostage in Russia, are a stark reminder to Americans that terrorism is not all about us. It is the tactic of preference for the self-obsessed radical movements of our age.

title: 1954:Senate chides McCarthy : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
CB2, the Hipper Crate & Barrel, Is Not Just in Chicago Anymore
description: For the last four years, Crate & Barrel's younger and hipper housewares and furniture lines have been available only in one Chicago store, CB2.

title: Bush Is 'Unfit' to Lead U.S., Kerry Charges
description: Senator John Kerry lashed back at President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney tonight, saying that he would not remain quiet while his patriotism was being questioned by men who had not served in Vietnam and who had ``misled the nation into Iraq.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Reactor Shuts Down
description: One of the two reactors at the Indian Point nuclear power plant was shut down yesterday after workers discovered a problem with a valve that regulates the flow of water into one of the steam generators, according to Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy Nuclear Northeast, the company that owns the plant. There was no release of radioactive material into the environment from the reactor, which is known as Indian Point 2, and Entergy expects it to be back in service by the weekend, he said. It was the first time since the blackout last summer that either reactor had ceased operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EGAN, MARY T.
description: EGAN--Mary T. on August 31, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Raymond Egan. Loving mother of Heather Leeds and her husband Thomas V. Leeds. Cherished grandmother of Christine, T. Evan and Rory. Fond sister to her brothers Robert, Thomas and John Carr. Family will receive friends Thursday 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In celebration of her life, Mass will be held Friday 10am at St. Thomas More, 89 St between Madison and Park. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALIKOFF, STANLEY
description: KALIKOFF -- Stanley. Died peacefully on August 31, 2004, at age 80, of Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of the late Elaine Bierman Kalikoff, father of Beth and Hedy, grandfather of Sylvie, Eva and Natalie, brother of the late Annette Kalikoff Picard, uncle to Lawrence, David and Robert Picard, brother-in-law to Beverly Wein and Kurt Picard, father-in-law to Ray Studebaker and Will Milberg, dear cousin and friend to so many. His sweet and loving presence, his modesty, kindness and generosity will be terribly missed. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, September 7, 2004, 10 A.M. Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Donations in his memory to any of the following are welcome: Parkinson's Disease Foundation (www.pdf.org), United Cerebral Palsy (www.ucp.org); Temple Beth El, Somerville, NJ; Temple Beth Shalom, Hastings - on - Hudson, NY; Temple De Hirsch Sinai, Seattle, WA.

title: Text of Remarks Made by Governor George Pataki
description: The full text of remarks made by Governor George Pataki, as prepared for delivery.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Pink Elephants column of the special Republican convention section yesterday about a breakfast for the Texas delegation at the Hilton Hotel misidentified the event's sponsor. (The error also occurred in a picture caption about arrests of protesters outside the hotel who wore pig snouts while demonstrating against Halliburton.) The breakfast sponsor was TXU, a Texas energy corporation, not Halliburton.

title: IHS ENERGY ACQUIRES CAMBRIDGE ENERGY RESEARCH
description: IHS Energy, which provides maps and technical databases to oil and natural gas producers, bought Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting company founded by the author Daniel Yergin. Mr. Yergin will continue to oversee Cambridge Energy's research and will serve on IHS Energy's governing board. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. IHS Energy is owned by the Thyssen-Bornemisza Group, a closely held European conglomerate. Cambridge Energy, based in Cambridge, Mass., was majority-owned by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc., a buyout firm based in New York. Mr. Yergin is the author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power," a history of the oil industry that won the Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction in 1992.

title: France's role in Sudan : When Darfur is safer, seek a political solution

title: Justice Dept. Seeks End to Its Detroit Terror Case
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 - The Justice Department on Wednesday assailed its own legal strategy in the case that had brought its first courtroom victory in the war on terror.

title: Text of Remarks Made by General Tommy Franks
description: The following is the full text of remarks made by General Tommy Franks, as prepared for delivery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nathan Lane Injured On Stage
description: Nathan Lane, left, the star of the Lincoln Center Theater musical "The Frogs," was injured during the first act of yesterday's matinee and was unable to perform the rest of the show, said his publicist, Simon Halls. Mr. Lane, left, who plays the central role of Dionysos in an adaptation of the Greek comedy by Aristophanes, gashed and bruised his legs during a scene in which he descends through a trapdoor in the stage floor. He was evaluated by doctors and had no broken bones. His condition will be evaluated again today. Timothy Gulan, Mr. Lane's understudy, finished the matinee and was to perform last night. Jesse McKinley (NYT)

description: Boston Scientific Says It Has Weathered Recall Boston Scientific said that it had regained virtually all of the business it lost after a recall this summer of some of its heart stents.

description: The following is the full text of remarks made by Mel Martinez, secretary of housing and urban development.

title: Paris cedes control of telephone company
A Minimalist Chapel Opens in the Czech Republic
description: FIVE years ago, John Pawson, the minimalist British architect known for championing the least-is-more look, was hired by a group of brown-robed Cistercian monks from France to build a monastery in the Czech Republic.

title: This Time, It's Easy for Capriati
description: After being pushed to three sets in her opening-round match at the United States Open on Monday, Jennifer Capriati was looking to improve and to impress last night.

title: Nepalese Attack a Mosque and Muslims in Katmandu
description: Correction Appended

title: Businessman's Sense of Legacy Saves a Synagogue
description: In the remnant world of Lower East Side synagogues, where survivors of a rich Orthodox Jewish past are carrying on by patching their plaster or becoming cultural foundations, Congregation Chasam Sopher has hit the Lotto.

title: On the Trail of Discontinued Fabrics
description: A READER who loves her sofa and her bedroom draperies so much that she has been loyal to them for more than two decades recently wrote to me for help.

title: Wishing Rainbows On a Classic Chair
description: In celebration of the 90th birthday of the Danish designer Hans J. Wegner, his iconic Wishbone chair, first produced in 1950, has been reissued by Carl Hansen & Son in eight lacquer colors that have not been available since the late 1950's. For 45 years, the chair was offered only in natural wood finishes, like oak and cherry, but now it comes in yellow, green, blue, black, white and three shades of red.

title: A Senate Candidate Calls Gays Hedonists
description: Alan Keyes, the Republican candidate for Senate in Illinois, told a radio reporter at the Republican National Convention that gays and lesbians are "selfish hedonists," including Mary Cheney, the lesbian daughter of Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: From Decisions to Impressions, in 4 Decades
description: In all probability, this is it for me, the last of 20 national political conventions, stretching all the way back to the 1960's -that is, unless I snag a special assignment in 2008 from Geriatric Weekly.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Wage Agreement
description: Ireland's trade unions and the national employers' business lobby approved a pay deal yesterday that promises a 5.5 percent increase in wages over the next 18 months. The pact is the latest in a series of state-sponsored agreements that have helped prevent large-scale strikes in Ireland since the 1980's. A few smaller unions, representing nurses, teachers, bank officials and bartenders, voted against the deal, but the largest labor organizations supported it after winning informal government pledges to cut taxes for low-income workers in December. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RUTMAN, HERBERT A.
description: RUTMAN--Herbert A. 2/22/319/2/03. In loving memory of a beloved husband & "Daddy." Forever in our hearts. Esterly and all the "Poos'

description: In percent

title: Mets' Woes Extending to Florida
description: Manager Art Howe was asked yesterday if his team was cursed, and as he paused to ponder the absurdity of the question, he began to give the notion some credence.

title: The Camera Can Wait: Directors Hear Opera's Call
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Inflation Slows
description: Indonesia's inflation rate appears to be slowing, reducing pressure on the central bank to raise interest rates and brake economic growth as the country prepares for a presidential election runoff later this month. The official statistics bureau said that consumer prices rose 6.6 percent in August compared with a year earlier; the increase in July was 7.2 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: The Eerie Allure of Ghosts and the Electoral College

title: National Briefing | Washington: Slim Chance Of Judicial Help For U.S. Citizen Held By Saudis
description: A judge indicated that he was unlikely to order the United States to obtain the release of an American citizen detained for more than a year in Saudi Arabia. The family of the man, Ahmed Abu Ali of Falls Church, Va., contends that the Bush administration unlawfully ordered him held for interrogation about suspected terrorist plots. Judge John D. Bates of United States District Court said in a written opinion that because Mr. Abu Ali was in Saudi custody he doubted that an American court would have jurisdiction. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Jobless Figures on Friday Could Emphasize Bush's Big Weakness
description: About 10 hours after President Bush accepts his party's nomination tonight, the government will release an important report on the state of the economy. Even some of his allies say that if it is weak it could dampen Republican enthusiasm coming out of the convention and leave Mr. Bush on the defensive for a pivotal issue heading into the campaign homestretch.

Lebanon's Lost Sovereignty
description: When it comes to occupied Arab territory, Syria applies a brazen double standard and does not even have the decency to be discreet about it: In Iraq, the Golan Heights, the West Bank and Gaza, every additional day of foreign occupation is viewed as intolerable, and immediate, unimpeded sovereignty is considered imperative. For Lebanon, under the thumb of Syrian troops for the past 28 years, Damascus never uses the word occupation and never hesitates to abuse Lebanese sovereignty.

The issue of the candidacy of Mr. Sarkozy, who is viewed as openly ambitious, has been at the center of France's political life for the past three months. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Shoot Robbery Suspect
description: A suspect was shot in the knee and a pit bull was killed yesterday after the police chased four robbery suspects into a house in East New York and an officer fired several shots when he was charged by the dog, the authorities said. The man who was injured was in the line of fire and was shot accidentally, the police said. He was in stable condition last night at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. The police said that the shooting, at 4:50 p.m., took place when two officers approached the robbery suspects, who were sitting on a stoop, and the suspects ran into the house, at 746 Barbey Street. All four suspects, whose identities were not disclosed, were in custody last night, and charges against them were pending, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: G.M. and Ford to Cut Production
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 - General Motors and Ford Motor said today that they would cut car and truck production in the fourth quarter by as much as 7 percent because vehicles were piling up unsold in inventory. Each company experienced a sharp drop in sales last month, along with the auto industry as a whole, new figures released today show.

description: Tonight, at the Republican National Convention in New York, George W. Bush will step onto the podium and accept his party's nomination for president. Though conventions themselves have receded in importance, the acceptance speech has remained potent, offering the candidate -- even one who has been in the public eye for four years -- the chance to define himself. So what should the president say? The Op-Ed page asked speechwriters from six Republican administrations, including the current one, to propose a conclusion to President Bush's address -- one that sums up what they think the winning Republican campaign themes for 2004 should be.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: North Korean Refugees Rush School
description: A group of 29 people apparently from North Korea forced their way into a Japanese school in Beijing in a gambit for political asylum. The group apparently cut a hole in a fence that surrounded the school and presented themselves as political refugees. The Japanese government expressed confidence that they were from North Korea but had not yet announced how it would handle the matter. For several years, a growing number of North Koreans have used China as an escape path. In several incidents, small groups have sought asylum at embassies in Beijing. But yesterday's group -- 11 men, 15 women and 3 children -- is the largest in recent memory. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Apple Computer's new iMac home computer misstated a revenue forecast for the company from Charles Wolf, an analyst at the investment firm of Needham & Company. He predicted that Apple would generate $2.085 billion in revenue for the current quarter, not $2.85 billion. The article also misstated the entry-level price for a class of Apple computers incorporating a pair of the company's G5 microprocessor chips. It is $1,999, not $2,999.

title: Country Conquests
description: Tim McGraw's new album "Live Like You Were Dying" (Curb), below, has made its debut at No. 1 on both the Billboard pop and country charts, continuing a boom year for Nashville. The album's first-week sales of 766,000 were the most by any country act this year. Mr. McGraw, the husband of Faith Hill and the son of the late Mets pitcher Tug McGraw, has recorded seven No. 1 Billboard country albums and three No. 1 pop albums. The No. 2, 3, and 4 spots on the new pop albums chart are all by urban artists: R. Kelly's "Happy People/U Saved Me" (Jive/Zomba), Young Buck's "Straight Outta Ca$hville" (Interscope) and Mase's "Welcome Back" (Bad Boy). The latest "NOW That's What I Call Music!" compilation (Universal/EMI/Sony/Zomba) falls from No. 1 to No. 5. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Rations, Water and a Mask, In Time for Hurricane Frances
description: The Ready Kit emergency backpack -- made by Home Guard, a company in Charlotte, N.C., and available this month at Gracious Home -- contains water pouches and food rations, a biohazard waste bag, a face mask, plastic barrier sheeting, a flashlight, a utility wrench and a whistle. It has three days' worth of food and water. A taste test revealed the water to have a slightly metallic taste, while the rations (to be eaten every six hours, in small pieces) resemble greasy granola bars. The food, it is fair to say, would make the three days seem like much, much longer.

Walls That Join the Conversation
description: FOR those who are tired of wallpaper and want a more distinctive look, three-dimensional wall decorations this season offer fresh twists on materials and imagery. Some of these textured objects take their inspiration from nature. From France comes snap-together plastic seaweed, which works as art, a room divider or curtains. An artist offers slices of cork that can be massed or scattered. And a designer near San Francisco makes jazzy three-dimensional wood sculptures that move across a wall in an echo of the 1960's.

The duo's most recent CD was "Red Dirt Road," an excellent and unpredictable album. The disc ends with "Holy War," a gospel-powered tirade that draws a comparison between Muslim fundamentalists abroad and Christian fundamentalists at home.

Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Shareholder Suit Reinstated
description: A federal appeals court reinstated a shareholder suit that claims Oracle, the world's third-largest software maker, improperly booked about $228 million in sales in 2000 to conceal slowing demand. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, reinstated the suit yesterday; it had been dismissed three times by a trial court judge. The suit claims Oracle, based in Redwood City, Calif., created fake sales to hide a decline in demand related to the slowing economy and defects in a new product. A 1995 law intended to curb frivolous securities fraud claims imposes strict limits for such lawsuits to survive a company's motion to dismiss. Plaintiffs must prove strong indications of intentional misconduct or willful recklessness to make it to trial. Jennifer Glass, a spokeswoman for the company, said it was still reviewing the opinion and declined to comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACKS, DAVID G.
description: SACKS--David G. The Jewish Outreach Institute mourns the passing of its former chairman. David was instrumental in helping to solidify the Institute's role in transforming research into practice, helping to pave the way for hundreds of thousands of interfaith families and their children to find their rightful place within the bounds of the Jewish community. We extend our deepest sympathy to Marcella; to David's children; and to the entire Sacks and Rosen families. Rabbi Kerry M. Olitzky, Exec Director Terrence Elkes, President Eugene Grant, Chairman

title: Data to DVD in Six Minutes: A New Drive Steps on the Gas
description: DVD recorders, which work at a slow burn compared with their zippier CD-recorder counterparts, are picking up speed. A new drive from Sony can cook up a complete single-sided DVD in six minutes or so. The Sony DRU-710A internal DVD recorder clocks a recording speed of 16x for a DVD+R disc and can handle several other CD and DVD formats at varying speeds.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Illegal Immigrants Found On Yacht
description: Two men were charged with trying to smuggle 50 Mexicans into Los Angeles Harbor on a rented yacht, the authorities said. The boat was intercepted by the Coast Guard on Monday night near the entrance to the harbor. Among the human cargo was a 3-year-old boy and a woman in the final month of her pregnancy. The daylong cruise began in Ensenada, Mexico, and each passenger had paid $3,000, immigration authorities said. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: Want to Rent a Movie? Help Yourself
description: WHEN VCR's appeared on the market in the early 1980's, renting movies was expensive and cumbersome. It often required costly membership fees at video stores that were few and far between.

title: Class-Action Status Is Upheld for Doctors Suing Insurers
description: An appeals court upheld class-action status yesterday for a lawsuit brought on behalf of at least 600,000 doctors contending that six of the nation's largest health insurers regularly reduce payments for medical services.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Union Chief Stepping Down
description: Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America, said he would retire at the end of his term next August. Mr. Bahr, left, who has led the union since 1985, made the announcement at the union's annual convention in Anaheim. The executive board voted unanimously to recommend that Larry Cohen, the union's executive vice president, be elected to succeed Mr. Bahr. Delegates will vote on a new president at the union's convention next August. The union has 700,000 members and represents workers in the telecommunications industry and journalism, among other fields. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Schumer's Opponents Are Fighting for 2nd Place
description: New York Republicans are well aware that their little-known candidate for the United States Senate has a slim chance of defeating Charles E. Schumer, the popular Democratic incumbent. "We know it's an uphill fight," Gov. George E. Pataki said on Monday during an event in Manhattan for the candidate, Howard Mills, a state assemblyman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPLEWICZ, ROMA
description: KOPLEWICZ--Roma, 85. Beloved wife, friend and lover of Joseph for 62 years. Devoted mother to Edith, Harold and Linda. Adoring grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. Loyal and caring friend and dedicated social worker died August 31st. After surviving the horrors of the Holocaust, she was reunited with her Joe and together they lived life to its fullest. Her extraordinary "joie de vivre" will live on in her friends and family. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Friday at 10:00 AM. Donations may be made to Roma and Joseph Koplewicz fund at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl, SW, Washington, DC 20024

title: Milosevic Startled: His Rousing 2-Day Defense Wins No Applause
description: THE HAGUE, Sept. 1 - It was to have been Slobodan Milosevic's day of dignity, the day on which the former Serbian leader would, with certain drama, lay out his defense strategy in his trial on war crimes stemming from the Balkan wars of the 1990's.

title: Palestinian Prisoners in Israeli Jails End Hunger Strike
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 2 A Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails called off their 18-day hunger strike today, and while Palestinian officials tried to put a brave face on it, there was little doubt that the end of the strike without clear Israeli concessions was a significant defeat.

title: Oil Futures Prices Rise 4.5% on Outsize Drop in Supplies
description: Crude oil futures prices surged by almost $2 a barrel yesterday, the biggest increase in two months, after the Energy Department reported that United States oil supplies had declined more than expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERLINGER, RHONIE HOFHEIMER
description: BERLINGER--Rhonie Hofheimer, peacefully at home on August 31, 2004 after 89 vigorous years. Loving and beloved wife of the late George F. Berlinger. Devoted mother of Nancy Klee Stone and Mary Ellen Klee. Admiring mother-in-law of Bob Stone. Dear sister of Marion H. Levy and the late Lt. Lester Hofheimer. Proud "Noni" of Peter and Betsy, Robert and Douglas Kempner; Jim and Janet, Ellen and Julia Kempner; Carrie and Matthew, Brian and Daniel Getz. Rhonie actively served as a VicePresident of the National Alzheimer's Association since her husband's death in 1986. Funeral private. A memorial service and celebration of her life will be held Sunday, September 12 at 4pm at the Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, NY, 914946-1660. In lieu of flowers the family would greatly appreciate contributions in Rhonie's memory to Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL, 60601; Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY, 10601 or a charity of your choice.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - Army criminal investigators will recommend that about two dozen soldiers face criminal charges or administrative punishment in connection with the deaths of two prisoners at an American detention center in Afghanistan in December 2002, Army officials said Wednesday.

title: Rewards Of Art
description: Marie-Louise Dietrich, a 19-year-old student from the Black Forest town of Willstaett, Germany, got more than she bargained for when she and her mother braved the long line outside the New National Gallery in Berlin to see the 212 masterworks on loan from the Museum of Modern Art. First she was greeted by Mayor Klaus Wowereit and then, as the millionth visitor to the most popular exhibition in Berlin since the end of World War II, she was presented with plane tickets to New York and an invitation to the grand reopening of the renovated museum. Visitors have been waiting for as long as six hours to see the show, which has extended its hours till as late as 2 a.m. in the days leading to its closing on Sept. 19. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspected Suicide In Park
description: An unidentified man was found dead on a bridle path in Central Park around lunchtime yesterday, and detectives believe he shot himself, a police official said. The man, who had been shot in the head and had a pistol in his hand, was found on the reservoir path near the South Pumphouse, at 86th Street. The victim, who appeared to be in his 20's, was not carrying identification. The death was under investigation and an autopsy was scheduled for today. William K.Rashbaum(NYT)

title: Facing Fine, City Frees Hundreds of Detainees
description: A state judge in Manhattan yesterday angrily ordered the city to release more than 550 protesters who had been detained without seeing a judge -- some for as long as 60 hours -- after they were arrested at demonstrations against the Republican National Convention. When not all the protesters had been released by 6 p.m., he held the city in contempt and ordered a fine of $1,000 for each person still held, without setting a time frame.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Exports Surge
description: Malaysia's exports rose unexpectedly in July, helped by increased sales of computer chips and other electrical and electronics goods in Asia, Europe and the United States. Exports rose 29 percent from a year earlier, to 42.63 billion ringgit ($11 billion), the fastest rate in seven months, the trade ministry said. The rate was up from 23 percent in June. Imports rose 25.8 percent in July from a year ago, to 35.03 billion ringgit, giving Malaysia a trade surplus of 7.6 billion ringgit, up 47 percent from the period a year ago.

Spano, citing the potential for a catastrophic terrorist attack on the Kensico Dam, said on Thursday that the road that runs over the dam would be permanently closed to vehicles, though pedestrians would continue to have access.

title: Faced With Poor Ratings, Networks Soul Search
description: On his last night in the anchor chair at a political convention, Tom Brokaw of NBC was feeling resigned. The conventions, he said in an interview yesterday, were mere "infomercials," with little to interest anyone beyond political partisans.

title: Intel Lowers Its Forecasts; Shares Plunge After Hours
description: The chip giant Intel sharply lowered its revenue and profit margin projections for the third quarter late yesterday, citing unexpectedly weak demand. Investors sent its shares tumbling in after-hours trading.

title: She's No Longer Just the Williamses' Friend
description: Interviews with reporters and conversations with fans have always ended the same way for Angela Haynes. That is the burden of being from Compton, Calif., home of Venus and Serena Williams.

title: The M Line and the Hemline: Miniskirt Protocols
description: While standing, smooth down as much fabric as possible with both hands. Then cross the knees, bend and sit. Optional precaution: place purse over lap.

title: As Florida Braces For 2nd Big Storm, The Flight Begins
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 2 - As a formidable hurricane lurched closer, tens of thousands of Florida residents fled their coastal homes on Thursday and clogged highways and airports, taking no chances as predictions about the storm's path remained sketchy and forecasters warned of potentially widespread flooding and destruction.

title: Europa : Looking more closely at the message of Sochi
End of Kobe Bryant Case Brings Out Strong Sentiments
description: EAGLE, Colo., Sept. 2 - The sheriff was back in blue jeans on Thursday, attired for a midday bike ride, as good an indication as any that things here may be resuming their regular rhythm.

title: Day at the Met, Pepper Mill at the Ready
description: "That's what I want for dinner" might seem like the comment of a philistine when spoken in front of a genuine oil painting in a very serious museum. It did, in fact, evoke a gasp from an eavesdropping bystander when I uttered it to a friend recently as we contemplated "Still Life With Lobster and Fruit" by the 17th-century Dutch artist Abraham van Beyeren in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As much as I appreciated the painter's drawing skills and his triumphs of color, form and composition, my first thought was of the fresh sea flavor of the pearly meat within the fiery red shell, and how well it would be complemented by a sparkling macdoine of those grapes, melon and peaches.

title: Lieber Shines, Distancing Yankees From 'a Dark Time'
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre said before last night's game that he still had faith in his starting rotation. He is the president of a fan club that could fit in a Volkswagen bus.

title: Henry James Slept Here
description: WHEREAS Arrowhead and the Little Red House are modest, the Mount, Edith Wharton's 42-room estate in Lenox, is one of the most celebrated homes in the Berkshires. The novelist adored these hills. "The truth is," she wrote, "that I am in love with the place, climate, scenery, life & all."

title: An African Foul-Up, With an Intriguing Cast of Britons
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 2 - They say the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton. Alas, the same appears not to be true of coups in Equatorial Guinea.

title: Namath's Latest Guarantee Comes With Strings Attached
description: Joe Namath, who guaranteed the Jets' Super Bowl victory over the Baltimore Colts in 1969, is now guaranteeing that the Jets will play in a Super Bowl in their proposed $1.4 billion, retractable roof stadium on the far West Side of Manhattan.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Warriors of the Right Take to the Streets
description: The Protest Warriors were looking for a protest to protest. Things were slow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASOWITZ, FELICE
description: KASOWITZ--Felice. September 1, 2004, of 681 Heather Lane, West Haven, CT. Devoted wife of Robert Kasowitz. Beloved mother of Stephen Kasowitz of New Haven, Mark Kasowitz of NYC and Susan Oakey Kasowitz of Milford, CT. Also survived by five cherished grandchildren. Funeral services at Congregation B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Road, Woodbridge, CT Monday morning at 10:30 o'clock with interment services to follow in the B'nai Jacob Memorial Park, Wintergreen Ave, New Haven. Memorial contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, G.I. Oncology Fund, P.O. Box 27106, NY NY 10087 or to CT Hospice, 100 Double Beach Rd, Branford CT 06405 or the Congregation B'nai Jacob. A period of mourning will be observed at 681 Heather Lane, West Haven, CT through Wednesday. Robert E. Shure Funeral Home 203-562-8244 KASOWITZ--Felice. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of Felice Kasowitz, mother of Marc and mother-in-law of our Board member, Lori. The Y community has been particularly blessed by the involvement of the Kasowitz family. Felice, an ardent patron of the entire Y, also focused her energy on supporting the Y's Makor/Steinhardt Center, cochairing one of the center's main fundraising events. Felice's spirit and values will be kept alive at the Y for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marc, Lori, their daughter Samantha and the entire Kasowitz family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Michael Goldstein, President Matthew Bronfman, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

title: Cabaret Guide
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Ban on Head Scarves Takes Effect in France
description: PARIS, Sept. 2 - A law banning Islamic head scarves and other religious symbols from French public schools took effect peacefully on Thursday, transforming the first day of school into a nationwide show of defiance of a demand by the kidnappers of two French journalists in Iraq that the law be rescinded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, DAVID
description: KAUFMAN -- David. Died peacefully on his boat in Florida, on September 2, 2004. Beloved husband of Michele and the late Lesley. Devoted father of Jody Bartman, Larry Kaufman and Wendy Talerman, and father-in-law of Michael Bartman, Stacey Kaufman and Steven Talerman. Dear son-in-law of Renee Plumer and Gloria Bussanich. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Sam, Danni, Scott, Kate and Nicole. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about riots in Nepal in response to the execution of 12 Nepalese workers by Iraqi militants misstated the ownership of businesses that were ransacked. They were both Muslim- and Hindu-owned, not just Muslim.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Iraqi Girl's Surgery
description: Surgeons in Cincinnati have sealed a hole in the heart of a 7-year-old Iraqi girl, whose father showed up unexpectedly with the child at a United States Army base outside of Baghdad last month pleading for medical care. The girl, Fatma Saad Abdulaziz, left Children's Hospital Medical Center on Wednesday and will remain in Cincinnati for at least a month while she undergoes treatment for a lingering heart infection. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Pennington to Tune Up for First Opening Start
description: He's almost there.

title: With Conventions Over, Campaign Shifts to Economy
description: President Bush rode a wave of post-convention, partisan euphoria into Pennsylvania and the Midwest today, pledging to use time-honored Republican principles to create new jobs for a fast-changing world.

title: CALPINE EXPECTS TO MAKE $200 MILLION IN SALE OF RESERVES
description: The Calpine Corporation, a power producer, said it expected pretax gains totaling more than $200 million from the sale of natural gas reserves in the Rocky Mountains and Canada. Two United States gas companies bought the Rocky Mountain assets for about $223 million, Calpine said. The sales were announced Aug. 20, but the buyers were not disclosed. Calpine, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said it expected the sale of those assets to yield a pretax gain of about $100 million. Separately, Calpine said it completed an agreement announced two weeks ago to sell its Canadian gas reserves and petroleum assets to PrimeWest Energy Trust for 825 million Canadian dollars ($632 million). That sale will give it a pretax gain of more than $100 million, Calpine said.

title: War Strategy Played Out as Recreation
description: Why do people like puzzles? Because they can solve them. Puzzles provide comic relief from "the angst earned by the unanswerable larger questions," Marcel Danesi writes in "The Puzzle Instinct" (Indiana University Press, 2002). "Since there are no definitive answers to the large-scale questions, we are strangely reassured by the answers built into the small-scale ones."

title: For the Fading Mets, Home Is Where the Losses Are
description: Finally, mercifully, they are gone.

title: Malaysian High Court Voids Convictions of Ex-Deputy Premier
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 2 - The high court in Malaysia overturned the sodomy conviction of former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim on Thursday and allowed him to go free after serving six years in prison.

title: Spare Times
description: ON THE STREET

title: New Ads Focus on Economy
description: With their conventions behind them, Senator John Kerry and President Bush will turn to the paid airwaves to get their messages across, each beginning a barrage of commercials next week that hit strikingly similar themes about the economy and jobs.

title: Radio Ad Revenue Fell Slightly in July
description: After five months of growth, radio advertising revenue dipped slightly in July, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York said yesterday.

title: Fast, Frisky and Caffeinated, Fox News Looked Right at Home All Week
description: Correction Appended

title: In New London, Conn.
description: SHIPS have been sailing into New London's deep harbor since 1646 -- schooners and packet ships, an English armada led by Benedict Arnold, nuclear submarines that glide silently up the Thames River, cresting the water like the backs of whales. The town helped shape Eugene O'Neill, who set two of his greatest plays at his family's New London cottage, and as tall ships visit and ferries disgorge cars and passengers from Long Island and Block Island, its salty flavor still feels real. New London's struggles are real, too, evidenced by some empty storefronts. But with huge pots of flowers bedecking lampposts and luxury apartments renting in once-neglected buildings, a new liveliness blends with breathtaking harbor vistas, glimpses of history and the enduring draw of the sea. MAURA J. CASEY

title: In Melville's Footsteps
description: ON Aug. 5, 1850, the novelist Herman Melville, the editor Evert Duyckinck and the writer Oliver Wendell Holmes took the morning train from Pittsfield to Stockbridge in western Massachusetts. The group joined several others, including their host, David Dudley Field Jr., and the 46-year-old author Nathaniel Hawthorne. Hawthorne had recently moved to Lenox after losing his job in the port of Salem. Melville, 32, was at work on a whaling adventure; his manuscript was already late at his London publisher.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Local Elections Postponed
description: The authorities said regional elections for mayors and governors would be postponed a month and be held on Oct. 31, giving the National Electoral Council more time to organize after the Aug. 15 vote to recall President Hugo Chvez. The postponement benefits the fractured opposition, which now has more time to prepare for elections that could consolidate Mr. Chvez's hold on power. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: A Calmed-Down S2000
description: Unlike the Mazdaspeed Miata, the upgrades made to the latest version of the Honda S2000 are not necessarily apparent from a quick glance at the specifications. For example, the engine is slightly larger, but the horsepower rating is unchanged. However, the revisions do make the car noticeably easier to drive.

title: Clinton Hospitalized With Chest Pains and Will Face Surgery
description: Former President Bill Clinton today checked himself into New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan where he will undergo heart bypass surgery in the next few days after complaining of shortness of breath and chest pains, his office said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Computer Study Of Recall Vote
description: Two leading American computer science researchers, after studying results of the Aug. 15 recall referendum that President Hugo Chvez won handily, did not detect any statistical irregularities that would indicate fraud, as antigovernment groups contend. The researchers, Edward Felten of Princeton University and Aviel D. Rubin of Johns Hopkins, using election results provided by Smate, a group that helped lead the recall, did note that tampering with electronic machines would not create the statistical anomalies they were searching for. But they said the fraud alleged was not the type they would expect a cheating government to employ. The Organization of American States and the Atlanta-based Carter Center, monitors of the election, have emphatically said that their audits showed no discrepancies or machine manipulation. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: A Toughened-Up Miata
description: When it arrived 15 years ago, the Miata's clean looks, turn-on-a-dime handling and reasonable sticker price reminded enthusiasts - in the best ways - of classic British roadsters. It is certainly due for an update, but in the meantime the company is selling the leaner, meaner Mazdaspeed MX-5 Miata for little more than the cosmetically enhanced "special edition" Miatas that have been rolled out repeatedly in recent years.

title: Mr. Bush's Acceptance Speech
description: When President Bush accepted his party's nomination last night, he energetically presented himself as the man who could keep America safe in a time of international terrorism. His handlers believe that is the key to his re-election. But if Mr. Bush intends to have a second term, he needs to do something more -- particularly if he hopes to win by more than 500 votes this time. The president needs to speak to the large number of moderate voters who feel that things have been going in the wrong direction over the last four years, and convince them that he has the capacity to learn from mistakes and do better. On that count, his acceptance speech fell short.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: U.N. Court Imposes Lawyers On Milosevic
description: Judges trying Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, on war crimes charges imposed on him two defense lawyers, both Britons. Mr. Milosevic said he would appeal. He began his defense in the 30-month-long trial this week and is expected to call his first witnesses on Tuesday. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: When the People Are Dead, It's O.K. to Stare
description: Few television shows are built around images. A pilot episode is sold on its script, after all -- just words. Television comedies typically start with a concept, while dramas start with setting and characters. And logistics so dictate the way a television show is shot that any single tableau a creator has in his mind's eye generally gets ditched somewhere along the way in the name of economy.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: From a Rusty Motorcycle, a Tribute to a 9/11 Hero
description: Years after the World Trade Center attacks, New York City firefighters have seen the nation's adulation wash over them and then subside. "F.D.N.Y. Dream Bike" is a high-minded documentary saluting one of the brave brethren, but it unwittingly opens a window into the confusing effects of grief and fame.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Phone Rating Raised
description: The ratings agency Moody's Investors Service raised its outlook on the creditworthiness of the Philippine cellular network operator Globe Telecom. Moody's said its outlook on Globe's domestic debt rating was changed to positive, citing its healthy finances and the rapid growth of the country's cellular industry. But Moody's left unchanged its negative outlook on Globe's foreign debt ratings, saying political uncertainty and a weak Philippine peso posed inherent risks. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: An unwelcome guest : Will Europe sit down with Myanmar?
Judge Reverses Convictions in Detroit 'Terrorism' Case
description: DETROIT, Sept. 2 - A federal judge threw out the terrorism convictions of two Arab immigrants on Thursday, undoing what the Justice Department once proclaimed was its first major courtroom victory in the war on terror.

title: Mysteries of San Andreas Fault Are Explored by a Drill
description: PARKFIELD, Calif., Sept. 2 - There is nothing more nerve-racking for many Californians than the unpredictable and irritable San Andreas fault, which leveled much of San Francisco the last time it kicked up a big earthquake in 1906.

title: WORTHINGTON TO BUY ASSETS FROM WESTERN INDUSTRIES
description: Worthington Industries, which shapes steel for automakers, said it agreed to buy the propane and specialty-gas cylinder assets of Western Industries for $64.5 million to bolster its cylinder-making unit. Western's cylinder operations had 2003 sales of about $50 million. The unit makes disposable one-pound cylinders for camping stoves, portable heaters and other items. Worthington, based in Columbus, Ohio, is the market leader in the United States for cylinders that hold propane gas for consumer products such as barbecue grills and camping stoves, though none in the one-pound range. Worthington's business had sales of $328.7 million last year. Western Industries is based in Milwaukee.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT IS INVESTIGATING CAREER EDUCATION
description: The Career Education Corporation, which operates the Katharine Gibbs secretarial schools and for-profit colleges, said that the Justice Department was investigating the company. The company, which is based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., said it was not informed of the focus of the investigation. Career Education said in June that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the company amid allegations of overstated enrollment and manipulated financial statements. Sean Murphy, a company spokesman, declined to comment on the investigation. An assistant United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois, Nancy K. Needles, also declined to comment.

title: The Bryant Trial: Anatomy of a Case That Fell Apart
description: Correction Appended

title: July Factory Orders Exceeded Forecasts; Productivity Pace Slows
description: July factory orders rose the most in four months, exceeding forecasts, and productivity gains slowed last quarter, two government reports released yesterday showed.

title: Song downloads from British Web sites stand to be counted : New top-20 list for digital world
Lawyer Says Court Aides Steered Cases for Him
description: A divorce lawyer who testified this week that he had committed crimes with former State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Garson said yesterday that getting his cases before the judge was not a simple process of ask and receive.

title: Snowmobiles and Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: The Show Is Over. Now for the Awards.
description: The Walter Mondale Where's-the-Beef Award: George W. Bush, who told the conventioneers, "Anyone who wants more details on my agenda can find them online." Ever the wonks, we followed the directions to georgewbush.com, seeking the details of the crowd-pleasing promise in his speech to "lead a bipartisan effort to reform and simplify the federal tax code." Here's all we found: "President Bush will work with Congress to make the tax code simpler for taxpayers, encourage saving and investment, and improve the economy's ability to create jobs and raise wages."

title: It's High Noon in the Chinese Desert (Swords Poised)
description: Horsemanship and a weary swagger are apparently all that are required to tame wild forces on a western frontier, no matter the hemisphere. In the wild, wild west of China, as in the American one, bandits and bullies spill blood needlessly while a sad outcast imposes some peace, making "Warriors of Heaven and Earth" the latest Chinese answer to the American western film genre: martial arts meets Marshal Will Kane.

title: Republicans Try to Expand Appeal to Religious Voters
description: Correction Appended

title: 1954:Appeasement Worries : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Haas on Road to Recovery with Surprise Victory at the Open
description: While the women's matches held to form thisafternoon at the United States Open, it was the men's turn to provide the drama. Tommy Haas played the comeback kid and Juan Carlos Ferrero the upset victim.

title: Denino's
description: Allow me to posit something perverse: it is too easy to find the food of your choice in this city. Mexican? Two blocks away. Sushi? Half a block in the other direction. Don't want to leave home? Leaf through the towering stack of delivery menus in the cupboard. Almost anything is within reach. Almost nothing requires real effort.

title: Arab blues at Oxford : The Middle East's lost resources
For Some, Bargain Dining Transcends Political Ideology
description: The Republicans and the protesters who have dogged their steps this week may not agree on Iraq or the economy, but they both like to eat well -- and at a discount.

title: Six Agencies Chosen For Army Review
description: The United States Army has chosen six agencies to take part in a required review for its account, including its lead agency since 2000, Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe. Billings were estimated at $200 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Some folks look at me and see a certain swagger, which in Texas is called 'walking.' Now and then I come across as a little too blunt -- and for that we can all thank the white-haired lady sitting right up there."
