title: A One-Man Show in 6 Flavors Treats Confession as Humor
description: Judging by the tedious "Albino Pigeon," no incentive exists for seeking out the Zipper Theater at 336 West 37th Street to endure the five other one-man performances that John Lehr is presenting on Monday nights through Nov. 8 under the collective title "The Lehr Curse: A Series of Comedic Lectures."

title: Excerpts From Pataki: It's a Matter of Trust
description: Following are excerpts from the speech by Gov. George E. Pataki last night at the Republican National Convention, as transcribed by The New York Times. The full transcription and video are at nytimes.com/campaign.

title: Bush and the Bard : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Filipinos Still Seek Work in Iraq Despite Danger and Ban
description: MANILA, Sept. 2 - Despite a presidential order banning Filipino workers from going to Iraq, hundreds of people still line up every day at employment agencies here, hoping for a chance to get a job in that strife-torn country.

title: McGreevey Seems Set To Exit On His Terms
description: TRENTON, Sept. 2 - After revealing on national television that he is gay, seeing his name become the punch line of countless late-night comedy gags, and fending off a coup attempt from within his own party, Gov. James E. McGreevey needs only to remain in office until midnight Friday to outlast the state deadline that would automatically force a special election to choose his successor.

title: MEANWHILE : First-class hopes for third-world players
Metro Briefings
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANDELMAN, WALTER
description: HANDELMAN--Walter. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Sr., Rabbi Sidney Freedman, President

title: Halliburton Says Joint Venture Considered Paying Bribes
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that officers from a Nigerian joint venture considered paying bribes to win contracts.

title: Pro-Israel Lobby Said to Have Been Inquiry Target
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - The inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into whether a Pentagon analyst passed classified information to Israel grew out of a longstanding covert national security inquiry into the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, people who have been officially briefed on the matter said Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Despite Its Optimism, Bank In Europe Lets Rate Stand The European Central Bank is sounding markedly more confident these days than it did earlier this year about the economic recovery in the 12 countries that use the euro. But it is not ready to back up its words with action.

title: I.B.M. Offers $10,000 to Owners of Contaminated Houses
description: The I.B.M. Corporation announced yesterday that it was willing to pay $10,000 each to the owners of nearly 500 contaminated homes in the upstate village of Endicott if the owners give up their right to sue for property damages caused by industrial pollution.

title: Americans Fail to Match Russians' Level of Desire
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 2 - For the second time in two games, the veteran United States team was outscored, outshot, outskated and outplayed in the World Cup of Hockey tournament.

title: On the Jagged Edge of Maine
description: MAPS are like the friend you had in sixth grade who announced that he was going to ride chunks of ice down the river through the local golf course and that you were welcome to come along. Or the pal in college who said she knew you could sleep in random haylofts in the Swiss Alps without annoying either the cattle or the farmers. For the susceptible traveler, in other words, maps are flirts with engaging smiles who can reliably sniff out a good time but don't really know what they are talking about.

title: South Koreans Say Secret Work Refined Uranium
description: The South Korean government has admitted to the International Atomic Energy Agency that a group of the country's scientists secretly produced a small amount of near-weapons grade uranium, raising suspicions that South Korea may have attempted a secret program to counter North Korea's nuclear arsenal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPLEWICZ, ROMA
description: KOPLEWICZ--Roma, 85. Beloved wife, friend and lover of Joseph for 62 years. Devoted mother to Edith, Harold and Linda. Adoring grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. Loyal and caring friend and dedicated social worker died August 31st. After surviving the horrors of the Holocaust, she was reunited with her Joe and together they lived life to its fullest. Her extraordinary "joie de vivre" will live on in her friends and family. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Friday at 10:00 AM. Donations may be made to Roma and Joseph Koplewicz fund at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl, SW, Washington, DC 20024 KOPLEWICZ -- Roma. The board and faculty of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the loss of Roma Koplewicz, devoted wife, partner and friend of Joseph (Joe) Koplewicz, beloved mother of Edith, Linda and Harold S. Koplewicz, Director, loving grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. After surviving the Holocaust, Roma enjoyed a long and joyous marriage to Joe and together they created a family that she cared for dearly. Roma was passionate about her work as a social worker and was a loving and steadfast friend to many. Our thoughts and prayers are with Dr. Koplewicz and his family. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair, Board of Directors NYU Child Study Center

title: From Decisions to Impressions, in 4 Decades
description: In all probability, this is it for me, the last of 20 national political conventions, stretching all the way back to the 1960's -- that is, unless I snag a special assignment in 2008 from Geriatric Weekly.

title: Any Right-Wing Artists?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACKS, DAVID
description: SACKS--David. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York mourns the passing of David Sacks, husband of Marcella Rosen, esteemed member of JCRC's Board of Directors. May the Sacks and Rosen families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Matthew J. Maryles, Pres. Michael S. Miller, Executive Vice Pres. & CEO SACKS--David G. The Board of Governors of the East Hampton Tennis Club and its membership mourn the passing of David Sacks, beloved husband of our member Marcella Rosen. We extend our deepest sympathy to Marcella, and the entire Sacks and Rosen families. Marshall J. Gluck, President SACKS--David. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member, David Sacks. We mourn the loss of our member and a significant leader of the Jewish community. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred Youngwood, President

title: ARTS GUIDE
China's power struggle : Rivalry in Beijing makes the neighbors nervous
Top French party post will hold pitfalls for action-focused Sarkozy
Revisiting the Korean War in a Tale of Two Brothers
description: The Korean filmmaker Kang Je-gyu is the Steven Spielberg of East Asia, and not just because his movies routinely become blockbusters. Both his 1996 first feature, "The Gingko Bed," and his 1999 "Shiri" broke box-office records in South Korea by building compelling genre stories around questions of national identity, a formula that has long been a winner for Mr. Spielberg.

title: Ask ROGER COLLIS : Skimping on air, saving on fuel
Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDNER, ANNA LOUISE CAMPBELL
description: RUDNER -- Anna Louise Campbell, formerly of Shrewsbury and Lincroft, NJ, died peacefully on August 29, 2004 at age 81. Beloved daughter of the late Bruce Wallace Campbell and Margaret Rue Campbell, sister of the late Bruce Wallace Campbell, Jr and the late Robert R. Campbell, wife of the late James Spann Jeffers and exwife of Oscar Charles Rudner, mother of Stephen Campbell Rudner of Darien, CT, mother-in-law of Bridget Shea Rudner, and grandmother of Susanna Kennedy Rudner and Quinn Throckmorton Rudner. We will miss her love, friendship and leadership in the community. Service was held on September 1, 2004 at the Presbyterian Church at Shrewsbury. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Monmouth County Historial Association, 70 Court Street, Freehold, New Jersey 07728.

title: Helen Lane, a Translator of Literature, Dies at 83
description: Helen Lane, a versatile translator whose projects included works by many important Latin-American authors, died on Sunday in Albuquerque, where she had lived since returning from France 11 years ago. She was 83.

title: Russian Town's Young Treasures Under Threat
description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 2 - There are no children home at 13 Oktyabrskaya Street, except for the littlest ones, too young to go to school. All the others are hostages, held by militants in the school across the street.

title: U.S. Economy Added 144,000 Jobs in August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  The pace of job creation picked up modestly in August and the unemployment rate edged down, the Labor Department said today in a report that provided relief to President Bush and many investors who had feared worse.

title: Exploring Male Panic, Part 2, This Time When Nearing 50
description: If the frantic pace and hysterical tone of Gabriele Muccino's film "Remember Me, My Love" are any indication, middle-class urbanites in contemporary Italy are even more crass, old-age-phobic and obsessed with body-image than their counterparts in the United States. The movie casts a jaundiced eye on the pressures that threaten to destroy the Ristuccias, a family of four whose members are goaded by an inner restlessness fueled by the cheesy, sensation-oriented pop culture surrounding them.

title: It's Safe to Return, Girlie Men
description: SOUND the all-clear, you who ran away to escape the invasion. It's safe to come home now. The Republicans are done partying, the city still stands, and many New Yorkers can get back to muttering about the players at Madison Square Garden who really frost them: the Knicks and the Rangers.

title: Outlook for Mourning Remains Uncertain
description: Alonzo Mourning wants to play again, but the decision to return is not as simple as it sounds. Mourning had a kidney transplant on Dec. 19, 2003, and still faces a constant threat of rejection. The disease that caused his kidney disorder (focal glomerulosclerosis) has a 30 percent chance of recurring.

title: Fresh Acts, Fresh Air
description: Fresh Acts, Fresh Air

title: Fighting Words, at the Convention and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Rose 38% In July
description: Global sales of semiconductors rose 38 percent to $18 billion in July from a year earlier, helped by demand for chips used in personal computers, cars and consumer electronics, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday. From June, chip sales climbed 1 percent, the group said. The industry remains on track for year-on-year growth of about 28 percent and record sales of $214 billion, the group said. In June, month-on-month sales rose 2.8 percent. The association said the slower growth rate in July from the previous month was "not unexpected."

title: Despite Loss, the Giants' Line Shows Progress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 2 - Kurt Warner's first preseason as the Giants' quarterback ended ominously as he was sacked twice more Thursday night, when the team faced the Baltimore Ravens in its last exhibition game before opening against the Eagles.

title: In Speech, Old Phrase, New Idea
description: When President Bush made the notion of an "ownership society" the signature phrase of his convention address last night, he was reviving a term he has used before for different purposes.

title: Jailed Palestinians End Fast Meant to Win Concessions
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 2 - After 18 days, Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails called off their hunger strike on Thursday, and while Palestinian officials tried to put on a brave face, there was little doubt that they had suffered a significant defeat.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: LeCroy To Acquire Computer Access
description: The LeCroy Corporation, a maker of equipment that analyzes disk drives, said yesterday that it would buy the Computer Access Technology Corporation for about $85 million in cash and stock options to strengthen its position in the data storage market. Computer Access stockholders will receive $6 in cash for each share, or about $81 million, a 58 percent premium over Computer Access's closing price on Wednesday. Both companies make equipment that tests the electronic signal in computers, and their products and markets do not overlap, LeCroy's chief executive, Thomas H. Reslewic, said. LeCroy's products analyze electronic signals in hardware, while Computer Access's products test software. LeCroy sells two-thirds of its products in Europe and Asia, while Computer Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., mostly sells in the United States. Computer Access shares rose $2, to $5.80.

title: Militia Leaders Charging Betrayal by Iraqi Premier
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 2 - Leaders of the insurgent Mahdi Army declared Thursday that they had been betrayed by Prime Minister Ayad Allawi, who has been trying to lure away the militia's supporters with millions of dollars in aid.

title: Study Finds Bird-Flu Virus Can Spread Among Cats
description: The avian influenza virus that has spread widely among poultry and other birds in Southeast Asia and infected some people there has also crossed another species barrier to infect cats, and can be spread among them as well, Dutch scientists have found.

title: Senator Who Crossed Party Line Becomes One of Convention's Most Polarizing Figures
description: If convention keynote addresses are meant to set the political pot to boil, Senator Zell Miller's fiery old-time denunciation of his fellow Democratic senator John Kerry certainly accomplished that goal.

title: Adventurer | Hiking Mount Whitney
description: IT will never be described as off the beaten track, but that does not stop about 16,000 people each year from finding their personal Everest in Mount Whitney. Though it is just three hours from Los Angeles, it is the highest mountain in the contiguous United States, and these hikers set out for the summit on a tough, 22-mile round-trip trail that was constructed 100 years ago this summer.

title: Some Dire Talk From Yukos Lifts Oil Prices
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 - World oil prices rose on Thursday after Russia's largest oil producer, Yukos, said a court ruling "paralyzes" the company's operations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the World Business Briefing column on Tuesday with a report about the possible bankruptcy of the Australian mining company Sons of Gwalia was positioned incorrectly. It showed Thomas Fischer, chief executive of the German Bank West LB, who was identified in a separate report about talks by the bank to sell a stake in a provider of tourism services. (It did not show Neil Hamilton, chairman of Gwalia.)

title: Saturday's Top Games
description: !No. 13 California at Air ForceNoon, ESPN2 (Regional)California goes into Colorado Springs with its highest ranking in 50years and with one of the best offensive combinations in the nation inquarterback Aaron Rodgers and receiver Geoff McArthur. Air Forceis replacing quarterback Chance Harridge with Shaun Carney, thefirst freshman since 1986 to start under center there. The last timethese teams played, Air Force handed the Bears, then ranked 23rd,a 23-21 loss in Berkeley in 2002.

title: From an Island of a Stage, Bush States Case for Serving Another Term
description: Such a lonely little island it seemed for most of the evening, that vacant preserve in the tumultuous sea of delegates.

title: In the Bush Years, Government Grows as the Private Sector Struggles
description: BIG government is back. And while that fact may not have been heralded at Madison Square Garden this week, it is largely responsible for the best long-term economic statistic that Republicans cited.

title: Bush Is 'Unfit' to Lead U.S., Kerry Charges
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Friday, Sept. 3 - Roaring back at his Republican rivals, Senator John Kerry called President Bush "unfit to lead this country" for "misleading" America into war in Iraq and said Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney avoided fighting in the Vietnam War.

title: With Spare Passes in Hand, Hecklers Found It Surprisingly Easy to Crash the Party
description: With tens of thousands of heavily armed police officers swarming around Madison Square Garden, helicopters whirling overhead and bomb-sniffing dogs on every corner, the Republican National Convention was supposed to be the most tightly secured political event in history.

title: For Health Survey, Many Offer More Excuses Than Details
description: New York City's ambitious effort to give physical exams and blood tests to more than 2,000 people has run into unexpected trouble getting residents to participate, especially in affluent areas.

title: European Influences on Americans' Views
description: PORTLAND, Me. - In the 19th and early 20th centuries American painters and sculptors were busily discovering themselves -- and America -- through Europe and its artists. Marsden Hartley was influenced by Czanne, Picasso, Cubism and time spent in Germany; Theodore Robinson was in tune with Renoir. Thomas Eakins built a solid technique from the teachings of Jean-Lon Grme in Paris, and Alexander Calder found a model in the work of Mir.

title: U.S. Sues Sears, Accusing It of Racial Bias
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has sued Sears, Roebuck, contending that it illegally fired an automotive repair store manager because he was black.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: New Numbers For Sea Turtles Netted
description: Federal scientists have sharply raised an estimate of how many loggerhead sea turtles, a threatened species, are being tangled, injured or killed in scallop dredges off the coast between North Carolina and New Jersey. In February, the National Marine Fisheries Service estimated that 110 turtles were caught in a six-month stretch last year. The new estimate is more than 600. Andrew Revkin (NYT)

title: Star, Bush Fan, Governor: A Three-Arnold Circus
description: In the waning pink-eyed moments of the Republicans' grand political carnival, there were so many celebrations. And so little time.

title: Twilight Soul's Last Gleaming, With a Little Help From Friends
description: You've probably seen the man who called himself Rockets Redglare. He was the desk clerk at the seedy hotel Tom Hanks checked into in "Big," an unlucky liquor store clerk in Jim Jarmusch's "Mystery Train," the sushi-averse taxi driver in "Desperately Seeking Susan" and himself in "Basquiat." He did stand-up comedy downtown. ("Why is nobody named Hitler anymore?") He was the Sex Pistols' bodyguard for a while and Sid Vicious's drug dealer. Beyond that, he never amounted to much; only a good friend would make a movie about him. That friend is Luis Fernandez de la Reguera, this aimless, sometimes amiable documentary's first-time director.

title: Serious Films for Popcorn Season
description: Remember when the good old summertime was the movies' silly season? While serious films went on vacation, armadas of flying saucers spewing popcorn took over the skies. But then the competitive spirit started leaking into the sultry atmosphere. Counterprogramming became an entertainment buzzword.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-Oil Chief Extradited
description: American authorities extradited Rogelio Montemayor, the former director of the state-owned oil company, Pemex, and turned him over to officials in Mexico City to face charges of illegally funneling $200 million from the company to support the Institutional Revolutionary Party's 2000 presidential campaign. The party's candidate was defeated by Vicente Fox, who has made the investigation into Pemex funds the center of his campaign against corruption. Mr. Montemayor was arrested in Houston in October 2002. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, SIDNEY J.
description: BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. The American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel deeply mourns the passing of our Founding Board Member, Treasurer Emeritus, generous benefactor and spirited leader. Patron and Founder of the Sidney and Anita Bernstein Library on the campus in Ramat Gan, Israel, he was part of the creation of the Bennett and Pauline Rose Archives housing historical garments and textiles. Since the founding of the American Committee in 1971, Sidney J. Bernstein was committed to the upbuilding of the College adding to its importance in the educational picture of the State of Israel. Beloved by so many, he will be sorely missed by all who had the opportunity to know him. Heartfelt condolences to his daughters Anne L. Bernstein, our devoted Board Member, Elaine S. Bernstein, son Paul Bernstein (Barbara) and to their families. Bruce Pernick, President Charlotte Fainblatt, Exec. Dir. BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Sidney J. Bernstein, a treasured supporter of the New York Jewish community. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved children, Anne, Elaine, and Paul; to his nephew Asher; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. BERNSTEIN--Sidney J. We note with sorrow the death of Sidney J. Bernstein, our cousin, our friend, our mentor. A fine human being who brightened the lives of so many, he will live on in our warm memories. Sandra P. Rose Daniel and Joanna S. Rose Elihu and Susan W. Rose and their Families

title: REPUBLICANS IN NEW YORK / Wrapping things up : Republicans, in a festive mood, celebrate early
French Reporters Moved; 3 Turks Killed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 2 - Two French journalists kidnapped last month have been handed over to an Iraqi guerrilla group that has advocated for their release, French officials said Thursday, raising hopes the men may be freed soon.

title: PRESIDENT OF PAYLESS RESIGNS AND RETAILER WILL CUT JOBS
description: Payless ShoeSource, a shoe retailer that is closing stores amid declining earnings and sales, said its president had resigned and it was cutting an undisclosed number of jobs. The chief executive, Steven Douglass, will assume the duties of the president, Duane L. Cantrell, who is also resigning from the board, Payless said. Payless, which is based in Topeka, Kan., plans to close or sell 703 stores and stop operating its Parade of Shoes stores by January as part of a plan to save $12 million a year. The company is also trimming sales to other stores and cutting costs to increase profit, which has declined for six consecutive quarters.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Aug. 25 about Senator John Kerry's visit with a group of children at the Statue of Liberty referred erroneously in some copies to his running mate, Senator John Edwards. Mr. Edwards was not pictured and not present.

title: AIR CHINA TO PAY BOEING $360 MILLION FOR SEVEN 737 JETS
description: The Boeing Company won a $360 million order from Air China, the country's biggest overseas carrier, for seven 737-700 jetliners. Air China will pay an average of $52 million for each of the 737 planes, Boeing said. The 737-700 can carry 126 to 149 passengers and has a maximum flying range of 3,800 nautical miles. The purchase by Air China is part of its plan to have a fleet of 151 aircraft by the end of this year. The carrier is expanding its fleet to take advantage of the Chinese government's easing of travel restrictions. Air China, based in Beijing, is a government-run, closely held airline. Boeing is based in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALIKOFF, STANLEY
description: KALIKOFF -- Stanley. Died peacefully on August 31, 2004, at age 80, of Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of the late Elaine Bierman Kalikoff, father of Beth and Hedy, grandfather of Sylvie, Eva and Natalie, brother of the late Annette Kalikoff Picard, uncle to Lawrence, David and Robert Picard, brother-in-law to Beverly Wein and Kurt Picard, father-in-law to Ray Studebaker and Will Milberg, dear cousin and friend to so many. His sweet and loving presence, his modesty, kindness and generosity will be terribly missed. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, September 7, 2004, 10 A.M. Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Donations in his memory to any of the following are welcome: Parkinson's Disease Foundation (www.pdf.org), United Cerebral Palsy (www.ucp.org); Temple Beth El, Somerville, NJ; Temple Beth Shalom, Hastings - on - Hudson, NY; Temple De Hirsch Sinai, Seattle, WA.

title: Arroyo asks Filipinos to 'chip in' to combat a fiscal crisis : Cutting a deficit with plastic knives
Paid Notice: Deaths   SHOULSON, SONIA
description: SHOULSON--Sonia. The Yeshiva University and Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary family mourn the passing of the beloved mother of Bruce D. Shoulson, devoted member of our RIETS Board of Trustees. In honor of his parents, Bruce and his wife, Robyn, established the Rabbi I. Harry and Sonia Shoulson Seforim Fund at RIETS and the Rabbi I. Harry and Sonia Shoulson Scholarship for YU undergraduates. We extend heartfelt condolences to Bruce and Robyn, their three children, and their grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: The Electoral College : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
China Says Influx of Capital Hurts Efforts to Cool Economy
description: BEIJING, Sept. 2 - China's central bank governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, said the government's efforts to slow the economy are at a critical stage, with monetary policy becoming harder to put in place because of rising inflows of foreign capital.

title: Some Children Freed but Hostage Talks Halt
description: BESLAN, Russia, Friday, Sept. 3 - Heavily armed fighters who seized a school here in southern Russia released 26 hostages on Thursday, all women and children, some of them only babies. Their release was the first sign that negotiators had made progress in their efforts to end the siege peacefully, but the fighters continued to rebuff other entreaties and offers, including safe passage out of the city.

title: At the Age of 29, a Republican Fund-Raiser Has Already Become a High Roller
description: He has met seven times with President Bush, who now knows him by sight. He shot skeet with Vice President Dick Cheney. The Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, made a point of reaching out to him. And a group of leading Republican fund-raisers in Florida who are old enough to be his father are pushing their young protg to the forefront of their cause.

description: THERE'S that voice again: "This is Patricia McCann here." It is a low mezzo register, so intimate and homey, especially on 1010 WINS, the no-nonsense all-news radio station that promises to give you the world if you give it 22 minutes.

title: Buoyed G.O.P. Says It Has Framed Agenda for Fall
description: Republicans ended their convention yesterday on a confident note, optimistic that they had framed the debate for the fall campaign around President Bush's strengths as a wartime president -- and that they had succeeded in raising significant doubts about Senator John Kerry with slashing attacks on the Democrat as too indecisive and liberal to lead.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Boy Is Believed To Have Drowned
description: A 17-year-old boy was missing last night and was believed to have drowned after lifeguards were unable to rescue him from the surf off Rockaway Beach, the police said. The boy was swimming with two companions about 5 p.m. near Beach 92nd Street when all three swimmers ran into trouble. Although lifeguards were able to rescue two of the swimmers, the police said, the third remained unaccounted for after 9 p.m. The authorities declined to identify any of the swimmers. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Heads in the Sand
description: When asked this week on CNN how long the U.S. military is likely to remain in Iraq, Senator John McCain replied "probably" 10 or 20 years. "That's not so bad," he said, adding, "We've been in Korea for 50 years. We've been in West Germany for 50 years."

title: Move seen as message to new members : EU to take legal action on U.K. nuclear 'pond'
5 Acquitted in '94 Bombing of a Jewish Center in Argentina
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 - The trial of four Argentine police officers and a car thief, accused of providing the vehicle used in a deadly terrorist bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires, ended Thursday in the acquittal of all the defendants.

Stark, Sketchy Portraits of Dubious Detentions
description: The tired and poor whom the Statue of Liberty welcomes describe the pain of disinvitation in "Persons of Interest," a tenderhearted series of incarceration horror stories. After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, many Arabs or Muslims living in the United States had their immigrant status checked in ways that seemed often arbitrary, sometimes systematic and mostly inhumane.

description: Telephones and computers that were donated for use at the Republican National Convention will now be used to improve security and otherwise enhance the New York City public schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday.

title: Aging Champion Faces a Young Challenger
description: PALATINE, Ill., Aug. 28 - For three decades Representative Philip M. Crane has been a fixture at Republican conventions. As a fire-breathing antitax crusader who ran for president in 1980 and loves being called the most conservative member of the House of Representatives, he can always be counted on to rouse the party faithful.

title: WELLS FARGO TO BUY FIRST COMMUNITY CAPITAL, A TEXAS BANK
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it agreed to pay $124 million in stock to buy the First Community Capital Corporation, a banking company in Houston with $553 million in assets. First Community has 210 employees, 17 branches and 19 automated teller machines in the Clear Lake and NASA area near Houston. The bank was founded in Pearland, Tex., in 1995 with $3.2 million in capital. The transaction will be completed by the first quarter of 2005, Wells Fargo said. The company, based in San Francisco, now has 103 branches and 11,000 employees in Texas.

title: With Red Sox, Glass Is Always Half-Empty
description: BOSTON, Sept. 2 - Afternoon patrons at the Baseball Tavern were convinced Thursday that George Steinbrenner had a secret plan to keep his team from finishing lower than first in the American League East.

title: Nortel Financial Statements to Be Delayed
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, which is restating results back through 2001, said yesterday that it would not have financial statements for last year and the first half of 2004 ready until the end of October, a month later than planned.

title: Spain Looks to Sell More Than Its Sand and Sun
description: MADRID, Sept. 2 - With hotels reporting some 40 percent of their rooms unoccupied this season, and, for a second summer, many rooms empty even in the hotels that line Spain's fabled beaches, government and industry officials say it is time to scrap the recipe that has built the country into the world's most popular tourist destination after France.

title: Captives Escape After Hours of Pitched Battles
description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 3 A The siege of a school here in southern Russia ended today in panic, violence and death 52 hours after it began. At least 200 people A most of them students, teachers and parents A died, according to official reports and witnesses, after two large explosions sparked pitched battles between the heavily armed hostage-takers and Russian forces.

Paid Notice: Deaths   DATTNER, EMANUEL
description: DATTNER -- Emanuel. Be loved husband of Jean. Devoted father of Karen (Alan) and Leslie (Maxine). Loving grandfather of Jill (Kyle), Ian, Jennifer and Lauren. Adoring great-grandfather of Taylor. Services today 1 PM, Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: EU team spirit : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Paid Notice: Deaths   VALENTINE, CAROL
description: VALENTINE--Carol, 63, of Valencia Road, Niskayuna, NY, died Saturday, August 28, 2004, after a two-and-one-half year courageous battle with acute leukemia. She was born September 14, 1940, in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of the late William and Vivian MacTiernan, last of Phoenix Avenue, Schenectady. Carol previously resided on the Upper Westside in New York City. Mrs. Valentine attended Prospect Heights High School, Brooklyn, NY. She received a BA, from Duke University; and a MA from Columbia University. Carol was a teacher with the U.S. Peace Corps, Roslyn Public Schools, Schenectady County Planned Parenthood, and NYS Department of Health. She was a health administrator--Director of WIC for the NYS Department of Health. Carol was a current member and past president of the First Unitarian Society of Schenectady. She was also a past member of the First Unitarian Society of Albany and of the All Souls Unitarian Congregation in New York City. Carol spent much of her life in service to others, both in her employment and to her family. She will be remembered by her family and friends as a creative force; for art she produced, for the places she designed and for the people she helped shape and nurture. To all of her pursuits she brought the light of her laugh, and the light of her wisdom and insight, making the lives of so many people-particularly women and children--better and stronger. She is survived by her husband, Carl, whom she married April 1, 1961, in Hamburg, NY; her four children, Laurae, Cate, Kristen and Glen; six grandchildren, Lance, Collin, Jeremy, Will, Sofia and Cooper; her brother, William MacTiernan and her sister, Janis Hoffman. Service will be held Sunday, September 12, 2004, at 3:00 PM, at the First Unitarian Society of Schenectady, 1221 Wendell Ave. Contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood (Hudson - Mo hawk), Schenectady Patient Assistance Fund (PAF) in memory of Carol Valentine, 414 Union Street, Schenectady, NY 12305.

title: REPUBLICANS IN NEW YORK / Wrapping things up: President's theme:he'll protect the U.S.
World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pope Discusses Abuse Scandal With U.S. Bishops
description: Pope John Paul II met with bishops from New England, including Archbishop Sean P. O'Malley of Boston, the city at the center of the sex abuse scandal in the American Roman Catholic Church. The pope acknowledged that the scandal had "cast a shadow" on the church. He told the bishops to encourage their members to "persevere" and to offer guidance to priests, many of whom have suffered, he said, because of "the much-publicized failings" of church administrators. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Conrad M. Black's use of money from the Hollinger International publishing company to make charitable donations referred incorrectly to a $100,000 pledge he made to the New York Public Library without the company's help. It was indeed paid.

title: Cape May Point, N.J.
description: A SIGN over the doorway of Betsy and Tom Swann's house in Cape May Point proclaims: "At the beach, we forget to count the days." That could be the motto for just about any vacation at this tiny shore resort on the southern tip of New Jersey. Days blend into one another like waves lapping at the shore: garden work in the morning, a dip in the ocean, a trip to the general store, a stroll along the beach when night falls.

title: Europeans, Hopeful on Growth, Leave Rates Unchanged
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 2 - The European Central Bank is sounding markedly more confident these days than it had earlier this year about the economic recovery in the 12 countries that use the euro. But it is not ready to back up its words with action.

title: New York Marine Convicted of Assaulting Iraqi Prisoners
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Sept. 2 - A Marine reservist from New York City was convicted Thursday in a military court of assault and dereliction of duty for his conduct as a prison guard in Iraq last year.

Reposing Vanella's Chapels, 29 Madison St, NYC, Friday, 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection, St. James R.C. Church, Saturday, 10:00 AM

title: National Briefing | West: California: Briefs On Behalf Of Same-Sex Couples
description: The City and the County of San Francisco filed briefs in Superior Court on behalf of advocacy groups and 12 couples, arguing that preventing same-sex couples from marrying violates rights to due process, privacy, freedom of expression and the equal protection clause of the State Constitution. In August, the State Supreme Court voided more than 4,000 marriage licenses issued in San Francisco. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

description: TANNENBAUM--Iris. To our beautiful cousin. May you rest in peace. Love Ellen & Marty Goldman

title: Pop and Jazz Listings
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Denying the Troops a Secret Ballot
description: Members of the military will be allowed to vote this year by faxing or e-mailing their ballots -- after waiving their right to a secret ballot. Beyond this fundamentally undemocratic requirement, the Electronic Transmission Service, as it's known, has far too many problems to make it reliable, starting with the political partisanship of the contractor running it. The Defense Department is making matters worse by withholding basic information about the service, and should suspend it immediately.

title: Eerie Shots,  la `Vertigo,' but No Sign of Stewart
description: Paul McGuigan's "Wicker Park" -- which opens nationwide today -- finds Josh Hartnett, still looking like the slightly slow-witted captain of a high-school football team, as Matthew, a young Chicagoan poised on the brink of respectability. He has a beautiful, wealthy fiance (Jessica Par), a job with her brother's advertising agency and a plane ticket in his pocket for Shanghai, where he is to negotiate the agency's first Asian contract.

title: Pataki's Speech Caps a Week of Parties and Promotion
description: Gov. George E. Pataki capped off a frenzied week playing host to the Republican National Convention by introducing President Bush last night and lighting into his old Yale acquaintance John Kerry as "a candidate who has to Google his own name to find where he stands."

title: Decision Time for Governor McGreevey
description: There's still time, though not much, for James McGreevey to end his governorship on a positive note by doing the right thing for his fellow New Jerseyans. Under state law, he has until midnight tonight to decide whether to leave office now or stick with his earlier decision to remain on the job until Nov. 15. If he quits now, both parties can begin organizing for a special election to choose a new governor on Nov. 2. If he remains in office beyond midnight, there can be no special election, and Richard Codey, the president of the State Senate, will take over as acting governor on Nov. 15 and serve out the remainder of Mr. McGreevey's term, which expires in January 2006.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a dispute over two pit bulls that have attacked other dogs, one fatally, in the Turtle Bay neighborhood of Manhattan included an outdated reference to a reporter's attempts to reach the City Health Department, which is responsible for protecting the public from menacing dogs. As noted elsewhere in the article, a spokesman for the department, Sid Dinsey, did indeed return a call; he said the department would investigate the attacks.

title: Whimsical Yankees. Fancy That.
description: SALEM, Mass. - THINK of "Fancy" not as a term for the hifalutin or overly ornate, but as covering a definite period in American taste, like neo-Classical or Victorian. Viewed not only as a style but also as a cultural phenomenon, it is the theme of a big, sprawling and ambitious show at the Peabody Essex Museum here titled "American Fancy: Exuberance in the Arts, 1790-1840."

title: Mazel Tov: 350 Years of Jews in America
description: IN a way, catching a ride is how it all began. Fleeing the threat of Portuguese violence, 23 Jewish refugees boarded the Sainte Catherine, a ship that was setting sail for New Amsterdam. They arrived in the Dutch colony almost exactly 350 years ago on Sept. 12, 1654.

title: Unhappily Married and on a Low Road
description: The brilliant, sinister French thriller "Red Lights," which opens today in New York, is a twisty road movie in which every sign points toward catastrophe. As night falls during the journey of Antoine (Jean-Pierre Darroussin), and Hlne (Carole Bouquet) Dunan, an unhappily married couple on their way from Paris to Bordeaux, the highway takes them into descending levels of psychosexual hell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROCKMAN, IRENE
description: BROCKMAN--Irene. Passed away two days before her 99th birthday. Devoted wife of the late Larry. Beloved mother of Alan and Robert (and Jeannette). Adoring grandmother of George and Joshua. Extraordinarily active in communal affairs as Trustee of Riverdale Temple, member of Women's American Ort and Hadassah-Fieldston Chapter and life member of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee. Honored by UJA-Federation. Funeral services were held privately. Donations may be made to Fire Island Pines Property Owners Association Charitable Foundation, PO Box 5305, Fire Island Pines, NY 11782.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Stunning Herself, a Young Russian Ousts Myskina
description: Half excited, half stunned, Anna Chakvetadze of Russia covered her mouth. She had just defeated Anastasia Myskina, her nation's top player and the United States Open's fourth-seeded woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, TENNEN BAUM, ANNA
description: SCHWARTZ - TENNEN BAUM--Anna. A woman ahead of her time, has passed away at the age of 91. She affected the lives of everyone she met with her passion, intelligence and honesty. She will be missed by her family, daughters Sylvia and Joyce, her son Larry, her six grandchildren and great-granddaughter and all who knew her.

title: Records on Exonerated Man Are Kept Off Limits to Press
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 2 - It was a victory, but a hollow one, for a newspaper and an author seeking the release of police records in the investigation of one of Connecticut's most notorious unsolved crimes.

title: Bush Offers Bold Strokes, but Few Details in Speech
description: For a nation divided over his stewardship, distressed about the economy and dubious about the war with Iraq, President Bush had one overriding message last night: He's still the one.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Credit Concern Acquired
description: The Shinsei Bank won the bidding to buy a stake in the consumer finance company Aplus from another Japanese bank, UFJ Holdings, a UFJ spokesman, Naoki Hirokawa, said. Shinsei, based in Tokyo, outbid HSBC Holdings of Britain. The price was not disclosed. Aplus, based in Osaka, has 4.7 million credit card holders and 66 branches in Japan. Shinsei was taken over by Ripplewood Holdings of New York and other investors in 2000.

title: The Met and a Guest Step Off in Opposite Directions
description: Andy Goldsworthy's "Stone Houses," a large two-part stone and wood sculpture, now on the roof terrace of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a strange beast: a tentative step forward for the museum and a definite step backward for the artist.

title: Fighting Words, at the Convention and Beyond

description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

description: To the Editor:

title: A Virgin and Pregnant? She Has One Explanation
description: Awkwardly suspended between social realism and metaphysical speculation, Deborah Kampmeier's independent feature "Virgin," which opens today in Manhattan, is set in an unidentified small town where the teenage Jessie (Elisabeth Moss of "The West Wing") is growing up alienated. Her father (Peter Gerety) is a strict Christian fundamentalist, her mother (Robin Wright Penn) is an anxiety-ridden secret drinker, nd her younger sister (Stephanie Gatchet) is a prissy little daddy's girl and gifted athlete who dedicates her victories in local track events to the glory of God.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Hearst Corp., New York, owner of Esquire and Cosmopolitan magazines, agreed to acquire White Directory Publishers Inc., Buffalo. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

description: They were grabbing a bite at a Ray's Pizza before heading to Madison Square Garden, two women with Republican Convention V.I.P. tags on display, when the talk turned to immigration.

title: Fresh From Broadway, the Amazing Marc Reads the Mood Around the Garden
description: There is one person on Broadway who will not be overjoyed to see the Elephants fold up their big tent and leave town, for reasons having nothing to do with his politics.

description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, LOREN
description: TIERNEY--Loren. The Department of Medicine and the NYU/Bellevue Pulmonary Division sadly announce the passing of Loren Tierney, M.D. She served as Chief Medical Resident, Pulmonary Fellow, and Clinical Instructor at NYU/Bellevue for 13 years. She was revered by her patients and widely respected by her peers. She was the rare individual who succeeded in happily combining superb medical care and community and family service. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her family. William N. Rom, M.D. Director, Pulmonary & Critical Care Medicine NYU School of Medicine Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine, NYU School of Medicine

title: Steinbrenner Draws on 9/11 After Yanks' 22-0 Defeat
description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, said yesterday that he had motivational messages placed around Yankee Stadium on Wednesday to inspire his players and to let New Yorkers know that his players are as resilient as the public has been in dealing with the trauma after Sept. 11, 2001.

title: As Storm Nears Bahamas, Residents Hunker Down
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Sept. 2 - The wind was picking up here Thursday afternoon as Hurricane Frances worked its way up the Bahamas, kicking up 15-foot waves in the sparsely populated southeastern islands. But Mervyn Taylor, a graying civil servant, was playing a leisurely game of dominoes outside the Columbus Primary School with some friends who, like himself, had boarded up their houses and now were just waiting for the storm.

title: INSIDE
description: Convention news appears today in a separate section, The Republicans, Pages P1 to 12.

title: 1904:Sultan Fired On : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
MEDTRONIC SAYS A 2ND SUIT IS FILED OVER ALLEGED KICKBACKS
description: Medtronic, the world's largest maker of spinal implants, said a second whistle-blower filed a lawsuit related to a federal investigation of its spinal division over illegal payments said to have been offered to doctors. The complaint arises out of "similar facts and circumstances" as one filed by a whistle-blower a year ago and will not expand the Justice Department inquiry, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The department is investigating the Sofamor Danek spinal unit, which Medtronic purchased in 1999 for $3.3 billion. Medtronic said the Justice Department informed the company on Sept. 4, 2003, that it was investigating allegations raised under a federal antikickback statute. In November, Medtronic received a government subpoena seeking related documents.

title: Do You Remember Henin-Hardenne? Didn't Think So
description: AS if the lingering effects of a viral infection and a more recent cold weren't bad enough, Justine Henin-Hardenne couldn't quite shake her Olympic hangover, a 31-year-old Israeli journeywoman and a sudden bout of shaky self-esteem yesterday.

title: The Dark Night of a Woman, the Tragic Victim of . . . What?
description: There are still avant-garde film and video makers who opt for the scruffy, low-tech approach, but more and more artists are learning to compete with the glossy production values of Hollywood movies, pop music videos and television commercials. "Single Wide," a video projection by the team of Teresa Hubbard and Alexander Birchler on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art's Altria branch, is a good example of that increasing prowess. It also shows how technical and semiotic sophistication can lead to something more studiously academic than wildly original. Imagine a workmanlike but less than transcendental mix of Gregory Crewdson's Spielbergian photography, Janet Cardiff's near hallucinatory audio effects and one of Eija-Liisa Ahtila's video tales of a lone woman going crazy.

title: Security Council Passes Resolution to Limit Syrian Role in Lebanon
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 2 - The Security Council on Thursday night passed an American- and French-sponsored resolution pressing Lebanon to reject Syrian intervention in its politics and calling on all foreign forces to leave the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   APFEL, ELIZABETH
description: APFEL--Elizabeth, on May 30, 2004. Mother of Geoffrey Garner, Richard Garner, Carolyn Apfel (Garner), and Susan Apfel. Grandmother of Max and Joshua Garner. Sister of Robert Simon.

title: Oil Could Help Japan Resolve Territorial Fight With Russia
description: Correction Appended

title: Bush Outlines Plan for a 2nd Term and Attacks Kerry's Record
description: Correction Appended

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Altera Sales To Fall Short Of Forecast
description: The Altera Corporation, the world's No.2 maker of programmable semiconductors, said yesterday that third-quarter sales would be $269 million, less than its forecast of $274 million to $280 million. The company was expected to have third-quarter sales of $276.8 million, the average estimate of 18 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Altera, based in San Jose, Calif., did not provide a profit forecast in a statement at its Web site. Altera joins Intel in cutting its sales forecast, underscoring concern that orders for computers and electronics are not growing as fast as expected. Intel said yesterday that sales this quarter would be $8.3 billion to $8.6 billion, less than the $8.6 billion to $9.2 billion forecast previously, because of slowing sales of personal computers. Altera's sales will increase at least 28 percent from the $209.5 million a year earlier. Altera shares fell 88 cents in extended trading after the announcement. The shares lost 3 cents, to $19.06, in regular trading.

title: INSIDE
description: Islamic Head Scarf Ban Takes Effect in France A law banning Islamic head scarves and other religious symbols from French public schools went into effect, transforming the first day of school into a nationwide show of defiance of a demand by the captors of two French journalists in Iraq that the law be rescinded. PAGE A9

title: Technology Briefing | People: Match.com Names Chief Executive
description: Match.com, an Internet dating service, said Jim Safka will take over as chief executive on Sept. 9, succeeding Tim Sullivan, who is stepping down to pursue other opportunities with the parent of Match.com, InterActiveCorp. Mr. Safka was most recently vice president and general manager for electronic commerce of AT&T Wireless Services, which Cingular Wireless agreed to buy in February for $41 billion. Before joining AT&T Wireless in 2002, he was vice president for marketing with the E*Trade Financial Corporation, Match.com, which is based in Dallas, said yesterday. Mr. Sullivan joined Match.com in January 2001 as chief operating officer and was named chief executive later that year, the company said. Paid subscribers to all InterActiveCorp personals brands during Mr. Sullivan's tenure rose to about 1 million, from 189,500 in early 2001, the company said. Shares of InterActiveCorp rose 16 cents, to $22.94.

title: Northwest Cancels a Travel Agency Fee
description: By Reuters

title: A Home That's a Cosmos of Shipwrecked Cultures
description: HEIR TO THE GLIMMERING WORLD By Cynthia Ozick 310 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $24.

title: Absolut to Try Television Ads
description: TO introduce a raspberry-flavored version of its flagship brand, the Absolut Spirits Company will boldly go where no Absolut vodka has gone before in the United States: onto television.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Hair Rules on the Stage and Screen
description: A curious exhibition called "Hair" is tucked into a side room at the ornate Natural History Museum in London and will remain there until Sept. 26. It's the kind of quasi-interactive show designed for busloads of bored kids, offering innocent follicles magnified a thousand times and earnest histories of the social history of hair and pop-scientific descriptions of what it consists of and how it grows.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Power Plant Panel
description: The government set up a panel to look into the Dabhol power plant, a $2.9 billion operation -- idle for three years -- that is capable of producing 2,184 megawatts of power. Once showcased as an example of India's economic liberalization, the plant fell idle after a dispute over payments for power by a utility in the state of Maharashtra, which is part owner of the plant. The government is eager to restart the project, which was built by the Enron Corporation. But Dabhol is mired in disputes over debt and arbitration proceedings involving its shareholders, including General Electric and the Bechtel Group, which own 86 percent of the project after buying Enron's stake earlier this year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Nokia lifts profile in a rising cellphone market
Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPKA, MORRIS
description: LIPKA--Morris. On September 1 at 96 years of age in Tamarac, FL. Formerly of White Plains. Husband of the late Genesse Levine Lipka and the late Sara Weiss Lipka. Survived by his sons, Leonard of Alexandria, VA, Kenneth of Boca Raton, FL, and Robert of Weston, CT. Affectionately known as "Papa" to nine grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Born in Pultusk, Poland in 1908, Morris Lipka came to the United States in 1920. He joined Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers Union in 1929 and founded General Sheet Metal Works in 1943. He was vice president of the Sheet Metal Workers Owners Association for many years and earned the admiration and respect of his industry peers and business associates. Services will be held at 10:00 A.M. Friday, September 3, at Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENSON, LENORE
description: BENSON--Lenore. The Fashion Group International regrets the passing of its former Executive Director, Lenore Benson, after a distinguished career of more than 50 years in fashion retailing and publishing. Her many friends and colleagues will miss her talent, enthusiasm and warmth. Services will be held at St. John's R.C. Church, Woodstock, NY, on Tuesday, September 7th at 11:00 A.M. Interment immediately following. A Memorial Service will take place in October, in Manhattan.

title: Building the Stage
description: The stage at the Republican National Convention was transformed for the President's appearance there on Thursday night.

title: On The Market
The Grand Finale
description: At the culmination of the four-day convention, President Bush repeatedly and soberly referred to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as he portrayed his first term as one shaped by that tragedy.

title: Shelter for Shoulders
description: Designers have tweaked the poncho in a variety of ways for fall, offering alternatives that are less flimsy and more interesting than the crocheted style seen everywhere this summer.

title: Forces Storm Russian School
Forces Storm Russian School
description: The siege of a school in southern Russia ended Friday in panic, violence and death 52 hours after it began.
