title: 4 Navy Commandos Are Charged in Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - Four Navy special forces personnel have been charged with abusing an Iraqi detainee who later died during questioning at Abu Ghraib prison last November, and then lying about it, Navy officials said Friday.

title: INSIDE
description: Thousands of Literary Treasures Lost in German Fire As many as 30,000 irreplaceable books were destroyed in a fire at one of Germany's most historic libraries, the Anna Amalia Library in Weimar.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANDELMAN, WALTER
description: HANDELMAN--Walter in his 68th year on September 2. He was beloved by wife, Marlene, sons, Marc and Matthew, and grandchildren Kara Pauline and Miles Alex Jake. Also survived by his beloved sister-in-law, Maxine Miller, and sister, Shirley Pincus of Queens. Funeral services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, North Station Plaza in Great Neck on Sunday at 10:30 A.M. Interment at Mount Hebron cemetery in Flushing. An active member of the community and Village Engineer for Great Neck Plaza Village for over thirty years, he was greatly admired and respected by many in the engineering profession. He loved being able to serve Great Neck Plaza and the Village will miss his enormous talents and compassionate ways. A retired engineer with the State DOT, he was Engineer-InCharge for dozens of major highway construction projects in NYC and Long Island.

title: Europe, easing budget rules, bows to the inevitable
Plans are unveiled on state deficits : A more flexible EU?
Cheney Says Kerry Suffers 'Fundamental Misunderstanding'
description: PENDLETON, Ore., Sept. 3 - In his first public appearance after the Republican convention, Vice President Dick Cheney stood by every one of the administration's foreign and economic policies in a speech here on Friday that drew unflattering comparisons with the positions of Senator John Kerry.

title: 250 Die as Siege at a Russian School Ends in Chaos
description: BESLAN, Russia, Saturday, Sept. 4 - The siege of a school here in southern Russia ended Friday in panic, violence and death 52 hours after it began. At least 250 people -- most of them students, teachers and parents -- died, according to official reports and witnesses, after two large explosions set off pitched battles between heavily armed captors and Russian forces that continued for hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPLEWICZ, ROMA
description: KOPLEWICZ--Roma, 85. Beloved wife, friend and lover of Joseph for 62 years. Devoted mother to Edith, Harold and Linda. Adoring grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. Loyal and caring friend and dedicated social worker died August 31st. After surviving the horrors of the Holocaust, she was reunited with her Joe and together they lived life to its fullest. Her extraordinary "joie de vivre" will live on in her friends and family. Donations may be made to Roma and Joseph Koplewicz fund at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl, SW, Washington, DC 20024 KOPLEWICZ -- Roma. The board and faculty of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the loss of Roma Koplewicz, devoted wife, partner and friend of Joseph (Joe) Koplewicz, beloved mother of Edith, Linda and Harold S. Koplewicz, Director, loving grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. After surviving the Holocaust, Roma enjoyed a long and joyous marriage to Joe and together they created a family that she cared for dearly. Roma was passionate about her work as a social worker and was a loving and steadfast friend to many. Our thoughts and prayers are with Dr. Koplewicz and his family. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair, Board of Directors NYU Child Study Center

title: Bush Plans Could Raise U.S. Deficits
description: President Bush promised in his nomination acceptance speech to improve the lives of millions of Americans by expanding a variety of existing programs, but neither he nor his aides explained how they would pay for the proposals, some of which promised to accelerate the budget deficit over the next decade.

title: Great expectations / What's a reasonable return?: Optimism dies hard  no matter what
Lebanon Agrees to Extend Term of Leader Imposed by Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 3 - As expected, Lebanon's Parliament on Friday rubber-stamped Syria's order to keep its handpicked president in office, voting in an extraordinary session to amend the Constitution to give him three more years.

title: Bush's Second Term
description: White House aides like to say that George W. Bush is a transformational president. That's an exaggeration, but if he's elected to a second term and acts on the words he uttered on Thursday night, he just might be.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Wednesday about "Hawaii," a new police drama on NBC, misstated the subject of another show that is set in Hawaii, "North Shore" on Fox. It is about a hotel that offers guests sexual favors, not about the sex industry.

title: Profit for Liquor Maker
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C., the big liquor maker, said yesterday that it expected to report increased profit for its fiscal year as a result of growth in Britain and the United States.

title: 1954:Intercontinental Missile : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Traffic Lanes Restored, City Gets Groove Back
description: By 7 a.m. yesterday, the police had reopened all the exits of Pennsylvania Station. By 10 a.m., workers had taken down a billboard wrapped around the Cond Nast building in Times Square that read "Democracy is best taught by example, not war." By 1 p.m., Capt. Danny Mulligan of the New York Police Department was telling drivers on Eighth Avenue that they would soon be able to make that left turn onto West 31st Street.

title: COUCHE-TARD TO BUY 22 CONVENIENCE STORES IN PHOENIX AREA
description: Alimentation Couche-Tard, which operates convenience stores, said yesterday it would buy 22 gas stations and shops in the Phoenix area from Shell Oil Products U.S. The stores would be converted to Couche-Tard's Circle K brand, while the gas pumps, currently selling Texaco fuel, will switch to the Shell brand, under the terms of the $33 million deal. Couche-Tard also agreed to shift to Shell gasoline at an unspecified number of its current outlets. Couche-Tard will own the buildings and land at 20 of the properties after the deal closes in November. It will lease the remaining two locations from Shell. Couche-Tard, based near Montreal in Laval, Quebec, operates 4,898 convenience stores under a variety of brand names throughout North America. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: TOTAL OF FRANCE RESERVES LOUISIANA TERMINAL CAPACITY
description: Cheniere Energy Inc., an oil and natural gas explorer, said yesterday that Total S.A. of France reserved the right to about 40 percent of the capacity of a liquefied natural gas terminal Cheniere plans to build in Louisiana. Total would have the right to produce 1 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day at the proposed Sabine Pass terminal for 20 years. The terminal, which has yet to get final regulatory approval, would have a daily production capacity of 2.6 billion cubic feet. Cheniere expects approval for the terminal by the end of this year, with construction to begin in the first quarter of 2005, a spokesman, David Castaneda, said. Stock in Cheniere, which is based in Houston, rose $2.85, to $20.84 a share.

title: Russian TV Turns Away From Crisis
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3 - During one of Russia's most searing hostage crises, one that struck fear across the country and made news around the world, the country's three largest television networks hesitated, then flailed, and finally turned away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAUS, GILBERT
description: KRAUS--Gilbert. On September 1, 2004. Beloved husband of Irena, devoted father of Scott and Dennis, loving brother of Harold, cherished grandfather of Blake. A beautiful and wonderful man who loved life and who will be missed by all. Services on Sunday, 11:15AM at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. KRAUS--Gilbert. The Round Dune community mourns the passing of Gil Kraus. We extend our deepest sympathy to Irina and family. Susan Schiller, President

title: Tempest in a Starbucks Cup? A Billing Expos Turns Out to Be Decaffeinated
description: When a lawyer bills $500 an hour plus expenses for his services, does adding $3 to the bill for a cup of cappuccino at breakfast each morning cross the line?

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Losses Reveal the Franchise's Depth of Desperation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 - Mets fans, it could get worse.

title: Rose Slivka, 85, Writer and Champion of Crafts as Fine Art, Dies
description: Rose Slivka, a writer, critic and editor and a major figure in the advancement of crafts as a serious artistic discipline in the United States, died on Thursday in Southampton, N.Y. She was 85 and lived in Springs, N.Y.

title: A Bush Slap at Hollywood Draws Expected Responses
description: President Bush made only one reference to Hollywood in his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention on Thursday night, and it was almost in passing, but he hit the moviemaking community where it lives. In a shrewdly calculated trope that knitted together two of Senator John Kerry's recent public remarks, the president distanced himself and his core constituency from both his Democratic opponent and one of the more prominent Democratic strongholds.

title: Fewer Schools Labeled Failing in New York
description: One out of four New York City public schools failed to meet state proficiency standards last year, but the number fell by 10 percent compared with the year before, the State Education Department said yesterday.

title: South African Is Charged With Making Nuclear Components
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 3 - The South African police charged a 53-year-old engineer from the country's industrial heartland on Friday with buying materials for and assembling gas centrifuges to purify uranium, apparently for Libya's secret nuclear-bomb program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Aug. 3 about the influence that first ladies have had on style in America misstated the source of Dolley Madison's taste for turbans, which she popularized for many American women. Her fashion sense did not come from excursions to Europe; she never traveled there. But she ordered the turbans from Paris.

title: Stocks Off as Intel's Weak Forecast Overshadows Jobs Data
description: Stocks were little changed outside the technology sector yesterday as investors shrugged off a new kind of surprise from the labor market: job growth for the previous month came in as forecast.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Taking advantage of the panic, hostages began to escape. The bandits began shooting them in the back. The special forces on our side had to cover the fleeing hostages. This is unfortunately how it happened."

title: 1929:Singers Flee to Tuileries : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Justice After War
description: Efforts to think clearly and systematically about the morality of warfare have traditionally fallen under two headings. "Jus ad bellum" referred to moral questions about going to war. "Jus in bello" covered moral questions about the conduct of war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the inauguration of Martn Torrijos as president of Panama referred incorrectly to the Bush administration's response to accusations that the United States had influenced Panama's decision to pardon four Cuban exiles who had been accused of plotting to assassinate President Fidel Castro of Cuba in 2000. The administration did not refrain from commenting. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, interviewed on Panamanian television, said that the pardons were "strictly a matter that was decided by the Panamanian government" and that "Panama is a sovereign nation that can handle these matters on its own without any input from the United States." On Aug. 26, a State Department spokesman said: "This was a decision by the government of Panama. We never lobbied the Panamanian Government to pardon anyone."

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: 2 Floating Astronauts
description: Two astronauts floated outside the International Space Station for 5 hours 20 minutes to carry out more improvement and maintenance work on their orbiting residence. For Col. Gennadi I. Padalka of the Russian Air Force and Lt. Col. Edward Mike Fincke of the United States Air Force, it was the fourth excursion outside the station since they took up residence there in April. Working on the Russian side of the complex, the two men first replaced a panel needed to control a cooling pump, then installed three antennas. The antennas will help European automatic freighters rendezvous with the station beginning late next year. The two men also remained motionless for 15 minutes so ground controllers could study why the station tends to tilt as astronauts are outside spacewalking. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS APPOINTED AT NCR
description: The NCR Corporation, the world's largest maker of automated teller machines, named Pete Bocian as its chief financial officer. Mr. Bocian, 49, has been with NCR for 21 years and had been serving as interim finance chief after the resignation of the previous chief financial officer in October. NCR's sales rose 4 percent to 6 percent the last three quarters after dropping the nine quarters before. NCR is expected to post a profit of 20 cents a share in the third quarter, according to the average forecast of five analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Sales are expected to rise about 2 percent, to $1.39 billion.

title: What Calm in Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Agonizing Vigil Leads to Reunion or Despair
description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 3 - When the first tremendous explosion shook the air, sending a blast wave through the neighborhood around Middle School No.1, the crowd of women near the southern police barricades buckled over. An old woman's eyes welled instantly with tears. She began to pound her head with her fists. Another woman wailed.

title: Reacting to terrorism : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Herbert Haft, Founder of Discount Drugstores, Dies at 84
description: Herbert H. Haft, a combative Washington pharmacist who pioneered discount pricing in drugstores but later became more widely known for aggressive financial maneuvering and a bitter family legal battle for control of a business empire, died Wednesday in a Washington hospital. He was 84.

title: Citing Threats, Entrepreneur Wants to Quit Caller ID Venture
description: It may be known as caller ID spoofing, but it is evidently no laughing matter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: House Prices Decline
description: After a five-year surge, house prices in Britain fell 0.6 percent in August, Halifax, a leading mortgage lender, said. The decline could mean that five interest rate increases by the Bank of England since November have damped a boom that doubled many house prices. Despite last month's fall, house prices were still an average 21.3 per cent higher than in August 2003, according to the monthly Halifax house price index. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Norwegian Stars Show Why They're Winning
description: The players of Scandinavia have long been at the top of the international ladder and collect medals regularly in European and world championships. Even tiny Iceland has won the Bermuda Bowl, the oldest world trophy. The women of Denmark have been outstandingly successful.

title: QRS DROPS DEAL WITH JDA AND AGREES TO BUYOUT BY INOVIS
description: The QRS Corporation, which makes software used by retailers, said it ended its acquisition agreement with the JDA Software Group and agreed to a higher, all-cash offer of $116 million from another company. The closely held Inovis International Inc. agreed to buy QRS for $7 a share. QRS, which is based in Richmond, Calif., agreed in June to be acquired by JDA for about $100 million in stock. The transaction with Inovis, a software maker, is expected to be completed by the end of the year. JDA is based in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: No absence of malice in talk on both sides
U.S. Seeking the Right Blend for the Soccer World Cup
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 3 - Sixty minutes into a World Cup qualifying match in Jamaica last month, the United States trailed and risked losing its first game ever to the Reggae Boyz. Then Coach Bruce Arena sent in forward Brian Ching, who had never scored a goal for the national team.

title: A Hidden Swing Vote: Evangelicals
description: The press has made a big issue of how President Bush and Senator John Kerry are both trying to woo voters from groups that usually support the other side, be they military veterans, Hispanics or Jews. Yet one group that receives almost no attention is Christian evangelicals. We are repeatedly told they form the president's unshakeable electoral base. But in truth, this claim is vastly simplistic: the fashionable image of masses of white evangelical voters, stirred up by the tricks of Karl Rove and led by Bible-thumping clergymen, marching in lock step to deny rights to women and to gays, is hardly born out by the data. Rather, the real Republican base is the same as it was before Richard Nixon's "Southern strategy" appealed to religious Protestants in 1968: the wealthy and the powerful.

title: An Unlikely Streak Ends, but Not Without Notice
description: Angela Haynes's run ended yesterday, earlier than she had hoped but much later than nearly everyone else expected. Haynes, in the United States Open as a wild card, won her first two matches before losing in the third round yesterday to 16th-seeded Francesca Schiavone of Italy, 6-3, 7-6 (3).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about President Bush's address to the Republican National Convention misstated the former title of Gen. Tommy R. Franks, who also spoke. He was head of the United States Central Command, not chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: 144,000 Jobs Were Added in August, a Bit of an Uptick
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - The pace of job creation picked up modestly in August and the unemployment rate edged down, the Labor Department said on Friday in a report that offered some political relief to the White House but only tepid signs of a rebound in employment.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Investigators Seek Lie-Detector Tests in Terrorism Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - Justice Department investigators have sought to have senior federal prosecutors take polygraph examinations in an effort to determine who leaked the name of a confidential informant in a Detroit terrorism case that has become a major embarrassment for the department, officials said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIGHTOWER, KEITH
description: HIGHTOWER--Keith. Of Madison, NJ on Thursday, September 2, 2004. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Romak), loving father of Sean, Brian, Kim and Kerry. Devoted son of Sully and Connie Hightower and dear brother of Dr. Martin Hightower and Mrs. Devie Shevlin. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral mass Tuesday 11 AM at St. Vincent Martyr Church, Madison. Interment St. Vincent's Cemetery, Madison. Visitation Monday 4-7 PM at the Madison Memorial Home, 159 Main St, Madison, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Vincent Martyr School Scholarship Fund, 26 Green Village Rd., Madison, NJ 07940 in his memory would be appreciated.

title: A New Jersey Deputy Chief Is Killed Fighting a House Fire
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 3 - The city's deputy fire chief was killed in a seemingly unremarkable house fire here early Friday morning after he roused all 15 occupants to safety.

title: Donald B. Effler, Pioneer in Open-Heart Surgery in 50's, Dies at 89
description: Dr. Donald B. Effler, the leader of a team of surgeons at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio that helped develop and refine heart surgery, died on Aug. 24 in Jamesville, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Reinventing Thailand : Urban voters challenge Thaksin's forceful style
CONTINENTAL AIR TO DEFER PENSION CONTRIBUTIONS THIS YEAR
description: Continental Airlines Inc. will skip contributions to employee pension plans this year, taking advantage of a law enacted in April. The move will help the company keep $1.5 billion in unrestricted cash during "these difficult and turbulent times," Continental said in a filing. The airline said that it had planned to put $250 million in the plans and had faced a minimum funding requirement of $17 million. The new law gave airlines, steel makers and other companies the option to defer pension funding during the subsequent two years. Continental is based in Houston.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the hostage crisis at a school in Russia misspelled the given name of the regional interior minister, who was quoted by Russian news agencies as saying the guerrillas had threatened to destroy the building if any attempt was made to free the hostages. He is Kazbek Dzantiyev, not Kazdek.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the opening of the Republican National Convention misstated the surname of a speaker, the widow of a New York City firefighter who was killed at the World Trade Center. She is Tara Stackpole, not Stockpile.

title: Floridians Flee as Giant Storm Slowly Heads In
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 3 - Hurricane Frances engulfed the Bahamas on Friday, leaving at least one person dead before moving, ever more slowly, toward an anxious Florida, where 2.5 million people -- nearly 15 percent of the state's population -- have been urged to evacuate their homes.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day will be observed.

title: the end user / A voice for the consumer : Cold reality of urban hot spots
Saudi Arabia Is Sued by Firm That Lost 658 in Twin Towers
description: Cantor Fitzgerald, the brokerage firm that lost 658 employees in the Sept. 11 attack, has sued Saudi Arabia, charging that the kingdom "provided funding and material support and substantial assistance" to Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden.

title: A Prankster Invasion in the Elephant House
description: The Yes Men, a pair of politically charged performance artists whose anticorporate mockery at World Trade Organization meetings is chronicled in a new documentary film, were taking aim this week at President Bush and the party faithful at the Republican convention.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
The Perfect Storm Name
description: Raleigh, N.C. - For those of us in the Southeast, hurricane season is a frightening time. For the fortunate, it may mean only close calls or near misses -- of fallen limbs or sudden changes in the storm path.

title: A Marijuana Salesman Seems to Lose Another Round
description: NAALDWIJK, the Netherlands - JAMES R. BURTON, who once served a year in federal prison, still gets a kick out of the signs at his marijuana plantation here reminding employees whom to call in the event of an emergency: the Dutch police.

title: 1904:Four Climbers Die : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
PFIZER TO PAY $430 MILLION FOR CLAIMS AGAINST UNIT
description: Pfizer agreed to pay $430 million to resolve claims against a subsidiary that sold products containing asbestos in the 1970's. The settlement will result in a third-quarter charge of $229 million, Pfizer said. The subsidiary, the Quigley Company, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday. Quigley, which was acquired by Pfizer in 1968, formerly made materials used to coat steel-making equipment. Pfizer agreed to contribute $405 million over 40 years to a trust that will pay remaining and future claims against Quigley, whose only business since 1992 has been the management of its lawsuits. Pfizer, which is based in New York, and Quigley are named in 171,611 pending lawsuits that claim injuries caused by exposure to asbestos, silica or mixed dust.

title: Guardsman Given Life in Prison for Trying to Help Al Qaeda
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 3 - A National Guardsman was sentenced on Friday to life in prison for trying to aid Al Qaeda. The soldier, Specialist Ryan G. Anderson, had been caught in a sting operation offering information on military vulnerabilities to investigators posing as members of the Qaeda terrorist group.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Retail Sales Decline
description: Australian retail sales unexpectedly declined in July, following the largest increase in three years in June. Retail sales fell 1 percent from June, the first drop in seven months, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said. The decline came despite recent tax cuts and an increase in government benefits for families. "Households are showing more restraint in spending than the market was expecting, given the tax cuts and government handouts," said Tom Kenny, chief economist at Nomura Australia Ltd. in Sydney.

title: Accounting Board May Delay Debt Rule
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board will consider delaying a rule that finance companies contend may force them to write down more of their debt securities that are held for sale.

title: Globalist : Get used to it, Europe:Bush could win again
The Modern in Berlin
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Uneventful Summer by the Shore Gets Mixed Reviews
description: There was no major blackout, but then there was no unbearable sweaty stretch, either; no 100-degree sweltering front to linger like a purplish haze over Manhattan, causing a run on air-conditioners and a mass exodus to the shore.

title: Citing Higher Costs, U.S. Plans Rise in Medicare Premium
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - A day after President Bush heralded his efforts to help the elderly cope with increased medical expenses, federal officials announced the largest premium increase in dollars in the Medicare program's history, raising the monthly expense by $11.60 to $78.20.

title: Job Figures Help President Promote Economic Record
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 3 - President Bush opened his general election drive on Friday, storming through three swing states, citing modest new figures for job growth and portraying himself as the only safe choice in an age of terrorist threat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOBIN, EDWARD A.
description: SOBIN--Edward A. Loving husband of Loretta Sobin and the late Gloria Mandel Sobin. Devoted father of Carole Sobin and Bruce Sobin. Beloved grandfather of Greg and Jessica Sobin and Deborah and Andrew Levison. Service Sunday, 1 PM, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to Southbury H.V. Hadassah, P.O. Box 1215, Southbury, CT 06488, or East End Temple Torah Fund, 245 E. 17th St., New York, NY 10003.

description: To the Editor:

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, New York Messed With Texans
description: The travelers climbed into the rented Chevrolet van with the tinted windows and the big, big gas tank yesterday afternoon, their clothing unwashed, their money spent, their number depleted. Five wild days in New York City had taken a toll.

title: A general's crusade : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Police and Protesters Spar a Last Time, Over the Peace
description: Starbucks survived, the streets were not ablaze, and the police did not wipe acid from their faces or blood from their nightsticks. As the Republican National Convention departed, New York 2004 turned out not to be Seattle 1999, when window-smashing and marauding through the streets during a trade summit meeting gave rise to fears that any large political gathering would dissolve into lawlessness and anarchy.
