description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIND, RABBI LEON
description: WIND--Rabbi Leon. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with deep sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi emeritus of Temple Beth Sholom of Manchester, CT. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASOWITZ, FELICE
description: KASOWITZ--Felice. September 1, 2004, of 681 Heather Lane, West Haven, CT. Devoted wife of Robert Kasowitz. Beloved mother of Stephen Kasowitz of New Haven, Marc Kasowitz of NYC and Susan Oakey Kasowitz of Milford, CT. Also survived by five cherished grandchildren. Funeral services at Congregation B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Road, Woodbridge, CT Monday morning at 10:30 o'clock with interment services to follow in the B'nai Jacob Memorial Park, Wintergreen Ave, New Haven. Memorial contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, G.I. Oncology Fund, P.O. Box 27106, NY NY 10087 or to CT Hospice, 100 Double Beach Rd, Branford CT 06405 or the Congregation B'nai Jacob. A period of mourning will be observed at 681 Heather Lane, West Haven, CT through Wednesday. Robert E. Shure Funeral Home 203-562-8244 KASOWITZ--Felice. We were deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Felice Kasowitz, mother of our founding and senior partner, Marc Kasowitz, mother-in-law of Lori & grandmother of Samantha. We will always remember Felice's incredible warmth and friendliness, and the pride she took in the development and accomplishments of our firm. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Kasowitz family. Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman LLP

title: Milosevic on trial : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
No Special Election, as McGreevey Stays Course
description: The effort to get Gov. James E. McGreevey to resign as New Jersey governor before a midnight deadline yesterday, triggering a special election this fall, has failed.

title: Poor Timing for Latest Selfish Action
description: Kevin Brown loves his role as lone Yankee, the pitching perfectionist and the man who is never satisfied with what he has done on the mound. If that approach is what makes Brown feel invincible, then the Yankees understand it as long as Brown pitches effectively.

title: Hutchison Plans Offering of Phone Unit
description: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., the Hong Kong conglomerate controlled by the billionaire Li Ka-shing, filed with regulators in the United States yesterday to raise as much as $2 billion in an initial public offering of its phone business, which operates in Hong Kong, India and six other markets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Medicare Premiums To Rise 17% Next Year A day after President Bush highlighted his efforts to help the elderly cope with increased medical expenses, federal officials announced the largest premium increase in the Medicare program's history, raising the monthly expense $11.60, to $78.20, next year.

title: Polish President Appeals for a More 'Open and Gracious' U.S.
description: WARSAW, Sept. 1 - The president of Poland, one of America's closest European allies, has made a rare and impassioned plea to Washington to be "flexible, open and gracious." In a veiled criticism of United States foreign policy, President Alexander Kwasniewski said he did not want to see "America take the ideas of the neoconservatives of isolationism, to have full dominance in the world and to play a divide and rule policy. It is a mistake."

title: Catching Nell
description: The other night, just before dusk, I walked across the pasture with a bucket of grain. Two dozen chickens followed me in a mob. Some came running toward me, wings flapping, as if with enough room they might actually take off. I led them into their pen, scattered the grain and closed the gate. Then I drove the ducks and the geese into their yard. "Drove" is too strong a word. I hinted at the direction I wanted them to go, and they went. I opened another gate and led the horses down to the barnyard. When they had been fed, I stepped into the pigpen. The gilt came over for a rubdown, and the barrow flopped down beside her. They lay back to back, eyes closed, pale pink bellies available for scratching.

title: Clinton Suffers Pains in Chest; Bypass Surgery Is Scheduled
description: Stricken with chest pains and shortness of breath, former President Bill Clinton checked into a Manhattan hospital yesterday for heart bypass surgery after X-rays revealed significant blockages in three or four coronary arteries. The operation, which is to take place early next week, could sideline Mr. Clinton during the height of the presidential campaign.

title: Giambi Mum After Report on Tumor
description: Jason Giambi wheeled his black Porsche into the players' parking lot at Yankee Stadium at 5:04 p.m. yesterday, about a half-hour after the rest of the Yankees started their mandatory stretching. Giambi then hustled by reporters who wanted to ask him about a newspaper report that said his benign tumor, the location of which had not been publicly disclosed, was in his pituitary gland.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Patent Challenge Withdrawn
description: Novartis, the largest drug maker in Switzerland, said that an Indian rival, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories, had withdrawn its challenge to a patent in the United States for the fungal treatment Lamisil, one of Novartis's leading sellers last year. Dr. Reddy's, which is based in Hyderabad, will not sell a generic version of the Novartis medicine until after the patent expires in December 2006 and perhaps not for another six months if the patent is extended, Novartis said. Lamisil had sales of about $978 million last year, with about half of the revenue coming from the United States. Dr. Reddy's said that it decided to drop the suit because of the time it would take to go through a trial and pursue an appeal. Novartis is based in Basel.

title: Jets Climb Back With a Lift From the Bench
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 3 - Talk about feast or famine.

title: Star's Perks: Hairstylist, Limousine, License to Kill
description: Luckily for Mel Gibson, his last vanity project, "The Passion of the Christ," has probably made enough money to cover the expense of his new one, "Paparazzi." This amazingly arrogant, immoral film is almost certain to suffer a fast, richly deserved death at the Labor Day box office.

title: Another Pitcher Makes Early Exit, and So Do the Mets
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 - Mets pitcher Victor Zambrano and infielder Jos Reyes, rehabilitating from injuries in Port St. Lucie, Fla., fled north to join the Mets and escape the wrath of Hurricane Frances.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Still Have Plenty to Prove, Even to Themselves
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 3 - In the preseason finale Thursday night, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin wanted to instill confidence in his beleaguered offensive line. On the first play of the second quarter, the Giants faced a third-and-1 from their 32-yard line. The call came from the sideline, but he changed it.

title: INVESTING : Learning to love the hedge funds
2 CENTS' WORTH / Commentary : Carmakers sell the ultimate ego trip
Judge Says Lawyers Can Question Cardinal
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLESINGER, HELEN
description: SLESINGER--Helen. Beloved wife of the late Charles Slesinger. A woman of valor and a lady of strength has passed away at the age of 95. She affected everyone she met with her interest, intensity, concern for their welfare, devotion and intelligence. A remarkable role model who will be sorely missed by her family, son Jacques, daughter Liane, four grandchildren and ten great - grandchildren. Funeral Sunday 12:45PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, DR. LOREN
description: TIERNEY--Dr. Loren. The Department of Family Medicine of Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center expresses its deepest sympathy to our Residency Director, Dr. Jim Mumford, on the passing of his beloved wife, Dr. Loren Tierney. We will always remember Loren's unbounded devotion to her family; her warmth, wit and generosity; and her strength, courage and grace as she battled her illness. We extend our embrace to Jamie, Cooper, Anna, and the rest of Loren's family as they absorb this incalculable loss.

title: Anne Coffin Hanson, 82, Yale Professor of Art History, Dies
description: Anne Coffin Hanson, an art historian and curator and the first woman to be hired as a full tenured professor at Yale, died yesterday at her home in New Haven. She was 82.

title: Suspect Escapes Police at Airport
description: A man who was being returned from California to face charges of burglary in Suffolk County escaped his police guard in a terminal restroom at La Guardia Airport last night and remained at large early this morning, the authorities said.

title: For Giuliani and Pataki, Starring Roles Could Collide
description: Gov. George E. Pataki had just left a breakfast on Tuesday with delegates from New Hampshire, which happens to hold the first presidential primary in the nation, when Tom Rath, a committeeman, seemed to give him the kind of review that politicians long to hear.

title: In Largely Quiet Iraq, Pipeline Is Attacked
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 3 - An unusual quiet continued Friday for the second straight day in Iraq, with American forces and insurgents apparently taking a pause after months of heavy combat.

title: Free of Pain, Haas Renews His Climb in Ranking
description: It is odd seeing large numbers next to his name, figures that indicate he is just another professional tennis player, that he is nothing special, not a real threat.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Held the Line and Managed to Walk It, Too
description: In his attempt to carefully position himself between his Republican guests and his reluctant host city, Michael R. Bloomberg showed New York City two mayors this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEKIMIAN, LEON J., M.D.
description: HEKIMIAN--Leon J., M.D., 86, died September 1, of laryngeal cancer. In private psychiatric practice since 1956, he was also assistant professor of psychiatry at NYU School of Medicine and coauthor of many research papers on drug effects. He also owned and bred racehorses for many years. He is survived by his wife Carol and his son Peter.

title: Clinton Operation Aims to Restore Blood Flow
description: Correction Appended

title: South Koreans Repeat: We Have No Atom Bomb Program
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 3 - Officials in South Korea continued Friday to try to assure the world that the nation had no nuclear arms program, with its top nuclear researcher saying government scientists had enriched a speck of uranium "smaller than a sesame seed" merely "to satisfy their curiosity."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FOSTER, COL. RASE ROBERT
description: FOSTER--Col. Rase Robert, 1960--2003. You are always at our side. We love you now and forever. Essie and Hal, Michael, Stacy, Tamar and Jody

title: Upward Mobility Gets Further Up
description: Upward mobility, or "movin' on up," as the theme song for the 1970's sitcom "The Jeffersons" put it, isn't the same for African-American families today as it was three decades ago. In 1975, when the show was first broadcast, the gap between rich and poor hadn't stretched into the chasm; the white middle-class and black urban culture were on friendlier terms, and a basketball player couldn't expect to be handed a multimillion-dollar contract.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, ESTHER
description: FRIEDMAN--Esther, on September 2, 2004, sister of Morris, sister-in-law of Norma and of Philip and Ruth. We will miss her. Services Sunday, September 5th, 2PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Mack Joins Board of REIT
description: John J. Mack, the former co-chief executive of the Credit Suisse Group, has joined the board of a real estate investment trust run by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, one of the first new business roles he has accepted since leaving Credit Suisse in June.

title: The Region, a Primer
description: NORTH OSSETIA -- has a population of just over 710,000, according to the 2002 census. The population is most-ly Orthodox Christian with some Mus 2/3lims and significant pagan traditions. Historically known as Alania, the region was a Silk Route crossroads. Unlike those in most of the region, Ossetians were not espec-ially resistant to Russian rule.

title: In an Earthy Landscape the Mood Is Mellow
description: Some groups can seem too casual to get their due, and the Paul Motian-Joe Lovano-Bill Frisell trio is one of them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Household Spending Rises
description: Japanese household spending rose 1.1 percent in July compared with a year earlier, as consumers spent more on clothing and housing. The increase is a welcome sign that consumption, which accounts for more than half of the economy, is again picking up after household spending unexpectedly fell by 2.6 percent in June. Japanese policy makers are hoping a prolonged rebound in consumer spending will help extend an economic recovery that has so far been built mostly on exports. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Back Tax Bill Against Yukos Is Increased
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3 - The Tax Ministry increased its 2001 back tax bill against the oil giant Yukos to $4.1 billion on Friday, bringing its total tax claims against the company to $7.5 billion.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Begins New Push as Rules on Money Change
description: Republicans are opening a fresh round of fund-raising this month, trying to spin momentum from their convention into millions of dollars for the party as President Bush's campaign switches to public financing this week.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Copper Makers Fined
description: The European Commis-sion has fined a group of copper pipe makers 222.3 million euros ($270.5 million) for operating a price-fixing cartel during a 12-year period, the commission said. The companies include Generale Industrie Metallurgiche of Italy, Outokumpu Oyj of Finland and IMI, which is based in Britain. Mueller Industries of the United States escaped a fine because, regulators said, it broke ranks with the other cartel members and informed European regulators about the cartel. "European consumers paid more for plumbing replacement work or when buying a house than if the healthy forces of competition had been at play," Mario Monti, above, the competition commissioner for the European Union, said in a statement. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Internationally, Taking Sides in the U.S. Presidential Race
description: LONDON, Sept. 3 - It's as if the whole world were voting in the American election as pundits, politicians and average blokes on street corners took sides on Friday at the close of the Republican National Convention.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle on Thursday provided an erroneous clue for 47 Across, seeking the answer "Laval." The clue "Montreal university" was incorrect because Laval University is in Quebec City, not Montreal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the inauguration of MartAn Torrijos as president of Panama referred incorrectly to the Bush administration's response to accusations that the United States had influenced Panama's decision to pardon four Cuban exiles who had been accused of plotting to assassinate President Fidel Castro of Cuba in 2000. The administration did not refrain from commenting. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, interviewed on Panamanian television, said that the pardons were "strictly a matter that was decided by the Panamanian government" and that "Panama is a sovereign nation that can handle these matters on its own without any input from the United States." On Aug. 26, a State Department spokesman said: "This was a decision by the government of Panama. We never lobbied the Panamanian Government to pardon anyone." (Go to Article)

title: CYPRESS SEMICONDUCTOR SEES EARNINGS BELOW ESTIMATES
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, which makes chips used in video game consoles and mobile phones, said results for the third quarter will be below analysts' estimates because of higher client inventory and a slowdown in electronics spending. Profit excluding some costs will be 11 cents to 15 cents a share, and sales will be $237.9 million to $251.1 million, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected Cypress, which is based in San Jose, Calif., to post a profit of 25 cents and sales of $274.6 million. Stock in Cypress fell 81 cents, to $8.89 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Libya Signs Berlin Bomb Settlement
description: Libya signed an agreement to pay $35 million in compensation to more than 160 victims of a 1986 bomb attack on a Berlin discotheque popular with American military personnel. The settlement, agreed to last month, involves the non-American victims involved in the attack, which killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and injured more than 200 people. Lawyers are seeking a separate compensation in the United States for Americans wounded in the attack and the two dead soldiers. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Prize Novel Full of Truths That Stretch Believability
description: In March 1985 at a Soviet orphanage, a severely disabled Russian teenager improbably named Ruben David Gonzalez Gallego was watching television as Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the newly anointed Soviet leader, received well-wishers from abroad. Among them was Ignacio Gallego, the patriarch of Spanish Communism.

title: Name of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 977 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: M.L.B.

title: Deadly Stalemate in Chechnya
description: A staggering series of recent terrorist attacks rooted in the Chechen conflict have been both horrific and remote to most Americans. It's hard to imagine what the public reaction would have been here if terrorists had seized a school full of children, blown up two passenger planes and set off a deadly suicide bomb outside a subway station in Western Europe or Canada. But the Chechen conflict has always seemed to be an internal problem in a rather remote part of Russia that has little impact on the rest of the world. The Russian government, which is both suspicious of external interference and proud, has encouraged that attitude. Unfortunately, it's wrong.

title: Driving Takes Its Toll
description: This summer, Americans continued to rack up highway miles. Even while higher gas prices raised vacationing and commuting costs, most drivers acted as though this was a temporary glitch, complacently looking forward to the return of reasonable prices. For decades, Americans have grown too accustomed to cheap gas, buying S.U.V.'s and V-8's, driving more and more miles per capita every year. We are now more dependent on imported oil than ever before. But is there any viable alternative? Our own history offers us a possible solution.

title: Literary Treasures Lost in Fire at German Library
description: BERLIN, Sept. 3. - Up to 30,000 irreplaceable books were destroyed in a fire on Thursday night at one of Germany's most historic libraries, in the eastern city of Weimar, officials said on Friday.

title: Antiwar Group Grabs Attention With Messages Dressed in Pink
description: They have lobbied in the halls of Congress wearing pig costumes and wandered the streets of Manhattan dressed in evening wear and rags.

title: Past and Present, Passionately Blended
description: The heightened political atmosphere in New York this week was met, in two very different programs, with passionate idealism and tragic comedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSPAN, EZRA M., M.D.
description: GREENSPAN--Ezra M., M.D. On September 3, 2004. Loving father of Karen, Ellen, and David. Husband of Edith. Grandfather of Elizabeth, Diana, and Adam. Services Tuesday, September 7th, at 11:15 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Chemotherapy Foundation, 183 Madison Avenue #

title: Yankees' Frustrations Hit Breaking Point
description: Yankees pitcher Kevin Brown, pushed over the brink by his aching body and rotten luck, finally channeled his anger into one hard punch into the clubhouse wall last night.

title: The Police and the Protests
description: New Yorkers can be proud of the way they handled their duties as hosts of the Republican convention. The best news was that nothing happened. Given the huge number of demonstrators, the fears of terrorism and the determination on the part of some anti-Bush protesters to confront the delegates directly, things went about as well as was conceivable. Not even the famous Great Lawn in Central Park suffered any ill effects, as people respected the court rulings keeping organized demonstrations away. This page had urged the city to let the demonstrators use the lawn for their rally, but we're nonetheless happy to know the grass survived.

title: Life in the Universe
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
Philippines Pinching Pesos to Fight a Huge and Worsening Deficit
description: MANILA, Sept. 3 - Hoping to gain popular support in fighting a worsening fiscal crisis, the Philippine government has begun a highly publicized series of austerity measures, including reducing the number of cars in President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's convoy and urging officials to forgo expensive catered events in favor of cheap food on plastic plates.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KEMPNER, IVAN, MD.
description: KEMPNER--Ivan, MD. 18 Elul and loved, missed, remembered. Wife Arline & daughters Robbi, Juli, Lan

title: Kerry Urges Voters to Look Past Bush's 'Last-Minute Promises'
description: NEWARK, Ohio, Sept. 3 - Senator John Kerry opened the final 60 days of the presidential campaign on Friday with a slashing indictment of President Bush's record on jobs and health care, saying he had misled the United States into war in Iraq and left a trail of broken promises and worsened problems at home.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Sara Lee Corp., Chicago, the food and clothing company, said it expected to contribute about $236 million to its pension plans for the fiscal year ending July 3, compared with $112 million in fiscal 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGERS, HARRY PETER
description: ROGERS--Harry Peter. Beloved husband of Louise G. Rogers. Died Thursday evening in New York City from complications of a stroke. He was 90 years old. He served as a Lieutenant in the Navy during World War II and had retired from Con Edison in 1979 after serving as a Mechanical Engineer for forty years. He was the father of Gordon Rogers, like a father to Victoria Leacock and is survived by his wife and his brother Eugene Rogers and his family.

title: Serena Williams, Fashion Queen, Rules the Court
description: Losing appears to be the last thing on Andy Roddick's mind at this year's United States Open.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nokia Falters, and the Finns Take Stock
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 3 - After the party, the hangover; after the binge, the bills.

title: Even in Stormy Weather, Florida's Appeal Endures
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Sept. 3 - Hurricane Frances was out there, somewhere, but more mystery at the moment than menace in the mind of Christine Weslowski as she leaned into the big warm breeze blowing hard across the boardwalk here.

title: Birdstone Has Shot at Upsetting Smarty Jones Again
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 3 - When Smarty Jones was retired from racing last month, the widespread assumption was that the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness would be named this year's champion 3-year-old colt and, perhaps, the horse of the year as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROCKMAN, IRENE
description: BROCKMAN--Irene. Passed away two days before her 99th birthday. Devoted wife of the late Larry. Beloved mother of Alan and Robert (and Jeannette). Adoring grandmother of George and Joshua. Extraordinarily active in communal affairs as Trustee of Riverdale Temple, member of Women's American Ort and Hadassah-Fieldston Chapter and life member of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee. Honored by UJA-Federation. Funeral services were held privately. Donations may be made to Fire Island Pines Property Owners Association Charitable Foundation, PO Box 5305, Fire Island Pines, NY 11782.

title: MEANWHILE : MoMA goes to Berlin:A tale of two Europes
World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Executive Resigns
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest phone company, said the chief executive of its majority-owned Internet unit, T-Online International, resigned after it named an executive from I.B.M. to run a new unit merging fixed-line and Internet operations. Deutsche Telekom said it named Walter Raizner, the head of I.B.M.'s German unit, to take charge of a newly created unit that will combine consumer business at T-Online and T-Com, its fixed-line division. Deutsche Telekom is based in Bonn.

title: With Jaundiced Eyes and Barbed Tongues
description: Benjamin Franklin Carney III is a tough name to live up to. Mr. Carney, the long-faced author and star of the double-focused solo show "Homeland Insecurity," playing at the American Place Theater in Manhattan through Sunday, is no relation to the Franklin of legend, but he does claim an ancestor who served with George Washington. And his autobiographical play is, at least partly, an attempt to grapple with his identity as a 10th-generation American and Southerner.

title: The President's Moment: American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul says the work was not approved : South Korea repudiates uranium experiments
Slow Week for Art, With Few Exceptions
description: Except the 1999 gallery show where the art dealer Mary Boone handed out live ammunition, inadvertently cheering the hearts of National Rifle Association members everywhere, it is safe to say that the New York art world has had little positive interaction recently with conservative politics.

title: Cars at Yellowstone Park
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Wireless Moves to Sell Canada Asset
description: AT&T Wireless Services Inc., the third-largest United States mobile phone company, reached an agreement yesterday with Rogers Communications Inc. to help sell AT&T Wireless's 34 percent stake in Rogers Wireless Communications Inc.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Euphoria in Malaysia : Which Anwar Ibrahim walks free?
A Russian furniture craze, courtesy of a London dealer
COCA-COLA OFFERS TO SETTLE ANTITRUST CASE IN EUROPE
description: Coca-Cola offered to change the way it sells beverages in Britain and four European countries to settle a five-year-old antitrust investigation. The European Commission is circulating the proposal among competitors and customers for their comments, Coca-Cola said in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A Coca-Cola spokesman, Ben Deutsch, declined to elaborate. The investigation began in 1999 and covers Britain, Germany, Austria, Belgium and Denmark. It focuses on Coca-Cola's practice of offering rebates tied to sales volume. Coke's rival, PepsiCo, instigated the investigation with a complaint about Coke's sales practices and is reviewing the proposal.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 26 with the obituary of Wilton Mkwayi, who was imprisoned with Nelson Mandela for fighting apartheid in South Africa, reversed the identities of two men among the three shown with raised fists after their release in 1989. Mr. Mkwayi was at the right and Walter Sisulu at the left. As correctly noted, Elias Motsoaledi was at the center. The picture is online today at http://www.nytimes.com/corrections. A reader reported the error soon after it appeared; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: With Hull Out of the Lineup, the U.S. Wins Its First Game
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 3 - Brett Hull may be the most accomplished and best-known American player in National Hockey League history, but he was not in the lineup Friday night when the United States beat Slovakia, 3-1, in a World Cup of Hockey game at the Xcel Energy Center.

title: Colorado Working to Overcome Scandal
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 3 - Students are settling into the routine of this semester at the University of Colorado, where classes began two weeks ago. They whiz around campus on mountain bikes and flock at night to the restaurants and bars on Pearl Street and the Hill.

title: A muscular economy : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Machete Attack At Security Agency
description: The police arrested a man armed with a machete and a knife who rampaged in a British government building in London housing the MI5 domestic security service and the Northern Ireland office. The police said officers used a stun gun to bring the man down after he wounded two security guards. The motives behind the attack were unclear. The Press Association news agency quoted the police as saying the attack was not linked to terrorism. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: If You Own It, Map It
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ghosts of El Morocco
Hurricane Frances Approaches
description: Shrieking winds and angry sheets of rain thrashed Florida's coast on Saturday as residents hunkered down in crowded shelters.

title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Kate Solomon, Dan Slivjanovski
description: Kate Jenny Solomon and Dan Slivjanovski are to be married today on Martha's Vineyard. Judge Miriam Cedarbaum of United States District in New York will officiate at the Beach Plum Inn in Chilmark, Mass.

title: Unfurled
description: The city was slipcovered in stars and stripes for last week's Republican National Convention. Many of the delegates (left) dressed in tricolors. Protesters in last Sunday's march (right) made their own flag dresses.

title: France Takes Reins of NATO Force in Kosovo at Trying Time
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Sept. 1 - France took command of NATO peacekeeping operations in this Serbian province on Wednesday. The move puts French generals in charge of NATO's two major current operations, here in Kosovo and in Afghanistan, where a French officer took command of NATO forces in August.

title: No Power, No Patience, but the Hits Keep Coming
description: For someone hitting .251, Bret Boone gives Ichiro Suzuki an awfully hard time. Whenever Suzuki, the Mariners' lightning-quick leadoff man, scoots safely to first on a four-hopper to short, a flare to center or a 30-foot bunt for yet another three-hit game, Boone accosts him in the Seattle dugout.

title: The Highlands, White Plains: A Bit of Yesterday, Pushing Back on Tomorrow
description: A PICTURE taken today of Susan Kleinman Wechsler and her two toddlers outside their White Plains house could almost be mistaken for one taken of her grandmother or great-grandmother before her. With its tidy pre-World War II homes, picket fences and well-kept yards, the Highlands neighborhood of the city, where Ms. Wechsler lives, has not changed much since her forebears were raising families there.

title: Holiday on Monday: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES -- Closed. POST OFFICES -- Express Mail only; main post office open on Eighth Avenue at 32nd Street. BANKS -- Closed. PARKING -- Alternate-side regulations will be suspended. SANITATION -- No pickups, street cleaning or recycling. SCHOOLS -- Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS -- Closed. TRANSPORTATION -- New York City subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North trains will operate on holiday schedules.

title: Doctors Without Behavioral Borders
description: THE pilot episode of "Medical Investigation," NBC's new medical science series, retells a famous old New York story about a rare type of food poisoning that produces blue patients. (The pilot will be broadcast on Thursday night at 10 Eastern; the following night at the same time, the show will assume its regular slot). Though its source isn't credited, the episode (written by Jason Horwitch) is an homage to "Eleven Blue Men," the great medical journalist Berton Rouech's classic account of a mysterious food poisoning that literally turned 11 New York City alcoholics blue.

title: Fully Booked on Any Day of the Trip
description: AS we are being driven through the palm oil groves of Costa Rica, my mother's head is buried in Keen's guide to Central American mollusks. My father is unsticking the clammy thin pages of a biography of Trotsky, and my brother is reading about obscure weaponry used in the Civil War. Every once in a while, a bump in the dirt road might cause them to look out at an idle herd of cattle or a ditch-digging operation. I would have a book on my lap as well if I weren't inclined toward carsickness.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 22 with an article about Maui misidentified the architect of a large house fronted by palm trees, an example of very expensive houses being built in the area. It was designed by Thomas A. Kligerman of Ike Kligerman Barkley Architects in Manhattan, not by Ricardo Legorreta.

title: A Message in Every Squeeze
description: ASIDE from his guest appearance in the 1977 Woody Allen film "Annie Hall," Marshall McLuhan, the Canadian cultural critic, is most famous for coining the phrase, "The medium is the message." Mr. McLuhan, of course, was referring the corrosive effects of mass entertainment and information. But the expression could also apply to a whitening toothpaste called 1 800 BEST DDS, a product that blurs -- if not outright erases -- the line between merchandise and marketing tool.

title: Giuliani Honor Draws Anti-Abortion Fire
description: In the view of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops, politicians who belong to the church but depart from its teachings on abortion should be denied honors from a Catholic institution.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor: "The High Road in the Andes," by Robin Cembalest (Aug. 15) brought back memories of two days and nights at the mountaintop ruins of Machu Picchu years ago.

title: Hardcover Highlights
Paid Notice: Deaths   SACKS, DAVID G.
description: SACKS--David G. The children of David Sacks mourn their father, a giant in the New York philanthropic and business communities. A graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School he was a retired partner of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, served as Chief Administrative Officer of Lehman Brothers and President and ViceChairman of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons. He was President of UJA-Federation of NY, Chairman of the Board and President of the Jewish Outreach Institute, President of Westchester Jewish Community Services, on the Board of Visitors of Columbia College, the Board of Overseers of Hebrew Union College and on the Boards of the 92nd Street Y, the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, the HealthCare Chaplaincy and the Jewish Communal Fund. His achievements were a blessing to those who profited from his wisdom, keen sense of humor and commitment to public service. His children, Jonathan Sacks (Evelyn) of NYC, Deborah Chapin (Stephen) of Mamaroneck, NY, Judith Bliss (Steven) of Morristown, NJ and Joshua Sacks (Emily) of Weston, CT and ten grandchildren ask that contributions be sent to The Sacks-Louie Charitable Trust, c/o Jonathan Sacks, 101 Central Park West, NY, NY 10023 to be distributed in his honor.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article and a related chart last Sunday, listing Standard & Poor's 500 companies with the highest percentages of female directors, included an erroneous reference from Spencer Stuart, the executive recruiting firm, to the composition of the board of Golden West Financial and its resulting rank. Five of its nine members are women, not four. Thus Golden West is first, at 56 percent, ahead of Albertsons, at 50 percent.

title: The Big Duck
description: To the Editor:

title: Peekskill Kitchen That Spans the World
description: PEEKSKILL - IN its 14th year, Zephs' sits on the fringe of town here, its handsome brick face trimmed with dark green shutters and cup-and-saucer vines. Once a grist mill, the restaurant is bordered by a miniature jungle of cartoonish cultivars: stalks of sorghum, big red cannas, giant elephant ears. The exuberant vegetation does its best to screen the rubble-strewn lot next door, but it also lines the way to some of the most memorable food I have eaten in Westchester.

title: The Mouse in the Antiques Shop
description: NOT so long ago, throngs of people used to antique for entire weekend afternoons. Customers would stroll from shop to shop in towns like Tarrytown and Larchmont, to look, touch, hang out, savoring the ritual of the hunt at least as much as the eureka moment of actually finding the item they were hunting for.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of an author in the New & Noteworthy Paperbacks column on Page 20 of the Book Review today is positioned incorrectly. It shows Chuck Klosterman, not David Von Drehle, and should appear with the third-from-last entry, not the second-from-last.

title: In Sea Cliff, the Battle of the Tower
description: SINCE January, Katie Seiden, a sculptor in Sea Cliff, has been peppering her village with petitions and appeals opposing its plan to build a 12-story cellphone tower disguised as a flagpole.

title: Assembly Required
description: Experiencing at least one culinary epiphany in France seems to be a rite of passage for all serious gourmands, amateurs and professionals alike. For Elizabeth David, it was a simple Gruyre omelette at the restaurant Molire in Avignon. For Julia Child, it was oysters on the half shell, sole meunire and a green salad she ate at La Couronne in Rouen. My own acorn on the head occurred while studying abroad and culminated, after a lengthy gestation, in a cold-eyed reappraisal of a similarly humble dish: tuna salad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOBIN, EDWARD A.
description: SOBIN--Edward A. Loving husband of Loretta Sobin and the late Gloria Mandel Sobin. Devoted father of Carole Sobin and Bruce Sobin. Beloved grandfather of Greg and Jessica Sobin and Deborah and Andrew Levison. Service Sunday, 1 PM, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to Southbury H.V. Hadassah, P.O. Box 1215, Southbury, CT 06488, or East End Temple Torah Fund, 245 E. 17th St., New York, NY 10003.

title: Acting Out Those Garage-Band Dreams
description: TALK about repressed. For 20 years, Jerry Harden has played by the rules of Middle America. He has racked up the requisite beautiful wife, the two snarling teenage children, the nice house in the suburbs, the banking job and the hefty bills that come attached. With his starchy gray pinstripe suit and earnest demeanor, no one would guess his personal life was anything short of a snore -- until one morning a mangy dog of a fellow shows up at the bank dangling a lucrative paycheck. Next thing you know, the quintessential family man is leaving work early, getting home late and demonstrating uncharacteristically erratic behavior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YEUNG, WINSTON C.Y.
description: YEUNG--Winston C.Y., of Hastings - on - Hudson, Man hattan and Hong Kong, died at 67 on Tuesday, August 31, 2004. He was educated in the U.K. as a Chartered Accountant and later became an entrepreneur. He is survived by his wife, Helena Tse, daughter, Karen Kar-Ling, two brothers, Chi Tak and Dr. Lawrence Chi Kin, and seven sisters, Kit Chee, Kit Wan, Catherine Kit Ming, Kit Har, Jessica Kit Ching, Alice Kit Sum and Winnie Kit Fong, and 13 nieces and nephews. Funeral is private. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society of Pennsylvania, 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

title: Domestic Partnership: The Line Forms Here
description: JOE NASSANEY was shocked when Carl Baccaro, his partner of 32 years, asked him if he would like to become his legal partner. New Jersey's Domestic Partner Act was to take effect a few days later, which allowed gay and elderly couples a legal status short of marriage.

title: 'Nuclear Terrorism': Counting Down to the New Armageddon
description: NUCLEAR TERRORISM The Ultimate Preventable Catastrophe. By Graham Allison. 263 pp. Times Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $24.

title: A George Lucas Far, Far Away
description: IN 1971, a 27-year-old George Lucas released his first theatrical film, "THX 1138," a feature-length expansion of a 15-minute short that he'd made as a student at the University of Southern California. It may be set in a chilly, antiseptic future, but "THX" is a quintessentially paranoid reflection of the culture wars of its time, a tale of young rebels (with bald pates rather than long, hippie hair) defying an authoritarian state. Robert Duvall plays THX 1138, a worker in a robot factory who awakens to the forbidden joys of love and sex when his roommate, LUH 3417 (Maggie McOmie, in her first and only film), substitutes stimulants for the sedatives the state forces its citizens to take. Arrested for crimes of affection, THX is sent to a highly metaphorical prison without walls -- a huge, echoing white space, from which THX and his fearful companion, SEN 5241 (Donald Pleasance) are determined to escape.

title: A Stadium Long Gone, but Not Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: The Only Question Is Whether the Little Men Will Be Green
description: THERE'S no place like home. Or is there? Astronomers took another step toward the dream of finding another Earth, and perhaps other life, with the announcement by teams of European and American astronomers of the discovery of three new planets much smaller than any that had been seen around other stars before, circling stars called Gliese 436, Cancri 55 and mu Arae.

title: TiVo, Cable or Satellite? Choose That Smart TV Wisely
description: TECHNOPHILES like to brag about their electronic toys and how they cannot live without them. But recently, even tech novices have started crowing about their digital video recorders, or DVR's.

title: Welcome to the Rainbow State
description: Correction Appended

title: Introducing the New Sitcom Stars: Men Who Aren't Always Wrong
description: "SO much of what's defined as a family sitcom now has become a wife telling a husband what a moron he is," said the television producer Mike Scully. "Nobody does that better than 'Everybody Loves Raymond' -- so why bother trying to copy that?" Instead, Mr. Scully and his wife, Julie Thacker-Scully, created "Complete Savages," about a macho single dad with five unruly sons who've driven countless housekeepers from their home.

title: Good Deals for Banks, Both Coming and Going
description: WHEN Loews Cineplex Entertainment was sold this summer to a consortium of investors, the deal seemed pretty standard. A bunch of private equity investors anted up some cash and then borrowed some more from Wall Street banks to pay the $1.5 billion asking price.

title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming This Fall: The Romanovs Visit Newark
description: WHILE politics will be center stage in New Jersey this fall, many necessary diversions await in the art museums as the new season begins. The offerings include snazzy touring exhibitions, chancy curatorial endeavors and an informal focus on grass-roots, up-and-coming contemporary artists. This is all glad news for art lovers.

title: Can a Label Sum Up a Heritage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIGHTOWER, KEITH
description: HIGHTOWER--Keith. Of Madison, NJ on Thursday, September 2, 2004. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Romak), loving father of Sean, Brian, Kim and Kerry. Devoted son of Sully and Connie Hightower and dear brother of Dr. Martin Hightower and Mrs. Devie Shevlin. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral mass Tuesday 11 AM at St. Vincent Martyr Church, Madison. Interment St. Vincent's Cemetery, Madison. Visitation Monday 4-7 PM at the Madison Memorial Home, 159 Main St, Madison, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Vincent Martyr School Scholarship Fund, 26 Green Village Rd., Madison, NJ 07940 in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Dictionaries
description: A dictionary carries the same weight of authority as the U.S. Constitution or Newton's laws of motion -- or that's what many people seem to think. I wish they were right. But our dictionaries, like our language, are constantly in flux. And let's be honest: most lexicographers, or dictionary makers, aren't iconic figures like the founding fathers or Sir Isaac Newton. Not to give anyone the short end of the stick, but let's say that, on average, lexicographers are as smart and conscientious, as highly skilled and motivated, as physicians. For the most part they do meticulous work. But occasionally they forget to check your blood pressure. Or they fail to specify whether "wildlife" has a plural and, if so, whether it's "wildlives," like the plural of life, or "wildlifes," like the plural of still life.

title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann Dilworth, John Lathrop
description: Ann Evans Dilworth and John Lathrop were married yesterday at their home in Santa Fe, N.M. The Rev. Donald Hassemer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Colin P. Kelly III, also an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: A Portrait of the Dancer as a Young Man (in Pain)
description: IN lots of ways, Jordan Cohen is a typical 14-year-old. One of his favorite bands, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, is on his cellphone. After dinner, he watches Conan O'Brien reruns on Comedy Central. He's given to hyperbole: "That was the best pasta I've ever had in my whole life."

title: Midas Eyes Has Plenty After a Short Turnaround
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 4 - Bobby Frankel rarely runs a horse on 10 days of rest. When he does, there is usually a good reason.

title: 49ers Are Finding That This Cap Doesn't Fit
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif. - The Super Bowl trophies stand like sentries at the entrance to the San Francisco 49ers' offices, protectors of a franchise's legacy as one of the greatest in National Football League history. But the photos of the five locker-room celebrations that are also on display might as well be sepia-toned. The faces in those happy pictures -- Walsh, DeBartolo, Montana, Policy -- are as far removed from the current team as those victories, relegated to the scrapbook of past glories.

title: Can You Hear Me Now?
description: THREE years ago this week, when terrorists attacked, many New Yorkers found themselves unable to make a telephone call. Cellphone networks were clogged or went down, and many people lost even land-line service at home or in the office. Telephone communication was gridlocked except for pay phones, which became our lifelines.

title: A brand new museum, caves and 30,000-year-old art
description: Lodging and Restaurants

title: Deductions and Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Fun Takes the Reins At a Dude Ranch
description: HIGHLAND - IT does not take a wrangler to raise a child, but a wrangler could very well be the answer to vexed parents who want that child to join them in that most slow-paced of sports: gazing at the leaves that will begin to turn candy colors later this month. In terms of tortures perpetrated on children by well-meaning moms and dads, family leaf-watching jaunts are tops on the list for the preteenage set, to say nothing of teenagers, with 1,237,463 separate reasons why such trips are boring and dumb. We'll just touch upon the top two, then quickly jump to a local solution.

title: Corrections
description: A byline on Aug. 15 for an article about 3 East 75th Street, a onetime mansion in which tenants were relocated during renovations, omitted the writer's middle name, and a note on the writer misspelled part of the title of her novel. She is Mary Pleshette Willis; the novel is "Papa's Cord," not "Chord."

title: Lost Cause
description: I do not believe in the curse; I do not lovingly anticipate pain. I root, live and breathe for the Red Sox to beat out the Yankees and win the division. Period.

title: Party Faithful
description: Correction Appended

title: Outsourcing Corner Offices
description: A gag popular with cartoonists -- replacing highly paid American executives with lower-cost foreign managers abroad -- is getting a little attention in the public policy realm.

title: The King of Nostalgia, and Maybe of Belleville
description: Belleville - I FIRST heard Danny Stiles on the radio one rainy, spring night. At the urging of a friend who knew my crooner taste in music, I tuned into his Saturday show on WNYC around 9 p.m. Mr. Stiles, who lives in Short Hills, calls himself the "King of Nostalgia," the "Vicar of Vintage," and on various radio stations -- WNYC (820 AM), WNSW (1430 AM) and WPAT (930 AM) -- you can hear him play pop standards and big band tunes performed by the likes of Frank Sinatra, Glenn Miller, Artie Shaw, Billie Holiday, Rudy Vallee and Fats Waller.

title: Introduction
description: Our cover article on the efforts of Ken Thigpen and Jewell Reed to make it as a family drew overwhelming support. Economic opportunity, readers said, was crucial. The Bush marriage initiative was criticized by some. Also: Born Democrats, baseball's great losers and Reverend Billy's converts.

title: Page Two: Aug. 29-Sept. 4; CASE DISMISSED
description: The Kobe Bryant sexual assault case, for all its sound and fury, ended with most of the questions it raised unanswered. The prosecutor in Eagle, Colo., dropped all charges against Mr. Bryant, a star basketball player for the Los Angeles Lakers, who had been accused of raping a woman last summer at a hotel near Vail. Mr. Bryant apologized to the woman, and admitted that what seemed like consensual sex to him might have been different for her. And the woman, whose name has never been officially released, will apparently continue with her civil suit, seeking financial damages against Mr. Bryant in Federal District Court in Denver. Kirk Johnson

title: Over 55 and Sticking Around
description: NEARLY three years ago, Michael and Karen Thaler took a hard look at their 33-year-old Dix Hills colonial: the kitchen needed updating, the sprinkler system leaked and appliances were on the blink.

title: Corrections
description: The L.I.@Work column last Sunday and a related picture caption misidentified the operator of the New Frontier Opportunity Center, a hiring hall in Glen Cove. It is run by La Fuerza Unida, a private group, not by the City of Glen Cove.

title: Birth of a Fashionista
description: THE first time it happened, I was changing her diaper. I don't remember her exact age, but she was already talking. Maybe a dozen words. As I reached for a new outfit, my daughter swatted it with her hand and said, "No!" A barely verbal child was telling me she didn't like the clothes I had picked out. She had her own sense of style.

title: Eve Kaplan, Christopher Walbrecht
description: Eve Selice Kaplan will be married today to Christopher Kenneth Walbrecht in Riverhead, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz will officiate at the farm of the bride's parents, Dr. Annette Hollander and Myron Kaplan, who also live in Englewood, N.J.

title: Showering a Madonna With Affection, Not Devotion
description: Today, few remnants survive of the little Italian neighborhood that once flourished in the section of the East Village bounded by Eighth Street, 14th Street, Avenue A and Second Avenue: Lanza's restaurant, Veniero's Pastry Shop, De Robertis Pasticceria -- and not much more.

title: New Designs Allow for Courtyards
description: UNTIL recently, courtyards -- landscaped areas that are walled for privacy -- have been a mainstay in the South and the West. Now, home-building professionals say, new homes farther north are increasingly being configured so that a property owner can build a wall to turn a patio into a courtyard.

title: Pinot Noir in Two Guises
description: LONG ISLAND pinot noirs have been iffy over the years. A newcomer, the 2002 Tasting Room pinot noir, produced and bottled by Broadfields Wine Cellars, deserves soft applause. It's a spicy, gutsy, light-bodied little wine that hints at bigger possibilities and successors in subsequent warm vintages.

title: 58 Days to Go; Money: No Object
description: President George Bush and Senator John Kerry, with the two party committees that support them, have raised more than $1 billion in this year's race, and neither side is planning to close the cash register anytime soon.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Come Sun, Come Show

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 5, 2004
description: Weeks

title: 58 Days to Go; What Matters Now
description: FIRST it was going to be the $80 million in Republican television advertisements unloaded on Senator John Kerry this spring -- quickly matched by a barrage of television attacks dumped on President Bush by Democrats.

title: Homeland Security Funds: Is New York Getting Its Fair Share?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Consumers Accept
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Listings

title: Raising Kevion
description: Had we the will to lift this family out of poverty, the federal or state government would provide a mason's job for Ken, either by way of a public-works project or by enforcing antidiscrimination laws. Jewell would receive a real living wage for doing the work we claim to value but for which we pay little. Such solutions would require significant public spending, not unlike the expenditures for the G.I. Bill, which built America's white middle class. Advocating marriage for poor black families costs little, accomplishes nothing and blames the victims of enduring racism and sexism.

title: From Bathtub to Winery
description: NORTH SALEM - WHEN George Naumburg Jr. bought a patch of land here, he expected it to be a place to relax on weekends. He didn't anticipate that he would run it as Westchester's only commercial vineyard and winery.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the 'listed at' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Government by, for and Secret From the People
description: THE capital's worst-kept secret is out: the federal government is becoming even more secretive.

title: One Key to the State's Future? This Woman Says It's the Horse
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - KARYN MALINOWSKI'S path in life was most likely set by the time she was 7 or 8. That was when she took her first pony ride and began her lifelong fascination with horses.

title: Clubs' Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Shoot Two Brothers in Brooklyn
description: The police shot and wounded two brothers yesterday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, after warning one brother, who family members say has mental health problems, to drop a 10-inch knife with which he was threatening an ambulance crew.

title: Dead to Rights?
description: A friend and I disagree about an investment he wants to make. It involves buying (at a discount) the life insurance of terminally ill individuals who want proceeds from their policies before their demise. My friend sees this as helping the "victim" receive funds now. I see it as making money from someone's death. You? Stanley Farb, Jeffersonville, Pa. Your friend would indeed profit from someone's death -- as do morticians, limousine drivers and florists. That in itself is not discreditable, assuming he does not hasten that death (by, for instance, running someone over with the limo or bludgeoning him with a bouquet). You might better see that insurance policy as akin to any asset a person sells to raise cash: a car, a savings bond, a record collection. If you buy it at a fair price -- that ambiguous but significant term -- you do no wrong.

title: Grand Central in His Heart and on His Back
description: I LIKE Grand Central Terminal as much as the next guy. I admire its grandeur. I think they did a great job refurbishing it, and I'm grateful to Jackie Kennedy and the others who fought to prevent its demolition. But my admiration has its limits.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Page Two: Aug. 29-Sept. 4; The Nuclear Genie Pops Out Yet Again
description: THE South Koreans called it a "laboratory experiment," which it was, but of the sort that is often the first step toward making an atomic bomb.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 22 about two Merrill Lynch brokers, Valery and Janine Craane, who are accusing the firm of sex discrimination, misidentified the occupation and employer of Valery Craane's husband at his death. He was an accountant for the former Creole Petroleum Corporation, not an auditor at Arthur Andersen.

title: Bluejean Masterpiece
description: Levi's alife Custom 501's Levi's is up there with Coca-Cola and Nike as a company people refer to when they want to make a point about how pervasive a brand can be. So it's worth wondering what this household name is up to in deciding, after more than 150 years of existence, to forge its first-ever co-brand, the limited edition Levi's alife Custom 501's. There will be just 501 pairs, each in one of five colors, priced at $165 and available at exactly one store -- which itself will exist for just one month.

title: 'Only We Who Guard the Mystery Shall Be Unhappy'
description: PORTIONS of Tony Kushner's unfinished new play, "Only We Who Guard the Mystery Shall Be Unhappy," an argument against the Bush presidency and the current administration's foreign policy, have been presented to audiences around the country lately as parts of benefit evenings for liberal groups and to encourage community discussion. In the play's opening scene, Laura Bush reads to dead Iraqi children from Dostoyevsky's novel "The Brothers Karamazov." Last week, New York Theater Workshop presented three evenings of free readings from the play, with Holly Hunter as Laura Bush, Cynthia Nixon as the angel who introduces her to the children and Lisa Kron as the narrator. Last month, at a benefit in Manhattan for the liberal activist group MoveOn.org, John Cameron Mitchell read the part of Mrs. Bush, Patricia Clarkson was the angel and Kristen Johnston the narrator. Those three performers will repeat their roles on Oct. 17 at another MoveOn.org benefit reading of the script, this time in the Great Hall at Cooper Union.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCENOW/NYC A More than 160 artists will perform over the course of the festival. Wed., 7: Opening performance and party, the Center, 208 West 13th Street. Thur., 9:30; Fri., 7 and 9:30: Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street at Astor Place. Next Sun., 3: Marcus Garvey Park Amphitheater, 122nd Street & Mount Morris Park West. (718) 850-2488. www.dancenownyc.org. Through Sept. 18.

title: Outgrowing the Home Office
description: WORKING from home went well for Michael Friedman as long as he worked alone. Then, as his one-man public relations business grew, he seriously considered hiring an employee.

title: For Civil Court
description: There are some good candidates running in this year's handful of contested races for New York City Civil Court. As usual, though, there is also a host of less promising contenders, at least some of whom are likely to win elevation to the bench in the low-visibility judicial races occurring this season in Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUTCHIN, DESMOND
description: DUTCHIN--Desmond, died on August 30, 2004, at age 71, at his home in East Elmhurst, Queens. Beloved husband of Eunice Dutchin, father of Vanessa, Desmond Jr., and Darren. Grandfather of Kaitlyn and Jennifer. Brother of Lucious, Winston, Oliver, Emelda, Martin, Rhona and Salomon. Father-in-law of Yonette and Yolin Dutchin. Dear uncle, cousin and friend to so many. His sweet and loving presence, his modesty, kindness and generosity will be terribly missed. A mass of Christian burial was celebrated Saturday, September 4, 2004. Donations in his memory to The American Heart Association are welcome.

title: The Real Joke
description: To the Editor:

title: With Polls on the Move, Bush and Kerry Take Their Economic Message to Ohio
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Sept. 4 - Fortified by new polls showing him with a clear lead over Senator John Kerry, President Bush talked of economic renewal and tried to blunt Democratic attacks on his economic record as both he and Mr. Kerry campaigned Saturday across northeastern Ohio.

title: 'Heir to the Glimmering World': Sects and the City
description: HEIR TO THE GLIMMERING WORLD By Cynthia Ozick. 310 pp. Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LISSAUER, JANET M.
description: LISSAUER--Janet M. 9/6/03. Mom, a year has passed and we miss your humor, strength and courage. You remain an inspiration to us. Thank you for so many rich memories. You still make us laugh and we think of you each day. We were blessed with your love and devotion. Love, Phyllis and Ladd

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 15 about a train trip to Machu Picchu in Peru referred incorrectly to the accessibility of the Inca ruins there. Hikers who camp overnight on the Inca Trail can reach the site by sunrise; it is not necessary to stay at the guest lodge nearby to do so.

title: Can a Label Sum Up a Heritage?
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Correction Appended

title: Raising Kevion
description: Jason DeParle's fine article clamors for a happier ending. Isn't there one construction company in all of Milwaukee that would hire Ken as a mason? With a decent paying job, he can marry Jewell and continue his admirable struggle to do the right thing. Keep us informed, please.

title: A Convention for Carnivores
description: My viewing pleasure of last week's Republican convention was slightly compromised by my television's autonomous and irrevocable decision to activate the Spanish-language closed-captioning feature. Frustrating as this initially was, it provided moments of multicultural illumination, as when Senator Zell Miller was identified as "Senador Molinero del Zell," and Senator Olympia Snowe became "Senador Nieve de Olympia." Chris Matthews's comment that Rudolph Giuliani had just given a red-meat speech was rendered as "una habla de carne roja." And the chant "Four more years!" which on the 100th utterance begins to sound as if Leni Riefenstahl is filming the occasion, seems charming and even invigorating when spelled out in the language of Cervantes: "Cuatro ms aos!"

title: Don't Tell Anyone, but There's This Rich Joke Going Around . . .
description: WEALTHY people teach their offspring early not to tell other children that they're rich. They prefer euphemisms, like "we're comfortable." Now, New Jersey is going to have to do the same thing.

title: Scarsdale Ponders How to Build a Better Garage
description: Scarsdale officials are asking developers to come up with ideas for a mixed-use downtown parking garage, in hopes of putting to rest a long debate about the garage and its effect on the village.

title: Rock, Paper, Scissors: High Drama in the Tournament Ring
description: MY opponent and I faced each other across the white lines, separated by an arm's length in the dark, smoky bar. He planted his feet firmly, shoulder-width apart, while I fell into a fighting stance, right foot forward -- a natural response from years of tae kwon do. The referee stood between us. The crowd looked on expectantly.

title: Homeland Security Funds: Is New York Getting Its Fair Share?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Sunday for a picture of a mannequin head used in the acoustic modeling of rooms, with an article about acoustical design, omitted the photographer's name. He was Andre Constantini; an engineering firm, Arup, provided the picture.

title: Ilana Kobrin, David Prager
description: Ilana Rachel Kobrin, the daughter of Dr. Nancy H. Kobrin and Dr. Jerry L. Kobrin of Mendota Heights, Minn., is to be married today to David William Prager, the son of Dora Binder Levin of Little Rock, Ark., and Nathan I. Prager of Memphis. Rabbi Rafael Grossman is to officiate at Peavey Plaza in Minneapolis.

title: Casinohampton
description: Next on the docket in the court of ironic justice: Shinnecock Indian Nation v. Hamptons.

title: An Elegant 1920's Building at an Unshowy Address
description: ROSARIO CANDELA'S 1929 design for the apartment house at 133 East 80th Street is as good as any of his luxury buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues -- but it is nestled on homely little Lexington. A cleaning program is under way that reveals its unusual details -- and also shows some of the problems presented in renovating even one of the best buildings of the 1920's.

title: Mercedes's Baby SL Builds Up Its Muscles
description: TESTED: 2005 Mercedes-Benz SLK350 WHAT IS IT? Sporty two-seater with a retractable hardtop. HOW MUCH? Starts at $46,220. WHAT'S DIFFERENT? Guy-friendly styling; a new 268-horsepower dual-cam V-6. HOW QUICK? Zero-to-60 m.p.h. in 5.4 seconds (manufacturer's estimate). ALTERNATIVES: Audi TT 3.2, BMW Z4 3.0i, Porsche Boxster

title: Owens for Congress
description: The primary contest for the 11th Congressional District seat, which covers a large swath of Brooklyn from Brownsville to Park Slope, has become a heated one, thanks largely to the announcement by the Democratic incumbent, Representative Major R. Owens, that this would be his last race. Instead of a solitary victory lap, he faces a strong challenge from two City Council members, both of them his former protges.

title: The Political Brain
description: It is interesting to note that inhibited functioning of the amygdala, in addition to being a predictor of Republican loyalty, has also been linked to another brain disorder: autism.

title: Seeking Betsey
description: To the Editor: I have found reading R.W. Apple Jr.'s articles akin to viewing a Hirschfeld drawing. Rather than looking for and counting the Ninas, I count the paragraphs until I find the quote, "my wife, Betsey." It's fun.

title: Carrie Cannon, Tadd Wessel
description: Carrie Brown Cannon, the daughter of Carol Ann Cannon of Moultrie, Ga., and the late Charles Henry Cannon III, is to be married today to Tadd Seaton Wessel, a son of Elizabeth Seaton Hoffman of Bellbrook, Ohio, and John Richard Wessel of St. Croix, V.I. The Rev. Richard E. Turner Sr., a United Methodist minister, is to officiate at Camp Merrie-Woode, a summer camp near Cashiers, N.C., that the bride's family has attended for three generations.

title: Surprise Over A Guilty Plea And a Sentence
description: UNTIL the word "guilty" actually came out of Jefferson B. Davis's mouth, people who knew him simply could not believe that he had harmed a young boy. Not Jeff Davis. Not a man who had worked in Hartford to preserve farmland as it rapidly disappeared, who took a lead role in making sure the towns of Northeastern Connecticut were not forgotten in the Legislature, whose liberal views did not seem to bother the Republican district that voted him into office six times.

title: Battleground Art: Revisiting the Culture Wars in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI - IT's hard to imagine a better time or place than this election year and the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati to mount the exhibition "Crimes and Misdemeanors: Politics in U.S. Art of the 1980's." What more symbolic venue could there be for a show about yesteryear's culture wars? It was the Contemporary, after all, that was besieged in 1990 when its then director, Dennis Barrie, was hauled into county court for "pandering obscenity" after showing Robert Mapplethorpe's homoerotic photographs.

title: U.S. Gets a Victory; El Salvador Gets Angry
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. 4 - A dominant United States team collected a 2-0 victory in a World Cup qualifying match Saturday as El Salvador struggled with the American attack and international soccer rules regarding the wearing of jewelry.

title: Wrecked Russian School Is Opened to Public
description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 5 A Shafts of light passed through the bullet holes in the pupils desks, which had been stacked at windows, makeshift barricades against attack. Grisly scenes awaited behind them.

title: A Wave of Photos Of Faces Still Missed
description: THE anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001, will be observed by the unveiling of the Flag of Remembrance, a 20-by-27-foot American flag composed of the names and photographs of World Trade Center victims. The flag was created by Mindy Kombert and Sherry Kronenfeld, Chappaqua residents who suspended their graphic design business after the terrorist attacks to devote time to the project.

title: Warmth Was Wanted; Instead, Putin's Chilly Responses Darken the Political Clouds
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4 - President Vladimir V. Putin broke his two-day silence on the wrenching siege of Middle School No.1 when he flew Saturday to Beslan, a small city in southern Russia, but his first public remarks -- "Today all Russia suffers for you" -- made briefly, before dawn, were addressed to the region's president and leaders of its security agencies, not to those who suffered most.

title: 58 Days to Go; Early Voting: Florida Factor
description: The concept of a single national Election Day is quickly becoming a thing of the past.

title: 'War and the American Presidency': Dire Conclusions
description: WAR AND THE AMERICAN PRESIDENCY By Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. 160 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95.

title: PHOTO-OP
It's a Win-Win Outcome After a 2-Sport Doubleheader
description: ORGANIZERS of both the Buick Championship golf tournament in Cromwell and the Pilot Pen Tennis tournament in New Haven were satisfied with the turnout at their near simultaneous tournaments, despite some unexpected obstacles.

title: Your Board Can Ban Political Placards
description: YOU own a co-op or a condo. You want to make sure your voice is heard this November, so you put a poster for your favorite candidate in your living room window or on your front lawn. But your board says no signs are allowed. You wonder, Haven't these people heard about the First Amendment?

description: "I want it!" "No." "All my friends have it!" "No." "You're the worst parent in the world!" "Granted." "But I'll pay for it." "O.K. Do you know how much it costs?" "Uh, no."

description: ONLY in an election year ruled by fiction could a sissy who used Daddy's connections to escape Vietnam turn an actual war hero into a girlie-man.

title: Shelter For Shoulders
description: Designers have tweaked the poncho in a variety of ways for fall, offering alternatives that are less flimsy and more interesting than the crocheted style seen everywhere this summer. Here are some of the season's best variations on a theme.

title: San Cristbal Is Emerging From the Mist
description: THE taxi driver crosses himself as we enter the winding two-lane highway and start to rise out of San Cristbal de las Casas into the clouds. We look out the windows in silence, the first pangs of post-vacation blues creeping in.

description: Correction Appended

title: Another Marathon, Another Victory
description: Sargis Sargsian covered his eyes and rolled flat onto his back. If he had stayed in that position and taken a nap, no one at the National Tennis Center would have blamed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGERS, HARRY PETER
description: ROGERS--Harry Peter. Beloved husband of Louise G. Rogers. Died Thursday evening in New York City from complications of a stroke. He was 90 years old. He served as a Lieutenant in the Navy during World War II and had retired from Con Edison in 1979 after serving as a Mechanical Engineer for forty years. He was the father of Gordon Rogers, like a father to Victoria Leacock and is survived by his wife and his brother Eugene Rogers and his family.

title: Ghosts of El Morocco
description: FOR many years, my family maintained an apartment on East 48th Street in Manhattan, from which my benevolent Uncle Len, who raised me from childhood, would often dart out in the night.

title: In the Berkshires
description: Few places have more local color than the Berkshires in autumn. Soon after the last notes of the Tanglewood season fade into the trees, the trees themselves become the main attraction from one end of Berkshire County to the other. Sugar, red and moosewood maples; gray, white, yellow, black and river birches; oaks and sassafras -- an astonishing mix of trees -- dapple the landscape in dazzling reds, yellows, oranges and purples.

title: New Voices Blend In And Pay Off at Caramoor
description: THE summer season has ended at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts here, a season of New Yorker cartoon advertisements, Czech accents and a youthful new general director, Michael Barrett, who has begun to nudge the 59-year-old Katonah institution ever so gently in new directions.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Mazdaspeed Miata and Honda S2000; In Hot Pursuit of an Endless Summer
description: IT is a familiar problem in the car business: a once-revolutionary model has been around so long that it no longer generates much excitement in the showroom. But the bean counters in the executive suite remain determined to wring still more revenue from the aging design.

title: Jennifer Katz, Evan Lipson
description: Jennifer Lynn Katz, the daughter of Kay Jacobs Katz of Rockville, Md., and the late Dr. Barry Stephen Katz, was married last evening to Evan Jacob Lipson, the son of Frank Lipson of Potomac, Md., and the late Helaine Orkin Lipson. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig performed the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation in Potomac, Md.

description: WEIS--Gertrude. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted, longtime and founding member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Amy Lemle, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

description: Jonathan Dee's article on Reverend Billy was delightful (Aug. 22). I was reminded of the Guerrilla Girls, another wonderfully creative group.

description: Florida officials ordered the largest evacuation in state history as another storm approached, less than a month after Hurricane Charley battered communities that had not anticipated being in its path.

description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 4 - RUTGERS 19, MICHIGAN STATE 14

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We have to admit that we failed to recognize the complexity and danger of the processes going on in our country and the world as a whole. At any rate, we failed to react to them adequately. We demonstrated our weakness, and the weak are beaten."

title: Global Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: A Phone Venture: Calling All Prisoners
description: BRIAN PRINS's motto is this: One man's monopoly is another man's opportunity. After being released from prison in May 2002, the first thing he did was to make a business of pulling customers from under MCI's exclusive control of New York States prison phone system.

title: Under the Spell of Quetzalcatl
description: FROM my hotel window on my first morning in Tepoztln, I took in the soaring volcanic peaks where Quetzalcatl, the brilliantly plumed Aztec dragon god, is said to have been born. In the blue-green valley that is part of this central Mexico town stood a 16th-century cathedral with ivory-colored spires. To the left, the sun was rising over the broad cliff wall of Sierra del Tepozteco, striated with spectacular sandstone eaves upon which an ancient temple was perched, and which appeared and disappeared behind the drifting morning fog.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Suffering Effects of 50's A-Bomb Tests
description: EMMETT, Idaho, Aug. 31 - In the 1950's and early 1960's, at the height of the cold war, people in this southwestern Idaho town thought what they occasionally saw dusting their fruit orchards and cow pastures was frost -- only it was not cold to the touch, several longtime residents said. Others described it as a gray-white powder that seemed to come out of nowhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, ESTHER
description: FRIEDMAN--Esther, on September 2, 2004, sister of Morris, sister-in-law of Norma and of Philip and Ruth. We will miss her. Services Sunday, September 5th, 2PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY.
