description: KEMPNER--Ivan, MD. 18 Elul and loved, missed, remembered. Wife Arline & daughters Robbi, Juli, Lani

title: Paperback Fiction
Samantha Scharff, Aaron Kopelowitz
description: Samantha Jacalyn Scharff, the daughter of Sandra and Irving Scharff of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Aaron Howard Kopelowitz, a son of Rochelle and Martin Kopelowitz of East Meadow, N.Y. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at Capitale, the party space in Manhattan.

title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Change Africa's Borders
description: To the Editor:

title: Why the Dying Richard Strauss Couldn't Get Enough of 'Daphne'
description: ON June 11, 1949, his 85th birthday, Richard Strauss performed at his piano for the last time. A camera crew was filming a short documentary on him ("A Life for Music"), and the director asked him to play an excerpt from a long life's work. One's head spins at the possibilities -- more than 200 songs, many tone poems, 15 operas. Would he choose something from "Don Juan" or "Der Rosenkavalier"?

title: Short Stories: Anxiety Attacks
description: It's been 40 years since Richard Hofstadter diagnosed the "paranoid style" in American politics, conveniently handing fiction writers a useful tool for making some of their crazier characters seem prescient. From the Warren Report and Vietnam through Watergate and the war on terror, the cognitive dissonance between what we suspect to be true and what we're told is true leads, predictably, to anxiety. And for candid snapshots of an anxious people, there's no better place to look than the newest wave of short fiction to emerge in the post-9/11 era.

title: A Young Gun in Politics, All He's Missing Is a Race
description: Anton Konev, a 20-year-old State Assembly aide, performs multiple duties for the campaign he is working on: answering the phone, collecting signatures, forming policy positions, thinking up a name for the party. That is hardly surprising, because Mr. Konev is not only the campaign chairman and the press secretary but also the candidate.

title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Flying to Tinian
description: To the Editor: Regarding "A Ghost in the Jungle" (Aug. 8), one way to reach Tinian without flying to Japan is to fly from Guam. Continental Micronesia offers daily flights between Honolulu and Guam (7 hours 30 minutes). From Guam, Pacific Island Aviation, a Northwest Airlines affiliate, schedules four daily flights to Saipan (50 minutes) using 27-passenger turboprops. On some days, Pacific Island Aviation has a Saipan-Tinian-Guam flight, so it's easily possible to make a stopover on Tinian. The flight time from Saipan to Tinian is only 12 minutes. Saipan and Tinian are part of the Commonwealth of the Northern Marianas. United States citizens need only proof of citizenship; visas are not required.

title: 'Canes Are All the Rage
description: This week, college football breaks new ground. Florida State will face Miami on Friday night -- a game originally scheduled to take the Monday night spotlight on ABC before Hurricane Frances came along. That ABC picked Florida State versus Miami, while the traditional powerhouses Notre Dame, Alabama and Penn State enter the season unranked, tells you everything you need to know about the transfer of power over the past 25 years. That Miami and Florida State will be representing the Atlantic Coast Conference, once known exclusively for basketball showdowns on Tobacco Road, tells you even more.

title: Views of Foliage Are Vermont Appetizer
description: The eight-minute gondola ride up Mount Mansfield -- at 4,395 feet, Vermont's highest peak -- is a popular fall excursion for those seeking a megadose of foliage. But on two upcoming weekends, the gondola will also carry those seeking a chance to dine while enjoying the views.

title: The Making of An Xbox Warrior
description: After reading Clive Thompson's article on video games like Full Spectrum Warrior (Aug. 22), I was amazed at the extent to which the military is willing to invest in procuring the technical support needed to develop such a recruiting and training tool.

title: Canada Tops Russia to Stay Unbeaten in World Cup
description: TORONTO, Sept. 4 - Playing in its homeland with a blend of skilled experience, ambitious youth and world-class goaltending, Canada has been the best team in the World Cup of Hockey. A 3-1 victory over Russia on Saturday night at the Air Canada Center gave Canada the only three-game sweep among eight teams in the preliminary round.

title: The Fall Hunt Is On at Arrowhead
description: RIVER FALLS, Wis. - As an icebreaker for the young and the uninitiated, Kansas City Chiefs guard Will Shields invited linemen Chris Bober, Brett Williams and Jordan Black to go turkey hunting during the off-season on land Shields owns on the Missouri-Kansas border. Shields, the longest-tenured member of the Chiefs and a nine-time Pro Bowl selection, had two admonitions for the greenhorns.

title: Correction
description: An illustration last Sunday depicting recently stolen artworks wanted by Interpol, the international police agency, misattributed a sculpture listed by the agency's New Delhi office and misstated the date of its disappearance. It was by an unknown artist, not by Fernando Botero, and it was stolen in December 2003, not in 2004.

title: Finding Real Paradise in Historic Charlestown
description: Correction Appended

title: Summertime Blues
description: I AM spending Labor Day at my house, yet I still have the feeling that it is time to "go home." For me, this weekend is always a poignant portal between summer and the rest of life. Now the difference is mostly a state of mind, but there was a time when the change was literal and abrupt. I had to leave a place I loved completely and return to a more complicated, demanding world. It was a hard transition, and I still carry that sense of dislocation within me at this time of year. I wanted summer to last forever and dreaded going home. Now, I still mind summer's end, but I find that missing the past helps me appreciate where I am.

title: Bounce Back and Race Ahead
description: IN THE 1950's, I played basketball for the College of William and Mary. In my junior year, the team was traveling to the University of Pennsylvania for a game when the station wagon I was riding in got hit head-on.

title: Hoping That a Bar Doesn't Live Up to Its Name
description: What's in a letter?

title: Sticking to the Script
description: To the Editor:

title: Working Your Way Down
description: As they so often do, economic reality and political expediency parted ways with the release of August's employment report on Friday. The reality is that unless President Bush pulls nearly one million jobs out of a hat in the next four months, he will indeed become the first president since Herbert Hoover to preside over a decline in employment in a single term in the White House. But Mr. Bush is determined to act as if nothing bad is happening on, as he likes to put it, "my watch." And so in his first appearance after the Republican National Convention -- in a corner of the sliver of undecided America -- he declared that the numbers showed that the economy is "spreading prosperity and opportunity and nothing will hold us back."

title: From a Yarn Spinner, Variations for Minimalist Strings
description: Bridgehampton - BELIEVE me, I don't usually steal from art galleries. But visiting an exhibition of Fred Sandback's prints at the Dan Flavin Art Institute here, I accidentally bundled into my papers a display copy of a pamphlet printed for one of Mr. Sandback's exhibitions in Winchendon, Mass., in 1982. I've since returned it to the institute with a groveling note of apology, but not before noticing, among the opening pages, a brief artist's statement.

title: Putin Tells the Russians: 'We Shall Be Stronger'
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4 - Following is a transcript of President Vladimir V. Putin's televised remarks at the Kremlin on Saturday night, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Tasting the Apple, and Liking It
description: Jan Sweeney, a delegate from St. Paul, seems like the kind of steadfast Republican who would go through Hades itself to support her president, but she was not so sure about New York. Ms. Sweeney eventually decided to risk it, but first she put her affairs in order.

title: A Change of Scene
description: There are plenty of shocks in DECEPTION (Little, Brown, $23.95), which is only to be expected from an elegantly engineered novel of psychological suspense. But the most surprising thing about this subtle depiction of a disintegrating yuppie marriage is the person who wrote it: Denise Mina, an author admired for her bleak views of Glasgow's criminal underbelly.

title: Free Fall Continues: Mets Lose 8th Straight
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 - About the only thing the Mets have accomplished in the last month is to put their manager's job in jeopardy.

title: Security Deposit on Regulated Rental
description: Q We have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment for the last 29 years. Our lease just expired, and our landlord refuses to give us our copy of the new lease unless we pay additional security of $403.01.

title: Democrats Urge Kerry to Turn Up Intensity of Campaign
description: President Bush roared out of his New York convention last week, leaving many Democrats nervous about the state of the presidential race and pressing Senator John Kerry to torque up what they described as a wandering and low-energy campaign.

title: Clinton Hill, Brooklyn: It All Started With the House
description: ON a late August afternoon, the cream- and chocolate-colored facade of 401 Clinton Avenue in Brooklyn offered an elegant and impassive front, like a Southern lady of a certain age dozing on her front porch. With all her accessories perfectly preserved -- the opalescent stained glass made by a Tiffany competitor, John LaFarge; the turned wood spines of the parlor archways; the Gothic plaster ceiling in the dining room; the gleaming mahogany paneling and mantels -- it was hard to imagine that much goes on in this museum.

title: Reverend Billy's Unholy War
description: More people organize their day to shop on Sunday than to go to church. Coached by ads, we are taught that the things we buy can transform us. Our much-vaunted freedom is mostly exercised by the choice we have in the cereal aisle of our supermarket!

title: Corrections
description: The Postings column last Sunday about the conversion of a teachers union headquarters at 260 Park Avenue South into condominiums misidentified the architect. He is Karl Fischer; Shamir Shah is the interior designer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COLUMBO, RUSS
description: COLUMBO--Russ. 70 years have passed since that fateful day, Sept 2, 1934, yet your voice lingers on. International Russ Columbo Fan Club Harvey Gittler, President Oberlin, OH

title: Nicole Jaeger, Daniel Erlij
description: Nicole Elise Jaeger, the daughter of Shelley Holstein of Eureka, Calif., and Richard Jaeger of Berkeley, Calif., is to be married today to Daniel Mordecai Erlij, the son of David and Sarah Erlij of Brooklyn. Rabbi Brian Schuldenfrei is to officiate at the Wattles Mansion in Los Angeles.

title: Cal Earns High Marks on the Field
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 4 - CALIFORNIA 56, AIR FORCE 14

title: PASSION FOR PORSCHE
description: When Gary C. Kelly was named chief executive of Southwest Airlines this summer, almost every article mentioned that he drives a red 1998 Porsche 911 sports car. This was no midlife crisis toy for Mr. Kelly, who is 50, but the culmination of a boyhood desire. His father worked for a Porsche retailer and wholesaler in San Antonio, and Mr. Kelly grew up around the cars. "They say every boy loves cars, and I grew up loving Porsches," he said last week. Micheline Maynard

title: The Redeemer
description: I. Cannes: The Slow Drive to Triumph Stuck in traffic in a black sedan on his way to the Palais des Festivals for the Cannes International Film Festival premiere of his new movie, 'Bad Education,' Pedro Almodvar seemed, as he often does, both anxious and curious. He fidgeted, he fussed. When he rolled down the window, the paparazzi, who were walking three-deep alongside the slow-moving car, screamed at him: 'Pedro! Pedro!' and cut off his view of the street, where his image was plastered on walls and where fans waited to mob him. He strained to see past all this. He was intrigued by what one woman in the crowd was wearing, by the relationship -- which was what, exactly? -- between two men eating ice cream. He was looking for details, a hint of narrative, the movie.

title: 'Secrets of the Soul': Is Psychoanalysis Science or Is It Toast?
description: SECRETS OF THE SOUL A Social and Cultural History of Psychoanalysis. By Eli Zaretsky. Illustrated. 429 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Celebrating the Bridge No One Wants to Sell
description: JUST upriver from the Brooklyn Bridge, there stands a big blue structure that gets remarkably less attention and respect than its famous neighbor. Yet even though the Manhattan Bridge is regarded by New Yorkers as little more than a less congested route over the East River, it is no historical lightweight.

title: Eight Days a Week
description: WITH its pharmacopeia of teas, powders, pills and soothing cinnamon candles, Hugh Jackman's dressing room at the Imperial Theater is little more than a pit stop for his eight-times-a-week endurance marathon. Singing in 20 of the 27 numbers in "The Boy From Oz," he is onstage for all but three or four minutes. Critics reviewing the opening last October were glad of his omnipresence, applauding his Broadway debut as the flamboyant performer and songwriter Peter Allen, while panning almost everything else about the show, especially its schematic and sometimes cringe-inducing book. But Mr. Jackman's charm made the production (which improved with time) a hit anyway; when it closes next Sunday, after 32 previews and 365 regular performances, it will have recouped its initial investment of $8.25 million on gross ticket sales of more than $42 million. Astonishingly, when Mr. Jackman sat down for a conversation a few weeks before closing, he had not missed even one of those performances, a feat that gave him, he said, a masochistic thrill but had also taken its toll. Two hours before a Friday night curtain, when he should have been eating his dinner, he talked about what the experience had meant, and done, to him. JESSE GREEN

title: Homeland Security Funds: Is New York Getting Its Fair Share?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Heir to the Glimmering World'
description: In 1935, when I was just eighteen, I entered the household of RudolfMitwisser, the scholar of Karaism. "The scholar of Karaism"- at thattime I had no idea what that meant, or why it should be "the" instead of"a," or who Rudolf Mitwisser was. I understood only that he was the fatherof what seemed to be numerous children, and that he had comefrom Germany two years before. I knew these things from an advertisementin the Albany Star:

title: Online Alerts For Airport Lines
description: For fliers worried about the long lines that can form while passengers fumble with their shoes, pocket change and belts, the Transportation Security Administration has a new feature on its Web site that lets passengers look up security checkpoint waiting times at airports in the United States.

title: A Graceful Exit to Greener Pastures
description: Q. You've landed a fabulous new job -- don't they all start out that way? -- so it's time to resign and leave your current cubicle cloister. How do you quit with class and preserve the relationships you've built at your soon-to-be-former company?

description: DARIEN, Ill. - Students are returning to classes across the nation amid a cacophony of contradictory messages about the quality of their education, as thousands of schools with vaunted reputations have been rated in recent weeks as low-performing under a federal law.

title: The Right Approach Can Keep Joy in Mudville
description: In the last several weeks youth baseball has received a lot of attention, and I think that is great.

title: Page Two: Aug. 29-Sept. 4; UNCOVERED
description: In France, a legal ban on Islamic head scarves and other religious symbols in public schools took effect largely without incident, despite a demand by the kidnappers of two French journalists in Iraq that the law be rescinded.

The Rev. Winston Bath, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Hudson.

title: McGreevey Stays Put, and Intrigue Builds
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3 - Gov. James E. McGreevey's uncharted, uncertain journey toward resignation reached two important milestones in recent days, yet with each new fact that emerged, the entire ordeal seemed to grow more puzzling.

title: INSIDE
description: A Day of Attacks in Iraq A car bombing yesterday at a police academy in northern Iraq killed 17 people, while near Mosul, a battle left at least 13 Iraqis dead. Above, a firefighter watched a sabotaged pipeline near the major Kirkuk oil center. PAGE 18

title: THE GUIDE
description: A Political Canvas

title: Low-Profile Republicans? How About No Profile?
description: As Republicans staged their skillfully choreographed national convention in Manhattan, there were moments when it appeared as though the entire New Jersey delegation might have been whisked off to the undisclosed bunker where Dick Cheney hunkered down in the months after 9/11.

title: Education is on the Horizon
description: COMBINE a love for sailing and a doctorate in education and what do you get? The new captain of the schooner Amistad, which is based in New Haven. Eliza N. Garfield, a Manhattan native, Harvard graduate and experienced sailor, took command of the ship this summer and hopes to get students more involved with the ship.

title: The Next Shock: Not Oil, but Debt
description: WITH oil prices hovering above $40 a barrel, experts have calmed frayed nerves by noting that today's services-driven American economy is much less addicted to the black stuff than yesterday's industrial economy. From 1973 to 2003, after all, the amount of oil and gas needed to create a dollar of gross domestic product fell by half. Structural changes in the economy have let the nation absorb the recent shock of rising crude.

title: Katrina Fischer, Michael Kuh
description: Katrina Louisa Fischer, the daughter of Elizabeth and Peter Fischer of Washington, is to be married today to Michael Joseph Kuh, the son of Joyce and Richard Kuh of New York. Justice Felice K. Shea, who is retired from State Supreme Court in New York, is to officiate at the Yale Club in New York.

title: A Global War: Many Fronts, Little Unity
description: WHETHER or not the war on terror is winnable, it can determine who wins an election. President Bush went back and forth on the first question last week, but was relentless in setting a drastic paradigm for the November vote, portraying the election as a historic choice between a wobbly Democrat whose indecision could bring cataclysm and his own unwavering direction in America's hour of need.

title: Amy Solomonson, Colin Miner
description: Amy Elise Solomonson and Colin Daniel Miner are to be married today at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park in New York. Rabbi Adele Agin will perform the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Raising Kevion
description: The problems are not cultural, as the government's plan to promote marriage would suggest. The problems are economic and social. Black men don't suffer from an inherent inability to love their women and children. They have been conditioned to flee by a nation that has systematically limited their educational and employment opportunities.

description: Former President Bill Clinton on Friday checked into New York-Presbyterian Hospital, where he was expected to undergo heart bypass surgery.

description: PRACTICING for a grand circus finale, Dina Moustafa, 14, of Manhasset climbed to the top of a human pyramid made up of her bunkmates at Camp Adventure on Shelter Island.

title: 'Judging Thomas'
description: In the summer of 1955 Clarence Thomas left his mother'stenement in Savannah, clutching a brown paper shopping bagstuffed with everything he owned. The seven-year-old walkedwith his mother and younger brother, Myers, who carried hisown paper bag. The abrupt departure came with no warning andlittle explanation from his mother. They were going to livewith their grandparents, she told them. She would see themwhen she could, she said. Having seen his grandfather onlyonce in his life, Clarence knew almost nothing about the manwho was suddenly to be his guardian. He regarded MyersAnderson as some kind of god, a rich man who lived in a bighouse and owned both a car and a truck.

title: Running Mate
description: Q:In the past few weeks, you've been traveling around the country by yourself to campaign for the Kerry-Edwards ticket. What's that like?

description: YOU'D think John Kerry could be excused for wanting to spend a summer afternoon on the water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPLEWICZ, ROMA
description: KOPLEWICZ--Roma, 85. Beloved wife, friend and lover of Joseph for 62 years. Devoted mother to Edith, Harold and Linda. Adoring grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. Loyal and caring friend and dedicated social worker died August 31st. After surviving the horrors of the Holocaust, she was reunited with her Joe and together they lived life to its fullest. Her extraordinary "joie de vivre" will live on in her friends and family. Donations may be made to Roma and Joseph Koplewicz fund at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Pl, SW, Washington, DC 20024

title: Duke Ellington, Piano Man
description: JILL SCOTT -- Probably the only lyricist ever to proclaim, "I am not afraid to be glutinous," Jill Scott eases between confession and manifesto on "Beautifully Human: Words and Sounds Vol. 2" (Hidden Beach). As she explores lust and loyalty -- promising fidelity in one song, admitting an affair in another -- Ms. Scott and her collaborators combine easygoing vamps and her airy, playful voice in tracks that are poised between monologue and song. The tunes snap into focus when, every so often, she proffers a full-fledged refrain, and even when she doesn't, she knows how to draw a listener into her ruminations.

title: Putin Says Russia Faces Full 'War' to Divide Nation
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4 - In a rare address to his nation, coming at a time of grave crisis, President Vladimir V. Putin said Saturday that the school siege in the southern city of Beslan was an attack on all of Russia and called for the mobilization of society to resist what he called "a total and full-scale war" to splinter the country.

title: Somber Museum
description: To the Editor: We too were left with somber thoughts when we visited the Nissim de Camondo Museum, as Alice Steinbach did ("Past, Prologue and Paris," Aug. 15). But ours were quite different from hers.

description: THE weather is bad at your intended destination and the plane is diverted. Soon you find yourself on the ground closer to home than to the plane's original destination. Can you get off and make your way from there?

description: A group of 11 homes known as Back to Backs, built in the early 19th century for the expanding workforce in Birmingham, 114 miles north of London, has been restored and opened to the public. The Birmingham Conservation Trust restored the buildings and The National Trust decorated the interiors with help from former residents, the local community and documents and photographs found in the houses. Some original features, like fireplaces and doors, have survived. Antiques were bought from fairs and local residents donated other pieces.

description: Mrs. Fields takes her chocolate chips sprinkled on pecan pie these days. And a caterer does the baking.

description: LABOR DAY has sneaked up on us, and the end of summer -- with its low, gray clouds -- beckons. But here are a couple exhibits that might let you hold onto summer a bit longer.

title: Hardcover Fiction
A Heated Dispute In Newark
description: NEWARK - ALMOST every building along the Mulberry Street corridor near City Hall here prominently displays signs protesting a proposed redevelopment plan. Some state, "Let's Build Tomorrow Together" or "Save Our Homes." Another series features a red circle with a slash slicing through the words "eminent domain abuse."

After devouring a bagel covered in lox, he leaned forward and launched into his favorite story from the Democratic presidential primaries.

title: Deploying Children as Weapons of Mass Affection

Arnold Schwarzenegger and the first lady, Laura Bush, on Tuesday. And of course, a father who had just been nominated for a second term as president of the United States.

title: QUICK BITE/Totowa; Rembrance of Breakfasts Past

It opened in 1965 as part of the long-defunct Aunt Jemima's Kitchen chain. Private ownership and the name change followed in 1973.

title: Dream Boat Proves Hard to Handle

He and the 36-foot boat, its Italian-imported brass fittings glittering in the morning sun, add a stunning silhouette to a landscape of kayaks, Jet Skis, and motorboats.

title: In Internet Calling, Skype Is Living Up to the Hype
description: HOW big a deal will Skype turn out to be? I have no idea whether the company itself, which was founded one year ago, will someday come to epitomize and dominate a particular booming business, the way Google, eBay and Amazon now do. But I feel confident that the service it provides will be attractive to most people who give it a serious look.

title: All God's Children
description: In a cinder-block classroom at the edge of Biola University's manicured campus in a Los Angeles suburb, Craig Detweiler was blasting the music of Nick Cave at his Intro to Mass Media class. Two dozen students were arranged in a horseshoe of swivel chairs, and they were looking blankly at a photo of Cave, a sullen goth-rocker, which Detweiler's laptop was projecting onto a pull-down screen.

title: Adrienne Abbate, Daniel Mackta

title: U.S. Low-Fare Airlines Branch Out Abroad
description: NOT long ago, traveling to winter vacation spots like the Bahamas and Mexico meant paying top prices on major airlines. Now, low-fare airlines are jumping in with new international service, hoping to steal customers from more established rivals just as they have in the United States.

title: Judges, Out in the Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, It Is a Mansion, So Pay the Tax
description: THE Gramercy Park co-op purchased by the young eye surgeon just three weeks ago has two spacious bedrooms, two and a half bathrooms and a large terrace with unobstructed views of the Empire State Building. It's quite nice by Manhattan standards, but few would confuse it for a mansion.

title: Danika Cleary, Mateusz Laszuk
description: Danika Jade Cleary and Mateusz Jakub Laszuk were married last evening at the Lighthouse, an event space in New York. Rabbi Rebecca Shinder performed the ceremony.

title: Ralph Nader Qualifies For Presidential Ballot
description: Ralph Nader has accumulated enough signatures on petitions to appear on the state ballot as an independent candidate for president this November, according to a spokesman for Secretary of State Susan Bysiewicz.

title: 'Secrets of the Soul'
description: In the modern West there have been two episodes of genuine,widespread introspection: Calvinism and Freudianism. In both casesthe turn inward accompanied a great social revolution: the rise ofcapitalism in the first, and its transformation into an engine ofmass consumption in the second. In both cases, too, the results wereironic. Calvinism urged people to look inside themselves todetermine whether they had been saved, but it wound up contributingto a new discipline of work, savings, and family life. Freudianintrospection aimed to foster the individual's capacity to live anauthentically personal life, yet it wound up helping to consolidateconsumer society. In both cases, finally, the turn towardself-examination generated a new language. In the case of Calvinism,the language centered on the Protestant idea of the soul, an ideathat helped shape such later concepts as character, integrity, andautonomy. The new Freudian lexicon, by contrast, centered on theidea of the unconscious, the distinctive analytic contribution totwentieth-century personal life.

title: Quiet Force Drives Bonds Toward No. 700
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 - On the way to home run history, Roger Maris lost clumps of hair. Hank Aaron went dizzy reading hate mail. Mark McGwire compared himself to a caged animal.

description: Lleyton Hewitt gave up Australian Rules Football at age 13 and became the youngest qualifier at the Australian Open by age 15. His athletic ability equals that of top-ranked Roger Federer, said the former Australian tennis star John Newcombe.

title: Depth of Planning by Rebels Is Evident in School's Remains
description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 5 A Inside the charred, bullet-pocked wreckage of Middle School No. 1 lies evidence of the terror Russia faces: two parts of the library's wooden floor had been pried up, evidently by the heavily armed attackers who seized the school and held 1,000 hostages for 52 hours.

title: A Week in Limbo, Till a Chill Bit the Air

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LISTON, DR. MARY FRANCES
description: LISTON--Dr. Mary Frances. Passed away on September 3, 2004 at St. Cabrini Nursing Home in Dobbs Ferry. Dr. Liston is survived by her sister Helen Hennessy of Scarsdale, NY and her niece Mary Ellen Hennessy-Jones of Madison, NJ. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours Sunday, 7-9, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583 (914-725-1137).

title: 58 Days to Go; The Debates
description: With the post-convention-poll-bounce thing now over (Senator John Kerry did not really get one; President Bush very likely did), it is time to start speculating about an arguably more important phenomenon: the post-debate poll bounce.

title: The Red Arrow
description: To the Editor: As a onetime passenger on the Red Arrow train between St. Petersburg and Moscow ("It's Russian for Luxe, Aug. 15), I enjoyed, a bit ruefully, Steven Lee Myers's report on this splendid service.

title: Jessica Wohl, Mark Weinraub
description: Jessica Nicole Wohl, a daughter of Susan and Carl Wohl of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married today to Mark Howard Weinraub, a son of Carole and Robert Weinraub of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Marvin Richardson is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: Rutgers Is Above .500
description: The Scarlet Knights, before a record Rutgers Stadium crowd, held on for a 19-14 victory over Michigan State. Rutgers needed four field goals from Jeremy Ito as it turned the tables on last season's loss to the Spartans. In Baton Rouge, La., Louisiana State rallied to force overtime, then won, 22-21, after Oregon State failed to convert an extra point for the third time.

title: Page Two: Aug. 29-Sept. 4; A BARRIER BREACHED
description: Israelis were just beginning to relax. A combination of good intelligence and the growing West Bank separation barrier seemed to have stopped Palestinian terrorism inside Israel. But on Tuesday, the last shopping day before the first day of school, two suicide bombers from Hebron blew up two buses barely a minute apart in the Negev city of Beersheba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAGUNA, LAWRENCE
description: LAGUNA--Lawrence. Awardwinning architect, of Oceanside, NY on September 1. Who's Who in America; AIA. Beloved husband of 61 years to noted American artist, Mariella Laguna. Proud father of Kenny and wife Meryl; Sanford and wife Hillary. Grandfather to Carianne, Peri, Nicky and Chad. A gifted and humble man who will be greatly missed.

title: Under This Tent, a Tuneup for the Soul
description: There are no set rules to staging a tent revival, those outdoor prayer meetings found in certain religious circles and in Flannery O'Connor stories. But setting up on a patch of sidewalk next to an auto shop by the West Side Highway doesn't exactly seem like a formula for success.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: STEPHEN GLASS (Hayden Christensen, a k a the young Anakin Skywalker) tells his editor at The New Republic that he feels awful because he's made a "huge error" in an article. The young Republicans weren't drinking booze from a hotel mini-bar; it actually came from a rented fridge. But in SHATTERED GLASS (2003), that's the least of young Stephen's sins. He's the nicest guy in the world, it seems, but he, uh, makes up half of his articles. And he gets caught. Peter Sarsgaard plays the editor who digs out the truth. Billy Ray wrote, directed and proved that backstage journalism can make entertaining moral drama and fact-checking can be fun-- Friday at 5 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Flushing, Call Your Agent
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwitting Wives Are Prey in South Africa Scandal
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 4 - The first Sylvia Tshigo knew of her marriage was the day her husband showed up at her door in March 2003, requesting a divorce.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOTTLIEB, ABE
description: GOTTLIEB--Abe. 4/18/089/7/74. Even though you physically left us that fateful day, your spirit and zest for the good life lives on in our children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Phyllis and Family

title: On This Day, Youth Is Served a Lesson
description: IT is not as easy as it looked in London. There, at Wimbledon, Maria Sharapova had nothing to lose besides her relative anonymity. Here, two months and many photo opportunities later, she was center stage at the United States Open, even at the expense of another who deserved it more.

title: Michell Tollinchi, Christopher Michel
description: Michell Marie Tollinchi, a daughter of Obdulia and Jos Antonio Tollinchi II of Kingsbridge Heights, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Yves Christopher Michel, a son of Harriet and Yves Michel of Manhattan. The Rev. Robert Trainor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church in Kingsbridge Heights.

title: Finding a Little Paradise in Fishing the Tailwaters
description: CRAIG, Mont. - As an angler, I cannot think of a more perfect town than this hamlet. It has two restaurants, one breakfast joint, two fly shops and 42 full-time residents. No newspaper, no museum, no professional sports team. Nothing but fly-rodders and trout.

title: A Lasting Gift, From a Terrific Club That Nobody Wanted to Join
description: HOBOKEN, N.J. - IN the beginning was an empty space so vast, it seemed like it would last forever.

title: HOUSE AND HOME
description: If anyone knows the value of the right address, Daniel Parisi does. He has reaped millions from the Internet domain Whitehouse.com, which he leases to a pornographic Web site that attracts visitors who confuse the address with Whitehouse.gov, the virtual home of President Bush.

title: Bert Russ, Thomas Sharp
description: John Albert Russ IV and Thomas Edwin Sharp were married yesterday in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario. Doreen Peever, a Unitarian chaplain, performed the ceremony.

title: A Shelter for the Weakest Proves to Be None Too Strong
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla., Sunday, Sept. 5 - Jean Marc Spiers was a preemie, still just 7 pounds at 2 months old, and his mother spoke only Haitian Creole. Jesse Sanchez, 2, breathed with the help of a tracheotomy and ate through a feeding tube. Mulchan Gopie, 75, fed soft cereal to his disabled daughter, Maria, 28, as he held her head in his lap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARADISE, JOSEPH L.
description: PARADISE--Joseph L. Died September 4, 2004, at age 101. Father of Stephen Paradise, Judith Moskowitz and Gail Kelly. Loving grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of eight. Funeral service Wednesday, 12 noon, at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, NY; 914-381-1809.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   IMBARRATO, AURELIA CALIGIURI
description: IMBARRATO--Aurelia Caligiuri. September 2, 1917 August 28, 1992. You are in our hearts always. Valerie and Julia

title: Awaiting Surgery, ClintonIs Up and Seeing Visitors
description: Awaiting open heart surgery early this week, former President Bill Clinton remained hospitalized in New York yesterday, but was reported in good spirits, moving around his room, dressed in street clothes. He was visited by his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, for most of the afternoon and night, and by their daughter, Chelsea.

title: Stephanie Hill, Benjamin Wilchfort
description: Stephanie Frederica Hill, the daughter of Lyn Stiefel Hill and Forbes I. Hill of Brooklyn, is to be married in Manhattan today to Benjamin Simon Wilchfort, the son of Blanka and Dr. David Wilchfort of Munich. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider is to officiate at the Rainbow Room.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   OSLER, JULIE
description: OSLER--Julie. Sept. 3, 2003. Missed and loved by her sisters, family and friends. She is with us

title: The Most Important Article in Our History
description: IF the presidential election were Mae West, her reply to a flatterer calling her the "most important election ever" could easily be: "I bet you say that to all the elections, big boy." Surprise, all you election 2004 superlative-pushers, from Bruce Springsteen to the Christian Coalition: This election is the "most important" in our history -- our lifetimes, a generation, whatever -- only if you ignore a slew of others.

title: Identity Stew
description: EVEN in his black-and-white waiter's garb, Michael Lan stands out, his hair spiked, his dark brown eyes scrutinizing customers from behind rose-tinted glasses.

title: Elizabeth Marvel, Bill Camp
description: Elizabeth Marvel and Bill Camp, who are both actors, were married yesterday at Stern Grove, a park in San Francisco. Heron Freed Toor, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated.

title: Operatic Dishes (Arias, Too)
description: "THERE'S not a whiff of curry here now," said Ron Hoffman, co-owner of Bliss, a new East Setauket restaurant. Bliss is very different from the Village Bistro, the previous occupant of this location, which had a common ownership and kitchen with the Curry Club, its next-door neighbor.

title: Winning Hearts of Iraqis With a Sewage Pipeline
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 4 - On a garbage-strewn street of the embattled Baghdad slum of Sadr City, there is an unusual outpost of American might.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOWLTON, JONATHAN
description: KNOWLTON--Jonathan. Artist. February 22, 1937-August 19, 2004. Retired professor of Fine Arts, University of Alberta, passed away in his 67th year. He will be sadly missed by his son Christopher and wife Lissette, daughter Katherine and husband Matthew Soares, granddaughter Natalia, brother Eben and wife Marie Noelle, and stepmother Helen Foote Knowlton. Jonathan was a graduate of Milton Academy, Yale University, and Berkeley University (MFA); a Fulbright scholar; and was awarded a series of Canada Council and University research grants from 197789. His paintings and prints are included in the permanent collections of major museums, universities, and corporations across Canada and the US including MOMA (NYC), LACM, Palace of the Legion of Honor (San Francisco), MFA (Montreal), and the V and A Museum (London). He continued painting until his death.

title: Survival of the Wettest
description: Garden City - LONG ISLAND politicians don't agree on much except for water. Democrats and Republicans alike have been steadfast in saying that the future of Long Island depends on a high-quality water supply. Why, then, are they allowing our wetlands to be dangerously exposed to destruction?

title: Can a Label Sum Up a Heritage?
description: To the Editor:

title: The New New York Skyline
description: Correction Appended

title: Practice at Your Own Risk, Music Lovers
description: To the Editor:

title: As Population Rises, So Does Poverty (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 58 Days to Go; Running Mates: Rural Routes
description: In the end, all vice-presidential candidates face the same calculus: How to soften the rough edges and balance the geographic shortcomings of their running mates while doing as much harm as possible to the other side.

title: Camille Noe, J. P. Pagn
description: Camille Patrice Noe, a daughter of Vanessa and Tipton Noe of Dearborn, Mich., is to be married today to Nelson Luis Pagn, the son of Lydia Lizarribar-Masini of San Juan, P.R., and Nelson Pagn of Marietta, Ga. Juan Masini-Soler, the bridegroom's stepfather, who was designated by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts as a marriage officiant, is to perform the ceremony at Brooksby Farm in Peabody, Mass.

title: Alexandra Fuchs, Gideon Argov
description: Alexandra Fuchs and Gideon Argov are to be married today at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park in a ceremony performed by Rabbi Helene Ferris.

title: 'The End of Faith': Against Toleration
description: THE END OF FAITH Religion, Terror, and the Future of Reason. By Sam Harris. 336 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: Accent? What Accent?
description: IT isn't as recognizable as the soft drawl of the Deep South, the twang of Texas or the sing-song cadences of Minnesota, but, yes, there is a Connecticut accent.

title: Hey Kids, Try This at Home
description: CHRISTINA GODDARD has been consumed by fashion ever since she can recall. She has entered her designs, including a hooded pink bodysuit and a fishnet micro mini, in competitions, and she sketches prolifically -- some would say compulsively.

title: DataBank; Gloomy News From Intel Weighs on the Nasdaq
description: The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose last week, withstanding the vagaries of a week overshadowed by the Republican National Convention, an unsurprising but mostly positive employment report and surprisingly negative news from the chip maker, Intel.

title: 58 Days to Go; The Wives: Visible and Invisible
description: In the case of Teresa Heinz Kerry, the pundits have been asking a telling question. Is she an asset or a liability? As long as that is the question, the answer is clear. Since reviews of her speech in July at the Democratic convention ran the gamut from self-absorbed to wifty, her public presence has been reduced.

title: Allison Slater, Brian Ray
description: Allison Heather Slater, the daughter of Karen and Douglas Slater of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married today to Brian Garrett Ray, a son of Ellen Ray and Dr. Michael Ray of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Chaim Rogoff is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: One Japanese on a Quest of Atonement
description: HARBIN, China - There are details that Ichiro Koyama has forgotten about his arrival in China as a young Japanese conscript in 1940 during the chaos of war.

title: Line Jean-Louis, Chris Taylor
description: Line Jean-Louis and Chris Taylor were married yesterday at Glenmere Mansion, an event space in Chester, N.Y. The Rev. Mel Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Selig Neubardt, Early Birth Control Proponent, Dies at 78
description: Dr. Selig Neubardt, a Westchester obstetrician and gynecologist and an author who was a prominent early advocate for birth control and safe abortion, died on Aug. 24 in White Plains. He was 78 and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OLFORD, DR. STEPHEN F.
description: OLFORD--Dr. Stephen F., a champion of expository preaching and a mentor to many evangelical Christian leaders, died August 29th at age 86. He was pastor emeritus of Calvary Baptist Church in New York, where he served as senior minister from 1959-1973. His influence upon thousands of pastors and preachers was profound. Dr. Olford established the Stephen Olford Center for Biblical Preaching in Memphis, TN, in 1988, where he was active until his death. Dr. Olford's wife of 56 years, Heather, succeeds him, as well as his sons, Jonathan and David; their wives, Catherine and Ellen, and five grandchildren. Visitation will take place on Tuesday, September 7th, from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M. at Olford Ministries International, 4000 Riverdale Road, Memphis. A public memorial service will take place at Bellevue Baptist Church at 1 P.M. on Wednesday, September 8th. The Olford family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, gifts can be given to Olford Ministries International.

title: Damage Is Mostly Light as Storm Pelts Island Chain
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sept. 4 - Terry Delancy spent the hot, humid morning on Saturday cleaning up broken tree limbs and shrubs at his home and small car-rental business and helping a neighbor repair a roof. Gusts of wind swirled the debris away from Mr. Delancy, and brief, sudden showers soaked his shirt.

title: 58 Days to Go; Polls: The Carter Exception
description: Surveys in the next several days will show what kind of bounce President Bush receives from the convention, as well as mark the Labor Day positions of Mr. Bush and Senator John Kerry in their quest for the presidency. That the two indicators come almost simultaneously adds another element of polling unpredictability to an already unusual campaign.

title: $1.75 Million Plan Approved To Plant Scallops in Suffolk
description: Steve Levy, Suffolk's county executive, signed legislation on Wednesday for a $1.75 million plan to restock the Peconic bays with scallops. This will be the largest effort to restore the once-plentiful scallop population that was decimated by algae blooms in the mid-1980's.

title: Barbara Walters: The Exit Interview
description: AFTER a quarter century as co-host, Barbara Walters, the alpha female of broadcast news, is leaving "20/20," the ABC program on which she has interviewed Fidel Castro, Christopher Reeve, Hillary Rodham Clinton and -- before 48.5 million viewers in 1999 -- Monica Lewinsky.

title: Judith Singer, Beth Gamse
description: Dr. Judith D. Singer and Dr. Beth C. Gamse are to be married today in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Barbara Rosman Penzner is to officiate at the residence of the master of Eliot House, a dormitory at Harvard University.

title: Can a Label Sum Up a Heritage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ayana Wright, Miguel Lambert
description: Ayana Teneile Wright, a daughter of Deborah Smith-Wright and Raymond Wright of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening to Miguel Urskin Lambert, the son of Mary Joyce Lambert of the Bronx and Mathias Maxwell of Laborie, St. Lucia. The Rev. Walter A. Birkle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Church in the Bronx.

title: Dustbusters
description: HOW CLEAN IS YOUR HOUSE? Hundreds of Handy Tips to Make Your Home Sparkle By Kim Woodburn and Aggie MacKenzie Dutton, 192 pages, $22.95.

title: Parishioners Turn Activist to Keep Their Church Open
description: WEYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 3 - Mary Akoury gives a lot of time and energy to St. Albert the Great Church here, but never did she imagine that her faith and her affinity for this parish would lead her to spend Wednesday night trying to sleep in the ninth pew from the altar as part of what is being called a 24-hour-a-day prayer vigil, or to sign on as a plaintiff in a lawsuit against the archdiocese -- all in an effort to save the church.

title: 'Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell': Hogwarts for Grown-Ups
description: JONATHAN STRANGE & MR. NORRELL By Susanna Clarke. Illustrations by Portia Rosenberg. 782 pp. Bloomsbury. $27.95.

title: Democrats Compete to Challenge Senator
description: For a quarter-century, State Senator Olga A. Mendez has held a seat that was considered among the safest in the Legislature. Election after election, she won handily, usually with very little in the way of campaign money or competition.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Tune Struck

title: A Stadium Long Gone, but Not Forgotten (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Chelsea Building Swaps Muses, from Photography to Dance
description: A DECIDEDLY blurry real estate picture is finally coming into focus for the photographer Annie Leibovitz.

title: Laura Vanderkam, Michael Conway
description: Laura Ruth Vanderkam and Michael Dwight Conway were married yesterday at the Princeton Theological Seminary in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. James Moorhead, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: 'An Evening of Long Goodbyes'
description: A black wind was blowing outside the bow window. All afternoon ithad been playing its tricks: scooping up handfuls of leaves andflinging them over the lawn, spinning Old Man Thompson's weathervane this way and that, seizing rapaciously at Bel's ruby leathercoat as she battled down the driveway to her audition. Now and then,from the rear of the house, I would hear it shriek through the bonesof the Folly, and I'd look up from the TV with a start. If this wereKansas-I remember thinking-it might have been the beginnings of aterrible Twister; but this wasn't Kansas, and what the wind blew inwas worse than witches or winged monkeys. For today was the day thatFrank arrived at Amaurot.

title: Here We Are Again
description: For five years, environmental and public advocacy groups in the Hudson Valley have been fighting a proposal from St. Lawrence Cement to build an immense new coal-fired cement plant just south of Hudson, N.Y. As it stands, the proposal is moving with excruciating slowness through the Department of Environmental Conservation's approval process, heading toward eventual adjudication. The state has outlined nine major areas of concern that St. Lawrence Cement must address, including the plant's damaging visual impact in a historic, scenic region and the environmental impact of a toxic plume that would reach across much of the Northeast.

title: Tiffany's Gems Can Hold Off Bats for Only So Long
description: The Greensboro Bats still have not figured out how to solve Chuck Tiffany, but they have at least figured out how to outlast him.

title: Welcome to Iraq, Mr. President
description: Even as the 2004 political campaign continues to focus on refighting the Vietnam War, one thing is certain: whoever wins the presidency will have other priorities. It will be the war in Iraq, the war that this generation of Americans is actually fighting and dying in, that George W. Bush or John Kerry will have to confront. Either man will have to do so at a time when Iraq poses difficult, perhaps even impossible, options for United States policymakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEWINS, ROBERT DANA
description: HEWINS--Robert Dana. Died peacefully in Bellevue, WA, on September 1, 2004, at age 80. Beloved father of Genevieve Hewins Swanson of Cedar Knolls, NJ, Ward Dana Hewins of Boston, MA, and Robert Theodore Hewins of Amsterdam, The Netherlands. Beloved grandfather of Chloe Jane Hewins and Robert James Hewins. Devoted husband of Irene Bourgeois Hewins. Born and raised in Quincy and Falmouth, MA, he was a US Marine Corps veteran of WWII, where he served in the Pacific. A magna cum laude graduate of Brown University in 1951, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, he spent his entire career as an international banker with Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in the US, Belgium, Asia and Bermuda, until his retirement in 1986. While living in Belgium he was very active in the Belgian-American community, with particular emphasis in the field of education. He was decorated as Officier in the Order of Leopold II by King Baudoin for his contributions. A voracious reader and lover of the New York Times, he had an insatiable interest in US and European history. He was a charming and witty man, with a sharp sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Brown University.

title: Into Prehistory In the Dordogne
description: PRESENTING prehistory to the masses is a daunting task. The unknowns -- from what prehistoric men and women looked like to how to define prehistoric artistic expression -- are often too great to make the subject accessible to amateurs.

title: Even the Brightest Quarterback Prospects Are Eased Into the N.F.L. Fray
description: Boomer Esiason woke up the night before his first start as a rookie quarterback in 1984 waving his arms and screaming, "That's the wrong formation!" When Esiason recalls now what it was like to start as a rookie for the Cincinnati Bengals, he remembers not the glory or the excitement, just the confusion.

title: Ruth Shalit, Robertson Barrett
description: Ruth Shalit and Henry Robertson Barrett IV were married yesterday evening at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York. Rabbi Kenneth J. Chasen officiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about people living near Madison Square Garden, the site of the Republican National Convention, referred incorrectly to the frozen zone, from West 31st to West 33rd Street between Seventh and Ninth Avenues, in which pedestrian access was limited. There is indeed a residential building in the zone, the Pennmark, at 315 West 33rd.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GINGOLD, JEFFREY
description: GINGOLD--Jeffrey. 2/19/48--8/31/87. In our hearts always. We love you, Mom, Arlene and Bonnie

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
Workingman's Cantata
description: MY grandfather, Tony Vescovi, never celebrated Labor Day. He was a man of the clock -- up for work in the mosaic and terrazzo trade at 5 a.m. -- not of the calendar. In 40 years on the job, he never received a day of paid vacation. But he didn't complain. When he came home after his shift, he stripped to the waist and washed his body of grit and combed concrete chips out of his thick brown hair. Then he sat down to eat at a table that, in his eyes, was bountiful. He relished his work and, as an immigrant, he loved the country that provided it.

title: Safe and Sound
description: RITUALS are magical. Riding a bike through Central Park every summer morning while listening to Maria Callas on my iPod, then coming back two hours later along the sunswept trees of Riverside Drive and finding Callas exactly where I'd left her. Listening to Brahms's intermezzos at Starbucks every afternoon while indulging my new addiction, iced grande skimmed lattes. Such rituals give greater luster to random things I already love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKAL, ROBIN (NEE LEVINSON)
description: SOKAL--Robin (nee Levinson). Passed away Sunday, August 15, 2004, in Vienna, Austria. After a successful career with Time-Life and subsequently the United Nations, and, having been a devoted mother, friend and colleague, she will be greatly missed by her daughter, Sophia, her family and many friends.

title: A Faded Literary Light
description: A Faded Literary Light

title: A 19th-Century Survivor Ships Its Last Fragrant Bouquet
description: In 1967, the year a young florist named Hyman Spitz met his future wife, tuxedo merchants and wedding photographers dotted the avenues of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. But today, hip-hop clothiers and cellphone dealers hold court, and the high-end furniture galleries of Rockaway Avenue are long gone.

title: Hi, My Name Is Sam, and I'll be Your Broker
description: IN this city's central casting office, few stock characters are more set in their roles than the slick and savvy real estate agent and the starry-eyed starving artist waiting on tables.

title: Irvington to Limit On-Street Parking
description: Irvington residents who live near the Metro-North train station have long complained about commuters who parked their cars on residential streets all day long. Many of the houses in the area have been carved into apartments and have no driveways. But only the New York State Legislature has the power to authorize municipalities to restrict access to public roadways, said Eamon Moynihan, a spokesman for the New York State Department of State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASOWITZ, FELICE
description: KASOWITZ--Felice. September 1, 2004, of 681 Heather Lane, West Haven, CT. Devoted wife of Robert Kasowitz. Beloved mother of Stephen Kasowitz of New Haven, Marc Kasowitz of NYC and Susan Oakey Kasowitz of Milford, CT. Also survived by five cherished grandchildren. Funeral services at Congregation B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Road, Woodbridge, CT Monday morning at 10:30 o'clock with interment services to follow in the B'nai Jacob Memorial Park, Wintergreen Ave, New Haven. Memorial contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, G.I. Oncology Fund, P.O. Box 27106, NY NY 10087 or to CT Hospice, 100 Double Beach Rd, Branford CT 06405 or the Congregation B'nai Jacob. A period of mourning will be observed at 681 Heather Lane, West Haven, CT through Wednesday. Robert E. Shure Funeral Home 203-562-8244

title: The Political Brain
description: I would propose that all Americans are born as Democrats but later change allegiance, depending on their social conditions and experience (The Way We Live Now, Steven Johnson, Aug. 22). Classic examples are President Reagan and Senator Zell Miller of Georgia.

title: History Unearthed, In Spots
description: MILLBROOK - TO the untrained eye, the small, brown circles visible while walking through the open field, barren of grass, were nothing but random, dark stains in the soil.

title: Motorists Ignoring Sirens Of Emergency Vehicles
description: An increasing number of drivers have not been pulling over for fire trucks and ambulances responding to emergencies, according to officials in Norwalk and Stamford.

title: The Cost of Cost Analysis
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDFARB, AIDA
description: GOLDFARB--Aida. Wife of the late Max. Loving mother to Joan Talbert and Fran Smyth. Adored grandmother of Wendy Gordon (Keith) and Kevin Smyth. Dearest greatgrandmother of Jessica Gordon, Kitson and Jack Smyth. Extraordinary teacher and special friend to many. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions to Far Rockaway High School, Goldfarb Scholarship Fund, c/o Wendy Gordon, 9 Antoinette Ct, Suffern, NY 10901.

title: Rubens Is Seeded First As the Fall Shows Beckon
description: INTERESTING art exhibitions seem to pop up all over Connecticut each fall like rabbits from a magician's hat. This season is no exception, with an abundance of quality shows scheduled throughout the state. Several stand out, and one or two may even have you champing at the bit.

title: Lost Cause
description: Charles McGrath's diagnosis of Red Sox fans feels familiar to anyone who rooted for the Dodgers in the 40's and early 50's (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 22). We, too, knew the romantic allure of defeat, the pleasure of "pain remembered and pain lovingly anticipated." It was almost an anticlimax when the Dodgers finally won a Series in 1955.

title: How 'Flex Time' Became a Republican Idea
description: FOR more than three decades, feminists and other liberals have championed the idea of flex time -- the concept that employees should have more freedom to adjust their work schedules to their families' needs. Such freedom would be a boon, they say, for working mothers, who may need to leave work early on one day, but could stay late on another.

title: In a Matchup Against Youth, Age Triumphs
description: At the end, Mary Pierce dropped to her knees to offer a prayer of thanks, a moment far removed from the injuries that have swallowed so much of the past few years and that had made a victory over tennis's latest starlet, Maria Sharapova, seem so unlikely.

title: Almodvar's Women
description: The actresses who have embodied his art.

title: Remembering Mr. Met
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE MARKET
description: 1960's House in Norwalk $775,000

title: To Negotiate or Not
description: WE may never know what sparked Friday's massacre at a school in Beslan, in Russia's fractured Caucasus region. Russian special forces say they had to assault the school after militants fired on some of the 1,000 or more people held hostage inside.

title: A Presidential Campaign Tinged With Rust
description: THE names must seem like mantras for schedulers on the Bush and Kerry campaigns: Ohio, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin. Those great swing states of the aging industrial heartland have become the tape loop of the 2004 campaign, linked by their Rust Belt tribulations and stodgy disavowal of permanent Red or Blue status. Having fallen behind economically, they have surged to the forefront politically this year on the wings of their industrial frailty.

title: Clinton Correctional Facility Blues
description: THE pain of imprisonment is two-fold -- there's what you endure on the inside, and there's what you leave behind. It's little surprise, then, that the video for the first post-incarceration single from the rapper Shyne is an inmate's fantasy: a panoptic view of the woman he left behind.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about the plans of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, to work as a volunteer for Habitat for Humanity misidentified the source of his M.B.A. degree. It was Harvard, not the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern.

title: Off the Bench Last, Bollinger Shows His Best
description: Throughout a bumpy training camp for quarterback Brooks Bollinger, Jets coaches kept saying that he had the right stuff to be Chad Pennington's backup.

title: Hollywood, From Flying Saucers to Flying Squirrels
description: Warner Bros. Studios 301 West Olive, Burbank -- The backlot tour is the least commercialized studio tour. You visit various studio departments and often can watch a TV show being filmed.

title: A Visitor Florida Didn't Welcome
description: WITH mounting anxiety, Darren Robertshaw watched television reports on Aug. 13 as Hurricane Charley began to wobble and then suddenly veer off its forecast course, to aim its fury at Florida's southwestern coast -- where the hotel he operates was full of guests.

title: Pamela Joyner, Alfred Giuffrida
description: Pamela J. Joyner and Alfred J. Giuffrida were married Monday at City Hall in San Francisco. Mayor Gavin Newsom officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDFISCHER, SALLY (SA RAH) KLAW
description: GOLDFISCHER -- Sally (Sa rah) Klaw. 98, of Lauderhill, FL, died September 1, 2004. Adored and adoring wife of the late William, predeceased by her beloved son Jerry. Devoted mother of Patrica Israel. Cherished by granddaughter Staci Girsch, her husband Barry, and greatgrandsons Bryan and Randy. Loving Nana of Leslie, Steve, Alex and Jay Meisner, Mark and Amy, Stephanie, Evan, Julie, Sabrina and Gigi Goldfischer. Sally brought integrity, compassion, joie de vivre, and beauty to all who would open their hearts and minds.

title: Brown Faces Surgery; Now Yanks Lack Punch
description: At least the walls inside the Yankees' clubhouse were left intact yesterday. The Yankees actually did not hit much of anything before they got dressed and went home.

title: Parenting a Common Loon
description: A pair of exquisite common loons returned this year to the lake in the Adirondacks where the birds and I both feel serenely at home. Sometime in late July, these loons produced a chick, a small, brown thing that could barely be spotted riding the lake on its mother's back.

title: Pssst... We're All Out Here
description: It was bad enough when citizens in most of the nation -- in a mere 33 states or so -- were written off by presidential campaign managers as dwelling outside this year's political battlegrounds and therefore hardly worth serious attention. But thanks to the wonders of computerization and modern survey research, both red and blue campaign generals are narrowing the area of interest still further. The 17 presumed battleground states have been further parsed for purposes of campaigning and spending to what are being called the Big Ten and the Little Seven. And now, an berarena dubbed the Very Big Three seems to be fast emerging above all of the others.

title: Debating the Future Of Gardiners Island
description: THE Goelets, the new owners of Gardiners Island upon the recent death of Robert David Lion Gardiner, gave limited assurances but no guarantee last week that they had no plans to develop the historic 3,300-acre island off Long Island's South Fork.

title: A True Power Breakfast, Even if No One's Buying
description: In May, when Le Parker Meridien hotel on West 57th Street began offering a $1,000 frittata at its restaurant, Norma's, it created something of a brief media stir. The Daily News gave it the front-page treatment. Camera crews from CNN showed up for the unveiling of the dish, which is billed as the "Zillion Dollar Frittata" and is made with lobster and 10 ounces of sevruga caviar. No less a bon vivant than Sylvester Stallone was cowed by its abundance.

title: Another Side of Clarence Thomas
description: JUDGING THOMAS The Life and Times of Clarence Thomas. By Ken Foskett. Illustrated. 339 pp. William Morrow. $24.95.

title: Always on the Job, Employees Pay With Health
description: American workers are stressed out, and in an unforgiving economy, they are becoming more so every day.

title: Five-Star Lodging at a Refurbished Animal Shelter in Huntington
description: ELWOOD - IT was Lulu's lucky day. Someone had seen her picture on a Web site, fallen in love with her and come to take her home.

title: In Carolina, Delhomme Is Finding His Stride
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C. - The Carolina Panthers quarterback and racehorse owner Jake Delhomme, having finished his stunning run to the Super Bowl in February, allowed himself to get caught up in a romp of a different sort this off-season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, JAMES
description: COHEN--James. Of Richmond, VA. Born January 26, 1916. Husband to the late Ruth Newman Cohen. Father to Karl and Penny Cohen, Marcia Penn and Leivy Smolar, Jeffrey and Linda Cohen. Blessed with 18 adoring grandchildren and 14 loving great-grandchildren. Along with his late brothers, Ben and David Cohen, and late sister Stella Tobin, founded retail chain John's Bargain Stores. In his role as Executive VP he helped steer the retail giant to success in the 1940's-1960's. He'll long be remembered for his generosity, good humor and love of all children. In lieu of remembrances, the family asks that donations be made to Bon Scoures Hospice, 8580 Magellan Parkway, Richmond, VA 23227. Services today, 1 PM, at "Gutterman's," 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: The Week Ahead
description: DEFENDING A DICTATOR -- The first defense witnesses in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic -- the former president of Yugoslavia who now faces 66 counts of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity before an international court in the Netherlands -- are expected to be called on Tuesday by freshly appointed lawyers working on behalf of an unwelcoming client. The defense phase of Mr. Milosevic's trial began last week with two days of rambling oratory from the former dictator, who has insisted on defending himself in the two-year-old trial. But judges in the case, citing Mr. Milosevic's attempts to prolong health-related delays by refusing prescribed medications -- as well as his overall contempt for the court -- decided to appoint two lawyers to act as Mr. Milosevic's defense. "That's a scandal," Mr. Milosevic said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Megan Doherty, Andrew Kelley
description: Megan Marta Doherty, a daughter of Frances and Douglas Doherty of Williamsport, Pa., is to be married today to Andrew Standish Kelley, the son of Marsha Burden Kelley and David N. Kelley II of Marion, Mass. The Rev. David DeSalvo, an Episcopal deacon, will officiate at Gedney Manor, an inn in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Lost Cause
description: It is the remarkable talent of the Red Sox to blow the final game, give up the home run in the late innings, let the ball roll through the fielder's legs and find other inventive ways to lose when it counts the most that endears them to baseball fans and makes them interesting to the news media. If they win a pennant or even worse a World Series, they will lose their mystique and become just another ball club.

title: Stephanie Henshaw, Milan DiGiulio
description: Stephanie Kirsten Henshaw, a daughter of Charlotte and Dr. Stanley K. Henshaw of Leonia, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Milan Mason DiGiulio, a son of Vivien and Paul DiGiulio of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Richard Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUBER, MARY ELIZABETH SEDMAN
description: HUBER--Mary Elizabeth Sedman. Died August 18, at 95. Born in Missoula, MT, she was married to Henry Silver Huber, MD, of New York City until his death in 1972. She is survived by Mary Tambiah of Cambridge, MA, Harriet Huber of Seattle, WA, Janet Schiff of Wayside, NJ, six grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Game, Set and Match For Acclaim Entertainment

title: Two Bombshells In One Little Borough
description: Correction Appended

title: Does a Tiger Lurk in the Middle of a Fearful Symmetry?
description: CHORWON, South Korea - From atop an observatory hard on the southern limit of the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, Lim Sun Nam peered through binoculars at the cold-war spectacle below. He paid no attention to the barbed wire fences, the guard posts with rifle-toting soldiers, or the propaganda billboards on the northern side exclaiming "Against America" and "Prosperity of the People."

title: Glitter and Glass
description: PHILADELPHIA - THIS city, the locals like to say, is a town of neighborhoods, which is perhaps why Washington Square, a lounge and restaurant in a mostly residential area of Center City, has taken pains to evoke homeyness by placing a bowl of designer dog biscuits before its gated entrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, DR. LOREN
description: TIERNEY--Dr. Loren. Age 42, died Wednesday, at Calvary Hospital after a long illness. A Rutgers and SUNY Downstate Medical School graduate, she served as Chief Medical Resident, Pulmonary Fellow and Clinical Instructor at NYU/Bellevue for 13 years. She was revered by her patients and widely repsected by her peers. In the years since her illness was diagnosed, she continued to serve her patients with distiction and compassion, and maintained an active, loving home life. She is survived by her parents, Hannah and Myles Tierney, her husband James M. Mumford, M.D., and three children, James, Cooper and Anna. She is also survived by the many people at the Medical Center whose lives she touched and who will never forget her. Palliative Care Service NYU Hospital Center Joseph Lowy, M.D., Dir Catherine X. White, R.N., M.A. Stuart Kaufer, M.S.W., C.S.W.

title: For the Democratic Primary, Choose Carefully
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in this section on Aug. 22 about the bar scene at the shore referred incorrectly to the Tradewinds, in Sea Bright. It has been demolished; it did not reopen this season.

title: Virgin Blue Expands Into the Pacific
description: Pacific Blue, the new division of the Australian low-cost airline Virgin Blue, began operating flights to Australia from Christchurch, New Zealand, early this year. Today, it serves Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne from Christchurch, New Zealand, and Sydney from Wellington, New Zealand.

title: Wonder Twins Activate a Sound That Isn't Crunch Folk or Riot-Grrl Punk
description: A LOT has happened in the way of lipstick lesbianism since 2002, the year that the 23-year-old gay Canadian twins Tegan and Sara Quin released their plaintive third album, "If It Was You." The throbbing hits of the Russian duo Tatu, whose onstage petting was eventually revealed as a publicity ploy, reverberated in dance clubs; Showtime launched "The L Word," its answer to "Sex and the City"; and Madonna famously locked lips with Britney Spears at MTV's Video Music Awards. While these were essentially stunts, the Quins legitimately pushed boundaries. Though their album sold only modestly, even by indie-rock standards (18,000 copies), its classic songs represented a striking departure from the gentle strumming and crunching blare of many gay female artists.

title: The Delegate as Commuter
description: TEN Westchester Republicans, rewarded for their loyalty and hard work for the party, as well as for their telegenic diversity, attended the Republican National Convention last week, four as delegates and six as alternates.

title: Raising Kevion
description: Your writer describes the 90's as a time when the government realized the importance of welfare reform and "public education." I remember that public education: Newt Gingrich suggested that young mothers on welfare were better off placing their children in orphanages. I remember the beginning of welfare reform, which kicked single moms off the rolls into working multiple jobs, leaving them precious little time for their children or themselves.

title: Raising Kevion
description: By default or by design, women have shown themselves to be nothing less than survivors. Despite this self-sufficiency, many women still yearn for a partner, a father for their children, a "whole" family. Many low-income and welfare women are housing and feeding men who offer them little but an illusion of what they really want.

title: Kiane Frye, Argin Hutchins
description: Kiane Rosa Lucille Frye, the daughter of Diane Thurston Frye and Marcellous P. Frye of Glenwood, Md., was married yesterday to Argin McKay Edward Hutchins, the son of Judge Miriam Brown Hutchins and Argin M. Hutchins of Baltimore. The Rev. Dr. John L. Wright officiated at the First Baptist Church of Guilford in Columbia, Md.

title: Corrections
description: A highlight entry on Page 44 of the Television section today for Friday at 8 p.m. on NBC carries an outdated title for a "Dateline NBC" installment. Formerly "The Hiker," it has been renamed "Desperate Days in Blue John Canyon."

title: Allow Me to Introduce My Friend, Andrew Jackson
description: IT was in late spring that I first heard that guys at the door of the Phish show had been accepting cash instead of tickets. Not just the occasional bribe: according to someone who was at a Coney Island show, they were accepting so much cash from so many people that they barely had time to stuff it in their pockets. With the summer's biggest concerts on the horizon, and some beginning to sell out, I began to wonder if Phish fans were onto something. What if the very need for tickets could be eliminated with a few well-placed bills? Why pay several hundred dollars for a scalped ticket when the hand of a willing bouncer might be greased for only 50? Of course, bribery is illegal, and I felt filthy even thinking about it. But the summer changes people, and as the days grew long and warm, I resolved to try my hand.

title: Astros Find New Meaning in Their Once-Lost Season
description: CAN a team that is 20 games out of first with six weeks to go in the season make the playoffs? In Major League Baseball it can, thanks to the wild card.

title: Page Two: Aug. 29-Sept. 4; PROSECUTOR PROBLEMS
description: Citing a pattern of misconduct by prosecutors, a federal judge in Detroit threw out the terrorism convictions of two Arab immigrants -- Abdel-Ilah Elmardoudi, 38, and Karim Koubriti, 26, both from Morocco -- undoing a case the Justice Department once called a major victory in the war on terror.

title: Can a Label Sum Up a Heritage? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Big Brother Use a Pooper-Scooper?
description: The signs, bright yellow, pink, blue and white and adorned with smiley faces, first appeared in couple of weeks ago, offering an odd mixture of cheer and menace. Affixed to trees along the block of President Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues in Park Slope, Brooklyn, they bear a bracing message: "Please Curb Your Dog; Cameras Are On."

title: A Target on the Hudson
description: THE Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan is just 35 miles from Times Square. More than 20 million people live within 50 miles of Indian Point, which means that it is surrounded by a more densely populated area than any other nuclear plant in the country.You can rent a helicopter and fly over Indian Point for a close examination. No one will stop you, even though Al Qaeda members flew over Indian Point on Sept. 11, 2001, and even though the group was recently reported to have considered using hijacked tourist helicopters in New York City as weapons.

title: Pubs Gone Wild
description: A few months ago, I moved back to England after what turned out to be an 11-year leave of absence, spent in Spain, Mexico, Argentina and, mostly, New York. Recently married, I persuaded my wife, Silvana, that a base in Europe seemed like the solid start we needed, as opposed to her native Buenos Aires, where crime keeps creeping higher and the peso remains in rags. I would rediscover and induct her into a world of green pastures, sublime theater, TV commercials that approached high art, Marks & Spencer's underwear and the most heavenly Indian cuisine this side of the Ganges.

title: Earlimart
description: HERMOSA BEACH, Calif. - CALL them Ishmaels. It didn't matter that it was high tide and the frothy five-foot waves were livid. Or that only one of the four guys knew how to surf. As the sun sank on a recent Thursday night in Hermosa Beach, the members of the gutsy Los Angeles band Earlimart dropped trou and took to the sea.

title: A Wacky Game Is Found Insulting
description: For the better part of two summers, a Wildwood Boardwalk concessionaire, Michael Rutkowski, has run a paintball game that took aim at Saddam Hussein and Osama bin Laden. Called, ungrammatically, Wack the Iraq, it had as a come-on from the boardwalk a life-size statue in camouflage that looked vaguely like Mr. Hussein.

title: Nuanced Taste From Burgundy
description: First-rate inexpensive Bourgogne Rouge is virtually unfindable. A standout exception is the 2002 Le Meurger ($15) at the Burgundy Wine Company, 143 West 26th Street. This spicy pinot noir for novices hints at the nuances in red Burgundies from famed vineyards that attract collectors. A complementary introductory chardonnay is Hubert Chavy's 2003 Les Femelottes ($15), a rich, nutlike Bourgogne blanc that resembles Meursault and that lingers on the palate for minutes. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Inching Toward Elections, Palestinians Begin Voter Registration

title: Suicide Blast Kills 15 in Worst of Several Attacks in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 4 - A suicide car bombing killed at least 17 people outside a police academy in Kirkuk in northern Iraq, the deadliest of several attacks around the country on Saturday as insurgents pressed their campaign against the interim government and American forces.

description: PAGANO--Marion Lubrano. Beloved wife of the late Placido Pagano, died peacefully at home in Englewood Cliffs, NJ on August 29, 2004. Much loved mother of Christina and Peter. Dear sister of Theresa. She will be missed for her laughter and love.
