description: Merchants in Westchester are hoping that the state's tax-free period, which began on Tuesday and runs through tomorrow, translates into extra income for them. The seven days coincide with the back-to-school buying period.

Morrison of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. David McBriar performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Durham.

description: Baghdad, Iraq - AT a recent meeting with a group of tribal sheiks, an American general spoke with evident frustration about the latest Iraqi city to fall into the hands of insurgents.

description: Wayne P. Pacelle, 39, a native of New Haven and a graduate of Notre Dame High School in West Haven and Yale University, has taken over as president and chief executive of the Humane Society of the United States in Washington.

description: WITH Americans giving President Bush a big edge over Senator John Kerry on matters of national security, the hopes of the Kerry campaign rest on what they view as Mr. Bush's Achilles' heel: the loss of 900,000 jobs since Mr. Bush took office.

Pandit Anil Krishnaji Hingwe, a Hindu priest, is to perform the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: For the Jets' Architect, Blueprints Are Taking Shape
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. - Plague? Pestilence? Considering every other calamity that befell the Jets last season, it might have been only a slight exaggeration to think that surely they, too, were just around the corner.

title: Early Reaction Is Positive On a New Yankee Stadium
description: The New York Yankees' plan for a new $750 million, open-air stadium in the Bronx, which they hope to announce publicly at the end of the month, is winning generally positive reviews so far in meetings with elected officials and city agencies.

title: Climate, and Bad Luck, Favor Hurricanes in Florida
description: Battered on the west three weeks ago by Hurricane Charley and being battered this weekend on the east by Hurricane Frances, Florida is a victim of a climate currently favorable for hurricanes and of simple bad luck.

title: Valerie Frankel and Stephen Quint
description: VALERIE FRANKEL has always been the risk-taking type. When she was in college, she stormed the stage at a Clash concert and sang "Garageland" with Joe Strummer. At 22, she quit her first job to write a book. She had three chapters sketched out at the time, her mother said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPARBER, NATALIE
description: SPARBER--Natalie. Of Aventura, Florida, precious sweetheart, wife, friend, lover and the joy of her beloved husband, Michael. Outstanding, devoted, true-blue, beloved, revered forever in the memory of her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, Arlyne and Richard, Jill and David, Gregory and Patti, Joey and Richard, Danielle and Jennifer and Matthew and Nicole. Respected and loved by Michael's children and grandchildren. Natalie will never be forgotten. She will live forever in our hearts and minds. Her memory will be a blessing we will cherish.

title: Where 9, Not 1, Is the Loneliest Number
description: In the jumble of letters and numbers that make up the New York subway system, the No. 9 line in Manhattan and the Bronx is forever playing second fiddle. It is always at the back end of the phrase "the 1 and 9 trains," and its fan club, if one exists, is miniscule.

Extraordinarily active in communal affairs as Trustee of Riverdale Temple, member of Women's American Ort and Hadassah-Fieldston Chapter and life member of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee. title: It Failed Its Inventor at First, But a Gambit Retains Its Allure
description: The rationale for the infamous Marshall Gambit, first played by Frank Marshall against Jos Raul Capablanca in New York in 1918, is that White has developed slowly and Black now has a chance to make him pay for it. The gambit is introduced after 8 c3 d5 with 9 ed Nd5 10 Ne5 Ne5 11 Re5. In that first game, Capablanca won with a magnificent defense against an opponent who had prepared the gambit with hours of secret analysis, having avoided it when facing anyone else to maintain its shock value.

title: 52 Hours of Horror and Death for Captives at Russian School
description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 4 - Long before the first bombs exploded in Middle School No.1, marking the beginning of a ferocious battle that left hundreds of schoolchildren and their parents and teachers dead, the hostages had descended to near despair.

title: He's Not Beethoven, and There's Nothing Wrong With That
description: It's almost alarming to hear the music leap off the disc, self-confident and strong: a little Haydnesque, a little Schubertian and, yes, a little Beethovenian but with a character of its own. Who is this guy?

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLLY, SEYMOUR
description: WOLLY--Seymour, 86, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Farmingdale and Huntington, NY, and Rockville, MD, died September 3, 2004. Beloved husband for 62 years of Ida (Gillman), father of Michael and Marcia, grandfather of Peter, Mark, and Brian, father-in-law of Valentine (Nazarian), and uncle of Bruce Gillman. Sy was a graduate of NYU, a veteran of the Air Force in WWII and the Korean War, proprietor of Wolly's Hardware in Farmingdale, NY, and a volunteer at the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center in Commack, NY, and the Morse Geriatric Center of West Palm Beach, FL. An avid golfer, he was one of the first caddies at Bethpage Golf Course. He will be in our memories forever. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Greater Washington D.C. Chapter, 108 N. Alfred Street, Alexandria, VA 22314. Funeral service will be held September 7 at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 21 E. Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, NY. Call 631-499-6060 for time. Interment Huntington Jewish Center Cemetery.

title: Sabrina Underwood, Jonathan Su
description: Sabrina Underwood, a daughter of Cheong and Ken Underwood of Alexandria, Va., was married last evening to Jonathan Chun-wei Su, a son of Wong Min Tsu Su and Chiu-wen Su of Los Angeles and Taipei, Taiwan. The Rev. Matthew Lee, a minister of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, performed the ceremony at the St. Regis Hotel in Washington.

title: 'Nuclear Terrorism'
description: "WHY DO YOU use an axe when you can use a bulldozer?" That wasOsama bin Laden's question in 1996 to Khalid Sheikh Mohammed,the chief planner of what grew into the most deadly attack on theAmerican homeland in the nation's history. Mohammed is now inAmerican custody, the highest-ranking Al Qaeda leader captured todate in the war on terrorism. He has told interrogators that the"axe" to which bin Laden referred was his proposal to charter asmall plane, fill it with explosives, and crash it into CIA headquartersin Langley, Virginia. Bin Laden sent him back to the drawingboard with a charge to devise a more dramatic, devastating blowagainst the "hated enemy."

title: Therapist Is Charged With Physical and Sexual Assault on Boy, 4
description: A behavioral therapist was arrested on Thursday and charged with physically and sexually assaulting a 4-year-old autistic boy in his home in Long Hill, N.J., the authorities said yesterday.

Rabbi Ronne Friedman will officiate at the Seeds of Peace summer camp in Otisfield, Me., with Cantor Roy B. Einhorn taking part.

title: South Korea Calls Experiment Far Below Bomb-Grade Level
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 4 - The father of South Korea's nuclear research program told foreign reporters on Saturday that scientists under his command had performed an enrichment experiment "three of four times," but that in each case the enrichment level had not gone over 10 percent, far below the bomb-grade level of 90 percent.

title: Jobs
description: If nothing else, John Kerry has revived the public's memory of Herbert Hoover. Again and again, the Democratic candidate has reminded people that George W. Bush has "the worst record on jobs since Herbert Hoover," that Bush is in line to become the first president "since Hoover" to preside over a shrinking payroll, that he has "stood by," Hoover-like, while the good honest folk who make up the backbone of the country have lost their jobs.

title: Very-High-Priced Clothes, Very-Low-Rise Space
description: PARK AVENUE in the East 50's is famous for its landmark modern skyscrapers: the Seagram Building, Mies van der Rohe's bronze and glass icon at 53rd Street, and Lever House, Gordon Bunshaft's glass and stainless-steel treasure between 53rd and 54th.

title: Elfrieda Dyck, 87, Mennonite Who Helped Thousands Resettle, Dies
description: SCOTTDALE, Pa., Sept. 3 - Elfrieda Dyck, a Canadian nurse who helped thousands of Mennonite refugees from Eastern Europe find new homes in South America, died here on Aug. 20. She was 87.

title: Ex-Mentor of Rebel Iraqi Cleric Breaks From His Protg
description: QUM, Iran - The Shiite cleric based in Iran who was the mentor of the rebel Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr has in recent weeks publicly broken with Mr. Sadr and withdrawn his support.

title: It's a Lonely World Out There
description: Laura Occhipinti never had much use for Friday nights in front of the television set. And before moving to North Plainfield in January, spending them that way was not much of an issue because she had been running with the same reliable Bergen County crowd since returning there after her Rutgers graduation several years earlier. But with relocation -- in her case, to take a job as a caseworker at Children's Specialized Hospital in Mountainside -- came loneliness.

title: On the Stoop, 'Whatever' Is Always in Focus
description: WHEN the sun goes down at the Murray Spaceshoe on West 10th Street near Greenwich Avenue, two self-proclaimed "ukulele freaks," Ted Gottfried and Jason Tagg, like to sit outside and "uke on the stoop."

title: A Lesson in Indian Fare (at a Low Cost)
description: I AM very fond of good, Indian home-cooking food, having spent a few years researching and writing about it. The spicing and saucing is specific and subtle. Each dish tastes different and the tastes are often surprising.

title: 'How to Make Love Like a Porn Star': Lovers and Other Strangers
description: HOW TO MAKE LOVE LIKE A PORN STAR A Cautionary Tale. By Jenna Jameson with Neil Strauss. Illustrated. 579 pp. ReganBooks/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.95.

title: Downtown Milford Is Now Hip In Months With or Without an R
description: BOATS from a nearby island docking in the harbor. Groups of 20-and 30-somethings making the rounds of crowded patio bars. The sounds of a live Mariachi band coming from an open-air restaurant. Tourists browsing local shops and trendy boutiques and relaxing in hip coffee shops.

title: The Commuter's Tale
description: "I think I could turn and live with animals," Walt Whitman wrote, eerily foreshadowing life on the Long Island Rail Road. "They are so placid and self-contain'd. . . . They do not sweat and whine about their condition."

title: To Get Out of a Stall, Apply Lift. An Election May Work.
description: THERE seems to be little that could lift stocks these days, with the market just about a week away from stumbling through its fifth-longest stall since 1983.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: WAIT AND SAVE -- The Chesapeake Bay is a good destination for a quick getaway from New York, and for those who plan their escapes impulsively, the Five Gables Inn and Spa, www.fivegables.com, in St. Michaels, a Maryland town on the bay, has a discount. Through Nov. 15, guests who make a reservation two days or less in advance for a one-night stay, Sunday through Thursday night, will pay 25 percent less than the regular rates, which range from $160 to $260, plus tax; a large Continental breakfast is included. The offer is good for one night only and must be made by telephone. The inn has an indoor heated pool , a spa, a steam room and a sauna. The 14 guest rooms are located in three 19th century houses. To reserve, call (877) 466-0100.

title: MUSEUMS: From Sand Castles To Old Gray Mares; Once More to the Beach
description: LABOR DAY has sneaked up on us, and the end of summer -- with its low, gray clouds -- beckons. But here are a couple exhibits that might let you hold onto summer a bit longer.

title: School Clothes-Shopping, Wish Lists in Hand
description: THEY were on a mission, they were on a budget and they had about an hour. Joanne Manley, who usually spends her days as a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank in White Plains, was shopping for school clothes with Shermaine,11, a sixth grader who usually spends her days at the Coachman Family Center, a transitional housing shelter for homeless families in Westchester.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about people living near Madison Square Garden, the site of the Republican National Convention, referred incorrectly to the frozen zone, from West 31st to West 33rd Street between Seventh and Ninth Avenues, in which pedestrian access was limited. There is indeed a residential building in the zone, the Pennmark, at 315 West 33rd.

title: Huge Emotions in Ever Smaller Packages
description: ERNEST BLOCH'S reputation has neither plummeted nor soared since his death in 1959. It seems rather to be quietly on the wane, a slow fade to gray. During his lifetime he steered clear of most fashionable musical trends, and his body of work may be too diverse and idiosyncratic for a more general revival of interest.

title: Aug. 29-Sept. 4
description: THE NUCLEAR GENIE POPS OUT YET AGAINThe South Koreans called it a "laboratory experiment," which it was, but of the sort that is often the first step toward making an atomic bomb.

title: 'Harbor'
description: Water never warms in American harbors. They had told him. Shivering,on the high deck of a groaning tanker, told more. He made out a farfield of whitecaps many feet below. By the prow, the wind waspulling back the flags into flat, clear pictures. His beard whippedpast his face; his overlong hair flew east. His hands and neckburned from insulation he had torn from a crate in the hold thatmost likely, he realized, after a few days of scratching skin tobleeding, was asbestos. He willed himself to stop but woke to bloodcaking his shins, under his nails, ridged in his ears. The coldtightened him into a pain that killed sleep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUSH, SUSAN L.
description: BUSH--Susan L. of Connecticut and New York died July 26. Respected by the pharmaceutical advertising community of which she was a part for 30 years. A dear friend to so many, she was truly one of a kind. She will be greatly missed.

title: HUD Proposes Lower Rent Subsidies
description: WHEN she read the news, Beverly C. Weinberg could not believe it. "I'm here 22 years, and this is the first time the rates have decreased," she said.

title: Slow but Fierce, Vast Hurricane Batters the Florida Coast
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Sunday, Sept. 5 - Shrieking winds and angry sheets of rain thrashed Florida's coast as residents hunkered down in crowded shelters or in their barricaded homes to ride out the plodding, sprawling Hurricane Frances. Hurricane-force winds were reported by midday Saturday and by 1 a.m. Sunday, the center of the eye of the storm made landfall in Sewall's Point, Fla., about 25 miles north of here, the National Hurricane Center reported.

title: We Repeat Ourselves
description: WHEN it comes to portraying Senator John Kerry as a flip-flopper, at least the Republicans are consistent.

title: Corrections
description: The "In the Region" article in New Jersey copies on Aug. 22 about the Palace at Somerset Park, a conference center being built in Franklin Township, misidentified the interstate highway near the site. It is Route 287, not Route 78. The article also gave an outdated name for a major company with offices in the township. It is L'Oral USA, not L'Oreal Cosmair.

title: As Population Rises, So Does Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 1 about the film "Stander" referred incorrectly at one point to its authorship. While the director, Bronwen Hughes, revised Bima Stagg's original script and was credited by Susan Hoffman, a producer, with having written the film, Mr. Stagg received sole screenplay credit.

title: That Wasn't the Week That Was
description: And some people thought that the Republican National Convention would produce no news. The nation learned this week that George W. Bush agonizes. Who knew?

title: Andrea Hirschhorn, Jason Gershwin
description: Andrea Lisa Hirschhorn, the daughter of Lynne and Mark Hirschhorn of Tenafly, N.J., is to be married today to Jason Noah Gershwin, the son of Laynie and Sam M. Gershwin of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Azriel Fellner is to officiate at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J. Cantor Israel Singer is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Repent! Repent! Ye E-ZPass Offenders
description: When Joe Orlando became a spokesman for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and started getting calls from people baring their souls and offering to send money, he was hesitant to take it seriously.

Young Han Kim, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bride, is to officiate at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan.

description: Ne'er the Twain Shall Meet

description: Eliza Shaw Valk and Robin McEvoy Campbell are to be married today at the New Haven Lawn Club. Peter Salovey, the dean of Yale College and a justice of the peace, will officiate. Joan Suval, a founding member of the Ananda Ashram in Monroe, N.Y., will participate in the ceremony, leading rituals from the Vedic tradition.

title: After Killing by Police, a Family's Raw Wounds Endure
description: After Killing by Police, a Family's Raw Wounds Endure

title: Imagine
description: In 1972, a night watchman patrolling a hotel-office complex noticed that the basement garage door had been taped open and, attributing this to the carelessness of a maintenance worker earlier that day, peeled the tape off. When, on his next round, he found the door taped open again, he called the police. As a result, citizens of the United States do not enjoy the benefits (or suffer the aggravations) of national health insurance.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Raising Kevion
description: Jason DeParle's superb article called to mind political wisdom different from President Bush's "healthy marriage" initiative (Aug. 22). Instead, I was reminded of the powerful imagery evoked by Barack Obama's "audacity of hope" speech at the Democratic National Convention. Ken Thigpen and those in his circumstances need that hope, and they need the economic support and employment opportunities necessary to overcome the enormous obstacles they face. Few of us could keep things together in their circumstances on $20,000 a year, marriage license or not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUKHERJI, BHARATI
description: MUKHERJI -- Bharati. Be loved mother of Asish and Pradipta, grandmother of Minki, Pinka and Ronnie, passed away on Thursday, August 26, 2004 at Sioux Falls, SD. Her mental strength inspired her loved ones. Funeral services are scheduled for Sunday, September 5th.

title: Somber Museum
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to have read your well-written article. I lived in Paris for eight years, and during two years when my husband and I lived in the 17th Arrondissement, we spent many happy hours in the Parc Monceau. We took along our folding chairs to read and enjoy the beauty and tranquillity of the gardens.

title: In Foxboro, Starting at the Bottom for the Team at the Top
description: FOXBORO, Mass. - On Vince Wilfork's first day of practice at the University of Miami three years ago, he found safety Ed Reed and linebacker Jonathan Vilma on the same defense with him, and offensive tackle Bryant McKinnie and quarterback Ken Dorsey lining up on offense. That team won the national championship in Wilfork's freshman season, and all but Dorsey, who is battling for the starting job in San Francisco, became a first-round draft pick in the National Football League.

title: Trying to Clean House at the Federation of Labor
description: THIS weekend, at the parades and barbecues, at the rallies and the picnics that local unions will hold for members and their families, one familiar face will be missing: Jack Caffey's.

description: Sadr City is the sprawling neighborhood in eastern Baghdad that is the main base for the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr.

The Scene
description: Middle School No. 1 was opened Sunday to the people of Beslan, Russia. For the small republic of North Ossetia, the hellish place was ground zero.

description: Millions of Florida residents were left without power and hundreds of thousands without ready access to gasoline, groceries or other daily staples.

description: LONG BEACH, N.Y., Sept. 5 - The shells of Long Beach, on the South Shore of Long Island, are the chipped, worn variety not much prized by collectors. They lose their sheen five minutes out of the seawater.

description: ABRAMS -- Miriam. Died peacefully on September 4, 2004. Beloved wife and devoted partner of Paul for 66 years. Devoted mother of John and Carol. Cherished sister of Harold and Murray Rose. Loving grandmother of Alec, Rachel and Jacob. Graveside services today, 10:15 am, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For more information contact Hellman-Garlick Memorial Chapel, Briarcliff Manor, NY; 914-762-5501.

title: Merck Says It Will Post the Results of All Drug Trials
description: Merck & Company says it will post the results of its clinical trials on drugs on a Web site run by the National Institutes of Health. The move comes ahead of a House subcommittee hearing this week where, it is expected, drug companies will be excoriated for refusing to publish unfavorable clinical trial results.

title: Strangers on a (Private) Plane, Agassi and Sargsian Bonded
description: IT was late Saturday night, with the grandstand girders finally still after nearly five hours of stamping, with the roars that had sustained Sargis Sargsian over, when a Connecticut family returned to its home near New Haven.

title: Reckless Full-Body Medical Scans
description: For a prime example of medical screening that has proliferated beyond reason, consider the alarming case of full-body computed tomography scans to detect cancer, cardiovascular disease and other conditions. Narrowly targeted C.T. scans aimed at particular organs are undeniably valuable when used by doctors to pin down a diagnosis in sick patients. But full-body scans to screen healthy individuals for hidden disease have never been shown to be effective, and now there is evidence that the scans may be harmful. A new study finds that the scans impart radiation doses comparable to those received by atomic-bomb survivors in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, causing a small but significant increase in the risk of cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDLER, MALCOLM, D.D.S.
description: SANDLER--Malcolm, D.D.S. On September 5, of New York City. Beloved uncle and friend to many. Graveside services Tuesday, 10:30 am, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASSEL, MILTON EDWARD
description: CASSEL--Milton Edward. 95 years old, died September 4, 2004, in New York. Milton was a distinguished musician and a graduate of Juilliard in January of 1929. Mr. Cassel had been President of the Rita Allen Foundation for many years and had been a strong advocate for medical research. Milton was a former member of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Cassel is survived by his wife Lucette Cassel.

title: Spy Case Renews Debate Over Pro-Israel Lobby's Ties to Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 - It began like most national security investigations, with a squad of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents surreptitiously tailing two men, noting where they went and whom they met. What was different about this case was that the surveillance subjects were lobbyists for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, and one of their contacts turned out to be a policy analyst at the Pentagon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROCKMAN, IRENE
description: BROCKMAN--Irene. Our condolences to Alan Brockman, our friend and esteemed member of our Board of Trustees, on the death of his mother, Irene, who died peacefully in her 99th year. Congregation B'nai Olam Fire Island Pines

title: Mutually Assured Deconstruction
description: President Bush likes to zing John Kerry for his more infelicitous pronouncements, like his votes for and against a certain appropriations bill. But this is a perilous path for a malaprop-prone president.

title: From Now Until Then
description: Not all that long ago, Labor Day in a presidential election year marked the beginning of the real campaign, the 60-day race to the finish line. But like the Christmas holiday season, the fall new-TV season and virtually every other season in the American calendar, the campaign season no longer acknowledges a starting line. The race has been on for months and months. If Labor Day means anything to the election cycle this year, it means an increase in nervous tension for the politically involved -- a new resolve to make the next two months count.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPLEWICZ, ROMA
description: KOPLEWICZ -- Roma. The board and faculty of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the loss of Roma Koplewicz, devoted wife, partner and friend of Joseph (Joe) Koplewicz, beloved mother of Edith, Linda and Harold S. Koplewicz, Director, loving grandmother to Joshua, Adam, Sam and Alex. After surviving the Holocaust, Roma enjoyed a long and joyous marriage to Joe and together they created a family that she cared for dearly. Roma was passionate about her work as a social worker and was a loving and steadfast friend to many. Our thoughts and prayers are with Dr. Koplewicz and his family. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair, Board of Directors NYU Child Study Center

title: The Candidates' Tariff Dodge
description: This election year is even worse than usual when it comes to avoiding tough issues. And of all the hard choices the candidates are not confronting, the question of agricultural subsidies may be the one they're ducking most energetically. Both John Kerry and George Bush must know that the current budget-busting farm subsidy program is ruinous on multiple counts. At roughly $15 billion a year, the program is part of the deficit problem. While the subsidies do little or nothing to help American family farmers, they place a crippling burden on poor farmers elsewhere. Their inability to compete with subsidized farm products from rich nations distorts trade and hurts developing countries.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Aug. 27 reported that policies for interrogating prisoners in Iraq, approved in late 2003 by Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, then the top commander there, drew on interrogation practices previously approved for captives in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and in Afghanistan.

title: Car Bomb Kills 7 U.S. Marines and 3 Iraqi Soldiers Near Falluja
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 6  A car bomb tore into a convoy of American and Iraqi troops near Falluja today, killing seven marines and three Iraqis in the single deadliest attack on American troops in four months, American military officials said.

Mitchell mentions not Walter Gropius or Le Corbusier or Frank Lloyd Wright but Buckminster Fuller, whose Dymaxion car, a zeppelin-shaped three wheeler, created a sensation in 1933.

description: The one show captivating the movie industry during the dog days of summer is the ongoing saga at Miramax Films as the co-founders, Bob and Harvey Weinstein, try to renegotiate their deal with The Walt Disney Company.

description: Those hoping to soak up the last rays of summer sun yesterday were disappointed when choppy waters and gray skies greeted them at the shore. With rip currents and rough surf at the Jersey Shore and Long Island beaches, most people were forced to stay out of the water.

title: Plan to Tame Journalists Just Stirs Them Up in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 5 - A plan by President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva to create a national journalists' council to regulate Brazil's boisterous press has prompted mounting criticism here. News organizations that would be affected by the bill call it the most serious threat to freedom of expression here since a right-wing military dictatorship was toppled two decades ago.

title: Newcomer Wins Classic
description: Darragh Kerins, an Irishman riding out of South Salem, N.Y., rode Nabucco to a victory at the $150,000 Hampton Classic Grand Prix, the final event of the 29th annual Hampton Classic Horse Show yesterday in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the prospects for receiving messages from distant planets misstated the affiliation of Dr. Frank Drake, the first astronomer to search for radio signals from aliens, in 1960. He did the search at the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Green Bank, W.Va., not at Cornell.

title: Products Slide Into More TV Shows, With Help From New Middlemen
description: Leslie Moonves loves to talk about the Steven Spielberg movie "Minority Report." Mr. Moonves, the co-president and co-chief operating officer of Viacom, which owns CBS, Paramount Television and Showtime, still sings the praises of the movie two years after he saw it. But it was not the cinematography or Tom Cruise's star turn that moved him. It was all the brand names -- Lexus, Gap, Reebok, Guinness and American Express -- that found their way into the film.

title: Songs That Vote Early and Often
description: With the election impending, all sorts of musicians have decided to devote their fall releases to political thoughts. Here's a selection from the first wave, representing a musical spectrum from country-rock to metal to urban dance music. These share a leftist perspective, as do albums due for release later this month by John Fogerty, Keb Mo' and others, but the other side may yet make itself heard in the coming weeks.

description: TAGER -- Marcia. Beloved wife and mother, died September 5, 2004. Survived by sons Mike, Andy, David, Geoff and Ed and Al Blackman; daughters-in-law Lisa and Jennifer; grandchildren Alison, Daniel, Julia and Sarah; sister Anne Kantor; and Susie and Gary Bank, and Amy and Olaf Van Genabeek. Funeral September 8, Wein & Wein, 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, at 11:30 am. Shiva at 193 Elm St, Tenafly.

description: LEVY--Dr. William Leonard. September 4, 2004. Of Providence, RI, formerly of Fall River and Falmouth, MA. Husband of Martha. Father of Rick Levy and Rhea Wilson, Plainfield, VT, Judd and Susan Levy, Manhattan, Deborah Levy, Longmeadow, MA, and Maggie and David Lissy, Westport, CT. Grandfather of seven and greatgrandfather of one. Contributions may be made to the New York Chapter of the National MS Society, 30 West 26th St, NY, NY 10010.

title: OBITUARY
The Comeback Prez
description: WASHINGTON - All that sustained thumb-sucking you heard about this being a polarized electorate, with only a tiny sliver of undecideds, has just ended with a loud pop. Polls that showed John Kerry ahead by a few points going into his convention a month ago now show President Bush up 11 points. That means the old "swing vote" still swings and the battle for voters is in the political center.

title: Colorado Is Not Quite All Better
description: BOULDER, Colo. - The scene at the end of Colorado's victory Saturday night was probably not what the university was looking for after a tumultuous off-season.

title: Re-entering a World Her Heart Had Never Left
description: Anita Baker, the veteran R&B singer, sat in the offices of Blue Note Records in the Flatiron district contemplating a matter of grave importance: what to wear on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno." Would she go conservative or opt for something a little more revealing? Blow her hair out or keep it curly? "I don't know," she said, sighing deeply. "I'll figure out something."

description: Jared Fogle has been portrayed as an avatar of weight loss ever since January 2000, when Subway restaurants began advertising his story of losing 245 pounds while eating low-fat Subway sandwiches.

title: Wrestling With Extension Cords and Gas Cans
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Sept. 5 - The battery was dying on the baby's apnea monitor in the shelter in Fort Pierce as volunteers scrambled for extension cords. Rain was falling directly on kitchen counters in roofless mobile homes outside Vero Beach. Farther inland, green, unripe grapefruit rode the white-capping swells in citrus groves, like lumber rolling down a river.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Perle Asserts Hollinger'sConrad Black Misled Him
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 - Last fall, as the board of Hollinger International prepared to oust its founding executive, Conrad M. Black, the director most protective and supportive of him turned to a friend and balked.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  With their party conventions behind them, members of Congress return Tuesday for a politically charged march to Election Day that has been complicated by the call to reorganize the nation's intelligence agencies and Congress itself.

title: Proposals on How to Handle Options
description: PARIS - ACCOUNTING for stock options has become an international battleground, but those wars may be nearing an end as major industrial countries move toward rules that force companies to deduct the value of options from their earnings.

title: Asean sets regional talks
Dancehall's Vicious Side: Antigay Attitudes
description: When the reggae star Beenie Man came to the Hammerstein Ballroom on Friday, he received his usual welcome. There was a frenetic introduction. There was an exuberant crowd of thousands, waving whatever he told them to wave: hands, flags, cellphones. And out front there were about a dozen pickets, hoisting signs and chanting: "No more murder music! No more murder music!"

title: 2nd Hurricane Deepens Wounds in Stricken Florida
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 5 - Hurricane Frances relentlessly enveloped most of Florida on Sunday in severe squalls, lashing rain and scattershot destruction. In its wide wake, millions of residents were left without power and hundreds of thousands without ready access to gasoline, groceries or other daily staples. Doors and roofs were ripped from an uncounted number of homes and businesses, leaving them exposed to the 6 to 10 inches of rain that poured over them by late afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARAN, SUZANNE
description: MARAN--Suzanne. 5 years gone from us. You are missed and loved each day and are in our hearts forever. Larry, Andy and Caroline

title: INSIDE
description: Spy Case Renews Debate Over Ties to Pentagon The criminal investigation into whether officials from the American Israel Public Affairs Committee passed classified information from a Pentagon analyst to Israel has become one of the most byzantine counterintelligence stories in recent memory and renewed debate over the lobby's ties to conservatives in the Pentagon. title: Taiwanese PC Maker on Verge of Sales Push Into U.S. and China
description: Acer, the Taiwanese personal computer maker, received a cold dose of reality the last time it tried to conquer the world. But it says it has learned its lesson, and it is going after the United States and Chinese markets again.

title: A Lower Drinking Age?
description: To the Editor:

title: Roddick Continues to Show His Dominance
description: It has been an uninspiring United States Open for the American men, who fell apart with remarkable alacrity in the first week of the tournament. Until this year, when Taylor Dent, Mardy Fish and Vincent Spadea all lost in the second round, the Open had never gone into the third round with only two American men.

title: As Greyhound Cuts Back, the Middle of Nowhere Means Going Nowhere
description: RITZVILLE, Wash. - Elva Link is 70 years old and has not owned a car since her white '85 Pontiac broke down four years ago and was too expensive to fix.

title: Breaking Through Diffidence With Poise
description: WANTAGH, N.Y., Sept. 3 - Norah Jones wasn't projecting any mystique when she performed on Friday night at the Jones Beach Theater here. She joked about having a beach named after her, and she admitted she worried about singing the wrong words. When she spoke about adding lyrics to the melody of Duke Ellington's "Melancholia" for the song "Don't Miss You at All," she modestly wondered if he would have disapproved. But whenever she began to sing, girlish diffidence turned into a musician's poise. With outward humility and inner assurance, Ms. Jones has found a cozy niche that has turned out to be hugely popular.

title: Front Porch Hecklers
description: CANONSBURG, Pa., Sept. 6 -- It is a point of pride for John Kerry's campaign that his audiences at mass rallies are not screened. No loyalty oaths, no affidavits, no invitations necessary.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Frank Lloyd Wright Stays Busy in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO - Half a century after Frank Lloyd Wright's renowned Larkin Administration Building was demolished here to make way for a parking lot, this city is taking ambitious steps to reclaim its Wright heritage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLLY, SEYMOUR
description: WOLLY--Seymour, 86, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Farmingdale and Huntington, NY, and Rockville, MD, died September 3, 2004. Beloved husband for 62 years of Ida (Gillman), father of Michael and Marcia, grandfather of Peter, Mark, and Brian, father-in-law of Valentine (Nazarian), and uncle of Bruce Gillman. Sy was a graduate of NYU, a veteran of the Air Force in WWII and the Korean War, proprietor of Wolly's Hardware in Farmingdale, NY, and a volunteer at the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center in Commack, NY, and the Morse Geriatric Center of West Palm Beach, FL. An avid golfer, he was one of the first caddies at Bethpage Golf Course. He will be in our memories forever. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Greater Washington D.C. Chapter, 108 N. Alfred Street, Alexandria, VA 22314. Funeral service will be held September 7 at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 21 E. Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, NY. Call 631-499-6060 for time. Interment Huntington Jewish Center Cemetery.

Ken was a member of the Knickerbocker Club for 50 years and an Honorary member of the Ardsley Country Club. He is survived by his brother Langdon Stevenson and his sister-in-law Mary Fullerton Farr of Mill Valley, CA, and his sister-in-law Margaret R. Stevenson of Haverford, PA, seven nieces and nephews and ten grandnieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held in October. She has no health insurance through the diner, and her husband's insurance ran out after he was on disability for more than a year. But she already knows that she is going to vote for President Bush.

It also comes with a recommendation from one of its chief subjects: Bill Gates of Microsoft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMENFELD, VIOLET
description: BLUMENFELD--Violet. On August 31, 2004. Family and friends deeply mourn her passing. She is survived by her nieces, Frances, Gail, Lora Ann, and nephew Peter, as well as her great and great-greatnieces and nephews. For years she was the kind, patient, and elegant manager of the Swoboda School of Ballet in NYC. Her second career as a travel agent for Ports of Call and Travel Bureau, Inc, took her around the world, making friends wherever she went. Services Tuesday, Spetember 7, at 11:30 am, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: More Speed, More Stuff
description: There is another digital divide, according to a new survey: the one between households that connect to the Internet through a dial-up and those who do so through high-speed broadband. The survey of 1,044 homes by the Diffusion Group, a Dallas-based research firm, found that broadband users rank ahead of dial-up users when it comes to ownership of several kinds of high-tech devices, including DVD players and hand-held computers. A striking gap is found with digital still cameras. Only 57 percent of dial-up households own at least one, compared with 74 percent of houses with high-speed Internet. Michael Greeson, Diffusions president, said that might be partly because high-speed homes are more likely to be families with children.

title: Schrder's Party, Under Fire for Cuts, Is Routed in State Election
description: BERLIN, Sept. 5 - Chancellor Gerhard Schrder and his Social Democrats suffered a stinging loss in the western state of Saarland on Sunday in the first of several regional elections whose outcome may measure the political price of unpopular cuts in social welfare programs.

title: Launch of Israeli Spy Satellite Fails
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 6 A An Israeli spy satellite intended to increase the country's surveillance over Iran landed in the sea today after a rocket malfunction shortly after takeoff, Israeli officials said.

Scully, must repay seven months of his salary to the government, federal investigators said today.

title: Gerard Piel, 89, Who Revived Scientific American Magazine, Dies
description: Gerard Piel, a science writer and editor who helped revive Scientific American magazine a half-century ago and made it thrive, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital of Queens. He was 89 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: A Sociologist With an Advanced Degree in Calamity
description: WASHINGTON - Kathleen Tierney, 55, a professor of sociology at the University of Colorado, has a rsum that reads like a postmodern version of the Book of Job: she has worked Hurricane Andrew, the Los Angeles riots and a succession of nasty California earthquakes.

title: Thousands Protest Near Red Square Over Killings at School
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7  Tens of thousands of people massed near Red Square today to mourn their slain children, while President Vladimir V. Putin vented his anger at the killers and at critics who call for a moderate response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAAR, PHILIP
description: DAAR--Philip, 93, died August 29th at home in Walnut Creek, CA. Son of immigrant parents, he was a native of NYC. A graduate of De Witt Clinton HS and City College with graduate work at Columbia. Remembered as an inspiring and colorful physics teacher and union activist at Midwood HS, Flushing HS and C.W. Post College. Owned and directed a children's camp, Schroon Lodge Camp in the Adirondacks. Phil had a full and rich retirement. Always interested in underlying principles, he studied philosophy at Queens College. He became a talented artist. He sang in the Great Neck and Queens College choruses. Moving to California in 1992, he founded the Rossmoor Philosophy Club and continued his art despite a debilitating Parkinson's disease. His work was exhibited at a juried art show. Phil was a person of balance and strength, inner and outer. He mixed a deep and inquiring intelligence with wit and humor. He was one of a kind. He was much loved by his wife, Charlotte, sons and daughters-in-law, Frank and Sheila, Steven and Dale, Randy and Susan; daughter, Judy; daughter and son-in-law, Melissa and Osvaldo; grandchildren, Noah, Mitchell, Alan, Violet, Tomas, and Samuel.

title: Head scarves in France : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPNICK, SYLVIA (SYD)
description: KAPNICK--Sylvia (Syd). Died at age 84 on September 3, 2004. Beloved wife and dearest friend of Oscar Kapnick. Devoted and loving mother of Steven Kapnick, the late JoAnne Kapnick and the late Susan Kapnick Bart. Devoted and loving mother-in-law of Joan Kapnick and Jacob Bart. Adored and cherished grandmother of Joshua and Madelyn Bart. She was a strong and independent woman, deeply loved and respected by all those who knew her. Together with her husband, she contributed to many charitable activities including longtime support for the Sound Shore Medical Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, United Hebrew Geriatric Center, the Guidance Center and Temple Israel of New Rochelle. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY, on Wednesday, September 8, at 10 AM. Shiva will be observed on Wednesday and Thursday at the Bart residence.

title: Yanks Show Visitors No Shelter
description: The Yankees finally played ball last night, taking advantage of an opponent that looked as if it had spent the whole day sitting in ballparks, on buses and in an airplane.

title: A Mythic Reality
description: The best book I've read about America after 9/11 isn't about either America or 9/11. It's "War Is a Force That Gives Us Meaning," an essay on the psychology of war by Chris Hedges, a veteran war correspondent. Better than any poll analysis or focus group, it explains why President Bush, despite policy failures at home and abroad, is ahead in the polls.

title: For Clinton's Lead Surgeon, Little More Than a Day's Work
description: Dr. Craig R. Smith was supposed to have Friday off. He left his home in Westchester County, N.Y., and drove toward the Adirondacks, where he and his wife honeymooned 34 years ago, and where they planned to celebrate their anniversary Sunday at their summer home.

title: Von Furstenberg takes Paris
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota Increasing Production In China
description: Toyota Motor and a Chinese partner, Guangzhou Automobile Group, will spend 3.8 billion yuan ($460 million) to build a factory in southern China. The plant, in the city of Guangzhou, is scheduled to produce 100,000 Camry sedans a year beginning in 2006. Toyota, the world's second-largest carmaker after General Motors, is a latecomer to China, where it lags many of its smaller global rivals in terms of sales. Volkswagen is the market leader in China with nearly a third of sales there, followed by G.M. and Honda Motor. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Barn Doors Close at Saratoga
description: Saratoga Race Course concluded its 36-day meeting yesterday without two noteworthy names adding to their accomplishments.

title: Before vote, NATO will increase Afghan force
Start-Up Invests Faith in 99 Students
description: Years from now, in a city that has yet to be made, a lawyer, a pediatrician, a teacher or perhaps even a millionaire turned philanthropist will ponder life's crazy course and remember how their futures began on this very day.

title: Hull and Routine Grow Old Together for United States
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 6 - Some people still think of Brett Hull as his father's son, but he has long been his own man. He showed it as an amateur two decades ago when he chose to play for the United States after Canada rejected him.

title: India and Pakistan End 2 Days of Talks; Make Gains on Some Issues but Not on Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 6 - The foreign ministers of India and Pakistan concluded two days of talks here on Monday, with modest progress on a host of issues and an unusually blunt acknowledgment that the dispute over Kashmir still looms between them. But privately, officials from both sides said they remained hopeful about the peace efforts.

title: The Early Bird Gets the Free Hot Dog and Soda
description: Chris Cook piled his wife, daughter and two nephews into the car at 5:30 yesterday morning for the four-hour drive from his home in Glens Falls, N.Y., to Yankee Stadium. He did not mind the long trip or the early departure. This was supposed to be a special day, a rare trip to a Yankees game and a birthday present for his 10-year-old daughter, Jennifer.

title: A Universe of Loss and Recovery for 9/11 Families, Survey Shows
description: They would always be their own universe, the 9/11 families. They were the people the victims did not come home to that day, the people who lived with an emotional rawness that was immediate, extraordinarily public and enduring.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the economy's lackluster rate of job creation misstated the pace of employment growth foreseen by the president's Council of Economic Advisers last December. To realize the council's forecast of the total number of jobs held by Americans in 2004, the economy would have to create more than 300,000 jobs a month this year, not 216,000.

title: Enough to Make Handel Reach for His Walkman
description: During the late 1720's Handel had two rival prima donnas in the London opera company he ran: Francesca Cuzzoni and Faustina Bordoni. From all reports both were superb sopranos and powerful artists with big personalities. Like the savvy showman he was, Handel stoked the rivalry by including tailor-made roles for each of them in several of his operas. The public loved it. Warring Cuzzoni and Bordoni fans routinely interrupted performances with competing ovations and catcalls.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Business Investment Grows
description: Investment by Japanese corporations rose 10.7 percent for the second quarter of 2004 from the same quarter a year earlier, easing concerns that Japan's economic recovery may be slowing. The increase follows a 10.1 percent gain for the first quarter. Last month, the government reported that the economy grew at a surprisingly slow annual rate of 1.7 percent in the second quarter, compared with 6.6 percent in the first quarter, citing weaker capital spending. With the new data, economists now expect the government to raise its economic growth estimate when it releases revised figures on Friday. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Palestinian voter registration included one organization erroneously among those that might benefit if the Fatah faction of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, faltered in elections. The gainers would be Hamas, Islamic Jihad and the leftist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Hezbollah, centered in neighboring Lebanon, is not a Palestinian party, so it would not gain any electoral advantage. (Go to Article)

title: The Latest Poll

The album created a sensation in Spain, becoming one of the top-selling albums in that country's history. The critic Ben Ratliff of The New York Times hailed "Lgrimas Negras" as "one of the great new cross-pollinating documents of Latin music" when he named it 2003's Album of the Year.

title: Voter ID Problems in Florida
description: There is no excuse for turning away eligible voters at the polls, but that is what apparently happened in Florida's primary elections last week. Under Florida law, registered voters can vote without showing identification. But election officials at some polling places misstated the law and tried to keep eligible voters from voting. In one county, the official sample ballot got the law wrong. Officials in Florida, and nationwide, must improve their poll workers' training and written materials to ensure that this does not happen in the November election.

title: Perseverance Pays Off for the Jets' Reese

The box office rose again in the summer of 2004 as it has in recent years, but this season it felt as if Hollywood found a way to give audiences their money's worth, industry executives said.

title: On Labor Day, Nominees Have Work to Do
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - With the presidential race down to a two-month stretch, Republicans and Democrats are in unison on two points: President Bush is in a more commanding position than many in his own party forecast only a month ago, while Senator John Kerry is struggling to catch up. Mr. Bush seems to have hit his political stride at the very moment that Mr. Kerry is facing fundamental questions about his candidacy.

title: N.Y.U. Student Is Killed in Fall at Tisch School
description: A 23-year-old graduate film student at New York University fell to her death yesterday from the roof of the Tisch School of the Arts in what school officials said was apparently a suicide. It was the seventh high-profile death of an N.Y.U. student in a year, and the second death of a Tisch student in less than a week.

title: General Says Less Coercion of Captives Yields Better Data
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 6 - American interrogators working in Iraq have obtained as much as 50 percent more high-value intelligence since a series of coercive practices like hooding, stripping and sleep deprivation were banned, a senior American official said Monday.

title: Telling Time in Margaritaville
description: WANTAGH, N.Y., Sept. 4 - All year long, unlikely acts have been sidling up the Billboard charts, scoring No. 1 hits before many listeners know their names. But one of the summer's most surprising No. 1 albums was "License to Chill" (RCA), by a singer whose name everyone knows: Jimmy Buffett.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Progress For Coke In Inquiry
description: The Coca-Cola Company moved closer to settling a five-year European Commission antitrust inquiry after regulators said yesterday that an offer from the company to revamp its sales practices was very good. "The commission is very satisfied with what is on the table," commission spokesman Tilman Lueder said about Coca-Cola's offer last week to make changes to its practices in Austria, Belgium, Britain, Denmark and Germany. The commission will consult major customers and competitors for their reaction, he said. The European Union began an inquiry in 1999, after a complaint by a rival PepsiCo Inc. into whether Coca-Cola was using rebates to persuade retailers to keep competing products off their shelves.

title: Fighting the AIDS Epidemic by Issuing Condoms in the Prisons
description: The novelist E.Lynn Harris has become a fixture on the best-seller list and a favorite among black women by writing steamy books about men who live "on the down low" -- men who cheat on wives and girlfriends by having sex with other men. The fear of men "on the down low" is now palpable among black women, who are more than 20 times as likely to contract AIDS as white women and are understandably anxious about protecting themselves. This fixation has also become a cottage industry, dealt with in books, lectures, plays and an episode of the popular television series "Law & Order."

description: The former communications adviser to Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin, Dominique Ambiel, was found guilty of soliciting sex from an under-age prostitute and was fined $1,800 by the Paris court. Mr. Ambiel was arrested with a teenage Romanian prostitute in his car last April. He denied the charges but resigned his government post. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: When Dog Bites Dog, Man Is Next
description: New York is a place where eight million people share a crowded landscape with roughly one million dogs -- and where as many as 10,000 people have been bitten by dogs in a single year. People who love dogs and people who don't can peacefully coexist only when dog owners handle their animals responsibly and the authorities intervene promptly when dangerous animals place people, and other animals, at risk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMBERG, ESTERITA (CISSIE)
description: BLUMBERG--Esterita (Cissie), 76, of Liberty, New York, died peacefully with her family at her side on September 3, 2004. She was the mother of Paul (and Noelle), and Amy (and Michael) Goldbas, Simsbury, CT, second mother of Kris Ohlson, grandmother of Matt, Jamie, Joanna, Jessie and Jake, sister of Robert (and Harriet) Rosenberg. Predeceased by her husband and best friend Larry Blumberg, they owned and operated Green Acres Hotel. She authored the popular book "Remember the Catskills-Tales of a Recovering Hotelkeeper" and was a columnist for the Sullivan County Democrat. She was active in progressive politics and community affairs, following in her father's footsteps, who was one of the first Socialists elected to the New York State Assembly, as well as the executive vice president of the Ladies Garment Workers Union. Cissie ran for Congress, was on the Board of Education, and was appointed by the governor of New York State to serve on the Board of Visitors for Rockland Psychiatric Center. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, September 8, 2004, at 1 PM in the Garlick Funeral Home, 388 Broadway, Monticello, NY. The family will receive on Wednesday, September 8, 2004 at 4-8 and Thursday, September 9, 2004, at 2-8, at her home in Liberty. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be sent to any group working to unseat George Bush, or to the New Hope Community, Box 289, Loch Sheldrake, New York 12759.

description: High oil prices and a new outbreak of bird flu combined to slow Thailand's economic growth in the second quarter, according to statistics released yesterday. The National Economic and Social Development Board said the economy grew 6.3 percent in the three months ended June 30 compared with a year earlier, down from 6.6 percent growth in the first quarter. title: General Pinochet's Day in Court
description: The law is at last catching up with Gen. Augusto Pinochet, whose Chilean military regime oversaw the killing of thousands of political opponents during the 1970's and 1980's. Late last month, Chile's Supreme Court lifted the immunity that had long shielded General Pinochet from accountability for his actions during those tragic years. As a result, prosecutors may now be able to bring charges against the unrepentant former military dictator, now 88 years old, for some of the more notorious crimes carried out in his name, and, according to allegations, on his orders.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Record Auto Production In August
description: Automakers in Brazil increased output last month for the fourth month, producing 198,058 vehicles, a record for the month of August. That was a 5 percent increase from July and a 47 percent jump from a year earlier, the country's automakers' association said yesterday. Domestic auto sales, meanwhile, dropped 2.5 percent from the previous month to 130,483 vehicles, in part because of a truckers' strike that slowed delivery to dealerships. However, on a year-on-year basis, auto sales jumped 29.5 percent last month. Exports also rose again in August, to $773.3 million, bringing the year-to-date total to $5.14 billion. The auto sector expects exports to total $7.5 billion this year. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: China Ex-President May Be Set to Yield Last Powerful Post
description: BEIJING, Sept. 6 - Jiang Zemin, China's military chief and senior leader, has told Communist Party officials that he plans to resign, prompting an intense and so far inconclusive struggle for control of the armed forces, two people with leadership connections say.

Devoted aunt of Laura, Janice, Rachel and Melissa. Her many friends and relatives in Belgium, France and the United States will miss her love, her loyalty, her wit, her kindness, her goodness. There will be a private memorial service. Contributions in her memory to a charity of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Credit Suisse Names Chief
description: Credit Suisse First Boston hired Zhang Liping to head the investment bank's China business. Mr. Zhang, 45, succeeds Wei Christianson, who quit after the June departure of John J. Mack. Mr. Zhang was chairman of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson's unit in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan from 1998 and 2001, Credit Suisse said in a statement. Most recently he was chief executive of Imagi International Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed producer of animated motion pictures.

Mrs. Poor spent most of her life in Ridgewood, NJ and was a member of the Westside Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood. She was the benefactor and supporter of the Forum School in Wyckoff, NJ. The family will have a private memorial service at a later date. She is survived by her son, Timothy Poor and his wife Teresa of Pine Knoll Shores, NC; four grandchildren, Lauren and Diana Poor of Pine Knoll Shores, NC, and Tara VanNostand and Stephen Breitenbach, both of Long Island, NY; and also three great - grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her husband, Richard W. Poor, and a daughter, Susan P. Breitenbach. Munden Funeral Home, Morehead City, NC.

description: YONKERS, Sept. 4 - Akeem Smith, 15, had it all worked out. Tenth grade was going to be all right.

title: Sugar Is Sweet ... and Unhealthy
description: To the Editor:

title: EU tries to cool dispute with Russia over hostage episode
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It will be all 9/11, all the time."

title: Global Shares Rise, Led by Technology Issues
description: Stocks around the world advanced yesterday, led by technology-related companies including LogicaCMG and Canon, amid optimism that a recent slump was exaggerated given the outlook for earnings growth.

title: Shhhh! Pretend You've Never Seen Those Styles
description: When buyers from the biggest stores in the world take their seats before the hotly lighted runways of New York's Fashion Week, which starts tomorrow, they will uphold the fiction that they are seeing the new silhouettes, the new styles and the new colors from American designers for the first time. The waiting -- and the pre-show chatter -- intensifies; when a hush descends, the audience sits up in anticipation.

title: Grief in Russia Mixes With Harsh Words for Government
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6 - As Russia began two days of national mourning for the victims of a school siege in North Ossetia, criticism mounted over the government's handling of the wave of terrorism that has taken more than 500 lives in the past two weeks.

title: It Is a Reality Boxing Show, but the Real Fight Is Elsewhere
description: The bell will sound tonight and punches will be thrown, but the combatants who really want to take each other's heads off won't be in the ring when the Fox reality series, "The Next Great Champ," goes on the air at 9 p.m.

title: Another Theft Arrest
description: ANOTHER THEFT ARREST -- A screener employed by the Transportation Security Administration has been charged with stealing about $500 in cash from the suitcase of a Delta Air Lines passenger at Mid-Continent Airport in Wichita, Kan. Eric Melgren, the United States attorney for Kansas, said that Chad Butler, 33, of Wichita, was indicted by a federal grand jury after being arrested Aug. 25. Mr. Butler resigned from his job, the T.S.A. said. Since April, about two dozen T.S.A. screeners have been charged with stealing from bags at airports in Detroit; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; New Orleans; New York; and Philadelphia.

title: Go Where the Money Is: On the Subway
description: THE opening line, delivered almost like a mantra only at maximum decibels, has become as familiar to subway riders as the warning to stand clear of the closing doors. With slight variations, it goes like this: "Ladies and gentlemen, sorry for disturbing you."

title: Q & A
description: The Drain or the Dump?

title: Boy Dies; Mother Charged
description: A woman in Suffolk County was charged with assault yesterday in the death of her 4-year-old son, whom the police said she had beaten.

title: Bush Unlikely to Fulfill Vow on Deficit, Budget Office Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 A Almost regardless of what happens in Iraq and Afghanistan, President Bush is very unlikely to fulfill his promise of reducing the federal budget deficit by half within five years, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: Two Decades Uncovering the Next New Thing
description: What is the next big thing? That Fuji blimp of a question tends to hover in the air over the fashion world, never more ominously than at the kickoff of the twice-yearly New York Fashion Week, which starts on Wednesday. Compulsory novelty is a given in fashion, of course. But is it always a good thing?

title: Global Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOLDBERG, WILLIAM ERIC
description: GOLDBERG--William Eric. January 2, 1971-Sept 7, 2000 Today marks four years since you left us. We miss your smile, your laughter and your unending support. You are forever in our hearts and we miss you every minute of every day. You are our angel--please watch over us. We love you. Love, Mom and Heather

title: Drowned, Not Downed, Trees in the Amazon Get Nasty
description: TUCURU, Brazil - A funny thing happened back when the Brazilian government was building the giant $8 billion dam that bears the name of this town in the eastern Amazon. Somebody neglected to cut down the trees and clear the other growth in the 1,100-square-mile area that would be flooded, and 20 years later that has become a problem.

title: Helping Frequent Fliers Redeem Miles for Tickets, Online
description: Everybody mutters darkly about the difficulty of redeeming frequent flier miles for free travel. Long telephone sessions trying to pin down that elusive seat are typical, and sometimes the experience is almost as frustrating for the airline agent as for the customer.

title: Colombian Soldiers Said to Assassinate Union Leaders
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 7 A The attorney general's office in Colombia said late Monday that Colombian soldiers assassinated three union leaders last month, an account that contrasts sharply with the army's earlier claim that the three men were Marxist rebels killed in a firefight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Must Return To Court
description: The chief in-house lawyer for Yukos, Dmitry Gololobov, was ordered to appear before prosecutors to discuss claims of asset-stripping by Yukos managers at Eastern Oil after its acquisition by Yukos. His office and apartment were also searched. Investigators of the Russian prosecutor general's office called Mr. Gololobov for questioning, and a Yukos spokesman, Alexander Shadrin, told the Interfax news agency that the search was conducted under the auspices of a criminal case against a shareholder of the oil company, Leonid Nevzlin. Mr. Gololobov told Interfax that he considered the summons and searches a repressive measure. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Who's the Outsider? Well, That Depends on Where You Stand
description: THE LOVE WIFE By Gish Jen 379 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Dental Advice: Start Early. Very Early.
description: If you waited until your children started school to take them to the dentist, you waited too long. Good dental care starts in infancy, even before the first tooth emerges. By school age, children should be well on their way to a lifetime of healthy teeth and gums.

title: Global Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHAPIRO, ALVIN
description: SHAPIRO--Alvin. 09/07/26-07/19/03. Dearest Al/Dad/Poppy, our love is here to stay. We miss you so much. Helen, Kids & Grandchildre

title: Clinton Is Given Bypass Surgery for 4 Arteries
description: Former President Bill Clinton, a cigar-smoking workaholic whose family history of heart disease and passion for junk food had set him up for a heart attack in the near future, underwent successful quadruple coronary bypass surgery yesterday at a hospital in New York, his doctors said.

title: How to Watch the Watchers
description: Last week President Bush issued four executive orders addressing matters that were subjects of recommendations by the 9/11 commission. One of the four orders created a President's Board on Safeguarding Americans' Civil Liberties. While it is laudable that a civil liberties board was included in the first set of presidential actions in response to the commission's recommendations, the new board falls short of addressing the concerns that led the commission to recommend the creation of a meaningful oversight board in the first place.

title: Once Again, Mets Sputter Toward End of a Season
description: A year ago, the Mets were going nowhere when they swept the first-place Atlanta Braves in a three-game series at Shea Stadium on the first three days of September. The surprising victories did not really mean all that much: the Braves left town with an 87-52 record, which was still the best in baseball; and the Mets were 62-76, which still left them at the bottom of the National League East.

title: In a Speck of 9/11 Dust, a World of Chaos
description: When David Scharf first examined dust that another photographer had scooped up from her quarantined apartment 350 feet from the collapsed World Trade Center, he was a bit spooked.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Palestinian voter registration included one organization erroneously among those that might benefit if the Fatah faction of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, faltered in elections. The gainers would be Hamas, Islamic Jihad and the leftist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Hezbollah, centered in neighboring Lebanon, is not a Palestinian party, so it would not gain any electoral advantage.

title: Festival in Austria is font of new ideas : On the Danube, art and technology unite
Investors catch up on changes in portfolio direction and strategy : What your fund manager did this summer
Arts Briefing
description: Correction Appended

title: Konarka to Acquire Solar Technology
description: Konarka Technologies, a start-up solar power company based in Lowell, Mass., is expected to announce today that it has acquired from Siemens of Germany the technology to print power cells on flexible sheets of plastic.

title: Baby Boy on Heart Pump Receives Transplant
description: Miles Coulson, a 5-month-old baby who has been kept alive since July 13 by a pump flown in specially from Germany to assist his failing heart, received a heart transplant early yesterday. The transplant took place at Lucile Packard Children's Hospital at Stanford University, where Miles has been a patient since June 12. The operation took four hours, went smoothly and ended about 3:30 a.m., said Dr. Bruce Reitz, who performed the transplant.

title: US Airways Pilots Reject Wage and Benefit Cuts
description: The future of US Airways' drive for $800 million in wage and benefit cuts from its employees is in doubt, after leaders of the pilots union rejected late Monday a bid to have pilots vote on a concessions proposal from the airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FROELICH, DENISE MCN.
description: FROELICH -- Denise McN. September 5, 2004. Beloved wife of Robert L. Froelich, adored mother of Corina Lea and Emma Elizabeth Baumann Froelich, Cecilia Froelich Moss and Helen Froelich Plummer. Funeral Mass Thursday, September 9, 10:00 AM, The Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children, 122 East 42 St, NY, NY 10168.

title: Bush and Kerry Clash Over Iraq and a Timetable
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 - Senator John Kerry and President Bush clashed repeatedly over Iraq on Monday, with Mr. Kerry branding it "the wrong war in the wrong place at the wrong time" and saying he wanted all American troops home within four years, while Mr. Bush defended the war as "right for America then and it's right for America now."

title: A Mosquito's Gift in Singapore: A Bad Case of Breakbone Fever
description: SINGAPORE - It began with a slight headache across my temples, the sort of feeling you would expect after a long day of meetings. By the time I returned home, I had begun to feel flu-ish. The headache became a migraine, concentrated behind my eyes, as though a pair of imps were squatting under my frontal lobe, kicking at my sockets. I spent the night vomiting, delirious, with a fever that crept close to 104 degrees.

title: An Actor's Craft and His Faith Intersect
description: AASIF Mandvi's first lesson on the racism that can come with living in a community where you are different should have prepared him for his second. As a small Indian-born schoolboy in the working-class town of Bradford, England, he was often taunted and chased home from school by "the white boys."

title: Laissez-Faire My Gas Guzzler, Already
description: "I don't like gas being this expensive," said Paul Kaesberg, an oncologist at the University of Wisconsin Hospital and Clinics in Madison who routinely pays $1.90 a gallon. "My driving is integral to my job, it's integral to my pleasure in life. I won't cut back on that. I might cut back on other things."

title: Endowment Chairman Coaxes Funds for the Arts
description: WASHINGTON - One summer afternoon, Dana Gioia, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, brought his staff and his board of advisers to the Capitol for a tour. Their guide was Representative John L. Mica, Republican of Florida.

title: 1904:Bad News for Russia : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: 4 Ministers Stepping Down
description: A cabinet shake-up appeared in the offing in the wake of a Syrian-ordered amendment of the Constitution to give a three-year extension to Syria's chosen Lebanese president, mile Lahoud. Environment Minister Fars Boueiz, who had been a potential presidential candidate and delivered a passionate speech against the amendment last week, announced that he was resigning, saying, "It is not natural I should remain in a government with which I differ on a pivotal national issue." Walid Jumblatt, the Druse chieftain who is a political enemy of Mr. Lahoud and who has also opposed the constitutional change, said three ministers aligned to him -- those for culture, the economy and the displaced -- would present their resignations today. John Kifner (NYT)

title: 7 U.S. Marines and 3 Iraqis Are Killed in a Car Bomb Attack
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 6 - A car bomb tore through a convoy of American and Iraqi troops near Falluja Monday morning, killing seven marines and three Iraqis in the single deadliest attack on American troops in four months, American military officials said. It was not immediately clear whether it was a suicide attack.

title: EU praises Coke offer to change contracts
World Business Briefing | Europe: Oil Prices Hurt Airlines
description: European airlines may have trouble meeting earnings forecasts because of high oil prices, Standard & Poor's said yesterday. Additionally, airlines and manufacturers of airplane parts "could suffer weakening credit quality," analyst Leigh Bailey wrote in a report. The only way for airlines to avoid this weakening is to pass fuel costs to consumers, the rating agency report said. That may prove difficult. Competition has increased in recent years, as new low-cost carriers entered the market, undercutting prices set by more established airlines. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: MIDDLE EAST

description: THE CLAIM -- A nightcap will help you sleep.

description: Images taken by Project Rebirth, a nonprofit organization dedicated to creating a historical record of the rebuilding at ground zero.

title: Car Design at M.I.T.
Speransky Children's Hospital
description: A Moscow hospital is filled with a mournful buzz and the activity of people grasping for a way to help six survivors of the three-day hostage-taking at Middle School No. 1.

title: THREE YEARS ON: Sept. 11, 2001 : U.S. visa delays sap corporate bottom line
Wall St. Banker Given a Harsher-Than-Required Sentence
description: A federal judge imposed a harsher-than-required sentence today on Frank P. Quattrone, a leading technology investment banker of the 1990's who was convicted of obstruction of justice in May.

title: Bob Evans, Who Helped I.B.M. Transform Data Processing, Dies at 77
description: Bob O. Evans, a computer scientist who in the 1960's led the development of a new class of mainframe computers -- the famous 360's -- helping turn I.B.M. into a data-processing power, died on Thursday in Hillsborough, Calif. He was 77.

title: Publicis Shakes Up Its New York Office
description: Publicis Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, is reorganizing the creative department at its New York office, which includes the departure of the senior executive there.

title: A Sudden Fall From Up High, Landing on a Trampoline
description: Written, produced and directed by Dardo Toledo Barros, a Brazilian financier turned filmmaker, "I Hate So Paulo" is the story of Daniel (Claudio Fontana), a Brazilian financier who becomes a filmmaker.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Burning Cables Cause Evacuations
description: Seventy people were evacuated from two TriBeCa buildings yesterday after electric cables and insulation burned beneath manholes and released dangerous levels of carbon monoxide, Fire Department officials said. The buildings, near the corner of Vestry and Hudson Streets, were evacuated just before 10 a.m. and reopened by 5 p.m., said Martha Liipfert, a spokeswoman for Consolidated Edison. Carbon monoxide levels had reached 205 parts per million, fire officials said, about 20 times what is considered a safe level, although there were no reported injuries. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Britain refuses to put cap on auditors' liability
Racial 'Handicaps' and a Great Sprint Forward
description: BEIJING, Sept. 7 - He is now nicknamed "the Yellow Bullet." His gold medal is said to be "the heaviest," or most significant, of the 32 that China won in the Athens Olympics. He carried the Chinese flag in the closing ceremonies and has returned home to riches and glory.

title: The Convention: 2 Scenes
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Weehawken: 3 Light-Rail Stations Open
description: New Jersey Transit opened three new light-rail stations yesterday, extending service north from Hoboken Terminal to Weehawken. The three new stops at Second and Ninth Streets in Hoboken, and at Lincoln Harbor east of 19th Street in Weehawken, are part of a $1.2 billion effort to link much of northern New Jersey via rail. A one-mile extension in Bayonne, from 34th Street to 22nd Street, was completed last year. Three more stations will open over the next year: at Port Imperial, in Weehawken; at Bergenline Avenue in Union City; and at Tonnelle Avenue in North Bergen. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about financial practices at the James Beard Foundation, the culinary charity in New York, referred imprecisely to a comment from a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service. The spokesman, who was not identified, said organizations like the Beard Foundation would not necessarily violate their nonprofit status by doing little beyond holding dinners and events. The spokesman referred to nonprofit organizations in general and did not discuss the foundation itself.
