description: In This Case, It Came Straight From Video

title: Eastern German Chemical Industry Stages a Comeback
description: Correction Appended

title: Fed Chief Hints at More Interest Rate Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 A Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that economic expansion had "regained some traction" after the slowdown earlier this summer, and he suggested that the central bank would stick to its plan of gradually raising interest rates in September and in the months that follow.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 30 about new security portals that can detect microscopic traces of explosives as people pass through included an erroneous price from General Electric, the manufacturer, for the model at the Statue of Liberty, known as EntryScan 3. It costs $132,000, not $40,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, DAVID ANTHONY
description: ROSS--David Anthony. Age 60 of New York City and East Hampton. On September 7, 2004. Dear husband of Penelope and the late Andrine, stepfather of Robert and Reed Kemp, brother of Richard, Alfred, Peter, Mary Louise Irvine and Donald, and devoted uncle to 18 nieces and nephews. Memorial visitation at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue. Thursday, September 9, 6-9PM. Funeral Mass, Friday, September 10, 11AM, Most Holy Trinity Church, Easthampton. Contributions in memory of David to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10022, would be appreciated by the family.

title: Straight From the Rabbit's Mouth
description: "I'VE never liked salad dressing because I love the flavors of different lettuces too much," Josh DeChellis said, slicing two tomatoes into eighths with a chef's knife. "So many dressings mask the salad."

title: U.S.-Philippines : It's time to get together again
Paid Notice: Deaths   BURGESS, WHITEHEAD, IRETA B.
description: BURGESS - WHITEHEAD -Ireta B. On September 6, 2004, beloved wife of the late Louis Whitehead, dear sister of the late Mary Stedman, and the late Walter Burgess. Proud resident of New York City and long-time member of The University Club. Services Thursday September 9th, 1:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Hot nights in Copenhagen
Calendar Quirks and Teacher Training Translate Into Slow Start for Schools
description: They call themselves the Single Moms Club, and one evening just before Labor Day they were gathered in one member's Upper West Side apartment eating mango sorbet and Caesar salad and watching "The Golden Girls" on TV while their children, ranging from first graders to sixth graders, romped around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKOWITZ, SABINE
description: BERKOWITZ -- Sabine. Sur vived by son Albert Baumgarten. Funeral Wednesday September 8, 1 PM at Plaza Memorial Chapels. BERKOWITZ -- Sabine. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of our member Sabine Berkowitz. May her entire family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Joseph S. Kaplan, President Paulette Papilsky, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, MILDRED (MILLIE)
description: WEISS--Mildred (Millie). The Board of Directors and members of Bocaire Country Club Inc in Boca Raton, Florida record with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Millie Weiss on September 5, 2004 in Munster, Indiana. Our deepest sympathies go to her husband Marvin (Mickey) and all of her family. Services were held at 11 AM, Tuesday, September 7 at Burns-Kish FH in Munster, IN Kurt Merl, President

title: British Soldier Charged With Murder of Iraqi
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 - A British soldier who served in a tank regiment in Iraq was charged here on Tuesday with murdering an Iraqi civilian in August 2003.

title: Tkachuk Leads U.S. to Victory Over Russia
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 7 - In a high corner of Xcel Energy Center, a large group of vocal fans of the Russian team displayed the flag of their country and the flag of the former Soviet Union for Tuesday night's quarterfinal game between Russia and the United States in the World Cup of Hockey.

title: Lemieux Reigns in Hockey's Shared Memory
description: TORONTO, Sept. 6 - Mario Lemieux fell to the ice Saturday night, writhing and clutching his helmeted head. The 19,226 fans at the Air Canada Center gasped, then hushed for about a minute. A trainer hurried to Lemieux.

title: Inquiry Proposes Penalties for Hiding Medicare Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - The Bush administration illegally withheld data from Congress on the cost of the new Medicare law, and as a penalty, the former head of the Medicare agency, Thomas A. Scully, should repay seven months of his salary to the government, federal investigators said Tuesday.

title: Heavy Rain Disrupts Subways, Flooding Tunnels
description: Heavy rainfall caused by the remains of Hurricane Frances lashed the New York area today, flooding roads and Manhattan's intricate underground subway network at the peak of the morning rush hour. Hundreds of thousands of commuters were forced to overcome delays or negotiate alternative routes to work.

title: The Magic of Napa With Urban Polish
description: THE butter-poached lobster almost did it, but not quite. I had been wooed with succulent lobster before. The Island Creek oysters and Iranian caviar, mingled in a kind of sabayon that I was served during that same dinner and during others, made a seductive case. But I was wary of such ostentation.

title: Halliburton Weighs Options as Iraq Work Changes
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 7 - The Halliburton Company signaled on Tuesday that it might try to reduce its role as the largest private contractor in Iraq after learning that the Army planned to break apart its largest contract in the country to attract other companies to bid for the work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKULE, JACK
description: BERKULE--Jack. September 8, 1913 to September 6, 2004. Founder of Accounting Statistics Co. and innovator of Payroll Data Processing Services. Devoted and loving husband, strong leader of his family. A brilliant and driven man among men. He will be deeply missed by his beautiful and devoted wife of 65 years, Lee Berkule, his children, Barry and Patricia Berkule, Lloyd (deceased) and Andrea Berkule, and Arlene and Paul Lenok, and his grandchildren, Erik and Stephanie, Samantha, David, Elizabeth and Amanda. His humility, morality and work ethic served as an example to us all. We know you will always watch over us, Dad. We love you. BERKULE--Jack, of Scarsdale, NY, on September 6th, 2004. Beloved husband of Lee Berkule for 64 years, father of Barry (Patricia) Berkule, Lloyd Berkule (deceased), Arlene (Paul) Lenok, grandfather of Elizabeth, David, Amanda, Erik and Samantha. All our love forever and ever. You will always be with us. Services at Riverside Chapel, NYC, Wednesday, 12 noon. BERKULE -- Jack. Founder and President of Accounting Statistics Company, Inc., since 1947. A leader in the payroll data processing field. And the most loved employer. We will never forget you, and we will be always thinking of you. The Employees of ASC BERKULE--Jack. The best father a family could ever wish for, thank you for being with us and guiding us with all your love and knowledge. You will always be in our hearts. Loving you every day forever. Barry, Patricia, Elizabeth Berkule BERKULE--Jack. To my dearest husband, the most loving, kind and, generous man, I'd every known. I will love you forever. Your loving wife, Lee

title: A Ketchup Too Spicy for the G.O.P.
description: CAN a ketchup be too partisan? And what exactly does "conservative" taste like?

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Siemens Says Operators To Approve Phone Update
description: Siemens, the mobile phone maker, said yesterday that service providers including the Vodafone Group agreed to approve a software update that fixes a flaw in its 65 series handsets by the end of the week. Vodafone and T-Mobile International were among operators that removed the handsets from shops in Germany after Siemens said on Aug. 26 that the software problem causes some phones to play a loud melody that may lead to hearing damage. Siemens, which is based in Munich, made updated software available on its Web site yesterday. Operators that add features to the 65 series phones need to test and approve the software before installing it. Vodafone, which took away the handsets from its 1,400 self-managed and franchised shops in Germany, said it needed more time for testing before it could offer the phones again.

title: Squeeze Play: A Different Way To Make Juice
description: A new series of squeezers, color-coded and sized for oranges, lemons and limes, are counterintuitive. From the shape of them, you might be inclined to put the rounded end of a citrus half -- the skin side, not the cut side -- down into the cup of the squeezer. But that's a dead end. Instead, you need to put the flat, cut side down, close the thing and press, and the result is lots of seedless juice and a citrus shell that winds up inside-out. The gadget, based on a traditional Mexican design, is $12.95 to $15.95 at Broadway Panhandler.

title: Town Comes to the Aid of Its Castle
description: REDSTONE, Colo., Sept. 3 - The vast, red-roofed mansion south of town is eerily quiet, its century-old walls closely guarding the secrets of its long-dead guests, people like John D. Rockefeller and Theodore Roosevelt and the coal baron who built it and died there.

title: Administration Intensifies Efforts to Inform Travelers of New Entry Requirements
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 A With only weeks to go before sweeping policy shifts begin affecting foreign visitors at American airports, Bush administration officials are intensifying their efforts to inform travelers from more than 20 industrialized nations to prepare for tough new entry requirements, officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Skater Killed In Accident
description: A 13-year-old boy who was skating behind a bicycle was killed late yesterday afternoon when he was crushed under the wheels of a truck. David Muniz was wearing in-line skates while holding onto the back of a friend's bicycle on Throop Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, the police said. The bike turned, swinging the boy into oncoming traffic, where he was hit by the truck, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said the truck driver would not face charges. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Nokia dangles BlackBerry in effort to tempt more business users
Raise Gas Tax, Not Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifetime Magazine Closing
description: The Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company will cease to publish Lifetime magazine amid disappointing results since the publication's introduction in April 2003.

title: The Good, the Greasy and the Quadruple-Decker
description: WITHOUT looking up from his clippers, David Boswell quietly and thoughtfully discussed the various burgers of his hometown. Mr. Boswell, the owner of the Coleman Barber Shop, a one-chair operation on First Street in Miami, Okla., prefers the thick burgers at the Stables, a local casino.

title: Duty Chafes on Capitol Hill
description: Congress has eased in from a six-week recess of politicking with the reform of the nation's bedeviled intelligence system clearly crying out as the lawmakers' top priority. But don't count on that happening quickly or effectively without some serious pressure. Election Day beckons, and Republican leaders are already wasting precious time on one more go at their oldie-but-goodie election-year issues -- restricting abortion rights, reducing judgments from lawsuits, and protecting the flag and the Pledge of Allegiance -- with one new partisan meat scrap tossed in: banning same-sex marriages. (In shameful contrast, the renewal of the proven assault-weapons ban, which expires Monday, is nowhere in the homeland security priorities of either the Republican-led Congress or President Bush.)

title: North Korea allows foreign law firm to set up shop
Paid Notice: Deaths   PIEL, GERARD
description: PIEL--Gerard. The Board of Managers of The New York Botanical Garden mourns the passing of Honorary Manager, Gerard Piel. Gerry served on The Garden's Board with distinction for nearly three decades, 1971-1998, and since then, as an Honorary Board Member. Of his many volunteer assignments on the Board, among the most important was his leadership of the Botanical Science Committee, which he chaired for many years. We will miss Gerry's devotion to the Gardens' International Plant Science Center, and his wisdom, humor, generosity, and the clarity and facility with which he was able to humanize the language of science. Our warmest condolences go out to his wife, Eleanor Jackson Piel, their two children, Eleanor Womack, and Jonathan Piel, and their families. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Emeritus Gregory Long, President and CEO

title: World Briefings
description: AMERICAS

title: The Convention: 2 Scenes
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Executive Named
description: The Bank of China's Hong Kong unit, which is replacing managers after two deputy chief executives quit amid a fund scandal, has named Raymond Lee as the chief financial officer, three months after he joined as chief operating officer. BOC Hong Kong hired Mr. Lee in June, nine months after external auditors said the lender should reorganize to reduce risk. The bank is also adding more executive directors as recommended and elevating the importance of the rank of chief risk officer. Mr. Lee, also a deputy chief executive, succeeds Law Man Wah, who will become general manager overseeing the financial department, a spokeswoman, Angel Yip, said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Towing Firms May Lose Licenses
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs is seeking to revoke the licenses of three towing companies that it says engaged in practices like illegally towing cars, overcharging customers and issuing improper receipts. The department may also fine the companies up to $100,000 and hopes to get restitution for 65 people who filed complaints. Hearings for the companies -- Port of N.Y.C. in Brooklyn, Yankee Mike's Towing in Queens, and N.Y.'s Finest Towing in the Bronx -- have been scheduled before an administrative law judge beginning next Tuesday. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: At Baylor University, a Struggle Over Mind and Soul
description: WACO, Tex. - Jenny Ebbeling, who graduated from Baylor University in May, jokes that so many changes had occurred on campus since her father dropped her off four years ago, she was worried that he would not recognize the place when he returned for commencement.

title: Unions Vow to Fight Alitalia's Planned Layoffs
description: MILAN, Sept. 7 - A day after the airline Alitalia said that it would cut 5,000 jobs, reducing its work force by almost 25 percent, its unions promised to fight the layoffs through a variety of actions, from more negotiations to brief hunger strikes.

title: The Search for Livable Worlds
description: Scientists eager to find life on other worlds -- or at least ones that might support Life as We Know It -- felt a shiver of excitement last week. Three teams of astronomers reported finding the smallest distant planets yet detected, suggesting that Earth-size planets with benign climates might be just around the corner. But there was a bit of discouraging news as well. A new calculation suggests that scientists may be looking in the wrong places for messages sent by any distant intelligent beings.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Arrest In Fake Marriages
description: The police in Pretoria arrested a 39-year-old priest on charges of illegally sanctioning at least 600 bogus marriages between foreign men and South African women who had no knowledge of the nuptials. The priest, Hendrik Uys Jansen, was thought to be part of a nationwide ring of marriage officers conducting sham marriages, largely on behalf of illegal immigrants who want the benefits of residency that marriage to a South African citizen brings. Thousands of women -- and some men -- have discovered recently that they had been married without their knowledge. The Home Affairs Ministry, which oversees immigration, has acknowledged that corrupt officials in its ranks have been aiding the schemes. Michael Wines (NYT)

ARTHROCARE WILL BUY OPUS TO ADD MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY
description: The ArthroCare Corporation, a maker of devices used in arthroscopic surgery, agreed to buy Opus Medical for $130 million in cash and stock to add technology used to repair shoulder damage. Opus shareholders will receive $30 million in cash and $60 million in ArthroCare stock. Opus will also receive a $40 million payment next year based on 2005 sales, ArthroCare said. Opus Medical's technology may reduce trauma and make repairs of the rotator cuff, the muscle and tendons surrounding the shoulder, faster and easier than traditional surgery, ArthroCare said. ArthroCare, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., expects the purchase to break even in 2005, and add to earnings thereafter. Opus Medical is based in San Juan Capistrano, Calif.

description: A map on Monday with an article about Eskimos who live with climate shift and wildlife changes in the Canadian territory of Nunavut located the former whaling settlement of Pangnirtung incorrectly. It is on the Cumberland Peninsula, just below the Arctic Circle, not to the south on the Hudson Strait.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Nun Is Refused ID Card Over Head Covering
description: A nun in the central city of L'Aquila was told that a photograph of her wearing a habit was not acceptable for a national identity card because her head was covered, Italian newspapers reported, after a civil servant there had also rejected a photograph from a Muslim woman wearing a head covering. The equation between Christian and Muslim practices drew protest from the local Roman Catholic bishop, and local officials are seeking clarification of a national law that requires photographs for the national identity cards to show a person's features clearly. Meanwhile, the papers reported, local officials are temporarily accepting photographs from women with their heads covered as long as their faces are clearly shown. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Elderly, Frail Refugees but Grateful for Help, Remain Stuck in Shelters
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 7 - The big, high-ceilinged exhibition hall here at the Palm Beach County fairgrounds has been turned into what looks like a huge field hospital. No one is critically ill there. But everyone is elderly, and nearly everyone has some kind of health problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FROELICH, DENISE MCN.
description: FROELICH -- Denise McN. September 5, 2004. Beloved wife of Robert L. Froelich, adored mother of Corina Lea and Emma Elizabeth Baumann Froelich, Cecilia Froelich Moss and Helen Froelich Plummer. Funeral Mass Thursday, September 9, 10:00 AM, The Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children, 122 East 42 St, NY, NY 10168. FROELICH -- Denise McN. September 5th, 2004. The Board of Directors and staff of the Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children mourn the passing of Board Member Denise Froelich, a true friend to refugees around the world. We will miss her dedication, spirit, warmth and wisdom. We send our deepest sympathy to her husband Robby and her family. Carolyn Makinson, Exec. Dir. Kathleen Newland, Bd. Chair FROELICH--Denise. The residents and Board of Directors of 875 Park Avenue mourn the passing of Denise Froelich, a longtime friend, neighbor and past president of our Board of Directors. Our prayers and sympathies go out to the entire Froelich family. Harvey Schulweis, President 875 Park Avenue Corp.

description: As most of New York City's 80,000 public school teachers returned to work yesterday, the Department of Education and union leaders offered starkly different portraits of the state of the city schools under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Chancellor Joel I. Klein.

title: World Briefing | North Pole: Just Balmy, But That Was Back Then
description: Layered ancient mud extracted from a submerged ridge near the North Pole has revealed that the now frigid polar waters were a subtropical life-filled sea 55 million years ago. A drilling ship, shielded from drifting sea ice by several icebreakers, extracted a core more than 1,000 feet long over the last three weeks. Researchers on the ship, part of an international ocean-drilling project, say that certain mud layers are filled with fossils of tiny animals and plants that only lived in waters of 68 degrees, a far cry from the 29-degree temperatures typical now. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, DR. LOREN
description: TIERNEY--Dr. Loren. Age 42, died Wednesday, at Calvary Hospital after a long illness. A Rutgers and SUNY Downstate Medical School graduate, she served as Chief Medical Resident, Pulmonary Fellow and Clinical Instructor at NYU/Bellevue for 13 years. She was revered by her patients and widely repsected by her peers. In the years since her illness was diagnosed, she continued to serve her patients with distiction and compassion, and maintained an active, loving home life. She is survived by her parents, Hannah and Myles Tierney, her husband James M. Mumford, M.D., and three children, James, Cooper and Anna. She is also survived by the many people at the Medical Center whose lives she touched and who will never forget her. Palliative Care Service NYU Hospital Center Joseph Lowy, M.D., Dir Catherine X. White, R.N., M.A. Stuart Kaufer, M.S.W., C.S.W. TIERNEY--Loren. Our deepest condolences to the family of our beloved friend, Loren Tierney. She was stolen from everyone she loved and who loved her despite her courageous battle against breast cancer. Even in the very end she showed us how beautiful life is. Her loving friends, Eva Kosta, M.D. Raymonda Rastegar, M.D. Grace Wright, M.D.

Battles in Baghdad Slum Leave 40 Iraqis and a G.I. Dead
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 7 - A weeklong calm that had taken hold of the Shiite ghetto of Sadr City and raised hopes for a peaceful settlement of the armed standoff there dissolved into gun battles Monday night and Tuesday, leaving at least 40 Iraqis and 1 American soldier dead and 202 people wounded.

title: Russia's tragedy : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Shipload Of Toxic Waste Sinks Off Coast
description: Turkish authorities warned of a potential environmental disaster after a rusting ship containing 2,200 tons of toxic material sank at the Mediterranean port of Iskenderun overnight. The Ulla, with its cargo of waste from Spanish power plants, first arrived at the port four years ago, after Algeria, its intended destination, turned the ship away. Turkey had long sought to have the ship returned to Spain. But bureaucratic and legal delays had kept it, and its cargo of carcinogenic materials, moored and rusting in the bay, according to the watchdog group Greenpeace. Susan Sachs (NYT)

title: Delta to Cut Up to 7,000 Jobs in Restructuring Bid
description: Delta Air Lines said today that it would cut 6,000 to 7,000 jobs over the next 18 months as part of a sweeping restructuring plan that the airline said would save $5 billion a year in costs by 2006.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair To Reshuffle Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said he would reshuffle his cabinet by the end of the week. But at a news conference he declined to be drawn into speculation about who might be brought into the government. Political analysts said the changes could reflect renewed tensions between Mr. Blair and his chief rival within the government, the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Britain refuses to put cap on auditors' liability

description: Democrats launched a stinging counterattack today to comments by Vice President Dick Cheney suggesting that a vote for John Kerry could invite another terror attack, with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi calling on President Bush to disassociate himself from such remarks.

title: Bush Deficit Cut Is Seen as Flawed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Even if the United States saved billions of dollars by withdrawing all troops from Iraq and Afghanistan, President Bush would still be unlikely to fulfill his promise to reduce the federal budget deficit by half within five years, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said Tuesday.

title: EU commissioner's remarks on Turkey raising eyebrows
Chasing Puppy Innocence in a Pit Bull World
description: Whether his subject is the jazz trumpeter Chet Baker, teenage boxers or the comfort of pets, the filmmaker Bruce Weber contemplates it with a kind of double vision. One eye is that of an impressionable boy forever on the verge of adolescence, star-struck and flooded with inchoate yearnings. The other is the discriminating eye of a commercial genius, promoting his youthful dream world with the skill of a practiced seducer.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Monday, about assertions that New York City violated the civil rights of some protesters arrested during the Republican National Convention, gave an incorrect attribution for a preconvention estimate of 1,000 arrests per day. That prediction, made in March, was from Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, not Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner. (Mr. Morgenthau attributed the figure to the Police Department, but the department declined to speculate on the number of arrests at the time.)

title: Milosevic Loses Director Role in His Own Courtroom Drama
description: THE HAGUE, Sept. 7 - The ghosts that have long haunted Slobodan Milosevic have finally appeared in court, and they have fundamentally altered the war crimes trial of the former Yugoslav president.

title: Teenager Faces Felony Charges in Fatal Beating of 2 Pit Bulls
description: A Bronx teenager was arrested yesterday on charges that he used a large tree branch to beat two pit bulls to death last week, officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Index Forecasts Growth
description: Japan's index of leading economic indicators was above 50 percent for an 11th month in July, signaling that the world's second-biggest economy will extend five quarters of expansion. The index, which measures job offers, consumer confidence and other indicators of future activity, was at 66.7 percent, the government said, the same as June's revised figure. A reading above 50 percent signals growth in three to six months.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broker Evaluates Proposals
description: The stockbroker Cazenove Group said that it was evaluating proposals from other firms, but did not provide details. The broker, which counts the royal family among its clients, said in May that it was considering takeover offers. Recent reports say that Cazenove executives have talked with J.P. Morgan Chase about a joint venture. Cazenove also reported a 14.8 million pretax profit ($26.2 million), excluding one-time items, in the first quarter, up more than 700 percent from a year ago. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Taught to Be Principals, and Now Facing the Test
description: Rene Y. Belton spent the last year shadowing the principal of a top elementary school and dreaming up solutions to problems like how to appease an irate parent while managing a false fire alarm. She listened to business luminaries like John F. Welch Jr. share tips on leadership, read "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People," created mock school budgets and, when the pressure mounted, took part in group hugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSPAN, EZRA M.
description: GREENSPAN--Ezra M. It is with profound sorrow that the Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague. Founder and First Medical Director of the Chemotherapy Foundation, Dr. Greenspan was a consummate educator who brought intellect, wisdom, great clinical skills, vast expertise and personal integrity to the task of training young physicians. Not only in the forefront of research in medical oncology, he was primarily and especially a personal doctor to all his patients throughout the world. Devoted to medicine, Mount Sinai and its alumni, Dr. Greenspan served as President of the Association in 1968. In 1982, the Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Greenspan in acknowledgement of his profound professional achievements and his extraordinary service to the medical center and the Alumni. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. William Stein, M.D., Pres. Barry Stimmel, M. D., VP Elliot Rayfield, M.D., Secretary Betty Mintz, M.D.,Treasurer

Officials Say Proposed Rules for Gas Leaks Are Too Lax
description: Proposed regulations that would allow Consolidated Edison's gas and steam systems to have a backlog of up to 100 unrepaired -- and potentially lethal -- gas leaks at the end of each year have drawn outrage from some officials, who say the rules do not go far enough in forcing Con Ed and other utilities to stop the leaks from occurring. The regulations come after a study in July revealed that Con Ed had 6,412 gas leaks in 2003, of which 2,251 were considered serious.

title: Expected Call for Advance Registration of Drug Tests
description: The debate over the disclosure of clinical drug trials could reach a turning point this week, with editors of influential medical journals expected to call for fundamental changes in the way such tests are reported.

title: School Siege in Russia Sparks Self-Criticism in Arab World
description: BEIRUT, Sept 8 A The brutal school siege in Russia, with hundreds of children dead and wounded, has sparked an unusual round of self-criticism and introspection in the Muslim and Arab world.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 States Seek Pollution Controls
description: The attorneys general of New York and Connecticut filed a federal lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday calling for the Environmental Protection Agency to issue stricter national standards to limit storm water pollution seeping from construction sites. The suit says that while states like New York and Connecticut already have tough regulations on pollutants like oils, pesticides, and heavy metals from the sites, other states have an unfair competitive advantage by not having them. "Dirty runoff from construction sites is one of the largest sources of water pollution," Attorney General Eliot Spitzer of New York said in a statement also signed by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut. "But now the E.P.A. refuses to act." The statement said that the agency proposed regulations on the discharges in June 2002 but later withdrew them. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Inside The Vault
description: The Green Vault, one of Europe's most valuable treasure chambers with 1,068 paintings, golden objects and jewelry pieces from the Renaissance to the Rococo period, was reopened yesterday at the Royal Palace in the eastern German city of Dresden, almost 60 years after it was bombed and partly destroyed in the last days of World War II. Most of the treasures, many of which were taken to the Soviet Union during the war but returned to East Germany at the end of the 1950's, had been in storage for decades, with only a few pieces on display at the city's Albertinum Museum. The Green Vault, established by the Saxon ruler August the Strong (1670-1733) and originally opened in 1729, was refurbished by the state of Saxony for $30 million. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Missing in Action
description: President Bush claims that in the fall of 1972, he fulfilled his Air National Guard duties at a base in Alabama. But Bob Mintz was there -- and he is sure Mr. Bush wasn't.

title: THE WORKPLACE : Bully them to make them leave
Filmmakers Examining the 'What Ifs' of Nuclear Power
description: Cesium-137 is not your usual topic for a Midtown Manhattan lunch. But if you sit down with Maryann De Leo and Rory Kennedy, who have completed documentaries on the effects on children of the Chernobyl nuclear accident in 1986 (Ms. De Leo) and the Indian Point power plant in Buchanan, N.Y. (Ms. Kennedy), it is not long before the subject comes up. (Cesium-137 is radioactive waste, an isotope produced when uranium or plutonium undergoes fission.)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Pakistani Pleads Not Guilty
description: A Pakistani man who was arrested in July after the Charlotte police saw him videotaping buildings downtown pleaded not guilty to six offenses unrelated to terrorism. Federal prosecutors say the man, Kamran Akhtar, lied to the authorities about his name and his immigration status, possessed false identification and refused to leave the country after he was denied asylum in 1997. Tapes in Mr. Akhtar's possession included images of buildings and transit systems in Atlanta, Dallas, Houston and New Orleans, and the building in Charlotte where the F.B.I. office is situated. Mr. Akhtar's family has said the tapes are innocent tourist ones. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Law Firm Established
description: North Korea has allowed the establishment of the country's first private law firm as part of its efforts to attract international investors, according to a principal in the venture. The firm, Hay, Kalb & Associates, opened an office in Pyongyang on Aug. 15, said Michael Hay, who owns the firm with a North Korean partner. The firm has a dozen lawyers and plans to focus on foreign companies seeking opportunities in North Korea. The establishment of a partly foreign-owned firm in North Korea is an instance in which the Communist government is more open than its capitalist neighbor to the south. South Korea remains closed to foreign law firms. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Halliburton Indicates It May Reduce Iraq Role Halliburton signaled that it may try to reduce its role as the largest private contractor in Iraq after learning that the Army plans to break apart its largest contract in the country to attract additional bidders for the work.

title: Nos. 1, 2 and 3 on Jets' List: Shut Down Running Game
description: From almost the first moment they joined the Jets, defensive ends Shaun Ellis and John Abraham have had careers that have run nearly as parallel as their positions as bookends. They were selected minutes apart in the first round of the 2000 draft. And the contracts that each signed as rookies will expire at the end of this season.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS JOIN REQUEST FOR TRUSTEE AT UNITED
description: The union representing flight attendants at United Airlines joined the machinists' union yesterday in asking a federal bankruptcy court judge to appoint a trustee to run the airline. Such a move would essentially unseat the chief executive, Glenn F. Tilton, but bankruptcy court judges rarely grant such motions except in cases or fraud or clear mismanagement. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers filed a motion last month asking that a trustee be named. Among other matters, United's unions are upset at the company's warning that it is likely to terminate their pension plans and replace them with less-generous retirement programs. Judge Eugene R. Wedoff will hear the request at a Sept. 17 hearing in Chicago, near United's home base. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: Alzheimer's Patient, 88, Kills Wife, Police Say
description: An 88-year-old Queens man with Alzheimer's disease stabbed his 80-year-old wife and beat her to death with a broomstick yesterday morning, the police said.

description: ROSEN--Murray H. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Adoring, protective and generous father of Norma. Loving and proud grandfather of Robin and Richard Schottenfeld and Caren and Marc Tishfield. Affectionate and caring great grandfather of Michael, Jason and Max. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, ERNEST
description: STEIN--Ernest. How can a man approaching 104 be so young? An old fashioned man so forward looking? A serious man so much fun? A stately man so devilish? Yet, he was not paraxdoxical. He was elegant, generous, kind, beautiful. His intellect stimulated us; his music touched our hearts. We will miss our dear friend Ernest. Helen Stambler and Jim Neuberger

title: The Discreet Charm of the Very Bourgeois Toy Store?
description: F.A.O. Schwarz may be shuttered and dark, but its catalog is somersaulting back in the direction of well-heeled children and the adults who indulge them. Luxed up and revamped to appeal to its most affluent customers, the glossy new catalog will arrive at a million households this week.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurance Acquisition
description: The insurance company Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance said it would buy the Asian general insurance operations of Aviva of Britain for $450 million. Mitsui, based in Tokyo, said the deal would probably make it the top provider of nonlife insurance in the region covered by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, ahead of the American International Group. The acquisition will help Mitsui increase revenue overseas amid sluggish growth in Japan. The deal includes Aviva's general insurance businesses in Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: First foreign practice is a lure to investors : Law firm allowed in Pyongyang
World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer's Profit Rises
description: The life insurer, Swiss Life Holding, reported higher profit in the first half as it paid less to pensioners and said it expected a return to premium growth this year. Net income rose to 398 million Swiss francs ($313 million) from 66 million francs a year ago, the company said. Profit included a 164 million-franc one-time gain related to regulatory changes in retirement payments. The company expects "a moderate rate of premium growth" this year after gross premiums fell 4 percent in 2003 following Swiss Life's exit from less-profitable business lines and some markets, the chief executive, Rolf Drig, said. A recent job-cutting program helped reduce expenses, and premiums increased in the company's three biggest markets -- France, Germany and Switzerland.

title: Looking For Literature
description: Anthony Cheetham, the founder and former chief executive of Orion Publishing, will join Random House as a consultant working to sign new authors and explore new publishing opportunities, Random House announced yesterday. Mr. Cheetham will work with Knopf in the United States and the Random House Group in Britain, in addition to working on his own books. Mr. Cheetham founded Orion in 1991 after being ousted from the Random House Group. He had joined Random House in 1989 when it purchased Century Hutchinson, a British publisher. Mr. Cheetham founded Century Ltd. in 1982, later buying Hutchinson. EDWARD WYATT

By the spring of 2002 three cameras were pointed at the pit, each taking one shot every five minutes, round the clock. Months later, three more cameras were added.

Beyers Naude, Who Fought Apartheid, Dies at 89
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 7 - Beyers Naude, an Afrikaner cleric who renounced apartheid, defied his church and became his nation's leading exponent of white resistance to racism, died Tuesday in a Johannesburg suburb, family members said. He was 89 years old.

title: Nokia dangles BlackBerry in effort to tempt more business users
Cheney Warns of Terror Risk if Kerry Wins
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 7 - Stepping up the battle over national security, Vice President Dick Cheney warned on Tuesday that the country would be at risk of a terror attack if it made "the wrong choice" in November, and President Bush accused Senator John Kerry of adopting the antiwar language of his Democratic primary rival Howard Dean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABBETT, RUTH VIRGINIA ''GINNY.''

title: After the Storm
description: Hurricane Amnesia is not the name of a storm. It's a form of memory loss that develops in the wake of a significant hurricane. The storm is remembered, especially for the very real suffering of its victims, but the lessons that should be drawn from it often are not. Thanks to Hurricanes Charley and Frances, Florida has had an unwelcome chance to rediscover things it has learned before. Preparing for a hurricane doesn't mean just boarding up windows and getting out of town. It means much tougher building codes, like the ones that several counties still have on the books. A tougher statewide code would mean tougher structures, and that would mean a better chance of standing up to hurricane-force winds.

title: CAMPAIGN 2004 : Cheney suggests a Kerry victory could invite a terrorist attack
BRITISH AIRWAYS PLANS TO SELL STAKE IN QANTAS AIRWAYS
description: British Airways plans to sell its stake in Qantas Airways, valued at 1.1 billion Australian dollars ($764 million), to improve its balance sheet and to finance possible takeovers, Qantas said yesterday. Trading in Qantas, which is based in Sydney and is Australia's largest airline, was halted as British Airways seeks to sell its 18.25 percent stake in the next 48 hours. British Airways bought its stake in 1993, when Australia's government sought a cornerstone shareholder before selling the rest of the airline in an initial public offering.

description: He remembers Rick Ankiel from last season in the dugout with the Class AA Tennessee Smokies in Kodak, Tenn., a long way from the big leagues.

description: Circuit City Stores, the electronics chain, said yesterday that second-quarter sales rose 8.8 percent, as the acquisition of Canada's InterTan helped the company record its biggest revenue gain in two years.

Treasured mother of Alice and Lucy, grandmother of Tanya, Greg, Ezra, Josh, Gideon and Sam, great-grandmother of Evelyn and Isaac, mother-inlaw of Richard Mandel and William Friedman, grandmother-in-law of Alyson and Amanda. Cherished sister of Marion Hyman, aunt to three nieces and two nephews. Memorial service Friday, September 10 at 2:00 pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, at 91st Street. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Planned Parenthood of New York, 26 Bleecker Street, NY, NY 10012.

Funeral service is 10:30 AM Thursday, September 9, 2004 at Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home, Inc., 100 Franklin Ave., Pearl River. Burial will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: Steinbrenner Wants Answers From M.L.B.
description: The doubleheader that never happened on Monday is now the doubleheader that will be played today. Major League Baseball announced the revised schedule for the Yankees' homestand yesterday, saying the Yankees had dropped their request that Tampa Bay forfeit the game it did not show up for on Monday, but also apologizing to the Yankees and their fans for the inconvenience they endured.

title: 2 Fund Groups to Pay $450 Million to End Inquiry
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 - The Invesco Funds Group and an affiliate, AIM Advisors, agreed on Tuesday to a $450 million settlement with regulators, who accused the companies of improperly allowing favored investors to rapidly trade in and out of their funds.

title: European Economies Slow as Consumers Stay Home
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 7 - The European economy slowed significantly in the second quarter as spending lagged, official reports showed Tuesday, and economists expected growth in the region to be soft into early next year as consumers hang onto their cash.

title: Gay Activists in the G.O.P. Withhold Endorsement
description: The board of Log Cabin Republicans, the largest group for gay men and lesbians in the party, voted overwhelming last night against endorsing President Bush for re-election because of his support for a proposed constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage.

title: Giants Choose Christie for Kicking Experience
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 7 - It was a moment from the cruel theater of life in the National Football League. When place-kicker Steve Christie walked into the Giants' locker room Tuesday morning, he saw the man he was replacing, Todd France. The two did not exchange a word. Christie took a seat at a locker that did not even have a nameplate, a fitting statement about how transient Christie's career -- and the Giants' kicking position -- has become.

title: U.S.-Philippines : It's time to get together again
Does Iran Want Another Lebanon?
description: LONDON - After the peaceful end to the military standoff in Najaf last month, many Iraqis and Americans hoped that the conflict between the Iraqi interim government and the young cleric Moktada al-Sadr had been resolved, and that Mr. Sadr's men would go back to their normal lives. The heavy fighting that erupted in the Baghdad slum of Sadr City yesterday showed that nothing could have been further from the truth. News reports suggest that rather than dispersing, Mr. Sadr's followers have simply returned home to carry on the fight. Thus the fundamental weakness of the Najaf peace deal -- allowing Mr. Sadr's army to keep its weapons -- has finally been exposed, raising the question of what role the militia will play in a future Iraq.

title: INSIDE
description: Fund Companies Settle Case for $450 Million The Invesco Funds Group and an affiliate, AIM Advisors, agreed to a $450 million settlement with regulators, who accused the companies of improperly allowing favored investors to trade in and out of their funds. The settlement, which ends contentious negotiations, caps a year of investigation into the mutual fund industry. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

title: He seeks clearance to re-enter politics : Malaysian high court reviews Anwar's case

description: The first time Alex Rodriguez and the Yankees played the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park nearly five months ago, he said, he felt like a spectator instead of a player, as if he were experiencing the games "outside of my body."

title: U.S. Conceding Rebels Control Regions of Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - As American military deaths in Iraq operations surpassed the 1,000 mark, top Pentagon officials said Tuesday that insurgents controlled important parts of central Iraq and that it was unclear when American and Iraqi forces would be able to secure those areas.

title: Trying to Stone Collaborators, Seoul Party Hits Glass House
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 7 - Drawing ammunition from Korea's rocky 20th-century history, South Korea's president took careful aim at his most prominent rival, and fired. But when the smoke cleared recently, the leader of his own party lay politically dying.

title: CBS Realigns Entertainment Divisions
description: Leslie Moonves, the co-president of Viacom, yesterday realigned the management of the company's CBS entertainment division and Paramount television production studio, promising smoother and greater interaction between the two.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: First Day Of Business In New Parliament
description: Three years late and millions of dollars over budget, the new Scottish Parliament building finally opened for business. The new building, designed by the late Barcelonan architect Enric Miralles, cost 431 million, or more than $760 million, and its construction was dogged by mishaps and accusations of mismanagement. Jack McConnell, the Scottish first minister, called the building stunning. "But for the people of Scotland, it is not this building that really matters," he said. "It is what we do in this building that really matters." A report into cost overruns and delays is to be published next week. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Schrder is bloodied but hopeful
Olive Oils on a Mediterranean Tour
description: JOEY FORTUNATO must be one of the happier chefs in New York these days. Turn into West Fourth Street in Greenwich Village from Charles or Perry Street, and in the middle of the block you will find his newest creation, Extra Virgin, a little gem of a restaurant. On any evening the outside tables -- there aren't many -- will be full and, unless it's raining, half a dozen or more people will be standing around on the sidewalk waiting for tables, inside and out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPNICK, SYLVIA (SYD)
description: KAPNICK--Sylvia (Syd). Died at age 84 on September 3, 2004. Beloved wife and dearest friend of Oscar Kapnick. Adored and cherished grandmother of Joshua and Madelyn Bart. She was a strong and independent woman, deeply loved and respected by all those who knew her. Together with her husband, she contributed to many charitable activities including longtime support for the Sound Shore Medical Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, United Hebrew Geriatric Center, the Guidance Center and Temple Israel of New Rochelle. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY, on Wednesday, September 8, at 10 AM. Shiva will be observed on Wednesday and Thursday at the Bart residence. KAPNICK -- Sylvia "Syd". Temple Israel of New Rochelle expresses condolences to the family of Sylvia "Syd" Kapnick. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Opposition Mayor Freed
description: The mayor of a district of Caracas, a hero to government opponents and an agitator to authorities who say he incited violence, was released after being imprisoned for four months on charges that he organized violent protests outside the Cuban Embassy in Caracas during a coup in April 2002 that briefly ousted President Hugo Chvez. The jailing of Henrique Capriles, the mayor of Baruta, was seen as a politically motivated measure by Mr. Chvez's foes and some foreign diplomats. A judge granted Mr. Capriles conditional freedom pending a trial, requiring him to appear occasionally before a judge. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Study Finds Lack of Data on Health Effects of 9/11 Dust
description: Days before the third anniversary of the destruction of the World Trade Center, federal agencies have yet to make a coordinated and comprehensive effort to study the health effects of the debris that filled the air in the weeks after the attack, according to a draft copy of a government study to be presented to Congress today. The study also shows that there is still no federal treatment program for those suffering from related problems.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some copies of the special Republican convention section on Friday showing the decline in Manhattan commuter traffic last week gave incorrect figures for ridership on the PATH train to and from New Jersey. It was down on Monday by 3 percent (not 39.4), on Tuesday by 4.1 percent (not 37.6) and on Wednesday by 5.9 percent (not 33.8). The higher figures appeared elsewhere in the chart, correctly, to represent the drop in the number of vehicles using the Lincoln Tunnel inbound.

Husband of Letitia Clarke Pallone; loving father of Andrea and Angela Pallone of Wethersfield, CT, Richard (Mery) Scanlon of NYC, Sean (Yngrid) Scanlon of Lincroft, NJ and Sheila (David) Blische of New Hope, PA. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHIRLEY, BETSY BEINECKE
description: SHIRLEY -- Betsy Beinecke died peacefully on September 4, 2004 at her home in Bernardsville, New Jersey. She lived in Bernardsville for more than sixty years and spent her summers on Islesboro, Maine. She was a renowned collector of children's Americana. Her collection includes first editions of books and manuscripts dating back to the earliest years of the American Republic, as well as drawings and paintings from such children's classics as "Treasure Island" and "Eloise." For many years she served as a trustee of the Newark Museum in Newark, New Jersey. She was predeceased in 1996 by her husband of fifty-five years, Carl Shirley. Betsy B. Shirley was born in 1919 in New York City. She was the daughter of Katherine and Walter Beinecke. She grew up in New York City and Nantucket. She is survived by her daughters and sons-in-law, Jody and Tom Gill of Milton, Massachusetts and Betsy and Mickey Michel of Gladstone, New Jersey and six grandchildren, Fritz Michel of Los Angeles, Jake Michel of Washington, D.C., Katie Michel of New York City, Peter Forkner of Arlington, Virginia, Adam Forkner of New York City abd Benjamin Forkner of Los Angeles. She also leaves two great-granddaughters, Sadie Michel Schlesinger and Stella Sperry Michel. Services will be private. The family asks that memorial contributions be made to Big Tree Boating, P.O. Box 273, Islesboro, Maine 04848. For more info contact the Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack, NJ, 908-234-0590.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MSS Group And Telwares To Merge
description: The MSS Group, a consultant firm that helps companies manage their telecommunications spending, and Telwares, which negotiates with carriers on behalf of corporations, said yesterday that they would merge. The combined company, which will be called the MSS Group, will have $50 million in sales and count among its clients 140 companies in the Fortune 500. The lead investors in MSS, based in Denver, are Bank-One and J.P. Morgan Chase. Ken Belson (NYT)

Kelo's tidy pink cottage from the blue house that Wilhelmina Dery's grandmother bought in 1901 and where Mrs. Dery and her husband, Charles, still live.

title: Kerry, Sharpening Criticism of Bush, Lists Costs of Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  Senator John Kerry sharpened his criticism of President Bush today over the costs of the war in Iraq, but the president quickly responded that the Americans who died there would be properly honored only by "completing the mission."

title: Confusing, Yet Captivating
description: Cape gooseberries are not gooseberries at all, but physalis, a member of the nightshade family and a relative of the tomatillo, which they resemble. This small fruit, usually orange, has a papery husk. In the Southeast, it grows wild and is called a ground cherry. Cape gooseberries are juicy, hinting of pineapple, and can be used like cherry tomatoes. They are in Greenmarkets for about $3 a pint until the end of the month. Norwich Meadows Farm (below) has them on Sundays in Tompkins Square and Mondays in Union Square. Oak Grove Plantation has them on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays in Union Square.

title: Bipartisan Bill Offered on 9/11 Panel's Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - An influential bipartisan group of members of Congress, backed by leaders of the Sept. 11 commission, said on Tuesday that they were offering a bill in the House and Senate to enact virtually all the commission's recommendations, including its call for a national intelligence director to oversee all of the government's spy agencies.

Beloved wife of Robert C., loving mother of Chris and his wife Martha, Laurie Leonard and her husband Mike, and Lynn and her fiance Dan Rosen; cherished grandmother of Molly, Cara, Megan and Duncan McConaughey and Sean and Cassie Leonard; dear sister of Beverly Prevost and her husband Ned. Funeral service at Tenafly Presbyterian Church, Thursday, September 9 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers charitable contributions may be made to The Hospice of Englewood Hospital and Medical Center.

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber Strays Far From 'Cats'
description: LONDON, Sept. 2 - For the composer of colossal musical hits like "Cats" and "The Phantom of the Opera," any lesser success risks being construed as failure. After Andrew Lloyd Webber's last two shows fared poorly here, some London theater critics proclaimed that he had lost his touch. Now, as he prepares to open a new musical, "The Woman in White," based on Wilkie Collins's mid-19th-century "sensation novel," he has a chance to prove them wrong.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Felons' Voting Rights
description: About 600 felons who have lost their voting rights must write a letter to the state seeking permission to reregister to vote, provide three personal references and gain approval from a prosecutor, according to new rules approved by Gov. Ernie Fletcher. The felons must meet an Oct. 4 deadline to vote in the November general election. Voting rights advocates say the new rules unfairly single out members of minorities and the poor, but Mr. Fletcher, a Republican, said he believed felons should explain why they deserved to regain their voting rights. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: The Homework That the Student Ate
description: ALONG with ashtrays in the teachers lounge and dodge ball, the days of the homemade bag lunch seem to be numbered, as school cafeteria meals become more sophisticated and as pressure on working moms and dads cuts into precious morning hours.

title: Asian Twist For Tomatoes
description: WHEN asked what ingredients they will miss most as summer fades to fall, many people mention tomatoes. But even as the ultraripe tomatoes of peak season give way to the lesser lights of September, there are ways to coax intense flavor from them.

title: Bush Backs Budget Authority for New Intelligence Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 A President Bush shifted his stance today on how much power a new national intelligence director should have, declaring that he supports giving the new chief full power over intelligence spending.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day last Wednesday, about the board of Hollinger International, misstated the political affiliation of a director, Richard R. Burt. He was an official during a Republican administration, that of Ronald Reagan, not a Democratic one.

title: Bogot Says Colombian Troops Assassinated 3 Union Leaders
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Sept. 7 - The attorney general's office said late Monday that Colombian soldiers assassinated three union leaders last month, an account that contrasts sharply with the army's earlier contention that the three men were Marxist rebels killed in a firefight.

title: Dreamed You Never Studied? Be Proud
description: Even now, more than 30 years since his life as a student ended, Joel I. Klein occasionally has the dream. He is walking into a classroom for the final exam, usually for a science course in high school, only to discover he has missed it. Sometimes, in the dream, the other pupils are leaving just as he arrives. Sometimes he has slept through the test. Sometimes he has studied through it. The one constant is the horror of failure.

title: Second Thoughts in California
description: This is the time on the presidential political calendar when voters begin paying attention and wondering how they were ever left with this particular choice of candidates in the first place. The answer is not in the stars; it's in the ever more unrepresentative primary process, and it is of more than passing interest that California is throwing in the towel and moving its primary day back where it belongs, in June instead of March.

title: HEALTHSOUTH NAMES A NEW CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: The HealthSouth Corporation, the rehabilitation hospital chain accused of $2.7 billion in accounting fraud, named John Workman, 53, chief financial officer. Mr. Workman, who starts on Sept. 20, is a former chief executive and chief financial officer of the U.S. Can Company, HealthSouth said. He succeeds Guy Sansone, an executive with the turnaround firm Alvarez & Marsal, who had been acting chief financial officer since March 2003. HealthSouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., has replaced most of its management.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EarthLink To Sell New Handsets
description: EarthLink, one of the nation's largest Internet service providers, will start selling handsets that provide e-mail message and voice services. The company, based in Atlanta, will offer its customers the BlackBerry 7750, which can make phone calls, send and receive e-mail messages and search the Internet. EarthLink will charge $39.95 a month for an unlimited amount of data, and an additional $39.95 for 500 voice minutes with free weekends and nights. To date, EarthLink has sold handsets that send only data. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Having honed his Provenal palate as the executive chef at NICE MATIN on the Upper West Side, ANDY D'AMICO , below, has added another city in the south of France to his portfolio. He is now also the executive chef at MARSEILLE , 630 Ninth Avenue (44th Street), where his menu includes tapenade, sardines, daube of beef and rouget fillets with ratatouille.

description: PRESIDENT BUSH Remarks yesterday in Columbia, Mo.:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Introduces New Business Programs
description: Computer Associates International introduced management software yesterday designed to give businesses a better understanding of the costs associated with their computing systems. The company introduced an update to its Unicenter IT Service Management line of applications. The Unicenter programs are designed to track the performance of the components used to deliver a business application. A company could use Computer Associates' software to measure the use of the hardware and software, like servers, storage and desktop software, needed to run a sales order entry application. The tools work in conjunction with the company's Unicenter monitoring software, which tracks performance and usage of network components. "Customers want to be able to define I.T. in terms of service for the business, not infrastructure elements, and be able to charge back for that based on actual utilization, not some flat basis like number of employees," said Lokesh Jindal, the director of product marketing at Computer Associates.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Thursday about the filmmaker Zhang Yimou misidentified the place where he makes his movies. It is mainland China, not Hong Kong.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 7 - Orlando Cabrera is swiping Manny Ramirez's wristbands, mimicking swings for Ellis Burks, furiously taping and retaping his bats in front of David Ortiz. He makes more sudden movements than a Pedro Martnez breaking ball.

She worked with lifelong friend Lainie Kazan; produced the music TV program, Night Flight and was VP, Scene Int'l. Survived by daughter Lilah, partner John Keese, and Stephen Friedland. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or The Wisdom School, Santa Fe, NM. Contact: friendsofcynthia@ hotmail.com

Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLOGG, MARION S.
description: KELLOGG--Marion S. Entered into eternal rest Saturday, August 14, 2004, at age 84. Ms. Kellogg was born June 15, 1920 in Rochester, N.Y., the daughter of the late Howard and Stella (nee Dengler) Kellogg. She leaves her cousin, Dorothy (Sanders) McGee of Longport, N.J. Marion retired as the first woman Vice President of General Electric Company. She joined General Electric when she was Assistant Professor (and first woman instructor) in the Physics Department of Brown University. At General Electric, she held a variety of operating assignments in Human Resources Consulting including Marketing, Production and General Management. These culminated in her appointment as Vice President of Corporate Consulting Services in 1974. In this capacity, she managed an organization of about 1000 persons engaged in leading edge consulting in the fields of engineering, marketing and manufacturing. She retired from General Electric in 1983. During her career with GE, she served as a consultant in Europe, Africa and North and South America for a variety of businesses and companies. She was the author of five books and was awarded honorary doctorates by Saint Lawrence University, Russell Sage College, Babson College and Manhattanville College. She is the recipient of the Mary Parker Follett Award for her contributions to the application of management priciples. She was a Fellow of the International Academy of Management and member of Sigma Xi and the New York Academy of Sciences. She served on the Board of Directors of Emhart Corporation, Cigna Corp., Citytrust Bancorp and was a Trustee of Manhattanville College. Services and interment were held in Rochester, N.Y. To light a candle of condolence, please visit www. millerfuneralhomes.com

title: Ars Electronica Asks What Will Be Next
description: LINZ, Austria, Sept. 6 - Twenty-five years ago an electronic music festival and conference called Ars Electronica was added to a local celebration of Anton Bruckner, the native son composer. Since then the festival's focus has broadened considerably, and it is a leading forum for media art, which uses technology, often in an interactive fashion.

title: Virginia Is 6th State to Keep Nader Off Ballot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Ralph Nader's efforts to place his name before voters in the presidential election stumbled again on Tuesday when officials in Virginia said that he failed to submit enough valid signatures to be listed on the ballot.

title: Group Says Terror Attack on Indian Point Would Be Apocalyptic
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - A group campaigning to shut the Indian Point nuclear plant is firing new broadsides against the reactors, releasing a report on Wednesday that asserts that a successful terrorist attack could cause apocalyptic damage.

title: G.E. to Put Insurance Units Under One Name
description: General Electric said yesterday that it would unify more than a dozen reinsurance and commercial insurance businesses under the brand name GE Insurance Solutions.

title: YES to Decide on New Executive
description: The board of the YES Network is expected to meet today or tomorrow to name a replacement for Leo Hindery Jr., who resigned as the president and chief executive of the Yankees' channel nearly five months ago. The board is expected to choose from Tracy Dolgin, a former Fox Sports Net executive who has been a consultant to YES since earlier this year; Bob Gutkowski, the former president of Madison Square Garden; and Joe Cohen, a former Garden executive. The final decision could come by the end of the week. Richard Sandomir

title: Advocacy Groups and Campaigns: An Uneasy Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - Just last week, Stanley Greenberg was the polling mastermind guiding the way three liberal groups spent tens of millions of dollars attacking President Bush and registering voters. But he quit that position to be an unpaid adviser to the Kerry campaign as it presses to sharpen its message in the final 56 days before the election.

title: For Battleground Florida, No Delay in Hurricane Aid
description: If one is going to live in a locale hit by multiple hurricanes, it does not hurt to be a resident of a presidential battleground state when it comes to federal aid.

description: A diagram of the human heart on Saturday with an article about plans for former President Bill Clinton's bypass operation misplaced one of the three grafts shown. It should have originated in the aorta, not in a pulmonary artery. A correct diagram appears today, on Page A21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAESAR, HENRY A. II.
description: CAESAR--Henry A. II. September 5, 2004, at age 89. Devoted husband of Allison Garver Caesar, father of Sanderson Caesar, of Wawa, PA, Porter D. Caesar II, of Wolfeboro, NH, Austin Brewster Caesar, of Conifer, CO, and John Garver Caesar, of Brewster, NY. Brother of Leslie Caesar Stillman, of Litchfield, CT, and the late Porter D. Caesar, also survived by eight grandchildren, and six great grandchildren. Noted sculptor, represented in collections across the country. Memorial service Saturday September 11th at 11 A.M. at Saint Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT. Donations may be made to Waveny Care Center, Inc., 3 Farm Road, New Canaan, CT 06840 or to The Harry Caesar Sculpture Fund, New Canaan Society For The Arts, PO Box 1044, New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: 2 Italians and 2 Iraqis Abducted From Offices in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 7 - Armed men seized two Italian aid workers and two Iraqis in their offices here on Tuesday in the most brazen kidnapping raid here in months.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Travel Stake Sale Canceled
description: The European travel company TUI canceled the initial offering of its Hapag-Lloyd shipping unit because of adverse market conditions. The chief executive, Michael Frenzel, left, said TUI saw "no chance of fetching Hapag-Lloyd's real value" and had dropped the plan for a public offering as well as a sale of the unit. Earlier, TUI said it would place 49.9 percent of the unit on the stock market to help reduce TUI's net debt of more than 3 billion euros ($3.6 billion). Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUDNER, M. RIPLEY
description: HUDNER--M. Ripley, aged 23, died on September 6 when the vehicle he was driving struck a curbstone in Tiverton, R.I. and veered out of control. Death was instantaneous. "Rip" Hudner was born on January 10, 1981 in New York City to Michael S. and Hope Freeman Hudner, of Little Compton and Providence, R.I. He attended the Episcopal and the Buckley Schools in Manhattan through seventh grade. He attended Moses Brown School, Providence, for grades eight and nine. He graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, Massachusetts, In the class of 1999, where he wrote an opinion column for the school paper and hosted a DJ and commentary show on the school radio station. He was also an alumnus of Hurricane Island Outward Bound School. He was accepted at Harvard College with the class of 2003, but was never able to attend due to developing health issues. He studied at Oxford Tutorial College in England, cooperated in establishing an eco-tourism project in Fiji, interned in the Singapore office of the family shipping business, and studied for three semesters at Harvard Extension School. He loved to travel. Some of his experiences included riding a camel at the Great Wall of China at age three, he spent the Millennium New Year's in the Antarctic, and he traveled by rail through Europe when studying in England. He was an avid backpacker with a particular love of Acadia National Park in Maine, and loved being on the water. He participated in the Newport - to - Bermuda race in 1992, when he was the youngest person in the fleet at age eleven, and again in 1996. In 2000, he sailed with his family from Newport to Ireland. He was an ardent practioner of yoga and meditation and had a deep and abiding love of music. Eventually, in 2001, he was diagnosed with a several forms of thought disorder. He struggled incessantly to overcome these issues and had made considerable progress at the time of his death. He was committed to living a fulfilling life. In addition to his parents, he is survived by his sister, Bay Adams Hudner, a freshman at Harvard. He is the grandson of the late Harold K. and Dorothy S. Hudner of Swansea, Massachusetts and the late Charles W. and Carla P. Freeman of Providence and Nassau. A memorial service in celebration of the life and spirit of Rip Hudner will be held on Friday, September 10 at 11:00 at the Sakonnet Vineyard, Little Compton. Attendees are encouraged to share their memories of Rip Hudner at the service. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the Rip Hudner Memorial Fund at Moses Brown School, 250 Lloyd Avenue, Providence, RI 02906-2398 or in his memory to the National Association For Mental Illness (NAMI).

title: Correction
Russia's tragedy : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Sifting for Truth as Bush and Kerry Wage a War of Words Over Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - In asserting Tuesday that Senator John Kerry had shifted position once again on Iraq, was President Bush selectively quoting Mr. Kerry to distort what Democrats say is his nuanced but consistent record? Or was he accurately highlighting what Republicans say is the Democratic presidential nominee's long history of unprincipled flip-flops?

title: Kosher Decoded
description: Observing Jewish dietary laws is a particular challenge in the modern world, partly because they govern not just food but also the appliances used for cooking. For example, in a kosher household a blender must have two jars and two blades, to keep meat and dairy separate. Lis Stern advises cooks on contemporary ways of adhering to these ancient laws, called kashrut, in "How to Keep Kosher" (William Morrow, $24.95). She discusses how to gradually establish a kosher kitchen, talks about special holiday requirements and explains subtle distinctions in the rules for handling meat, fish and poultry. There is a small collection of traditional recipes, for dishes like matzoh balls and cholent.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BERLINGER, RHONIE HOFHEIMER
description: BERLINGER--Rhonie Hofheimer, peacefully at home on August 31, 2004 after 89 vigorous years. Loving and beloved wife of the late George F. Berlinger. Devoted mother of Nancy Klee Stone & Mary Ellen Klee. Admiring mother-in-law of Bob Stone. Dear sister of Marion H. Levy & the late Lt. Lester Hofheimer. Proud "Noni" of Peter and Betsy, Robert and Douglas Kempner; Jim and Janet, Ellen and Julia Kempner; Carrie & Matthew, Brian & Daniel Getz. Rhonie actively served as a VicePresident of the National Alzheimer's Association since her husband's death in 1986. Funeral private. A memorial service and celebration of her life will be held Sunday, September 12 at 4 PM at the Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Avenue, White Plains, New York, 914-946-1660. In lieu of flowers the family would greatly appreciate contributions in Rhonie's memory to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601 and Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL, 60601; or a charity of your choice.

title: Stalking the Wild Salmon
description: Some consumers have crossed farm-raised salmon off their shopping lists for environmental and health reasons. But what kind of smoked salmon are they buying? Western smoked salmon is usually from wild fish caught in Washington or Alaska. Acme Smoked Fish in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is now cold-smoking wild sockeye from the Pacific Northwest that's almost vermilion in color, right. It has a firm, muscular texture and a mellow mildness. In about a week it will be sold under the Blue Hill Bay label at Costco stores, $9.95 for 12 ounces. Smoked king salmon bearing the Acme label ($32 a pound at Russ & Daughters), is paler and more assertive. Acme's outlet store, 30 Gem Street in Greenpoint, carries these fish on Fridays from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.

title: Unorthodox Publisher Animates Hip-Hop Lit
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio - Don't underestimate Vickie Stringer, zipping along in her BMW X5, multitasking as she goes, giving one radio interview on her cellphone to a station in Florida, another interview to the reporter beside her and depositing a check at her drive-in bank.

title: Confusing, Yet Captivating
description: Cape gooseberries are not gooseberries at all, but physalis, a member of the nightshade family and a relative of the tomatillo, which they resemble. This small fruit, usually orange, has a papery husk. In the Southeast, it grows wild and is called a ground cherry. Cape gooseberries are juicy, hinting of pineapple, and can be used like cherry tomatoes. They are in Greenmarkets for about $3 a pint until the end of the month. Norwich Meadows Farm has them on Sundays in Tompkins Square and Mondays in Union Square. Oak Grove Plantation has them on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays in Union Square.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It's absolutely essential that eight weeks from today, on Nov. 2, we make the right choice, because if we make the wrong choice then the danger is that we'll get hit again and we'll be hit in a way that will be devastating from the standpoint of the United States."

title: Lost From Skyline, but Not From the Landscape
description: THEY are lost, of course. But they have not disappeared. Three years after it seemed that the name and image of the twin towers would be mournfully expunged from the cityscape, the World Trade Center survives. Not on the skyline, but on street signs and shopping bags and book covers, in Fire Department insignia and the logo of the Alliance for Downtown New York, in a subway station and a parking garage, at the gateway to SoHo and in the lobby of an apartment building that was especially hard hit on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Deal Preserves Hong Kong's Hub Status
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 8 - Beijing agreed on Wednesday to allow more flights from here to cities across China, a step that promises to make air travel to China easier, less expensive and possibly safer. The deal could also influence legislative elections here on Sunday in which relations with the mainland are the main issue.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 A The Central Intelligence Agency kept dozens of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison and other detention facilities in Iraq off official rosters to hide them from Red Cross inspections, far more than has been previously reported, two senior Army generals said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Verizon To Sell Canadian Unit To Bain
description: Verizon Communications has agreed to sell its Canadian telephone-directory unit to Bain Capital, based in Boston, for $1.54 billion to invest in faster-growing businesses. The sale is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to be completed by the end of 2004, Verizon said yesterday. The service, SuperPages Canada, is the country's second-largest directories publisher. It had sales of $293 million in 2003. Verizon is investing in new services including high-speed Internet access and video over fiber optic lines as demand for traditional service declines. Shares of Verizon, which also has a majority stake in the nation's biggest mobile phone company, rose 2 cents to $40.42. SuperPages Canada produces 118 directories.

title: Israeli Military Continues Major Push Into Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 A Israeli forces continued a major operation in Gaza today with tanks and armored vehicles to suppress rocket fire into Israel, and in the process killed seven Palestinians. In the West Bank, Israeli troops killed another Palestinian.

title: 1904:French Invade England : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
BBC Is Exploring Options for Its Commercial Unit
description: LONDON, Sept. 8 - Britain's public service broadcaster, the British Broadcasting Corporation, said on Wednesday that it had been in touch with the American media giants Time Warner and Walt Disney, as well as other companies including Germany's Bertelsman, to discuss options for its BBC Worldwide commercial subsidiary.
