title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEUREY, THEODORE V.
description: FEUREY--Theodore V., 65, of Manhattan, died over Labor Day weekend. Beloved father of Brendan Hayes Feurey and Caitlin Mary Feurey. He was a 30-year veteran newsman with WCBS radio, UPI radio, The New York Post, the International Herald Tribune, and the Newark Evening News. In the past decade, he was a national media consultant. He is survived by his brothers Edward and Timothy, sisters Kay Holland and Peggy Kittle, sister-in-law Claudia Feurey and former wife, Monie Begley Feurey. A memorial service will held on Saturday, September 11, at 11:30AM at Cami Hall, 165 West 57th Street. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations be made to: Radio Television News Directors Foundation, 1600 K Street, N.W., Suite 700, Washington, D.C. 20006.

title: COOPER TIRE TO CUT JOBS AND QUIT MAKING INNER TUBES
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would cut 129 jobs at a factory in Mississippi and would stop producing inner tubes there because of declining demand. The cuts will result in $7 million of expenses in the third quarter, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Cooper Tire, based in Findlay, Ohio, said it would dedicate resources to making other products that would help it expand. Thirty employees will continue working at the factory, in Clarksdale, Miss., the company said.

title: FRANKS NURSERY FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION AGAIN
description: Franks Nursery and Crafts Inc., a lawn and garden specialty chain, filed for Chapter 11 protection for a second time yesterday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan and said it planned to liquidate by conducting going-out-of-business sales at its stores. The company, which operates 169 stores in 14 states, listed assets of $123.8 million and debts of $140.5 million as of Aug. 8. Franks, based in Troy, Mich., emerged from bankruptcy proceedings in Greenbelt, Md., in May 2002. Since then, however, the company has sustained losses that it attributed to general economic weakness, declining customer traffic, unfavorable weather, a drop-off in the Christmas tree business and supply chain problems, according to a statement from the chief executive, Walter Spokowski, filed with the court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUSH, SUSAN
description: BUSH -- Susan. Fascinating, talented, fabulously funny, fiercely independent, outspoken and a caring, lovely friend. We will miss you.

Fed Chief Sees More Traction in Expansion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said on Wednesday that the economic expansion had "regained some traction" after the slowdown this summer and suggested that the central bank could be expected to keep raising interest rates, including at its next meeting later this month.

title: FOCUS BRANDS TO BUY CINNABON FROM AFC ENTERPRISES
description: AFC Enterprises Inc., the franchiser and operator of Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits restaurants, said yesterday that it would sell its Cinnabon unit to Focus Brands Inc. for $30.3 million in cash, a move that would let it concentrate on its main chicken business. Focus Brands is an affiliate of a buyout firm, the Roark Capital Group of Atlanta. AFC, which sold Seattle's Best Coffee to the Starbucks Corporation last year, is considering getting rid of all its businesses except the Popeyes chain, which serves Cajun chicken and shrimp dishes. The sale of the Cinnabon subsidiary, which has 592 bakeries at airports, train stations and other high-traffic locations, also includes the international franchise rights for Seattle's Best Coffee, which were not included in the sale of the chain to Starbucks. AFC is based in Atlanta.

title: Huge Book Retailer Expands Its Publishing Role
description: When Barnes & Noble moved to expand its own publishing business aggressively last year, it sent shivers through the industry. It seems the chill is not going to wear off anytime soon.

title: An Olympic Track for Cultural Hurdlers
description: Ask anyone at City Hall: bringing the Olympics to New York City is not an easy job. A group of ambitious businessmen and social activists have discovered that the same thing applies not only to the kind of Olympics that feature pole vaulting and parallel bars but also to a much different kind that would match the cultural skills of contestants from around the world.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Dismantling Of Chemical Weapons Starts
description: Workers dismantled the first rocket that carried a small part of 7.3 million pounds of chemical agents at the Army Umatilla Chemical Depot, west of Hermiston. Officials delayed the initial dismantling last month when a trial caused trace amounts of industrial chemical vapor to be detected at the plant. Officials said the problem had been resolved. The dismantled rocket is the first of 220,000 weapons to be neutralized by 2010 at a cost of $2.4 billion. Brian Alexander (NYT)

title: Ilona Marton, 92, Who Wrote of '56 Revolt, Dies
description: Ilona Marton, an award-winning journalist who was imprisoned for her coverage of events leading up to the Hungarian uprising of 1956, died Saturday at her home in Silver Spring, Md. She was 92.

title: Japan's Record 7th Typhoon; The Death Toll Is at Least 31
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8 - Japan's typhoon record was broken with a bang this week as battering winds and mountainous waves overturned ocean-going freighters, ripped out trees from Hiroshima's Peace Memorial Park, and shredded a 700-year-old shrine, long a national icon of tranquillity.

title: Putting Suspect Files in Solitary Confinement
description: Q. What is the difference between a repaired virus and a quarantined one?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 7 about calls in Cambodia for a trial of the leaders of the Khmer Rouge regime of the 1970's misstated Prime Minister Hun Sen's tenure. He has wielded prime ministerial powers, either on his own or in a power-sharing agreement, since 1985, not 1993. A reader first reported the error in January; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Mom vs. Nanny: The Time Trials
description: Next week, my 2 1/2-year-old daughter, Phoebe, will join millions of children across the country when she walks into nursery school and embarks on what, fingers crossed, will be a 20-year journey through America's formal education system. And I will join the millions of parents who have been waiting all summer, all 2 1/2 years, for that day to arrive. In my giddy anticipation of her first day of school, I have memorized the class list. I have taped a photo of her teacher to the refrigerator. I have taught her how to raise her hand. When I'm having a bad day at work or feeling particularly anxious about something, I think of Phoebe sitting in her classroom and I'm overwhelmed by happiness.

title: In reply, the president vows to honor dead by 'completing mission' : Kerry faults Bush over cost of Iraq war
Russia's Antiterror Tactics: Reward and a First Strike
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8 - The Russian government offered a $10 million reward Wednesday for the killing or capture of two Chechen rebel leaders, and a top general said Moscow reserved the right to make pre-emptive strikes against terrorists abroad.

title: Retro-Inspired Planter Puts a Date Stamp on Perennials
description: Bradley Cook calls Show, his shop in Los Feliz, a "modern lifestyle" store, because it sells a combination of accessories, jewelry, housewares and furniture dating from, or reminiscent of, the era of midcentury Modernism. One new item he carries is a fiberglass Retro Bullet Planter by a company called Hip Haven. The planter ($130) comes in three sizes and in turquoise, ivory and tangerine. Show, 1722 North Vermont Avenue in Los Feliz Village, Los Angeles, (323) 644-1960, www.showlifestyle.com.

title: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: A Camera Small in Stature Knows How to Accessorize
description: The difference between most pocket-size point-and-shoot digital cameras and the high-end models is not just simpler controls, but lower resolution and a lack of performance-expanding accessories.

title: Cheney and the Politics of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Convulses a Group of Writers
description: Correction Appended

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ovitz Seeks to Be Excused From a Disney Suit
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 8 - A lawyer for Michael S. Ovitz, the former president of the Walt Disney Company, argued Wednesday that his client should be excused as a defendant in a lawsuit that contends that the $140 million buyout of Mr. Ovitz's five-year contract violated Delaware law.

title: Jack Daniel's Honors  Star of Campaign
description: Jack Daniel's Honors

title: The Roots of Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disgraceful Campaign Speech
description: There are some things a presidential campaign should steer clear of, through innate good taste, prudence or just a sensible fear of a voter backlash. We'd have thought that both the Kerry and Bush camps would instinctively know that it would be appalling to suggest that terrorists were rooting for one side or another in this race. But Vice President Dick Cheney seemed to breach that unspoken barrier this week in Des Moines. If John Kerry was elected president, Mr. Cheney warned the crowd, "the danger is that we'll get hit again." In a long, rather rambling statement, he said the United States might then fall back into a "pre-9/11 mind-set" that "these terrorist attacks are just criminal acts."

title: Bush Now Backs Budget Powers in New Spy Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - President Bush said on Wednesday that he wanted to give a new national intelligence director "full budgetary authority," a sharp shift from an earlier position and an acquiescence to a major recommendation of the Sept. 11 commission.

title: Aging Sewers Are Unable to Keep Up With the Flow
description: The downpour that immobilized much of the New York City subway system yesterday highlighted how an otherwise durable transit network still finds itself particularly vulnerable to an altogether predictable threat: a quick, heavy rainfall.

title: Expanding Beleaguered Schools, Experimentally
description: Faced with an expanding student population and increasingly dilapidated school facilities, the Los Angeles Unified School District has embarked on the largest building program in its history. Fourteen billion dollars has been allocated for improvements, including the construction of 80 new schools, eight opening their doors today.

title: Japanese Wares on American Soil
description: Tortoise, a store in Venice, Calif., sells Japanese housewares and furniture, most of which cannot be found elsewhere in the United States, say its owners, Keiko and Taku Shinomoto. There is a wide selection of kitchenware and tabletop items by Sori Yanagi. His stainless steel and wood-handled flatware, left, is $98 a place setting; square porcelain plates are $14 to $41. Mr. Shinomoto offers his own line of modern wood furniture. There is a bridal registry; 1208 Abbot Kinney Boulevard, www.tortoiselife.com, (310) 314-8448. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: For Two 9/11 Memorials, a Man Who Listened
description: JERSEY CITY - FREDERIC SCHWARTZ is standing on a peninsula at Liberty State Park where ground is to be broken tomorrow for the 9/11 memorial he has designed for New Jersey, only three-and-a-half hours after ground is broken in Westchester County for the 9/11 memorial he has designed there. But for a moment, his sad eyes are not focused on the empty sky across the Hudson River where the World Trade Center is supposed to be.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the damage caused by Hurricane Frances referred incorrectly in some copies to Bobby Bowden, whose grandson and former son-in-law were among the people killed in the storm. He is the current Florida State University football coach, not the former one.

title: A Point Is a Point: The U.S. Takes It
description: PANAMA, Sept. 8 - World Cup qualifying in the North American, Central American and Caribbean region is never merely a job for the United States, but it is always an adventure.

title: Semiconductors Offer a New Way to Cut the Cord
description: WHAT a liberating feeling it is to cut the cord and go wireless, taking a suddenly untethered laptop, for example, and heading for the couch or porch swing to work on the Internet.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
A Grim Milestone: 1,000 U.S. Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney Spits Toads
description: WASHINGTON - George W. Bush and Dick Cheney have always used the president's father as a reverse lodestar. In 1992, the senior Mr. Bush wooed the voters with "Message: I care." So this week, Mr. Cheney wooed the voters with, Message: You die.

title: The Unmovable Ironweed
description: The Unmovable Ironweed

title: Turn On the TV, and Off We Go, Into the Calm Blue Yonder
description: Robert Norton, a Los Angeles businessman, has found a new use for flat screen plasma televisions. Working with Pantone Inc., he has created "Colorcalm Skies," a DVD of images and sound intended to turn the screens into soothing dcor. Designed by the British graphics firm Spin, "Colorcalm Skies" (below) features a display of changing skies in 36 shades of six Pantone colors (red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple). The DVD was introduced yesterday in press kits at Fashion Week in New York; it is $19.99 at www.colorcalm.com.

title: Britain Refuses to Put Cap on Liability of Big Auditors
description: The Big Four auditing firms were rebuffed by the British government earlier this week as the government refused to propose legislation to limit their potential liability for bad audits. But corporate directors received a sympathetic response as they sought to avoid having to pay legal fees when they are sued.

title: Insurance Premiums Take a Toll
description: Pioneer Super Market in the Echo Park section of Los Angeles had survived price wars, earthquakes and riots. But Pioneer, which opened in the early 1930's and was drawing about 25,000 shoppers a week last year, could not endure California's workers' compensation system. Last month the owner, Leonard Leum, shuttered the store.

title: U.S. Envoy Urged to Ask Afghans to Drop Torture Case Against 3
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 8 - Lawyers representing two of the three Americans accused of running a private jail and kidnapping and torturing prisoners said Wednesday that they had asked the United States ambassador here to request that the Afghan authorities drop the charges.

title: University of Michigan Gets a $100 Million Gift
description: The University of Michigan has received its largest gift ever, $100 million, from a New York real estate magnate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUMMINGS, VICTOR, M.D.
description: CUMMINGS--Victor, M.D., on September 6. Husband of Jacqueline (Lehman). Father of Nina (Thom) and David (Bonnie). Grandfather of Michael, Courtenay, Mackenzie and Jason. No funeral or visitation. Contributions may be made to Gerstenberg Center Hospice of Palm Beach Co.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, ERNEST
description: STEIN--Ernest. 4 Sept, died peacefully at home in NYC. b. Munich 13 Nov 1900, emigrated to NYC '21, married Doris Blumenthal '36. Businessman and amateur musician, this renaissance man loved his family, music, art, literature and gardening in the country; read and spoke French, German and English; practiced his piano every day until a month before death; and loved his daily walks. Musical studies started with his mother and included composition with Martinu at Tanglewood, early '40s. Compositions performed in U.S. and Europe. Poetry published in '89 and '90. Beginning at age 98, appeared annually for three years on "A Prairie Home Companion with Garrison Keillor" playing piano and reciting his poetry. With little remaining strength, some of his last words were "beautiful" when shown a bouquet of flowers, and "thank you" uttered often to care-givers and loved ones. From one of his poems "A Toast" The past is fairy tales. The future dreams. The music of the moment/Is the only Truth. Enjoy it to the fullest! Here is to life which, As the bubbles in this glass, Forever newly rises. Drink deep and often. More, much more to come! Ernest is survived by sons Bob, John and Andy; two daughters-in-law and four grandchildren.

title: United in Their Grief, but Divided on What to Do on Election Day
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 - His only child, Pfc. Tim R. Brown Jr., died in Iraq last year. But Tim R. Brown Sr. supports the war more strongly than ever. And he intends to cast an enthusiastic vote for President Bush in November.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Driver Killed On F.D.R. Drive
description: A 22-year-old woman was killed early yesterday on the northbound side of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 90th Street after she lost control of her Mercury Sable, the police said. The woman, whom police identified as Yvette Flagg, of Milwaukee, was traveling above 50 miles per hour in the right lane when the car skidded across the road and ran into the left guardrail. The car flipped over, and Ms. Flagg, who was not wearing her seat belt, was ejected. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIEL, GERARD
description: PIEL--Gerard. The Board of Directors of the Marconi Foundation at Columbia University celebrates the life of Gerard Piel, a long-standing friend and director. A public intellectual, scientific pioneer and founder/publisher of Scientific American, Gerry interpreted the nuances of 20th century science for both citizens and scientists through his many books, articles and publications. The recipient of 20 honorary degrees and honors, including the George Polk Award, Arches of Science Award and Rosenberg Medal of the University of Chicago, Gerry served as president of the American Association of the Advancement of Science and member of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University. We join his wife, Eleanor Jackson Piel, and children, Eleanor and Jonathan, in remembering Gerard Piel's humanity, humor and sagacity. John Jay Iselin, President, Marconi Foundation at Columbia University

title: Europe Rejects Looser Labels for Genetically Altered Food
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 8 - The European Commission changed its mind Wednesday and abandoned its earlier plan to permit laboratory-made seeds in food without being labeled as such.

title: Your Own Hit Parade on a Hard Drive, With MP3 Files
description: In the same way that people used to record their favorite songs from the radio on cassettes or their favorite TV shows with VCR's, they can now capture streaming audio from the Internet on a computer hard drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTON, MARVYN
description: CARTON -- Marvyn, passed away on September 7, 2004. Husband of Christine (nee Ores). Father of Dana, John and his wife Wendy Rowden, Jeremy, and the late Pamela. Grandfather of Mark Caprio, Pamela, Emily and Sam Carton. Memorial service Friday, September 10th, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions to a charity of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Raised
description: The Bank of Canada raised its main overnight lending rate to 2.25 percent from 2.0 percent because the economy was expanding at a faster pace than it had expected. The increase was the first by the country's central bank in 18 months. "With the economy operating close to its capacity, monetary stimulus needs to be reduced to avoid a buildup of inflationary pressures," the bank said. Consumer prices rose 2.3 percent in Canada in July largely because of pricier oil. The increase in the overnight rate, which is used for transactions between banks, was followed by prime rate increases by most of Canada's major banks. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Connecticut Ethics Panel Threatens Its Own Director
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 8 - The state Ethics Commission threatened its executive director with disciplinary action on Wednesday after a state investigation revealed that he had directed a staff member to lie if asked to respond to a federal subpoena and to destroy a tape of a commission meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHARER, JONATHAN M.
description: SCHARER--Jonathan M. It is with overwhelming sadness that everyone at Overland Entertainment mourns the loss of our beloved founder, fearless leader, mentor, visionary, and most of all, our so dearly loved friend. You will be with us always and are forever in our hearts. We will carry on your legacy and always remember your unparalleled generosity. Our condolences and much love to Vivian and Sy Scharer, Joan Karan, and James Caselli.

title: Marlins Like Having the Mets Around
description: MIAMI, Sept. 8 - The numbers that symbolize the Mets' futility grew more surreal Wednesday night. Their latest defeat produced a grim picture: no runs, four hits, few signs of life.

title: U.S. Forces Take Action in Areas Dominated by Iraqi Insurgents
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 9 A American troops today entered the city of Samarra for the first time in months, marking what appears to be a small but significant step in their effort to regain control of the contested Sunni Triangle.

title: Cheney and the Politics of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Blast in Indonesia Kills 8 Near Australian Embassy
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 9 A A car bomb exploded outside the Australian Embassy here today, killing at least eight people, and the Indonesian police chief said the blast was the work of the Al Qaeda-linked Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah.

title: U.S. Will Send Detainee Home From Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - The Pentagon has determined that a detainee held for an extended period in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, should no longer be classified as an unlawful enemy combatant and will be returned to his native country, a senior official said Wednesday.

title: China Poised for Decision on Raising Interest Rates
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 8 - With a slew of important economic statistics due for release in the next several days, China's central bank is in the final stages of deciding on what could be the country's first increase in interest rates in nine years, economists and government-controlled media said on Wednesday.

title: BUTTERFAT BET LEADS DEAN FOODS TO ISSUE PROFIT WARNING
description: The Dean Foods Company, a milk processor, cut its profit forecasts because of bad bets on dairy prices and because of record fuel and commodity costs. Dean, based in Dallas, said late Tuesday that its third-quarter profit would be 44 cents to 46 cents a share, down from its previous forecast of 54 cents to 57 cents. The company also lowered its forecast for the full year. The chief executive, Gregg Engles, said the company would take a $4 million charge against earnings this year to cover bad bets on butterfat prices. Profit margins have also been hurt by rising prices for fuel to operate the company's delivery trucks, he said. Dean's stock fell $6.73, to $30.40 a share.

title: Delta Aims to Cut Jobs 12%, Drop a Hub and Reduce Pay
description: Correction Appended

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about humanizing the design of hospitals misspelled part of the name of one in England that is an example of the new architecture. It is the Norfolk and Norwich Hospital, not Norfolk and Norridge.

title: Sharon's 'Gaza Problem': It May Be Israelis, Not Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 - Shimon Peres, a former prime minister of Israel, once said there are no real negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians, only among Israelis themselves about what to concede.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Files On Priests In Sex Cases Have To Be Turned Over
description: A judge in Superior Court ordered the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles to turn over confidential files on several priests accused of sexually abusing children, rejecting the church's contention that doing so would inhibit its ability to practice its religion freely. The judge, Thomas F. Nuss, did allow the church to keep confidential certain personnel files. Subpoenas for the documents were issued 27 months ago in an investigation by District Attorney Steve Cooley. The archdiocese said it would appeal. John Broder (NYT)

title: Preserving the Past
description: Preserving the Past

title: Cheney and the Politics of Terror (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Selecting Gadonneix ends power struggle : New chief of EDF faces strife and budget woes
Donald Allen, 92, Book Editor of Bold New Voices in Poetry, Dies
description: Donald Merriam Allen, a poetry editor whose 1960 anthology of the era's contemporary and avant-garde poets remains a milestone in American letters, died on Aug. 29 in San Francisco. He was 92.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Apple Computer Chief To Return
description: After undergoing surgery in late July for a rare form of pancreatic cancer, Apple Computer's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, left, is on the road to recovery and plans to return to full-time work later this month. Mr. Jobs, who underwent successful surgery to remove cancer from his pancreas, is attending some company meetings and plans to return to full-time work later this month, an Apple spokeswoman, Katie Cotton, said. The rare cancer was a far more curable form than typical pancreatic cancer, Mr. Jobs wrote in an e-mail message to employees after his surgery. At the time of his surgery, Mr. Jobs, 49, had estimated he would return to work in September. That apparently is on track. Tim Cook, an executive vice president who oversees Apple's sales, operations and Macintosh unit, has been running the company's daily operations during Mr. Jobs's absence.

title: Reimagining the Mall And Other Spaces for Venice
description: Two of the six architectural firms representing the United States at the Venice Architecture Biennale, which starts on Saturday, are based in Los Angeles. For the American exhibit, called "Transcending Type," each of the firms was asked to rethink an archetype of American design. George Yu Architects reconceived the shopping mall, and Predock Frane Architects, above (Hadrian Predock is in front, with John Frane), addressed spiritual environments. Predock Frane has experience with contemplative spaces. It is building a Zen Buddhist monastery in Desert Hot Springs, Calif., and has created the master plan for another in Jemez, N.M. Its Center of Gravity Foundation Hall is at right. For the Biennale, the firm has designed an installation evoking the play of water and light in Venice.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the federal government's decision to restore funds to a housing program for the poor referred imprecisely to New York City's share and misstated the total. The share, more than $52 million, is part of the nationwide amount being restored to the program (known as Section 8), not a separate outlay. The total is $156 million, not $160 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLEN, MORRIS ''JIBBY,''
description: WELLEN--Morris "Jibby," of Jersey City, NJ, on September 7, 2004. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of the late Ronde Wasserman; loving grandfather of Stacey and Margot. Services at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ, Thursday, 11:30 AM. For information, call "Wien & Wien," 800-322-0533.

title: Wild Card Ensures That It's Nothing Like '78
description: DEREK JETER spoke with a profundity that matched the way he plays. "If we win," he said at the start of the week, "how can we be caught?"

title: With Funds Winding Down, Questions Remain About Longer-Term Needs
description: An astonishing $3 billion was raised to help the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and nearly all that money has been spent, the bulk of it handed over in cash grants, some without regard to financial need.

title: Pentagon Hurrying to Correct Conditions in Iraqi Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - In response to the abuse of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, the military has adopted dozens of the nearly 400 recommendations made by military and independent inquiries into the mistreatment, Pentagon officials said Wednesday.

title: A 3-0 Trump Split in 5 Hearts Doesn't Phase an Early Riser
description: Bridge insomniacs of the world unite: you can play at 5:30 a.m. if you wish.

title: Syria in Lebanon : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Brings Back An Ally
description: Embarking on a much-heralded cabinet shuffle, Prime Minister Tony Blair appointed an ally, Alan Milburn, to a new position with significant influence on the government's campaign for elections possible next year, the BBC reported. Mr. Milburn, a former health minister who will now have the formal title of chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, is seen as a close ally of Mr. Blair in his rivalry with Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer. Mr. Blair was also reported to have appointed a former labor union leader, Alan Johnson, another loyalist, as minister of pensions -- a important job at a time of widespread concern among older voters about uncertain retirement benefits.

title: So, What Is the Best Day for a Primary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagles Give Reid a Contract Extension
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP) - Coach Andy Reid received a four-year contract extension from the Philadelphia Eagles on Wednesday that will take him through the 2010 season.

title: Shift in Medicare Use Expected
description: THE new, sharply higher charges announced for Medicare beneficiaries last week may prompt more elderly people to join Medicare health maintenance organizations operated by private industry, according to health insurance executives and industry analysts.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about a severely burned boy who survived the hostage-taking at a school in southern Russia gave incorrect identifications in some copies for him and a woman standing by his bed. The boy was a 7-year-old identified only as Alan. (Alan Ezeyeva, 12, was another survivor being treated at the hospital.) Both women in the picture were nurses; neither was the wounded boy's mother.

title: Abduction of Peace Activists Brings War Home in Italy
description: ROME, Sept. 8 - The greatest shock here was not just the awful fact itself, that two vibrant young Italian women were kidnapped in Iraq, dragged from their office by attackers who, it seems, knew their names. The deeper jolt was that they worked for a relief group that was outspokenly against the war in Iraq and helped child victims of the war.

title: At Wal-Mart, the New Word Is Compromise
description: In an apparent mea culpa, the chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that the company's "message has not in fact gotten out" and called it "management's failure."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRINKERHOFF, LILLIAN WESTAWAY
description: BRINKERHOFF -- Lillian Westaway. 3/7/22 -- 9/9/02. Forever more beautiful than summer, more giving than harvest. Your boys and their boys ride the waves for you.

title: A Smooth, Snug Skin Extends Life of Discs
description: Despite all the buzz over downloadable music, movies and games, optical discs -- namely CD's and DVD's -- still rule the marketplace in delivering digital information and entertainment.

title: Allies Resist U.S. Efforts to Pressure Iran on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - The Bush administration's campaign to persuade Iran to abandon its suspected nuclear weapons programs is running into resistance among some allies and disputes over the seriousness of a new Iranian offer to suspend part of its activities, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIBBY, JOHN K.
description: LIBBY--John K. Age 78, died at home on September 6, 2004. Devoted husband of Mary and adoring father of K-K Libby, Aniik Libby Gustin and Virginia Libby Osborne. A private family memorial service to be held at Saint Anne's Episcopal Church, Bridgehampton, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations would be welcomed to Channel 13, WNET, Office of Development, 450 West 33 St., New York, New York 10001.

title: Hurricane-Proof?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Time to Pick Up Your Room, Honey
description: THERE can never be enough storage for children's toys, which, as any parent knows, seem to multiply and perpetually end up underfoot. (Most parents do not enjoy bathing with a gaggle of rubber ducks either.) Fortunately, a wide variety of boxes, bags and bins can now accommodate playthings of all sizes -- and some of the storage units might also qualify as toys.

title: MCKESSON LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST, CITING PRICES
description: The McKesson Corporation, a drug wholesaler, said its net income in the second quarter would fall because of fewer price increases, setting off a 15 percent decline in its share price. McKesson, based in San Francisco, said late Tuesday that profit would fall to 20 cents to 25 cents a share, compared with 53 cents a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn 50 cents in the period, which ends Sept. 30. Quarterly earnings will drop because drug makers are not raising prices in the United States on as many products as expected, a McKesson spokesman, Larry Kurtz, said. Stock in McKesson fell $4.85, to $26.98 a share.

title: Before College, After Treehouses
description: BACK in the 60's and 70's, high school students tended to spend July and August perfecting their tans. If they were especially ambitious, they might work as camp counselors, or take a crack at the summer reading list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, DR. SAMUEL
description: SCHNEIDER--Dr. Samuel, 97, beloved father, grandfather, brother-in-law and friend, passed away on September 4, after a distinguished life as a professor, philosopher and author. Graveside service Friday, September 10, at 11AM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale.

title: A Writer Must Be Tricky for 2 Realities to Coexist
description: THE FIRST DESIRE By Nancy Reisman 310 pages. Pantheon Books. $24.

title: Seeing a Mushroom Cloud in New York
description: Rory Kennedy has set a real challenge for herself this time. Her best-known documentaries have focused on an extended Appalachian family ("American Hollow") and a troubled Mississippi child and his psychologically destructive grandmother ("A Boy's Life"). Even "Pandemic: Facing AIDS" twisted heartstrings with the experience of one woman who is thrown out of the house after telling her father about her illness.

title: Major Medical Journals Will Require Registration of Trials
description: A group of leading medical journals yesterday released a plan to stop publishing the results of clinical trials unless a test is registered at its outset in a public database.

title: Operator Fired From 2 Homes for Mentally Ill
description: The Pataki administration abruptly removed the new operator of a notorious home for mentally ill adults in Queens yesterday, all but acknowledging that it had failed to examine his record when it put him in charge last month.

title: The New Trend in Spending
description: LISTEN to the jobs debate carefully, and you might get the idea that the problem with the economy is that Americans just are not materialistic enough.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: L.C.D. Expansion Delayed
description: A Taiwanese company that makes liquid-crystal displays for computers and televisions said yesterday that it would delay construction of a plant because of a decline in demand. The company, the Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corporation, said the plant, which would be its fifth, would make glass panels that could be cut into television screens measuring 40 inches diagonally and larger. Demand for flat-panel televisions has not been as strong as expected because prices are much higher than those of cathode-ray tube televisions, said market researchers like DisplaySearch. A 32-inch flat TV can cost as much as seven times more than similar-size tube models.

title: Powell Declares Genocide in Sudan in Bid to Raise Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 A Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, seeking to raise pressure on Sudan to stop the atrocities in Darfur, declared today for the first time that the killings, rapes and destruction that have forced 1.5 million people from their homes amounted to genocide and should be treated as such by the United Nations.

title: Bush and Kerry Campaign Hard in Swing States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9  President Bush and Senator John Kerry campaigned today in Pennsylvania and Iowa, respectively, two vital swing states, where they emphasized jobs, health care and other domestic issues more than national security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, GEORGE
description: BROWN--George. Prominent violist. Of Melville, NY on September 8. Beloved husband of DeVera (Debby), devoted father of Shelley and Dr. Michael Rosen, Dr. Marc and Debra Brown, and Attorney Eric and Rhonda Brown, loving grandfather of David and Joanna Rosen, Elissa Rosen, Stephanie and Evan Brown, Nicole Niederfer and Adam Brown, great-grandfather of Katarina Rosen, brother of Esther Mesher. Funeral at Gutterman's, Jericho Turnpike, Friday, September 10, 10 AM. Donations to Lymphoma Foundation, Box 6236, NYC 10128.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Joint Auto-Making Venture
description: The South Korean automaker Hyundai Motor, which broke off an Asian trucks venture with DaimlerChrysler in May, said it had found a new partner to make buses and trucks in China. Hyundai Motor said it would set up a $780 million assembly line in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui with the Jianghuai Automobile Company. The assembly line, which is scheduled to start in 2006, will be able to make 90,000 trucks, 10,000 buses and 50,000 van engines by 2010, Hyundai said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MEYERHOFF, INGE NEE ZUBER
description: MEYERHOFF--Inge nee Zuber. March 11, 1932 through September 9th, 2002

title: Klein Says Discipline Will Be Tightened
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that in the coming school year he hoped to expand efforts to address disciplinary problems in the city's schools, one of the hottest issues last year.

title: Iraq Airstrike Killed Civilians, U.S. Military Acknowledges

description: LONDON - HAVAS, the French advertising agency company, entered the bidding for Grey Global Group of New York on Wednesday, joining the WPP Group of Britain and the American private equity firm Hellman & Friedman.

description: The Yankees' home field is at 161st Street and River Avenue in the Bronx, about eight miles from Major League Baseball's main offices on Park Avenue in Manhattan. But the proximity of these high-powered neighbors cannot camouflage their mutual distrust.

title: Australian Embassy in Indonesia Bombed
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Sept. 9 - An explosion outside the Australian Embassy on Thursday killed three people, wounded dozens of others -- eight of them critically -- and caused extensive damage to the embassy and nearby buildings.

title: Since 9/11, Rich Arabs Again Frolic in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 - Lebanon, once a byword for terrorism, is in the midst of an extraordinary boom in tourism, real estate construction and development, thanks, officials here believe, to terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISLER, ALEXANDER
description: HEISLER -- Alexander of NYC, on September 7, 2004. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Ackerman), devoted father of Dr. Kenneth Heisler, Phyllis Gerstell & Janice Wile, father-in-law of Kristen Heisler, Glenn Gerstell and Kenneth Wile. Dear brother of Ruth Rose. Loving grandfather of Matina, Emily, Robert, Kenneth Jr., Juliet, Daniel, Thomas and Jonathan. title: VIACOM OFFERS SHAREHOLDERS A TRADE FOR BLOCKBUSTER
description: Viacom Inc., the media company, is offering its investors a 16 percent discount to exchange their Viacom shares for stock in Blockbuster Inc., the video rental chain it is shedding. At 5.15 Blockbuster shares for each share of Viacom, the offer values Blockbuster at $6.63 to $6.72, less than yesterday's closing price of $7.90. Viacom owns 82 percent of Blockbuster and announced plans in February to divest itself of the company. The discount reflects the need for Viacom to entice investors skeptical about the prospects for Blockbuster, which has lost about $3.6 billion since 1997. Sales at Blockbuster have declined two out of the last four quarters.

title: The Chiangs, Father and Son, Can't Rest in Peace Just Yet
description: DASI, Taiwan - The two black marble sarcophagi sit in similar mausoleums less than a mile apart, each a one-story building of house size arranged around a tiny, grassy courtyard in a wooded valley an hour's drive southwest of Taipei.

title: China Warns Against Any Effort to Block Its Clothing Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 - Hoping to block a last-minute attempt to protect the ailing American textile industry, China warned on Wednesday that it had the right to challenge any limit on its exports to the United States when all global quotas on textiles and clothing are lifted next year.

title: Celebrating Sounds Rooted in Gritty but Fertile New Turf
description: There were Jews in Manhattan before there was a New York City. A boat with 23 Jews arrived in New Amsterdam in September 1654, and the event is being commemorated with the weeklong New York Jewish Music and Heritage Festival, which began with a concert on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y. "Great Jewish Artists Perform Great Jewish Composers" featured music by 10 native and adopted New Yorkers, played by two of them in person -- Philip Glass and Neil Sedaka -- and interpreted by other musicians.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Contests Fines
description: New York City's chief lawyer asked a State Supreme Court justice yesterday to dismiss fines imposed on the city for not releasing hundreds of convention protesters last Thursday. A hearing is scheduled for today to determine what actions may be taken against the city after Justice John Cataldo ordered it to release the 550 protesters who were arrested during the Republican National Convention and detained at Pier 57, some for more than 60 hours, without appearing in front of a judge. When the city did not release all of them by 6 p.m. last Thursday, Justice Cataldo held the city in contempt and ordered a $1,000 fine for each person held. In a letter to the judge, Michael A. Cardozo, the Corporation Counsel, said that because all of the detainees have now been released, "no further purpose would be served by the imposition of a contempt fine." City officials have repeatedly said that the system was overwhelmed by the number of arrests. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: North Korea Says Seoul's Nuclear Experiments Stoke Arms Race
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 9 - North Korea warned on Wednesday that a recently disclosed South Korean experiment with uranium enrichment could "accelerate a northeast Asia nuclear arms race," and accused the United States of applying a "double standard" to the nuclear programs of the two Koreas.

title: Please Don't Walk on the Grass: It's Meant for Sitting, After All
description: When Charles Trotter, a corporate events producer in Los Angeles, was on an art and architecture tour last year in Venice, Calif., he was struck by the interest in design of so many people there. Then and there, he conceived the idea of CA Boom, a design showcase, which would be part trade show, part happening, part conference, part home tour and part party.

title: Group Linked to Al Qaeda Says It Seized Italian Women
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 8 - A previously unknown Islamic group claiming loyalty to a leader of Al Qaeda took responsibility on Wednesday for the kidnapping Tuesday of two Italian aid workers.

The speaker was a senior administration official who declined to be identified -- not Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman.

title: Corrections

It is Texans (not Texas) for Truth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERLINGER, MRS. GEORGE F. (RHONIE)
description: BERLINGER--Mrs. George F. (Rhonie). One of the most ardent and devoted members of the Alzheimer's Association family. A mentor to Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, devoted Rita Hayworth Gala Steering Committee member for more than 19 years, and distinguished member of the Alzheimer's Association National Board of Directors. Rhonie never lost her drive and her infectious enthusiasm for fighting the ongoing battle to conquer Alzheimer's Disease. Her steadfast advice, counsel and support will be sorely missed by Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, founder, Rita Hayworth Gala, and Rita Hayworth Gala Steering Committee members Muffie Potter Aston, Donna Dixon Aykroyd, Cornelia Sharpe Bregman, Margo Catsimatidis, Claudia Cohen, Nancy Corzine, Milly de Cabrol, Ellin Delsener, Somers Farkas, Deborah Grubman, Phyllis George, Nurit Kahane Haase, Anne Hearst, Michele Herbert, Susan Hess, Kathy Hilton, Deborah Norville, Della Rounick, Andrea Stark, and Felicia Taylor.

In the hearts of many Americans, for example. In the minds of many New Yorkers.

A panel that convened to look at the bids gave every indication that the company in charge was slated to win the contract again.

It has ignited a three-way feud among the Yankees, the Devil Rays and Major League Baseball, and for the third time, the game has proved maddeningly elusive.

title: Unraveling Kerry's Iraq Plan
description: Nobody gets angrier about Senator John Kerry's complicated position on Iraq than his own supporters. The Democratic base would love to see him lashing out at President Bush over the war. But for all of his current tough talk about Mr. Bush's "wrong choices," Mr. Kerry has blurred his message, particularly with his recent statement that he would have voted for the Senate's war resolution even if he had known that Saddam Hussein had no significant cache of weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Kerry also basically agrees with the president that it is now necessary to stay the course -- something that will require a continued American military presence in Iraq for years. It's no wonder the issue hasn't provided the Democrats much traction.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 6 Civilians Die In Army Clash
description: Six civilians were killed and 11 injured when soldiers clashed with militants in the northwestern town of Wana, near the Afghan border, a Pakistani military spokesman said. Three soldiers were wounded when an improvised explosive device detonated as a military convoy passed. A firefight then erupted between the soldiers and militants hiding in compounds near the town's main market. The army arrested 28 people, but no militants were killed or wounded. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: U.S. Urges Security Council to Take Tougher Stance on Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 8 - The United States circulated a draft Security Council resolution on Sudan on Wednesday threatening penalties on its oil industry, expanding an African Union force monitoring violence in the Darfur region and calling for the United Nations to create an international commission to determine whether genocide had occurred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEIL, ANNE JOSEPHINE MURRAY
description: O'NEIL -- Anne Josephine Murray. 79, died September 3, 2004. A native of New York, Anne grew up between Brooklyn, Manhattan and Southampton, NY. She attended Manhattanville College and graduated with the class of 1946. Anne is survived by her husband of 51 years, Ralph Michael O'Neil, her 7 children: Peter A. of Denver CO; Stephen J. (Susan Honeycutt) of NY, NY; Maria O'Neil Ruddock (Samuel) of Gates Mills, OH; Mark F.(Monique) of Locust Valley, NY; Anne (James Ricotta) of Weston, MA; Monica (Stephen Jennings) of Belmont, MA and Karen (Jonathan Stone) of NY, NY; nineteen grandchildren and 7 siblings. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, September 11 at 11AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, 342 S. Chillicothe Rd., Aurora, OH, where family will visit with friends immediately after mass. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10022 or Sacred Heart 1 East 91st Street, NY, NY 10128. For information: Kindrich-McHugh Steinbauer Funeral Home, Solon, OH. 440-248-6088.

title: Crash of a Robotic Space Probe
description: We've heard so much about the difficulty of conducting operations in the unforgiving environment of space that it was disheartening to see a space mission come to grief because parachutes failed to deploy in Earth's own atmosphere. After gathering solar wind particles for more than two years in an area far beyond the Moon, NASA's Genesis spacecraft headed toward home, where it released a scientific capsule that crashed into the ground at high speed yesterday, possibly obliterating most of the material so painstakingly gathered. The only solace was that this was a relatively cheap automated mission, so no lives were lost and the budgetary impact will be slight. The accident was a reminder that robotic missions can fail just as readily as missions with astronauts, but with less catastrophic results.

title: Unexpected Costs Leave Westchester Medical Center With Bigger Hurdles in Bid for Solvency
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Sept. 8 - Westchester Medical Center, which has been aggressively working to improve its bleak financial outlook, is increasing its projected loss for the year by $10 million, to $41 million, because of unexpected costs, officials said Wednesday.

title: Team Hopeful in Its Effort to Recreate Primal Life
description: Scientists analyzing the genomes of microbes believe that they have reconstructed the pivotal event that created the one-celled organism from which all animals and plants are descended, including people.

title: Loan Applications Rise
description: Mortgage applications rose last week to the highest level in four months, according to a private survey.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Head Scarf Ban Defied
description: About 100 to 120 Muslim girls in the eastern Alsace region are defying the law banning head scarves in schools, the education minister, Franois Fillon, said. But, he said, "I think we will be able to convince almost all of these young girls to change their minds." Students face expulsion if they refuse to abide the law. In Bobigny, near Paris, about 30 Sikh boys have refused to remove their turbans in school. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: The Configurations Expand and Contract, on Cue
description: The jazz pianist Kenny Barron has been a sideman since the late 1950's and a bandleader since the mid-70's -- a long enough stretch to work with all kinds of musicians and to experience a period of fragmentation and diversification for jazz. His playing sounds like a confident synthesis of jazz's last five decades, and in recent years he has assumed a natural position as one of the best overall utility players. But he hasn't stuck to one reliable format.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILL, ARTHUR
description: GILL--Arthur, 73 of Irvingtonon-Hudson, died September 7, 2004 after a lengthy illness. He was born in Brooklyn on February 4, 1931, the son of Estelle and Max Gill. He graduated from James Madison High School in 1948 and from City College of New York in 1952. He served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. Mr. Gill was founder and president of Argil Electronics, a distributor of industrial electronic parts worldwide. His philanthropic work included presidency of the American Hostel Association in the 1960's and many organizations concerned with conservation of the environment. He was one of the founders and moving forces in the Arrowhead Group of the order of the Arrow, an honorary society of former boy scouts. The fact that thse men will be celebrating its 44th reunion at Ten Mile River this weekend is witness to Arthur's selfless dedication. He is survived by his wife, Carol Gill, and his two daughters Susan Gill and her husband Ronald Northrup of Sea Cliff; Barbara GillVayo and her husband William Vayo of White Plains; his two step daughters Deborah Jacobs and her husband Philip Jacobs of Fairfield, CT, and Marjorie Weston and her husband Brian Weston of Katonah and six grandchildren: Lucy Vayo, Marc and Alec Jacobs, Betsy, Caroline and Scott Weston. Funeral Thursday 1:00pm Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastingson-Hudson, NY. Memorials in lieu of flowers can be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: AVON REDUCES ITS OUTLOOK FOR UNITED STATES SALES
description: Avon Products Inc. cut its forecast for sales in the United States in the third quarter as demand weakened for the company's color cosmetics. Avon, based in New York, said sales in the United States would be flat in the quarter, a reduction from its previous forecast for an increase of as much as 4 percent from a year earlier. Avon will begin a new marketing campaign this month in the United States, where it gets more than a third of its revenue. The company expects worldwide sales in the third quarter to increase 11 percent. Sales in Europe, Latin America and the Asia/Pacific region have been higher than it expected. Avon also reaffirmed its third-quarter profit forecast of 34 cents a share.

title: Arts Briefing
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about a severely burned boy who survived the hostage-taking at a school in southern Russia gave incorrect identifications in some copies for him and a woman standing by his bed. The boy was a 7-year-old identified only as Alan. (Alan Ezeyeva, 12, was another survivor being treated at the hospital.) Both women in the picture were nurses; neither was the wounded boy's mother. (Go to Article)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bridgehampton: Conviction Is Cast Into Doubt
description: The manslaughter conviction of a Bridgehampton woman could be revisited after an investigation threw doubt on the testimony of a Southampton police lieutenant, the Suffolk County district attorney's office said. Internal affairs investigators for the Suffolk County police concluded that contrary to his court testimony, Lt. William Armstrong never went to the scene of the 2002 hit-and-run crash in Sagaponack that killed a pedestrian, Henry A. Yarrell, 38. The woman, Leslie Jennemann, had been out dancing and drinking before the accident and was convicted in May of second-degree manslaughter and leaving the scene. She is serving a sentence of two to six years at a prison in Albion. No charges have been filed against Lieutenant Armstrong, but a spokesman for the Suffolk County district attorney, Thomas J. Spota, said the lieutenant's lawyer had turned down requests to meet with prosecutors. Ms. Jennemann's lawyer, James O'Rourke, said he would ask Justice Robert W. Doyle of State Supreme Court to overturn her conviction. Peter Beller (NYT)

title: Appreciation : The legacies of Poland's poet
Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDIN, SYDNEY
description: RUDIN--Sydney, age 89, of Margate, FL, formerly of Far Rockaway, NY, died September 3, 2004. Beloved husband of Lorraine for 70 years; cherished father of Ronnie Pollard (Arnold) and Jackie Rudin; devoted grandfather of Jill Millner (Douglas) and Lisa Pollard; adoring great grandpa of Harris Scott Millner; Big brother of Corkey Hochler and Frieda Lezak. Funeral Services were held 11:45 am, Wednesday, September 8, 2004 at the Star of David Funeral Home, 7701 Bailey Road, North Lauderdale, FL. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Broward County Library System, 100 S. Andrews Ave, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33301.

title: Serving Many Masters at the Venice Film Festival
description: VENICE, Sept. 8 - After being named director of the Venice International Film Festival in March, Marco Mller, a movie producer, had just four months to put together the 12-day program that ends on Saturday. In practice he had an even greater challenge: as the event's fourth director in seven years Mr. Mller was also expected to reinvent the festival to satisfy competing constituencies, including the movie industry, the international media, the celebrity cult and the Italian government, which largely finances the festival.

title: Give the Chechens a Land of Their Own
description: The terrorist attack in Beslan in Russia's North Caucasus was not only bloody but viciously sadistic: the children taken hostage by pro-Chechen terrorists were denied food and drink and even forbidden to go to the bathroom, then massacred when the siege was broken. It is proper for the civilized world to express outrage and feel solidarity with the Russian people. But to say this is not necessarily to agree with those -- including President Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia -- who would equate the massacre with the 9/11 attacks and Islamic terrorism in general.

title: Downpour Overwhelms Transit in Morning Rush
description: Torrential rains linked to Hurricane Frances moved into the New York metropolitan area yesterday, flooding the city's subway system during the morning rush and bringing the region's finely choreographed transportation network nearly to its knees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOOM, HERBERT H.
description: BLOOM--Herbert H., on September 7, 2004, of White Plains, NY, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Loving husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Barbara Bloom, Pat Comerford and Joan Frederick. Adored grandfather of Ross, Jay, Carolyn and Hallie. All services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZILL, NICHOLAS
description: ZILL--Nicholas. Of Brick, NJ, passed away peacefully on Sunday, September 5 at a nursing home from Parkinson's disease and several strokes. He was 89 years old. Beloved father of Nicholas, Sasha, Mark and Paul, grandfather of ten and greatgrandfather of three. Brother of Anne, Peter and the late Anthony. Former market research executive for the Hearst Corporation, book reviewer for the North County News (Westchester) and past president of Rova Farms in Cassville, NJ. Funeral service will be held at St. Vladimir's Cemetery, Jackson, NJ on Saturday, Sept. 11 at 11 AM.

title: After Devastating Grenada, Storm Bears Down on Jamaica
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 9 - Packing winds up to 160 miles an hour, Hurricane Ivan, the third powerful storm to boil up out of the Atlantic this year, bore down on Jamaica on Thursday evening after devastating Grenada. The authorities began evacuating the Florida Keys in anticipation of being hammered this weekend.

description: PRENDERGAST--Kevin H., Professor Emeritus, Columbia University. Survived by his wife Jane, daughters Laura and Catherine. Family will receive friends Saturday, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, 3-8PM.

description: Richard G. Butler, the founder of the Aryan Nations and a leading figure in the white supremacist movement who preached that Jews descend from Satan and black people are subhuman, died yesterday in his home. He was 86.

title: Add Water, and Presto, It's New York
description: WE dealt with frozen zones. Wailing sirens day and night. Demonstrations around every corner. Streets blocked. Terror alerts. An insistently friendly occupying force. Wall-to-wall parties with the security constraints that come with them.

title: Coca-Cola Unit Trims Forecast
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises, the soft drink distributor, said yesterday that earnings this year would fall more than it expected because higher prices and cooler weather were hurting sales.

title: Singh Makes It to Top and Is Hoping to Stay
description: For the first time in his career, Vijay Singh will enter a golf tournament as the No. 1 player in the world. That status will not change his approach, however.

title: Hagiography of a Drug Lord (He Loves Children)
description: Pablo Escobar Gaviria, king of the cocaine smugglers, died a folk hero's death in 1993. His final moments -- on the roof of his three-story hide-out in Medelln, Colombia, firing two 9-millimeter pistols at his would-be captors before being brought down by police snipers -- were worthy of a James Cagney gangster movie.

title: Nassau Refinancing Seeks to Prop Up Health Agency
description: GARDEN CITY, Sept. 8 - Nassau officials endorsed a $300 million refinancing on Wednesday to avert the collapse of the county's beleaguered health care agency. They also outlined other plans to revamp the system to ensure its long-range survival.

title: Download Music and Movies
description: NOT long ago, streaming video on a computer meant dealing with images hardly bigger than a Ritz cracker. Dial-up Internet connections made those pictures choppy, blurry and not terribly gripping. Audio was better, but not by much.

title: W. H. Krome George, Who Led Alcoa, Dies at 86
description: W.H. Krome George, a former chairman and chief executive of Alcoa, who was credited with overseeing the company's expansion into a global concern, died on Monday in Mars, Pa. He was 86 and lived in Sewickley, Pa.

title: Protests Powered by Cellphone
description: AS thousands of protesters marched through Manhattan during the Republican National Convention last week, some were equipped with a wireless tactical communications device connected to a distributed information service that provided detailed and nearly instantaneous updates about route changes, street closures and police actions.

title: Designers, Models, Socialites and Two Little Dogs, Too
description: To say that Fashion Week is by its nature surreal may be, one admits, a big "no duh." But periodically it bears repeating. While there are undoubtedly some unusual things going on at the average Renaissance Weekend or World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, it seems safe to assume that little occurs at those Big Thoughts gatherings that is half as nutty as a typical day in this city when the style flock alights.

By CAREN OSTEN GERSZBERG
With the right gear, roasting marshmallows and sleeping under the stars, even just a few feet from the comforts of home, can seem like an adventure.

title: In Napa, Calif.
description: SAN FRANCISCANS have long ducked off Highway 29 to wait out the traffic with a stroll through one of downtown Napa's neighborhoods of wide streets, airy parks and gingerbread-style houses. But lately, there's been reason to linger a bit longer in this once sleepy town at the stem of the Napa Valley wine country. With hip eateries, a contemporary art museum on the revitalized riverfront and a 19th-century opera house now featuring a series of world music performances, downtown Napa has become a destination in its own right. Behind some of the oldest stone storefronts in California you can discover the newest flavor combinations, with-it clothing stores, and a sense that you've found something hidden, something on the verge of a boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UMANOFF, ROSE
description: UMANOFF--Rose, 85 years old of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Died on September 3. Loving mother of Jane and Dan. Devoted grandmother of Becky, Lila, Zak and Nicole. Adoring great-grandmother of Max and dear mother-in-law of Bo. Rose was a positive, enthusiastic and youthful presence with her family and friends. Her love of tennis, gardening, antiquing and creating beautiful crafts was boundless. Rose was loved by many and will be missed by all. Contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood.

description: EVEN though the carbohydrate-cutting phenomenon may have peaked, it has produced a new vocabulary of food ranging from Atkins brand barbecue sauce to Z-Carb chocolate bars.

description: A 12- to 15-foot-deep trench for a sewer line in Brooklyn collapsed yesterday afternoon, killing a worker inside, the police said.

description: The health fund covering 55,000 New York City janitors is nearing insolvency, and janitors' union officials yesterday threatened a strike against more than 1,000 office buildings in October if the real estate industry does not come up with money to close the fund's $175 million operating deficit.

title: Falling Bodies, a 9/11 Image Etched in Pain
description: Three years later, they remain open questions, and many people wonder if firm answers would lead to more pain or less, to practical lessons for society or to just a spectacle for the morbidly curious.

title: A Search for a Dry Shelter in a Teenager's Dreary Life
description: In "Evergreen," which opens today in New York and New Jersey, a moony ingnue looks through the rain-slicked windows of moving vehicles. Along this indie film's bumpy ride, a 14-year-old girl called Henri takes in drive-by glimpses of Everett, Wash., her new hometown. Amid the drizzle are all the abandoned lots and roadside shards of Cobain country, a harsh terrain for a young sprout.

title: Russian Leader Promises Open Inquiry Into Terror Attack
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 A In an unusual retreat under public pressure, President Vladimir V. Putin today promised an open inquiry into the recent slaughter of hostages in a school house, although the forum he chose left critics doubtful of his intentions.

description: Twenty-eight firefighters and three residents of a high-rise apartment building in Chinatown were injured yesterday in a three-alarm fire that was fueled by heavy winds, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Posts Profit
description: The beer maker InBev said first-half profit rose 20 percent as demand for Stella Artois in Russia and acquisitions in China increased sales. The brewer, formerly known as Interbrew, said net income climbed to 205 million euros ($250 million) from 171 million euros a year earlier. Sales rose 7 percent to 3.5 billion euros. Both figures exclude AmBev, the Brazilian brewer the company gained control of last month. The company faces a tough comparison with sales from a year ago, when a heat wave encouraged beer consumption. The chief executive, John Brock, above, said the company's recent acquisitions of brewers in other parts of the world would offset the decline in Europe.

title: Creative Director Joins Bartle Bogle New York
description: Kevin Roddy has been hired as the executive creative director of the New York office of the London agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty, after leaving a similar post at the New York office of Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas.

title: Waltzing Around and Around
description: The Austrian Cultural Forum's Mostly Modern festival, an annual fall series of free recitals and chamber music concerts that intriguingly mix older works with more recent and unusual ones, began on Tuesday night with a recital by the pianist Anika Vavic, who was born in Belgrade but lives in Vienna. As usual for concerts at the Forum, on East 52nd Street near Fifth Avenue, the hall was packed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTMAN, ESTHER KELLY BILL
description: HARTMAN--Esther Kelly Bill. Died on September 1, 2004 in Lyme, CT. She was born on September 29, 1923, in New Rochelle, NY, the daughter of the late James Raymond and Esther Elizabeth Kelly Bill. She attended the Thorton Donovan School and Rye Country Day School. In 1945, she graduated with honors from Smith College (Northampton, MA). She met John W. Hartman in St. Augustine, FL. They were married on November 8, 1947, in New Rochelle, NY. Together they lived in St. Augustine, FL, New York City, Darien, CT, New Canaan, CT, Ocean Reef, Key Largo, FL and Lyme, CT during summers for all of her life. Kelly Hartman's volunteer activities included work for the American Red Cross in Darien, New Canaan, and New York. She also founded and volunteered at the Ocean Reef Library and volunteered at the Lyme Public Library. She supported the Lyme Library, fire department and ambulance. Hartman Park, their gift to the Town of Lyme, was originally part of her Bill family's land. With her husband, she made major contributions to the above libraries and to the Florence Griswold Museum, including the Hartman Education Barn, The Child & Family Agency of Southeastern Connecticut, High Hopes Therapeutic Riding, Inc., Old Lyme, CT and to Florida Keys Land and Sea Trust, Marathon, FL. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her children Kelly Bill Hartman Sherwood and Raymond Bill Hartman; her grandchildren Katarina and Nicola and her cousin Sally J. Bill. She was also predeceased by her sister Jane Bill Neely. Memorial contributions in Mrs. Hartman's memory may be made to any of her favorite charities mentioned. Burial will be private. There are no calling hours.

title: Officers Lack Skills to Vet Saudis Seeking U.S. Visas, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - A counterterrorism program intended to prevent terror suspects in Saudi Arabia from acquiring United States visas has been hindered by inadequate financing and training, leaving many homeland security officers in Saudi Arabia unable to speak Arabic and unfamiliar with how to conduct criminal investigations, according to a Department of Homeland Security report released Thursday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago Plans To Link 2,000 Security Cameras
description: Chicago officials announced a plan to link 2,000 surveillance cameras into a network in a new center where workers can watch for criminal activities and security emergencies. Mayor Richard M. Daley said the network would integrate cameras from all departments and let 911 emergency telephone operators view surveillance of emergency calls. David Bernstein (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an internal financial review by the James Beard Foundation, the culinary charity in New York that has acknowledged financial irregularities, misstated some developments. The possibility of wrongdoing by a board member was acknowledged by James Haggerty, a foundation spokesman, in response to The Times's question after the meeting; it was not announced by the board.

title: Budget Fares Change Face of Air Travel for Indians
description: BANGALORE, India, Sept. 9 - Three-year-old Harsha could not stop chattering about flying in an airplane. Her mother, Kusum Baid, a 29-year-old Bangalore homemaker, was also eager, and a little anxious. On Aug. 25, Ms. Baid boarded a flight for the first time in her life and, with her two children, flew from Bangalore to New Delhi to visit her family.

title: Settlement in DuPont Water Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - DuPont has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit in which West Virginia residents accused the company of having contaminated local water supplies with an important chemical used to make Teflon products.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Officials Stop Tiger Search
description: Officials have stopped searching for what appeared to be a loose tiger, first sighted two weeks ago, near Fort Polk. About 100 soldiers, animal trackers and Vernon Parish sheriff's deputies had searched and set meat-baited traps in an area of five to six square miles. They have stopped finding evidence of the tiger and said it left or was privately captured. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: For Would-Be Scorseses, the Streets Are Truly Mean
description: Independent filmmaking, as it comes across in "Film School," has two parts: hysteria and logistics.

title: ASTRAZENECA MAY NEED TO FILE MORE DATA FOR EXANTA
description: AstraZeneca may need to provide more data to prove its experimental blood thinner, Exanta, is safe and effective, Food and Drug Administration reviewers said. An independent panel will consider the F.D.A. staff review in weighing whether to recommend approval. The agency reviewers said Exanta posed a risk of liver damage, and questioned the way the company designed studies. The F.D.A. concerns may delay approval and limit sales, analysts said. AstraZeneca, which is based in London, is seeking United States approval for Exanta for three uses: preventing clots in people undergoing knee-replacement surgery, the long-term prevention of clots and the prevention of stroke in people with heart-rhythm problems. The company's stock fell 5 percent on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIRDSALL, LEONE COTTRELL, M.D.
description: BIRDSALL--Leone Cottrell, M.D. Age 94, died on September 8, 2004. Dr. Cottrell was a Pediatrician and Child Psychiatrist, a member of The New York Embroiderers Guild, The Society of Women Geographers and a Life Member of The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Predeceased by her husband, Charles H. Birdsall, Esq. in 1965, she is survived by three loving daughters, Marion Rendon, Jean Simson and Helen Shepherd, three grandchildren, Santiago, Ann Beatriz and Leone Rendon, and four great - grandchildren. The Wake and Service will be held at Campbell Funeral Home, Saturday, September 11, 2004, 10AM-12PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 E. 70 St., NYC 10021.

Sister of Lawrence Wachs and Helene Whitman. Grandmother of Jason, Jamie, Spencer, Logan and Jake. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, "GuttermanMusicant," 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. title: Not to Be Obvious, Models Are Back
description: Except for those of the lone black woman, their eyes are all blue. Each face is different, but only by minute degrees. One has a nose that is a tiny bit larger. The lower lip of another is more pouty and petulant. Every one of them has a symmetrical cast of feature and an expression that it does not take a Naomi Wolf to see as submissive and unchallenging.

World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Orders for Japanese machinery fell a seasonally adjusted 11.3 percent in July from a month earlier in the latest of a string of recent data that points to a slowing of Japan's recovery. The decline was worse than economists expected and followed a 10 percent increase in machinery orders the month before. The biggest reasons for the decline in July orders were falling demand from makers of autos, transportation equipment and semiconductors. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Hearing Confronts Insurers Who Market to Soldiers

The chairman, Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana, challenged not only the sales practices of their agents but also the fundamental merits of their products.

description: American designers, unlike their European counterparts, seem particularly susceptible to the allure of old rooms. John Bartlett, after a sabbatical, chose to make his return to fashion yesterday in a reading room at the Harvard Club, a place where he lived when he first arrived in New York from college and the Midwest. Member United Scenic Artist Local 829 and WWII Veteran. Beloved husband of the late Sarah "Colley" (nee Ballister). Devoted father of Mark, Scott and Tom Ballou. title: In Tape, Top Aide To Bin Laden Vows New Strikes at U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Osama bin Laden's top deputy appeared in a new videotape broadcast on an Arab television network on Thursday, taunting the United States for becoming mired in what he called unsuccessful campaigns in Iraq and Afghanistan while vowing that Al Qaeda would attack the United States again.

title: The Long Shadow of War
description: Each time President Bush has run for public office, he has had to weather critics' charges that he received silver-spoon treatment during the Vietnam War as a politician's son who gained coveted admission to the Texas Air National Guard while other young Americans were drafted into combat. The charges are back once more, this time with some telling new details in the form of private memos attributed to Mr. Bush's squadron commander of three decades ago.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 2 New Arrests On Nuclear Proliferation Charges
description: The police charged two more engineers with participating in a nuclear-technology smuggling ring, but left unanswered the issue of why a third man, arrested last week on the same charges, was set free on Wednesday with charges dropped. The two men, Gerhard Wisser and Daniel Geiges, were the owner and an employee of Krisch Engineering in Randpark, a Johannesburg suburb. Both were charged with violating laws that essentially prohibit making and trafficking components for in nuclear weapons. They were arraigned, however, in Vanderbiljpark, 50 miles south of Johannesburg and where the third engineer, Johan Andries Muller Meyer, was arrested. Abdul S. Minty, chairman of the government's nuclear oversight agency, declined in a telephone interview to explain the link between the arrests. But he said he had scheduled a news conference for today. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Benson Looks Like Pitcher the Mets Traded For
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9 - Kris Benson has had a chance to see the Mets at their worst since they traded for him, and he says he still wants to forsake free agency and remain a Met after the season. Benson is looking for stability, and he said Thursday that the Mets had agreed to discuss a three-year contract with him, although the amount of the contract remains unresolved.

title: Putin Moves to Strengthen Antiterror Forces in South
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9 - The Kremlin reorganized its local security services on Thursday in the region where hundreds of people were killed last week in a school hostage-taking, the first public step in a program of heightened security announced earlier by President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: The OSCE meets in Brussels : A partnership to fight hate and intolerance
Cracking Under the Pressure? It's Just the Opposite, for Some
description: For Michael Jones, an architect at a top-tier firm in New York, juggling multiple projects and running on four hours of sleep is business as usual. Mr. Jones has adjusted, he says, to a rapid pace and the constant pressure that leads his colleagues to "blow up" from time to time.

Powell declared Thursday that the United States viewed the killings, rapes and destruction of homes in the Darfur region of western Sudan as genocide, and he called on the United Nations Security Council to recognize that the situation required urgent action.

title: Yesterday's Shocker Is Today's Must Read
description: Origami: it used to be such an innocent craft, such a sweet way of creating flowers and boats and critters. Well, don't look now, but there's a new wrinkle to the old Japanese art of folding paper. Rizzoli will soon publish "Very Naughty Origami," with step-by-step instructions on how to shock your friends and neighbors with lascivious handiwork. The book's pice de rsistance is an illustration of little paper people having group sex.

description: BACKPACKING? Car camping? For a grand finale to the sleep-out season, the backyard can be just as appealing. With the right gear, roasting marshmallows over a campfire and sleeping under the stars, even just a few feet from the comforts of home, can seem like an adventure whether you're 6 or 66.

description: "When we reviewed the evidence compiled by our team, we concluded - I concluded - that genocide has been committed in Darfur and that the Government of Sudan and the Janjaweed bear responsibility, and that genocide may still be occurring."
