Election Board Restricts Ads for Anti-Kerry Film
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - The Federal Election Commission on Thursday denied a request by an independent advocacy group to use unregulated contributions to pay for television and radio commercials promoting a documentary and a book critical of Senator John Kerry.

title: Roundabout On Long Island
description: THE notion of a bucolic Sunday drive on Long Island may bewilder anyone who has suffered through a traffic-clogged crawl back to New York from the Hamptons. But Long Island is funny that way. Just when you think you've got its number, it will unsettle you, in a lovely way, by tossing unexpected gems in your path. And nowhere is that truer than along the North Shore, where Route 25A and its tiny spurs wend their way through winsome villages, canopies of trees, bedrocks of history and sweeping, sandy vistas.

title: Like Politicians Everywhere, Afghans Can Tie New Roads to Votes
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Sept. 9 - It was a pre-election scene that has been played out in every country where politicians slap backs and kiss babies. There were the beginnings of new road, a groundbreaking and a bunch of officials promoting the candidate they said deserved full credit.

title: Trading In His Playbook for Operatic Scores
description: MORRIS ROBINSON, a 330-pound ode to the quirky rewards of a bidisciplinary lifestyle, is luxuriating on his black leather sofa, his brown eyes fixated on a televised football highlights show while the operatic strains of Mozart's "Magic Flute" float into his ears via his trusty Bose headphones.

title: Copenhagen Journal; Wedding Vows Can Lock Danes Out of Their Homeland
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 7 - When Signe Norgaard Nielsen and Franklin Lamot Lescaille met in Havana about three years ago, it did not take them long to fall in love and decide to get married. What has become a lengthy ordeal for the couple began when the pair applied to live in Denmark, the country where Signe and her ancestors were born.

title: European Union Lauds and Prods Turkey on Chances of Joining
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 9 - The enlargement commissioner of the European Union, the man whose good opinion could help propel Turkey into membership negotiations, gave very little away on this week as he swept through a whirl of meetings with Kurdish activists, Christian and Jewish leaders, and government officials in the Turkish provinces.

title: U.S. Military Kills Scores in Fighting Near Mosul
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 9 - After a long morning of fierce but one-sided combat near the northern city of Mosul on Thursday, American forces said they had killed 57 enemy fighters with great precision, and without a single American casualty.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Qualcomm To Acquire Iridigm
description: Qualcomm, the world's second-largest maker of chips that power mobile telephones, will buy the Iridigm Display Corporation for $170 million to acquire its patented technology for cellphone screens. The price covers the 86 percent of Iridigm that Qualcomm does not already own, the company said yesterday. Iridigm's so-called iMod technology is cheaper to make and uses less battery power than existing liquid crystal-display, or L.C.D., screens, said Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego. The technology allows manufacturers to make lower-priced phones with more features like color screens that display pictures and video. Demand for cellphones with color screens and features like cameras lifted global shipments 37 percent, to $163.7 million during the second quarter, the research company IDC said. Qualcomm makes wireless-phone chips and sell licenses for the use of its patented code-division multiple-access, or C.D.M.A., technology for transmitting phone calls. Shares of Qualcomm rose 14 cents to close at $39.65.

title: Pop and Jazz Listings
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRESLER, ALAN L.
description: BRESLER--Alan L. Born in Memphis, a resident of Boca Raton for the past eight years. Alan passed away suddenly on September 9, 2004. His zeal for life took him many places. He was formerly a resident of New York City, London and Beverly Hills. He is survived by his loving wife Jeri Poller and his brother Bob Bresler and his many cherished friends. He was in the financial services industry for over 35 years. "Gutterman's", 800-992-9262.

title: Indonesian Police Release Details of Deadly Car Bomb
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10 A The Indonesian police today showed a photograph that they said was taken by a security camera of a white van outside the Australian embassy 29 seconds before it exploded in the terror attack Thursday.

description: ONCE the N.F.C. Beast and then the N.F.C. Least, it's now the N.F.C. Feast.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about former President Bill Clinton's recovery from heart surgery referred incorrectly in some copies to the time he started taking a statin for high cholesterol. He began the drug during the last months of his presidency, not after he left office. (Go to Article)

title: Oh, to Be a Tree Instead of a Girl!
description: The New York City Opera opened its season on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, and made big news in the city's cultural life, with a new production of Strauss' seldom heard late opera "Daphne," highlighted by a winning portrayal of the daunting title role by the vibrant coloratura soprano Elizabeth Futral. George Manahan conducted a surely paced and essentially well-played account of this sweeping, radiant and difficult score, written in a single act of 90 minutes.

title: Eisner to Step Down as Disney Chief in 2006
description: Michael D. Eisner, the embattled chief executive officer of the Walt Disney Co., told the board of directors Thursday that he plans to step down in two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an internal financial review by the James Beard Foundation, the culinary charity in New York that has acknowledged financial irregularities, misstated some developments. The possibility of wrongdoing by a board member was acknowledged by James Haggerty, a foundation spokesman, in response to The Times's question after the meeting; it was not announced by the board.

title: Kerry Says Bush Assault Weapons Stance Aids Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  President Bush campaigned today in sections of Appalachia, where he said that his economic and tax policies were turning things around. In St. Louis, Senator John Kerry said the president was helping terrorists by letting a ban on assault weapons expire next week.

title: DINING : Bistros to build a dream on
Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In Aborted Payroll Robbery
description: Three or four men in a van tried to rob two retired police officers making a payroll delivery in Ozone Park yesterday morning, and fled on Atlantic Avenue after one of the former officers opened fire, the police said. The men in the van returned fire, hitting no one, and sped off, leaving one passenger behind. Officers in a passing patrol car saw the man, identified as Jonathan Boston, 19, chasing after the van and carrying a rifle, and arrested him. The retired officers, who operate a check-cashing service, were arriving at the Railex Corporation, at 89th Street and Atlantic Avenue, when they were set upon. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HARRIS INTERACTIVE INC., Rochester, a market-research consulting firm, said it had bought WirthlinWorldwide, Reston, Va., an opinion-research and consulting company, for $41.8 million.

title: Call to Arms, With Trouble Right Here in Zombie City
description: Movies based on video games inevitably come in for an extra share of critical derision, but the writer and director Paul W. S. Anderson has made a solid career of them, from the sleeper "Mortal Kombat" in 1995 to last month's not-so-hot "Alien vs. Predator." "Resident Evil: Apocalypse," which Mr. Anderson wrote and helped produce but did not direct, is the sequel to his game-based "Resident Evil" of two years ago. If you are in the mood for leggy heroines (the film has two) blasting down zombie armies with absurdly large automatic weapons, the film gives very good value for the money.

title: Agreement Is Reached on $200 Million for Bronx Parks
description: After more than a year of wrangling, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and state leaders have agreed on the details of how to spend $200 million on parks projects in the Bronx, including $6 million for the park that would house a new stadium for the Yankees.

title: Drawing Line of Duty at Line of Fire
description: On the eve of another Sept. 11, it is worth noting that terror comes in many guises, not just as monsters who turn airplanes into missiles. Terror can also come calling as a lone madman with a gun.

title: In Flatbush, 2 Challengers Work to Unseat a State Senator Before He Really Settles In
description: There is widespread agreement among politicians in New York, where state legislators are rarely defeated once they get into office, that the best opportunity to beat an incumbent is in his or her first re-election campaign.

title: Hong Kong elections : When winners lose, the message is the victory
On a Bounce or on a Roll, Bush Enjoys an Edge Over Kerry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - President Bush enters the fall campaign with a modest lead over Senator John Kerry after fortifying his standing as the better candidate to fight terrorism and turning many Americans against Mr. Kerry, according to polls released since the Republican National Convention and interviews with campaign aides.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Beef Ban Reconsidered
description: Japan moved a step closer to lifting a nine-month ban on imports of beef from the United States after a government food safety commission lent support to the idea of dropping a requirement to test young cows for mad cow disease. Japan stopped the imports in December after the discovery of a case of mad cow disease in the United States. Before the ban, Japan imported some $1.4 billion in beef a year from the United States. Japan has been calling for ranchers in the United States to test every cow for the disease as a condition to resuming imports, but Washington has refused to go along. Yesterday, the government food panel effectively said that there was no reason to require the testing of younger cows when it announced it has concluded that such tests could not detect the disease in animals younger than 20 months. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Saturdays Top Games
description: !No. 8 Michigan (1-0) at Notre Dame (0-1)2:30 p.m., NBCLast week, the Irish came up with only 11 yards on the ground duringa 20-17 loss to Brigham Young. This week, Notre Dame is hopingthat running back Ryan Grant, who sat out last week, will play.Michigan will start the freshman quarterback Chad Henne for theinjured Matt Gutierrez. After a tense rematch Thursday night with the Indianapolis Colts, whom they vanquished in the playoffs in January to go to the Super Bowl, the party rolls on in New England.

title: A New Sheen for an Art Deco Designer
description: It was big news in June when Christie's New York sold a single bronze armchair, designed around 1919 by the French Art Deco designer Armand Albert Rateau, for $970,700, a world auction record for a 20th-century chair.

title: New chief faces debt, unions and market : French utility's next era
A Manhattan Whose Spirit Has Left Warmth Behind
description: Those of us who fret that Woody Allen's finger is no longer on the pulse of his beloved New York City can take cold comfort in "When Will I Be Loved," James Toback's smudged postcard of a city in thrall to sex and money. In place of Mr. Allen's anxious, bleeding heart, Mr. Toback substitutes a tumescent wallet. Instead of nourishing the soul, the classical music that spills through much of the film like a fountain spewing ice water serves only as upscale dcor for the delectation of "them that's got," to quote Billie Holiday.

title: A Shift in the Balance Between a Singer and Musicians
description: Smooth chemistry between a pop-jazz singer like Stacey Kent and her musicians is something we tend to take so much for granted that when it's missing, it comes as a shock to realize how delicate it really is. Ms. Kent, who is opening the fall season at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel with a new show, "Lucky to Be Me -- From Berlin to Bernstein," has a tart, buoyant voice that flutters and glints like a sunlit butterfly as it alights on the flowers of the great American songbook.

title: Long-Winded Matchup Goes Federer's Way
description: Players' shirts beat against their bodies like waves against a rock. The tennis ball often did a strange jig as it crossed the net. Young men armed with the task of shielding players from the sun during breaks struggled to keep their umbrellas upright, and courtside chairs teetered like reeds in a storm.

description: ARE the Big Four accounting firms members of an endangered species, destined to die from litigation?

title: Stop Blaming Putin and Start Helping Him
description: Moscow - On Monday, against the backdrop of the terrorist attack in Beslan, President Vladimir Putin of Russia held a remarkable four-hour discussion with a small group of American and Western European journalists and analysts at his official residence at Novo-Ogaryovo, outside Moscow. The meeting had been scheduled as part of a two-day conference on Russian-Western relations, but given the unfolding horrors at School No. 1, we were certain it would be canceled. Instead, President Putin turned it into a very personal exercise in public diplomacy.

title: New U.S. economy: Not just buying stuff
Ebookers shares soar on talks with possible buyers
ALASKA AIR TO ELIMINATE 900 JOBS TO REDUCE COSTS
description: Alaska Airlines will eliminate 900 jobs, or about 8 percent of its workforce, to reduce annual costs by as much as $35 million, the company said yesterday. The airline, which is based in Seattle, said it would close its heavy maintenance base in Oakland, Calif., and cut 340 jobs there. The airline, which did not eliminate jobs after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as some rivals did, will also cut 273 employees by contracting out the cleaning of planes in Seattle and in the Alaska cities of Anchorage, Fairbanks and Juneau. The company will also close some ground support and maintenance operations.

title: Valuing Wilderness
description: Two of the nation's most important environmental laws turned 40 the other day: the Wilderness Act and the law establishing the Land and Water Conservation Fund. Both had roots in the Eisenhower and Kennedy administrations, both were signed into law by President Lyndon Johnson on Sept. 3, 1964, and both remain very much alive and doing what they were intended to do, which is to preserve wild places and protect America's dwindling open spaces for future generations. Yet neither law is getting the nurturing it needs from the current administration and Congress.

title: Zimbabwe Sentences 68 Accused Mercenaries to Prison
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 10 A Simon Mann, the British soldier-of-fortune accused of masterminding a botched coup last March against Equatorial Guinea's ruler, was sentenced to seven years in prison today for illegally trying to buy weapons in Zimbabwe.

title: Kent, Conn.
description: THE gateway from New York into the town of Kent, on the western edge of Litchfield County, is Bulls Bridge, a one-lane covered bridge that insists those who cross it slow down. It's an appropriate welcome to a town incorporated in 1739 and known for its state parks, outdoor activities and blend of culture and country life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VILLENCY, CHARLES
description: VILLENCY -- Charles, 97. Peacefully September 6, 2004. Formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. Your life was rich with adventure, intellectual pursuits, devotion to family. Your gentle, consistant love for your wife Mignon, children Roxanne, Lynn and Stephen. Grandchildren Ariel and Rachel will not be forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BEDDARD, ANITA
description: BEDDARD--Anita. You are in our hearts, minds and souls always. We love and miss you so. Michael, Fred, and Devo

description: There was a bomber on the loose in New York City.

description: GROZNY, Russia, Sept. 8 - Mariyam Taburova and three of her roommates left the cramped, dismal apartment they shared here in Chechnya on Aug. 22. She has not been seen or heard from since. The others, however, have been.

title: A Farsighted New Fortress Mentality on Wall St.
description: In May, senior executives from Wall Street's top investment banks gathered at a conference center with a cadre of federal and local law enforcement authorities. Their task for the day was to simulate, down to the last detail, the aftermath of an explosion of a bomb in Midtown followed by others in Lower Manhattan.

title: Opening the Ears to the Exciting Soundscape of World Music
description: This is not a column about the World Music Institute, which is celebrating the opening of its 20th season this weekend. The institute is the subject of an exhibition starting today that runs to Nov. 27 at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, and is jointly presenting a concert of Colombian and Mexican music at the Central Park SummerStage on Sunday afternoon.

title: Billy Davis, Who Developed Iconic TV Ads, Dies at 72
description: Billy Davis, a Detroit singer and songwriter turned advertising executive who was involved in many of the most memorable R&B hits and musical ad campaigns of the late 20th century, died on Sept. 2 at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 72. Mr. Davis's sister, Gladys Adams, did not announce a cause, saying only that he had been ill for some time.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cisco To Buy NetSolve For $128.5 Million
description: Cisco Systems, the world's largest maker of computer networking equipment, said it would acquire NetSolve Inc. for $128.5 million to add software applications for managing corporate networks. NetSolve provides remote network and technology management services for businesses, Cisco said yesterday. The purchase price of $11 a share was a 23.6 percent premium to NetSolve's closing price of $8.90 yesterday in Nasdaq composite trading. NetSolve is based in Austin, Tex. Its shares rose $2, to $10.80, in extended trading. NetSolve's software is already used with Cisco products by companies sending data, video and telephone calls over the Internet, said a Cisco spokeswoman, Jeanette Gibson. Cisco is expanding into Internet-based communication and security to lessen its reliance on the switches and routers that make up 65 percent of sales. Shares of Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., rose 62 cents, to $19.93.

title: Piniella's Alternative May Be Same Sad Story
description: HAVING played, coached, managed, general managed and broadcast in New York for 15 years, Lou Piniella cannot be accused of navet. So when he raised a question in the form of a statement yesterday, he really knew the answer.

Funeral Service on Sunday, 10 AM at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home 352 E. 87th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory are requested to Search & Care, 1844 2nd Ave., NY, NY 10128.

title: More Fruit in Central Florida Is on Ground Than on Trees
description: WAHNETA, Fla., Sept. 8 - The citrus trees, once pregnant with fruit, have been stripped by the winds. The grapefruits and oranges, which once held the promise of months of steady wages, lie scattered in the muddy ground like brightly colored spherical pebbles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, GRACE GILBERT

title: Roddick's Comeback Falls Short
description: Fighting power with power, Joachim Johansson ended Andy Roddick's bid to repeat as United States Open champion last night. Ousting the defending champion and the last American in the men's draw, Johansson outlasted Roddick, 6-4, 6-4, 3-6, 2-6, 6-4, at Arthur Ashe Stadium, moving into a semifinal match tomorrow against Lleyton Hewitt.

title: F.B.I. Says Arrests Disrupted Trade in Stolen or Expired Medicine
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9 - Federal agents conducted raids in New Jersey, New York and three other states on Thursday to break up what they said were operations that distributed more than $56 million worth of expired or stolen medicines in the past 15 months.

title: A Loner Confronts His Hard Lesson in Self-Reliance
description: When Tom Brokaw takes two hours to tell a story, he is likely to take you someplace important. Strange then, with all the bombs bursting and mud flying, that he would follow a lone obsessive, a self-amputating hiker, down a hole in the Utah desert to retell a tale that is so widely known.

title: U.S. Shows Its Resolve, Warts and All
description: PANAMA, Sept. 9 - During World Cup qualifying, the United States men's soccer team has developed a characteristic that is both reassuring and maddening.

title: The Dishonesty Thing
description: It's the dishonesty, stupid. The real issue in the National Guard story isn't what George W. Bush did three decades ago. It's the recent pattern of lies: his assertions that he fulfilled his obligations when he obviously didn't, the White House's repeated claims that it had released all of the relevant documents when it hadn't.

title: Bush Attacks His Opponent Over His Record on Taxes
description: COLMAR, Pa., Sept. 9 - President Bush began a new attack on Senator John Kerry's economic record on Thursday, terming the senator a wastrel who would raise taxes on ordinary Americans and significantly increase government spending.

title: Where the Doctors Are Real and the Patients Enhanced
description: In case viewers have any doubt about the intent of "Miami Slice," Bravo's six-part documentary series about five successful Florida plastic surgeons, all they need to do is consider the transitions. Between segments the camera turns to close-ups of large, firm breasts in bikini tops; bare, flat abdomens; and perky buttocks in swimsuits or microminiskirts.

title: Art Listings
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Times Refuses Reprint in Moore Book
description: The publisher of a coming book by the filmmaker Michael Moore said yesterday that The New York Times had denied permission for Mr. Moore to include in his book a May article in which The Times reviewed shortcomings in its own reporting about the events leading up to the war in Iraq.

title: A Bank Takeover Fight, of Which Little Is Known
description: TOKYO, Sept. 9 - The unusual takeover battle for the ailing lender UFJ Holdings is shaking up Japan's ultraconservative financial industry, but many UFJ shareholders are wondering if anything has really changed.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Cap Gemini Posts Wider Loss
description: Cap Gemini, a French computer services company, posted a wider-than-expected first-half loss, attributing it to cost overruns on some contracts, and said its chief financial officer was leaving the company. The net loss, 135 million euros ($164 million), compared with a loss of 90 million euros a year earlier. The chief executive, Paul Hermelin, said the chief financial officer, William Bitan, would leave and be succeeded by Nicolas Dufourcq. He did not say why Mr. Bitan left. Mr. Hermelin said more managements changes were expected. Standard & Poor's cut the company's credit rating, and its stock fell 13 percent.

title: Ingredients of a Best Seller: Faith, Luck and Hard Work
description: Friends say Jeffrey Marx has always seemed oddly blessed.

title: After Devastating Grenada, Hurricane Bears Down on Jamaica
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 9 - Packing winds up to 150 miles an hour, Hurricane Ivan, the third powerful storm to boil up out of the Atlantic this year, bore down on Jamaica on Thursday evening after devastating Grenada. The authorities began evacuating the Florida Keys in anticipation of being hammered this weekend.

title: Reborn, Lake Erie Beckons Kayakers
description: PUT-IN-BAY, Ohio - SITTING in calm, lazy water and surrounded by lily pads and great blue herons, it's hard to imagine the Lake Erie Islands as anything but a kayaker's retreat. The marshy inlet is too shallow to reach by motorboat; too untamed to traverse by foot. The 12-foot kayak, on the other hand, slices through the water effortlessly, weaving in and out like a pond skater.

title: Yankees Sweep to Widen Lead
description: The Yankees finally succeeded in playing a doubleheader yesterday, and the hapless Tampa Bay Devil Rays were the perfect foils. With two easy victories, the Yankees did something they had not done in the previous 16 days. They gained ground on the Boston Red Sox.

title: Continental giants say they won't help East take jobs away : EU sends a message to newest members
Daniel Joseph Martinez -- 'The House America Built'
description: The Project 37 West 57th Street Through Oct. 2

title: Moody's Raises a Key Debt Rating on Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 9 - Moody's Investors Service, the credit rating agency, upgraded Brazil's sovereign debt rating on Thursday, saying strong exports and prudent debt management had helped make the country, South America's largest economy, less vulnerable to sudden swings in market sentiment.

title: Witnesses Pull Out of Trial After Judges Refuse to Let Milosevic Act as His Own Lawyer
description: THE HAGUE, Sept. 9 - Just days after judges assigned two British lawyers to defend Slobodan Milosevic, his war crimes trial ran into new difficulties on Thursday as scheduled witnesses pulled out in protest.

title: Sniper Victims in Settlement With Gun Maker and Dealer
description: The families of eight victims of the Washington-area snipers won a landmark $2.5 million settlement Wednesday from the manufacturer and the dealer who supplied the Bushmaster XM-15 rifle used in the 2002 shootings.

title: Judge Keeps City on Notice Over Convention Protest Arrests
description: A state court judge in Manhattan, unmoved by irate objections from lawyers for New York City, declined yesterday to dismiss contempt proceedings against the city for holding protesters too long during the Republican National Convention.

title: First-half profit increases
Presidential Qualities and Military Records (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Napa, Calif.
description: SAN FRANCISCANS have long ducked off Highway 29 to wait out the traffic with a stroll through one of downtown Napa's neighborhoods of wide streets, airy parks and gingerbread-style houses. But lately, there's been reason to linger a bit longer in this once sleepy town at the stem of the Napa Valley wine country. With hip eateries, a contemporary art museum on the revitalized riverfront and a 19th-century opera house now featuring a series of world music performances, downtown Napa has become a destination in its own right. Behind some of the oldest stone storefronts in California you can discover the newest flavor combinations, with-it clothing stores, and a sense that you've found something hidden, something on the verge of a boom. DEBRA A. KLEIN

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Judge Allows Oracle to Bid for PeopleSoft
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that Oracle, the nation's second-largest software company, could proceed with its hostile bid for PeopleSoft, handing the Justice Department a rare defeat in a legal challenge to a corporate merger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARK, KENNETH B.
description: STARK--Kenneth B. September 9, after a year illness. Beloved husband of Renee. Loving father of Melissa and Aimee, sons-in-law Mark Bildner and Edward Goldberg. He also leaves father William, brother Hal, sister Risa Kritzstein, nephews and nieces.

title: Peter Ruta -- 'Picturing New York'
description: Museum of the City of New York 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street Through Oct. 11

title: American and Iraqi Forces Try to Regain Control of Sunni Strongholds
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 9 - American forces entered the city of Samarra for the first time in months on Thursday, taking what appeared to be a small but significant step in their effort to regain control of contested Sunni areas north and west of the capital.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Auto Exports Rise
description: Auto exports from Mexico rose 15.3 percent in August, the strongest month for sales abroad this year, the Mexican Automotive Industry Association said. Production increased 11.3 percent and domestic sales grew 8.8 percent, the association said. The rising exports were driven by recovering demand for Mexican-made models in the United States.

title: Kerry Invokes the Bible in Appeal for Black Votes
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9 - Senator John Kerry turned to the Bible on Thursday to go after President Bush, warning a black Baptist audience here to "beware of false prophets which come to you in sheep's clothing."

title: How Does a Terrorist Come to Be?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Counties Count the Costs of Storms in Which a Boy, 3, Drowned
description: Against a brilliantly sunny backdrop yesterday, state and local officials in New York were assessing the damage from the rains that pounded the region this week, and an upstate hamlet was mourning a 3-year-old boy who drowned in a swollen creek.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of England opted to hold its key interest rate steady at 4.75 percent, signaling that policy makers think the British housing market has cooled. The bank has raised interest rates five times since November in an attempt to slow rising home prices and consumer spending.

title: Soccer : Goals that speak louder than words
US Airways Seen as Likely to Declare Bankruptcy
description: Barring a last-minute change of heart by its recalcitrant unions, US Airways appears all but certain to seek bankruptcy protection on Sunday, people briefed on the situation said yesterday.

title: How Does a Terrorist Come to Be?
description: To the Editor:

title: A President-to-Be and His Rosebud
description: With shows like "Everwood" and "Gilmore Girls," the WB has perfected the family drama. "Jack & Bobby" is a bigger step: a First Family drama.

title: R.E. Lapp, 87, Physicist in Cold-War Debate on Civil Defense, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Ralph E. Lapp, a physicist who was involved in atomic weapons from the earliest days of the Manhattan Project, was a prominent figure in the cold-war debate about civil defense and continued to speak out about the health effects of radiation into the 1990's, died Tuesday in Alexandria, Va. He was 87.

title: Corrections
description: A brief note in the Soccer Report column on Tuesday about the World Cup qualifying match on Saturday between the United States and El Salvador, in which a Salvadoran player was ejected for wearing jewelry and the game nearly erupted into a brawl because of physical play, misstated a comment to Reuters by Jim Moorhouse, a spokesman for U.S. Soccer. He said, "It was a very odd game" -- not "a very good game."

title: Keeping Creativity Alive, Even in Hell
description: I REMEMBER thinking in school how I would grow up and would protect my students from unpleasant impressions, from uncertainty, from scrappy learning," Friedl Dicker-Brandeis wrote to a friend in 1940. "Today only one thing seems important -- to rouse the desire towards creative work, to make it a habit, and to teach how to overcome difficulties that are insignificant in comparison with the goal to which you are striving."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EL DAMAA, FADI
description: El DAMAA--Fadi, September 6, 2004. Loving son of Sami El Damaa and Wadad, devoted brother of Ghassan, Anis, Amal and Hoda. Dear friend of Steve, Luigi and David. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st St), Friday, September 10, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, September 11, 10AM, at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West 31st Street.

title: Lawmaker Says F.D.A. Held Back Drug Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - The chairman of a House committee angrily accused the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday of withholding documents on the effects of antidepressants on children.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Butcher Bros. Steak House
description: I am a fool for a great many things in life, but I am a fool above all for porterhouses. Put a good one in front of me, give me a fork and knife and say goodbye, because for the next 10 minutes, I'll be gone. Perhaps I'll nod or utter a few syllables and seem to be interacting with the world beyond my beef, but that won't really be true. I'll be eating my porterhouse. I won't be able to focus on anything else.

title: Hiking 2,100 Miles in Bite-Size Pieces
description: EACH spring, about 30 hikers a day leave Springer Mountain in north Georgia, the southern terminus of the Appalachian Trail, with the goal of hiking north to Mount Katahdin, the trail's end in Maine. Only a few, though, ever make the entire 2,174.1-mile journey. In 2003, for instance, just 391 of the roughly 1,800 hikers who set out from Georgia to make the roughly six-month trek managed to do so, according to the Appalachian Trail Conference, the organization that oversees the trail.

title: Campaigns Enlist Big Names to Set Debates' Details
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - In the Kerry corner there are two of the most powerful lawyers in Washington, Vernon E. Jordan Jr. and Robert B. Barnett, not to mention the sitting governors of Michigan and Arizona, Jennifer M. Granholm and Janet Napolitano.

title: A Salute to Personal Acts of Resistance Against Evil
description: There was Pinchas Rosenbaum, a Hungarian rabbi's son who disguised himself as a Nazi officer and managed to save a thousand Jews; Anna Heilman, the only survivor of the successful plot to blow up Crematorium No. 4 at Birkenau; and Willy Perl, an Austrian man who persuaded leaders in Berlin to let him "deport" Jews, making it possible for thousands to escape safely to Palestine.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Copter Crash Kills 6 British Soldiers
description: Six British soldiers taking part in a joint military exercise died when their Lynx helicopter crashed in a field near southeastern Brno. The British Defense Ministry is investigating, and the exercise, which was to run until next Friday, was suspended. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: The Seductions of Fall
description: PEAKS ISLAND, Me. - DRAWN by the timeless beauty of its ocean vistas, the spooky ruins of World War II-era military installations and the romance of life on a Down East island that is both far from it all and a quick 20-minute ferry ride from Portland's bustling waterfront, tourists and day trippers flock here by the boatload all summer long.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts by the Bush campaign to counter negative accounts in a book by Kitty Kelley referred incompletely to the media outlets to which the Republican Party sent an e-mail message questioning aspects of her previous biographies. The message was sent to radio shows, not just to conservative ones.

title: Gambling Mogul Back With Korey Kay Group
description: Steven Wynn, the gambling entrepreneur, is reuniting with Korey Kay & Partners in New York. Mr. Wynn's new company, Wynn Resorts in Las Vegas, has named Korey Kay to handle general consumer advertising for Wynn Las Vegas, the $2.7 billion resort and country club scheduled to open on April 28, 2005. Spending has not been determined.

title: How Does a Terrorist Come to Be?
description: To the Editor:

title: House Votes to Block Administration's Rules on Overtime
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - The House voted Thursday to roll back new Bush administration rules governing overtime pay, providing Democrats a rare victory over the Republican majority in a debate colored by the approach of the November elections.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Belgium seeks to get rid of loose change
Half measures won't loosen a chokehold
Theater Listings
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

title: Presidential Qualities And Military Records
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Pay Fliers $1.5 Million for Pilfering of Checked Bags
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - The Transportation Security Administration will pay more than $1.5 million to some 15,000 airline passengers who claim that items in their checked baggage were stolen or damaged in the last 18 months, the agency plans to announce next week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 'The Wall' May Return To SoHo Building
description: A well-known minimalist sculpture in SoHo could be restored to the wall of a building at 599 Broadway from which it was removed two years ago to allow structural repairs. A federal judge, Deborah A. Batts, ruled in Manhattan yesterday that the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission had not violated the free speech rights of the building's owner, the Board of Managers of the SoHo International Arts Condominium, when it denied a permit to remove the sculpture permanently. The work, created by the artist Forrest Myers in 1973, was called "The Wall" and consisted of horizontal projections from 42 existing channel irons on the Houston Street side of the building. Condominium officials wanted to install an advertisement on the wall. Glenn Collins (NYT)

title: Convention Brought No Profit, Garden Says
description: Madison Square Garden will make little or no profit from the Republican National Convention, its officials said yesterday, even though it was paid nearly $6 million in fees from the convention's host committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANTERMAN, MILDRED
description: KANTERMAN--Mildred. The Dworetz, Ralston, and Baron families mourn the passing of "Miss K", our much loved friend and associate for more than half a century. We express deepest sympathy to Leroy Kanterman and all the family and many friends.

title: Following the Heart on a Path That Leads to an Alien Life
description: "It is all film, it is all a construction. But even so, it hurts." This self-conscious, self-evident observation, spoken (in Danish) by a narrator who also turns out to be one of the film's characters, is delivered twice in Christoffer Boe's "Reconstruction" -- once at the beginning and once at the end. The words are an explicit reminder of a paradox that haunts most movies, and other forms of fiction as well: as artificial as they are -- and "Reconstruction" wears its artifice like a close-fitting off-the-rack sport coat -- they nonetheless evoke, and induce, real feelings. Or at least they can.

title: Nassau Legislators Plan a Salary Increase
description: GARDEN CITY, Sept. 9 - The Nassau County Legislature is planning to increase the salary of its 19 members to $75,000 from the current $39,500, granting their first raises in 16 years, legislative officials said on Thursday.

title: Cricket : U.S. 'weekend warriors' face stars
Cons Meet Their Match: They Swindle Each Other
description: John C. Reilly may be one of our finer character actors, but his portrayal of Richard Gaddis, a gimlet-eyed con man, in "Criminal" allows too many vestiges of the duped schlub of a husband he played in "Chicago" to leak into his performance. A trickster always on the lookout for a mark, Richard is an arrogant cynic who ought to come across as a slithery, venomous descendant of Sydney Greenstreet or of David Mamet's pet reptile, Joe Mantegna.

title: Crouching Chef, Hidden Cauldron
description: Crouching Chef, Hidden Cauldron

title: No Fears: Laptop D.J.'s Have a Feast
description: DOWNLOADING music from the Internet is not illegal. Plenty of music available online is not just free but also easily available, legal and -- most important -- worth hearing.

title: Car Bomb in Jakarta Kills 9 At Australian Embassy
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 9 - The car bomb that exploded outside the Australian Embassy here on Thursday morning, killing at least nine people and injuring more than 150, was the work of the Qaeda-linked Islamic group, Jemaah Islamiyah, the Indonesian police chief said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial production rose in July for the 11th consecutive month, gaining 9.6 percent from a year ago, the government's statistics agency said. When compared with June, output climbed 0.5 percent in July, the fifth consecutive monthly gain. Industrial production has risen a cumulative 7.8 percent in the first seven months, fueled by booming exports and an increase in domestic demand as Brazil's economic recovery grows. Automakers helped lead the surge in July, increasing output 5.6 percent from the previous month. Most economists expect the Brazilian economy to expand about 4.5 percent this year, up from initial forecasts of 3.5 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDEMANN, BEATRICE R.
description: LINDEMANN -- Beatrice R. Died September 8 in Palm Beach at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Loving mother of Donna and the late Steve. Adoring grandmother of Trisha and David, Eric and Trish, and Ariana and great grandmother of Rebecca, Jordan, Tyler and Casey. She will always be in our hearts.

title: The Duel Between Body and Soul
description: New Haven - What people think about many of the big issues that will be discussed in the next two months -- like gay marriage, stem-cell research and the role of religion in public life -- is intimately related to their views on human nature. And while there may be differences between Republicans and Democrats, one fundamental assumption is accepted by almost everyone. This would be reassuring -- if science didn't tell us that this assumption is mistaken.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Immigrant Says Taxi Inspectors Beat Him
description: A Jordanian immigrant filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against the city yesterday, alleging that a pair of Taxi and Limousine Commission inspectors followed him from the Bronx into Westchester County several months ago, pulled him over and beat him up. Mohammed Abumulaweh, 25, of Yonkers, who is being represented by Ronald L. Kuby and George Wachtel, said the inspectors then handcuffed him, drove him back to the Bronx, cursed at him, called him a terrorist, impounded his car, and ticketed him for unauthorized operation of a for-hire vehicle, which his lawyers deny. A commission spokesman said an internal review was continuing. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAVON, DAVID H.
description: NAVON--David H. Age 79. Of Amherst, MA., after a brief illness, on September 8, 2004. A world-wide, renowned scientist, music was also the great passion of his life. He gave unconditional love to his wife, Bobbe (Amsel) Navon, son Marc, daughter-in-law Michelle, daughter Beth, son-inlaw Jonathan and grandchildren Max, Elana, Evan & Julia. Beth and Jonathan will be receiving friends at their home Monday, Sept. 13, 4-8PM.

title: Write-downs bring wider loss at BAE
Formula One Racing : Racing's low-tech secret:A happy team is a winning team
READER'S DIGEST CHANGES ACCOUNTING FOR PROMOTIONS
description: Reader's Digest, the magazine publisher, will take $104 million in charges for changing the way it accounts for mailings and promotions to attract new subscribers. The company recorded costs of $27 million, or 17 cents a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter, which ended June 30. The remaining $77 million will be accounted for during the current fiscal year, the company said. Reader's Digest, which is based in Pleasantville, N.Y., started taking promotional costs as an expense in July after previously deferring and amortizing some of the expense. The company said it discussed its treatment of the costs with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Reader's Digest's magazines include Reader's Digest, Backyard Living and Taste of Home.

title: Court Rules Regulators Erred on Refunds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 - A federal appeals court here ruled on Thursday that federal regulators had erred in rejecting up to $2.8 billion in refunds to California electric customers resulting from what the court called "artificial manipulation on a massive scale" of the state's energy market.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Found Shot To Death On Highway
description: A 54-year-old man was found shot to death in a vehicle on the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens yesterday morning, the police said. A woman driving on the expressway found Mitchel Engel, of Armonk, N.Y., in the southbound lane near Linden Boulevard in South Jamaica just after 7 a.m., hunched over in the driver's seat of a 2003 blue Ford Expedition, shot under the eye, the police said. There were no suspects, the police said. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Disney Chief to Leave, Setting Off Race for Job
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 - Michael D. Eisner, who has spent much of the last year fending off challenges to his two-decade reign at the Walt Disney Company, has announced an exit on his own terms, immediately shifting the spotlight from the rancorous debate over his leadership to speculation over who will succeed him.

title: RENT-A-CENTER CUTS PROFIT FORECAST; SHARES FALL
description: Rent-A-Center Inc., a rent-to-own retailer, cut its forecast for profit in the third quarter, setting off a 14 percent decline in its share price. Rent-A-Center, based in Plano, Tex., cut its earnings forecast to 47 cents to 48 cents a share late Wednesday, citing slower consumer demand and higher fuel prices. In July, the company forecast profit of 58 cents to 60 cents for the quarter. Rent-A-Center also reduced its 2004 profit outlook to $2.30 to $2.33 a share, from $2.62 to $2.70 a share. Stock in the company fell $4.43, to $26.20 a share.

title: FIDELITY NATIONAL AGREES TO BUY INTERCEPT
description: Fidelity National Financial Inc., a title insurer, agreed to buy InterCept Inc., a payment processor, for $408 million. InterCept holders will get $18.90 a share in cash or a combination of cash and stock, Fidelity said. The price is 8.3 percent more than Intercept's closing share price Wednesday of $17.45. The deal would be the 12th acquisition by Fidelity in the last 12 months. Fidelity, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., also said it would delay the sale of shares in some units until at least the first quarter of 2005 because of the InterCept purchase and "the relatively weak and unpredictable current equity market conditions." InterCept is based in Norcross, Ga.

title: The Americans Stay, and Play, Together
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 9 - When this core group of American hockey players first represented the United States eight years ago, it was a young and carefree bunch.

title: No Accountability on Abu Ghraib
description: After months of Senate hearings and eight Pentagon investigations, it is obvious that the administration does not intend to hold any high-ranking official accountable for the nightmare at Abu Ghraib. It was pretty clear yesterday that Senator John Warner's well-intentioned hearings of the Armed Services Committee are not going to do it either.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: D Train Derails
description: A subway train derailed on the D line in the Bronx around 9 o'clock last night, interrupting service between Tremont Avenue and 205th Street. No injuries were reported. Two wheels of the train's fifth car lifted off the tracks as the train was entering the Bedford Park Boulevard station, said Charles F. Seaton, a spokesman for New York City Transit. Six cars had already entered the station, and passengers were able to exit onto the platform. The cause of the derailment is under investigation and service is expected to resume by this morning. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: 'Have You Seen This Candidate?'
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 10  So many questions, so little access.

title: New Conference and Old Expectations for Miami
description: After dominating the Big East Conference for years in its annual bid for a national championship, the University of Miami football team might have expected a certain level of reverence upon joining the Atlantic Coast Conference this season. The reality slap came quickly in late July, when members of the news media who cover the A.C.C. picked the Hurricanes to finish second in the conference behind their hated rival, Florida State.

title: Family Granted New Trial in Police Killing of Troubled Man
description: A federal judge dealt a stinging setback to the city and the police yesterday by overturning a jury verdict that had cleared the city of liability in the 1999 police shooting of an emotionally disturbed man who was clutching a hammer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   D'ARCANGELO, MARJORIE ELIZABETH (FOSTER)
description: D'ARCANGELO -- Marjorie Elizabeth (Foster) of Mamaroneck, NY, on September 8, 2004 at age 86. Marjorie was born in Newark, NJ on June 2, 1918 to James Edwin and Elizabeth Lavigna (Evans) Foster. Marjorie received a Bachelor of Science degree from New York University in 1942. On October 20, 1945 she married the late A. Rick D'Arcangelo, who predeceased her in February 2004. She was a wonderful mother and devoted wife whose support for her family, her husband and his career was unwavering. Marjorie is survived by her children James R. (wife Mary Ellen), Inez E. (husband Alfred Thoben), Martha A. and John P. (wife Kathleen). Also survived by nine grandchildren and one great grandchild. Marjorie is predeceased by her brother John Warren Foster (wife Jacqueline). Reposing on Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 4 & 7 to 9PM at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck. Funeral Mass Monday 11:00am at St. Gregory the Great Roman Catholic Church followed by interment at Greenwood Union, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to the A. Rick andMarjorie E. D'ArcangeloScholarship Fund at NYU , NYU Stern School of Business, 44 West 4th St., Ste 10-54 NY, NY 10012.

title: From Happenstance and Determination, an International Exhibition
description: How did this retrospective come to exist? Remember, Friedl Dicker-Brandeis had not been heralded as an artist after World War II, but as a teacher. Exhibitions of her work had been scant in her lifetime -- a few paintings in a group show of Bauhaus artists, a solo exhibition in a London gallery in 1940, which she couldn't attend because of the war. Her work was scattered.

title: Profit rises at Publicis as ad sector recovers
Accounts
description: Unilever Home and Personal Care division, Trumbull, Conn., expanded its relationship with J. Walter Thompson, New York, part of the WPP Group, by shifting the creative account of the Vaseline Intensive Care skin-care line to Thompson from McCann Erickson Worldwide, New York, part of the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Spending, estimated at $10 million to $20 million a year recently, is expected to be increased. Thompson also handles division brands like Caress and Lever 2000.

title: Spitzer and 5 Others Want Alternative to Pesticide in Housing
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer of New York and five of his counterparts filed a federal lawsuit yesterday in an attempt to force the Department of Housing and Urban Development to reduce the use of pesticides in public housing developments.

title: Union Chief Sues Board Members Over Pay Cut
description: In an unusual display of internal friction, Lillian Roberts, the executive director of District Council 37, has filed a lawsuit accusing most of the union's board members of race, sex and age discrimination for cutting her salary.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: British Travel Company Considers Sale
description: The European Internet travel company Ebookers said yesterday that it was considering a possible sale of the company and was in discussions with several interested parties. Ebookers' stock closed up 25 percent on the London Stock Exchange, giving the company a market capitalization of 145.9 million ($260.1 million). In July the company warned that this year's profit could be significantly lower than estimates of about 10 million. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Loss widens 33% on cost overruns at Capgemini
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank Stake Sold
description: Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano said it had sold about half of its stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland, or 79 million shares, raising 1.22 billion ($1.49 billion). Banco Santander is in the middle of an 8.5 billion acquisition of the British mortgage lender Abbey National. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Formal Recognition For Traditional Healers
description: Parliament approved legislation to license and regulate certain classes of traditional healers much as Western-style physicians are regulated, making healers' services and many of their remedies eligible for insurance reimbursements and granting them some powers once reserved for doctors. Supporters called the law long overdue recognition for valid African medical practices like herbal cures, dismissed by outsiders as quackery. Critics said the healers' reliance on consultation with spirits and other nonscientific practices makes licensing a fraud. In a bow to skeptics, the law forbids the healers to treat such serious ailments as cancer and AIDS. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers' Union Says Contract Bargaining Is Near
description: After nearly a year of deadlock, the union representing New York City public school teachers said yesterday that it had made progress in contract talks with the Bloomberg administration. The union, the United Federation of Teachers, has been working without a contract since May 31, 2003. The Bloomberg administration infuriated the union this year by proposing to virtually scrap the existing 200-page contract in favor of a bare-bones eight-page proposal. The union's president, Randi Weingarten, said yesterday that the city had withdrawn that proposal, and that "all sides now appear ready to bargain." David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Dementieva Has No Desire for an All-Russian Final
description: Elena Dementieva returned home in June after she and her serve had crumbled against Anastasia Myskina in the French Open final, the first all-Russian final in a Grand Slam tennis tournament. She was amazed that she and Myskina, her childhood friend, were regarded with awe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTIG, MICHAEL
description: HARTIG--Michael. Good-bye, old friend. The old days were the best days. Thanks for your guidance Lenny Fischer

title: Children's Events
description: Theater

title: New York, New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: Presidential Qualities And Military Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about former President Bill Clinton's recovery from heart surgery referred incorrectly in some copies to the time he started taking a statin for high cholesterol. He began the drug during the last months of his presidency, not after he left office.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 - Israeli forces continued a major operation in Gaza on Thursday with tanks and armored vehicles to suppress rocket fire into Israel, and in the process killed seven Palestinians. Another Palestinian was killed by Israeli troops in the West Bank.

Hank Kim and Richard Linnett were named to lead the unit as directors; they had been editors and columnists for Advertising Age, New York, published by Crain Communications.

description: Correction Appended

title: ALCOA SEES EARNINGS BELOW ANALYSTS' ESTIMATES
description: Alcoa Inc., the aluminum producer, said profit from continuing operations will be 30 cents to 35 cents a share in the third quarter, below analysts' estimates, because of higher energy costs, lower demand in Europe and a labor strike. The company, which is based in Pittsburgh, was expected to earn 52 cents, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Alcoa had net income of $280 million, or 33 cents, in the third quarter last year. A strike at the company's aluminum-making facility in Becancour, Quebec, a fire at a plant in Pennsylvania and costs to close plants in Washington and Ohio will reduce results by 7 cents to 9 cents a share, Alcoa said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drain Cleaning Reductions Caused Floods
description: Recent cutbacks in the number of sewer drains being cleaned by the city is the reason that many streets flooded during Wednesday's storm, the city public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, said in a letter sent to city environmental officials yesterday. Drawing from data released by the mayor's office, Ms. Gotbaum said that the total number of sewer drains cleaned in the city declined to 30,481 in 2003 from 37,631 in 2002. By September 2003, the city had cleaned 11,000, but so far this year it has cleaned only 8,000. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: ARTS GUIDE
Army Says C.I.A. Hid More Iraqis Than It Claimed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - Army jailers in Iraq, acting at the Central Intelligence Agency's request, kept dozens of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison and other detention facilities off official rosters to hide them from Red Cross inspectors, two senior Army generals said Thursday. The total is far more than had been previously reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEIMAN, LEE
description: HEIMAN--Lee, 72, of North Woodmere, NY on September 2. Devoted husband of Roberta. Loving father of Todd, Bruce, Randi. Proud grandfather of seven. Author, editor and President of Golden Lee Books. He will be remembered for his wonderful sense of humor, the twinkle in his eye and his unending thirst for knowledge. He will always be in our hearts.

description: Directed by Mark Vicente, Betsy Chasse and William Arntz Not rated, 108 minutes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACKERMAN, NANCY
description: ACKERMAN -- Nancy, 73, passed away peacefully on September 9 at her home in Metuchen, N.J. She was the devoted wife of Bernard, loving mother of Terri, Sandra, and Howard, adoring grandmother of Lionel, Jesse, and Jackie, loving sister of Robert and sister-in-law Carol, and devoted to Jenny, James, Lance, Steve, and Maggie. Nancy was a dear friend to so many in Metuchen and Stockbridge. Educated at Cornell and New York Universities, she served professionally for many years as a chemistry instructor at Rutgers University and later made herself indispensable as the marketing coordinator of Ackrad Laboratories, a medical device company founded by Bud. She was a past-president of the Metuchen League of Women Voters and a member of the Metuchen Planning Board and the Stockbridge Bowl Association. Funeral services will be held at Temple Neve Shalom, 250 Grove Avenue, Metuchen, at 1:30PM, Friday, September 10. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: How Does a Terrorist Come to Be? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Kidnapped! Or, Can You Hear Me Now?
description: One of the many virtues of "Cellular," an improbably enjoyable new telecommunications action thriller, is that it wastes very little time on preliminary exposition. Kim Basinger, looking glamorous in a black dress and sunglasses, is walking her young son to the school bus. Their conversation lasts just long enough to establish the crucial information that Ms. Basinger's character, Jessica Martin, is a science teacher. The extra wave goodbye that she and her son exchange is a signal that something bad is about to happen, and a minute later some bald, black-denimed kidnappers kick in the kitchen door of Jessica's elegant Brentwood home, shoot the housekeeper dead and drag Jessica away to a remote safe house in the hills above Los Angeles.

title: NUCOR RAISES ESTIMATE FOR PROFIT IN THIRD QUARTER
description: The Nucor Corporation, a steel maker, raised its forecast yesterday for profit for the third quarter. The company boosted its dividend and will split its stock for the first time since 1993. Profit for the quarter will be $4.40 to $4.60 a share, higher than a forecast of $3.20 to $3.40 Nucor made in July. Stronger demand is helping the company raise prices and pass on rising costs for natural gas and scrap. The profit would be higher than the $3.72 a share forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Nucor's stock rose $6.13, or 7 percent, to $88.43 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIBBY, JOHN K.
description: LIBBY--John K. Age 78, died at home on September 6, 2004. Devoted husband of Mary and adoring father of K-K Libby, Aniik Libby Gustin and Virginia Libby Osborne. A private family memorial service to be held at Saint Anne's Episcopal Church, Bridgehampton, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations would be welcomed to Channel 13, WNET, Office of Development, 450 West 33 St., New York, New York 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, ERNEST
description: STEIN--Ernest. 4 Sept, died peacefully at home in NYC. b. Munich 13 Nov 1900, emigrated to NYC '21, married Doris Blumenthal '36. Businessman and amateur musician, this renaissance man loved his family, music, art, literature and gardening in the country; read and spoke French, German and English; practiced his piano every day until a month before death; and loved his daily walks. Musical studies started with his mother and included composition with Martinu at Tanglewood, early '40s. Compositions performed in U.S. and Europe. Poetry published in '89 and '90. Beginning at age 98, appeared annually for three years on "A Prairie Home Companion with Garrison Keillor" playing piano and reciting his poetry. With little remaining strength, some of his last words were "beautiful" when shown a bouquet of flowers, and "thank you" uttered often to care-givers and loved ones. From one of his poems "A Toast" The past is fairy tales. The future dreams. The music of the moment/Is the only Truth. Enjoy it to the fullest! Here is to life which, As the bubbles in this glass, Forever newly rises. Drink deep and often. More, much more to come! Ernest is survived by sons Bob, John and Andy; two daughters-in-law and four grandchildren.

title: G.O.P. Riled by 2 CNN Hosts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 - The Bush campaign has questioned CNN's allowing James Carville and Paul Begala to continue as commentators despite their role as informal advisers to the Kerry campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOURSI, PAUL J.
description: SCOURSI--Paul J. age 87, of Ozone Park, NY on August 26, 2004. Beloved husband of Beatrice for 62 years. Loving father of Christine Sanchez and Jean Scoursi. Devoted father - in - law of Ernest Sanchez. Also survived by his loving sister-in-law Marion Temme and cherished cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. Served in the U.S. Army in WWII in England, France, Germany and Okinawa. A graduate of John Adams High School, St. John's University (BBA) and New York University (MBA). Avid golfer, traveler and Yankee fan. Funeral mass was held at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church. Now resting at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Francis Hospital Chapel, Port Washington, NY on Saturday, September 25 at 5:15 P.M. His memory is a blessing that we will cherish.

title: Memories of Bartman Die Hard for Cubs Fans
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 8 - It was a birthday gift from his girlfriend and brother, a box-seat ticket to a Chicago Cubs game against Montreal at Wrigley Field. Caesar Palacios, who is 27, was surprised and delighted, being a lifelong Cubs fan. He had no idea, however -- none of them did -- that his $36 seat down the left-field line was that seat.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDS, BARBARA R.
description: SANDS--Barbara R. On September 9, 2004 in Albany, NY. Born in NYC, she was an Albany area resident the last 15 years. She received her Master's in Social Work from the State University of NY at Albany. She had been employed as a Prevention Social Worker for the Parson's Child and Family Center in Albany and retired due to illness. She leaves her parents, a brother, nephews and nieces and her daughter Rachel of Albany. A memorial service will be held at the Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Ave, Albany, NY on Friday, September 10, 2004 at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Ovarian Cancer Research.

But that decision, which came in an antitrust case brought by the Justice Department, appears to have done nothing to soften PeopleSoft's resolve to remain independent.

title: On Guard, America
description: As regressive milestones go, few are as frightful in this new era of homeland security as the decision by Congress and the Bush administration to allow the expiration of the 10-year-old law protecting the public from assault rifles and other rapid-fire battlefield weapons. The law -- a far from perfect but demonstrably effective restraint on high-tech gunslingers -- expires on Monday with not a whimper from the White House.

title: Playing Ancient Instruments After Much Talk About Them
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9 - It must have been a great relief for the Olympic athletes finally to take the fields and arenas in Athens last month and put all the talk of illegal drugs and potential terrorism behind. Similarly, when the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra opened its season here on Thursday evening at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, it must have welcomed the opportunity to seize the spotlight back from the cache of ancient and valuable string instruments it bought from the pet-care mogul and collector Herbert Axelrod last year, and from the shady circumstances surrounding the sale that have recently emerged.

description: Ralph G. Allen, a Guggenheim-winning theater historian who parlayed a scholarly paper on the pratfalls, bawdy humor and very bad puns of American burlesque into the book of the hit Broadway musical "Sugar Babies," died on Thursday after a walk in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan and Knoxville, Tenn.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BIERHOFF, FREDERIC A.
description: BIERHOFF--Frederic A., 78, of Pleasantville, NY and Leicester, VT, died peacefully on September 6, 2004. He was the best friend of his wife, Ruth, loving father of Alan and Alison, and cherished grandfather of Rebecca. Fred was a navy veteran of World War II. His parents Alan and Janet and his brother Richard predeceased him. He was a graduate of Ethical Culture Fieldston School, attended MIT and was a graduate of New England College as a civil engineer. Frederic was a man of humor and generosity with the gift of making people from all walks of life feel happy in his presence. A memorial service will take place on September 19 at 2PM at the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Woods Road, White Plains, NY. All friends and relatives are invited to attend. As an expression of sympathy, contributions can be made in his name to his favorite organization: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 434 West 33rd Street, NY, NY 10001

title: Today's Top Games
description: No. 8 Michigan (1-0) at Notre Dame (0-1) 2:30 p.m., NBC Last week, the Irish came up with only 11 yards on the ground during a 20-17 loss to Brigham Young. This week, Notre Dame is hoping that running back Ryan Grant, who sat out last week, will play. Michigan will start the freshman quarterback Chad Henne for the injured Matt Gutierrez. The Irish are 5-10 in their last 15 games and are big underdogs at home against Michigan. It could be another long season in South Bend.

title: 'Holy Warriors' in Samarra Reject Accord With Americans
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 10 - A group claiming to speak for insurgents in the contested city of Samarra said Friday that it had rejected an agreement that allowed American forces and the Iraqi government to re-enter the city, and the group pledged to continue fighting.

title: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS BUYS 1.9% OF GOOGLE SHARES
description: Fidelity Investments, the world's largest mutual fund manager, has bought about $549 million in Google stock, about 1.9 percent of all shares of the Internet search engine. Fidelity, based in Boston, reported in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it held 5.21 million Class A shares of Google, or 16 percent of that class. The Fidelity Growth Company Fund owns 1.83 million of the shares, the filing said. They were worth about $192.8 million at today's close. Google, the world's most-used Internet search service, and some of its early investors raised $1.67 billion in an initial public offering on Aug. 18. Stock in Google, based in Mountain View, Calif. rose $3.02, to $105.33 a share. (Bloomberg News)

title: After 63 Years, a Synagogue Gets a Rabbi
description: MONTPELIER, Vt. - The Shabbat service on a muggy Friday night at Temple Beth Jacob here was like so many before it. The faithful clutched prayer books as sundown approached, singing prayers in Hebrew and listening to a leader read from Deuteronomy.

title: The Novel's Latest Version Pops Onto China's Cellphones
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 10 - As a critically acclaimed writer of dense, doorstop-size novels, Qian Fuzhang said he had finally developed a guilty conscience.

title: Zimbabwe Sentences Briton to 7 Years in Jail on Arms Charge
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 10 - Simon Mann, the British soldier of fortune accused of masterminding a botched coup attempt in March against Equatorial Guinea's ruler, was sentenced Friday to seven years in prison for illegally trying to buy weapons in Zimbabwe.

title: Primary in Nassau Is Casting Long Shadow
description: Officially, the names on the ballot in Tuesday's Democratic primary for State Assembly on Nassau's North Shore are Charles D. Lavine and David S. Sidikman. But they are only proxies in a bigger battle between two much better-known Democrats, County Ex'ecutive Thomas R. Suozzi and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

Editors' Note
description: An article from Washington yesterday described a new video recording by Osama bin Laden's top deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri, taunting the United States for becoming mired in what he called unsuccessful military campaigns in Afghanistan and Iraq. The article quoted Mr. Zawahiri as saying on the tape, "Bush, reinforce your security measures" and "The Islamic nation which sent you the New York and Washington brigades has taken the firm decision to send you successive brigades to sow death and aspire to paradise." The headline, based on those statements, said, "In Tape, Top Aide to Bin Laden Vows New Strikes at U.S."

title: Devils' Stevens Plans to Return
description: If there is a National Hockey League season, Scott Stevens, the Devils' captain, plans to play in every game. Stevens, 40, who missed the rest of the season after sustaining a concussion on Jan. 7, said yesterday that he had skated the last three days and had no postconcussion symptoms. "I'm just going to pace myself and ease into it," he told reporters after a workout yesterday morning. Stevens, a defenseman, has led the Devils to three Stanley Cups in his 13 seasons with the team. Training camp is scheduled to start next week. Dave Caldwell

But nowhere has that been more pronounced than in the Bronx, where several members of the City Council and the legislature have followed their parents' footsteps into politics.

title: Old Fans Still Bubble Along to Lawrence Welk
description: BRANSON, Mo. - Lawrence Welk disappeared from commercial television 20 years ago, but Alice Hutchinson, 84, will watch a rerun of his show on Saturday night, as she does every week. She will tape it and make copies for friends. She will chat about it for hours online.

title: The Public Knowledge of 9/11
description: In the three years since 9/11, we've begun to understand that it's possible to know what happened without knowing what happened. It's the difference between knowledge that is both private and communal -- our memories of where we were, what we saw, what we lost -- and knowledge that is truly public. Some of what we need to know publicly has been provided by the report of the 9/11 commission. Other answers are lacking.

title: An Intellectual Journal Finds Another Editor
description: Six months after the abrupt dismissal of its editor, The American Scholar, one of the nation's leading literary and intellectual journals, has found a successor.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: India's industrial output grew at a rate of 7.9 percent in July, helped by robust domestic demand. According to data released by the government, manufacturing grew 7.6 percent in July and consumer durables grew 15.1 percent. Industry accounts for about a fourth of India's gross domestic product. But analysts said economic growth this year might decline from last year's rate of 8.2 percent because global oil prices are high and because rainfall has been late, hurting the rural farm economy. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Gunman Kills Two Detectives in Brooklyn
description: A police stop in Brooklyn last night turned into a bloody shootout that left two detectives dead and a gunman wounded. The gunman hijacked a minivan but was swiftly tracked down by police dogs to a nearby building and arrested, the police said.

title: DEAN FOODS PLANS TO STOP MAKING WEIGHT-LOSS DRINKS
description: The Dean Foods Company, the dairy products producer, said yesterday that it would stop making weight-loss shakes and drinks because of poor sales. Dean Foods, which makes the Healthy Shake Weight Loss Beverage and the Bonus Nutritional Supplement, will close its nutritional-drinks plant in Michigan in the fourth quarter, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Customers were told that production of nutritional drinks will cease by Nov. 7, according to the filing. Cory Olson, a spokesman for the company, which is based in Dallas, declined to say specifically where the Michigan plant is located or how many workers at the plant would be affected by the shutdown.
