Viceroy of the Jungle. King of Par. In the halls of Congress, there are even those who call him "the Kurtz of the Amazon," in a reference to Joseph Conrad's novella, "Heart of Darkness."

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: New Data Shows Growth
description: Industrial production in China grew slightly faster than expected last month, the National Bureau of Statistics said, in the latest sign that administrative measures to slow economic growth and forestall inflation may be easing. For five months ending in July, year-over-year growth in Chinese industrial output gradually slowed down as policy makers in Beijing hit the brakes by restricting bank loans and limiting land-use and environmental impact approvals. But that trend ended in August, when production was up 15.9 percent compared with the same month last year. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Draws Criticism From Kerry on Assault-Weapons Ban
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 10 - Senator John Kerry said on Friday that the refusal of Republican Congressional leaders to consider extending the assault-weapons ban showed that the president and his party were not serious about fighting terrorism.

title: INSIDE
description: Hurricane Hits Jamaica, With Florida in Its Path Hurricane Ivan began to lash Jamaica with wind and rain as electricity was turned off and the government declared a state of emergency. In Florida, officials stepped up efforts to evacuate the Keys, and weary residents, like a sandbag crew in Tampa, braced for the third storm in four weeks. PAGE A9

title: Balance and Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: CRICKET : Pressure for young Zimbabwean bowler
Stars and Stripes Are Gone, but There Is Plenty to Salute
description: JENNIFER CAPRIATI had already dispatched Serena Williams, with a little help from the flawed human eye. Justine Henin-Hardenne was long gone, leaving a vacuum at the top of the draw. By the time Capriati took the court late yesterday afternoon, the hottest player on the hard courts this summer, Lindsay Davenport, had limped out of the United States Open, possibly for good.

title: Tips for improving your batting average
Corrections
In His Return to Coaching Ranks, Ross Stakes Out Higher Ground at Army
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 8 - Down a steep hill from the Army football stadium, inside the West Point Cemetery perched above the Hudson River, there is a large headstone shaped like a football.

title: San Diego's Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Reign of Terror
description: On my last visit to the Darfur area in Sudan, in June, I found a man groaning under a tree. He had been shot in the neck and jaw and left for dead in a pile of corpses. Seeking shelter under the very next tree were a pair of widows whose husbands had both been shot to death. Under the next tree I found a 4-year-old orphan girl caring for her starving 1-year-old brother. And under the tree next to that was a woman whose husband had been killed, along with her 7-and 4-year-old sons, before she was gang-raped and mutilated.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Family Of Drowned Park Patrons Sues City
description: Relatives of four Chicago residents who drowned on June 16 at the Fort Worth Water Gardens sued the city and a number of individuals and organizations. The victims died when three of them tried to rescue the fourth, a child who had slipped into an ornamental pool swollen by heavy rains to more than double its usual depth of three and a half feet. The lawsuit requested at least $1 million for each of 72 allegations. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: From Dying Movies, the Birth of a Score
description: The composer Michael Gordon has written several works meant partly to reconfigure the way audiences listen to symphonic music. Mostly, these experiments have been staged in Europe, although Mr. Gordon lives in New York. But on Thursday evening at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn, Mr. Gordon presented the American concert premiere of perhaps the most ambitious of these scores, "Decasia." A multimedia collaboration with the filmmaker Bill Morrison that had its premiere in Basel, Switzerland, in 2001 and that has been available to Americans as a film and on DVD, "Decasia" will play at St. Ann's (38 Water Street) through tomorrow.

title: Quirks, nomads and redemption : Venice warms up a bit
Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVIN, NEIL
description: LEVIN--Neil. In honored memory of our beloved Neil and the men and women who perished with him on September 11, 2001. Neil's family

title: 1954:Big 3 Answer Soviets : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
A Welcome Russian Inquiry
description: Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, is hardly known for his tolerance of second-guessing, so it is remarkable that he invited the upper house of Russia's Parliament yesterday to hold an open inquiry into last week's seizure of hostages at the Beslan middle school and the massacre that followed. The upper house, like the rest of Parliament, is packed with Putin loyalists. But Russia would best be served if it showed enough independence to produce the "complete, objective picture" Mr. Putin claimed that he wanted.

title: Observances at Ground Zero Today
description: 7 A.M. -- Public starts arriving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FENER, SARAH
description: FENER -- Sarah. Beloved mother of George and David. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday 11:30AM Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue (near East 10th Street), NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MATTHEWS, JUDITH
description: MATTHEWS -- Judith. Mat thew Jacob Haas has arrived. Happy Birthday, Grandma Judy. Love always, Steve, Howard, Sandy, Dave, Juliette and Matthew.

title: Bush and Kerry Step Up Attacks in Swing States
description: CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, Sept. 10 - As President Bush on Friday leveled one of his strongest attacks on Senator John Kerry's position on Iraq, Kerry advisers said they had agreed on the need to ratchet up their campaign by challenging the president's trustworthiness and leadership skills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARONSTEIN, JACQUELINE BLUESTONE
description: ARONSTEIN -- Jacqueline Bluestone, of Port Washington, NY, died on September 9, ten days after her 69th birthday, at her son's home in Northampton, MA. She is survived by her husband of 41 years, Richard, her sons Steven and Jonathan, and beloved grandson Noah. She was a psychologist in the NYC Schools for twenty years and in private practice for thirty. She touched her many devoted friends with her boundless enthusiasm and energy. In her yearlong courageous battle with illness, everyone around her was constantly moved by her inexhaustible strength and optimism. Funeral Sunday, September 12, at 1PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jonathan Scharer, 56, Producer of 'Forbidden Broadway' Spoof, Dies
description: Jonathan Mark Scharer, the original producer of the perennial Off Broadway spoof revue, "Forbidden Broadway," died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUGHES, CAMM, JEAN FRANCES
description: HUGHES-CAMM--Jean Frances, 34, died September 8, 2004, after a courageous battle with Hodgkins disease, at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas. Jean grew up in the Bronx, attended Monsignor Scanlan High School and the State University at Albany, where she graduated in 1991. Jean married David Camm in 1992 and moved to Florida where she lived close to her father, Martin Hughes. Jean is surivived by her husband, David Camm, her daughter Caitlin, 3, her father Martin Hughes and his wife Marjorie, her mother Phyllis Hughes, her loving brother Thomas Huges of Brooklyn and many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. Services will be held at Stower's Funeral Home, 401 West Brandon Boulevard, Brandon, FL. 813-689-1211, on Sunday, September 12, 2004, 4pm to 8pm. A mass will be celebrated on Monday, September 13, 10am, at St. Stephen Church, 5049 Bell Shoals Road, Valrico, FL.

title: Population explosion : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Health Effects of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: As Deadline Crept Closer, a Rush to Sue Over Sept. 11
description: A deadline yesterday for lawsuits related to the Sept. 11 attacks prompted a rush to the New York federal courthouse where all such suits have been filed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BEERMAN, JOAN R.
description: BEERMAN--Joan R. 4/6/479/11/03. Dearest friend, you are always in my thoughts. We all miss you.

title: Floridians Are Left Weary by Threat of Another Hurricane
description: FORT MEADE, Fla., Sept. 10 - Battered by Hurricane Charley, deluged by Hurricane Frances and with yet another huge hurricane, named Ivan, approaching from the south, residents of this town of 6,000 are getting pretty weary of multiple climatic assaults.

title: How to Remember, How to Forget
description: Madrid - Our perception of time is all too variable, and there are many factors that can strangely affect it, breaking the thread of continuity. When a love affair ends for example, -- when you've abandoned all hope and freed yourself from the spider web you were tangled in -- everything that belonged to the time of that love suddenly becomes "the past," and things that happened only a year ago when you were with the person who left you, or whom you left, now seem distant and incongruously remote.

title: Court Rules Against Pennsylvania Law That Curbs Child-Pornography Sites
description: A federal court struck down a Pennsylvania law yesterday, ruling that the state could no longer force Internet service providers to block customers' access to Web sites thought to be distributing child pornography.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Forecast Revised
description: The government on Friday revised second-quarter economic growth to an annual 1.3 percent, from a tepid 1.7 percent. The pace of growth was the lowest in more than a year and much slower than forecast by economists, who expected the number to be revised upward after what was seen as a surprisingly low initial estimate last month. Japan's economy grew at a much faster pace of 6.4 percent in the first quarter, after a 7.4 percent rise in the last quarter of 2003. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: America's Arty History Teacher
description: TELLURIDE, Colo., Sept. 4 - Long ago, the woman said, she had encountered the prizefighter Jack Johnson. Or maybe her father had. In any case, she was crying. Something in the latest documentary by Ken Burns, "Unforgivable Blackness: The Rise and Fall of Jack Johnson," brought back memories that she wanted to discuss with Mr. Burns, who was greeting fans Sept. 4 outside the Galaxy, a school gym that is converted into a vanguard movie theater once a year for the Telluride Film Festival.

title: 2 Tribune Papers Revise Circulation Again
description: The Tribune Company said yesterday that two of its newspapers, Newsday and the Spanish-language daily Hoy, had overstated their average circulation figures by even more than the company initially disclosed in early June, when it released the results of a preliminary investigation into the papers' circulation practices. In the case of Newsday, the overstatement was as much as 122,000 copies.

title: For Honest Reports of Drug Trials
description: A vast majority of patients and doctors would surely agree that pharmaceutical companies ought to reveal the results of clinical trials that suggest that their drugs don't work or may even be harmful. Yet all too often such results are either suppressed or are buried in obscure locations, and only glowing reports are widely disseminated. This week a coalition of leading medical journals announced a publication policy that should help rectify the problem but is hardly a full solution. The industry's trade group, meanwhile, offered a weak plan to quell the controversy without requiring much reform.

title: City Faces Hearing on Paying a Protester Fine
description: The city avoided further legal trouble yesterday by producing a list of the roughly 600 people detained during the Republican National Convention who were released on the orders of a State Supreme Court judge in the hours after he held the city in contempt.

title: Mysteries of the Kingdom of Kush
The Collections / NEW YORK : Young designers vie for survival on retail floor
Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 28 about John E. O'Neill, co-author of a book that contends Senator John Kerry lied about his Vietnam service, referred incorrectly to the illness of Mr. O'Neill's wife, to whom he donated a kidney. The disease, Wegener's granulomatosis, is a rare condition that damages organs by an inflammation of the blood vessels -- not a form of lupus, an autoimmune disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAMSEY, PETER C.
description: RAMSEY--Peter C., on September 10th, 2004 after a courageous and dignified battle with lung cancer. Best friend, devoted and loving husband of Maryalice. Loving son of Rosalie C. Ramsey. Devoted brother of Christie C. Ramsey. He was a generous, caring and compassionate gentleman who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, September 12th, 6-9 PM, and Monday 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, September 14th, 10 AM, at St. John the Martyr Church, E. 72nd St. between 2nd and 3rd Aves. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Loomis Chaffee School, Windsor, CT 06095 or your favorite charity.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Slows
description: Inflation slowed in August after hitting a 15-month high in July, helped by a drop in utility rates and gasoline prices. The government said its consumer price index, the central bank's main gauge in setting interest rates, rose 0.69 percent last month, slightly more than what most economists had expected but down sharply from a 0.91 percent increase in July. The reading brought the accumulated inflation rate this year to 5.14 percent, just short of the government's year-end target of 5.5 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: What Russia Knows Now
description: MOSCOW - The blow struck by Islamic terrorism at the twin towers in New York three years ago came as a complete surprise to Russia. We had not suspected that the new century would begin with such a bloody dawn. Our people spent that day frozen in horror in front of their television sets: What kind of enemy was this, capable of bringing to life the most monstrous fantasies of Hollywood? I was outside the American Embassy in Moscow late on the evening of Sept. 11, 2001. The pavement was littered with flowers and lighted candles. I think that never have Russians been brought so close to America by such profound and heartfelt compassion.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Suspected Rebels Hurl Bombs At U.S. Center
description: Suspected Maoist rebels in Katmandu, the capital, hurled three small bombs into the compound of the American Center, an information and cultural center operated by the American Embassy, the police said. No one was injured in the explosions, which came after the center had closed for the day, but they caused minor damage. It was the first direct attack on an American government building in the eight-year Maoist insurgency. The bombing came amid increasing attacks by the Maoists, who successfully blockaded the capital for several days last month. Dhruba Adhikary (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in Circuits on Thursday about the Kanguru Slim FC-RW, a port-able multimedia player, misstated the manufacturer's Web address. It is www.kanguru.com, not kangaru.com.

title: The Race Within the Race Nears End
description: RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 10 - September used to bring the yawning stretch drive of Nascar's interminable 36-race schedule, the time of year when almost all of the drivers and much of the drama had already been eliminated from the season-long chase for the points title.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: CBS Defends Its Report on Bush Military Record
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSMITH, FRANK M.
description: GOLDSMITH--Frank M., age 83, died September 9, 2004 in Stamford, CT after a long illness. Husband of Liz, father of Judy (Charles) Naden, Tony (Leslie) and Donald, grandfather of Laura, David, Lee and Jamie. Memorial service is at Edgehill Lifecare Community, 122 Palmers Hill Rd., Stamford, CT, on Sunday, September 12, 3 PM. Memorial donations to White Plains Hospital Center or Westchester Historical Society.

title: Bishop Says Conflict on Gays Distracts From Vital Issues
description: Bishop V. Gene Robinson, whose ordination as the first openly gay Episcopal bishop opened a rift in the international Anglican Communion, said at a forum on Thursday night that the conflict over homosexuality in his church and in the presidential campaign had become a distraction from more vital issues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   TRAVERS, WALLY
description: TRAVERS--Wally. 1957-2001. Wally, you are so incredibly special to our family. We are blessed to have had you and all the wonderful memories that you left. How our hearts ache for more. You are loved and missed every day. Love your niece, Patt

title: Beads, Shells and Prints From Far-Flung Places
description: After 9/11, fashion responded to the grimly reconstructed world order with clothes that bespoke the seriousness of a new era. Dark palettes and minimalist thinking prevailed; sex suddenly seemed outmoded. Designers rightly read the cultural mood and realized that no one wanted to go out looking like a petit four or Ciccolina. The passage of time ensured a correction. Recent fashion seasons have produced colors as varied as those on a Candyland board. Fur, velvet and jeweling seemed as ubiquitous as muslin.

title: In Verona, Italian Player Wins Individual Contest
description: The sixth Generali World Individual Championship ended yesterday in a victory for Norberto Bocchi of Italy. Second was Andrew Robson of England, and third was Jens Auken of Denmark. Fifty-two players from 26 countries on six continents battled for three days in Verona, Italy, each playing two deals with each of the others.

title: C.I.A. Cites Order on Supervised Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - A classified directive issued in August 2003 by the Central Intelligence Agency specifically prohibited the agency's employees from conducting the kinds of unsupervised interrogations of Iraqi detainees that military investigators say occurred on a widespread basis at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, senior intelligence officials said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SIMON, MICHAEL JOHN
description: SIMON--Michael John 7/27/61--9/11/01 Those two planes did it all/ How they made those giants fall/Soon I'm filled with pain and sorrow/At the same time I feel hollow/As of long dark days past filled with fear/ Thinking about those terrorists, are they near?/Simply I close my eyes...saying everything will be all right/ Thinking a lot about my dad/ About the man I once had. Michael John Simon, Jr.

title: Qwest Said to Settle S.E.C. Investigation
description: Qwest Communications, the Midwest regional telecommunications giant, has agreed to pay $250 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into its accounting practices, the company's union said yesterday.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Down by 10, Miami Rallies to Prevail on Overtime Run
description: MIAMI, Sept. 10 - After losing five consecutive games to the University of Miami, Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden liked his team's chances in Friday night's season opener for both teams. Bowden said the law of averages favored the Seminoles.

title: Scientists Think Data From Space Capsule Can Be Salvaged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - Samples and data inside the wrecked Genesis space capsule appear intact enough to salvage most of the mission's science, optimistic researchers said Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about self-criticism and introspection in the Muslim and Arab world after the school siege in southern Russia, which left more than 300 people dead, omitted credit for the translation of five newspaper commentaries. They were provided by the Middle East Media Research Institute in Washington. (Go to Article)

title: Patriotism and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Russian Summit in the Final
description: When Elena Dementieva scorched a backhand winner down the line, Jennifer Capriati dropped her head in failed retreat for a final time.

title: F.D.A. PANEL VOTES AGAINST BACKING DRUG BY ASTRAZENECA
description: AstraZeneca failed to win backing from a federal government panel for its Exanta blood thinner, a possible first alternative to the drug Coumadin in more than 50 years. A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel voted to tell the agency that Exanta's potential risk to hearts and livers outweighs the benefits for patients who have had knee-replacement surgery and for preventing new blood clots in people already being treated for one. The F.D.A. often adopts the recommendations of its panels. F.D.A. staff doctors released a report on Thursday questioning the drug's safety and effectiveness. AstraZeneca is based in London.

title: Don't Reward Acts of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney Offers Explanation of Comment About Kerry
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 - In an interview published Friday, Vice President Dick Cheney said he wanted to "clean up" the impression he left at a campaign forum on Tuesday when he said that the United States could "get hit again" if voters made the wrong choice in November.

title: U.S. Expects More Violence as Iraq Vote Draws Near
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Friday that violence would intensify in Iraq as elections scheduled there for January approach and insurgents try to derail the country's nascent political process. But he and President Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said the United States was determined to ensure that voting takes place as planned.

title: Woodward Favorite Is on the Fast Track
description: To the legions of handicappers who like to reduce a horse's performance to a single number, a speed figure, there is no question about the identity of the fastest horse in the country.

title: For Eisner, a Sharp Turn on a Trip Through Disney
description: Michael D. Eisner is planning to go away, and investors are happy.

title: ENRON TO SELL NATURAL GAS PIPELINES TO JOINT VENTURE
description: The Enron Corporation, which owes creditors more than $74 billion, won court approval for a $2.45 billion sale of its natural gas pipelines in the United States to a joint venture of the Southern Union Company and the General Electric Company. Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the sale in a hearing yesterday in New York. The venture, CCE Holdings, was the highest bidder in last week's auction of the pipeline unit, Enron's largest remaining asset. The deal is part of the company's plan to exit bankruptcy by raising about $12 billion, mainly from asset sales. Enron, based in Houston, has two major businesses -- Portland General electricity utility and power plants and pipelines outside of North America. Once all the units are sold, Enron will cease to exist.

title: Indonesian Police Say Van in Attack Carried 2 or 3 Bombers
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10 - The Indonesian police said Friday that they believed that at least two, and possibly three, suicide bombers were in a van that exploded outside the Australian Embassy here on Thursday, killing nine Indonesians and wounding more than 180 people.

title: Heavy Metal Thunder, and a Ringing in the Ears
description: GREENPORT, N.Y. - Bob Laub sat at a table at the Harbourfront Deli here, railing against stereotype.

title: Vazquez Bewildered by Another Early Exit
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 - Javier Vazquez shuffled toward the exit of the visiting clubhouse, alone with his thoughts after a mystifying performance in the Yankees' 14-8 loss to the Baltimore Orioles. Was that really Vazquez who ended his night with a walk, a hit batsman and another walk, all with the bases loaded? It was a question he could not answer.

title: Call in Albany to Abolish One House of Legislature
description: ALBANY, Sept. 10 - A small group of Democratic state lawmakers called Friday for amending the State Constitution to eliminate one house of the State Legislature, abolish the state's public authorities, overhaul a budget process that has produced 20 late budgets in a row and put an end to the gerrymandering of legislative districts.

title: Sept. 11, Yet Nothing Stops the Tides
description: NEW YORK has its ends of the earth, odd little places so psychically removed from the rest of the city that they barely heed the urban scat. Places like City Island, that Bronx curio of a community lingering like an afterthought in the chop and sway of the Long Island Sound.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHONBERG, GEORGE
description: SCHONBERG--George. Gone nine years. So absent-so present. Love always, Doris

title: Bush's Backers Donate Heavily to Veteran Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, an advocacy group that jolted the presidential race with commercials questioning Senator John Kerry's military service, said it had raised $6.7 million in a windfall brought about by the group's high profile in recent weeks.

title: Why Chile Is Hopeful
description: Durham, N.C. - As a Chilean, I can only imagine that when Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who led a bloody coup against Chile's elected government on Sept. 11, 1973, watched the death and destruction that were visited on the United States by terrorists exactly 28 years later, he must have felt a grim sort of satisfaction, perhaps a perverse tremor of absolution. He had been chastised by the world and accused of crimes against humanity, but maybe now people would understand that his violations of human rights were a small price to pay for security, finally realize that democracy is a luxury we cannot afford in times of war, and agree that it is absolutely necessary to strike your enemies preemptively.

title: The Collections / NEW YORK : As America's mood shifts, downtown style is over
Sudan Government's Attacks Stoke Rebels' Fury
description: FARAWIYA, Sudan - Three skinny urchins, covered in sand from head to toe, arrived here at a base camp of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army the other day. They said they had run away from home -- a tent in a refugee camp across the border in Chad -- and walked three days across the desert, one bottle of water between them and no food. They said their villages had been destroyed. They were 11 to 13 years old. They now had one ambition: to join the rebels.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Watch column on Sept. 3, about coverage of the Republican National Convention by Fox News, misspelled the name of the playwright and diplomat whose bristly manner was likened to that of some Fox anchors. She was Clare Boothe Luce, not Claire Booth Luce.

title: 1904:"Herald" Under Attack : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 1 about a mixed report on the state of women's health around the world misidentified the issuer. The report was produced by three nongovernmental organizations -- Population Action International, Family Care International and the International Planned Parenthood Federation -- not by the United Nations Population Fund.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: Delta Fails to Gain Bondholders' Support for Debt Reduction Plan
description: Delta Air Lines, which is struggling to avoid a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, said yesterday that it was unable to persuade enough bondholders to change the terms of their securities, a move that could have helped the carrier clean up its balance sheet.

title: Globalist : Beneath Iraq statistics, grief invades U.S. homes
Notre Dame Loses Footing Upon a Shifting Landscape
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 10 - A plaque commemorating Notre Dame's 1946 national championship football team caught lineman Bobby Morton's eye earlier this week at the university's football facility. Notre Dame went 8-0-1 that year under Frank Leahy, and Morton marveled that the Irish gave up only 24 points all season. "Twenty-four points in one season? That's ridiculous," Morton said, pointing to the standards of dominance that Notre Dame had set.

title: State's Ethics Chief Is Fired; He Plans Appeal
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 10 - The executive director of the State Ethics Commission was fired on Friday, after a hearing in which he vehemently denied accusations that he had ordered a staff member to lie in response to a federal subpoena or had broken other office rules.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EASTMAN KODAK CO., Rochester, the world's largest photography company, will close 5 of 11 overnight photo-finishing labs in France by the end of the year, affecting 219 workers.

title: Prime minister of Luxembourg is cast as first 'Mr. Euro'
Paper chase / How to ferret out financial information : Quick and dirty, maybe, but due diligence pays
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ruling Class War
description: There are two sorts of people in the information-age elite, spreadsheet people and paragraph people. Spreadsheet people work with numbers, wear loafers and support Republicans. Paragraph people work with prose, don't shine their shoes as often as they should and back Democrats.

title: 1929:A Millionaire's Haircut : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Rape of Rutgers Student Reminds a Campus of Earlier Attacks
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 10 - A Rutgers University graduate student was raped Wednesday at an apartment complex within a few hundred yards of campus.

title: Don't Reward Acts of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Says He's Ready for Opener
description: Giants cornerback Will Allen, sidelined since the second quarter of the Aug. 27 exhibition game against the Jets with a sprained left knee, declared yesterday that he would be ready to go in the opener tomorrow at the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Parents Suffer the Stress of the Mayor's Test Plan
description: When Dionne Stewart-Monsanto learned that her daughter Busisiwe, 8, a third grader, had excelled at her citywide tests last spring, she was proud. But the more overwhelming emotion, she said, was the relief that came weeks earlier, when the tests were over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINMAN, GEORGE
description: FEINMAN--George, on September 9th, 2004 in Delray Beach, FL. Longtime resident of Queens. Sylvia's beloved husband for 56 years. Loving father of Marsha Byrnes and Sandie Antar. Devoted Pop Pop of Steven, Jeremy, Daniel, Mark and Rebecca. Funeral service Sunday, 9:30 AM, at RiversideNassau North, Great Neck.

description: To the Editor:

title: Finland Comes Alive With Two Late Goals
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 10 - Before Friday night's semifinal in the World Cup of Hockey, Coach Raimo Summanen of Finland and Coach Ron Wilson of the United States discussed different opponents.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,003 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: A justified and dangerous fury in Russia
Clinton Leaves the Hospital 4 Days After Heart Surgery
description: Former President Bill Clinton went home from a Manhattan hospital yesterday, four days after undergoing a quadruple bypass operation, his office said.

title: Corrections
Two Groups Awarded World Arts Prizes
description: Prizes of $100,000 were awarded by the World Culture Open at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night to a Venezuelan who works with his country's National Symphony Youth Orchestra and to a group from Brazil that tries to end the "marginalization" of parts of the population there.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about a rally of Roman Catholics at the Republican National Convention in New York misidentified a bishop from Corpus Christi, Tex., who urged Catholics to vote only for candidates who oppose abortion rights. He was Bishop Emeritus Rene H. Gracida, not Bishop Edmond Carmody.

title: Mitsubishi Tokyo Provides $6.4 Billion to UFJ
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 - The Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, Japan's second-largest bank, agreed on Friday to provide 700 billion yen ($6.4 billion) of emergency financing to UFJ Holdings in a transaction intended to block a rival bid for the ailing Japanese bank.

title: Dear Old Golden Rule Days, Full of Strife and Striving
description: Something in the friendship between conformists and romantics appeals to fiction writers. Think of Tom and Huck, Nick and Gatsby, Tom Ripley and Dickie Greenleaf. The nervous, watchful character is a convenient double for the writer, or the reader.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SVIRIDOFF, DORIS
description: SVIRIDOFF--Doris. 85, beloved wife of the late Mitchell Sviridoff, died peacefully on September 8, 2004. In recent years, she divided her time among New York City, Martha's Vineyard and Los Angeles. She is survived by her daughters Karen Segal of Los Angeles and Michele Sviridoff of New York City, her grandson Christopher Nichelson and her great grandchildren Kiyoshi and Sanae.

title: Sounds of a Silent Place
description: Correction Appended

title: Stadium Ally on Council Got Donations From the Jets
description: As chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, David I. Weprin has emerged as a valuable teammate for the New York Jets, twice holding City Hall news conferences to release reports supporting the proposal for a new stadium on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Few Enroll in Low-Cost Drug Demonstration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - A new program to provide low-cost drugs to people with cancer and other serious illnesses has fallen far short of expectations, as just a small number of eligible patients have applied for the benefits, officials said Friday.

title: Jack Rohan, Former Coach of Columbia Basketball, Dies at 72
description: Jack Rohan, who in two stretches covering 18 seasons became Columbia University's most successful men's basketball coach, died Aug. 9 in a nursing home in South Yarmouth, Mass. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EMMANUEL, HANNA MATHILDE
description: EMMANUEL--Hanna Mathilde. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Peter Neustadter, Parnas

title: U.S. Weighs Import Limits on China
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 10 - Brushing aside Chinese warnings of a possible challenge to the World Trade Organization, a senior American trade official said Friday that the United States would limit apparel imports if American manufacturers provided evidence that such restrictions were needed.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: State Official Impeached
description: Carroll Fisher, the state insurance commissioner, was impeached by the state's House of Representatives and accused of corruption, incompetence and neglect of duty. The Senate will decide on Tuesday when to hear the case. After the impeachment, Mr. Fisher, 64, declined to resign. He is accused of accepting art and furnishings from an organization representing the insurance industry and of depositing a $1,000 contribution to his campaign into his personal account. Mr. Fisher is awaiting trial in a state court on several felony charges, including embezzlement. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: BELDEN WILL CUT 562 WORKERS IN THE U.S. AND EUROPE
description: Belden CDT, which makes electronics and communications cables, will lay off as many as 562 employees, about 9.4 percent of its work force, as it closes plants in the United States and Europe. The company, which is based in St. Louis, will close its Montrose cable plant in Auburn, Mass., that employs about 100 people. Belden said it would also shutter a plant in Skelmersdale, England, that makes cables for data networking under the name Raydex and employs about 220 people. The plant closings are part of Belden's plan to save $25 million a year after its merger in July with the Cable Design Technologies Corporation and rid itself of unprofitable lines, said Dee Johnson, Belden's director of investor relations.

title: Japan pares forecast amid signs of slowdown
Budget Cuts Leave Gaps in Yonkers Schools
description: YONKERS, Sept. 10 - The first week of the term in the beleaguered Yonkers public school system was marked by scheduling mix-ups and widespread uncertainty, parents and students said on Friday, as administrators rushed to fill holes left by sweeping budget cuts.

title: The advantage is mutual : Free and fair trade in the Americas
Most in Poll See Convention as a Negative
description: A majority of New Yorkers who responded to a recent poll said they did not think it was a good idea for New York City to play host to the Republican National Convention last week.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Executive Penalized
description: The chief executive of Kookmin Bank, who declined to assist in recent government-led rescues of ailing companies, is being forced out by regulators on charges of accounting violations. The executive, Kim Jung-tae, left, will be barred by the Financial Supervisory Service from working in finance for three years after he steps down in October. He was accused of breaching accounting standards to evade taxes while merging Kookmin's credit card unit with the bank last September. Mr. Kim said that the accounting procedures were "in accordance with our corporate value and the interests of shareholders." The bank said its board would decide on a response on Monday. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: Fallen in War: Faces of a Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: Unblame the Victim: Heart Disease Causes Vary
description: Apparently, it is not enough that former President Bill Clinton has had his chest sliced open, his breast bone sawed through and his heart stopped cold and replumbed. He must also suffer the finger wagging and I-told-you-so's of those who say he caused his heart disease by indulging in cheeseburgers, cigars and too much work.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Roads To Switch To Metric System
description: After forcing a generation of drivers to grapple with speed limits marked as miles per hour and distances marked in kilometers, Ireland will convert all its road signs and speed limits to the metric system, the transportation minister, Seamus Brennan, said. The current system "is very confusing," he said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: The Waitress Isn't Kidding When She Tells You to Leave a Tip
description: When stopping in for a meal at Soprano's Italian and American Grill in Lake George, N.Y., leave a good tip.

title: Rituals of Grief
description: Hundreds drew close to the sites of the worst terrorist attack in United States history on Saturday to remember and mourn those lost three years earlier, on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Making Cars Safer for Pedestrians
description: IT is a dark, moonless night, and the jogger on the road is wearing dark clothing. You do not see him, but your car does.

title: Christina Schwartz, Holt Price
description: Christina Marianne Schwartz and William Holt Price were married yesterday at the Nauticus Marina in Osterville, Mass. David Harrison, a retired judge of Gloucester District Court in Massachusetts, officiated.

title: Going to Extremes
description: Traub writes that John Kerry is "so agonizingly uncomfortable with categorical language that he starts equivocating in the middle of an otherwise declarative sentence" and refers to Kerry's "nuancifications." This sure sounds like a fancy way of saying that Kerry is a flip-flopper!

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHARER, JONATHAN M.
description: SCHARER--Jonathan M. The Board of Directors and staff of The American Foundation for AIDS Research (amfAR) mourn the loss of our cherished friend and long-time supporter, Jonathan Scharer. We salute Jonathan's steadfast commitment to the fight against AIDS and extend heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman and Chairman of the Board Jerome J. Radwin, CEO American Foundation for AIDS Research

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREBIN, MARY
description: GREBIN--Mary. On September 10, 2004, of Leonia, N.J., formerly of North Bellmore, L.I. Beloved mother of Burton Grebin, M.D. and Rochelle Steiger. Dear sister of Goldie Michaels. Cherished grandmother of Jason, Perry, Scott and Karyn. Adored great grandmother of Lucy and Zoe. Services Monday, 11AM, "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Colombia's 3 Million Refugees, Hidden in Plain Sight
description: SOACHA, Colombia - IN a slum of several thousand people called La Isla, residents have put up everything from drugstores to laundry marts, evangelical churches to beauty salons. Battered buses ferry young women who work as maids in the nearby capital, Bogot. Youngsters with neatly combed hair and pressed uniforms scamper off to school.

title: MY NEW GUN (Columbia Tri-Star, Sept. 28)
description: When Stacy Cochran's drier-than-vermouth suburban comedy "My New Gun" appeared in 1992, it seemed to augur a bright future for the then-nascent idea of independent filmmaking. In the 12 years since, legions of directors have spun out small movies laced with quirks (quirks having become easy substitutes for originality, brains and craftsmanship). But few indie movies of the recent past have the disarmingly gentle spark, or the understated wit, of "My New Gun." Diane Lane plays Debbie, a New Jersey housewife who's not actually bored -- that would be too boring. Rather, she makes the best of the orderly life she shares with her passive-aggressively attentive doctor husband, Gerald (Stephen Collins). On a whim Gerald buys her a gun, despite (or maybe because of) her protestations. Her neighbor, the protective, mysterious, soft-spoken Skippy (James LeGros), spirits the gun out of the house for reasons Debbie doesn't immediately understand. The nuttier their situation gets, the more the tacit sympathy between them grows: their dialogue is like Dada poetry, with extra beats to take the place of the things they don't dare say. Unlike so many comedies set in the suburbs, "My New Gun" -- its serviceably lavish houses and roadside restaurants lovingly shot by Ed Lachman -- is fueled by optimism and a sense of adventure. Ms. Cochran's movie, never the indie hit it should have been and at last available on DVD, suggests that the suburbs aren't nearly as stupid and lifeless as the movies usually make them out to be. People don't make the suburbs boring -- filmmakers do. STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Kerry Suggests Rivals Might Suppress Black Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - Senator John Kerry suggested on Saturday that Republicans might be trying to suppress black votes in key electoral battlegrounds, pledging to an audience of the capital's black elite to make sure that "every vote is counted and every vote counts."

title: The Space Race
description: Developers have been bulldozing, paving, shingling and siding Long Island for more than 50 years, with not much standing in the way of their sprawling ambitions, unless you count Long Island Sound, the Atlantic Ocean and Queens.

title: For Greenwich Students, A Study on Walking Routes
description: The town of Greenwich is studying ways to make it safer for students to walk to school.

title: Giving Cancer Victims Reason to Hope
description: "I am a 46 year old who was, and still is feeling great. I had heartburn and since I was due for my yearly physical, went to see my primary care physician. At the check-up, he noticed that my liver functions were high, and ordered a sonogram. The results showed spots. He thought maybe they were gallstones and ordered a CT scan. At 5 p.m., he told me that I had stage IV colon cancer. I was numb . . .

title: Women's Rights, Turkish Style
description: As part of a slate of reforms aimed at securing membership in the European Union, Turkey's ruling party has proposed a major overhaul of the country's criminal code. There is much value in the effort. Prompted by a coalition of women's groups, it includes stronger laws against rape, sexual assault and sexual harassment. Unfortunately, several other provisions affecting women are dangerously regressive, seeking to codify in law beliefs and practices that reflect the party's own conservative Islamic roots rather than the European Union's modern vision of human rights.

title: Buenos Aires: An Insider's Address Book
description: FESTIVITIES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, CARYL, ROBIN
description: GOLDMAN--Caryl-Robin, on September 5th, 2004. Beloved daughter of the late Jack and Fay Goldman. Loving sister of Joyce Goldman Weiner and sister-in-law of Dennis Weiner. Dear aunt to Jacqueline Goldman Weiner. Survived by her cherished pet, Coco. Private services were held.

title: Mawae Planted Firmly at Center of Jets' Universe
description: Kevin Mawae used to shave his ankles on the long nights before his high school games in Louisiana, and his game-day routine never wavered. In college, his uniform had a swatch of his old jersey from Leesville High School sewn inside. He enlisted all manner of trinkets to promote strength, success, longevity.

title: By Their Subway Stations Ye Shall Know Them
description: JUST over two years ago, three dedicated New York bloggers posted a version of the city's subway map on the Internet and linked their online diaries to their nearest station. Then they sent a few e-mails inviting people to do the same.

title: For Some Who Endured Losses at Ground Zero, Going There Is Too Much to Bear
description: Hundreds of people made their way to ground zero yesterday to pay tribute to loved ones who were lost. Names were read, and there was music -- Dvorak and "Danny Boy." And there were flowers, and tears.

title: In Madrid
description: After ceding at least a decade to the northern cities of Barcelona and Bilbao as the centers of chic and modern Spain, Madrid is playing a spirited game of catch-up. In revamping its image, it is reasserting itself not just as the capital of the country but also as the vortex of Spanish culture, at once modern and traditional, encompassing grand cuisine and rustic tapas, stellar museums and street culture. It was after all for its location -- almost exactly in the center of the Iberian peninsula -- that King Philip II designated it the capital in 1561, and the city is once again drawing on its crossroads status to forge an identity as a leading European city.

title: Domestic Deceit
description: Our longtime housekeeper (a foreign-born legal resident) has grown her business, hiring a Mexican woman (here illegally) to clean houses. Of the $80 I pay the housekeeper, between $10 and $15 goes to the woman who actually cleans. She speaks no English and probably couldn't have gotten the job on her own. If we offered her $60 directly, she'd be paid more fairly and we'd save $20, but our original housekeeper would lose. Should we do it? Steven Kane, Los Angeles 'Grown her business" -- yes, much like Pharaoh grew his pyramid-building operation. By subcontracting her work at $2 to $3 an hour (assuming five hours to clean a house), your housekeeper has breached ethics, the minimum-wage law and ordinary human decency. For you to benefit from this exploitation is thoroughly discreditable.

title: A Door Opens. The View Is Ugly.
description: REMEMBER how bitterly most mutual fund companies -- especially Fidelity and Vanguard -- fought the Securities and Exchange Commission idea to make them disclose how they voted on board elections, executive pay and other corporate governance issues? Now that rule is in force, and investors can see for themselves why some funds were reluctant to let the sun shine in.

title: Another Take On Special Election
description: To the Editor:

title: The Performances to Watch
description: Correction Appended

title: The Return of the Hostess From Hell
description: ALL hail the return of the American theater's favorite fun couple, George and Martha, those guest-baiting, blood-drawing denizens of academe in "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," the play that made Edward Albee a household name in 1962. After a "Gone With the Wind"-style search for the actress to play Martha -- during which everyone from Mercedes Ruehl to Jessica Lange hovered as tantalizing possibilities -- the role was awarded to Kathleen Turner, who proved herself box-office magic by showing up in the altogether in the sorry, soggy stage version of "The Graduate." As Martha, the hostess from hell and self-described earth mother, she (presumably) keeps her clothes on. But she has far more opportunity to get naked emotionally. Bill Irwin, the great physical comedian who showed an unexpected affinity for Albee angst when he appeared in "The Goat," is George, Martha's husband, accomplice and sparring partner. David Harbour and Mireille Enos are the young and dewy guests who get gotten. Directed by Anthony Page, a seasoned and sensitive hand at Albee-brand vitriol, the play begins previews on March 12 at a Broadway theater to be announced.

title: Plains Verse
description: Q: How did you find out you'd been selected as the new poet laureate?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VERONESE, JEAN LANGE
description: VERONESE--Jean Lange. On September 10, 2004, after a brief illness. Daughter of the late Dr. William Lange and Gertrude Lange. Devoted mother of Suzanne, William and his wife Emily. Devoted grandmother of Jazmyn and James. Stepdaughter of Leila S. Lange. Visitation Sunday 25 and 7-9 PM, at Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 Ninth St, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral service Monday, September 13, 2004, at 10 AM, The Old First Reformed Church, Seventh Avenue and Carroll St., Brooklyn. For more information, contact Henry McCaddin Funeral Home at 718-499-8700.

title: Nelly Gets Conceptual, and Jazz Comes to Columbus Circle
description: Correction Appended

title: From Central Park to Outer Space
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: . . . And as For The Rest of the Crew . . .
description: Somewhat less mysterious is the fate of the governor's top aides.

title: The Vision Seekers
description: Here's the truth: I have traveled more than 4,000 miles to the middle of the Peruvian Amazon to be "cured" by shamans. It's nighttime. The riverboat I'm on plies dark waters, the jungle thick on either side, emitting loud reptilian sounds that drone on like police sirens. I see no lights, no villages anywhere.

title: Memories in High Relief
description: While a lot of attention has been paid to the 9/11 memorial in Lower Manhattan, not enough has been focused on the memorials that are springing up throughout Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey. That's a shame, because each has a special importance. And with each new design or proposal, more questions arise: When are there enough memorials? Does every town have to have its own?

title: Rituals of Grief, on a Day Eased Only by Time
description: They gathered at a hole in the ground in Lower Manhattan, a lonely patch of earth in rural Pennsylvania and a spot near the healed breach in the seat of military power, the Pentagon. The crowds were smaller than in past years, the grief perhaps muffled a bit by the gauze that time weaves over raw wounds, as hundreds drew close to the sites of the worst terrorist attack in United States history yesterday to remember and mourn those lost three years earlier, on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Greek Defense Minister Quits for Deadly Copter Crash
description: ATHENS, Sept. 12 A A day after Africa's senior Greek Orthodox prelate and 16 others died in a helicopter crash in the northern Aegean, the Greek defense minister, Spilios Spiliotopoulos, dismissed the country's air force chief for delaying rescue attempts and then tendered his own resignation.

title: Woody, Whoopi, Miller, Mamet and Elvis
description: September

title: Splendor, at Last
description: IN September 1929, a few weeks before the stock market crash, a three-towered apartment building in late Italian Renaissance style opened on the corner of Central Park West and 81st Street. It was named the Beresford, after the hotel it replaced, and was a masterwork of the architect Emery Roth, a Jewish emigrant from the Austro-Hungarian Empire whose background limited his chances for commissions to build on the posh east side of the park.

title: Landscape of the Midnight Sun
description: IN Louisa Matthiasdottir's landscape paintings, the terrain is open and flat, the light hard and clean, the colors cold and Nordic. Every animal, house, tree and figure looks chiseled and squarish: toylike silhouettes stripped down to elemental shapes. Matthiasdottir's humor is dry, her mood serene but oblique, as if something serious lurked below the simplified surface.

title: Everybody's a Writer, It Seems, and Now Everybody Can Be Their Own Publisher
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. - WE will probably never see "Bandit's StoryMy Life as a Police Dog" on a best-seller list.

title: Bring On the Pasta and (Yes) Anchovies
description: SOMETIMES I muse about what a banquet it would be to take a superlative dish from each of a number of good restaurants. There are many places that are not consistently topnotch in all their menu items, but they do have certain knock-out dishes that make me want to return again and again.

title: A Tuscan Order
description: In this era of endlessly inventive self-improvement, when everything human can be remolded, twisted, gutted, slimmed, sucked and completely metamorphosed, either by steely surgeons or afternoon-television coiffeurs and re-lipstickers, three questions about the kitchen arise: first, can you give a restaurant a face lift -- even for one night? Second, is doing so as painful as the human version? And third, if the restaurant is the culinary equivalent of Diane Lane, why would you want to? The answers are yes, no and read on.

title: Katherine Fisher, Henry Schwab
description: Katherine Norcross Fisher, a daughter of Philip B. Fisher Jr. of New York and the late Emily Norcross Fisher, is to be married today to Henry David Schwab, a son of Judith Pearlman Schwab of Skokie, Ill., and Paul S. Schwab of Chicago. Rabbi Beth Jannus is to officiate at the Holman Ranch in Carmel Valley, Calif.

title: Cornwall Covered Bridge To Close for a Day of Repairs
description: The West Cornwall Bridge on Route 128 will be closed Tuesday to repair damage caused by a tour bus last month, an official with the State Department of Transportation said.

title: Unease Over the Signs That Mark Our Times
description: For a little spit of an island where residents value quaint shops with names like Timeless Sweets and chafe at any sign of new development, the modern illuminated signs on the island's first national franchises were just too much for some to bear.

title: Can Mr. Chips Transform Intel?
description: Santa Clara, Calif. - PAUL S. OTELLINI was 41 and a rising star at Intel when, in 1992, his boss informed him that the company would choose him as its new chief of sales and marketing.

title: Employment by Dogma? Lay Teachers Are Testing the Roman Catholic Church
description: The Roman Catholic Church has a long history of supporting the rights of workers in fields and factories around the world. But in Brooklyn and Queens, teachers at five Catholic schools insist that the church has ignored its own tenets of social justice by engaging in unfair labor practices against their union, and New York State has backed up the charge with a complaint against the Brooklyn diocese.

title: Catherine McGarry, Oliver Prichard
description: Catherine Lyne McGarry, a daughter of Carol and J. Michael McGarry of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Oliver William Prichard, the son of Ann and Peter Prichard of Washington. The Rev. Robert G. Biron, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Church in New London, N.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOIDELL, PAULA KARMIEL
description: GOIDELL -- Paula Karmiel, died on August 23, 2004, in Boynton Beach, Florida, after her courageous battle with recurrent meningiomas. A talented interior designer, Paula was a lover of theatre, opera, museums, music, travel and life. She will be greatly missed by her family and a huge legion of friends.

title: Letters
description: David Brooks's ideas for reinventing the G.O.P. won bipartisan support, with Republican and Democratic readers alike applauding his proposals. Moving to a different playing field, both supporters and skeptics weighed in on four more years for JoePa at Penn State.

title: For Baby, and Parents
description: New parents who are feeling -- postpartum anxiety about all that unlovely baby gear can find a reprieve in a new bouncy seat by Oeuf. The sleek seat -- devoid of dancing bears or weird black-and-white gingham graphics -- is made of cotton canvas on a stainless steel frame and can hold babies up to 18 pounds. The machine-washable canvas covers come in chocolate brown with a choice of a pink, blue or white accent stripe. At $110 (from Auto. in New York, 212-229-2292), the seat is more expensive than mass-produced brands, which cost $20 to $40, but for picky parents (or clever baby shower guests), it provides an elegant platform for that squalling bundle of joy.

title: Computer Measures Political Mudslinging
description: At long last, researchers have trained an impartial referee to keep score of political mud fights.

title: Maddening
description: Madden NFL 2005 The middle of August was a momentous time for sports fans. Sure, there was the start of the Olympics. But for many people the more important event was the release of the latest installment in the Madden NFL Football video-game series. According to its publisher, Electronic Arts, Madden NFL 2005 sold 1.3 million copies in the first week of its release. At $46 a pop, that's a Hollywood-movie-level opening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUMMINGS, VICTOR, M.D.
description: CUMMINGS--Victor, M.D. On September 6, 2004 after a long battle with unremitting disease. Graduated NYU College of Medicine, served in Korea earning a Bronze Star. He organized the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at the Medical College of Ohio and retired as Chairman in 1992. His kindness, dedication and sense of humor will be missed. Condolences to Jacqueline, Nina and David. E.S. and Eileen Siker Dan Schube Ira and Mary Barash Pauline Alexander

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, BESSIE
description: GREENBERG--Bessie. The American Friends of Beth Hatefutsoth, the Museum of the Jewish Diaspora in Tel Aviv, expresses its heartfelt condolences to past President and Board Member Stephen M. Greenberg on the passing of his mother. May her memory be for a blessing for the entire family. Sam E. Bloch, Chairman Aaron Feingold, President Gloria Golan, Director

title: High Morale Fuels Success for Teams in Formula One
description: Jason Riley, who calls himself "a truck driver and general dogsbody" for the Renault Formula One team, said his job is easier when the team is successful.

title: Beth Cohen, Christopher Chazin
description: Beth Hilary Cohen and Christopher Adam Chazin are to be married today in Bensalem, Pa. Rabbi Seymour Rosenbloom is to officiate at the Penn Ryn Mansion.

title: Studying Dr. Kinsey's Sex Life
description: NOT quite a movie star but too helplessly charismatic to be considered a character actor, Liam Neeson has proved unusually adept at playing half-forgotten figures, of various nationalities, from 20th-century history. His finest work to date has come in the roles of Oskar Schindler, the conscience-stricken Nazi in Steven Spielberg's "Schindler's List," and Michael Collins, the conflicted Irish freedom fighter in Neil Jordan's underrated revisionist epic of the same name. Now, in Bill Condon's "Kinsey" (Nov. 12), he will play a revolutionary of a decidedly different sort: Alfred C. Kinsey, the midcentury American sex researcher whose findings, first published in the best seller "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" in 1948, helped to bring sex out of the Victorian shadows and into the glare of the modern media.

title: Sept. 5-11
description: RIDING OUT THE HURRICANE IN A MOBILE HOME Hurricanes may seem indiscriminate in their fury, but the storms that have struck Florida in the last 30 days prove those taking the hardest hit often live in mobile homes or other low-income areas.

title: Athletic Profiling
description: Richard Pound, the president of the World Anti-Doping Agency, has a point when he says that the record number of positive drug tests at the Athens Olympics was a good sign. Those tests, along with the bizarre mini-drama that ensued when two Greek runners skipped their test appointments, show that a serious effort was made by the antidoping forces. But you don't have to be a hardened cynic to realize that the antidoping effort is nonetheless in crisis.

title: Mother and Child: A Spreadsheet
description: To the Editor:

title: Megan Quinn, Thomas Davis
description: Megan Colleen Quinn, the daughter of Karen and Thomas Quinn of Montville, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas Swift Davis, the son of Dana and Thomas Davis of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Luke Travers, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Holy Family Chapel of the College of St. Elizabeth in Morristown, N.J.

title: 1 Cottage + 1 Cottage = 1 Home
description: HOW a house becomes a home and how that home shapes a life -- these are the stories told by Kate Whouley's cottages. There are two of them, joined up like dominos, alike but not the same -- married, as Ms. Whouley says -- tucked among the evergreens above the edge of a cranberry bog near Barnstable, Mass., on Cape Cod.

title: Beth Saunders, Ali Farahnakian
description: Beth Saunders, a television producer, and Ali Farahnakian, an actor, were married yesterday evening at the Beekman Tower Hotel in New York. The Rev. Susan Turchin, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Port's House of God Goes Green
description: NEWARK - THE Seamen's Church Institute center in Port Newark has long been a haven, providing a spiritual respite amid the port's commercial bustle of trucks, container yards and big ships. And last week the two-story building took a step toward becoming an oasis of another sort, as the first environmentally friendly building in the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's sprawling stock of real estate.

description: To the Editor:

title: Blues, Burlesque and Balanchine
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: 'Spanglish'
description: Written by James L. Brooks Opening Dec. 17.

description: To the Editor:

title: Look at What the Italians Uncovered
description: ARCHAEOLOGICAL digs in and near Rome in the mid- to late 19th century yielded wondrous things: ancient necklaces, bracelets and brooches -- stuff as dreams are made on. Inspired by these treasures, Italian goldsmiths created magical new works, as will be seen in "The Castellani and Italian Archaeological Jewelry" at the Bard Graduate Center in New York from Nov. 18-Feb. 6. The exhibition, the first in this country to document the archaeological revival style, will display 280 lightly bejeweled, stylish ornaments, rich in granulation, micromosaics and cameos, in what promises to be an illuminating survey of a glamorous movement that brightened the Victorian age.

title: The Sleep of Forgetfulness (and the Bed Remembers)
description: IF you have flipped through a magazine or turned on the television or radio lately, you may have encountered advertisements for mattresses promoting technology developed by NASA.

title: Melissa Groo, Matthew Gelder
description: Melissa Semmes Groo and Matthew Scott Gelder were married yesterday in Trappe, Md. The Rev. James Bank, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at Martin's Point Farm, which is owned by members of the bride's family.

title: School Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: British Ad Giant Buys Grey, a Storied U.S. Firm
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  The British advertising agency WPP Group said today that it had won the bidding for Grey Global Group, the world's last large independent advertising firm, with an offer believed to be worth about $1.4 billion in cash and stock.

title: Greek Orthodox Patriarch Dies With 12 Others in Copter Crash
description: ATHENS, Sept. 11 - Africa's senior Greek Orthodox leader, Patriarch Petros VII of Alexandria, Egypt, and a dozen other religious officials were killed Saturday when a helicopter carrying them to the monastic community of Mt. Athos in northern Greece crashed minutes before it was scheduled to land.

title: Alexis Ryan, Lex Hrabe
description: Katharine Alexis Ryan, the daughter of Noelle G. Vitt and the stepdaughter of Geoffrey J. Vitt of Norwich, Vt., is to be married today to Alexander Downs Hrabe, the son of Margaret Downs Hrabe and Richard A. Hrabe of Batesville, Va. Judge Walter Gorman of Rhode Island District Court in Newport is to officiate at a summer house in Little Compton, R.I., owned by friends of the bride's family. The Rev. Dr. Jewell-Ann Parton, a Presbyterian minister, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: A Serendipitous Souvenir
description: FOR those of us of a certain age, a stroll down memory lane of the cold war unreels images that never let go. Kids hiding under desks. Bomb shelters dug in backyards. A nuclear world split in two, East and West staring each other down along the Iron Curtain, all of us just a trigger-pull away from the grand finale. The Last Mushroom Cloud.

title: Bistro Fare With Urban Ambience
description: HARTSDALE - HARRYS may be "of Hartsdale," but its spirit is pure Manhattan. This restaurant provides all the polish and sophistication of Midtown Manhattan bistros, but closer to home. It has even copied a New York City trend of offering special multicourse meals at $20.04. Instead of dining in the city and catching the late train, commuters can stop in at Harrys, situated conveniently opposite the train station here.

title: Middle School Angst Revisited
description: Metuchen - EACH time I headed to seventh-grade English for my volunteer job as a writing coach last year, I would hesitate before daring to pass through the sardine-can aisle where throngs of adolescents chatted between rows of brightly colored lockers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKULE, JACK
description: BERKULE--Jack. The best father a family could ever wish for, thank you for being with us and guiding us with all your love and knowledge. You will always be in our hearts. Loving you every day forever. Barry, Patricia, Elizabeth Berkule

title: Judith Frankel, Jos Coln
description: Judith Leibholz Frankel, an executive recruiter, and Dr. Jos Francisco Coln, a specialist in physical and rehabilitation medicine, are to be married today at their home in West Orange, N.J. Cantor Dan Rous is to perform the ceremony.

title: The Future of the Past
description: TO take no sides in history would be as false as to take no sides in life," the historian Barbara W. Tuchman once wrote. If that applies to the written word, it is just as true for the presentation of history in museums. Museums can't be objective because history isn't. To be meaningful, a museum needs a slant. On the other hand, a museum dedicated to the history of a place is supposed to be broadly representative. So there's the contradiction: if a museum is doing its job, you might say, it's ticking somebody off.

title: On the Voting Machine Makers' Tab
description: As doubts have grown about the reliability of electronic voting, some of its loudest defenders have been state and local election officials. Many of those same officials have financial ties to voting machine companies. While they may sincerely think that electronic voting machines are so trustworthy that there is no need for a paper record of votes, their views have to be regarded with suspicion until their conflicts are addressed.

title: In the Right Place at the Right Time
description: LINKED in friendship, connected by pain, the United States and Russia were a welcoming host and a gracious guest last night.

title: Military Specialist Pleads Guilty to Abuse and Is Jailed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 11 - The first American military intelligence specialist to stand trial in connection with the abuse of detainees at Abu Ghraib prison pleaded guilty here on Saturday to abusing prisoners. He was sentenced to eight months in jail.

title: Paperback Fiction
Dance Listings
description: GABRI CHRISTA DANZAISA A "Dominata." Dance Theater Workshop, 219 W. 19th St. (212) 924-0077. Wed.-Sat., 7:30.

title: A-Bomb 'Guinea Pigs'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM -- SCENE STEALERS: Thomas Haden Church; The Performances to Watch
description: FANS of Thomas Haden Church's five-year stint as Lowell the mechanic on the 90's sitcom "Wings" can take heart at last. After a film career that pretty much peaked with "George of the Jungle" (1997) and hit bottom earlier this year with something called "Serial Killing 4 Dummies," Mr. Church has landed a role and a movie that allow him to cover himself with comic glory.

title: In McMinnville, the Goose Has Landed
description: I'd passed it before, of course. It's hard not to if you live in this corner of the state, and hard not to gawk when you do: you're headed down Highway 18, the main road from Portland to the Oregon coast, driving past quaint, red-brick McMinnville in the heart of the Willamette Valley wine region, and there before you, in the glass-fronted hangar of the Evergreen Aviation Museum, looms the object described in its day as "the colossus" and "the monster," the largest-wingspan airplane ever to fly, the Spruce Goose.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KELLY, MICHAEL W.
description: KELLY -- Michael W. 1946-2003. Son of Eleanor and Mike. Brother of Florence and Joan. Friend of Michael Boden, Jerry Doherty, Tom Indaco, Carol Taylor and Ed Wilton. Greatly missed and forever in our hearts. "Honesty is the best policy."

title: Page Two: Sept. 5-11; HE SAID GENOCIDE
description: When Secretary of State Colin L. Powell spoke before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday, the big question was whether he would use the word genocide in describing the violent ethnic cleansing campaign in the Darfur region of Sudan. He did, and that brought some praise from those who have urged the administration to do more.

title: President? Forget It. Who Should Win the Corner Office?
description: Look at it this way: Workers pay taxes, taxes finance government, and the president heads the government. So, like it or not, you are working for the president for part of each day.

title: THE GARDEN OF ALLAH; INTERMEZZO (MGM, Oct. 19)
description: Gregory Ratoff's 1939 film "Intermezzo" and Richard Boleslawski's 1936 film "The Garden of Allah" are both included in MGM's release of selected weepies produced by David O. Selznick in the 30's and 40's. But the similarities end there -- one is juicy, the other merely wet. In "Intermezzo," Leslie Howard and, in her first English-language role, Ingrid Bergman play a violinist and a pianist whose passion for music draws them together and causes untold pain for his wife and family. The problem is, Howard's violinist is too much of a puppet to inspire much of anything except snoozing -- both Bergman's dewily desirable pianist and Edna Best's dull but long-suffering wife are far too good for him.

title: Federer's Power to Meet Hewitt's Precision in Men's Final
description: The Americans bowed out relatively early. Controversy clouded the elimination of one of the game's biggest names, Serena Williams, and rain and wind each had a day to ravage the tournament. But in the final match of this year's United States Open, it can be argued that things will finally be as they should be.

title: 'Arc of Justice'
description: The streets of Detroit shimmered with heat. Most years, autumnarrived the first week of September. Not in 1925. Two days pastLabor Day and the sun blazed like July. Heat curled up from the asphalt,wrapped around telephone poles and streetlight stanchions, drifted pastthe unmarked doors of darkened speakeasies, seeped through windowsthrown open to catch a breeze, and settled into the city's flats and houseswhere it lay, thick and oppressive, as afternoon edged into evening.
