description: The Blimp Patrol

title: Sculptures in the Earth and Colored Lines in Space
description: FURTHER proof of the renewed fascination with Minimalism and other radical 60's and 70's art comes this fall with two big traveling retrospectives.

title: Sharon Leao, Jonathan Kanz
description: Dr. Sharon Gayle Rilloraza Leao and Dr. Jonathan Julius Kanz were married yesterday at St. Matthias Church in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. The Rev. Patrick Frawley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Preparing for Hurricanes
description: Correction Appended

title: Wagner With Sleep Breaks
description: TALK if you will about Wagnerian length, but consider a "Tristan und Isolde" in Los Angeles that lasts for three days.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Focus on the Acropolis

title: Thoughts on a Clear Pane
description: One of New York's time-honored pastimes, avoiding eye contact with strangers on the subway, comes in multiple forms. Falling asleep, looking at one's shoes, studying ads for Anna Nicole Smith's diet plan -- all good choices.

title: Not Perfect, but a Recovery All the Same
description: IF there are any nonpartisan economists left -- besides me, of course -- one of them should write a book on Bush 43 Economics. It's a rich subject, involving many contradictions and mysteries.

title: The Bargain
description: This short story, written more than 50 years ago, came to light for the first time when Gerald Clarke, Truman Capote's biographer, was preparing a collection of his letters (due out, along with "The Complete Stories," later this month). In a letter dated May 15, 1950, Capote, who was 25 and had already published his first novel, "Other Voices, Other Rooms," wrote that he had just finished a new story -- The Bargain." The story disappeared from view, however, and was apparently lost. It was discovered earlier this year in the archives of the New York Public Library, where it had been filed along with the rest of the personal papers found after his death in 1984. It appears here for the first time -- as far as anyone knows, the last unpublished story by Truman Capote.

title: No Number, No Ride
description: HECTOR MALDONADO received a letter recently that threatens to turn his life upside down. The letter, from the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, informed Mr. Maldonado that because the agency was unable to verify his Social Security number, his driver's license -- which he has had for 19 years -- would be suspended. He was given 15 days to provide the correct documentation.

title: Gunman Shoots Desk Clerk and Abducts Wife From Hospital in Queens, Police Say
description: A man who was enraged that his wife planned to file for divorce walked into the emergency room of the Queens hospital where she was working yesterday and abducted her after shooting a desk clerk, witnesses and the authorities said.

title: The Islamic World, Seen in Westbury
description: WESTBURY - PENNY D'ANTONIO, a retired English teacher from Port Washington, and Homaira Mamoor, a graduate student from West Islip, spent the day together recently at the Islamic Center of Long Island here.

title: Rivers Run Black, and Chinese Die of Cancer
description: HUANGMENGYING, China - Wang Lincheng began his accounting at the brick hut of a farmer. Dead of cancer, he said flatly, his dress shoes sinking in the mud. Dead of cancer, he repeated, glancing at another vacant house.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 22 about two brokers at Merrill Lynch who are accusing the firm of sex discrimination included an outdated name for the building in Midtown Manhattan that houses their office. It is the Citigroup Center, no longer Citicorp.

title: Japanese Inspired And Nature Infused
description: NORTH SALEM - THE galleries of the Hammond Museum are also the gateway to its main attraction, a Japanese stroll garden. The garden provides authentic contemplative experiences, like the pleasant shock of the terrace of red maple trees amid all the greenery, or the attraction of being drawn into scanning the pond's lily pads for well-camouflaged frogs.

title: Cities Show Off New Threads: Dublin
description: The Irish have a voracious appetite for live music and, outside the devoted fans of local singer-songwriters, a broad range of tastes, from Eastern European folk and Spanish flamenco to jazz, reggae and hip-hop. That mishmash of styles has a stylish new home in Crawdaddy, a cozy place that opened in the tunnels of an old train station downtown last April.

title: How Garth Fagan Keeps His Dancers Aloft
description: ROCHESTER - IF you know only one thing about the choreographer Garth Fagan, you know that he created the sensational dance sequences for the Broadway show "The Lion King." Chances are you don't know that Momo Peter Sanno, who performed in the German production of "The Lion King" and had only met Mr. Fagan once, was so eager to join Garth Fagan Dance that he took a 3 a.m. train to the Bavarian city of Frth -- three hours after that night's Hamburg performance ended -- so he could make a 9 a.m. master class and, he hoped, impress Mr. Fagan. (It worked.) You don't know that Sharon Skepple, when she was a freshman at the North Carolina School of the Arts, was so wowed by a video of the company's work that she saved her tips from her job at Pizza Hut so she could take Mr. Fagan's summer workshop, then quit school and joined up. "When the rest of my class graduated, I was performing with the company in Palermo," she recalls. And you don't know that Steve Humphrey was an 18-year-old music student when he met Mr. Fagan, who was teaching a dance class at the State University of New York in Brockport, and promptly switched majors. Mr. Sanno, 23, joined the company in 2003; Ms. Skepple, 40, in 1988; and Mr. Humphrey, 52, in 1970.

title: Atlanta Police Officer Is Accused of Robbing Three Banks
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 11 - Officer Stanley Street was in court this month, but he was not in uniform and not there to testify. Wearing a white T-shirt and tan elastic-waist pants, he entered in handcuffs and sat silently at the defense table as a federal judge denied him bond "to ensure the safety of the community."

title: 'Sammy's Hill'
description: The party really started to rock when Willie Nelson and QueenNefertiti began pouring shots. I downed one and felt my stomach immediatelyreplaced by a large liquor bonfire that spread through my chest, itsflames licking up the inside of my throat. Willie leaned over and whisperedthat Winnie the Pooh had the hots for me. No way! I loved thatguy! As I watched Winnie get down on the dance floor, throwing smolderingPooh Bear glances in my direction, I all of a sudden felt myselffloating. Flapping my arms, I rose higher and higher. Soon I was at thirtythousand feet, and a bit chilly. I plucked the edge of the cloud nearest meand draped it over my shoulders, fashioning a cumulus-nimbus pashmina.Feeling quite stylish, I surveyed the landscape below. I checked inwith the mountain ranges, the vast oceans, the tiny cities, the-

title: Reaching Out, and Into a Turf Battle
description: GOSPEL music blared over the loudspeakers. Hands swayed through the air in prayer. At the Lakeside Theater in Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, Donnie McClurkin, the velvet-voiced, Grammy Award-winning pastor from Freeport, united a congregation of 12,000.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM -- SCENE STEALERS: Rodrigo de la Serna; The Performances to Watch
description: IN "The Motorcycle Diaries," Walter Salles's road movie about the eight-month trip that started the transformation of a 23-year-old medical student into a revolutionary warrior, Rodrigo de la Serna plays the biochemist Alberto Granado, a somewhat Sancho Panza-like sidekick to Gael Garca Bernal's Ernesto (Che) Guevara.

title: 100 Years of Going Underground
description: New York's subway system, the nation's largest, turns 100 next month -- a big moment for an institution we take so much for granted. Perhaps the flash flooding last week that knocked out so much of its service was meant to be a reminder of how important its steady service is to the city.

title: Audiovox Workers Dodge a Big Bullet
description: WHEN the Audiovox Corporation, the Hauppauge electronics company known for everything from car stereos to flat-screen television sets, sells off its cellphone operations later this year, nothing earthshaking is expected to happen. The subsidiary's 269 employees are expected to show up the morning after the sale, slide into their same desks, make their calls and carry out their assigned duties as if nothing, or at least very little, has happened.

title: Atomic Activity in North Korea Raises Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - President Bush and his top advisers have received intelligence reports in recent days describing a confusing series of actions by North Korea that some experts believe could indicate the country is preparing to conduct its first test explosion of a nuclear weapon, according to senior officials with access to the intelligence.

title: Amid the Smell of Burning Leaves, The Scent of Autumn Greasepaint
description: THE best of any theater season combines new and old. This fall promises both. Beloved plays like "Guys and Dolls" at the Long Wharf in New Haven join original works like "The Clean House" at Yale Repertory to keep audiences both entertained and challenged. Here is a look at Connecticut's offerings this season.

title: Christine Lee, Michael Walsdorf
description: Christine Soyoung Lee, the daughter of Dr. Yunsook P. Lee and Dr. Su Cherl Lee of Baltimore, is to be married today to Michael Robert Walsdorf Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsdorf of River Forest, Ill. The Rev. Matthew Roche, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.

title: Introduction
description: David Brooks's ideas for reinventing the G.O.P. won bipartisan support, with Republican and Democratic readers alike applauding his proposals. Moving to a different playing field, both supporters and skeptics weighed in on four more years for JoePa at Penn State.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Sept. 11 is never going to become just another day."

title: Primary Choices
description: Primary elections will be held throughout the state on Tuesday, Sept. 14. Poll hours in Westchester are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. The following is the editorial page endorsement in the region's most competitive contests:

title: A Star to Shed Light on Janacek's Bleak Operatic Landscape
description: OPINIONS may differ as to what constitutes a highlight at the Metropolitan Opera these days, but few disagreed last season about Karita Mattila's performance as Strauss's Salome, a tour de force of singing and acting.

title: For Hipsters, a Little Cardio to Go With the Espresso
description: On a cloudy afternoon last week, a young couple rode their bikes past Maxim Health and Fitness, a glossy new gym on Driggs Avenue and North Ninth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She had blue hair; he sported tight black jeans and Converse high-tops, and his pale arms were covered in tattoos.

title: Susanna Patrick, Lawrence Hedblom
description: Susanna Tilghman Patrick and Lawrence James Hedblom were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James R. Patrick of Maumee, Ohio. Judge J. Ronald Bowman of the Lucas County Common Pleas Court in Toledo, Ohio, officiated.

description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 11 - LOUISVILLE 52, ARMY 21

title: A Spritz From the Past
description: The 50's influence -- in fashion has trickled down to fragrance. This year, perfume makers are reviving the atomizer, that vanity-table icon from the heyday of glamour. Eau de Parfum by Prada (below right, $95 at Saks Fifth Avenue) offers the warm sting of amber in a coolly beautiful bottle fitted with a silk and silver squeeze vaporizer. Zita by Paula Dorf mixes tea rose with the scent of fresh-cut grass in a blush-colored Art Deco bottle ($55 at Sephora.com), while the floral Maman Cherie by Fragonard (below left) comes in a minimalist rounded flask with a pink atomizer ($56 at Bigelow Chemists in New York, 800-793-5433). Nanadebary also uses a rosy bottle -- this one decorated with a whimsical drawing of a nearly nude woman -- for its spicy combination of cedar, tangerine and nutmeg ($130 at Beautyhabit.com). And the citrus Colonia Splash by Acqua di Parma (above, $175 at Barneys New York), for both men and women, comes in a strong silver flask with a black silken-corded pump.

title: A Hastings Site Draws a Third Plan
description: For the third time in two years, Ginsburg Development of Hawthorne, has tinkered with its proposal for a 7.5-acre site along Route 9A in the northeast corner of Hastings-on-Hudson.

description: Hudson by Ferry

description: Correction Appended

title: COMMUNICATIONS NETWORK URGED
description: A broad communications network would reduce vulnerability to terrorism in the critical port region of New York and New Jersey, said a report issued on Wednesday by the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. The report, which was commissioned by the Smith Richardson Foundation of Westport, Conn., suggested that a single attack in the area could affect a broad swath of freight and transportation systems across the Northeast and threaten millions of residents. It proposed a network linking more than 30 agencies from all levels of government, along with private companies that help run the air and sea ports, to coordinate a faster and more effective response. Jessica Bruder

title: Corrections
description: An art listing on Page 99 of Arts & Leisure today misidentifies the current exhibition at the Plane Space gallery and misstates the neighborhood. The attraction is an installation, "Ideal City," by Kim Beck -- not drawings, sculpture and video by Mark Woods. The gallery, at 102 Charles Street, is in Greenwich Village, not SoHo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, HENRY
description: WILLIAMS--Henry. February 19, 1928 to August 17, 2004. Henry, professor, psychologist, consultant, devoted his life to working with those less fortunate. He was the recipient of numerous awards, President Carter's National Council on Disability, E.B. Whitten Silver Medallion, the Distinguished Sevice Award from the National Association of Non-White Rehabilitation Worker's, National Achievement Award, and the Pioneer Award from the National Council on Multi-Cultural concerns. He was also Vice-President of New York's 100 Black Men. Henry leaves a wife, Sheila; brother, Richard; children, Patricia and Henri; daughter-in-law, Joan; and grandchildren, Phaelyn, Llauren, Elexius and Jamie. Memorial services at Metropolitan AME Church, 58 W. 135th St., NY, NY at 6pm on September 15.

title: 'The Egyptologist': Who Is Buried in Atum-hadu's Tomb?
description: THE EGYPTOLOGIST By Arthur Phillips. 383 pp. Random House. $24.95.

title: Genesis Meets Its Apocalypse
description: MAYBE Genesis was in a rush to get home. Maybe years of floating in space had made the spacecraft a little unstable, like Hal in "2001: a Space Odyssey." Maybe, entranced by the beauty of Utah's desolate landscape, it just forgot to pull its parachute cord.

title: 'The First Desire'
description: July, the air grassy and mild, the sort of morning Sadie waits forthrough the deep of Buffalo winters-mornings when it seems the cityhas surrendered to pleasure, to color and light. The harsh seasonsare unimaginable. It's as if this is how all of life is meant to be;as if drinking coffee and reading, gardening and casual pianoplaying, are her true occupations; as if cardinals flashing throughthe yards and the lush green of lawns and the maple's fat leavessignal a permanent arrival. There are dahlias on the dining table,yellow and red, late strawberries. It's still early, and Sadie hasan hour, maybe two, before the day's obligations intrude. The easytime, she thinks, the garden time. It's something she associateswith marriage-not the image of a couple in the garden, but theluxury of time alone at her own house. A luxury apparent only afterher mother's death, for which of course there is no compensation;but here is the second summer of such mornings, a time not yetoccluded by children. She is twenty-four years old. Here is hercoffee, the morning paper; in the back hall there are red geraniumsto plant in a window box. The day is already bright, and she opensthe living room drapes to the grass and pansies and oaks, and stops.There's a man on her lawn: light brown suit, cigar in hand, facingaway from her. Slim and coltish, an impatience in his stance, a lackof definition she usually associates with faces but here sees evenin the posture, the lines of his shoulders. It's Irving, her babybrother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGER, HAROLD
description: UNGER--Harold. We mourn the loss of our esteemed President who died on September 6, 2004. He served our 85 year old fraternal society with distinction and dedication for many years. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Shirley and his entire family. The First Plancher Benevolent Society Sandy Gotlib Secretary/Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLOGG, MARION S.
description: KELLOGG--Marion S. Entered into eternal rest Saturday, August 14, 2004, at age 84. Ms. Kellogg was born June 15, 1920 in Rochester, N.Y., the daughter of the late Howard and Stella (nee Dengler) Kellogg. She leaves her cousin, Dorothy (Sanders) McGee of Longport, N.J. Marion retired as the first woman Vice President of General Electric Company. She joined General Electric when she was Assistant Professor (and first woman instructor) in the Physics Department of Brown University. At General Electric, she held a variety of operating assignments in Human Resources Consulting including Marketing, Production and General Management. These culminated in her appointment as Vice President of Corporate Consulting Services in 1974. In this capacity, she managed an organization of about 1000 persons engaged in leading edge consulting in the fields of engineering, marketing and manufacturing. She retired from General Electric in 1983. During her career with GE, she served as a consultant in Europe, Africa and North and South America for a variety of businesses and companies. She was the author of five books and was awarded honorary doctorates by Saint Lawrence University, Russell Sage College, Babson College and Manhattanville College. She is the recipient of the Mary Parker Follett Award for her contributions to the application of management priciples. She was a Fellow of the International Academy of Management and member of Sigma Xi and the New York Academy of Sciences. She served on the Board of Directors of Emhart Corporation, Cigna Corp., Citytrust Bancorp and was a Trustee of Manhattanville College. Services and interment were held in Rochester, N.Y. To light a candle of condolence, please visit www. millerfuneralhomes.com

title: P.S.: They Left a Big Tip
description: LOS ANGELES - NO one could ever say that the Argentine actress Ma Maestro, who stars in the new movie "Motorcycle Diaries," is not willing to try new things. Since she moved to Los Angeles five years ago from Buenos Aires, she has taken up boxing and barge fishing and has gone scuba diving with a school of 60 feeding sharks.

title: Chargers' Rivers Knows His Time Will Come
description: SAN DIEGO - Two preseason games was not enough, it turns out. Philip Rivers, the San Diego Chargers' rookie quarterback, missed 25 days and 29 practices because of a contract holdout, and still thought he could beat out Drew Brees for the starting job. Coach Marty Schottenheimer seconded the motion, calling the competition wide open upon Rivers's arrival on Aug. 24.

title: 'The First Desire': The Sound and the Fury
description: THE FIRST DESIRE By Nancy Reisman. 310 pp. Pantheon Books. $24.

title: Edith Wharton: A Manhattan Literary Giant Who Didn't Love New York
description: EDITH WHARTON, whose deft portraits of the upper class are taken as definitive accounts of the late 19th century, remains one of the most potent names in the literature of New York. Not that she was a partisan of the city. Her portraits of New York were almost uniformly negative, and she left the city as soon as she could. That's why, in part, the physical traces of the author of "The Age of Innocence" and "The House of Mirth" are few and far between.

title: Having an Identity Crisis? You Must Be in Seventh Grade
description: MEN may be from Mars and women from Venus, but all teenagers are simply from Planet Hormone -- a rock that orbits erratically through middle school hallways, constantly threatening a meltdown of its inner core.

title: Wanted G.I. Surrenders To U.S. Army In Japan
description: CAMP ZAMA, Japan, Sept. 11 - Almost 40 years after disappearing one snowy night into the mists of North Korea, Charles Robert Jenkins, his face creased and his hair thinned, presented himself on Saturday here at the headquarters for the United States Army in Japan.

description: IN the 1940's and 50's, visual artists like Pollock and de Kooning flocked to the East End in awe of the light and creative possibilities of rural living.

description: DEMOCRACY MATTERS Winning the Fight Against Imperialism. By Cornel West. 229 pp. Penguin Press. $24.95.

title: Beijing's Allies Keep Most Seats in Hong Kong Vote, Exit Polls Show
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Sept. 13  Advocates of greater democracy scored little if any gains in elections here on Sunday, and fell short of winning a majority in the legislature, television exit polls and a partial count of the vote showed.

title: LAWSUIT SEEKS SPECIAL ELECTION
description: Two voting-rights lawyers urged a federal district judge on Wednesday to order a special election so that New Jersey voters can choose a successor to Governor McGreevey on the November ballot. The two lawyers, Bruce Afran and Carl Mayer, argue that a vacancy in the governor's office occurred on Aug. 12 when Mr. McGreevey announced his resignation. Because that date that falls more than 60 days before the next general election, a vacancy on that day would trigger a special election under the state Constitution. Judge Garrett E. Brown Jr. said after a hearing that he would issue a ruling this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZOUSMER, HELEN
description: ZOUSMER--Helen. 89, of Chicago, formerly of NYC and West Palm Beach, FL. Predeceased by her husband Perry and a daughter Jane. Lovingly survived by her son Arnold (Michele), daughter Rochelle Share; grandchildren Joanna, Alexandra and Max. Graveside service is at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Monday, 10:30 am.

title: Constance Napoli, Bruce O'Leary
description: Constance Maria Napoli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Napoli of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Bruce Richard O'Leary, a son of Jacqueline O'Leary of Willowbrook, Staten Island, and Richard O'Leary of Woodbridge, N.J. The Rev. Pierce Kenny performed the ceremony at Sacred Hearts and St. Stephen Church in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: The Habitats column on Aug. 29, about a house in Greenwich Village, misspelled the name of a Dickens character in "Great Expectations" whose attic was contrasted with the modern owners' archival approach to renovation. She was Miss Havisham, not Haversham.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Upper East Side Two-Bedroom $599,000 MANHATTAN: 333 East 80th Street, #5G A two-bedroom, one-bath apartment in a co-op building. The bathroom has been renovated recently, and the raised kitchen has new granite countertops. description: SAUNDERSON -- Alexander. Long time friend of the Metropolitan Opera and head of its National Council, died August 15th in Santa Barbara, CA. Memorial service for family and friends will be held at 4 P.M. September 16 at St. David's Church, Radnor, PA.

title: Southold and Shelter Island Sue Over Ferry Traffic
description: The Town Boards of Southold and Shelter Island voted last week to file suit in federal court to overturn zoning laws in the Town of East Hampton that bar vehicle ferries there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOGEL, RAY
description: FOGEL--Ray. 92, died September 10, 2004. Loving wife to Eli. Beloved mother of Peter, Kenneth and Jill. Grandmother to Leah and William. She will always be in our hearts.

title: The Week Ahead; REMEMBER THE BABE
description: Both towns just played host to national political conventions, but now the truly important contest begins. The Boston Red Sox arrive in New York on Friday, and the American League East pennant could be on the line.

title: Returning to the Scene of the Caper
description: YOU would have to return to the golden age of studio filmmaking, when there were more stars in Hollywood than there were dotting the heavens, to find another movie that wears its glamour and lack of significance with as much insouciance as "Ocean's Eleven." Released three years ago, Steven Soderbergh's evanescent entertainment didn't rack up the big awards and critical plaudits lavished on the director's previous heavy hitters, the Academy Award-winning "Traffic" and "Erin Brockovich." But this sly caper thriller, a nice-and-easy remake of the kitsch 1960 Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin vehicle, tickled the senses with a touch as light and expert as an old-school watchmaker's.

title: Conditions in Ohio Point to Kerry, but Bush Runs Strong
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 10 - It wasn't supposed to be like this.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: LOOT: And Other Stories, by Nadine Gordimer. (Penguin, $14.) This structurally diverse collection, Gordimer's first since 1991, the year she won the Nobel Prize, offers portraits of characters bowed by the complicated burden of loss. In the title story, set in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake, tragedy and opportunity present themselves in equal measure. "At times ironic, at others enraged, defiant or rueful, the work gathered here reflects the unflinching ferocity of its author's imagination," Claire Messud said in the Book Review last year.

title: Jacquelyn Ottman, Geoffrey Southworth
description: Jacquelyn Anne Ottman and Geoffrey Scott Southworth were married yesterday in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Anthony Stephens, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Osborn, a retirement community, where the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Ottman, live.

title: On a Brooklyn Street, the List of the Fallen Grows by Two
description: Of all the memories rattling around Deputy Inspector Vincent Di Donato's head yesterday, the one that stuck in his mind was one that he invented. The scene is Friday night in the crowded quarters of the detective squad in the 67th Precinct in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: The Beta Male article last Sunday, about gay fashion advice from shows like "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy," misstated the circulation of Cargo, a five-month-old Cond Nast shopping magazine for men, whose readers, the article speculated, could not all be gay. It is 300,000, not a million.

description: IT was a homecoming celebration of sorts at the Briarcliff Middle School and High School complex recently as a number of teachers readied their classrooms for the new school year.

description: Members of Iraq's merchant class are targets for kidnappers, robbers roam their cargo routes and their lives have narrowed to speedy commutes between offices and homes. Many wonder if the danger is too great for them to stay.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review in the Book Review on Aug. 15 about "Boiling Point," by Ross Gelbspan, on global warming, referred incorrectly to the author's participation in a Pulitzer Prize. As he writes in the book, he was not among the staff members of The Boston Globe named in 1984 for the prize, in local investigative specialized reporting about race relations. The Globe, however, designated him a "co-recipient" because of his editing of the series.

And it helped kick off a series of similarly lavish and compendious surveys at the Guggenheim Museum and elsewhere.

title: The Tour That Never Was
description: Welcome to the World Trade Center! Before we begin our tour, take a moment to get familiar with your player. When you arrive at our observation deck on the 107th floor, look for overhead banners displaying numbers placed near the windows. To hear an audio message, simply enter the number you see into your keypad. You may access these messages at your own pace and in any order you choose. Enjoy your tour!

description: Falling oil prices helped buoy the stock market in four days of trading last week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at its highest point since July 2.

title: How to Reinvent The G.O.P.
description: David Brooks always gets my attention with his insightful analysis. His approach to Islamic extremism, taxation, education, energy, social mobility and citizenship is thoughtful and exciting. He calls upon conservative and moderate Republicans to embrace these ideas, but I suspect he doesn't believe that will happen. Maybe what he is suggesting is a new party -- one that would attract Republicans and Democrats alike who are willing to break with tradition. I, for one, would be interested in that.

title: Corrections
description: An art listing on Page 99 of Arts & Leisure today misidentifies the current exhibition at the Plane Space gallery and misstates the neighborhood. The attraction is an installation, "Ideal City," by Kim Beck - not drawings, sculpture and video by Mark Woods. The gallery, at 102 Charles Street, is in Greenwich Village, not SoHo. (Go to Article)

title: Izzle
description: Bob Newhart did it. Fran Drescher did it. Tens of thousands of Web sites have done it. And now, in the pages of this very paper, there it is -- a word modified with the ubiquitous izzle. Some clever Times copy editor, for a June article about Chrysler's new 300C sedan, created the headline, "Fo' Shizzle, That Big Bad Chrysler Really Does Sizzle."

title: Powell Meets the Press
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has been trying to walk a pretty thin line throughout the campaign season, showing his allegiance to President Bush while not venturing as far out as some of his administration colleagues have in portraying Senate John Kerry as soft on national security issues.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Alfred Solomon, 104, Innovator in the Sale of Hats, Dies
description: Alfred Z. Solomon, who transformed the way American women buy fashionable hats and in later years became famous as the cigar-chomping dean of the Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga, N.Y., died on Sept. 4 in Saratoga. He was 104.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hernndez Continues to Pitch Like the Ace of Pinstripes
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 - Orlando Hernndez had just struck out a cleanup hitter who has 125 runs batted in, ending the third inning with the bases loaded. Too early to celebrate? Not for Hernndez, who is savoring every moment of his reincarnation.

title: One More WB Show About Troubled Youth (But These Teenagers Actually Grow Up)
description: THE WB network has become almost exclusively associated with youth. That may be about to change with the premiere of "Jack & Bobby" at 9 tonight. The new series centers on a single mother (Christine Lahti) and her two high-school-age sons (Matt Long and Logan Lerman), one of whom grows up to be president of the United States. As a result, the show looks forward and back at the same time, exploring issues of politics and current events. Interspersed with contemporary scenes about the young men's formative experiences are documentary-like interviews with people who talk about the brother who became president 40 years later.

title: PHOTO-OP
Paid Notice: Deaths   CALMENSON, LEO
description: CALMENSON--Leo. (June 30, 1919) of Scottsdale, Arizona passed away on June 12, 2004. Born and raised in NYC, Leo spent time in Tucson, Arizona where he graduated from Tucson Sr. High in 1938. He attended University of Arizona. Leo worked for Bell Laboratories after WWII, but eventually became a successful independent insurance broker with the Traveler's in NY. He is predeceased by his beloved wife, Beatrice (nee Bloom). His last five years were spent living in Scottsdale. He is survived by his daughter Amy Korn, son-inlaw Ron, grandchildren Ellyn and Benjamin of Paradise Valley, Arizona, brother Carl of Miami Beach, Florida, nieces, nephews, cousins and many friends. Leo was a man who was well loved and admired by all, of sharp mind and wit and "a character who had a lot of character." He thought of life not as one big problem but as one big mystery. His loss is great and he will surely be missed by all. He will forever be in our hearts.

title: The Neurologist
description: In a workplace -- where scrubs and sensible shoes are always in fashion, Dr. Teena Shetty violates the dress code with flair. Dr. Shetty, 30, typically wears high heels, flowing skirts and fine jewelry (along with a white doctor's coat) while seeing patients at Massachusetts General and Brigham and Women's Hospitals in Boston, where she is pursuing a fellowship in neuromuscular disease. Here, though, she is dressed for a night out, in a Jane Laug silk top bought at Barneys last spring and a tulle skirt she found in Beijing this summer. Her lizard pumps, also from last spring, are by Prada, and so is the bag, which is several years old. Her pearl earrings are by Mikimoto, and her pendant, like most of her jewelry, is from India.

title: Yipes, Clinton! That Could Be Me
description: In the days following Bill Clinton's quadruple bypass last Monday, Dr. Harvey S. Hecht, the director of preventive cardiology at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, received twice as many calls as usual from concerned middle-aged people, largely men. Most of the callers were worried that they might be just like Mr. Clinton -- seemingly healthy, cardiological time bombs.

title: 'Up From Zero': Who Can Reach the Dead?

title: Once Upon a Time in Breughelland
description: ONE of the great nights of my operagoing life came in September 2002, with a haunting production of Messiaen's mystical and challenging "St. Franois d'Assise," its American stage premiere at the San Francisco Opera. Thanks to its adventurous (and now lame-duck) general manager, Pamela Rosenberg, the company will present the American stage premiere of another exhilarating and important contemporary opera, Gyorgy Ligeti's apocalyptic romp "Le Grand Macabre," opening on Oct. 29.

title: At Loggerheads Over Landmarks
description: YONKERS - IN the 13 years since the City of Yonkers passed its local landmark law, the Landmarks Preservation Board has designated two historic districts and four individual sites. Halcyon Place, with its French Second Empire and Queen Anne homes, and Cedar Knolls, a lush, tree-lined neighborhood of Colonial and Tudor Revival houses mostly built in the 1920's, as well as the Eleazar Hart House, Fisher/Father Divine House, the Old Stone Cotton Mill and Alder Manor, were all designated by the board and the Yonkers City Council, which has final say.

title: In a Tidal Wave, China's Masses Pour From Farm to City
description: BEIJING - ANYONE who has visited China's ballooning, chaotic cities cannot help but notice the construction cranes. It is not unheard of to count 50 cranes, maybe more, rising between new concrete apartment towers or thickets of half-built skyscrapers. They twist in the twilight haze like enormous insects.

description: Mojave Desert

title: Katherine Frost, Robert Huntington III
description: Katherine Ann Frost and Robert Hubbard Huntington III were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Westerly, R.I. The Rev. Robert Anthony officiated, and the Rev. Marcel Taillon, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Nostalgia, Anyone? Hope Rises at Forest Hills
description: Although much of the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium in Queens has fallen into disrepair, the stoic stone eagles still standing solemn sentry around its top rim retain their grandeur.

title: Memories in High Relief
description: WHILE a lot of attention has been paid to the 9/11 memorial in Lower Manhattan, not enough has been focused on the memorials that are springing up throughout Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey. That's a shame, because each has a special importance. And with each new design or proposal, more questions arise: When are there enough memorials? Does every town have to have its own?

description: Correction Appended

title: The Beating Heart of Medieval Cairo
description: Scores of human teeth are jumbled together in a small glass box that is on display within the imposing, honey-colored limestone towers of Zuweila Gate, one of four spectacular portals remaining from Cairo's medieval walls. A few hundred years ago, supplicants seeking relief from sickness or other evils slipped a (usually rotten) tooth behind the metal cladding of the hulking wooden doors as offerings to a local faith healer believed to haunt the place. The doors revealed their interior secrets during renovations completed last year. I, too, often seek a certain relief by trekking to Zuweila Gate -- or Bab Zuweila, as it is known in Arabic. I do not petition the ghost; I find the more tangible spirit of the place captivating, an antidote to the endless tensions of the region.

title: MetroStars Rebound Despite Slow Start
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 11 - The MetroStars had plenty of excuses at their disposal had they needed them Saturday night.

description: HURRICANES may seem indiscriminate in their fury, but the storms that have struck Florida in the last 30 days prove those taking the hardest hit often live in mobile homes or other low-income areas.

title: Renovations in Rome Create a Clash of Images
description: ROME - OVER the last several years, Romans have become used to the way in which some of their oldest churches, monuments and palaces are renovated.

title: College Bound Doesn't Mean Far From Home
description: FOR decades, when the state's high school graduates went off to college, most headed out of state, going to Boston, New York and Washington. But in the last few years that exodus has slowed and now more graduating high school seniors are attending colleges in the state than out, boosting admissions at such colleges as the University of Connecticut, Quinnipiac University and at community colleges.

description: SAMMY'S HILL By Kristin Gore. 387 pp. Miramax Books/Hyperion. $23.95.

Friends, colleagues and patients welcome to attend. Inquiries: Diane 212-736-9696.

title: PHOTO-OP
The Girl on the Platform
description: SHE lay crumpled and silent and dirty, but breathing, peacefully. A thought rang up as I stood on the platform: Should I stop and help? The next train was approaching, and I was in a hurry. Everyone draws a boundary between which human tragedies to ignore and which to confront. I was about to cross mine.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: HOW did this one get lost in the box-office shuffle? Gwyneth Paltrow plays Sylvia Plath, the 20th century's ultimate American suicidal-feminist-martyr poet, in Christine Jeffs's SYLVIA (2003). Ms. Paltrow is fiercely believable and intellectually radiant in this story of Plath's troubled marriage to the British poet Ted Hughes (Daniel Craig). Ted is awfully enlightened for a 1950's husband. When Sylvia deals with writer's block by baking cakes and pies, he tells her: "You've got to write. That's what poets do." Unfortunately he's the more successful of the two, which brings female admirers in droves. Sylvia becomes convinced that he's having an affair, and she's not imagining it. "The truth comes to me," she tells him when he returns from a tryst. "And the truth loves me" -- Saturday at 11:30 a.m. on Cinemax.

Fokine's varied ballets demonstrated the validity of both the one-act dance-drama and what is now known as abstract ballet, as audiences will discover when American Ballet Theater performs at City Center this fall (Oct.20-Nov.7). It will present a season filled with new productions as well as revivals of modern-ballet classics.

title: Dog Days, For Swimming
description: DOGS may be mythologized as man's best friend, but they've had a heck of a time parlaying that high regard into much in the way of political power. Maybe they are overlooked because of their goofy nature or their steadfast loyalty, or maybe it's just that they don't speak the language. But political fortunes are seldom static, and those dog years spent in the political wilderness are now, as anyone who looks up and down the county today can tell, as much a relic as an Adlai pin.

He was an Assistant Principal at P.S. 157 Bronx and in charge of remedial reading for the District. He made a big difference to the children with reading difficulties. He left a wife, Mildred, two loving sons, Dr. Richard Zeitlin and Dr. Alan Zeitlin and his daughter-in-law Sherri Zeitlin and four magnificent grandchildren, Ferrin, Brigitte, Sam and Eleanor. The funeral will take place on Sunday at the Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, at 1 PM. The family requests that contributions in Paul's name be made to the Ferrin Randall Zeitlin Foundation for Sarcoma Research at the Parkway Hospital Administration, 70-35 113 St., Forest Hills, NY 11365.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, REES
description: HARRIS--Rees. 87, of 71 Between The Lake Road, Four Winds, died Sunday, September 7, 2004, at the Sharon Hospital in Sharon, CT, after being stricken at his home. He was the husband of Virginia (Lloyd) Harris. Mr. Harris was born in Irvington-on-theHudson, NY, on August 26, 1917, son of the late Ieuan and Laura (Houghton) Harris. Mr. Harris was a well known and respected businessman in the Town of Salisbury. He was a 1936 graduate of the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, CT. From there he earned his B.A. degree from Williams College in 1940. Following graduation he enrolled at the Ryan School of Aeronautics and earned his commercial pilot's license in 1941. With the coming of WWII Mr. Harris enlisted in the army in 1942. From 1942 to 1943 he served with the 87th 10th Mountain Division. From 1944 to 1945 he was attached to the 2nd Division 38th Inf. He participated in the Aleutian Campaign in 1943 and later saw combat in both the European, and Pacific-Asiatic Theaters of operations. Mr. Harris was awarded the Asiatic-Pacific Defense Medal and Ribbon with Bronze Service Star, the European-African-Middle Eastern Ribbon with 4 Bronze Service Stars, and the Distinguished Unit Citation. Mr. Harris was discharged July 12, 1954, after rising to the rank of Captain. On July 26, 1988, by Executive order of the President of the United States, Captain Harris was awarded the Bronze Star Medal for "meritorius achievement in ground combat against the armed enemy during World War II in the European-African-Middle Eastern Theater of Operations." While living in the Town of Salisbury Mr. Harris was an active member in many civic organizations including: serving as a member of the Connecticut General Assembly in 1951, a past president of the Sharon Hospital Board of Directors, a member for more than 50 years of the National Ski Patrol and the Catamount Ski Patrol in Hillsdale, NY. A past trustee of the Indian Mountain School. Mr. Harris was the founder of the Salisbury Volunteer Ambulance Service and had served as the chairman of the Governor's Commission of E.M.S. Mr. Harris also served on the Board of the Friends of the Bermuda Aquarium. Mr. Harris was also a member of the Mid-Ocean Club and the Bermuda Yacht Club both on the Island of Bermuda. A member of the Sharon Country Club, Sharon, CT, the Connanicut Yacht Club of Jamestown, RI, and the Racquet and Tennis Club and EnglishSpeaking Union both in New York City. Mr. Harris was a member of St. John's Church in Salisbury and a member of Montgomery Lodge in Lakeville and the Order of St. John's Knight of New York. In addition to his wife Mr. Harris is survived by his two children: William R. Harris Jr. of Lakeville, CT, and Laura H. Harris of Wakefield, RI. His brother David F. Harris of Salisbury, CT, and three grandchildren. Mr. Harris was predeceased by his first wife of 31 years Harriet (Bontecou) Harris, his step - mother Gwendolyn M. Harris and his brother John H. Harris. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, September 15, 2004, at 11 a.m. in St. John's Church, Main St, Salisbury, CT 06068. There are no calling hours. Flowers may be sent or contributions in his memory be made to the Bermuda Aquarium, 40 North Shore Rd., Hamilton Parrish Flatts, Bermuda, FL04 or to The Order of St. John Priory in the United States of America, 150 East 55th Street, New York City, NY 10022. For more information contact, NewkirkPalmer Funeral Home, 118 Main St, North Canan, CT 06018, 860-824-7350.

Even your coverage was similar to coverage of the Supreme Court, where there are almost always obligatory references to the robustness of the septuagenarian and octogenarian justices and how they supposedly possess more energy now than they did 40 years ago. Does anyone really believe this?

Developers attributed some of the increase to housing construction subsidized by city and state programs.

title: Japan Torqued, Melted, Reconfigured
description: KNOWN best in the United States for his image of a beer bottle twisted into an ungodly carcass by the atomic blast at Nagasaki, Shomei Tomatsu is one of Japan's most influential postwar photographers. In the series from which that photograph comes, "11:02 Nagasaki" (named for the exact time the bomb hit), and in other series, including "Home," "Chewing Gum and Chocolate" and "Oh Shinjuku!," Mr. Tomatsu has captured the fragmentation of Japanese urban life. He sometimes crops his photographs in abstract ways or prints them in high contrast. It is hard to find a boring Tomatsu photograph. But it is also often hard to tell what precisely is going on in his pictures. His kind of expressionistic documentary style, novel in Japan in the early 1960's, provoked a debate in the nation's photographic community. In the pages of the journal Asahi Camera, the photojournalist Natori Yonosuke inveighed against the young generation of photographers for discarding storytelling and "reality" in favor of expression and "image." Mr. Tomatsu (born in 1930) defended himself and his peers, arguing that expressiveness in no way precluded a "respect for a specific reality." And by the mid-1960's Mr. Tomatsu, along with Daido Moriyama, Eikoh Hosoe and Masahisa Fukase, had defined a new kind of photography in Japan. Whether it's a picture of a prostitute glowering at the camera and blowing what look like rays of smoke out her nose ("Aprs Guerre, Prostitute, Nagoya"), a shot of a single figure hurled through blurred space ("Protest, Tokyo") or an image of a screaming long-haired youth ("Underground City, Coca-Cola, Tokyo"), Mr. Tomatsu's work deals with the clashes between Japanese tradition and Western modernity. "Shomei Tomatsu: Skin of the Nation," an exhibition of 260 photographs at the Japan Society in New York (Sept. 22-Jan. 2), organized by the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in association with the Japan Society, will present several works from each of his major series made during the last five decades. It is Mr. Tomatsu's first major American retrospective.

title: New Jersey: Seeking to Recapture Past Glory
description: LONG BRANCH - ONCE, this was the playground of presidents. Over the years, seven presidents visited this strip of beachfront while they were in office; they stayed in a string of elegant hotels and hobnobbed with captains of industry. Later, the ambience descended to honky-tonk, with a funky boardwalk amusement park, a Ferris wheel, a water slide and a Haunted Mansion that burned to the ground along with the fishing pier in 1987.

title: Long Term in Drug Case Fuels Debate on Sentencing
description: Weldon H. Angelos, a 25-year-old producer of rap records, will be sentenced Tuesday in federal court in Salt Lake City for selling several hundred dollars in marijuana on each of three occasions, his first offenses. He faces 63 years in prison.

title: Lincoln Center Goes Moulin Rouge
description: DANCE and drama meet too rarely on New York stages, but Lincoln Center Theater struck gold when it most recently mixed those media. Susan Stroman's scintillating dance play "Contact" began life on Lincoln Center's small Mitzi E. Newhouse stage. Now the choreographer Martha Clarke moves into the same space with an intriguing array of collaborators to conjure late-19th-century Paris and the circle of artists and demimondaines surrounding Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec in "Belle poque." The fin of this particular sicle appears to hold a fascination for Ms. Clarke: her "Vienna: Lusthaus," recently revived to acclaim Off Broadway, evoked the same era. Once again her co-author is Charles L. Mee, a playwright known for his unfettered -- on occasion rather too unfettered -- imagination. The show, which begins previews on Oct. 28 and opens on Nov. 21, is set in and around the celebrated Moulin Rouge. It will employ the fall season's most enticingly assorted array of actors, singers and dancers, including the venerated operatic mezzo-soprano Joyce Castle and Mabou Mines' Ruth Maleczech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOGAERTS, WINOC

Beloved father of Andree and grandfather of Isabelle, Matthew and William. Memorial service Thursday, September 16, 2004 at 6PM at St. Frances Xavier Church at 46 West 16th St.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM -- SCENE STEALERS: Imelda Staunton; The Performances to Watch
description: IMELDA STAUNTON is one of Britain's most admired stage actors, with three Oliviers -- the British Tony -- and a rsum stocked with prestigious films. But despite having played such memorable characters as the deliriously giddy social climber in Ang Lee's "Sense and Sensibility" (1995) and the neurotic, death-haunted young mother in Kenneth Branagh's "Peter's Friends" (1992), she is barely known here. Her film roles tend to be small, and she disappears into them thoroughly. With her button eyes and snub nose, Ms. Staunton looks too wholesome to be anyone's idea of a star. So leave it to Mike Leigh -- a director who has helped make stars but cares only about actors -- to cast her not just in a leading role but in an utterly dominant one.

Retired Vice President J.P. Morgan Bank. Memorial Service October 9, 2004, 11 AM, St. Cassian Church, Upper Montclair, NJ. Donations to Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Sta., PO Box 4777, NY, NY 10163 or www.michaeljfox.org.

title: Cherish a Rare Encounter With the Scarlet Tanager
description: Behind our home in Easton, Conn., my father planted three blueberry bushes that we covered with tobacco netting in the summer, when the bushes were about to bear fruit. The netting was intended to keep birds, mostly catbirds, away from the ripe berries. But they occasionally would find a hole or go under the netting.

title: A Cad for All Seasons?
description: LIKE Chekhov's three sisters, or Godzilla for that matter, the Cockney womanizer Alfie belongs to a certain time and place. You cannot easily update and relocate him, as people do with Shakespeare's characters. Let Romeo and Juliet leave the balconies of Verona for the fire escapes of the West Side. Let there be a "Hamlet Goes Business" (to cite Aki Kaurismaki's reinvention of the prince for modern-day corporate Finland). Godzilla, by contrast, never feels fully himself when he's away from Tokyo, as Roland Emmerich inadvertently proved in his 1998 remake. What chance might there be, then, for an "Alfie Goes Manhattan"?

title: Q. How Was Your Vacation? A. Pretty Newsy, Thanks

All questions below are exactly the sort of softballs you'd toss if you were interviewing yourself.

The open garage door revealed a tarp-covered motorcycle and a woodworking shop -- a typical weekend scene in cul-de-sac New York.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 11 - The Afghan government on Saturday announced the removal of the powerful governor of Herat, in western Afghanistan, one of the country's longest standing warlords. The move appeared to be intended to undercut the governor, one of the major opponents to President Hamid Karzai, before the Oct. 9 presidential elections.

title: Farewell to Pets, and to Free Breakfast?
description: RYAN SHERMAN doesn't mince words with apartment hunters. "When I take a client out, I prepare them for the worst," said Mr. Sherman, a broker and executive vice president at Century 21 William B. May. Gone are the days when his clients could look at apartments and have a day to mull over the options. Now he insists that they come armed with bank statements, investment account information, a letter from their employer, at least two personal references and, most important, a checkbook.

title: Allies Against Terror, Sliding Farther Apart

Putin of Russia and found a man with whom he could do business. But if there is any soul-searching going on today in the Bush administration, it is over why the latest attacks by Chechen terrorists in Russia have deepened a recent estrangement between the two countries.

title: Czeslaw Milosz, 1911-2004
description: "The death of a man is like the fall of a mighty nation," declared Czeslaw Milosz in one of the many poems in which he speculated upon the experience of dying. The poem explains that the fall occurs because the nation is no longer mighty, "its cities are empty, its population dispersed / . . . its mission forgotten, its language lost." Yet it is the death of this man that is like the fall of a mighty nation, but a nation full and undispersed, its mission honored and its language imperishable. The magnitude of Czeslaw Milosz, who died in Krakow on Aug. 14 at the age of 93, is almost unimaginable. He was a hero of the history of his time and a hero of the literature of his time. For friends and for strangers, for lovers of liberty and for lovers of beauty, he was, for more than half a century, an indispensable man. Milosz discharged his obligations to his age and his obligations to his soul with the same diligence and the same depth. The stability of his mind, its preternatural composure, was one of the great sanctuaries of the 20th century, a prophecy of the eventual emancipation. He had the rare gift of knowing how to be at once troubled and unperturbed. When light was needed, he was light; when stone was needed, he was stone. Milosz's spiritual intensity never interfered with his historical clarity. His inner freedom seems never to have failed him. His life and his work justified, in all their complexities, the most elementary belief in the power of the truth. He had the face of a hawk and the heart of a dove. He was as tough as time, or almost.

title: Music Preview: Famous and New
description: TRUE to fashion, in Westchester County, the coming music season embraces the beloved old composers and mostly ignores more recent ones -- although the 20th century has finally made it onto the charts, judging from the popularity of composers like Prokofiev and Stravinsky. Concerts are long on the standard repertory and short on the new works that tend to send audiences home in a huff.

title: Amy Tamez, Patrick Layng
description: Amy Lynn Tamez, the daughter of Christine and Donald E. Tamez of Joliet, Ill., was married yesterday to Patrick James Layng, a son of Deborah and George R. Layng of Ramsey, N.J. The Rev. Anthony Schueller performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York.

title: How to Reinvent The G.O.P.
description: In the 1960's, Milton Friedman argued that the military draft was not only a tax but also the very worst kind: a tax extracted in kind, just as feudal lords extracted labor from peasants. Mandatory national service is worse yet, because it conscripts people -- specifically, young adults with little political power -- to fulfill the dreams of social engineers. It is, pure and simple, involuntary servitude, something that is neither progressive nor conservative.

title: Fashion Stills
description: Narrative crept back into art through a side door marked fashion photography. In April 1967, French Vogue published a spread by Bob Richardson, the American photographer, that soon became a legend. Informally christened "the Greek trip" by Richardson's admirers, the spread featured Donna Mitchell, a striking brunet model, hanging out on the Aegean island of Rhodes with a male companion.

title: In Orvieto, Stories of Heaven and Hell
description: The cable car scoots more or less straight uphill from the modern railway station at Orvieto Scalo to the medieval town of Orvieto. My inner 5-year-old would like nothing better than to spend my entire time here riding up and down on the Little Funicolare That Could. But the adult I've become disembarks at the terminal and heads up the Corso Cavour, the gently curving main street lined with Renaissance palazzi and tempting shops selling local cheeses, wine and examples of the culinary miracles that can be performed with the flesh of the domestic pig and the wild boar.

title: Depression, a Frequent Visitor to Wall St.
description: EARLY one afternoon in July, Dennis J. Bertrum, a former top brokerage executive at Prudential Securities, leapt out of the bedroom window of his 26th-floor apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: SEVEN BRIDES FOR SEVEN BROTHERS 50TH-ANNIVERSARY TWO-DISC SPECIAL EDITION (Warner Home Video, Oct. 12)
description: One of the most cheerfully disreputable movie musicals ever made, Stanley Donen's "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers" is the story of seven mountain men -- the eldest played by the preposterously manly Howard Keel in a buckskin jacket -- who, yearning for the company of womenfolk, kidnap some flouncy fillies from a nearby town. Frightened and saddened at first, the women eventually warm to their captors and happily wed them -- this is Stockholm Syndrome in Cinemascope. While those with overly delicate feminist sensibilities may find the sexual politics of "Seven Brides" too horrifying to contemplate, the rest of us will want to play the barn-raising sequence -- choreographed by Michael Kidd, it is one of the most rousing dance numbers ever put on screen -- over and over again. In a commemorative featurette included here, we learn that one of the musical numbers, in which the mountain brothers lament how tired they are of "sleeping with sheep," alarmed the censors at the time. The line stayed in the song, but no sheep, fleece-clad or otherwise, were allowed to appear in the scene. Our lamblike innocence thus protected, we're that much freer to enjoy the sultry vision of Julie Newmeyer (later known as Julie Newmar, TV's Catwoman), in a wasp-waisted white corset and bloomers, lasciviously lounging on one of the brothers' vacated beds, wondering which one of them slept in it. STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

description: Tara Joy Kates, the daughter of Robin Kates and Chester Kates, both of Teaneck, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Bryan Michael Burt, the son of Jacqueline Burt of Clifton, N.J., and the late Dr. Michael Burt. description: The first time I became a refugee, I was 19, and I became a refugee inside my own country. I was born in Fishkhabour, in northern Iraq. There were about 200 Christian families in the village, and we were farmers.

His father, George Herbert Walker Bush, the 41st president of the United States, was the subject of perhaps a half-dozen books during his time in office. George W. Bush, the 43rd president, is already the subject of more than 100.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about New Jersey's growing reputation as a state hospitable to lesbians and gay men misspelled part of the name of a gay advocacy group. It is the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, not Lamda.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM -- SCENE STEALERS: Eve; The Performances to Watch
description: THE pretty young hip-hop artist Eve has a list of acting credits that includes both "Barbershop" movies, a forthcoming comedy in a similar vein called "The Cookout" and her own sitcom on UPN. But "The Woodsman," a tough-minded indie opening Dec. 24, gives her a chance to get serious, and she makes the most of it.

title: Page Two: Sept. 5-11; OFFICIATING, ANYONE?
description: Serena Williams received four terrible calls in the third set of her loss to Jennifer Capriati in the 2004 United States Open. But Williams may forever be remembered for her classy behavior afterward. She threw no temper tantrums, called for no investigations and did not touch the fine line between whining and justly criticizing the officials in her post-match news conference. In return, Williams received an apologetic phone call from officials at the United States Tennis Association, the day after the match. Chris Broussard

title: How a Hedge Cutter Helped Shape Tennis History
description: John McEnroe has yet to mention me during his tennis broadcasts or on his noisy new talk show, which is odd, considering that this is the 30th anniversary of a pivotal summer on his path to tennis immortality -- and I helped clear the path.

title: Spray What?
description: WHILE the vibrancy on coastal points along southern New Jersey typically wanes in the fading sunlight of September, the marsh at Cape May Point bustles with activity well beyond Labor Day.

title: Peruvian Train
description: To the Editor: Regarding "The High Road in the Andes" (Aug. 15) by Robin Cembalest, in 2003 the face of extreme wealth became symbolized in the luxury train Hiram Bingham to Machu Picchu. This is a $416.50 (round trip), three-and-a-half-hour ride in a land where the descendants of the Incas are either unemployed or live on less than $100 per month.

title: That Bulbous Nose! Those Dancing Feet! That Shiny New Gun!
description: THE W. C. FIELDS COMEDY COLLECTION (Universal, Nov. 9, five discs) The character W. C. Fields perfected was dead set against work, thrift, sobriety, chastity, honesty in general, dutifulness of any kind and compassion in any measure. And if you don't feel even a glimmer of affinity for him, you've probably been a misery to people all your life. The iconography of Fields -- the bulbous, gin-reddened nose, the rotund build, the top hat or skimmer -- may be more familiar to moviegoers under 40 than the man's work is. And those encountering Fields for the first time in "International House," "You Can't Cheat an Honest Man," "It's a Gift," "My Little Chickadee" and "The Bank Dick" may at first assume he's nothing more than a middle-aged guy doing groaning gags about mothers-in-law and wives. Which would be as wrongheaded as saying that Henry Miller represented the smutty side of Fodor's.

title: Backpacker's Newly Charted Course: Profits
description: In Dean E. Fengya's trips to 100 countries over the last 25 years, he has nearly seen and done it all. He has been a cook at ski resorts in the Bavarian Alps. He has lived with the Bedouins in Egypt. And, to save up for his voyages around the world, he ventured to the sunny climes of Bay Head, where he worked as a life guard and a waiter.

title: Black Clouds for Dolphins; Blue Skies for Titans
description: MIAMI, Sept. 11 - The chants of "Fire Wannstedt" began early on Saturday at Pro Player Stadium. So did the frenzied booing of Jay Fiedler, the Miami Dolphins' starting quarterback. The Dolphins and their coach, Dave Wannstedt, are under siege, and the season has just begun.

title: Painters Who Specialize In Sleight of Hand
description: LIKE others, I suspect, I never tire of the story of Zeuxis and Parrhasios, a pair of early Greek painters who staged a contest to determine the superior artist of the two. Zeuxis, we are told, painted grapes that were so realistic that birds swooped down to eat them. Zeuxis then asked Parrhasios to pull aside the curtain covering his painting. When Zeuxis learned that the curtain itself was a painting, he conceded defeat: his work had managed to fool birds, but Parrhasios had fooled him.

title: Buildings Fit for a Parliament and a President
description: September

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   JAFFIN, PAULINE LOWENBERG
description: JAFFIN--Pauline Lowenberg March 4, 1911-Sept 12, 1949 Wife of Edward Jaffin, deceased. Dearest mother and grandmother, sister and aunt. You live in our hearts and we will love you forever. Jackie, Bobbie, Paula, Mary, Lillian, Judy and Nina

title: Even More Modern
description: THE completion of Yoshio Taniguchi's design for the renovation and expansion of the Museum of Modern Art's West 53rd Street complex is one of the most anticipated architectural events in New York in years. The project's practical aim was to give clarity and order to a jumble of buildings and additions built up over 65 years. But the Modern's ultimate ambitions are far more sweeping: to create a more intimate experience between art and viewer, to come to terms with the rapid pace of technology and to redefine how the story of modern art is told. Oh, and also to define the new museum for the 21st century.

title: A Moderate Wind at Open-Mike Night
description: Morris Plains - DRIFTING into a drowsy reverie, Tony Pisciotta, a postal worker by day, leaned back on his wooden stool and strummed a lullaby of a song he had written for his "lady," who was seated four rows ahead of him in a small sea of folding chairs. His salt-and-pepper hair and unscuffed white sneakers shook, causing the plywood stage to creak. A sprinkling of applause skittered across the room, and his time was up. Then a different 50-year-old white guy in khaki shorts took the stage.

title: Yellow Fever
description: I understand the concerns that for some the Live Strong bracelet may be just the flavor of the month of causes and that the Lance Armstrong Foundation may not be the beneficiary of all that eBay money (Consumed, Rob Walker, Aug. 29). However, it is worth saying that when you are feeling sick and tired from fighting cancer, it's pretty cool to see that yellow bracelet on a passerby.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUCHINER, A. MARTIN
description: STUCHINER--A. Martin. On September 11, 2004. Beloved husband of Terry. Devoted father of David and Kathy, Ann, Robert and Judith. Loving grandfather of Jacob, Emily and Sara. Dear brother of Milton and Dorothy. Friends may call Monday at Frank E. Campbell from 7-9 PM. Services Tuesday, September 14, 9:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORETZ, DAVID, M.D.
description: KORETZ--David, M.D. September 3, 2004. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Cherished father of Robert and Bonnie Koretz, Ellen and Eric Bromberg, Nancy and Matt Weingast, and Karen and Rich Gordon. Adoring grandfather of Jeffrey, Daniel, Leah, Jessica, Henry, Jason, Joshua, Brett, Lily and Melissa. Brother of Kenneth and Carole Koretz, Susan and Paul Kramer, and Lynne Gordon. He will be sorely missed and forever in our hearts. Please send donations to the Todd Saslow Campership Fund, c/o Foundation for Diabetes, 112 Prospect Street, POB 133, Ridgewood, N.J. 07450 or your favorite charity.

title: Imagining Toyland Without One of Its Giants
description: Panorama City, Calif. - LABOR DAY weekend at the Wal-Mart here was a great shopping scene for children. As they pushed carts brimming with new notebooks, clothes and shoes through the aisles, they got a small preview of what might be in store for them this Christmas season -- when their parents return to Wal-Mart to rifle through the low-priced Barbie dolls, Beyblade tops, Cabbage Patch Kids and Hot Wheels cars that are already beginning to show up.

title: Tobacco Barns Becoming Endangered in Maryland
description: HUNTINGTOWN, Md. - Inside the big red tobacco barn, John Prouty's mind meanders through the decades. He can almost see the canopy of stalks, almost smell their sweet scent as he fondly recalls how he stood about 25 feet up on a wooden tier as a child, hanging tobacco to cure.

title: Glen Cove's Debt Rating Falls From A3 to Baa2
description: Moody's Investors Service has downgraded its long-term debt rating for the City of Glen Cove from A3 to Baa2, a two-grade drop and the second reduction in 14 months.

title: Republicans Pack Punch. Democrats Take It. (For Now)
description: DO Republicans play a rougher game of politics than Democrats?

title: Long Island: Asking Voters to Buy More Open Land
description: COMPARED with Nassau County, its neighbor to the west, Suffolk County still has glorious expanses of open land, but many of these beautiful vistas are being lost. As a result, governments and preservationists are continually looking for ways to save land from development.

title: Decorate a Couch With a Tourist
description: Casey Fenton says he has never seen "The Man Who Came to Dinner." Maybe he should, to understand the potential risks in his newest venture, the CouchSurfing Project, in which he and his partners have set up a Web site that guides house guests to willing hosts around the world.

title: Mayfield Wins, and Field for Runoff Takes Shape
description: RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 11 - The tension was palpable, the stakes as significant as for any race in the 2004 Nascar Nextel Cup season. It was inevitable that wrecks would follow Saturday night in the Chevy Rock & Roll 400 at Richmond International Raceway.

title: As Island Death Toll Rises, Hurricane Gains in Strength
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 11 - Hurricane Ivan spun away from Jamaica on Saturday and intensified to a dangerous Category 5 storm with winds up to 165 miles an hour as it headed toward the Gulf Coast of the United States, with the Cayman Islands and Cuba immediately in its sights.

title: Forget It?
description: A friend of mine said something horrible recently: "I'm just so over 9/11." We'd been watching TV -- a fluffy gossip show featuring models as reporters -- and during a long commercial break I'd picked up the channel changer and happened across a cable-news discussion of the war on terrorism. One of the experts used the phrase "twin towers." Another mentioned the "hunt for Osama." Their language seemed dated, musty and faintly embarrassing, and I quickly switched back to "Extra." That's when my friend made her comment, adding this: "I'm ashamed of myself, but it's true. I'm totally over it."

A Faded City Builds Its Fountain of Hope

title: How Many Deaths Are Too Many?
description: Washington - IN the fall of 1965, the death toll for American troops in Vietnam quietly passed 1,000. The escalation in the number of American forces was just underway, the antiwar movement was still in its infancy and the word "quagmire" was not yet in common usage.

title: In Search of Our Next Big Topic of Conversation
description: IT'S been a long time since married women made much of a mark on television. Yet suddenly the fall season is all Emma Bovary all the time.

title: A Softer Man
description: This fall, Stacey Bendet, -- the designer of the cult-favorite women's label Alice & Olivia , is introducing a line of men's sweaters, called Anthony & Mo. Made of supersoft 12-gauge cashmere (and named for two of Ms. Bendet's best friends from the University of Pennsylvania), the sweaters are most notable for their brilliant color combinations: rich, heathered neutrals offset by buoyant blue, lime, lavender and orange. The strongest ones in the collection (which ranges from $330 to $550 at Scoop stores) include a featherweight baseball-shirt sweater, just right for early fall, and reversible, double-faced hoodies and crewnecks, which are substantial enough to serve as cool-weather jackets straight into winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, IRVING
description: HOROWITZ--Irving. The Kinoy family wishes to extend their heartfelt condolences to the Horowitz family at the loss of their beloved friend, Irving Horowitz.

title: Reservation Comes Into Play as Officials Make Water-Management Decisions
description: MIAMI, Sept. 11 - The wetlands of southern Florida were formed for, or at least well adapted to, the weather of the hurricane belt. Most of its natural vegetation grows low, except for the oak trees. Its native animals are built low to the ground; alligators hunker down and present their tails to the wind when it gets wild.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the 'listed at' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS
description: Sept. 7: Robert Zemeckis's first film, "I Wanna Hold Your Hand" (Universal), a comedy about the pandemonium set off by the Beatles' appearance on "The Ed Sullivan Show." Sept. 14: Mike Nichols's mammoth film version of Tony Kushner's mammoth "Angels in America" (HBO); a boxed set of five of John Cassavetes's influential psychodramas (Criterion); and, at long last, "Star Wars" (Fox), the original three films. Sept. 28: The documentary that will make you eat your spinach, "Super Size Me" (Hart Sharp Video) and Michel Gondry's much-admired comedy "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," from a script by Charlie Kaufman (Universal). Oct. 5: Just in time for Election Day gift giving, Michael Moore's "Fahrenheit 9/11" (Lions Gate). Oct. 19: The wonderful French documentary "To Be and to Have" (New Yorker), about a year in the life of a rural one-room schoolhouse; and five films from the acclaimed director Wong Kar-wai, including the great "Chungking Express" (Kino). Nov. 2: "Shrek 2" (DreamWorks), dishing out more happily-ever-after. Nov. 9: "Gone With the Wind" (Warner Brothers), getting the epic treatment in a four-disc set that includes a new high-resolution transfer of the film, a reproduction of the souvenir book sold during the initial roadshow engagements, new documentaries, reminiscences from Olivia de Havilland and newsreel film from not only the 1939 Atlanta premiere but also the 1961 "re-premiere" marking the centennial of the Civil War. Nov. 23: The first decent movie made from the Harry Potter books, Alfonso Cuarn's "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" (Warner Brothers). Nov. 30: The return of the hero who made teenage angst in Queens fashionable, in "Spider-Man 2" (Columbia). Dec. 14: The 40th-anniversary release of "Mary Poppins" (Buena Vista), to remind us that before the hills came alive with the sound of Julie Andrews's impeccable diction, it rang out across the rooftops of London. To be announced: The expanded edition of the last installment of Peter Jackson's "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, "The Return of the King" (New Line).

title: Connecticut: A New High for Stamford's High End
description: Correction Appended

title: Of Moles and Men
description: BY the time Michael Frayn's drama "Democracy" opens on Nov. 18 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, you may be feeling burned dry by election fever. But don't be quick to turn your back on this sharp-witted biographical study of shadowy personalities in the glare of public life, inspired by the career of the former West German chancellor Willy Brandt. Presented to deserved critical acclaim in London, Mr. Frayn's latest work does for politics what his "Copenhagen" did for physics, transforming the stuff of textbooks into scintillating, thought-churning theater. It's hard to imagine the American cast being better than that of the National Theater and West End productions, led by Roger Allam as a charismatic, Clintonesque Brandt and Conleth Hill as his double-dealing assistant Gnter Guillaume, who was an East German mole. But there is definite promise in the casting of James Naughton (as the chancellor) and Richard Thomas (in Mr. Hill's role). Even better, Michael Blakemore, who brought sustained snap and crackle to the London productions, is on board again as director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHAYES, LEON
description: SCHAYES--Leon. Devoted husband of Lia Schayes, father of Dr. Bernard Schayes, will be missed by granddaughters Stephanie, Alexandra and Isabelle and daughter-in-law Jeanne. He was loved by all.

title: Nonprofit Agencies' Books Face More Scrutiny
description: IN July, soon after the United Way of Long Island ended its fiscal year, auditors from PricewaterhouseCoopers arrived at the organization's headquarters in Commack and settled into their annual task of reviewing the books, as required by state law.

title: Borghese's Robust Reds
description: WITH the first lingering mouthful of the 2001 Ovation, it is clear why Castello di Borghese priced this superpremium Bordeaux-style red at $75.

title: How to Reinvent The G.O.P.
description: Brooks fails to mention a disturbing principle emerging within the new Republican Party: its arrogation of Christianity as the power behind its power. Just as their antithetical enemy, radical Islam, hungers for a universal return to primitivism, conservative Republicans want to literally legislate the hell out of me. Quite to the contrary, they scare the hell out of me.

title: Chinese Airline
description: To the Editor: "U.S. Airlines Like New Deal With China" (Correspondent's Report, Aug. 15), about new flights to China and the difficulties of traveling on Civil Aviation of China airlines (C.A.A.C.) within that country, reminded me of the day some years ago when I nervously awaited a much-delayed departure flight in the Beijing airport. Seeing my obvious agitation, a Chinese man sitting nearby leaned over to me and asked, "You know what C.A.A.C. stands for, don't you?" When I indicated that I didn't, he replied, "China Airlines -- Always Canceled."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL
