title: Building Castles on the Stage
description: ALWAYS greeted as a cult figure, Pina Bausch -- queen of German dance theater -- returns to the Brooklyn Academy of Music with still another installment in her epic examination of human aspirations and failures.

title: Keeping Up With the Krogers
description: TARUNI SETH, a mother of two who lives in Berkeley Heights may not know it, but she is a hot commodity in New Jersey grocers' circles. Her family's monthly grocery bill may seem insignificant in an industry that sells tens of millions of dollars in products statewide, but because she divides her time between Stop & Shop, Whole Foods and Kings, her shopping dollars are at play.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 1
description: Tampa Bay Buccaneers (7-9) at Washington Redskins (5-11) 1 p.m.

title: For Police Officers, Two Deaths Compound the Pain
description: Detective Bobby Parker followed his calling to the end. As he lay dying on a Brooklyn street on Friday night, he managed to call 911 and tell the operator that the man who had shot him and his fellow detective, Patrick Rafferty, was pictured in a mug shot on the dashboard of their car.

title: On I-95, a Bridge Reopens After Being Reborn
description: A new southbound side of the Howard Avenue bridge on Interstate 95 in Bridgeport was opened Tuesday night, replacing a temporary route after a fiery tanker truck accident in March.

title: 'Rashomon' Meets 'Gilligan's Island'
description: "LOST," a new ABC drama about air-crash survivors marooned on a spooky deserted island, sounds ludicrous -- "Gilligan's Island" meets "The X-Files." It's not that bad; in fact, it is quite good, and at times so gripping it doesn't really need the supernatural subplot (something big, bad and scary in the jungle).

title: From the Boxing Ring to the Nail Salon
description: MY FATHER'S FIGHTER By Ronald K. Fried Permanent Press ($24, hardcover)

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; The Skinny on Fatburger
description: I don't care if you've sold burgers for more than half a century. You have not truly succeeded until you have passed muster, and passed the mustard, in the Garden State. Enter Fatburger, the southern-California-based chain founded in 1952, which recently opened its first New Jersey location.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, CYNTHIA BLAU
description: FRIEDLAND--Cynthia Blau, on September 6, of cancer. Her life was dedicated to music, family and friends. She worked with lifelong friend Lainie Kazan; produced the music TV program, Night Flight and was VP, Scene Int'l. Survived by daughter Lilah, partner John Keese, and Stephen Friedland. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or The Wisdom School, Santa Fe, NM. Contact: friendsofcynthia@ hotmail.com

title: . . . And Mr. Codey Also Inherits Senator Lance
description: Even before tackling any personnel decisions, Mr. Codey has already begun reckoning with the level of debt the state faces, expressing dismay at estimates as high as $5 billion for next year's budget. One official who was not surprised is the Senate's minority leader, Leonard Lance.

title: Protests Over Removal of Afghan Governor Continue
description: HERAT, Afghanistan, Sept.12 A Violent demonstrators ransacked and burned at least four United Nations office compounds in this city and a human rights office, as they clashed with the national police and army in an angry protest at the removal of the governor Ismail Khan by the central government.

title: Former New Jersey Jail Guard Claims Unfair Firing After Testifying Against Other Guards
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 10 - Juan Espinosa said he was relieved nine years ago when authorities asked him to wear a concealed recording device to help convict fellow correction officers who had brutalized 25 illegal immigrants held at the Union County jail here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEYS, WILLIAM ANDERSON III (''COMMODORE'')
description: KEYS--William Anderson III ("Commodore"). Formerly of Bronxville, NY, died September 1, 2004 at the age of 90. Mr. Keys is survived by a daughter, Dale Bruce of Camden, ME, three granddaughters, Cameron Masson of Wellesley, MA, Heather Bruce and Jennifer Bruce, both of Camden, plus three great - grandchildren. Mr. Keys was predeceased by his wife Natalie Keys and son Tyler Keys. A Memorial Service will be held at the American Yacht Club in Rye, NY on Sunday, September 26 at 1 PM. Donations may be sent to Coastal Mountains Land Trust, 101 Mount Battle St., Camden, ME 04843 or to Youthlinks, 420 Broadway, Rockland, ME 04841. See online memorial at www.wsclancy.com

title: Don't Try This in Vogue
description: THE dress is a near-sheer sheath of silk as fragile as cicada wings, its material stretched improbably over a moderately hairy male chest. It appears in a series of brooding, sexually ambiguous vignettes conceived by Steven Meisel, who makes his photographic debut in W magazine on Monday, with a cover article coyly titled "ASexual Revolution."

title: Other Bats, Other Stats
description: To The Editor:

title: Kuznetsova Is the Better Russian at U.S. Open
description: The butterflies were understandable for 19-year-old Svetlana Kuznetsova, who walked onto the court and stared wide-eyed into the prime-time lights and the packed crowd around her.

title: Creating the New History of Jazz
description: JAZZ is an art in which the materials are largely fixed: like young actors in Shakespeare or O'Neill, young players must find a way to speak a language that was venerable before they were born. But the jazz pianist Jason Moran has tended also to look for new materials to use -- and not necessarily songs.

title: Profitable Scoop
description: SHIRLEY FERRIS has never had so much fun working so hard in her life, and as a farmer's wife of 45 years, she is no stranger to hard work.

title: It's Official: A New Owner for the Grasso House
description: AT last, the Windsor Locks birthplace of Ella T. Grasso, Connecticut's first female governor, has a new owner. The subject of a recent foreclosure auction, the Grasso home was in limbo because its new owner, Reine Weigert of Windsor Locks, overlooked the property's $85,000 mortgage, and after making the winning bid, feared she couldn't afford it.

title: The Week Ahead; QUESTIONABLE ACTS
description: "The Family: The Real Story Behind the Bush Dynasty," an unflattering and gossipy portrait by the celebrity biographer Kitty Kelley, is scheduled for release on Tuesday, but it has already set off a flurry of accusations and denials. Anxious Republicans have begun disseminating lists of tawdry and questionable allegations from her previous biographies of Nancy Reagan and Frank Sinatra in an effort to discredit her work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LONG, ALLAN L.
description: LONG--Allan L. Of New York City and East Hampton on September 9, 2004. Loving husband of Sally, stepfather of Deborah Klein, Michael Friedman. Funeral service Sunday, 2:30 PM at Independent Jewish Cemetery, Sag Harbor, NY.

title: Some Minor League Machinations Gave Minnesota an Ace
description: IMAGINE a Houston Astros starting pitching rotation of Roger Clemens, Roy Oswalt, a healthy Andy Pettitte and Johan Santana. Or think about a Florida Marlins rotation of Dontrelle Willis, Josh Beckett, Carl Pavano and Santana.

title: Trumpologies
description: One morning in July, Donald J. Trump walked across the vast, peach-colored marble lobby of Trump Tower toward his fans, who had formed into two orderly lines stretching from the skyscraper's doors to Trump's black limo, idling at the curb. "I don't think this happened to Bill Zeckendorf," he cracked. Zeckendorf, a very successful real-estate developer, was the closest thing to Donald Trump a generation ago -- which is to say, not close at all. We plunged outside, and the fans, observing a correct distance, thrust out copies of Trump's latest, mega-best-selling book, "Trump: How to Get Rich."

title: The Week Ahead; TURF TALKS
description: Lawmakers will begin meeting behind closed doors about an aspect of the Sept. 11 report that has a direct impact on them: how to change Congressional oversight of intelligence agencies. A 22-member Senate task force charged with fixing what the Sept. 11 commission described as "dysfunctional" oversight will for the first time convene to begin exploring the delicate task of who should sacrifice turf.

title: Diversity as Policy, Not as Window Dressing
description: AMERICAN workers are willing to accept diversity in their workplaces, but they fault top management for not promoting diversity in the right way, according to a national survey of 5,500 workers by the National Urban League. Following are excerpts from a conversation with Marc H. Morial, president and chief executive of the league:

title: RUSH REDUX
description: After a long career in corporate finance, much of it at Honeywell, Lawrence W. Stranghoener enjoyed the culture at Thrivent Financial, where, as chief financial officer, he oversaw the merger of two faith-based insurance and investment firms affiliated with the Lutheran Church. But he longed for the hurly-burly of a public company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZEICHNER, RITA MAE (NEE SILVERBERG)
description: ZEICHNER--Rita Mae (nee Silverberg). 76, passed away on Tuesday, August 24, 2004 at her residence on the island of Nevis in the West Indies. She formerly resided in New Haven, CT Washington, DC, San Francisco, CA, Vancouver, BC, Tucson and Paradise Valley, AZ. She is survived by her sons Adam, Jonathan (Monica), Erich (Gabrielle), Walter, her grandchildren John, Yasmine, Oliver, Loulie and Jobim and her brother Robert Silverberg (Robyn). She gave (Joy and Sweetness) to those who knew and loved her and will be dearly missed. Contributions to your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: Questions For Mira Nair
description: Mira Nair is mistaken in saying that "Islamophobia has completely raged in the Western world since 9/11" (Deborah Solomon, Aug. 29). A phobia is an irrational fear of something, despite the awareness that it is unreasonable or unwarranted.

title: A Voice of Hatred Is Gone, but Not Its Echo
description: Seattle - TOWARD the end of his life, the man who was once the nation's most visible face of white supremacy, a Nazi-uniform-wearing, jackbooted ideologue whom his critics called "the grandfather of hate," was a frail old widower gasping for breath in a tiny donated house in northern Idaho.

title: In California, Students Find Housing Lucrative
description: LOS ANGELES - FOR about a year or so, Efren Ramirez, 20, a pre-med student at Santa Monica College, had been paying $900 a month for a small studio apartment and shared bathroom. Knowing that he had many years of school ahead, Mr. Ramirez decided that spending money on rent didn't make sense, and he started looking for an alternative.

title: Jamie Foxx Goes Dark to Play a Musical Hero
description: TARZANA, Calif. - DEEP in the belly of his sprawling ranch home in this modest suburban neighborhood, past the fleet of luxury automobiles lining the front driveway, past the living room decorated with African art, past the gym and the billiard room, is where you'll find Jamie Foxx this afternoon, munching on a bag of barbecue chips in his high-tech recording studio.

title: 'Up From Zero'
description: The Winter Garden is a 200-foot-long, 125-foot-high glass-enclosedroom in the middle of the World Financial Center, a cluster ofhigh-rise office buildings and shops in Lower Manhattan, across thestreet from the site where the World Trade Center once stood. It hadbeen severely damaged in the terrorist attack that destroyed thetrade center on September 11, 2001, and when it was restored thefollowing year its reopening was taken as a welcome symbol of therenewal of the area. The Winter Garden is one of the few large,indoor public rooms that Lower Manhattan has. It is not a typicalpublic space for New York. It has a dozen palm trees, a grand,formal staircase, and a view to the Hudson River. Most of the time,it functions like an indoor version of a public square, wherevisitors and shoppers and office workers mill around under thearchitect Cesar Pelli's spectacular arched glass ceiling or sitreading newspapers and sipping coffee on metal benches.

title: Tasmania
description: I was going to head up the dreamlike Gordon River, rain forest all around me, with old Denny Hamill on his fishing boat, and we would sit around fires of a night and talk of the power and magic of the river country through which we were journeying.

title: Grim Homework
description: AS memorial candles burned in the columned doorway of' Tisch School of the Arts at New York University on Wednesday for a student who fell from the building's roof in an apparent suicide two days earlier, five undergraduates sat in a broken circle in a drab lounge of Weinstein Hall, a nearby freshman dormitory. They swapped sentiments about the sixth fatal fall of an N.Y.U. student in the past year. The dreary second-floor room, 2B Lounge, had all the institutional charm of a dentist's waiting room, and the students, dressed in T-shirts and jeans, approached the topic with the grim acceptance of patients contemplating an unavoidable root canal.

title: 'Where the Right Went Wrong': A Paleoconservative Takes on the Neoconservatives
description: WHERE THE RIGHT WENT WRONG How Neoconservatives Subverted the Reagan Revolution and Hijacked the Bush Presidency. By Patrick J. Buchanan. 264 pp. Thomas Dunne Books/ St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: The Singer-Songwriter
description: Stevens is the kind of sensitive post-folkie who draws comparisons to Nick Drake ...; Elliott Smith and Iron and Wine, but he is not just another cookie-cutter emo-boy.' Last year, Sufjan Stevens released "Greetings From Michigan: The Great Lake State" -- a strange, elegiac and warmly literate concept album that made his home state seem like its own reverberating lonely planet. This wasn't Michael Moore's Michigan, or the novelist Jim Harrison's, or Eminem's, or anyone else's. Stevens, who was born in Detroit and grew up there and in Alanson, a small lumber town in northern Michigan, took listeners on a kind of plaintive dream-tour, from Flint to Sault Sainte Marie to Ypsilanti, in lyrics that tended to be about not just factories and marching bands but also personal heartbreak and desolation. The album was a declaration of a serious -- and seriously idiosyncratic -- talent.

title: A Modernist Diaspora
description: WORLD WAR II turned the map of European musical modernism upside down, scattering composers from cities like Vienna and Berlin to unlikely destinations like Los Angeles and suburban New York.

title: Cuban, Sharpton and Branson: The New Trumps?
description: Correction Appended

title: Once More, With Too Much Feeling
description: SLUR it isn't so, Kiki! Carnegie Hall, of all places, will be the site next Sunday of "Kiki & Herb Will Die for You," the final local appearance of the town's most endearingly unhinged chanteuse and her emotionally damaged helpmeet at the piano. Theatergoers who haven't stumbled upon Justin Bond and Kenny Mellman's crash-and-burn parody of a faded cabaret act Off Broadway will have one last chance to marinate in their unique aura before Kiki and Herb retire, metaphorically, to that great piano bar in the sky.

title: Right-Wing Israelis Protest Withdrawal Plan
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 12 A Thousands of right-wing Israelis packed the streets of central Jerusalem tonight in the latest mass protest against Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip.

title: At Iowa Farms, Barn Door is Open
description: At Iowa Farms, Barn Door Is Open

title: US Airways Files for Bankruptcy Protection; 2nd Time in 2 Years
description: US Airways filed for Chapter 11 today, its second round in bankruptcy in two years, after workers refused to grant $800 million in cuts the company had sought to reduce its costs to the level of low-fare airlines.

title: To the Lighthouse and Beyond
description: I went to Cornwall to see the lighthouse -- Virginia Woolf's, that is, the one that stands tantalizingly out of reach until the very end of what is arguably her best novel, "To the Lighthouse." The novel is Woolf's most autobiographical. (Transfixed by the portrait of their mother, her sister Vanessa wrote, "It is almost painful to have her so raised from the dead.") Set in the Hebrides, it is based on Woolf's recollections of idyllic childhood summers spent at St. Ives on the Cornish coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAMSEY, PETER C.
description: RAMSEY--Peter C., on September 10th, 2004 after a courageous and dignified battle with lung cancer. Best friend, devoted and loving husband of Maryalice. Loving son of Rosalie C. Ramsey. Devoted brother of Christie C. Ramsey. He was a generous, caring and compassionate gentleman who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, September 12th, 6-9 PM, and Monday 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, September 14th, 10 AM, at St. John the Martyr Church, E. 72nd St. between 2nd and 3rd Aves. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Loomis Chaffee School, Windsor, CT 06095 or your favorite charity.

title: Older People Shouldn't Be Segregated
description: To the Editor:

title: On His Way to 700, Bonds Keeps Walking
description: PHOENIX, Sept. 11 - The race for 700 home runs has slowed to a walk.

title: Iran Says It Will Reject Nuclear Limitations
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 12 A With the United Nations nuclear watchdog expected to resume reviewing Iran's case on Monday, Iran said today that it would reject any limitation on its right to master nuclear technology but that it would provide guarantees that its nuclear program had peaceful purposes.

title: A Chicago Tour With a Punch Line
description: Imagine a walking tour of Chicago led by Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd or George Wendt, each a former member of the Second City comedy troupe. Although none of those stars is about to become a tour guide, one of their successors in the current Second City cast has been leading walks around the Old Town neighborhood, which has been the theater's home for 45 years.

title: Bustle in Berlin
description: MY wife, Betsey, and I have visited Berlin often over the past 25 years, and we found ourselves there again on the May weekend when 10 new countries were admitted to the European Union. Each one set up a tented pavilion in the Pariser Platz, in the shadow of the Brandenburg Gate, distributing beer, wine and samples of their cuisines to large, festive local crowds. The most popular tent, ironically enough, was that of Poland, the country that Hitler's panzers invaded in 1939, precipitating World War II.

title: Going to Extremes
description: In his essay, James Traub suggests to his son that "hanging peace flags out the window is not a meaningful response to the terrorist threat or to a nation attempting to find its way out of tyranny and chaos" (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 29).

title: Celebration: San Francisco
description: Few cities have inspired better epigrammatic praise than San Francisco. Paul Kantner of Jefferson Airplane described it as "49 square miles surrounded by reality." John Steinbeck claimed the city was "a golden handcuff with the key thrown away." And H. L. Mencken wrote that, upon arrival, he was immediately thrilled by the "subtle but unmistakable sense of escape from the United States."

title: And Bear in Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEISLER, ALEXANDER
description: HEISLER -- Alexander of NYC, on September 7, 2004. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Ackerman), devoted father and father-in-law of Dr. Kenneth and Kristen Heisler, Phyllis and Glenn Gerstell and Janice and Kenneth Wile. Dear brother of Ruth Rose. Loving grandfather of Matina, Emily, Robert, Kenneth Jr., Juliet, Daniel, Thomas and Jonathan. Loving uncle to his nieces and nephews. Services will be held Sunday, 9:30AM, "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Memories in lieu of flowers may be sent to the J. M. L. Care Center of Falmouth, Massachusetts 02540.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEAGHER, JUNE ANNE
description: MEAGHER--June Anne. On September 9, 2004 of NYC, formerly of Jamesport and Southold. Avid Democrat and Yankee fan. Beloved daughter of James and Dorothy Meagher of Florida and formerly of Jamesport. Loving sister of Janet Rogers and Kathy Meagher-Hinsch. Devoted aunt of Billy, Christian and Jacqueline Rogers and great aunt of Katie, Caroline, Cameron, Colin, Evan and Madeline Rogers. Reposing at the William F. Coster Funeral Home, Main Rd., Route 25, Cutchogue, NY Sunday 7-9 PM and Monday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday 10 AM at St. Patrick's Church in Southold. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to a charity of your choice.

title: The Citizen Stranger
description: Some time in late summer, 350 years ago, 23 Jews arrived in what was then New Amsterdam, beginning one of the most remarkable chapters in the history of an already remarkable Diaspora. It is tempting to picture a single, symbolic boat carrying George Gershwin, Jonas Salk, Groucho Marx, Meyer Lansky, Emma Goldman, Hank Greenberg and an untold number of garment workers, accountants, public school teachers and dermatologists. But that first wave of immigrants -- if 23 men, women and children can be called a wave -- were refugees from Recife, Brazil, which had passed from the Dutch to the Portuguese and was now open to the Inquisition and closed to Jews.

title: The Week Ahead; THE BITTER CAMPAIGN
description: On the one hand, John Kerry and President Bush will go to all the usual places and do all the usual things -- think Michigan and Wisconsin, rallies and bus trips -- as they campaign for the presidency this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEXLER, MELISSA
description: WEXLER--Melissa. 5/9/58 -- 9/12/81 Sweet Missy, the void remains though filled with love and eternal despair for you. Love Mommy, Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri and Larry

title: How to Reinvent The G.O.P.
description: The title of David Brooks's article was too limiting. It should have been "How to Reinvent America," because it speaks to all of us. It rang true to me, and I'm a life-long Democrat.

title: 'The Egyptologist'
description: !31 Dec. Sunset. Outside the tomb of Atum-hadu. On the Victrola 50:"I'm Sitting on the Back Porch Swing (Won't You Come Sit by Me,Dear?)."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOM, HENRY MCEWAN
description: BLOM--Henry McEwan. On September 5, 2004. Loving husband to Solveig A. Blom, deceased October 1999. Survived by his wife Elizabeth of Boca Raton, FL. Loving father of Dr. Margaret Liv Blom, Dr. Henry A. Blom and Dr. Paul H. Blom. Devoted grandfather to Colin, Hakon, Christian, Ian, Kaia, Lara and Brooke. For information regarding services, please call 914-961-0087.

title: Corrections
description: The Square Feet article on Aug. 29, about retail activity at Union Square, misstated the location of a site formerly occupied by J. W. May's and Bradlees. It is at the southeast corner of 14th Street and University Place, not the southwest. The article also misidentified an insurer whose building is now the site of a W hotel. It was Guardian Life, not the Travelers Insurance Company.

title: Colleen McGuire, Thomas Gilmartin
description: Colleen Marie McGuire, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. McGuire of East Hampton, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Austin Gilmartin, a son of Col. and Mrs. Michael W. Gilmartin of Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Donald J. Desmond performed the ceremony at Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: Hostage-Takers Teach the French the Limits of Diplomacy
description: PARIS - GEOPOLITICAL question of the week: What do Carlos the Jackal and the pope have in common?

title: Schoolyard Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: A Legal Right to a Storage Space

title: The Making of a President
description: BURBANK, Calif. - IN a two-hour meeting last month to "break out" the story for the seventh episode of the new WB drama "Jack and Bobby," Greg Berlanti and his team of eight writers discussed Kobe Bryant, the odds of Mr. Berlanti's newly discovered lobster allergy proving fatal, and where Billy Joel played on his 1990 "Storm Front" concert tour. Then Mr. Berlanti stood up and led a short, intense discussion about what -- a health scare? fear of aging? -- might drive Grace, the romance-weary mother of the two title characters, played by Christine Lahti, into the arms of a younger man. Mr. Berlanti sat again and asked one of the writers how her effort to quit smoking was going. He had decided several weeks earlier that she should quit, and asked all the writers to give up something in solidarity (he gave up fries). Then the discussion turned to the subtle dynamics of self-sabotage and how it might be affecting one of their teenage characters.

title: Page Two: Sept. 5-11; AFTER THE G.O.P., LE DELUGE
description: In the end, Mother Nature succeeded, where the Republican National Convention and the protesters failed. A downpour connected to Hurricane Frances on Wednesday caused New York City's finely choreographed transportation network to grind to a halt. Flooding on the tracks and malfunctioning signals stranded hundreds of thousands people, some in sweltering stations or aboard stuck trains. In scenes reminiscent of last summer's blackout, many decided to walk, streaming over the Brooklyn Bridge and down the city's thoroughfares. Others shoved their way onto buses. By evening, order was restored. Michael Luo

title: Try Not to Annoy Your Llama
description: The outfitter hangs the last saddlebag on the last llama and turns to address The Question. Always, somebody asks The Question.

title: Her Three Sons
description: THE unlikely participation of the publicity-loathing playwright (and occasional movie idol) Sam Shepard, returning to the New York stage as an actor for the first time in decades, in itself makes this production an essential ticket for theater lovers. But there is guaranteed to be more than star appeal to "A Number," Caryl Churchill's latest offering. Like her harrowing "Far Away," this densely resonant, hourlong futurist drama -- which presents a new style of family portrait, courtesy of genetic engineering -- highlights Ms. Churchill's special gift for spinning topical concerns into timeless fables.

title: Industrial Pollution Destroys Fish Farms in Rural Region of China
description: ZHENGDIAN, China - The tens of thousands of fishermen who live on houseboats scattered throughout the tributaries of the Huai River basin are farmers without land. They raise fingerlings in netted fish farms that they later sell on local markets.

title: So There's This Guy Looking for Work . . .
description: Whether out of despair over the dearth of new developments, or merely from a collective yearning to look to the future, political gossip has turned from what Governor McGreevey did in office to what he will do starting on Nov. 15, when he leaves it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIERNEY, LOREN
description: TIERNEY--Loren. Our deepest condolences to the family of our beloved friend, Loren Tierney. She was stolen from everyone she loved and who loved her despite her courageous battle against breast cancer. Even in the very end she showed us how beautiful life is. Her loving friends, Eva Kosta, M.D. Raymonda Rastegar, M.D. Grace Wright, M.D.

title: Desire Lee, Jay Spaleta
description: Desire Lee, a daughter of Joyce Lee and Dr. Youngick Lee of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married last evening at the Mountain Top Inn in Chittenden, Vt., to Joseph John Spaleta, the son of Dale and Bruno Spaleta of Farmingdale, N.Y. Katherine Hall, a justice of the peace in Chittenden, officiated with Sister Anne Foley, a Roman Catholic nun who is an aunt of the bridegroom.

title: A Republican on Ice In a Land of Democrats
description: LITTLE FALLS - IT is the political season in Montclair. The cocktail-party canapes are seductively fresh and the town's drawing-room talk is Democratic, often veering sharply to the left. But Floyd Hall, an unabashed Republican, does not seem to mind.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the children's paperback best-seller list is omitted from Page 26 of the Book Review today and replaced by the children's picture books list, which was intended for next Sunday. All of the children's lists may be found online at nytimes.com/books.

title: Dutchess County: Signs of a Comeback in Downtrodden Beacon
description: DURING the waning years of the 20th century, even Beacon's spectacular position between a 1,500-foot-high mountain peak and the eastern shores of the Hudson River in southern Dutchess County failed to lure sightseers or shoppers, much less rouse development interest. One of a number of hard-pressed communities along the river, Beacon had sections along Main Street that "resembled a bombed-out war district," the city's mayor, Clara Lou Gould, recalled recently.

title: A Girl Named Brooklyn
description: IT is curiosity, above all, that puts this baby, at least provisionally, on the list of the fall's must-sees. What could a show so bluntly and broadly titled as "Brooklyn, the Musical" possibly deliver? A choral dirge in which sad legions take to the stage to lament the flight of the Dodgers, perhaps. A shaggy bunch of Williamsburg neo-bohemians frolicking, "Rent"-style, in a capacious converted warehouse. Maybe a Gilbert and Sullivan-inspired patter number denoting the geographic and sociological distinctions between Carroll Gardens, Park Slope and Cobble Hill -- often so mystifying to Manhattanites.

title: Page Two: Sept. 5-11; HE'S GONE (IN 2006)
description: Michael D. Eisner, who for 20 years has reigned over the Walt Disney Company, informed the board of directors that he would not stay on as chief executive past 2006. The decision was his own, he said, and he endorsed Robert Iger, the Disney president, as his potential successor. But the board said it would continue its search for a successor, and it is unclear whether Mr. Eisner will be allowed to stay if it chooses a candidate sooner.

title: Shakespeare's Leap
description: A young man from a small provincial town -- a man without independent wealth, without powerful family connections and without a university education -- moved to London in the late 1580's and, in a remarkably short time, became the greatest playwright not of his age alone but of all time. His works appeal to the learned and the unlettered, to urban sophisticates and provincial first-time theatergoers. He makes his audiences laugh and cry; he turns politics into poetry; he recklessly mingles vulgar clowning and philosophical subtlety. He grasps with equal penetration the intimate lives of kings and of beggars; he seems at one moment to have studied law, at another theology, at another ancient history, while at the same time he effortlessly mimics the accents of country bumpkins and takes delight in old wives' tales. Virtually all his rivals in the highly competitive theater business found themselves on the straight road to starvation; this one playwright by contrast made enough money to buy one of the best houses in the hometown to which he retired when he was around 50, the self-made protagonist of an amazing success story that has resisted explanation for 400 years.

title: As It Is Written
description: 'Spanglish'

title: N.F.L. Forecasters Fooled by Last Season's Success
description: Welcome to the most hopeful day on the sports calendar. The start of baseball season may inspire the nation's prose stylists with notions of rebirth and possibility, but today -- the first Sunday of N.F.L. games -- offers more reason to dream than any other day.

title: What Would Bert Do?
description: ATLANTIC CITY - BERT PARKS lives. Sort of.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WADSWORTH, VIRGINIA HIGGINSON
description: WADSWORTH--Virginia Higginson, 74, of Cambridge, died Tuesday, August 31. She attended The Windsor School and graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1948. She graduated from Boston University in 1972, and earned an MS from Lesley College in 1973. From 1980 to 1992, Virginia was the co-owner of New England Sights. Virginia was an active member of The Vincent Club and served on the board of the Visiting Nurses Association of Cambridge. She was predeceased by her husband, Charles, in 1995. Virginia leaves: son, Charles Merrick, of Cambridge; daughter, Christina Higginson, of Weybridge, VT; grandchildren, Louisa and Haley; sisters, Patricia H. Biggar of Cambridge, Wendy S. Heard of Wolfboro, NH; brother, George of Pacific Palisades, CA. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 23 at 2 PM, Church of the Redeemer, 379 Hammond St., Chestnut Hill, MA. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Vincent Club, 71 Brimmer St., Boston, MA 02138, or to Chilton House Hospice, VNA Care Network, 245 Winter St., Waltham, MA 02451-8792

title: That Bulbous Nose! Those Dancing Feet! That Shiny New Gun!
description: THE W. C. FIELDS COMEDY COLLECTION (Universal, Nov. 9, five discs) The character W. C. Fields perfected was dead set against work, thrift, sobriety, chastity, honesty in general, dutifulness of any kind and compassion in any measure. And if you don't feel even a glimmer of affinity for him, you've probably been a misery to people all your life. The iconography of Fields A the bulbous, gin-reddened nose, the rotund build, the top hat or skimmer A may be more familiar to moviegoers under 40 than the man's work is. And those encountering Fields for the first time in "International House," "You Can't Cheat an Honest Man," "It's a Gift," "My Little Chickadee" and "The Bank Dick" may at first assume he's nothing more than a middle-aged guy doing groaning gags about mothers-in-law and wives. Which would be as wrongheaded as saying that Henry Miller represented the smutty side of Fodor's.

title: Dear Legislators: While You Were Gone
description: The Legislature is poised to return from summer vacation this week and, boy, has the place changed while everyone was away.

title: Do Newspapers Make Good News Look Bad?
description: CONSERVATIVE pundits routinely accuse the news media of injecting a liberal bias into coverage of issues from abortion to gun control to gay marriage.

title: Mother and Child: A Spreadsheet
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Envoy Seeks to Enlist the Clergy to Ease Conflicts
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 10 - John C. Danforth, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said Friday that he was actively trying to create a new forum for leaders of the world's faiths to involve themselves in resolving the conflicts in a world of terror.

title: Little Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaigner (And Candidate)
description: As New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has campaigned against Wall Street miscreants, his critics have regularly accused him of being an ambitious politician more interested in gaining higher office than in watching out for the little guy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASS, REV. JONATHAN T.
description: GLASS--Rev. Jonathan T. Associate Executive Director, National Association of Episcopal Schools, died suddenly at home on August 27, 2004. Memorial service Wednesday, September 22nd, 2PM in Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10 St, N.Y. followed by a reception in Tuttle Hall at the Church.

title: A Booster Seat on Wheels
description: BECAUSE babies are rather limited in their descriptive abilities, it's impossible to verify Geir Stokke's assertion that infants "certainly appreciate" strollers that position them farther above the ground than other strollers do. But Mr. Stokke, the president of Stokke USA, a design company based in Atlanta, makes a convincing case.

title: Sweating More Than the Workout as Luxury Watches Go Missing
description: On its surface, the men's locker room at the New York Sports Club in Battery Park City doesn't have the look of a classic crime den. The fluorescent lights and he-man builds alone would do much to ward off most criminals. Then again, the absence of a security guard, the sweaty preoccupation of the regulars and the abundance of all those wallets and watches left unattended could prove enticing. It is the latter item that seems to have drawn the most felonious attention.

title: 'The Folly of Empire'
description: At noon, October 18, 2003, President George W.Bush landed in Manila as part of a six-nationAsian tour. Because officials were concernedabout a terrorist attack on the embattledislands, the presidential airplane, Air ForceOne, was shepherded into Philippine air space byF-15s. Bush's speech to the Philippine Congresswas delayed by what one reporter described as"undulating throngs of demonstrators who linedhis motorcade route past rows of shacks."Outside the Philippine House of Representatives,several thousand more demonstrators greetedBush, and several Philippine legislators stageda walkout during his twenty-minute speech.

title: And, Action!
description: All dates subject to change.

title: Casting a Meaningful Vote
description: The Times has always believed that it is important to judge each candidate for public office as an individual. We have never liked the idea of supporting frivolous contenders to "send a message." Voters generally feel the same way, and look for the most qualified candidate, even if they are faced with deeply flawed options. This year, however, the few primary races for New York's abysmal State Legislature are a special case, and we have a different kind of recommendation.

title: Guidebooks
description: To the Editor: Regarding "A Guidebook for Every Taste" (Practical Traveler, Aug. 22), I read it with interest, but couldn't keep a smile from my face. In the early 90's, my husband and I bought the Hachette guidebook to France. Although published in 1988, it somehow "looked good" and "felt right" to us.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 12, 2004
description: Correction Appended

title: Menus That Look Beyond Dutch Borders
description: LIKE many travelers, I could sum up my image of the Dutch culinary scene in one word: rijsttafel, the multidish Indonesian rice table. Thus, on a recent visit to Amsterdam with my buddy Joyce, I expected that we'd have our share. Not so. Our Dutch friends prefer The Hague for rijsttafel and steered us instead toward traditional French.

title: Questions For Mira Nair
description: I find it strange that Mira Nair freely expresses her resentment of the West and America, which have given her the creative and expressive freedom she currently enjoys. As a consumer, I personally cannot support the artistic products of a director who views our national tragedy through the filtered lens of a parochial and pitiless Islamophilia.

title: 'Silver City'
description: Written by John Sayles. Opening Friday.

title: Mets Take Longer for Same Result
description: It was 20 games ago that the Mets found themselves in a moment just like this one, fighting their way through a wild extra-inning game. And on that day, when they survived in San Francisco, they were sure that it was a sign of life, that the team would claw and scratch to the finish line in a season that still had hope.

title: Illegal Immigrants Are Wary in Danbury
description: AT the condominium complex on Hospital Avenue in Danbury, there are few words more frightening than "immigration." Many immigrants live in the complex, so when two men knocked on the doors of apartments there late last month, representing themselves as immigration officials, residents said, some panicked. There are about 20,000 illegal immigrants in the city, Danbury police said, and there are predators who know how to get what they want.

title: The Man Who Made Sculpture Out of Meat Cleavers
description: AMONG the current flurry of exhibitions devoted to Minimalist and post-Minimalist trends and artists, the survey of Barry LeVa's work, Jan. 15-April 3 at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia, should be unusually revelatory. Mr. LeVa is one of the least appreciated innovators of the deconstructive sculpture known variously as post-Minimalism, Process Art and "anti-form," which sprang up around the world in the late 1960's. In the United States, his fellow travelers included Richard Serra, Bruce Nauman, Keith Sonnier, Eva Hesse and Mel Bocher, all of whom, like Mr. LaVa, declined to make traditional, static sculpture, even as practiced by the Minimalists. Reacting to such diverse forces as Jackson Pollock, happenings, Claes Oldenburg's soft sculptures and the task-oriented choreography of Yvonne Rainer, Lucinda Childs and Trisha Brown, these artists replaced sculpture's rigid structure with a new sense of flexibility in terms of time, space, process and perception.

title: Kerry's Stance On the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBMAN, HERBERT
description: LIEBMAN--Herbert. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of David and Audrey. Cherished grandfather of Joshua and Kate. Loving brother of Betty Franzel. Services Monday, 10 am, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Swapping Bishop for Knight: Not Many Do It These Days
description: Just what you don't want in a title tournament occurred in the 105th United States Open Championship: seven players tied for first place in the 2004 edition, held in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., from Aug. 7 to 15. They were Rodrigo Vasquez of Chile, Andranik Matikozian of Armenia, and Alexander Onischuk, Aleksander Wojtkiewicz, Ildar Ibragimov, Renier Gonzalez and Marcel Martinez of the United States.

title: Giants Cramming for an Early Test
description: There are generally not a lot of good things to be said about the specter of playing the Eagles in Philadelphia. They are a good team, play in one of the National Football League's most hostile environments and have beaten the Giants in five of the last six games between the teams, including three straight at home. But the Giants are not exactly fearing today's assignment. In many ways, they relish it.

title: DAZED AND CONFUSED and FAST TIMES AT RIDGEMONT HIGH: ULTIMATE PARTY COLLECTION (Universal, Nov. 2)
description: So few teen movies get anything about teenage life right that the ones that do become classics of a kind. Richard Linklater's 1993 ensemble comedy "Dazed and Confused" is a remarkable piece of 70's pop-culture anthropology. Mr. Linklater gets not just the clothes and music and attitudes eerily right; some of the characters, like Parker Posey's queen-bitch senior, are so authentic they can make you feel you're back among people you'd hoped never to see again. But "Dazed and Confused" works better as anthropology than as drama. The film is caught between Mr. Linklater's impulse to make a mainstream comedy and his urge to go for something darker.

title: A Straight Chain Movie House Gets a Queer-Eye Makeover
description: It's not your grandfather's Clearview Cinemas.

title: Speaking Softly, Carrying a Big Lute
description: THE Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church on the Upper West Side has long offered the most varied and consistently satisfying early-music programs in New York. And even in a season that includes a 10-day burst of medieval, Renaissance and Baroque music, courtesy of the New York Early Music Celebration in early October, the Corpus Christi programs look especially inviting.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet: Nothing but Beethoven

title: Such a Polite Young Van
description: TESTED: 2005 Honda Odyssey Touring WHAT IS IT? Next generation of Honda's popular, groundbreaking minivan. HOW MUCH? Estimated prices from $25,000 (LX) to $38,000 (Touring with navigation system and DVD player). WHEN? On sale Sept. 22. WHAT MAKES IT RUN? Single-cam V-6 (3.5 liters, 255 horsepower); 5-speed automatic transmission; front-wheel drive. E.P.A. CITY/HIGHWAY MILEAGE: 20/28 ALTERNATIVES: Toyota Sienna XLE Limited, Chrysler Town & Country Limited, Nissan Quest 3.5 SE; Mercury Monterey Premier; Buick Terraza.

title: Some Bad Calls Worse Than Others
description: Some Bad Calls Worse Than Others

title: Preventive War: A Failed Doctrine
description: If facts mattered in American politics, the Bush-Cheney ticket would not be basing its re-election campaign on the fear-mongering contention that the surest defense against future terrorist attacks lies in the badly discredited doctrine of preventive war. Vice President Dick Cheney took this argument to a disgraceful low last week when he implied that electing John Kerry and returning to traditional American foreign policy values would invite a devastating new strike.

title: Old Vines, New Owner
description: One year after Jean-Marie Fourrier, an admired Burgundian grower in Gevrey-Chambertin, bought a property in tiny Faugres, a hilly Languedoc appellation, he made 2002 lgance, a beautiful, earthy Mediterranean red. Grenache grapes from old vines dominate the wine. At $12.50, this underpriced bottle may be the top value at Rosenthal Wine Merchant, 318 East 84th Street (Second Avenue), which specializes in wines that express the singular makeups of the owners' vineyards. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Universal Horror, Local Remembrance
description: While a lot of attention has been paid to the 9/11 memorial in Lower Manhattan, not enough has been focused on the memorials that are springing up throughout Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey. That's a shame, because each has a special importance. And with each new design or proposal, more questions arise: When are there enough memorials? Does every town have to have its own?

title: New Book Says Bush Officials Were Told of Detainee Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - Senior military and national security officials in the Bush administration were repeatedly warned by subordinates in 2002 and 2003 that prisoners in military custody were being abused, according to a new book by a prominent journalist.

title: How to Reinvent The G.O.P.
description: Bravo, David Brooks (Aug. 29), for making a conservative case based on principle without once slinging mud, avoiding issues, talking down to voters or denigrating the other party. As a liberal, I have yearned for years to hear from a conservative who took the high ground. I think liberals and conservatives need one another. If Brooks were running for president, I would disagree with many of his proposals, but I would feel proud to be part of a country that had him in it.

title: What Fashion Owes to XXX
description: HOW quaint it now seems that only five years ago, the director John Waters could declare pornography the last cultural outlaw. Pornography was becoming hip, he was quoted as saying in The New York Times in March 1999, because it was "extreme behavior that's in on the joke."

title: Why Middle Schools Are Being Questioned
description: IT is the time of braces, changing bodies, shorts that look too baggy and backpacks that look too big. The sixth graders approach their building asking, "Where do we go?" while most seventh and eighth graders know how to exude an air of confidence.

title: 'Arc of Justice': I Swear It Was in Self-Defense
description: ARC OF JUSTICE A Saga of Race, Civil Rights, and Murder in the Jazz Age. By Kevin Boyle. Illustrated. 415 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $26.

title: Sarah Ransom, Paul McKenna
description: Sarah Grace Ransom, a daughter of Marjorie Ann Ransom of Washington and the late David M. Ransom, was married yesterday to Paul Raleigh McKenna, a son of Rene and James J. McKenna of New York. The Rev. Vienna Cobb-Anderson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Gurney's Inn in Montauk, N.Y.

title: Kirsten Dunst Pretends to Be a Jock
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD - KIRSTEN DUNST tells a story about the strangeness of fame. She was 12 and had landed what would be her breakthrough role as an aging woman in a child's body opposite Tom Cruise and Brad Pitt in "Interview With the Vampire." At the time, she lived with her family in a complex of furnished apartments near the Warner Brothers lot that is famous as a way station for stage parents and their child-star offspring and as a hotbed of scuttlebutt and competition. One day, Ms. Dunst recalled, a young girl approached her and bragged, "My agent says I'm going to be the next Kirsten Dunst."

title: Should a Lawyer See a Listing Agreement?
description: ONLY the most confident property owner would enter into a contract with a buyer to sell a house or apartment without first getting the advice of a lawyer.

title: If the Revenue Column Says Zero, Avoid the I.P.O.
description: Correction Appended

title: The Cat on the Couch
description: My brother and sister-in-law are not therapy-oriented. But this summer, when Hugo, their 15-year-old tabby cat, started urinating on their bed and in their son's backpack, they did what they and their veterinarian thought was the sensible thing.

description: To the Editor:

title: East Meets West in a Blurred Embrace
description: IT'S a testament to the disfavor in which ambiguity is held in Western culture that the word blur is nearly always a slur. Really, isn't it all a blur?

title: When in Doubt, Ask
description: I WAS going to be a biology major with a chemistry minor, but I didn't know precisely what I would do with my degree.

description: November

title: 'I'll Be Your Mirror': The Art of the Interview
description: I'LL BE YOUR MIRROR The Selected Andy Warhol Interviews, 1962-1987. Edited by Kenneth Goldsmith. Illustrated. 448 pp. Carroll & Graf. $17.

title: Chechen Rebels Mainly Driven by Nationalism
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11 - Chechnya's separatists have received money, men, training and ideological inspiration from international Islamic organizations, but they remain an indigenous and largely self-sustaining force motivated by nationalist more than Islamic goals, Russian and international officials and experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIRDSALL, LEONE COTTRELL, M.D.
description: BIRDSALL--Leone Cottrell, M.D. Age 94, died on September 8, 2004. Dr. Cottrell was a Pediatrician and Child Psychiatrist, a member of The New York Embroiderers Guild, The Society of Women Geographers and a Life Member of The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Predeceased by her husband, Charles H. Birdsall, Esq. in 1965, she is survived by three loving daughters, Marion Rendon, Jean Simson and Helen Shepherd, three grandchildren, Santiago, Ann Beatriz and Leone Rendon, and four great - grandchildren. The Wake and Service will be held at Campbell Funeral Home, Saturday, September 11, 2004, 10AM-12PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 E. 70 St., NYC 10021.

title: Suffolk Police Again Seize Drunken Drivers' Cars
description: After a six-month hiatus, the Suffolk County Police Department has again begun to impound cars and boats operated by drunken drivers who are repeat offenders. By last Wednesday, 18 cars and one boat were under lock and key and could be auctioned off.

title: A 3-Generation Day
description: What with closing down the summer house and getting the kids back to school, it may have slipped your mind that today is Grandparents Day. But if you're planning to celebrate, here are child-friendly restaurants that also appeal to two generations of their elders.

title: Regina Carter and Alvester Garnett
description: WITH at least 200 club dates and concerts around the world each year, the members of Regina Carter's jazz ensemble say the loneliness of the road is offset by the familylike atmosphere of the band.

title: Seeking the Buzz Starbucks Couldn't Get
description: HERE comes Jean M. Delphonse, a look of concentration on his face, shuttling from the Broadway local and his day job handling Web site content at TheStreet.com, the online financial newspaper, to his first solo business venture, a coffee shop tucked among the brownstones of Hamilton Heights, just north of Morningside Heights. In one hand, he clutches a book called "Against the Gods: The Remarkable Story of Risk."

title: Dance Week: $10 for 5 Courses
description: FOR dance-loving New Yorkers of a certain age, the Delacorte Dance Festival in Central Park was a summer ritual in the 1960's and 1970's. For a week or so, companies and artists of all varieties would share the stage, dancing through wind and rain, in rough-and-tumble shows that drew audiences of all ages and degrees of dance sophistication.

title: Little Italy
description: CALDWELL - FROM the moment you enter through the bank of French doors that separate it from the street, Trattoria Fresco exerts an irresistible pull. Part of it is the hearty, unaffected welcome from the young staff. A bigger part is the open kitchen, situated right at the front of the house, where less astute owners might have put a coatroom.

title: Uneasy Riders
description: THE boom in Latin American cinema signaled by art-house hits like "Amores Perros," "Y Tu Mam Tambin," "Central Station" and "City of God" should be further spurred by "The Motorcycle Diaries," which opens Sept. 24. Acclaimed at Sundance, the movie (in Spanish, with English subtitles) was directed by the Brazilian filmmaker Walter Salles, whose "Central Station" offered a deeply compassionate view of Brazilian society and won Academy Award nominations for best foreign-language film and best actress (Fernanda Montenegro).

title: Sara Messeloff, Lawrence Tanz
description: Sara Michelle Messeloff, a daughter of Esther and Jonathan D. Messeloff of New York, is to be married today in Pearl River, N.Y., to Lawrence Edward Tanz, a son of Judith L. Tanz and Dr. Alfred Tanz, also of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the Hilton Pearl River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHANNESSEN, MILDRED R.
description: JOHANNESSEN--Mildred R. After 83 years of life, died September 4, 2004. Devoted wife of 40 years to John E. Johannessen. Mother of Susan, Sally, Lisa, Lynne and Jack. Grandmother of six. Born in Concord, MA, and lived in Englewood and Tenafly, NJ and Grantham, NH before moving to Ft. Myers, FL. Memorial services will be held Tuesday, September 14, at 11AM at the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, 150 E. Palisade Ave., Englewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to Wellness Community of the SF East Bay, 3276 McNutt Ave., Walnut Creek, CA 94597; Forest United Methodist Church, 17635 E. SR40, Silver Springs, FL 34488; or the charity of your choice.

title: One (Manly) Man and a Baby
description: KEVIN HILL wants "unforced, unexpected affection," or so he tells a lady in a bar, using pickup poetry so pure and fast-acting it ought to be banned like a date-rape drug.

title: 'The Undressed Art'
description: Eleanor Dickinson's line is lively and lyrical, a flute passage fromVivaldi, confident and sunny. It flows from the end of her felt-tipmarker in curls and ribbons to divide form from formlessness, tomark the places where light glances and clings, to define the subtlecurves of life. It is a remarkably supple and observant line, fullof information, full of understanding of how a wrist curls or afinger bends, broad where shadows collect, finer as lightintensifies, broken and invisible where light dazzles. It comes intoa kind of miraculous life, born from the tip of the pen bold andfinished, yet continually moving, continually revealing anddescribing: the back of a middle finger folding delicately away fromthe light, rounding down and darkening to the fingertip, thenturning sharply where its contour meets the last knuckle of theindex finger, now thin again in the light, down again to the indexfinger's rounded tip. By and by, a hand-or its contour-has appearedon the paper, and to my eye it has the exact proportion, the weight,the texture, the strength, the experience, the life of the handacross the room.

title: Going Mobile? Well, Not Quite Yet
description: ONE exhibition ends, another opens. Few people beyond museum staff members have any idea what happens in between. But, as the Nassau County Museum of Art's staff was recently reminded, exhibitions don't just install themselves.

title: Attention Parents: Class Is in Session
description: DRIVING back from a family trip in upstate New York two weeks ago, my husband and I noticed a shoe store with several enormous bright orange "Back-to-School Sale" signs plastered in the windows. In desperate need of footwear for our three children buckled in the back seat, we quickly parked the car eager to buy more than a few pairs of shoes.

title: Hardcover Highlights
The Lessons of Classroom 506
description: I. First Impressions It was the first day of school last year, Sept. 8, 2003. The kindergartners were arriving in batches at Classroom 506 at the Manhattan School for Children, on 93rd Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues. The parents of these 5-year-olds said they felt lucky to be taking their children to M.S.C. that morning, lucky to have won the scramble for admission to this sought-after institution -- a public school with particular cachet among artistic, educated Upper West Side families who can't or won't pay for private education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARONSTEIN, JACQUELINE BLUESTONE
description: ARONSTEIN -- Jacqueline Bluestone, of Port Washington, NY, died on September 9, ten days after her 69th birthday, at her son's home in Northampton, MA. She is survived by her husband of 41 years, Richard, her sons Steven and Jonathan, and beloved grandson Noah. She was a psychologist in the NYC Schools for twenty years and in private practice for thirty. She touched her many devoted friends with her boundless enthusiasm and energy. In her yearlong courageous battle with illness, everyone around her was constantly moved by her inexhaustible strength and optimism. Funeral Sunday, September 12, at 1PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY.

title: U2, the Band That Never Embarrasses Itself
description: U2'S next album, due in November, will grapple with two challenges: one musical, one cultural.

title: Canada Looks for Ways to Fix Its Health Care System
description: WHITBY, Ontario, Sept. 9 - Esther Pacione needs a family doctor. At age 56 she is afflicted with severe ataxia, a neurological condition that causes her acute pain, choking and loss of consciousness. The walls of her home are scuffed from the times she fell and hit her head.

title: Kerry's Stance On the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Cities Show Off New Threads: Brussels
description: Art Nouveau was certainly new 100 years ago but Brussels is intent on again presenting it as a novelty. And why not? The capital of Belgium and of the European Union remains a particularly splendid display window for that elegant turn-of-the-century style with its long and undulating lines.

title: Alison Levy, Charles Nightingale
description: Alison Beth Levy, the daughter of Susan Pontac and Stanley Levy, both of San Diego, is to be married there today to Charles Ross Nightingale, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Nightingale of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Herbert Isaacson is to officiate at the Paradise Point Resort.

title: Blair's New Cabinet Seems to Blur Lines in Labor Party
description: LONDON, Sept. 10 A In advance of elections possible next year, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has completed a cabinet realignment that might have been intended to draw the lines for the fray but seemed to blur them, too.

title: Lecavalier Rescues Canada
description: TORONTO, Sept. 11 - Only a second major upset by Finland will keep Canada from claiming the World Cup of Hockey, but upsets do happen at this elite level. There was almost another one Saturday night, before Canada and its backup goalie qualified for the championship game by beating the Czech Republic, 4-3, in overtime at the Air Canada Center.

title: Eminem vs. Eminem vs. Eminem
description: ON an early track called "Bad Influence," Eminem bragged about being a "human horror film, but with a funnier plot." And for a long time, it was true: he was known primarily for giving his fans blood and punch lines. His breakthrough single, "My Name Is," began with one of hip-hop's most famous introductions: "Hi, kids, do you like violence?/Wanna see me stick nine-inch nails through each one of my eyelids?"

title: Interstellar Serial Killer
description: M. John Harrison is out there. In every sense. In the first few pages of his latest novel, LIGHT (Spectra/Bantam, paper, $16), set in England in 1999, we meet Michael Kearney, a physicist who kills women to placate his personal demons. But before we can get a grip on this mild-mannered serial killer, the focus shifts to the year 2400 and Seria Mau Genlicher, who has sacrificed most of her body to become the captain of a faster-than-light "K-ship." When we first meet her, she's methodically destroying a convoy of unarmed spaceships along with their hapless crews. The only apparent link between these two cold-blooded killers is an offhand mention of the "standard Tate-Kearney transformations" -- a set of equations that, it's implied, have made interstellar flight possible.

title: Thanks, Moms
description: If by this time next year the Yonkers school crisis has been solved and the seemingly endless cycle of teacher layoffs, program cuts, protest marches and testy school board meetings has become a sour, dimming memory, the question for historians to ponder will be this:

title: If It Quacks Like a Lame Duck
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10 - In the month since he announced his resignation, Gov. James E. McGreevey has been publicly cast into so many new roles -- as unlikely gay trailblazer, symbol of New Jersey's tainted political culture and punch line for late-night comics -- that it would be easy to overlook his day job as chief executive of the nation's ninth most populous state.

title: Nancy Lindeman, Mark Myers
description: Nancy Heloise Lindeman is to be married today to Mark David Myers. Rabbi Steven Moskowitz is to officiate at the Central Park Boathouse, with Cantor Marcey Wagner taking part.

title: Tastes of India, Tailored for a New Generation
description: WHEN Simson Kalathara walks across the street to the Ambadi restaurant, he doesn't always recognize the pastries arrayed in the display case. A meal served in his Bengal Tiger restaurant is prepared just as it would be in India. His three children, who opened Ambadi in White Plains last month, rely on recipes of their own design. Like many business owners in Westchester, the family is adapting to make Indian culture more accessible to a generation that was born in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDREASSEN, GERTRUDE
description: ANDREASSEN--Gertrude. Age 86, on Thursday, August 19, 2004, of Rockville, MD, formerly of Sound Beach, NY and Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Gustav Andreassen. Mother of Carol Andreassen of Kensington, MD. Sister of Joan Fingeroth of Brooklyn, NY and aunt of James Fingeroth and Janet Roccanova, both of New York. A memorial service will be held at the GreenWood Cemetery Chapel, Brooklyn, NY, Wednesday, September 15, 2004 at 11 AM. That bit of whimsy points up the sense of humor of this creative and talented chef and restaurateur, known as a trendsetter and risk-taker.

title: At Least 25 Dead After Violent Day in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 12 A In a series of calculated attacks that reflect the growing power of the Iraqi insurgency, at least 25 Iraqis were killed by suicide car bombings and a barrage of missile and mortar fire in several neighborhoods across Baghdad today.

title: Wilderness to War Zones: In Relentless Pursuit of Oil

description: From 1999 to 2002, American multinational corporations increased profits taken in countries with no taxes or low rates by 68 percent, while sharply reducing profits taken in countries where they engage in substantial business activity, a study to be published today in the journal Tax Notes shows.

title: Your New Baby: A Boy or a Girl?
description: PROSPECTIVE parents have long sought to influence whether their child would be a girl or a boy, but only recently has technology begun to tip the odds in their favor. Automakers, on the other hand, have practiced sex selection for years, determining at conception the traits that each new model would project.

He is an assistant professor at the Memorial University of Newfoundland, in Canada; there is no University of Newfoundland. (Go to Article)

title: The Arithmetic of War
description: It is hard to appreciate at a time of war in Iraq, genocide in Sudan, terrorism in Russia and other places, and the endless cycle of violence in Israel, but there is actually less warfare in the developing world now than at the end of the 20th century. Two forthcoming reports from groups that track such things, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute and Project Ploughshares in Canada, indicate a steady decline over the past 10 years in the number of wars in the third world. A Congressional study shows that governments, especially poor ones, buy fewer heavy weapons.

description: JAKARTA, Indonesia Sept. 11 - At the height of his powers here in 1994, General Suharto ordered the closing of Tempo, a Time lookalike magazine of wide readership and great authority.

description: Every so often during the runway collections, I am forced to wonder exactly what would have become of the world if Miuccia Prada had pursued her studies in political science instead of building a fashion house now virtually unchecked in its aesthetic imperialism.

title: What Your College President Didn't Tell You
description: BEAUFORT, S.C. - Much has been made in recent years of the unwillingness among college and university presidents to venture above the parapet and challenge some of the shibboleths of higher education. By this I do not mean advocacy of political positions. Presidents who would keep their campuses places where ideas are in fact freely exchanged ought to avoid signing public letters or endorsing candidates, tempting as it may be.

description: FEINER--Samuel. Age 87, of Glen Gardner, NJ. Died peacefully with his family at his side on September 1, 2004. He is survived by his wife, Jeanne Burmon Feiner. His first wife was Zelda Resnick Feiner who passed away in 1987. He is also survived by his children Jeffrey Feiner of Miller Place, NY, and Susan Feiner and her husband Marc Goloff of New York, NY; sister Ruth Berman of Florida; step-children David Burmon and his wife Kayo of Weston, MA, and Edward Burmon of Canton, MA; grandchildren Sophie and Benjamin Goloff, Lynn, Kate and Andrew Burmon; nephew Richard Cherry and his wife Carol of Larchmont, NY; nieces Maxine Berman of Florida, Eilene Feiner Blank, Gail Feiner Popaconstantopoulas, and Amy Jane Feiner; and greatnieces Rebecca and Melissa Cherry. title: C.I.A. Nominee Said toChampion Budgets Over Watchdog Role

Goss, Republican of Florida, watched over American intelligence agencies through all seven years that George J. Tenet was running them. Corrections
description: A listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide of Weekend on Friday misidentified the saxophonist in Fieldwork, a jazz trio that performed that evening at the Whitney Museum. He is Steve Lehman, not Aaron Stewart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, MALCOLM L.
description: STEIN--Malcolm L. On September 11, 2004. Beloved husband of Harriet Weiss Stein. Loving father of Jonathan W. Stein (Sharon Merriam) and Alison Eve Stein (Andrew Isaacs). Son of the late Charles and Lillian Stein. Brother of Dr. Marjorie L. Stein. Son-in-law of Blanche Barasch Weiss and the late David Weiss. Brother-in-law of Howard and Karen Weiss, uncle of Bara and Alex Tisch, Sabrina Weiss and Adam Weiss. A loved and respected friend and advisor. Graduate of Columbia Univerity School of Law, 1965; LL.M. 1967. Lecturer in law, Columbia University School of Law, 1967-1969. Attorney-advisor, Office of Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, U.S. Treasury Department, Washington, DC, 1969 - 1971. Partner, Roberts & Holland, 1975-1991. Founder and Partner, Stein, Shiers & Goldsmith, 1992-present. Funeral services will be held September 13, at 11:45, at Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: Afghan Crowds Loot and Burn Over Governor's Dismissal
description: HERAT, Afghanistan, Sept. 12 - Violent demonstrators ransacked and burned at least four United Nations office compounds and a human rights office here on Sunday as they clashed with the national police and army in an angry protest at the removal of Gov. Ismail Khan by the central government.

description: TEHRAN, Sept. 12 - With the United Nations nuclear watchdog expected to resume reviewing Iran's case on Monday, Iran said Sunday that it would reject any limitation on its right to master nuclear technology but that it would provide guarantees that its nuclear program had peaceful purposes.

title: Kerry and Bush Trade Charges on End of Weapons Ban, and Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 A Senator John Kerry accused President Bush today of caving in to "powerful friends" in the gun lobby in allowing a decade-old ban on assault weapons to expire. The White House immediately countered by accusing Mr. Kerry of indulging in "another false attack" in trying to capitalize on the gun-control issue.

title: Experts See Little Immediate Change, but Say Prospects Could Deteriorate as Months Pass
description: Planes will take off on schedule. The service will be pretty much as you remember it. And your frequent flier miles are safe.

title: VENICE FESTIVAL AWARDS
description: The 61st Venice International Film Festival has awarded its Golden Lion for best film to Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake," the story of a postwar London housewife who secretly provides free abortions to women with unwanted pregnancies. The prize for best actress went to Imelda Staunton, who plays the title role. "I would like to thank most sincerely the Cannes film festival for rejecting this film so I could come to Venice," Mr. Leigh said to applause after receiving his prize from Sophia Loren at Saturday's awards ceremony in the Fenice opera house. "Mar Adentro" ("Out to Sea"), by the Chilean-born Spanish director Alejandro Amenbar, also took two prizes. As runner-up to "Vera Drake," it won the Jury Grand Prize, the Silver Lion, while the best-actor award went to Javier Bardem, who plays a Spanish quadraplegic seeking help in ending his life. Another Silver Lion, a special prize for best director, went to Kim Ki-duk, the South Korean director of "Binjip" ("3-Iron"), which follows a young man who breaks into empty houses set around a golf course. The awards also included Golden Lions for lifetime achievement for the veteran directors Stanley Donen and Manoel de Oliveira. ALAN RIDING

title: Fred Ebb, 76, Lyricist Behind 'Cabaret' and Other Hits, Dies
description: Fred Ebb, the devilishly witty Broadway lyricist who was half of the legendary musical theater team of Kander and Ebb, responsible for the songs in classic shows like "Cabaret" and "Chicago," died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. Mr. Ebb was coy about his exact age; his birth year was regularly listed as 1933, but the funeral home, after consulting with his family, will list his age as 76.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: US Airways Again Files For Bankruptcy Protection US Airways filed for Chapter 11 protection, its second such filing in two years, after workers refused the airline's push for $800 million in wage and benefit cuts.

title: 50 Miles of Scenic Suffering for Fun, Fitness and Health
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Sept. 12 - Around the Shawangunk Mountains about 80 miles from Manhattan, the cool early-morning dew serves as a reminder that days warm enough for outdoor fun are numbered.

title: An American Champion Wins An Individual Women's Title
description: World titles are usually won by a team or a partnership. The exception is the Generali World Individual, played last week in Verona, Italy. In the open division an Italian world champion, Norberto Bocchi, snatched victory with a strong surge in the final session. The women's title went to an American world champion, Tobi Sokolow, who will be trying for another victory next month. She is a member of the United States women's team that will contest the World Olympiad in Istanbul. Second to Sokolow in Verona was Benedicte Cronier of France, the defending champion. Third was Nicola Smith of England.

title: US Airways Tries to Reorganize for a 2nd Time
description: US Airways filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday for a second time after workers refused to grant $800 million in cuts it had sought to reduce its costs to the level of low-fare airlines.

title: Most Crimes of Violence and Property Hover at 30-Year Lows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 - The rate of property crime and violent crime other than homicides remained at a 30-year low in 2003, the Justice Department said Sunday.

title: A Traffic Jam Does to Owens What the Giants Cannot
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 - Before he caught three touchdown passes in his much-anticipated debut with the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, Terrell Owens nearly pulled his own version of Pascual Perez.

title: Secondary Has Room to Improve
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 12 - After a week when the Jets' defense seemed most concerned about how it would fare against the legs of Cincinnati running back Rudi Johnson, it was Carson Palmer's right arm that exposed the secondary as another area in need of attention.

description: As The New York Post continues to notch circulation gains against its rival, The Daily News, The News is fashioning a weapon that it hopes will protect its lead, at least on Sundays: a glossy, 48-page magazine mostly made up of photos of celebrities captured at parties in and around New York.

title: U.S. Attacks Rebel Base in Falluja; 20 Are Killed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 13 - American fighter planes fired at targets in Falluja on Monday in strikes aimed at what commanders said was a meeting place for operatives working with the militant leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi.

description: HAVANA, Sept. 12 - Hurricane Ivan hammered the Cayman Islands on Sunday with winds that moved like bulldozers at 155 miles per hour, as thousands of people in Cuba and Florida braced for one of the most powerful storms to boil up out of the Atlantic.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 12 - With the vast parking lots at Giants Stadium awash in beach umbrellas, barbecue smoke and beer coolers, it was painfully obvious to some New York Jets fans on Sunday that the team's proposed stadium in Manhattan would deprive them of a cherished pregame tradition: tailgating.

title: INSIDE
description: C.I.A. Nominee Faces Questions on Past Oversight As chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Porter J. Goss cast himself more as a rebuilder than as a watchdog. Now, with Senate hearings about to begin on his nomination to be director of central intelligence, Mr. Goss is facing questions about those years of oversight. While he has supporters in both parties, critics say he was a consistent champion of bigger budgets but much less persistent when it came to scrutinizing mistakes. PAGE A17

title: Looking for Energy in the Campaign
description: Presidential candidates have long dangled the promise of "energy independence" in front of the American voter. And all have known that it is an unattainable goal, largely because the United States, which uses one-quarter of the world's oil production, owns less than 3 percent of the world's oil reserves. What America can do, however, is reduce imports -- by producing cars that require less gasoline and by developing other fuels that cars can run on. Over time, such a strategy could enhance our energy security and give us more influence over prices. It would also make a big dent in America's emissions of global warming gases.

title: Through All Their Ordeals, Iraqis Bank on Free Food
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 12 - Iraq may be tormented by ethnic and religious divisions, but one thing still unites the entire populace, from holy warriors of the Sunni Triangle to middle-class supporters of the government to disaffected Shiites of the south. What nearly every Iraqi family gets, regardless of income and no matter whose guns rule the local streets, is the central government's monthly gift of free food.

description: HONG KONG, Monday, Sept. 13 - With most of the vote counted, advocates of greater democracy appeared to have scored modest gains in elections here on Sunday, but fell short of winning a majority in the legislature.

title: With Eye on Storm, Skittish Floridians Search for Safety

With a third powerful hurricane bearing down on Florida within a month, thousands of residents spent the weekend uncertain whether, when or where to flee.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 13 about an announcement by Gov. James E. McGreevey on a solution to New Jersey's problems with the E-ZPass toll system misstated the ownership and headquarters location of the operator, Affiliated Computer Services. The company is based in Dallas, not Washington. It bought a unit of Lockheed Martin in August 2001; it is not a Lockheed subsidiary. A reader reported the errors late last month; his e-mail was delayed in routing at The Times.

title: Current-Event Cartoons as the Stuff of Theater
description: LONDON, Sep. 12 - At first he seems little more than an amusingly flat cartoon, George W. Bush as he might appear as part of the gang on "South Park." Portrayed by Alex Jennings in "Stuff Happens," the noisily heralded play by David Hare that opened on Friday at the National Theater, the sitting president of the United States also looks a lot like one of the Lollipop Kids from "The Wizard of Oz," a little boy trying to project toughness with a squint, a swagger and a squaring of shoulders.

title: Suozzi Says Nassau's Fiscal Crisis Is Over
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 12 - The fiscal crisis that erupted in the late 1990's and threatened to bankrupt Nassau County -- one of the country's wealthiest suburbs -- is now over, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said on Sunday.

Jim Courier Starts Sports Promotion Firm
description: The tennis player and analyst Jim Courier is opening a company in New York, called InsideOut Sports and Entertainment, that will develop and produce promotions and events for advertisers. Mr. Courier, 34, is a partner in InsideOut along with Tim Stallard, 41, and Jon Venison, 33. Mr. Stallard had been president of ProLink Sports and Entertainment in Austin, Tex., which is being absorbed by InsideOut. Mr. Venison had been vice president at a media and communications investment firm, LiveWire Capital, in White Plains. InsideOut will also manage Mr. Courier's marketing and tennis careers.
