title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHT, CLAIRE BARBAN BLEIBERG
description: SCHACHT -- Claire Barban Bleiberg. 82, died peacefully in her sleep after a long illness at the home of her daughter. She was pleased with her life and her choices, proud of her family, and grateful for the devotion of her friends. She was a beautiful, vital, generous and outspoken person who will be greatly missed. The only memorial she wanted was to live in the memory of those who loved her. She was predeceased by Jacob Bleiberg, M.D., Lawrence Schacht, Arnold Singer and Robert Kahn. She leaves her chldren, Mona Bleiberg Bennett, M.D. and Peter Bleiberg, their spouses Michael I. Bennett, M.D. and Sallye Bleiberg, and four grandchildren, Rebecca and Sarah Bennett and Sara and Laura Bothwell. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Democratic National Committee, or the Mycosis Fungoides Foundation, PO Box 374, Birmingham, MI 48012.

title: Demanding More From Cable
description: Satellite television service providers are winning the battle for subscribers, but digital cable is making gains. During the second quarter of this year, 821,000 customers signed up for satellite service while 277,000 people dropped their basic cable, according to estimates from the Independent Research Group. But Erik Zamkoff, an analyst with the group, said that 649,000 people signed up for digital cable service during the same period, meaning that cable companies are starting to see benefits for the costly and extensive upgrades they have made to digital service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYER, SYLVIA
description: MAYER--Sylvia. 91, of Great Neck, NY. Passed away peacefully September 11, 2004. A strong and wonderful person. Caring wife, best friend and partner of husband Cyrus, who recently passed away. Devoted and beloved mother of Michael and Carole, Chester and Kathy, Amy and Alan Goodstein. Beloved grandmother of Scott and Annie, Robert, Bobby, Kacy, Shauna, Zachary and Alyssa. Rest in peace, much love. Services Monday at 2 pm, Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, NY, 5 Old Mill Road, 516-487-0900.

title: USC whips Colorado State; Oklahoma wins
Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about pollution accusations in Indonesia directed against the Newmont Mining Company, the world's biggest gold producer, misstated the affiliation of Evan Edinger, an environmental scientist who has analyzed mining waste in Buyat Bay. He is an assistant professor at the Memorial University of Newfoundland, in Canada; there is no University of Newfoundland.

title: ON ADVERTISING : Marketing's great leap in China
'Batman' Ends Protest at Buckingham Palace
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 A A group that advocates greater rights for fathers in child custody cases sent two of its operatives over the fence at Buckingham Palace today and one of them, dressed as Batman, scampered up a ladder to a ledge near the Queen's balcony, setting off a security alert and a tense standoff with police.

title: Petros VII, 55, Top Patriarch Who Sought Religious Dialogue, Dies
description: Petros VII, patriarch of Alexandria, who preached Christian-Muslim dialogue from one of the world's oldest seats of Christianity and who vigorously promoted the growth of Greek Orthodoxy in Africa, died Saturday at the age of 55.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEIG, ANNIKA HELENE
description: TEIG--Annika Helene, 33, architect. Died Friday, September 10, in New York from acute leukemia. Born August 29, 1971, in Oslo, Norway. Annika studied and practiced architecture in Norway and Berlin; then in New York at Columbia and SOM. Also an entrepreneur, musician, leader, writer, designer, pacifist, scholar, humanist, Norwegian, gourmet, sailor, skier, American, New Yorker, wife, daughter, sister, granddaughter, aunt, niece, cousin, and friend. A four o'clock memorial service will be held Thursday, September 16, at the Lawrence Beach Club, 1399 Beech Street, Atlantic Beach, NY. The American-Scandinavian Foundation, 58 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10016, is accepting donations in her memory.

description: Collections from Roberto Menichetti, Derek Lam, Diane von Furstenberg, Tuleh and Oscar de la Renta.

title: The First Day of School
description: New York City's nearly 1.1 million public school students returned for the opening of a new school year and of 91 new schools.

title: Bid to Decriminalize Prostitution in Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 13 - San Pablo Avenue was once the thriving, racy final stretch of the nation's first highway between New York and San Francisco, a center for jazz halls, gambling houses and brothels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISER, THEODORE T.
description: WEISER--Theodore T. September 12, 2004. Of Boynton Beach, formerly of Long Island and White Meadow Lake. Beloved husband of the late Hilda, father of Adele Klitzner & Hazel Weiser, grandfather to Rebecca, Lauren & Lena. Graduate of Brooklyn Law School 1940. Former President of NYS Bar Association Young Lawyers Section, American Arbitration Association. Private funeral. Donations may be sent to the Weiser Memorial Fund in L.I. title: Upfront Political Artist Taps Inner Show Queen
description: Here's news: many gay men are inordinately fond of Broadway musicals. You've heard? O.K., for most of us that's not a revelation. But as awareness has spread that homosexual men come in all shapes, sizes, levels of fabulousness and even political persuasions, once-reviled gay stereotypes have made a raging comeback. It has become permissible once again to depict gay men engaging in such previously disgraced activities as dithering and decorating. (See, for example, Jack on "Will & Grace," and those five fellows seemingly in permanent rotation on Bravo.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAFFEN, ISADORE
description: KAFFEN--Isadore. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend. Services Wednesday, 11:45 AM, "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, KENNEDY, HOMER III
description: YOUNG - KENNEDY -- Homer III, age 52, passed away on September 1, 2004 surrounded by his loving friends after a brief illness. He was an active member of his Inwood community and will be deeply missed.

title: Soothing Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway To Cut Back TV Sales
description: Gateway, which began selling flat-screen televisions in 2002, is retreating from the business and says it may return to profitability in the fourth quarter. Gateway will offer TV's only on its Web site and over the phone, said a spokesman, David Hallisey. Gateway has not released a new model in 10 months. The chief executive, Wayne Inouye, is re-emphasizing personal computers to halt losses of more than $2 billion since 2000.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: U.S. To Give $1 Million Against Rebels
description: Three days after a bomb attack by suspected Maoist rebels on an American government building in Katmandu, the capital, the United States Embassy said it was requesting an additional $1 million in security assistance to the Nepalese government. The embassy said it has also asked the State Department to suspend Peace Corps activities in Nepal and allow the evacuation of family members of American diplomats. Dhruba Adhikary (NYT)

title: Russia's Lurch Backward
description: Faced with the most serious crisis of his presidency, Vladimir Putin has yielded to his darkest instincts. Russia's stumbling security services clearly need to be revitalized to fight terrorism. Mr. Putin, however, is using Beslan's tragedy as an excuse for suffocating the last vestiges of Yeltsin-era democracy. Yesterday, evoking Russia's long history of an autocratic concentration of power, Mr. Putin called for legislation to end the popular election of regional governors and voting in parliamentary districts in favor of slates selected by national party leaders, who are more likely to bend to presidential whims.

title: Review at C.I.A. and Justice Brings No 9/11 Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Internal reviews still under way at the Central Intelligence Agency and recently completed at the Justice Department, examining their performance in the run-up to the Sept. 11 attacks, have not resulted in any disciplinary actions, government officials said on Monday.

title: Yankees Fanatic to Head YES
description: Tracy Dolgin took over as the president of the YES Network yesterday, knowing that much of the hard work of building the Yankees-Nets channel is over -- from the rapid start-up to the successful fight to be carried by Cablevision. Dolgin, the former president of Fox Sports Net and executive vice president for Fox Sports, succeeded Leo Hindery Jr., who resigned in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIEDERKEHR, MATTHEW
description: WIEDERKEHR--Matthew of South Orange, N.J., on Monday, September 13, 2004. Beloved husband of Jennifer (nee Levy). Devoted father of Lilly Jane and Mia Isabel. Loving son of Lee and Ronnie. Dear brother of Evan and Mandi. Adoring uncle of Ethan. Cherished grandson of Ethel and Philip. Funeral service Tuesday, September 14, at 10 A.M. in Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Rd., South Orange, N.J. Interment B'Nai Abraham Memorial Park. Contributions may be made to the Colorectal Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, POB 27106 NY, NY 10087.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Utility Sets Share Price
description: The Electric Power Development Company said it expected to raise as much as 375 billion yen ($3.4 billion) in what would be Japan's largest initial public offering in years. The company, an electricity wholesaler better known as J-Power, said it would offer its shares at 2,500 yen to 2,700 yen each. The sale would be Japan's largest initial public offering since the 2.1 trillion yen offering of NTT DoCoMo shares in 1998. The government now holds an 83 percent stake and the rest of J-Power is owned by a group of Japanese power companies. J-Power is scheduled to begin trading in Tokyo on Oct. 6. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Fund-Raiser Cashes in Big on Convention
description: For more than 20 years, Cathy Blaney was a foot soldier in New York's Republican political machine, cutting her teeth as a receptionist for the Reagan-Bush campaign, then as a do-it-all political operative for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, and later as the chief fund-raiser for Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUCHINER, MARTIN
description: STUCHINER--Martin. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime and wonderfully involved member Martin Stuchiner. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred Youngwood, President

title: In a Fight Over King Crab, Russians Show Their Claws
description: PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKY, Russia - Kamchatka, the rugged, remote peninsula of volcanoes and ice, is famous for its crab, none more than the red king crab that has long been this poor place's hard currency. The problem here today is trying to find one to eat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBMAN, HERBERT
description: LIEBMAN -- Herbert. The Board of Directors of The City College Fund extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Elaine and family. A devoted son of City College, he will be missed by all of us. Stanley H. Kaplan, Chair Herbert Robinson, Pres. James L. Schatz, Exec. Dir.

description: BASEBALL

title: Ex-Banker Asks Appeals Court to Seal Letters
description: Frank P. Quattrone, the former chief technology banker at Credit Suisse First Boston who was sentenced to 18 months in prison last week, accused the judge in his case yesterday of callousness for disclosing his 15-year-old daughter's medical disorder and asked an appeals court to seal letters from family and friends seeking leniency.

title: 1954:Army Wives Expelled : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Police Say Suspect in the Killing of Two Detectives Fired Seven Times at Close Range
description: As the wounded suspect in the killing of two police detectives was brought into a courtroom in a wheelchair to be arraigned on murder charges, details emerged yesterday that painted the fatal shootings in Brooklyn on Friday as an intense, sudden burst of aggression.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Crossing To Restate 2003 Results
description: Global Crossing, which left bankruptcy in December, will restate its 2003 results, reversing an earlier decision that accounting mistakes could be fixed by taking a charge. Global Crossing, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, and operates fiber optic networks, will increase 2003 costs related to the use of other carriers' networks by $67 million, the company said yesterday. The restatement will increase Global Crossing's 2003 net loss before gains from Jan. 1 to Dec. 9 to $295 million from $230 million, the company said. It will increase the net loss for the rest of the year to $11 million from $9 million.

title: 'There Is a Cape Buffalo Loose in the Hallway'
description: On a business trip to Amsterdam I met two women who were on their way to Kenya to follow the wildebeest migration into Tanzania. They said there was room for one more person and invited me to join them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Carmaker To Expand In India
description: The Japanese small-car specialist Suzuki Motor said it would build a second automobile factory in India, raising its annual production capacity in the fast-growing market to 750,000 vehicles from 500,000. Production is scheduled to begin in 2007. Suzuki, in which General Motors holds a 20 percent stake, did not say how much the plant was expected to cost. Suzuki also said it would spend 10 billion yen to build a diesel engine factory in India capable of producing 100,000 small engines a year, beginning in 2006. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Health Care Suit For The Uninsured
description: Yale-New Haven Hospital and Yale-New Haven Health System were named yesterday in a class-action lawsuit accusing the hospital system of "charging inordinately inflated rates for medical care to patients who are uninsured." The suit, filed in federal court in New Haven, is the 47th filed across the country this summer by a group of lawyers accusing nonprofit hospital systems of making uninsured patients pay full price or much more while discounting charges to insurers and Medicare and Medicaid. A spokesman for Yale-New Haven Hospital, Vin Petrini, said the hospital recently had recently scaled back collection practices that included placing liens on patients' homes. William Yardley (NYT)

title: A Doctor Puts the Drug Industry Under a Microscope
description: WASHINGTON - In many ways, Dr. Marcia Angell is an unlikely muckraker. A pathologist by training, she is the former editor in chief of The New England Journal of Medicine. She is also a senior lecturer at Harvard Medical School.

title: Arizona Didn't Walk the Walk Versus Bonds
description: BARRY BONDS will be in Milwaukee tonight going after his 700th home run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMMIS, JESSE F., JR.
description: SAMMIS--Jesse F., Jr. A longtime resident of Greenwich, CT and well-known sportsman and realtor died on September 12, 2004. Mr. Sammis was born in Huntington, Long Island on January 23, 1911. He was in the St. Bernard's School, NJ, Class of 1929, Pomfret School, Class of 1930, and attended Williams College, Class of 1934. He served in WWII in the Far East arena in Burma. He is survived by his wife Dorothy Forstmann Sammis; three children-Jesse F. Sammis III, Anne Mimi Sammis, and Peter Harvey Sammis; four grandchildren--Anne Patterson, Thomas W. Patterson, Suzanne Sammis Cabot, and Jesse F. Sammis IV; and seven great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, Greenwich, CT, at 3:00 PM on Thursday, September 16, 2004. Donations may be made to the Audubon Society of Greenwich, Riversville Road, Greenwich, CT.

title: Turning cautious on emerging markets
Company Shows Argentina How to Shake Its Isolation
description: BUENOS AIRES - In the summer of 2001, just as the worst economic crisis in Argentina's history was coming to a boil, Paul H. O'Neill, then the United States Treasury secretary, set off a furor here by suggesting that the country might have avoided collapse had it ever bothered to learn to export.

title: Spending there is on track to pass Japan's as global No. 2 : China's ad market is surging, too
Washington Offers Guarded Critique of Putin's Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 A Secretary of State Colin L. Powell reacted with guarded criticism of President Vladimir V. Putin's new steps to consolidate his power over Russia's political system, warning that the fight against terrorism should not become an excuse to move away from "democratic reforms of the democratic process."

title: Kansas City Exposes Yanks' Feeble Pitching
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 13 - If an injured pitcher could take a loss, Kevin Brown might have deserved one on Monday. It was Brown's turn in the Yankees' rotation, but he is not throwing at all now. He risked his season when he broke his left hand against a clubhouse wall 10 days ago, and the Yankees are paying for his petulance.

title: China's new fashion whispers but does not shout 'Asia'
Soothing Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Walks Line Between Kerry Ad and War Documentary
description: TORONTO, Sept. 13 - The premiere on Tuesday night of a sympathetic documentary about Senator John Kerry stakes out new territory at the crossroads of politics and cinema: will audiences pay to see what amounts to a two-hour political tribute to a man spotlighted free on the news every night? Can a theatrically released feature film create last-minute momentum for a presidential candidate? Could the effort boomerang?

title: U.S. Trade Gap Reached Record $166.2 Billion in 2nd Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 A In a sign of the growing imbalance of the American dollar against other currencies, the United States posted a record trade deficit of $166.2 billion in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today, raising new concerns about the country's indebtedness.

title: Crochet Hooks Aplenty on a Wide Sartorial Sea
description: On the off chance that anyone out there is actually wondering what trends fashion has in store for spring (as opposed to, let's say, the extent of Kim Jong Il's nuclear stockpile), this reporter is pleased to oblige. Come spring it will be time to haul out the crochet hooks and the battered old copy of "Wide Sargasso Sea," to judge by the stuff designers are sending out onto the catwalks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLAUS, RUBY M.
description: CLAUS--Ruby M. Carlsbad, CA. Died on September 12, 2004 at Scripps Hospital in Encinitas California after a brief illness. She was 93 years of age. A long time resident of Chappaqua, NY, Mrs. Claus was the wife of Carl Claus (deceased) for 66 years. She was the daughter of the late Orton H. and Lois Miller (nee Parker) of Barberton, Ohio. She attended Mount Union College in Alliance, Ohio where she was a member of the Delta Delta Delta Sorority. In addition Mrs. Claus was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, an honorary member of the Whippoorwill Country Club in Armonk, NY, and a former member of the Junior League of Augusta, GA. She is survived by her son Carl M. Claus and two grandchildren Lois F. Claus and Carl R. Claus. Interment will be private. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions be made to Scripps Hospital, 354 Santa Fe Drive, Encinitas, CA 92024.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREBIN, MARY
description: GREBIN--Mary. New YorkPresbyterian Healthcare System wishes to extend its sincere sympathies on the death of Mary Grebin, beloved mother of Burton Grebin, MD, President and CEO of St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children, and a longtime colleague and friend. Our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Grebin and his family, at this time of mourning. Mr. John J. Mack, Chairman Mr. Donald L. Boudreau John E. Merow, Esq. Vice Chairman Herbert Pardes, MD President and Chief Executive Officer Arthur A. Klein, MD Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer

title: HOLLYWOOD CASINO SHREVEPORT FORCED INTO CHAPTER 11
description: Hollywood Casino Shreveport, which operates a riverboat casino on the Red River in Louisiana, said creditors had forced it to file for bankruptcy protection. A note holder who had tried to buy the casino and two construction contractors who have sued the company filed the petition to force the action, said HCS I Inc., which owns 99 percent of the casino. Hollywood Casino Shreveport said it had planned to make its own bankruptcy filing later this year. The company wants to sell itself for $160 million to Eldorado Resorts while under bankruptcy protection, the HCSI president, John Hull, said.

title: Elections Today In New York
description: Primary elections will be held today in New York. Polling places in New York City and surrounding counties are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Elsewhere in the state, polling places will be open from noon to 9 p.m. Details are at www.elections.state.ny.us.

title: Keeping Children Off the Street Corners
description: At 3:40 a.m. on July 25, 2003, Nicolette R. offered to perform oral sex on an undercover police officer on Bryant Avenue in the Bronx for $40. She had been arrested once before on prostitution charges, in another city, but had been quickly let go when her pimp paid the fine.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE DROPS. Orange juice prices fell on speculation that groves in Florida will escape damage from Hurricane Ivan. In New York, orange juice for November delivery fell 5.8 cents, or 7 percent, to 76.6 cents a pound.

description: THE CLAIM -- Tea has more caffeine than coffee.

description: Technology stocks rose yesterday for a third day as a sales forecast from the Broadcom Corporation, a maker of semiconductors used in consumer electronics, spurred optimism about the industry's earnings outlook.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Fires Lead To Volvo Recall
description: The Ford Motor Company's Volvo unit recalled 460,000 sedans and wagons worldwide, the biggest in Volvo's 76-year history, after at least seven fires in an engine fan. The recall covers all S60 and S80 sedans and the V70 and V70XC wagons from the 2000 and 2001 model years as well as some from 1999, said a Volvo spokesman, Dan Johnson. An overheated cooling fan caused the fires, with no accidents or injuries reported, Mr. Johnson said. The recall includes about 150,000 vehicles in the United States.

title: 'Excuse Me. May I Have Your Seat?'
description: Thirty years ago, they were wide-eyed, first-year graduate students, ordered by their iconoclastic professor, Dr. Stanley Milgram, to venture into the New York City subway to conduct an unusual experiment.

title: One Less Hassle
description: ONE LESS HASSLE -- "Imagine no more lugging your bags to the airport," said Blaine Miyasato, the head of customer service at Hawaiian Airlines. He was not daydreaming. Customers of Hawaiian can pay for a Transportation Security Administration-certified delivery person to pick up their bags at their hotel, home or office in Hawaii (and present them with their boarding passes), then deliver the luggage to the airport. The baggage is then processed and sent to the destination airport or to the passenger's home or hotel on the West Coast. The service costs $30 for the first passenger (with a limit of two bags) and $15 for other passengers flying to the same destination. Hawaiian Air has contracted with the luggage-delivery company BaggageDirect.com. Bags can be picked up the morning of a flight or the day before at hotels, homes or offices in Honolulu and at major resorts on Maui for direct flights to Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego, Portland and Seattle. Hawaiian Air says it also offers the service for flights to Hawaii originating in Los Angeles and plans to expand to other mainland cities. "We believe this will rapidly take hold throughout the industry," said Jim Brown, a spokesman for Kinetics Inc., which provides the passenger-processing technology used by BaggageDirect.

title: CBS Offers New Experts to Support Guard Memos
description: When the CBS News anchor Dan Rather defended himself on camera and in interviews last Friday against questions being raised about documents he had used to bolster a report on President Bush's National Guard service, he and network executives considered the case closed.

title: Expected N.H.L. Lockout Curbs the Enthusiasm
description: TORONTO, Sept. 13 - Before Canada and the Czech Republic met in a semifinal of the World Cup of Hockey here on Saturday night, a scalper was asking $150 for tickets that retailed for $275. The previous night in St. Paul, before the other semifinal, between Finland and the United States, scalpers tried to unload $82 seats for less than half their face value.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Times Square Landmark To Be Sold
description: The former Knickerbocker Hotel, 1466 Broadway at 42nd Street, is to be sold for $160 million by the SL Green Realty Corporation to Sitt Asset Management and Steven J. Sutton. Built by the Astor family, the 16-story building opened as a luxurious hotel in 1906 but was turned into an office building in 1921. A Gap store is at ground level today. Green recently completed a $14.6 million renovation. The new owners may convert the upper floors back into a hotel, said Eddie Sitt. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Arrogance in the Pentagon : After success in Bosnia, why failure in Iraq?
59th General Assembly : A battered UN needs to go back to its roots
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Workers Sue
description: A group of workers has filed a class-action lawsuit against the companies hired to clean up after the World Trade Center attack. The workers claim they were exposed to toxic fumes and debris at ground zero. The lawsuit, which also names the entities that leased and managed the trade center, was filed on Friday in federal court in Manhattan and announced yesterday. The companies have not yet responded. The plaintiffs also intend to sue the City of New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the federal Environmental Protection Agency, David E. Worby, the lawyer for the workers, said. He was joined at a news conference by 13 people who he said had physical ailments directly related to their exposure to what he said were 9/11 toxins. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: U.S. Opens 2 Inquiries Into Arrest of Muslim Lawyer in Oregon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - The Justice Department has opened dual internal investigations into the department's arrest of a Muslim lawyer in Oregon who was mistakenly linked to the Madrid train bombings because fingerprints found at the scene of that terrorist attack were misread, officials said Monday.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

A Hedge Fund Master Receives Unwanted Attention
description: In a tough year on Wall Street, Israel A. Englander should be riding high. His $3.5 billion in hedge funds are up more than 8 percent -- at a time when the stock market is barely up for the year.

description: Hospital Supply Marketing Attracts New Scrutiny Efforts to end abusive practices in the marketing of hospital supplies will intensify this week, with a Senate panel expected to recommend a tougher anti-kickback law.

title: Packers Go Right to Top in Their Bid for N.F.C. Supremacy
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 13 - The Green Bay Packers could have and perhaps should have met the Carolina Panthers in last season's National Football Conference championship game. Instead, the Packers spent the off-season having to live down a blown lead against Philadelphia, a defeat that cost them a shot at the Panthers and maybe even the Super Bowl.

title: When the 'Spreadsheet People' Go to Vote

title: Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend on June 11 about pictures of Governors Island misstated the age of its fortress, Castle Williams. The error was repeated in a correction in this space on Aug. 3 (correcting a spurious legend that Walt Disney had once been incarcerated there). The fortress was built in the 19th century, not the 18th.

title: At Guard Convention, Bush Says He Is Proud of His Service
description: Even as questions about his service in the Texas Air National Guard continued to swirl through the presidential campaign, President Bush told a conference of the National Guard Association today that he was "proud to be one of them."

title: Aging: Alzheimer's on the Road
description: Even after Alzheimer's disease is diagnosed, experts say, many older people with the condition continue to drive. But a study released yesterday suggests that their driving ability should be carefully scrutinized.

title: At Schools, a Fresh Spin on Lunchroom Fare
description: A modern egg cream and healthier Jamaican beef patties are among the new menu items being offered this year to the 1.1 million children in New York City's public schools.

title: F.D.A. Links Drugs to Being Suicidal
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 13 - Top officials of the Food and Drug Administration acknowledged for the first time on Monday that antidepressants appeared to lead some children and teenagers to become suicidal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the authenticity of memos that suggested President Bush had received favorable treatment in the National Guard referred imprecisely in some copies to the Vietnam War experience of Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, who contended that the president had lied about fulfilling his Guard duty. While Mr. Harkin was indeed a Navy flier in Vietnam, he did not fly combat missions; he flew damaged planes out of the country for repair.

title: Mets' Brain Trust Isn't Thinking So Straight
description: THE Atlanta Braves, who visited Shea Stadium for a doubleheader last night, have won 12 -- going on 13 -- consecutive division championships. The Mets are in danger of finishing in last place for the third successive season.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: 2,000 More NATO Troops
description: NATO is to send an additional 2,000 troops to Kosovo ahead of parliamentary elections next month in the province, which is administered by the United Nations. The troops are being supplied by Italy, France and Germany and will bring the number of soldiers in the region to 20,000 by the time of the Oct. 23 vote. The NATO peacekeeping force in Kosovo was heavily criticized for its slow response to ethnic violence in the province in March. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Storm, Just Grazing Cuba, Crawls Toward Gulf Coast
description: HAVANA, Sept. 13 - Hurricane Ivan spared Cuba the worst of its fury on Monday, skirting the western tip of the island before lurching toward Mexico and then returning to its slow, fearsome path to the United States Gulf Coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSTEIN, LIBBY
description: GREENSTEIN -- Libby. Age 95. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Blanche and Herman. Loving sister of Alex Molk. Cofounder, with Ben, of Daher, Inc. Libby lit up every room she ever walked into, and made everyone's life more fun. The memories of her indominatable spirit will always give us joy.

title: Hawk vs. Hawk
description: The debate on how to proceed in Iraq is not between the hawks and the doves: it's within the hawk community, and it's between the gradualists and the confrontationalists.

title: Petroleum From Decay? Maybe Not, Study Says
description: Long-dead plant matter may not be the world's only source of hydrocarbons. Twelve miles or more beneath its surface, in hellish temperatures and under pressures 50,000 times that at sea level, the earth itself may be generating methane, say researchers who have squeezed common rock and water together to reproduce these conditions.

title: Your Heart, Your Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking On the Myth
description: On Sunday, a celebrating crowd gathered around a burning U.S. armored vehicle. Then a helicopter opened fire; a child and a journalist for an Arabic TV news channel were among those killed. Later, the channel repeatedly showed the journalist doubling over and screaming, "I'm dying; I'm dying."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: North Hempstead: Clean Water Aid Is Sought
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer yesterday proposed allocating $300 million in federal funds to help counties and towns prevent pollution from storm water runoff. He said suburban governments are paying too much to comply with the Clean Water Act. Mr. Schumer said the cost of preventing contaminated water from running off highways and lawns and into water supplies has far outstripped federal estimates. Complying with the regulations on Long Island had been estimated at $9.6 million, but Mr. Schumer said that just six cities and towns on Long Island had already spent $9.9 million. "Clean water and balanced books should not have to be an either-or choice," Mr. Schumer said. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Lawyer Relayed Statement of Terrorist, Reporter Says
description: An Egyptian reporter for the Reuters news agency testified under government subpoena yesterday in federal court that Lynne F. Stewart, a lawyer accused of aiding terrorism, called him four years ago to publicize a statement from a client convicted of terrorism, at a time when she was under orders not to do so.

title: CKE Restaurants Posts Loss in Quarter
description: CKE Restaurants Inc., which operates Hardee's and Carl's Jr. fast-food restaurants, reported a second-quarter loss yesterday after recording $7 million in costs to settle three class-action lawsuits.

title: Pittsburgh, Once a Showplace Hub, Feels US Airways' Woes
description: In the sprawling US Airways club at the Pittsburgh International Airport early Saturday afternoon, Fox News was blaring from the television, mostly to itself. Except for a reporter and a few employees, the club was empty. So was the long, gleaming terminal, where planes waited at fewer than half a dozen of the more than 100 departure gates.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Speaking in Tongues

title: This Lad's Life: Write, Ogle. Rewrite, Ogle. Drink, Ogle. Repeat.
description: In "Lads: A Memoir of Manhood," a former associate editor at Maxim, Dave Itzkoff, takes a baseball bat to his former employer, suggesting that behind the facade of rollicking lads and willing females, the magazine was a gulag where overworked and underpaid editors labored endlessly to come up with something -- anything -- that would sustain the magazine's monstrous newsstand sales.

title: WPP on Track to Become Second-Largest Agency
description: Correction Appended

title: CBS Offers New Experts To Support Guard Memos
description: Correction Appended

title: WHIRLPOOL TO INVEST $320 MILLION IN MEXICAN UNIT
description: Whirlpool plans to spend about $320 million over four years to produce more refrigerators, washing machines and stoves in Mexico, said Roy Armes, director general of the company's Mexican unit. "Mexico is one of the biggest investments that our company is making at this point in time," he said. Whirlpool, which paid $320 million two years ago for its stake in its Mexican joint-venture appliance unit, exports about 35 percent of its products. Whirlpool, based in Benton Harbor, Mich., will produce washing machines in its Monterrey plant by the second half of 2005 and will start construction next month on a refrigerator factory near the northern city of Saltillo.

title: Spanish Prime Minister Steers His Nation Back Into European Fold
description: Meeting yesterday with the leaders of Germany and France, Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero of Spain marked the return of his country to a more European-oriented foreign policy after his predecessor turned Spain into a staunch ally of America in the Iraq war.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Rules Against Paula Jones
description: A judge ruled yesterday against Paula Corbin Jones in her breach of contract lawsuit against Abraham Hirschfeld, the unpredictable New York real estate mogul. In a suit filed in August 2001, Ms. Jones claimed that Mr. Hirschfeld still owed her $1 million he promised to give her three years earlier if she would drop her sexual harassment suit against President Clinton. But Judge Peter K. Leisure of Federal District Court in Manhattan cited a letter dated Nov. 13, 1998, from a lawyer for Ms. Jones in which she agreed that "the money from Mr. Hirschfeld is no longer on the table," as part of her $850,000 settlement with Mr. Clinton. Judge Leisure threw out Ms. Jones's suit, but Mr. Hirschfeld, 84, did not go unpenalized. He was ordered to pay Ms. Jones's legal fees relating to one of Mr. Hirschfeld's motions that the judge deemed frivolous. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend on June 11 about pictures of Governors Island misstated the age of its fortress, Castle Williams. The error was repeated in a correction in this space on Aug. 3 (correcting a spurious legend that Walt Disney had once been incarcerated there). The fortress was built in the 19th century, not the 18th.

title: Taking Care of Teeth
description: To the Editor:

title: Recommendations: Averting Blood Clots in Flight
description: Responding to air travelers' concerns about blood clots, a problem sometimes called economy-class syndrome, a medical group issued recommendations yesterday on how to reduce this risk.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell on signs of slowing growth in Japan, the world's second-largest economy behind the United States. In New York, the dollar settled at 110.12 yen, up from 109.50 yen on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HSU, SUSAN
description: HSU--Susan. Died September 11, 2004. Founder of popular Su Su Yum Yum restaurant in Brooklyn Heights. Services at Cobble Hill Chapel, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, New York, 718-875-1640 or 718-522-3981. Viewing 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM Tuesday. Memorial service Wednesday, September 15, 12 noon. Burial service to follow at Kensico Cemetery, 3 PM.

title: F.D.A. Approves Lens Implant That Corrects Nearsightedness
description: Correction Appended

title: MIDAMERICAN ENERGY ENDS ZINC EXTRACTION PROJECT
description: MidAmerican Energy Holdings, which is 81 percent owned by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., said it would record a $340 million expense after taxes to shut down a money-losing zinc extraction project in California's Imperial Valley. MidAmerican, based in Des Moines, has lost $69 million on the project since beginning extraction in 2002, and its total investment was about $400 million, according to its most recent quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Berkshire, the investment company in Omaha that is controlled by Warren E. Buffett, will take a proportional share of the expense.

title: Afghan Region's New Governor Says Violence Is Ended; Denounces Warlord
description: HERAT, Afghanistan, Sept. 13 - The new governor of Herat, Sayed Muhammad Khairkhwa, spent Monday, his first day at work, ensconced at the top of the hill in the city's finest guesthouse, surrounded by American troops with maps and satellite dishes and dozens of Afghan National Army soldiers.

title: Death Penalty Is Not Option in Slaying of 2 Detectives
description: Brooklyn prosecutors filed first-degree murder charges yesterday against Marlon Legere, the 28-year-old man charged with killing two police detectives last week. But they said they could not seek his execution because no capital punishment law is in place, signaling a sharp shift in the status of the death penalty in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIVERA, CESAR
description: RIVERA--Cesar. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Cesar Rivera, associated with The Times from November 11th, 1967 until retiring in September 1st, 1994.

title: When Animals Articulate
description: When Animals Articulate

title: Talent Zoo Is Reinvited To Media Conference
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies has changed its mind about barring an Atlanta recruiter called Talent Zoo from taking part in a coming conference. The decision by the association to rescind the invitation was reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal.

title: The Urgent Task Left From 9/11
description: It was good news when President Bush flip-flopped on intelligence reform and endorsed giving the proposed new post of national intelligence director some real authority. That removed any excuse for the House and Senate to delay. It is time for them to enact true reform of the government's failure-ridden patchwork of 15 competing agencies.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I think that we now all believe that there is an increase in suicidal thinking and action that is consistent across all the drugs."

title: In England, 'Football' Is Life
description: Robert Green was not exactly in the middle of the maelstrom recently as England's national men's team drew with Austria and then went silent after beating Poland in World Cup qualifying matches. Not in the middle, but Green, a promising young goalkeeper for Norwich City, certainly had an orchestra seat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Reacts To Rating Cut
description: The Swiss reinsurance company Converium Holding said it expected to lose business after its financial strength rating was lowered by Standard & Poor's, setting off a 16 percent decline in its share price. Standard & Poor's cut Converium's financial strength rating two steps, to BBB from A-, on Friday, stating that "management credibility has been impaired," and citing concern about Converium's ability to "retain and attract business." A spokeswoman, Esther Gerster, said the board stood behind the chief executive, Dirk Lohmann, and his management team. Converium said in July that it had not set aside enough money to cover claims from policies written in the United States from 1997 to 2001. Increasing the reserves led to a $660 million second-quarter loss. The company, which is based in Zurich, shut its United States reinsurance business to new policies and announced a plan to sell shares.

title: Kerry Faults Bush for Failing to Press Weapons Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Senator John Kerry used the expiration of the assault-weapons ban on Monday to broaden his attack on President Bush over crime and security. Mr. Kerry said Mr. Bush had failed a "test of character" by not pressing Congress to extend the ban and by cutting financing for community police officers.

title: At War Against Dam, Tribe Turns to Old Ways
description: SHASTA LAKE, Calif., Sept. 13 - The enemy stands 602 feet tall and weighs 15 million tons. But Mark Franco said he was unafraid. His face painted with black stripes and his head crowned with eagle feathers, the 49-year-old Mr. Franco was at war for the first time in his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHIBNIK, JOAN
description: CHIBNIK--Joan. On September 11, 2004. Loving wife of the late Sheldon. Dear mother of Michael and Katharine. Beloved sister of Naomi and Diana and aunt of Constance, Judith, Laura, Deborah and Marion.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Ohio: Prosecutor Declines To Run Again
description: The Hamilton County prosecutor, Michael Allen, a Republican who has been under fire within his own party since acknowledging last month an affair with a female assistant prosecutor, withdrew from his race for re-election in November. Five Republicans said they would run for the post as write-in candidates, including the state treasurer, Joseph Deters, who was a Hamilton County prosecutor in the 1990's. Mr. Allen, above, faces a federal sexual harassment lawsuit from the assistant prosecutor, Rebecca Collins. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Putin and Russia : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
U.S. Court Considers a Once-and-for-All Tobacco Lawsuit
description: The federal appeals court in New York is considering a case that could radically reshape the national legal battle over the health effects of cigarettes and could set the stage for the largest verdict ever against the tobacco industry.

title: Corrections
description: A report from The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Wednesday about the nomination of Paul A. Crotty to succeed Judge Harold A. Baer on Federal District Court in Manhattan misstated Judge Baer's plans. He will remain on the bench as a senior judge, taking a reduced workload; he is not retiring.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Drug Suspect In New York
description: Jos Mara Henao Meja, suspected of leading a major narcotics organization based in Medelln, was arraigned in Federal District Court in Manhattan after being extradited from Colombia three days earlier. Mr. Henao, who was arrested by Colombian police in September 2002, was on a Justice Department short list of the world's top narcotics traffickers. He operated by putting up his extensive land holdings in Colombia as collateral for cocaine purchases, prosecutors charged, and he ran a network of distribution cells in American cities that communicated with each other mainly by pager. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Critics Call for Early Ouster of Disney Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 - Roy E. Disney, a nephew of Walt Disney, and his financial adviser, Stanley P. Gold, called on directors of the Walt Disney Company to search for a successor for Michael D. Eisner immediately, instead of waiting two years for his contract to expire.

title: Marlins Making Themselves at Home in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 - As the public address announcer bellowed a high-decibel greeting to everyone in attendance Monday afternoon -- "Welcome, ladies and gentleman, to U.S. Cellular Field!" -- not a soul was in the stands.

title: ALCOA AND UNION TO MEET AGAIN IN EFFORT TO END STRIKE
description: Alcoa plans to meet with workers at its Becancour smelter in Quebec in an effort to end a nine-week strike by United Steelworkers. Both sides said they might be willing to make concessions after meeting twice last week. The union is seeking changes in job security, subcontracting and pensions. Kevin Lowery, an Alcoa spokesman, said the company was "open to discussing certain aspects of the proposal." Gordon Ringuette, a union official, said the meeting might take place this week.

title: Behavior: Just Don't Breathe In
description: How bad was the air in Delaware's bars and casinos before the state enacted limits on smoking in public places two years ago? So bad that toll collectors in the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel probably breathe in less pollution.

title: A Calm, but Confusing, First Day of School
description: "Hi -- what school are you here for?" Les Ford, the sweet-voiced man standing by the front door, asked as students arrived yesterday morning for the opening of classes.

title: J. A. Westphal, 74, Tinkerer and Leader in Astronomy, Dies
description: James A. Westphal, an astronomer who led the Palomar Observatory and directed the team that built the first camera for the Hubble Space Telescope, died on Wednesday at his home in Altadena, Calif. He was 74.

title: San Gennaro Festival Adding Ex-Prosecutors to Its Board
description: Organizers of the Feast of San Gennaro said yesterday that they were adding five new board members, including two former prosecutors who would represent the mayor, in response to concerns that organized crime had once again tainted the annual festival in Little Italy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Retailers feel a worldwide chill
Key Rates
description: In percent

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a driver who became trapped in his car when a falling tree toppled a power line in Queens misattributed a report that the driver, Robert Kreisler, escaped major injuries because he remained inside the car. The comment was from Michael G. Clendenin, executive director for the Electrical Safety Foundation International -- not from Kenneth Downey, a Con Ed worker at the scene.

title: Glum Day for Hong Kong Democrats
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 13 - A series of tactical errors, with peculiarities in the voting process, prevented democracy advocates here from winning as many seats as expected in the legislative elections on Sunday, politicians and political analysts said here on Monday.

title: New Priorities in Environment
description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. to Address Possible Abuses in Hospital Supply Industry
description: Efforts to end abusive practices in the marketing of hospital supplies will intensify this week, with a Senate panel expected to recommend a tougher anti-kickback law today.

title: 1904:Ocean-Going Autos?: IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Sorting Out the Winners if US Airways Doesn't Survive
description: US Airways' second trip to bankruptcy court holds both promise and peril for the nation's other major airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, JOEL
description: SCHNEIDER -- Joel. The Board of Trustees, friends and colleagues at Sesame Workshop and around the world mourn the loss of Joel Schneider. He passed away on Sunday, September 12. It goes without saying how much we will miss this gentle man for his caring, inspiring, knowledgeable, witty and decent contributions made each and every day to Sesame Workshop's mission. He deeply believed in our work and was an outstanding ambassador in this country and around the world, helping children reach their highest potential through informal education. In his memory, Sesame Workshop will establish the "Joel Schneider International Research Fund for Global Health" to honor his passion and continue the Workshop's global health initiative--which he so ably led. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to this fund at Sesame Workshop, One Lincoln Plaza, New York, NY 10023. We are so grateful for the time we had with Joel and for the impact he made on so many lives. Our thoughts are with his family at this time. Gary E. Knell President and CEO Vincent A. Mai Chairman of the Board

title: Israel Approves Plan to Compensate Settlers
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 14 A Israel's security cabinet approved a compensation package today that would pay roughly $200,000 to $300,000 to each Jewish family that agrees to leave the Gaza Strip under Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's withdrawal plan.

title: Politicus : Polarized and divided?Not Americans on Iraq
Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOW, ETHEL FISHER
description: SOLOW--Ethel Fisher. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted mother of Peter, Matthew and the late Tom. Cherished grandmother of Jessica, Rebecca, Michael and Russell. Loving brother of Jerome and his wife Anne. Dear uncle of Jeffrey, Marc and Jodi. Services Tuesday, 1PM, Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Don't Play a Numbers Game, Experts Say, Just Eat Your Vegetables
description: Low-carbohydrate diets are everywhere, and the glycemic index has become the trendiest new concept in weight loss. Dr. Atkins' "New Diet Revolution," "The South Beach Diet," "The Zone" and even "The Idiot's Guide to Weight Loss" teach readers that all carbohydrates are not alike and that the way to judge which are good and which are bad is by how fast they are digested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YEDLIN, BENEDICT
description: YEDLIN--Benedict died September 10th in Princeton, New Jersey. He was 81 years old. Ben was a long time resident of Princeton and founder of The Yedlin Company, a real estate development and building company responsible for numerous commercial and residental projects in the Princeton area. Ben was born in Brooklyn, New York, attended Abraham Lincoln High School, and graduated from Brooklyn College. He was a decorated veteran of WWII. Six of his 50 combat missions as a ball turret gunner in a B24 Liberator bomber were flown over the oil fields of Ploesti, Romania. Ben was the founder and a board member of the New Jersey Chapter of Cancer Care and a board member of the Foundation for Mercer County Community College. He also served on the Housing Board of Princeton Township. He was a member of the 449th Bomb Group Association, from which he received a Humanitarian Service Award in 1998. He was also a member of the 15th Airborne Association, and the International B24 Liberator Club. Ben produced and directed videos and wrote about his WWII ex periences. Mr. Yedlin is survived by his wife, Antonia Flint; his sister and brother-inlaw, Isabel and Melvin Wolock; and his three children from his first marriage to Rita (Cahn) Yedlin: Charlie Yedlin and wife, Shelly, Jane Yedlin and husband, George McFadden, and Nancy Yedlin and husband, Peter Blasini, he is also survived by two stepdaughters: Jessica Flint and Jocelyn Flint and husband, Jeremy Robinson, Ben was the grandfather of six: Robert and Andrew Yedlin, Max and Jesse McFadden and Jake and Will Blasini. He was predeceased by his second wife, Nancy (McCartin) Yedlin. Contributions may be made in Ben's memory to: Cancer Care of New Jersey, 141 Dayton St., Ridgewood, NJ 07450. A memorial service is being planned to honor Ben in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACHRACH, MARJORIE BAKER
description: BACHRACH--Marjorie Baker, on Saturday September 11, 2004, after a long illness, at age 71. Beloved wife of the late Robert Lee Bachrach. Adored mother of Jeff and the late Clifford Lee Bachrach. Treasured sister of Deborah and Robert W. Bloch. Loving mother-in-law of Stacey Roth Bachrach and proud grandmother of Adam and Eric Bachrach. Loving mother-in-law of Karen Cohen (Bachrach) and proud grandmother of Trevor and Jessica Haba. Special aunt of Alexandra, Larry and Daniel Jeydel. Devoted aunt of Susan Stephens, Wendy Bachrach, Jonathan Gordon, Tricia Allgood and Alison Watters. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to East Hill Woods Memorial Fund, 611 East Hill Rd, Southbury, CT 06488 or a charity of your choice.

title: Childhood: Shortness Is No Stigma
description: A new study may give pause to parents considering seeking growth hormone treatments for their children because they are small in height.

description: DASHEVSKY--Jean. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Jean Dashevsky, beloved mother of Beverly Dash, and extends deepest condolences to their families. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: In Senate Hearing, C.I.A. Pick Pledges Nonpartisanship
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Representative Porter J. Goss, the Florida Republican who is President Bush's nominee to head the Central Intelligence Agency, asserted today in the face of occasionally sharp questioning by Democratic senators that if confirmed he would be an objective, nonpartisan spy chief.

title: Fade to Black
description: Gray is the new black. Blue is the new black. Wearing cell phones is the new black.

title: BP Venture in Russia Plans More Output and Investment
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 - The Russian venture of BP will increase oil output this year by more than its planned 12 percent and plans to raise spending in 2005 for a second year to ramp up production as oil continues to trade near historic highs.

description: Correction Appended

title: Hoping to Draw New Music From a Novelist's Old Poems
description: Before he became famous for his novels and screenplays, Paul Auster wrote poetry full of elusive imagery and observations that varied from the spooky to the amusingly and philosophically inarguable. Once he turned his attention to prose, 25 years ago, he left poetry behind. But the publication of "Collected Poems" (Overlook Press) early this year suggested a project for the Guggenheim Museum's Works and Process series, which opened its 21st season on Sunday with a program built on this side of Mr. Auster's work.

title: For Democrats, Dampened Hopes of Winning the House
description: Just a few weeks back, Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the No. 2 Democrat in the House, was predicting the potential of a Democratic takeover of the House in November, a power shift that he said would require the help of a political wind at the party's back. Well, he isn't feeling much of a draft these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOONKEL, WILLIAM I.
description: TOONKEL--William I. On Sunday, September 12, 2004, of Glen Rock, New Jersey. Husband of Rhoda (nee Minsberg). Father of Ellis Jeffrey Toonkel and his wife Felice, Gayle E. Toonkel and Richard N. Toonkel and his wife Laura. Grandfather of Jacob Hammond Toonkel, Isaac William Toonkel and Jennifer Fine McDermut. Great grandfather of Matthew Ellis McDermut and Fiona Margot McDermut.

title: As Weather Shifts, Beaches May Pay a Heavy Price
description: Coastal geologists, meteorologists and other experts have long warned Floridians not to rely on the relatively placid weather that prevailed in the last few decades, when their state grew explosively. Now the hurricane pattern is shifting, meteorologists say, and the shift has dangerous implications for the beaches -- and the coastal hotels, roads and condominiums -- on which Florida's tourism economy depends.

title: Bid to Decriminalize Prostitution in Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 13 - San Pablo Avenue was once the thriving, racy final stretch of the nation's first highway between New York and San Francisco, a center for jazz halls, gambling houses and brothels.

title: Unable to Save Their Houses, Jamaicans Manage at Least to Save One Another
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 13 - Karl Bradford swept a calloused hand toward the middle of the coffee-colored Hope River, raging swollen after the drenching rains of Hurricane Ivan.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,005 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Sony-Led Group Makes a Late Bid to Wrest MGM From Time Warner
description: A consortium led by the Sony Corporation of America reached a tentative agreement yesterday to buy Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the Hollywood studio famous for James Bond and the Pink Panther, for about $4.8 billion in cash, snatching it from Time Warner at the 11th hour.

description: If all goes according to plan, about half a dozen elderly people at risk of blindness will visit Dr. Lawrence J. Singerman's retina clinic in the coming weeks to receive injections in the whites of their eyes.

description: Magazine ad pages rose again in August for the fourth consecutive month of growth, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York said yesterday.

description: Watching the summer's events unfold -- war protests, an Olympics scoring scandal, numerous terror scares -- some people may have felt that it was all very familiar, that they had somehow been through this before.

description: STOLLER--Mildred, 83, of Tamarac, FL passed away September 10, 2004. Beloved mother of Steven, John, Bruce and Billy. Grandmother of Chad, Reuben, Jeremy and William, Amanda, Allison and Dominque. Great-grandmother of Nova and Jared. Sister of Tony Rolfe. Graveside service Monday September 13th, 11:15AM at Star of David Memorial Gardens, 7701 Bailey Road N. Lauderdale, 954-722-9000.

title: Putting Good Bacteria to Work
description: From a cellular perspective, you might think the human body was mostly human. But you'd be wrong. It is actually mostly bacterial.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Convention Detainee To Sue City
description: A Manhattan man notified the city yesterday that he intended to sue for wrongful arrest and imprisonment during the Republican National Convention. The man, Mark Perro, 21, says he was caught in a police sweep of protesters as he walked home from work. He said he was held for 48 hours before being given a summons for parading without a permit, according to a claim filed yesterday. He may be the first person to take civil action against the city over the convention arrests, said Kate O'Brien Ahlers, a spokeswoman for the City Law Department. In the filing, Mr. Perro, who works for a public relations company on 17th Street, said he was arrested on 16th Street and Irving Place on Aug. 31. A lawyer hired by Mr. Perro's parents was unable to speak with him while he was in custody, the filing said. Jim Dwyer (NYT)

title: When Edwards Needed Him the Most, Martin Was There
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 13 - On offense, two of the Jets' top three receivers, Wayne Chrebet and Santana Moss, had seemingly spent more time in the trainer's room than they had on the practice field. On defense, all but one of the starters among the linebackers and secondary had played last season either at a different position or for a different team.

title: Nature's Remedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Women suicide bombers : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Bill Rancic, who won a job with Donald Trump on the television show "The Apprentice," referred imprecisely to the Chicago hotel and condominium project on which Mr. Rancic is working. Mr. Trump has signed a $73 million agreement to buy Hollinger International's stake in the project along with its site, now occupied by a Hollinger property, The Chicago Sun-Times. The purchase is not complete; Mr. Trump is to pay the balance on the departure of The Sun-Times, expected next month.

title: World Briefings
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Cutting an Outrageous Path of Camp, Sleaze and Silliness
description: Last week was the start of New York's Fashion Week, and it was also a week when two big-in-England new-wave bands came to town. On Thursday night the Roseland Ballroom played host to Franz Ferdinand, a sly Scottish group in love with well-tailored bass lines and stiletto-sharp guitars. In fact, Franz Ferdinand's self-titled debut albumseems ready for the catwalk: it sounds stylish and slightly anorexic.

title: US Airways Asks to Skip Pension Payment
description: US Airways started out on its second bankruptcy by asking a federal judge yesterday for permission to skip a $110 million contribution to its employee pension plans that is due tomorrow.

title: Pyongyang critics face dissuasion, intimidation and threats : South cool to anti-Kim activists
When the Vision Goes, the Hallucinations Begin
description: One day a few years ago, Doris Stowens saw the monsters from Maurice Sendak's "Where the Wild Things Are" stomping into her bedroom. Then the creatures morphed into traditional Thai dancers with long brass fingernails, whose furious dance took them from the floor to the walls to the ceiling.

title: North Korea Seen as Tying Nuclear Talks to U.S. Election
description: SEOUL Sept. 14 A North Korea is waiting out the American presidential election in order to bargain with the winner over its nuclear weapons program, according to analysts here and a British diplomat who left Pyongyang today.

title: BAYER AND SCHERING-PLOUGH FORM PARTNERSHIP
description: Bayer said yesterday that it had entered a partnership with Schering-Plough for marketing and distribution of Bayer's primary care pharmaceuticals, including the impotence drug Levitra in the United States and Puerto Rico. The deal will reduce Bayer's health care costs in the United States by 75 percent, affecting 1,800 jobs that will be cut or transferred to Schering-Plough, based in Kenilworth, N.J. Bayer, based in Leverkusen, Germany, will focus its United States health care business on profitable specialty drugs, biotechnology products and will start an oncology business unit with headquarters in West Haven, Conn. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Here a Skunk, There a Skunk: A New Kind of Wildlife Census
description: Road kill is a subject of endless fascination. To some of us.

title: Proving the Possibilities of the Humble Recorder
description: The music sounds like lost puppies, mourning birds, wordless voices. It flits and starts and even frolics in little bursts across the stage, now quiet as a hoarse rasp of almost tuneless breath, now rising to the shriek of a factory whistle.

title: Raising the Pressure in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 13 - With four months to go before nationwide elections in Iraq, the insurgency has grown more brazen and sophisticated, prompting American commanders to begin a series of military operations to regain control over large sections of the country lost in recent months.

title: When the 'Spreadsheet People' Go to Vote (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASLOW, NORMAN
description: MASLOW -- Norman. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our former President, Norman Maslow. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his family. Ted Markson, President

title: When the 'Spreadsheet People' Go to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Wife's Abduction at Hospital Is Apprehended
description: After an intense manhunt, a man who kidnapped his wife from a hospital in Queens on Saturday and shot a desk clerk in the face was captured yesterday -- armed -- as the couple stepped off a Greyhound bus in North Carolina, the police said.

title: Another Approach: Fingers on the Genetic Switchboard
description: RNA interference is not the only new way to control the activity of genes in the body. When 81-year-old Peter Cummins received 10 injections in each of his legs last month, he became part of the first human testing of another potentially promising method: proteins known as zinc-finger transcription factors.

title: U.S. Seeks Tougher Tone in Resolution on Iran's Nuclear Program
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Executive Accepts Ruling
description: The South Korean bank Kookmin said it would start selecting candidates to succeed its chief executive, Kim Jung Tae, after failing to agree on whether to appeal a ruling barring him from running the bank. Mr. Kim told a board meeting in Seoul he did not plan to challenge a ruling that he was negligent when the bank prepared its 2003 accounts, a Kookmin spokesman said. Kookmin's board decided to seek outside legal advice during the next few weeks before deciding whether the bank would appeal the ruling, the spokesman said. The bank, which is based in Seoul, was fined 2 billion won ($1.8 million) by the Financial Supervisory Commission for violating accounting standards when the bank merged with its credit card unit last year. Mr. Kim was banned by the regulator from running the bank when his three-year term ends.

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter column yesterday, about President Bush's comfortable manner at campaign events, misstated the intended use of the $87 billion he requested from Congress last year. It was for military and reconstruction efforts in Afghanistan and Iraq -- not Afghanistan and Washington.

title: A Merger of Labels Puts Trove in Limbo
description: In the weeks since American and European authorities approved the merger of the recorded-music businesses of Sony and Bertelsmann , two of the world's five biggest record companies, virtually all the discussion has been about what the deal means in the vast popular-music market, with barely a mention of the labels' classical catalogs.

title: An Outsider's Grim Prognosis for Pension Agency
description: It has been a struggle for some, but most big companies are coming up with enough cash to keep their pension funds legally sound, after three years of extraordinary losses. Not so their government backstop. Slowly but surely, the federal agency that insures pensions is running out of money.

title: The world vote : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
You Can't Always Get What You Want
description: You Can't Always Get What You Want

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, MELVIN
description: SCHACHTER--Melvin. Loving, gentle, silly, tennis-playing husband of Yvette, father of Allison, Janice and Julia; best friend of the gorillas and life-long supporters of the underdog. You live on in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAKEMAN, IRENE
description: BLAKEMAN--Irene. September 12, 2004. Class personified. Loving and beloved by daughters Joan Blakeman of NYC and Janet Martin of FL. We are always together. Joan and Janet

title: Mayor Recommits toAmbitious Recycling Pact
description: The Bloomberg administration plans to announce today that it will sign a 20-year contract with one of the nation's largest recycling companies, a move that assures the city's broad recommitment to recycling.

title: Kennedy is Confident Kerry Will Right His Ship
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy says he is not too worked up about the shape of the presidential race right now despite the fact that his junior colleague from Massachusetts is trailing in the polls.

title: Wal-Mart's New Spin
description: Wal-Mart, the world's biggest company, says it wants to improve its image both by doing a better job of getting its message out and by being more willing to "compromise." This new approach makes sense, given the charges that have been hurled against the company recently. But if Wal-Mart wants to improve its image, it should focus less on shaping its message and more on changing the way it does business.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, MARY
description: BERNSTEIN--Mary. Mommy darling, it's been 3 long years today and you are so loved and missed. Barbara

title: Opponents Call Putin'sOverhaul Plan a Step Back
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 - President Vladimir V. Putin ordered a stunning overhaul of Russia's political system on Monday in what he called an effort to unite the country against terrorism. If enacted, as expected, the proposals would strengthen his already pervasive control over the legislative branch and regional governments.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: More Letters Rigged To Ignite
description: The offices of Govs. Mark Warner of Virginia and Bob Wise of West Virginia received letters that were rigged to ignite, making a total of 19 sent to governors and the head of the Nevada Department of Corrections since last week, officials said. The two most recent letters were intercepted before they could ignite. Investigators are focusing on the maximum-security Ely State Prison in Nevada, the return address, a state official said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Violence From Denzel Washington; Talking Cows From Disney
description: Man on Fire

title: AOL store tempts comparison shoppers
U.S. Modifies Sanctions Threat in New Sudan Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 14 A The United States circulated a new draft resolution on Sudan today, seeking to overcome opposition on the Security Council by modifying a threat to put sanctions on the country's leaders and its oil industry if the government fails to curb the continuing violence in the Darfur region.

title: Marketing Cost Cited as Profit Falls at Campbell
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit declined 20 percent, the biggest drop in more than two years, as costs for marketing and job cuts rose.

title: Giambi Is Almost Ready, But Has No Place to Go
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 13 - Now comes the latest Jason Giambi predicament for the Yankees. Giambi still needs work in the minor leagues as he recovers from a benign tumor, but all of the Yankees' affiliates are done for the season.

title: Enjoy Being a Girl? De la Renta's Your Guy
description: Oscar de la Renta, who makes caftans for the Dowager Duchess of Devonshire to wear at home in her itty-bitty pile, Chatsworth, had the ponytailed freshman Ashley Olsen at his show yesterday, one of those modern incongruities that only fashion can reconcile.

title: Correction
Hostages in Iraq : Aid agencies shouldn't take unnecessary risks
1929:Victim in a Trunk : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
An Artist Who Makes the Field His Canvas
description: The most carefully handled bat in baseball comes wrapped in cellophane.

title: CARDINAL HEALTH TO RESTATE RESULTS FOR 3 YEARS
description: Cardinal Health Inc., one of the nation's largest drug distributors, said it would restate three years of financial results and delay its report for the fiscal fourth quarter by an additional 15 days. Earnings will fall 25 percent in the first quarter of the fiscal year, which began July 1, from the year earlier, and by 10 percent to 15 percent in the first six months, the company said in a filing. The Securities and Exchange Commission began an inquiry last October into how Cardinal accounts for revenue, including from bulk deliveries to customers' warehouses. Cardinal's chief financial officer resigned in July, and the company's audit committee is conducting a review. The board's audit committee determined that results from fiscal 2001, 2002 and 2003 and the first three quarters of 2004 "should no longer be relied upon."

title: Buckingham Palace's New Tourist Attraction: Batman
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 - A group that advocates greater rights for fathers in child custody cases sent two of its operatives over the fence at Buckingham Palace on Monday. One of them, dressed as Batman, scampered up a ladder to a ledge near the queen's balcony, setting off a security alert and a tense standoff with the police.

title: Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend on June 11 about pictures of Governors Island misstated the age of its fortress, Castle Williams. The error was repeated in a correction in this space on Aug. 3 (correcting a spurious legend that Walt Disney had once been incarcerated there). The fortress was built in the 19th century, not the 18th.

title: Despite oil, 'global recovery confirmed'
INSIDE
description: Her Name Is Woman (His Is Oscar de la Renta) In his spring collection for Fashion Week, the designer celebrated femininity with frothy taffeta skirts, loopy crocheted knits and embroidered hothouse caftans: clothes that projected to the farthest row. FASHION, PAGE B11

title: Serbia parties called 'mafia'-riddled
Nascar Wasn't Broke, but They Fixed It
description: It is rare for a sport to change the nature of its television contracts in the middle of a deal. Oh, there are tweaks, like changing starting times, but big alterations are usually ways for a league to induce networks to pay more money in a new agreement.

title: Your Heart, Your Choices (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dropping Hyphen, Some Great Old Stores Become Just Macy's
description: In the not-so-distant past, the names Burdines, Rich's, Goldsmith's, Bon March and Lazarus had a local glory as the emporiums where customers bought their back-to-school clothes and discovered their Mother's Day presents. But yesterday, their owner, Federated Department Stores, announced that those stores, nearly 200 of them, would be known simply as Macy's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cab Service For Disabled
description: Taxi and Limousine Commission officials announced yesterday that the minimum price for a wheelchair-accessible taxicab medallion at next month's auction would be 18 percent less than that of a regular medallion. Officials are hoping to stimulate interest in 27 medallions that will be set aside for wheelchair-accessible yellow cabs in the auction. Twenty-seven medallions for cabs that use compressed natural gas will have the same discount. In all, 300 medallions will be auctioned off. Taxi officials set the minimum bid price for wheelchair-accessible and natural-gas medallions at $219,000, or $48,000 below the minimum bid for a regular individual medallion. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Envoy rejects criticism by EU members : Turkey is advised to drop adultery law
Bodily Exercise Profiteth
description: Correction Appended

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Cooper Union Engages the Neighborhood
description: Tucked away on a triangular island at the edge of Astor Place, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art seems the very picture of academic isolation. Its hulking brown Foundation Building, completed in 1859, is as forbidding as a monastery.

title: When the Computers Crash, All That's Left Are the Patients
description: Our clinic computers went on the blink last week, and work ground to a halt. The receptionists couldn't confirm scheduled appointments or make new ones. The nurses had no way to record vital signs or transmit phone messages. The billers couldn't bill.

title: Rent Subsidies Are Preserved for Manhattan Plaza Tenants
description: After months of intense negotiations, the tenants and new owner of the Manhattan Plaza housing development, near the Broadway theater district, said yesterday that they had hammered out an agreement to preserve the development's complex system of subsidized rents.

title: Seeking a Favor, and Finding It, Among the Strangers on a Train
description: Really, how hard could it be? Walk into a crowded subway car, bend down and ask a seated stranger -- politely but directly -- to give up his or her seat.

title: German president breaks a taboo
Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend on June 11 about pictures of Governors Island misstated the age of its fortress, Castle Williams. The error was repeated in a correction in this space on Aug. 3 (correcting a spurious legend that Walt Disney had once been incarcerated there). The fortress was built in the 19th century, not the 18th.

title: Bush Describes Kerry's Health Care Proposal as a 'Government Takeover'
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Sept. 13 - President Bush sped across southwest Michigan on Monday, assailing Senator John Kerry for plans that he said would result in nationalized health care. Mr. Bush also defended his proposal to privatize part of Social Security, saying longstanding Democratic contentions that it would undercut the system amounted to "the most tired, pathetic way to campaign for the presidency."

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: LSI Logic Loss To Be Wider
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, which makes computer chips for DVD players and storage equipment, said yesterday that its third-quarter net loss would be wider than forecast because customers have too much inventory. The loss will be 14 cents to 17 cents a share, compared with a prior forecast of break even to a 3-cent loss, said the company, which is based in Milpitas, Calif. Sales will be $370 million to $400 million, less than the $435 million to $465 million forecast earlier, the company said. Shares of the company dropped 30 cents, or 5.7 percent, to $4.95, in extended trading after the report was released.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the authenticity of memos that suggested President Bush had received favorable treatment in the National Guard referred imprecisely in some copies to the Vietnam War experience of Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, who contended that the president had lied about fulfilling his Guard duty. While Mr. Harkin was indeed a Navy flier in Vietnam, he did not fly combat missions; he flew damaged planes out of the country for repair. (Go to Article)

title: North Korea Offers to Show Site of Blast to Diplomats
