description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Sept. 14 - North Korea will show foreign diplomats as early as Tuesday the site of a mysterious explosion that it said was intended to blow up a mountain for a hydroelectric dam, British journalists reported Monday night from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.

title: The name game:Can anyone famous be a designer?
Burial Site of Dinosaurs Holds Clues to Their Lives
description: Fossil evidence of dinosaurs caring for their young is rare, but it is hard to imagine what else could have been going on in a 125-million-year-old tableau unearthed in northeastern China. In about five square feet of space, paleontologists discovered the remains of an adult dinosaur and 34 youngsters.

title: Car Bomb Kills at Least 47 at a Police Headquarters in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 14 A A suicide car bomb packed with artillery shells exploded outside police headquarters here this morning, ripping into a crowd of hundreds of young men seeking to join the nascent Iraqi police force, killing at least 47 people and wounding 114 others, police and health officials said.

title: White House Opposes Democratic Plan for Medicare Price Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 A The Bush administration came out today in opposition to Democratic proposals to hold down the scheduled 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums next year, saying that a one-year freeze would lead to much higher premiums in 2006.

title: A Rope Breaks, and an Exuberant Teenager Is Dead
description: A 16-year-old Manhattan boy who tried to enter his former apartment by rappelling from the roof was killed yesterday when his rope broke and he fell several stories to his death.

title: It Was a Debut to Forget for Warner and the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 13 - As the game in front of him sputtered to a close, the look on Kurt Warner's face said everything.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged In Robbery Of Nun
description: A 33-year-old man was charged yesterday in the robbery of a Roman Catholic nun near her convent in July, the police said. Detectives identified the man, Miguel Hacha, through descriptions and found him in a homeless shelter, officials said, and the nun identified him in a lineup. The police say Mr. Hacha grabbed the nun, Sister Ngozi Ohari, near her convent in East New York and took her pocketbook. Ms. Ohari was wearing a habit when she left the St. Rita's Convent on Shepherd Avenue to take the subway to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, witnesses said. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: When the 'Spreadsheet People' Go to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: In Coughlin Time, You Can Be Early and Still Be Late
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 13 - In the player-relations department, the reign of Giants Coach Tom Coughlin started poorly and is already showing signs of unraveling one game into the season.

title: Powell Rejects 9/11 Panel's Plan for Intelligence Office
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - The Bush administration said Monday that it disagreed with a major recommendation of the Sept. 11 commission and that the president did not want officials of the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and the Pentagon to serve in the inner circle of a new national intelligence director.

title: Bringing Credibility to a Firefighter's Tale
description: WHEN Terry Quinn was a teenager in the late 1970's, he attended a Christmas party at a Manhattan firehouse. The firemen, and they were all men then, were at ease. Their families were there. The firehouse was fun; the firemen were fun. "It was weird, at least to me, to see people in their workplace enjoy each other." said Mr. Quinn, the Brooklyn-born son of an insurance executive and a homemaker. "It put a bug in my ear."

title: VIRTUAL-ORCHESTRA PROBLEMS
description: The New York State Employment Relations Board has issued a complaint against the Opera Company of Brooklyn for unilaterally voiding its contract with Local 802 of American Federation of Musicians, which represents Broadway and many off Broadway musicians, union officials announced. The complaint, issued last Tuesday, stated that the opera company violated state law when it withdrew from its contract with the union in late April after objecting to a clause that prohibited the company from using a so-called virtual orchestra machine, which the union says costs its members jobs. David Lennon, the president of Local 802, hailed the board's ruling in a statement. Jay D. Meetze, the company's founder and principal conductor, said his company has a hearing with the board next month and is moving ahead with meetings with the makers of the virtual orchestra machine, RealTime Music Solutions. "We are confident that they will understand our side," Mr. Meetze said. JESSE McKINLEY

title: North Korea Seen as Tying Nuclear Talks to U.S. Election
description: SEOUL Sept. 14 A North Korea is waiting out the American presidential election in order to bargain with the winner over its nuclear weapons program, according to analysts here and a British diplomat who left Pyongyang today.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft And Polycom Plan Venture
description: Microsoft and Polycom are scheduled to announce today a multiyear development and marketing partnership intended to combine further existing audio and videoconferencing technology with personal computers. The first offering from the two companies, available later this year, will bring Microsoft's instant messaging technology to a range of Polycom audio and videoconferencing devices. By 2006, the companies plan to offer the ability to start a conference session from desktop applications like Microsoft Office with a few clicks of a computer mouse, said Anupam Sahai, the director of system architecture and technology for Polycom. As part of the alliance, Polycom, a leader in phone- and video-conferencing for corporations, will endorse Session Initiation Protocol, a standard for collaboration software that Microsoft is backing. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: The Memory of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sale Of Apartments Is Approved
description: The Health and Social Affairs Ministry said that it had approved the sale of more than 80,000 state-owned apartments to the Fortress Investment Group of New York for 2.1 billion euros ($2.6 billion). Fortress was the high bidder for the properties, which are being sold by Gagfah, a unit of a government-run insurance group. The government agency plans to use the revenue from the sale to try to prevent an increase in state pension insurance contributions. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, MALCOLM L.
description: STEIN--Malcolm L. On September 11, 2004. Beloved husband of Harriet Weiss Stein. Loving father of Jonathan W. Stein (Sharon Merriam) and Alison Eve Stein (Andrew Isaacs). Son of the late Charles and Lillian Stein. Brother of Dr. Marjorie L. Stein. Son-in-law of Blanche Barasch Weiss and the late David Weiss. Brother-in-law of Howard and Karen Weiss, uncle of Bara and Alex Tisch, Sabrina Weiss and Adam Weiss. A loved and respected friend and advisor. Graduate of Columbia Univerity School of Law, 1965; LL.M. 1967. Lecturer in law, Columbia University School of Law, 1967-1969. Attorney-advisor, Office of Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, U.S. Treasury Department, Washington, DC, 1969 - 1971. Partner, Roberts & Holland, 1975-1991. Founder and Partner, Stein, Shiers & Goldsmith, 1992-present. Funeral services will be held September 13, at 11:45, at Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: U.S. Attacks Rebel Base in Falluja; 20 Are Killed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 13 - American fighter planes fired at targets in Falluja on Monday in strikes aimed at what commanders said was a meeting place for operatives working with the militant leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi.

title: Arts Briefing
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: If He's Out, Howe Would Prefer to Know Now
description: Art Howe politely declined to be a good soldier yesterday. He said that if it were true that the Mets intended to dismiss him as the team's manager once this embarrassing season was over, he would prefer to be shown the door immediately.

title: The Right Ear Is From Mars
description: Belting out a few notes on key might take years of practice, and perfect pitch the right genetics, but when it comes to something as simple as telling noise from symphony, speech from music, all ears are created equal -- or so it was once thought.

title: Funds' Manager Settles Case Over Trading
description: PEA Capital, which manages seven Pimco funds, and two affiliates agreed yesterday to pay $50 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations that they allowed a hedge fund to make frequent trades at the expense of other investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLLER, SHIRLEY (TUCKER)
description: STOLLER--Shirley (Tucker), 79, of Hollywood, FL, died on September 9, 2004. She is survived by her family Marcia, Bruce, Alexis and Jarrett Kern. She was greatly loved and will be missed.

title: Passengers Are Cleared to Network About the Cabin
description: On a flight to speak to the New York Power Authority in upstate New York, Gilda Carle was writing an article about how to progress in networking from "eye-olog" -- a word she coined to denote eye contact -- to dialogue, then monologue.

title: Subandrio, 89, Indonesian Independence Advocate Jailed for 30 Years, Dies
description: Subandrio, who was a major voice for Indonesian independence while he was President Sukarno's foreign minister but then spent 30 years in prison after being condemned to die by a military tribunal in 1966, died on July 3 at his home in South Jakarta. He was 89.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Aegis Group, London, raised its forecasts for worldwide advertising spending in 2004 and 2005, citing growth in markets like Asia, Europe and the United States. Aegis now calls for a gain this year of 5.7 percent from 2003, compared with a forecast in March for a gain of 5.3 percent. For next year, Aegis predicts an increase of 5 percent from 2004, compared with a previous estimate of 4.4 percent.

title: Junking Science
description: The Bush administration has from time to time found it convenient to distort science to serve political ends. The result is a purposeful confusion of scientific protocols in which "sound science" becomes whatever the administration says it is. In the short run, this is a tactic to override basic environmental protections in favor of industry. In the long run, it undermines the authority of science itself.

title: Netanyahu Joins Call for Referendum on Pullout of Gaza Settlers
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 - Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's influential finance minister, called Monday for a national referendum on the proposed withdrawal of Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip. The referendum could complicate the plan set out by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: Learning After 9/11 That There Is a Balm in Baseball
description: A few days after the World Trade Center attacks, Scott Brosius found himself inside the Armory on Lexington Avenue, among shocked families submitting DNA samples that might be matched with any trace of missing loved ones. Like many that week, Mr. Brosius, the Yankees' third baseman, felt humbled by some big questions, not the least of which were: "What am I doing here? What do I have to offer these people?"

title: A Great Tax Plan (for Accountants)
description: As a tax guy, I found myself chuckling quietly when President Bush said in his speech at the Republican National Convention that he would "lead a bipartisan effort to reform and simplify the federal tax code." Before long, I was howling with laughter. Sorry, folks, but efforts to "simplify" the code always bring clients streaming through my door. And the president quickly went on to show why: he wasn't able to offer simplification without adding two levels of complication within the next two minutes.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Rogers To Buy Back Stake In Unit
description: Rogers Communications tentatively agreed yesterday to buy back a 34 percent stake in its Rogers Wireless unit now held by AT&T Wireless. The deal, valued at 1.77 billion Canadian dollars, was widely expected as Rogers had earlier agreed to help AT&T Wireless shed its stake by the end of the month. If the transaction is approved by both companies' boards, Rogers will pay AT&T Wireless 36.37 Canadian dollars for each of the 48.6 million shares it holds. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Jerome Chodorov, Broadway and Film Writer, Dies at 93
description: Jerome Chodorov, a prolific playwright and librettist and co-author of the book for the musical "Wonderful Town," who survived as a screenwriter despite being on a Hollywood blacklist, died on Sunday in Nyack, N.Y. He was 93 and lived in Pomona, N.Y.

title: Preserving an Old-Forest Wilderness at the Ends of the Earth
description: LAGO ESCONDIDO, Chile - Tierra del Fuego is a harsh, desolate and unyielding place, hostile to most human endeavors. But from the ruins of a failed logging venture here at "the uttermost part of the earth," an innovative effort to manage and preserve the world's southernmost old-forest wilderness is about to begin.

title: A Balanced Budget, Without Higher Property Taxes, Is Proposed for Nassau County
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 13 - Congratulations were offered and applause broke out here Monday afternoon as the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, declared victory over the county's fiscal crisis by proposing a balanced budget for 2005 that does not raise property taxes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Marlboros For China
description: The Philip Morris International unit of the Altria Group won approval for the first time to have its Marlboro brand cigarettes made in China, said the state-run Longyan Cigarette Factory. "The State Tobacco Monopoly Administration appointed us to make cigarettes for Philip Morris," said Liu Zhuping, an official at Longyan Cigarette in Fujian. "We will wait for Philip Morris's tobacco leaves to arrive and produce as many sticks as State Tobacco tells us to." A Philip Morris spokeswoman, Nerida White, declined to comment. State Tobacco controls production, marketing and trade in China's $31 billion cigarette market.

title: A Prescription for Drug Success
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Get
description: The must-haves: Army boots, tweeds, skinny ties, wingtips, rose-gold watches and parkas.

title: The Romantics
description: Who better to rock fall's seductively bohemian looks than the modern troubadour?

title: Graphic Design
description: This season, good style is in the details, from cuff links to cuffed trousers.

title: Tickling the Ivy
description: Bulldog, bulldog, bow-wow-wow! A study of the men's wear classics with some Yale student bodies.

title: 8 Is Enough
description: Need some jean therapy? These styles are just what the denim doctor ordered.

title: The Originals
description: Starting here, starting now, T will make a habit of celebrating individuals with genuine style, that rarest of commodities.

title: Fun, Floral and Fringe
description: Photographs from Marc Jacobs, Marc, Michael Kors, Anna Sui, J. Mendel, Donna Karan, Milly and more.

title: Fast-Paced Drama
description: "The 24-Hour Plays" is an annual theatrical high-wire act in which six one-acts are written, cast, directed and performed in less than a day.

title: Promotions Announced for Slain Detectives
description: The two police detectives who were shot and killed on Friday have been promoted posthumously to the rank of first-grade detective, officials said yesterday.

title: Amid the Cannoli, a Remnant of the Bad Old Days Returns to the San Gennaro Festival
description: COME one come all to the Feast of San Gennaro. Eat the spicy sausage that you will remember well into October. Contemplate the larger meaning of "Volare." Honor the event's religious roots by buying a plastic statuette in the church courtyard (blessings free with purchase).

title: In Guard Speech, Bush Says He Is Proud of His Service
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 14 - Speaking to National Guard members and veterans at a politically charged moment, President Bush acknowledged on Tuesday the hardships that the war in Iraq had caused Guard members and their families, and attacked Senator John Kerry for arguing that the United States was spending too much in Iraq, and too little at home.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Celestica To Miss Profit Forecast
description: Celestica, the world's fourth-biggest maker of electronics for other companies, said yesterday that third-quarter profit and sales would miss forecasts. Sales will be $2.05 billion to $2.15 billion, with profit at 7 cents to 11 cents a share, the company, based in Toronto, said. In July, Celestica had forecast sales of $2.25 billion to $2.40 billion and profit of 11 cents to 17 cents. A spokeswoman, Laurie Flanagan, did not return a message left with the company. The sales and profit shortfall is the result of some large communications and information-technology customers reducing their orders, the company said. Shares rose 18 cents, to $14.57.

title: The Minimalist; A Little Lump Of Luxury In the Pasta
description: IN a world that seems awash in luxurious ingredients, maybe crab meat doesn't seem like such a big deal anymore. Still, at $40 a pound or so, a few six- or eight-ounce crab cakes can mean a pretty expensive meal. Eaten straight, crab meat does not go very far.

title: All in a Day's Frenzy: 6 Plays in 24 Hours
description: Correction Appended

title: Big nations 'examine' Russian's proposals; others are critical : EU divided in reaction to Putin's power play
Developer Gives Suozzi Helping Hand in Land Deal
description: GLEN COVE, N.Y., Sept. 14 - The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, is about to move into a new house here and wrap up what he calls a very smart real estate deal. His family will get a more private home for $1.025 million, and he will earn $650,000 by selling a piece of the land, a maneuver made possible by a real estate developer who is a political donor to Mr. Suozzi.

title: Corrections
Paid Notice: Deaths   LOPEZ, JENNIFER A.
description: LOPEZ--Jennifer A. Beloved daughter of John and Carole Lopez. Sister of John, Jude, Jamie, Jim, Julia and Jessica. A memorial service will be held Friday, Sept 17th, 2004, 4PM at the Marble Collegiate Church, 1 W. 29 St, N.Y.C.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Gay Rights Insurance Law Signed
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed gay rights legislation into law Monday, requiring insurance companies doing business in California to offer the same health coverage to registered same-sex partners as they do to married couples. "This is proof that the governor meant what he said when he said he wanted to be the governor for all Californians," said Lorri L. Jean, chief executive of the L.A. Gay and Lesbian Center. The new law does not extend to unmarried heterosexual couples under age 62. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Computer Company Breakup
description: The LG IBM P.C. Corporation, a joint South Korean computer-making venture between I.B.M. and LG Electronics, said it would be broken up by January. I.B.M. and LG will divide the operations of the venture, which was established in 1996 and posted a profit of $8.6 million last year. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., will retain the server, ThinkCenter desktop computer and ThinkPad laptop businesses. LG, which is based in Seoul, is expected to start marketing its own Xnote laptops and Multinet desktops more extensively after the breakup. LG IBM was implicated in a bribery scandal this year. The company was accused of obtaining state contracts for computer parts and supplies illegally. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: Fewer Death Sentences Being Imposed in U.S.
description: Juries imposed far fewer death sentences in each of the last four years than they did on average over the previous decade, according to a new report.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic's Lawyers Ask For Trial Suspension
description: The court-appointed British lawyers who have just begun their defense of Slobodan Milosevic requested that the war crimes trial be halted, pending an appeals ruling. The United Nations judges recently imposed the two lawyers on Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, against his will after cardiologists found him too ill to continue defending himself. But Mr. Milosevic wants to appeal and recover the right to act as his own lawyer. Meanwhile, he has refused any contact with the defense team, and numerous witnesses have canceled their appearances, creating a new bind for the bench in the drawn-out and troubled trial. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: WPP closes in on Omnicom, the No. 1
National Study Shows Colleges in Need of Help
description: America's schools -- from kindergarten to high school -- have improved in recent years. But, in many states, universities are being left behind, according to a national "report card" of American higher education being released today.

title: Buenos Das, Swing Voter
description: Unlike African-Americans -- who as a constituency are overwhelmingly Democratic -- Latinos are a little more mysterious with their intentions at the polls. In a year in which politicians expect to live or die by the swing vote, Hispanic voters are like catnip to the presidential candidates. Tilt a few of the expected seven million Latino ballots this way or that in a few battleground states, and the election can be won, or so the strategists believe. That's why Latinos in Florida, New Mexico, Arizona, Nevada and Colorado are being saturated by political ads on radio and television and in print, ads that are being bought like never before in Spanish.

title: Mysteries of the Adriatic Revealed
description: ITALY is often called a vast ocean of wine, and to this day it offers great opportunities for exploration. Some regions, like Piedmont and Tuscany, are well navigated, while other areas have at least been sketched out. But one of the true joys of Italian wine is the chance to travel in relatively uncharted waters, where pleasures appear unexpectedly, and assumptions crumble like so many mirages.

title: In Chicago, an Ambiguous Memorial to the Haymarket Attack
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 - A bomb thrown into a crowd at a Chicago labor rally 118 years ago incited such intense passions that until now, people here were unable to agree on how to memorialize the victims.

title: G.M. Helps to Drive a Detroit Revival
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14 - The largest private landlord in downtown Detroit, the General Motors Corporation, is nearing the end of a major renovation of its riverfront headquarters complex that has significantly transformed one of the city's most iconic structures.

title: Taxes for an Ownership Society
description: When President Bush talks about an "ownership society," hold on to your wallet. The slogan, like "compassionate conservative" before it, is sufficiently vague to mean many things to many people, and the few details that Mr. Bush has provided -- encouraging more home ownership and offering new tax-sheltered savings plans -- seem innocuous enough. But in tax terms, "ownership society" means only one thing: the further reduction, if not the elimination, of taxes on savings and investments, including taxes on dividends and on capital gains on stocks, bonds and real estate. That, in turn, means, by definition, a shift in the tax burden onto wages and salaries -- or, put more simply, a wage tax.

title: Jamaican Economy Grows, Despite Storm
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 14 - As Hurricane Ivan approached Jamaica last week, government and business leaders worried that the country's fragile economic recovery would be knocked into a tailspin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLACH, IRWIN (BOB)
description: WALLACH--Irwin (Bob), 79, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away September 10, 2004. Beloved husband of Edith Wallach, loving father of Robyn Sternschein. Devoted fatherin-law of Evan Sternschein. Loving grandfather of Alexa and Samuel. Dear brother of Dorothy (Angelo) Occhino. Proud Veteran of WWII. Services were held in FL.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mayor Criticizes Lapse Of Gun Ban
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that all elected officials in Washington were responsible for the expiration of the assault weapons ban strongly supported by the mayor and his police commissioner. "It's a disgrace that we're going to allow guns to be sold on the streets," Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference in Brooklyn to announce a new recycling plant. And, in a rare criticism of President Bush, a fellow Republican, Mr. Bloomberg said, "I think the president can do more." Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Change Urged for Nursing-Home Voters
description: Election officials should supervise voting in nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities and give brief mental tests to residents with dementia to determine whether they are competent to vote, a panel of experts in law and medicine is recommending.

title: From One College President to Another (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: What Bush Did Right on North Korea
description: Washington - A fiery explosion in North Korea has set off an unhelpful debate in the American presidential campaign. Senator John Kerry, the Democratic nominee, has pointed to the blast, detected by satellite last week, as evidence that President Bush's approach to North Korea is a failure and risks causing "a nuclear nightmare."

title: Old Suit Roils Senate Race In Oklahoma
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, HOPE PERRY
description: GOLDSTEIN--Hope Perry of New York and Chicago on September 14th in New York at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Alfred Goldstein, dedicated mother of Mark and Robert and daughter-in-law Stephanie (nee Levinson), adoring grandmother of Nicholas and Danielle and loving sister of Dr. Jerome Perry. A former executive of Sears, Roebuck and Co., and volunteer at the Costume Institute of The Metropolitan Museum of Art of New York, she was currently a founding member of The Jewish Women's Foundation of Metropolitan Chicago, member of the Women's Association of The Chicago Symphony Orchestra and a Trustee of The Museum of Contemporary Art of Chicago. Funeral Services will be held September 15th at 10 AM at Central Synagogue in New York at 55th Street and Lexington Ave. Memorial Observance (Shiva) will be held at her New York residence from 3PM to 6PM today. Gifts in her memory may be made to The Hope Perry Goldstein Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 3rd Avenue, NY, NY, 28th floor. GOLDSTEIN--Hope. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member, Hope Goldstein. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred Youngwood, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Flat-Panel TV Venture
description: Canon and the Toshiba Corporation announced plans to spend 200 billion yen ($1.8 billion) over the next three years in a joint venture to build a new kind of monitor for flat-panel televisions, making the two Japanese electronics makers the latest in a string of companies to make major investments in flat-panel production. The new joint venture is scheduled to begin production of the panels by next August and aims to make 75,000 of the 50-inch panels a month by the end of 2007. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Brown University Receives $100 Million Gift for Financial Aid
description: Brown University announced yesterday that it had received its largest donation ever, $100 million for financial aid, continuing a series of record-breaking gifts to major American universities this year. With the gift, Brown will eliminate loans for its neediest students, much as the University of Virginia and the University of North Carolina have committed to doing in the last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Firefighters Disciplined
description: Two Fire Department lieutenants who stood by during a firehouse brawl in Tottenville on New Year's Eve have been demoted or fined, the department said. The brawl left Firefighter Robert Walsh critically injured. Lt. Raymond G. Kane was demoted to the rank of firefighter and suspended for 30 days, and Lt. Gregory L. McFarland was suspended for 30 days and fined five months' pay, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said. The penalties were first reported yesterday in The Staten Island Advance. Both lieutenants were present during the fight between Michael R. Silvestri and Mr. Walsh. Mr. Silvestri faces criminal charges for swinging a chair into Mr. Walsh's face in a dispute over the date Elvis Presley was born. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Israelis Raid Hideouts in West Bank, Killing 9 Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 15  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon acknowledged that Israel was not currently following the moribund Mideast peace plan, and said an Israeli pullout from the Gaza Strip was unlikely to revive it, according to a newspaper interview published today.

title: Man Admits Role in Ring That Stole Credit Identities
description: A man who used his position as a humble help-line employee for a Long Island credit software company to help himself to the financial identities of tens of thousands of people pleaded guilty to federal fraud charges yesterday and faces at least 10 years in jail.

title: Recipe: Caramelized Peaches
description: Adapted from "Jacques PApin's Fast Food My Way" (Houghton Mifflin)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Proxim Settles Suit With Symbol Technologies
description: The Proxim Corporation, a wireless-networking equipment maker, has agreed to pay $22.75 million and additional royalties to its rival Symbol Technologies to end all litigation over wireless technology. The two companies also agreed yesterday not to sue each other over patents for networking products through September 2009 and license each other's technology. Proxim will pay a 2 percent royalty on certain wireless local area network products. The technology allows the use of mobile computers in retail stores, warehouses or even hospitals where nurses scan a patient's wrist band for treatment data. The settlement replaces a $26 million jury verdict won by Symbol in September 2003. Symbol later obtained a ruling that it did not infringe Proxim patents. Proxim is based in Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: Record trade deficit leaves dollar wobbly
Paid Notice: Deaths   BURTON, HELGA
description: BURTON--Helga, 79, died on September 14th, 2004. Beloved wife of Bernard for 55 years. Devoted and loving mother of Vivian, Monica (Sam Sneed), and Michelle (Michael Zuckman). Adoring grandmother of Rachel, Nicole, Daniel, Jake and David. Sister of Gisela. Beloved cousin of Trudy & other relatives and many friends. Services Sunday 11AM at "RiversideNassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHODOROV, JEROME
description: CHODOROV--Jerome. The Dramatists Guild Council is saddened by the death of former Council member Jerome Chodorov. Our condolences to his friends and family for their loss...a loss shared by colleagues who will miss the company and collaboration of this esteemed playwright. John Weidman, President The Dramatists Guild of America

title: A Healthier America
description: To the Editor:

title: 1929:New Encyclopedia : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
9/11 Contamination Is High at Bank Tower, Study Says
description: A new environmental study of the former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero, independent of the bank and its insurers, has confirmed the presence of high levels of asbestos, dioxin, lead and other contaminants throughout the unused 40-story tower.

title: Preventive War: Success or Failure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Deutsche executives retreat to ready a new strategy
City Teacher Training
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Takes His First Drive at the Media
description: BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Sept. 14 - If Tiger Woods does not play well at the Ryder Cup, it will not be because he and his fiance, Elin Nordegren, are not getting along. On Tuesday, Woods vehemently denied a recent report in The Boston Herald that he and Nordegren had broken up.

title: Target Gives New Look to the Bronx
description: Not far from Spuyten Duyvil, the junction of the Harlem and Hudson Rivers in northern Manhattan, two commercial development trends have also converged: a big-box retailer with a major suburban presence has established an urban beachhead and in the process desolate industrial land has been given a much more lucrative reuse.

title: Who Went to Vietnam?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
Mother's Recipes and Father's Noodles
description: IT'S a compliment masquerading as a question that everyone, at some point, has uttered after an extraordinarily good home-cooked meal: "Have you ever thought about opening a restaurant?"

title: Police Say Suspect in Hospital Shooting Tried to Escape
description: A man charged with abducting his wife from a Queens hospital emergency room on Saturday and shooting her co-worker tried to escape from the police yesterday by lunging out a patrol car window in North Carolina while he was being extradited to New York, the authorities said.

title: With Hurricane Ivan Closing In, Throngs Retreat From Gulf Coast
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 - Every highway out of this city below sea level ground to a near halt for most of Tuesday as residents heeded evacuation orders. They left the neighborhood of the Mississippi River and Lake Pontchartrain to join tens of thousands of people from a 300-mile swath of the Gulf Coast in fleeing Hurricane Ivan and winds of nearly 140 miles an hour.

title: Carmakers Face Huge Retiree Health Care Costs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14 - Ernest Pusey is older than General Motors.

title: Yes, We'll Recycle. Just Tell Us How.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Public, and Cheerful, Face of Nuclear Power
description: WHITE PLAINS - ONE day it's a faulty steam valve causing a temporary shutdown; the next it's an environmental group clamoring for a permanent shutdown. No matter what the news swirling around the Indian Point nuclear power plant -- and given the vehement opposition to it, the news is not always favorable -- out trots Jim Steets, the plant's most visible spokesman, with an easy smile and an eagerness to field any question.

title: Supercrime And Punishment
description: The fourth chapter of "Identity Crisis," a seven-part mystery that forces the DC Comics superheroes to question their culpability in a vengeful murder, is on sale today. The series, which began in June, has been one of this summer's top-selling comic books. The events in "Identity Crisis" stem from the rape of a hero's wife and the Justice League's questionable retaliation. The series is written by Brad Meltzer, a thriller novelist and the co-creator of "Jack & Bobby," a new WB television drama. "I'm absolutely humbled by the reaction," Mr. Meltzer said in a telephone interview. "The No. 1 compliment I've gotten is, 'I don't read comics, but I'm reading this."' Internet message boards have been buzzing with readers' reactions, good and bad. Some posters have even accused the writer of misogyny, for the rape and murder of one woman and the apparent murder, last month, of another. Mr. Meltzer suggested a wait-and-see approach and said that Issue 4 had "all the chess pieces in place," including greater involvement from Batman, who puts his detective skills to work, and Superman, who will find the threat hitting very close to home. GEORGE GENEGUSTINES

title: James D. Barber, Expert on Presidents, Dies at 74
description: James D. Barber, a Duke University political scientist and authority on the American presidential character who predicted the downfall of Richard M. Nixon several years before the fact, died Sunday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 74.

title: Giambi Returns to Lineup as the D.H.
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 14 - The Yankees are making sure they will be at full strength for this weekend's series with the Boston Red Sox. Jason Giambi returned from the disabled list Tuesday and went 0 for 3 with a walk as the designated hitter in the Yankees' 4-0 victory over the Royals. Gary Sheffield announced that he would not get cortisone shots in his separated left shoulder after all. Both moves come with Boston in mind.

title: Mr. Bush's Glass House
description: President Bush's paramount problem with his National Guard years is not that he took shortcuts in 1972. The problem is that he still refuses to come clean about it.

title: Those Who Reported in Vegas Stayed in Vegas
description: When President Bush spoke to the National Guard Association on Tuesday afternoon in Las Vegas, he started with the city's motto: "What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas." He didn't add, and couldn't know at the time, that something else was about to stay in Vegas: Just about the entire White House press corps.

title: Citigroup Regrets Bond Trades in Europe
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 - Citigroup told employees on Tuesday that it regretted executing a $13.5 billion bond trade that has raised the ire of rival traders in Europe and led to an investigation by regulators in Britain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Officials Urge Audit
description: The state comptroller should audit Yonkers as well as its school system, Industrial Development Agency and local development corporations, two City Council members, Dee Barbato and John Murtagh, said yesterday. The council members, in a letter to the comptroller, said they were reacting to accusations of mismanagement of the city's administration. In July, Yonkers' state legislative delegation made a similar request of the comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi. A spokesman for Mr. Hevesi said yesterday that the comptroller had not decided how to respond. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: 1954:Space Ships in France : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Literary Prize for Judy Blume, Confidante to Teenagers
description: Judy Blume, whose frank portrayals of the travails of adolescence have won flocks of teenaged fans but whose books have sometimes been pulled from library shelves after being deemed inappropriate for preteens, has been selected by the National Book Foundation for its annual medal for distinguished contribution to American letters.

title: Americans seem not to focus on the war
JOHNSON & JOHNSON WARNED ABOUT PAIN PATCH CLAIMS
description: Johnson & Johnson made false or misleading claims about its Duragesic pain-relief skin patch, according to a warning letter from the Food and Drug Administration. The complaints center on a promotional card that has been distributed to doctors since 2003, said Carol Goodrich, a spokeswoman for Johnson & Johnson's Janssen Pharmaceutica unit, which makes the patch. The agency said Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., overstated claims of less risk of abuse and fewer side effects than other painkillers. "We're working closely with the F.D.A. to address their concerns as quickly as possible," Ms. Goodrich said.

title: A Mandatory Gratuity Is Just a Tip, and Thus Not Mandatory, a Prosecutor Says
description: As it turns out, a tip is just a tip, even if you put "mandatory" in front of it.

title: Martha Stewart Asks to Begin Sentence as Soon as Possible
description: Declaring that she wanted to "put this nightmare behind me," Martha Stewart said today that she would enter a federal prison to begin her five-month sentence without waiting to see whether an appeals court overturned the guilty verdict a jury reached earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, FRANK M.
description: FRIEDLAND--Frank M. Beloved husband of Joan for 59 years. Loving father of Barbara and Douglas Schwartz, Dr. James and Wendy Friedland, and Amy Morgens. Devoted grandfather of Justin and Gregory. Dear brother of Leo.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly Speaker Testifies
description: Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the Assembly, testified behind closed doors yesterday for more than three hours before the state's lobbying commission. The commission is investigating whether Caesars Entertainment Inc. violated the state's $75 limit on gifts to lawmakers when it gave Mr. Silver and his wife a sharply discounted suite at one of its Las Vegas hotels in 2002. The Silvers were charged $109 a night for a suite that has rented for as much as $1,500 a night in the past. Caesars is seeking to open a casino in New York State. Mr. Silver declined to elaborate on his testimony. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONNELL, JOHN RANDOLPH
description: DONNELL--John Randolph. Of Palm Beach. Oilman, banker and philanthropist, died at his home in Newport, RI, September 8, 2004. He was 92 years old. In recent years he has divided his time, between homes in Newport and Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Donnell was born June 22, 1912 in Findlay, OH, second of three sons born to Otto Dewey and Glenn McClelland Donnell. His grandfather James C. Donnell founded the Ohio Oil Co., which was then renamed the Marathon Oil Co. in 1962. He attended Findlay city schools and received a Bachelor of Science degree in electrical engineering from Case Institute of Technology, now Case Western Reserve University, in Cleveland, Ohio. Thereafter he attended the Harvard Business School. Mr. Donnell joined the Ohio Oil Co. in 1936 as special representative in the executive office. In 1954 he became a director and vice president in charge of supply and transportation. From 1961 until 1966, he was responsible for the company's worldwide activities with the title of president, of international operations. He retained his interest in the oil industry throughout his retirement, and was a member of the American Petroleum Institute, until his death. Mr. Donnell was elected a director of the First National Bank of Findlay in 1939, and succeeded his father as chairman of the board in 1947, serving in that capacity until it was sold to the Fifth Third Bank of Ohio. He was also a director of the Toledo Trust Company. Long active in civic affairs, he was president of the Findlay Board of Education. He also chaired the Hancock County War Finance Committee during World War II. He was also a past president of the Blanchard Valley Hospital Association and the Findlay Country Club. In 1982, he received a Distinguished Volunteer Award from the United Way of Hancock County in recognition of his leaadership of its initial campaign. He was also a founding member of the Findlay Skeet Club. In 1954, he was elected to the board of Case Institute Technology, and in 1967, to the board of its successor, Case Western Reserve University. He established the Donnell Institute Professorship at Case to honor his father, Otto, and his son, John, Jr., both Case graduates. In 1995 he received the Case Gold Medal, highest award of the Case Alumni Association, for his service to the university and the community at large. In honor of his deceased stepdaughter, he funded the building of the Nancy Caraboolad Arts Center, in Hathaway Brown School for Girls, in Shaker Heights, Ohio. Mr. Donnell received honorary doctorates from Salem College in Salem, West Virginia, and from the University of Findlay in Ohio. He was very interested and involved in committees, of the Winterthur Musuem in Delaware and the National Gallery in Washington, DC. He was a board member in Palm Beach of the Society for the Four Arts. He is a honorary board member of the Toledo Museum of Art. Of all his interest, Mr. Donnell was most devoted to the Boy Scouts. He was awarded the Silver Antelope, the Silver Beaver, and the Silver Buffalo, the National Council's highest honor, in 1958. In his later years he was on the board of the World Scout Foundation, and for his service, was awarded the Bronze Wolf, the organization's highest award, for his service. He was a wine connoisseur and had one of the most important wine cellars in this country. He was the Grand Senechal of Toledo Sous-Commanderie of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, for eight years and in Ohio he belonged to the Cleveland and Toledo chapters. He was also a member of the Palm Beach chapter. In sports, he loved golf, fishing, shooting and croquet. He was an avid supporter of the Newport Croquet Club and he was on the national level. He was on the Croquet Foundation of America's board of directors. He was inducted into their National Croquet Hall of Fame in 1989. In Newport, he belonged to the Clambake Club, The Reading Room and the Spouting Rock Beach Association. In Palm Beach, he belonged to the Bath and Tennis Club, The Everglades Club, The Beach Club and The Old Guard. In Cleveland, Ohio, he belonged to the Union Club, the Country Club and the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club. In Pennsylvania, the Rolling Rock Club. His interests in Newport were the Newport Art Museum, The Redwood Library and The Preservation Society. Mr. Donnell married Margaret Louise Watt of Long Beach, California on February 1, 1939. Mrs. Donnell died in 1980. He married Maureen N. Caraboolad of Shaker Heights, Ohio, on July 31, 1981, and she survives, as well as do five children from his first marriage, John R. Jr., of Atlanta, GA, Ann D. Davis of Tiburon, CA, William W. of New York, NY, Thomas B. of Findlay and Richard H. of Topsham, ME. Also surviving are his three stepsons, Geoffrey S. Caraboolad of Boston, MA and Edgartown, MA, Michael S. Caraboolad of Gates Mills, Ohio, and Richard S. Caraboolad of Clevland, Ohio, and the Late Nancy Caraboolad Hayes. He also leaves six grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren and six step-grandchildren. His brothers James and Dewey, preceded him in death. A family memorial service will be held in Findlay, Ohio on September 18, 2004 at The First Presbyterian Church. A memorial service for all his friends, will take place in Palm Beach, Florida on Thanksgiving weekend. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Gulf Stream Boy Scouts of America, 8335 North Military Trail, FL, 33484. The Society of the Four Arts, 2 Four Arts Plaza, Palm Beach, FL, 33480.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, MALCOLM
description: STEIN--Malcolm. A life fully lived, but too short. We will remember you forever, dear friend. Adrienne and Bob Sharon

title: At the UN energy agency : Showdown over Iranian nukes
Suit Over Independent Advocacy Groups
description: Lawmakers who sponsored the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law filed suit yesterday against the Federal Election Commission in an effort to compel the agency to regulate independent advocacy groups.

title: New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: Recipe: Glazed Onions
description: Adapted from "Readers Digest: 30 Minute Cookbook"

title: Late-Summer Sweetness, Arising
description: IF the classic fruit tart is a well-heeled matron, a crostata is a lusty peasant girl. Pressed into a fluted mold for form and discipline? Not likely. A crostata, a free-form Italian version of the French galette or croustade, is a low-rise tart, large or small. No stays or straps required. Roll it out, fill it up, crimp it over and slide it into a blazing oven.

title: Bill to Require Sanctions on Lawyers Passes House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Taking aim at the nation's trial lawyers and what it says is a glut of unnecessary legal actions, the Republican-led House approved a measure on Tuesday requiring sanctions against lawyers who file lawsuits deemed frivolous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURTIN, BERNADETTE MUR PHY
description: CURTIN -- Bernadette Mur phy. Bernadette, or Murph as you probably knew her has lost her heroic fight against her mortal enemy, the disease known as Multiple Sclerosis. Just as she wished her tired and tortured body has been turned over to the medical scientists in their fight against this terrible disease. Service will be confined to a Memorial Mass to be celebrated at 11 AM on Friday, September 17, 2004 at the St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, NY. We will sing no sad songs Nor shall we weep But rejoice that she is resting at peace In the loving arms of her Lord. Remember her as we do Always with a smile And constantly in your prayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOUNCE, DR. EILEEN DEGREGORIO
description: DOUNCE--Dr. Eileen DeGregorio, 51, Psychologist, died of hereditary Gastric Cancer on September 11, 2004. Dr. Eileen DeGregorio Dounce was born in Lausanne, Switzerland on April 13, 1953 to Dr. William and Mrs. Edna DeGregorio. She received her B.S. from Fairfield University in 1975 and her PhD. from the University of Miami in 1982. She lived in Grand Cayman Islands since 1983 where Eileen ran the Graduate School for the International College of the Cayman Islands. She also founded The Institute for Behavioral Science, where she consulted companies on the Island regarding employee motivation and productivity. She is survived by her husband Randolph Dounce, her mother Edna DeGregorio, a brother Richard and sister Lynn DeGregorio. Friends may call Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville. Memorial service Saturday 11 AM, Union Church of Pocantico Hills, 555 Bedford Rd (Rt. 448), Sleepy Hollow, New York. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Eileen Dounce Fund for Gastric Cancer, P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087-7106.

title: Many Delta Pilots Plan to Retire Next Month
description: The pilots' union at Delta Air Lines said last night that an "unusually high" number of pilots planned to retire early in October because of concerns about the airline's deteriorating financial situation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Finds Bugging Device
description: Sinn Fein, the political party with links to the Irish Republican Army, said it had found a bugging device in its Belfast headquarters, a week after a similar device was found at the home of an assistant to the party's president, Gerry Adams. Mr. Adams said he would present the device to Prime Minister Tony Blair at talks set to open at Leeds Castle in England on Thursday and seek an explanation. Mr. Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, are convening the talks with Roman Catholic and Protestant political parties in an attempt to revive a power-sharing government in Northern Ireland. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLER, ETHEL
description: MULLER--Ethel on September 2, 2004 of lung cancer. Wife of the late Larry Muller, sister of Bella, Carl and David Dorfman. She was loved by many and will be missed by all. Memorial service Saturday October 2 at 11 AM at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York. In lieu of flowers send donations to the Lung Association.

title: Bush Administration Opposes Move to Delay Medicare Premium Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The Bush administration came out Tuesday in opposition to Democratic proposals to hold down the scheduled 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums next year, saying that a one-year freeze would lead to much higher premiums in 2006.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: A Landmark Appointment
description: Wallace B. Jefferson, the first black justice of the State Supreme Court, was nominated to be chief justice by Gov. Rick Perry. If confirmed by the State Senate, Justice Jefferson would succeed Thomas R. Phillips, who resigned this month to teach law. Justice Jefferson, 41, was in private practice in San Antonio before he was appointed to the nine-member court in 2001 by Mr. Perry, a Republican, and is considered one of the court's most conservative justices. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Exploring Design as Metamorphosis
description: VENICE, Sept. 13 - It is fortunate that many people seem naturally drawn to architectural models because, without them, the ninth Venice Architecture Biennale would be reduced to photographs, drawings, videos and words. But even stunning handmade computer-designed models point to a problem with architectural exhibitions. They cannot show what architecture is really about -- buildings and the contexts in which they are placed.

title: City Sees Savings in a Partnership Built on Tons of Plastic and Metal
description: One of the toughest challenges with recycling has always been finding markets for the recycled goods, whose resale can then help defray the costs of the program. In announcing a 20-year recycling contract yesterday, the Bloomberg administration said it had solved that problem by encouraging a company to find those markets.

title: N.H.L. to Lock Out Players on Thursday
description: In some ways, a labor lockout in the National Hockey League is like overtime in the Stanley Cup playoffs. It could end quickly and decisively. Then again, it might grind on indefinitely, leaving both sides exhausted and diminished, with even the winners feeling beaten down and worn out.

title: People Let Me Tell You 'Bout My Best Friend ...
description: Since Dick Cheney is President Bush's running mate, why is the president talking a whole lot less about him on the campaign trail than he is about a politician who is not on the ballot on Nov. 2  Junichiro Koizumi?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIEDERKEHR, MATT
description: WIEDERKEHR -- Matt. To Jennifer, Lily and Mia, Ronnie and Lee, Evan, Mandy and Ethan and family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Losquadro, Josephberg & Lane families WIEDERKEHR--Matthew. In memory of Matthew Wiederkehr who will be affectionately remembered by all the Levkoffs. You will be in our thoughts and hearts forever.

title: A Back-to-School Offer for Home Cooks
description: Diane and Joseph DiMeo opened their storefront cooking school, the Neighborhood Kitchen, in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, a couple of weeks ago with a focus on home cooking, said Ms. DiMeo, who was a cook at Patois in Brooklyn. The classroom, a former diner at 231 Court Street (Warren Street), is equipped with stainless steel counters and professional stoves. The classes are hands on, with no more than 12 students in each. A basic course and a few on Asian, Italian and Spanish dishes, seasonal cooking, baking and knife care are taught in day or evening sessions. Wine classes and some for children and couples are also available. Most are $150 and last three hours: (718) 246-2433. The school is holding an open house on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a redevelopment plan for Mount Vernon, N.Y., that includes a landscaped traffic circle enclosing a fountain, and a statue to be relocated from another site in the city, described the statue incompletely. According to the plaque, it commemorates Mount Vernon soldiers and sailors who died not only in the Spanish-American War of 1898, but also in the Philippine Insurrection, which began the next year. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday about "The Tony Danza Show" on ABC misspelled the given name of the announcer. She is Ereka Vetrini, not Erica.

title: Alitalia Pilots Accept Deal With Wage and Job Cuts
description: MILAN, Sept. 14 - Alitalia took a step Tuesday toward resolving the labor disputes that have threatened to push it into bankruptcy, agreeing to new contracts with its 2,300 pilots.

title: Powell Offers New Criticism of Putin Limits on Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Secretary of State Colin L. Powell expressed concern on Tuesday over President Vladimir V. Putin's recent action to consolidate his power in Russia, declaring that Mr. Putin was "pulling back" on democratic reforms in the name of fighting terrorism.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Putin Backs Gazprom Bid To Acquire Oil Company The Russian natural gas giant Gazprom said that it would buy one of the country's top oil companies, a move that would create a state-owned energy juggernaut.

title: Metropolitan Museum Names Woman as President
description: For the first time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has chosen a woman as president: Emily Kernan Rafferty, the Met's current senior vice president for external affairs. Ms. Rafferty will succeed David E. McKinney when he retires in January.

title: Interpublic's Debt On S.&P. Credit Watch
description: The Standard & Poor's rating service said yesterday that it had returned the debt ratings of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York to its credit watch listing.

title: Adultery a Crime? The Turks Think Again and Say No
description: VAN, Turkey, Sept. 14 - After suffering a wave of criticism from European Union officials, women's groups, newspaper columnists and finally from its own members, Turkey's governing party abandoned a proposal on Tuesday to criminalize adultery.

title: SUNY and CUNY Enrollments Rise Despite Tougher Standards
description: Enrollment at both the City University and the State University of New York, the state's two public university systems, rose slightly this fall, the universities said yesterday.

title: A Threat to Democracy in Indonesia
description: Indonesia has made impressive strides toward democracy since thedictator Suharto was ousted six years ago, as Monday's final round in alively presidential race is likely to demonstrate. So it would be ashameful, and serious setback if a Jakarta court returns a verdict of guiltyin a libel case that has become a serious test of whether a free press cancontinue to function in Indonesia.

title: Memos on Bush Are Fake But Accurate, Typist Says
description: Correction Appended

title: Vote Drives Gain Avid Attention of Youth in '04
description: Correction Appended

title: Dark Clouds Continue to Linger Over Howe
description: "Life isn't fair," Art Howe's father used to tell him when he was growing up in a Pittsburgh housing project. And that was before Howe became the Mets' embattled manager.

title: New Scrutiny for Airline Bailout Plan Three Years After Sept. 11
description: The federal loan board created in 2001 to help assure the survival of the floundering airline industry may ultimately face the opposite task and be forced to decide whether to pull the plug on US Airways.

title: Canada's Cup Victory May End Up Half Empty
description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. Proposes a Softer Threat on Sudan's Oil
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 14 - The United States circulated a revision to its draft resolution about Sudan on Tuesday, seeking to overcome opposition on the Security Council by modifying a threat to put sanctions on the country's leaders and its oil industry if the government fails to curb violence in the Darfur region.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about a History Channel documentary on the War of 1812 misstated part of the refrain of "The Battle of New Orleans," a 1959 song cited as an example of a rare invocation of the war in American culture. The refrain starts, "We fired our guns and the British kept a comin'." ("We fired once more" occurs later in the refrain).

title: Luckily, We Stopped Short of the Word 'Loehmann's'
description: Luckily, We Stopped Short Of the Word 'Loehmann's'

title: A wily, prickly portrait of Bush
Air Control Failure Disrupts Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Sept. 15 - Hundreds of airliners around the country were held on the ground for hours on Tuesday night when the air traffic control center that handles long-distance flights in Southern California lost voice communications with 800 planes in flight because of a technical problem.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Grants Same-Sex Divorce
description: Two Ontario women were granted Canada's first same-sex divorce after a provincial court judge ruled that the traditional definition of spouse in the country's Divorce Act is unconstitutional. Same-sex marriage is legal in four Canadian jurisdictions -- Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia and the Yukon -- but the federal divorce law still considers marriage as only between a man and a woman. The federal government, which has referred the issue of same-sex marriage to the Supreme Court to rule on its constitutionality before introducing legislation in Parliament to legalize it across the country, did not challenge the divorce decision and conceded that the definition of spouse in the Divorce Act violates the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. There are about 3,000 married same-sex couples in Canada, but until the federal divorce law is amended, the decision relates only to Ontario, the most populous province. The identities of the women, who had been together for nearly 10 years but separated after five days of marriage in June 2003, were kept secret. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday 11 about the decision by Michael Otto to violate United States securities laws in 2002, when he controlled the Spiegel mail-order company before it went bankrupt, referred imprecisely to a 90-minute interview he gave The Times last Wednesday. While his comments were his most extensive public defense, they were not his first. He answered some questions from The Wall Street Journal in June.

title: Rising, Arms Like Wings, Beneath Invisible Towers
description: The Evening Stars dance festival used to be held in September in a small outdoor theater erected on the plaza between the two World Trade Center towers. Cancelled in 2001, the festival moved to Battery Park but there were no performances on Sept. 11 until this year, in a new setting near Bowling Green.

title: An Inheritance Of Flavors And Colors
description: SO many times when cooking, you do what you do just because that's the way you have always done it. It's not that there is no place for inventiveness in the kitchen, but everyday cooking relies on familiarity and the reassuring flow of habit.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Falls
description: German investor confidence fell to a 15-month low this month, reflecting concern that high oil prices and weak consumer spending might jeopardize Germany's economic recovery. The ZEW Center for European Economic Research said its index measuring the expectations of institutional investors and analysts dropped to 38.4 from 45.3 a month ago. Consumer spending is not likely to pick up while unemployment is still rising. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Weaning Parents From Children as They Head Off to College
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. - One momentous morning 35 Septembers ago, Abby Snay's parents packed their Oldsmobile from trunk to dome light with her suitcases, her books, even her hair dryer, and drove from their Chicago home to her first day of college at Washington University in St. Louis. Once the elder Snays unloaded the car and lugged the stuff into Abby's dorm room, they turned around and rode the five hours back, confident she would survive.

title: Despite Tragic Deaths, Indestructible Heroines
description: There's a lot to be said for starting the musical year by revisiting two of the most beloved operas in the repertory. Attending consecutive performances at New York City Opera on Thursday and Friday nights, watching two sopranos die with much pathos and grand music in Puccini's "Bohme" and Verdi's "Traviata," one couldn't help but identify a common theme that both heroines suffer from conspicuous consumption.

title: Sony Set to Exert Influence on Discs
description: The purchase of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by a group led by Sony will not only give the company an enormous film library but also considerable power in its fight to set the format for the next generation of digital video discs.

title: Crayola Meets Cotton Candy on the Runway
description: To look at Donna Karan's futuristic suits, with their cometlike streaks of silver and dmod panels of corsetry, was to see countless sci-fi movies realized, specifically that moment when the woman of the house arrives home and, after performing a successful docking maneuver with her spacecraft, hits a switch on the fridge door that produces a nutritionally balanced meal for her grateful family.

title: Automakers hold tight control in most European countries : EU may open car-parts market
New Interest in Hospital Deals
description: HOSPITAL mergers seem to be coming into fashion again.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For These Earthy Reds, a Lusty Dish From a Place Where Lamb Is King
description: THOUGH the climate of the Adriatic Coast contributed to the character of the red wines from Abruzzi, the Marches and Emilia-Romagna, none of the wines suggested simply sipping them with a nice piece of fish. These are dense, well-knit wines that demand lusty food.

title: OPEC to Put Formal Lifting of Output on the Table
description: VIENNA, Sept. 14 - With oil prices still stubbornly high despite OPEC's persistent efforts to lower them, oil ministers are meeting here on Wednesday to consider raising the group's formal output ceiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAHAM, JULIE
description: GRAHAM--Julie, 56, of Brooklyn, N.Y., died September 12. A passionate artist, graphic designer and devoted teacher, she colored the lives of her family and friends with her wit, strength and friendship. She is survived by her husband Stephen Truslow, her son Eric, and a loving circle of family and friends. Memorial 12 noon, September 26th, 181 Lincoln Pl., Brooklyn. Gifts to The Julie Graham Art Fund, Berkeley Carroll School, 808 Union St., Brooklyn, New York 11217.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Air Passenger Faces Charges
description: A man has been charged with placing bullets and other explosive items that he may have considered Soviet souvenirs on a flight from Dubai to Kennedy International Airport. The man, Shaun Louis Marshall, 26, was also accused of attempting to place the items on a continuing flight to Los Angeles, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday. Mr. Marshall is an American employee of a company hired by the State Department to clear poppy fields in Afghanistan. He was questioned at Kennedy Airport on Aug. 19 and permitted to continue to Los Angeles after the items were confiscated. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Big nations 'examine' Russian's proposals; others are critical : EU divided in reaction to Putin's power play
Amid Protests, House of Commons Votes to Ban Fox Hunting
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 A After a day of rowdy demonstrations that saw five protesters storm the chamber at the House of Commons, legislators voted today to outlaw the centuries-old sport of fox hunting with hounds.

title: THE WORKPLACE : Setting limits on work time
Corrections
description: A headline with the advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the WPP Group's agreement to buy the Grey Global Group, misstated the size ranking of WPP. It is already the second-largest agency company, behind the Omnicom Group; it is not becoming the second biggest with the acquisition.

description: To the Editor:
