description: To the Editor:

title: Car Blast Kills 2 Iraqis Following Bloody Day
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 15 A American soldiers discovered the decapitated bodies of three Arab men today along a highway north of Baghdad, while a suicide car bomb exploded at an Iraqi National Guard checkpoint south of the capital, killing two men and wounding 10 others, American military and Iraqi officials said.

title: British pub life : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
As its loss widens, Vivendi predicts a brighter future
At the Gift Shop: Souvenirs of Buchenwald
description: WEIMAR, Germany - Tourists visiting the city of Goethe and Schiller are bombarded with busts, key chains and other trinkets bearing the likeness of Weimar's two biggest celebrities in nearly every shop.

title: Preventive War: Success or Failure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REEVES, NEWTON D.
description: REEVES--Newton D. on September 13, 2004. Beloved husband of Dorothy, brother of Alfred, uncle of Ray and Jim Newton. Graduated from Cooper Union and was a graphic artist. Services will be held privately. Donations can be made in his name to: 1st Cerebral Palsy of N.J., 7 Sanford Ave, Belleville, NJ 07109

title: Lobster, Winterized
description: As the season for lobster rolls winds down, here's an option for fall and winter: the lobster burger. At the Falls, an alluringly dim new bar and restaurant at 218 Lafayette Street (Spring Street), the chef, John Kekalos, lightly sautes a succulent patty of lobster meat and serves it on a toasted bun from Amy's Bread with chive-seasoned mayonnaise and fries. The lobster burger, $14, is one of a collection of designer burgers at this spot, which is owned by Mr. Kekalos and Danny and Michael Dorrian.

title: Recipe: Salmon With Lime Herb Butter
description: Adapted from "Reader's Digest: 30 Minute Cookbook"

title: Seeing Threat to Iraq Elections, U.S. Seeks to Shift Rebuilding Funds to Security
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The Bush administration said Tuesday that it would shift nearly 20 percent of its aid budget for Iraq out of reconstruction projects and into security and short-term job-creation programs, acknowledging that continued violence threatened its plans for elections early next year.

title: Preventive War: Success or Failure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Max Abramovitz, 96, Architect of Avery Fisher Hall, Dies
description: Correction Appended

title: Art : Swords into art on Taiwan
A Favorite Bush Campaign Topic: Japan's Prime Minister
description: Since Dick Cheney is President Bush's running mate, why is the president talking a whole lot less about him on the campaign trail than he is about a politician who is not on the ballot on Nov. 2 A Junichiro Koizumi?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL, WILLIAM MALTBY
description: KIMBALL--William Maltby. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 20th at the Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10 St, N.Y. at 4PM. Reception will follow at The Harvard Club.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Car Parts Law Proposed
description: The European Commission proposed to liberalize the market for replacement car parts, which in most European countries is monopolized by the car manufacturers themselves. The commission plans to alter existing laws by curbing the carmakers' design copyright on spare parts. The change would allow independent manufacturers to compete in Europe's spare parts market, which totals more than 10 billion euros in sales a year.The proposal will be debated by national governments and the European Parliament. Germany and France are expected to resist citing safety concerns as their argument against allowing other manufacturers to copy spare parts of Volkswagen of Germany or Peugeot of France. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: TRASH HAULER ADJUSTS PROFIT FORECAST AGAIN
description: Allied Waste Industries, the trash hauler, cut its profit forecast for the second time in two months because of higher costs for truck maintenance. Operating income before depreciation and amortization will be 3 percent to 4 percent below a forecast in July, when the company cut its forecast by as much as 4 percent from an earlier profit target of $1.6 billion, Allied said. Allied's chief executive, Thomas Van Weelden, said yesterday that the company would spend $40 million in 2004 to improve its fleet of vehicles, resulting in $65 million in savings in 2005. Revenue growth remains on target at 2 percent, the company said.

title: People
description: Scott Tegethoff was named executive vice president and global account director for the L'Oral account at Universal McCann, New York, part of the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He had been executive vice president and communications planning director for the Procter & Gamble account at MediaVest USA, New York, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group division of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Survey Confirms It: Women Outjuggle Men
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - It may fall into the category of Things You Knew but Could Never Prove, but a new survey by the Department of Labor shows that the average working woman spends about twice as much time as the average working man on household chores and the care of children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBUD, RUTH, JEAN
description: EISENBUD--Ruth-Jean. Age 91. Loved wife of Leonard, mother of David, mother-inlaw of Monika, grandma of Daniel and Alina, great grandma of Shannon, sister of Annette Rubinstein. Professor at NYU and Adelphi, psychoanalyst whose work was radiant with poetry and use of dreams. EISENBUD--Ruth-Jean, 91, a founding figure of psychology-psychoanalysis, a Professor Emeritus at NYU, where she will be remembered as an inspiring teacher and supervisor who dazzled students with her brilliant insights into dreams and unconscious processes. Lewis Aron, Ph.D., Director New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy & Psychoanalysis

title: A brutal custom : Join forces to banish the mutilation of women
Americans seem not to focus on the war
Senators See Budget Shift on Iraq as Sign of Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the Bush administration's request to divert more than $3 billion from reconstruction work in Iraq to security measures was a sign that the American campaign in Iraq is in serious trouble.

title: TWO CONTRACTORS TO WORK ON ARMY PROGRAM
description: General Dynamics and Lockheed Martin will stop competing on a program and instead work together on the $12 billion effort to design a communications network for the Army. The program, the Warfighter Information Network-Tactical, will link commanders at the Pentagon to troops in the field. Under the arrangement, General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., will lead the team and Lockheed, based in Bethesda, Md., will be the "major subcontractor" responsible for about 50 percent of the work, the Army and General Dynamics said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposals For Public Pay Toilets
description: The city has received five proposals from companies that want to put as many as 20 pay toilets on the street, the Department of Transportation announced yesterday. Mayor Bloomberg and the City Council approved the toilets last year. The contracted company would install, maintain and sell ads on some of the 3,650 street structures, not only toilets but newsstands and bus shelters. The city's projected share over 20 years would be $400 million. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: In Venice, triumphs after the chaos
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xilinx 2nd-Quarter Sales To Fall Short
description: Xilinx, the world's biggest maker of programmable semiconductors, said yesterday that second-quarter sales would miss forecast because customers have too much inventory. Revenue for the period ending this month will decline 5 percent to 7 percent from the first quarter's $423.6 million, the company, based in San Jose, Calif., said in a statement. In July, Xilinx forecast a sales increase of 2 percent to 4 percent. The new forecast equals a range of $393.9 million to $402.4 million. Analysts expected sales of $429.8 million, the average of 22 estimates in a Thomson Financial survey. Sales totaled $315.6 million a year earlier. Shares of Xilinx fell $1.10, to $27.90 in extended trading after the announcement. They dropped 15 cents, to $29.04 in regular trading.

title: City Centers for Placement in High Schools Are Swamped
description: Hundreds of parents and children mobbed enrollment centers yesterday seeking placement in New York City public high schools, but Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said most of them would be disappointed because the city simply did not have enough seats in desirable schools, even after opening 53 new small high schools this year.

title: NBC and JCDecaux In a Joint Venture
description: NBC Universal in New York entered the outdoor advertising business yesterday by forming a venture with JCDecaux in Paris to compete for a contract to provide and maintain street furniture, including bus shelters and newsstands, for New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRYANT, FRANCIS L.
description: BRYANT -- Francis L. Of Bronxville, on September 13, 2004. Husband of Leola Zintl Bryant and the late Irene M. Bryant. Father of Laura Mulligan and Suzanne Jansen. Stepfather of Colby and Anna Zintl. Service at the Christ Church of Bronxville on Saturday, September 18th at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Christ Church, Bronxville, New York 10708.

title: The All-Too-Human Hitler, on Your Big Screen
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 14 - The release of a major movie about Hitler is, by definition, a remarkable event in Germany, especially if it portrays one of history's great monsters as a human being, given to moments of tenderness as well as the more familiar paroxysms of hatred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACHRACH, MARJORIE BAKER
description: BACHRACH--Marjorie Baker, on Saturday September 11, 2004, after a long illness, at age 71. Beloved wife of the late Robert Lee Bachrach. Adored mother of Jeff and the late Clifford Lee Bachrach. Cherished daughter of the late Florence and J. Harold Garfunkel. Treasured sister of Deborah and Robert W. Bloch. Loving mother-in-law of Stacey Roth Bachrach and proud grandmother of Adam and Eric Bachrach. Loving mother-in-law of Karen Cohen (Bachrach) and proud grandmother of Trevor and Jessica Haba. Special aunt of Alexandra, Larry and Daniel Jeydel. Devoted aunt of Susan Stephens, Wendy Bachrach, Jonathan Gordon, Tricia Allgood and Alison Watters. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to East Hill Woods Memorial Fund, 611 East Hill Rd, Southbury, CT 06488 or a charity of your choice.

title: The Panthers Get a Splash of Cold Water in Their Faces
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 14 - A shocking run to the Super Bowl last season put the Carolina Panthers on the national stage to start the 2004 schedule with a rare Monday night appearance.

title: Record Deficit for a Crucial Trade Figure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The United States hit a record deficit of $166.2 billion last quarter in trade and capital flows with the rest of the world, the Commerce Department reported Tuesday, raising fresh concerns about the nation's overall indebtedness and prompting some analysts to warn of threats to the value of the American dollar.

title: New Interest in Ancient Sounds
description: Currently in its 30th season, the group Music from Japan has long been a valuable contributor to New York concert life. It is best known for commissioning and presenting the works of contemporary Japanese composers, bringing new music that local listeners would otherwise have little opportunity to hear.

title: Amid Job Cuts, Housing Chief Added Luxuries
description: Correction Appended

title: Those Who Reported in Vegas Stayed in Vegas
description: When President Bush spoke to the National Guard Association on Tuesday afternoon in Las Vegas, he started with the city's motto: "What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas." He didn't add, and couldn't know at the time, that something else was about to stay in Vegas: Just about the entire White House press corps.

title: Putin Backs Gazprom Bid to Buy Big Oil Company
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14 - The Russian natural gas giant Gazprom said on Tuesday that it would buy one of the country's top oil companies, a move that would create a state-owned energy juggernaut.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: TDC Offers To Buy Song Networks
description: TDC, the largest phone company in Denmark, offered to buy the Swedish Internet company, Song Networks Holding, for 4.1 billion Swedish kronor ($552.8 million) to bolster its market share in Scandinavia. Song Networks' shares surged 48 percent. TDC, based in Copenhagen, offered 70 kronor in cash, or 0.2577 TDC shares, for every Song Networks share, the chief executive, Henning Dyremose, said yesterday in a conference call. That was 47 percent more than Stockholm-based Song's closing price of 47.5 kronor on Monday. TDC expects cost savings of 200 million Danish kroner a year starting in 2007. Scandinavian phone companies have been expanding through acquisitions as competition in the saturating telecom market hurts prices and leaves little room for growth. In July, TeliaSonera, Scandinavia's largest phone company, agreed to buy Orange's Danish unit, doubling its market share in the country, while Telenor, Norway's state-owned phone company, is expanding in countries like Pakistan. Song Networks, which provides Internet access services, including broadband, reported net income of 94 million kronor in the second quarter as sales rose and costs declined. Song, which has had four quarterly profits since 1999, posted a 6.6 percent gain in second-quarter sales to 633 million kronor.

title: Israel's Political 'Big Bang'
description: Washington - In Hebrew, physicists call the theory about the formation of the universe the hamapatz hagadol -- the "big bang." In Israeli politics, that phrase is used today to describe the potential realignment of parties and power.

title: From One College President to Another . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: At National Guard Meeting, It's Today's War That Matters
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 14 - They wanted to know about today's war, not one fought 35 years ago.

title: From Those Putin Would Weaken, Praise
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14 - On Monday, President Vladimir V. Putin announced he would strip Russia's 89 regions of much of their authority and electoral legitimacy. On Tuesday, not one of the leaders of those regions said a public word of protest.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Ex-Inmates To Get Voting Rights Notice
description: The state's parole system will provide former inmates written notice that they have the right to vote, a move that could allow up to 21,000 felons to vote in the Nov. 2 presidential election. State prison officials on Monday agreed to alert former inmates of their voting rights promptly in return for the dropping of a lawsuit filed last month against the state by the Prison Reform Advocacy Center, a Cincinnati group. The suit said elections officials across Ohio regularly told ex-offenders that they must complete their parole and special paperwork before registering to vote. State law says felons are permitted to vote provided they are not incarcerated. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Terrorism in Spain : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Bleak Prognosis by C.I.A. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Representative Porter J. Goss of Florida said on Tuesday that rebuilding the Central Intelligence Agency would take more than five years and that American spies needed to be encouraged to take more risks.

title: New York City's Poverty Rate Holds Steady While Nation's Rises
description: The Census Bureau's annual survey measuring income and poverty rates show that the national poverty rate rose for the third year in a row in 2003 to include one in eight Americans, an increase largely attributed to the recession and slow recovery that have battered the national economy since 2001.

title: North Korea to Wait Out Election In U.S., Then Talk, Diplomat Says
description: Correction Appended

title: C.I.A. Unit on bin Laden Is Understaffed, a Senior Official Tells Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Three years after the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and the Pentagon, the Central Intelligence Agency has fewer experienced case officers assigned to its headquarters unit dealing with Osama bin Laden than it did at the time of the attacks, despite repeated pleas from the unit's leaders for reinforcements, a senior C.I.A. officer with extensive counterterrorism experience has told Congress.

title: What Price Nostalgia? Looking Ahead to Resale
description: Yesterday afternoon on eBay, a pair of 1985 Nike Air Jordans climbed to a price of $15,200, a figure that exceeded the opening bid placed two days earlier by $15,190.01. The pair of red, white and black sneakers had been purchased at a yard sale two years ago, the seller acknowledged, and were "either authentic or a really, really, really good fake."

title: Good Grief, C.B., You Blockhead, Is It Really Bye-Bye to the Beagle?
description: Correction Appended

title: 1904:Unter den Linden : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Dutch Tell of a Spate of Threats From Islamists
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 11 - People here were puzzled last July when the government suddenly declared a security alert but offered no explanation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NARINSKY, SONIA W.
description: NARINSKY--Sonia W. On September 13, 2004, at the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Zelda (Robert) Glass. Cherished grandmother of Neil (Kerry) Glass and the late Eric Glass. Dear great grandmother of Noah Glass. Sonia was a retired teacher in the West New York, N.J. school system and a graduate of Trenton State Teachers College. Graveside service in Sarasota, FL. on September 15. Contributions may be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, or the hospice of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi's Loss Grows
description: The French me-dia company Vivendi Universal said that its second-quarter loss widened on costs related to the sale of its assets in the United States to the General Electric Company and on slumping sales of video games. The net loss was 1.85 billion euros ($2.27 billion), compared with a loss of 313 million euros a year earlier, Vivendi said. The loss included costs of 2.1 billion euros related to the effect of foreign-exchange rates on the creation of NBC Universal and a wider-than-expected loss at Universal Games. Vivendi sold American entertainment assets including Universal film studios and USA Networks to NBC as part of a plan to cut debt to less than 5 billion euros at the end of the year. Excluding one-time items, Vivendi's profit rose 7 percent, to 888 million euros, and the company raised its forecast for the full year. The chief executive, Jean-Ren Fourtou, above, said he expected adjusted net income to grow more than 25 percent next year.

Japanese has become culinary fodder for all-purpose fabulousness, a low-carbohydrate prop in elaborate theatrical productions that are ultimately about much more than food.

title: Database Demand Gives Oracle 16% Profit Rise

title: Sour Grapes That Yield a Sweet Finish
description: Sweet vinegar has become a must in every pantry. But instead of cheap balsamic vinegars, which are often harsh and one-dimensional, cooks can now opt for better sweet vinegars, including Porto, a dark, grapey port wine vinegar made by O Olive Oil in San Rafael, Calif. Drizzle this smooth new barrel-aged condiment on the last of the heirloom tomatoes, use it to punch up an autumn beef stew or add a little to the glaze for a seasonal prune or plum tart. Porto is about $10 for 6.8 ounces at Grace's Marketplace, Whole Foods and Citarella.

title: F.T.C. WITHDRAWS COMPLAINT AGAINST ARCH COAL DEAL
description: The Federal Trade Commission withdrew its administrative complaint against Arch Coal's $364 million acquisition of Triton Coal as the agency decides whether to drop the case. Arch completed the purchase on Aug. 20 after a federal appeals court in Washington refused the government's request for an order blocking it. The F.T.C., which says the combination will raise prices of coal mined in Wyoming to generate electricity, has withdrawn its request for an agency trial that would have begun Oct. 12 before an administrative law judge, an F.T.C. spokesman, Mitch Katz, said. The move will let F.T.C. lawyers discuss options with the five commissioners, including dropping the case, he said.

title: Review of Nuclear Plant Security Is Faulted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Nuclear power plants will soon be required to defend against bigger, more capable groups of attackers, but Congressional auditors said Tuesday that it would be years before the Nuclear Regulatory Commission would know if the plants meet the requirements.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Official Sees No Rise In Mailing Rates
description: Postmaster General John E. Potter said the Postal Service did not intend to increase its mailing rates until 2006. The service said it saved more than $8 billion over three years and sought to cut its costs by an additional $1 billion in 2005. Speaking at a board of governors meeting in Boston, the postal service's chief financial officer, Richard J. Strasser, said the agency should have a balanced budget next year, despite a decline in first-class mail caused in part by the broadened use of electronic mail and improved services for paying bills on the Internet. John Files (NYT)

title: China's Plan: Import a Gold Medal
description: BLUE RIVER, Ore., Sept. 12 - Eighty-four players on the fringes of American professional basketball and two dozen Chinese basketball officials eyed one another this week across a wooden floor here. They were trying to bridge language and cultural barriers, sometimes wondering aloud what the other side was thinking. One point was understood: as basketball in China undergoes a rapid evolution, each side knows its value to the other.

Will be fondly remembered by sons Mark and Gary, daughters-in-law Rhonda and Wendy, grandchildren Randy, Audrey, Julie, David and Greg, stepsons Peter and William Ente, stepdaughter-inlaw Lisa, and step-grandchildren Zachary, Sam, Jacob and Jonah. World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Warns Of Climate Threat
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair urged the international community to consider global warming a dire threat and agree on a plan of action to curb the "alarming" growth of greenhouse gases. The threat, he said in a speech, poses a "challenge so far-reaching in its impact and irreversible in its destructive power that it alters radically human existence." With Britain assuming the rotating presidency of the Group of 8 industrialized countries next year, Mr. Blair said he would make it a priority to urge the member nations to agree on the "basic science" of climate change and its threat, and on the best way to try to address the problem. But he said it was also essential to reach out to other countries, including China and India. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: Signs Point to Hurricane's Retaining Strength
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 14 - Weather models and satellite measurements of ocean heat all indicated Tuesday that Hurricane Ivan was likely to remain an extremely dangerous storm as it roared ashore, most likely near the Alabama-Mississippi border early on Thursday, with winds beginning to rake the coast on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAGNER, JULIA A.
description: WAGNER--Julia A. Of New York City, N.Y. Passed from this life on September 13, 2004 at the age of 80. She was a native of Alexandria, VA., born there on February 15, 1924 to the late Luigi and Domenica Coppa. She is a graduate of George Washington High School and George Washington University. After marrying the love of her life, the late Edward A. Wagner, she pursued her career as his Assistant Editor of Horoscope Magazine for Dell Publishing Company. After her retirement, she continued to visit her family in Virginia. She is survived by her loving sister, Lucy C. Strobel and her brothers-in-law, Frank O. Strobel and Mack Bishop. She leaves behind five devoted nieces and three grand nieces and seven grand nephews. Family will receive friends at Demaines Funeral Home, 520 South Washington St., Alexandria, VA. September 18, 6-8 PM and September 19, 2-4 PM and 6-8PM. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Rita's Catholic Church, Alexandria, at 10 AM, September 20, 2004. Interment will follow at Mt. Comfort Cemetery. Donations in Julia's memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19 Street, New York City, N.Y. 10013.

title: MONDAVI PLANS SALE OF LUXURY WINES
description: Robert Mondavi, the maker of Woodbridge and Opus One wines, said last night that it planned to sell the assets of its luxury wine businesses. The company said it would try to sell its Robert Mondavi Winery and vineyards, as well as its 50 percent stake in Opus One, Ornellaia, Luce della Vite and Vina Sena to a private investor. Mondavi will focus on its "lifestyle" wines, which include a line of midpriced wines under the Mondavi name and its mass-market Woodbridge wines, most of which sell in the $6 to $10 price range. The company also cut its fiscal 2005 earnings forecast by 50 cents a share, to about $1.30 to $1.50, and also said that R. Michael Mondavi, whose father founded the company, had resigned as a company executive and vice chairman.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Elmont: Racetrack Employee Killed
description: An early-morning scuffle left one man dead yesterday near the grounds of Belmont Park, the Nassau County police said. Dilip Amarsingh, 31, a Guyanese immigrant and exercise jockey, was killed as he approached a restaurant on the racetrack's grounds, the police said. He had been feuding with Michael Lutchman, 43, of Queens Village, when the two met outside the restaurant at about 5:25 a.m. Mr. Amarsingh was stabbed in the chest and was pronounced dead at Winthrop-University Hospital. Mr. Lutchman was charged with second-degree murder, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Sentence In Corruption Case
description: Peter T. Sylver, left, once considered a rising political star, was sentenced yesterday after pleading guilty in July to charging personal expenses to a government credit card and harassing a female county employee. Mr. Sylver, a former deputy Nassau county executive, was sentenced to three years' probation and fined $110. Yesterday, appearing before Judge Victor M. Ort of Nassau County Court, Mr. Sylver repaid the balance of the $4,700 that was owed the county. In exchange for the guilty plea, county prosecutors dropped a felony charge for the improper use of his county credit card. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Hong Kong's Election
description: Elections in Hong Kong this week were a big disappointment as an exercise in democracy. Pro-democracy or independent-minded candidates won about 60 percent of the vote, a stunning victory by any measure except the one applied to this election. Under the skewed system Beijing insists on maintaining, that entitled the pro-democracy candidates to only about 40 percent of the seats in the legislature. That will make it harder for democrats to push for more freedoms, like the direct election of the territory's chief executive. It may also be difficult for pro-democracy legislators to do more than delay the initiatives favored by the Chinese government and its chosen chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa.

title: Israeli Panel Approves Payout for Settlers Who Leave Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 14 - Israel's security cabinet approved a compensation package on Tuesday that would pay roughly $200,000 to $300,000 to each Jewish family that agrees to leave the Gaza Strip under Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's withdrawal plan.

title: Bombing Kills 47 at Police Station in Iraqi Capital
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 14 - An increasingly bold and organized insurgency seized the offensive again on Tuesday as a suicide car bomb packed with artillery shells exploded outside police headquarters here, ripping into a crowd of hundreds of young men seeking to join the Iraqi police force and killing at least 47 people and wounding 114 others, police and health officials said.

description: EBB--Fred. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the death of legendary lyricist Fred Ebb. With partner John Kander, Mr. Ebb helped to shape the modern American musical. And even as his witty and searing lyrics continue to impact audiences around the world, we, his colleagues, begin to sadly realize that there will be no more words. Our deepest sympathies to his loved ones at this difficult time. John Weidman, President The Dramatists Guild of America EBB--Fred. We join the theatre community in mourning the loss of an extraordinary man and a brilliant talent, who blessed us with Chicago. With condolences to his family and to John Kander, Martin Richards Sam Crothers The Producer Circle Co.

And there, in the middle of it all, was Marion S. Barry Jr., shaking hands, slapping backs and savoring yet another improbable political comeback.

title: Mixing the Ghosts of the 1880's With the Spirit of 2004
description: Outside the fairgrounds, the newly opened Htel de Sers, off the Avenue George V, embodies a concept that has been popular this season: the layering of historical foundations with modern elements. The 1880 building, originally the town house of the Marquis de Sers, became the Hotel Queen Elizabeth in the 1950's, and suffered some unfortunate modifications. Thomas Vidalenc (above center), the architect for the renovation, wanted to avoid what he calls the "lie of fake style" found in many grandiose Paris hotels. "I wanted to be honest to both the old and the new," he said. "When I was a student, I stayed in cheap hotels. When I had more money, I stayed in more luxurious places. The cheaper hotels are often more honest."

The animal figures are from the company's archives, as are the decorative patterns painted across their bodies. The fawn (lower left), for instance, is embellished with a dot motif used on an 18th-century teacup. Markings along the inside rim of the bowls identify each person who worked on the piece as well as color numbers and other technical information. There are five in all, including a snail and a bird (not shown). $1,200 to $2,370, mid-October, from Moss; (212) 204-7100.

Technology Briefing | Software: Lawyers' Fees Cut In Microsoft Case
description: A judge cut in half a $268 million request for fees from lawyers who represented California consumers in an antitrust suit that resulted in a $1.1 billion settlement with Microsoft. Judge Paul H. Alvarado of California Superior Court in San Francisco told Microsoft in an order last week to pay the lawyers $112.5 million. The award is about $35 million more than what Microsoft suggested in court filings. The California suit, filed in 2000, accused Microsoft of overcharging for PC software by maintaining a monopoly over its Windows operating system. The case was settled last year. Microsoft has settled similar suits in 14 states and the District of Columbia. Consumer suits are still pending in Iowa, Nebraska, New York and Wisconsin. "We think the judge did a very thoughtful job, carefully and properly applying California law, and the class counsel received a fair award," a Microsoft spokesman, Jim Desler, said. The award includes $101 million in fees and $11.5 million in expenses to be shared among lawyers at 31 law firms, including Townsend & Townsend & Crew, based in San Francisco. Under the antitrust settlement, California purchasers of Microsoft products will receive vouchers ranging from $5 to $29 that can be used to buy any manufacturer's personal-computer hardware or software. Two-thirds of the unclaimed vouchers will go to California schools in low-income areas. Judge Alvarado wrote that the lawyers in the case derived many of their claims from previous antitrust cases against Microsoft.

title: Councilwoman Unveils a Plan for Grading the School System
description: With the intention of grading the Bloomberg administration and the Department of Education on how well they are managing the city's public school system, City Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz issued her version of a learning plan yesterday, detailing what it would take to pass her tests with high marks.

title: Deconstructing the Gaze of Rembrandt
description: There was his sensitivity to human character, his grasp of light and shade, his virtuoso hand with a brush. But Rembrandt's self-portraits reveal another characteristic that may have contributed to his genius: a walleye.

title: Hopkins, Gladly the Bully, Is Ready for De La Hoya
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 15 - Oscar De La Hoya stared straight ahead as Bernard Hopkins ranted, shouted, joked and preached his way through his monologue Wednesday. De La Hoya, almost always the favorite in a fabulous career, is the underdog challenger to Hopkins in their middleweight title fight Saturday night.

title: A Health Insurance Option Coming to Federal Workers
description: In the biggest test yet of an idea central to the Bush administration's health care policy, the government will offer more than three million federal employees and their families a new type of high-deductible health insurance that includes tax-free savings accounts, the federal Office of Personnel Management said yesterday.

title: Oil Riches Confound Reform
description: In the past year, as the reality of homegrown terrorism blasted its way into the collective psyche of the Saudi royal family, the monarchy edged, at last, in the direction of domestic reform. The agenda consisted mostly of talk -- an official dialogue between the rulers and the intellectuals on once-taboo topics like human rights and the status of women. But in a place as severely repressed as Saudi Arabia, discussion in itself is an achievement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOTTRAM, ELIZABETH
description: MOTTRAM -- Elizabeth. Of New York City died at home after a long illness on September 12, 2004. Beloved daughter of Dorothy Mottram, sister to John and Margaret, and friend of countless others, Elizabeth was brilliant, funny, talented, beautiful, and a joy to be with every day of her life. She lives in our hearts. Services will be held at 2:30 P.M. on Monday, September 20 at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St, with a tea reception to follow at the House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th St. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Elizabeth's name to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1775 Broadway, New York, NY 10019.

title: Nets Quiet About Kidd Trade Talk
description: The Nets continued to refuse to comment yesterday on speculation that they might trade Jason Kidd, but team officials are perturbed that talk of trading Kidd for Portland's Shareef Abdur-Rahim had been portrayed so seriously, an Eastern Conference executive said.

title: For a City Hall Widow, Politics Can Wait, for Now
description: JERSEY CITY - THE voice on the answering machine is a familiar one: "Hi, this is Glenn," says the former mayor of Jersey City. "And this is Sandy Cunningham," adds his widow.

title: Is Chivalry Dead? Or Is It Underground?
description: To the Editor:

title: 1954:Adenauer Shares Views : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Paid Notice: Deaths   CONNOLLY, MARGARET M. ''PEGGY.''
description: CONNOLLY -- Margaret M. "Peggy." On September 12, 2004, former teacher and administrator at John Adams High School, Ozone Park. Mass Friday 9:45 A.M. at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Forest Hills. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KIMBALL, WILLIAM MALTBY
description: KIMBALL--William Maltby. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 20th at the Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10 St, N.Y. at 4PM. Reception will follow at The Harvard Club.

title: I.B.M. Shrugs Off Loss of a Contract It Once Flaunted
description: Back in December 2002, when J.P. Morgan Chase announced a seven-year, $5 billion deal to outsource much of its data processing to I.B.M., both companies bragged that the contract -- the largest of its kind for I.B.M. -- would reduce costs, create value and propel innovation at J.P. Morgan.

title: JUDGE DENIES BUSH REQUEST
description: A federal judge denied the Bush campaign's request to force the Federal Election Commission to act on a complaint filed months ago that seeks to stop independent advocacy groups from spending tens of millions in this year's presidential race. The campaign wanted the commission to act on the complaint against so-called 527 committees within 30 days. Thereafter, it could seek court action directly against the groups. Jay P. Lefkowitz, who argued the case for Mr. Bush, accused the commission of using a "pocket veto" by moving so slowly. While Judge James Robertson acknowledged that the commission moved at a "glacial pace," he also said "that is the way Congress set it up and, apparently, that is the way Congress likes it." The case before the commission is still pending, but Thomas J. Josefiak, Mr. Bush's general counsel, said the campaign might appeal or pursue other legal remedies. "It's not over," he said. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: Four Major Orchestras Facing Contract Issues
description: At the Philadelphia Orchestra, management says its contract with the musicians is a "roadmap to extinction." The players of the Cleveland Orchestra, which has racked up a $7.4 million accumulated deficit, are demanding pay parity with their colleagues in Boston. In Chicago, a former federal judge was called in to mediate.

title: Puppets on the Dark Side, Hooded, Armed and Mournful
description: "Dead Puppet Talk" The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street

title: The First Draft of Freedom
description: Washington - The trial of one brave journalist in Indonesia has implications far beyond the courtroom in Jakarta. By the time this article appears, the Central Jakarta District Court is supposed to have handed down a verdict in the case of Bambang Harymurti, the chief editor of Tempo, Indonesia's leading newsmagazine, and two of his colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, JOSHUA
description: SCHACHTER -- Joshua. Be loved husband of Naomi. Loving father of Ellen and Robert Korval, Ronnie and Arthur Israel, and Gail and Kenny Siegel. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services "BoulevardRiverside", 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 1PM Friday.

title: Embracing Melancholy as a Muse
description: In Neil Hannon's songs, characters are always losing things: cigarettes, time, friends, lovers, dreams. "I just cannot seem to keep hold of anything," Mr. Hannon sang when he led his band, the Divine Comedy, at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night. One character wakes up after a drunken romantic tryst to find his love embracing someone else; in another, a couple end a blithe drive in "daddy's car" with it wrapped around a tree.

title: Bartle Bogle New York Makes More Changes
description: Bartle Bogle Hegarty in London has made further changes at its New York office.

title: Bush vs. Kerry: The Security Front (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rose Gacioch, a Star in Women's Pro Baseball, Dies at 89
description: Rose Gacioch, an outstanding outfielder and pitcher in the heyday of women's professional baseball who became a mainstay of the Rockford Peaches team later featured in the movie "A League of Their Own," died last Thursday at a nursing home in Clinton Township, Mich. She was 89.

title: Reserve Chief Says Force Not Properly Prepared to Fight War on Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 A The chief of the Army Reserve warned today that at the current pace of operations in the war against terrorism, the Army faced a serious risk of running out of crucial specialists in the reserves who can be involuntarily called up for active duty.

title: CENDANT TO BUY RAMADA'S FOREIGN HOTELS AND NAME
description: Cendant, the world's No.1 hotel franchiser, has agreed to buy Ramada's overseas hotel business from Marriott International to gain full control of the Ramada name. Terms were not disclosed pending final negotiations, Cendant said. Marriott agreed in April to sell the United States Ramada and Days Inn hotels to Cendant for about $200 million. Cendant would acquire 204 hotels with about 28,000 rooms overseas, bringing its foreign portfolio to about 10 percent. Cendant, which franchises hotels including Super 8, Travelodge and Howard Johnson, said it expected to sign a sales agreement and complete the Ramada purchase within a few months.

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM TO CLOSE FACTORIES IN IRELAND
description: The clothing manufacturer Fruit of the Loom will lay off 630 employees and shut its remaining two factories in Ireland over the next five years to move its spinning, knitting and dyeing operations to Morocco, where it employs 1,700 people and has cheaper labor costs. Fruit of the Loom had closed four other Irish sites when it filed for bankruptcy protection in 2000. The Irish government's enterprise and employment minister, Mary Harney, said the closure meant that Europe was no longer a competitive location for the textile industry.

title: Bush vs. Kerry: The Security Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin's Increased Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Mercenaries in Afghan Case Get 8 to 10 Years in Prison
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 15 - Three Americans were sentenced here on Wednesday to 8 to 10 years in prison for running a private jail and torturing prisoners, after a panel of three Afghan judges rejected their claim that they were working for a Pentagon counterterrorist group led by Lt. Gen. William G. Boykin, the deputy undersecretary of defense for intelligence.

title: Chrebet Savors His Return to Action
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 15 - All through his recovery from the lingering effects of a concussion, Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet tried his best to explain to his wife why he wanted -- why he needed -- to return to the team.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Shipper Control
description: Temasek Holdings, an investment company owned by the government of Singapore, bought control of Neptune Orient Lines, which operates a fleet of container ships, for $566 million. Temasek raised its stake in the company, the biggest shipping line in Singapore, to 53.5 percent, according to a statement released to the stock exchange by an adviser, the Goldman Sachs Group. A buyout offer of 2.80 Singapore dollars ($1.66) a share, which was due to expire yesterday, was extended to Sept. 29.

title: Martha Stewart Asks to Begin Sentence as Soon as Possible
description: Saying she wished to "put this nightmare behind me," Martha Stewart said yesterday that she wanted to enter a federal prison as soon as possible to begin serving her five-month sentence, without waiting to see whether an appeals court would overturn her conviction on conspiracy and other charges earlier this year.

title: The Power of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: At Lunch With June Lockhart, Jon Provost and Lassie
description: Correction Appended

title: To Get Earful, Albany Must Open Its Ears
description: WELL into yesterday's education hearing in the august auditorium of the City Bar Association, one of the panelists, E. Leo Milonas, interrupted a lawyer for the state who was talking about the sludged-up political process in Albany.

title: The Thriller From America That Has the French in Thrall
description: PARIS, Sept. 15 - Now and then, the highbrow world of French culture recognizes the power and profitability of a good story, even if the story happens to be told by an American.

title: New Yorks Economic Resilience
description: THREE years after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, economists have pieced together a reasonably good picture of their effect on New York City's economy. That picture is one of remarkable resilience.

title: Infineon to Pay a Fine in the Fixing of Chip Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - Federal prosecutors announced on Wednesday that they had cracked a global cartel that had illegally fixed prices of memory chips in personal computers and servers for three years, and that one of the companies involved, Infineon Technologies, had agreed to plead guilty to one criminal count and pay a fine of $160 million.

title: Annan Urges Security Council to Act Quickly on Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16 A Intervening personally in an ongoing Security Council debate, Secretary General Kofi Annan urged the panel today to act quickly on a resolution to curb the violence in Sudan's Darfur region and said he was eager to set up a commission called for in the measure to investigate whether genocide had occurred.

title: Price Comparison for Drugs Is Put on Federal Web Site
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - Over objections from some drug companies, the Bush administration unveiled a new feature of a federal Web site on Wednesday comparing prices for similar brand-name drugs that can be used to treat conditions like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, arthritis and allergies.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Mother Is Sentenced In Baby's Death
description: A woman who confessed to killing her newborn son on Christmas Day 2001 was sentenced yesterday to 18 years to life in prison. Last year, the woman, Kathleen Brown, now 28, of North Massapequa, was convicted of murder, but the verdict was voided for technical reasons. But last June, she pleaded guilty, admitting she had placed her newborn son in a plastic bag while he was still alive. In a separate case, in January 2004, prosecutors said they had linked her DNA to that of another newborn boy whose body was found in a plastic bag in April 2001.

title: Wall Street Journal to Start Saturday Issue
description: The Wall Street Journal announced yesterday that it would begin publishing a Saturday issue starting in the fall of 2005. By following its business readers home for the weekend, the newspaper is trying for gains in consumer advertising at a time when its core advertisers in technology and finance continue to struggle.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hotel Concern Ousts Chief
description: The InterContinental Hotels Group said yesterday that it had ousted its chief executive, Richard North, and would search for an executive with greater marketing experience as it focuses on building brands like Holiday Inn. The company, which is based in Windsor, England, said it was looking for a chief executive who can lead its transformation from a company that owns hotels to one that manages or franchises them. Mr. North, 54, will leave at the end of this month, the chairman, David Webster, said. He has been chief executive since October 2002. Mr. Webster said that he would serve as chief executive while the company seeks a successor.

title: Is Chivalry Dead? Or Is It Underground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Salutes and Memories as a Slain Detective Is Mourned
description: EAST ISLIP, N.Y., Sept. 15 - After the funeral hymns, the sermons and the eulogies had ended, the coffin bearing a New York City police detective glided from the shoulders of the six pallbearers into a hearse on Wednesday, and thousands of police officers crisply saluted.

title: Unlike U.S., Asia and Europe keep baggage thefts down : Fliers find hazards at American stops
1904:Japanese Advance : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Paid Notice: Deaths   BRYANT, FRANCIS L. JR.
description: BRYANT--Francis L. Jr. Of Bronxville on September 13, 2004. Husband of Leola Zintl Bryant and the late Irene M. Bryant. Father of Laura Mulligan and Suzanne Jansen, grandfather of Robert, Matthew and Thomas Mulligan and Sumner Jansen, fatherin-law of Bryan Mulligan and David Jansen, brother of Betty Jean Parsons, stepfather of Colby and Anna Zintl. Service at the Christ Church of Bronxville on Saturday, September 18 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Jay Moynihan Colorectal Cancer Center, New York Hospital, 70th St. and York Ave., New York, NY.

title: The Return of Katherine Harris
description: Every state has an obligation to run elections that are not only fair, but also appear fair to the average voter. After the debacle of 2000, Florida's officials should understand this better than anyone. But its top elections officer, Glenda Hood, is acting in ways that create a strong impression that she is manipulating the rules to help re-elect her boss's brother. After her maneuvers this week to try to put Ralph Nader on the ballot, she cannot be trusted to run an impartial election.

title: Alitalia nears more union deals
Paid Notice: Memorials   HOCHBERG, CAROL ELAINE
description: HOCHBERG--Carol Elaine. You've been gone for six years. And in that time we have led our lives--in celebration of yours. And we will continue to do so giving to others as you gave to us. And we will never forget you. Scott H. Cooper & Family Michael & Aileen Greenberg-Kriner & Family Don & Ione Spear & Family

title: Yankees Study Forecast and Hope for the Best
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 15 - With all three of this weekend's games against the Boston Red Sox sold out, the last thing the Yankees need is for Hurricane Ivan to drop by. But they are already thinking of contingency plans and hoping for the best.

title: M.T.A. Project Rocked Anew by Mafia Link
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's effort to turn a vacant 32-story office building at the foot of Manhattan into its headquarters has long been regarded by many as a fiasco -- more than $300 million over budget and plagued by leaky pipes, courtroom battles and accusations of cronyism.

title: Lady's-Mantle, Leaning to Tatty
description: Lady's-Mantle, Leaning to Tatty

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Jerry Turner, longtime artistic director of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, misstated the surname of the program's founder. He was Angus Bowmer, not Browner.

title: Bush Addresses Prescription Drugs Issue
description: President Bush is trying to shore up one of his potential weaknesses on domestic issues and is spending considerable time these days talking about his efforts to get a better grip on health care costs.

title: At Ground Zero, New Tower Pushes Higher Than Original
description: Looking like rust-colored tendrils 664 feet overhead, the newest steel columns at 7 World Trade Center have pushed ground zero to a milestone in the sky.

title: Hurricane Swamped Communities Along Alabama's Coast
description: GULF SHORES, Ala., Sept. 16 A Water lapped up to the doorways of shops and homes, branches were ripped from sodden tree trunks and wild animals ran free from the local zoo as Hurricane Ivan swamped the Gulf of Mexico communities of Alabama today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHODOROV, JEROME
description: CHODOROV--Jerome. The entire Broadway company of Wonderful Town The Musical mourns the passing of our beloved book writer Jerome Chodorov.

title: DUKE ENERGY SETTLES CALIFORNIA ENERGY CRISIS CHARGES
description: Duke Energy has agreed to pay $549,973 to settle federal charges of manipulating prices during the California energy crisis of 2000 and 2001, federal energy regulators said. The money represents Duke's revenue from double-selling power generation services needed to assure the state's power grid, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said. It has settled with at least 21 companies for about $22 million for improper trading during the crisis.

title: The Grapevine Is Whispering; It Says Mondavi
description: The Mondavi family, who recently gave up control of the corporation that bears its name, could be a long-shot bidder for its most famous winery.

title: Kerry Mounts Fierce Attack on Bush's Economic Policies
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15 - Senator John Kerry lashed out at President Bush's economic record on Wednesday, saying that Mr. Bush had created more excuses than jobs and that in the closing months of his term he could no longer refuse to take responsibility for the failures on his watch.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: It's Emily By A Baby Nose
description: After more than a decade as the city's most popular name for newborn girls, Ashley was edged out by Emily last year, according to the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. In all, 583 of the 60,554 girls born in the city were named Emily in 2003. Ashley hung on to the No. 2 spot at 539 and was still the favorite among Spanish speakers. The top name for blacks was Kayla, while whites preferred Sarah, and Asians and Pacific Islanders favored Michelle. Among the 63,791 boys born in the city, Michael, at 950 newborns, remained the most popular name, besting Justin and Daniel. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLD, JACK
description: GOLD--Jack, 78, died of salmonellosis on September 15, 2004, two years after the death of his much loved wife, Rhoda. He is survived by his three children, Matthew, Stephanie and Roberta Gold. His two grandchildren, Rebecca and Ilyssa Gold, his brother Leon Gold, his sister Linda Chuman, and nine beloved nieces and nephews. Jack will be missed, not just by his family, but also by his friends in the community where he and Rhoda raised their family in Caldwell, NJ and the colleagues he worked with in his long market research career. Services will be held Sunday, 9:30 A.M. at "Plaza Jewish Community Chapel", 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Markets Help Endowment Pass $22 Billion at Harvard
description: Harvard's giant endowment, by far the largest of any university's, grew further in the last fiscal year, reaching $22.6 billion by June 30 with the help of a 21.1 percent return on its investments, the Harvard Management Company says.

title: S.E.C. AND MCLEODUSA SETTLE BOOKKEEPING CASE
description: McLeodUSA, the communications company, has agreed to settle an administrative lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission over erroneous bookkeeping in 2001. The S.E.C. accused the company, based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, of overstating its revenue by about $11.2 million and failing to disclose the nature of some long-term lease sales, among other errors. McLeodUSA neither admitted nor denied the S.E.C.'s accusations and was not fined as a part of the settlement.

title: Riding high on 'busted' convertibles
Aaron Director, Economist, Dies at 102
description: Correction Appended

title: Johnny Ramone, Signal Guitarist for the Ramones, Dies at 55
description: Johnny Ramone, the stone-faced guitarist of the punk band the Ramones, whose fast, buzzsaw blasts of noise laid the foundation for a school of rock guitar, died on Wednesday afternoon at his home in Los Angeles. He was 55.

title: Network Says It Will Check Questions On Bush Files
description: CBS News said for the first time last night that there were legitimate questions about the authenticity of documents it presented in a "60 Minutes" report last week that raised new issues about President Bush's service in the National Guard -- and said it would aggressively investigate them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNEIP, ARTHUR B.
description: KNEIP--Arthur B. September 14, 2004, of Wynnewood, PA. Husband of the late Carolyn (nee Zuckerman). Mother of Maggie Kneip and William A. Kneip. Grandfather of Caroline and Daniel Andrew. Also survived by David W. Evans. Art was a proud graduate of William & Mary (1941), a marketing executive in Detroit and Philadelphia, an avid Temple participant, and a lover of tennis, the arts and people. He will be missed by many. Relatives and friends are invited to Services Sunday, September 19, 2004, at 1:30 PM, at the Main Line Reform Temple, 410 Montgomery Avenue, Wynnewood, PA. Interment Haym Salomon Memorial Park. The family will return to the late residence and respectfully request that contributions in his memory be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at Main Line Reform Temple. Joseph Levine & Son, www.levinefuneral.com

title: The Collections / New York : Sunny escapism at the beach
New Jersey Theaters to Use Caption Devices for Deaf
description: Correction Appended

title: National Briefing | West: California: Deal Made For Hearst Ranch
description: A state board approved a deal that would preserve most of the 82,000 acre Hearst Ranch, owned by descendents of William Randolph Hearst. The 6-to-0 vote by the Coastal Conservancy ensured that all but a fraction of the $95 million required for the deal was in place. The money will be used to buy the Hearst descendents' development rights in what is believed to be the largest land conservation deal of its kind. Nick Madigan (NYT)

title: Mayor Pushes Donation Cap as Council Seeks Increase
description: The Bloomberg administration is quietly intensifying its campaign to severely limit the amount that can be donated to political candidates by people who do business with New York City. But at the same time, the City Council is cobbling together its own legislation to increase the legal limits on campaign contributions.

title: As Mayor Sees a Better City, Numbers Show a Mixed Report
description: While crime in the city continued to decline in the past year, more New Yorkers complained that police officers had abused their authority through improper searches and unwarranted threats of arrest, according to statistics released yesterday by the Bloomberg administration.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Friday about the Alexander Hamilton exhibition at the New-York Historical Society misstated the site of the Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History, which has lent its historical collection. It is at 19 West 44th Street in Manhattan; only its collection, along with a curatorial staff, is housed at the society.

title: A Doubling-Minded Professor
description: Correction Appended

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I woke up this morning praying it had turned, but it was still there, like a bloodhound."

title: Murdoch Receives $12.5 Million Bonus
description: The chairman and chief executive of the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch, was paid $17 million, a 42 percent increase, in fiscal 2004 as television shows like "American Idol" and increased numbers of viewers at the FX cable network raised profit.

title: Not Afraid to Get in the Yankees' Faces, Again
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 - Well, yes, when Jason Varitek of the Boston Red Sox was stuffing his catcher's mitt into the matinee-idol profile of Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez -- this being the baseball equivalent of a knuckle sandwich -- they indeed had words. But exactly what were those words, and did they contain a classic insult to Rodriguez?

title: World Briefings
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Sibling star power:The sister acts are taking center stage
Politics 101, With All Its Spitballs and Sneers
description: AMERICA (THE BOOK) A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction By Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin and David Javerbaum 244 pages. Warner Books. $24.95.

title: Company Hired for Overseas Ballots Faced Lawsuit Over a Bill
description: A Pentagon contractor that has been entrusted with handling the unsealed absentee ballots of military and civilian voters overseas was sued two years ago by a Tennessee business that accused it of fabricating information and other fraudulent behavior involving an overdue bill, according to federal court records.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Brewer Expands With Purchase
description: The brewer SABMiller said its Chinese venture bought three unprofitable breweries in China from Lion Nathan for $71 million. SABMiller said the venture, China Resources Breweries, would also assume about $83 million of debt. SABMiller is pursuing acquisitions in China and rolling out its brands there after losing a bid for the Harbin Brewery Group to the Anheuser-Busch Companies.

title: Small Doses of Glamour To Toss Around
description: The Maison et Objet design show, held in Paris this month, paired old-fashioned glamour with quick-fix dcor. Below, a little frou-frou from the company Maison de Vacances. The velvet and linen throw pillows are 15 by 31 inches ($124) or 20 by 39 inches ($145); ostrich feather pillows, 10 by 16 inches ($226), can be ordered from Nancy Koltes at Home; 31 Spring Street, New York; (212) 219-2271.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LABIANCA, VINCENT,
description: LABIANCA--Vincent, MUNOZ--Isabel./m No one ever dies who lives in hearts left behind. I still miss these people.

title: They're Robots? Those Beasts!
description: NAHANT, Mass. - JOSEPH AYERS was crouched over a laptop in a cool cinder block shed barely big enough to house a ride-on lawn mower, watching a boxy-shelled black lobster through a rectangular acrylic window.

title: Transforming a Prison, With U.S. Image in Mind
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 15 - On the outskirts of Baghdad, in the day-old "Camp Liberty" that American military officials presented as an example of the new Abu Ghraib prison, some 300 Iraqi prisoners, cleared of wrongdoing, were being released early Wednesday morning.

title: Bush Campaigns in Minnesota on Health Savings Accounts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - President Bush campaigned today in Minnesota, a swing state he lost in 2000 but that seems to be in play this year, where he described Senator John Kerry as out of touch on issues from health care to Iraq.

title: Take Kerry's Swift Boat for a Nonpolitical Spin
description: SENATOR JOHN KERRY'S Vietnam War record has been a focus of the presidential campaign for weeks. For a New York company that produces reality-based video games, that makes the topic ripe for a jump from politics to pixels.

title: Pakistani Chief Might Retain His Dual Role
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Thursday, Sept. 16 - Pakistan's information minister announced Wednesday night that President Pervez Musharraf would renege on a public promise to take off his military uniform and serve as Pakistan's civilian president. Then, hours later, the minister appeared on a private television channel at 1 a.m. Thursday and said it was simply his "own hope and appeal" that General Musharraf break his promise.

title: On Screens in Toronto, Method in the Madness
description: TORONTO, Sept. 15 - If you mixed up a handful of different breakfast cereals and flung it in the air, the randomly falling Corn Flakes, Cocoa Puffs and Froot Loops might appear to be arranging themselves, by color and shape, into interesting patterns and clusters. Similarly, if you gathered together more than 300 movies and scattered them across a large Canadian city, a serendipitous sense of order might emerge.

title: Democrats Seek Louder Voice From Edwards
description: POMEROY, Ohio, Sept. 15 - Don Imus had a question for Senator John Kerry when the senator called in to Mr. Imus's morning televised radio program on Wednesday.

title: Anthony Toney, 91, Painter and Teacher, Dies
description: Anthony Toney, a painter who taught at the New School of Social Research for 43 years, died on Friday in Marin County, Calif. He was 91 and lived in Fairfax, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: Correction Appended

title: Top Deutsche executives retreat to prepare new strategy for growth
Hong Kong Holds Off on Strict Internal Security Laws
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16 A Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive of Hong Kong, today ruled out trying to pass internal security legislation any time soon, a strong sign that his backers in Beijing have decided to take a conciliatory stance here after legislative elections last Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the origins of baseball misstated the middle initial of a sporting-goods entrepreneur who helped create a commission in the early 20th century to determine when and where baseball was invented. He was A.G. Spalding, not A.B.

title: Considering Microsoft's ITunes Store
description: On Sept. 2, Microsoft unveiled its iTunes Music Store.That sentence may sound a little strange, but that is, in fact, what happened. The Microsoft music store (in beta at music.msn.com) couldn't look more like Apple's iTunes music store (itunes.com) if you ran it through a copying machine."Apple set the bar very high," a Microsoft manger admitted. "We're trying to match that. We told our developers, 'Look at how Apple does it.'"

title: Take Along the Musicin All Its Many Formats
description: Q. Are there digital audio players that support not only MP3, WAV and Apple Lossless file formats, but also SHN and FLAC files?

title: Kerry's plan for Iraq : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Familiar Democratic Faces, but New Duties in Kerry Camp
description: Two weeks after the Kerry campaign's second major staff overhaul in 10 months, Joe Lockhart, a former White House press secretary, has taken charge of much of its daily communications, several campaign officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stewart Seeks to Begin Her Prison Term Soon Saying she wished to "put this nightmare behind me," Martha Stewart said she wanted to enter a federal prison as soon as possible to begin serving her five-month sentence without waiting to see whether an appeals court would overturn her conviction on conspiracy and other charges earlier this year.

title: Ferocious Hurricane Punishes the Gulf Coast
description: MOBILE, Ala., Thursday, Sept 16 - Hurricane Ivan pummeled and paralyzed the central Gulf Coast late Wednesday and early Thursday as it surged toward the broad bay here with a ferocity not seen in the region since Hurricane Camille struck to the west in 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERG, ROBERT
description: STEINBERG -- Robert. On September 12, 2004. Of Long Island, British Virgin Islands and NYC. Devoted husband of Janet, loving father to Dr. Mark Steinberg and Julie Steinberg Knobel, dear grandfather to Samantha, Alex, Rebecca and Rachel. Survived by his devoted Cavalier King Charles spaniels, Rocky and Oscar. His stories and sense of humor will be missed.

title: In a Mad Mad Mad Mad World, Expect Clowns and Flurries
description: "Slava's Snowshow" Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSCHENFELD, SEYMOUR
description: KIRSCHENFELD -- Seymour. 78, succumbed to cancer August 28. Predeceased by his first wife Greta. Survived by his wife Evelyn; his children Paul, Jonathan and Laura; his stepchildren Julianne and Allison; his sister Sylvia, brother Jack, and six grandchildren.

title: Intelligence Proposals Gain in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - The momentum behind creation of a new, powerful job of national intelligence director gained force on Wednesday with the introduction of a bipartisan Senate bill to grant sweeping budget authority to such an official and a simultaneous promise by House leaders to pass a related bill before going home this fall to campaign for re-election.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Indians March Against Violence
description: Nearly 40,000 Indians, many wearing traditional ponchos and carrying ceremonial canes, are walking 75 miles along the Pan American Highway in southwestern Colombia to protest violence directed at their communities in the country's long civil conflict. The nation's tribes are often caught in the middle of the brutal war that pits Marxist rebels against right-wing paramilitaries. The Indians, most from the Paez and Guambiana tribes, began their march on Tuesday in the state of Cauca and intend to reach Cali, where they are planning a rally. Juan Forero (NYT)

3 Decapitated Bodies Found; 2 Men Are Killed in Bombing
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 15 - American soldiers discovered the decapitated bodies of three Arab men on Wednesday morning along a highway north of Baghdad. The men were not immediately identified, but were thought to be Iraqis. At an Iraqi National Guard checkpoint south of the capital, a suicide car bomb exploded, killing 2 men and wounding 10 others, American military and Iraqi officials said.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Stakeholder May Offer To Buy Cyberonics
description: Advanced Neuromodulation Systems, which bought a 15 percent stake in Cyberonics last month, said yesterday that it wanted to discuss buying the company and was prepared to offer about $520 million in cash and stock. The offer for Cyberonics equals $22 a share, said Advanced Neuromodulation, based in Plano, Tex. Shares of Cyberonics, which is based in Houston, plunged 40 percent on Aug. 12 after federal regulators rejected its request for approval to market its only product, an epilepsy device, for use against depression. Cyberonics shares rose $4.32, to $23.23. Advanced Neuromodulation shares rose 91 cents, to $33.11. The total purchase price is based on 23.6 million shares outstanding as of July 30, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The proposal constitutes a 47 percent premium on the closing price of $14.95 on Aug. 19, the day before Advanced Neuromodulation bought its stake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODSTEIN, SIDNEY J.
description: GOODSTEIN--Sidney J. Age 87. Beloved husband of Kay, father of Barbara and Edward, brother of Sylvia Ettenger and Dr. Milton Goodstein. Established and ran Good Realty Co., of Paoli, PA, until the age of 85, then retired to Lantana, FL. Founding member of Temple Israel of Upper Darby. Born February 1, 1917, to Eva (Miller) and Herman, immigrants from Kiev and Odessa, who were successful business people in Philadelphia. Married to Kay (nee Benson) for 63 years.

title: Hell on Wheels: The Home-Wrecker in the Backyard
description: WHEN Irwin and I got married, it was a casual affair in my parents' backyard. My mother made a tenderloin and a turkey salad, and my sister made bread. Uncle George brought his homegrown tomatoes, and my father poured Champagne into plastic glasses. The next day we found the turkey salad. It was on top of the refrigerator.

title: Deficit, Cutbacks and Crisis for Abbey Theater at 100
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 15 - Founded by W.B. Yeats and Lady Gregory in 1904 as the voice of the emerging Irish nation, the Abbey proudly remains Ireland's national theater. But grandiose celebrations of its first century have been marred by low box-office figures, the discreet cancellation of two plays, and job cuts that will eliminate one-third of its staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'BRIEN, JOEL
description: O'BRIEN--Joel. 61, in Los Angeles on September 9. Beloved musician and artist. He was an impeccable rock drummer who recorded with James Taylor, Carole King and many others; a visual artist of fertile and whimsical imagination; a jazz instrumentalist, vocalist, and composer steeped in the tradition that he loved passionately. He was a conserver of lost treasures and an inventor of new combinations. His family and friends mourn his loss and treasure the memory of his humor, generosity, and rare freedom of spirit.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Judge Rules School Financing Is Illegal
description: Judge John K. Dietz of District Court in Austin ruled that education financing in the state was unconstitutional and stopped it from financing its $30 billion system unless the Legislature proposed a remedy in a year. After six weeks of testimony in a suit by more than 300 school districts, Judge Dietz agreed that Texas spent too little money to guarantee all 4.3 million students adequate educations and distributed aid unfairly. Attorney General Greg Abbott said he would appeal. Steve Barnes (NYT)

It is west of Nosappu, Japan, not east.

description: MIAMI, Sept. 15 - Twelve years ago when Hurricane Andrew pummeled South Florida, 11 small insurance companies went out of business and the giants in home insurance, State Farm and Allstate, were staggered.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Reporter's 2nd Subpoena In C.I.A. Case
description: A Time magazine reporter, Matthew Cooper, was subpoenaed Tuesday for a second time in an inquiry into the disclosure of the identity of Valerie Plame, a covert C.I.A. officer. After Mr. Cooper was ordered jailed last month for failing to name his sources, he gave testimony limited to his contacts with I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, and the court withdrew its order. Time said Mr. Cooper testified with Mr. Libby's consent. The new subpoena apparently concerns information from other officials. Yesterday a Washington Post reporter, Walter Pincus, also testified. Mr. Pincus said he would not identify an official who discussed Ms. Plame's identity with him in July 2003, but agreed to recount the substance of his conversation with the official. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Software Tutors Offer Help and Customized Hints
description: FOURTEEN-year-old Rochelle Brown was close to solving an algebra problem. Yet she stumbled repeatedly on one calculation: -2.3 + .5. As she sat at a computer screen, she kept typing 2.8, an incorrect answer. Eventually a hint popped up: "Think about the sign of your answer."

title: EU urged to rethink its approach to security
OPRAH'S CHOICE
description: It may be the first time that anyone has referred to a novel by Pearl S. Buck as "juicy as all get out." But that was the assessment of Oprah Winfrey yesterday when she named Buck's 1931 novel "The Good Earth" as the next selection for Oprah's Book Club. Set in rural China in the early 1900's during the reign of the last emperor, the novel tells the story of Wang Lung, a farmer, and his wife. "It's a sweeping saga that's been called 'a universal tale of the destiny of man,"' Ms. Winfrey said in a news release yesterday announcing the selection. A best seller, the novel won the Pulitzer Prize in 1932. In 1938, Buck became the first American woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. Simon & Schuster's Washington Square Press has printed 750,000 copies of a new trade paperback version of the book featuring the Oprah's Book Club label. Since Ms. Winfrey restarted her book club in June 2003, after a hiatus of about a year, she has featured only classic novels, sending several of them onto the best-seller lists, including this summer's pick, "Anna Karenina." EDWARD WYATT

They are affixed with paste, like wallpaper, but are sturdy enough to be reused. To order, $40 and up from the Collection, 011-33-1-42-77-04-20. Miniature Worlds (above) are adhesive-backed photo friezes from Extratapete, a German company. They are 4.5 inches high and 13 feet long. title: Corrections

The paper, which dropped seven strips, including "Judge Parker," replaced them with five others and then invited readers to vote on restoring one dropped strip. While "Judge Parker" received the most votes, there was not an independent write-in campaign.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Home Health Aides Set To Strike
description: New York State's largest health care union, 1199/S.E.I.U., announced yesterday that more than 2,500 home health aides intended to begin a strike on Sept. 21 against Premier Home Health Care Services, one of the region's largest providers of home health care. Union officials said that Premier had rejected 1199's call for a wage increase to $10 an hour, and that Premier's workers average less than $7 an hour. The company says its workers average $7.60 an hour. After a three-day strike in June, the union persuaded several home care agencies to agree to pay $10 by 2007, but Premier's lawyer, Thomas Greble, said the company's reimbursement rate was so low that it could not possibly afford such a large increase. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: It's Available in Sleek, but It's Going to Cost You
description: FOR decades, the Danish electronics company Bang & Olufsen has designed gadgets for those looking for style and willing to pay for it. The company's latest cordless phone offering in the United States, the BeoCom 2, however, is particularly artful.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - The television cameras were rolling, giddy voters were rejoicing and a city bus stopped in its tracks on Wednesday as a jostling crowd in the poorest corner of the nation's capital scrambled for a glimpse of the unlikely star of the moment. And there, in the middle of it all, was Marion S. Barry Jr., shaking hands, slapping backs and savoring yet another improbable political comeback.

title: WELLS FARGO WILL MERGE SOME STRONG CAPITAL FUNDS
description: Wells Fargo and Company, which is buying the assets of Strong Capital Management, said yesterday that it planned to merge the companies' mutual funds. Forty-two Strong funds will continue to be offered and 27 will be merged into others, a Strong spokesman said. Wells Fargo also signed Strong's chief investment officer, Richard Weiss, and most of the firm's investment managers to multiyear contracts. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, said it expected to acquire Strong's $30.6 billion in assets by the end of the year and fold together the two firms' funds by the second quarter of 2005. Strong has been beleaguered by a drain of assets and portfolio managers since it was linked to improper fund trading in September 2003.

She is a graphic artist, and he a "former businessman;" their firm, Urbanod, is in Marseille. The tiles, in subtly varied shades of chestnut brown, are nonadhesive and nonskid. They can be fitted together in any configuration, then taken apart and reassembled at will. They are sold in boxes of 10 or 20 pieces ($1,150 or $2,200, respectively). Included, but not shown, are diamond-shaped sections that fill in the gaps for a more solid appearance. Shipping is extra. To order, www.urbanoid.fr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OGILVY, MELINDA GRAEME
description: OGILVY--Melinda Graeme. Died September 1 at home after a valiant battle with cancer in Old Greenwich, CT. The daughter of the late Florence Prince and George Levick Street, Jr. She was born on July 16, 1919 in Richmond, VA. She attended St. Catharine's School, then studied voice at Juilliard in New York City, leaving school to marry David Ogilvy, who became the founder of Ogilvy & Mather Advertising. After farming among the Amish in Lancaster, PA, she moved to Old Greenwich in 1948 and was active in the Greenwich Choral Society, the Greenwich Red Cross, the Old Greenwich Garden Club and the Bush Holley House. She is survived by her son David F. Ogilvy, his wife Anne, stepgrandsons Fridolf, William, Stillman and Christopher Hanson, step-granddaughters Charlotte and Wells Poler, and seven grandchildren. She was predeceased by her brothers George Street, winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, Abbot Street, her sister Betty Joy Reeves and her former husband. A Memorial celebration will be held Saturday, September 18, 4 PM at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Greenwich Land Trust, Box 1152, Greenwich, CT 06836, Greenwich Historical Society, 29 Strickland Rd., Coscob, CT 06807 or American Red Cross, 99 Indian Field Road, Coscob, CT. 06807.
