title: Attacks Against the Hungarian Minority in Serbia Are Increasing
description: SUBOTICA, Serbia, Sept. 15 - When the Setets family set off this morning to take their 13-year-old daughter to school, they got a shock. As they left their small, two-room house on the outskirts of Subotica, in northern Serbia, they found a 15-inch kitchen knife imbedded in their front door. Alongside it, someone had sprayed the Serbian word for "death" in red. Further to the right was "Drop dead, Hungarians."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Illegal Airline Aid Estimated
description: A regional government in southern Belgium has estimated that it paid 4 million euros ($4.9 million) in illegal aid to the Irish airline Ryanair, the European Commission said. In February, the commission ordered the regional government to recover illegal aid in a move that it said was aimed at restoring fair competition in the market. The amount may be disputed by Ryanair, which has requested further information about the calculations. Ryanair appealed the commission's ruling in February at the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg, but no trial date has been set. Ryanair, which is based in Dublin, received discounts for landing and service fees at the Charleroi airport in southern Belgium. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Attention to (Fine) Detail Is a Camera's Strong Suit
description: Entering yet another electronics category, Sony says it will bring out a high-definition video camcorder designed for the consumer market.

title: Doctors Say They Will Cut Antidepressant Use
description: Psychiatrists, pediatricians and family practice doctors said in interviews that they would restrict their use of antidepressants in the wake of a federal advisory committee's decision that the medicines should contain severe warnings about the risks of suicide.

title: Lockout Official, Both Sides Square Off
description: In some ways, a labor lockout in the National Hockey League is like overtime in the Stanley Cup playoffs. It could end quickly and decisively. Then again, it might grind on indefinitely, leaving both sides exhausted and the winners feeling beaten down.

title: Alzheimer's in the Living Room: How One Family Rallies to Cope
description: After his retirement as a New York City carpenter four years ago, and before he faded into the incoherent fog of Alzheimer's disease, Christopher Dillon and his two grown sons renovated a bathroom in the basement of the family's Queens home.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Perrier Decision Postponed
description: The bottled-water unit of Nestl has postponed until at least October any decision on whether to sell its Perrier brand, six weeks after workers rejected a proposal by the company to cut costs at the subsidiary's plant in southern France. The employees' central council "was informed of the possibility of selling the Perrier division, a project that will be examined along with others, including grouping the Vittel and Contrex organizations into a single structure," the unit, Nestl Waters, said after a meeting between senior management and the employee council in Paris.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,017 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Risks of Antidepressants
description: The latest medical verdict on the use of antidepressant pills to treat teenagers and children is every bit as depressing as the original warnings raised months ago. There is remarkably little evidence that most of the pills are effective in treating depression in such young patients and increasing evidence that they can lead to suicidal thoughts and behavior. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration was quite right this week when it urged the strongest possible warnings for doctors and patients about the potential dangers.

title: Coke Says 2nd-Half Profit Will Miss Target
description: The Coca-Cola Company warned yesterday that its earnings for the second half of the year would fall short of forecasts, citing competitive pressures in North America and unseasonably cool and rainy weather in Europe.

title: Mortgage Applications Off
description: Mortgage applications declined last week from a four-month high, reflecting fewer home purchases, a private survey has found.

title: Incumbents Lose, Albany Shudders
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 - As a rule, lawmakers in Albany tend to have job security on a par with unionized civil servants or tenured university professors.

title: HONOR BOUND
description: Warren Beatty, John Williams, Elton John, Ossie Davis and his wife, Ruby Dee, and Joan Sutherland were named yesterday to receive this year's Kennedy Center Honors in the performing arts. The presentation of the awards for lifetime achievement is to take place at the center on Dec. 5 and be broadcast on CBS later that month. JOHN FILES

description: Correction Appended

title: 1929:Death by Torture : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Trial Suspended
description: Judges at the war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, adjourned the case for a month to allow his two new defense lawyers time to track down and prepare witnesses. Since the tribunal imposed the lawyers on Mr. Milosevic this month, he has refused to communicate with them because he wants to continue to defend himself, and numerous witnesses scheduled to travel to The Hague have canceled their appearances in solidarity with him. Whether the lawyers will be able to build a defense case without any guidance from or contact with the accused is the question now much on everyone's mind, court officials said. Patrick Robinson, the presiding judge, said that the trial would reconvene on Oct. 12. "The prestige, reputation and integrity" of the court is at stake, he said, and the trial has to be continued. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: For the Queen of Expos, Four Walls That Won't Talk
description: WASHINGTON - KITTY KELLEY keeps an unusual shrine to herself.

title: Best Buy Earnings Increase 7.9%
description: The Best Buy Company said yesterday that earnings for the second quarter climbed 7.9 percent as the company increased sales of digital televisions and offered more computer-support services.

title: Hurricane Ivan's Fury Kills 20 Along the Gulf Coast
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 16 - Ending its ominous, slow waltz through the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico, Hurricane Ivan thrashed the Gulf Coast from midnight to sunrise Thursday.

title: Giants Lose Stoutmire for Season With Injury
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 15 - It was hard to imagine the situation getting worse for the Giants' defense in the aftermath of the Eagles torching it with 330 passing yards, but the news that safety Omar Stoutmire would miss the rest of the season with a knee injury accomplished just that. An already reeling defense reeled a little more.

title: Democratic Senator Helps Fellow Lawmakers With $1 Million Check
description: Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat who used to head his state's gaming commission, has upped the ante significantly in the battle for the Senate majority.

title: Bush vs. Kerry: The Security Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Are You Undecided? Or Not?
description: Los Angeles - I'd like to address this to the Undecideds: I'm on to you. You may be fooling everyone else with your little "undecided" act, but you're not fooling me. You know perfectly well whom you're voting for. The only reason you say you're undecided is that it's a cheap ploy to get attention. How do I know? Because I'm the most indecisive person in the world. I set the template, baby, and you're not passing the smell test.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Council Subpoenas Threatened Over Mass Arrests of Protesters
description: City Council leaders yesterday sought more public scrutiny of the mass arrests of protesters during the Republican National Convention, and one councilman angrily threatened to seek a subpoena to compel Bloomberg administration officials to answer their questions.

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Release Files on Abu Ghraib
description: A federal judge in New York, complaining that the Bush administration "shows an indifference" to the freedom of information laws, has ordered the Pentagon and other agencies to produce a list of all their documents on the detentions at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq by Oct. 15.

title: 'Insurgents' vs. 'terrorists' : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
OPEC Raises Output Ceiling in Gesture to Lower Price
description: VIENNA, Sept. 15 - In a largely symbolic decision, OPEC agreed on Wednesday to increase its formal production ceiling, underlining the group's resolve to bring down high oil prices. But the move will have no impact on the physical oil market, because most OPEC members are already producing at or near capacity and well above their existing quotas.

title: Brooklyn Man, 25, Is Fatally Shot by an Off-Duty Police Officer
description: A Brooklyn man was shot and killed by an off-duty police officer last night in what appeared to be an accident, the police said.

title: Civilian Dead, and Bitterness: No Way to Bridge the Rage?
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 15 - In a remarkable appearance, the commander of American forces in Baghdad stood before a roomful of Arab and Western reporters on Wednesday, trying to explain the confusing events that led to the deaths of Iraqi civilians at the hands of his men.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Tuesday about "R-Rated: Republicans in Hollywood," an AMC documentary about politics and the movie industry, referred incorrectly to the box office performance of "The Day After Tomorrow," a feature film with a global warming theme. Its domestic receipts totaled $186.4 million, and its worldwide sales $540.4 million, according to Variety.com; it was not a flop.

title: A Bird's-Eye Atlas of New York, Ready for Its Close-Up
description: WHILE you look for your home among the block-by-block aerial views in "New York: The Photo Atlas," showing every square foot of the city as it existed on June 2 and June 6, 2003, you may find yourself thinking, If only they'd told me they were going to take my picture that day, I would have dressed a little better.

title: Way Is Cleared for Santander to Buy British Home Lender
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 - Santander Central Hispano of Spain looks certain to clinch its deal for the British mortgage lender Abbey National, after HBOS, a potential rival, said on Wednesday that it would not make a counterbid, and European Commission regulators cleared the Spanish takeover.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Yahoo's acquisition of the online Musicmatch service, referred imprecisely to songs that can be played on the Apple iPod. While RealNetworks' online store is the only one besides Apple's to sell songs in the protected iPod format, other companies sell them in the MP3 format, which the player can also use.

title: Dogs Need a Best Friend, Too
description: OTTO has always slept with Bone.

title: For China, One Party Is Enough, Leader Says
description: BEIJING, Sept. 15 - The Chinese Communist Party chief, Hu Jintao, said Wednesday that Western-style multiparty democracy was a "blind alley" for China and that the one-party state would fight "power abuse and corruption" by policing itself better.

title: Fallon Wins Emmy For Citibank Spot
description: A commercial for Citibank by Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, has been awarded the annual Emmy for best spot by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LOPEZ, JENNIFER A.
description: LOPEZ--Jennifer A. Beloved daughter of John and Carole Lopez. Sister of John, Jude, Jamie, Jim, Julia and Jessica. A memorial service will be held Friday, Sept 17th, 2004, 4PM at the Marble Collegiate Church, 1 W. 29 St, N.Y.C.

title: Spending Bills Falling Victim to Demands for Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 - With the end of the federal fiscal year just two weeks away, Congress is far from completing its required spending bills and the always difficult job is being complicated by pre-election political fights and demands for more money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JERIA RIOS, PABLO RAMON
description: JERIA RIOS--Pablo Ramon. September 11, 2004. Much beloved relative and friend. Survivor of Dawson Island, Chile. Found peace in NYC. Brought joy to all who knew him. Services Friday, 10 AM at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Winning, Not Appearances, Counts
description: BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Sept. 15 - Hal Sutton has added spice to the 35th Ryder Cup by daring to be different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REEVES, NEWTON D.
description: REEVES--Newton D. on September 13, 2004. Beloved husband of Dorothy, brother of Alfred, uncle of Ray and Jim. Newton graduated from Cooper Union and was a graphic artist. Services will be held privately. Donations can be made in his name to: 1st Cerebral Palsy of N.J., 7 Sanford Ave, Belleville, NJ 07109

title: Russians Cite Porous Security in Terror Bombings of 2 Planes
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15 - First through police bungling, then in part through a petty bribe, the two Chechen women who killed themselves and 88 others in the bombings of two Russian passenger jets last month were able to pass uninspected through layers of airport security and checks, even after being identified as possible terrorists, Russia's senior prosecutor said Wednesday.

title: Democrats Call for Release of Pessimistic Report on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 A Leading Democrats demanded today that the Bush administration declassify and release a new National Intelligence Estimate that lays out a dark view of prospects for Iraq, including the possibility of civil war.

title: Chairs That Straddle the Line Between Yesterday and Tomorrow
description: The clean-lined, gracefully curved oak chair above is part of the Ligne Emea collection from Alki, a French Basque company. "We wanted to create something in between traditional and ultramodern," said Jean Louis Iratzoki, the line's designer. "Like using the same ingredients from an old recipe to make something new." The collection is made by experienced cabinetmakers and includes dining tables, bookcases, and other pieces. The chair, available through dealers and designers, is about $500 (prices vary depending on quantity and shipping method); alki.export@wanadoo.fr.

title: TRAVOLTA'S TALE
description: Disney's Hyperion publishing unit signed John Travolta, left, this month to write a celebrity autobiography, that swing-for-the-fences staple of the publishing industry, to be released in the fall of 2006. People involved in the deal said Hyperion paid about $3 million for the North American rights to the book, which will include Mr. Travolta's assessment of the role of Scientology in his life and career. EDWARD WYATT

title: COEUR D'ALENE SHAREHOLDERS ADVISED TO BUY WHEATON
description: Coeur d'Alene Mines Corporation, a silver producer, said yesterday that proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services had recommended that Coeur's shareholders vote to buy Wheaton River Minerals of Vancouver, British Columbia. Coeur shareholders are scheduled to vote on the purchase Sept. 30. Coeur d'Alene Mines, based in Idaho, offered 0.796 Coeur d'Alene shares for each Wheaton share or a payment of as much as 5.47 Canadian dollars ($4.21) in cash, for each Wheaton share last month.

description: BESLAN, Russia, Sept. 16 - This is a town that has gone beyond mourning, a town of silence and numbness, where streets and courtyards are empty of children, where people greet each other without smiles.

title: The Collections / New York : Lauren's take on Hollywood
Kestner Wins Met PGA
description: Darrell Kestner of Deepdale Golf Club in Manhasset, N.Y., tied the course record with a five-under-par 65, finished with a 54-hole total of 201 and won by nine strokes, successfully defending his title in the Lincoln/Met PGA championship at the Inwood Country Club on Long Island yesterday.

title: Mirror, Mirror Is No Problem for a Mouse With Laser Power
description: With the arrival of the optical mouse, computer users finally had an alternative to the easily gummed-up roller-ball mechanism. But the optical mouse has an Achilles' heel: it does not work on transparent or highly reflective material.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALEY, JAMES E.
description: HEALEY--James E., Mt. Laurel, NJ, on September 14 at the age of 88. Born in Somerville, MA, an employee of Allstate Insurance for 25 years, he raised his family in Albany and Delmar, NY before retiring to Cape Cod, MA. Awarded the Soldier's Medal for service with the OSS in WWII. He is survived by his wife Vernice, sons James and Thomas and daughter Marilyn. You will be in our thoughts and hearts forever.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Power Plant Goes Off Line
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant was taken off line yesterday for the second time in two weeks because of a valve problem, a spokesman for the plant said. The plant will be kept off line for several days to repair a valve that was not closing fully and is supposed to control nonradioactive water funneled to the plant's steam generator, said Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy Nuclear Northeast, the owner of the plant. On Sept. 1, a different valve connected to the steam generator malfunctioned, and the plant was taken off line for two days. Indian Point 3, the second operational reactor at the site, was not affected and continued operating normally, Mr. Steets said. Before the recent problems, the plant operated for 382 consecutive days after last summer's blackout. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: All the Pretty Clothes. And Then, Calvin Klein.
description: On Aug. 23, Francisco Costa, the women's designer at Calvin Klein, returned to New York from a week in Wyoming to finish his spring collection. His companion, a horse trainer named John De Stefano Jr., was in Saratoga for the summer racing season and, alone in the city, Mr. Costa began to chafe. He was not happy with the clothes. His first collection for Calvin Klein, shown in the fall of 2003, had drawn raves but the second had been a near disaster. Now, with the spring 2005 show only a few weeks away, Mr. Costa, a former protg of Tom Ford's, felt he had much to prove.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Sept. 8 about a revival in the chemicals industry in eastern Germany misstated the location of the city of Stade, the start of a pipeline used by Dow Chemical to obtain ingredients. It is in Germany, not the Netherlands.

title: The Return of the Sims
description: RACHEL loves Mike. Mike loves Rachel. Mike also loves Carol and is trying to seduce Alice. Rachel punched Mike and wept hysterically when she saw him flirt with Alice, which was a little hypocritical since she is also having an affair with Carol. Surprisingly, Ted, a child adopted by Rachel and Mike, seems to take all this in stride.

title: On Death Row, a Battle Over the Fatal Cocktail
description: FRANKFORT, Ky. - Edward L. Harper, the last man to be executed in this state, took 12 minutes to die. Observers on that spring evening in 1999 said he looked tranquil as an executioner pumped a series of three chemicals into him -- a barbiturate to make him unconscious, then a paralyzing agent, and then a chemical used in road salt, to stop his heart.

title: Retiree Found Guilty, Juror Found Tipsy, and Verdict Stands
description: The jury's verdict on March 2 was guilty: a retired firefighter convicted of stealing souvenirs while volunteering at ground zero. Six weeks later, his lawyers appealed, arguing not over the testimony at the trial, but over the jury that decided the verdict.

title: Iraq is no Bosnia : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Mickelson Says Equipment Change Won't Hurt Him
description: BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Sept. 15 - Phil Mickelson reiterated Wednesday that his performance at the Ryder Cup would not suffer because of his recent switch to using some Callaway golf equipment. Mickelson will use a Callaway ball, a Callaway driver and Callaway fairway woods at the Ryder Cup, but he will keep his Titleist irons in his bag.

Barrett & Son Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St., NYC; 9:30am Friday. Funeral Mass Sacred Heart RC Church, 10:30am Friday. Cremation private.

title: For People With Impaired Vision, Software That Speaks Up
description: Using a cellphone can be a challenge for the blind and those with limited vision. Even making a call can be difficult, and using features that are available only by menu-driven choices on the screen can be next to impossible.

title: Failing the Senate Intelligence Test
description: The Senate has begun the bizarre exercise of anointing Representative Porter Goss as President Bush's choice as the lame-duck director of central intelligence -- as if the halls of Congress were not ringing with proposals to soon change the job drastically by creating a superchief of national intelligence. Making the appointment is part of Mr. Bush's efforts to convince voters that he is responding to the 9/11 commission's report on the alarming intelligence follies before Sept. 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq. But the nation needs the kind of deep, organic reform proposed by the independent 9/11 commission, and by serious proposals for change that are now being debated in Congress, not this kind of cosmetic gamesmanship.

Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about disputed memos obtained by CBS News that cast doubt on aspects of President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard truncated a quotation from David Van Os, a lawyer for Bill Burkett, a retired National Guard officer whom Newsweek called a source of the memos. Asked what role Mr. Burkett had in raising questions about Mr. Bush's military service, Mr. Van Os posed a hypothetical chain of events in which someone -- not Mr. Burkett, he said -- reconstructed documents that the preparer believed existed in 1972 or 1973. Mr. Van Os then asked "what difference would even that make" to the "factual reality of where was George W. Bush at the times in question and what was he doing?"

title: Rapper's Former Bodyguard Charged in 1994 Murder Case
description: A former bodyguard for the rapper Fat Joe was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in a shooting 10 years ago in the Bronx which the rapper witnessed, an investigator familiar with the details of the case said.

title: Quarterback Controversy Imperils a Successful Season for Dolphins
description: It was called WoodStrock back in 1981, a charming, if sometimes confusing, quarterback shuffle that led the Miami Dolphins to an 11-4-1 record. The pairing worked for Don Shula then because of the differing styles of his two quarterbacks. Don Strock was the classic pocket passer, David Woodley the more athletic one, and opposing defensive coordinators were forced to plan for both.

title: PROPERTIES : Trophy address?Nothing beats Belgravia
Majestic or Mundane, That's Life
description: HENRY LUCE, in his prospectus for a new picture magazine in 1934, said his goal was "to see things a thousand miles away, things hidden behind walls and within rooms, things dangerous to come to; the women that men love and many children." The magazine was supposed to "harness the main stream of optical consciousness of our time" through the "mind-guided camera."

title: Schwab Trading Fell 11%
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount broker, said daily trading by customers fell 11 percent in August from July.

title: IRAQ STUDY FINDS DESIRE FOR ARMS, BUT NOT CAPACITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - A new report on Iraq's illicit weapons program is expected to conclude that Saddam Hussein's government had a clear intent to produce nuclear, chemical and biological weapons if United Nations sanctions were lifted, government officials said Thursday. But, like earlier reports, it finds no evidence that Iraq had begun any large-scale program for weapons production by the time of the American invasion last year, the officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Jobless Rate Falls
description: New York City's unemployment rate dropped to its lowest level since September 2001 last month, as the city added 48,600 jobs in the past year, according to statistics released yesterday by the State Labor Department. The city unemployment rate was 6.7 percent, down from 7.5 in July and 8.4 percent a year ago. The state unemployment rate edged lower still, to 5.6 percent, close to the national rate of 5.4 percent. Several sectors drove the job growth, which was led by strong gains in employment services, publishing, broadcasting, retail and leisure and hospitality, while the city's signature industry, finance, remained basically flat. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Fending Off Alien Robots, but Still Time to Flirt
description: In the elegant murk of "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow," Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow slip into comic book archetypes of the dashing aviator and the intrepid girl reporter with supreme confidence. Superman, Lois Lane and a flight-suited Errol Flynn, not to mention Flash Gordon, Buck Rogers and even James Bond, pop to mind as you watch Mr. Law's suave airman, Joe Sullivan (a k a Sky Captain), and Ms. Paltrow's sexy tomboy swap teasing banter en route from New York to an Asian Shangri-La.

title: Ousted Shell Chairman Assails Regulators
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 - Sir Philip Watts, in his first public statement since he was ousted as chairman of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in March, said on Thursday that British financial regulators had violated his rights in their investigation of the company's restatement of its oil and natural gas reserves.

title: Familiar Roles for Rather and His Critics

The interview turned into a tense shouting match that cemented the impression among conservatives that Mr. Rather favors the other side.

title: Dvorak, A Warm And Witty Melodist

title: Private Plans Costing More for Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - Members of Congress expressed concern on Thursday about new data indicating that Medicare pays private health plans more than it would cost to care for the same patients in the traditional Medicare program.

title: Kerry Trails Bush by 8 Points in New Poll and Faces Obstacles
description: Senator John Kerry faces substantial obstacles in his bid to unseat President Bush, with voters saying he has not laid out a case for why he wants to be president and expressing strong concern about his ability to manage an international crisis, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

description: Two Canadian agency companies have made acquisitions, both for undisclosed terms.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Sports yesterday with a baseball analysis article about Art Howe's difficulties as manager of the New York Mets misstated the day of the Atlanta Braves game in which he was shown. It was Monday, not Wednesday.

title: That Bad Aura? We Had Renters
description: EVERY year just after Labor Day, Joseph Benzola, proprietor of Metaphysical Books and Tools in Sag Harbor, N.Y., finds himself doing a brisk business in sage sticks. They're not for an annual migration of Wiccans through Wainscott, but for homeowners reclaiming their properties from the summer renters. "People come in and buy them to use in purification rituals," said Mr. Benzola. "Right now, we're out of white sage and people are in a panic."

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Iron Ore Contract
description: The mining company Companhia Vale do Rio Doce signed a 10-year contract with the JFE Steel Corporation of Japan to supply 70 million tons of iron ore, starting in 2005. Including an existing contract between them, Rio Doce will sell 92 million tons of iron ore, a crucial ingredient in steel, to the JFE Group from 2005 to 2014. Rio Doce declined to disclose the value of the deal. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Learning to Win at Love With a Center Court Rally
description: Will pre-match sexual hijinks give you the edge you need to win at tennis? Or will they distract you from mobilizing the killer instinct essential to victory? That's the earth-shattering question at the heart of "Wimbledon," a likable, formulaic sports movie that follows the miraculous comeback of an insecure 31-year-old British tennis pro, Peter Colt (Paul Bettany) whose career resurrects on the wings of love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ATTARDI, FRANK
description: ATTARDI--Frank, on September 15, 2004, at age 70. Beloved husband of Linda Dano Attardi. Loving father of David Attardi and Elisa Weber. Cherished grandfather of Jenna Attardi and Hannah and Abigail Weber. Devoted brother of Marie Acciani and Vera Gheduzzi. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, September 17th, 2-5 & 6-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84 St., Saturday, 11 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Sloan - Kettering Memorial Hospital for Lung Cancer Research. Memorial tributes may be at www.mem.com

title: From Kicking in Doors to Kissing the Kids

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OGILVY, MELINDA GRAEME
description: OGILVY--Melinda Graeme. Died September 1 at home after a valiant battle with cancer in Old Greenwich, CT. The daughter of the late Florence Prince and George Levick Street, Jr. She was born on July 16, 1919 in Richmond, VA. She attended St. Catharine's School, then studied voice at Juilliard in New York City, leaving school to marry David Ogilvy, who became the founder of Ogilvy & Mather Advertising. After farming among the Amish in Lancaster, PA, she moved to Old Greenwich in 1948 and was active in the Greenwich Choral Society, the Greenwich Red Cross, the Old Greenwich Garden Club and the Bush Holley House. She is survived by her son David F. Ogilvy, his wife Anne, stepgrandsons Fridolf, William, Stillman and Christopher Hanson, step-granddaughters Charlotte and Wells Poler, and seven grandchildren. She was predeceased by her brothers George Street, winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, Abbot Street, her sister Betty Joy Reeves and her former husband. A Memorial celebration will be held Saturday, September 18, 4 PM at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Greenwich Land Trust, Box 1152, Greenwich, CT 06836, Greenwich Historical Society, 29 Strickland Rd., Coscob, CT 06807 or American Red Cross, 99 Indian Field Road, Coscob, CT. 06807.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPPMAN, BARRY
description: LIPPMAN--Barry. Age 73. Of Maplewood, New Jersey, died September 15, 2004. Beloved husband of Paula, for 49 years. Devoted and loving father of John (Stacey) and Douglas (Jane). Adoring grandfather of Tommy, Taylor and Danielle. He was Vice President of Investments at the Jeffrey Matthews Financial Group. He was a member of Mountain Ridge Country Club and Admiral's Cove Country Club. He was proud to serve as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy. He was a graduate of the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania. He was loved by many and will be missed by all. A private tribute will be held next week. Donations may be made in his name to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

description: The North Carolina Growers Association, which represents 1,000 farmers, signed a union contract yesterday covering 8,500 guest workers from Mexico -- a move that the association and union said was the first union contract in the nation for guest workers.

title: Fed Study Regards Its Strategy a Success
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - An unusual strategy adopted by the Federal Reserve in the summer of 2003 for stoking the nation's economy without cutting interest rates was a success, researchers at the central bank have concluded in a new study.

title: In Suffolk, a Budget Proposal Free of Deficits
description: Suffolk County Executive Steve Levy came into office in January predicting certain doom for the county's finances -- a looming $240 million budget shortfall and the possibility of tax increases or service cuts. But he said yesterday that he would submit a budget free of deficits to the County Legislature today.

Where Time, Not Terrorism, Is the Enemy
description: ELEVEN steps down from Eldridge Street, in a room worn with age, two dozen worshipers greeted the Jewish New Year yesterday armed with nothing but prayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, TOLMACH, DOR OTHY (NEE LEFKOFSKY)
description: COLEMAN - TOLMACH -- Dor othy (nee Lefkofsky) of Brooklyn, on Wednesday September 15, 2004 after a short illness at age 90. She was the wife of the late Samuel Tolmach and the late Gerald Coleman, father of William Coleman, (Marjorie), grandmother of Rebekah and Sarah Coleman. Dorothy was born in Cleveland, Ohio and came to New York in 1934. She received her BA from Western Reserve College (now Case Western) and her MA from Teachers College at Columbia University. Professionally, she was an early childhood teacher, administrator and education professor for over 35 years. She was a member of the YPSL's in the 1930s and the Three Arrows Cooperative Society in Putnam Valley, New York for almost fifty years. She was a warm, caring person, a fighter for progressive causes and a devoted reader of The New York Times and the New Leader until her death. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, please make your contribution to the early childhood institution of your choice or to an organization supporting the election of John Kerry. COLEMAN - TOLMACH -- Dor othy. Three Arrows Cooperative Society mourns the loss of Dorothy Coleman-Tolmach, long-time member and friend, whose wisdom, wit and warmth guided us for six decades. Our sympathy to her son Bill and his family and to her extended family. Cate Crowley, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMOVITZ, MAX
description: ABRAMOVITZ -- Max. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Max Abramovitz, a renowned architect who served with distinction as Trustee, Honorary Trustee and Life Trustee for 57 years. Max chaired the Building Planning Committee during the founding of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and oversaw the creation of the Annenberg Building to have the school. His dedication will long be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Abramovitz family. Peter W. May, Chairman Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President & CEO

title: Browsing in Bethlehem: Tidy Brick on a Foundation of Steel
description: IN Bethlehem, Pa., the abandoned steel works stand like an Alexander Calder nightmare -- skeletal, spooky and weirdly mesmerizing. Dark, angular buildings, where 30,000 people once worked at coke ovens, blast furnaces and sheet mills, loom vacant for block after block, more than three miles in all. Above the locked gates, a clock is permanently stopped at 11:30, halted with the plant, which produced its last steel in 2001.

title: A Heroine With Homework and a Galaxy to Rescue
description: At first glance, Betty is just another cute redhead at Moose Jaw Heights Junior High. She lives with her parents and a cat she despises in a sunny suburban house with 1960's-ish Jetsons dcor. Her mother, who looks like Debbie Harry tarted up for a John Waters movie, likes to save money by cutting Betty's hair herself. So Betty, the heroine of Cartoon Network's likable new animated series "Atomic Betty," which has its premiere tonight, is terrified of having her school picture taken. (Dad, who is glimpsed very briefly in the first episode, appears to take his fashion direction from Jimmy Olsen, 1950's cub reporter on the first "Superman" series.)

title: Campaign Briefing: THE RUNNING MATES; EDWARDS ENDS RURAL TOUR
description: Senator John Edwards concluded a two-day bus tour of rural Ohio and West Virginia on Thursday with spirited attacks on the Bush administration's record in Iraq and on the economy and health care. Taking note that Mr. Bush was speaking on health care in Minnesota, Mr. Edwards told a crowd of a few thousand in Portsmouth, Ohio, "I hear it was a short speech," before accusing the administration of allowing the number of people without health insurance to increase by 5 million, to 45 million, during Mr. Bush's term. Mr. Edwards visited several small towns in southeastern Ohio and northwest West Virginia. The Bush campaign responded in a statement with a bevy of statistics that it said suggested the economy was being revived. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, PEARL (NEE KAPLAN)
description: GREENBERG -- Pearl (nee Kaplan). On September 13th, 2004. Beloved wife of David. Devoted and loving mother of Martin Greenberg and Carol Sleeper. Sister of Arnold Kaplan and Helen Morse. Grandmother of Deborah and Daniel Greenberg, Eric, Maxine and Naomi Sleeper and great-grandmother of Rachel and Hannah Henry, and Jade Greenberg. Services will be held on Sunday, September 19th at 11:30AM at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

description: Al Leiter explained how much sense it makes for the owner of a multimillion-dollar company to solicit opinions from his employees. Find out their thoughts. Ask them how the product can improve. Offer them a chance to affect the future.

description: Encouraged by New Yorkers' fondness for meals built from an accretion of small dishes, Turkish restaurants have recently begun to pop up in greater numbers, offering diners the pleasures of mezes. These restaurants may or may not stand the test of time.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Max Abramovitz, the architect who designed Avery Fisher Hall, misstated the role of his partner, Wallace K. Harrison, in the design of Rockefeller Center. Mr. Harrison was one of its five primary architects and, for a brief period toward the end of the project, the chief architect; he did not oversee the entire project. The obituary also misstated the site of a retrospective of Mr. Abramovitz's work that opened on Tuesday. It is at the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery on the Columbia University campus, not at the Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library.

title: Harvey Wheeler, 85, Author of a Nuclear-Disaster Novel, Dies
description: Harvey Wheeler, a political scientist and author, whose novel about nuclear war by accident, "Fail-Safe," caused a national shudder in 1962, died on Sept. 6 at his home in Carpinteria, Calif. He was 85.

title: Like 76 Trombones, Multiple Pianos Make a Formidable Sound
description: My eye -- but perhaps fortunately not my ear -- was caught the other day by a photo in The New York Times showing a celebration on the 100th birthday on Aug. 22 of Deng Xiaoping, the "paramount leader" of China, held in the city of Shenzhen. The photo showed 128 pianos and pianists, part of 200 performers playing together at the Shenzhen Citizens Center. Surely they made a mighty racket, but to what end?

Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBENSKY, SEYMOUR
description: DUBENSKY--Seymour died September 14, 2004. Loving husband and partner in life of the late Helena Dubensky. Adored father of Joyce (Philip) and Ken (Gayle). Grandpa of Josh, Ravi, Laurence and Geremy. Brother, best friend and law partner for over 50 years of Abe, deceased, and big brother to Claire Bodian. Special friend to so many. Pal to Nikki and Sandy. A gentleman attorney, a man of expansive intelligence, vast kindness and wit. Your life was a blessing. We will miss you forever. Funeral services at 10AM on September 19, 2004 at Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, Dobbs Ferry, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, or the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Gunmen Kidnap, Then Free Palestinian Officer
description: Palestinian gunmen kidnapped a senior Palestinian security officer in Gaza City and held him for several hours before releasing him unharmed, the latest in a string of such abductions. Muhammad al-Batrawi, a brigadier general, was seized by armed men who surrounded his car. He was taken to the Nusseirat refugee camp, several miles to the south, and security officials said they negotiated his freedom a few hours later. The kidnapping, like others recently, appeared linked to internal Palestinian feuding. General Batrawi was appointed by the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, yet his kidnappers belonged to Mr. Arafat's political movement, Fatah, security officials said. As in previous cases, the security officials did not announce any arrests. Greg Myre (NYT)

Worlds Apart, Two Detectives Worked and Died Together
description: In the busy 67th Precinct in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Detectives Patrick H. Rafferty and Robert L. Parker came together to form the backbone of their team. Strong men with big personalities, they were, their fellow detectives say, the mentors, the ones to call for especially tough situations in what has long been one of the city's most violent precincts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNEIP, ARTHUR B.
description: KNEIP--Arthur B. September 14, 2004, of Wynnewood, PA. Husband of the late Carolyn (nee Zuckerman). Mother of Maggie Kneip and William A. Kneip. Grandfather of Caroline and Daniel Andrew. Also survived by David W. Evans. Art was a proud graduate of William & Mary (1941), a marketing executive in Detroit and Philadelphia, an avid Temple participant, and a lover of tennis, the arts and people. He will be missed by many. Relatives and friends are invited to Services Sunday, September 19, 2004, at 1:30 PM, at the Main Line Reform Temple, 410 Montgomery Avenue, Wynnewood, PA. Interment Haym Salomon Memorial Park. The family will return to the late residence and respectfully request that contributions in his memory be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at Main Line Reform Temple. Joseph Levine & Son, www.levinefuneral.com

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Guilty Verdicts In Vote-Buying Case
description: A federal jury in London found two men guilty of fraud in a conspiracy to buy votes in a 2002 judicial election. Prosecutors said one of the men, Ross Harris, a Pikeville businessman, led a scheme to buy votes under the guise of paying voters $50 each to transport people to the polls. Mr. Harris's employee Loren G. Turner was also convicted. Eight other people, including John D. Hays, the candidate who was said to have benefited, are scheduled for trial next month. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: An Unlikely Love Takes Root in the Barren Ground of War
description: "Zelary," which takes place in a small village in Czechoslovakia during the Nazi occupation, was the official submission of the Czech Republic to last year's Academy Awards. The movie, directed by Ondrej Trojan and based on a novella by Kveta Legatova, might be said to belong to the official genre of European nominees for the best foreign-language film Oscar, since it is yet another small-scale drama of life during World War II. It has a familiar, lived-in feel, and if its observations of rural life at a time of political turmoil don't feel terribly original, they are nonetheless absorbing and sometimes powerful.

title: Ford Raises Earnings Forecast and Unveils New Plan for Jaguar
description: DETROIT, Sept. 17 A The Ford Motor Company raised its third-quarter earnings guidance today and unveiled the beginning of a restructuring plan for its struggling Jaguar division.

title: Those Soaring Medicare Premiums
description: The Medicare premium increase announced last week -- the largest in the program's history -- has ratcheted up campaign accusations on both sides. John Kerry's campaign is accusing President Bush of failing to restrain the escalation in health costs that is propelling the increase, but this is not an issue that lends itself readily to a blame game. The inescapable truth is that costs throughout the health care system, not just in Medicare, continue to escalate. Someone -- generally the patients or the taxpayers -- must pay the bills. The question raised by the Medicare premium debate is whether too much of the burden is now falling on beneficiaries.

title: Swords as Status in Old Japan
description: The sales of Asian art are about to begin in New York, with previews this weekend of Chinese, Japanese and Korean works at Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Target Stores Bans Salvation Army Appeals
description: The Target Corporation said it would no longer allow Salvation Armybell-ringers to solicit donations outside its 1,272 stores in 47 states. The retailer, based in Minneapolis, has a no-solicitation policy, but has allowed Salvation Army appeals in the holiday season. A spokeswoman said Target reassessed its policy because more nonprofit groups were seeking exceptions. David Bernstein (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Shamil Basayev, the Chechen warlord accused of having plotted the attacks that terrorized Russia this summer and killed hundreds, misidentified the region adjacent to Chechnya in which he and his fighters seized a hospital and held 1,500 hostages in 1995. It was Stavropol, not Dagestan.

title: The Sixth Borough
description: Once upon a time, New York City had a Sixth Borough. You won't read about it in any of the history books, because there's nothing -- save for the circumstantial evidence in Central Park -- to prove that it was there at all. Which makes its existence very easy to dismiss. Especially in a time like this one, when the world is so unpredictable, and it takes all of one's resources just to get by in the present tense. But even though most people will say they have no time or reason to believe in the Sixth Borough, and don't believe in the Sixth Borough, they will still use the word "believe."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Interest Rate Raised
description: The Swiss National Bank raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time within three months as Switzerland's economy recovers from last year's contraction, which was the worst in more than a decade. The bank's policy makers, led by Jean-Pierre Roth, voted to increase the three-month rate by 0.25 percentage point, to 0.75 percent, the bank said. The Swiss economy has relied on exports to help it pull out of last year's contraction, the first since 1993. Reviving investment and consumer spending, the bank said, will help the economy grow 2 percent this year, the fastest pace since 2000.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Rogers Wireless May Bid For Microcell
description: Rogers Wireless Communications signaled yesterday that it might enter the bidding for Microcell Telecommunications, Canada's smallest wireless provider. In a statement, Rogers said it had asked the Canadian government's Competition Bureau to offer an advance ruling on any possible takeover. Rogers, based in Toronto, also said that it had held talks with Microcell, which operates under the Fido brand name. The company emphasized, however, that it had not made any decision to begin a takeover or arranged any financing for such a deal. "There is no assurance that such offer would be made," the statement said. Microcell and Rogers Wireless are the only Canadian companies that use G.S.M. wireless network technology. The Telus Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, earlier made a hostile bid for Microcell worth 1.1 billion Canadian dollars ($770 million). Ian Austen (NYT)

title: In Address to Guard, Kerry Says Bush Isn't Telling Truth on Iraq

description: Two Manhattan museums on the same block are currently presenting lavish exhibitions of historical American jewelry. The American Folk Art Museum is host to "Masterpieces of American Jewelry," a selection of about 200 pieces, most of them commercially produced, dating from the late 18th century to the late 20th. And the Museum of Arts and Design is featuring a show dedicated to the New York jewelry designer and producer Seaman Schepps.

title: In Red Bank, N.J.
description: THOUGH the Atlantic Ocean is just eight miles away, Red Bank, on the south shore of the Navesink River, with many of its 11,500 residents living in modest Victorian homes, takes pride in its roots as a river town. English sailors first noticed its banks of red clay in 1609; it was settled in the late 17th century and developed into a bustling port rom which seafood and crops were sent to New York City. In the 1980's, its commercial district suffered an economic downturn that earned it the unfortunate moniker "Dead Bank." Today, with help from a downtown business alliance, the town has changed again. Red Bank supports a growing array of trendy shops and restaurants, and has fashioned itself into a mini-center for the arts, with famous neighbors including Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi in nearby towns. And while summer brings outdoor festivals, concerts and movies to the town's streets and public riverfront areas -- Riverside Gardens Park and Marine Park -- the crowds disperse during autumn, making the view of boats cruising the Navesink much easier to enjoy. CHRISTINE EGAN

title: ARMOR RAISES ESTIMATE AS CONTRACT IS EXTENDED
description: Armor Holdings Inc. raised its revenue forecast for 2004 after winning a contract extension to build armored vehicles known as Humvees for the Army. Armor, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., said late Wednesday that the extension should add $35 million to its 2004 revenue forecast of $835 million to $865 million. Armor's aerospace and military group agreed to increase production and provide 450 of the vehicles a month for the rest of 2004 and into 2005. The contract also adds vehicles to an existing backlog that is scheduled for delivery in 2005. Stock in Armor rose $1.54, to $30 a share.

title: Annan Urges Prompt Action on Sudan Draft
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16 - Intervening in a Security Council debate, Secretary General Kofi Annan urged the panel on Thursday to act quickly on a new resolution to curb the violence in Darfur, in western Sudan. He said he was eager to set up a commission called for in the measure to determine whether ethnic violence there had reached the level of genocide.

title: After Eisner, the Disney Board Faces Its Own Deluge
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 - Michael D. Eisner may have quelled speculation about his future last week, but the board of Walt Disney will have to answer several tough questions about the company's future in the weeks and months to come.

title: Art Listings
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mortar Shell Found
description: An Upper East Side apartment building was evacuated yesterday when what appeared to be a howitzer shell was found near a third-floor garbage bin. The explosive part of the device, described as a souvenir World War II-era howitzer shell, had been removed and the object posed no danger. But as a precaution, the block was cordoned off around 10 a.m. and the residents of 205 East 69th Street were told to leave. They returned at 2 p.m. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: U.S. Push for More Scrutiny of Iran Nuclear Program Fails
description: VIENNA, Sept. 17 A The United States once again failed to persuade the International Atomic Energy Agency today that it should refer Iran's suspect nuclear program to the United Nations Security Council, accepting instead a repetition of calls for the country to stop uranium-enrichment activities and clear up remaining questions about its nuclear ambitions.

title: Penn Faces a 2-Team Challenge in Ivy
description: Before he finished his college career last year, quarterback Mike Mitchell helped Penn win two Ivy League championships and was named the league's 2003 player of the year.

title: Ground Staff and Alitalia Reach Pact on Cutbacks
description: MILAN, Sept. 16 - Alitalia, the Italian state-run airline, reached an agreement Thursday on new contracts with its 14,000 ground workers, all but ensuring that the company will survive a financial crisis that had pushed it to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: MILLENNIUM CHEMICALS SAYS S.E.C. REQUESTS DOCUMENTS
description: Millennium Chemicals, which is being bought by Lyondell Chemical, said the Securities and Exchange Commission asked for information on the company's financial restatements. Millennium restated results in August for 2001 through 2003 and for the first quarter of 2004 to correct deferred tax calculations related to its stake in Equistar Chemicals, a joint venture with Lyondell. The errors resulted from weak internal controls, Millennium said in a regulatory filing. Millennium, based in Hunt Valley, Md., is a leading producer of white pigment used to make paint and paper.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about disputed memos obtained by CBS News that cast doubt on aspects of President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard truncated a quotation from David Van Os, a lawyer for Bill Burkett, a retired National Guard officer whom Newsweek called a source of the memos. Asked what role Mr. Burkett had in raising questions about Mr. Bush's military service, Mr. Van Os posed a hypothetical chain of events in which someone -- not Mr. Burkett, he said -- reconstructed documents that the preparer believed existed in 1972 or 1973. Mr. Van Os then asked "what difference would even that make" to the "factual reality of where was George W. Bush at the times in question and what was he doing?"

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 16 - President Hamid Karzai had to abort a rare campaign rally on Thursday in Gardez, southeast of the capital, when a rocket was fired over his helicopter as it came in to land.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES TO ELIMINATE 230 JOBS
description: Hillenbrand Industries, whose businesses include coffins and hospital beds, said it would cut 230 jobs. The company also lowered its earnings forecast for fiscal 2004 to $2.95 to $3 a share, compared with its previous estimate of $3.19 to $3.24, because of lower-than-expected sales and higher costs. For its previous fiscal year, the company reported profit from continuing operations of $2.95 a share. The company is cutting about 130 jobs in the United States and about 100 in Europe, a spokeswoman, Wendy Wilson, said. Hillenbrand, based in Batesville, Ind., has about 10,000 employees.

title: U.S. Groups Press China Over Piracy
description: BEIJING, Sept. 16 - It looks like the edition of Bill Clinton's memoirs in American bookstores. It is in English, has a glossy cover with the same photo of the tanned, smiling former president, the same bronze-tinted title, and a spine announcing its publisher to be Knopf.

Times Reporter Ordered to Testify in Leak Case
description: A federal district judge in Washington has ordered a reporter for The New York Times to testify before a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the identity of a covert C.I.A. officer.

Full Throttle And Fully Legal
description: SAN DIEGO - MOST days, Qualcomm Stadium, which the San Diego Padres departed earlier this year, sits empty, the only sounds the steadily blowing wind and the occasional clatter of the overhead shuttle from downtown, ghostlike, carrying no passengers.

Under the Weight of 700, Bonds Returns Home to Lift His Growing Legend
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 - As Barry Bonds stood in the on-deck circle at Miller Park on Thursday afternoon, he gazed upon the thousands who had come to see him hit a ball into the seats, and he recognized a face from home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, JOSHUA
description: SCHACHTER--Joshua. Farewell, our cherished friend. You leave a legacy of love, energy and compassion. You were the center of your family's universe and a beloved friend of our family. We will miss you dearly. We extend our deepest sympathy to beloved wife Naomi; daughters Ellen, Ronnie, Gail and their families. Gertrude, Charles, Stephanie, Jay, Rochelle and Bruce Newman

title: Iran's nuclear program : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
National Briefing | West: California: Short Stay For A Music Director
description: Kent Nagano, the music director of the Los Angeles Opera, notified the opera's board that he would step down at the end of his contract in 2006. When Mr. Nagano took the Los Angeles job in 2003, he also accepted the position as music director of the Bavarian State Opera in Munich starting in 2006. The Munich contract forbids him from being music director of another opera company. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: A Boxer, Actor and Tapper's Task: Start Talking
description: REINCARNATION has its privileges. As proof, ponder Tony Danza, the Brooklyn boxer made good who, after donating a slick quarter-century to the Hollywood entertainment machine, has segued back to New York City as host of his own self-titled, self-referential morning talk show on ABC. Where else can a viewer learn what spices up Paris Hilton's lasagna recipe or see James Gandolfini, aka Tony Soprano, moonlight as a talent booker for Mr. Danza's show?

title: Houses on Islands: Conveniently Away From the Workaday World
description: Correction Appended

title: The War, Through Different Lenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Campaign Spending Limit Urged
description: The Senate president, Richard J. Codey, who is to become the acting governor when Gov. James E. McGreevey steps down in November, told the State Election Law Enforcement Commission yesterday that he would try to block its proposed increases in the limits on campaign contributions to political organizations. Mr. Codey, a Democrat, will keep his Senate post while he is acting governor for 14 months. The proposed limits would allow donations of $43,000 to county political organizations, now capped at $37,000. In a letter to the commission chairwoman, Jerry Fitzgerald English, Mr. Codey said the new limit would be nearly four times the average other states allow. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Luxury Market Blooms Near Red Square; Designer Boutiques Rush In to Meet Demands of the Wealthy in Moscow
description: Correction Appended

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN PLAN TO BUY RAILROAD IS REJECTED
description: Kansas City Southern's plan to take control of TFM, Mexico's biggest railroad, from Grupo TMM was rejected by Mexico's foreign investment regulator, the companies said yesterday. The decision blocks Kansas City Southern from adding to its 37 percent stake in TFM by buying Grupo TMM's 43 percent. Kansas City Southern, based in Kansas City, Mo., and TMM, Mexico's biggest transport company, will ask Mexico to reconsider the deal, which was worth $412 million when it was announced in April 2003. Majority ownership of a railway by a foreign company is subject to the regulator's approval.

title: General Warns of a Looming Shortage of Specialists
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - The chief of the Army Reserve warned on Thursday that at the current pace of operations in places like Afghanistan and Iraq, the Army faced a serious risk of running out of crucial specialists in the Reserves who can be involuntarily called up for active duty.

title: Paul Henry Ramirez
description: 'In Fluent Form' Mary Boone Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street Through Oct. 23

title: In Decorous Mayfair These Days, the U.S. Is Out of Place
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 - It is impossible to miss the American Embassy, hulking menacingly in genteel Mayfair with all the subtlety of a man wearing sunglasses and body armor to tea at the Ritz. The embassy is, for instance, the only building in the immediate area surrounded by chain-link fences, patrolled by guards with automatic weapons, and protected by the sort of concrete barriers that Darth Vader might select for his own headquarters.

title: Philosophizing Sex Dolls Amid Film Noir Intrigue
description: Androids don't dream of electric sheep in Mamoru Oshii's hallucinatory meditation on life in the shadow of the machine world, "Ghost in the Shell 2: Innocence." They dream of suicide, an unlikely act of violence that one android, or gynoid, a sexual pet with a tragic face and luridly flexible limbs, commits by clawing at its synthetic skin like a grieving widow. In this plaintive, often stunningly beautiful anime, where sex dolls commit virtual seppuku against a swirl of film noir intrigue, philosophical speculation, eye-popping images and serious science-fiction cool, a toxic cloud hangs over all tomorrow's parties.

title: ARTS GUIDE
Fund-Raiser for Rowland Brings Out Old Friends
description: MIDDLEBURY, Conn., Sept. 16 - One man removed the license plate from his white Mercedes, apparently in an attempt to avoid being identified. A woman in the passenger seat hid her face. But others simply blew by, heading up the winding driveway to the big house in the hills where what might seem an unlikely fund-raiser was held Thursday evening for former Gov. John G. Rowland.

title: It's Styles That Make Fights, Even Among Trainers
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 16 - Unbidden, Floyd Mayweather Sr. will tell you how good he is as a trainer. It doesn't hurt that he trains Oscar De La Hoya, but even if he were prepping a palooka, Mayweather would boast.

title: A Nobel Prize Winner in His Element, Amid Mountains of Pudding
description: AMHERST, Mass. - The Garden Cafeteria, on the corner of Rutgers Street and East Broadway on the Lower East Side, where immigrant Jews -- many of them Holocaust survivors -- met to eat and hold forth, was for years what the Yiddish writer and Nobel Prize winner Isaac Bashevis Singer (1904-91) called his second home. After dropping his copy at the offices of The Jewish Daily Forward next door, he would stop in for "mountains" of rice pudding and literary schmoozing with fellow writers.

title: WET SEAL HIRES ADVISER TO HELP EXPLORE ALTERNATIVES
description: Wet Seal Inc., the struggling retailer of teenage apparel, said yesterday that it had hired Rothschild Inc. as a financial adviser to help it explore strategic alternatives. A representative for Wet Seal said that Rothschild would serve as an adviser to a special committee, which has not yet made a decision about the company's alternatives. Wet Seal, which is based in Foothill Ranch, Calif., said last month that it was appointing the special committee to analyze alternatives to enhance shareholder value. Rothschild, a restructuring and bankruptcy adviser based in New York, is a unit of N.M. Rothschild & Sons Ltd.

title: A new sports cheer:Timber!
Next Up at City Hall
description: Correction Appended

title: Miscellany
description: Fairchild Publications, New York, plans to begin publishing a women's version of Vitals, its month-old shopping magazine for men, in March. Fairchild is part of Advance Publications. A Fairchild sibling, Cond Nast Publications, publishes two shopping magazines, Cargo for men and Lucky for women, and plans to introduce a third, Domino, emphasizing home products, in 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELTON, DORIS
description: FELTON--Doris. The membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Floor announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend Doris Felton and extend our sincerest condolences to her husband and our esteemed member Hon. Murray B. Felton and their family. Melvin S. Taub President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about challenges facing BellSouth misspelled the name of a consulting firm of an analyst, Andrew Cole, who commented on the threat from the cable industry. It is A.T. Kearney, not Kearny.

title: Theater Listings
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Saturday night only.

title: A Puzzling Change for Mickelson
description: Bloomfield Township, Mich. - MORE than any of the rest of the world's best golfers, Phil Mickelson has often tried to do the spectacular because he thinks he will hit a magical shot. If he's in the trees, he doesn't chip out, he goes for the green. If he has a 40-footer, he doesn't lag it close and settle for a par, he tries to make it.

title: Glittery Glamour and Idealism Do Battle in World War II Europe
description: "Head in the Clouds" illustrates how time can play nasty tricks on even the trustiest golden-oldie topic for a movie. Take World War II. In the wake of "Saving Private Ryan," "The Pianist" and the mini-series "Band of Brothers," this pulpy, sex-drenched wartime epic seems frivolous, quaint and foolishly prurient. The more enthusiastically it nods to the romantic gloss and high-minded blather of a movie like "Doctor Zhivago," while throwing in some modern kinks, the more old-fashioned it looks and sounds. We're not living in 1965, boys and girls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOTTRAM, ELIZABETH
description: MOTTRAM--Elizabeth. Douglas Elliman mourns the loss of their esteemed colleague and friend. We will endeavor to keep your memory alive by attempting to emulate your positive, professional and optimistic outlook on living life and treating all people with respect and dignity. You provided us with a shining example of how to combine the virtues of perfect etiquette and manners with being a leader in our industry. You were a true presence in a diverse field and your integrity and high standards have motivated us all to strive for your level of excellence.

title: Collapse of 60 Charter Schools Leaves Californians Scrambling
description: Ken Larson was pacing the floor of his office in a tiny elementary school in Oro Grande, Calif., surrounded by the chaos of fax lines beeping, three beleaguered secretaries peppering him with questions and phone lines ringing for the umpteenth time.

title: Ford to Ship Electric Cars Back to Norway
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would ship as many as 300 Think electric cars back to Norway, sparing remnants of the failed project from the scrap heap.

title: Europe Dominates U.S. at Start of Ryder Cup
description: BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Sept. 17 A For Europe, it was a glorious start to the 35th Ryder Cup. For the United States, it was a nightmare.

title: Bush Says He Would Follow Same Course in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - President Bush said today that his decision to take the United States to war in Iraq had been very difficult but morally correct, and that he would follow the same course if he had it to do all over again.

title: Philips Widens Its Product Range
description: THE last big batch of commercials from Royal Philips Electronics memorably showed, among other things, a stylish couple watching a thin plasma-screen television installed on their ceiling.

title: Reconquering the West
description: Kris Kristofferson, left, is a folksy cowboy and Chris Cooper plays a bumbling neophyte running for governor of Colorodo in "Silver City," John Sayles's satire on political corruption fueled by the greed of real-estate speculators and corporate honchos contemptuous of ordinary people. The movie features a sprawling cast, including Danny Huston, who investigates a conspiracy involving land developers and mining companies colluding with politicians to line their pockets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL, WILLIAM MALTBY
description: KIMBALL--William Maltby. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 20th at the Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10 St, N.Y. at 4PM. Reception will follow at The Harvard Club.

title: Juvenile Unit Needs a Touch of Home, Rell Says
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 16 - After touring the training school for boys here on Thursday, where a room now costs the state about $866 a day, Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut said she supported spending more money to give the detention center a more homelike feeling.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about disputed memos obtained by CBS News that cast doubt on aspects of President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard truncated a quotation from David Van Os, a lawyer for Bill Burkett, a retired National Guard officer whom Newsweek called a source of the memos. Asked what role Mr. Burkett had in raising questions about Mr. Bush's military service, Mr. Van Os posed a hypothetical chain of events in which someone -- not Mr. Burkett, he said -- reconstructed documents that the preparer believed existed in 1972 or 1973. Mr. Van Os then asked "what difference would even that make" to the "factual reality of where was George W. Bush at the times in question and what was he doing?"

title: How Denying the Vote to Ex-Offenders Undermines Democracy
description: Pundits blame apathy for the decline in voter turnout that has become a fact of life in the United States in the last several decades. But not everyone who skips the polls on Election Day does so by choice. This November, for example, an estimated five million people -- roughly 2.3 percent of the number of people eligible to vote -- will be barred from voting by state laws that strip convicted felons of the franchise, often temporarily but sometimes for life.

title: Clear Channel Is Expanding in Spanish Radio
description: Clear Channel Communications, the nation's biggest radio conglomerate, said yesterday that it planned to convert up to 25 of its stations to Spanish-language formats as it pursues a larger share of the advertising dollars aimed at Hispanic listeners.

title: Taxing Global Profits
description: A new study showing that American multinational companies booked a record $149 billion of profits in tax-haven countries in 2002 is further evidence, if any were needed, that the corporate tax structure is much in need of repair.

title: U.S. Says Diplomat Quit Post, Then Met With Taiwan Agents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - A former senior State Department official charged with trying to conceal a prohibited trip to Taiwan last year resigned from the government on July 30 and then met with two Taiwan intelligence agents the next day, according to a criminal affidavit filed in federal court.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Andrew Lord
description: Paul Kasmin Gallery 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street Chelsea Through Oct. 9

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the dispute over memos relating to President Bush's National Guard service misidentified the setting in which Bill Glennon, an I.B.M. typewriter specialist, examined them. He viewed copies on his computer at home, not at CBS.

title: In a Battered Pensacola, 'It Was Bad Everywhere'
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept 16 - People in this Gulf Coast city emerged from their safe havens on Thursday to find their city battered, splintered and tossed about like so much toy furniture in the hands of a furious child.

title: An Artful Woman Skips Georgia Town, Having Taken It to the Cleaners
description: ALPHARETTA, Ga., Sept. 16 - S. Since Callahan envisioned an exclusive quarterly magazine, big and glossy like the old Life or Look, to be called The Alpharetta Social Registrar.

title: Racetrack Deal Dropped
description: MI Developments Inc., a Canadian real estate company controlled by Frank Stronach, has dropped a $285 million bid to buy the rest of the racetrack operator Magna Entertainment Corporation.

title: International Traveler / Update:PARIS:
A Sign From Beijing? Hong Kong Chief Shelves the Security Law
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16 - Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, ruled out on Thursday trying to pass internal security legislation any time soon, a strong sign that his backers in Beijing have decided to take a conciliatory stance after legislative elections here last Sunday.

title: Voices, Video and Dance, Conversing on Emigration
description: Something happens in Gabri Christa's "Dominata." That cannot be said of a great many dances these days, full though they may be of steps and gestures, pure movement or large themes. But Ms. Christa and her grittily individualistic dancers manage to transform the black-box stage of Dance Theater Workshop, where her DanzAisa company opened on Wednesday night, into a Caribbean streetscape, and to evoke the state of mind of a Caribbean transplant to New York.

title: Returning to the Baseball Diamond, With Life Lessons to Learn
description: Directed by Charles Stone III PG-13, 104 minutes

title: 'Crutch'
description: Directed by Rob Moretti Not rated, 89 minutes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUSCZYNSKI, HENRY
description: LUSCZYNSKI--Henry, 83, Beloved father of Lori Simon and son-in-law Joel M. Simon of NYC. died September 13th. A World War II Marine Corp meteorologist, he was a talented draughtsman designer developing the G.I. Joe doll and Sunfish sailboat. Funeral celebration Saturday in Springfield, MA. Contributions to Marion Sarcoidosis Foundation, C/O United Bank 1077 St. James Avenue, Springfield, MA 01104.

title: The Pen Is Mightier Than the Lock
description: The cunning bicycle thieves of New York City always seem to be one step ahead of lockmakers. Design a more sophisticated lock and the thieves make a better pick. Make a sturdier chain and they get bigger bolt cutters. And if all else fails, they just dig up the parking meter or stop sign to unshackle the bike from it. But to open some of the toughest locks on the market, a thief needs only to flick his Bic pen.

title: Uncorking a River
description: SUMMERSVILLE, W.Va. - AT a little before 7 a.m. last Friday, a caravan of purple-and-green school buses pierced through the morning fog and pulled into a steadily filling parking lot at the base of the Summersville Dam. Like a column of picnic ants, hundreds of people in orange life vests, neoprene wet suits and white helmets formed a line down to the lip of the Gauley River. Then, precisely at 7, the Army Corps of Engineers uncorked the dam, sending 2,300 cubic feet of water per second into the Gauley, churning the usually ho-hum creek into a 25-mile thrill ride that ranks among the fiercest rapids in the nation, if not the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, RICHARD J.
description: COHN--Richard J., on September 15, 2004. Beloved husband of Leita Hesen. Devoted brother of Adelaide Peters. Loving uncle of Tom and Gerry Peters. A graduate of Lawrence High School and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. A longtime member of the American Stock Exchange and options trader for Susquehanna. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Saturday, September 18, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services Sunday, September 19, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to SloanKettering Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, MARGIT LOEPERT
description: SIMON--Margit Loepert. At the age of 81. Beloved wife of Peter, Sr. for over 61 years. Loving mother of Peter, Jr., and mother-in-law of Ellen. Adored grandmother of Jennifer. Dear sister of Helga Rosenberger. Devoted sisterin-law of Ellen Simon Marks, and aunt of Bob Simon, and Lynn Edelstein. Please remember her for what she was to all of us. Interment private. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St., Sunday, September 19th, 2:00-6:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory to Meals on Wheels or a charity of your choice.

Shopping | Fall Clean-Up
description: WITH fall on the way, your fading, leaf-strewn yard and garden can just sit there and molder, waiting for the first snow to cover its shame. Or it can be raked, pruned, swept and firmly tucked in for a long winter nap. Given this year's seriously powerful helpers, a weekend of outdoor nurturing promises deep satisfaction for both soil and spirit, as well as a glorious renewal come spring. SUZANNE HAMLIN

National Briefing | Washington: New Designs, Front And Back, For The Nickel
description: The United States Mint introduced two new designs for the nickel to begin circulating next year, part of a three-year commemoration celebrating the bicentennial of both the Louisiana Purchase and the Lewis and Clark expedition. Thomas Jefferson's profile will remain on the coin's front side, but will shift to the left and show more detail; the other side will alternate images of a bison and a rocky Pacific coastline with the words "Ocean in view! O! The joy!" from Capt. William Clark's journal. Jefferson's likeness had not changed since 1938; in 2006 the image of Monticello will return to the back of the coin. John Files (NYT)

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 17  Iraqi health officials said American airstrikes that demolished homes late today in a village south of the volatile city of Falluja killed at least 44 people and wounded 27, including women and children.

description: OTTAWA, Sept. 16 - The Canadian government began the sale of its 19 percent stake in Petro-Canada on Thursday in what will most likely be the largest share sale in Canadian history.

title: Nassau County Shop Owners Worry as Robber Grows Violent
description: MANHASSET, N.Y., Sept. 15 - The 19-year-old clerk at Steiner's Pastry had just pushed a baking rack back to the freezer when she noticed a customer had slipped into the store. It was five minutes before closing. As she asked, "Can I help you?" she saw him tie a handkerchief around his face. Then she saw his gun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRINCE, ROBIN HERNDON
description: PRINCE--Robin Herndon, 67, of Greenwich, CT, died Tuesday, September 14, 2004. Chairman of Jamison Prince Asset Management, previously a Principal of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, General Partner of Royal Partners, former Senior V.P. of Bessemer Trust Company. Survived by father Sydney Rhodes Prince, Jr., wife Lolly Howell Prince, former Selectman of Greenwich, two daughters and a son. Calling hours will be held Thursday, September 16 at Leo P. Gallagher & Son, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, 4-8PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held 11AM on Friday, September 17, at St. Michael Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich. PRINCE--Robin H. The employees of Jamison Prince Asset Management mourn the passing of our Chairman, who was a leader, mentor and friend--his spirit will forever be entwined in the fabric of the firm.

description: GULF SHORES, Ala., Sept. 17 A Armed National Guardsmen turned back residents today from the areas hardest-hit by Hurricane Ivan as local authorities in Alabama waited for the tidal surge to recede in order to make basic damage assessments.
