description: Here are some favorite Dvorak recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. Availability is hard to determine in the current state of the market. Most of the recordings here can be found on Amazon.com or in major record stores. CD's range in price from $11.98 to $16.98 for one CD to $47.98 for a six-CD set. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Johnny Ramone, Pioneer Punk Guitarist, Is Dead at 55
description: Johnny Ramone, the stone-faced guitarist of the punk band the Ramones, whose fast, buzz-saw blasts of noise laid the foundation for a school of rock guitar, died on Wednesday afternoon at his home in Los Angeles. He was 55.

title: To Our Readers
Boosting the Fabulous Invalid
description: Jeffrey Ash, now a theater producer, was recalling his days in advertising when he remembered "Frankenstein," a play by Victor Gialanella that opened and closed on Broadway at the Palace Theater on Jan. 4, 1981. As a founder of Ash/LeDonne, a theatrical ad agency, now defunct, Mr. Ash had handled the show's pre-opening campaign and became one of its instant creditors.

The book on the Bushes : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Peace Talks Open
description: The Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders of Northern Ireland gathered at Leeds Castle in England under strong admonition from the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland to resolve the differences that led to the collapse of the power-sharing accord known as the Good Friday Agreement of 1998. Prime Minister Tony Blair made it clear that foremost among the concessions he wanted to see was the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army. "This is the moment of decision as to whether those acts of completion will happen or not," he said. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: HUD Asks Newark Agency to Explain Its Hiring Policy
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16 - The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development sent a letter to the Newark Housing Authority on Thursday asking the agency to explain its policy on hiring family members.

title: $78,000 for a Cane That Helped a Legend Walk the Line
description: In his 1964 song "Understand Your Man," Johnny Cash gave some bitter and specific estate instructions to the woman he was leaving in the dust: "You can give my other suit to the Salvation Army," he sang, "and everything else I leave behind."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOFFEN, RONA
description: GOFFEN--Rona, died September 8, 2004. Her family mourns the passing of Rona Goffen of Princeton, NJ, noted art historian and Board of Governors Professor at Rutgers University. Her enthusiasm and expertise in the Renaissance inspired all who knew her. Memorial service will be held November 20th at 10:30AM at Kirkpatrick Chapel at Rutgers University. Lucy Fremont Laura Hayford Charlotte Garrett Drs. David & Judith Brook Dr. Adam Brook Jonathan, Nicole & Juliette Brook

title: Manila seeks donations from top taxpayers
German nationalists count on resentment
Lloyd Webber's Emoting Victorians
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 - And who said those genteel Victorians had trouble expressing their emotions? The decorously costumed creatures in "The Woman in White," the much-anticipated new musical from Andrew Lloyd Webber, certainly do not. No sooner do they tumble into love -- as three of them manage within the first 10 minutes of this swoony, flattening adaptation of Wilkie Collins's classic suspense novel -- than crashing, purple waves of song gush from their mouths.

title: Adultery as a Criminal Offense May Still Have a Life in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 16 - Conservative lawmakers rebelled Thursday and insisted on reviving a proposal to criminalize adultery, even as the Parliament neared completion of a reform package to bring Turkey's laws in line with European Union human rights standards.

title: Liberty Leaves Radio City With Shot at Playoffs
description: The Liberty, knowing it had to win two of the three games left to clinch a spot in the W.N.B.A. playoffs, defeated another playoff contender, the Indiana Fever, 77-71, in overtime last night at Radio City Music Hall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Former Chief of Shell Challenges Regulator Sir Philip Watts, in his first public statement since he was ousted as chairman of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in March, said that British financial regulators had violated his rights in their investigation of the company's huge restatement of its oil and natural gas reserves.

title: Bush Says Kerry Is Pushing Nationalized Health Care
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Sept. 16 - Using terms reminiscent of Republican attacks on President Bill Clinton's ill-fated effort to reshape the health care system a decade ago, President Bush attacked Senator John Kerry's health care proposal on Thursday, saying "it's a plan that is massive and it's big, and it puts the government in control of health care."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIEL, GERARD
description: PIEL--Gerard. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Natural Resources Defense Council mourn the passing of Gerard Piel, the founding editor and publisher of "Scientific American." Mr. Piel served as a judge for the Oakes Award, one of the nation's premier environmental writing prizes, established by NRDC in 1994. We will miss his insight, enthusiasm, wit, endless inquisitiveness and boundless energy. We extend our deeply felt condolences to his family.

title: Intelligence estimate from July is bleaker than Bush's tone : U.S. study has a dark forecast for Iraq
Warning on Reserves
description: The chief of the Army Reserve said that at the current pace of operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, there was a serious risk of running out of crucial specialists who could be involuntarily called up for active duty.

title: Campaign Briefing: THE SURROGATES; DEAD G.I.'S MOTHER IS ARRESTED AT LAURA BUSH SPEECH
description: The mother of a soldier killed in Iraq was arrested after interrupting a speech by Laura Bush in Hamilton, N.J. Mrs. Bush appeared before a crowd of more than 700 people at the Colonial Fire Hall, trumpeting President Bush's efforts to fight terrorism and stimulate the economy with tax cuts. When she made reference to the war in Iraq, she was interrupted by a spectator, Sue Niederer, who shouted, "Why don't your children serve?" Mr. Bush's supporters quickly surrounded Ms. Niederer, who wore a shirt bearing a photo of her son, Seth Dvorin, an Army lieutenant killed in Iraq in February, and the words "President Bush, You Killed My Son." As Bush supporters shouted "Four more years!" and Mrs. Bush resumed her speech, security guards led Ms. Niederer from the auditorium. Later, as Ms. Niederer stood near the doorway to the fire hall being interviewed by reporters, she refused a request to leave the premises and was arrested on charges of trespassing. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

Storms Could Cause Delay in Shuttle Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - The battering that the hurricanes of the last month has inflicted on NASA centers could strain an already tight schedule for resuming shuttle flights, but it is too early to tell how badly, experts said Thursday.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 A Senator John Kerry continued his sharp criticism of the Bush administration today, this time accusing it of steering lucrative no-bid contracts to the Halliburton company, which Vice President Dick Cheney once headed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, RHODA
description: WEINER--Rhoda, September 14, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Barbara and the late Barry. Dear grandmother of Debra, Adam and Rachel. Greatgrandmother of Noah. Service Sunday 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th St & Amsterdam Ave

title: Chechen Rebel Takes Credit for Recent Attacks in Russia
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17 A Shamil Basayev, the one-footed and elusive Chechen guerrilla commander who has become Russia's most-wanted man, has taken responsibility for planning acts of terror that killed more than 440 people since August, and he is threatening more attacks, a separatist Web site said today.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Depot Stops Demolition Of Chemicals
description: Destruction of a chemical weapons stockpile was halted at the Umatilla Chemical Depot near Hermiston after two workers mistakenly entered a room containing liquid sarin, the toxic nerve agent, that had been drained from 11 rockets. A spokeswoman for the depot said the workers were fine, though they were not wearing the protective clothing required to enter the room. She said plant procedures would be re-evaluated before work resumed. Eli Sanders (NYT)

title: This Is Bush's Vietnam
description: ARLINGTON, Va. - The rows of simple white headstones in the broad expanses of brilliant green lawns are scrupulously arranged, and they seem to go on and on, endlessly, in every direction.

title: Corrections
Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHONEY, WILLIAM B.
description: MAHONEY--William B. September 15, 2004, in Miami. A writer, trade unionist, an alcoholism counselor, he touched many lives in his 92 years. His short stories and sports columns appeared in magazines, books and two daily newspapers; he negotiated for the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union and won awards editing its magazine; he helped people stay sober. He is survived by four children--Judith Mahoney Pasternak of New York, Joan Mahoney of Detroit, and Martha Mahoney and Donald Mahoney of Miami--ten grandchildren, three great grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the ACLU or Jobs with Justice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Rise At Luxury Concern
description: The luxury goods maker Richemont said sales rose 15 percent in the five months to August as demand recovered for its watch and jewelry brands, which include Cartier. In addition, Norbert Platt, left, president of the Montblanc unit, known for its fountain pens, was named chief executive. Sales at constant currencies rose 17 percent, the executive chairman, Johann Rupert, said at the annual meeting. Richemont, which begins its financial year in April, did not give total revenue for the five months. Mr. Platt, 57, has worked at Montblanc for 17 years, Mr. Rupert said. Mr. Platt will succeed Mr. Rupert as chief executive immediately. Mr. Rupert will remain chairman.

title: Florida Battered Again
description: People in the Gulf Coast city of Pensacola, Fla., emerged after Hurricane Ivan to find backyards flooded, trees uprooted and light posts bent at right angles. Still, many said it could have been worse.

title: NEOPHARM REGAINS OWNERSHIP OF 2 CANCER COMPOUNDS
description: NeoPharm Inc. said it regained ownership of two cancer compounds after a unit of Pfizer stopped developing them more than two years ago. NeoPharm, based in Lake Forest, Ill., and Pfizer, of New York, ended a pact covering liposome-encapsulated paclitaxel and liposome-encapsulated doxorubicin. Both treatments use a technology that combines fats with the drugs to cut side effects and possibly increase effectiveness. Taking full ownership allows NeoPharm to seek federal approval by early 2007 of its formulation of paclitaxel, a compound that has been cleared for ovarian, breast and lung cancers, the company's chief financial officer, Larry Kenyon, said.

title: Reflecting on World Events in Leather and Lace-Up Boots
description: The intriguing new face of the chameleonic German singer and actress Ute Lemper is as fascinating (and daunting) as the other musical personas she has cultivated in the seven years she has lived in New York.

description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 16 - The ball is in the back seat of Jets safety Erik Coleman's truck. It is wrapped in tape and marked with the words "Interception 1:51. 4th Quarter vs. Bengals."

title: Archdiocese Leaves Kerry and President Off Guest List
description: For more than 50 years, the road to the White House has almost always included a white-tie rest stop at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner, a charity roast at the Waldorf-Astoria named for the nation's first Roman Catholic to be a major party's presidential nominee.

title: Budget Use of Pensions Sows Trouble in San Diego
description: San Diego is caught in a financial bind, facing the possibility of a bankruptcy filing, largely because of a $1.2 billion shortfall in its pension fund for municipal workers. For years the city has spent money from illusory pension fund earnings, according to the authors of a new report released yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Shamil Basayev, the Chechen warlord accused of having plotted the attacks that terrorized Russia this summer and killed hundreds, misidentified the region adjacent to Chechnya in which he and his fighters seized a hospital and held 1,500 hostages in 1995. It was Stavropol, not Dagestan. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Paul Caine as publisher of People magazine misstated its circulation ranking among Time Warner's magazines. It is the second-largest; Time ranks first. The report also misstated the surname of Mr. Caine's successor as publisher at Entertainment Weekly. He is Tom Morrissy, not Morrissey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COX, ARCHIBALD
description: COX--Archibald. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, October 8th in The Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA. at 2 PM.

title: City Arrest Tactics, Used on Protesters, Face Test in Court
description: New York City has one memento from the 2004 Republican National Convention that seems destined to last: an especially bitter dispute over the city's methods and motives in detaining hundreds of protesters, well beyond the ordinary legal time limit of 24 hours, without the usual access to lawyers.

title: Bush Shows Congress Plan for Spy Czar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 - The White House submitted to Congress on Thursday its proposed version of legislation to establish the job of a powerful national intelligence director, calling for the spy czar to have somewhat less power than some lawmakers and members of the independent Sept. 11 commission had hoped.

title: Mayor Is Urged to Use Barges to Carry Commercial Trash
description: Raising the pressure as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg prepares to release his 20-year waste management plan, city lawmakers and community advocates said yesterday that the city should use barges rather than trucks to move commercial trash to out-of-state landfills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVID, ELSE
description: DAVID--Else. Died peacefully September 14th at age 101. Beloved cousin of Ernest W. and Amy Michel and family, Lotte Rein and families, Israel. Widow of Cantor Arthur David. Wonderful friend, Holocaust survivor, longtime volunteer, active in her Synagogue who named Golden Age Club in her honor. Services 12 Noon Sunday, September 19th, Congregation Ohav Shaloum, 4624 Broadway.

title: In Address to Guard, Kerry Says Bush Isn't Telling Truth on Iraq
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 16 - Senator John Kerry said at a National Guard conference on Thursday that President Bush was living in "a fantasy world of spin" and that the president had deceived them when he presented an optimistic picture of the war in Iraq at the same conference two days before.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mortgage Lender Acquired
description: A Spanish bank, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, will buy Hipotecaria Nacional, Mexico's biggest specialty mortgage lender, for $375 million to gain clients among less-affluent home buyers in Mexico and the United States. The Spanish bank will make the purchase through its Bancomer unit, Mexico's largest commercial bank by assets, Banco Bilbao told regulators. Hipotecaria Nacional, with $2.15 billion in loans, is one of 17 pure mortgage lenders that focus more on blue-collar clients. Hipotecaria Nacional already has offices in New York and San Diego that lend to some of the millions of Mexicans living in the United States.

title: Inside a Dying Movie House Filled With Lonely Phantoms
description: "Goodbye Dragon Inn" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 15, 2003; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The unrated film -- in Mandarin with English subtitles -- opens today at the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OFFICE DEPOT INC., Delray Beach, Fla., the office supplies retailer, said it would buy back as much as $500 million of its shares during the next two years.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fourth Province Legalizes Gay Marriage
description: A judge in Manitoba ruled that the traditional definition of marriage was unconstitutional and must be changed to include same-sex couples, making the province the fourth to legalize same-sex marriage since June 2003. The provinces that already allow such marriages are Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia. Same-sex marriage is also legal in the Yukon territory. Together, the five jurisdictions account for nearly 80 percent of the population. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: PROPERTIES : HOME PAGES
Beyond the Cacophony of India to Realms of Princes and Gods
description: You catch a plane in New York, fly for almost a day and land in India in the middle of the night. And if you happen to find yourself a few hours later, at dawn, in the middle of a small-town marketplace, you really know what it means to be someplace else.

title: Euro RSCG Worldwide Adds New York Chief
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide, part of Havas, said yesterday that it had named David Jones, executive vice president and managing director for global business, to the new post of chief executive for New York.

description: A picture caption on the first sports page in some copies on Wednesday about the World Cup of Hockey game between Canada and Finland misidentified a Canadian player celebrating his goal with a teammate, Kris Draper. He was Shane Doan, not Joe Thornton.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Wednesday about the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Vocals Competition in Washington misidentified the presenter of the first-place prize. He was Edward T. Welburn, vice president for design at General Motors North America; the fourth-place prize was presented by Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

description: BALAY--Roland (May 28, 1902--September 16, 2004). Knoedler & Company celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Roland Balay, grandson of our founder, Michael Knoedler, and President Emeritus of the gallery (1956-1976). Mr. Balay served artists and collectors with dedication and vision which continue to be an inspiration to this day. Our sympathies go out to his wife of 30 years, Felicie Trayman Balay, and to his devoted family.

title: Book Report : Cowboy capitalism
Brian Wilson and the Significance of an Abandoned Masterpiece
description: Some readers, and I am one of them, prefer the version of "The Prelude" that Wordsworth finished in 1805 and laid aside to the version published soon after his death in 1850. "The Prelude" is an autobiographical poem, and a certain freshness and immediacy evaporated as Wordsworth revised the text. His is a case in which an early work of art comes to have greater authority than the artist, in later life, who made it. As a poet, the young Wordsworth overrules his older self.

title: Biggest Mistake by Mickelson Came Before Play Began
description: Bloomfield Township, Mich. - IN the Ryder Cup, the Americans may still have the name, but the Europeans continue to have the game.

Meng sat in his campaign office in Flushing, Queens, greeting a stream of well-wishers and reflecting on a victory that places him on the path to be the first Asian-American member of the State Legislature.

description: RATHE--Frederick A. Age 87, of Cold Spring, NY, died on September 16, 2004. Beloved husband of Ethel (Nissman) Rathe. Father of Robert and Richard. Grandfather and great - grandfather. Private cremation in Ferncliff Crematory. A celebration of Fred's life will take place at the family's residence in Cold Spring on Sunday, September 19, 2004 at 12 noon. Family and friends are invited. For more information, contact the Clinton Funeral Home, Cold Spring, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGAR, GERTRUD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOSLER, STUART N.
description: SOSLER--Stuart N., 68, of Stuart, FL died September 17th, 2004. Beloved father of Neil and Andree and fatherin-law of Heather Katzen Sosler. Adoring grandfather of Caroline. Loving husband of the late Carolyn Atlas Sosler. He is also survived by sister, Francine Sosler. Stuart was born in New York City on March 17th, 1936. Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and former partner of Bear Stearns & Co. Services 2:00 PM, Sunday, September 19th, 2004 at Riverside Memorial, 1920 Alton Rd, Miami Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to an organization supporting the election of John Kerry.

title: Rightists hope strife pulls votes in Saxony
World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Water Utility Reverses Loss
description: Veolia Environnement , the French water company, returned to profit in the first half of the year on higher demand for water and waste management in the United States and Asia. The company also said it planned to increase its dividend. Net income was 181.4 million euros ($221 million), compared with a net loss of 2.1 billion euros in the period last year, when the company wrote down the value of its U.S. Filter Corporation unit. Veolia, which is based in Paris, gets about 12 percent of its revenue from the United States. The chief executive, Henri Proglio, said all five of the company's divisions contributed to the growth.

title: They Said It Couldn't Be Done
description: Many computer scientists insist that electronic voting machines will be trustworthy only when they produce paper receipts that can be audited. But supporters of electronic voting have long argued that doing so would be extremely difficult, if not impossible. Nevada proved the naysayers wrong this month, running the first statewide election in which electronic voting machines produced paper records of votes cast. Election officials across the country now have no excuse not to provide systems that voters can trust.

title: In Nature's Own Concert Hall, Sound Is Forever
description: MOAB, Utah, Sept. 17 - It is a rare music festival that requires patrons to sign a risk waiver as they purchase tickets. But that is one of the peculiarities of the Moab Music Festival, which takes the idea of outdoor concerts to the extreme by ferrying musicians, guests and instruments -- including, on Thursday, a Steinway grand piano -- 15 miles along the Colorado River for a late afternoon performance in a towering red-rock grotto.

title: Correction
1929:Russians Map North : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Voice Restoring Elemental Flamenco Passion
description: Flamenco has been fused every which way lately: reharmonized with jazz, molded into pop songs, combined with Afro-Caribbean rhythms. But the younger generation still includes traditionalists like Rafael de Utrera, one of Spain's most acclaimed young flamenco vocalists. He sang a stark, intimate set at Joe's Pub on Tuesday night.

title: N.B.A. Cancels Game in Russia, Citing Terrorism Risk
description: The National Basketball Association announced yesterday that it had canceled an Oct. 8 exhibition game in Russia featuring the Utah Jazz against the Moscow club CSKA because the recent terrorist attacks in the country presented a security threat to the game.

title: Crude Oil Soars to 4-Week High on Storm-Related Shutdowns
description: Crude oil surged to a four-week high, bringing the gain this week to almost $3 a barrel, on concern that shutdowns caused by Hurricane Ivan would further reduce inventories. Gasoline futures also rose to a four-week high, capping the largest weekly gain in a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMAS, VURGHESE
description: THOMAS--Vurghese, August 28, 1926-September 14, 2004. Survived by his wife, children, brother, sisters, and grandchildren. Services are at St. Rocco's Church, Saturday, 9:30AM, Burial at Greenwood Cemetery, 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARDER, HENRY U.
description: HARDER--Henry U., 79, of Yarmouth, ME died at home on September 6, 2004 after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in NYC on March 9th, 1925, he was the son of Gertrude U. Harris and Lewis F. Harder. He lived for many years in Greenwich, CT before retiring to Maine. Upper Saranac Lake, NY was his summer retreat. Graduating from St. Marks School in Southboro, MA, 1943, he joined the Navy serving as Lt. j.g. and Naval Aviator. He graduated from Yale, Class of 1945W. Henry joined the insurance firm of Chubb & Son in July of 1948, became President in October of 1972, and was CEO from 1980-1988 when he retired. He served as a trustee of St. George's School for 20 years. Henry is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Calista Lincoln, five children: Fred and his wife, Karin, of Mercer Island, WA; Trudy Briggs and her husband Jim, of Pownal, ME; Calista Hollyer and her husband, Jan; Holly Catlin and her husband, Bruce; Maj. Henry U. Harder, Jr.,Vermont Air National Guard and his wife Natalie, all of Vermont. Henry was the proud grandfather of 14 grandchildren. Henry is survived by a brother, Philip, three sisters, Avery Kennedy, Cynthia Murray, Jenepher Parr and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by two brothers, Lewis and John. A memorial service took place in Yarmouth at St. Bartholomew's Church on September 11, 2004, a service will also take place next summer in the Adirondacks. In lieu of flowers, memorial remembrances can be sent to: St. Bartholomew's Church, 396 Gilman Rd, Yarmouth, ME 04096 or St. George's School, Newport, RI 02840.

title: Information Is the Best Medicine
description: Measures to make the results of drug trials more accessible to doctors and the public, as well as the federal government's probable stiffer warnings on the use of antidepressants for children, are definitely steps in the right direction. But my experience as a family doctor on the front lines of medicine leads me to believe that these moves won't be enough to curb the influence of the drug companies on our health care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAFFE, VITA SANDRA
description: JAFFE--Vita Sandra. March 5, 1923,--September 16, 2004, New York City. Vita is survived by her loving and devoted husband, Matthew, of 46 years; her beloved children, Dana, Byron and Robert; endearing grandchildren, Benjamin, Hannah, and Nathaniel; adoring daughters-inlaw, Kendra, Beth, and devoted son-in-law, Theodore; best friend and companion, Marilyn Brunson. Vita was a lady's lady, classy, sophisticated and demure, respected by all who knew her for her understanding and kindness. She did everything with an open hand, heart, and mind. Vita was an unusual human being, a registered nurse, educator, employer, and administrator of Matthew Jaffe Enterprises. Vita showed us how to live elegantly and will be missed greatly by all of us forever. Services Sunday, 11:30AM September 19, at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, 212362-6600. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Deborah Hospital Foundation, 800-631-0954 or www.deborahfoundation.org

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBY, HENRY J.
description: JACOBY--Henry J., 87, of New York City on September 15, 2004. Beloved husband of Doris Goodman Jacoby; brother of Gertrude Handelman and Leah Berton; father of Ruth Ellen Jacoby Barnert, Karen Jacoby Zovic, and Jean Jacoby Bentley; grandfather of Matthew Jacoby Barnert, Michelle Celeste Zovic, Nicholas Henry Zovic, Barritt Wolff Jacoby Bentley, and Emma Rose Bentley Jacoby. Of complications from a heart attack after a brief illness. Retired President and Chairman of the Board of Grow Tunneling Corporation, Honorary Vice President and Trustee of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, former Chairman of the Board, Walden School, former President of the Anthropology Museum of the People of New York. We will always love and miss him. Funeral services will be held on Monday 11:30 AM at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions be made to the Nature Conservancy.

title: Hire the Guy With a Head for Baseball
description: MR. MET does not have the ability to speak. This could be related to his hydrocephalic condition, or to fear among his handlers that if he ever brought foam tongue to palate, he might sound like Anna Nicole Smith, or some tapped-out denizen of a Flushing boardinghouse who gargles with gin.

title: Tax Break Bringing Businesses, and Fraud, to the Virgin Islands
description: ST. THOMAS, V.I. - Inside and outside the freshly stuccoed mansions that hug the hillsides here, the gardeners and cleaning women come and go.

title: Operator of Nuclear Plant Readying Strike Substitutes
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 - The operator of the Indian Point nuclear power plant is training a replacement force to take over security should the regular guards go on strike when their contract expires on Oct. 2, officials said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EASTON, DAVID
description: EASTON--David. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its Honorary Trustee and devoted servant and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Sports Briefing: OLYMPICS; Hormone Tests in Athens
description: Dick Pound, the chief of the World Anti-Doping Agency, confirmed yesterday that athletes were tested for human growth hormone for the first time during the Olympic Games in Athens.

title: US Airways Said to Plan to Ask Court for Pay Cuts
description: US Airways plans to ask a federal bankruptcy judge on Oct. 7 to impose temporary pay cuts on its workers unless it can reach agreement with its unions before then, people who have been briefed on the company's strategy said yesterday.

title: TETRA TECH SEES QUARTERLY PROFIT WELL BELOW FORECAST
description: Tetra Tech Inc., a provider of engineering and technical services, said fourth-quarter profit would be "substantially below" its forecast, setting off a 20 percent decline in its share price. In July, the company said fourth-quarter profit would be 24 cents a share, in line with analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Tetra Tech, based in Pasadena, Calif., did not provide specific figures and said it would update investors in a few weeks. The company's stock fell $3.53, to $13.89 a share.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about disputed memos obtained by CBS News that cast doubt on aspects of President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard truncated a quotation from David Van Os, a lawyer for Bill Burkett, a retired National Guard officer. Asked what role Mr. Burkett had in raising questions about Mr. Bush's military service, Mr. Van Os posed a hypothetical chain of events in which someone -- not Mr. Burkett, he said -- reconstructed documents that the preparer believed existed in 1972 or 1973. Mr. Van Os then asked "what difference would even that make" to the "factual reality of where was George W. Bush at the times in question and what was he doing?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIESEN, MAE (NEE HALPERIN)
description: WIESEN--Mae (nee Halperin). Died Friday, September 17 in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Loving mother of the late Dorothy Sokolski and David Wiesen, PhD. Loving grandmother of Pearl, Joy, Rachel, Seth and Jonathan. Motherin-law of Ellen Wiesen. Sister of Berenice Adams. Devoted sister-in-law and aunt, proud great-grandmother. Graveside service Sunday, September 19, 2:00 P.M. at Union Field Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, LILLIAN. AGE 96, (NEE FARBER), AKA ''GONA'' AND ''GRANDMERE''
description: FEINBERG--Lillian. Age 96, (nee Farber), AKA "Gona" and "Grandmere", the last of the seven Farber children, wife for nearly 70 years of the late Abraham Feinberg and mother of the late Richard Feinberg MD, died Friday at her home. Mom, everyone who knew you loved you and felt loved by you. Grandchildren: Jeffrey, Audrey, Michael and Steven. Great-grandchildren: Jonathan, Noah, Will, Gabriella, Daniel, Jason, Lilly and Isaac. In-laws: Bill, Shirley and Belle. In-law children: Doris, Norbert, Jim, Martha, Cindy and Karen. My step-children John, Gilly, Jed and Jamie, and all your nieces and nephews. I felt your love and support my entire life. You taught me about the "inner life" and launched me on a career. I'll remember you forever sweetest Mama. And, by the way, did I tell you how gorgeous you are---always. Your Purple Mouse, Judy. Service Sunday 10:45 A.M. at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Medical Development for Israel-Feinberg Child Study Center would be appreciated.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Varying Polls Reflect Volatility, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - With national public opinion surveys showing the presidential race to be anywhere from a dead heat between President Bush and Senator John Kerry to Mr. Bush's holding a commanding lead, potential voters have their choice of what to believe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Qualcomm's Audit Proposal Worries Shareholders Qualcomm, the maker of microprocessors for cellphones, received a lesson in stock market jitters when it announced that it planned to study whether to change its accounting practices to reflect the growing size and volatility of the mobile communications market.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about disputed memos obtained by CBS News that cast doubt on aspects of President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard truncated a quotation from David Van Os, a lawyer for Bill Burkett, a retired National Guard officer. Asked what role Mr. Burkett had in raising questions about Mr. Bush's military service, Mr. Van Os posed a hypothetical chain of events in which someone -- not Mr. Burkett, he said -- reconstructed documents that the preparer believed existed in 1972 or 1973. Mr. Van Os then asked "what difference would even that make" to the "factual reality of where was George W. Bush at the times in question and what was he doing?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, RHODA

title: COCA-COLA CHIEF TO BE PAID LESS THAN PREDECESSOR
description: The Coca-Cola Company set the salary and bonus of its chief executive, E. Neville Isdell, at $4.5 million, less than his predecessor's, amid sluggish sales, the company said in a regulatory filing. The company will pay Mr. Isdell a base salary of $1.5 million and a bonus of up to $3 million, Coca-Cola said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The salary and bonus are in addition to a previously announced award of 450,000 stock options and a one-time restricted stock award of 140,000 shares. Mr. Isdell returned to Coca-Cola in June to succeed Douglas N. Daft, who retired; Mr. Daft earned a salary and bonus of $5.5 million in 2003. Mr. Isdell said on Wednesday that Coca-Cola needed to take "corrective actions" after the company forecast that second-half earnings would decline because of sluggish sales.

title: Europeans Storm America at the Ryder Cup
description: BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Sept. 17 - The Americans need a Plan B at the Ryder Cup after the Europeans annihilated Plan A.

After Being Bounced Around Florida Is Bouncing Back

title: Virginia Hamilton Adair, 91, a Poet Famous Late in Life, Dies
description: Virginia Hamilton Adair, a California poet who published her first collection, "Ants on the Melon," when she was 83, died on Thursday in Claremont, Calif., her daughter, Katharine Adair Waugh, said. She was 91 and lived in Claremont.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, S. DAVID
description: LEVY--S. David. 67. Passed away peacefully on September 15. Beloved husband of Seena Schnall Levy, father of Karena Levy and her husband, Richard Buczkowski, and Benjamin Levy, brother of Richard H. Levy and Philip G. Levy. Graduate of University of Wisconsin, Madison, 1959 and Harvard Law School, 1962. Co-founder of the Biograph Theatre, coowner of the legendary Key Theatre with his wife, both in Washington DC. Services will be held at 2 PM on Sunday, September 19 at Washington Hebrew Congregation, Macomb St., at Mass Ave., NW, Washington DC. Interment at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 5789 Cooper Ave., Ridgewood, NY, 718-386-6700, at 1 PM on Monday, September 20. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Alexander Graham Bell Association for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, 3417 Volta Plc., NW, Washington DC, 20007, and the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Ave., NY, NY 10017.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - Less than seven weeks before the presidential election, employment figures released on Friday showed that job creation slowed to a crawl last month in some swing states hit hard by widespread layoffs in manufacturing.

description: SHIMM--Mark. Born 1947, passed away September 16, after a long courageous battle with Leukemia and Lymphoma. Mark was a gifted photographer and songwriter who leaves a legacy of beautiful work. He is survived by sisters Emily Sendler (David) of Riverdale, Dorrine Levy (Jack) of Liberty, and niece and nephews Karen, Matthew, Adam and Michael. A graveside service will be held Sunday, September 19 at Jeffersonville Jewish Cemetery. Contact Garlick Funeral Home: 845-647-7747.

It was the first six months of this year, not 2003. (A correction prepared in mid-August went astray at The Times.)

title: A One-Man Team Named Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 - When Barry Bonds was asked about his quest for 700 home runs, he gave an answer about the pennant race. When he was asked about a specific at-bat, he responded with a monologue about the latest game.

title: NEW ATTACK ON KERRY BY VIETNAM VETERANS GROUP
description: A group of Navy Swift boat veterans who oppose Senator John Kerry released a new advertisement questioning his credibility that will run for six days in the swing states of Nevada and New Mexico. The commercial, from Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, contrasts Mr. Kerry speaking in 1971 and this year about his Vietnam War decorations and what he did with them. Snippets of the appearances are shown rapidly, back and forth and back again, as Mr. Kerry seems to say in 1971 that he threw away medals and this year seems to say he threw away ribbons. The spot closes with the screen showing the word "Trust?" and a voice asking, "John Kerry. Can you trust anything he says?" The advertisement, the group's fifth, was quickly dismissed by Kerry aides. "This group has been completely discredited," said Chad Clanton, a campaign spokesman. "It's clear they are doing President Bush's dirty work." ABC News objected to the spot's use of videotape from an interview with Mr. Kerry on one of its programs. Michael Janofsky

title: Commander's Letter Praised Bush to Father
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - Two days after completing his basic training for the Texas Air National Guard in 1968, George W. Bush drew special attention from one of his commanders in the form of a letter praising him to his father, then a member of Congress from Texas, a document released late Friday by the Pentagon shows.

Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about Republican rallies for Roman Catholic and Jewish voters misstated the 2000 estimate of Catholic voters and referred incorrectly to their presidential choices that year. About 47 million Catholics, not 60 million, were eligible to vote in 2000, according to the Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate at Georgetown University. About half of the 27 million Catholics who voted -- not half of all eligible Catholic voters -- cast ballots for George W. Bush.

description: SHANGHAI - WHEN Guo Guoting pauses to think about the course his life has taken, it is the jagged lines, the result of a series of accidents, that impress him most.

title: Internationalism sweeps the Paris Biennale
Beyond The Fringe
description: The 2004 New York International Fringe Festival, which completed its eighth year in August, sold a record number of tickets to this year's performances, festival officials said yesterday. Elena K. Holy, the festival's producing artistic director, said it had sold or distributed some 60,000 tickets, an increase of about 20 percent over the 2003 festival. Online sales were particularly popular, Ms. Holy said, though part of the increase could be attributed to an agreement with Actors Equity, the professional actors and stage managers union, which allowed the festival to use larger theaters. This year's festival, which included 171 shows at 20 theaters over 17 days, ended on Aug. 29. JESSE McKINLEY

It's Speed Against Strength in De La Hoya vs. Hopkins
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 18 - Over 12 years, Oscar De La Hoya has fought in seven weight classes, weighing as little as 128A34 pounds and as much as 160. Many of us gain weight as we age, but De La Hoya has made it work for him without needing Jenny Craig: He has won eight titles in six divisions.

An e-mail message from Technician Sahlberg on Sept. 2 alerted The Times that the identifications were incorrect; this correction was delayed for verification of the correct identifications.

description: Glenn Presnell, a star back in the National Football League during the 1930's with the Portsmouth (Ohio) Spartans and their successor franchise, the Detroit Lions, died Monday at a nursing home in Ironton, Ohio. He was 99.

title: COURT LIFTS BAN ON ALPHARMA'S GENERIC EPILEPSY DRUG
description: Alpharma said a federal appeals court had lifted an order blocking it from selling a generic version of the epilepsy medicine Neurontin, Pfizer's fourth-largest drug. Alpharma shares rose 10 percent. The ban was issued in July after Apotex challenged Alpharma's right to six months of market exclusivity for gabapentin, the crucial ingredient in the medicine. The closely held Apotex, based in Toronto, wants to sell its own version of Neurontin. An Alpharma spokeswoman, Kathleen Makrakis, declined to say when Alpharma, based in Fort Lee, N.J., would start selling the medicine. Arguments in Apotex's appeal are set for Dec. 6 and a spokesman, Bob Billings, said Apotex planned an emergency request to reinstate the ban on Alpharma.

title: Friends Seek to Honor Electrocuted Woman by Renaming the Street Where She Died
description: After Jodie S. Lane was electrocuted by a charged metal plate on a Manhattan street on Jan. 16, her loved ones said she would never be forgotten. Alex Wilbourne intends to keep that promise.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Money To Patrol For Looting At Ruins
description: Gov. Olene S. Walker signed a bill appropriating money for aerial surveillance this winter to check for signs of looting at a long-secret Indian archeological site called Range Creek. The site, announced by scientists this summer, is near the town of Price, about 100 miles southeast of Salt Lake City. The $152,000 program, approved by the Legislature in a special session, is intended as a stopgap until permanent protection measures can be considered in January at the regular legislative session. Scientists said the site, believed to date from about A.D. 900 to 1100, was preserved by a ranch family that guarded access and kept the ruins secret. The state obtained title to land this year. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: Actor For A Day
description: Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who won a Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for challenging South Africa's apartheid regime, will perform in the political drama "Guantnamo: Honor Bound to Defend Freedom," at the Culture Project (45 Bleecker Street), for one night only next month. Reverend Tutu will appear on Oct. 2 as Lord Justice Steyn, a British magistrate who objects to the detainment of political prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, an American military base in Cuba. The archbishop's appearance was arranged by Allan Buchman, the artistic director of the Culture Project, who approached him shortly before the show opened last month. "He's very outspoken on this issue," Mr. Buchman said. "And he indicated that he wanted to draw attention to it any way he could." JESSE McKINLEY

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Antitrust Nominee Sells Shares
description: Neelie Kroes, set to become the European Union's top antitrust regulator, said she had sold all her shares and put the assets in a trust, removing potential conflicts of interest. "I sold my shares; I sold my options," Ms. Kroes, left, told reporters in Leuven, Belgium. "I just asked an external accountant and tax experts to create a trust with an independent board, and I can't touch upon that anymore." Ms. Kroes's experience on the boards of telecommunications, shipping, military, technology and logistics companies has been praised by Jos Manuel Duro Barroso, the commission's president-designate, as an asset for the post, which in the past has been dominated by academics and politicians. Some members of the European Parliament have said the ties could also make her liable to accusations of favoritism. Ms. Kroes, a former Dutch transport minister, will be questioned about her business ties during confirmation hearings before the European Parliament on Sept. 28. The 25 designated members of the next commission are set to take office on Nov. 1.

title: Corrections

The interviewer, pressing Mr. Annan, asked, "It was illegal?" and Mr. Annan responded, "Yes, if you wish." The interviewer repeated, "It was illegal?" and Mr. Annan said, "Yes, I have indicated it is not in conformity with the U.N. Charter; from our point of view and from the Charter point of view, it was illegal."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELTON, DORIS JOYCE
description: FELTON--Doris Joyce. Of Great Neck, NY and Boca Raton, FL, passed away on September 17, 2004. Born on December 9, 1919 and raised in Brooklyn, NY to Judge Phillip and Tabby Simon. Simple words cannot express the void to her beloved family and so many friends. Doris is survived by her husband of 62 years, Hon. Murray B. Felton, children William, Miles, Leslie and Alicia and their spouses, Jodi, David and Sherrill. Adoring grandma to Kimberlee, Matthew, Drew, Trevor, Michael, Jonathan, Andrew and Zachary and loving great-grandma to Alyssa and Kyle. Devoted best friend and sister-in-law to Ethel Kalka. Doris was a woman who enjoyed life to the fullest and taught everyone around her to do the same. Her smiling and lovable nature brightened and touched every life. Doris also volunteered her time with North Shore Community Hospital and was cofounder of the women's chapter of ADL in Boca Raton. Contributions may be sent to ADL. Services will be held Sunday, 3 PM at Gutterman-Warheit Chapel, 7240 N. Federal Highway, Boca.

title: Intentions Versus Reality in Iraq
description: For months, President Bush has been playing down the findings of David Kay, the first American arms inspector, who debunked the claim that Saddam Hussein had possessed a hoard of weapons of mass destruction ready to use at any moment. He urged Americans to wait for the verdict of Mr. Kay's successor, Charles Duelfer. That verdict is now at hand, and it only strengthens the case against Mr. Bush's main reason for waging preventive war against Iraq. Iraq was not an imminent or urgent threat, and Mr. Duelfer's report undermines the idea that it was even a "gathering threat," as Mr. Bush now routinely describes it. It more likely was a diminished power, hit hard by two wars and a decade of sanctions, that may have still harbored ambitions to develop new weaponry if the opportunity arose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUCHIN, ERNESTINE ''ERNIE''
description: SUCHIN--Ernestine "Ernie" of Scotch Plains, N.J. Daughter of Joseph and Julia Mutnick, passed away peacefully on Monday, September 13, 2004 in her home surrounded by her family, friends and pets. She worked for many years as a realtor in Scarsdale, N.Y. and Westfield, N.J. In addition to raising three children, she was an active member of the community, receiving numerous citations for her wide and varied philanthropic endeavors. She had a special passion for the disenfranchised. Her love of animals was well known to all. Ernie is survived by her children Linda Davino, Neil Suchin, and Scott Suchin, M.D., her four grandchildren Gregory, Mark, Charli and Jolie, her daughters-in-law Carol and Alona, her son-in-law Gary and her beloved dogs Willie, Alfie, Cissy and Pippin. Her husband Jerome and twin sister Geraldine predeceased her. Her loving presence will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 19, 3PM at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583 (914725-1137). In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Humane Society or the ASPCA.

title: Bonds Barges Into Elite Club
description: Barry Bonds admits he has amazed himself, so why shouldn't we all be amazed? Most of us weren't around to watch Babe Ruth hit more home runs in a season than many teams did. Some of us witnessed Hank Aaron amass home runs by demonstrating a stunning consistency in which he matched his uniform number -- 44 -- in home runs more than he displayed awesome, one-of-a-kind season totals.

title: U.N. Threatens Sanctions Against Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 18 A The Security Council passed a resolution on Sudan today holding out the threat of sanctions on the country's leaders and its oil industry if the government fails to curb ethnic violence and setting up an inquiry into whether that violence constitutes genocide.

title: Swan Songs as a Duo Plan Life's Second Act
description: New York's favorite over-the-hill lounge act, Kiki and Herb, are about to hit the after-party in the sky. Justin Bond, 41, who plays Kiki, the 60-something "boozy chanteusie," and Kenny Mellman, 36, who is Kiki's hostile accompanist, Herb, are calling it quits on their decade-old sendup of failed show people: a strange, thrilling, cathartic and dementedly funny concoction with the energy of a rock show, the polysemy of performance art and the frisson of visiting hours at the insane asylum. The duo will commit career suicide the classy way, with a farewell performance, "Kiki and Herb Will Die for You," at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night. Ada Calhoun spoke with them on the eve of their demise.

description: CANTONMENT, Fla., Sept. 17 - Hurricanes are mostly perceived as coastal disasters, and rightly so given the impact their surging waters and blasting winds can have.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about disputed memos obtained by CBS News that cast doubt on aspects of President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard truncated a quotation from David Van Os, a lawyer for Bill Burkett, a retired National Guard officer. Asked what role Mr. Burkett had in raising questions about Mr. Bush's military service, Mr. Van Os posed a hypothetical chain of events in which someone -- not Mr. Burkett, he said -- reconstructed documents that the preparer believed existed in 1972 or 1973. Mr. Van Os then asked "what difference would even that make" to the "factual reality of where was George W. Bush at the times in question and what was he doing?"

Corrections

The official, shown with Prime Minister Paul Martin, was Dalton McGuinty, not McGinty; he is the premier of Ontario. (Ottawa, the national capital, is in that province.)

title: In the Desert, Wrecks Tell of Those Who Don't Wear a Uniform but Die Too
description: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait, Sept. 12 - In a stinging, gusting sandstorm, a door on a huge charred truck creaked open and slammed shut again and again, as if the driver were still trying to escape before catastrophe struck. Nearby, the sand whistled through a bullet-riddled sport utility vehicle sitting on its twisted hubs in the desert.

title: Nuclear Agency's Action on Iran Falls Short of U.S. Goal
description: VIENNA, Sept. 17 - The United States once again failed to persuade the International Atomic Energy Agency on Friday that it should refer Iran's suspect nuclear program to the United Nations Security Council, accepting instead a repetition of calls for the country to stop uranium enrichment activities and clear up remaining questions about its nuclear ambitions.

For Detective, the Show Was the Thing
description: Gathering under a swampy gray sky in Brooklyn, thousands of mourners said their farewells yesterday to Detective Robert L. Parker, ending an agonizing week of wakes and eulogies for the detective and his partner, who was slain along with him.

title: SALLIE MAE BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN ARROW FINANCIAL
description: The SLM Corporation, the student-loan company known as Sallie Mae, bought a majority stake in Arrow Financial Services to add debt services. Terms were not disclosed. Sallie Mae has an option to purchase the remaining interest in Arrow, based in Niles, Ill., during the next three years, an SLM spokesman, Tom Joyce, said. The purchase will allow SLM to collect fees and debts and expand its accounts-receivable services, Mr. Joyce said. Sallie Mae, which is based in Reston, Va., manages about $95 billion in student loans for more than seven million borrowers.

title: Rick James Autopsy Results
description: An autopsy of the funk star Rick James found nine drugs in his system, though his death was due to a heart attack, the Los Angeles County coroner's office announced on Thursday. "Toxicology revealed the presence of the following drugs: Alprazolam (Xanax), Diazepam (Valium), Bupropion (Wellbutrin), Citalopram (Celexa), Hydrocodone (Vicodin), Digoxin, Chlorpheniramine, methamphetamine and cocaine," the coroner's statement said. "None of the drugs or drug combinations were found to be at levels that were life threatening in and of themselves." The cause of death was ruled acute cardiac dysfunction due to idiopathic cardiomyopathy, or an enlarged heart. David Campbell, a spokesman for the coroner's office, told The Associated Press, "He didn't die of a drug overdose." Mr. James, who sang "Super Freak" and other hits, died on Aug. 6 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 56. BEN SISARIO

In New York, she volunteered for the Actors' Fund as a "buddy" to performers dying of HIV/AIDS. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Lee Falk; children, Willy Falk and Cathy Caccioppoli; son-in-law, Dr. Giuseppe Caccioppoli; granddaughters, Nina and Joanna.

title: Florida Supreme Court Gives Nader a Spot on State Ballot
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 17 - The Florida Supreme Court bolstered President Bush's prospects in this swing state on Friday, ruling that Ralph Nader could appear on the November ballot as the Reform Party's presidential candidate.

title: In Stricter Study, U.S. Scales Back Claim on Cuba Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - The Bush administration, using stringent standards adopted after the failure to find banned weapons in Iraq, has conducted a new assessment of Cuba's biological weapons capacity and concluded that it is no longer clear that Cuba has an active, offensive bio-weapons program, according to administration officials.

title: Existential Television
description: So how would you make a television program about whether God exists?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: American Held On Treason CHarges
description: Criminal investigators have arrested a German-American woman on suspicion that she tried to sell secret military documents to a "non-NATO" country last year, the federal prosecutors office in Karlsruhe said. The woman, described as a 43-year-old freelance translator of German origin who holds American citizenship and identified only as Michaela T., has been living in Canada for some time and was detained this month while she was visiting her parents in Germany. The transfer of the documents, which she had been given to translate for a German company, was prevented, the prosecutors said, without indicating which country might have been trying to buy them. Investigators said the documents contained a state secret that might have jeopardized German security. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Lt. Col. Jack Bolt, 83, Only Marine to Be an Ace in 2 Wars, Dies
description: Lt. Col. Jack Bolt, who flew with the Marines' Black Sheep Squadron in World War II and was the only Marine pilot to be an ace in two wars, died Sept. 8 at a hospital in Tampa, Fla. He was 83 and lived in New Smyrna Beach, Fla.

NATO Runs Short of Troops to Expand Afghan Peacekeeping
description: KABUL, Afghanistan - Nearly a year after the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed to expand its peacekeeping operations beyond this sprawling, mountain-ringed capital, the program is bogged down because member states are reluctant to send troops into the increasingly unstable countryside, NATO officers say.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an interview given by Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, to the British Broadcasting Corporation omitted part of an exchange about the Iraq war. The interviewer, pressing Mr. Annan, asked, "It was illegal?" and Mr. Annan responded, "Yes, if you wish." The interviewer repeated, "It was illegal?'' and Mr. Annan said, "Yes, I have indicated it is not in conformity with the U.N. Charter; from our point of view and from the Charter point of view, it was illegal."

title: Kerry's Cast of Thousands
description: Across the wine-dark sea they come, honing Kerry's message. They come from Harvard, K Street and the studios of CNN. "Once more into the breach!" they cry, as they join the conference call of thousands.

description: BARBANELL--June B., on September 16, 2004, at age 63. Adored wife of Arthur. Loving mother of Meredith Sands and grandmother of Hamilton. Devoted sister of Theodor Brown. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 12:30PM. Interment private.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Sudan Vote Today
description: The Security Council votes today on a new resolution on Sudan creating an international commission to determine whether ethnic violence there had reached the level of genocide and calling for possible penalties on the Sudanese government and the country's oil industry if Arab militias held responsible for killing and evicting black African villagers are not reined in. The United States-drafted resolution, revised four times over eight days to overcome objections from several countries, also gives a lead role in the relief and pacification effort to the 53-member African Union. China, a buyer of Sudanese oil, had threatened to veto the measure, but Secretary General Kofi Annan countered the threat with an appeal to the Council on Thursday to act "without delay." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: PARMALAT GETS NEW DEADLINE TO EMERGE FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation and Citigroup Inc. gave the United States unit of Parmalat Finanziaria, Italy's biggest food company, two more weeks to file a plan to leave bankruptcy and avoid default. The unit, Parmalat USA Corporation, has until Sept. 30 to file the plan and until Dec. 31 to win court confirmation, the company said in papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. The filing deadline had been yesterday. "The company is trying hard to meet the new deadline, but can't guarantee it will," said Stephen B. Selbst, Parmalat USA's bankruptcy lawyer. "We informed the court we may need additional extensions, but we're working hard to try and meet this deadline." Parmalat is using funds from G.E. and Citigroup to pay employees and vendors.

title: Social Security Poses Hurdles for President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 - President Bush's vision of an "ownership society" is built, as much as anything else, on a sweeping promise: that he will transform Social Security so younger workers can divert some of their payroll taxes into private investment accounts.

A graduate of Lawrence High School and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. A longtime member of the American Stock Exchange and options trader for Susquehanna. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Saturday, September 18, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Here's the Book on Sheffield: His Life Is All About the Struggle
description: THERE'S a great book inside Gary Sheffield. The title is uncertain but the theme is clear: the journey of a young man with raw talent. Raised in a tough environment, he used his muscle to get out, his mind to survive and his sheer will to become the most valuable player of the most storied franchise in baseball.

title: U.S. Airstrikes Kill Dozens as Guerrilla Attacks Rage
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 17 - Iraqi health officials said Friday that American airstrikes that demolished homes late Thursday in a village south of the volatile city of Falluja killed at least 44 people and injured 27 others, including women and children. Attacks occurred around the country, including a deadly car bombing in the capital and fighting between British troops and Shiite militiamen in Basra.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Bid Accelerated
description: The Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group said it provided 700 billion yen in emergency funds to its takeover target, UFJ Holdings, as it moved quickly to head off a rival bid for the bank. Mitsubishi Tokyo, Japan's second-largest bank, was expected to wait until the end of the month to inject the funds, intended to prevent the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group from making its own bid for UFJ, the smallest of Japan's four so-called mega-banks. In exchange for the funds, which UFJ will use to write off some of its bad loans, Mitsubishi Tokyo will receive preferred shares in UFJ's commercial banking unit. Those shares carry voting rights that could be used to block a takeover attempt by another company. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: ON THE RECORD
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the plan of the artistic director of Shakespeare's Globe in London, Mark Rylance, to leave his post at the end of next year misstated the role he played in the theater's all-male production of "Twelfth Night." It was Olivia; Viola was played by Michael Brown.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Declines
description: Canada's inflation rate unexpectedly dropped to 1.9 percent in August from 2.3 percent a month earlier, Statistics Canada said. The government agency said that the decrease was mostly caused by falling gasoline prices. After rising 18 percent annualized in July, gasoline costs increased by 7.8 percent last month. Automobile prices fell by 2.6 percent because of manufacturers' incentives intended to clear out 2004 models. A separate consumer price index that excludes energy and other products with volatile prices was slightly more stable. It rose 1.5 percent in August after reaching 1.9 percent in July. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Chief Is Ousted in Shake-Up at Argentina's Central Bank
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 17 - Argentina's president, Nstor Kirchner, ousted the head of the central bank on Friday, removing one of the government's most respected figures on Wall Street just as the country seeks to work out the final details of a $100 billion debt restructuring.

title: Texan Involved in CBS Report Tried to Help Kerry Campaign
description: BAIRD, Tex., Sept. 17 - Bill Burkett, the former Texas National Guard officer who has been caught up in the mystery of how CBS News acquired memos that seem to question President Bush's Vietnam-era National Guard service, unsuccessfully offered information and advice to help the Kerry campaign attack Mr. Bush, according to a posting Mr. Burkett wrote in an e-mail newsletter.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that Congress was finally heeding his calls for more antiterrorism money for New York City and other potential targets, but that the work to secure the aid must go on.

description: By Tuesday morning Hollywood screenwriters, working without a contract for the last half year, will have decided whether they are ripe for revolution.

title: An Emmy for the Man Behind the Faces

title: The Redeemer
description: Thanks for Lynn Hirschberg's article on the great director Pedro Almodvar -- not to mention the terrific cover photograph and the accompanying portfolio, "Almodvar's Women" (Sofia Sanchez and Mauro Mongiello, Sept. 5). My first job in the entertainment industry was working for an art-house film distributor, booking Almodvar's early works into cities from Miami to Minneapolis, then watching as he enjoyed his first large-scale success here when "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown" opened the New York Film Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPITZ, JEROLD B.
description: SPITZ--Jerold B., 59, of West Hartford, CT, died September 16 at home surrounded by loved ones: beloved wife Lauren, his best friend, and Eisches Chayil; his cherished children: Maren and Warren of West Hartford, and Danielle and David Kolojay of Sharon, MA; adored stepdaughters: Erica and Jillian Tuchman both of NYC; loving mother Belle Spitz of W. Palm Beach, FL; loving brothers: Hyman and Edith of Brooklyn, NY and Richard and Jill Jill and children Jenny and Max of White Plains, NY; and revered in-laws: Irma and Daniel Engel of Boynton Beach, FL. He was predeceased by his father, Max Spitz. A dedicated and admired physician and entrepreneur, he founded The Little Blue Book, MDHub.com, and QuikMD. Funeral services Beth El Temple, West Hartford, CT, September 19, 1:30PM. Interment to follow, Congregation Knesses Israel Cemetery, Pittsfield, MA. His spirit, compassion, and generosity will be deeply missed.

title: Paperback Writer
description: I doubt I bought a single new hardcover book for myself (as opposed to for a class) until sometime after I'd turned 30. Being underemployed and unencumbered by children like a lot of people in their 20's, I read a lot, but the only new books I could afford were paperbacks. So I waited for the new novel everyone was talking about to come out in paperback.

title: OB-Gyns Drop Efforts For a Delivery Surcharge
description: Women's Health Connecticut, an association of 150 of the state's obstetricians and gynecologists, announced last week that its members had decided not to assess a planned $500 surcharge to patients for delivering babies.

title: Worst-Case Scenarios
description: Westchester residents can be forgiven for feeling jumpy, given the talk this month about the apocalyptic cloud that seems to be looming over the county. First it was the announcement that West Lake Drive, above Kensico Dam in Valhalla, would be closed to vehicles for good. Andrew Spano, the county executive, had to decide between traffic headaches from the closed road or the possibility of a 60-foot wall of water washing away White Plains and leaving New York City without drinking water. He chose the headaches, but only after demanding, and getting, a federal study showing that the risk from a terrorist truck bomb at the dam was too great to ignore.

title: The Yale Man
description: Whatever happens in November, the president will be a Yale man -- though the term doesn't mean quite what it used to. It's not that Yale College has become academically less selective. Yale is now much harder to get into than it was in the days of Kerry and Bush, and if former Yale men had to reapply now, many would be quickly turned away. Some might even be encouraged to brush up for a while at a community college or to consider vocational training. "You know, you don't have to go to college," the admissions counselor might say, "even if your name is Chauncey Walker-Forbes Woolsey IV."

description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 15 - With its 60-foot-tall, 30-ton bronze of praying hands and an even taller prayer tower capped by a billowing eternal flame, Oral Roberts University is a strong symbol for Christian conservatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THIERIOT, CHARLES HENSCHEL III
description: THIERIOT--Charles Henschel III, February 16, 1947-August 22, 2004. Died in his sleep at home in Bel-Air, CA at the age of 57. Charlie was born and raised in Locust Valley, NY. He attended Greenvale School in Greenvale, NY; St. Mark's School in Southboro, MA; Menlo College in Atherton, CA; the University of California at Los Angeles; and graduated from Cal State Los Angeles. He is survived by his beloved wife, Deborah; loving son, Andrew; sisters, Julia Dick Thieriot of Round Hill, VA and Frances Thornton Thieriot of Los Angeles, CA; and adoring cats, Cleo, Kodak, Midnight, Milano and Tommie. Predeceased by his father, Charles Henschel Thieriot II of Locust Valley, NY; mother, Julia Macy Thompson of Victoria, BC and half-brother, Cary Nicholas Potter of New York City, NY. An inventor and professional mechanical engineer, Charlie was also an avid sports car enthusiast and Trans Am race car driver. He was actively involved with and a former president of the Alfa Romeo Owners Club of Southern California. Charlie was an extremely kind and generous person with a wonderfully wry sense of humor. He will be greatly missed by his family and wide circle of friends. A private memorial service and celebration of his life was held on August 29th at his cherished home overlooking the Santa Monica Mountains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Childrens Hospital-Boston, 1 Autumn St., Boston, MA 02215-5301, Attention: Tricia Paulino, check memo: Muscular Dystrophy Research Fund or charity of choice.

title: The Zone; Toward a More Perfect He-V
description: Weighted Side-Bends Stand with your weight evenly distributed, chest up, shoulders back, holding a 10- to 15-pound dumbbell in your left hand. Slowly bend your torso toward the right, exhaling as you go, drawing the navel in toward your spine. Keep both feet firmly on the ground. Inhale and steadily return upright. Bend to the left, making certain your hips stay even. Return upright; do 15 repetitions. Switch the dumbbell to your right hand and repeat the move 15 times. Do three sets on each side.

title: Corrections
description: The Choice Tables column on Sept. 5, about Oaxaca, Mexico, referred imprecisely to ingredients used in some outsize tortillas known as tlayudas. The tortillas themselves -- as well as beans and salsa -- were eaten in the Americas before Columbus; lard and cheese were not. The column also misstated the price of a bottle of Petite Sirah wine; it is $18.50, not $210. (The use of "$" in Mexico to signify pesos led to the misunderstanding.)

title: DataBank; Coca-Cola Interrupts a Dow Winning Streak
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell last week for the first time in five weeks, a small decline attributed mainly to the problems of one stock, Coca-Cola.

title: Parking for Guests With Disabilities
description: Q. My mother owns a condo in a new complex in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. We visit her several times a week with our disabled son, but there is never a place for us to park. We have to park several blocks away on the street using a city-issued on-street parking permit, but then have to lug all of our medical equipment to go see her. I have complained to the management, and they told me that each of the 10 new buildings has ramps and a single spot for people with disabilities that a qualified tenant can rent for $350 a month, but we can't rent it since we don't live there. There is no guest parking specifically for people with disabilities. Could this possibly be legal? . . . Peter Klein, Brooklyn.

title: Shadow Play
description: Who is that guy, half there, half not, scissored out of the photographs? Actually, make that slashed. In reality, he is an actor hired to play the part of a sugar daddy in these pictures that Nikki S. Lee staged of herself dressed in offerings from the fall couture. Teasing reality, and the notoriously unstable tales we tend to weave around it, is one of the tactics that Lee has used to keep the art world ensorcelled since her arrival half a decade ago. * The critical boilerplate on the 33-year-old artist is that her work is about the politics of identity; she is that outsider who experimentally drifts into other people's lives and slips on their skins. Lee most successfully performed this serial imposture in Projects, a series of photographs that involved meticulously changing her hair, her weight, her clothes and even her skin color to infiltrate a variety of what people tend to call subcultures. Once transformed, she would then have a friend snap her photograph. * Certain immutable elements of Lee's own reality affected her masquerade, foremost among them physiognomy and race. Lee is from South Korea, born in 1970 and raised in Seoul. She did graduate work in the United States, at N.Y.U. and at the Fashion Institute of Technology, where she studied fashion photography and no doubt learned some of the tricks she came to use in her accomplished impersonations. "I really enjoy fashion shows as a performative activity," Lee said recently. "To me, it's like people showing art in a gallery, only the sculpture moves." * Whether passing for a stereotypical skate rat or an exotic dancer or a trailer-park resident in rural Ohio, Lee can rely on the viewer to bring his own stereotypes to her work. What's wrong with this picture? you find yourself asking, regardless of how politically loaded the question may be. How did that pretty young Asian woman in a tube top end up sitting alongside a grizzled Jethro Bodine type with a Confederate flag on the wall behind him and a shotgun across his lap? * "I like boundaries," Lee said. "People know it's fake, but they don't. I like it that they get kind of confused." * You might imagine that there was not much left untried by an artist seeking to flout the assumptions built into a gaze. You would be wrong. In making her Projects series, Lee not only found novel ways to cultivate the terrain but while doing so she was also able to slip into yet another persona -- that of an art-world star whose work justifiably bears comparison to that of other shape-shifters, people like Cindy Sherman, Lucas Samaras, Charles Ray. * Projects put Nikki S. Lee (the S is for Seung Hee, her given name) on the art-world map; it certainly guaranteed her speed-dial status on the cellphones of all international curators organizing shows around themes of identity and race. After a while, though, Projects began to trouble the artist, who worried that she might end up a stereotype of an artist who made commentary on stereotypes. * "Photography in the 90's was very theatrical in a way, very stagy, very set up and very dry," she said. "I felt like I wanted to go back to the essence of the snapshot, the reason why people take pictures in the first place, to document themselves, their families, something real and sentimental in their lives." * So a while back, Lee began work on a new series, this one called Parts. In Parts, Lee simplifies the narrative and narrows the focus to a woman and a man, or a woman and a hand, anyway. The unidentified male limb that shares each frame with Lee in these latest pictures is the truncated symbol of a relationship that remains unexplained. The idea, she said, is to leave the viewer guessing about the identity of the mysterious man at the Ritz Hotel in Paris, wondering what his relationship is to her. * Naturally, it is a fiction, but then so is the haute couture. Plenty of people are aware by now that the couture is little more than a rarefied form of performance art whose symbolic content is intended to fuel mass-market consumption (in the form of perfumes and accessories) but whose basic product is created for a clientele that probably numbers 500 people worldwide. This particular performance is pitched to a sentimental fantasy nurtured by many of us, that to forge a relationship, however attenuated, with luxury products is somehow to dally with a class above our own. * "At first, when I tried on the clothes, I almost died because they were so formal, so tight and so expensive," Lee said. "I thought to myself, Who is going to wear this? But then I figured out that it didn't really matter if the clothes were ever worn. The collector buys the clothes and maybe just keeps them. What really matters to them is being the one who owns the dress."

title: Factory Made
description: Ever feel like doing the hustler? Try this look, influenced in part by a photo of the Warhol himbo Joe Dallesandro and made famous by the Smiths' debut-album cover. With its eye-brushing bang and shaved back, this perennial haircut is enjoying another return. The hairstylist Losi (for John Frieda Salon) says, ''In the 80's, we called this 'the Model Cut,' because all the male models had it.'' Model or not, you can get the look with the right products. Start with Kiehl's Protein Shampoo ($14). For straight hair, use ''just a schmear'' of John Frieda wax ($7) while damp to control fly-aways. Those with wavy locks should mix Kiehl's Extra-Strength Styling Gel and Creme with Silk Groom ($16 and $17) to damp hair and briefly blow-dry while brushing forward. But Brillo-haired boys beware. As Losi cautions, ''With curly hair, this cut can have a mushroom effect.''

title: Showing Your Worth Without Showing Off
description: Q. You've begun to suspect that the importance of your stellar contributions to a big project is eluding your boss. How do you lobby for the credit you deserve without seeming like a smarmy self-promoter?

title: The American Idol Diaries
description: VIDEOS for soundtrack songs are more likely to shill than to soar; not many can bear the clunkiness that comes from having to serve as a de facto trailer for the film. Kelly Clarkson's "Breakaway," a late-summer hit from the soundtrack of "The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement," overcomes this burden by illustrating a single theme shared by the song, the movie and Ms. Clarkson's biography: little girl, follow that dream.

Jean Paul Gaultier Smoothing Fortifying Nail Pen Climbing the corporate ladder can be rough on hands. Fortunately, instant manicure-grade man luster is at your fingertips with this handy nail pen, $16, which adds a mean sheen that's not embarrassingly glossy. At Bloomingdale's.3. Malin+Goetz Face Moisturizer This Chelsea-based line of unisex face, body and hair products is as simple as its packaging. The gentle moisturizer is totally stripped down to prevent irritation and residue buildup, $45. Go to www.malinandgoetz.com.4. Ren Tamanu High Glide Shaving Oil Are you the sensitive type? No dyes, fragrances or petrochemicals here -- just natural, nourishing oils that wash away after shaving for smooth, greaseless skin, $28. At Barneys New York.5. He has already filed suits accusing his former board at Hollinger International and its investigative adviser of besmirching his reputation (after a special committee of the board concluded that he and his partner, F.David Radler, had run a "corporate kleptocracy").
