description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 19 A A militant group posted today a gruesome Internet video of the beheading of three men said to be members of the Kurdistan Democratic Party, one of two major Kurdish political parties in Iraq.

title: The Skinny
description: Let's say you're a thin guy with feet that don't block the aisles of the N train. This is important. Size matters when you're trying to look cool. If what you're striving for in your Thom Browne gray worsted suit is a picture of retro urbanity -- the "jivey Ivy" look of the late 1950's, four-button jacket and snug-fitting trousers -- the last thing you want is some girl to look down at your size-12 feet and think, "Hel-LO, Jethro!" You need a wider trouser leg, man, or you're going to look like a Beverly hillbilly.

title: That's the Way It Was. And I Liked It.
description: IN the good times before cappuccino and sushi and rucola went global, in the good times before everything began to look the same, in the good times before adventure became a sport, in the good times when the Paris Mtro smelled of Gauloises and garlic and the warehouses of London and New York had not yet been converted to lofts, in the good times before seat belts that beep when not fastened, in the good times when soccer clubs were not yet corporations and spies really did come in from the cold, in the good times before speed cameras and e-mail and overheard cellphone conversations on the train ("Honey, I'm on the train"), in the good times when enemies were not stateless, in those good times, long ago, I vowed never to become a curmudgeon waxing lyrical about the past.

At the moment, all eyes are on the slightly built, ever-so-natty Fonzworth Bentley.

title: Play Misty for Me
description: In "Cool Hand Luke," Paul Newman sits on his prison bunk moments after learning his mother (the incomparable Jo Van Fleet) has died. For a moment he is a boy again, picking out what must be her favorite song, "Plastic Jesus," on his banjo.

title: What He Learned in the War
description: WAR is a terrible thing. Walt Whitman knew it, as did Ernest Hemingway. So did Reuben Kadish (1913-1992), a talented painter and friend of Jackson Pollock who found himself more or less unable, or unwilling, to paint following a stint as an Army artist in India and Burma during World War II. He re-emerged in the late 1950's as a sculptor, working mostly in terra cotta, with which he fashioned expressionistic forms that reflect feelings of alienation and conflict.

title: Questions For Elizabeth Edwards
description: Elizabeth Edwards's answers made it apparent that she is a woman of candor and courage. In replying to one of the questions, she very accurately described self-knowledge as "the rarest trait in a human being." It is clear that she is in firm possession of this trait.

title: Are Some Red States Blue About Jobs?
description: HOW big of an issue will the economy be on Election Day? Pollsters have been saying that it's a top concern for undecided voters. That makes sense, given that people with strong feelings about foreign policy, civil rights or the candidates' personalities have probably made up their minds already. But could differences in economic performance among the states actually determine how the election shakes out?

title: Rona Goffen, 60, Art Historian and Teacher, Dies
description: Rona Goffen, a historian of Medieval and Renaissance art, died on Sept. 8 in Princeton, N.J. She was 60 and lived in Princeton.

title: The Week Ahead; IT'S NOT THE EMMYS, IT'S . . .
description: HBO shines on Sunday nights and is expected to shine again tonight -- only on a different channel. The Emmy Awards on ABC is expected to be a celebration of HBO, which landed 124 nominations, more than CBS, ABC and Fox combined. About the only suspense will be whether "The Sopranos" will be named best drama, the only significant prize it has yet to win, and whether the show's creator, David Chase, will be on hand to accept the trophy. He contemplated boycotting rather than seeing "The West Wing" win again. Bill Carter

title: New York Olympics RunHinges on Dividing Votes
description: After talking privately with nearly every person who will vote on the site of the 2012 Olympics, the people behind New York City's bid for the Summer Games now think they have a realistic chance to win by adopting a divide-and-conquer strategy against the four European capitals that are their competitors.

title: Reaching a Goal, Stroke by Stroke
description: AT age 70, George Brunstad of Ridgefield recently became the oldest person to swim across the English Channel, and in the process he helped raise money for charity.

title: Waterfront Waves
description: MAMARONECK - ON the shore of Long Island Sound here, the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club, with its manicured lawns and 19th-century stone and shingle buildings, pays tribute to days gone by.

title: Barbarians at the Digital Gate
description: KARSTEN M. SELF, who oversees a children's computer lab at a youth center in Napa, Calif., spends about a half-hour each morning electronically scanning 10 PC's. He is searching for files and traces of code that threaten to hijack the computers by silently monitoring the children's online activities or by plastering their screens with dizzying -- and nearly unstoppable -- onslaughts of pop-up advertisements.

title: FOOD FIGHT
description: Organized labor reveres the Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914 because it affirms the right of unions to strike, boycott and picket. Now the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International is using the law in a new way, as a flanking attack in a stalemated strike at the Penford Corporation.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENVENISTE, JAYE
description: BENVENISTE -- Jaye. 87, passed away peacefully at home on September 17, 2004. She successfully battled pancreatic cancer for many years. She will be forever in the hearts and souls of her loving nephews Stuart Shikiar and Albert Shikiar, her greatnephews Samuel Max Shikiar and David Shikiar, and greatnieces Karen Masters and Susan Santillo. Her wit, wisdom, courage and grace will be fondly remembered by the many people she touched in her rich life. Service Tuesday, September 21, at 11:30 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Back in the Lab
description: Dr. Kay Scarpetta, the prickly forensic pathologist who sharpens the saws in Patricia Cornwell's mordant thrillers, is back with a vengeance in TRACE (Putnam, $26.95). "I don't play games," she coolly informs Dr. Joel Marcus, the incompetent idiot who has taken over her job as chief medical examiner of Virginia, leaving no doubt about who is really in charge here. The envious Marcus has already demoralized the lab staff and spitefully trashed the office that Scarpetta had personally built into "the most prominent statewide medical examiner system in the United States" until she was "publicly degraded" and forced to resign five years ago. Now he tries to humiliate her when she is called in to consult on the unexplained death of a 14-year-old girl whose father's Washington connections threaten to gum up the case in the "sticky politics" between the F.B.I. and Homeland Security.

title: Revolutionary War Items Uncovered in Museum
description: A cache of items believed to be from the Revolutionary War was recently found under a floor in West Haven's oldest building: the Ward-Heitmann House.

title: Some Action Figures Are Meant to Be Seen, Not Smashed
description: TEN years ago, Todd McFarlane wanted to produce an action figure of the character Spawn from his best-selling comic book series. He met with toy companies but felt that none understood how to make or market a plastic likeness of the character that would properly honor its macabre spirit.

title: All God's Children
description: So Biola places graduate students in top Ph.D. programs hoping they will learn to argue in "sophisticated secular terms" and is offering the tools of science so students may "do battle with other faiths and with secular ideas."

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SHOOTER By Walter Dean Myers. Amistad/HarperTempest, $15.99. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Nell's Returns With a New Name, New Stars and a Cleaner Floor
description: MADONNA refused to pay the $5 cover charge and was turned away. Cher got sick of waiting in line and stormed off. And one night John Casablancas, the boss of the Elite model agency, rolled up with a dozen leggy beauties and was firmly told he could bring in only one. Such was a typical gold-dusted evening in the late 1980's at Nell's, the nightclub on West 14th Street celebrated in Brett Easton Ellis's "American Psycho."

title: Columbia Falls Behind Fordham Early, Then a Comeback Slips Away
description: By halftime last night, the rare sense of cautious optimism that had pervaded the Columbia University football program had begun to dissipate, with the Lions staring at a 17-point deficit in their season opener against Fordham.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COX, ARCHIBALD
description: COX--Archibald. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, October 8th in The Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Harvard University, in Cambridge, MA. at 2 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBY, HENRY J.
description: JACOBY--Henry J., 87, of New York City on September 15, 2004. Beloved husband of Doris Goodman Jacoby; brother of Gertrude Handelman and Leah Berton; father of Ruth Ellen Jacoby Barnert, Karen Jacoby Zovic, and Jean Jacoby Bentley; grandfather of Matthew Jacoby Barnert, Michelle Celeste Zovic, Nicholas Henry Zovic, Barritt Wolff Jacoby Bentley, and Emma Rose Bentley Jacoby. Of complications from a heart attack after a brief illness. Retired President and Chairman of the Board of Grow Tunneling Corporation, Honorary Vice President and Trustee of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, former Chairman of the Board, Walden School, former President of the Anthropology Museum of the People of New York. We will always love and miss him. Funeral services will be held on Monday 11:30 AM at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions be made to the Nature Conservancy.

title: Officer Reilly He's Not
description: NEW AMSTERDAM, circa 1655. Asser Levy, a member of the first little colony of Jews that arrived from Brazil to escape religious persecution, petitions Peter Stuyvesant, the governor of the colony, for the right to join the local militia. In what proved to be one of the first "official" acts of anti-Semitism in America, Stuyvesant refused. An autocratic man with a peg leg, he was determined to drive all Jews, Catholics and blacks out of New Amsterdam. When Levy refused to pay the tax in support of a militia he could not join, "Stuyvesant threatened to put him in jail and did put him in jail," said Rabbi Alvin Kass, chief chaplain of the New York Police Department.

title: Amy Webster, Christian Kiser
description: Amy Catherine Webster and Christian Waugh Kiser were married yesterday by the Rev. Timothy T. Read at the First Presbyterian Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: 'Of Mice and Men': Steinbeck's Bunkhouse, Filled With Tension
description: Madison - IF there were any dry eyes opening night at the conclusion of the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey's gut-wrenching production of "Of Mice and Men," they were the exception. The deafening silence that greeted the final blackout and the cheers that followed gave witness to the enduring power of John Steinbeck's dramatization of his 1937 novel to grab its audience by the heart and never let go.

title: Senate Minority Leader Faces Foe in Debate
description: The Bush administration has failed to protect United States forces in Iraq with necessary equipment and resources, the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle, said today in a televised debate.

title: Next Stop: Indian
description: Princeton Junction - AN ideal site for a restaurant is not under a hill and behind a building and on the way to a bath supply store. And an ideal name wouldn't conjure up an image of historically polluted waters.

description: 1. XACT Stream Jockey Plug + Play Receiver: (right) Satellite radio has become sleeker with this palm-size portable pod, which can also be snapped out of its case to use in your home and car players. The tiny tuner offers 105 digital stations of commercial-free radio from SIRIUS, and the battery provides three hours of listening time. Receiver, $100 to $150; player, $100. Go to www.getxact.com.

Devoted Nanny to Jonathan, David, Simon, Hannah, Amy, Donna, Sam and Sylvia. Sister of Jean and much loved aunt of Beth, Ellen and Melanie. Private funeral. Donations to local women's shelters would be greatly appreciated.

title: Spraying Phragmites? Once Won't Do
description: To the Editor:

title: The Originals
description: IN THIS BRAVE NEW WORLD, WHERE SCIENCE HAS ENABLED SHORT PEOPLE TO BECOME TALL AND HOMELY PEOPLE TO BECOME "PRETTY," ISOLATING THE STYLE GENE IS ONLY A MATTER OF TIME. UNTIL THEN, ALL THOSE WHO WISH TO APPEAR COMME IL FAUT MUST RELY ON ACCEPTED NORMS / AND STYLISTS. IN FACT, IT IS A LITTLE-KNOWN TRUTH THAT THE BEST-DRESSED LISTS ARE MORE OR LESS BOGUS. A-LIST ACTORS AND ACTRESSES, EXTOLLED FOR THEIR PERSONAL STYLE, ARE OFTEN CAPTIVES OF PROFESSIONALS WHO SIZE UP THEIR LOOK AND ORDER UP THE CLOTHES. GLAMOUR MADE ORDINARY. BUT THE ORIGINALS ARE DIFFERENT. THESE ARE MEN AND WOMEN WHO OOZE STYLE FROM EVERY PORE. THEY CAN LOOK AT A PAIR OF PANTS AND KNOW JUST WHAT SKIRT / YES, SKIRT /TO WRAP AROUND IT. THEY HAVE AN INNATE SENSE OF THEIR BODY'S ARCHITECTURE, AND THEY PLAY TO THEIR PROPORTIONS. THESE ARE PEOPLE WHO ARE NOT PART OF THE HERD, BUT ONE OF A KIND. THEY ARE INSPIRING.

Harris and John Kirkwood Harris of the Bronx, is to be married today to Bob-Milton Oluwafemi Ayo, the son of Icelyn Ayo of the Bronx and Daniel Ayo of Lagos, Nigeria. The Rev. Dr. Steve D. Cassimy, a minister of the Seventh Day Adventist Church, is to officiate at the V.I.P. Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Page Two: Sept. 12-18; Still Willing To Dwell In the Wind's Way
description: ON the coasts that know hurricanes, people have an almost intimate way of speaking about the memorable ones. "I was here for Betsy," they say in New Orleans of the 1965 storm. In Mobile and along the Gulf Coast, they say, "I remember Frederick" (1979).

title: So, That's the Point of This Company
description: BARRY DILLER, the chairman and chief executive of IAC/InterActiveCorp, wowed Wall Street analysts who had come for a conference last fall at his company, an amalgamation of primarily Internet-based businesses. Profits, he said, would rise annually by 25 percent or more, to $3 billion in 2008. Based on that projection, analysts raised their expectations for revenue growth in IAC's important travel division to 41 percent for the second quarter this year.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Wear and Tell

title: Low Air Fares
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Tracking Down Cheap Air Fares" by Susan Stellin (Aug. 29): Here's a site that I came across that has an excellent search engine for discount airlines operating in Europe: www.openjet.com. I used it to book travel between London, Prague and Berlin on bmibaby, as well as a hotel in Prague. Unfortunately, I had to cancel that trip, but I would certainly go back to the site again if I were planning another trip to Europe.

title: Technology and the Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Senators Voice Rising Concerns on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 A Reflecting rising concerns, one senior Republican senator said today that the United States was in "deep trouble" in Iraq, another denounced administration "incompetence" in Iraqi reconstruction, while two others said that unless American-led forces quickly retake several areas from insurgents, credible elections cannot be held in January.

title: In Colorado, Traffic on the Interstate Is at a Peak
description: DENVER - IT'S a late summer Sunday afternoon and all is quiet in the Rocky Mountains of central Colorado. That could mean one of two things. Either you're far away from Interstate 70, frolicking in an alpine meadow, or you're on the Interstate itself, immobilized in your car with the thousands of other fuming weekenders heading east toward Denver.

title: There's a Sinatra in Town Again
description: HOBOKEN - HER grandfather moved out of Hoboken in 1939. But Angela Jennifer Azzarto, the 30-year-old daughter of Nancy Sinatra and the choreographer Hugh Lambert and the granddaughter of Frank Sinatra, has moved in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GALKA, DONALD S.
description: GALKA -- Donald S. who founded and headed Tri-Venture Cos., Inc., died September 11. "Water, water everywhere, nor any drop to drink..." Blessed are the waterbearers, for they are the peacemakers. Don, you held onto the dream. We deeply mourn your passing, but you live on in our hearts. Richard Clark, Alan Rude, Beatrice Williams-Rude, Florence Bernstein, Lynn Clark, Thomas Au

title: And Bear in Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Bakery Retail Outlet Closes in Yonkers
description: The Greyston Cafe and Bakery, the retail outlet of the Greyston Bakery, which hires "hard-to-employ" workers, has closed its doors at the corner of Main Street and Warburton Avenue in Yonkers after 15 months in business, said Steven Brown, president of the Greyston Foundation, who cited a lack of profitability.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GLUCKIN, GLORIA H.
description: GLUCKIN--Gloria H. Passed away September 16, 2003. Devoted wife and loving mother. "Our Auntie Mame-You Are With Us Always".

title: Nonprofit Organizations
description: To the Editor:

title: Pick a Message, Any Message
description: Monterey, Calif. - If John Kerry is to win this election, he will have to be much bolder about telling the American people exactly what he will do to make the country better. As a wise colleague in the House of Representatives once told me: voters don't care so much about what you believe so long as you believe in something.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMSTERDAM, MARVIN
description: AMSTERDAM--Marvin. Age 65, of Ridgewood, NJ. Husband of Susan, father of Debbie (Jim) Van Horn and Bonnie (Ira) Birnbaum. Brother of Florence Weinstock, proud grandfather of Aaron, Sarah and Natania. Services are today, 12:30 PM, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. #

title: Kerry's Lesson: Lambeau Rhymes With Rambo
description: THE key interview in this year's presidential campaign was not with any of the big national newspapers or newsweeklies. It was for the October issue of Field & Stream magazine.

title: Suzuki Moves Ahead, Leaving a Long Suit Behind
description: SUZUKI'S new product offensive coincides with the end of the company's eight-year legal offensive against Consumer Reports magazine, a dispute that diverted attention and resources from the core business while keeping a potentially negative issue -- involving questions about the safety of a discontinued S.U.V. -- in the public eye.

title: Tours on Foot Planned Online
description: DAVID STEFANCIC, an associate professor of history at Saint Mary's College in Notre Dame, Ind., has for the last decade had both the good and bad fortune of leading walking tours of students in European cities as director of the college's European Summer Study Program.

title: New Building in Yonkers For Environmental Center
description: Chest waders were the suggested attire for yesterday's opening of the Beczak Environmental Education Center's new building on the Yonkers waterfront, where dragging a 30-foot net in the Hudson River was scheduled as part of the festivities.

title: A Home Field Without Advantage
description: The football squad at South Bronx High School practices in donated New York Jets jerseys on a beautiful, three-year-old $3 million athletic complex behind the school on St. Ann's Avenue in Melrose. It is a dream setup for a team just entering its first year of varsity competition, with only one problem: the field is too narrow to play official games.

title: The B-Q-Eateries
description: It's no secret that you can get a great meal outside Manhattan, sometimes even saving a few dollars in the process. Here are some newer places -- both pricey and not -- that have opened in the last few years in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: The Remix; It's all about Bryan Ferry, Pulp Fashion, Croatia, Gum Blondes, Cardigans, A Designer Prodigy and David Hockney
description: The fashion flock has a kooky way of describing seasonal direction, saying things like, "This season is all about Dickens." Or Sikhs or pimps or Puritans or Studio 54. For men, this season is apparently all about Bryan Ferry. One of New York's top merchants told me that his buying inspiration was Ferry, the former lead singer of Roxy Music, and "the idea of an English rock star who lives in the country but still gets dressed up, with velvet and razor-sharp tailoring."

title: For Hussein, a Spartan Life at His Former Palace
description: Correction Appended

title: For the Disabled, a Showplace of a School
description: EAST HAMPTON - THE first day of school for the second grade at the Child Development Center of the Hamptons began with show and tell, an activity meant to introduce each child to the rest. Everyone sat on the floor as one child after another was called to sit in a chair and display his trinkets: a rock that reportedly looks like Jupiter, photos of cows taken on a summer vacation in Ireland, a matching pair of pine cones, a hockey trophy. "I got a concussion last year so I'm not playing hockey this year," the trophy's owner explained matter-of-factly.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Flip-Flopping Slip-Slides Into the Debate
description: Correction Appended

title: Iran Rejects U.N. Call to Freeze Nuclear Enrichment
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 19  Iran rejected today a call by the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency to freeze all its uranium enrichment programs and warned that it would drop out of the Nonproliferation Treaty if its case is sent to the Security Council.

title: 'The Falls': Force of Nature
description: THE FALLS By Joyce Carol Oates. 481 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $26.95.

title: 'My Old Man'
description: Why is this happening to me, Rabbi?" the dyingman moaned from his bed.

title: Hardcover Highlights
Paid Notice: Deaths   ZELINKA, SALLY KAPLAN
description: ZELINKA--Sally Kaplan. Of Queens. On Wednesday, September 15, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Richard and Jay. Adoring grandmother of Sydney, Jack, Savannah and Cassidy. Memorial services Sunday, September 19, 10AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills (corner 66 Ave). In lieu of flowers, contributions to World Wildlife Fund.

title: Bronx Tale: Much Ado About What?
description: NOT to rain on our grand Bronx baseball parade like the remnants of a hurricane, but what, exactly, is everyone so fired up about? With both the Yankees and the Red Sox seemingly nestled in postseason position, how can home-field advantage in October be worth all this insomnia, all this angst?

title: Blair Tries to Counter Iraq Skeptics in Europe
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 A Prime Minister Tony Blair admonished the international community today not to waiver in its support for military victory in Iraq and the establishment of democracy there, arguing that Iraq is the "crucible" in which global terrorism will either succeed or founder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, LILLIAN. AGE 96, (NEE FARBER)
description: FEINBERG--Lillian. Age 96, (nee Farber), AKA "Gona" and "Grandmere", the last of the seven Farber children, wife for nearly 70 years of the late Abraham Feinberg and mother of the late Richard Feinberg MD, died Friday at her home. Mom, everyone who knew you loved you and felt loved by you. Grandchildren: Jeffrey, Audrey, Michael and Steven. Great-grandchildren: Jonathan, Noah, Will, Gabriella, Daniel, Jason, Lilly and Isaac. In-laws: Bill, Shirley and Belle. In-law children: Doris, Norbert, Jim, Martha, Cindy and Karen. My step-children John, Gilly, Jed and Jamie, and all your nieces and nephews. I felt your love and support my entire life. You taught me about the "inner life" and launched me on a career. I'll remember you forever sweetest Mama. And, by the way, did I tell you how gorgeous you are---always. Your Purple Mouse, Judy. Service Sunday 10:45 A.M. at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Medical Development for Israel-Feinberg Child Study Center would be preferred.

title: Horses Are Evil, and Other Perceptive Observations
description: I'VE had it with horses. Yeah, that's right; I'm fed up with Equus caballus, the horse, our state animal. We need to strip the beast of that title and give it to a more honorable animal. Like the rat. Or perhaps the slime mold.

title: Trouble at the Firehouse
description: CENTERPORT - AFTER four defeats, members of the Centerport Fire Department plan to go door to door in their 2,800-home fire district today, canvassing for support for what they say will be their last attempt to get the voters' approval to expand the department's cramped firehouse, and maybe mend a few fences along the way.

title: Becky Sartini, Christopher Flanagan
description: Dr. Becky Lynn Sartini, the daughter of Susan Sartini Perry of Lakeville, Mass., and James R. Sartini of Newport, R.I., is to be married today to Christopher Hugh Flanagan, the son of Cynthia G. and Stephan C. Flanagan of Fall River, Mass. Paul Suttell, a justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, is to officiate at the Sakonnet Golf Club in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Behind Many Brilliant Moves Lies an Opponent's Mistake
description: Chess is a game of mistakes. We can admire stunning play, but the seamy side of this is that brilliant moves need errors on the part of the opponent. As the grandmaster and pundit Savielly Tartakover said, "Sacrifices only prove that someone has blundered." No one is free from occasional boo-boos. And that does not exclude grandmasters.

title: When Gender Isn't a Given
description: AT the moment after labor when a mother hears whether her new child is a boy or a girl, Lisa Greene was told she had a son. She named her baby Ryan and went home. Ms. Greene learned five days after the birth that her baby was really a girl.

title: The Curing of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Kunzelmann, John Hastings IV
description: Laura Rawson Kunzelmann and John Murray Hastings IV were married yesterday at the Black Point Inn in Scarborough, Me. The Very Rev. William M. Hale, an Episcopal priest and dean emeritus of St. Paul's Cathedral in Syracuse, officiated.

title: Storm Chasing on Wall Street
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, GEORGE
description: SMITH--George. Of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on September 17, 2004, at age 92. Formerly of Englewood, NJ, he was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband for 68 years to Mildred. Loving father to Stephen and Peter (Kim). Devoted brother to Sherman and the late Al and Ruth. Adoring grandfather to Jodi (Steven), Brett, Lilly and Quinn. Cherished great-grandfather to Griffin, Gage and Payton. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial, 333 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, on Tuesday, September 21, at 1 PM.

title: Celluloid Hero
description: Scorsese was blown away by him. Preminger and Wilder couldn't open a film without him. And for Hitchcock, he created some of the most nerve-rattling movie scenes ever filmed. But Saul Bass wasn't an actor or a studio head or a gung-ho producer. He was a designer of opening credits, managing, in the Hollywood of the 1950's and 60's, to transform a dreary list of cast and crew into a miniature movie that engaged the audience's emotions from the first frame.

title: The MGM Approach: Pay Me First, Sign the Deal Later
description: THE term "in principle" is usually a bright red flag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, ELLEN XANDRIA
description: GOLDBERG--Ellen Xandria. Passed away September 18. She was 58 years old. Beloved mother of Laura Goldberg Ortiz and Julie Goldberg. Loving grandmother of Drew and Jordan Ortiz. Cherished sister of Richard Ivan Gussaroff. Daughter of the late Jennie Ehrlich Gussaroff and George Gussaroff. Dear friend of Elaine Buchsbaum, Joan Swillings and Ruth Brown. Ellen had an irrepressible spirit and zest for life and a love above all for her family. In lieu of flowers, donations to the MS Society would be appreciated by the family. Services Sunday, September 19, 1 pm, at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 9/11 Panel Members Form Group to Press Recommendations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 - Members of the independent Sept. 11 commission have received pledges of nearly $1 million for a private educational group they have created to press for enactment of the panel's recommendations, commission officials said Friday.

title: Anna Netrebko, at the Top but Still Rising
description: BRITTEN: 'PETER GRIMES' Glenn Winslade, Anthony Michaels-Moore, Jill Grove; London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, conducted by Colin Davis. LSO Live 0054, three CD's.

title: Anna Netrebko, at the Top but Still Rising
description: LUKAS LIGETI: 'MYSTERY SYSTEM' Amadinda Percussion Group; Ethel; Procd Rodesco-Letort; Kathleen Supov, pianist. Tzadik TZ-099, CD.

title: Expansion Sank Terror Screening Program, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 - A computer-based system intended for spotting possible terrorists before they could board airplanes was expanded during its development to serve broader police purposes, according to internal documents of the Transportation Security Administration.

title: Willkommen! Bienvenue! Mind If We Smoke?
description: BELLPORT - ONSTAGE at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport, the actors and actresses puffed their way through the Kit Kat Club scenes in the musical "Cabaret," oblivious to the signs throughout the theater that read, "Thank you for not smoking."

title: This Boat Is Your Boat, This Boat Is My Boat, and the Hudson Is Beckoning
description: BEACON, N.Y. - IN most ways, it's not much a modest gaff-rigged Hudson River ferry sloop, hundreds of which once plied the waters of the river. The deck needs major repairs, a squirrel has taken a bite out of the jib, the hull's been rebuilt, and it has already outlived its expected life span. It will never win a big-time sailing competition.

title: Pamela Nolan, David Cross
description: Pamela Healey Nolan, a daughter of Edward Patrick Nolan of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and the late Toni Healey Nolan, was married yesterday to David Daniel Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey D. Cross Jr., of Charleston, S.C. Msgr. James Vaughey, a Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Theresa in Briarcliff Manor.

title: David Baron, Paul Myers
description: David Hume Baron and Paul Stewart Myers were married yesterday in Boston. Gayle Smalley, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Clive Talking
description: In 1995, Clive Owen went to Los Angeles to become a star. Owen, who is co-starring in "Closer," the ensemble drama about tangled relationships that will be released in December, was already well known in England for his work on television and in the theater, and he had acted in some well-regarded small films. "So, like every British actor, I did the rounds in Hollywood," recalled Owen, as he ordered a "very hot" coffee at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York. Owen is tall and has a great beat-up face, dominated by the contrast between his smashed nose and his lambent hazel eyes. He has a brooding aura -- innate grace mixed with potential volatility. Without saying a word, Owen projects internal conflicts, a mood of existential turmoil that could erupt in violence, or a kiss, or both.

title: Questions For Elizabeth Edwards
description: They say opposites attract. Senator John Edwards seems to be cheerful and upbeat. His wife, Elizabeth, came across in your profile as mean-spirited and negative. Her comments about Lynne Cheney were petty.

title: Rap of Ages
description: NOT too long ago, rappers were often obliged to act younger than their age: on hip-hop albums, as in teen movies, twentysomethings impersonated high school students. But these days, lots of rappers are trying to act older, more sophisticated. Faux-vintage sports jerseys have given way to collared shirts and sport coats. (Looking for a good price on a lightly used, rainbow-striped Denver Nuggets throwback? You're in luck.) And when Jay-Z rapped, "No chrome on the wheels/I'm a grown-up, for real," thousands of nervous car owners checked their rims for left-over signs of adolescent exuberance. Who wants to be young and thuggin' when you could be grown and sexy, instead?

title: How Would They End the War?
description: WASHINGTON - PRESIDENT BUSH told voters in Minnesota on Thursday that "there's ongoing acts of violence" in Iraq but "this country's headed toward democracy."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGAR, GERTRUD
description: UNGAR--Gertrud on September 3rd, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Josef. Dear sister of the late Ilse Grossman. Devoted aunt of Harriet Hammer and Susan and Norman Roberts. Great-aunt of Kevin Hammer. Service Monday 1PM at "The Riverside", 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue

title: Bringing the Battle to the President
description: Washington - Senator John Kerry will lose the election unless he turns the issue of national security to his advantage. He began to do so, for the first time in weeks, with his speech on Thursday in Las Vegas, where he took President Bush to task for not being honest about the war in Iraq. In an earlier speech on the economy, he also tore into Mr. Bush's penchant for shifting blame to others.

title: Quite a Grab, Without a Net
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP) - Barry Bonds's 700th home run ball did not end up in the flotilla of kayaks in McCovey Cove, or in the small fishing nets held by children above the right-field bleachers in SBC Park.

title: Easy Rider
description: Q: Your new movie, "The Motorcycle Diaries," which opens in New York on Sept. 24, traces the political awakening in 1952 of Che Guevara during an 8,000-mile trip through Argentina, Chile and Peru. Why were you attracted to this material?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEIXEL, VARDON
description: DEIXEL--Vardon, at age 88, on September 13, 2004. Beloved husband and best friend of Helen for 57 years. Cherished father of Deborah and her husband William Blumberg. Adored grandfather of Andrew and Emily Blumberg. Dear brother of Donald. Memorial Service on Sunday October 17 at 3pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALK, AUDREY
description: FALK--Audrey. September 16th, in Oklahoma. Born 1929 in London; she lived in New York, Honolulu, and Lawton, Oklahoma. In New York, she volunteered for the Actors' Fund as a "buddy" to performers dying of HIV/AIDS. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Lee Falk; children, Willy Falk and Cathy Caccioppoli; son-in-law, Dr. Giuseppe Caccioppoli; granddaughters, Nina and Joanna.

title: Women and the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: All God's Children
description: Biola University stifles the creative spirit of a gay student, sends him to counseling to be "cured"; students like Brittany and Krista sit in a coffee shop wearing their faith like some pathetic armor; those with different beliefs are described as "they that are sick."

title: Church That Once Offered Refuge Sits at the Eye of a Storm
description: SINCE its founding in 1957, the Hungarian Reformed Church, on 82nd Street between Second and Third Avenues, has been a spiritual refuge for immigrants who fled Hungary in the years after the Communist takeover of their country. But in recent months something resembling a civil war has broken out inside the church's quiet walls.

title: The Message Gets Sent
description: The news that an obscure member of the State Assembly was defeated in a primary hardly seems like headline material. But in the closed and timid world of Albany, voter rejection of Assemblyman David Sidikman should be something approaching an earthquake. Mr. Sidikman, who represents the North Shore, was a perfectly average legislator who focused on constituent services. He was thrown out of office not because of bad behavior, or even because his victorious opponent, Charles Lavine, seemed destined to be a political star. The only real player in this drama was the moribund, dysfunctional State Legislature itself. The Nassau County executive, Thomas Suozzi, urged voters to send Albany a message by tossing out the noncontroversial Mr. Sidikman, and the voters complied.

title: The Remix; Vice Advice
description: "A kid with a rattail or a guy wearing flip-flops with awful toes just makes my skin crawl," says Gavin McInnes, who writes the scathing Dos and Don'ts fashion column for the severely un-P.C. Vice, which he helped found in 1994. Targets are either decimated to the point that they enter the fashion witness-protection program, or are deemed a rare example of coolness. Now the column is collected in "Dos & Don'ts: 10 Years of Vice Magazine's Street Fashion Critiques" (Warner Books). "We all want to be a stylist," he says, "to go up to somebody and say, 'Dude, cut the ponytail!"' But McInnes, whose back bears a tattoo of a jellyfish eating Fidel Castro and Chiang Kai-shek, is admittedly a questionable arbiter of taste. "I'm good because I'm a drunk and can make the crassest commentary. Sober people censor themselves too much." WILLIAM VAN METER

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: The Sixth Boroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: Mix Watergate and a Wild Child
description: AS in a well-cooked dish, ingredients blend in works by the Big Dance Theater, creating elusive flavors and textures. Its founders, Annie-B Parson and Paul Lazar, merge bits of speech, music, movement, props and costumes to create evocative, highly complex works like "Plan B," which opens on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop on West 19th Street. The work uses fragments of Richard Nixon's Watergate tapes and the adult diaries of Kaspar Hauser, who in 1828 became an international celebrity as a "wild child" abandoned in a German forest. These disparate elements combine in an exploration of corruption and innocence.

title: The Mantry
description: What Every Larder Needs and How to Use It

title: Pamela McDermott, James Long
description: Pamela Anne McDermott and James Francis Long were married on Friday at Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Bishop Christopher Jones of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Elphin in Ireland performed the ceremony. The Rev. James E. Devlin, also a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Abigail Bradford, Galo Alvez
description: Abigail Lee Bradford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford III of Maplewood, N.J., was married last evening to Gonzalo Diego Alvez, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Orosman Alvez of Springfield, N.J. The Rev. Vanessa R. Southern, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club in South Orange, N.J.

title: Low Air Fares
description: To the Editor: Ms. Stellin cited Orbitz and Expedia as especially good places to find low fares because they let you search one day earlier or later than the day you want to travel. She didn't mention that Travelocity has a "flexible dates" feature, which I think is even better.

title: Idette Elizondo, Mandeep Dagli
description: Milissa Idette Elizondo and Mandeep Sanat Dagli were married yesterday at the Willard InterContinental hotel in Washington. The Rev. Stephen Stahley, a Catholic priest of the Society of Christ's Priesthood, officiated. Pandit Anand Mohan, a Hindu priest, assisted in the ceremony.

title: Finding a New Cool Geneva (Even in the Old Town)
description: THE words "Geneva" and "frugal" are almost never associated. I was sure there were ways around this problem, so I enlisted my friend Sebastien, who is training for a job as a Red Cross delegate, as a guinea pig.

title: Not One for the Sidelines
description: I was at a wedding recently with my fiance, and this woman comes up to me and says, "Oh, I hear you're in the Special Olympics!" That's about the biggest insult you could say to me. The Special Olympics are for people with severe mental disabilities. They're held every year in every city, and everyone gets a hug and a ribbon at the end. The Paralympics aren't like that. We train year-round. It's very competitive -- there's wheelchair basketball, fencing, powerlifting, judo -- it's not one of these disabled sports where people are like: "Oh, it's so good to see you out here. You just threw that one foot, and we're so glad!"

title: The Remix; Bubblicious
description: What could be more fitting than a portrait of Britney Spears rendered in shades of Bazooka? Actually, according to the Canadian artist Jason Kronenwald, who relies on Wrigley the way some other artists depend on oils, the curves belonging to the bubblegum princess are rendered in Trident and Bubble Tape. "Better texture," he says. With a dedicated team of family and friends chomping their hearts out for him, Kronenwald has tackled over a dozen sticky subjects since 1996. For the latest additions to his goovre, check out his Web site, www.gumblondes.com. This guy is ready to blow up. STEFFIE NELSON

title: Needle Exchange Gains Old Friend
description: TRENTON - WHEN Governor McGreevey was elected three years ago, one group in particular saw his victory as a coup of its own. After all, Mr. McGreevey had promised to start a pilot program that would allow intravenous drug users to trade dirty needles for clean ones in an effort to slow H.I.V. and hepatitis C transmission.

title: Italian Elegance, City Roots
description: WANT a Saturday night reservation in November for the hot, new Il Mulino in Roslyn Estates? Start dialing now. Much of the initial enthusiasm has been generated by its pedigree: It is a branch of Il Mulino in Manhattan, voted the best Italian in New York City by the Zagat Survey for most of that restaurant's 23 years.

title: Lowe Takes the Baton And Promptly Drops It
description: JUST when the Boston Red Sox thought it was safe to send Derek Lowe into serious action, Lowe, their No. 3 starting pitcher, self-destructed yesterday. He self-destructed with his pitches, and he self-destructed with an ill-advised throw to third base.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Frequency Electronics Posts Profit for Quarter

title: Resignation of China's Senior Leader Appears Imminent
description: BEIJING, Sept. 18 - Jiang Zemin, China's military chief and longtime senior leader, may formally step down on Sunday, putting President Hu Jintao in full command of the Chinese Army, state and governing party, according to people informed of the proceedings of a secretive Communist Party meeting.

title: Booze, Babes and Introspection
description: CHICAGO - LOTS of people who give up a nasty crack cocaine habit and then almost die do something predictable, like find Jesus, buy a minivan, take up yoga. Not Felix Dennis, the wealthy British founder of the raunchy men's magazine Maxim. Mr. Dennis -- who still lives a pretty close approximation of the Maxim ideal, complete with booze and babes and expensive diesel-fueled toys -- has become a poet.

title: 'The Inner Circle'
description: For all my bravado that day at the tavern, I have to admit I had my qualms about the interview, and Iknow this must sound ridiculous coming from me, since I've contributed materially to the project to adegree exceeded only by Corcoran and Prok himself, and ultimately wound up conducting some twothousand interviews on my own, but if the truth be known, I was scared. Or perhaps "intimidated" would bea better word. You have to understand that back then sex and sexuality simply weren't discussed-anywhere, in any forum-and certainly not in a public lecture hall on a college campus. Marriage courseshad begun to spring up at other colleges and universities around the country, most pointedly in response tothe VD scare of the thirties, but they were bland and euphemistic, and as far as counseling was concerned,as far as a frank face-to-face discussion of pathologies and predilections, there was nothing available to theaverage person aside from the banalities of the local minister or priest.

title: Indian Point and Alternatives (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gael Garca Bernal: Just Another Homeless Young Star
description: MEXICO CITY - THE lunch rush has ended at a popular, upscale cafe, and one of the most attractive and acclaimed young movie actors in the world hobbles through the room of empty tables on crutches. He's so rumpled and heavily bundled up it looks as if he's spent the night on the street. Blushing and taking off his cap, he explains that he's just had hernia surgery. "I have been lifting heavy suitcases up and down a lot of stairs," he says. "I don't have my own place yet, so I stay with different friends." Unloading a big floppy satchel and laying his crutches on the floor, he shrugs, pulls off his jacket and takes a seat. Then, he makes eye contact. Gael Garca Bernal, it turns out, is a divine sight even in a post-operative state.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about car rental agencies in Switzerland for drivers with restricted licenses referred incompletely to the speed of Smart cars, made by DaimlerChrysler. While the particular cars used by the agencies are blocked at the dealer from going faster than 28 miles an hour, Smart cars can normally be driven at highway speeds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUCHIN, ERNESTINE ''ERNIE''
description: SUCHIN--Ernestine "Ernie" of Scotch Plains, N.J. Daughter of Joseph and Julia Mutnick, passed away peacefully on Monday, September 13, 2004 in her home surrounded by her family, friends and pets. She worked for many years as a realtor in Scarsdale, N.Y. and Westfield, N.J. In addition to raising three children, she was an active member of the community, receiving numerous citations for her wide and varied philanthropic endeavors. She had a special passion for the disenfranchised. Her love of animals was well known to all. Ernie is survived by her children Linda Davino, Neil Suchin, and Scott Suchin, M.D., her four grandchildren Gregory, Mark, Charli and Jolie, her daughters-in-law Carol and Alona, her son-in-law Gary and her beloved dogs Willie, Alfie, Cissy and Pippin. Her husband Jerome and twin sister Geraldine predeceased her. Her loving presence will be missed by all those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 19, 3PM at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583 (914725-1137). In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Humane Society or the ASPCA.

title: Fern Holland's War
description: Late one night this past March in the Babylon Hotel, on the banks of the Euphrates River, Fern Holland sat alone in her office writing e-mail -- unwinding, she wrote to a friend, with a glass of Johnnie Walker and listening to Michelle Branch singing "All You Wanted." She had many things on her mind, and among them was figuring out where she could get a bulldozer so she could help two Iraqi women get their land back.

title: The Remix; A Celux Few
description: Think getting into a Manhattan co-op is difficult? Try joining Celux, the members-only Tokyo boutique owned by LVMH. Although fees -- around $2,000 to sign up and then $250 a year -- are not prohibitively expensive, candidates need to be referred by a member (not so easy when the list is confidential) and to fill out a probing form before being grilled in person. The chosen few can buy till they cry from a supercool selection of LVMH-owned labels, including Louis Vuitton and Dior, as well as emerging stars like Libertine. But while the often limited-edition merch has a rock edge, as do the raucous regularly staged parties, the accent is always on luxury, or ragujyueri, as the Japanese sometimes refer to it. "We want to redefine luxury for the postbubble generation," says Asako Yano, the store's general manager. "We're definitely an experiment, an incubator for new brands and cultural trends, but at the end of the day we have LVMH in our veins." To tap into the company's lifeblood, or simply to be humiliated, go to www.celux.com. HORACIO SILVA

title: A Case Study
description: If shopping is an intoxicating activity -- and it is -- then shopping for wine is doubly so. The pleasures afforded by fine wines have remained unflagging since Biblical times, when psalms and celebrations were undoubtedly inspired by the fermented grape. Odd that such an ancient practice is still considered among the most civilized of pursuits. No matter. The Samurai Shopper is firmly in favor of civilization and raises her glass to it each and every sunset, with reverence, hosannas and an occasional filthy limerick. So when a Manhattan store called PJ Wine announced its 2004 Spanish Wine Festival at a church on Central Park West, I was jazzed. All samurai live by a code of self-discipline and austerity, but a fine wine is the gateway to nirvana. And if it isn't, it ought to be.

title: Iran Faces Criticism By Nuclear Agency
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency's 35-nation board of governors passed a resolution yesterday criticizing Iran for a lack of candor about its nuclear program and calling on Tehran to suspend all activities that could contribute to producing a nuclear bomb.

title: United States Has Big Deficit and Little Time to Come Back
description: BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Sept. 18 - Throughout the 35th Ryder Cup, Europe has purred like a Ferrari, while the United States has sputtered like a jalopy.

title: A Plan to Transform Manhattan's Final Frontier Has the Pioneers Worried
description: Real estate developers hunting for new development sites call the far West Side of Manhattan the last frontier. The Bloomberg administration calls it a blighted wasteland ready for radical transformation.

title: A Firehouse, and a Stoop, on West 10th Street
description: To the Editor:

title: The Olympics and the Stadium
description: The Olympic Games in Athens were a great public relations success for Greece, and the good vibrations seem to have left New Yorkers feeling pretty receptive to the Bloomberg administration's drive to become the host for the Games in 2012. That's all well and good. But Mayor Michael Bloomberg is now trying to use the Olympics as a bludgeon to force the city to accept his plans to help the Jets build the most expensive football stadium in history on prime Manhattan waterfront.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "My guess is that Saddam is dying every day. He is in prison, he is alone, he has lost everything, he has no power, nothing; and to him, that is worse than death."

title: Elizabeth Gillett and William McNeiece
description: WILLIAM McNEIECE can navigate nearly any situation with cowboy boots and a few direct words.

title: Seeking a Way to Cope With Abandoned Cats
description: To the Editor:

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
Ralph Nader: Neither Coke Nor Pepsi
description: THE GOOD FIGHT Declare Your Independence and Close the Democracy Gap. By Ralph Nader. 294 pp. Regan Books. $25.95.

title: Page Two: Sept. 12-18; LOCKING THE BARN DOOR
description: Russian travelers were dismayed to learn last week how easy it had apparently been for terrorists to penetrate security at Domededovo airport in Moscow and smuggle explosives aboard flights of two domestic airlines on Aug. 24.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE setting of THE MAGDALENE SISTERS (2002) is ridiculous. It's a convent in 1960's Ireland where "bad girls" (or girls who might turn bad because they're too pretty or flirtatious for their own good) are sent. They're put in prisonlike uniforms and sentenced, sometimes for life, to work long hours in hot laundries without speaking and forced to strip naked and stand in line while the nuns ridicule their breasts and genitals. Ridiculous but true. The last of these institutions were shut down in 1996, and Peter Mullan's grim, eye-opening drama about them is well worth taping or staying up late for. Nora-Jane Noone, Anne-Marie Duff and Dorothy Duffy play unfortunate young residents (one committed the sin of having been raped), and Geraldine McEwan is the nun of their nightmares -- Wednesday/Early Thursday at 12:15 a.m. on Starz.

title: Who Gets Inside the Ivory Tower?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet: Magical Hands and Voice

title: Adelphi Settles Suit Over Bias in Nursing
description: ADELPHI UNIVERSITY paid $600,000 last month to Althea Davis, a former director of the school's nurse practitioner program, to settle a lawsuit in which Dr. Davis accused Adelphi of racial discrimination.

title: Good News: Turnaround Specialists Are Gloomy
description: ATTENDING a meeting of turnaround professionals during a time of economic recovery is a little like going to a mortician's convention after a drug company introduces a blockbuster drug for a fatal illness. There's good news, but not for everyone.

title: No Stars, Just Cuffs
description: WASHINGTON - In World Wars I and II, gold star mothers were the queens of their neighborhoods, the stars in their windows ensuring that they would be treated with great respect for their sacrifice in sending sons overseas to fight and die against the Germans and Japanese.

title: 2004 Suzuki Forenza & Verona: Not From Around Here, Are You?
description: DETROIT - IN today's global auto industry, Chinese workers bolt bumpers onto Jeeps while good ol' boys drive Nissan trucks off the assembly line in Mississippi (and polish Mercedes's three-pointed star in Alabama).

title: A Skyscraper to Sing About
description: CAROLINE SHERMAN and Bobby Hull, both composers, lyricists and librettists, don't want to take a leap forward with musical theater. They would rather go back 60 years or so, to a time of hope and happy endings.

title: OP-ART
Northern Ireland Talks Falter, Despite Blair and Ahern Nudges
description: LEEDS CASTLE, England, Sept. 18 - Despite pressure from the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland, three days of negotiations among the leaders of Northern Ireland's political parties failed to bridge important differences over how to share power and end paramilitary violence.

title: The Get; Hi, Tech!
description: Gadgets worth inspecting. Jamie Wallis plugs in.

title: Last Round of Voting in Indonesia to Start on Monday
description: JAKARTA, Sept. 19 A On the eve of a landmark election for president of Indonesia, Normawatie knows precisely which of the two candidates she is going to vote for.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: The Get; 8 Is Enough
description: Need some jean therapy? These styles are just what the denim doctor ordered.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PEOPLE OF SPARKS By Jeanne DuPrau. Random House, $15.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DAVIS, GERTRUDE
description: DAVIS--Gertrude. Noted music educator, died June 16, 2004 in New York City at the age of 93. A Memorial will be held Saturday morning, October 2, 2004 from 10AM-12 noon, Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th St., Room 504, NY

title: 'The Connection'
description: In August 2000, Ahmed Hikmat Shakir, a thirty-seven-year-oldIraqi, quietly began his job as a "greeter" at the KualaLumpur International Airport in Malaysia. The job, a commonone in Southeast Asia and the Middle East, normally involveslittle more than welcoming visiting dignitaries and makingcertain that they move smoothly through the laborious entryprocess.

title: Wild Wes
description: Style in films, like style in life, is somewhat suspect and vaguely un-American. Most nonperiod movie dressing is blandly sexy -- for women, some variation on what Jennifer Aniston might wear. And the men, well, most men in American movies aim for a tough-guy look that would fit nicely on George W. Bush. If you are concerned with clothes, can you have any content? "That question always annoys me," the director Wes Anderson said. "I have found that a sense of originality in style usually signals something interesting. Which is one of the reasons why I go to movies."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GERBER, CAROLYN OTTENHEIMER
description: GERBER--Carolyn Ottenheimer. 10/15/23-9/20/44. A war bride. A war tragedy. A promise kept. Charles S. Gerber

title: No Crowds of Commuters Here
description: SECAUCUS - IT is a getaway Friday afternoon, and the roads in New Jersey are already thickening with cars. On the radio 1010 WINS is warning of troubles on the bridges and in the tunnels. The swarms are beginning their descent on the train stations in Hoboken and Newark.

title: Man Kills His Wife in Park, Police Say
description: A man shot and killed his estranged wife outside a crowded park in the Westchester County village of Mamaroneck yesterday afternoon and then fled with their three young children, who had watched the shooting from his van, the police said.

title: 'April Fool's Day': Ivan the Terrified
description: APRIL FOOL'S DAY By Josip Novakovich. 226 pp. HarperCollins Publishers. $23.95.

title: Introduction
description: Our Sept. 5 issue drew praise for Pedro Almodvar, the Spanish director, and for the pictures of his leading ladies. Others called our article on a Christian college fair but criticized the school as too judging of others. And Elizabeth Edwards won over many with her repartee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOOMIS, JOSEPH
description: LOOMIS--Joseph. On September 18, 2004. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Father of Mark, Gregg and Roxanne, Roy and Claudia. Loving grandfather of Gregory, Brian, Jonathon and Harrison. Services today, at 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Putin Gambles on Raw Power
description: MOSCOW - COUNTRIES react differently to terror. After the Sept. 11 attacks, Americans rallied behind their government of their own free will. After the Madrid train bombings last March, Spaniards ousted theirs. President Vladimir V. Putin took steps last week that seem to ensure that Russians will do neither.

title: The Story Behind 'The Plot Against America'
description: Philip Roth's new novel, "The Plot Against America," which will be published by Houghton Mifflin next month, imagines an America in which the 1940 presidential election resulted not in a third term for Franklin D. Roosevelt but in a victory for a Republican ticket headed by Charles A. Lindbergh. The Book Review asked Roth to write an essay about his new book and how he came to write it.

title: Corrections; A Correction: 'All Time' Isn't Forever
description: When Babe Ruth hit his 700th home run on July 13, 1934, it may have seemed reasonable for The New York Times to proclaim that Ruth's total "promises to endure for all time." After all, he had 386 more home runs than anyone else.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 29, about finding low air fares, included an erroneous report from Southwest about the availability of its tickets online. Some fares can indeed be found on Web sites other than Southwest's, including www.americanexpress.com, not exclusively on www.southwest.com.

title: A Sound Decision on Cement
description: In an important decision earlier this month, Erin Crotty, the commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, upheld common sense, the rule of law and the primacy of environmental concerns. Ms. Crotty -- supported, we assume, by her boss, Gov. George Pataki -- decided to hold St. Lawrence Cement, which wants to build an enormous coal-fired cement plant just south of Hudson, N.Y., to the full legal standard of environmental scrutiny. St. Lawrence Cement had asked the D.E.C. to grandfather the mine it plans to operate, exempting it from review under the State Environmental Quality Review Act. Commissioner Crotty refused. She has also called for full adjudication of several critical issues surrounding the plant.

title: Bonds Adds Another Amazing Run to the Game
description: BARRY BONDS admits he has amazed himself, so why shouldn't we all be amazed? Most of us weren't around to watch Babe Ruth hit more home runs in a season than many teams did. Some of us witnessed Hank Aaron amass home runs by demonstrating a stunning consistency in which he matched his uniform number - 44 - in home runs more than he displayed awesome, one-of-a-kind season totals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, HAROLD M.
description: KAUFMAN--Harold M. 88, of Roslyn, NY, on September 18, 2004. Loving husband of Edna. Devoted father of David, Harriet, Robert, Karen and Steven. Adoring grandfather of Jill and Jeremy Bohrer, Elana Kaufman and Matthew White. Proud great-grandfather of Sophie Bohrer. Services to be held at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, Monday, at 11:30 AM. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to YAI National Institute for People with Disabilities, 460 West 34th St, NY, NY 10001.

title: On the Parquet at El Morocco
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions For Elizabeth Edwards
description: Perhaps the reason that 22 million "unmarried" (single?) women did not vote in the last election is because no candidate or incumbent ever acknowledges our existence. Families get tax cuts, deductions, write-offs, etc., while single-household residents receive very little, if anything. I would like to hear the candidates include the issues relevant to those of us struggling as single Americans for a change, instead of being considered as merely the silent or invisible minority. Perhaps then those single Americans who have not recently voted would have a reason to do so.

title: The Week Ahead; DIPLOMACY
description: Among President Bush's favorite places, the United Nations ranks pretty low. But he'll be there anyway on Tuesday, making the case that its members must put aside differences on Iraq and make the transition to democracy there work. He will also meet with Kofi Annan, the U.N.'s secretary general, who last week called the decision to invade Iraq "illegal." David E. Sanger

title: ON THE MARKET
description: A Place to Make Noise $775,000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALAY, ROLAND
description: BALAY--Roland (May 28, 1902--September 16, 2004). Knoedler & Company celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Roland Balay, grandson of our founder, Michael Knoedler, and President Emeritus of the gallery (1956-1976). Mr. Balay served artists and collectors with dedication and vision which continue to be an inspiration to this day. Our sympathies go out to his wife of 30 years, Felicie Trayman Balay, and to his devoted family.

title: Kristina Alg, Stephen Penhoet
description: Kristina Noel Alg and Stephen Girardin Penhoet, architects in Washington, were married yesterday by the Rev. Stanley A. Dubowski, an Old Catholic priest, at Toyon Farm in Napa, Calif.

title: What We Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: The Remix; Doc-umentary
description: After losing its footing in recent years, Dr. Martens is picking itself up by its bootstraps and staging a comeback.

title: Port Authority
description: The martini is as overrated as Robbie Williams. The drink that stirs a true English gentleman is port. Brits like me have been sipping it after dinner ever since the Portuguese went head to head with the French for a share of the lucrative English wine market in 1703. At Cambridge, my alma mater, port is still so much a part of university life that almost every one of the more than two dozen colleges offers a custom-blended version for sale, complete with collegiate label and crest (drunken dons optional).

title: Bringing Down the House in Fairfield County
description: IT'S a milestone, yes, but not one that Fairfield County residents, preservationists, even some home builders are particularly proud of.

title: Hurricane Ivan's Last Gasp Leaves New York Region Soaked
description: The remnants of Hurricane Ivan sloshed into New York City and environs yesterday, shutting down large patches of the city's subway system, causing New Jersey to declare a state of emergency in four counties and threatening to flood rivers as far north as Sullivan County, N.Y.

title: A Divisive Landmark Battle in Yonkers
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Russia's Ethnic Jigsaw Puzzle
description: FOR half a century Russia, in the Western mind, was the Soviet Union -- the Communist monolith behind the Iron Curtain. But with failure of the Soviet state, and the independence of its satellite states in Eastern and Central Europe and the Baltics, came the re-emergence within Russia itself of innumerable ethnic, religious, historical and geographical divisions that had been papered over or forcibly suppressed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELTON, DORIS
description: FELTON--Doris. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the loss of Doris Felton. A wonderful lady and like our second Mom. She shall be greatly missed. Ellie and Martin Lifton

title: Lessons From a 'Textbook' War Crimes Trial
description: THE HAGUE - When the judge told Slobodan Milosevic that, like it or not, from now on he had to deal with defense lawyers named by the court, Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, raised his hands and responded, "Well, you go ahead and deal with it."

title: Another Deep Hole and Not Enough Rope
description: Bloomfield Township, Mich. - WHEN the 1999 United States Ryder Cup team trailed the Europeans, 10-6, going into Sunday's 12 singles matches at the Country Club outside Boston, Ben Crenshaw, the United States captain, issued a declaration of confidence in his golfers.

title: Diana Barnes, Dan Philpott
description: Dr. Diana Hart Barnes, a daughter of Angela L. Barnes and Dr. Peter D. Barnes of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to Dr. James Daniel Philpott Jr., a son of Linda J. Philpott of Bradfordwoods, Pa., and Mr. Philpott of Cranberry Township, Pa. The Rev. John D. Stoeger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel in Pittsburgh.

title: Semistylish Italian in a Vast Space
description: BEDFORD HILLS - IT was the sliced peaches macerated in sugar, Grand Marnier and mint leaves that won me over at Spasso. Sunny and fragrant, with a dab of dense whipped cream, the boozy, tenderized fruit was delicious.

title: Poet, Actress, Ad Executive
description: BOTH of my parents were performers with the Peking Opera. They expected me to do the same, but I didn't like opera at all. I liked ballet.

title: A Growth Stock Is a Growth Stock Is a Value Stock
description: WHEN managers of mutual funds that concentrate on value stocks start buying growth stocks, it's time to take notice.

title: The Smell of a Cheap Thrill
description: FOR all its varied beauty and fascination, you could argue that art is nothing more than a matter of perspective. Some artists look sideways, some look up. Some look from the outside in, some from the inside out.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 19, 2004
description: Weeks

title: China Pulls Up the Drawbridge
description: BEIJING - FOR a while, it was looking like the Wild Wild East here. After essentially sealing the country off from foreign architects for much of the 20th century, the Chinese government kicked off the 21st by turning itself into the biggest single patron of avant-garde architecture in the world.

title: The Remix; Moog Music
description: Forty years after he invented the synthesizer that bears his name, Bob Moog is back for an encore. The patron saint of electrogeeks is the subject of "Moog," a documentary opening this month, which details how the entrepreneurial inventor packaged the unwieldy components of electronic music -- filters, amplifiers, oscillators -- and made them widely accessible. "He's the Leo Fender of synthesizers," says Money Mark, a longtime keyboardist for the Beastie Boys, who is featured in the film. The circuit of Moog's influence connects the million-selling "Switched-On Bach," by Wendy Carlos, to Stereolab's pop cool; the dance-floor ecstasy of "I Feel Love," by Donna Summer, to the progressive rock of Yes. Even the producers du jour, the Neptunes, are fans of Moog (shown right, in 1971). Just don't make the mistake of equating synthesized sounds with synthetic ones. As Moog says in the film, these sounds are real. STEFFIE NELSON

title: Heavy Rotation
description: LAS Haxial Helmet Put an end to sweaty, buggy hair: this high-tech helmet features air-channeling vents to cool the head, as well as internal netting to keep out insects; $169. Go to www.lashelmets.com.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 29 about melodies for the prayers sung during the Jewish High Holy Days included an incomplete quotation from Debbie Friedman, a cantor who discusses nusach, the traditional mode of chanting the liturgy, in an unreleased documentary called "A Cantor's Tale." Ms. Friedman said in full: "We should preserve nusach, and I'm a firm believer that we should do what we can to preserve it. But if we do that exclusively, then we can forget about preserving it at all, because no one's going to show up." The abbreviated quotation read "Forget about preserving nusach. No one is going to show up."

title: No Princess Sleeps in This Castle
description: FISHKILL - SILHOUETTED in the mist on Bannerman Island, the ruins of Bannerman Castle beckon intriguingly, a familiar sight to boaters heading north on the Hudson River past Storm King Mountain. The island and its burned-out buildings, hinting of ghosts and tall tales, have been closed to the public for decades, but now there is a chance to see its rocky terrain close up.

title: In a City Unfamiliar, Seeking a Bond to a Dead Son
description: THEY landed at Kennedy Airport looking like ordinary tourists. Fatigued by the long flight from Brussels, their hometown, they were carrying two modest suitcases between them. But they had no interest in seeing the sights. Michel and Paola Braut came to the city for the anniversary of Sept. 11 in search of fading connections to Patrice, their 31-year-old son and only child, whom they lost in the attacks on the World Trade Center three years ago.

title: Uncle Sam, Visionary Builder?
description: IN an age when government buildings are viewed more as terrorist targets than emblems of democratic values, the federal government's "Excellence in Architecture" program may seem an anachronism. Created in 1994, less than two years into the Clinton presidency, the program sought to raise the abysmal standards of design set in the 1970's and 80's, when American architecture was at a low point and government projects were typically built by politically connected corporations.

title: The Dirty Secret of the Solo Record
description: CHANNELS -- "Open" (Desoto Records), the debut E.P. of this band fronted by the singer and guitarist J. Robbins, formerly of the indie bands Jawbox and Burning Airlines, sounds, unsurprisingly, a lot like albums by Jawbox and Burning Airlines -- melodically complex, mathematically challenging, and lyrically rich. Produced by Mr. Robbins, it uses the dissonant, angular guitar work and odd time signatures that have been his trademarks. The six-song E.P. includes a flawless rendition of the John Cale classic "Fear Is a Man's Best Friend," which builds on the original with Janet Morgan's confident vocals and Mr. Robbins's tasteful arrangements.

title: New Jersey: Town Houses to Fill in a Parking Lot
description: AT one end of the shoreline on Raritan Bay in petite Keyport Borough, a new 12-town-house condo development is about to rise.

title: The Benefits of Living Above the Store
description: THERE are very few ways to outwit the market and find a bargain.

title: Sooners Methodical in Picking Off the Ducks
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 18 - OKLAHOMA 31, OREGON 7

title: The Sixth Boroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: There's Gold in That Rubbish
description: If Mayor Michael Bloomberg does nothing else to help New York City with its mushrooming garbage problem, he will have accomplished something monumental by committing residents to long-term recycling of their bottles, plastics and cans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARABY, DAVID
description: SHARABY--David. Beloved husband of 49 years to Lena. Loving father of Michael, Danny, Elliott, Susan and Jeffrey. Cherished brother of Abraham, Sheldon, Sammy, Morris and Shoshana. Adored grandfather to 22 grandchildren. Passed away on September 17, 2004, at his home in Florida. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Services today, 2:15 PM, at "Boulevard-Riverside Chapels," 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THORNBROUGH, ALBERT
description: THORNBROUGH -- Albert Adam passed away September 8th as a result of complications from a stroke he suffered six weeks ago. He had just celebrated his 92nd birthday. He was born on the plains in Lakin, Kansas and lived there through the Dust Bowl and the Depression. After graduating from Kansas State University in 1934 with high honors, he began graduate studies at Harvard which led to a Master's Degree in Agricultural Economics before WWII intervened. He served in Washington in the Office of Price Administration and the Army Corps of Engineers during the War, eventually joining the Reserves as a Lieutenant Colonel in 1946. His business career began with Harry Ferguson Inc., the farm equipment manufacturer, in Detroit in 1946. After the company merged with Massey Harris in 1953, he advanced to the President of the combined entity in 1956. He became Chief Executive Officer in 1966 and served in that role until his retirement in 1978. He presided over Massey's global expansion in the 60's and 70's. During much of this period he and his family resided in Toronto, Canada. However, he considered Boca Raton his home for the last 40 years. During his career and his retirement he served as a director and trustee of numerous boards including the University of Guelph, Lynn University, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the Farm Equipment Institute and the Royal Palm Yacht and Country Club. Mr. Thornbrough, devoted husband for 61 years to Virginia Thornbrough, is survived by his three children: Susan Thornbrough Staiger and Jon Staiger; Wayne Thornbrough and his wife Barbara; Grant Thornbrough and his wife Diana. In addition, he leaves six adult grandchildren and one new great-grandchild. He also leaves behind his beloved Marlene Fay whose companionship enriched his later years. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 26th at 2PM at the First Presbyterian Church of Boca Raton. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Albert Thornbrough Scholarship Fund at Lynn University, 3601 North Military Trail, Boca Raton, Florida 33431, or to the charity of your choice. His path from the plains, to the highest levels of academia, to successful global businessman while serving his country and community has been an inspiration to his family and friends around the world.

title: Bouncing Among Shelters and Among City Schools
description: Jacqueline Fortunato had a choice to make last week: she could either use the $20 she borrowed from a friend at the homeless shelter where she lives to take her family's clothes to the laundry, or put the money toward bus and train fare to shuttle her two oldest boys to their elementary schools.

title: Smallpox, A Scare And a Test
description: TRENTON - CLIFTON LACY sat at the kitchen table with his wife, drinking seltzer and glancing at the clock. It was nearly midnight, a few minutes before the end of July 4, 2002, and, for Dr. Lacy, that was a relief.

title: 'My Old Man': From Moses to the Marquis de Sade
description: MY OLD MAN By Amy Sohn. 320 pp. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: Correction
description: The Word for Word column last Sunday, a selection of excerpts about former President Clinton and fast food, misidentified the town where he attended high school. It is Hot Springs, Ark.; Hope is his birthplace.

title: Ariella Papa, Michael Greaney
description: Ariella Papa, a novelist, and Michael Greaney, a television producer, were married on Block Island, R.I., yesterday. James J. Sullivan, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Narragansett Inn in New Harbor.

title: Bettina Grant, Tyler McCarthy
description: Elizabeth Waters Grant, the daughter of Elizabeth L. Grant and Michael D. Grant of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Tyler James McCarthy, a son of Patricia A. McCarthy of Washington Depot, Conn., and the late William J. McCarthy. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRITZ, BARRY R.
description: FRITZ--Barry R. 64, of Stony Creek and Woodbridge, CT, peacefully on September 17, surrounded by his loved ones. Son of the late Harry and Belle. Most beloved husband of Mary and devoted brother of Robert. Adored stepfather of Jed and Katie Doyle. Favorite uncle, cousin, friend. Wise teacher of 37 years to students at Quinnipiac University. Barry's warmth, kindness, wit and gentle guidance will be remembered by all of us who knew him, as his spirit will live within us. Graveside service Sunday, September 19, 2 pm, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY. Memorial service in Connecticut to be announced at a later date.

title: Freshman Quarterback Is Contained at Last
description: DURHAM, N.H., Sept. 18 - WILLIAM AND MARY 9, NEW HAMPSHIRE 7

title: 12 Years After the Riots, Rodney King Gets Along
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 - He is still recognizable, though he has walked with a limp since he lost control of his car last year, crashed into a house at 100 miles an hour and shattered his pelvis.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE FORTRESS OF SOLITUDE, by Jonathan Lethem. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) Lethem's melancholy and marvelous novel elegizes a slice of urban life in 1970's Brooklyn. The coming-of-age of geeky Dylan Ebdus (who seems to be Lethem's alter ego) and his hip black neighbor, Mingus Rude, is stuffed with cultural touchstones: from comic books, popular music and graffiti to crack cocaine and gentrification. Selected by the Book Review editors as one of the best books of 2003, "Fortress" is "crowded . . . with lessons, insights, facts, dates, song titles and minor characters," A. O. Scott wrote here, "and the naturalistic geography of a borough Lethem knows like the back of his hand is illuminated by a daub of magic realism."

title: .000 AND COUNTING
description: When a federal jury in Memphis acquitted Vernice B. Kuglin of tax evasion in August 2003, she became a hero to tax protesters. But while she may have avoided a conviction for breaking the law, Ms. Kuglin, a Federal Express pilot in Memphis, did not escape the taxes and penalties.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 19, 2004
description: Weeks

title: Sept. 12-18
description: STILL WILLING TO DWELL IN THE WIND'S WAY On the coasts that know hurricanes, people have an almost intimate way of speaking about the memorable ones.
