"I was here for Betsy," they say in New Orleans of the 1965 storm. In Mobile and along the Gulf Coast, they say, "I remember Frederick" (1979).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DIG! By Andrea Zimmerman and David Clemesha. Illustrated by Marc Rosenthal. Harcourt, $16. (Ages 2 to 5)

title: The Get; Wings of Desire
description: This season, elegantly tooled wingtips are tops. Pick your flight pattern.

title: The Talk
description: Man Man / (man) / n. / an adult male human; a male representative, as of a location or company, e.g., "Our man in Tajikistan"; / intj. / can be used as an expletive to indicate intense feeling: "Oh, man, that was close!"; often Man (slang), a person or group in a position of authority, as in, "Michael Moore's new underwear line really socks it to the Man"; a prefix that butches up even the most effeminate fashion touches, e.g., "That's a pretty pair of mandals you're wearing," or "Love the manbag!"

title: Two Stars in Seattle
description: !Two Stars in Seattle

title: U.S. Plans Year-End Drive to Take Iraqi Rebel Areas
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 18 - Faced with a growing insurgency and a January deadline for national elections, American commanders in Iraq say they are preparing operations to open up rebel-held areas, especially Falluja, the restive city west of Baghdad now under control of insurgents and Islamist groups.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SAMOSE, CELIA
description: SAMOSE--Celia. In loving memory of your birthday, September 19th. Grandchildren

title: Mental Snapshots
description: To the Editor: Roger Mummert's article on mental snapshots reminded me of my own. Leaving Nazi Germany as a child, I knew that I had to imprint into my memory certain places, where I had found peace, security and freedom.

title: Susan Lindauer's Mission to Baghdad
description: Susan Lindauer, as portrayed in David Samuels's article (Aug. 29), could probably use some psychotropic medication. But this mad, mad world would be a much kinder, gentler place in the hands of bumbling madwomen with grandiose visions of peaceful conflict resolution than in the grip of bumbling madmen whose aim is personal aggrandizement enforced by ever-increasing attacks on the most fundamental human freedoms.

title: The Sound of Passing Time
description: HAVING little money to finance new issues and faced with diminishing public tolerance for yet another recording of the standard repertory, classical labels are pursuing a gray-haired audience that, in the years after World War II, witnessed the birth of the long-playing record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENKRANZ, JULES JOSEPH
description: ROSENKRANZ -- Jules Joseph. Age 91, of New York City, died September 17, 2004. Mr. Rosenkranz was the beloved husband of Marjorie Sable Rosenkranz. He was former Vice President of Durst Manufacturing. Jules was loved by all whose lives he touched and will be remembered for his kindness, generosity and compassion. Jules is survived by his two loving daughters Ann and Jill Rosenkranz of Massa chusetts. Services will be held at Campbell Funeral Home, 81 St and Madison Ave, in New York, on September 19.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 5 about new skyscrapers proposed or under construction in New York referred incorrectly to the owner of a London building designed by Richard Rogers, who is working on a development project in Queens with Silvercup Studios. It is the Lloyd's insurance exchange, not the Lloyd's bank.

title: Anna Freitag, Michael Kedersha
description: Dr. Anna Carol Freitag and Michael John Luke Kedersha were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Thorne, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Neil O'Connell, also a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Questions For Elizabeth Edwards
description: If the selection of a presidential candidate were based upon the quality and character of his or her spouse, I would select John Edwards. Deborah Solomon's interview (Sept. 5) with Elizabeth Edwards revealed a woman of intelligence, wit, compassion and honesty. I believe the majority of Americans would wish its leaders to have the same qualities.

title: Stubborn Contract Talks Closer to Delaying Start of Season for the Philadelphia Orchestra
description: Representatives for musicians with the Philadelphia Orchestra voted last night to authorize a strike, edging closer to action that would scuttle the start of the venerable ensemble's 105th season on Tuesday.

title: Elisabeth Dietel, Thomas Nuez II
description: Mary Elisabeth Dietel, the daughter of Carolyn S. Dietel and John W. Dietel of Holyoke, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Nuez II, a son of Silvia Cruz Nuez and Mr. Nuez of Miami. The Rev. Robert G. Biron performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Church in New London, N.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOOKER, SAMUEL D., JR.
description: HOOKER--Samuel D., Jr. In his 91st year. Loving brother of Naomi H. Chamberlain and Olivia J. Hooker. He will be missed by a host of friends in Chicago and White Plains.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the "In the Region" article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about Highgrove, a condominium project planned for downtown Stamford, misstated the location of a pool, Jacuzzi, sauna and massage facilities within the development. They will be on top of the four-story garage, not on top of the residential tower.

title: Casting an Eye Toward Brooklyn's `Hidden Jewel'
description: CROWN HEIGHTS is a study in contrasts. Thanks to a bountiful supply of often richly detailed single-family and multifamily homes, many of the community's streets are now lined with turn-of-the-20th-century town houses that have been painstakingly renovated.

title: Advertisements for Myself
description: Most young designers dream of becoming successful the old-fashioned way, by getting one commission, then another, until they've attracted a high-profile client list and generated a body of work that turns them into a marketable brand. But not if you're Ora-Ito. The 27-year-old Frenchman (whose given name is the equally exotic Ito Morabito) decided that it was much more modern to become a brand first, and then parlay it into design commissions. And it worked. He now has a 15-person office whose client list includes Nike, Heineken, Adidas, the furniture manufacturer Cappellini and the lighting giant Artemide. Not bad for a design-school dropout.

title: The Week Ahead
description: DIPLOMACY Among President Bush's favorite places, the United Nations ranks pretty low. But he'll be there anyway on Tuesday, making the case that its members must put aside differences on Iraq and make the transition to democracy there work. He will also meet with Kofi Annan, the U.N.'s secretary general, who last week called the decision to invade Iraq "illegal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITNEY, JAMES J.
description: WHITNEY--James J., age 88, passed away September 9, 2004, at home in Peoria, Arizona. Born and raised in New York City, Jim was a US Army Lieutenant during WWII. He built a home in Dobbs Ferry, NY, and worked for 30 years in the NYC Fire Department. He was assigned to Ladder 42, Ladder 19, Rescue 3 where he served as Captain, and retired in 1978 as Chief of Battalion 4 in lower Manhattan. Jim garnered numerous citations throughout his career for bravery in the line of duty. He was a generous and loving person, a true believer in adventure, compassion and the goodness of human spirit. He is survived by his son James Scott Whitney, his daughter Ada Whitney, his companion Marion Cano, Jon Vesey and his grandchildren, Henry, Jordan and Kristen. His spirit, humor and guidance will be greatly missed by us all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLITS, HAROLD J.
description: BLITS--Harold J., 88, of Aventura, FL, formerly of Lawrence, NY, died Saturday, August 14th, 2004 after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Eveline.

title: The Curing of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: The Remix; Isn't It Special?
description: Fred Rogers has gone to the big neighborhood in the sky, but his fashion legend lives on. The fall collections paid their respects, with designers from Jil Sander and Marc Jacobs to Donna Karan for DKNY, below, showing versions of his beloved cardigan. While only Etro's colorful woolens approached the hand-knit feel of Rogers's signature sweaters -- many of which were made by his mother during his 30-year television career -- most designers offered a sleek alternative to the slouchy cardi made popular by Kurt Cobain. Meanwhile, RTFT (the house footwear label of Alife, the Lower East Side generator of sneaker trends) has produced the Mr. Rogers shoe -- a pneumatic penny loafer that is to the original Weejun what today's curvy, computer-designed Chevy Avalanche is to the old-fashioned pickup.

title: A World of Nuclear Dangers
description: The cold war generation grew up worrying about the bomb, the Russians and World War III. Today's nuclear nightmares are more varied, but no less scary. The list of nuclear-armed states is lengthening alarmingly, and each new entry increases the chances that some nasty regional war could turn nuclear. Nuclear terrorism has emerged as a terrifying new threat. Russia has huge, poorly guarded stockpiles of nuclear bomb fuel and there is a small but increasing possibility that its decaying early warning system could trigger an accidental launch.

title: 3 Generations Under 1 Roof
description: Randall Grahm, 51, the owner of Bonny Doon Vineyard, lives in a 2,500-square-foot two-story "California-eclectic style" home in Santa Cruz with his partner, Chin-shu, 42; their 18-month-old daughter, Amlie; and Chin-shu's mother, Chen.

title: A Splash By a Riesling
description: IF you like Mosel riesling, you will like Pindar's 2003 Johannisberg riesling. This bottle -- a bargain $11 at the winery in Peconic -- is one of the best Long Island rieslings I have tasted in a while.

title: From Long Island To the West Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: The Utility Company Around the Corner
description: THE general manager of Norwich's utilities department was visiting an industrial customer one day when he learned the business was planning to leave the city.

title: In Revision
description: An ethics column offers its writer a chance to make variegated errors, a weekly opportunity to go wrong in a whole new way. It keeps the job fresh. Here are several cases in which astute responses from readers induced me to reconsider my original positions. It is my necessary but perilous task to venture occasionally into territory most safely traversed by experts. While I do not go forth without a guide, recently the information provided by one such Virgil proved unreliable. Much that he averred about medieval manuscripts was dubious. He asserted that these manuscripts "are not books in the manner we conceive of contemporary books" but assemblages of individual documents, and thus I concluded that it was O.K. to break apart those volumes and sell the pages separately. This is baloney, many medievalists told me in e-mail messages. (It is startling to discover just how many medievalists there are.)

title: Democracy on the Back Burner
description: Ma Thanegi, a Burmese writer in Yangon, Myanmar, leaned over her stove to peer out her apartment window. Outside, a man wearing a longyi, or sarong, was walking through the apartment complex, shouting for all to hear. He was one of the many tradesmen -- some buying old newspapers, some selling tofu salad -- whose cries pierced Thanegi's walls during my visit with her in July. "This one is buying hair for wigs," she reported with amusement. The hair peddler pays a premium -- about 60 cents a pound -- for long hair. Thanegi's hair is cropped; not much to sell.

title: Meghan Hadlock, Gregory Kitzerow
description: Meghan Elizabeth Hadlock, the daughter of Judith and John Hadlock of New York, was married last evening to Gregory John Kitzerow, a son of Geraldine and Christopher Kitzerow of Long Valley, N.J. The Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Topless Club
description: The writer P.J. O'Rourke once observed: "There are a number of mechanical devices which increase sexual arousal, particularly in women. Chief among these is the Mercedes-Benz 380SL convertible." The man has a point. Bentley and Jaguar may have come on like Scientology on wheels, managing to seduce some A-list celebrities, but their Hollywood conversion rate is nothing compared to that of the Mercedes SL.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRYER, JEFFREY
description: BRYER--Jeffrey. Your 62nd birthday dearest Jeff. You are always in my heart and thoughts. Mother

title: Why a Red Sox Fan Shouldn't Really Want His Team to End the World
description: You have a friend who is a Boston Red Sox fan. A good, loyal friend. A confidant you can pity.

title: Board Rejects Parts of Patriot Act
description: WHITE PLAINS - THE Westchester County Board of Legislators joined a growing list of counties and cities across the nation last week when it passed a resolution condemning parts of the USA Patriot Act for violating civil rights.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DANIEL, BEVERLY
description: DANIEL--Beverly. It's been a year, but you're always in our thoughts and in our hearts. We miss you in every way. Be assured, in this political season, we are all doing the right thing. We love you, Jo, Josh, Emily, Lily, Ruby Quincy, Ruthie, Sean

title: Capital Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time Bill O'Reilly Got It Right
description: IF a stopped clock is right twice a day, why shouldn't Bill O'Reilly be right at least once in a blue moon? When Fox News's most self-infatuated star attacked CNN for keeping James Carville and Paul Begala as hosts on "Crossfire" after they had joined the Kerry campaign, he fingered yet another symptom of the decline and fall of the American news culture. "In the wake of the vicious attacks on Fox News for allegedly being 'G.O.P. TV,' I expected the media to brutally dismember CNN and the new boys on John Kerry's bus," Mr. O'Reilly wrote in his syndicated column. "But instead it's been the silence of the lambs from the press. Can you say media bias?"

title: Alzheimer's Sufferers and Their Caretakers (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Lower 80's, Willard's Pals Gnaw Away
description: Darkness had fallen, and John Robertson, a doorman at 90 Riverside Drive, an elegant prewar co-op, knew that the street gangs were already on the move. Standing sentry on West 81st Street last Monday, he squinted into the dim, lamplit night, unfooled by the stillness. "They're here," he said knowingly. "That's for sure."

title: Coughlin's Quirks Have Place in the N.F.L.
description: He was such a stickler for being early that his wife set their clocks at home ahead by 10 minutes, and she had to beg him not to arrive at parties on time. He was a devout Catholic who would not dream of cursing or berating someone, until he got on a football field, where he would jump on a blocking sled and scream at his players using the vilest language.

title: Crazy Prices Gone, Like Disco and Elvis
description: Crazy Prices Gone, One More Time

title: Guests May Be Lacking, but Not Spirit
description: SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y. - For one of a supposedly dying breed, the Raleigh Hotel, a resort in the old Catskill tradition, was almost hopping -- or at least not limping -- on an overcast Saturday in late summer.

title: Wendi Jackson, Blair Smith
description: Correction Appended

title: The Get; Boot Up
description: It's time to kick/start your wardrobe with a bit of high-market grunge.

title: White-Collar Stress? Stop the Whining
description: WORKPLACE stress is back in the news. American workers are frazzled to the point of illness, experts say, and enlightened employers are offering yoga classes, massage and other palliatives to combat the problem.

title: 'The Second Bill of Rights': A New New Deal
description: THE SECOND BILL OF RIGHTS FDR's Unfinished Revolution and Why We Need It More Than Ever. By Cass R. Sunstein. 294 pp. Basic Books. $25.

title: The Zone; Factory Made
description: Ever feel like doing the hustler? Try this look, influenced in part by a photo of the Warhol himbo Joe Dallesandro and made famous by the Smiths' debut-album cover. With its eye-brushing bang and shaved back, this perennial haircut is enjoying another return. The hairstylist Losi (for John Frieda Salon) says, "In the 80's, we called this 'the Model Cut,' because all the male models had it." Model or not, you can get the look with the right products. Start with Kiehl's Protein Shampoo ($14). For straight hair, use "just a schmear" of John Frieda wax ($7) while damp to control fly-aways. Those with wavy locks should mix Kiehl's Extra-Strength Styling Gel and Creme with Silk Groom ($16 and $17) to damp hair and briefly blow-dry while brushing forward. But Brillo-haired boys beware. As Losi cautions, "With curly hair, this cut can have a mushroom effect."

title: Farewell, Brendan Arena And Tom Aquarium
description: Tom Kean and Brendan Byrne may well be among the most beloved of New Jersey's former governors. They still can't seem to get any respect.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Not a Pass Pastime

title: Evelyn Crow, Roy Abrams
description: Evelyn Gwyneth Crow, the daughter of Linda and Todd Crow of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married last evening to Roy Quincy Abrams, a son of Jan and Stefan Abrams of New York. Rabbi Judith S. Lewis officiated at the Harvard Club of New York City.

title: Following New Rules, Parties Steer Money to the States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 - When Robert and Mary Lloyd Estrin decided to give money to state Democratic parties this year, they sent a total of at least $20,000 to Arizona, Colorado and Nevada -- unexpected choices, perhaps, for a couple from California.

title: A Bond Forged on Cellulite Is About to Run Its Course
description: Peggy Levine, a small woman who runs a small exercise studio on West 92nd Street, always feared she wouldn't be able to dance fast enough to keep up with the changing times. "When 'You've Got Mail' came out, I said, 'That's me!"' recalled Ms. Levine, referring to the 1998 movie in which a little Upper West Side bookshop owned by Meg Ryan's character is forced out of business by the arrival of a chain.

title: Anna Netrebko, at the Top but Still Rising
description: ANNA NETREBKO: 'SEMPRE LIBERA'Anna Netrebko, soprano; Mahler Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Claudio Abbado. Deutsche Grammophon 474 800-2, CD; 474 881-2, SACD.

title: Bombs Kill 19 in Kirkuk and Wound 3 in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 18 - A suicide car bomb exploded Saturday in the northern oil city of Kirkuk after the car plowed into a crowd of men seeking jobs with the Iraqi National Guard, killing 19 people and wounding 67 others, the Health Ministry said.

title: Laura Billings, David O'Neil
description: Laura Michele Billings, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, is to be married today to David Andrew O'Neil, an associate in a law firm. The Rev. T. Alan Garrity, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate at the Coco Reef resort in Paget Parish, Bermuda.

title: Running Down Main Street
description: AT a 5-kilometer road race in Portland last Saturday, Karen Rogers inched one town closer to her goal of running a race in each of Connecticut's 169 towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, S. DAVID
description: LEVY--S. David. 67. Passed away peacefully on September 15. Beloved husband of Seena Schnall Levy, father of Karena Levy and her husband, Richard Buczkowski, and Benjamin Levy, brother of Richard H. Levy and Philip G. Levy. Graduate of University of Wisconsin, Madison, 1959 and Harvard Law School, 1962. Co-founder of the Biograph Theatre, coowner of the legendary Key Theatre with his wife, both in Washington DC. Services will be held at 2 PM on Sunday, September 19 at Washington Hebrew Congregation, Macomb St., at Mass Ave., NW, Washington DC. Interment at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 5789 Cooper Ave., Ridgewood, NY, 718-386-6700, at 1 PM on Monday, September 20. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Alexander Graham Bell Association for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, 3417 Volta Plc., NW, Washington DC, 20007, and the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Ave., NY, NY 10017.

title: Commodities Are Riding on China's Coattails
description: THROUGHOUT the first half of this year, investors in commodities fretted about China. They worried that its economy was in for a hard landing, as construction, property values and equities all seemed to be overheating.

title: Coloradans to Consider Splitting Electoral College Votes
description: DENVER, Sept. 18 - Colorado voters have delivered the state for the Republican presidential candidate in every election in the last half century, except when Bill Clinton won by a whisker in 1992 and Lyndon B. Johnson swamped Barry Goldwater in 1964.

title: Bald Eagle Answers Call of the Unwild
description: CAN a juvenile bald eagle that feasted for weeks on pizza and fried chicken ever find happiness in the wild again?

title: 35 Guantnamo Detainees Are Given to Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 - The Pentagon announced on Saturday that it had transferred 35 detainees from the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to Pakistani custody, as part of a continuing effort by the Bush administration to reduce the number of prisoners at the naval base there.

title: Mental Snapshots; Low Air Fares
description: Mental Snapshots

title: From One Girl's Legacy, a Promise of Hope
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, MARGIT LOEPERT
description: SIMON--Margit Loepert. At the age of 81. Beloved wife of Peter, Sr. for over 61 years. Loving mother of Peter, Jr., and mother-in-law of Ellen. Adored grandmother of Jennifer. Dear sister of Helga Rosenberger. Devoted sisterin-law of Ellen Simon Marks, and aunt of Bob Simon, and Lynn Edelstein. Please remember her for what she was to all of us. Interment private. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St., Sunday, September 19th, 2:00-6:00 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript of a conversation between film critics of The New York Times last Sunday about movies being released this fall and winter included an actor incorrectly in the cast of "Closer," scheduled to open Dec. 3. Mark Ruffalo is not in the film.

title: Hopkins Is the First to Knock Out De La Hoya
description: LAS VEGAS, Sept. 18 - It ended in a flash, an agonizing instant that Oscar De La Hoya will remember for the rest of his life.

title: In Crete, Mobility With a Guide and a Glide
description: AS our plane landed in Iraklion, I considered whether sea kayaking in Crete was going to be a peak experience or a long way to go for a gyro sandwich. For years I'd listened enviously to my friends' tales of adventure travel. I have multiple sclerosis, so trekking in Tibet was out. But kayaking -- which requires upper body strength, not leg power -- seemed like a good bet.

title: Neue School
description: "In the East, we never knew painting was dead," says Gerd Harry Lybke, who runs the Eigen+Art galleries in Berlin and Leipzig, referring a tad disingenuously to how far off the radar German art once was. Not anymore. The powers that spree -- curators and collectors -- are beating a path to Germany, to the former East Germany, to be exact, to find the next big art star. Charles Saatchi is refrigerating his sliced-up animals to make room for Teutonic talent. Dealers like Jay Jopling and David Zwirner are scouting the former GDR. And at Marianne Boesky in New York, "Clara Park," a group show of Leipzig painters, opened earlier this month. In fact, Y.G.A.'s -- young German artists -- have replaced Y.B.A.'s -- their British predecessors -- as the art stars of the decade. But rather than shock audiences, or run up bar tabs at the Groucho Club, these guys just want to paint.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Last Seduction
description: Querying Carolyn Murphy is a day at the beach. The coolly elegant face of Este Lauder is breezily relaxed about life, family and career. If she had followed up her impressive 1999 film debut in "Liberty Heights," she could have kept "/actress" on her rsum. Instead, she put her movie career on hold to raise her daughter, Dylan, and make a home with her boyfriend, Brandon Boyd, Incubus's lead singer, and their growing menagerie. Since Murphy is arguably the last word in modern beauty, we thought we'd ask her last things first.

title: The Zone; Homme Shanti
description: There's something in the air, and it smells like . . . spiritual enlightenment. Consider the red string cabala bracelet, or bendel, which is the new Von Dutch cap. Even manly-men have begun toting yoga-mat bags, as the enlightened purveyors of fashion meditate on fall. Tony & Tina's Color Cards enable you to "read" your color vibrations and diagnose what ails you. To bring the healing energy of a Japanese hot spring into your tub, try EvisuSpa Rock and EvisuSpa 4-Ever, two new lines of aromatherapeutic bath products. You can smell like the holy men of Mysore, India, where the Art of Shaving gets the theraupeutic essences it puts into its sandalwood cologne. Or go to the mat for self-improvement with yogi-to-the-stars David Life, who leads a "Class for Busy People" -- on DVD from the Jivamukti Yoga Center in Manhattan. But if it's the luck-attracting red string you still covet, Slatkin & Company has included a blessed bendel with each of the eight candles in its new Kabbalah line -- further proof that the mind-body-wallet connection just gets deeper. STEFFIE NELSON

title: Page Two: Sept. 12-18; BROUGHT TO BOOK
description: The legal fallout mounted last week from the failures of the City of New York's system for processing of mass arrests during the Republican National Convention.

title: The Remix; Vroom at the Top
description: Roberto Menichetti's most recent show took place in a former tobacco factory in Florence, a fitting setting for the smoking-hot designer, whose new men's-wear collection makes its debut this fall. His rsum includes three years as the creative director of Burberry, where Menichetti, a motocross enthusiast, revved up the plaid-mad company's image. The 37-year-old son of Italian tailors says that his new line runs the spectrum of his own closet -- from basic cotton tees to hand-knit cashmere sweaters and luxury leathers (future plans include a line of motorcycling gear). He must have one big closet. STEFFIE NELSON

title: A Statute Left Standing Gives Parishioners Solace
description: A statue of Mary that was left unscathed after an explosion demolished a church in Colchester earlier this month has become a pilgrimage site for people throughout the area, some of whom believe the statue's survival was a miracle.

title: Auburn Converts Second Chance to Stun L.S.U.
description: AUBURN, Ala., Sept. 18 - Three days after Hurricane Ivan ravaged the state, in a game that almost did not take place, 14th-ranked Auburn rallied Saturday for a dramatic 10-9 victory over No. 5 Louisiana State, the defending co-national champion.

title: Yawning in the Uffizi
description: WHEN I was 9 years old, my family took a trip to Italy. My mother suggested I keep a journal during the trip, and apparently I agreed to do so because I still have it: a hardback book, bound with paper and cloth, and stuffed with postcards, stickers, drawings, snapshots and page after page of my preadolescent penses, written in the kind of earnest, labored cursive that only a mother could love.

title: Trust Your Gut
description: Washington - As a seasoned and experienced public servant, Senator John Kerry has known perilous times when his political future looked bleak. For some mystical reasons that can be explained only by dissecting his political DNA, Mr. Kerry is like the prize-winning horse Seabiscuit -- he runs best from behind.

title: Our Lady of the Hutch
description: AS drivers on the Hutchinson River Parkway endure worse-than-usual traffic congestion because of road-improvement projects and construction of a shopping center at Sandford Boulevard, most are not aware of the rare woman for whom the parkway is named. Even those who are would be hard pressed, while inching forward in traffic, to conjure up her final scene, in which tomahawks flew, smoke billowed from a 17th-century farmhouse and children screamed for their lives.

title: Ready or Not, Electronic Voting Goes National
description: Just over six weeks before the nation holds the first general election in which touch-screen voting will play a major role, specialists agree that whatever the remaining questions about the technology's readiness, it is now too late to make any significant changes.

title: Police in Italy Close In on Revived Guerrilla Group
description: Correction Appended

title: The Nudist Buddhist Borderline-Abusive Love-In
description: LOS ANGELES - DAVID O. RUSSELL had developed something of a reputation. The screenwriter and director of "Flirting With Disaster" and "Three Kings" had become known for smart, wildly original movies, and for attracting top actors despite relatively modest budgets. But he was also known for alienating some of those actors while shooting (most notoriously when he and George Clooney ended up in a fistfight on the set of "Three Kings.") For his next movie, "I Huckabees," Mr. Russell was determined to chart a happier course.

title: The Talk; Gentlemen, Start Your Engines
description: Harley-Davidsons might be status symbols overseas, but when it comes to gearing up, the Italians prefer to keep it local. Whether they're riding their motorcycles in faded Diesel or Etro tweeds, the stylish men of Milan top it off with a Momo Design helmet. With its graphic rubberized shell and a sleek design inspired by helicopter pilots' headgear, the carbon fiber and Kevlar cap has become the accessory del giorno for everyone from the Ferrari boys to the dashing Fiat chairman, Luca Cordero di Montezemolo.

title: The Winding Road Of Emissions Testing
description: An official with Agbar Technologies, the contractor responsible for Connecticut's vehicle emissions testing, said Wednesday that the company planned to test its new software at 24 stations by the end of the week.

title: As Season Begins, Networks Struggle In Cable's Shadow
description: The new prime-time television season officially starts this week, and much more than bragging rights to ratings supremacy will be on the line for the broadcast networks.

title: Going Underground
description: GARDEN CITY - LONG ISLAND can no longer afford to run its economic lifeblood and millions of its residents through the boroughs of New York City. The terrorist assault on Manhattan and the region's static economy are two strong reasons for Long Island to have a direct connection to New England across the Long Island Sound. Creating such a connection would require significant money (an estimated $1.3 billion) and political courage, but unless we begin to study our strategic options, Long Island will remain a dead end for 2.7 million people.

title: Atomic Agency Votes to Censure Iran Over Its Nuclear Program
description: PARIS, Sept. 18 - The International Atomic Energy Agency's 35-nation board of governors passed a resolution on Saturday criticizing Iran for a lack of candor over its nuclear program and calling for the country to suspend all uranium enrichment activities that could contribute to producing fuel for a nuclear bomb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, RABBI ASHER
description: BLOCK--Rabbi Asher. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi emeritus of Little Neck Jewish Center in Queens. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: The Remix; Rebel Sell
description: "It's like you've been shot at," chuckles the Parisian designer Ramdane Touhami as he pokes at his bullet-torn jacket. "It's military chic." With his new store, Bureau Politique, Touhami, an impish 29-year-old skateboarder and ex-D.J., is taking army surplus to a new level. A subversive trendsetter, he sees himself as an "agitation and propaganda expert," a person who, when asked to contribute artwork for Hello Kitty's 30th-birthday exhibition, depicted her as Napoleon. At 17, he dropped out of accounting courses to make a small fortune with a mock-Timberland "Teuchiland" T-shirt touting hashish, then went on to stoke the skateboarder craze in Paris with his King Size fashion brand.

title: Whose Recovery Is It, Anyhow?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Poet's Corner
description: The man behind Bergdorf Goodman men sees fall as a tweedy mix of Frank O'Hara and you.

title: Whitney Parks, Jordan Berns
description: Whitney Sanders Parks, the daughter of Carole and Nicholas R. Parks of Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Jordan Chester Berns, a son of Kathleen Z. Berns of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Edward A. Berns. The Rev. Churchill G. Pinder performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.

title: Spano's Rx for Families? A Little Mortadella
description: RECENTLY, I set some lamb chops in front of my 15-year-old son and asked, "Did you know that studies show that the more often children eat dinner with their families, the less likely they are to smoke, drink or use illegal drugs?"

title: The Stars Align For Asian Art Shows
description: Every two years, more or less, there are four major contemporary-art biennales across Asia. This year, the dates of all four are in relative alignment, making for a possible fall excursion for committed contemporary-art buffs. All four can be visited during the last two weeks in October, but ambitious travelers should reconfirm closing dates with venues or organizing bodies.

title: No Victory Over Traffic
description: No Victory Over Traffic

title: A Convenience Store for Health
description: WHITE PLAINS - NOT long after Lisa Gussack hung out her shingle as a midwife in 1980, she realized the job would involve far more than delivering babies. Pregnant women complained of backaches, new mothers suffered from the blues, and fathers often got lost in all the excitement. "Not to mention the needs of the babies themselves," Ms. Gussack said.

title: Bang Bang, You're Elected
description: The nation's capital city will soon suffer a brazen insult at the hands of the House of Representatives as a legislative majority prepares to vote for the decontrol of guns in the city -- that's right, a majority of lawmakers, sworn to "insure domestic tranquillity" for the nation, would make D.C. stand for Dodge City. As far as election year pandering goes, the impending vote to legalize handguns and semiautomatic weapons on the streets -- striking down the home-rule wishes of Washington's citizens -- may answer the question of how low Congressional politicians will go in bowing to the gun lobby.

title: Mastering the Mixed-Use Market: It Helps If You Can Talk the Talk
description: WHEN buying a mixed-use building, it pays to focus on various neighborhoods and to get to know some of the real estate brokers there. Shopkeepers and residents might also be helpful. They can tell you when certain properties are coming to market. Some buildings are never listed with a broker -- they're simply advertised with a "call owner" sign in the window.

title: The Sixth Boroughs (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Going To Extremes
description: As the 24-year-old daughter of "hippie-turned-yuppie" parents, I have grown up with nostalgia for my parents' generation. I was raised liberal, but I've never been an activist. I am writing because I was filled with anger and sadness as I read James Traub's essay (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 29). I went to the protest on the Sunday of the Republican Convention. Seeing so many people of my generation get off their couches on a Sunday morning and come together in the name of something political and important brought tears to my eyes. So instead of criticizing the protesters as 60's wannabes "drunk on the heady wine of total denunciation," Traub should be rejoicing that his son wants to join the crowds that have been absent for too long. All I can say is it's about time.

title: Margaret Kelly, 94, Founder of the Bluebell Girls, Dies
description: Margaret Kelly, a proper Irishwoman better known as Miss Bluebell who founded the Bluebell Girls, the long-stemmed, high-kicking, slightly clad troupe considered the most glamorous chorus line in Paris and perhaps the world, died in her sleep on Sept. 11 at her home in Paris, her son Patrick Leibovici said. She was 94.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Pamela Borgeson, Malcolm Kratzer
description: Pamela Gay Borgeson and Malcolm Montgomery Kratzer, both partners at the law firm Shearman & Sterling in New York, were married yesterday in New Jersey at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Dr. James H. Harris Jr., a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An annotated pop music listing in the New Season issue last Sunday about Don Byron's new album, "Ivey-Divey," omitted one of his instruments. He plays clarinet as well as tenor saxophone.

title: A State-of-the-Sect Message
description: PURCHASE - RACING against a deadline with the setting sun on a recent Friday afternoon, Rochel Butman drove back to Westchester from Brooklyn along the Van Wyck Expressway, her five children in the back of the family van listening to the Yeshiva Boys' Choir on the CD player.

title: Step Right Up and Beat the Numbers
description: AMAZING, isn't it, how investors still reward companies for pulling out all the stops to meet or exceed the financial results they promised? Witness, for example, how they applauded the midquarter update that Texas Instruments delivered on Sept. 8.

title: Adrienne Scholz, Samuel Hines
description: Adrienne Michele Scholz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter M. Scholz of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Samuel John Hines, the son of Elaine Crabtree Davis of Higher Denham, England, and Dennis Hines of Brighton, England. The Rev. Dr. Charles Miller, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, SHARON
description: KATZ--Sharon. The American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) mourns the loss of Westchester Council and Executive Committee Member, Sharon Katz. We and the entire pro-Israel community share in the loss of our dear friend and committed activist.

title: The Week Ahead; 2004 CAMPAIGN
description: Forget Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida. Senator John Kerry is taking his campaign next week to an even more important stop: "Late Show With David Letterman." Mr. Kerry is not known as the funniest guy on the campaign trail, but here's one bet: He will deliver a Top 10 list. And humorless or not, how bad could an appearance on the show be? Mr. Kerry can be certain that for one night at least, he'll be making the jokes -- rather than being the butt of them. Adam Nagourney

title: Yanks Pour It On to Cool Off Boston
description: There might as well have been a rain delay, for all the waiting Jon Lieber had to do. Walks, a pitching change, an injury -- Lieber had to endure it all.

title: QUICK BITE/On the Road; Have Pig, Will Travel
description: Dave Caprioni starts a typical workday with the tools of his trade: a slow kettle cooker in the shape of a pig and a 100-pound hog straight from the slaughterhouse. Mr. Caprioni has been towing kettle cookers to some of the finest outdoor spots in the state for over 10 years as the owner of "Pigs on Wheels."

title: Don't Forget Training
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonds's Human Side Moves Onto Center Stage
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 - As Barry Bonds spoke Friday night about strength and concentration, his 5-year-old daughter, Aisha, clutched his bulging right biceps as if she were squeezing her favorite stuffed animal.

title: On the Parquet at El Morocco (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 5 about the combination of computer animation and live action in the current film "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow," which detailed the elements present in one frame of the film, misidentified the format in which the actress Gwyneth Paltrow was recorded. It was high-definition video, not film.

title: A Healthier Heppner in 'Otello'
description: The two hardest tenor roles in the opera repertory are supposed to be Wagner's Tristan and Verdi's Otello. Ben Heppner, the Canadian tenor, 48, has done them both. But New York has yet to hear his Otello, which he brings to the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow, to open the company's season.

title: Airlines' Human Touch Comes at a Price
description: For travelers who prefer to speak with an agent rather than book their airline tickets on the Web, that service increasingly comes with a price tag. In recent weeks, several airlines have announced new fees for booking frequent-flier awards and, in some cases, paid tickets through an airline representative.

title: First Take at Directing For a Film Hand
description: WHILE most children in Harrington Park spend their summers investigating the ins and outs of local swimming pools, Gregory Jacobs chose a different route when he was 11. He was hard at work behind a camera, shooting his seminal indie short, "Super Chicken." The film -- about a teacher who becomes a chicken and rescues people -- was a 70's cult classic, at least among friends and family.

title: Iran Moves to Roll Back Rights Won by Women
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 18 - The hard-liners who won Iran's parliamentary elections last February have focused on women's rights in their efforts to reverse some of the reforms carried out under the moderate president, Mohammad Khatami.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: SOUTH AFRICA SPECIAL -- For travel Oct. 15 to Nov. 30, South African Airways has round-trip fares to Johannesburg or Cape Town starting at $1,040 plus tax from Kennedy Airport or Atlanta. A Terrific Two package includes air fare, two nights in Johannesburg (at the City Lodge Morningside) and three nights in Cape Town (Victoria and Alfred City Lodge Hotel), the flight between the two cities, daily breakfast, a car rental in Cape Town and some tours for $1,499 a person, based on double occupancy. The package is sold by South African Airways Holidays. Information: (866) 722-2476 or www.flysaa.com for the airline and (888) 777-1138 or www.saaholidays.net for the package.

title: The Remix; Tie Rep
description: The young man who strides into the Carlyle is well dressed; he has on a charcoal suit, a blue-and-white-striped shirt, gold cuff links and a bright orange necktie. The only thing missing from Baruch Shemtov's regular ensemble is his yarmulke, which he removes in business situations. Shemtov, a baby-faced senior at Ramaz, the modern Orthodox Jewish high school on the Upper East Side, considers the Carlyle his home away from home, the perfect milieu for an image-conscious 16-year-old trying to become the next Ralph Lauren.

title: The Gospel on Hats
description: "CROWNS" is a musical tribute to hats. Well, it goes much deeper: it is a celebration of the role of hats in Southern black culture, of the endurance of black women in the South, of the unconquerable urge for self-expression. The James Baldwin quote that frames the stage -- "Our crowns have been bought and paid for, all we have to do is wear them" -- gives the hat metaphorical resonance, as a symbol of dignity earned by years of struggle.

title: Should the City's Streetlights Be All the Same or Different?
description: THE New York City Department of Transportation and the Department of Design and Construction will select a new standard design this fall for the city's more than 320,000 streetlights. The last citywide standard was Donald Deskey's "cobra head" of 1958, and the history of streetlight design suggests that the logic of uniformity poses problems in a city of widely varying streetscapes.

title: A New View of Where Rates Will Go
description: OH where, oh where are interest rates going? No one knows, but the disagreement is growing.

title: When School's Out, But Practice Is On
description: AMONG high school parents, it amounts to a covenant: If you want your child to play a sport, be prepared to knit family vacation plans into practice and game schedules -- which are rarely limited, in this day and age, to the months when school is in session.

title: The Remix; SAVILLE ON SAVILE: SINGING FERRY'S PRAISES
description: As an art director, my entre to fashion and visual culture was courtesy of Roxy Music. The cover of "Another Time, Another Place," Bryan Ferry's second solo album, released in 1974, was like a picture window to an aspirational world. I was 19, I lived in the industrial north of England and I was on the learning curve of glamour. My next-door neighbor gave me a white Vegas-style tuxedo, and I had white shoes like Bryan did. I learned about style through his sartorial journey: it starts off almost post-Elvis, and it ends up in a Harris tweed jacket. Bryan is really fantastic at taking Savile Row and giving it a bit of sex appeal. Any man would do well to follow suit. PETER SAVILLE

title: The Get; Meet You in MiTo
description: Correction Appended

title: Minnesota Returns to a Star Role on National Stage
description: DEER RIVER, Minn. - For most of the four decades and more that I have been watching national politics, Minnesota has played a leading role.

title: Claire Applegate, David Maxwell Jr.
description: Claire Sullivan Applegate, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Applegate III of Cincinnati, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to David Bryce Maxwell Jr., a son of Kathryn Winkhaus Maxwell of Locust Valley, N.Y., and Mr. Maxwell of Amsterdam. The Rev. Dr. Gerald R. Fritz, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Third World Revolution as a Product of Italian Design
description: THERE has never been a shortage of movies that invite us to imagine the past -- to sink into the embroidered cushions and try on the fancy-dress plumage of earlier times. But while countless films use the resources of costume and set design to create an illusion of historical reality, few are as rigorous in their attempts to illuminate the less visible manifestations of history, to use the transparency of the medium as a way of clarifying the mysterious and half-forgotten past.

title: Cargo Cult
description: When it comes to luggage, Guy Trebay is a royalist.The Queen of England made me buy my luggage. Well, O.K., not exactly. But it was "Old Bess," as the Duchess of Windsor used to call her, who sold me on the stuff, since my first reaction to a Globe-Trotter suitcase was that it imparted to its owner a sad, defeated Willy Loman air. But the queen, then a princess, proudly packed her trousseau in Globe-Trotter suitcases and managed to look quite snappy on tarmac and gangplank. The ill-fated Diana, Princess of Wales, carried the hats she detested in them, and the Duke of Edinburgh employs the cases exclusively. After all, if there is anything the inheritors of an empire should know, it's how to pack. Made by hand of vulcanized fiberboard over an ash frame, using methods barely changed since the company's founding in 1897, Globe-Trotters are essentially cardboard suitcases. They are lightweight, boxy, expensive -- from $365 to $1,460 -- and so aggressively nondescript that they are favored not merely by nobility, but also by a select group of fashion's own royals -- designers and stylists -- as well as by a fanatical group of cargo cultists in Japan, and, nowadays, by me.

title: Editors' Note; Note to Readers
description: What's your favorite hardware store, fish market, luncheonette? Readers are invited to submit their choices for the crme de la crme of Long Island shops -- stores found along a Main Street or in a downtown area -- in whatever category comes to mind: pub, card store, ice cream parlor. Suggestions will be sifted for an article scheduled to appear in the "Long Island at Its Best" special section in November. E-mail: lishops@nytimes.com.

title: Paperback Fiction
A Faulty Terrace Door in a Co-op
description: Q. Our co-op apartment has a faulty terrace door that does not lock or close properly. The managing agent confirmed that the door is the co-op's responsibility, but the co-op has been dragging its feet for six months; the one repair bid it received was deemed too expensive, so the board is seeking additional bids. Once a bid is accepted, a repair could take another three months. This will take us into winter. Do we have any recourse? . . . Robert Tucker, Manhattan.

title: Climbing the Ladder, One Rung at a Time
description: UNLIKE people who search intently for the ideal home, Caroline and David Gould realized early on they were willing to settle for something good enough.

title: Susan Han, Raymond Liu
description: Dr. Susan Zee Sook Han, a resident in endodontics, and Dr. Raymond Wei-Han Liu, a resident in pediatrics, were married in Manhattan yesterday. The Rev. Jon M. Walton performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York.

title: Contours
description: Women attending last week's New York spring 2005 shows displayed today's split personality on skirt shapes: narrow, left, versus full, right. Some of the full skirts were enhanced with petticoats, inset, or they were bell-shaped and box-pleated, above, with 12-inch unpressed hems to puff out the silhouette.

title: Alzheimer's Sufferers And Their Caretakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHECHTMAN, DANIEL
description: SCHECHTMAN -- Daniel on September 15, 2004. Beloved husband of Marion. Dear brother of Selma Epstein. Devoted son of the late Samuel and Tillie Schechtman. To know him was to love him. Services private.

title: Swift Boat
description: Modern political campaigns are often remembered by the odd names of advertisements. The Johnson-Goldwater campaign of 1964 calls to mind the daisy spot, a TV commercial that showed the petals being pulled off a flower counting down to an atomic explosion. The Bush-Dukakis campaign of 1988 calls to mind the Willie Horton commercial, about a murderer allowed weekend parole. Now it seems the 2004 presidential campaign will be identified with the Swift boat spot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACKMAN, JEANETTE
description: BLACKMAN -- Jeanette, on September 15, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Susan and Jeffrey Kane and Anne Blackman. Cherished grandmother of Harrison and Lowell Kane. Loving aunt of Esther Crown and Scott Weinstein. Services Sunday 12 noon at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Impressionism Flourishes Just Off I-95
description: Correction Appended

title: Across Years and Yards, Two Old-School Guys
description: Hours after the third most productive rushing day of his career, Curtis Martin's phone rang. It was his friend Jim Brown.

title: 'Duveen': The Art of the Deal
description: DUVEEN A Life in Art. By Meryle Secrest. Illustrated. 517 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Struggling, Even With a Tuition Break
description: In his 60 years, Norman Maxwell has been a woodworker, a contractor and an administrative assistant at Citibank and Goldman Sachs. He has been an actor in "Billy Bathgate," "The Prince of Tides" and "The Sopranos." He is the father of four and a veteran of the Vietnam War.

title: Apartment Prices May Be Up, But Tyco Sells at a Discount
description: IN a real estate boom where prices keep on climbing, who sells a luxury apartment on Central Park for less than they paid for it?

title: Page Two: Sept. 12-18; NO ROSY SCENARIO IN IRAQ
description: A classified official prognosis for Iraq turned out to be as gloomy as the picture emerging from Americans' television screens. A National Intelligence Estimate prepared for President Bush in July concluded that the best that could be hoped for in Iraq over the next 18 months was tenuous stability. The worst of the three possible cases described in the document was a trend toward civil war.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Despite their best intentions, parents of young readers often make a burdensome, prickly chore out of learning to read. Many 5-to-7-year-olds will find that burden lightened by Allan Ahlberg's HALF A PIG (illustrated by Jessica Ahlberg, Candlewick, $16.99; ages 4 to 8), an appealingly roguish book that cavorts at the boundaries of conventional narrative, slyly fortifying basic reading skills while wittily demystifying the act itself.

title: Japan Rewrites Its Manchuria Story
description: SHENYANG, China - THE Japanese-era buildings, built to last in red brick, still peek out, stolid and fastidious, from the shadows of the new Shenyang that is soaring up all about them.

title: Wearing Boxing Gloves With Those Tennis Whites
description: It is hard to say just what has gotten into people at the Van Voorhees Park tennis courts in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Maybe there is road rage spillover from the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, a few steps to the east, or maybe the broad-shouldered specter of the container ports a few steps west is giving players a little extra swagger.

title: Richard Chai, Working the Buzz
description: Correction Appended

title: The British Zombie Buddy Flick
description: "YOU'VE got red on you," a co-worker says to Shaun near the beginning of "Shaun of the Dead," a British zombie comedy that splatters onto American screens on Friday. Though that particular streak of red is caused by the leaky pen in Shaun's breast pocket, there will be plenty more red stains on Shaun before the film is over. A runaway hit in Britain, "Shaun of the Dead" is a subversive mixture of grandly scaled horror-movie carnage and low-key comedy, grounded in closely observed details of everyday life in England. It's one of the most successful blends of terror and humor since John Landis's 1981 movie, "American Werewolf in London" -- a film that the makers of "Shaun" drew upon, along with the 1978 George Romero classic, "Dawn of the Dead."

title: On the Prowl to Fly-Fish in the Last Days of Summer
description: ENFIELD, N.H.

title: The Remix; Dressed to Kill
description: The pulp fiction of the 1940's and 50's may have disappeared from the dime store (as has the dime store itself), but the noir look lives on. You can see it in films like "Ocean's Eleven" and "Get Shorty." Hey, it's to blame for the popularity of a mug like Quentin Tarantino. So, if Tarantino can make money playing off pulp's provocative imagery, then why not revive the books themselves?

title: Too Few Cooks Can Spoil the Broth, Too
description: WE'VE lost our cook! No soup kitchen until further notice."

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, part of the final sentence was omitted in an article last Sunday about the Taiwan director Tsai Ming-liang, whose film "Goodbye, Dragon Inn" is set in a theater that is showing its last movie. The article should have ended: "Relax your expectations of how fast a plot should move -- or, really, whether there must be a plot at all -- and you may feel your imagination reaching deep into the quiet, open spaces of 'Goodbye, Dragon Inn.' And what you find there is your self, in the act of watching a movie -- and maybe the cute person checking you out across the aisle."

title: Man Seeks Wife (And Oval Office)
description: MILLBURN - AMONG the many dismaying things about modern presidential campaigns is the cost-benefit ratio: for things that are so expensive, they provide precious little entertainment or insight. That summation can also be applied to "Of Thee I Sing," a musical about a presidential campaign, which is receiving a showy but vacuous revival at the Paper Mill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARPER, WALTER WARREN
description: HARPER -- Walter Warren. Los Angeles, August 10th, 2004. Born June 29th, 1915, in Catskill, New York, to Florence Alexander and Joseph Charles Harper. An outstanding athlete, Warren was the first African American to make the Varsity in Catskill. Married Katherine Louise Johnson, daughter of Alice Braxton and Dr. Roland R. Johnson in New York City in 1937. Warren worked 36 years for the U.S. Postal Service. After Katherine's passing in 1988, he wrote a memoir which began as a series of letters to the family. Survived by his son Michael, daughter Katherine Guyton, (his second child, Jonathan, died in 1977), sister Winifred Branham, brother Kenneth Harper, 12 grandchildren, 18 great - grandchildren, three great - great - grandchildren, three nieces, and many dear friends. Warren was a beloved patriarch and humanist. The family requests donations be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation in the name of W. Warren Harper.

title: As Florida Recovers From Storms, the 'Vultures' Circle for Bargains
description: ORLANDO, Fla. - KEN DEANER, a financial consultant in New York City, had his heart set on buying a second home in Miami a few weeks before Hurricanes Charley, Frances and Ivan hit. But now that real estate romance is over.

title: The Zone; Cabinet Makers
description: Shave Pipe Brush Ceci n'est pas une pipe. Practice the art of shaving with this Surrealist brush, $87. At Nickel Spa, 77 Eighth Avenue.

title: Leaving Office and Hoping to Leave a Mark
description: ST. LOUIS - In an odd way, Gov. Bob Holden of Missouri may have done Senator John Kerry a big favor in August by losing a primary bid for a second term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOBERG, REGINA L.
description: BOBERG--Regina L., age 92, of Urbana died on Wednesday, September 15, 2004. She was born January 29, 1912 in Pittsburgh, PA to August and Magdalena (Farbacher) Eichner. She is survived by her daughter Therese (Edward) Young of Urbana; son Edward (Phyllis) Boberg of London, OH. Preceded in death by her parents, and her husband, Gerard C. Boberg. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, September 20, 2004 in St. Mary's Church. Burial will be in Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Rochester, NY. The WalterSchoedinger Funeral Home, A Dignity Memorial Provider,

title: Who Gets Inside the Ivory Tower?
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the 'listed at' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the state. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Williams Shows Why He's Better in the Game
description: Bernie Williams was back in center field yesterday afternoon, less than 14 hours after witnessing a distressing defeat as he sat on the bench for the first time against the Red Sox this season.

title: A Nostalgic France Looks to the Era of the Dunce Cap
description: PARIS, Sept. 18 - The rage of reality television in France this season has nothing do with surviving on a desert island or competing for a husband.

title: The Big Duck's Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Recording, if Not Watching
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week Ahead; ECONOMY
description: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise short-term interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 1.75 percent, when its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday. That would be the third rate increase since June, and probably not the last this year. Fed officials believe that interest rates need to climb considerably to prevent inflation. Edmund L. Andrews

title: The Season; Graphic Design
description: This season, good style is in the details, from cuff links to cuffed trousers.

title: For All Humankind
description: SURVEYING the packed dance floor of Luke & Leroy, a bar in Greenwich Village, Dan Crane, a musician who recently moved from Manhattan to Los Angeles, said, "This place reminds me of that Blur song that goes 'Girls who are boys who like boys to be girls who do boys.' L.A. clubs aren't this ambisexual."

title: Archdiocese Halts Bid for Housing Aid at Church It May Raze
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has withdrawn an application for a federal grant of nearly $7 million to build housing for the elderly on the site of St. Thomas the Apostle Church, a 97-year-old structure in Harlem that preservationists and some neighborhood residents say should not be demolished.

title: All God's Children
description: Samantha M. Shapiro's article (Sept. 5) on Biola University students and the complicated intersection between an evangelical worldview and the world itself was refreshing. Reporting in the secular news media that doesn't simply dismiss, deride or scoff at evangelicalism is hard to come by.

title: Corrections
description: A letter last Sunday about hurricane preparations referred incorrectly to the political effects of a failure to clean up after a Queens snowstorm in 1969. While the episode dramatized the depth of feeling against John V. Lindsay, who was then mayor of New York, he was re-elected later that year; he was not "soon out of a job."

title: 'April Fool's Day'
description: Ivan Dolinar was born on the first of April in 1948. Since hisparents did not want him to go through life as a Fool's Dayjoke, they registered his birthday as the second of April, inthe Nizograd Birth Registry in Croatia. His surly father gavethe baby the first name that popped into his head - the mostcommon name in the region and, for that matter, Europe. Nobodyelse in the family tree, however, bore that name, from whatMilan could tell, and that was a further advantage to choosingit, since he didn't feel particularly grateful to the tree.

title: Got a Beard? Don't Bother to Run
description: THE presidential election is a little over six weeks away, and neither candidate has eked out much of an advantage. We are facing a close election with much at stake, and seldom has the future seemed so filled with significant unknowns. But one thing is absolutely, indisputably clear: barring an astonishing personal grooming decision, the man who occupies the Oval Office for the next four years will not have a beard or mustache.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TASHKER, FRANK I.
description: TASHKER--Frank I. Passed away September 8, 2004 after several weeks of declining health in Mountain View, CA. Brother of the late Bea Kahn and Edna Erdheim. Loving father of Michael Tashker of Palo Alto, CA and proud grandfather of Jessica and Sara. Frank ably represented pubs and restaurants in New York for over 50 years. Have a good meal and a drink in his memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, JENNIE
description: SIMON--Jennie. 102, died September 16, 2004. Beloved mother of Helene and Michael Wolff and the late Florence Simon. Dear wife of the late Morris Simon. Cherished grandmother of three and great-grandmother of eight. Services Sunday morning at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave. For service time, call 212-769-4400. Shiva begins Tuesday.

title: Mets' Victory Features a Certain Masked Man
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 - Todd Zeile hunkered down behind home plate at PNC Park at 7:32 p.m. Saturday and was a catcher on 14 years 16 days of rest.

title: A Harbor Voyage, Encompassing the Years
description: OFF our bow the lights of New York begin to glow as we ply the Hudson this August evening, our 85-foot boat, the Festiva, heading downriver toward Lower Manhattan. To our starboard the clock on the Hoboken waterfront turns giant hands toward 8 o'clock. To our port, at Chelsea Piers, tiny sportsmen whack golf balls inside a cage.

title: Shakespeare, the Bard of Offal
description: "WE get about 80 pounds of the stuff each trip," explained Dan Nurczyk, the props manager for "Rose Rage," as he walked away from the Big Apple Meat Market on Ninth Avenue, toward Broadway, during the New York production's first meat run. Mr. Nurczyk's cart was loaded down with buckets of animal hearts, tongues, tripe and assorted other innards to be used for Edward Hall's shrunk-down version of the Shakespeare trilogy, "Henry VI," Parts 1, 2, and 3 -- set in a Victorian-era butcher shop, and now playing at the Duke on 42nd Street.

title: Landscapes Where The Sky Is the Limit
description: PURCHASE - IS April Gornik the J.M.W. Turner of contemporary American painting? Perhaps. Continuing but modifying in an original way the landscape tradition inherited from Dutch 17th-century artists, Ms. Gornik creates landscapes with dramatic atmospheric moments -- dark swelling clouds, lightning, rain squalls or a setting sun. Her message is one of deep awe and reverence for nature.

title: 'Duveen'
description: It is generally agreed that, of the select band of womenenterprising enough to be called collectors in the nineteenthcentury, Lady Charlotte Schreiber won hands down. Possessed ofconsiderable means, dauntless energy, and the zest for the chasewhich is the natural prerequisite for the making of greatcollections, Lady Charlotte knew no barriers when it came to her ownquarry. These included lace, fans, and playing cards, and, aboveall, ceramics. She loved china with a passion in the days whenhardly anyone knew enough to recognize Chelsea, Bow, Worcester, andDerby, or cared, leaving such treasures to be picked up in any oldjunk shop for derisory sums. The more she collected, in thosehalcyon days of the 1860s and 1870s, the more enthralled she becameby the chase. As her son Montague Guest wrote, "She hunted high andlow, through England and abroad; France, Holland, Germany, Spain,Italy, Turkey, all were ransacked; she left no stone unturned, nodifficulty, discomfort, fatigue, or hardship of travel daunted her,or turned her from her purpose, and she would come back, after weekson the Continent ... rich with the fruits of her expeditions"

title: Maria Alonso, Michael Dzuzelewski Jr.
description: Maria Laura Alonso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luis Alonso of Mendoza, Argentina, was married yesterday in Smithtown, N.Y., to Michael Stanley Dzuzelewski Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dzuzelewski Sr. of Cambria Heights, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Canter, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Smithtown Landing Country Club.

title: Mental Snapshots
description: To the Editor: Those "mental snapshots" that Roger Mummert so treasures in "Snapshots: Album or Cerebrum" (Aug. 29) have many advantages. They are completely portable, they require no equipment except what comes naturally, and they don't need to be processed at the corner drugstore. I am tempted to add that, unlike traditional photos, they will not fade or wrinkle with time. But I'm not so certain about that.

title: Katharine von Mehren, Bruce Emmert
description: Katharine von Mehren and Bruce Franklin Emmert were married yesterday at the summer house of the bride's father and stepmother in Chilmark, Mass., on Martha's Vineyard. The ceremony was led by the bride's uncle, Arthur T. von Mehren, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the wedding.

title: Exile in Guidesville?
description: Directions: Solve the following problem, using any available space on the page (or on your head) for scratch work.

title: The Remix; JUICY LIKE THE WOLF
description: Twenty years ago, John Taylor was the prettiest of a pretty-boy band. Now 44 and still bleached blond, the Duran Duran bassist lives in L.A. with his equally glam wife, Gela, who's even better known as half of the sweatsuit sensation Juicy Couture. This summer, when not recording a new album with the original Fab Five, Taylor was the muse-on-call for Juicy's first men's-wear collection, dreaming up cheeky logos like "Hollywood Redneck" and "Tokyo Maid Service" to splash across snug tees.

title: The Wait Continues At Touro Law School
description: IN July, when Lawrence Raful became Touro Law Center's first new dean in 19 years, part of the lure was the Huntington school's long-anticipated move to Central Islip.

title: A Developer Abandons Building Variance
description: A Morningside Heights developer who won a major battle with neighbors over the height of a new apartment building on the corner of Broadway and West 110th Street unexpectedly gave in last week in the face of continuing opposition.

title: 'This Is Burning Man'
description: A swirl of claims, some contradictory, runs through the endlessconversation that Burning Man engenders in its devotees anddetractors. You'll hear them over and over again at parties,jubilees, raves, fundraisers, late-night welding sessions, tugboatsoirees, intimate desert rituals: Burning Man creates artists;Burning Man is self-indulgent play; Burning Man renews lives;Burning Man destroys lives; Burning Man changes the world; BurningMan is a dangerous catastrophe.

title: Who Was Abused?
description: There are several ways to view the small white house on Center Street in Bakersfield, Calif. From one perspective it's just another low-slung home in a working-class neighborhood, with a front yard, brown carpeting, a TV in the living room. Now consider it from the standpoint of the Kern County district attorney's office: 20 years ago, this was a crime scene of depraved proportions. According to investigators, in the living room with brown carpeting and a TV, boys between the ages of 6 and 8 were made to pose for pornographic photos. On a water bed in the back bedroom, the boys were sodomized by three men, while a mother had sex with her own son.

title: Contributors
description: Lynn Hirschberg "I like writing about things that have a huge influence," says Lynn Hirschberg, an editor-at-large for The Times Magazine. For this issue, her Hollywood High column, Page 112, takes a look at the screen styles that have influenced the director Wes Anderson, while her profile of our cover subject, Clive Owen, Page 170, reveals a man on the verge. A veteran of Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, New York Magazine and Esquire, Hirschberg began her career with an interest in film and fashion -- "that point where commerce meets art." She has always gravitated toward people who are in control of their destiny, exemplified by the "Originals" style portfolio (Page 147), which she edited. (Her highly original dog, August, was the inspiration.) Hirschberg, far right with Quentin Tarantino, says: "My favorite people, period, are directors. I love anyone with a God complex!"

title: Lisa Wang, David Booker
description: Lisa Yu Wang and David Boyd Booker were married last evening at the Cornell Club in New York. Judge Sue Ann Hoahng, who is retired from the New York City Civil Court, officiated.

title: Bedford Street, Greenwich Village
description: MAXWELL GILLINGHAM-RYAN wants to change this city, one apartment at a time. An Oberlin-educated former Waldorf School teacher, Mr. Gillingham-Ryan has handcrafted himself a profession that teeters on the edge of the Next Big Thing.

title: Necessary Treatments
description: No one dies of AIDS. This is not denialism. The truth is that the AIDS virus does not kill you -- it simply degrades your immune system so that something else does. Quite often that something is tuberculosis. TB is the leading AIDS-related killer, perhaps responsible for half of all AIDS-related deaths. In some parts of Africa, 75 percent of people with H.I.V. also have TB.

title: Whose Recovery Is It, Anyhow?
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Matchup | Week 2
description: Minnesota Vikings (1-0) at Philadelphia Eagles (1-0) 9 p.m. tomorrow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISCH, ADELE
description: FISCH--Adele. February 14, 1919--September 16, 2004. Born in Brooklyn. Received Brooklyn College BA and MA. Assistant principal Shellbank JHS, Brooklyn. Married Mortimer Fisch, 1942. Three children: Ellen, Abner and David. On retiring, moved to Bethlehem, NH. Survived by daughter Ellen Fisch Karcinell (Kenneth Karcinell), son David Fisch (Patience O'Neil), granddaughter Sarah Fried (Greg Fried), grandson Joseph Karcinell, great granddaughter Alice Fried, and brother Louis Fisch.

title: Of Bangs, Whimpers And Notions of a Legacy
description: As Governor McGreevey's endgame takes shape and pundits ponder what he will leave behind, one word is on everyone's lips: legacy.

title: In a Struggle, Rutgers Downs Kent State
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Sept. 18 - RUTGERS 29, KENT STATE 21

title: INSIDE
description: Northern Ireland Talks Falter, Despite Pressure Three days of negotiations among the leaders of Northern Ireland's political parties failed to bridge crucial differences over how to share power and end paramilitary violence, despite pressure from the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland. But the prime ministers, Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland, said progress had been made. PAGE 20

title: The Zone; X-Man
description: As the tattoo across Dave Mirra's belly attests, the 30-year-old from Greenville, N.C., considers himself a "self made" man. But that doesn't mean that the extreme-sport star has a look that maintains itself. His daily ramp-riding regimen has afforded him a record-breaking 13 X-Game gold medals, but perhaps more coveted are his ridiculously cut exterior obliques -- hereafter known as the he-V. Fortunately, for those of us who aren't as self-made, there's exercise. Turn the page for a simple (we didn't say easy) routine devised by Chase Taylor, a trainer at Equinox. Practice every other day, and you, too, can acquire fab abs. STEFFIE NELSON

title: Tiny Doll, 90, Munchkin and Circus Actor, Is Dead
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 10 - Elly Annie Schneider, who was known for many years in the circus world and on the big screen as Tiny Earles, then Tiny Doll, and who played one of the Munchkin villagers in the film version of "The Wizard of Oz," died here on Monday. She was 90.

title: The Curing of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, TOLMACH, DOR OTHY (NEE LEFKOFSKY)
description: COLEMAN - TOLMACH -- Dor othy (nee Lefkofsky) of Brooklyn, on Wednesday September 15, 2004 after a short illness at age 90. She was the wife of the late Samuel Tolmach and the late Gerald Coleman, father of William Coleman, (Marjorie), grandmother of Rebekah and Sarah Coleman. Dorothy was born in Cleveland, Ohio and came to New York in 1934. She received her BA from Western Reserve College (now Case Western) and her MA from Teachers College at Columbia University. Professionally, she was an early childhood teacher, administrator and education professor for over 35 years. She was a member of the YPSL's in the 1930s and the Three Arrows Cooperative Society in Putnam Valley, New York for almost fifty years. She was a warm, caring person, a fighter for progressive causes and a devoted reader of The New York Times and the New Leader until her death. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, please make your contribution to the early childhood institution of your choice or to an organization supporting the election of John Kerry.

title: Who Gets Inside the Ivory Tower?
description: To the Editor:

title: Allison Silver, Marc Balinsky
description: Allison Bari Silver, a daughter of Sheryll and Ronald Silver of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Marc Stuart Balinsky, the son of Madeline and Dr. Warren Balinsky of Setauket, N.Y. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated at the Old Westbury Country Club in Old Westbury, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARDER, HENRY U.
description: HARDER--Henry U., 79, of Yarmouth, ME died at home on September 6, 2004 after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in NYC on March 9th, 1925, he was the son of Gertrude U. Harris and Lewis F. Harder. He lived for many years in Greenwich, CT before retiring to Maine. Upper Saranac Lake, NY was his summer retreat. Graduating from St. Marks School in Southboro, MA, 1943, he joined the Navy serving as Lt. j.g. and Naval Aviator. He graduated from Yale, Class of 1945W. Henry joined the insurance firm of Chubb & Son in July of 1948, became President in October of 1972, and was CEO from 1980-1988 when he retired. He served as a trustee of St. George's School for 20 years. Henry is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Calista Lincoln, five children: Fred and his wife, Karin, of Mercer Island, WA; Trudy Briggs and her husband Jim, of Pownal, ME; Calista Hollyer and her husband, Jan; Holly Catlin and her husband, Bruce; Maj. Henry U. Harder, Jr.,Vermont Air National Guard and his wife Natalie, all of Vermont. Henry was the proud grandfather of 14 grandchildren. Henry is survived by a brother, Philip, three sisters, Avery Kennedy, Cynthia Murray, Jenepher Parr and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by two brothers, Lewis and John. A memorial service took place in Yarmouth at St. Bartholomew's Church on September 11, 2004, a service will also take place next summer in the Adirondacks. In lieu of flowers, memorial remembrances can be sent to: St. Bartholomew's Church, 396 Gilman Rd, Yarmouth, ME 04096 or St. George's School, Newport, RI 02840.

title: Helping Fashion the Face of the City
description: SOME years ago, I moved from New York to Chicago on a 10-month fellowship. I packed a rental car until the bumpers threatened to kiss the tar, and filled the remaining pockets with a cat and a poster. The cat was for companionship in the bland suburban apartment I had leased. The poster was for "The Diva Is Dismissed," a one-woman play at the Public Theater. It presented the show's star, Jenifer Lewis, as a head in a field of shrieking chartreuse. The head wore a bouffant and looked ready to bite. Hustling for attention, striking simultaneous notes of harshness and beauty, "The Diva" captured the essence of my abandoned city and brightened my new one.

title: The Hardest-Working Woman in the TV Biz
description: IN her first scenes in the pilot of "LAX," NBC's new workplace drama, Heather Locklear as Harley Random pulls up to her office one sunny South California morning already exhausted. She is apparently still wearing her black thigh-slit party dress from the night before. A pair of sexy heels dangle from her hand as her bare feet step tentatively out onto hot morning pavement. There is a blur of an ankle tattoo, a record of a partying past. As she reluctantly drags herself into the office, we are quite formally reintroduced to her Locklearisms -- the side of her prime-time-famous bosom, her chunky blonde mane. Stepping into her private bathroom, she splashes cold water on her face and stares at her reflection with a look that seems to say, "Can I really go through with this routine one more time?"

title: 'This Is Burning Man': The Rite of Summer
description: THIS IS BURNING MAN The Rise of a New American Underground. By Brian Doherty. Illustrated. 304 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: The Remix; Hockney Players
