description: When the artist David Hockney and his then boyfriend, Peter Schlesinger, moved from Los Angeles to London in the late 1960's, England was still high on Carnaby Street. A hedonistic generation was grooving on swinging parties, illegal substances and all things gaudily hued. With his choppy helmet of bottle-white hair, oversize raccoon glasses, mismatched socks, canvas sneakers and cotton-candy checkered suits, Hockney (far left) married off-kilter aristocratic lan with free-spirited American ease. The likes of Gilbert and George, Cecil Beaton, Manolo Blahnik and Ossie Clark found his left-field aesthetic as pleasing as a Pimm's-spiked lemonade.

title: Page Two: Sept. 12-18; Is There a Family Resemblance?
description: Correction Appended

title: The Television Show That Thinks It's a Novel
description: BALTIMORE - AT one of the least likely business meetings ever, a dignified man holding a mug of tea addresses his sales staff, gathered in a funeral parlor. The employees are guys with names like Poot, Bodie and Shamrock; the funeral home is a front (their business only indirectly involves death). Their boss, the upwardly mobile, tea-sipping Stringer Bell, is telling them that although they have lost territory (that is, street corners), they can offset the loss with improved product (better drugs). At the same time, he insists on running the meeting according to Robert's Rules of Order. This results in lines like, "Yo, yo, String -- Poot did have the floor," and other far less polite interjections.

title: Unless F.C.C. Balks, Channel 9 Will Return to New York
description: THREE decades ago, Marsha Stern headed a group called the New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting. Its seemingly quixotic goal: To challenge the licenses of every commercial television station in New York, with the intent of getting one to move to underserved and overlooked New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, ETHYL BERMAN
description: JOSEPH--Ethyl Berman, died September 10, 2004. Loving wife of the late Dan, mother of the late Dana. All who knew her in Rutherford, Southbury and Old Tappan will miss her. Her daughter, Leslie Stewart of Piermont, NY, and granddaughter, Deborah Feinberg of Silver Spring, MD, wish to have her memory honored through contributions to the Hospice of your choice.

title: A Quicker Paper Swapper
description: IN the grand scheme of things, loading a fresh roll into a paper towel holder qualifies as one of life's lesser annoyances, the sort of minor irritation that Andy Rooney, the "60 Minutes" curmudgeon, might preface with his trademark line, "Don't you hate it when. . . ."

title: Swallowing the Elephant
description: The moment when the Republican Party lost black America can be given a date: Oct. 26, 1960. Martin Luther King Jr., arrested in Georgia during a sit-in, had been transferred to a maximum-security prison and sentenced to four months on the chain gang, without bail. As The Times reported, John F. Kennedy called Coretta King, expressing his concern. Richard Nixon didn't.

title: Pasadena's Metro
description: To the Editor: I read "Your Car's Here, on Track 2" (Aug. 29) about getting around Los Angeles by the new light rail system.

title: Tax Collector Hits the Road in New Haven
description: IF you are delinquent on your car taxes in New Haven, or driving a car that was stolen there, beware; the city is gunning for you in a new way.

title: What Becomes a Legend? Mystery
description: WHAT visitor to Ellis Island doesn't walk about pondering the mysteries and miseries of the brave immigrants who came before?

title: Real Men Don't Clean Bathrooms
description: MAN hunt mastodon. Woman sweep cave, suckle young.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BARKIN, JESSE H.
description: BARKIN--Jesse H. Always in our hearts and minds. With love and affection. Ruth, Elyse, Stephen and Madeline

title: With Friends Like Lesniak, Who Needs Letterman?
description: TRENTON - Whether you consider him a pillar of perseverance or simply a glutton for punishment, you have to marvel at Governor McGreevey's immeasurable capacity to endure ridicule.

title: Dalmatia 101
description: No man is an island, but at least one men's-wear line is: Brioni. The Italian suit maker nabbed its name from an archipelago off the Dalmatian coast that was a society playground in the 1930's (when it belonged to Italy) and the Yugoslav president Tito's private retreat in the 70's, where he entertained the likes of Elizabeth Taylor. But several wars and regime changes have tarnished the area's luster, which is why Umberto Angeloni, Brioni's chief executive, has spent the last three years working with the island's current owners, the Croatian government, to return it to five-star splendor.

title: Desperately Seeking Dick Cheney
description: Correction Appended

title: If We're Not Being Rescued, Let's All Start New Lives
description: WHEN ABC executives approached J.J. Abrams about making a series centered on plane crash survivors marooned on a distant atoll, he knew the concept could work for a mini-series -- but a whole season of episodes?

title: Why a Red Sox Fan Shouldn't Really Want His Team to End the World
description: You have a friend who is a Boston Red Sox fan. A good, loyal friend. A confidant you can pity.

title: Elizabeth Feeney, Brian Fortune
description: Elizabeth Cox Feeney, a daughter of Elizabeth and Bernard Feeney of Madison, Conn., was married there on Friday to Brian Howard Fortune, a son of Jeanne Burke of Glen Cove, N.Y., and Brian M. Fortune of Kings Park, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph F. Keough, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Margaret Church.

title: Easier to Drink Than to Spell
description: Few dry Basque whites, a category of wines awaiting discovery, rival the captivating 2003 Txakoli (pronounced cha-ko-LEE) from Bodegas Itsas Mendi, near Bilbao. Ana Martn, perhaps Spain's top female winemaker, has turned Hondarrabi Zuri grapes, unknown in America, into a tangy, subtle drink redolent of minerals and green apples. Anchovies, shrimp, clams and cod from the Bay of Biscay are great partners for it.

title: A Democratic Town, But a Republican Campus
description: While the town of Princeton may be overwhelmingly Democratic, the buildings on the campus of the local university there continue to have a Republican cast to them.

title: The Get; The Ticking Point
description: Watches get face time with rich 18-karat rose gold.

title: Ethics Panel Has Its Work Cut Out
description: FOR 26 years, Connecticut's Ethics Commission has administered and enforced the state's code of ethics, issuing advisory opinions and levying thousands of dollars in fines for violations. But it took a scandal that brought down a governor and, most recently, the firing of its executive director to thrust the agency into the spotlight. Now, many people, including Gov. M. Jodi Rell, are eager to see whether its nine-member citizen panel can help restore the public's faith in state government.

title: Hear Their Voices
description: After decades of sexual crimes by priests erupted in the ghastly scandal of the last three years, the Roman Catholic Church has taken some decisive steps to repair the damage. Abusers have been removed, victims compensated and church assets sold. A few badly scarred dioceses have received new leaders chosen for their sincerity, humility and willingness to be tough on bad priests and gentle with victims and their families.

title: Rising Market Helps End a Standoff
description: IT is perhaps the ultimate New York developer's fantasy: finding a classic 12-story prewar Park Avenue building plus penthouse and restoring it from an empty shell into the sort of grand 4,200-square-foot apartments that haven't been built in a generation.

title: Corrections
description: The Strategies column last Sunday, about a study of initial public offerings, included an erroneous reference to the performance of Yahoo. Although the study's author, Prof. Jay R. Ritter, mentioned that company among those achieving substantial commercial success before they went public, Yahoo had sales of $1.4 million in the 12 months before it did so in 1996 -- less than the $50 million the study used as a threshold for such success.

title: PHOTO-OP
Nancy Needham, James Liddell
description: Nancy McKeown Needham, the daughter of Pamela Giles Bailey and the stepdaughter of William W. Bailey of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last evening to James Finley Liddell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Finley Liddell of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. John Maloney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: The Nudist Buddhist Borderline-Abusive Love-In
description: LOS ANGELES - DAVID O. RUSSELL had developed something of a reputation. The screenwriter and director of "Flirting With Disaster" and "Three Kings" had become known for smart, wildly original movies, and for attracting top actors despite relatively modest budgets. But he was also known for alienating some of those actors while shooting (most notoriously when he and George Clooney ended up in a fistfight on the set of "Three Kings.") For his next movie, "I [heart] Huckabees," Mr. Russell was determined to chart a happier course.

title: The Remix; Dalmatia 101
description: No man is an island, but at least one men's-wear line is: Brioni. The Italian suit maker nabbed its name from an archipelago off the Dalmatian coast that was a society playground in the 1930's (when it belonged to Italy) and the Yugoslav president Tito's private retreat in the 70's, where he entertained the likes of Elizabeth Taylor. But several wars and regime changes have tarnished the area's luster, which is why Umberto Angeloni, Brioni's chief executive, has spent the last three years working with the island's current owners, the Croatian government, to return it to five-star splendor.

description: To the Editor:

title: On the Parquet at El Morocco
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Another Unhappy Flier
description: Instead of awarding frequent flier miles, Thomas G. Plaskett, former chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation, now collects them. "I must have about three million," he said, "mostly on American," which is the main airline serving Dallas, where he runs a consulting firm, Fox Run Capital Associates.

title: If at First You Don't Succeed, Believe Harder
description: Correction Appended

title: John Waters, Selma Blair and Johnny Knoxville
description: HOLLYWOOD - THEY say Americans prolong adolescence, which may explain the appeal of John Waters. He's the kind of director whose films vault right over good taste and sexual norms and celebrate gross-out humor, wooden acting and bad wigs. His career spans 40 years and 16 films, one of which inspired the hit musical "Hairspray." On Friday his latest film, "A Dirty Shame," opens nationwide. A romp about people who suffer concussions and find themselves possessed by uncontrollable sexual urges, it stars Tracey Ullman, Johnny Knoxville and Selma Blair. The film received an NC-17 rating for its "pervasive sexual content," so adolescents may have trouble getting to see it.

title: Westchester: Using a Legend's Plans, 53 Years Later
description: MAHOPAC - "HEY honey, we just bought an island," Joseph Massaro told his surprised wife, Barbara, one afternoon in 1996. The acquisition, he explained, was part of a swap: an 11-acre island on Lake Mahopac here in exchange for a home the couple had for sale.

title: A Home for the Grange
description: A DISAPPOINTED politician, you know, is very apt to take refuge in a garden," a melancholic Alexander Hamilton advised a friend in 1802, two years before his fatal duel with Vice President Aaron Burr. His marathon feuds with the Jeffersonians had taken their toll. "Accordingly, I have purchased about 30 acres nine miles from town, have built a house, planted a garden, and entered upon some other simple improvements." By christening this house in Harlem Heights the Grange, the new owner paid tribute to the Hamilton clan's ancestral home in Scotland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBUD, RUTH, JEAN
description: EISENBUD--Ruth-Jean. Age 91. Loved wife of Leonard, mother of David, mother-inlaw of Monika, grandma of Daniel and Alina, great grandma of Shannon, sister of Annette Rubinstein. Professor at NYU and Adelphi, psychoanalyst whose work was radiant with poetry and use of dreams.

title: The Zone; Buzz Stop
description: The barber pole outside Neighborhood Barbers, Eric Uvaydov's East Village shop, isn't an ironic prop. Uvaydov, the Russian-born son of a barber, has old-school skills with clippers, a straight razor and scissors that keep his three seats filled with designers, magazine editors and models. Thanks to his location in Hipster Central, he's also become a de facto Mohawk expert. Neighborhood Barbers, at 439 East Ninth Street, opened four months ago, after enough of Uvaydov's regulars at Royal on St. Marks Place -- like the designer John Bartlett and the photographer David LaChappelle (a fan of the hot shave) -- persuaded him to go out on his own. Despite its popularity, the shop welcomes walk-ins, and the average wait is 20 minutes. "I love the democracy of a barber; there's no place for attitude," says Bartlett, who relies on Uvaydov for a traditional cut "with style." Not one to blow money on salons these days, Bartlett would be hard pressed to beat the price: a shave and cut costs $20. STEFFIE NELSON

title: Anna Netrebko, at the Top but Still Rising
description: ANNA NETREBKO: 'SEMPRE LIBERA' Anna Netrebko, soprano; Mahler Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Claudio Abbado. Deutsche Grammophon 474 800-2, CD; 474 881-2, SACD.

title: Ball Four! Take Your Measly Base, Slugger
description: Tom Seaver had seen enough. After watching Barry Bonds draw yet another somniferous walk two years ago, Seaver vented into his microphone, but not about what many viewers surely expected.

title: A Hearty Return, From Starter to Dessert
description: ROSEMARY & SAGE in Old Saybrook had been open for only a year and a half when a car drove through the window fronting Route 1 in the middle of the night and closed the place down for almost 12 months. The restaurant reopened this year at the end of June.

title: The Remix; THE LIFE AQUATIC
description: There is new hope for finding Nemo. The Italian architect Giancarlo Zema, 30, has designed the Trilobis 65, a multilevel floating home with a submerged glass room that allows for endless hours of Sea World sightseeing.

title: Merchant Class
description: Rarely a day passes that Unesco, the World Wildlife Fund, the National Audubon Society or some other well-intentioned organization doesn't issue a press release about another endangered site, species, race or language. To their lists of vanishing temples, butterflies, tribes and tongues, I'd like to add independent men's stores.

title: About American Culture
description: About American Culture TOMORROW -- A black-tie dinner at the Plaza will benefit the programs of the Institute for International Education, which administers the Fulbright program and works to educate international students about American culture and values during their graduate studies here. Drinks at 6:30 and dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $1,000, from (914)834-2868.

title: The Hand-Marked Ballot Wins for Accuracy
description: After the pandemonium over dimpled and pregnant chads in the 2000 election, nearly everyone agreed it was time to rethink old vote-counting ways. But the stampede to touch-screen voting was not inevitable.

title: 'The Inner Circle': The Joy of Sex Research
description: THE INNER CIRCLE By T. Coraghessan Boyle. 418 pp. Viking. $25.95.

title: Who Gets Inside the Ivory Tower? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Works From the Trove of an Adventurous Collector
description: DOUGLAS S. CRAMER, 73, has been collecting art all his life. A television producer of such hit series as "The Brady Bunch," "The Love Boat," "Batman" and "Dynasty," he began collecting museum posters as a teenager, then prints while living in New York in the 1950's, before moving to Los Angeles, where he collected paintings and sculpture by blue-chip pop and abstract artists.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 15 about the Inca ruins at Machu Picchu, in Peru, misspelled the name of the author of "The White Rock," an Andean travelogue. An e-mail message received on Sept. 10 from the book's author, Hugh Thomson, pointed out that his surname is not Thompson.

title: 'On the Wing'
description: Trailing steady electronic beeps from the tiny transmitter glued tothe base of her tail feather, the peregrine quartered tentatively upPadre Island's barrier beach. A tundra falcon, a barren-groundhunter born in the Arctic, she had for the past two weeks cruisedwith increasing randomness up and down Texas's offshore islands,seemingly reluctant to leave the windswept flats for the aliengreenery of the mainland. But today the springtime stream oftropical air welling in from the Gulf of Mexico had gripped her inits northerly flow, and after a final sideways cast along the surfshe swept inland, away from the sea.

title: Still Waters Bring Peace
description: In excursion guides, the word "outdoor" is often followed by "adventure," these days with its more contemporary neighbor, "extreme," spliced between the two. But Kathy Kenley, a naturalist and author, has chosen a different tack. Ms. Kenley wrote "Quiet Water New Jersey: Canoe and Kayak Guide" (Appalachian Mountain Club Press), for contemplative spirits not unlike herself. The book, split into three sections to cover northern, central and southern New Jersey's kayak-worthy lakes, ponds and reservoirs, serves mostly as an insider's guide to 50 of the state's tranquility hotspots.

title: For Many in Missouri, Picking a President Is More a Matter of Values Than Policy
description: ST. CHARLES, Mo. - Tom Ampleman, a blue-collar union member who lives near this suburb just outside St. Louis, says he voted for Bill Clinton twice and then Al Gore, but he is now grappling with deep religious misgivings about the Democratic Party.

title: Historical Museums And Their Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: The Redeemer

title: Trading Up
description: In a campaign that has been devoted to Vietnam, Iraq and the economy, there is one issue that John Kerry would do well to bring up, an issue that has received little attention this political season: trade. I would love to see Senator Kerry announce that if elected he will immediately convene a summit meeting on international trade and globalism to be held in Columbus, Ohio. He should announce that the meeting will be an annual event and that he intends to invite American business, political, and education leaders to join him.

title: 'On the Wing': You Are What They Eat
description: ON THE WING To the Edge of the Earth With the Peregrine Falcon. By Alan Tennant. Illustrated. 304 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Valerie Rockefeller, Steven Wayne
description: Valerie Blanchette Rockefeller, the daughter of Senator John D. Rockefeller IV and Mrs. Rockefeller of Charleston, W.Va., and Washington, and Steven William Wayne, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph William Wayne Jr. of Oak Brook, Ill., were married yesterday at the bride's parents' home in Washington. The Rev. William E. Calbert, a Baptist minister, officiated in a ceremony led by Richard C. Tibbetts, a friend of the bridegroom's.

title: The Modernist
description: "Sometimes you see fashion, and you could throw up," Jil Sander says with a shrug and a sigh. In New York for a 48-hour business trip, the German designer is seated in the rear of a Lincoln Town Car on one of those May days when the weather plays bait-and-switch and Manhattan is plunged into stifling summer before one has even registered spring. Despite the heat and an atmosphere that adheres to the skin like sooty cling wrap, New Yorkers -- in this particular part of Midtown, right across from the Cond Nast building -- seem to be doing their best to keep up the civic bargain. That is, they are decked out with a vengeance, with a dedication and passion -- snub-toed shoes and big belts and Thom Browne suits, with trousers hemmed to heights not seen since the days of Pee-wee Herman -- that demonstrate to the truly committed that dressing oneself is a competitive sport with no room for amateurs.

title: Joanna Pruess, Bob Lape
description: Joanna Pruess, a food and travel writer and a consultant to the food industry, and Bob Lape, a restaurant critic, are to be married today at the Central Park Boathouse in Manhattan. Justice Michael L. Pesce of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn will officiate. Judith Epstein, a California Superior Court judge in San Francisco and the twin sister of the bride, also took part in the ceremony.

title: He's Got Facts, She's Fascinated
description: He's Got Facts, She's Fascinated

title: The New Romantics
description: Men have never been good with the "L" word, which is why God invented the mix tape. And John Cusack movies. But music-loving Lotharios can now retire Bon Jovi's "I'll Be There for You." A group of finger-pickin' poets -- the newbadours, shall we? -- are reclaiming the label "pop" for anyone who thinks a love song needn't include the words "heart," "eye" and "sky."

title: PHOTO-OP
'The Good Fight'
description: My father had a pithy way to make a potent point. He describedthe two basic economic systems as follows: "Socialism isgovernment ownership of the means of production, whilecapitalism is the business ownership of the means ofgovernment."

title: Bush Says Questions About Guard Memos Used by CBS 'Need to Be Answered'
description: Correction Appended

title: The Week Ahead; ELECTION
description: Indonesia goes to the polls Monday to select a president in an election between two well-known figures: the incumbent, Megawati Sukarnoputri, and Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, her former security minister. The world's most populous Muslim country, Indonesia has made a quick transition to democracy since the dictator of three decades, General Suharto, resigned under pressure in 1998. Jane Perlez

title: Authority Is Approved for Sanctions Against Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 18 - The Security Council passed a resolution on Sudan on Saturday holding out the threat of sanctions on the country's leaders and its oil industry if the government fails to curb ethnic violence and setting up an inquiry into whether that violence constitutes genocide.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WINIKOFF, ELLEN
description: WINIKOFF--Ellen. Dearest daughter, sister, aunt. On your birthday and everyday, we think of you, miss you, love you. Marcia, Stanley, Linda, Amy, Kenny, Sami and El

title: A Mural of Strength, but for Its Invisibility
description: The metallic-looking mural of four chiseled men working on an oil rig is as striking for its location as for the quality of the art: it is affixed to the back wall of a dank, cluttered storage room under a school library in Soundview, the Bronx.

title: Laura Schachter, Matthew Hertzog
description: Laura Melissa Schachter and Matthew O'Malley Hertzog were married yesterday at the Water Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Allan Lokos, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Alyssa Stadlin, Robert Kuppersmith
description: Alyssa Paige Stadlin, the daughter of Gale Salz of Watchung, N.J., and Barry S. Stadlin of Montville, N.J., was married last evening in Woodbury, N.Y., to Robert Marc Kuppersmith, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel Kuppersmith of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Neil Kurshan performed the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center.

title: Selling Small Specialties, Chain Expands in a Big Way
description: ON June 27, 2003, there was not even one Laila Rowe store. The next day, there was one. Now there are eight. By the end of the year, there are expected to be 10.

title: Bookshelf: Children's Books in Brief
description: THE REMEMBERING STONE. By Barbara Timberlake Russell. Illustrated by Claire B. Cotts. Melanie Kroupa/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 5 to 8) Ana's mother wears a locket holding pictures of her parents who live far away in Costa Rica, and she owns a box of family treasures as well. Ana dreams of flying like a blackbird to visit family in a country she has never seen.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Drivers' Licenses and Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking a Stand Against Mushy Bananas
description: Unlike many a stubborn toddler, one thing can be said about the residents of Washington Heights and Inwood: they apparently eat their vegetables.

title: Rainy Days and Rock Opera
description: THE Fiery Furnaces have had a year that most bands can only dream of. They released their first album, "Gallowsbird's Bark," last September, and it quickly became the kind of record that it was shrewd to name-drop. Despite endless comparisons to the White Stripes (largely because the Fiery Furnaces are a brother-sister duo playing a nervy strain of folk-blues), the band stood on its own; if anything, it sounded like Patti Smith fronting Dylan the very week he went electric. Just last month, the band -- which headlines on Saturday at the Bowery Ballroom -- was nominated for the Shortlist Music Prize, a $10,000 award founded in 2001 that honors innovative underground music.

title: Elisabeth Newton, Matthew Anton
description: Elisabeth Dundas Newton and Matthew Douglas Anton were married yesterday at Herondale Farm in Ancramdale, N.Y. Guy McCloskey, a minister of Soka Gakkai International U.S.A., a Buddhist lay organization, officiated.

title: Autopsy Inconclusive in Death of 3-Year-Old Boy
description: In an autopsy conducted over several hours yesterday morning, city medical examiners were unable to determine the cause of death of a 3-year-old boy whose father had buried and later exhumed his body.

title: Who Gets Inside the Ivory Tower?
description: To the Editor:

title: FUND-RAISER ADMITS FRAUD
description: A Democratic Party fund-raiser pleaded guilty Wednesday to mail fraud in connection with extorting payoffs from a landowner in exchange for promises of help in settling a dispute with state officials. The fund-raiser, David M. D'Amiano, admitted to extorting $40,000 in contributions from the landowner, Mark Halper, and had sought $60,000 more from him. Mr. D'Amiano told the court on Wednesday that he had "prompted" the governor to use the code word Machiavelli in a conversation to signal that officials were on board with the scheme. Christopher J. Christie, the United State attorney for New Jersey, said the plea contradicted Mr. McGreevey's statement that his use of the word had been innocent. Ronald Smothers

title: 'The Finishing School': So Young, So Devilish
description: THE FINISHING SCHOOL By Muriel Spark. 181 pp. Doubleday. $16.95.

title: Think New York Is Expensive? Try Tokyo or Paris
description: Brace yourself, America. Breathe deeply. This may be a jolt to the national ego. Americans, after all, pride themselves on having the biggest, most expensive of everything, whether it's cars or houses or buckets of Coke.

title: A Better New York, Dumpling by Dumpling
description: The dumpling shacks of Chinatown are, as their name might suggest, typically tiny odorous places. Interior design is not necessarily an option when a hearty order of your primary product (five pieces) costs only a dollar.

title: LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR POST PROPOSED
description: Assembly Speaker Albio Sires has proposed legislation to establish a lieutenant governor's office. Currently, the president of the State Senate serves as acting governor in the event the governor is unable to serve, but Mr. Sires and some other legislators said that there was too much uncertainty in the current rules governing the succession. Under the proposal, the lieutenant governor and the governor would share the ticket, and the lieutenant governor would be eligible to head a state agency or perform other duties assigned by the governor. Because it would require a change in the state Constitution, the legislation must be approved by voters and by houses of the Legislature. John Sullivan

title: Who Gets Inside the Ivory Tower?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hardcover Fiction
A Crime That Isn't Banal
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Sprinkler System Can Save Your Life
description: ACCORDING to the Home Fire Sprinkler Coalition, an educational organization based in Quincy, Mass., property and casualty insurance companies offer discounts of up to 15 percent on fire insurance policy premiums when a home is protected by a residential fire sprinkler system.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENFELD, RON
description: ROSENFELD -- Ron. Died September 12, 1997. A long time gone, but never forgotten. You're always in my heart. With love, Tonelah

title: The Get; Slim Pickings
description: This fall, rep ties are so skinny, they verge on manorexic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVY, RENEE B.
description: LEVY--Renee B. You remain in our lives as a strong presence we embrace. Liz, Jerry, Peter, Max, Ruth

title: Add Lubovitch to Limn. Stir.
description: WHERE should a dance company turn for new works after the death of the choreographer who has been its raison d'tre? Jos Limn died in 1972. Afterward, Carla Maxwell, the artistic director of the troupe that bears his name, decided not to form a repository of dances by Limn and his contemporaries but instead to reach out to newer choreographers-- even ones who don't quite follow Limn's heroic, lyrical, male-centric tradition. Her choices have been diverse, including Daniel Nagrin, a craggily individualistic American solo artist, and Susanne Linke, a German choreographer known especially for the power and intense imagery of her dances for women.

title: The Scion Also Rises
description: Benot Vuitton has some serious baggage to carry. Even for an athletically built 26-year-old who stands about 6 feet 2 inches, he feels the burden of being the only member of his generation to work for the family business -- the multibillion-dollar luxury-goods empire named after his great-great-great-grandfather Louis Vuitton, who founded it in 1854. But if Benot is saddled with the weight of expectation, he totes it like a carry-on.

title: Baghdad's Strong Man Struggles to Keep His Grip
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - AYAD ALLAWI will have his right wrist in a cast when he arrives in the United States this week for his first visit as Iraq's interim prime minister, and it will provide the 59-year-old neurosurgeon with a powerful talking point. Asked about the wrist in an interview here as he prepared to leave for London, New York and Washington, Dr. Allawi joshed: "I've been shooting people, didn't you know?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIESEN, MAE (NEE HALPERIN)
description: WIESEN--Mae (nee Halperin). Died Friday, September 17 in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Loving mother of the late Dorothy Sokolski and David Wiesen, PhD. Loving grandmother of Pearl, Joy, Rachel, Seth and Jonathan. Motherin-law of Ellen Wiesen. Sister of Berenice Adams. Devoted sister-in-law and aunt, proud great-grandmother. Graveside service Sunday, September 19, 2:00 P.M. at Union Field Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York.

title: All God's Children
description: Does anyone else see the logical failure in Biola University's strategy of converting the world to Christianity through young women who feel the need to pray for the Lord's help before exposing themselves to the exotic life experiences of the local coffee-shop waitress? Shame on the parents for crippling their own children. And shame on Biola University for charging $20,000 a year merely to reinforce parental beliefs and prepare their youth for the intellectual challenges of first-century nomadic goat herding.

title: Calling All 'Jeopardy!' Purists: It's Time to Fight Back
description: A year ago, "Jeopardy!" dropped its 20-year policy of retiring undefeated champions after five games. The result was the invincible Ken Jennings, winner of 48 straight games and roughly $1.6 million as of Friday's broadcast. This is longer, according to the show's spokesman, than anyone has ever played any game show. Even Alex Trebek, the host, seems tired of him.

title: Nassau Fights Arrival of Rabid Raccoons
description: A STRAIN of raccoon-borne rabies spreading through New York State as well as other parts of the country and Canada appears to be gaining a foothold on Long Island, where rabid raccoons were unknown until this summer.

title: Sole Mate
description: Medium Footwear Josh Rubin, a blogger and designer based in New York, maintains a Web site he calls Cool Hunting, a regularly updated catalog of things (sneakers, gadgets, household products, etc.) that he finds interesting or inspiring. Not long ago he posted an item about Medium Footwear, a small shoe company founded by designers and "targeting Cultural Creatives -- a class of people who are responsible for designing and communicating many of the products and services you use today." Rubin confessed that he had actually been hip to Medium for about eight months but had held off telling his Web audience because he "wanted them to be my own little secret."

title: In Galveston, Tex.
description: Galveston, a laid-back city on an island two miles offshore in the Gulf of Mexico, has had a sometimes contentious relationship with the waters that wash up against it. This was where lvar Nez Cabeza de Vaca was shipwrecked in 1528, the start of an odyssey that he turned into oneof the New World's great travelogues.

title: Goodbye (Again), Norma Jean
description: Like any number of male intellectuals, Arthur Miller is not always wise when the subject turns to women. His "After the Fall" opened on Broadway in 1964, and many viewers considered it offensive. They could not understand why a playwright known for his lofty principles, for his famously sturdy and unshakable conscience, would have depicted his former wife so harshly. Marilyn Monroe was no longer alive to protest the character of Maggie, a popular singer who is addicted to pills and tyrannizes her husband with her implacable demands.

title: Ellen Dracos, Jeffrey Lemming
description: Ellen Patricia Dracos and Jeffrey Lynn Lemming were married last evening by the Rev. Troy Bryant, a United Methodist minister, at the Great Waters Golf Club in Greensboro, Ga.

title: A Legacy in Vinyl, Ever More Fragile
description: ROGER ROBERGE'S store, Mooncurser Records, took its name from the New England term for scavengers who plundered ships that ran aground on dark, moonless nights.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about celebrity photographers misspelled the name of an actor who has had problems with them. He is Tobey Maguire, not Toby McGuire.

title: The Get; The Need for Tweed
description: Rub elbow patches with a host of great Scots. no Ph.D. required.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IN THE SHADOW OF THE ARK By Anne Provoost. Translated by John Nieuwenhuizen. Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic, $17.95. (Ages 14 and up)

title: Lake Ontario Ferry Ceases Service
description: The fast ferry between Rochester and Toronto has shut down, with no indication of when it will resume service. The privately owned Canadian American Transportation System halted service Sept. 8 after less than three months.

title: Bling Dynasty
description: Move over, Puffy! Every time I see Sean Combs, he flashes that rock at me (and I think, I must remember to take my D&G shades to his show). But even his boldest bling is nothing compared to the jewels of my fashion heroes: the Indian maharajahs. The raj princes were the last male peacocks to understand the real power of gems.

title: New Children's Hospital Opens at Medical Center
description: The new $147 million Maria Fareri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla officially opened Tuesday.

title: The Zone; The Afterglow
description: Now that you're cut like Dave Mirra, the restof your body deserves pampering.

title: Maine Through Artists' Eyes
description: SOMETIMES New York can be so stifling that even a caterpillar will resort to extreme measures to get out of town. Weary of Manhattan's crowds and summer humidity, my old friend Paul Minden and I piled into my Volkswagen on a recent Sunday morning and headed north, far north, for a two-day sojourn on remote Monhegan Island, a rocky scrap of land and longtime artists' colony 10 miles off the tip of St. George Peninsula in Maine. We had not been on the road for more than three minutes before a fuzzy butterfly larva leapt acrobatically from an overhanging tree on 34th Street and landed on the hood of our car. This furry adventurer appeared to want in, so at the next red light, Paul dashed outside and scooped up our fellow traveler in a coffee cup. The road trip was on.

title: The Icing on the Cake
description: There is a bumper crop of brooches this season, and for shoppers who are too busy to do the pinning themselves, designers are offering clothes and accessories with jeweled pins already in place.

title: The Work of Eddie Adams
description: Eddie Adams, a photojournalist whose half-century of work was defined by a photo of a communist guerrilla being executed in a Saigon street during the Vietnam War, died on Sunday.

title: Emmy Awards: Red-Carpet Fashion
description: The nominees and winners of the 56th Annual Emmy Awards on the red carpet.

title: Winners of the 2004 Emmy Awards
description: HBO dominated at the 56th Annual Emmy Awards on Sunday, with 11 awards for "Angels in America" and honors for "The Sopranos" and "Sex and the City."

title: The Story Behind 'The Plot Against America'
description: Philip Roth's new novel, ''The Plot Against America,'' which will be published by Houghton Mifflin next month, imagines an America in which the 1940 presidential election resulted not in a third term for Franklin D. Roosevelt but in a victory for a Republican ticket headed by Charles A. Lindbergh. The Book Review asked Roth to write an essay about his new book and how he came to write it.

title: Words, Words Everywhere, but Only Absurdity to Drink
description: Presidential elections are always a joy for students of the uses and abuses of language. This fall it's like Christmas every day. For comic relief from dispiriting contemplation of this phenomenon, theatergoers may want to check out Eugne Ionesco's "Bald Soprano," now in revival at the Atlantic Theater Company, where it is paired with the playwright's more sinister exercise in absurdity, "The Lesson."

title: You Buy, They Spy
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: ON ADVERTISING : Grey sale marks end of an era
The House's Fear of Tom DeLay
description: The House ethics committee, ever the Capitol's hibernating watchdog, has been dithering for months about allegations that the majority leader, Tom DeLay, abused his office when he engineered the gerrymander of Texas House seats to cushion his Republican edge in Congress. The committee should have at least approved a formal inquiry by now, but the latest reports indicate that the issue will soon be deep-sixed as the Republican Congress shows no appetite for investigating Mr. DeLay, one of Washington's most feared and bare-knuckled partisans.

title: Bush's Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: Kerry Says Iraq War Raises Questions on Bush's Judgment
description: Senator John Kerry said today that the war in Iraq was a "profound diversion" from the war on terror and the fight against Osama bin Laden, and he asserted that President Bush's approach to the conflict had weakened national security instead of strengthening it.

title: Some Microsoft Customers Will Get to See Office Code
description: Microsoft plans to announce today that it will give dozens of governments and international agencies access to the programming code in its Office desktop software, including word processing, spreadsheet, presentation and e-mail programs.

title: Missing Children in Westchester Are Found Safe; Father Is Dead
description: The three children whose father was accused of kidnapping them after fatally shooting their mother in Westchester County were found safe last night, the police said. Hours later, their father was found dead.

title: Kerry Pulls Ads From Some States as Spending Is Limited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - Senator John Kerry, who was advertising in 20 states earlier this summer, had hoped by now to be playing on a broader canvas that included more states that President Bush won in 2000.

title: Foundation's Ex-PresidentMisused Funds, Chief Says
description: Correction Appended

title: Workers Face Difficult Choices as Airlines Seek Concessions
description: Leonard Robinson, who put in 30 years as a mechanic at Pan American World Airways, has a message for his counterparts at US Airways, Delta, United and other struggling airlines pressing their workers for concessions: do not wait until it is too late.

title: How Should We Deal With North Korea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Effort to Train New Iraqi Army Is Facing Delays
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - Three months into its new mission, the military command in charge of training and equipping Iraqi security forces has fewer than half of its permanent headquarters personnel in place, despite having one of the highest-priority roles in Iraq.

title: Eddie Adams, Journalist Who Showed Violence of Vietnam, Dies at 71
description: Eddie Adams, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalist and combat photographer who produced one of the most riveting images of the Vietnam War, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Festival Long on Daring if Short on Lalawood
description: TORONTO, Sept. 18 - The closing attraction of the 2004 Toronto International Film Festival was "Jiminy Glick in Lalawood," a surpassingly goofy comedy that takes place at (and was partly shot during) the 2003 film festival.

title: New York gains ground in bid for 2012 Games
Competing for DVD Supremacy
description: IF you thought the battle over videocassette formats -- VHS or Betamax -- was the technology war to end all others, think again.

title: Varitek Can't Buy a Hit in the Bronx This Year
description: The image of Jason Varitek's catcher's mitt shoved menacingly into the face of Alex Rodriguez has come to symbolize the Red Sox' resurgence. Varitek, Boston's catcher, set off the July 24 brawl with the Yankees at Fenway Park, awakening a team that seemed set on stumbling through the end of the season mired in mediocrity.

title: Israel Launches Airstrike in Gaza City
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 A An Israeli airstrike tonight in Gaza City, the second in as many days, killed two militants in the Islamic faction Hamas and wounded at least six bystanders, Palestinians said.

title: Portrait of George Bush in '72: Unanchored in Turbulent Time
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 17 - Nineteen seventy-two was the year George W. Bush dropped off the radar screen.

title: Users Find Too Many Phish in the Internet Sea
description: You can be whatever you want to be on the Internet -- even if you want to be Citibank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, JENNIE
description: SIMON -- Jennie. Congrega tion Or Zarua mourns the loss of its member, Jennie Simon. My the family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Daniel J. Beller, President

title: Coughlin Rules, but at What Cost to Giants?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. - THE Giants won their home opener yesterday.

title: In Ethnic Tinderbox, Fear of Revenge for School Killings
description: KARTSA, Russia, Sept. 19 - As grief begins to mutate into anger two weeks after the mass killings in Beslan, this drab little town not far away waits in fear for possible reprisals.

title: CBS News Concludes It Was Misled on National Guard Memos, Network Officials Say
description: After days of expressing confidence about the documents used in a "60 Minutes" report that raised new questions about President Bush's National Guard service, CBS News officials have grave doubts about the authenticity of the material, network officials said last night.

title: Samsung Ramps Up Advertising
description: SAMSUNG Electronics is tired of being dissed on American shores.

title: Correction
Paid Notice: Deaths   URSO, RUTH (TARLOW)
description: URSO--Ruth (Tarlow). Of Clearbrook, Monroe Township, NJ (formerly of Brooklyn and Massapequa), on Friday, September 17, 2004, age 94. Predeceased by her cherished husband Paul Urso. Survived by her beloved sister, Julia Hilfer, nephews, nieces and friends. For information, A.S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 North Main St, Cranbury, NJ.

title: Both a Borrower and a Lender Be
description: SHARING among siblings is expected in most families. By passing around everything from socks to sports equipment, children save their parents the cost of duplicating a great many of life's necessities.

title: MediaTalk; A Flirtation in Ethics Leaves Some Matters Utterly Unmentioned
description: Correction Appended

title: Seven Turnovers Do in the Redskins
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19 - The Washington Redskins were struggling to find something positive to take from their 20-14 loss to the Giants on Sunday, and this is what they came up with: They still had a chance to win with less than two minutes remaining despite committing seven turnovers and seven penalties and dropping innumerable passes.

title: 5th-Round Draft Pick Gives Jets' Secondary Some Sizzle
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 - Six weeks ago, the rookie Erik Coleman hoped to make the Jets' roster on special teams.

title: The Weather Makes Way for a Reunion
description: One of the best outdoor concerts of the summer took place on Saturday, at the last possible moment, as a drizzly afternoon gave way to the year's first chilly autumn night. The concert, starring the reunited Fugees, was billed as a "block party" by its organizer, the comedian Dave Chappelle. But it was also -- perhaps mainly -- a movie set: the director Michel Gondry was recording the whole thing for a concert film, which helps explain both the impressive lineup and the slow pacing.

title: Dancers and Performers Honored at the Bessies
description: New York dance had its annual gathering of the clan on Friday night at the Joyce Theater with the New York Dance and Performance Awards ceremony, dance's equivalent to the Oscars and Tonys. Better known as the Bessies, named after Bessie Schonberg, a choreography teacher who was a mentor to many, the awards carry prizes of $500 to $1,000. The event itself usually provides madcap talk and performing by downtown artists. This year, the 20th, the ceremony seemed a little more sober, with several poignantly eloquent acceptance speeches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLLYER, NORMAN S., P.E.
description: COLLYER--Norman S., P.E. Died September 18, in NC. Beloved husband to Helen for 67 years. Loving father to Gail and Linda, grandfather and great-grandfather.

title: Getting Political With Patents
description: IN this election year, there is no shortage of slogans and campaign sound bites that the candidates and their supporters hope will get voters' attention. Beyond the mostly bland official phrases, there are those dreamed up by individuals hoping to make their own political statement, or at least a buck.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Aaron Director, an economist who applied free-market analysis to antitrust law, misstated the timing of Friedrich von Hayek's "Road to Serfdom," which Dr. Director persuaded the University of Chicago Press to publish. It came out in 1944, not after World War II.

title: Reuters Asks a Chain to Remove Its Bylines
description: Having their bylines appear in newspapers is an unexpected bonus for news agency reporters. But now Reuters has asked Canada's largest newspaper chain to remove its writers' names from some articles.

title: Martnez Surprised by Yanks' Strategy
description: Teams do not beat Pedro Martnez. They usually have to outlast him. Manager Joe Torre has repeatedly described that strategy in explaining how the Yankees have had considerable success against Martnez, the hard-throwing, quick-talking pitcher for the Boston Red Sox. To have the best chance to win, a team must be patient.

title: Getting the Young to the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: You Say Prosciutto, I Say Pro-SHOOT, and Purists Cringe
description: Ann Gustafson can discuss food -- especially Italian food. She spent many days in the Bronx with her Sicilian grandmother, Sebastiana Ceraolo, learning how to cook with mozzarella. Only Mrs. Gustafson did not call it "mozzarella." She said "mozzarell."

title: Spurs gain draw with Chelsea
The Title Hopes of Stewart and Mayfield Could Be Wrecked
description: LOUDON, N.H., Sept. 19 - Tony Stewart's battered car was the first to be shoved onto a truck and driven away Sunday. His championship chase lasted about one hour.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a Broadway competition in which one-act plays are written, cast, directed and performed in 24 hours misstated the time of day when one writer last year, Warren Leight, discarded his script. It was 3 a.m., not 3 p.m. The article also misstated the hour Mr. Leight cited as the time "you go back to your tired old bag of tricks." It was around 5 a.m., not 5 p.m.

title: Japanese Island Tries to Evade Flight Path
description: SHIMOJI SHIMA, Japan, Sept. 17 - Too tiny to appear on most maps, this tropical island of snorkelers and sugar cane farmers, of turquoise waters and red soil flecked with white coral, may appear on the agendas of President Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi when they meet Tuesday on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Monday about Roger Federer's tennis victory over Lleyton Hewitt in the United States Open singles final referred incorrectly to two distinctions he earned. He became the first man -- but not the first player -- to win three Grand Slam titles in one year since Mats Wilander in 1988. Four women (Steffi Graf, Monica Seles, Martina Hingis and Serena Williams) have won three Grand Slam titles in a year since 1988. Federer also became the 11th man -- not the 4th -- to win at least three Grand Slam championships in a year. (Eight women have also won at least three Grand Slam titles in a year.)

title: In Defense of Civil Liberties
description: The debate over intelligence reform, as important as it is, has been obscuring a vital discussion about another recommendation by the bipartisan commission on the 9/11 attacks. The panel's report noted that no one in the government has the job of safeguarding civil liberties as the government seeks expanded powers to combat terrorism. It proposed assigning that critical task to a special board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, EDDIE
description: ADAMS--Eddie. Parade magazine mourns the loss of a colleague and dear friend. Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer Eddie Adams was the talent behind some of the most moving and poignant images ever to appear on the cover of Parade for more than 20 years. Eddie's genius was his ability to capture tension in every photo, whether it be the still of a murder or the animation in the eyes of a movie star. He was eclectic and incomparable, unyielding in the pursuit of excellence. Whatever the assignment -Pope John Paul II, Fidel Castro or Ronald Reagan; Arnold Schwarzenegger, Clint Eastwood or Cher; Mickey Mouse or Big Bird --Adams approached it with integrity and professionalism. His work is legendary. He was a compassionate and caring human being. He was a mentor to young photographers and a dedicated friend, husband and father. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Alyssa, his family and to everyone who cared about him. He will be missed. Walter Anderson Chairman Parade Publications

title: Elly Annie Schneider, 90, Ex-Munchkin, Dies
description: SARASOTA, Fla. - Elly Annie Schneider, who was known for many years in the circus world and on the big screen as Tiny Earles, then Tiny Doll, and who played one of the Munchkins in "The Wizard of Oz," died here on Sept. 6. She was 90.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Pouf, Alas, but Plenty of Pleasantries and Cooing
description: Star Jones, new in the Joan Rivers role on the Emmys' red carpet for the E! cable channel last night, said of her figure: "I lost a little bit of weight this year." Of her outfit: "It's summer chinchilla." Of her complexion: "You know black don't crack." Of her career: "A lawyer."

title: Marvin Mitchelson, 76, Father of Palimony, Is Dead
description: Marvin M. Mitchelson, the Hollywood divorce lawyer who parlayed the concept of "palimony" settlements for unmarried partners into a successful career representing celebrities, becoming a celebrity himself, died Saturday night in Los Angeles. He was 76.

title: Jets Learn How to Hold On Tight
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 - A lead that had been 20 points was whittled to 6. A crowd of 57,310 at Qualcomm Stadium was in full throat.

title: Colts Show Power and Finesse
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 19 - Peyton Manning crumpled to the ground in a tangle of Tennessee Titans bodies, clutching the football as he was sacked for a 10-yard loss and holding fast to a season that, two weeks old, could have been sinking into the mire. Then, with 90 yards in front of him, Manning listened as the next play call came crackling into his helmet, a directive to thread a pass between two defensive backs in the fourth quarter of a tie game.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Unilever and Colgate Warn of Slowdowns in Their Earnings
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 A Unilever, one of the world's leading consumer-products companies with products from Dove soap to Hellman's mayonnaise, surprised investors today by disclosing that its full-year earnings would grow by less than half the amount it had forecast earlier.

title: Iran Rebuffs U.N. Agency on Atom Issue
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 19 - Iran on Sunday rejected a call by the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency to freeze all its uranium enrichment programs and warned that it would drop out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty if its case was sent to the Security Council.

title: 'King of the Catwalk'
First Criminal Trial onEnron to Begin Today
description: As the first criminal trial stemming from the financial deals at Enron opens in Houston today, it will be notable as much for who is not among the six defendants as who is -- and for how little money was involved compared with how much in other Enron-related cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRITZ, BARRY R.
description: FRITZ--Barry R. 64, of Stony Creek and Woodbridge, CT, peacefully on September 17, surrounded by his loved ones. Son of the late Harry and Belle. Most beloved husband of Mary and devoted brother of Robert. Adored stepfather of Jed and Katie Doyle. Favorite uncle, cousin, friend. Wise teacher of 37 years to students at Quinnipiac University. Barry's warmth, kindness, wit and gentle guidance will be remembered by all of us who knew him, as his spirit will live within us. Graveside service Sunday, September 19, 2 pm, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY. Memorial service in Connecticut to be announced at a later date.

title: Pakistan's Leader Says He May Need to Stay as Army Chief
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20 A Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said in an interview today that his leadership was freeing his country from the menace of extremism and that this national "renaissance" might be lost if he kept his pledge to step down as Army chief at the end of this year.

title: Right-to-Roam Laws Let British Walk Over Class Lines
description: MILLPOND BOTTOM, England, Sept. 19 - They gathered under the pink walls of the Royal Oak Inn, then marched here to this gentle vale to claim their slice of new freedom.

title: Daschle Defends Iraq Remarks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - In a fiery debate on national television, the Republican challenger to Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader, accused Mr. Daschle of emboldening America's enemies by criticizing President Bush on the eve of war in Iraq. Mr. Daschle promptly condemned the remark.

title: Pentagon blocks site for voters outside U.S.
Ex-General Expected to Win Election in Indonesia
description: AKARTA, Sept. 20 A A former general, who has promised to uphold civilian rule, appears to have easily defeated the incumbent Megawati Sukarnoputri in IndonesiaAs presidential election today, according to a nationwide survey of votes.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about young voters' interest in the presidential election misstated the year Bill Clinton was asked at a youth voter forum whether he wore boxers or briefs. It was 1994, not 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, HAROLD M.
description: KAUFMAN--Harold M. 88, of Roslyn, NY, on September 18, 2004. Loving husband of Edna. Devoted father of David, Harriet, Robert, Karen and Steven. Adoring grandfather of Jill and Jeremy Bohrer, Elana Kaufman and Matthew White. Proud great-grandfather of Sophie Bohrer. Services to be held at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, Monday, at 11:30 AM. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to YAI National Institute for People with Disabilities, 460 West 34th St, NY, NY 10001.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I'll be there unless they kick me out."

title: Mamas, Trains, Prisons and a Wink
description: 'What I Do' Alan Jackson

title: 1904:Strikers Control Milan : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Yukos Says It Will Cut Oil Shipments to China The Russian oil giant Yukos said that it would immediately reduce some of its rail exports of crude oil to China. It appears to be the first time that Yukos's ability to transport oil has been affected by its tax dispute with the government, which has frozen most of its bank accounts.

title: Faroe Islanders in Sweden Show They Measure Up
description: In the chilly waters of the North Atlantic, roughly equidistant from Scotland, Norway and Iceland, are the tiny Faroe Islands, a dependency of Denmark that has a population of some 44,000. They have only 150 bridge players but field a team that holds its own internationally. In the European Championships in Malmo, Sweden, in June, they had the satisfaction of defeating, among others, Iceland and Finland, and they tied with Norway.

title: Stick It to the N.H.L.
description: TORONTO - The N.H.L. used to be such a nice league: compact, parochial, driven by a devoted fan base tied together by the love of speed and cold. It wove Canada and the northern United States together in a sweet geographic tangle, a friendly holler on America's sporting map, while megaphone-loud across the tundra. Its wild, old arenas -- the Montreal Forum, Chicago Stadium, Boston Garden, Maple Leaf Gardens -- were living museums where your grandfather used to watch Gordie Howe; in Canada, these rinks were historic beacons in a nation lacking great churches, golden bridges and glittering domes.

title: The Collections / New York : Rucci's couture closes the shows
Militants Show the Beheading of 3 Kurdish Hostages
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 19 - A militant group on Sunday posted a gruesome Internet video showing the beheading of three men said to be members of the Kurdistan Democratic Party, one of two major Kurdish political parties in Iraq.

title: Liberty's Top Draft Pick Gets It Done
description: The smile on Shameka Christon's face said it all yesterday.

title: Picking a Fight With Venezuela
description: The Bush administration's decision to stop supporting $250 million in loan requests that Venezuela has before international financial institutions has gone virtually unnoticed. Yet, by invoking such sanctions now, Washington risks making another mistake in dealing with Venezuela's mercurial strongman, President Hugo Chvez.

title: A Spotlight on Bernstein, Both Sides
description: You shouldn't judge an artist's work through his personality. Richard Wagner, for example, was unpleasant in person yet wrote magnificent music. But in the case of Leonard Bernstein it's hard to avoid the temptation. Here was someone with a big, flamboyant, likable personality, and he wrote big, flamboyant, likable music. A little over the top sometimes? Definitely. A little too lowbrow for many? Assuredly. Sometimes in questionable taste? Oh, yes. Talented? Hugely. Are we talking about the man or the music? Both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISER, JOSEPH J.
description: WEISER--Joseph J. On September 17, 2004. He was 92 years old. Mr. Weiser was a New York State Assemblyman for the Eastside District (District 74), New York State Commissioner of Off-Track Betting. He is survived by his beloved wife, Ruth, of 57 years, his children, Stanley and Karen Weiser, Susan and William Finley and Wendy and Brad Chayet, his sister, Judy Schauer, and his four grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Monday, September 20, 11:30 am, at "The Riverside," Amsterdam and 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANFORD, WILLIAM F.
description: SANFORD--William F. Of Bronxville, on September 16, 2004. Father of William L. Sanford. Son of Dorothy and the late William B. Sanford. Brother of Thomas D. Sanford and Nancy S. Pierson. Memorial service at The Reformed Church of Bronxville, on Thursday, September 30, at 4 pm. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Bronxville Scout Committee Endowment Fund, PO Box 630, Bronxville, NY 10708.

title: Coughlin Reacts Typically to His First Giants Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19 - The Tom Coughlin era for the Giants had begun with almost nothing but upheaval and controversy, a stream of player complaints and all-around impatience with his rules -- which made the postgame gesture of the players handing the game ball to him seem all the more meaningful.

description: COSTELLO--Jon Valentine. You are remembered everyday.

title: It's All Painted Black (at Least for October)
description: There have been some dark times recently at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, but the executives and employees have done their best to soldier through their founder's legal travails and her announcement last week that she is ready to begin serving her five-month sentence for obstruction of justice.

title: Back to Wall, Giants' Defense Turns Fearsome
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19 - When the Giants' defensive players walked off the field after the Washington Redskins embarrassed them with an easy touchdown drive in the first quarter Sunday afternoon, they had already tried the patience of the Giants Stadium crowd. Their fans had begun booing only three minutes into their home opener after an ugly rash of missed tackles and blown assignments. Once they got to the sideline, they found no sympathy.

title: Eisner's Sickbed Musings on a Successor Find Their Way Into Court
description: As Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, was being wheeled into an operating room for quadruple bypass surgery in July 1994, he called his wife, Jane, to his side and requested three things. First, she should not build a new house. Second, he wanted to be interred above ground. And third, she should tell Disney's board that if he died he should be succeeded by one of his two powerful Hollywood friends: Barry Diller or Michael Ovitz.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO--Joe. 2/5/199/20/96. Is it only eight years? In my thoughts every day. Nanc

title: Edwards Campaigns in Home State of North Carolina
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 20 A With promises to increase health care and preserve tax cuts for most people, Senator John Edwards today returned to his home state, where polls suggest Senator John Kerry is running behind President Bush.

title: Rightists Make Strong Strides in Eastern German State Elections
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 19 - Far-right parties made their strongest showing in six years in German state elections on Sunday, as voters reacted against Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's governing party after sharp cutbacks in welfare benefits.

title: A Music Download Site for Artists Less Known
description: The Internet has long carried the promise of being an outlet for new writers, artists and independent musicians. But to David Pakman, chief operating officer of eMusic, an online music service, that promise has not yet panned out.

description: I am John Kerry, falling further behind in the polls with only six weeks to go.

title: Official Business
description: Good morning, boys and girls. Today's lesson is about government, and how people in government make decisions that help all of us. Did you know that Illinois has an official state flower? It's the violet. Illinois also has a state mineral, fluorite, which is used to make steel, enamels, aluminum and many chemicals. It has a state fish, a state animal, a state tree, bird and insect.

title: IN THE RUNNING
description: TV on the Radio, Franz Ferdinand, Wilco, the Streets and Loretta Lynn are among the 10 pop artists selected as finalists for the Shortlist Music Prize, an award founded in 2001 to recognize innovative and underground music. The other finalists, chosen by a selection panel that included Norah Jones, Robert Smith of the Cure, Ahmir Thompson of the Roots, Jack Black and John Mayer, are Dizzee Rascal, Nellie McKay, Ghostface Killah, Air and the Killers. The $10,000 prize will be awarded at a concert in Los Angeles on Nov. 10. BEN SISARIO

description: An article on Wednesday about delays in further international talks on North Korea's nuclear program referred incorrectly to one theory about an explosion in North Korea last week that briefly raised suspicions that a nuclear device was being tested. The theory is that missile fuel exploded, but the kind of fuel was unknown; it was not liquid nitrogen, which is inert and cannot explode.

title: Pennington Parcels Out His Passes
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 - There was a 46-yard pass to receiver Jonathan Carter. A 48-yarder to Santana Moss to clinch the victory. And, in all, seven Jets players caught passes from quarterback Chad Pennington.

title: So, That's the Point of This Company (Extended Version)
description: BARRY DILLER, the chairman and chief executive of IAC/InterActiveCorp, wowed Wall Street analysts who had come for a conference last fall at his company, an amalgamation of primarily Internet-based businesses. Profits, he said, would rise annually by 25 percent or more, to $3 billion in 2008. Based on that projection, analysts raised their expectations for revenue growth in IAC's important travel division to 41 percent for the second quarter this year.

title: New Week, Same Big Issue
description: Except for occasional detours into issues such as health care costs and the running story over the military service of the two candidates, the war in Iraq continues to dominate the presidential campaign and is certain to do so again this week. Democrats plan a series of events aimed at discrediting White House policy in Iraq, Senator John Kerry's campaign has a critical new ad out and Iraqi Prime Minister Ayad Allawi is scheduled to appear on Capitol Hill for a warm reception from the majority Republicans.

title: Corrections
description: A Commercial Real Estate article in Business Day on Sept. 8 about Reckson Associates Realty's purchase of office buildings along the Route 24 corridor in New Jersey misstated the distance of the Reckson Office Center in Madison from certain destinations. The Reckson building is a three-minute walk from the front gate of the office park, which is six-tenths of a mile from the train station; the building itself is not three minutes from the train station. The building is about 35 minutes from Newark Liberty Airport; Morristown Airport is about 10 minutes away by car.

title: A Celebrity on TV, a Schlemiel at Home
description: Tony Kleinman's name loads the dice. First off, that surname -- little man -- has the kind of allegorical freight associated with socialist theater. Second, it sounds Jewish, which suggests that the lead character on CBS's "Listen Up," a figure based on Tony Kornheiser, the Washington Post columnist and the co-host of a talk show on ESPN, may be one of the few, if not the first, Jewish heads of a family on a network sitcom since Molly Goldberg dominated "The Goldbergs" in the 1950's.

title: Democrats Criticize Security Claims in New Bush Ad
description: With lawmakers expected to move ahead this week with legislative proposals to reorganize United States intelligence agencies, President Bush has a new television ad on the air that talks about how he and the Republican-led Congress are going about enhancing homeland security.

title: Online Columnist Quits, Citing Excessive Editing
description: Geneva Overholser, a 35-year veteran of the news business, has quit writing her weekly online column for the Poynter Institute, a journalism education organization, over a complaint that has tempted other reporters to walk out the door. The editors, she said, edited too much.

description: After days of expressing confidence about the documents used in a "60 Minutes" report that raised new questions about President Bush's National Guard service in the 1970's, CBS News officials have grave doubts about the authenticity of the material, network officials said.

title: Mussina Sparkles and Red Sox Lose Their Fizz
description: The Yankees had heard so much about the revitalized Boston Red Sox. Every day, it seemed, they would look at the scoreboard and see their rivals winning. Nomar Garciaparra was gone, the Red Sox were inspired, and the Yankees were vulnerable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANCHIN, FRANCES E. (NEE STEINBERG)
description: ANCHIN--Frances E. (nee Steinberg). On September 19, 2004. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted and loving mother of Roberta and Philip Strasburg, and James and Joan Anchin. Grandmother of Donald Strasburg, Lauren and Scott Freifeld, Scott and Lauren Anchin, Lee and Dori Anchin. Great-grandmother of Jared and Todd Freifeld. Sister of Bernard Steinberg. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 21, 2004, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, NYC, at 10 am. Contributions may be made to the Linda J. Anchin Scholarsip Fund, Mt. Vernon High School, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Investigate Child's Death
description: The police are looking into whether a 2-year-old boy who died early yesterday in Morningside Heights was a victim of child abuse, the authorities said. The police and emergency crews were called to an apartment at 1370 Broadway at 2 a.m. yesterday in response to a report of an unconscious child. The boy was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and pronounced dead at 2:26 a.m. A police official said the boy had suffered a broken bone, but it remained unclear whether it was related to his death, or whether his death was accidental. The boy's mother lived in the apartment with his aunt and another woman, neighbors said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Killed In Fight
description: A teenager was shot and killed after a fight between two groups in Harlem around 9:30 p.m. last night, the police said. He was 17. A 19-year-old man was also shot, and was in stable condition early today and was expected to live, the police said. The person who was believed to have shot both men at 119th Street at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard vanished into the crowd. Officers called for help after an unruly crowd of people involved in the fight showed up at North General Hospital, where one victim was taken. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Words, Words Everywhere, but Only Absurdity to Drink
description: Presidential elections are always a joy for students of the uses and abuses of language. This fall it's like Christmas every day. For comic relief from dispiriting contemplation of this phenomenon, theatergoers may want to check out Eugne Ionesco's "Bald Soprano," now in revival at the Atlantic Theater Company, where it is paired with the playwright's more sinister exercise in absurdity, "The Lesson."

description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENVENISTE, JAYE
description: BENVENISTE -- Jaye. 87, passed away peacefully at home on September 17, 2004. She successfully battled pancreatic cancer for many years. She will be forever in the hearts and souls of her loving nephews Stuart Shikiar and Albert Shikiar, her greatnephews Samuel Max Shikiar and David Shikiar, and greatnieces Karen Masters and Susan Santillo. Her wit, wisdom, courage and grace will be fondly remembered by the many people she touched in her rich life. Service Tuesday, September 21, at 11:30 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hu Takes Military Reins, Completing Shift in China
description: BEIJING, Sept. 19 - China's president, Hu Jintao, replaced Jiang Zemin as the country's military chief and de facto top leader on Sunday, state media announced, completing the first orderly transfer of power in the history of China's Communist Party.

title: Intimidation Alleged in Vote in Kazakhstan
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Sept. 19 - Kazakhstan voted for a largely toothless Parliament on Sunday in an election marred by low turnout, widespread irregularities and a climate of intimidation.

title: In Video Games, Sequels Are Winners
description: The videogame industry has a lot in common with the movie business in that both industries bank heavily on special effects, big releases and even glamour. And increasingly, the game industry shares something else with Hollywood: a heavy reliance on sequels. In the six-month period ending in June, only two of the 10 best-selling video games were based on original ideas, according to the NPD Group, a research firm. Most were spinoffs from other best-selling games or were licensed from pro sports; a few were based on blockbuster movies and books. The only original title in the top five is Halo, a first-person shooter game from Microsoft. The rest -- MVP Baseball 2004, NFL Street, Pokmon Colosseum and Fight Night 2004 -- are all sequels or sports spinoffs.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUTTENBERG, DERALD H.
description: RUTTENBERG--Derald H. 88, was born in Lafayette, IN, on February 17, 1916, and died on September 19, 2004, in New York City. He graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1937, Yale Law School in 1940, and Harvard University Graduate School of Business in 1942. In 1943, he entered the armed forces and served in the European Theater of Operations in the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey; he was discharged as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Air Force in 1945. Following his honorable discharge, he owned and ran various closely-held foundry and manufacturing companies in the midwest. He later moved to New York City and became Chairman of ITE-Circuit Breaker Co. in 1967. In 1969 he became President and Chief Executive Officer of Studebaker-Worthington, Inc. and Chairman and Chief Executive Officer in 1971, in which capacities he served until 1980. He then returned to private investing through Tinicum Incorporated, his family owned investment firm. He is survived by his wife Janet of 53 years and their four children John, Eric, Kathy and Hattie, as well as eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to either Yale Law School or the Derald H. Ruttenberg Cancer Center at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City.

title: Blair Urges Europe and U.N. Not to Waver on Fight in Iraq
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 - Prime Minister Tony Blair on Sunday admonished other nations not to waver in their support for military victory in Iraq and the establishment of democracy there, arguing that Iraq is now the "crucible" in which global terrorism will either succeed or founder.

title: Vivendi's Music Unit Climbs the Pop Chart With 2 Nelly Albums
description: Doug Morris, the chairman of Vivendi's Universal Music Group, is tuning up for a big week. On Wednesday, two albums just released by the Universal rapper Nelly, "Sweat" and "Suit," are expected to capture the top two positions on the nation's pop chart, with combined first-week sales of about 800,000 copies. It would be the first time anyone has claimed the top two spots at once since Guns N' Roses did it in 1991 and the first time the feat has been managed by a black artist.

title: Waiting for the Candidate to Emerge

It was clear that many voters had cast primary ballots for Mr. Kerry not because they liked him, or because they felt strongly about his positions on the issues, or because they were drawn to his compelling vision of a better future for the United States and the world, but simply because they felt he was capable of beating George W. Bush.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Drug Suspect Dies After Fall
description: A suspected drug dealer being chased by police officers along rooftops in the Bronx fell to his death yesterday afternoon, the police said. The man, 27, was not identified yesterday. The police said that officers pursued the man after seeing him sell drugs to a woman at 1372 Ogden Avenue in Morris Heights. They quickly arrested the woman, but the man ran up five flights of stairs to the roof, they said. He ran north from 1372 to 1376, 1380 and 1386, where he came upon a wall, the police said. He climbed the wall, perhaps assuming it adjoined another roof, but fell five stories through the six- to eight-foot gap between the next building, the police said. The officers chasing him were still one roof behind, on 1380, when he fell, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

But California, in an act of political and scientific rebellion against limits on stem cell research imposed by the Bush White House, may be on the verge of spending $300 million a year in each of the next 10 years on such research.

title: Microsoft Co-Founder Puts Different Spin on Sports
