Mr. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft and a sports mogul, was a firm believer in the power of the Web to change lives, and his investments reflected that. The Sporting News, a 118-year-old brand and perennial also-ran to Sports Illustrated, seemed like a horse and buggy in a garage filled with Segways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBY, HENRY J.
description: JACOBY--Henry J. The family of David, Sylvia, Jacob and Ivan Goodman note with great sadness the passing of our uncle. David remembers Henry not only as an uncle, but a mentor and business partner for 31 years. Henry's advice and calm voice guided David in navigating the complexities of building large civil construction projects and managing associated financial transactions. Henry was instrumental in the formation and success of United American Energy Corp. and helped David, CEO, as a key investor and advisor. Henry, you will be missed for your friendship, expertise, cheer-leading, and kindness.

Ruttenberg Cancer Center at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, died on Sunday at the hospital. He was 88 and lived in New York.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 - Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, said on Monday that he did not plan to remain on the board or become chairman when he retires in two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Charles Schwab & Company's settlement of a mutual fund trading case with the Securities and Exchange Commission referred incorrectly to the agency's accusations. The S.E.C. contended that Schwab had allowed some customers to change mutual fund orders after the 4 p.m. stock-market close, a violation of securities rules, creating the risk that such customers could unfairly capitalize on late-breaking news at the expense of other investors; it did not find the existence of an actual scheme to exploit the system in that way.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Human Genome Sciences, Rockville, Md., a biopharmaceutical company, named Argeris Karabelas as chairman after the retirement of William A. Haseltine as chairman and chief executive on Oct. 17. The company also promoted Craig A. Rosen, formerly president for research and development, as president and chief operating officer, effective immediately.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Can Collect Jury Award, Judge Rules
description: In the case of the prosecutor who was demoted because he infuriated his boss, a federal judge ruled yesterday that a former Brooklyn assistant district attorney can collect a $30,000 jury award against District Attorney Charles J. Hynes.

title: Even in Death, These Cats Got Special Treatment
description: When ancient Egyptians wanted to express their devotion to certain leaders or gods, they often said it with dead cats. Egyptians produced mummies of cats -- and of hawks, ibises, falcons and other small animals -- by the millions, particularly during and after the reign of Amenhotep III in 1400 B.C.

title: Relatives Sue Stun Gun Maker and Police Over a Man's Death
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 20 - When David Glowczenski began screaming incoherently and stalked out of his home in Southampton one morning in February, his family called 911 to ask for help. Mr. Glowczenski was a schizophrenic and no stranger to the police, but a struggle broke out when officers approached him that time, and after being shocked with a Taser stun gun, he collapsed and died.

description: Yesterday John Kerry came to New York University and did something amazing. He uttered a series of clear, declarative sentences on the subject of Iraq. Many of these sentences directly contradict his past statements on Iraq, but at least you could figure out what he was trying to say.

He later moved to New York City and became Chairman of ITE-Circuit Breaker Co. in 1967. World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit In Luxury Goods
description: The luxury goods maker Christian Dior, which controls LVMH Met Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said profit rose 59 percent in the first half on increased demand in the United States and Asia. Net income rose to 157 million euros ($191.3 million) from 99 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Operating profit rose 37 percent, to 1.01 billion euros. The company's biggest earner is its controlling stake in LVMH, which reported last week that profit rose 49 percent on increased demand for products like Champagne and Cognac.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Nader Reaches Maryland Ballot
description: Maryland allowed Ralph Nader on its presidential ballot, and Arkansas knocked him off, a decision that Mr. Nader will probably appeal. And he had a mixed result in Pennsylvania, where the state Supreme Court overturned a ruling that barred him from running. The Supreme Court ordered a lower court to review Mr. Nader's nominating petitions. Democratic-backed groups contend that two-thirds of the signatures are invalid. Mr. Nader is likely to be on the ballot in 34 states, said David W. Jones, president of TheNaderFactor.com, a group trying to persuade Nader supporters to vote Democratic. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an accusation by Senator John Kerry that the Bush administration was secretly planning to mobilize National Guard units immediately after the election misstated the position of Steve Schmidt, a campaign spokesman, who said that Mr. Kerry's attack "has as much accuracy as a Kitty Kelley novel." He works for the Bush campaign, not Mr. Kerry's.

title: U.S. Judge Orders Election Agency to Tighten Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - A federal judge has ordered the Federal Election Commission to enact tougher restrictions on how millions of dollars are spent on campaigns, saying that its rules have undermined the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law.

LAMAR ADVERTISING IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE OBIE MEDIA
description: The Lamar Advertising Company, which sells billboard advertising, agreed to buy the Obie Media Corporation for about $43 million to add advertising displays. Lamar will pay $7 for each share of Obie, 46 percent more than Obie's closing price on Friday. Lamar, which is based in Baton Rouge, La., will also assume about $23 million of debt. Obie, based in Eugene, Ore., makes and installs advertising displays that include posters on buses, benches, billboards and transit shelters. Lamar said it expected to complete the purchase early next year.

title: Sand Lost in Storms Leaves Beaches at Risk
description: The Alabama and Florida beaches damaged in recent hurricanes will naturally recover at least somewhat, coastal scientists say. But how fast and to what extent they can regain their prestorm shape depend on highly variable factors: the damage, how much they already suffer from chronic erosion and how densely they have been developed.

title: Be Prepared for Anything From Pyramids to Onions
description: After a conference in Oaxaca, Mexico, ended four years ago, I visited the ancient ruins and pyramids of the Zapotec culture. It wasn't obvious how steep the pyramid steps were until I started ascending them. On the way down, I passed a French woman who was huffing and puffing as she climbed up. Most people are awed when they come upon this site, which is thousands of years old. I overheard this woman, who was obviously out of shape, say rather petulantly, "Now honestly, you'd think they could have put an elevator in this pyramid."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: School Registration Criticized
description: State Senator Carl Kruger, a Brooklyn Democrat, criticized the City Department of Education's new high school registration process yesterday after receiving a complaint from a frustrated "A" student. The student, Vasily Danilenko, 15, who moved to Brooklyn after completing the ninth grade in New Jersey, said he was initially assigned to Leon M. Goldstein High School for the Sciences, but was told during orientation that the school had no record of him. He has since been bounced among various education offices, he said, and reassigned to two other schools -- but as a freshman, not a sophomore. A department spokesman said that the student was mistakenly assigned to Goldstein while the computer system was down, and that the department knew of about 20 other cases in which computer problems led to students being misassigned. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Puccini in Vienna, Struggling to Adjust

title: Norman F. Cantor, 74, a Noted Medievalist, Is Dead

He was 74 and a former resident of Greenwich Village.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Profit Rises 62% As Sales Increase
description: Adobe Systems, the world's biggest maker of graphic-design software, said yesterday that third-quarter profit surged 62 percent as higher spending on advertising fueled demand for design and publishing programs. Net income rose to $104.5 million, or 42 cents a share, from $64.5 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier, Adobe said. Sales rose 27 percent, to $403.7 million. The company was expected to report a profit of 39 cents a share, the average estimate of 20 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, and sales of $391.2 million. Shares of Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., rose $1.60, or 3 percent, to $49.55 in extended trading after the results were reported. The stock had fallen 19 cents, to $47.95, in regular trading. In the current quarter, the company was expected to earn 37 cents a share, the average estimate of 18 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, on sales of $389.3 million. In August, Adobe said profit in the quarter ended Sept. 3 would be 36 cents to 41 cents a share on sales of $380 million to $400 million. That exceeded its June profit forecast of 31 cents to 36 cents a share on sales of $360 million to $380 million.

title: In Address at U.N., Bush Defends Decision to Invade Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 A President Bush told skeptical foreign leaders and envoys today that Iraq was on its way to stability and democracy and called for "a new definition of security" that allows nations to act together to extend freedom to countries gripped by tyranny.

title: Analysts assert Alitalia still lacks a clear vision
Safety for Giants Is Tough On Opponents and Himself
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 20 - Safety Brent Alexander came out of Monday's meeting after the Giants' 20-14 victory over Washington on Sunday with the same attitude he had taken after nearly every game of his 11-year career. He did not revel in his two interceptions, or in his role in any of the seven turnovers the defense collected against the Redskins. He was past all of that shortly after the game ended.

title: Nike Profit Up 25%; U.S. Sales Climb
description: Nike said yesterday that first-quarter earnings were up 25 percent as demand for its athletic shoes fueled the fastest United States sales gain in more than a year.

title: Reborn After One Hurricane, Gulf Shores Is Back at Drawing Board
description: GULF SHORES, Ala., Sept 19 - For a mayor still barely able to reach the most damaged sections of his city, David L. Bodenhamer remains remarkably upbeat about the long-term fallout from Hurricane Ivan's landfall last week in his low-lying coastal community.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PalmOne Posts $19.6 Million Profit
description: PalmOne, the world's biggest maker of hand-held computers, reported its second straight quarterly profit yesterday, bolstered by surging demand for its Treo organizer and phone. The shares fell after PalmOne said profit this quarter would not meet analysts' estimates. First-quarter net income was $19.6 million, or 38 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $21.7 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 62 percent, to $273 million. PalmOne, based in Milpitas, Calif., is reaping higher profits from sales of the Treo 600, Paul Coster of J.P. Morgan wrote on Wednesday in a report to clients. Verizon Wireless and the T-Mobile unit of Deutsche Telekom began selling the device in the United States this year. PalmOne had posted five periods of losses before turning a profit in the fourth quarter. Profit excluding some one-time items was 43 cents a share in the first quarter, compared with the 20-cent average estimate of nine analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. PalmOne shares fell $3.29, to $33.99, in extended trading. In regular trading, shares rose $1.63, to $37.28.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Officers See Racism In Noose
description: The National Latino Officers Association of America said yesterday that a noose had been found inside the 42nd Precinct station house in the Tremont section of the Bronx, and claimed it was indicative of racial tensions there. At a news conference, officials of the group demanded immediate disciplinary action against anyone found to be responsible. At a separate appearance, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the department was investigating. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPHAEL, LUCILLE NATALIE
description: RAPHAEL--Lucille Natalie. Born February 20, 1922 died September 11, 2004. It is with great sorrow that we mourn the loss of our dear mother who valiantly lost her fight to cancer. She will be sorely missed by her daughter Joanne, her two sons Stephen and Mark, their wives Marjorie and Deabi and her loving grandchildren Jackie, Eric, Lee and Franchesca. Donations may be made to FLAIR C/O National Jewish Medical Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, CO. 80206

description: Stocks dropped yesterday as Colgate-Palmolive and Unilever cut profit forecasts, fueling concern that earnings growth is slowing at a time when borrowing costs are headed higher.

title: Where Bank Fled, Immigrant Tries Restaurant
description: A lifetime away from small-town Mexico and the California orchards of his childhood, Vicente Medina can now legitimately call himself a Park Avenue restaurateur. That might not be a bad idea if he wanted to confound expectations, since his 300-seat spot is where Park Avenue intersects Tremont Avenue -- in the Bronx.

title: Brooklyn Woman Found Slain After Boyfriend Crashes Car
description: A woman in East New York, Brooklyn, found her son's girlfriend brutally beaten and stabbed yesterday morning, shortly after learning that her son had been in a bad car crash.

title: U.S. Cycling Gold Medalist Denies Blood Transfusions
description: PARIS, Sept. 21 A Tyler Hamilton, the American bicycle racer who won an Olympic gold medal in the time trial last month in Athens, strongly denied today that he had used illegal performance-enhancing blood transfusions there and in a major race in Spain.

description: Correction Appended

title: Just Showing Up in Athens Is a Victory for Cambodians
description: For Nhork Kimhor, the road to Athens began with a sound he remembers as "Pung!"

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Bronx Man Held In Hate Crimes
description: The Westchester County authorities said yesterday that they had arrested a Bronx man for recruiting minors to post pro-Hitler and white power stickers on buildings, including a synagogue, in Mount Vernon. Thomas Zibelli, 33, of Radcliff Avenue, who worked as a security guard and in a machine shop, was charged with criminal mischief and aggravated harassment. Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney, designated the charges as hate crimes. Each carries a penalty of up to four years in state prison. Anne Marie Corbalis, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Pirro, said that Mr. Zibelli was being held without bail. Michael Osgood, a captain with the New York City Police Department's Hate Crimes Task Force, said that the Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, planned to charge Mr. Zibelli with child endangerment. Marek Fuchs (NYT)

title: People
description: Phil Smith was named president, a new post, at Boone/Oakley, Charlotte, N.C., joining the founders, John Boone and David Oakley, who until now were the sole managers. Mr. Smith, who has worked at advertising and design agencies, was most recently the chief creative officer at the Charlotte office of Muzak.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the possibility that Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, will break his promise to resign as the army chief by the end of this year misstated the country's age. It is 57 years old, not 47.

title: PFIZER AND MEDAREX JOIN IN DRUG DEVELOPMENT ACCORD
description: Pfizer has agreed to pay Medarex $80 million and buy $30 million of the company's stock in a 10-year agreement to develop medicines. Pfizer, which is based in New York, could spend more than $400 million including licensing fees and other payments, depending on whether 50 planned drugs win federal approval. Medarex will also get royalties on sales of the products. Stock in Medarex, which is based in Princeton, N.J., gained $1.07, to $7.90 a share. Pfizer is paying $6.21 a share to buy about 4.83 million shares, a Medarex spokeswoman, Jean Mantuano, said.

title: Bush Aides Divided on Confronting Iran Over A-Bomb
description: Correction Appended

title: Roger W. Straus Memorial
description: A memorial service for the book publisher Roger W. Straus Jr. will be held at 3 p.m. on Sept. 29 at the Unterberg Poetry Center at the 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Ave., in Manhattan. The service is open to the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANCHIN, FRANCES E. (NEE STEINBERG)
description: ANCHIN--Frances E. (nee Steinberg). On September 19, 2004. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted and loving mother of Roberta and Philip Strasburg, and James and Joan Anchin. Grandmother of Donald Strasburg, Lauren and Scott Freifeld, Scott and Lauren Anchin, Lee and Dori Anchin. Great-grandmother of Jared and Todd Freifeld. Sister of Bernard Steinberg. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 21, 2004, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, NYC, at 10 am. Contributions may be made to the Linda J. Anchin Scholarsip Fund, Mt. Vernon High School, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BESTE, WILLIAM ''BILL''
description: BESTE--William "Bill", 76, of Ocean Pines, MD., on September 18, 2004, formerly of New York. Husband of Nancie. Father of Eric, Patricia, Valerie, Kathi and Stacey. Brother of Robert. He was a graduate of Hofstra University and served in the 82nd Airborne. He worked at BBD&O as an Account Executive. Mass Wednesday, 11 AM at Saint Mary Star of the Sea Church, Ocean City, MD.

title: Iraqis Warn U.S. Plan to Divert Billions to Security Could Cut Off Crucial Services
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 20 - Iraqi officials in charge of rebuilding their country's shattered and decrepit infrastructure are warning that the Bush administration's plan to divert $3.46 billion from water, sewage, electricity and other reconstruction projects to security could leave many people without the crucial services that generally form the backbone of a stable and functioning democracy.

title: Corrections
Alitalia board passes reorganization plan
Newark Housing Chief Defends Spending and Layoffs
description: NEWARK, Sept. 20 - The executive director of the Newark Housing Authority, which is being reviewed by federal officials over allegations of excessive spending, gave reporters a tour on Monday of the headquarters building that is at the center of the dispute.

title: CAMPAIGN 2004 : Kerry sees a crisis of 'historic' dimension
Unilever and Colgate Issue Profit Warnings for Rest of the Year
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 - Two big consumer products companies, Unilever and Colgate-Palmolive, issued profit warnings on Monday, underscoring an increasingly tough competitive landscape for makers of some of the world's best-known brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVID, ELSE
description: DAVID--Else. We mourn the passing of an extraordinary woman of valor who devoted her life to the needs of the Jewish people worldwide. A Diamond Founder of the Hospital and a generous supporter of the Jesselson Heart Center and the Woman & Infant Center, she was a righteous woman who personified the highest qualities of dignity and elegance. She was a cherished friend who will be deeply missed. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: Bush Drew Record $259 Million During Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - President Bush raised roughly $259 million as he marched unchallenged through the primary season, shattering the record for presidential fund-raising and collecting millions more than his opponent, according to campaign finance reports filed Monday.

title: Bush's Address to U.N. General Assembly
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's speech at the United Nations today, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.

title: MAXIM SHARES PLUNGE AFTER MELANOMA DRUG TRIAL FAILS
description: Maxim Pharmaceuticals said an advanced trial showed that its experimental melanoma treatment, Ceplene, did not help patients with liver metastases live longer, setting off a 49 percent decline in its share price. Ceplene still holds promise for the treatment of other cancers, the company said. The Food and Drug Administration has given Maxim permission to provide the drug to melanoma patients while studying its effectiveness, and Ceplene has been successful in treating some kinds of leukemia. The trial was a "must do" for the company to get approval for Ceplene and the failure is a "major setback," a Merriman Curhan Ford & Company analyst, Kate Winkler, wrote in a report. Stock in Maxim, which is based in San Diego, fell $2.90, to $3.04 a share.

title: In Address at U.N., Bush Defends Decision to Invade Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 A President Bush told skeptical foreign leaders and envoys today that Iraq was on its way to stability and democracy and called for "a new definition of security" that allows nations to act together to extend freedom to countries gripped by tyranny.

title: Trial opens window on Enron dealings
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Union To Vote On Strike
description: The union representing 28,000 janitors and other building-service workers at 1,000 New York City office towers will vote on Thursday whether to authorize a strike beginning Oct. 1. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, is engaged in negotiations with building owners and managers over how to close a $150 million annual deficit in the union's health fund. Tomorrow, more than 10,000 of Local 32BJ's building-service workers on Long Island and in New Jersey, Connecticut and Westchester County will vote on whether to authorize strikes in separate but related contract negotiations. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Far-Right Gains in Germany Not Seen as Specter of Weimar
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 20 - A day after far-right parties made striking gains in state elections in eastern Germany, political analysts cautioned against drawing parallels to the political extremism of the Weimar Republic.

description: AMERICAS

title: Chicago Moving to 'Smart' Surveillance Cameras
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 - A highly advanced system of video surveillance that Chicago officials plan to install by 2006 will make people here some of the most closely observed in the world. Mayor Richard M. Daley says it will also make them much safer.

description: You may think that a genuine interest in consumer health prompts food companies to market products that claim to reduce the risk of heart disease or cancer or help people lose weight. Think again.

description: "The Stress Cure," by Dr. Vern S. Cherewatenko and Paul Perry. HarperCollins, $24.95.

title: Afghan Leader Tries to Persuade Main Rival to Quit Election Race
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 20 - President Hamid Karzai has been wooing his main rival in the presidential race, Yunus Qanooni, to persuade him to drop out and join Mr. Karzai's campaign, officials in both political camps said Monday.

title: Dawdling Over DNA
description: Kirk Bloodsworth, the first death row inmate exonerated by DNA evidence, was among those in attendance last week when the Senate Judiciary Committee was supposed to act on a worthy measure that would ensure fairer access to post-conviction DNA testing and encourage states to improve the abysmal caliber of legal representation in capital cases. Kellie Greene, the victim of a vicious 1994 assault who had to wait three years before the biological evidence was analyzed, was there, too, to spotlight other key provisions that would expand the funds available to clear up the nationwide backlog of more than 300,000 biological samples waiting for analyses.

title: Study Finds Less Youth Antidepressant Use
description: The number of teenagers and children being prescribed antidepressants in the United States dropped 18 percent over the last year after studies found that the medicines appeared to lead some to become suicidal, according to one provider of drug benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CLAMAN, ARNOLD Y.
description: CLAMAN--Arnold Y. A Memorial Service to be held September 25 at 2 P.M. at The Unitarian Church, Summit, NJ. Donations may be made to The Theatre Development Fund, 1501 Bdway, NYC 10036

title: Travel News
description: HAMMERING AWAY -- Airlines traditionally have fare sales after the summer travel season wanes, but this fall the most striking discounts seem to be on low-cost carriers seeking to battle competitors on carefully selected routes all over the country. For example, Southwest announced a sale that includes $39 one-way fares (with 14-day advance purchase) between Philadelphia and Hartford; a comparable one-way fare on the rival US Airways was listed at $382.10 yesterday. And in New York, JetBlue, ensconced since its inception at Kennedy International Airport, announced a move into La Guardia Airport, a busy business-travel airport, with seven round trips daily to the rapidly expanding Fort Lauderdale airport. The $135 round-trip fares are comparable to those charged on that route by Delta's low-fare start-up Song.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the United States Senate race in Oklahoma, which is being roiled by controversy over an old malpractice lawsuit against the Republican candidate, Tom Coburn, misattributed the comment that it was "a very serious matter." The speaker was Brad Luna, spokesman for Mr. Coburn's Democratic opponent, Representative Brad Carson, not Mr. Carson himself.

title: U.S. Lifts Trade Embargo on Libya in Return for Promise on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - President Bush revoked the United States trade embargo on Libya on Monday and took other steps aimed at eventually establishing normal relations with the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in return for its keeping a promise to give up nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.

title: Anti-Ad Group Tries Advertising
description: THE Adbusters Media Foundation, an advocacy group based in Vancouver, Canada, that wants to reduce marketers' influence over culture, is getting into the marketing game itself -- with sneakers meant to nip at Nike's heels.

title: Behind Deadly Kidnapping, a Father's Violent History
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., Sept. 20 - A man who the police said killed himself after murdering his wife, shooting her half-sister and kidnapping his three children was distraught over the loss of his job and his recent separation, a former neighbor said Monday. The police said that the man, Clifford Bonner, 42, had a history of violent behavior.

title: Far-right parties gain in Germany
Governor Backs Pardoning Russian Who Killed Chechen Woman
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 - A governor who once commanded Russian forces in Chechnya has endorsed a regional commission's recommendation that an army colonel imprisoned for the murder of a Chechen woman in 2000 be pardoned, the Russian news media reported Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHFELDER, J. GENE
description: HOCHFELDER--J. Gene. 82, patriarch of the Hochfelder Family. War hero, businessman, philanthropist, trusted friend, advisor to many. Born in NYC April 27, 1922. Died peacefully in his sleep at home September 20, 2004. Raised in Cedarhurst, NY, graduated Lawrence H.S. 1939, the Wharton School at University of Pennsylvannia, 1943. Enlisted U.S. Marine Corps in 1943, served with the 5th Marine Division Iwo Jima, Guadalcanal, and Guam, Capt. Hochfelder was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Presidential Citation for bravery and heroism in WW II's bloodiest battle. Predeceased by parents Lillian and Jake and beloved wife of 39 years, Patricia Beldoch. Founder of Bogene Closet Accesories, and later, Chairman of Beldoch Ind. Honorary Chairman, Brahman Management. Retired 1995. Former President National Notions Assoc., Olympic Tower Condo and Glen Head C.C. Industry Chairman and honoree UJA, ADL, Israel Bonds. Survived by his five proud sons: Jim (and Ellen), Tom (and Lynda), John (and Janet), Andrew (and Patricia), Peter (and Stacy); and his beloved wife of 20 years, Carol. Also survived by 13 adoring grandchildren: Amy and Scott Smith, Adam and Amy Hochfelder, Lauren, David, Jason, Julie, Josh, Alyssa, Robyn, Jake, Harrison, Charles and Lily; and four greatgrandchildren: Samantha, Hunter, Henry and Preston. Brother and life-long friend to Fred and Barbara; adored uncle to Maggie and Joanna. Brother-in-law and advisor to Michael Beldoch and Philip Hanan. Services Tuesday, September 21 at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC. Contributions may be made in his honor to UJA and/or ADL.

title: Expert Faults Court's Ruling About Waste From Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - The court that derailed the Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository in July, concluding that the government had not set strict enough rules on radioactivity leakage, based its decision on an incomplete reading of a National Academy of Sciences study, the chairman of the committee that wrote the study said on Monday.

title: Is Jersey Red Enough to Make Kerry Blue?
description: Is New Jersey deserting John Kerry? A new poll released today by Quinnipiac University found the Massachusetts senator tied with President Bush among likely and leaning voters there, although he had a slight lead among registered voters.

title: Jobs are it in Eastern Germany
Technology Briefing | Software: Red Hat Reports Profit Surge
description: Red Hat, the world's biggest distributor of the Linux computer operating system, said yesterday that second-quarter profit more than tripled as sales increased 60 percent, less than analysts had forecast. Net income rose to $11.8 million, or 6 cents a share, from $3.64 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier, Red Hat said. Sales for the quarter that ended Aug. 31 rose to $46.3 million from $29 million. The company said its Red Hat Enterprise Linux for businesses had 144,000 subscribers. Shares of Red Hat fell 52 cents, to $14.58, in extended trading after the report was released. They fell 13 cents, to $15.10, in regular trading.

description: Correction Appended

title: Majestic or mundane, that's Life
Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, EDDIE
description: ADAMS--Eddie. 1933-2004 With deep sorrow we mourn the loss of extraordinary photographer Eddie Adams. In his 45-year career, Eddie won hundreds of awards from his peers for his insightful and often startling photos that documented the human experience. Among his most poignant images were those of children and families affected by neuromuscular diseases, highlighted on the covers of Parade magazine. It is ironic that Eddie himself became the victim of one of those diseases. We are deeply grateful for the prominence he bestowed on Lou Gehrig's disease and for the help he brought toward finding a cure. Board of Directors Muscular Dystrophy Association Robert Ross President and CEO Robert M. Bennett Chairman Jerry Lewis National Chairman

title: 7 Steps to a Better Candidate
description: LOS ANGELES - Look, I want John Kerry to win, if only so I can fire my gun into the air and have it mean something for once. But, even though I think he'd be a better president, the guy's not going to make it with the campaign he's running. I mean, I haven't really followed it -- give me credit for having a life! -- but based on some comments from the "Sports-Center" anchors, it appears that Mr. Kerry should be doing better.

title: Chicago Board Case Ends
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 - An Illinois judge ruled on Monday that a settlement between the Chicago Board of Trade and some of its seatholders is fair, concluding a four-year court case and opening the way for the board of trade, a leading commodities market, to restructure and possibly make an initial public offering.

title: Indonesia's Next Leader: Very Capable but Questions Remain
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 21 A Indonesia's next president, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, commonly known here as S. B. Y., moved swiftly up the military ranks during the authoritarian rule of General Suharto, and then played a backseat role in the undoing of the regime.

title: Iraqi Video Shows Beheading of Man Said to Be American

title: The crisis in Darfur : This wolf is real, and nobody's listening
A Shakespearean Blood Bath of Cabbages and Kings
description: The spooky sound of metal scraping metal signals from the start that "Rose Rage," at the Duke on 42nd Street, is not, as you might imagine, a comedy about dueling florists or a sweet tale of backyard botanists squabbling over a contested variety. It's a hefty slab of Shakespeare: all three parts of "Henry VI," in fact, trimmed of fat and put through a meat grinder, then garnished with generous doses of directorial panache. A freshly sharpened cleaver, not a dagger or a sword, is the weapon of choice in Edward Hall's flashy, eminently accessible production, which presents 15th-century England as a slaughterhouse doing big business, where even the most privileged men are fated to become meat primed for the butcher block.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, MARGIT
description: SIMON--Margit. The Board and staff of City Parks Foundation mourn the passing of our dear friend Margit, a great lover of New York City's parks. We send our deepest condolences to Peter and the entire Simon family.

title: City Center Is Offering a Smorgasbord of Dance
description: City Center was where the New York City Ballet was born, in April 1948. When the company moved with the New York City Opera to Lincoln Center some two decades later, the theater's directors saved the underused hall from demolition by designating it a center for dance. That commitment has waned in recent years, but now City Center is returning the favor with a plan to provide new support for dance in hard economic times.

title: Charges of French anti-Semitism : A poisoned 'j'accuse' from America
Six Entrepreneurs Look Up, and Offer Advice
description: What can big business learn from small business? Here are views of small-business operators on big companies. BRIAN ALEXANDER

title: Partisans, and Nonpartisans, in Florida
description: Last week's face-off over whether Ralph Nader would be allowed a place on the Florida ballot was an object lesson in the role partisanship can play in setting the rules of an election. In her feverish maneuvering in support of Mr. Nader, Secretary of State Glenda Hood demeaned her office and the electoral process. The Florida Supreme Court, by contrast, applied the rules with the sort of nonpartisanship that is critical for democracy to function.

description: LOUDON, N.H., Sept. 20 - This really is a new age in stock-car racing. Robby Gordon, the scourge of Nascar, actually apologized for a reckless maneuver.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sept. 9 about the improvement of the New York Liberty women's basketball team after Pat Coyle succeeded Richie Adubato as coach misstated a comment from the team's general manager, Carol Blazejowski, about the midseason move of its home games to Radio City Music Hall from Madison Square Garden. Blazejowski said she was concerned about the move and somewhat dreaded it; she did not say she did not endorse it.

It was late 2000 and early 2001, not 1990 and 1991. A reader reported the error the day it appeared; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

description: It may be that the main order of business at the Juilliard School is the production of virtuoso soloists who can sail through the standard repertory with the best of them. But keeping the school's young musicians in touch with new music is also an important part of the mission, and as the director of several Juilliard-based new music groups, Joel Sachs oversees that side of the curriculum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEER, CYNTHIA ANN

For forty years, a memorable teacher at City and Country School, she will be remembered by her students and missed by her many friends. A memorial service will be announced.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Guard Killed At Capitol
description: A man stepped inside the Capitol in Springfield, shot a security guard to death, then rushed out and drove off, the authorities said. The shooting sent state workers running into offices, where they waited behind locked doors for nearly an hour. The Legislature was not in session, and Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, a Democrat, was not in the capital, 200 miles southwest of Chicago. The authorities were searching for a man they identified as Derek W. Potts, 24, who they said had been involved in an attempted armed robbery at a nearby military surplus store. Mr. Potts was charged with murder and burglary. Monica Davey (NYT)
