description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Find Defectsin Shelter System
description: In late July, Oliver Griffin, 58, was staying at the Charles H. Gay shelter for homeless men in New York City while recovering from spinal surgery when, he said, a new caseworker brought him what sounded like good news.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES LOWERS ESTIMATE FOR PROFIT
description: Superior Industries, a maker of vehicle wheels, said profit for the third quarter will be about half that of analysts' estimates because of factory start-up delays and declining auto production. Net income will be about 20 cents a share, compared with an estimate of 39 cents a share by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net income for the period a year earlier was 40 cents a share. Superior lost sales because of delays in restarting factories after the annual summer shutdown, the company's president, Steve Borick, said in a statement. Stock in Superior, which is based in Van Nuys, Calif., fell $1.53, or 5 percent, to $30.04 a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: A Forecast For Growth
description: Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, facing a falling stock market and elections next year, told a group of fund managers that his country's economy could grow 6 percent to 7 percent this year. Higher oil prices have slowed economic growth, but Mr. Thaksin assured investors gathered in Bangkok that rising export demand and domestic consumer spending would offset higher energy costs. More than 300 fund managers, from Thailand and overseas, are attending a government-sponsored seminar extolling the strengths of the Thai economy. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Nintendo's Newest Product Aims for Adults
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 - In a shift in strategy, Nintendo is expected to announce on Tuesday that it plans to begin selling its next generation of hand-held video game devices in the United States in time for the coming Christmas season.

title: CBS Quiet About Fallout, but Precedent Is Ominous
description: Correction Appended

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Study Raises Questions About Bioengineered Grass A new study shows that genes from genetically engineered grass spread much farther than previously known. The finding raises questions about the straying of other plants altered through biotechnology, and could hurt the efforts of two companies to win approval for the first bioengineered grass.

title: At Country Clubs, Gay Members Want All Privileges for Partners
description: Correction Appended

title: 29 Hurt as Commuter Train Hits a Truck in Westchester
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 20 - A southbound Metro-North train carrying about 200 passengers collided with a 18-wheel truck that had become stuck on the tracks during the morning rush on Monday. The accident sent 29 people to hospitals, with the most seriously injured passenger suffering a broken leg .

title: For the Jets, Two Victories, Two Unwelcome Injuries
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 20 - The Jets began their bye week Monday, and the time off comes not a moment too soon.

title: The Candidates' Advisers (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Advances Move to Nuclear Fuel, Defying U.N.
description: PARIS, Sept. 21 A Iran defied the United Nations today by announcing that it had begun converting tons of uranium into the gas needed to turn the radioactive element into nuclear fuel. The world body's International Atomic Energy Agency called on Saturday for the country to suspend all such activities.

title: Talking Sense, at Last, on Iraq
description: After weeks of politically damaging delay, John Kerry finally seems to have found his voice on what ought to be the central issue of this year's election: the mismanaged war in Iraq and how to bring it to an acceptable conclusion. It was none too soon. While the fate of the Iraqi people, the success of the war on terrorism and America's international standing have all been teetering ominously in the balance, Mr. Kerry has allowed the presidential campaign to veer off into squabbles about events long past -- like the candidates' 30-year-old war records -- and about Mr. Kerry's confusing and sometimes contradictory recent statements on foreign policy.

title: Weighing the Risks in a Health Savings Account
description: A LITTLE-NOTICED provision in the Medicare prescription drug law passed by Congress late last year is starting to shake up the group insurance market for small businesses.

title: All of a Sudden, the Neighborhood Looks a Lot Friendlier
description: Like most New Yorkers, I have real estate fever. Even though I hate moving, I can't travel anywhere without wondering what it would be like to live there. I can't walk down a street in Oaxaca or the East Village without window shopping for apartments and evaluating the restaurant scene and the availability of playgrounds.

title: As Delaware River Recedes, New Jersey Assesses Damage
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20 - Residents of towns along the Delaware River who were forced from their homes by flooding over the weekend started returning on Monday, while New Jersey officials assessed the damage to see if the state would be eligible for federal aid.

title: In Harshest Critique Yet, Kerry Attacks Bush Over War in Iraq
description: Correction Appended

title: Piano Classicist Strikes a Delicate Balance
description: The pianist Mulgrew Miller proves the efficacy of moderation. His playing commits no extravagance. At an even volume, he balances his improvisations among all the instrument's registers; he also balances bulletlike runs, sweet-and-sour experiments in harmony and rhythmic block-chording, producing just enough sound to ring through the band's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PYE, CLARA
description: PYE--Clara, 94, of Middlebury CT. on September 18, 2004. Widow of H. Walter Pye. Mother of Charles and Susan. Grandmother of Leah. Funeral Tuesday, September 21 at 2 PM at the MunsonLovetere Funeral Home, 235 Main St North, Southbury, CT.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: More Training After Deadly Fire
description: The Chicago Fire Department unveiled training and procedural changes nearly a year after mistakes contributed to six deaths in a fire at the Cook County Administration Building. A commission issued a scathing report in July on the department's handling of the fire. Firefighters will receive more training to fight high-rise fires, and veteran firefighters will undergo mandatory annual fitness tests. The department will also assign some personnel strictly for search and rescue operations. David Bernstein (NYT)

title: The Candidates' Advisers
description: To the Editor:

title: Owens Corning Asks to Consolidate Units
description: Owens Corning, the insulation maker, asked a judge to decide if it can consolidate its units as part of a reorganization plan so that it can speed up its exit from bankruptcy protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELTON, DORIS
description: FELTON--Doris. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Doris Felton, who with her beloved husband Murray were longtime ADL leaders and supporters on Long Island, NY and in Boca West in Florida. We extend our sincerest condolences to Murray, their children and the entire family. Barbara B. Balser, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Pakistani President May Stay in Uniform
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20 - Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said in an interview on Monday that his leadership was freeing his country from the menace of extremism and that this national "renaissance" might be lost if he kept his pledge to step down as army chief at the end of this year.

title: Nominee Says Iraq Threat Was Perhaps Overstated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Representative Porter J. Goss, the nominee to become director of central intelligence, said on Monday that some prewar statements by senior Bush administration officials might well have overstated available intelligence about the threat posed by Iraq.

title: Genital mutilation : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
The Candidates' Advisers
description: To the Editor:

title: The mail gets through, but carried by snails : Neither rain nor sleet nor dark but, ouch, the Net
With Red Sox Gone, Thrill Is, Too
description: The problem with playing a series that feels like October when it is only September comes the day after.

title: How Tax Cuts Feed the Beast
description: On the campaign trail, President Bush is busy telling voters that he wants to keep making government "smaller and more efficient" and that his opponent, John Kerry, wants a return to the days of big government. Forget the profligate spending of the past four years, he seems to suggest; instead, think of the many tax cuts that have been pushed through and how in time, as the saying goes, they will "starve the beast."

title: Hitler's other side : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Election in Kazakhstan Failed Democracy Test, Europeans Say
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Sept 20 - Parliamentary elections in Kazakhstan on Sunday fell short of international standards, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said Monday.

title: Seeking antitrust job, she vows never to return to board seats : EU's Kroes confronts conflicts of interest
Portraits From North Main Street, the Heart of a Town
description: ALTAMONT, Ill. - THE shorthand term for small business in economic debates is Main Street, and the sector has long been mythologized as the all-American heart of small towns and cities across the country. And, in fact, North Main Street here is the home primarily of small storefront shops and companies.

title: Frequent Fliers Wonder if Their Miles Have a Future
description: For the occasional traveler, the latest round of airline bankruptcy filings may feel like the early 1990's, when some big carriers flew under a dark cloud of bankruptcy protection and others never emerged from it.

title: Euro RCSG Worldwide Wins Glaxo Campaign
description: GlaxoSmithKline in Philadelphia has expanded its relationship with Euro RCSG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas, by awarding the agency the assignment to create campaigns aimed at consumers for Advair, an asthma medication. Spending on the assignment, which had been handled by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, was estimated at more than $100 million.

title: United to Offer a Premium Service on Some Transcontinental Flights
description: Not much makes sense these days in an industry that has lost more than $20 billion while cutting prices sharply as demand increases. So let's not automatically scoff at this bright idea from United, a bankrupt airline that is ready to start up a fancy new transcontinental service to lure high-paying premium business fliers who will pay top dollar for flat-bed seats and other frills.

title: Fighting to put London back on fashion map
On the Sunny Side of the Street, Optimism Is an Understatement
description: MAGAZINES aimed at small-business hopefuls are filled with ways to help them leave the gravitational pull of a salaried job and strike out on their own.

title: CBS Apologizes for Report on Bush Guard Service
description: After nearly two weeks at the center of a news media storm, Dan Rather and CBS News admitted yesterday that they could not authenticate four documents the network had used to raise new questions about President Bush's Vietnam-era National Guard service and said the news report had been a "mistake in judgment."

title: REALLY?
description: THE CLAIM -- Cellphones increase the risk of brain cancer.

title: Bush and Kerry Share City, if Not Much Else
description: New York City, never known for its tendency to swing, politically, nevertheless played host to both the red and blue teams last night, as President Bush and Senator John Kerry crossed paths here in their search for money and support.

title: For Buyers Who Have No Time
description: WHEN it comes to the PC needs of most small businesses, what is important is not speed but stability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORAN, THOMAS FRANCIS
description: HORAN--Thomas Francis on September 20, 2004 of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Mary. Loving father of Liz Barouh, John (Teresa), Maggie McGuire (Gregory), Paul and Cecilia Beane (Roger). Cherished grandfather of Alexander, Kevin, Thomas, Caitlin, Patrick and Michael. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue, Wednesday 3-6PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10AM, St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Kingston, N.Y. Contributions may be made in his memory to The Meredith Autism Program Gift Fund, 3800 Hillsborough Street, Raleigh, N.C. 27607-5298. 919-760-8080.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Teachers Plan One-Day Strike
description: The Kentucky Education Association, a union representing 45,000 public school teachers, plans to stage a one-day strike on Monday to protest a proposal to nearly triple the cost of health benefits for teachers, school employees and state workers. The union said that if health insurance costs did not remain in line with costs in nearby states, teachers would be urged to strike indefinitely, starting on Oct. 27. Gov. Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, warned that a 1970 court order prohibited the teachers from striking. Last month he proposed a plan that would save the state $150 million by raising insurance deductibles to $800 and tripling the cost of co-payments. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, HONORABLE, DAVID
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Honorable -David, Justice of The Supreme Court of the State of New York, County of Queens. Devoted husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Robin and Deborah. Dear son of Irma Goldstein Bollt; sister Bonnie Rifkin. Services today 1pm at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Genes From Engineered Grass Spread for Miles, Study Finds
description: A new study shows that genes from genetically engineered grass can spread much farther than previously known, a finding that raises questions about the straying of other plants altered through biotechnology and that could hurt the efforts of two companies to win approval for the first bioengineered grass.

title: Museum With an American Indian Voice
description: WASHINGTON - Early Tuesday morning, 20,000 members of more than 500 Indian tribes from all over the American hemisphere are expected to gather on the Mall to begin a ceremonial march toward the National Museum of the American Indian. But they will not just be celebrating the opening of the Smithsonian's new building. This Native Nations Procession, organized by the museum and forming, perhaps, the largest assembly of America's native peoples in modern times, will also be a self-celebration.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Baby Sneaker Recall
description: About 140,000 pairs of Reebok sneakers for toddlers have been recalled because a label on them poses a choking hazard, federal officials said. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said the "I3" tag on the tongue of the sneakers, the Iverson/Answer model, can be peeled off and swallowed. Ten model numbers, which can be found on a label on the underside of the shoe's tongue, are being recalled: 99553, B99553, 99554, B99554, 105155, B105155, 105158, B105158, 108292 and B108292. Reebok officials urged consumers to call (800) 843-4444 for information on refunds. John Files (NYT)

title: Bank
description: BANKS want your business, so which one do you want to give your business to? Answering that question, experts say, requires taking a clear look at just what a small business needs and doesn't need, reading the fine print about fees and limits and taking the time to comparison-shop.

title: Heat From Eagles' Defense Too Stifling for the Vikings
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 - The wide receiver duel between Randy Moss and Terrell Owens never materialized. The early-season matchup of leading N.F.C. contenders turned into a showcase not for offensive fireworks but for a blistering Eagles defense.

title: Regimens: Excess Protein Can Take a Toll
description: Patients with ulcerative colitis who consume lots of red meat or alcohol have a sharply higher risk of relapse, researchers reported last week.

title: In Fields Old and New, Sometimes It's the Little Guy Who's the Giant
description: GIANTS come in all sizes. Take Stratasys, a company based in Eden Prairie, Minn., with just over 200 employees and $50 million in revenue last year.

title: Colorado Election Keeps Bryant Debate Bubbling
description: EAGLE, Colo., Sept. 16 - The abrupt collapse of the sexual assault case against the basketball star Kobe Bryant this month left a lot of questions hanging in the air here in this central Colorado town where Docket No. 03 CR 204 rose and fell. And many of them center on the young district attorney, Mark Hurlbert, who brought the charge, pursued it for a year at great expense, then dropped it suddenly on the eve of the trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, STEVEN C.
description: GREENE--Steven C., 67, of Sag Harbor and Bedford, New York died on September 15, 2004. Survived by his wife Gunilla Greene, children Jon and Karen, stepsons Nicholas and Erik and sister Marilyn Ginsberg. A practicing attorney, his kindness, generosity and valued counsel will be forever remembered.

title: Debating Drug Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: Silvers Call to Override Patakion Budget Vetoes Collapses
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20 - Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver called his members back to Albany on Monday intending to embarrass Gov. George E. Pataki by overriding many of his vetoes of the state budget.

title: Second Thoughts on Restricting Drugs to Treat Depression in Adolescents
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 - It was Britain's warning to physicians last year not to treat depression in young people with six antidepressant drugs that set off an international debate and gave impetus to United States health authorities who made similar recommendations this week, saying the drugs largely failed to treat depression in children and teenagers and led some to become suicidal.

title: Designers Who Would Rather Whisper Than Shout
description: At his fashion show this month, Thakoon Panichgul introduced a 10-piece collection highlighted by a quilted coat in a shade of pink so tender it matched the inside of a bunny's ear. The color was not likely to shake up his audience, but then it was not meant to. "Everything about this collection is muted, not loud or vulgar," said Mr. Panichgul, a Thai-born New Yorker, whose label is simply Thakoon.

title: A Late Charge by the Crew
description: A tight race in Major League Soccer's Eastern Conference became even more cramped over the weekend as the Columbus Crew -- riding a 13-game unbeaten streak -- became the first of the eight qualifiers for the postseason, the MetroStars stumbled (again) and D.C. United won its second straight game (United has lost only once in its last seven matches).

title: Court Officer Convicted in Brooklyn Bribery Case
description: In the first trials in the corruption scandal surrounding a Brooklyn matrimonial judge, a veteran court officer was convicted yesterday of taking bribes to steer divorce cases to the judge. The judge's longtime clerk, however, was acquitted of similar charges.

title: The Dark Side Is Back Again in Its Stadium
description: HBO, the Emmy-laden sanctuary for sociopathic mobsters, dysfunctional undertakers and commitment-challenged women, has tried a change of pace by taking a walk on the schmaltzy side.

title: Disparities: For Cancer Survivors, Worse Care
description: People who survive cancer appear to get worse care than the general population when it comes to other diseases, a study released last week concluded.

title: INSIDE
description: Haitians Scramble to Escape Deadly Floodwaters More than 550 people died in Haiti over the weekend from flooding and mudslides set off by Tropical Storm Jeanne, according to aid workers, who said half of the northern city of Gonaves was still under water yesterday. PAGE A8

title: Real Madrid in chaos as coach quicky quits
World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Rejection Of Air Alliance Upheld
description: Qantas Airways' proposed alliance with Air New Zealand was rejected by New Zealand's High Court, the latest blow in Qantas's two-year attempt to team up to cut costs and fend off competition. Qantas's chief executive, Geoff Dixon, said the company would not appeal the ruling. "We need to move on," he said. The deal called for Qantas to take a 22.5 percent stake in Air New Zealand for 550 million New Zealand dollars ($363.1 million). The court upheld a decision by New Zealand's antitrust regulator, which in 2003 blocked the alliance, saying it would raise fares and hurt tourism.

title: Art's Fate
description: A weeklong hearing is to begin today on whether the financially beleaguered Barnes Foundation can move its multibillion-dollar art collection from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia. At issue is whether the move, which would probably involve building a new gallery on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway near the Philadelphia Museum of Art, would constitute the "least drastic deviation" from the 1922 trust indenture of Albert C. Barnes. To finance the move, three foundations -- the Pew Charitable Trusts, the Lenfest Foundation and the Annenberg Foundation -- have promised to help raise $150 million, including $50 million for an endowment. But three students at the Barnes Foundation, which was set up as an educational institution, are asking Montgomery County Orphans' Court Judge Stanley R. Ott to keep the gallery in Merion, even if means selling off thousands of artworks in storage or a Chester County property also owned by the Barnes. In a January decision, Judge Ott asked the Barnes trustees to provide estimates of how much money could be raised by selling nongallery assets, as well as a feasibility study on the move and the future costs of operating a Merion administration building, downtown gallery and the Chester County property. "The bottom line is that you can't raise $50 million by selling these things," said Ralph G. Wellington of Schnader Harrison Segal & Lewis, which is representing the foundation. "But even if you could, this is the wrong thing to do." JULIA M. KLEIN

title: Yanks' Giambi Watches, Waits and Wonders
description: While his teammates moved about their Yankee Stadium locker room in leisurely fashion before last night's game against Toronto, Jason Giambi hurriedly grabbed his bat and glove and seemed almost out of breath as he waited to rush out to the field for batting practice. For Giambi, pregame rituals are all he has.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about Saddam Hussein's life in a prison outside Baghdad, pending his trial on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity, misstated the year his forces used chemical weapons on the Kurdish village of Halabja, Iraq, killing at least 5,000 people. It was in March 1988, not 1998.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Don't Look Up

title: Soccer: Real Madrid in chaos as coach quicky quits
The F.E.C.'s Mockery of Its Own Law
description: If the Federal Election Commission has any sense of shame, it will immediately meet in an emergency session to deal with a scathing new court decision that pinions the commission for what it has long been: the chief writer and enabler of election law loopholes that invite big-money corruption of the political process. In a stinging judgment, a federal judge in Washington struck down 15 of the F.E.C.'s recent rule interpretations as gimmicks transparently designed to undermine -- not uphold -- the campaign finance reform law of 2002. Rarely has a federal watchdog been so thoroughly rebuked.

title: Q & A
description: Saving a Species

title: Wet Nose, Floppy Ears, Four Legs and a Million Business Opportunities
description: SOME people look at dogs and see their best friend. Others see a business opportunity. Here are a few such tales:

title: Mets or Expos Will Be Crowned the N.L. Least
description: FORGET Red Sox-Yankees. Never mind the National League wild card. Oakland-Anaheim, Los Angeles-San Francisco? Who cares? The most compelling race left is the pursuit of last place in the National League East.

title: Inch by Inch, Bush and Kerry Reach Agreement on Debates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - President Bush and Senator John Kerry agreed Monday to meet for three debates before Election Day, after their campaigns hashed out dozens of details about coin tosses, seating and makeup.

title: Only in Quantum Physics: Spinning While Standing Still
description: Quantum mechanics has done it again. In an experiment with supercooled helium, researchers at Penn State say they have found that as a solid ring spins around, part of it can remain perfectly still.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 24 about a racial discrimination lawsuit filed against the Eastman Kodak Company misspelled the surname of one plaintiff. She is Cynthia A. Gayden, not Grayden. A recent letter from Ms. Gayden alerted The Times to the error.

title: Treatment: Relieving Pain Without Pills
description: Massages, aromatherapy and even karaoke nights helped reduce pain in nursing home residents, researchers have found. So did taking a more systematic approach to the use of prescription drugs.

title: A Foe of Injustice and Champion of Lost Causes
description: MYRON BELDOCK was late. He rushed through the door of his Midtown Manhattan office, looking more frazzled than someone with nearly 50 years of experience as a lawyer has any right to look. At 75, he has a lot to do, what with a Syracuse case involving an arrest he insists was unjust, an appeal of an old Brooklyn murder conviction (a frame-up, he says), and who knows what other injustices may be lurking in the piles of papers littering his spacious office.

title: Politicus : Trying to put Islam on Europe's agenda
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEUER, WALTER
description: SCHEUER--Walter. An investor, philanthropist, and producer of documentary films, died on Monday, September 20, 2004, after a period of decline. Wally will be remembered with great love by his devoted wife, Marge, his children, David, Jeffrey, Susan, and Judith, their spouses, his seven grandchildren, and his many friends and associates. Wally was born in New York City in 1922, and attended The Ethical Culture School, Fieldston School, and Swarthmore College, from which he graduated with high honors. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army Signal Corps, in the South Pacific, including New Guinea and the Philippines, aboard The U.S.S. Blue Ridge. In 1979, in the middle of a successful career on Wall Street, he produced a documentary film about the violinist Issac Stern's tour of China, the first by a major Western classical musician. The film "From Mao To Mozart: Isaac Stern in China" won an Academy Award in 1981 for best documentary. In addition to "From Mao To Mozart" Walter Scheuer produced a number of other documentary films, including "High Fidelity" (1988) about the Guarneri Quartet, "November's Children" a 1991 film about the Velvet Revolution in Czechoslovakia, "Dancemaker" about The Paul Taylor Dance Company, and "Small Wonders" a film about Roberta Tzavaras and Opus 110 an organization devoted to teaching music to inner city children which was an Academy Award nominee in 1995, and became the basis for the feature film "Music Of The Heart." Mr. Scheuer served on the Boards of Carnegie Hall, Symphony Space, and The Paul Taylor Dance Company. He privately sponsored many young students from around the world to come to study in New York and supported other documentary filmmakers. In 1999, Mr. Scheuer was awarded his most cherished honor: an Honorary Degree from his alma mater, Swarthmore College. Services will be held on Thursday, September 23, at Riverside Chapel, West 76Street at 2:30 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Wednesday about an exhibition of sculptures by Tom Otterness on landscaped Broadway medians misspelled the name of a gallery that helped organize it. It is the Marlborough Gallery, not Marlboro.

title: A Widow Looks for Trophies, and Finds More
description: FAMILY ties bind in strange, mysterious and sometimes very sad ways, as two members of the extended New York City basketball community discovered not long ago.

title: In One Building, Outposts for a Globe Full of Toys
description: SOME businesses cluster in districts, others in buildings. The International Toy Center, at 200 Fifth Avenue and 24th Street in Manhattan, is to the toy industry what the garment district was to clothes: a thriving, industry-specific commercial zone, where companies of all sizes from around the globe gather to sell their goods.

title: Investors get choosier as field widens : Hedging smarter
Case Studies: New Clues on Dreams' Origins
description: Where do dreams come from? Scientists have debated the question for decades. But Swiss researchers last week reported new clues from the case of a woman who temporarily lost her ability to dream after a stroke, even though she still had periods of rapid eye movement sleep or R.E.M. sleep, also called "dream sleep," every night.

title: If Failure Is Normal, How Do Workers Fare?
description: MATTHEW GERSHNER, a salesman from Manhattan, remembers gauging the declining fortunes of a past employer by the location of its annual sales meeting. "One year it was held in Atlantic City at a nice hotel," he said. "The following year it was at a lodge in the Catskills, and the year after that, conference calls."

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Judy Barry was named vice president for marketing and business development at The Wall Street Journal, New York, published by Dow Jones & Company. She succeeds Jim Donoghue, now chief operating officer for financial information services at a sibling, Dow Jones Newswires. Ms. Barry had been a consultant and previously worked for publications including The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post.

title: Fed Raises a Key Rate a Quarter-Point as Widely Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates another notch this afternoon, and it suggested that it would keep raising them gradually over the next year.

title: Modern Is Offered Trove of Drawings
description: It began with a modest epiphany. Visiting the Armory Show on the Hudson waterfront last year, Harvey S. Shipley Miller was struck by the abundance of drawings on view.

title: Software Program
description: SOMEWHERE between sitting down at your computer to jot down ideas about a new widget store, and becoming big enough to hire a systems manager, the owner of a small company has to buy software to smooth the way.

title: Gee, Honey, Who Can Resist an Okie With Twangy Charm?
description: "Rodney" is no "Roseanne," but it is a lot like "Reba."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LOW, ELLIOTT LAWRENCE
description: LOW--Elliott Lawrence. 9/21/ 04-7/4/69. Born 100 years ago today, remembered always with admiration and love. Penny and Pet

title: Mother and Companion Are Accused of Killing Baby
description: The tally of the boy's injuries were approaching the number of weeks he had been alive: some 60 bruises to the head, torso and limbs, according to an autopsy, along with three recent rib fractures, a broken leg, a crushing blow to the liver, and a bruised duodenum -- the first section of his small intestine. He would have turned 2 in three weeks.

title: Medicare, Now and in the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS.The dollar rose on expectations that the Federal Reserve will lift its interest rate on overnight loans between banks today. In New York, the euro settled at $1.2165, down from $1.2178 on Friday.

title: An Explorer Both Musical and Jealous
description: The Marx brothers being currently unavailable, it has fallen to a cast of lesser lights to try to leach lunacy from musical fluff. Under the title "Meet the Real Ernest Shackleton: A Comedy About Antarctica," this slight, silly trifle is inhabiting the Sande Shurin Theater on the sixth floor of 311 West 43rd Street in Clinton through Sunday.

title: Sources of terrorism : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Breathing Room
description: Hours before their contract was to expire at midnight, the musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra and its management agreed on Sunday to continue negotiations for a month. The action precluded a strike that would have threatened the opening of the season tonight. A contract deadline was also due to slip by last night at the New York Philharmonic, and while little talk has taken place between management and musicians, tonight's season-opening concert did not appear threatened. The Cleveland Orchestra and Chicago Symphony are also negotiating without contracts in place. In a joint statement issued late Sunday night, the parties in Philadelphia promised to impose a news media blackout, which would be a sharp contrast to weeks of bitter jousting in newspapers and on rival Web sites. The musicians voted on Saturday to authorize a strike after their negotiating committee walked out of talks, calling management's latest offer on pensions insulting. But the talks were rekindled around midday Sunday, with the help of a federal mediator. Management is seeking to reduce labor costs to cover a $1.8 million budget shortfall and has proposed eliminating several full time positions, reducing pension expenses and limiting salary increases. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: 'Star Wars,' With Even More Digital Tweaks
description: 'The Star Wars Trilogy'

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES.Crude oil surged after Yukos Oil, the Russian oil giant, said it would halt shipments to China's biggest oil company. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 76 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $46.35 a barrel.

title: Even Humbled by Error, Dan Rather Has His Thorns
description: There were no folksy Texan phrases in Dan Rather's report last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPETZ, LEON M.
description: LIPETZ--Leon M. September 20, 2004 after a prolonged illness. A Holocaust survivor, survived by brothers Jacques and Eric. Sister-in-law Margaret, nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EFLAND, HOWARD
description: EFLAND--Howard. Though the curtain closed a year ago, the drama of a life well-lived continues. With deep affection on behalf of your pals; you are missed. Bob Halloran Frank Pignataro

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WYGODA, GERALD
description: WYGODA--Gerald. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourns the death of Gerald Wygoda. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his mother Ida, brother Joseph and the entire Wygoda family. Daniel Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Venerable Yacht Builder Tries to Regain Sea Legs
description: STURGEON BAY, Wis. - Generations of the rich and powerful have looked to this remote peninsula city on Lake Michigan, where the boat builder Palmer Johnson has long made and serviced their playthings of the sea.

title: Hypocrisy over Turkey : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Schwab Trims Review To Seven Ad Agencies
description: Charles Schwab, the discount brokerage firm, has narrowed a review for its creative and strategic account, with billings estimated at $90 million to $100 million, to seven agencies.

title: Credit Card
description: IT has been 16 years since Kathrine Gregory started her restaurant and catering consulting firm, but she vividly remembers how many credit cards were being offered to small-business owners then. "There were zero," she said.

title: Music to My Ears
description: To the Editor:

title: What Politics? Seventh Ave. Puts on a Sunny Face
description: Correction Appended

title: Rogers Wireless Makes Bid For Upstart Canadian Rival
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 20 - Rogers Wireless Communications positioned itself to become Canada's largest wireless service provider on Monday with a bid for the feisty market upstart, Microcell Telecommunications.

title: Yet Another Borough
description: To the Editor:

title: Grief and an Evening Vigil in a Michigan Small Town
description: Correction Appended

title: Golf : Europeans enjoy record victory
The Last Deception
description: It's Ayad Allawi week. President Bush, starting with his address at the U.N. today, will try to present Mr. Allawi -- a former Baathist who the BBC reports was chosen as prime minister because he was "equally mistrusted by everyone" -- as the leader of a sovereign nation on the path to democracy. If the media play along, Mr. Bush may be able to keep the Iraq disaster under wraps for a few more weeks.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Fraternities Must Hire Security
description: The University of Alabama said fraternities must hire a security guard for parties after three unrelated cases of violence at fraternity parties on Sept. 11. At Sigma Nu, a student was stabbed in the head and is in a coma. One man was beaten at the Pi Kappa Alpha house and another at the Theta Chi house. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Slower Chip Sales Forecast
description: The South Korean electronics company Samsung Electronics projected slower growth in the global semiconductor industry next year but said its own growth should increase as it expands in other areas. Hwang Chang Gyu, president of the semiconductor division, forecast growth in the semiconductor sector next year would slow to about 10 percent from this year's 20 percent. Samsung also brought out new products, including a data memory chip for mobile devices that it says provides the greatest amount of data storage among similar products. Samsung said it planned to begin production of the new chip in the second half of next year. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: PEOPLES ENERGY CUTS JOBS AND LOWERS FORECAST
description: Peoples Energy, owner of Chicago's natural gas utility, cut 110 jobs and lowered its earnings forecast for the fourth quarter after higher gas prices and milder weather decreased demand. Fiscal 2004 earnings will be $2.20 to $2.30 a share, compared with $2.87 in fiscal 2003. Peoples will have costs of $17 million, or 27 cents a share, after 300 employees accepted severance offers. Demand for gas fell 6 percent from a year earlier, the chief financial officer, Thomas Nardi, told an investor conference. Profit excluding severance costs will be $2.50 to $2.60 a share in fiscal 2004, down from a previous forecast of $2.60 to $2.70. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn $2.56 a share.

title: Israeli Airstrike Kills 2 Hamas Militants, Wounds 6 Bystanders
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 - An Israeli airstrike on Monday night in Gaza City, the second in as many days, killed two militants of the Islamic faction Hamas and wounded at least six bystanders, Palestinians said.

title: Second Thoughts for a Designer of Software That Aids Conservation
description: Australia's recent decision to ban fishing on a third of the Great Barrier Reef represented an important endorsement for an obscure computer program that has become the brains behind many conservation plans around the world.

title: ROCHE SAYS DRUG FOR PANCREATIC CANCER IS PROMISING
description: A drug being developed by Roche Holding, Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals helped patients with pancreatic cancer live longer when combined with chemotherapy, a late-stage study showed. About 26 percent of patients treated with the experimental drug, Tarceva, lived at least a year, compared with about 20 percent of patients who received only chemotherapy, the companies said. Roche, which is based in Basel, Switzerland, has filed for approval of the drug in the United States for lung cancer. Genentech, based in South San Francisco, and OSI, based in Melville, N.Y., will jointly market the drug in the United States and share revenue. Roche, which holds a majority stake in Genentech, will sell Tarceva in Europe and pay royalties to OSI, which invented the drug.

title: But skeptics doubt it will deliver jobs : French budget targets competitiveness gap
Paid Notice: Deaths   TOLINS, FLORENCE JILER ''PEGGY.''
description: TOLINS--Florence Jiler "Peggy." Memorial services were held on Monday at 4 P.M. at Leevy's Funeral Home, in Columbia, SC. Ms. Tolins, wife of Dr. Stephen H. Tolins, died Sunday in Columbia, SC. She was a journalist at The Bridgeport News, and was also a physical therapist. She is survived by a daughter, Amelia Coughlin, a son, Joseph Tolins, a brother, William Jiler, grandson, Shaun, and a granddaughter, Kelsey.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Thursday with an article about two former stars of the "Lassie" television show, June Lockhart and Jon Provost, misstated the timing of their work on the show. They were not the original stars; Jan Clayton and Tommy Rettig were.

title: Export Cut to China Seen as Clever Strategy on Yukos's Part
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 - Yukos, the Russian oil giant, is playing a weak hand well in its battle with the Kremlin by cutting its oil shipments to China ahead of a meeting between leaders of the countries this week, analysts said on Monday.

title: I.M.F. Chief Sees Potential Hazard in U.S. Fiscal Policies
description: The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Rodrigo de Rato, said yesterday that the dollar would have to fall and the United States would have to tackle its growing indebtedness to avoid a threat to the world economy some time in the future.

title: TELEFLEX CUTS EARNINGS ESTIMATES FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: Teleflex Inc., which makes aerospace equipment, auto parts and medical tools, reduced its earnings estimates because of lower pricing from automakers, weak sales of gas-turbine services and higher costs. Its shares fell 10 percent. Profit will be 38 cents to 40 cents a share in the third quarter and $2.60 to $2.70 for the full year, Teleflex said. The company, based in Limerick, Pa., previously forecast $2.90 to $3 for the year. Three subsidiaries, representing about 10 percent of sales, will lose a combined $30 million in 2004. The company said it had hired Goldman, Sachs to evaluate whether to sell, consolidate or close some businesses. Teleflex's shares fell $4.80, to $41.59.

title: Annan Repeats Misgivings About Legality of Iraq War
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 A Secretary General Kofi Annan opened the annual United Nations debate of world leaders today with a plea for greater observance of international law and a reminder of his misgivings about the legality of the war in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILLS, WILL
description: HILLS--Will, 60, of Kittery Point, ME and Brookline, MA, passed away on Sunday, September 19, 2004. In 1972 Will founded Limitless Design. He is survived by his wife Beth Segers, his parents Mr. & Mrs. James Maddox of New York City, two brothers-inlaw Carl Segers and Joseph Segers, and four nieces and nephews, Natalie, Anne Marie, Charlie and Katharine. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Friday, 11 AM, at St. Raphael Parish Church on 6 Whipple Rd., Kittery, ME 03904. Visiting Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 9-10:15 AM at the J. S. Pelkey Funeral Home, Kittery, ME. In lieu of flowers donations to Cambridge Adult Education Center, 42 Brattle St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUKS, JOSEPH
description: LUKS--Joseph, 92, of Long Beach, NY, and formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, died on September 19, 2004. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Loving father of Arlene Caplan and her husband Harvey, and Allan Luks and his wife Karen. Adored Poppa to Stacie, Jodi, Rachel, Ken and David. Great grandfather of Alexander and Noah. Funeral services today 1 PM at "Gutterman's", 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

title: On a Bridge of Sighs, the Suicidal Meet a Staying Hand
description: NANJING, China - The view from where Chen Si stood on the landmark Yangtze River Bridge captured the frantic, thrumming energy of China. Honking trucks and buses poured over the span as hundreds of barges slid along the dark brown water below. The sweeping downtown skyline rose in the distance.

title: In Presidential Debates, a Duelof Wits and Styles
description: The first of this year's three presidential and one vice-presidential debates will take place a week from Thursday, on Sept. 30, at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla., under an agreement announced yesterday by the representatives of the major-party campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENKRANZ, JULES
description: ROSENKRANZ--Jules. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Jules Rosenkranz. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred Youngwood, President

title: E.T., Are You Out There?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pataki Wins on Budget, but Gridlock Still Rules Albany
description: ALBANY, Sept. 21 - Gov. George E. Pataki, who has been increasingly marginalized by the Legislature in recent years, made it clear on Monday that he is still able to emerge from hibernation and flex his political muscles.

title: A Duo Conjures Up Nostalgia
description: Dixie Carter, that madcap steel magnolia from Tennessee, and John Wallowitch, the venerable Manhattan composer, singer and pianist of the old school, make an odd but charming couple. The relationship between the glamorous Southern cutup and the urbanite with a sly Cheshire-cat smile goes back more than 40 years. And when Ms. Carter sings Mr. Wallowitch's intimate after-hours ballads, "Come a Little Closer" and "This Moment," they conjure a poignant, less hectic Manhattan where sophistication implied nothing naughtier than an extra glass of Champagne and cocktail chatter discreetly laced with innuendo.

title: Cellar Door Opens, and the Mets Lean Into the Darkness
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 21 - With last place in the National League East on the line at Olympic Stadium this week, the Mets' lame-duck manager, Art Howe, said he had no plans to deliver a fire-and-brimstone speech in an attempt to rally his swooning team from one final embarrassment.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

Iran Moves Toward Enriching Uranium
description: PARIS, Sept. 21 - Iran defied the United Nations' nuclear agency on Tuesday, announcing that it had begun converting tons of uranium into gas, a crucial step in making fuel for a nuclear reactor or a nuclear bomb. The International Atomic Energy Agency called Saturday for Iran to suspend all such activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRUE, GERRY KAPLAN
description: TRUE--Gerry Kaplan. Manhattan artist and textile designer, died in Berkeley, CA September 19. She is survived by her children Lisa True and Merlyn Messenger.

title: In the Meatpacking District, Packed In
description: SELDOM has a Manhattan neighborhood gone from intriguing to annoying -- from on-the-cusp to over-the-top -- with the distressing speed and depressing thoroughness of the meatpacking district. It is not really a neighborhood anymore. It is an urban theme park: a gaudy epicurean grab bag that weds cuisines from here and there to cocktails from the here and now. It is a "Sex and the City" fantasy in which would-be Carries and could-be Bigs look for love and settle for lamb under supremely flattering lighting.

title: THE WORKPLACE : Postal jobs:Are losses permanent?
Islamist Web Site Reports Beheading of Second American
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Wednesday, Sept. 22 - A militant group posted an Internet message on Tuesday night saying it had beheaded the second American hostage in two days.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Child Chokes To Death On Piece Of Rubber Glove
description: A 5-year-old boy whose parents found him bleeding from the mouth and ears in their Prospect Park South home choked to death on a piece of rubber glove, the authorities said yesterday. The boy, Donovan Phillips, had been playing with a piece of a glove, the police said. He was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead about an hour later. The city medical examiner's office ruled the death accidental. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Leader Quits Corporate Governance Group Amid Clashes
description: The executive director of a prominent corporate governance group, the Council of Institutional Investors, resigned yesterday after protracted disagreements within the group about its governance and institutional goals.

title: TV Dinners For a Higher Frequency
description: The idea behind Artiko, a store that sells only frozen food, could have come right out of the 1950's. But back then they wouldn't have had the Thai red curry samosas and Japanese gyoza dumplings. With the convenience of heat-and-eat as compelling as ever, Artiko, 1807 Second Avenue (93rd Street), a branch of a store in Mamaroneck, N.Y., can be useful and satisfying. There are cocktail party tidbits like spanakopita and miniquiches, and macaroni and cheese and fish-shaped fish sticks for children's suppers. Or you can reheat delicious wild mushroom quesadillas and some Indian vegetarian dishes like dal makhani (lentils). In general, foods that have been wrapped in pastry, simmered or baked are best. The soups I tried were bland. And even though most of the items are under $10, some dishes, like salmon fillet with pesto and squash, emerge from the microwave overcooked and are not worth it. Delivery is available, and orders, nationwide, can also be placed at www.artikochef.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WADSWORTH, VIRGINIA HIGGINSON
description: WADSWORTH--Virginia Higginson, 74, died on Tuesday, August 31, 2004. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, October 23, 2004 at 2PM in the Church of the Redeemer, 379 Hammond St, Chestnut Hill, MA. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Vincent Club, 71 Brimmer St., Boston, MA 02138 or to Chilton House Hospice, 65 Chilton Street, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Sees Possible Mob Return To Festival
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that it was possible organized crime had again found a foothold in the Feast of San Gennaro, despite efforts by federal prosecutors and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to break the Mafia's grip on the annual Little Italy festival. Asked if he was confident that the operations of the feast remained free of mob involvement, Mr. Bloomberg said, "No, but I am confident that they will be free." He said the recent appointment of two former prosecutors to the board overseeing the festival had restored confidence. Concerns surfaced in July when the board president, Perry Criscitelli, resigned after being linked to organized crime during testimony in the trial of a reputed mob boss, Joseph C. Massino. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: A Season to Forget Continues for Woods
description: If Tiger Woods has endured a more challenging year as a professional golfer, he could not recall when that was.

title: 1929:Taking Millions, Cheaply : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Pepper-Spray Case Goes to Jury in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 - Maya Portugal says the majestic redwood trees of Northern California changed her forever. Her love for the sweeping forest canopies and lush old-growth groves has taken her from child explorer to teenage protester to adult plaintiff in a seven-year legal battle between the law enforcement officials of rural Humboldt County and environmentalists opposed to logging the redwoods.

title: Enron Criminal TrialBegins in Houston Court
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21 - The first criminal trial involving an Enron financial transaction began in federal court here Tuesday, with the prosecution arguing that the six defendants helped the onetime energy giant illegally increase its income through a bogus asset sale.

title: Diagnosing Democracy's Ills in Light of the Effects of 9/11
description: Democracy Matters Winning the Fight Against Imperialism By Cornel West 229 pages. Penguin Press. $24.95.

title: ANTIWAR MOVIE TO MAKE DEBUT
description: The director David O. Russell's new documentary, "Soldiers Pay," which Warner Brothers financed but decided not to distribute because of its political content, will have its debut Friday in San Francisco, paired with the antiwar documentary "Uncovered," which is now in theaters. Mr. Russell's 35-minute film, which includes interviews with Iraq war veterans, was acquired by Cinema Libre, an independent distributor. The two documentaries will be in 29 theaters across the country next week. Sharon Waxman (NYT)

title: Banks and the College Loan Loophole
description: The Bush administration has studiously looked the other way while well-connected lenders have exploited a loophole in the student loan program that will reap them nearly a billion dollars in undeserved subsidies this year alone. Congress, which rakes in contributions from banks and other lenders, was reluctant to even discuss this problem until a public outcry recently made it impossible to avoid. The Education Department has claimed that it lacks the authority to close the loophole unilaterally. But that position was blown away this week in an unusually caustic report by the Government Accountability Office, which outlined the scope of the problem and urged the Education Department to solve it quickly.

title: New Starters for Jets Have Extra Time to Prepare
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 21 - One is a highly touted rookie, a first-round pick whose expected ascension to the Jets' first string was delayed by the stellar play of a resurgent veteran in training camp. The other is an unheralded three-year veteran who, until Sunday, had perhaps the most anonymous job on the team as the backup to a player who had not missed a game in a decade.

title: Screenwriters Vote to Retain President
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 - After months of infighting, the union representing Hollywood screenwriters chose to retain its president, Dan Petrie Jr., in a 1,506-to-541 vote tallied Tuesday.

description: federal grand jury in New York charged Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, with securities fraud and obstruction of justice today, in what may be the last major criminal white-collar case to come out of the accounting scandals of the late 1990's.

Court Keeps Ball in Play for a West Side Stadium
description: Opponents of the city's plan to redevelop the far West Side of Manhattan and build a $1.4 billion stadium for the Jets suffered a setback yesterday, when a state judge rejected their request for an order halting the city's approval process.

description: A CHEF friend of mine once placed on his menu "One Perfect Pear." Served with cheese, it was (not surprisingly) a popular dessert, probably because it is nearly impossible for the average person to crave a good pear and eat one in the same day.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Commission on Presidential Debates told the Bush and Kerry campaigns Tuesday that it could not accede to their unusual request that it sign by Wednesday their 32-page agreement detailing parameters for the debates.

title: Bank puts emphasis on its home market : Ackermann refocuses Deutsche
Washing Away the Mud
description: What I found most dispiriting over the last month of politicking was the sight of two senior statesmen in the Republican Party -- yes, I mean you, George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole -- climbing on the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth bandwagon in its campaign to turn Mr. Kerry from war hero to craven braggart.

title: Israel's nukes serve to justify Iran's
US AIRWAYS AND DISPATCHERS' UNION AGREE ON CONTRACT
description: The US Airways Group, which sought bankruptcy protection last week after failing to win concessions from workers, reached an agreement with the Transport Workers Union on a cost-cutting contract for 151 flight dispatchers. The accord provides savings of $4.5 million to the company, including lower wages, said Don Wright, president of the union's Local 545. US Airways had been seeking the concessions as part of a plan to cut $800 million in labor costs. US Airways, based in Arlington, Va., said it was still negotiating with unions for its pilots, flight attendants, customer service agents, mechanics and baggage handlers.

description: Correction Appended

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Tip Leads To Arrest
description: A 24-year-old man charged with having shot an unarmed security guard to death on Monday at the Capitol in Springfield was arrested in Springfield after the police received a tip from a local resident who identified him. The authorities said the man, Derek W. Potts of Olney, was charged with first-degree murder, burglary and two gun violations. David Bernstein (NYT)

title: Spanish Bank Courts Hispanic Customers in United States
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 21 - Spain's Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria said on Tuesday that it would buy a south Texas banking group, Laredo National Bancshares, heating up the race by global banks to serve Hispanics living in the United States.

title: Lots of Chemicals, Little Reaction
description: Washington - While President Bush continues to make terrorism and domestic security the centerpiece of his campaign, he has made little mention of one of the most urgent threats to our safety: the risk that terrorists could cause thousands, even millions, of deaths by sabotaging one of the 15,000 industrial chemical plants across the United States.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Strike Halts Air And Sea Traffic
description: Some 400,000 public-sector workers went on strike, shutting down airports, seaports, banks, government offices and other institutions across the country. Israel's main labor federation, the Histadrut, called the strike in support of municipal workers who have not been paid in months. The government says that many municipalities are rife with mismanagement and must agree to a series of reforms. But the municipalities and their workers have rejected the demands. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about an interview with The Manchester Union-Leader in which President Bush questioned the authenticity of memos in a CBS News report on his military service referred incorrectly to Bill Burkett, who has been identified as a source of the report. He is a former officer in the Texas Army National Guard, not Air National Guard.

title: Goss Confirmed by Senate as Next C.I.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 A Representative Porter J. Goss, the Florida Republican who until recently was chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, was confirmed by the Senate today as the next director of central intelligence.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Sometime next spring AMY SACCO , below, is going to add a restaurant to her portfolio of clubs and lounges (Lot 61, Bungalow 8 and the Cabanas at the Maritime Hotel). Aside from the name, BETTE (for her mother), location (461 West 23rd Street) and concept (a European grill), nothing has been decided. But considering that naming a place is often the last detail to be confirmed, Ms. Sacco is already ahead of the game.

description: Elsewhere in town, the Sunday morning brunch crowd is not known for its sartorial splendor.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Vanity Fair's disclosure of a conflict of interest, in its October issue, misstated the origin of the ethics guidelines for the magazine's parent, Cond Nast Publications. They were issued in 1981 and revised most recently in 2004, not created this year in response to reports of a $100,000 payment made by a movie studio to Vanity Fair's editor, Graydon Carter.

title: The populist pianos of Shenzhen
Technology Briefing | Software: Sony To Sell Smaller Playstation 2
description: Sony will introduce a smaller version of its PlayStation 2 game console to stem falling demand. The new model, a quarter the size of the original, will go on sale in the United States on Nov. 1 and in Japan two days later, said Ken Kutaragi, chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment. Sony, which has shipped more than 72 million PlayStation 2's since their debut in March, is aiming to cut costs and drive demand after posting a first-quarter loss at its games division.

title: The Campaign So Far
description: President Bush's United Nations address and John Kerry's foreign policy speech in New York were the two big campaign moments of the week, and it's a relief to see both the candidates and the electorate focusing on the major issues. For a while it seemed as if extricating the candidates from the morass of their military records was going to be as difficult as extricating American forces from Iraq.

title: Big-Book Battle
description: Timing is everything, of course, not least when a publisher is trying to get readers to commit to an 845-page doorstop like "The Dark Tower VII" (Donald M. Grant/Scribner), Stephen King's latest novel and the final volume in the "Dark Tower" series. It appeared in bookstores yesterday. The trouble is, Mr. King did not have the new-release shelves to himself. "The System of the World" (William Morrow) by Neal Stephenson, 944 pages long and the third and final volume in his series, "The Baroque Cycle," also landed yesterday. Both books have the potential to move immediately into the upper ranks of the best-seller lists and to keep some readers out of bookstores for weeks. But with so many big books scheduled for release this fall, it is almost unavoidable that some will appear at the same time. "Even if you are shooting for a No. 1 best seller the first week out," said Ivan Held, an associate publisher at Warner Books, "you stake out your territory and stick with it." EDWARD WYATT

title: U.S. Agrees to Release American Caught With Taliban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 A The Justice Department has reached agreement with Yaser Esam Hamdi, an American citizen captured in Afghanistan nearly three years ago and held as an enemy combatant, that will allow him to go free without facing charges.

title: When a Company Pays Others to Short Its Stock
description: WHO ever heard of a company arranging for others to short millions of shares of its stock, and paying them to do so?

title: Booker Prize Finalists Are Named
description: A novel about South Africa's struggles to reconcile with its past, a fictionalization of Henry James's life, a tale spanning the centuries and told through a dizzying array of distinct voices, an account of the ravages of alcoholism in a family, a novel about a British tattoo artist living in Coney Island, and the story of a man caught up in the headiness of 1980's London -- these are the books on the 2004 Man Booker Prize shortlist, which was announced in London on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the presidential election in Indonesia misstated the current position of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Bush administration official who was ambassador there in the late 1980's and has said that the voting, in the world's most populous Muslim country, shows that Islam and democracy are compatible. He is deputy defense secretary, not assistant secretary.

title: Flight Is Diverted to Detain Former Pop Singer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Department of Homeland Security ordered a United Airlines jet flying from London to Washington rerouted to Bangor, Me., on Tuesday afternoon so it could intercept a passenger, Yusuf Islam, the musician formerly known as Cat Stevens, two government officials said.

title: China Construction Bank defers share listing
National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Bryant Records
description: Mark Hurlbert, the district attorney who prosecuted the sexual assault case against the basketball star Kobe Bryant, asked the judge not to seal the court records, as Mr. Bryant's lawyers had asked, because, he said, such secrecy could create public mistrust of the justice system. Mr. Bryant was charged with assaulting a woman in a Colorado hotel in June 2003, but the charge was dropped this month after the woman said she would no longer participate in the case. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 - Secretary General Kofi Annan opened the annual United Nations debate of world leaders on Tuesday with a plea for greater observance of international law and a reminder of his misgivings about the legality of the American-led war in Iraq.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKEL, LAWRENCE W.
description: FINKEL--Lawrence W. On September 20, 2004. Beloved father of Deborah Lennon, Kenneth and Alan Finkel. Loving Pop Pop to his grandchildren. A Low-Cost Focus Nods to Trends
description: THE Robert Mondavi Corporation's plan, announced last week, to sell its namesake winery and focus on inexpensive "lifestyle" wines, is further indication that the California wine business is moving in two directions: luxury wines, selling for up to $200 a bottle, and mass market "brand" wines aimed at a consumer uninterested in grape varieties, soil types and vintages.

title: Source Denies Story of Drugs in Bush Book
description: A Texas man who is quoted in Kitty Kelley's new book about the Bush family as saying that the first lady, Laura Bush, smoked and sold marijuana in her college days, said on Tuesday that his remarks were taken out of context. He said he had no firsthand information about any drug-related activity by Mrs. Bush.

title: CBS Says Producer Violated Policy by Putting Source in Touch With Kerry Aide
description: CBS News said yesterday that the producer of its flawed report about President Bush's National Guard service violated network policy by putting a source in touch with a top aide to Senator John Kerry.

Seafood Rule Without Jaws
description: AN interim regulation requiring most seafood to be labeled with its country of origin is scheduled to take effect on Sept. 30, but the Agriculture Department has told the seafood industry it would not enforce the rule for a year.

title: Mounting Toll
description: The number of irreplaceable books destroyed in a fire in the Anna Amalia Library in Weimar three weeks ago is much higher than was feared. A total of 50,000 rare literary pieces from the 17th and 18th centuries were destroyed in the blaze, compared with an original estimate of 30,000, said Helmut Seemann, the president of the Weimar Classic Foundation. In addition, 28,000 books were damaged by smoke and 34,000 by water used by the firefighters. The restoration of the damaged books and rebuilding of the 17th-century library, which is on Unesco's world heritage list, might cost as much as $73 million and last as long as 30 years. Before the blaze, the collection included one million items, including handwritten documents, maps and many historic copies of the Bible. The cause of the fire is still unclear. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: The Iraq War, in Kerry's View (7 Letters)

title: C.I.A. Review Is Critical of Prewar Iraq Analysis
description: McLEAN, Va., Sept. 21 - A review by the Central Intelligence Agency has identified serious weaknesses in analytical work on Iraq but continues to hold that the prewar conclusion that Iraq possessed illicit weapons was reasonable based on the information available at the time, an internal document shows.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Property Tax Reform Group Meets
description: A group of state lawmakers, charged with reforming the property tax system, met for the first time yesterday at Rutgers University to discuss how to provide long-term relief to state taxpayers. The Property Tax Convention Task Force will hold several public meetings next month throughout the state. State Senator John H. Adler, a group member, said he hoped that recommendations would be given to the Legislature by Thanksgiving and that a referendum for a constitutional convention would be on the ballot in November 2005. John Holl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARL, LILLIAN
description: PEARL--Lillian. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Lillian Pearl. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Alan and their family. Jack Sussman, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, PATRICK J., M.D.
description: FITZGERALD -- Patrick J., M.D. Pathologist, researcher and author, whose books included a history of cancer, succumbed to the disease on July 29, 2004. He died at his home in Sea Cliff, L.I., a week shy of his 91st birthday. In 1930, Dr. Fitzgerald rescued a man who had fallen through ice into the Little River in Massachusetts. For this he received the Carnegie Hero Medal and a scholarship, which launched him on a lifelong career in science. He was a pioneeer in autoradiology and former Chairman of Pathology at Downstate Medical Center and Memorial Sloan-Kettering. In 1985, he received the American Association of Pathologists' highest award for excellence, the Gold Headed Cane. A private memorial service will be held. Donations to commemorate his life may be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Third Hostage in Iraq Said to Plea for His Life in Videotape
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 22 A As the families of two Americans beheaded this week by Iraqi militants were still reeling from the news, an Islamic Web site today played a videotape of a man identifying himself as a British hostage, Kenneth Bigley, begging Prime Minister Tony Blair to help save his life, news agencies reported.

title: Kerry Camp Describes Contacts With Source of CBS Papers
description: Democrats vowed yesterday to keep alive questions about President Bush's Vietnam-era National Guard service despite the admission by CBS that it could not authenticate documents at the center of a report on his service. But the party instead spent much of the day explaining contacts between Senator John Kerry's campaign and the former National Guard officer who gave the network the documents.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about 30-minute cooking used a misspelled given name in some copies for a Food Network star and cookbook author. She is Rachael Ray, not Rachel.

title: ASIAN-AMERICANS UNDECIDED
description: A nationwide poll of Asian-American voters released last week showed that the group had substantially more undecided voters than the nation as a whole. Twenty percent said they had not decided which candidate to support, compared with most nationwide polls, which estimate undecided voters in the single-digit percentages. The poll, which interviewed 1,004 likely voters in nine languages from Aug. 19 to 29, had Mr. Kerry leading Mr. Bush by 43 percent to 36 percent. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about dining along the Dalmatian coast misspelled the name of a restaurant in Split, Croatia, that features local wines. It is Boban, not Baban.

title: 3 DeLay Aides Facing Charges In Fund-Raising
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Three aides who helped run a political action committee created by the House majority leader, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, were indicted by a grand jury in Texas on Tuesday on charges that included raising illegal corporate contributions and funneling them to state candidates during the 2002 elections.

description: Enron Criminal Trial Begins in Houston Court The first criminal trial involving an Enron financial transaction opened at federal court in Houston, with the prosecution arguing that the six defendants helped the onetime energy giant illegally increase its income through a bogus asset sale.

description: RANDOLPH, N.J. - THERE are probably easier products to sell than the John Birch Society, which was best known in the days when its founder, Robert Welch, described President Dwight D. Eisenhower as a "dedicated, conscious agent of the Communist conspiracy."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILLS, WILL
description: HILLS--Will, 60, of Kittery Point, ME and Brookline, MA, passed away on Sunday, September 19, 2004. In 1972 Will founded Limitless Design. He is survived by his wife Beth Segers, his parents Mr. & Mrs. James Maddox of New York City, two brothers-inlaw Carl Segers and Joseph Segers, and four nieces and nephews, Natalie, Anne Marie, Charlie and Katharine. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Friday, 11 AM, at St. Raphael Parish Church on 6 Whipple Rd., Kittery, ME 03904. Visiting Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 9-10:15 AM at the J. S. Pelkey Funeral Home, Kittery, ME. In lieu of flowers donations to Cambridge Adult Education Center, 42 Brattle St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: BUSH AND KERRY TIED IN NEW JERSEY
description: Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry are locked in a virtual tie in New Jersey, according to a new poll, the latest sign that a state long considered reliably Democratic has become surprisingly competitive in this year's presidential race. The poll, by Quinnipiac College, found that Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry each received the support of 48 percent of likely voters, while the independent candidate Ralph Nader was the choice of 2 percent. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: Big Asset Sales Are Expected From Shell
description: LONDON, Sept. 21 - The Royal Dutch/Shell Group will unveil a new corporate strategy on Wednesday that analysts said might include more than $11 billion in asset sales.

title: Adelphia Readies Cable Systems for Sale
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation, the bankrupt cable-television operator, said yesterday that it had divided its cable systems into seven regional groups that will be sold in an auction.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Government To Sell Stakes
description: The Egyptian Ministry of Investment announced plans to sell the government's shares in 10 companies in a number of industries including food and housing. No timetable for the sale was released. Mona el-Naggar(NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: In-Flight Entertainment Fees
description: Ryanair, the low-fare Irish airline, plans to start charging about $9 for in-flight entertainment on five of its Boeing 737-800's based at Stansted Airport outside London in November. The programs will include music videos, cartoons, and movies. If the venture is financially successful, the small laptop-style screens will be installed on the rest of Ryanair's fleet over the winter. The chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said the airline expected to make about 14 million euros ($17 million) a year from the entertainment fees. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Senate Committee Endorses Goss for C.I.A. Job
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Senate Intelligence Committee cleared the way on Tuesday for Representative Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, to win confirmation as the next director of central intelligence, with three Democrats joining all nine Republicans on the panel in endorsing Mr. Goss's nomination.

description: To the Editor:

U.S. Wants Air Traveler Files for Security Test
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Transportation Security Administration said Tuesday that it planned to require all airlines to turn over records on every passenger carried domestically in June, so the agency could test a new system to match passenger names against lists of known or suspected terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPOFSKY, DAVID
description: POPOFSKY--David. Born in Brooklyn, NY, February 6, 1934, David was a graduate of the Citadel in 1956 and served in the U.S. Army and was discharged with the rank of Captain. In 1973 David founded Popofsky Advertising Inc. in New York City. Over the years the agency worked on such brands as Robitussin, Dimetapp, Maalox, Bausch and Lomb, Becton Dickenson, Eucalyptamint, Genovese Drug Stores, Pathmark Supermarkets and Charms Candy. David was also a founder of the retail drug institute at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy as well as serving on its board as a boardmember. Separately he enjoyed a long career as a horse owner and breeder of thoroughbred racehorses that ran under the stable name Bee Pee Stables. In addition he was a longstanding proud member of the New York Friars Club. David is survived by his devoted wife Barbara and his two sons Michael and Scott as well as his two daughters-in-law Theresa and Michelle. David was also blessed with three lovely grandchildren Jordan, Sara, and Isabella. Services Thursday, September 23, 9:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, LILLIAN
description: FEINBERG -- Lillian. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, who with her late husband, Abraham, established a professorial chair in schizophrenia research in memory of their son, Dr. E. Richard Feinberg, a child psychiatrist and esteemed member of our faculty. To Mrs. Feinberg's daughter, Dr. Judith Schneider, and to her entire family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: She aims to avoid conflicts of interest : EU's Kroes to cut links with business world
PENSION FUND CONTESTS MOLSON EMPLOYEES' VOTE
description: A big Canadian pension plan is going to court to challenge a Molson decision to allow its employees to vote their options as if they were shares in the balloting on its proposed merger with the Adolph Coors Company. Lee Fullerton, a spokeswoman for the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, said the fund would ask a Quebec court to separate the option votes from those of Class A shareholders. Rather than filing a prospectus, Molson is conducting the merger under a plan that requires a shareholders' vote and court approval. The brewery contends that Canadian law requires it to include option holders in the vote, but some Canadian law experts said that the voting rights of option holders are unclear. Ian Austen (NYT)
