description: ANCHIN--Frances E. (nee Steinberg). On September 19, 2004. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted and loving mother of Roberta and Philip Strasburg, and James and Joan Anchin. Grandmother of Donald Strasburg, Lauren and Scott Freifeld, Scott and Lauren Anchin, Lee and Dori Anchin. Great-grandmother of Jared and Todd Freifeld. Sister of Bernard Steinberg. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 21, 2004, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, NYC, at 10 am. Contributions may be made to the Linda J. Anchin Scholarsip Fund, Mt. Vernon High School, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: ARTESYN TECHNOLOGIES REJECTS BUYOUT OFFER BY BEL FUSE
description: The board of Artesyn Technologies said yesterday that it had rejected Bel Fuse's unsolicited stock-for-stock bid to buy the company because the financial terms were not adequate. Bel Fuse, a maker of fuses and electronic components, made an offer on Sept. 9 to exchange 0.265 Class B nonvoting share for each share of Artesyn. That valued Artesyn shares 29 percent higher than their closing price on Sept. 8. Artesyn, based in Boca Raton, Fla., makes power-conversion equipment for the telecommunications industry. The rejected offer would have valued Artesyn shares at $9.14 a share, 7 percent less than Monday's closing price. A spokesman for Bel Fuse, based in Jersey City, said the company was reviewing Artesyn's rejection and declined to comment further.

title: The Truth at U.C.L.A. Sets Sciarra Free at Wagner
description: Quarterback John Sciarra did not need to be shoved out the door at U.C.L.A.; he only needed to hear some honest advice. When Steve Axman, then the Bruins' offensive coordinator, told Sciarra last season that if he wanted to play, he should transfer, Sciarra listened and left.

title: A Family Grieves, and Remains Hopeful
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Sept. 21 - On the eve of Jack Hensley's 49th birthday, his family grieved Tuesday behind the closed doors of their suburban home over unconfirmed claims that despite their pleas to his captors, he had been executed in Iraq.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates another quarter of a point on Tuesday, and it suggested that it will keep raising them gradually over the next year.

description: A state appeals court judge delayed contempt proceedings against New York City yesterday for holding protesters too long during the Republican National Convention, granting the city an appeal hearing in late November.

title: A SENATOR'S DOUBTS
description: He may not be quite in Zell Miller's league, but Senator Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island is fast becoming the favorite Republican of Democrats. Since the Republican National Convention, Mr. Chafee has been voicing uncertainty about whether he would vote for President Bush in November. The talk picked up again this week, and Mr. Chafee did nothing to quiet it yesterday when he went on "Inside Politics" on CNN and refused to say he would vote for the president. "It is no secret that I have big differences with the president on a host of issues," Mr. Chafee said, adding that one of his chief concerns is White House policy in Iraq. Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Sniper Trial
description: The Fairfax County Circuit Court judge in John A. Muhammad's second death-penalty trial for murders during the 2002 Washington-area sniper shootings removed himself after prosecutors contended that he had improperly interviewed potential witnesses and obtained documents related to the case. The judge, Jonathan C. Thacher, did not acknowledge any wrongdoing. In March, Mr. Muhammad was sentenced to death in his first trial, in Prince William County. John Files (NYT)

title: U.S. Seeks Cuts in Housing Aid to Urban Poor
description: The Bush administration has proposed reducing the value of subsidized-housing vouchers given to poor residents in New York City next year, with even bigger cuts planned for some urban areas in New England. The proposal is based on a disputed new formula that averages higher rents in big cities with those of suburban areas, which tend to have lower costs.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on Friday about a theater review of "Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead," at the SoHo Playhouse, was published in error. Bert V. Royal, who wrote the play, did in fact direct the production, as the review said last Wednesday. Susan W. Lovell directed a previous production, at the New York International Fringe Festival last month. (The correction was based on information in an outdated program distributed at the theater; The Times overlooked a later news release.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, JOSEPH F.
description: YOUNG--Joseph F., 80. Died suddenly at home September 18, 2004. Beloved husband of Mary Jane and loving father of Joseph F. Young, Jr., Megan Zwerner, Peter Young and Steven Young. Also survived by three brothers, one sister, seven grandchildren and seven stepchildren. A graduate of Union College, a resident of Babylon Village for over 50 years, an avid yachtsman and member of the Babylon Yacht Club. A senior executive with Cluett Peabody, NYC, for 26 years. An outstanding craftsman and great friend to many. Memorial Service at Babylon YC on September 26, 2004, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Conklin House Trust/Joe Young Fund, Village Hall, 153 West Main Street, Babylon, New York 11702.

title: When Budget Is Starved, Challenging Courses Are Frills
description: SEVERAL minutes into the first morning of the new school year at Midwood High School in Brooklyn, Olga Pikovskaya looked with dawning alarm at the computer printout showing her academic schedule. She had only four classes, and one of those was gym. Nowhere on the sheet were advanced placement French, orchestra, medieval literature -- all courses for which she had registered.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CITIGROUP INC., New York, the financial services company, said it had named Frits Seegers chief executive of its consumer business in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, succeeding Jean-Paul Votron, who left last month.

title: Kerry Returns to Florida, Hammering Bush on Iraq
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 21 - Senator John Kerry returned to Florida on Tuesday after an absence of a month, campaigning in a crucial swing state with a newly aggressive attack on President Bush's handling of Iraq and a feisty critique of the president's record on health care.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Student Finally Gets a School
description: An A-ranked student who was incorrectly assigned to three different high schools after moving to Brooklyn from New Jersey has finally settled in at Abraham Lincoln High, said State Senator Carl Kruger, who publicized the young man's plight on Monday. The student, Vasily Danilenko, 15, was initially assigned to a school that had no room for him while the computer placement system was down, a problem that an education official said had also affected other students. He was later assigned to a second school and then to Lincoln -- but as a freshman, even though he had completed the ninth grade. Yesterday, Mr. Kruger escorted the young man to Lincoln, and was assured that he would be a sophomore. Mr. Kruger faulted the chancellor's new high school placement process, calling it "a system that's broken." Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Turkish Company Will Accede to Demands of Iraqi Kidnappers
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 21 - The employer of 10 Turkish workers kidnapped simultaneously in Iraq last week made an emotional plea for their release on Tuesday, promising to freeze operations in Iraq to save their lives and denying that his company had any American partners.

title: Mourning the Warrior, and Questioning the War
description: MONROE TOWNSHIP, N.J. - WHEN Sue Niederer heard that Laura Bush was planning to speak in nearby Hamilton, N.J., she went to the local Republican headquarters, showed various forms of identification and took a ticket. Along with hundreds of Bush supporters, she found a spot in the Colonial Fire Hall last Thursday morning before the first lady was introduced.

title: Pfizer wrestles with Viagra spam
2 Bodies Found, Shot in the Head, in Nassau Towns
description: The bodies of a man and a woman, both shot in the head, were found within hours of each other yesterday in quiet suburban neighborhoods, the Nassau County police said.

title: Allawi Says Violence Reflects Weakness of Insurgency
description: Exuding confidence and optimism about his country's progress, the interim prime minister of Iraq said in New York today that security conditions were improving and that the recent upsurge in violence reflected the weakness, not the strength, of insurgent forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIMROTH, RUTH
description: ZIMROTH--Ruth, age 85, died September 20, 2004, in Bridgeport, CT. She is survived by her beloved husband, Sol Zimroth, and her children, Alice Kelly and her husband, George, Peter Zimroth and his wife, Estelle Parsons; grandchildren, David, Matthew, Rachel & Abraham; brother & sisters, David Sadowsky, Sara Trabish and Estelle Rynston. Funeral services will take place on Wednesday, September 22nd, at 11:00 AM, at Congregation B'nai Israel, 2710 Park Ave. in Bridgeport, CT., with interment following at B'nai Israel Cemetery in Monroe, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Social Action Fund of Cong. B'nai Israel or to a charity of one's choice.

title: Happiness for Yanks Is a Giambi Home Run
description: It was not a typical Jason Giambi home run. It did not dent the facade on the upper deck in right field or send fans in the bleachers scrambling for cover. It just barely lofted over the wall in left-center, just out of the reach of a leap by Toronto Blue Jays left fielder Gabe Gross, settling onto the netting above Monument Park last night.

title: Eagles stop Vikings at key times
JEWS FAVOR KERRY
description: Despite the Bush campaign's efforts to court Jewish voters this year, a new poll has found that most remain loyal to the Democratic candidate. Of 1,000 Jews who responded to a telephone poll taken in the last two weeks of August, 69 percent said they would vote for Mr. Kerry, 24 percent chose Mr. Bush and 3 percent picked Mr. Nader. Five percent said they were not sure. The poll was commissioned by the American Jewish Committee, and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEUTSCH, FREDA SMUKLER
description: DEUTSCH--Freda Smukler, born April 5, 1915, in Bialystok, Poland, passed away peacefully in Los Angeles on September 20. Dedicated wife to radiologist Irvin (died 1997), and loving mother and grandmother, she is survived by her children, Diane Thome, Nina Deutsch, Laurence Deutsch, and Mona Deutsch Miller (and husband, Steve), grandchildren, Thais Miller and David, Derek, and Lara Deutsch, and brothers, Irving (and wife, Ruth) and Leon (and wife, Bea) Claremon. She earned a B.A. from Hunter College in 1935 and an M.A. Psychology from Columbia in 1937. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday, 11:30am.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Government Deficit Declines
description: Efforts by the Philippine government to rein in its chronic budget deficit appear to be making progress. The government said it posted a deficit of 11.67 billion pesos ($208 million) in August, more than meeting the 16.03 billion peso goal and 35.7 percent lower than in the month last year. After warning that the country faced a fiscal crisis, President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has embarked on a drive to cut government spending as she tries to push new taxes through Congress. Analysts said recent data convinced them that the government could attain its goal of keeping the deficit to no more than 198 billion pesos this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Inquiries Into Deaths in U.S. Custody
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Army is investigating the deaths of three Iraqis and an Afghan Army recruit who were in American custody or came into contact with American forces, military investigators said Tuesday.

title: Extra Drama for 'Otello': Can He Do It?
description: Among many other things, the opening night of a new Metropolitan Opera season is a time for people-watching. And so it was on Monday for the gala performance of Verdi's "Otello," starring the tenor Ben Heppner in the title role, with James Levine conducting. Patrons in elegant evening gowns and tuxedos lingered on the grand stairway to watch as other patrons in elegant evening gowns and tuxedos kept streaming through.

title: Masai, Whites and Wildlife: No Peaceable Kingdom
description: LAIKIPIA, Kenya - The view from above explains why this rugged area of Kenya has a problem on its hands.

title: 1954:Saigon Fires on Crowd : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about the appointment of two directors at Citigroup misstated the position of one of them, Judith Rodin. She is president-elect of the Rockefeller Foundation, not president. The article also referred incorrectly to her departure from her previous position, as president of the University of Pennsylvania, and to its timing. She left in June after notifying the university of her intention in 2003. She did not leave last month to join the foundation.

title: S.E.C. PLANS TO SUE AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP
description: The American International Group said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission planned to sue the company for helping the PNC Financial Services Group remove bad loans from its books. AIG Financial Products, a unit of American International, sold partnerships that regulators said PNC improperly used for the loans. PNC, based in Pittsburgh, agreed last year to pay $115 million to settle Justice Department allegations that it used the entities to inflate 2001 earnings by 52 percent by removing $762 million in bad loans from financial statements. American International, based in New York, said the S.E.C. suit would be unwarranted.

title: Mozzarella's Moment (Move Over, Tomatoes)
description: ROME - THE restaurant's name is written on glass doors in red brush strokes that evoke Japanese characters. When chefs plunge their hands into water tanks to grab dinner for fashionable people around the bar, you almost expect something live to wriggle on the cutting board.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the aftermath of Hurricane Ivan misspelled the name of a beachfront complex of bars along the Florida-Alabama border that was damaged by the storm. It is Flora-Bama, not Floribama.

title: Heir to Nazi rebuffs exhibit's critics
Woman Found Shot Dead in Inwood
description: A woman who had been shot to death was found early yesterday between two parked automobiles in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Land Prices Fall
description: Average Japanese land prices fell for the 13th consecutive year, though the pace of decline slowed, according to a government survey. The average price of commercial properties fell 6.5 percent for the year ended July 1, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport said. That was less than the 7.4 percent drop a year earlier and the first time in four years that the pace of decline slowed. Residential land prices fell 4.6 percent for the year, compared with a 4.8 percent decline the previous year. Land prices have been tumbling since the collapse of stock and real estate values in the early 1990's. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Nonproliferation and disarmament go hand in hand
EU ready to approve Alitalia's rescue plan
Deutsche Bank's Chief Shuffles Top Executive Ranks
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 21 - Deutsche Bank shuffled the ranks in its executive suite on Tuesday, putting more power into the hands of two prominent investment bankers based in London, but also naming a German banker to a visible role as head of its lagging home market.

title: 2 Iraq Views, 2 Campaigns
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21 - To hear President Bush and John Kerry argue bitterly in the past two days about the American mission in Iraq is to wonder if they are talking about the same war, or even the same country.

title: Disney to Hire Search Firm to Find New Chief by June
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept 21 - The board of the Walt Disney Company said on Tuesday that it would immediately hire an executive search firm and would name a successor to its chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, by June 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLEIM, PETER A.
description: SCHLEIM--Peter A., creative genius born March 1942 in Berlin, Germany, passed away September 20, 2004. Author of many inventions and processes, he leaves behind a daughter, Carrie Stasiak of Poconos, PA; a sister, Fay Gillespie of Port Washington, NY; a partner, Paula SaintAmour of Marbletown, NY, and adoring grandsons, nieces and nephews, and many who loved him. For info call Simpson - Gaus Funeral Home, Kingston, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAGATI, MARGARET
description: DAGATI -- Margaret. Died September 19, 2004 at 15 Wolcott Hill Road, Camden, New York. She was born January 27, 1927 in Long Island, the daughter of George and Nancy Mancini Dagati. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please contact The Rome DDSO, collect 315-336-2300 with any special funeral arrangements.

title: 5 Are Injured as Explosions Rip Street Near Bus Hub
description: An electrical fire under a street near the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday set off explosions that sent heavy manhole covers more than 10 feet into the air, injuring five people and disrupting rush-hour traffic.

title: A Cycling Medalist Denies Evidence of Doping
description: PARIS, Sept. 21 - Tyler Hamilton, the American bicycle racer who won a gold medal in the individual time trial at the Olympics last month in Athens, is suspected of receiving illegal performance-enhancing blood transfusions for that event and for a major race in Spain.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on Friday about a theater review of "Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead," at the SoHo Playhouse, was published in error. Bert V. Royal, who wrote the play, did in fact direct the production, as the review said last Wednesday. Susan W. Lovell directed a previous production, at the New York International Fringe Festival last month. (The correction was based on information in an outdated program distributed at the theater; The Times overlooked a later news release.)

title: S.E.C. WILL NOT SEEK CIVIL CHARGES AGAINST KRAFT
description: Kraft Foods said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission would not recommend civil charges after a review of allegations that the company helped the grocery distributor Fleming Companies inflate revenue. Investigators contended last November that Kraft employees signed documents requested by Fleming that were used to overstate sales. The agency's staff decided against recommending an enforcement action after Kraft, based in Northfield, Ill., described its efforts to assure compliance to securities laws, Kraft's general counsel, Marc Firestone, said in a statement. Fleming, based in Brooklyn, sought bankruptcy protection last year; it settled S.E.C. allegations but did not pay a fine, the agency said last week.

title: Drums and Bells Open Indian Museum
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - To thundering drums, jubilant whoops and bell-jingling dancers, the Smithsonian on Tuesday opened the National Museum of the American Indian, dedicated to the history, culture and painful travails of native people in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Le Monde to cut 100 jobs to stem deficit
Growing Signs of a Slowing on Wall Street
description: Wall Street's earnings growth, fueled by two years of robust trading gains, is showing signs that it may taper off in coming quarters as a sluggish stock market and a less-favorable trading environment take a toll on profits.

title: Eagles Solve Culpepper-Moss Problem
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 - The solution to a complex problem was deceptively simple. The Eagles had two 5-foot-10 cornerbacks starting for the first time this season to match up against Minnesota's Randy Moss, who is a half-foot taller and perhaps the best receiver in the game. No problem.

title: Hostage executions in Iraq follow a ritual pattern
Fixing Argentina: One Grass-Roots but Uphill Approach
description: "The Take," a stirring, idealistic documentary that examines the grass-roots cooperative movement in financially devastated Argentina, raises basic questions about economics, government and human nature.

title: Bush's Speech to U.N. Wins Few Plaudits in Europe
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 A The editorial cartoon in the Times of London newspaper today was derisive: the first panel has President Bush telling the United Nations General Assembly, "Friends, our policy in Iraq is directed solely towards a successful election."

title: Taking Cold Cuts Beyond Bologna
description: Pale, red-rimmed, translucent slices of lomo, cured pork loin from Spain, air dried and seasoned with paprika and garlic, can adorn a plate of charcuterie or cheese like flower petals. The sweetly spicy, lean meat is best sliced paper thin and is lovely when scattered like shavings of white truffle over a saffron-tinged risotto. Lomo is $19.99 a pound at Citarella, $17 a pound unsliced and $19.96 a pound sliced at Fairway, and from www.tienda.com for $39.50 for a one-and-a-half-pound piece.

title: For U.S. to Note, Europe Flexes Muscle in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan - Shortly before leaving on a recent patrol, French and German soldiers who have assumed leadership of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's peacekeeping effort here gathered for a pep talk from France's defense minister, Michle Alliot-Marie.

title: No demand for listing cellphones, says Verizon
President Bush's Lead Balloon
description: We did not expect President Bush to come before the United Nations in the middle of his re-election campaign and acknowledge the serious mistakes his administration has made on Iraq. But that still left plenty of room for him to take advantage of this one last chance to appeal to an increasingly antagonistic world to help the Iraqis secure and rebuild their shattered nation and prepare for elections in just four months. Instead, Mr. Bush delivered an inexplicably defiant campaign speech in which he glossed over the current dire situation in Iraq for an audience acutely aware of the true state of affairs, and scolded them for refusing to endorse the American invasion in the first place.

title: Allawi, in U.S., Is Presented as a Symbol of Iraqi Progress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Bush administration began an intensive campaign this week to present Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq as the face of his nation and a symbol of progress, even as the violence in the country has been mounting and doubts have been growing that elections can be held there in January.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Train Trouble Causes Widespread Delays
description: A southbound B train partly derailed in Brooklyn yesterday during the morning rush, causing delays for thousands of commuters and halting subway service on some lines. The train, which had been traveling at 20 miles an hour, came to a halt 200 feet north of the DeKalb Avenue station about 8 a.m., when one of the two wheel assemblies under the seventh car went off the tracks, said Charles F. Seaton, a spokesman for New York City Transit. One passenger complaining of chest pains was taken to Long Island College Hospital. Because the station is a major junction, train service was snarled for much of the day. Officials were forced to suspend the B train in both directions, and trains on many other lines, including the A, C, E, F, D, N, R, Q and W, experienced long delays or had to be rerouted. Service was restored by evening. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHFELDER, J. GENE
description: HOCHFELDER--J. Gene. 82, patriarch of the Hochfelder Family. War hero, businessman, philanthropist, trusted friend, advisor to many. Born in NYC April 27, 1922. Died peacefully in his sleep at home September 20, 2004. Raised in Cedarhurst, NY, graduated Lawrence H.S. 1939, the Wharton School at University of Pennsylvannia, 1943. Enlisted U.S. Marine Corps in 1943, served with the 5th Marine Division Iwo Jima, Guadalcanal, and Guam, Capt. Hochfelder was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star and Presidential Citation for bravery and heroism in WW II's bloodiest battle. Predeceased by parents Lillian and Jake and beloved wife of 39 years, Patricia Beldoch. Founder of Bogene Closet Accesories, and later, Chairman of Beldoch Ind. Honorary Chairman, Brahman Management. Retired 1995. Former President National Notions Assoc., Olympic Tower Condo and Glen Head C.C. Industry Chairman and honoree UJA, ADL, Israel Bonds. Survived by his five proud sons: Jim (and Ellen), Tom (and Lynda), John (and Janet), Andrew (and Patricia), Peter (and Stacy); and his beloved wife of 20 years, Carol. Also survived by 13 adoring grandchildren: Amy and Scott Smith, Adam and Amy Hochfelder, Lauren, David, Jason, Julie, Josh, Alyssa, Robyn, Jake, Harrison, Charles and Lily; and four greatgrandchildren: Samantha, Hunter, Henry and Preston. Brother and life-long friend to Fred and Barbara; adored uncle to Maggie and Joanna. Brother-in-law and advisor to Michael Beldoch and Philip Hanan. Services Tuesday, September 21 at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC. Contributions may be made in his honor to UJA and/or ADL.

title: Russia grasps at security with an iron hand
4-day visit begins with closed meeting at Russian's dacha : Roh to press Putin on N. Korea
Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about the acceptance speech President Bush planned for his second nomination quoted incorrectly from a passage by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt in his speech to the 1936 Democratic convention in Philadelphia. He said: "To some generations much is given. Of other generations much is expected. This generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny" -- not simply "this generation" and not "a rendezvous with history."

title: As All-American as Egg Foo Yong
description: IT is an unusual trove of cultural kitsch: close to 10,000 Chinese restaurant menus going back to the late 1800's, filling an array of battered boxes and grocery bags. There is Ying's, a drive-through in Jacksonville, Fla., which describes itself as a purveyor of "Chinee Takee Outee," Jade Garden in Bismarck, N.D., which features the local specialty, "hot and spicy walleye," Brillante, a Mexican and Chinese spot in Paterson, N.J., which offers General Tso's Pollo.

title: Kerry in a Struggle for a Democratic Base: Women
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - It was no accident that John Kerry appeared Tuesday on "Live With Regis and Kelly" and recalled his days as a young prosecutor in a rape case. Or that he then flew from New York to Jacksonville, Fla., to promote his health care proposals. Or that on Thursday in Davenport, Iowa, he will preside over a forum on national security with an audience solely of women.

title: Landmarks Board Is Urged to Save a Church in Harlem
description: All Saints Church and the Church of St. Aloysius, two of Harlem's most ornate architectural and historical treasures, were on the official calendar of the Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday. But it was a Roman Catholic church without landmark status, St. Thomas the Apostle, that commanded the hearing.

title: Has hanging chad gone electronic?
Russian Cancels Pardon Request in Chechen Case
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21 - A Russian Army colonel convicted of murdering a Chechen woman in 2000 has withdrawn his application for a pardon, the Russian news media reported Tuesday.

title: Little Degree of Difficulty at Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 15 - Stifling yawns, University of Utah quarterback Alex Smith slogs into the Utes' weight room a few minutes before 8 a.m.

title: Getting Out the Vote: One Professor Insists Upon It
description: MADISON, N.J. - Merrill Skaggs has taught American literature at Drew University for four decades, but it wasn't until August that she became something of a campus celebrity.

title: The Republicans
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: Original American Fare, Open Fire and All
description: Mitsitam Native Foods Caf in the new Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, which opened yesterday in Washington, has an intriguing menu based on traditional tribal cooking from North and South America. For the preparation of some dishes, like ash-roasted sweet corn on the cob and cedar-planked juniper salmon, Restaurant Associates, which runs the restaurant, has installed an open fire pit manned by Richard Hetzler, the chef. The menu is divided by region, and has dishes like pumpkin soup with puffed wild rice, quinoa salad, pupusas with chili slaw, buffalo chili and tortilla soup. Prices are mostly under $10. The name, Mitsitam, means "let's eat" in the Piscataway and Delaware languages.

title: Spanish bank expands into Texas
Haiti's storm toll rises above 660
Expensive Gas and Nasty Weather Depress Retail Hopes
description: Before tropical storms closed stores and wiped out homes, when people thought the war in Iraq would soon be over, and before gasoline approached $2 a gallon, retailers and researchers were nearly all predicting a bang-up holiday shopping season, starting this Thanksgiving.

title: EU ready to approve Alitalia's rescue plan
Pocket-Size Guide To Asian Cooking
description: Add Asian Food Journal to the growing list of culinary publications. The first issue of this new TV-Guide-size magazine provides the basics about edamame, has an interview with Jean-Georges Vongerichten, offers a number of fusion recipes and covers izakaya, Japanese restaurants that serve sake with tapaslike foods. It has a restaurant guide and maps, and plenty of advertising for Asian restaurants and products. Asian Food Journal is published by Trend Pot, which also publishes a weekly in Japanese. Subscriptions are free from (800) 535-6863 or info@asianfoodjournal.com.

title: A very expensive guitar
Spanish Comforts, Spanish Adventures
description: WHEN New Yorkers need to find something, no matter how minutely specific, they often visit craigslist.com, a community board that whittles the world down to what you want from it.

title: Where the Sales Clerks Are Artists, Too
description: New York Central Art Supply in the East Village has the cramped, busy feeling of an old-fashioned neighborhood hardware store. Receipts are hand-written; inventories are managed by human memory, not computer.

description: Several agencies have named top creative executives.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - With Congress moving hurriedly to respond to the Sept. 11 commission and shake up the nation's intelligence agencies, a bipartisan group of former secretaries of state and defense led by Henry A. Kissinger urged Congress on Tuesday to slow down and put off any legislation until after the November election.

title: The Iraq War, in Kerry's View
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Golf Courses To Reduce Fertilizer Use
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is scheduled to announce an agreement today with operators of 30 private and public golf courses on eastern Long Island who will voluntarily reduce the use of fertilizers on their greens. Officials said it was the first time a group of golf courses in one area had agreed to such limits. The agency said the reductions would protect the Peconic Bay, a national estuary, and other local waters from groundwater and storm runoff containing excessive amounts of nitrogen, which stimulates algae growth. Algae consume oxygen in the water, harming fish and other marine life. John Rather (NYT)

title: At the UN, president defends his policies and vows to succeed : Bush says best path for Iraq is 'to prevail'
COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
description: A NEWER WAY of buying real estate, tenant-in-common programs, offer fractional ownership of large properties and are aimed at people who have recently sold other commercial property and seek to defer capital gains taxes. [C10.]

title: Troubled Souls Gather in the Local  Pub
How CBS News Got Burned
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It's more than all the colors and feathers, it's about coming home the way it should have been a long time ago. To come back in the same way and have people not laugh but respect you -- it shows we've come full circle."

title: Safety First
description: Last week, the Bush administration announced plans to change how it will spend nearly 20 percent of the $18.4 billion in approved aid for Iraq. The money will be shifted from rebuilding infrastructure to security, from capital improvements to employment generation, and from physical construction to social engineering projects. If these priorities had been adopted sooner, the situation in Iraq would probably be better than it is today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, NORMAN
description: BERNSTEIN--Norman. Devoted wife Harriet, loving children Anne and Mitch Stafman and Alyssa & Tracy Trojan. Loving grandsons Brian, Jeremy and Matthew. With all the love, "The Tuesday Night Group." Services at Hellmans Funeral Home, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, New York at 2 PM.

title: INSIDE
description: Hostage Reported Beheaded A militant group posted an Internet message saying it had beheaded a second American hostage in two days. The victim is believed to be Jack Hensley. PAGE A7

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the defeat of Paul A. Clyne, the incumbent, in the Democratic primary for district attorney in Albany County -- a race that was seen as a referendum on New York State's Rockefeller-era drug laws, which he largely favors -- misstated the affiliation of George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist, who opposes them. Mr. Soros is on the board of the Drug Policy Alliance, a nonprofit group that also opposes the laws; he is not chairman of the Drug Policy Alliance Network, a lobbying arm of the group.

title: Money Flowing to New Way to Pool Buyers
description: Since it was completed in 1990, Emerald Plaza, a 357,000-square-foot building, has been a distinctive part of the downtown San Diego skyline, especially at night, when it gives off a green neon glow.

description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors Open Case Against Tobacco Firms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - After five years of planning, the Justice Department's racketeering lawsuit against the nation's biggest tobacco companies began on Tuesday in Federal District Court here with opening arguments by prosecutors, who said the companies had deceived the public about smoking for more than 50 years.

title: 2 Dead in Suicide Bombing in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 A A female Palestinian suicide bomber blew herself up this afternoon and killed two Israeli police officers who had confronted her at a busy intersection in the northern part of Jerusalem, officials said.

title: Japan will outpace U.S., forecast says : OECD offering a brighter global outlook
Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a settlement under which movie theaters in New Jersey agreed to use captioning devices for deaf patrons misidentified the law that the state said the theaters had been violating. It was the New Jersey Law Against Discrimination, not the federal Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: Eisner won't stay on as Disney's chairman
A Cautious Reformer as Indonesia's Next President
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 21 - Indonesia's next president, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, moved swiftly up the military ranks during the authoritarian rule of Gen. Suharto and then played a back-seat role in the undoing of that government.

title: World Briefings
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: The Iraq War, in Kerry's View
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose club is it, anyway?: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Politician Indicted In Corruption Inquiry
description: A former Suffolk County legislator was indicted yesterday on charges that he took a $5,000 bribe from an undercover detective posing as a public-works contractor. The legislator, Wayne Prospect, pleaded not guilty in State Supreme Court to charges of bribery, receiving bribes, conspiracy and coercion. He was released on $5,000 bail. The indictment comes several months after Mr. Prospect and Stephen J. Baranello, a campaign adviser to the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, were arrested as part of a corruption investigation by the county district attorney. Mr. Baranello has pleaded guilty to bribery and conspiracy and is cooperating with prosecutors. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Guilty Plea Seen in Computer Associates Case
description: Steven Woghin, the former general counsel of Computer Associates, will plead guilty today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to criminal charges stemming from a two-year investigation into the company's accounting practices, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece And Turkey Cancel Military Exercises On Cyprus
description: Greece and Turkey agreed to cancel all separate military exercises in the eastern Mediterranean and on the divided island of Cyprus next month in the latest sign of trust between the two former foes. The agreement, according to media reports in both Greece and Turkey, was reached during a meeting of the two countries' foreign ministers on the sidelines of the General Assembly meeting in New York. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Dam Builder Tries New Role: Dam Breaker
description: Tucked away in Orange County, N.Y., a 90-year-old dam will start coming down today. Piece by piece, a team of engineers from the Nature Conservancy and the Army Corps of Engineers will begin removing major parts of the Cuddebackville Dam on the Neversink River as part of a painstaking effort to save an endangered mussel that is blocked by the dam from going upstream.

title: EDWARDS ON THE ECONOMY
description: Senator John Edwards, in a speech in Cleveland, laid out in detail why the Kerry campaign believed Mr. Bush had fostered "the most radical and dangerous economic agenda" since socialism a century ago, and what Senator John Kerry would do to change it. Mr. Edwards, sprinkling in dire economic statistics on Ohio's economic health, outlined the Kerry plan to maintain tax cuts for all but the wealthiest taxpayers and to provide tax credits and other measures to prompt economic development and raise earnings among lower-income people. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: View From Vazquez: Mind Over Mechanics
description: Manager Joe Torre took the low-key approach yesterday. He walked by a frustrated Javier Vazquez and said, "I'm glad you showed up today."

title: Tesco Takes a Round in Bout of British Retailers
description: LONDON, Sept. 21 - In the take-no-prisoners battle for the pocketbooks of Britain's shoppers, Tesco, the No. 1 supermarket, scored sharp gains on Tuesday, posting a 30 percent rise in first-half net income while Marks & Spencer, once the Main Street champion, reported a further decline in sales.

title: Kerry team contact was Seoul spy
Le Monde to cut 100 jobs to stem deficit
National Briefing | South: Virginia: DNA Testing
description: The state was awarded $2 million by the Department of Justice to expand and enhance its use of DNA testing in law enforcement. Virginia is the first state to receive federal financing under a five-year, $1 billion effort to solve crimes and exonerate the innocent through the use of DNA analysis. Lisa Bacon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Retail Sales Rise
description: Canadian retail sales posted a 0.5 percent increase in July, a third consecutive monthly gain, reaching a record 28.9 billion Canadian dollars, Statistics Canada said. The largest gains were in products related to the real estate market, like outdoor home supplies and home furnishings. General merchandise and clothing retailers also had substantial gains. Spending at pharmacies and on personal care products declined during the month. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: First, Find the Forger
description: WASHINGTON - Whoever, having devised . . . any scheme or artifice to defraud . . . transmits or causes to be transmitted by means of wire, radio or television communication in interstate or foreign commerce, any writings . . . for the purpose of executing such scheme or artifice, shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both. . . ." U.S. Criminal Code, Chapter 63, Section 1343.

title: Bloomberg Stands Tall for Bush, but Well Out of Camera Range
description: The thing is, mayors are busy people. Even when the president of the United States is in town.

title: CBS Storm Washes Over Viacom
description: As CBS News faces one of the worst public embarrassments in its history, experts say that the damage to the network's news division could be significant -- and costly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUTTENBERG, DERALD
description: RUTTENBERG--Derald. The Board, Faculty and Staff of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership extend deepest condolences to Perri PeltzRuttenberg, our beloved Board member and her husband, Eric, on the loss of his father, Derald Ruttenberg. May his memory be a blessing for his wife and all his family and for everyone who knew him and was touched by his generosity, thoughtfulness and his care and concern for humanity. Thomas O. Katz, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Donna M. Rosenthal Executive Vice Chairman Rabbi Brad Hirschfield Vice President

Wolfowitz, the Bush administration official who was ambassador there in the late 1980's and has said that the voting, in the world's most populous Muslim country, shows that Islam and democracy are compatible. He is deputy defense secretary, not assistant secretary. (Go to Article)

description: Lottery Numbers

title: 'CSI' Moves to Gotham but Is Still From Mars
description: "CSI: NY," which has its premiere tonight on CBS opposite NBC's "Law & Order," looks at first glance like an imposter version of its rival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WYNER, JAY S.
description: WYNER--Jay S., 83, of Sands Point, NY died on September 20, 2004. Adored husband of Ethel; beloved father of Shari and Richard Narva and Janis and Paul Sheinkopf; dear grandfather of Matthew, Laura, Arielle, Zachary, Josh, Jamie, Sarah and Shoshi; and loving brother of Ruth Schwartzberg, Dorothy Goldfarb, Sally Seidler and the late Maxine Diamond. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 23 at The Community Synagogue, Port Washington, New York. He was loved and admired by all who knew him and he will be in our hearts and thoughts forever.

title: The Mind's Eye as a Window to the City
description: WITH another day at the office behind him, Kevin Coughlin wades into the streets of a city that sings an incessant, contradictory song. Hear this; no, this; no, this. Step forward; step back; for God's sake, watch your step.

title: OECD offering a brighter global outlook

Yemeni Cleric Is Said to Urge Revenge Against Americans
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn claimed yesterday that a Yemeni cleric accused of major terrorism financing had issued a "public call for revenge against Americans for his arrest."

title: Seattle-Grown, Italian Flavored
description: Correction Appended

title: Sorry, Mr. Nice Guy, Your Ne'er-Do-Well Brother Inherits the Grand Prize
description: One way to grow up is to have a perverse or rich relative saddle you with something cumbersome -- money, land, a baby -- right in the middle of your salad days. Ralph Touchett does this to his cousin Isabel Archer in Henry James's "Portrait of a Lady": he sticks her with a big fortune so he can watch her get swindled. More recently, Kevin Hill's delinquent cousin on UPN's new fall drama "Kevin Hill" leaves him a baby, and that happy cad's status, freedom and affluence are efficiently curtailed.

title: Recalling a Slain Officer, and the Equality of Peril
description: No matter how many years separate them, the deaths of police officers killed in the line of duty share a solemn aura and perhaps the highest place in the department's hierarchy of honors. But yesterday, at a memorial ceremony for the first female officer to die in action in New York, the resonance was stronger than usual.

title: Officer to Leave J.P. Morgan Chase
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Dina Dublon, would resign and it named the vice chairman, David A. Coulter, head of the bank's West Coast operations.

title: Yanks Still Looking for Answers After Loaiza Trade
description: THERE was Esteban Loaiza, once the answer to the Yankees' fifth starter slot, fighting for relevance on the mound last night.

title: Death Of A Blog
description: The acerbic blog of news, culture and media criticism called The Minor Fall, The Major Lift is stopping the virtual presses. The anonymous author, writing as TMFTML, has posted a "Dear Internet" version of a Dear John letter, saying, "Our heart hasn't been in it." The author began the blog in May 2003 out of boredom and disgust with poor journalism, sharing ruminations on news items and writing headlines like "If the East River Was Whiskey (We'd Go to Brooklyn All the Time)." Now TMFTML feels that "blogging is over," citing attention in more traditional media. In an instant-message exchange yesterday, the author said, "I'm still disgusted, but I'm too tired to do anything about it." A virtual morgue is online at www.popfactor.com/tmftml/. NAT IVES

title: Office Building Subdivides to Shelter Many Tenants
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 21 - After Prodigy Services moved out of its offices in a 14-story rose-colored glass and concrete structure here in 1997, the building sat vacant, unable to attract the large tenants that would have been suited to its space. But after a $20 million renovation, the building is again drawing tenants, reflecting a more feasible arrangement of its interior space and the rising fortunes of the city around it.

title: Five Pieces of Silver
description: Opportunists have never stopped crawling over the rubble of Sept. 11, looking to make a buck. Small-time vendors, incapable of shame, began selling T-shirts even before the dust cleared. Other, more sophisticated, examples of that low but indestructible form of life, the 9/11 profiteer, have given their greed a sheen of philanthropy.

title: A Hedda for Self-Absorbed Modern Times
description: Hedda Gabler and Joni Mitchell -- soul mates? Disorienting as it is, that notion may be one of the tamest in Ivo van Hove's strange and strangely enthralling new production of Henrik Ibsen's much-mounted drama about a dangerously frustrated housewife. The arrival of this refreshingly daring revival, which opened last night Off Broadway at New York Theater Workshop, instantly slips the fall theater season into a higher gear.

title: Pittsburgh Symphony Decides 3 Directors Are Better Than One
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, proclaiming itself on the cutting edge of orchestra administration, announced yesterday that it would turn to a three-man rotation on the podium instead of hiring a full-time music director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANE, FRED ''SKIPPY''

Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEUER, WALTER
description: SCHEUER -- Walter. The Trustees, dancers and staff of the Paul Taylor Dance Foundation mourn the death of our beloved Walter Scheuer, Executive Vice President of the Board. A deeply devoted friend to Paul Taylor, Wally was the longest-serving Trustee in the 50-year history of the Taylor Company, having joined the Board in 1978. A philanthropist of extraordinary generosity, he played a leading role in such major initiatives as the Repertory Preservation Project and New Works Fund, and underwrote the Company's first tour to the People's Republic of China in 1996. He was also the creative force behind the documentary "Dancemaker," which has played a pivotal role in the Company's success. We will miss Wally's warmth, enthusiasm and friendship. We send our heartfelt condolences to Marge and his entire family. Paul Taylor Chairman of the Board Norton Belknap President of the Board Wallace Chappell Executive Director

World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Financial Group Names Chief
description: The financial services group Fortis appointed a Citigroup executive, Jean-Paul Votron, left, as chief executive. Mr. Votron, 53, led Citigroup's operations in Europe, the Middle East, Russia and Africa. He will succeed Anton Van Rossum, 59, who plans to retire next year. The change will take effect on Oct. 11. Mr. Votron takes control of a banking and insurance group with a market value of about 25 billion euros. Analysts speculated that Mr. Votron, who presided over a number of acquisitions at Citigroup, might be looking for acquisitions at Fortis, but Mr. Votron said he intended to increase revenue within Fortis's existing business. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Pasturing Sablefish in the Pacific
description: GUSTAVUS, Alaska - NOT long ago it would have seemed surprising that anyone would want to set up ocean farms to raise sablefish. Could there really be so much demand for that oily, paprika-flecked smoked fish?

title: Wireless Picture Relay Without a Camera Phone
description: Cellphones with cameras can send photos wirelessly, but the pictures are generally of poor quality. Last week, Nikon fired back, introducing a new digital camera with an adapter that allows it to send 12.4-megapixel photographs through the airwaves. But the wireless connectivity of the new model, the D2X, goes further: it can be operated wirelessly as well, froma computer up to 400 feet away, using a standard 802.11g Wi-Fi network.

title: A Kick and a Punch, but Don't Forget Compassion
description: WAY YIN YUEN has been playing video games for as long as he can remember. He lovingly remembers his Atari 2600, one of the first home video systems. Video games were his only passion until he found his second love, martial arts, at age 14.

title: Deal in Congress to Keep Tax Cuts,Widening Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Putting aside efforts to control the federal deficit before the elections, Republican and Democratic leaders agreed Wednesday to extend $145 billion worth of tax cuts sought by President Bush without trying to pay for them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Insurance Fraud Charged At Two Clinics
description: Eleven chiropractors, acupuncturists and other employees at two Queens clinics were indicted yesterday on charges that they submitted hundreds of false insurance claims -- worth more than $1 million -- for fake injuries from reported car accidents. More than 100 other people, many of them who pretended to be patients, were also charged in the case, which was announced by Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and other officials. The clinics, Booth Chiropractic and Acupuncture on Booth Street in Rego Park and Triboro Chiropractic and Acupuncture on Metropolitan Avenue in Middle Village, have been closed down, officials said. The clinic workers were charged with enterprise corruption, insurance fraud, grand larceny, falsifying business records and conspiracy. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

description: COHEN--Miriam R. Of Palm Beach, FL passed away September 21, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Edward F. Cohen, devoted mother of Arlene Farkas and Ken Sidel and Gail and Charles Rubinger, cherished grandmother of Matthew and Jessica Farkas, Carolyn and Jay Bloom and Elizabeth Rubinger, greatgrandmother of Teddy Farkas and Sean Bloom, great-aunt of Paul Dickler and Mindy Sherman. Service Thursday, September 23, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. COHEN--Miriam. The National Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of our dear friend and long-time member, Arlene Farkas, who serves with distinction as an honorary president of both our Division and our New York Chapter. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Protest Against Regional Leader
description: The police in the southern Russian republic Kalmykia broke up a protest by thousands of people in the capital, Elista, calling for the resignation of Kalmykia's president, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov. Television and news agencies reported that 89 people were arrested and several injured. Mr. Ilyumzhinov, who is also president of the World Chess Federation, has governed the impoverished region since 1993, using methods that his critics say are authoritarian. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

The rate in 2002 was 6 children per 1,000, not 100,00, and in 2003 it was 6.5 children per 1,000, not 100,000.

description: Is there any substitute for the humble, rustic sound of roots music? On Tuesday night one of the tradition's most beloved practitioners came to Madison Square Garden to sing songs of devotion and celebration. Her name is Gloria Estefan, and her notion of roots music might differ slightly from yours.

title: All About Allawi
description: Republicans quickly seized on today's Congressional address by Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq as irrefutable evidence that the invasion of his country was justified and that Bush administration policy there was working, hoping to defuse a growing campaign-season debate over the course of events in Iraq. title: PLEXUS CLOSES PLANT NEAR SEATTLE IN A RESTRUCTURING
description: The Plexus Corporation, a contract manufacturer whose annual sales have declined for two straight years, is closing a plant in Bothell, Wash., as part of a restructuring program. Most of the 160 workers at the plant in the Seattle suburb will not be offered other jobs within the company, a Plexus spokesman, Kristian Talvitie, said. Plexus, based in Neenah, Wis., makes products like ultrasound machines and Internet routers. The company said that it expected pretax savings of $2 million after the restructuring is completed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Bill On Shaken Baby Syndrome Signed
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed into law a requirement for hospitals to show mothers of newborn babies a video about shaken baby syndrome before they leave the hospital. The law, signed at White Plains Hospital Center yesterday, will take effect at the end of November and require all birthing centers and hospitals to show a state-approved education video, although mothers can decline to watch it. In 2002, the state Health Department reported that six children died because of shaken baby syndrome and another 31 children were hospitalized with related injuries. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Corrections
A Chance of Success Slips Away
description: Stanford, Calif. - President Bush describes Afghanistan, the first front on the war on terrorism, as a success. In comparison to Iraq, perhaps it is. But if you look at Afghanistan on its own merits, the lack of progress is disheartening. In 2002, President Bush promised a "Marshall Plan" for the country, with the goal of turning Afghanistan into a stable, democratic state. On Tuesday, before the United Nations General Assembly, the president said that "the Afghan people are on the path to democracy and freedom." Yet in nearly three years we have failed to create security, stability, prosperity or the rule of law in Afghanistan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Workers Authorize Strike
description: Thousands of janitors and other building-service workers at hundreds of office buildings on Long Island and in Connecticut, New Jersey and Westchester County voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize a strike, their union announced yesterday. The contract dispute involves four separate sets of negotiations for members of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union. Some of the strikes could begin as early as Oct. 1, and if all the suburban janitors walk out, could involve 12,000 workers. The main issues in the contract disputes are wage increases and how much of rising health care costs should be covered by the workers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Iran's Plans for Nuclear Fuel Widen Rift Over Technology
description: PARIS, Sept. 22 - Iran reiterated its right on Wednesday to produce uranium fuel for nuclear energy, seizing on a rift between nuclear-weapon nations that want to slow the spread of such technology and developing countries that see the technology as the entitlement of every signatory to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPOFSKY, DAVID
description: POPOFSKY--David. Born in Brooklyn, NY, February 6, 1934, David was a graduate of the Citadel in 1956 and served in the U.S. Army and was discharged with the rank of Captain. In 1973 David founded Popofsky Advertising Inc. in New York City. Over the years the agency worked on such brands as Robitussin, Dimetapp, Maalox, Bausch and Lomb, Becton Dickenson, Eucalyptamint, Genovese Drug Stores, Pathmark Supermarkets and Charms Candy. David was also a founder of the retail drug institute at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy as well as serving on its board as a boardmember. Separately he enjoyed a long career as a horse owner and breeder of thoroughbred racehorses that ran under the stable name Bee Pee Stables. In addition he was a longstanding proud member of the New York Friars Club. David is survived by his devoted wife Barbara and his two sons Michael and Scott as well as his two daughters-in-law Theresa and Michelle. David was also blessed with three lovely grandchildren Jordan, Sara, and Isabella. Services Thursday, September 23, 9:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY. POPOFSKY--David. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club are deeply saddened by the passing of their esteemed member, David Popofsky. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Services will be held on Thursday, September 23, 9:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director POPOFSKY--David. Popofsky Advertising Inc. and Naturopathic Labs Int'l Inc. mourn the passing of our founder and CEO David Popofsky with deep sadness. We admired David for his intelligence, knowledge, creativity, motivation and determination. He was a leader and friend to us and we will miss him. We, his professional family, extend our sympathies to Barbara, Michael and Scott and their families.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Courthouse Contractor Faces Charges
description: The president of a roofing company that helped to replace the roof of the Nassau County Courthouse was arrested yesterday on charges he lied on federal labor forms about paying his workers at prevailing wage rates. District Attorney Denis Dillon, whose office is located in the courthouse at 262 Old Country Road, said he received a tip in February that Jose Reillo of A&D Abatement was paying workers about $18 an hour instead of the $32.55 he had reported to the county and the United States Department of Labor -- an underpayment of $27,869. In First District Court in Hempstead yesterday, Mr. Reillo, 33, of Corona, Queens, pleaded not guilty to grand larceny and other felony charges. His trial is scheduled for next month. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Edward Larrabee Barnes, Modern Architect, Dies at 89
description: Edward Larrabee Barnes, a New York architect who cherished the ideals of clarity and functionality he learned from the Modernist masters even as he devised novel approaches to designing houses, campuses, museums, churches and skyscrapers, died on Tuesday in Cupertino, Calif. He was 89 and lived in Cambridge, Mass. The cause was complications of a stroke, said his son, John.

title: Poker Pros, Now in TV'sGlare, Always Want 'In'
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 - Sunday night, three of the luckiest guys alive finally caught a break and headed up to a room at the Borgata casino here for a rest in the middle of a long day at the World Poker Tour. In the past few years these three have each won millions of dollars -- the talk generally gets less specific when losses come up -- playing Texas Hold 'Em, a card game that has stormed across television and computer screens and put poker in the middle of the table as never before.

title: A Biographical Behemoth Is Ready to Bend Shelves
description: OXFORD, England - Walk up St. Giles, the great piazza that runs north of St. Mary Magdalen's church here, with St. John's College to your right and the Ashmolean Museum to your left, and before long you come to an inconspicuous Georgian house. Inside is no more glamorous, altogether a light-year from the glitzy modern abode of a New York book corporation. And yet this is where the publishing achievement of the year -- maybe of the decade -- has been accomplished. In Brian Harrison's office, arrayed in the simple livery of the Oxford University Press, dark blue with gold lettering, sits the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

title: Russians Crack Down on Security Breaches
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 - As lawmakers here debated how to respond to terrorist attacks, Russian investigators on Wednesday arrested an airport police supervisor who briefly detained two women suspected of killing themselves and 88 others aboard two passenger airliners last month, the Prosecutor General's Office said.

title: Hope Amid the Rubble
description: Washington - Based on what Americans have been seeing in the news media about Afghanistan lately, there may not be many who believed President Bush on Tuesday when he told the United Nations that the "Afghan people are on the path to democracy and freedom." But then again, not many Americans know what Afghanistan was like before the American-led invasion. Let me offer some perspective.

title: From Storage, a New Fashion
description: TOWARD the end of the latest Tom Cruise thriller, "Collateral," the story's action turns on the performance of a player new to most movie audiences. For a suspense-charged moment Mr. Cruise and his co-star, Jamie Foxx, are upstaged by a silvery finger of portable storage technology.

title: ENRON AGREES TO SELL GAS COMPRESSION UNIT TO PARAGON
description: The Enron Corporation has agreed to sell its Enron Compression Services unit to Paragon ECS Holdings for $51.6 million to raise money for its creditors. The unit provides natural gas compression services to the Florida Gas Transmission Company and to the Transwestern Pipeline Company, according to papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. The sale is part of Enron's plan to raise $12 billion to leave bankruptcy and pay off creditors owed at least $74 billion by next year. Before selling to Paragon, Enron will auction the unit's assets on Oct. 18. Debtors are often required to hold auctions for assets before completing a sale. Paragon could increase its bid at the auction.
