title: How Not to Save Social Security
description: Among the clear-cut policy differences between President Bush and Senator John Kerry is each man's take on Social Security. In his acceptance speech at the Republican convention, Mr. Bush said, "We must strengthen Social Security by allowing younger workers to save some of their taxes in a personal account." Mr. Kerry, in his acceptance speech, said, "I will not privatize Social Security."

title: Publisher Weighs Sale of YM as Advertising Slips
description: Gruner & Jahr Publishing USA, attempting to stem its losses after circulation scandals and the messy demise of Rosie magazine, told employees yesterday it was exploring the sale of YM, the company's faltering teenage magazine.

title: People
description: Sharon Love, president at the Promotion Network, Dallas, part of the Omnicom Group, was promoted to chief executive, succeeding Roger Winter, who becomes chairman. Ms. Love will continue to be based in the New York office. Rich Feitler, executive vice president, was promoted to president, succeeding Ms. Love. He will continue to be based in the Chicago office.

title: Secret Service Examining Threats Made by a Heckler
description: The mother of a soldier killed in Iraq who was arrested last week for interrupting a speech by Laura Bush is being investigated by the Secret Service for threatening remarks she made about President Bush, a Secret Service official confirmed yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Priceline.com Acquires Active Hotels
description: Priceline.com, a seller of discount travel services on the Internet, said Tuesday that it had bought Active Hotels of Britain for about $161 million in cash as the company seeks to expand its online hotel-reservations business in Europe. The purchase was Priceline.com's largest and adds 8,000 hotel properties to the 11,000 that can be booked through its sites. The acquisition will add to fourth-quarter profit, said Priceline.com, based in Norwalk, Conn. Adding Active Hotels will help Priceline.com's chief executive, Jeffery H. Boyd, accelerate expansion into Europe, where he said the online travel business was growing faster than in the United States. Priceline.com said last month that bookings growth would slow to a gain of 44 percent to 48 percent in the second half of the year on lower increases for hotel rooms and rental cars. The company raised its fourth-quarter profit forecast excluding certain costs to 14 cents to 18 cents a share because of the acquisition, from its earlier forecast of 13 cents to 17 cents. Priceline.com had accumulated $386.2 million in cash and cash equivalents at the end of the second quarter. Part of the cash was obtained through two convertible debt offerings that generated $225 million in sales in the last 14 months. Shares of Priceline.com rose $1.62, to $21.22, yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chip Executive Resigns
description: The electronics maker Royal Philips Electronics said the chief executive of its semiconductors division, Scott McGregor, was stepping down at his own request. Frans van Houten, a member of the group management committee who is responsible for the business groups of Philips' consumer electronics division, will take over, the company said. Mr. McGregor has led the chip unit since Sept. 1, 2001, the company said. He steps down effective Jan. 1 and is returning to the United States.

title: Deadlock on Pepper Spray
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 - A federal judge here declared a mistrial on Wednesday after a jury said it was deadlocked on whether law enforcement officials used excessive force when they daubed pepper spray in the eyes of antilogging demonstrators.

title: DYNEGY RESTATES RESULTS RELATED TO ILLINOIS POWER SALE
description: Dynegy said yesterday that it would restate results for 2003 and the first two quarters of this year because it understated reductions in good will related to the sale of its Illinois Power utility. Good will was reduced by an additional $259 million in the fourth quarter of 2003 and by $4 million and $2 million, respectively, in the first and second quarters of this year, the company said. Dynegy said it had recorded a good will impairment of $242 million in the fourth quarter of 2003. The sale is still subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dynegy, based in Houston, said that it expected to complete the sale of Illinois Power by the end of the year.

title: The Accidental Environmentalist
description: They call him Can Man, and that suits Juan Taylor just fine.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about the City University's plan to put a journalism school in the old New York Herald Tribune building on West 41st Street referred incorrectly to the way one Tribune reporter, Sanche de Gramont, was sent down the street to cover the death of a baritone on stage at the Metropolitan Opera in 1960. Mr. de Gramont was not pulled from a bar stool; he was at his desk in the newsroom. But other details of that evening are still a matter of dispute. Details, Page B6.

title: Records Show Five Crashes in Eight Years at Crossing
description: A railroad crossing in Bedford Hills, N.Y., where a Metro-North commuter train crashed into a tractor-trailer on Monday had been the site of four other accidents in the last eight years, including a fatal one, according to Federal Railroad Administration records.

title: Hernndez Drops First After Losing Yanks' Lead
description: Orlando Hernndez was oblivious about his opportunity to pitch the Yankees into the postseason last night. He was most likely listening to music or stretching or relaxing when a public relations official said that the Yankees would qualify for the playoffs by stifling the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Furniture to Fit the Smaller Scholar
description: FOR a child who doesn't want to do homework at the kitchen table any longer, a miniature workstation can help improve posture and work habits. Many stations have adjustable chairs and work surfaces, so they can grow with the youngster.

title: New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: China Sets Its First Fuel-Economy Rules
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 22 - Brushing aside concerns from the auto industry, the Chinese government has set fuel-economy standards on new cars, sport utility vehicles and vans for the first time, people with copies of the new rules said on Wednesday.

title: Maker of Twinkies and Wonder Bread Files for Chapter 11
description: People are still eating Hostess Twinkies and Wonder bread, but the problem for Interstate Bakeries is that they are eating less of them.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Tuesday about New York shows for spring 2005 misstated the beneficiary of proceeds from the sale of T-shirts featuring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at the Marc Jacobs store. The money goes to Friends of Hillary, the senator's re-election committee, not to Downtown for Democracy.

title: Exposing the Military Mind-Set
description: The staging is spartan and so are the characters in "Pugilist Specialist," an engrossing, inventive dissection of the American military mind being performed with stark precision at the 59E59 Theaters.

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, September 22, 2004. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

title: Ernst & Young Settles Conflict of Interest Case in California
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank Executive Named
description: The Anglo Irish Bank named David Drumm to succeed the chief executive, Sean FitzPatrick, left, who is retiring after leading the bank to 16 consecutive years of profit growth. Mr. Drumm, 37, is the head of banking in Dublin and the United States and will take over in January. The company, based in Dublin, had previously said that Mr. FitzPatrick would become chairman. Mr. Drumm established the bank's United States business in 1998 before moving back to Ireland last year to head the Dublin and United States banking divisions, which account for almost half of the company's overall earnings.

title: Russ Meyer, 82, a Filmmaker of Classics in a Lusty Genre, Dies
description: Russ Meyer, whose 1960's fantasy films about the antics of giant-breasted, often assertive women were among the first "nudies" to have a story line but who later flirted with respectability when his style of filmmaking became influential in the mainstream movie industry, died on Saturday at his home in the Hollywood Hills. He was 82.

title: The Real Problem With Electronic Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Schilling Adds Voice to Talk of the Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22 - Driving along the Mass Pike, as autumn arrives and the leaves start to change, it is normal enough to turn on a sports-talk radio station and hear a caller talking loudly and passionately about the Red Sox.

title: Guess Who's Invited to Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - In recognition of its growing economic power, China will meet with the Group of 7 for the first time next week in what could be a prelude to joining the elite club of wealthy industrialized nations.

title: Ex-prime minister weighs in on debate among Socialists : Jospin to vote for EU constitution
Death at the Opera, and the Fog of Memory
description: It was a long-ago city room story that several New York Herald Tribune veterans shared last month with a reporter from their old rival, The New York Times: the night 44 years ago when Leonard Warren died onstage at the Metropolitan Opera House and their colleague Sanche de Gramont rushed from a bar stool into an assignment that earned him a Pulitzer Prize.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Former Chief Executive Of Software Firm Indicted A federal grand jury charged Sanjay Kumar, left, the former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, with securities fraud and obstruction of justice, in what may be the last major criminal white-collar case to come out of the accounting scandals of the late 1990's.

title: A Woman and Her Baby Are Killed in Connecticut
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 22 - A woman and her 4-month-old son were stabbed to death on an isolated wooded ridge overlooking the Housatonic River on Tuesday evening, the police said on Wednesday. The crime stunned this small town and prompted a widespread overnight search that led the police to seek an arrest warrant for a suspect whose identity they would not reveal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Gas and Steam Rates To Increase
description: The state's Public Service Commission yesterday approved an increase in what Consolidated Edison charges for natural gas and steam customers. Regulators authorized charging an additional $46.8 million during the next year for gas delivery, which is about a 7.5 percent rate increase on average customers' bills. The increase, which was about $150 million less than the utility requested, will take effect Oct. 1 and rates will not change for three years. The new rate reflects the cost of delivery, not the price of natural gas itself, which fluctuates with the market. The commission also approved charging $49.6 million and $27.4 million more to steam customers in the first and second years respectively. But the commission explained that the overall cost to steam customers will be about $20 million because of savings from the utility's East River Repowering Project, a program of improvements to Con Ed's power plants. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINBAUM, DAVID
description: WEINBAUM -- David. We mourn the passing of an extraordinary man, a true gentleman. There was no more devoted husband, father, grandfather, great - grand father and brother. A noted antique importer for over 50 years, he was a decorated veteran of WWII. He will always be remembered for his kindness, generosity and his devotion to his family. His spirit will remain in our hearts forever. His family deeply grieves his loss. Beloved husband of Tobie, devoted father of Eileen and Barry, cherished grandfather of Meredith, Matthew, Benjamin, Steven and Alex, and greatgrandfather of Evan and Kate, loving brother of Marvin. Services Friday 9AM at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Real Problem With Electronic Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.S. Soldier Killed, Third This Week
description: An American soldier was killed while on patrol in eastern Afghanistan, the third American death this week, the military said. A spurt of attacks by insurgents around the country also wounded 14 American soldiers and 6 Afghan soldiers in the last few days. American and Afghan officials have warned that Taliban and other armed militants were preparing to increase attacks before the presidential election on Oct. 9. A total of 34 United States soldiers have died in Afghanistan this year, and about 100 in and around Afghanistan since the war began in 2001. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Vindictive Impulses
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Premier Hopes To Reassure Europeans
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan flew to Brussels in an attempt to rescue his country's tottering bid for European Union membership from the political morass created by his support for criminalizing adultery. He was to meet today with Gnter Verheugen, the union's enlargement commissioner, whose report on whether Turkey has met the conditions for starting accession talks is due on Oct. 6. The adultery proposal was to be included in a parliamentary vote on a new criminal code -- reforms that had been framed to satisfy European Union conditions -- but caused the entire package to be withdrawn. European Union officials have said that without the penal code changes, Turkey has no chance of obtaining a date for membership negotiations. Susan Sachs (NYT)

title: Pentagon lifts block on voter site
Top Shiite Cleric Is Said to Fear Voting in Iraq May Be Delayed
description: Correction Appended

title: Miscellany
description: Internet advertising revenue in the United States during the first half of 2004 increased 39.7 percent, to $4.6 billion, according to the Interactive Advertising Bureau, New York. For the second quarter, revenue showed an increase of 42.7 percent, to about $2.4 billion, compared with the same period a year earlier. PricewaterhouseCoopers compiles data for the bureau.

title: Kerry Steps Up His Attack on Bush Over Iraq
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 23 A Stepping up his attack on President Bush over Iraq, Senator John Kerry said today that conditions there were so bad that the elections planned for January were in jeopardy and that the president's upbeat assessments was contradicted by reality and intelligence reports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WYNER, JAY S.
description: WYNER--Jay S., 83, of Sands Point, NY died on September 20, 2004. Adored husband of Ethel; beloved father of Shari and Richard Narva and Janis and Paul Sheinkopf; dear grandfather of Matthew, Laura, Arielle, Zachary, Josh, Jamie, Sarah and Shoshi; and loving brother of Ruth Schwartzberg, Dorothy Goldfarb, Sally Seidler and the late Maxine Diamond. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 23 at The Community Synagogue, Port Washington, New York. He was loved and admired by all who knew him and he will be in our hearts and thoughts forever.

title: The Philharmonic Brings Surprise to the Familiar
description: The New York Philharmonic began its new season on Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall amid stark signs of the challenges facing major American orchestras. The opening night concert was a few days later than usual because the orchestra had planned to tour Europe earlier this month. But the tour was canceled when the financing collapsed. Moreover, like three other top American orchestras -- Chicago, Philadelphia and Cleveland -- the Philharmonic is in contract negotiations with the players, though for the moment those relations seem comparatively calm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUTTENBERG, DERALD
description: RUTTENBERG--Derald. The faculty and staff of the Department of Medicine at large and the Division of Hematology/Oncology, deeply mourns the passing of our visionary benefactor, Derald H. Ruttenberg. His keen intellect, insightful curiosity, clever wit and compassionate generosity will forever serve to inspire our community. His extraordinary leadership and tireless commitment to scholarship, along with his profound belief in the potential of people to make a difference in the outlook of patients who suffer from malignant disease, through discoveries in research and improvement in patient care, will never be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Janet; to his sons, Eric and John; to his daughters, Katherine and Hattie, and to the entire Ruttenberg family. Drs. Paul Klotman and Jonathan Licht

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSKIN, SUSAN LEVANT
description: ROSKIN--Susan LeVant, died September 21, 2004. With enduring love and affection we bid a fond adieu to Susan LeVant Roskin. No words can ever express how much she will be missed. Susan lived a full life with courage and dignity. She devoted herself to helping others as a professional guidance counselor, loving mother, sister, aunt and friend. No greater tribute can be paid to a life well lived and love well shared than the warm loving feelings and beautiful memories she has left with us. We wish her the much eluded peace she sought in her life. Her loving spirit will remain with us. Susan is survived by her loving son, Robert Roskin, sister Pat Spranger, brother Howard LeVant, sister-in-law Nancy LeVant and friend and former husband Bill Roskin. Funeral services will be at Riverside Memorial, W. 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave., Friday, September 24, 11:30 AM. Send donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 7 about fiscal troubles in San Diego, including an unfunded liability in its pension plan, misidentified another locality where questionable practices in a retirement fund are being investigated. It is Milwaukee County, not Milwaukee.

title: See-Through Kitchen, Park View
description: Caf Gray, the new restaurant of the chef Gray Kunz in the Time Warner Center, is "a modern interpretation of an Austrian brasserie," said its architect, David Rockwell. The 10,000-square-foot restaurant, to open on Oct. 1, features Viennese design motifs like lace -- not in lace curtains, but etched on glass room dividers -- and curvy leather banquettes.

title: Lawyers Start Their Defense of Tobacco
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Lawyers for the nation's biggest tobacco companies mounted an aggressive defense against the government's racketeering charges on Wednesday, insisting that mistakes made in the past did not constitute fraud and that their current business practices made any future fraud unlikely.

Last month the company introduced 22 of them, including a hanging chair ($143), top, by the model-musician Carla Bruni, and an aluminum shoehorn ($45), bottom, by Manolo Blahnik. Order through the Habitat store on Kings Road in London: 011-44-207-351-1211; e-mail, store .kingsroad@habitat .co.uk. Prices do not include shipping.

title: Opponents Say Republicans Plan Sequel to Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - House Democratic leaders and civil liberties advocates said Wednesday that a Republican bill responding to the findings of the Sept. 11 commission would go well beyond the panel's recommendations. It would call for broad new powers for law enforcement agencies, they said, and include new authority to conduct electronic surveillance in terrorism investigations.

title: When Candidates Pick Voters
description: The Voting Rights Act -- signed into law on Aug. 6, 1965 -- was a high point of the civil rights era. In 1965, there were 5 black members of Congress; today there are 39. No single piece of legislation since the 14th Amendment has had such a measurable and dramatic effect on the political fortunes of black Americans.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Says F.C.C. Is Overcharging For Airwaves
description: Nextel Communications said yesterday that federal regulators were asking it to pay $452 million more than it should for airwaves that the wireless carrier would receive in a $4.86 billion transaction with the government. The Federal Communications Commission underestimated the value of radio frequencies the company plans to trade, Nextel said in an F.C.C. filing. The company, based in Reston, Va., said the frequencies, used by cellphones, are worth $2.06 billion. The F.C.C. set their value at $1.61 billion. Nextel's chief executive, Timothy M. Donahue, met with F.C.C. officials in Washington this week to outline Nextel's objections to surrendering certain frequencies in exchange for a different set with greater capacity. The company contends that the government miscalculated the population in areas covered by the licenses, which is the basis for the valuation. Persuading the government to change the airwaves' value may reduce the $3.25 billion Nextel would be required to spend as part of the swap. In July, the F.C.C. awarded Nextel frequencies, valued at $4.86 billion, that the company sought to reduce interference with police and firefighters' radios. As part of the swap, Nextel will get new channels that allow it to expand in wireless Internet services. Shares of Nextel fell 74 cents, to $22.71.

title: Fingerprints on File, Right From the Patrol Car
description: BIOMETRICS, the science of using measurable physical characteristics to identify people, has added new weapons to the arsenals of law enforcement agencies, and as some of these new tools are connected to high-speed wireless communications they could become widely available to officers in the field, not just those back at headquarters.

description: EPSTEIN -- Morris. Loving husband of Joan, devoted father of Sheila Spicehandler, Jeffrey Epstein and the late Jack Epstein. Beloved grandfather of Sam, Andrew, Lauren, Eric and Ali. Before thousands of American Indians gathered on the prairie grass of this vast reservation on the northern Plains, the tribal president gave Senator Tom Daschle a red feather.

description: Claiming illegal labor practices, low wages and a hostile work environment, employees seeking to unionize at three hotels near major New York airports went on strike yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: One Of Two Murder Victims Identified
description: A young woman who was found shot in the head on Tuesday along a road in Old Westbury was identified yesterday as Isabella Olivia Mendoza, 16, of Hempstead. The Nassau police are continuing to seek the identity of a man who was also found on Tuesday, shot and stabbed, along a path near a rainwater runoff basin in Bethpage. An identifying feature was a tattoo behind his left shoulder of an angel kneeling in prayer on a cloud. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Loving fiance of Poala Dangelico. Brother of Pamela English. Also survived by many loving friends, family and colleagues. Funeral services Intelisano - Scarpa Funeral Home, 492 Clifton Ave, Clifton, NJ on Saturday, 9:15 AM. 10 AM Memorial Mass at St. Pauls RC Church, Clifton, NJ 973-340-1300. description: QUEBEC - If freedom of expression has limits in Canada, Jean-Franois Fillion is testing them as the radio shock jock whom both federal regulators and Quebec separatists want to silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALL, DAVID B. PH.D.
description: PALL--David B. Ph.D., Born April 2, 1914 in Thunder Bay, Ontario, died peacefully September 21, 2004 after a long illness. Loving husband of the late Josephine B. Pall and the late Helen R. Pall. Beloved father of Ellen Pall, Jane Block and Abigail Weinshank and the late Stephanie Pall and William Pall. Father-inlaw of Richard Dicker, Fred Weinshank and Olivia Pall. Grandfather of Stephen (Lauren), Kathryn (Bob), Elizabeth, Hillary, Alex, KK, Scott and Ben. Great-grandfather of Kameron, Mikayla, Adam, Helen and Brian. Founder of Pall Corporation, inventor, innovator in fine filtration systems, winner of the National Medal of Technology for his signficant contributions to science and medicine. Philanthropist, generous supporter of the arts and medicine, avid hiker, skier, music-lover. He was a brilliant man whose contributions to society left the world a better place. Services today, Thursday September 23rd at 2pm at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Long Island Chapter, 3281 Veterans Memorial Highway, Suite E13, Ronkonkoma, NY 11779 PALL--David B., PhD. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System is saddened by the passing of David B. Pall, PhD, the founder and former chairman of the Pall Corp. A life trustee of the health system, Dr. Pall joined the North Shore University Hospital Board of Trustees in 1970 and was highly regarded throughout the community for his philanthropic activity. We are eternally grateful for his commitment and generosity to the North Shore-LIJ Health System. He was an extraordinary businessman and a true gentleman. We will miss him. We extend our condolences to his family and friends. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Daniel de Roulet, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System PALL--David B. I am deeply saddened by the death of David B. Pall who was a good friend and intellectual mentor for over 30 years. My thoughts are with David's family. This extraordinary man enriched our lives and he will be greatly missed. Sandy Schlesinger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAMOVOT, ABRAHAM
description: GRAMOVOT--Abraham, died on September 13, 2004, at the age of 94. He is survived by his wife, Harriet; his daughter, Hollis, and his two grandchildren, Kym and Mitchell. He was a devoted husband for 60 years, and a loving father and grandfather. His memory will live in our hearts forever.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Back To Work
description: The leading labor federation called off a nationwide strike after a court ordered public-sector workers to return to their jobs and also ruled that the government must provide the money for unpaid wages. The Histadrut trade union called the strike Tuesday, keeping 400,000 workers off the job and paralyzing the country's economy. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: The Mayor Loves the Subway, Even at a Standstill
description: As United Nations diplomats and a presidential motorcade jammed the streets this week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg repeatedly counseled New Yorkers to ride the subways to avoid the gridlock.

title: Corrections

title: Saturday Game With Fewer Ads
description: The YES Network will carry Saturday night's Red Sox-Yankees game with advertising time reduced by 15 minutes, giving the channel time to offer taped vignettes, interviews and other features about the rivalry between the teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOST, IRVING
description: YOST--Irving Irving Yost died gently Tuesday evening at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. Irving established the Turning Point Inn in Gt. Barrington with his wife Shirley (deceased 1993). He will be missed by his loving partner Jane, his siblings Lee, Jessie, Harry & Phil, his children Cindy Rosenbaum of Goldens Bridge NY, Jamie Yost Vlcek of Monterey MA, and Gary Yost of Mill Valley CA, and their families and many friends. Memorial service at Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home in Gt. Barrington MA, on Friday Sept. 24th at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the Kerry campaign

title: Eastern Europe is not siphoning jobs from West, study finds
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility Bailout Approved
description: British Energy won European Union approval of a government bailout aimed at saving it from bankruptcy. The company will have to separate its nuclear, nonnuclear and sales units to ensure that only nuclear power benefits from state aid, the European Commission, the executive arm of the union, said. The union also put limits on British Energy's future pricing and investment. The British government is to provide 3.4 billion ($6.1 billion) for the bailout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MONROE, AARON LERNER
description: MONROE--Aaron Lerner, 81, formerly of Roslyn Heights, died on September 14, 2004. Beloved husband of Julia for 58 years. Devoted father of Cynthia Franken and Lynne Lerner. Proud grandfather of Jascha and Lily Havermans. Respected father-in-law of Richard Franken and Jos Havermans. A memorial will be held on Sunday, October 17th, 2004 at 3 P.M., at the Ethical Humanist Society, 38 Old Country Road, Garden, Garden City, New York. Phone 516-741-7304.

title: 3 Palestinians Shot Dead After Killing 3 Israeli Soldiers
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 23  Relying on dense fog for cover, three Palestinian gunmen reached an Israeli army outpost in the Gaza Strip early today and killed three soldiers before the attackers were themselves killed.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Government Denies Food Shortage
description: Zimbabwe's information minister said the nation would harvest more than enough maize to meet its needs for the coming year, contradicting a statement on Monday by the head of the nation's grain board that government maize purchases would amount to barely half of Zimbabwe's yearly requirements. The information minister, Jonathan Moyo, called reports of grain shortages "weapons of mass deception" spread by the West and the government's internal opponents. The Grain Marketing Board, the only legal buyer of maize, reported last week that it had collected less than 300,000 tons of maize, well short of the 1.4 million tons needed, and that it was likely to buy only 750,000 tons through March. Mr. Moyo said the harvest would total 2.4 million tons. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Reorganize the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., Bowing to Court, to Free 'Enemy Combatant'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Yaser E. Hamdi, an American citizen captured in Afghanistan and once deemed so dangerous that the American military held him incommunicado for more than two years as an enemy combatant, will be freed and allowed to return to Saudi Arabia in the next few days, officials said Wednesday.

title: Insurer to Refund Money To Soldiers Who Bought High-Cost Life Policies
description: Correction Appended

title: PFIZER ACQUIRES REST OF MERIDICA FOR $125 MILLION
description: Pfizer, the largest drug maker, said it would buy the remaining 90 percent stake of Meridica that it does not already own from the PA Consulting Group for $125 million and a contingent payment. Meridica makes devices that allow medicines for respiratory illnesses to be inhaled. Pfizer, based in New York, bought a 10 percent stake and licensed one of the company's inhalers last year. "Having this technology inside the company will allow Pfizer to improve the speed of bringing these products to market," a Pfizer spokesman, Paul Fitzhenry, said. The technology is still a "number of years away from commercialization," Mr. Fitzhenry said.

title: No Bush Is an Island
description: No Bush Is an Island

title: A Strategy for Shell?
description: LONDON - THE Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that it would sell as much as $12 billion in assets, spend $45 billion on new projects and consider some acquisitions as it tries to bolster oil and gas production.

title: Nothing to Sing About: A Lull in Fall Musicals
description: Musically speaking, the 2004-5 Broadway season is seriously off balance.

title: Minimalist Art to Set the Table, And a Minimalist Table to Hold It
description: If a sculpture by the artists Donald Judd or Dan Flavin is beyond your means, maybe an item designed by one of them for the home -- though not cheap -- is more realistic. Several pieces from "Design Is Not Art," an exhibition of domestic objects by 18 Minimalist and post-Minimalist artists at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, are for sale through the museum's shop. Among them are Isamu Noguchi's Prismatic Table ($350), dinnerware by Flavin (above, $4,500) and Judd's Desk No. 74 (below, $10,650). The museum is at 2 East 91 Street; (212) 849-8300. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: State Regulators Are Backing Pataki's Clean-Energy Goals
description: New York State regulators voted yesterday to adopt Gov. George E. Pataki's renewable-energy standards, which require the state to get about a quarter of its electricity from environmentally friendly sources by 2013.

title: No sanctuary for hate speech : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
10 Ways to Secure Data That Belong to You Alone
description: As the storage capacity of computers has soared, parking data, whether spreadsheets or snapshots, has become less of a problem. But what if the data is for your eyes only?

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Confirms Goss as Chief of the C.I.A. The Senate voted 77 to 17 to confirm the nomination of Representative Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, as director of central intelligence. Twenty-eight Democrats joined 49 Republicans in voting in favor of the confirmation, a show of support seen as a victory for President Bush. PAGE A22

title: Your Location and a Lot More
description: Outdoors enthusiasts looking for affordable orienteering equipment may appreciate a new portable Global Positioning System navigator that promises high accuracy for a low price.

title: 1929:Planning a New Bank : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Iraqi Oil Company Official Killed on 3rd Attempt
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 24  A senior oil official was gunned down this morning in the northern city of Mosul after having survived two previous attempts on his life.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Shrinks
description: Japan's trade surplus shrank for the first time in more than a year in August as rising oil prices fueled an increase in imports while export growth slowed. The drop in Japan's trade surplus raised some concerns about the sustainability of a recovery that has been led mostly by trade and contributed to declines in Japanese stocks and the yen. The August surplus declined 26 percent from a year earlier, to 778.46 billion yen ($7 billion). Imports surged 18.4 percent, to 3.55 trillion yen, largely because of rising oil prices. Exports also rose, although at a much slower pace of 10.4 percent, to 4.33 trillion yen, led by sales of autos and steel. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Insurgents Who Beheaded 2 Show Briton in Plea for Life
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Thursday, Sept. 23 - A militant group that beheaded two American engineers this week posted a video on the Internet early Thursday showing a third hostage, Kenneth Bigley, a Briton, pleading for his life.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Sept. 2 about the expansion of the wine business in Australia misstated the effect of a proposed trade agreement with the United States on Australian exports. While duties on American wines shipped to Australia would end Jan. 1, those on Australian wines exported to the United States would remain until Jan. 1, 2016. They would not end at the same time.

title: Verizon Wireless Expands High-Speed Data Network
description: Correction Appended

title: For Sale: A Diva's Eccentric Legacy
description: LVES, France - FANS of no-flaw decorating and meticulous housekeeping, brace yourselves. The French decorator Madeleine Castaing saw beauty in plastic flowers, considered the straight pin an essential decorating tool and loved leopard-spot wall-to-wall carpet.

title: Bicycle Lock Manufacturer to Provide Free Locks to Owners of Easily Unlockable Model
description: A top maker of bicycle locks said yesterday that it planned to give its customers new locks at no charge after several Internet sites posted videos showing that several of its models could be opened using the barrel of a ballpoint pen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, EUGENE L.
description: VOGEL--Eugene L. On September 20, 2004. Loving husband of Sara. Loving father of Jennifer Liling and Amanda Jane, and of their husbands Robert Davis and Michael Gallacher. Memorial service Sunday, 4PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Appleseed Foundation for Law and Justice, Inc., at The Appleseed Foundation, 727 15 St., N.W., Washington, D.C. 20005. Phone 202347-7960. VOGEL -- Eugene L. We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Counsel to our Firm, former Chairman of the Tax Department, and our partner for over 40 years. We remember with affection his insight, formidable intellect, breadth of knowledge and wit. Our condolences and deepest sympathy to his wife, Sara, and his daughters, Jennifer and Amanda. Katten Muchin Zavis Rosenman

title: Bombing Kills 2 Policemen in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 - A Palestinian suicide bomber blew herself up on Wednesday afternoon and killed two Israeli policemen who had confronted her at a busy intersection in Jerusalem, officials said.

title: An Order to Reclaim 'the Integrity of the Government'
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. James E. McGreevey's statement yesterday announcing his order banning campaign contributions by vendors that do business with government agencies in New Jersey:

title: Shopping by 'magalog':straight to the source
Commission relaxes the rules governing hours on the job : EU 'opens the door' to a longer workday
Courting the Small-Business Owner
description: Correction Appended

title: Ex-Banker Seeks Prison Order Reversal
description: Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston banker, asked a federal appeals court to reverse a judge's order requiring him to surrender to prison by Oct. 28 to begin serving an 18-month sentence for obstructing justice.

title: With a Nod to Vinyl, CD's Take Over the Turntable
description: IF you really want to prove yourself as a disc jockey, you have to do it with vinyl.

title: Automakers Attack Proposal to Address Global Warming
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22 - Automakers on Wednesday attacked a California plan to regulate automotive emissions of global warming gases.

title: Company's Coming? The Family Shutterbug Can Be Prepared
description: Anticipating the holiday season, when digital still and video cameras will be in heavy use, Adobe has introduced new video-editing software for home users and digital photo-editing software that includes a program for organizing and sharing images.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Hitachi TV's To Use Gemstar Program Guides
description: Gemstar-TV Guide's interactive program guides will make a debut on Hitachi America's digital television sets, the companies said yesterday. The companies announced a multiyear licensing deal for North America. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, nor was an introduction date. Gemstar will receive licensing fees based on the number of sets sold that include its technology. The guide allows television owners to view an electronic version of a show guide. Consumers will not have to subscribe to a service to view the guide. The guide is meant to be used with cable card-ready digital televisions, which eliminate set-top boxes. The inclusion of the guide in cable card-ready televisions is another carrot for consumers to encourage them to buy digital televisions.

title: Coffee Break: Now, Java in a Pod
description: BEFORE leaving for work from her home in the Maryland suburbs, Elisa Diehl likes to have a cup of espresso. But she doesn't have the patience to grind and measure beans for her Nespresso machine, so she uses "pods" -- single doses of premeasured coffee in thimble-shape capsules, which she orders by phone or on the Web.

title: Trump Hotels and Equity Firm Break Off Talks
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc., the flagship of Donald J. Trump's faltering casino holdings, said late last night that a recently announced deal with Credit Suisse First Boston to inject fresh money into the debt-laden concern had fallen apart, raising doubts about how much longer the company could remain in operation without filing for bankruptcy protection or being taken over by another gambling company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about an effort by leaders of the Sept. 11 commission to seek private donations and continue working after the end of its government support misidentified the committee headed by Porter J. Goss, Republican of Florida, which held hearings on the panel's recommendations. It is the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, not the Senate committee. A reader reported the error the day it appeared; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Poll Favors McGreevey Leaving As Promised
description: New Jersey voters are split over whether Gov. James E. McGreevey should have resigned because of an affair with a male staff member, but a large majority believe he should leave office as promised on Nov. 15, according to a poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac University. By waiting until November, the governor prevented a special election, guaranteeing he would be succeeded by the State Senate president, Richard J. Codey, a fellow Democrat. State Senator Raymond Lesniak, a McGreevey confidant, has suggested that the governor remain in office beyond November. But 61 percent of voters polled disagreed. Maurice Carroll, the poll director, said, "Voters are willing to put up with his date to go, but they want him to go as promised." John Sullivan (NYT)

title: U.S. Gold Mining Company Says Indonesia Detains 4 Officials
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23  The world's biggest gold producer, Newmont Mining Corporation, based in Denver, said today that the Indonesian police had detained six of its officials after questioning them about allegations of pollution from a company mine in northern Indonesia.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,032 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Antiques Arrayed in Paris. Americans Aren't.
description: PARIS - WATCHING Chanel-clad Americans graze on foie gras as they pored over gilded 18th-century consoles and Ruhlmann cabinets at a preview of the 22nd Biennale des Antiquaires -- Europe's grandest antiques show -- you would never guess that there was a strain in French-American relations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASSMAN, RABBI BERNARD
description: GLASSMAN--Rabbi Bernard. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi emeritus of Tifereth Israel Congregation New Bedford, MA. He served as book review editor of our journal and edited our annual booklet in memory of colleagues. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: Senate Confirms Goss as Intelligence Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - In what senators from both parties called a potential turning point for American intelligence agencies, the Senate voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to confirm the nomination of Representative Porter J. Goss of Florida as director of central intelligence.

title: Corrections
The President, the U.N. and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Say They Didn't Run Enough Last Season
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 22 - Through the season's first two games, the Jets have the league's top running game and the highest-scoring offense, and they are off to their best start in Coach Herman Edwards's four-year tenure.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Tour Operator Narrows Loss
description: The European tour operator Thomas Cook said its fiscal nine-month loss narrowed as demand for bookings increased and the company reduced costs at its Condor charter airline business. The pretax loss shrank to 286.7 million euros ($351.3 million) in the nine months through July from 354.6 million euros a year earlier, the chief executive, Wolfgang Beeser, said. Sales rose 2.5 percent, to 4.8 billion euros. Bookings were up 3.9 percent at the beginning of September. The company did not release net income numbers.

title: A Doctor's New Take on the Healing Arts
description: Juan Tapia-Mendoza, a pediatrician and former graffiti artist in New York -- his tag was C.A.T. 87 -- wanted to open a clinic for children providing emergency care at night. Hugo Martinez, a gallery owner and friend of Dr. Tapia-Mendoza, was looking for a new way to show graffiti art after closing his gallery in Brooklyn last year. So when Dr. Tapia-Mendoza (in white shirt, left) and three other physicians founded Pediatrics 2000, a clinic that will open on Monday in the Inwood section of Manhattan, they asked Mr. Martinez (in jeans jacket, with Dr. Tapia-Mendoza) to open a gallery there and to hire graffiti artists to paint the walls.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Prisoners Home From Guantnamo
description: Eleven Afghan prisoners held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, for up to three years, including one man who is a tribal leader and former Taliban commander, arrived and were released in Kabul. The release, arranged by an aide to President Hamid Karzai and presented at the presidential palace, was interpreted by many Afghans as a vote-seeking attempt to counter criticism of the frequent raids and detention of people by American forces in the country. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Low-Income Nonapplicants to Get Medicare Drug Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - After struggling for months to get Medicare beneficiaries to sign up for drug discount cards, the Bush administration said Wednesday that it would simply send the cards to 1.8 million people with low incomes who are eligible but have not applied.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Official Wants Con Ed To Pay For Break
description: Consolidated Edison should have to pay the city the $300,000 that it cost to clean up a massive water main break that occurred in Washington Heights last October, according to the New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., left. The water main break on Oct 16 at Amsterdam Avenue and 179th Street flooded businesses and apartment buildings with water and debris. The comptroller's office says it found that the rupture was caused by an electrical conduit owned by Con Ed that had been resting on top of the water main. Con Edison equipment did not cause the water main break," said Michael S. Clendenin, a spokesman for the utility. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEUER, WALTER
description: SCHEUER--Walter. It is with profound sorrow that I mourn the death of my dear friend Wally whose friendship I shared for over forty years. His passion for music and philanthropy paved the way for talented artists from all over the world. I extend my heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife Marge, children and grandchildren. Jack Erlanger SCHEUER--Wally. We mourn our dear friend, Wally, and will always be grateful for his visionary gift of "Mao To Mozart," a unique document which changed our lives. We will always remember his love, generosity and loyal support of our family. Our hearts go out to Marge and family. Shira, Michael, David, and Vera Stern

title: California's Stem Cell Challenge
description: Correction Appended

title: They Are Sleuths Who Weigh Prose
description: THE firestorm over the memos that figured in the CBS News report on President Bush's National Guard record featured a parade of expert document examiners who weighed in on font types, proportional spacing and superscripts. That kind of scrutiny is common enough that those who perform it have an occupational name: questioned-document examiners.

title: Making Windows More Secure
description: Correction Appended

title: House G.O.P. Offers Support to DeLay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - With his top aides indicted in Texas and an ethics complaint pending against him in Washington, Representative Tom DeLay addressed House Republicans on Wednesday and emerged with broad support, lawmakers who attended the meeting said.

title: Bloomberg Sets Detailed Plan to Cut Number of Homeless
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg began to flesh out his promise to reduce the number of homeless people on the streets and in New York's shelters, committing the city yesterday to a series of precise deadlines for his administration's goals.

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE SELLS STAKE IN HOSPITAL CHAIN
description: Forstmann Little & Company, the buyout firm founded in 1978 by Theodore J. Forstmann, has sold its remaining 23 percent stake in a rural hospital chain, Community Health Systems, for $560 million. The firm sold about 23.1 million shares for $24.21 each, Community Health said. Forstmann Little purchased the company, which runs 74 hospitals in 22 states, in 1996 and has almost tripled its original investment, said Winston Hutchins, the firm's chief financial officer. Forstmann Little, based in New York, has sold stakes in Community Health, based in Brentwood, Tenn., three times since an initial public offering in April 2000, Mr. Hutchins said.

title: Nader and Florida, 2004
description: To the Editor:

title: Rx for Iraq : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
CBS Appoints 2-Man Panel to Investigate Guard Report
description: CBS announced yesterday that Dick Thornburgh, a former attorney general, and Louis D. Boccardi, a former top executive of The Associated Press, would investigate the journalistic breakdowns that led to the broadcast of a flawed "60 Minutes" report about President Bush's National Guard service.

title: Even Near Home, a New Front Is Opening in the Terror Battle
description: CLIFTON, N.J. - The flags that sprouted after the Sept. 11 attacks still flap on lawns and flutter on poles outside well-tended homes here, about 15 miles from Manhattan. Looming above them is a concrete tower that houses a real-estate firm, an office supplies company -- and, until recently, investigators fear, an outpost of Al Qaeda.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Retailer's Profit Grows
description: Australia's largest retailer, Coles Myer, said net profit in the year ended July 25 rose 26.5 percent, to a record 576.5 million Australian dollars ($407 million), on cost cuts and higher sales at its supermarkets and department stores. Revenue rose 19.4 percent, to 32.3 billion Australian dollars. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: VENTIV HEALTH AGREES TO PURCHASE SMITH HANLEY
description: Ventiv Health, which provides marketing and sales services to pharmaceutical companies, has agreed to buy the Smith Hanley Corporation for $50 million in cash and may pay more based upon profitability targets, the company said. The purchase is expected to add 7 cents to Ventiv's 2005 full-year earnings per share. Ventiv's chief executive, Eran Broshy, said that the purchase would broaden the services it would offer to clients. The closely held Smith Hanley, based in Southport, Conn., provides contract and recruiting services for 65 pharmaceutical and biotechnology clients. Ventiv is based in Somerset, N.J.

title: Top Officials of Yukos Send Mixed Signals to Kremlin
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 - Two top officials of the Russian oil giant Yukos sent conciliatory and bristling signals to the Kremlin Wednesday as the company continued to totter under a $7.5 billion back tax bill.

title: Giambi and Brown Could Boost the Bench in October
description: The Yankees will soon meet to discuss their 25-man postseason roster, and two of the biggest curiosities are the recuperating Jason Giambi and Kevin Brown, the injured pitcher.

title: Sprawling 'Carmen' Returns to the Met
description: Bizet's "Carmen" was originally conceived as an opera comique -- with spoken dialogue and some tuneful set pieces -- and when done well, it can provide both gripping drama and genuine entertainment. But over the years, it has succumbed to a kind of edema, bloated into Grand Opera, some requisite ingredients of which are pageantlike spectacle and affected melodrama.

title: Kerry Maintains Domestic Focus, Turning to Social Security and Medicare
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 22 - Senator John Kerry extended his assault on President Bush's credibility from the war to the home front on Wednesday, asserting that on Social Security and Medicare, as on Iraq, Mr. Bush had failed to level with the American people.

title: The President, the U.N. and Iraq

title: Lottery Numbers
Prime-Time TV Plan For Martha Stewart
description: Correction Appended

title: For Mets, Last Place Is a State Of Mind
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 22 - Even though the Mets entered Wednesday night's game against Montreal clinging to a one-game lead over the Expos in the race to avoid last place in the National League East, Mike Piazza said it did not seem that way to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAT, EMANUEL
description: GAT--Emanuel. Passed away September 22, 2004. He is survived by his loving wife of 44 years, Naomi, devoted sons Michael and Jonathan, his brother Izhar and his wife Zipora, and their three children and three grandchildren. Graveside services today, 2PM at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York. The family will receive friends this afternoon & Sunday from 2PM-8PM at their residence.

title: Drawing Semiconductor Circuits, One Tiny Line at a Time
description: THE glue gun is a humble tool used in many a home project to lay down blobs of adhesive. Now a team of researchers from the United States Naval Research Laboratory and the Georgia Institute of Technology have devised a high-tech version of the glue gun to help lay down the ever-shrinking patterns of future circuits that have components the size of molecules.

title: The World's Best Player? This Hand Gives a Clue
description: Determining the world's best player is a subjective exercise, and almost all observers would choose one of the American stars who have won bunches of titles in the last decade.

title: The Womb as Photo Studio
description: IT'S a rite of passage for many expectant parents: baby's first ultrasound. The fuzzy images of the fetus, produced during an examination in an obstetrician's office, are prized by couples, passed around proudly among friends and relatives.

title: Study Finds AcceleratingDrop in Corporate Taxes
description: America's largest and most profitable companies paid less in corporate income taxes in the last three years, even as they increased profits, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Gain in Earnings for Darden Restaurants
description: By Reuters

title: McGreevey Bars Contracts for Political Donors
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22 - With only weeks until he steps down, Gov. James E. McGreevey issued a broad order on Wednesday that attempts to break the link between political contributions and government contracts in a state rattled by one corruption scandal after another.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Maker Fined
description: The chip maker Hynix Semiconductor and a former auditor were fined a combined 2.8 billion won ($2.4 million) by South Korea's financial regulator for accounting violations. Hynix, which misstated its 1999 financials by 2 trillion won, was fined 2 billion won, the maximum penalty, the Financial Supervisory Service said. Hynix and the regulator said that all the misstatements had been corrected. The Samil Accounting Corporation, which was Hynix's auditor at the time of the violations, was fined 770 million won for neglecting to recognize the violations, it said.

title: Life Sentence Sought in Witness Bribery Case
description: Brooklyn prosecutors won a widely noticed victory in August when a jury convicted a 30-year old man of bribing witnesses in a murder case. The prosecutors said the man, Dupree Harris, had thumbed his nose at the legal system for years, possibly even ordering the killing of a witness in the same murder case.

title: Underdog Liberty Likes Its Playoff Chances
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 22 - "You know, everybody counted us out," Liberty Coach Pat Coyle said Tuesday after a two-hour workout at the team's practice facility. "With all the injuries, with the coaching change, everyone, except for the people in that locker room, had counted us out."

title: European Press Criticizes Bush Address to U.N. as a Denial of a Worsening Situation in Iraq
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 - The editorial cartoon in The Times of London on Wednesday was derisive: the first panel showed President Bush telling the United Nations General Assembly, "Friends, our policy in Iraq is directed solely towards a successful election."

title: Adding Barricades, and Trying to Avoid the Feel of a Fortress
description: WHILE most eyes were focused last month on the fortification of Madison Square Garden for the Republican National Convention, one of the more aggressive occupations of public space in the name of private security occurred just north of Times Square.

title: Iraqi Leader Addresses Congress, Vowing Elections in January
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 A The interim prime minister of Iraq brought a message of gratitude and hope to the United States today, pledging that elections would take place in his country as scheduled in January. But hours later, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld raised the possibility that voting might not be held in some violence-torn regions of Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYER, SYLVIA
description: MAYER--Sylvia. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed Honorary Member, Sylvia Mayer. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Ted Tashlik, President

title: Lemony Snicket's Down and Dirty Indie
description: The writer Daniel Handler, aka Lemony Snicket, was in New York this week promoting two new works. One is "The Grim Grotto," the 11th installment of his hugely successful "Series of Unfortunate Events." These gothic children's books, following the star-crossed Baudelaire orphans through fantastical misadventures, have sold about 25 million copies in the last five years and won approval from grown-ups for their shrewd storytelling and clever wordplay.

title: Senator Kerry's Remarks
description: ollowing is a transript of remarks made by Senator John Kerry today in Columbus, Ohio.

title: For Those With a Million Pillows to Cover
description: If you find fabric prices daunting, 1502 Fabrics in High Point, N.C., has millions of yards of silks, cottons, wools and blends from companies like Robert Allen, Kravet and Duralee for up to 50 percent off retail. Closeouts from furniture companies are $6 to $8 a yard. Many patterns are online at www.1502fabrics.com, and samples of any can be mailed; (336) 434-2153. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: The Real Problem With Electronic Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINKEL, LAWRENCE W.
description: FINKEL--Lawrence W. On September 20, 2004. Beloved father of Deborah Lennon, Kenneth and Alan Finkel. Loving Pop Pop to his grandchildren. He died like he lived--he wanted nothing except the love he gave and the love he received. Dear friend of Charlotte Lesher. Services Thursday 2:15 P.M. at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Immersion Says Sony Unit Must Pay $82 Million
description: A unit of the Sony Corporation, the world's second-largest consumer electronics maker, must pay $82 million to the computer software developer Immersion for patent infringement, a jury in Oakland, Calif., found, Immersion said Tuesday. No judgment has been entered and the federal case can be appealed, Immersion said. Immersion filed a lawsuit in 2002 against Sony Computer Entertainment and Microsoft, saying the companies improperly used patented technology owned by Immersion in their video game systems. Last year, Immersion said Microsoft agreed to pay $26 million in exchange for licensing rights to Immersion patents. Sony's American depository receipts, each representing one ordinary share, fell 60 cents yesterday, to $33.84. Immersion shares rose 38 cents, to $6.20.

title: Untainted Elections?
description: To the Editor:

title: 1904:Russians Retreat Again : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
For Jobs, Brazilians Desert Their Cities
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 22 - A year and a half ago, Isabel Ftima Bueno and her husband, Ricardo Del Arco Pereira, gave up on So Paulo, a city that has long been a magnet for job seekers from all over Brazil.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a garden in Vermont owned by two landscape designers misspelled the name of a town in Massachusetts where they once lived. It is Pepperell, not Pepperill.

title: Seoul spy sought Kerry election role : Government role denied (folo)
An 'American Idol' Hopefuls Blog
description: Pick Your Lucky Stars

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Mideast Peace Plan's Sponsors Dismayed at Lack of Progress
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 22 - Secretary of State Colin L. Powell joined with envoys from Europe, Russia and the United Nations on Wednesday to express "deep concern" about the lack of progress in easing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Top Honors Taken By Miami Agency
description: Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami took top honors, winning best in show at the Athena Awards competition sponsored by the Newspaper Association of America.

title: Iraq Leader, Seeking Support, Calls Rise in Violence a Sign of Desperation by the Insurgents
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 22 - Iraq's interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi, using his robust self-confidence to try to counter growing pessimism over conditions in his country, said in an interview on Wednesday that the rise in the number and ferocity of terror attacks in the country by insurgents was proof that they were getting not stronger, but weaker.

title: Symbolic gesture to giant economy : Beijing invited to G-7 talks
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about rules proposed by the Food and Drug Administration to place on farmers the responsibility for the safety of eggs misstated the name of the director of food safety at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, who said that the government's estimate of 118,000 illnesses a year from salmonella was low. She is Caroline Smith DeWaal, not Caroline S.; she uses the surnames together.

title: BARNES BATTLE
description: An engineering consultant for the Barnes Foundation testified in a court hearing yesterday that a proposed new home for the foundation in downtown Philadelphia would probably include a physical duplicate of the entire 28,000-square-foot French Renaissance-style gallery that now houses it in Merion, Pa. Judge Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans' Court is to decide if the foundation should be allowed to make the move, which would violate the terms of the will of the art collector Albert C. Barnes. The foundation said that it would keep Barnes's ensemble of paintings and decorative objects intact as the collector specified. In an interview after testifying, the consultant, Harry M. Perks, a former Philadelphia streets commissioner, said, "It would be pretty hard to replicate the gallery and art without replicating the building." In fact, he said, "it would be impossible to do it any other way." Asked how it would fit within the proposed new home for the foundation, which was previously described as a 120,000- to-150,000-square-foot museum, Mr. Perks said, "I have no idea how they would do this." In other testimony yesterday, Matthew J. Schwenderman, a partner at Deloitte & Touche, hired by the Barnes to analyze the move financially, projected that the new museum would serve about 237,0000 visitors, not including school groups, in its first year, compared with 57,000 now. JULIA M. KLEIN

title: For Principal, New Boys' School Is a Call to Action
description: DAVID BANKS sounds like a proud father as he chats energetically about his hopes and dreams for the Eagle Academy for Young Men, the new all-boys public school in the Bronx where he is the founding principal.

title: Supply Worries Lift Oil Prices as Bond Yields Keep Falling
description: Crude oil prices jumped to within striking distance of $50 a barrel yesterday, while the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell below 4 percent for the first time since April. The major stock market gauges fell more than 1 percent.

title: He's From the White House, She's From a Clean House
description: Canvass the country's artistic elite and you probably won't find much affection for President Bush and his policies. And yet the current administration may be inadvertently responsible for a small-scale theater boom. Stages in New York and London are awash in plays condemning or lampooning the Bush bunch and its influence on world affairs.

title: Right to Remain Silent(?)
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Dogs on the Go
description: By VERA GIBBONS Dogs going away for the weekend can now travel in style, with everything from a luxe carrier fit for an heiress's puppy to a Burberry trench coat to keep out the cold and rain.

title: 'September Tapes'
description: Directed by Christian Johnston R, 90 minutes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWRENCE, ROBERT L.
description: LAWRENCE--Robert L. On September 23, 2004 at age 84. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Peter and Steven. Devoted grandfather of Vanessa and John. Dear brother of Howard. Private interment at West Point. Contributions in his memory to the Kerry-Edwards Campaign would be appreciated. LAWRENCE--Robert L. The West Point Society of New York mourns with profound sadness the passing of our former president and longtime beloved member of our Board of Governors. Bob's wit and candor combined with limitless energy made him unique among even his West Point brethren. To the end he was devoted completely to his Alma Mater and represented all of the best qualities that exemplified membership in the Long Gray Line. Our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: 'C.S.I.: N.Y.' and CBS Strong at Start of New TV Season
description: In a piece of good news for a network beset this week by a journalism controversy and a federal fine, CBS triumphed Wednesday night in the most anticipated ratings showdown of the new television season -- between its "C.S.I.: N.Y." and NBC's "Law & Order."

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia's agreement with the television producer Mark Burnett to create a prime-time television series misstated a term of the deal. It gives Mr. Burnett the right to purchase 2.5 million shares of stock at $12.59 a share, not $31.5 million in stock-based compensation.

title: Theater Listings
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

description: Gorney Bravin & Lee 534 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through Oct. 9

title: BUICK TO STAY IN WESTCHESTER
description: The Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y., has reached an agreement with the PGA Tour to stage the Buick Classic through 2010. The current contract expires in 2005, and there was talk that the tournament would move to another site. But the tournament's director, Peter Mele, said yesterday that a five-year contract extension had been agreed upon. Clifton Brown

title: FOOTSTAR IS ALLOWED TO SELL DISTRIBUTION CENTER TO ADS
description: Footstar, a bankrupt athletic-shoe retailer, obtained a judge's approval to sell a South Carolina distribution center to ADS Logistics Services for $20.3 million. Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of United States Bankruptcy Court in New York approved the sale after ADS raised its offer from an initial bid of $15.1 million at an auction last week. Footstar is selling retail operations to focus on operating shoe departments in discount and department stores. Footstar, based in West Nyack, N.Y., sold 353 retail stores to Foot Locker in May for $225 million. The company sold a California distribution center to the Thrifty Oil Company for $28 million in July. Footstar's creditors will share the proceeds after the company's plan to exit bankruptcy is approved.

title: An-My Le; 'Clara Park'; 'Sign of the Covenant'

description: NEW YORK

description: Remarks yesterday in Columbus, Ohio:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAVANEY, VICTORIA
description: CAVANEY--Victoria. Property Management Entrepreneur. Victoria Cavaney, 60, who owned and managed real estate in California, Northern Virginia and Hawaii, died Thursday in Inova Fairfax Hospital after suffering a stroke. She was the wife of Red Cavaney, President of the American Petroleum Institute. A native of Southern California, Mrs. Cavaney was a graduate of the University of Southern California where she studied International Relations. She was a resident of the Washington, D.C. area for 31 years. Among the properties she owned and managed was the Victoria Hotel, a family property named for her on Waikiki Beach in Honolulu. In addition to her real estate management, she served as a design consultant for residential properties. She was an active supporter of music and fine arts in the Washington area as well as in Honolulu. In Hawaii, she was a life member of the Hawaiian Music Hall of Fame and supporter of the theater. As a youngster, she was an active surfer in Newport Beach, California and in Hawaii long before it was common to see girls participating in the sport. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her two children, Tom Cavaney of Arlington, and Kristin Cavaney Roper of South Riding, VA, and two grandchildren, Quintin, 6, and Cameron Roper, 4. In lieu of a funeral service, the family will spread her ashes in the Pacific Ocean off Diamond Head Point in Oahu. In lieu of flowers, friends may make contributions to charities of their choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WULWICK, SAMUEL
description: WULWICK--Samuel. Devoted husband to Cynthia and Ronne Wohl Wulwick. Loving father to Joan and Kenneth Kastin, Kenneth and Ronnie Wulwick, and Dr. Robert and Doreen Wulwick. Caring grandfather to David and Abby, Lynn, Billy and Berta, Jennifer, Leslie, Amy, Stefanie and Emily. Adoring greatgrandfather to Daniel and Julia. A generous and compassionate man who made life more enjoyable to those around him. He will be sorely missed. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I., Sunday, 10:30. WULWICK -- Samuel. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Samuel Wulwick. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Jack Sussman, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary WULWICK--Samuel. We are deeply saddened by the loss of Papa Sam and extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Wulwick and Kastin family. Larry, Denise, Joselyn, and Arden Wohl WULWICK -- Samuel. My heartfelt condolences to the family, especially to Lynn, who so dearly loved her "Gramps". Nancy Wohl-Drake

title: No Consolation for Piniella
description: Lou Piniella was miserable after yesterday's 7-3 loss to the Yankees. "It's been difficult, it really has," he said as he looked back on a season in which the Devil Rays are now saddled with a 64-87 record, which means they will win at least one more game than they did a year ago, in Piniella's first year with the team.

title: Lure Fishbar
description: I have not logged nearly enough quality yacht time, to be sure, but as best I can tell, Lure Fishbar manages an uncanny evocation of a luxury vessel on the high seas. With its curved ceiling, glossy teak paneling, white leather banquettes and other nautical fillips, it could be a tycoon's floating playpen, a princess's Pacific cruiser.

title: Corrections
Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOTE, ANN KLEBAN
description: SLOTE--Ann Kleban. September 22, 2004. Wife of the late Bernard Neuman and Arthur D. Slote. Mother of Elizabeth and her husband, Ejlat Feuer, Nancy and her husband, Michael Slote-Danko, and the late James. Sister of Janet and her husband, Josiah Schneider, and grandmother of six. Valued teacher and friend. Memorials to the ACLU would be appreciated.

title: Bush Upbeat as Iraq Burns
description: George W. Bush was a supporter of the war in Vietnam. For a while.

title: Witness Tells of Hearing Talk About Merrill-Enron Side Deal
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 - In the most damaging testimony so far in the first Enron trial, a former credit analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company testified Thursday that in 1999, she heard several executives of her firm discuss a side deal that the government says was at the heart of a criminal conspiracy to bolster the energy company's earnings illegally.

title: I'll Take Cape Cod in June; You Get Cape Town in January
description: TIME shares are sold in intervals, measured in weeks or points, that equate to a partial ownership of a unit in a condominium-style building. If you buy a fixed week, you are guaranteed that unit at the same time every year. If you buy a floating week, you must reserve the time you want. Points-based systems allow for more flexibility: shorter stays or different-size accommodations. Here are some tips on buying time shares and using them for trading:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIERMAN, ARTHUR
description: BIERMAN--Arthur. Of St. Louis on September 22, 2004. Beloved husband of June Rubin Bierman. Dear father of Alexis Hafken of Barrington, RI, Fred (Ivy) Bierman of Sherman Oaks, CA, and Jon Bierman. Dear grandfather of David (Lynnette) Hafken, Robert Hafken, Michael (Tina) Hafken, Sean Kagan, and Samuel Bierman. Dear great grandfather of Emily and Eric Hafken. Dear brother of Rosalie Borus and the late Norman Bierman and Frances Yedidia. Our dear and loving brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and friend. Graveside service Friday, September 24, 11:30am at United Hebrew Temple Cemetery, St. Louis, MO. Mr. Bierman was a past president of the Jewish Center for Aged, St. Louis, MO. Contributions may be sent to the Arthur & June Bierman Hematology Research Fund at Barnes-Jewish Hospital, 600 S. Taylor Ave, Suite 120, St. Louis, MO 63110.

title: Congress Extends Liberty Bonds to '09
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - Congress on Thursday extended the Liberty Bond program, which the federal government enacted in the wake of the 9/11 terror attack to help rebuild Lower Manhattan, according to Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer.

title: To Rally Stocks, China Moves to Ease Foreign Trading Rules
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 23 - China plans to ease restrictions on overseas investors buying yuan-denominated shares, seeking to attract funds after the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indexes slumped to a five-year low earlier this month.

title: California dreaming
Detective Fired in Aftermath of Police Corruption Inquiry
description: A veteran narcotics detective who was about to retire with a lucrative disability pension was fired late last month after the Police Department concluded that he had helped another detective steal $250,000 in drug money in 1995, according to officials and documents. The theft was one of a series of crimes uncovered in a broad corruption investigation that began late last year.

title: INSIDE
description: Saving a Few Belongings in a Shattered Haitian Town Haitians in Gonaves, a town in the north devastated by Tropical Storm Jeanne, struggled through calf-deep, foul-smelling water. Clean water and food were precious commodities, and health workers said they feared the spread of disease. The storm killed more than 1,100 people, Haitian officials said, most of them in Gonaves. PAGE A3

title: Was the Past Better?
description: To the Editor:

title: Office Building Janitors Back a Strike Over Health Plan Cost
description: Unable to resolve a contract dispute over health insurance, thousands of janitors and doormen voted yesterday to authorize a strike beginning next Friday at 1,000 New York City office buildings.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about an interview with The Manchester Union-Leader in which President Bush questioned the authenticity of memos in a CBS News report on his military service misstated the given name of the National Guard commander who was said to have written them. He was Lt. Col. Jerry B. Killian, not Larry.

title: Proposal by Italy and Germany gains despite opposition : EU to study transit sites in Libya for immigrants
Struggling Quantrill Ready for Playoff Role
description: Paul Quantrill has pitched long enough to know an excuse. Too often, he will hear a pitcher rationalize poor results by explaining that he made good pitches, or the hits found a hole, or something like that. After a while, said Quantrill, a 13-year veteran, the numbers tell the truth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WOLOSOFF, MORTY
description: WOLOSOFF -- Morty. Gone another year but never forgotten. All of my love always. Gloria Wolosof

title: Formula One : Desperate days for also-rans
A Wash, a Wax, a Little Show Biz
description: ROGER KOSTER trekked to the rain forest mainly for his children. Chase, 10, loves to see the animals; Taylor, 12, gets a kick out of the colorful birds; and Emma, 4, gasps whenever the thunder rumbles.

title: Man Who Led a Mosque Is Convicted of Visa Fraud
description: A man who ran a makeshift mosque in the basement of his Brooklyn greeting-card store has been convicted of visa fraud in federal court for helping more than 200 illegal immigrants falsely obtain visas as religious workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUM, BERNARD S. (BUDDY)
description: BLUM--Bernard S. (Buddy), 70, of Longmeadow, MA, on September 22. Devoted husband of Sheila. Loving father of Jeremy, Peter, Mitchell, Arnita and Marge. Adoring grandfather. Cherished brother of Ellen Epstein and Barbara Blum. Life Member of SAE & AMS. "Bud's impact on the Aerospace Industry will be a lasting legacy." Bud's musical genius will never be forgotten.
