description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, RUTH FLEIS CHMANN
description: STRAUSS -- Ruth Fleis chmann, of Ardsley, NY, passed away peacefully at home on September 22, 2004. Loving wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother to Joyce, Bob, Stewart and Jeri. Cherished and proud Omi to Beth, Hank, Josh and Doug. Cofounder with Henry of Strauss Paper Company, Port Chester, NY. STRAUSS -- Ruth Fleis chmann. Omi, you will always be in our hearts. We love you. Beth and Hank

title: Powell Holds Brief Meeting With Minister From Libya
description: Correction Appended

title: Congress Slouches Toward Home
description: The Republican-controlled Congress is shambling to the end of one of the lightest workloads in decades without a hint of embarrassment, concentrating on the defense of the flag, tax cuts and marriage while failing at the most demanding obligations of government.

title: Barclays in talks with Absa Group
A Sewer Rash, a River in Eden and a Stream of Tears
description: In "Blissfully Yours," a delicate, ethereal dream of a film from the young Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul, two women and a man voyage into the wild, away from civilization and its discontents. Under a lush canopy of green, the travelers settle onto the bank of a small river for a modest picnic and some languid sex, cooling themselves in the lucent water and plunging into a parallel stream of tears. In this film, which opens today in Manhattan and marks the emergence of one of the more original and promising new voices to hit the international cinema scene in recent years, the primordial world offers only modest respite from everyday troubles.

title: Antarctic Glaciers Quicken Pace to Sea; Warming Is Cited
description: Spurred by warming coastal air and waters, some of Antarctica's glaciers have accelerated their seaward march, fresh observations show, suggesting that ocean levels might be irreversibly on the rise for centuries to come.

title: Top Oil Official Slain as Violence Continues to Churn in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Friday, Sept. 24 - A senior oil official who had survived two assassination attempts was shot and killed Thursday morning in the northern city of Mosul.

title: Oil reserve in U.S. may be tapped
World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Review Of Euro Data
description: A day after Greece admitted that it had massaged its finances around the time that it met the criteria to use the euro, the common currency of the European Union, the European Commission said it was sending a team to Athens to review deficit figures. But a commission spokesman said Greece's membership in the euro area was not in question. "The decision to admit Greece was based on the best information available at the time," the spokesman said. "That decision won't change." Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Singer Matches Van Morrison to Irving Berlin
description: Phillip Officer is a fount of optimism. Even when storm clouds dump buckets on this singer's head, he peers into the distance to discern a rainbow. What keeps him from being insistently cloying is his musicality and connoisseurship of songs from many decades, which he weaves into unconventional medleys.

title: Campaign Briefing: THE DEMOCRATS; WOOING WOMEN
description: Standing with a group of women that included the widow of a victim of the World Trade Center attack, Senator John Edwards declared that he and John Kerry would root out terrorists and "tell the truth" about the safety of the country and the war in Iraq. The Kerry campaign has sought to reach out to women as polls show support among them slipping toward President Bush. Mr. Edwards's guests at a forum in Davenport, Iowa, for women and families included the widow, Kristen Breitweiser, who was one of several who advocated creation of the independent 9/11 commission. She has endorsed Mr. Kerry. Mr. Edwards spoke as voters in Iowa began casting absentee ballots, the first state to do so. Randal C. Archibold

title: Five Lives Destined to Converge
description: Directed by Eric Schaeffer PG, 134 minutes

title: Dominican Retires Rich
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 23 - Former president Hiplito Meja left office a millionaire even as most of his countrymen saw deepening poverty. While earning a presidential salary equivalent to $2,400 a month, Mr. Meja, a former agronomist, raised his assets to 46.5 million pesos, or $1.26 million at the current exchange rate, from 19.7 million pesos in 2000, a declaration of wealth made public on Thursday said. Defeated for re-election in May, he left office last month. Many in his Caribbean nation of nine million fell into poverty or lost jobs after a major bank collapsed in 2003.

title: No Decision on the Expos, but a Sense of Urgency
description: Major League Baseball's relocation committee met with its executive council and Commissioner Bud Selig yesterday in Milwaukee about the future of the Montreal Expos. But everybody went home without a decision.

title: John Gotti Would Have Hated the Joint
description: John Gotti Would Have Hated the Joint

title: Iraq Can Wait for Democracy
description: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the Iraqi Shiite leader, is concerned that Shiites may not be adequately represented in a future government, fueling worries that the national election scheduled for January may not happen. And even if the election does proceed as planned, many Sunni clerics in the turbulent central region of the country are urging their followers to boycott it.

title: Free Federal Money? Depends on Who's Offering
description: ALBANY, Sept. 23 - New York's city, state and federal officials, it seems, do not always pull in the same direction, even when it comes to something as basic as preserving a program that offers counseling to firefighters, police officers and their families coping with the mental aftershocks of Sept. 11.

title: Taxes decline for top U.S. companies even as profits rise, study finds
ARTS GUIDE
The Candidates, Seen From the Classroom
description: CHICAGO - In an unofficial but very formal poll taken in my freshman writing class the other day, George Bush beat John Kerry by a vote of 13 to 2 (14 to 2, if you count me). My students were not voting on the candidates' ideas. They were voting on the skill (or lack of skill) displayed in the presentation of those ideas.

title: Bush and Allawi Say Iraqi Voting Won't Be Put Off
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - President Bush and Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq vowed in the White House Rose Garden on Thursday that Iraq would hold free elections as scheduled in January, even though Mr. Bush acknowledged the "persistent violence" in some parts of the country and Dr. Allawi conceded that the elections "may not be perfect."

title: EU boom produces Brussels bloom
Summoning History as a Weapon Against the Iraq War
description: WAR AND THE AMERICAN PRESIDENCY By Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. 160 pages. Norton. $23.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EMERSON, GLORIA
description: EMERSON--Gloria. In her own words "an award winning journalist and author who wrote about the war in Vietnam." Friends will remember her September 29, from 6:00 to 8 P.M. in the Religious Society of Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, Stuyvesant Square, with respect and affection but without flowers.

Cabby's a Politician, Taking Voters for a Ride. Honestly.
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 18 - The television screen shows a taxi trying to ease its way through Belgrade's gridlocked streets at midmorning. Inside, the driver and his passenger strike up a conversation that, inevitably, drifts into politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 16 about the risks of buying a small business misstated the surname of a professor who teaches a course at Iowa State University on small-business ownership. He is Howard VanAuken, not Vauken.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Liquor Maker's Profit Rises
description: The French liquor maker Pernod Ricard said its first-half profit rose 4.7 percent on growing Asian demand for Chivas Regal Scotch whiskey and Martell Cognac. Net income climbed to 169 million euros ($207.3 million), from 161.5 million euros a year earlier. Sales rose 5 percent, to 1.57 billion euros. Chivas shipments rose 11 percent and Martell shipments climbed 8 percent. Operating profit slipped 0.6 percent, to 282 million euros. The company raised its forecast for annual growth in its operating profit to 8 percent to 10 percent from 7 percent, the chairman, Patrick Ricard, above, told analysts at Pernod's headquarters in Paris.

title: EasyJet shares tumble on warning of fare wars
Troubled Unit of Halliburton May Go on Block
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 - When Halliburton was awarded contracts worth more than $12 billion for work in Iraq, critics said that the company was using its political connections to reap big profits. But now, in a sign that those contracts are not providing the boon executives had expected from a subsidiary weighed down by other problems, Halliburton said Thursday that it was considering a sale of the business.

title: Kidnappers and Captors United in a Common Cause
description: Directed by Bruce La Bruce Not rated, 90 minutes

title: Outlook is bleaker for some companies : Japanese carmakers adding to gains in Europe
Let Chips Fall, Rell Says, Expressing Her Disgust
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 23 - Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Thursday made her most forceful comments yet about the scandal that defined the administration she served in as lieutenant governor, expressing disgust and seeking political distance from the alleged criminal enterprise federal prosecutors say was run by the previous administration.

title: Ex-Executives of Computer Associates Plead Not Guilty
description: Two former top executives of Computer Associates International pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in Brooklyn to charges of securities fraud and obstruction of justice, one day after they were indicted.

title: As Bull Market Nears a Birthday, Few Seem Ready to Celebrate
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Montenegrin Members Quit Serbia-Montenegro Panel
description: Montenegro sought to distance itself from Serbia's lack of cooperation with the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague by resigning from an intergovernmental committee formed to improve relations with the court. Pedrag Boskovic, Montenegro's deputy interior minister, said the representatives of Montenegro on the national committee had quit because Serbia had done nothing to meet the tribunal's demands, the Belgrade-based B92 news agency reported. Serbia has been widely criticized for not handing over the former commander of the Bosnia Serb Army, Gen. Ratko Mladic, and four other Serbian generals, all of whom the court says are hiding in Serbia. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, LILLIAN
description: FEINBERG -- Lillian. The Board of Trustees and staff of Medical Development for Israel, Inc., the support organization for Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel, are deeply saddened by the loss of Mrs. Lillian Feinberg. Together with her husband Abraham, they established the Dr. E. Richard Feinberg Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry in memory of their son at Schneider Children's Medical Center of Israel. Their overwhelming generosity will benefit the children of Israel for generations to come. Our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Feinberg's daughter, Dr. Judith Schneider, and her husband, Mr. Norbert Weissberg, and their entire family. Medical Development for Israel, Inc. H. Irwin Levy, Chairman Ambassador Uri Bar-Ner Co-Chairman Arlette Cohen Executive Director

title: Police Warn of Arrests at a Mass Bike Ride
description: The police warned a group of 1,000 cyclists expected to congregate tonight at Union Square for a monthly ride that they faced mass arrests like those that occurred last month if they did not apply for a permit and obey traffic laws.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Central Bank Raises Inflation Target
description: Brazil's central bank raised its inflation target for next year to 5.1 percent from 4.5 percent, a move that should remove some pressure on the bank to increase interest rates in the coming months to curb rising consumer prices. The revision was disclosed in the minutes from the bank's monetary policy meeting last week, when it raised its benchmark lending rate by a quarter percentage point to 16.25 percent, the first rate increase in 19 months. The bank previously warned that more rate increases were on the horizon. But in the minutes released yesterday the bank said it hoped that the decision to pursue a higher inflation target in 2005 would give it the flexibility to raise interest rates only gradually. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: EU boom produces Brussels bloom
In the Arena : In the long run, fear joins the race
National Briefing
description: WEST

title: The Met's 'Madama Butterfly,' Revived but Not Reimagined
description: When Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" had its American premiere in Washington in 1906, the Japanese ambassador was in the audience, and you just have to wonder what he made of it all. This popular tear-jerker, which returned to the Met on Wednesday night, caricatures Japanese life and invents its own faux-Japanese music. Did he find anything onstage that rang true?

title: Just This Side of the Treacherous Border, Here Lies Juan Doe
description: HOLTVILLE, Calif., Sept. 17 - John Doe got lucky. His funeral was canceled.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Plan To Tax Litter
description: To help pay for an annual $84 million street-sweeping bill in Irish cities, the government may tax products that cause the biggest litter problem, like ATM receipts and fast food, the environment minister, Martin Cullen, said. A 10 percent levy on packs of chewing gum, the second most common piece of litter after cigarette butts, could raise more than $5 million. In 2002, Ireland imposed an 18-cent tax on plastic bags, which cut their use by 90 percent and went a long way in removing them from city streets and tree branches. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOEN, DAVID
description: SCHOEN--David. 40 years old. Parents Kenneth and Concetta, sister Carrie, partner Albert Williams. Died September 23rd. Memorial service Sunday, September 26th, Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring St, NYC at 10:30AM.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a settlement between the California Board of Accountancy and Ernst & Young in a case involving PeopleSoft, a company that the firm audited while the two had another business relationship, misstated the action taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the same matter. It filed an administrative proceeding against Ernst, and an administrative law judge imposed penalties. The settlement did not follow indications that the S.E.C. planned to file a lawsuit.

title: Charter Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: When Motherhood Becomes a Creepy Quest for the Truth
description: The actress Julianne Moore has one face as transparent as water, the other as opaque as a mystery. With her milky complexion and lapidary features, Ms. Moore can seem alarmingly fragile, as breakable and translucent as fine French porcelain. It's a face that suggests vulnerability, femininity and an almost otherworldly ethereality.

title: On the Road With Young Che
description: In the spring of 1952, two young men set out by motorcycle on an ambitious, footloose journey that they hoped would carry them from Buenos Aires up the spine of Chile, across the Andes and into the Peruvian Amazon. (They made it, a little behind schedule, though the unfortunate motorcycle did not.) Their road trip, however inspired and audacious it might have been, could have faded into personal memory and family lore, even though both travelers produced written accounts of their adventures. The older, a 29-year-old biochemist named Alberto Granado, is still alive and appears at the very end of "The Motorcycle Diaries," Walter Salles's stirring and warm-hearted reconstruction of that long-ago voyage. Granado's companion was a 23-year-old medical student named Ernesto Guevara de la Serna, whose subsequent career as a political idol, revolutionary martyr and T-shirt icon -- Che! -- reflects a charismatic, mysterious glow onto his early life.

Campaign Briefing: THE INDEPENDENTS; NO TO NADER IN OREGON
description: The Oregon Supreme Court ruled that Ralph Nader should be kept off the state's presidential ballot, the latest move in a long legal battle between Nader supporters and Secretary of State Bill Bradbury, a Democrat. Mr. Bradbury disqualified thousands of Nader signatures on a nominating petition. A lower court found that Mr. Bradbury overstepped his authority in enforcing election law, but the State Supreme Court reversed that decision, unanimously finding that his actions were necessary to prevent fraud. Supporters of Mr. Nader, who received 5 percent of the vote in Oregon in 2000, said he would appeal to the United States Supreme Court. Eli Sanders

title: Panel Warning of Shortage of U.S. Troops
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - A Pentagon-appointed panel of outside experts has concluded in a new study that the American military does not have sufficient forces to sustain current and anticipated stability operations, like the festering conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan and other missions that might arise.

title: CAMPBELL NAMES CHAIRMAN AND RAISES ITS DIVIDEND
description: The Campbell Soup Company named Harvey Golub, a former chief executive of the American Express Company, as chairman and raised its quarterly dividend 7.9 percent to reflect improving sales and profit. Mr. Golub, 65, will succeed George Sherman, who is retiring Nov. 18, Campbell said. Mr. Golub has been a director since 1996. The dividend, which was raised to 17 cents a share from 15.75 cents, is payable Nov. 1 to shareholders of record Oct. 11. Mr. Sherman, 63, is retiring from the board to focus on private equity.

title: California's Bold Step on Drug Addiction
description: Intravenous-drug users who spread disease by sharing dirty needles and engaging in unprotected sex are responsible for more than a third of all the AIDS cases in the United States and more than half of the new cases of hepatitis C. Addicts will continue to drive these epidemics until the country takes a more enlightened approach to drug treatment. That means discarding the laws that criminalize needle possession because such laws encourage addicts to share needles. It also means developing large-scale treatment programs that admit addicts right away instead making them wait months or years. A blueprint for such a program has been put forward in California, which has embarked on the most ambitious drug treatment effort yet seen in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNES, EDWARD LARRABEE
description: BARNES--Edward Larrabee. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of our Trustee Edward Larrabee Barnes. Ed was of a generation of architects who were steeped in modernism at Harvard and inspired by Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer. He is often first identified with the museums he designed-The Walker Art Center, the Sarah Scaife Gallery at Carnegie Mellon, the Dallas Museum of Art, and the Armand Hammer chief among them. He created beautiful, light-infused spaces in which architecture never upstages art, and through which visitors can flow easily. He also was one of the first modernist to bring a sensitivity to the local and the regional in his work, utilizing indigenous stone or wood to articulate his spare vocabulary. This tenet is perhaps most evident in his Haystack Mountain School of Arts and Crafts on Deer Isle, Maine. This country is filled with lasting monuments to Ed's genius, from huge projects like the IBM headquarters in New York, to private commissions done on a domestic scale. We especially extend our sympathies to his wife, Mary, who was our colleague in MoMA's Department of Architecture and Design in the 1940s, as well as to his son, his grandaughters, and the entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terence Riley, The Philip Johnson Chief Curator of Architecture and Design The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y. BARNES--Edward Larrabee. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of this esteemed architect whose passing will be deeply mourned.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Wall Township: Cleaners Site Added To Superfund List
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that the site of the former White Swan Cleaners and Sun Cleaners at Route 35 and Atlantic Avenue is now on the Superfund National Priorities List, making it eligible for federal Superfund dollars. Federal and state investigators found the area is polluted with tetrachloroethylene, a potentially toxic chemical used in dry cleaning, which is at risk of polluting three municipal wells. The E.P.A. also proposed adding the Crown Vantage landfill in Alexandria Township to the list, because of its proximity to the Delaware River. Much of the waste at Crown Vantage came from paper mills, and includes drums of varnish and ink and fly ash from coal burning. The industrial dump closed in 1970. Jason George (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: China Helps With Oil Shipping
description: China agreed to pay in advance for shipments next month of crude oil from Yukos, Russia's largest oil exporter, easing concern about supply disruptions. Yukos said on Monday that it would reduce rail shipments to China as a result of a cash drain caused by the Russian government's demands for $7.5 billion in back taxes. Gennadi Fadeyev, the chief executive of Russian Railways, said China had proposed an advance payment for a shipment of 367,000 barrels of oil that would be part of Yukos's shipments to the country next month.

title: Jews in the New Wilderness

What do such things have to do with celebrations of the 350th anniversary of the arrival of Jews in America? And how does a handsome exhibition drawing on four New York Public Library collections tie these items together?

title: One of the Lessons of College Is Being a Proper Daughter

At that point, the title character, a blank slate named Samantha Mackenzie (Katie Holmes), has moved from the White House to college, where she has encountered the typical freshman dissonance, or at least its PG-rated manifestation, including a sassy roommate and the dreamboat down the hall. So far, so formulaic, even despite the occasional ripple, like the cute guy in the Amnesty International T-shirt spiritedly delivering a speech against Sam's dad (Michael Keaton).

title: In Wilmington, N.C.
description: IN autumn, when the withering tropical heat has faded and the beach crowds have disappeared inland, the storybook oak-lined streets of Wilmington are cool and quiet. Though at night the bars may teem with students from the local campus of the University of North Carolina, the pace is relaxed in the shops and restaurants. Out along the Atlantic, there is plenty of sand between the beach towels even though the waters, warmed by the Gulf Stream, are still inviting. Over 250 years ago, a band of fortune seekers and opportunists braved the un-air-conditioned heat -- as well as the mosquitoes, alligators and bears along the banks of the Cape Fear River -- to create Wilmington, which in time became the northernmost hub of the Southern rice culture. Now it makes its living as a resort, a busy port and an aspiring movie capital. In 1983, Frank Capra Jr. found Wilmington a good place to shoot his film "Firestarter," and now his Wilmington studio, EUE/Screen Gems, says it is the largest film production facility east of California. Downtown this fall, you might find the cast of the WB network's "One Tree Hill" among the contented tourists in search of antiques, a night at the theater or a bowl of ground white hominy -- better known in these parts as grits. CHRIS DIXON

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Referendum On Same-Sex Marriage Can Proceed
description: The State Supreme Court unanimously refused to strike from the November general election ballot a referendum to ban same-sex marriages. The American Civil Liberties Union had challenged the initiative as unconstitutionally vague and discriminatory. Marian P. Opala, the vice chief justice, wrote that the proposal was "pure political process in progress" and that the court had no legal basis for action. Similar prohibitions against gay marriage are expected to appear on the ballots of at least 10 states; Louisiana voters approved a ban on same-sex marriage and civil unions this month. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: 1929:Snowden Sows Distrust : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Let's Get Real
description: Never mind the inevitable claims that John Kerry is soft on terrorism. What he must address is the question of how his policy in Iraq would differ from President Bush's. And his answer should be that unlike Mr. Bush, whose decisions have been dictated at every stage by grandiose visions and wishful thinking, he will get real -- focusing on what is really possible in Iraq, and what needs to be done to protect American security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOENE, BURKHARD
description: HOENE--Burkhard. 46, beloved son, brother, and adored friend of many, died peacefully at home on September 21, 2004 of pancreatic cancer. Born on December 10, 1957, he was raised in New Hampshire. In 1981, he graduated from UVM and began his career in fashion at Brooks Brothers. He was founder and designer of the Espionage clothing label and also helped establish the denim division of Harley Davidson. He founded Digital Fashion in 1993 to deliver expertise in pioneering digital media technologies in fashion. In 1995, he founded Fashion Planet Inc., as a joint venture between Digital Fashion and Digital Planet. His extraordinary photographic work that enriches humanity's visual journey, together with his beautiful and inspiring poetry, are his greatest achievements. He will be missed by all who love him. He is survived by his mother Ursula R. Hoene, siblings Eberhard, Barbara, Christina, Max, and their families. Donations may be made in memory of Burkhard Hoene, Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, research of Dr. G. Abu-Alfa, PO Box 27106, NY, NY 10087. Services at the Riverside Church, September 29, at 3:00 PM. HOENE--Burkhard. With profound sorrow, we mourn our dear friend Burke. We will always be grateful for the countless ways in which he made our lives better. Our thoughts are with his family and his friends. His passion for life and his great friendship will always be remembered by us. We bid him farewell and send him our love and affection to surround him on his great journey forward. We will always miss him. Brian, Lavinia and Ophelia HOENE -- Burkhard. Con dolences to the family of Burkhard Hoene. Burk, what a wonderful selfless giving friend you were. Your constant optimism and positive vibes will stay with us. Ariel, Stanley, Angela and Peter HOENE--Burkhard. We extend our deepest sympathy to Burkhard's family and friends. His kind spirit touched all our lives and we will miss him. Eleanor, Eleanora, Frank, Georgia, Kellie, Mustafa, Ruth

"Adaptive Behavior," the New Museum's first exhibition at this site, is a busy, intermittently interesting and often irritating presentation of mostly video works by 11 emerging artists from nine countries.

title: Kerouac's Trail Before He Hit the Road

Beside the whirring traffic, the volunteer tour guide, Paul Marion, stands on the corner, holding a copy of Jack Kerouac's novel "Dr. Sax." In a soft voice, Mr. Marion reads: "The other night I had a dream that I was sitting on the sidewalk on Moody Street, Pawtucketville, Lowell, Mass., with a pencil and paper in my hand saying to myself 'Describe the wrinkly tar of this sidewalk.' "

What you see is the huge, long, rectangular room, a converted factory, that is the heart of Mass MoCA, the rambling contemporary-art museum in North Adams, Mass.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: WebMD Names New Chief
description: The WebMD Corporation, which sells referral and claims-processing software to doctors, said yesterday that it had promoted Kevin Cameron to chief executive and that it might spin off or sell shares in its Internet content business, WebMD Health. Roger C. Holstein, who was chief executive for 17 months, will again run the unit, which provides medical information to consumers and doctors through Web sites. Mr. Cameron most recently was a special adviser to the chairman. The changes take effect Oct. 1, WebMD, which is based in Elmwood Park, N.J., said.

title: Kerry Accuses President of Misleading U.S. on Iraq
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 23 - Stepping up his efforts to put President Bush on the defensive over Iraq, Senator John Kerry said on Thursday that conditions there were so bad there that the elections planned for January were in jeopardy and that the president's assertions that things were improving did not match reality.

title: Shopping | Dogs On the Go
description: FALL demands new travel accessories, and not just for you. Luckily, dogs going away for the weekend can now travel in style, with everything from a luxe carrier fit for an heiress's puppy to a Burberry trench coat to keep out the cold and rain. No wonder Americans now spend more than $34 billion on their pets each year. VERA GIBBONS

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Uncertainty Over Photo Stamps
description: Stamps.com, which sells postage stamps over the Internet, said yesterday that a trial of a custom photo service with the United States Postal Service may be suspended. The photo service lets customers design stamps featuring pictures of babies, cars, pets and other images. The test, which had been expected to run through Sept. 30, will end on that date, and the service may be suspended, continued or followed with another trial, Stamps.com, based in Santa Monica, Calif., said.

title: German state banks near deal
De La Hoya's a Champ to Paying Viewers
description: Even in losing by a knockout Saturday night to Bernard Hopkins, Oscar De La Hoya continued to proved his potency in pay-per-view.

title: Turkey Offers Reassurance on Adultery Issue in Bid to Join Europe
description: PARIS, Sept. 23 - Turkey's marathon campaign to join the European Union appeared to gain momentum on Thursday after Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan assured the union's worried bureaucrats in Brussels that his governing Islamic party was not straying from Turkey's longstanding secular ideals.

title: California Backs Plan for Big Cut in Car Emissions
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 A California regulators unanimously approved a plan today to sharply reduce global-warming emissions from cars and trucks over the next 11 years, the first such regulation in the nation and one that would substantially affect vehicles sold in the state.

title: Scofield Stays Out in Front With His Trio
description: For 25 years the guitarist John Scofield has cooked enough comfortable permutations of jazz-funk, jazz-rock and the long, spacious grooves of jam-band music to reheat for the rest of his career. So his decision to scale back to a working trio with the bassist Steve Swallow and the drummer Bill Stewart seemed honest and challenging as well as a return to some older ground. (He made several trio albums with Mr. Swallow in the early 1980's.)

title: The Face of Iraqi Democracy
description: Iraq's appointed leader, Ayad Allawi, put on an impressive performance yesterday in Washington. Addressing Congress and then holding a joint news conference with President Bush, he thanked America in the name of the Iraqi people for overthrowing Saddam Hussein. Challenging the news reports that Americans get daily, Mr. Allawi claimed that security is improving, economic reconstruction is progressing and democratic institutions are taking root. It was everything the Bush re-election campaign could have asked for. Unfortunately, most of it was wrong.

title: Crab Grass, Cookouts, Sex Addicts and Neuters
description: In "A Dirty Shame," which opens today nationwide, John Waters imagines a raucous battle between unruly, polymorphously perverse, life-affirming sex addicts and the uptight neuters who hate sexuality in all its many forms. This is hardly new ground for Mr. Waters, who has been fighting for his right to be naughty since much of the current moviegoing public was in diapers (as a matter of infant hygiene, that is, rather than of erotic taste).

title: Iraqis Battle Over Control of Panel to Try Hussein
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 23 - A bitter political struggle has erupted over control of the special Iraqi tribunal set up to try Saddam Hussein and his associates, with Prime Minister Ayad Allawi and his rivals maneuvering for influence over the appointment of judges, the timing of trials, the scope of charges and even who will stand trial and who will escape the death penalty by cutting deals with prosecutors.

title: Martha Stewart Signs 5-Year Contract
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has entered a five-year employment contract with its founder, Martha Stewart, that will pay a base annual salary of $900,000 and make her eligible to receive a bonus of as much as $1.35 million a year.

title: Cannoli? He Used to Eat Mobsters for Lunch
description: THOSE purplish saddlebags under Nelson A. Boxer's bloodshot eyes are not, repeat not, a consequence of the Mafia-busting prosecutor-turned-corporate-lawyer's having partied too heartily at the 77th annual Feast of San Gennaro in Little Italy over the weekend. Mr. Boxer, of late a partner specializing in white-collar criminal defense and commercial litigation at the upscale Dechert law firm, comes by his saggy eyelids courtesy of an insomniac toddler. He and his wife have two young sons, and one of them kept him awake all weekend, an unwelcome coda to a succession of late weeknights at the firm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Says Wall Street Losses Hurt City
description: Disappointing profits reported by Wall Street firms could spell trouble for the city's budget, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. "A third of our tax revenues by some estimates, directly or indirectly, come from Wall Street," Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference. The Securities Industry Association reported last week that profits by financial firms fell 61 percent, to $3 billion, for the quarter that ended in June. The association said that while it expected lower profits after an exceptionally strong first quarter, the decline "exceeded expectations." The Bloomberg administration is forecasting a $3.8 billion budget deficit in the fiscal year that begins next July. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Islamic Scholar From Virginia Is Charged in Holy War Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - An Islamic scholar from Virginia was indicted Thursday by a federal grand jury on charges that in the days after the Sept. 11 attacks he urged a group of Muslim-American men to join a holy war against the United States by traveling to Afghanistan.

title: Mud on the Trail: Enough Is Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JORDAN, CHRISTOPHER F.
description: JORDAN--Christopher F., 68 years. Melbourne, Australia. Died September 22, 2004. Beloved husband of Jane Bennett. Father of Christopher IV, Peter, Luke, Simon. Grandfather of Annabel, Campbell, Christopher V and Emma. Brother of Peggy Anne and Patricia. Also survived by many cousins including Rev. Eugene and Mary Ellen McGovern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEUER, WALTER (WALLY)
description: SCHEUER--Walter (Wally). Our dear friend, Board Member and guardian angel. We celebrate your life. Your film "Small Wonders" touched and inspired so many lives. Your love of music and your generosity left footprints that will never wash away. Our hearts go out to Marge and to your family. We mourn your loss. Opus 118 Harlem School of Music

title: Accounts
description: Pfizer, New York, and Aventis, Strasbourg, France, to the Grey Healthcare Group, New York, to handle Exubera, a type of insulin being developed that could be inhaled. Spending has not been determined.

title: Surfing the Northwest, Where the Winds Are
description: THE first thing you notice driving east into Hood River, Ore., is the neon-colored sails skimming across the mile-wide Columbia River, looking like fluttering butterfly wings as they catch the afternoon sun. It takes a moment to realize there are people with those sails, standing on boards propelled by the wind. And then it's clear why Hood River is the epicenter of windsurfing in North America: wind, water and sun.

title: Barbarians in Squalor, Afraid of Becoming Girlie Men
description: Jokes about maggots, armpits, soiled underwear and Vagisil infest "Complete Savages," a nauseating sitcom whose executive producers include Mel Gibson, the man who brought us "The Passion of the Christ," a religious film that went to DVD last month.

title: Saturday's Top Games
description: !Iowa (2-1) at No. 18 Michigan (2-1)3:30 p.m., ABC (Regional)Iowa fell out of the top 25 after being routed, 44-7, by Arizona Stateand hopes to avoid losing two in a row. After falling to Notre Dame,Michigan held on for a 24-21 victory over San Diego State. Butquarterback Chad Henne threw three interceptions in that game. Anearly conference loss would be a lot for either team to bounce backfrom. Despite being favored at home, Michigan looks vulnerable andhas struggled with Iowa in the past.

title: Keeping chemicals safe : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Florida to Step Up Spending to Counter Images of Storm-Battered Beaches
description: SEPTEMBER is usually a slow month for tourism in Florida. But this year, after three deadly hurricanes have hammered the state, and with another threatening, tourists are really scarce.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about concern expressed by Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Husseini al-Sistani, Iraq's most powerful Shiite leader, that elections planned for January could be postponed, gave an incorrect name in some copies for the United Nations special representative, a Pakistani who is responsible for helping to organize the elections. He is Ashfar Jehangir Qazi, not Qazi Jenhangir. (Go to Article)

description: LISS--Beatrice. Of NYC, formerly of Aventura, FL and Brooklyn, NY. Securities Broker for State of Israel Bonds and worked very closely with Mr. Netanyahu. Beloved wife of Martin Liss. Devoted mother of Stephen Liss and Deborah Alliger. Cherished grandmother of Jordan, Jason, John and Diana. Also survived by five great-grandchildren. Sister of Howard Rosenthal and Rae Kass. Graveside services will be held on Sunday, 11AM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Directors, Gutterman's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENSTOCK, ROBERT
description: ROSENSTOCK--Robert. International lawyer, legal advisor to the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, member of the International Law Commission, died of natural causes on September 20. Mr. Rosenstock is survived by his wife of 34 years, Gerda Michorl Rosenstock, daughter Elizabeth Rosenstock-Siller, son-in-law Michael Siller, grandson Phillip Siller and sons Thomas and Nicholas. The memorial will be private. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be sent to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NYC 10032.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,037 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Lights! Camera! Sting! Popcorn and Pirandello Are Taking on the Mob
description: Movies are sometimes made for strange reasons, and sometimes for no good reason at all. "The Last Shot," an R-rated comedy from Disney which opens today nationwide, is about the first kind of movie, but unfortunately it belongs to the second type. Adapted from a nonfiction magazine article, it tells the improbable "making of" story of a film that was never actually made, but that was part of an F.B.I. sting operation aimed at the mob in Providence, R.I.

title: L.I. Killer Loses Motion on Prosecutor in Retrial Bid
description: A judge rejected a request yesterday by a man convicted of murdering his parents to remove the Suffolk County district attorney from a review of his case.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Food Service For Sale
description: The Dutch food company Royal Ahold said it planned to sell its Benelux food service, Deli XL, which last year recorded 837 million euros ($1.02 billion) in consolidated sales. Deli XL, which caters to institutions like company cafeterias, has reported declining results in recent years. Royal Ahold is in the process of selling selected assets as part of an effort to recover from a $1.2 billion accounting scandal last year, most of it centered at its U.S. Foodservice unit in Columbia, Md. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Squeezing the Poor On Housing Aid
description: To the Editor:

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Insider Challenges Drug Industry on Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - A dissident executive from Pfizer, the world's largest drug maker, denounced the pharmaceutical industry on Thursday for resisting legislation that would allow imports of low-cost prescription drugs from Canada and other countries.

title: Merkley Is Selected For Arby's Assignment
description: Arby's, the fast-food restaurants owned by the Triarc Companies, yesterday named Merkley & Partners in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative part of its national branding assignment. Spending was estimated at $15 million.

title: The Politics Of Funny, Or Vice Versa
description: Correction Appended

title: ALLIANT TECHSYSTEMS RAISES SALES AND PROFIT FORECASTS
description: Alliant Techsystems Inc., a maker of rocket motors and small-caliber ammunition for the military, raised its sales and profit forecasts for fiscal 2005 after buying the PSI Group, a satellite-parts maker. Profit for the year ending in March is now forecast at $3.90 to $4 a share, up from a forecast of $3.85 to $3.95 a share. Alliant, based in Edina, Minn., raised its sales forecast to $2.75 billion from $2.7 billion. The $165 million purchase of PSI, announced in July and completed yesterday, strengthens Alliant's offering of space-related products. PSI makes products for commercial and military satellites. The company has annual sales of about $100 million.

title: Laughing Instead of Screaming
description: The Statue of Liberty is bombed, but that is the least of the horrors in Larry Beinhart's scathing black comedy "The Librarian," about a plan to steal the next presidential election; the conspiracy includes hired killers working for the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEST, ERIC FOWLER
description: WEST--Eric Fowler, 80, of Lyme, CT and Holderness, NH died September 21, 2004, at home after a long illness. He graduated from Harvard with the class of 1946 after serving in WWII as a fighter pilot with the Army Air Force. Mr. West was associated with Alcan, an international aluminum company, from 1947 to 1985. He held senior executive positions in North America, Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, and served on the Alcan Board of Directors. Other boards included Fiduciary Trust International, the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard, and the National Parks and Recreation Association. A keen sportsman, he enjoyed bird hunting and fly fishing, above all salmon fishing on Canadian rivers. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Eugenia Lovett West, and by four children George S., Eric F. Jr., Tina, Victoria, and four grandchildren. Contributions may be made to Speare Memorial Hospital, 16 Hospital Rd, Plymouth, NH 03264 and to Pemi Baker Home Health and Hospice, 258 Highland St, Plymouth, NH 03264.

description: Horticultural Personals Department: Elegant Victorian conservatory seeks smart, youthful greenhouse. Object? Propagation.

title: Darwin Gets a Cheerleader: A Stripper on the School Board
description: For all those New Yorkers who have long dreamed of attending a tedious, malfunctioning school board meeting somewhere out in the heartland, relief has come at last. As the opening attraction in its new season, Playwrights Horizons has staged a tedious, malfunctioning play largely set at just such gatherings. Don't all jump at once, folks.

title: Stephen Baker, Ad Executive, Dies at 83
description: Stephen Baker, who created the "Let your fingers do the walking" ad campaign for the Yellow Pages and advised readers on how to live with a neurotic dog, died in Manhattan on Sept. 13. He was 83.

title: Rob Lowe Bets on His Wild Side
description: Some ideas sound so deliciously awful (I know: let's do "E.R.: Las Vegas") that it is boorish to mock them. Casting Rob Lowe as an idealistic doctor who hangs his shingle in a casino comes very close. But "Dr. Vegas," which starts tonight on CBS, turns out to be kind of fun -- kino cards and colonoscopies do mix.

title: Dreams for the Women, Indians for the Men
description: The Limn Dance Company looked both to the past and to the present on Tuesday night in one of two programs it will present in its two-week season at the Joyce Theater. But it was at the close, in a dance about midway between the two poles, that the evening came most alive.

title: African Union to Send Troops in Bid to Curb Sudan Violence
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23 - Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, said Thursday that the African Union, of which he is the chairman, had decided to send thousands of troops and monitors to help curb the violence in the Darfur region of Sudan. The fighting there has killed 50,000 villagers and displaced 1.4 million others.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about Microsoft's security enhancements to the Windows XP operating system, misstated the Web address for free downloads of Ad-Aware, a program offering protection against spyware. It is www.lavasoftusa.com.

title: PICTURE WINDOW : California dreaming
Overseer Says Fannie Mae May Be Due for Shake-Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - After harshly criticizing Fannie Mae for improper accounting practices in a 211-page report, federal regulators said on Thursday that they had raised the possibility of a management shake-up at the mortgage giant to clean up its culture and finances.

title: Democrats Focus on G.O.P.-Backed Sales Tax
description: Democrats are trying to drum up a campaign issue that they have already deployed with some success in select races and believe could resonate more widely: the prospect of a Republican-backed national sales tax.

title: 1904:Chief Joseph Dies : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
description: The unemployment rate in Brazil rose in August for the first time in four months, edging up to 11.4 percent from 11.2 percent in July. In releasing the data, the government's statistics agency stressed that the increase was not statistically significant, suggesting that the jobless rate may have risen because more people actively sought work last month now that the economy, South America's largest, is heating up. The number of unemployed people searching for jobs in the six metropolitan areas surveyed rose to 2.5 million in August, from 2.4 million the previous month. The number of employed people also increased, to 19.2 million from 19.1 million. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COMSTOCK, CHARLOTTE TOPPIN
description: COMSTOCK--Charlotte Toppin, of Palm City, Florida died on September 21, 2004 at the age of 86. She formerly resided in Stuart, FL and Essex, CT and was the wife of the late Peter Harwood Comstock. She is survived by four daughters, Marcia Ann Littel, Barbara Comstock Ronshagen, Constance C. Abrams, and Patricia Comstock Wilson. She is also survived by eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren and her sisters Janet Prann and Anne Comstock. Her brother, Robert M. Toppin, predeceased her. An avid golfer and sailor, she was a member of the Hobe Sound Golf Club. A service will be held in Essex at the end of October. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Martin County American Red Cross for the Local Disaster Relief Fund, 2750 South Kanner Highway, Stuart, FL 34994 or to a charity of your choice.

description: In an effort to protect players from using nutritional supplements that violate the National Football League's drug policy, the league and its players association have begun a program to certify manufacturers whose supplements include no banned ingredients.

title: Directors Agree on Contract With Hollywood Producers
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 - Negotiators for Hollywood producers agreed to increase health care payments for directors but did not raise payments for DVD sales and rentals in a new three-year contract reached Thursday.

description: PALL--David B., Ph.D. The trustees, faculty and staff of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory are deeply saddened at the passing of Dr. David Pall. Dr. Pall was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Laboratory from 1987 through 1993 and was an integral part of the expansion marking our second century of research. He will be greatly missed. To his family and his many friends, we express our deepest sympathy. William R. Miller, Chairman Bruce Stillman, President and Chief Executive Officer James D. Watson, Chancellor W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer PALL--David B. I am deeply saddened by the death of David B. Pall who was a good friend and intellectual mentor for over 30 years. My thoughts are with David's family. This extraordinary man enriched our lives and he will be greatly missed. Sandy Schlesinger

title: Ralph K. Andrist, 90, Historian Who Wrote About Plains Indians, Dies
description: Ralph Kenneth Andrist, a historian, author and editor who wrote the classic "The Long Death: The Last Days of the Plains Indian," died on Sunday at his home in Lynnwood, Wash. He was 90 and worked in New York for most of his career.

title: National Briefing | West: California: A Hybrid Engine Is As Good As A Friend
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, signed legislation that would allow up to 75,000 drivers of hybrid vehicles to use carpool lanes even when driving alone. The law is intended to encourage the manufacture and purchase of hybrids, which combine gasoline and electricity power for a fuel efficiency of at least 45 miles a gallon. It was opposed by the Ford Motor Company, whose new Escape Hybrid, a sport utility vehicle, averages 31 miles a gallon. Ford said that the law favored Japanese manufacturers, since only the Toyota Prius, Honda Insight and Honda Civic Hybrid now meet the requirement. The law requires federal approval before it can take effect. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

New Jersey Transit Will Consider Occupying New Station in Midtown

Farley post office building. The work could pave the way for the transit agency to become the new station's main tenant, instead of Amtrak.

title: Companion Said to Admit Killing Woman and Son
description: BANTAM, Conn., Sept. 23 - A man who contacted the police to report his companion and their 4-month-old son missing on Wednesday later confessed to stabbing them to death during an argument, the authorities said in court documents made public on Thursday.

title: Warnings Called Likely on Drug Risk for Suicide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - A top Food and Drug Administration official told Congress on Thursday that the agency was likely to force drug makers to put the strongest possible warning on antidepressants regarding the drugs' potential for increasing suicidal thinking and behavior in children.

title: Powell Deputy Says Elections Must Be 'Open to All' in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 A The second-ranking official at the State Department said today, in an apparent contradiction of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, that the elections scheduled for Iraq in January must be "open to all citizens."

title: Guard Accused of $25,000 Sick Pay Theft
description: A correction officer on Rikers Island was arrested and charged yesterday with stealing more than $25,000 in sick pay after 38 doctor's notes he submitted to the City Department of Correction were revealed as forgeries, officials said.

title: Feed-Tube Law Is Struck Down in Florida Case
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23 - Gov. Jeb Bush's efforts to keep a brain-damaged woman alive against her husband's wishes all but collapsed on Thursday, when the Florida Supreme Court ruled that the law letting the governor order her feeding tube reinserted violated the separation of powers guaranteed by the state's Constitution.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Russians Move To Arrest Opposition Politician
description: Correction Appended

title: Weary, Angry Haitians Dig Out of Storm
description: GONAVES, Haiti, Sept. 23 - As the death toll here in this shattered and flooded town rose above 1,000, people scrambled in the streets on Thursday after food handouts from the United Nations, shoveled mud from their flooded homes, and tried to come to grips with the aftermath of the tropical storm that raked the coast last weekend.

title: There's a Lot Up the Sleeves of Two Political Jokesters
description: It isn't every movie that features a man in a gold lam bodysuit with a three-foot gilt phallus that would make Superman blush or maybe just reconsider the whole Lois Lane thing. Then again it's not every film that features the Yes Men, a coterie of anti-corporate activists who travel the world with sartorial flair, political ire and a prodigious sense of the absurd. Like the makeover mavens from "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy," the Yes Men have a way of winning over strangers and commandeering drab rooms. As the golden appendage proves, they also know a little something about accessorizing.

title: New York City Gets Emergency Radio/TV System
description: The Bloomberg administration announced yesterday the creation of an emergency public communication system for New York City, modeled on the federal system, to enable the mayor to get emergency information to the public quickly through television and radio stations.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday ranking the broadcast networks in news and entertainment, with an article about the use of unauthenticated National Guard documents by CBS News and the effect on its parent, Viacom, misidentified the network that finished third in prime-time entertainment for the season ended in May. It was Fox, not ABC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEWITT, ADRIENNE DEERE
description: HEWITT--Adrienne Deere, of Middleburg, VA died on Saturday, September 18, 2004. She was the beloved wife of R. Carey Beer, loving mother of Alexander, Adrianna and Patrick Beer and daughter of the late Ambassador William A. Hewitt and the late Mrs. Patricia W. Hewitt. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 28, at 1pm at Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, VA. Memorial gifts may be made to the 2G Foundation, c/o Rock River Trust Company, 4709 44 St, Ste 5, Rock Island, IL 61201.

title: Congress Approves a Bill to Extend Bush's Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - The Republican-controlled Congress easily passed legislation on Thursday that would extend expiring provisions of last year's tax cuts for families as well as about 20 business tax cuts, at a cost of about $146 billion over 10 years.

title: Indonesia Detains 6 From U.S. Mining Business Over Pollution
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23 - The world's biggest gold producer, the Newmont Mining Corporation, based in Denver, said Thursday that the Indonesian police had detained six of its officials after questioning them about accusations of pollution from a company mine in northern Indonesia.

title: Recent Openings
description: It was a week for classics, as a condensed version of all three parts of Shakespeare's "Henry VI" and revivals of plays by Henrik Ibsen and Eugne Ionesco opened in New York.

title: Three Hours: 2 Out and 3 in at the State Ethics Commission
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 24 - Within a span of three hours on Friday, the chairwoman of the State Ethics Commission resigned, the agency's executive director was formally terminated and Gov. M.Jodi Rell named three new commissioners to the embattled watchdog agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNES, EDWARD LARRABEE
description: BARNES--Edward Larrabee. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of our Trustee Edward Larrabee Barnes. Ed was of a generation of architects who were steeped in modernism at Harvard and inspired by Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer. He is often first identified with the museums he designed-The Walker Art Center, the Sarah Scaife Gallery at Carnegie Mellon, the Dallas Museum of Art, and the Armand Hammer chief among them. He created beautiful, light-infused spaces in which architecture never upstages art, and through which visitors can flow easily. He also was one of the first modernist to bring a sensitivity to the local and the regional in his work, utilizing indigenous stone or wood to articulate his spare vocabulary. This tenet is perhaps most evident in his Haystack Mountain School of Arts and Crafts on Deer Isle, Maine. This country is filled with lasting monuments to Ed's genius, from huge projects like the IBM headquarters in New York, to private commissions done on a domestic scale. We especially extend our sympathies to his wife, Mary, who was our colleague in MoMA's Department of Architecture and Design in the 1940s, as well as to his son, his grandaughters, and the entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terence Riley, The Philip Johnson Chief Curator of Architecture and Design The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

In lieu of flowers donations to the Anti-Defamation League, 823 United Nations Plaza, NY, NY 10017, would be appreciated. For information, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

title: To Help Iraq Vote, Powell Seeks Meeting of Nations
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said Friday that the Bush administration was working with Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq to press the major Western democracies and several Middle Eastern countries, including Iran, to join with the United States in holding an international conference in October to bolster Iraq's electoral process.

title: US Airways Asks Court for Pay Cuts
description: US Airways late yesterday asked a federal bankruptcy court to approve emergency pay cuts plus other moves, aimed at raising $38 million in cash per month.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about an insurance company's plans to give refunds to soldiers who bought high-cost policies at Fort Benning, Ga., misstated the given name of one soldier. He is Specialist Brandon Conger, not Brendan.

title: Mets Game Moved Into Holiday
description: Until earlier this month, the Mets were scheduled to play the Cubs tonight at 7:10. Then came a call from Major League Baseball telling the team to switch the game to 1:25 p.m. to accommodate Fox Sports.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Official Suspended Over Party
description: The state suspended the Lyon County attorney, Lindell Choat, after a grand jury indicted him and his wife for a teenagers' beer party where a 19-year-old man reportedly tried to rape a girl, the authorities said. Mr. Choat and his wife, Mary Jane, face charges of providing alcoholic beverages to minors, with Mr. Choat also charged with trying to influence police officers not to investigate. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Agency Chief Is Fired After 7-Month-Old Dies in Day Care
description: The New York City health commissioner fired the official in charge of child-care inspections yesterday, after learning that two city inspectors had visited a day care center in Queens just an hour before a baby who died was found unconscious there.

title: National Briefing | West: California: San Diego Credit Troubles Intensify
description: Moody's Investors Service downgraded San Diego's credit rating for the second time in six weeks, citing the $1.2 billion shortfall in the city's employee pension fund. Moody's said the city's fiscal problems were significantly worse than they appeared to be in mid-August, when it took a similar action. The agency lowered ratings on $410 million worth of bonds to A1, in the middle of the agency's 10-grade scale, and warned that further action might come after the city releases its 2003 financial statement, which is 15 months overdue. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Counting Forces by Defining the Categories
description: In their debate on the war in Iraq, President Bush and Senator John Kerry had vastly different estimates this week of the number of trained Iraqi troops and police officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANNER, MILTON
description: KANNER--Milton. Died on September 22, 2004. Beloved father of David and Steven, grandfather of Zachary and Maura, loving companion of Beverly Wilkes. Memorial service 3PM Sunday Sept. 26 Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Cancer Research or John Kerry for President.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ALLEN, GEORGE. (AKA GEORGE AXILTREE)
description: ALLEN -- George. (AKA George Axiltree). Passed away September 21, 2004. One of New York's premier singing teachers. Worked at HB Studio and his own private practice. Member of Actors' Equity and the Dramatists Guild. Popular teacher/ writer and lover of museums, Broadway shows, nature and life in general. George was the son of the late Alexander and Mary Allen (Hanic). Brother of Charles Allen and Mildred Johnson. Memorial service Saturday, October 2nd, 2004 at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., N.Y.C., 2-6pm.

title: Another Opening, Another Show
description: Having celebrated the opening of its season on Tuesday evening, the New York Philharmonic returned to Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday with an entirely different program for the first of its subscription concerts. As on Tuesday, Lorin Maazel was on the podium and the violinist Maxim Vengerov was the soloist. But in place of the Beethoven Violin Concerto, which he played on Tuesday, Mr. Vengerov offered the smaller-scaled Mendelssohn Concerto. And instead of Dvorak's ``New World'' Symphony - so much for commemorating the centenary of the composer's death - Mr. Maazel led Messiaen's ``Offrandes OubliAees: MAeditation Symphonique Pour Orchestra'' and Beethoven's Seventh Symphony.

title: Brazilian Revolutionaries at Town Hall
description: Two stars of the tropicalia movement, which revolutionized Brazilian pop, performed at Town Hall this week: Gilberto Gil on Tuesday night, on a double bill with David Byrne, and Rita Lee on Wednesday night. In the 1960's, their iconoclasm and cosmopolitan ambition marked them as troublemakers; Mr. Gil was imprisoned and exiled by Brazil's military government, and Ms. Lee's band, Os Mutantes, were threatened and censored. They outlasted their opponents, and Mr. Gil was appointed Brazil's minister of culture in 2002.

title: PARENT OF UNION STATE BANK HIRES TAKEOVER ADVISER
description: The U.S.B. Holding Company, the parent of Union State Bank, said that it had hired a takeover adviser, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, to evaluate "strategic opportunities." The company, based in Orangeburg, N.Y., operates most of its 29 Union State branches in Rockland and Westchester Counties in New York and has about $3 billion in assets. U.S.B. Holding's chief financial officer, Steven Sabatini, declined to say whether the company was considering a sale.

title: When the Shooting Stopped
description: The death last weekend of my friend the photographer Eddie Adams took me back to a visit to the Saigon bureau of The Associated Press before Christmas of 1965. I was arranging, in those years before personal computers, to use the bureau's telegrapher to send back dispatches to my newspaper in New York. Eddie introduced himself and I asked him if he had any advice for me about covering the war.

title: 7 Officers Are Reassigned in Newark Conspiracy Case
description: NEWARK, Sept. 24 - The Newark Police Department moved on Friday to reassign seven officers implicated by a fellow patrolman as being part of a crew in the city's West District that engaged in brutal shakedowns of suspected drug dealers, planted evidence and conducted illegal searches.

title: Envoy Suggests Sharing Power to Aid Darfur
description: ABECHE, Chad, Sept. 24 - Stepping into the political quagmire of Sudan, Africa's largest country, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Ruud Lubbers, suggested Friday that limited autonomy could quell the rebellion in the Darfur region in the west, but made it clear that debating self-rule was not an option.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chinese Concern Wins Oil Stake
description: Sinochem, China's largest chemicals trader, won control of the bankrupt Inchon Oil Refinery Company of South Korea for 635.1 billion won ($553 million), a price 1.4 percent lower than its initial offer. Sinochem signed a final contract yesterday to take over Inchon Oil after getting court approval.

title: Wildlife's revenge : Even in urban Singapore, it can sometimes be a jungle
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airport Gains Reprieve
description: Berlin's historic Tempelhof Airport, the main landing site of the Berlin Airlift of 1948 and 1949, will not be permanently closed on Oct. 31, the city's administrative court ruled, and its future will await a full hearing on the case. Several airlines had challenged the city-ordered closure of the 81-year-old downtown airport, which Berlin wants to phase out, along with the airport at Tegel in the northwest of the city, in a plan to build up the airport at Schnefeld in the former East as the capital's new hub. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: ON THE RECORD
ST.JUDE MEDICAL TO STOP MAKING HEART DEVICE
description: St. Jude Medical said it would stop making a device used during heart operations and, as a result, take a one-time charge of $32 million to $37 million in the third quarter. A decline in the number of operations that used the equipment led to the decision to halt production of the device, a symmetry bypass aortic connector, as of Dec. 31, a St. Jude spokesman, Peter Gove, said. The company, based in St. Paul, said it wanted to invest in more profitable products, like defibrillators for correcting irregular heartbeats. St. Jude said on Thursday that it planned to buy Endocardial Solutions, also based in St. Paul, for $273 million to gain defibrillators that detect the most common form of abnormal heart rhythm.

title: Bush Denounces Kerry for His Remark on Allawi
description: RACINE, Wis., Sept. 24 - President Bush hit back hard at Senator John Kerry on Friday for what he called Mr. Kerry's attacks on Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq, who stood by the president's side this week as steadfastly as a member of the Bush campaign.

title: Mayor's Plan to Limit Gifts Will Go to a Wary Council
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will present a proposal to the City Council on Tuesday to sharply curtail campaign contributions from people who do business with the city.

title: AUSTRALIAN FOOTBALL : Melbourne sidelined as Brisbane and Port Adelaide clash
Russia Pushing Security Council for Wider List of Terror Suspects
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24 - Russia circulated a draft resolution among Security Council members on Friday that would establish a new list of terror suspects, all of whom would be subject to extradition.

title: Rocket Aimed at U.S. Convoy Kills 4 Iraqis; 8 Workers of Egyptian Company Are Kidnapped
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 24 - A rocket attack aimed at a passing American convoy on a commercial street in northern Baghdad killed 4 Iraqis and wounded 14 others on Friday, the American military and Iraqi security forces said.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Under Indictment, An Official Resigns
description: Insurance Commissioner Carroll Fisher, who is under indictment for five felony charges and who faced an impeachment trial Monday in the Oklahoma Senate, has resigned. Mr. Fisher, 64, a Democrat, had earlier said he would stay in office and vigorously contest the charges. Attorney General Drew Edmondson said he would proceed with the criminal case against Mr. Fisher, who is accused of mishandling state money, converting campaign contributions to his personal use and illegally operating a charity. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: A Family Says an Unexpected Goodbye to a Reluctant Soldier
description: Growing up, my sister and I were known as "the girls" to the adults in our family. This nickname was even more in evidence when we visited our grandparents in Cleveland four times a year. There were only five grandchildren: my two cousins -- both boys -- my brother, my sister and me. My older brother and cousins were the coolest kids I knew; my sister was a stand-in companion I resorted to between exhausting attempts to tag along with the adventurous trio. I'd abandon her and our Cabbage Patch dolls to chase after them as they disappeared into the woods to make boy mischief. But my little legs could never catch up. This was a club that "the girls" would not get into.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Plan Advances
description: Alitalia, the Italian airline, said eight of its nine biggest unions agreed to a plan to split the airline in two, enabling the carrier to get a loan to stay in business. Under the plan, the Italian government will reduce its 62 percent stake in the carrier, keeping at least 30 percent, Alitalia said. Alitalia's board approved the rescue plan on Monday after winning concessions from the unions to reduce the work force by about 20 percent. The approval allows Alitalia to obtain a loan of 400 million euros ($491 million) from Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein guaranteed by Italy's government. The union that represents 1,200 flight attendants did not sign the accord.

title: Yanks Celebrate Groundhog Day at Fenway
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24 - For all the angst here over Grady Little's brain lock last October, it might have been wise to have a Pedro Alarm in the Boston Red Sox dugout. It could ring in the ears of Terry Francona, the new manager, whenever Pedro Martnez takes the mound in the eighth inning against the Yankees.

title: New Pet Cause for the Very Rich: Swaying the Election

description: Tone is nearly everything in ``The Happy Prince,'' a fable written by Oscar Wilde. The story is slight and the telling of it delicate. But David Neumann and Amy Trompetter, the directors of a new production of the story that was performed on Thursday night at the Kitchen, pour just about everything into the hourlong piece.

The reward is $50,000, not $10,000; the ad spending is $100,000, not $10,000.

They recommended that doctors not prescribe antidepressants other than Prozac for children and adolescents; they did not ban the drugs.

title: Corrections

He is under secretary of state for arms control and international security; under secretary for nonproliferation is an unofficial shorthand form.

It represents 60 agencies, not 30.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil for November delivery rose to a record close of $48.88 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract has gained 7.2 percent for the week.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Fifth Province Allows Gay Marriage
description: The Nova Scotia Supreme Court ruled that banning same-sex marriage was unconstitutional, making the province the fifth to legalize such marriages. The decision comes just a week after a similar ruling in Manitoba. Same-sex marriage is also legal in Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia, and in the Yukon Territory. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: ATTACK ON ART
description: A woman damaged two art installations by Gordon Matta-Clark at the Hamburger Bahnhof museum in Berlin, a day after Friedrich Christian Flick's collection of contemporary art was opened there by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schrder. "Flick, now I forgive you," the woman shouted before she was taken into custody by the police. She was apparently referring to the controversy surrounding the collection of Mr. Flick, whose grandfather was a wealthy Nazi arms industrialist employing as many as 50,000 slave laborers in his factories. Critics have accused Mr. Flick of trying to whitewash his family's past with the exhibition, and they also pointed out that he had refused to contribute part of his family inheritance to a major compensation fund for slave laborers in 2001. "I don't believe that you inherit guilt," he said. "I believe that you can inherit responsibility." KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Waltzing between tax regimens to maximize your pension funds
Richard S. Arnold, 68, Judge Once Eyed for Supreme Court, Dies
description: Richard S. Arnold, a federal appeals court judge who issued influential rulings involving individual rights and narrowly missed a Supreme Court nomination, died on Thursday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 68.

title: State to Buy Land in Putnam, and Will Pay Taxes on It
description: PHILIPSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 24 - Gov. George E. Pataki announced on Friday that the state was buying two parcels of land in Putnam County, and he signed legislation that would put all state lands in the county on the tax rolls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, EVELYN
description: MARCUS--Evelyn, 93. Beloved wife of the late George Marcus. Beloved mother of Helen Zeitlin and the late Judith Harmon, loving grandmother, great-grandmother, mother-in-law and sister. Services New Montefiore Cemetery, Sunday, September 26, 2004, at 11:00 AM.

title: Israel's nukes : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
If Glove Fits, Brown Expects to Acquit Himself Well
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24 - Kevin Brown tried to jam his left hand into a glove Friday, and it did not quite fit. That made no difference, because Brown was throwing in the bullpen. But he could start here Sunday if a new, specially designed glove fits.

title: 9 Cyclists Are Arrested in Protest
description: Nine people were arrested last night and 40 bicycles were seized as about a thousand cyclists hit the streets in the monthly Critical Mass bicycle protest ride, the police said. The cyclists filled the canyons of Park Avenue and Broadway in a smaller replay of the ride that led to hundreds of arrests on the eve of the Republican National Convention.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday showing executive changes at Computer Associates, where the former chief executive was charged with securities fraud and obstruction of justice, referred incorrectly to 4 of the 11 officers who are no longer part of the executive management team. The four -- Mark Combs, Kevin Long, Gary Starkey and Frank Yang -- are still managers with the company; they have not left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUM, BERNARD S. (BUDDY)
description: BLUM--Bernard S. (Buddy), 70, of Longmeadow, MA, on September 22. Devoted husband of Sheila. Loving father of Jeremy, Peter, Mitchell, Arnita and Marge. Adoring grandfather. Cherished brother of Ellen Epstein and Barbara Blum. Life Member of SAE & AMS. "Bud's impact on the Aerospace Industry will be a lasting legacy." Bud's musical genius will never be forgotten.

title: Yankees-Red Sox Games a Consistent Ratings Hit
description: A Yankees-Red Sox series is reason for tension, hyperbole, an on-field tussle or two and, so often, Maalox moments for Boston fans.

title: Franoise Sagan, Who Had a Best Seller at 19 With 'Bonjour, Tristesse,' Dies at 69
description: Franoise Sagan, the rebellious French writer who achieved fame as a teenager with her first novel, "Bonjour Tristesse," a precocious tale of sexual disillusionment, but whose international reputation dimmed as literary tastes changed, died yesterday in Honfleur, in northern France. She was 69.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Bomblike Device Leads To Evacuation
description: A block of buildings in Asheville, including the Buncombe County administrative offices, was evacuated after elections board workers spotted what they thought was a makeshift bomb in a soda bottle on the office doorstep. The police bomb squad destroyed it, and the fragments will be evaluated by the state crime laboratory, said Capt. Tom Aardema of the police. Ariel Hart (NYT)
