title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAUSHAR, ABRAHAM
description: KRAUSHAR--Abraham. On September 23, 2004. Beloved husband of Pearl, devoted brother of Harold and Sam, loving father of Rachel Gila, Rona, Mordecai and their spouses. Cherished grandfather of Ariel, Eitan, Yehuda, Naomi, Dana and Jodi. Proud marine veteran, active member of the Jewish community and a true friend to all. Funeral service 10AM Sunday at Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, NJ.

title: An Un-American Way to Cam
description: President Bush and his surrogates are taking their re-election campaign into dangerous territory. Mr. Bush is running as the man best equipped to keep America safe from terrorists -- that was to be expected. We did not, however, anticipate that those on the Bush team would dare to argue that a vote for John Kerry would be a vote for Al Qaeda. Yet that is the message they are delivering -- with a repetition that makes it clear this is an organized effort to paint the Democratic candidate as a friend to terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SATO, KAZUO
description: SATO--Kazuo. On September 22, 2004. Professor Emeritus of Rutgers University. Beloved husband of Midori. Loving father of Gaku, Kumi, Nina and Topaz. Cherished grandfather of Akira, Mikiko, Galen and Padma. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, September 26, 2-5 PM. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lawmakers Take Beer Indoors
description: Parliament's lower house continued its legislative assault on beer, approving amendments to ban beer drinking in public places, where it has become strikingly prevalent, the newspaper Kommersant reported under the headline "Time to Go to the Pubs." The ban would include streets, parks, squares and stadiums, as well as subways, trains and buses. Last month, lawmakers enacted strict limits on beer advertising. Public consumption of vodka and other alcoholic beverages is already banned, though erratically enforced. The new restrictions could drastically affect sales of beer, an estimated 30 percent of which is sold for "immediate consumption," according to Kommersant. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 - California regulators approved a plan on Friday aimed at drastically reducing over the next 11 years the vehicle emissions of gases that scientists have linked to global warming.

title: U.S. Official Says Early Trials of Hussein and Others Are Unlikely, Despite Allawi's Demand
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 24 - A senior American official helping to prepare for the trials of Saddam Hussein and other top officials of the former government said Friday that "the likelihood of trials in the near future is remote," despite a demand by Iraq's interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi, that they begin by November.

description: WOLOSOFF -- Morty. Gone another year but never forgotten. All of my love always. Gloria Wolosof

title: Israel's nukes : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Higher Price For Oil Stake
description: Canada set a higher-than-expected price for the sale of its 19 percent stake in Petro-Canada, the oil company. The government set the price late Thursday at 64.50 Canadian dollars ($50.42) a share, 3 dollars higher than the price estimated in the prospectus for the shares released a week earlier. The new price will generate a total of 3.2 billion Canadian dollars, a record for a single offering in Canada. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Brooklyn Haitians Rally Again for Flooded Homeland
description: As Haiti, battered by a tropical storm, struggles to recover, workers at the Flatbush Haitian Center are raising money to help pay for clean water. The Haitian Centers Council in downtown Brooklyn, along with 13 firehouses throughout the city, is collecting food to send to a place where yesterday people remained hungry atop their houses, still stranded by floodwaters and counting their dead.

title: AT&T Cuts Jobs at Call Centers as It Struggles to Regroup
description: After promising in July to retreat from the residential phone market, AT&T has started to dismantle its vast operations -- by closing one telemarketing and customer-service call center at a time. But will those moves help the struggling behemoth?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: California Approves Plan To Cut Vehicle Emissions California regulators approved a plan aimed at sharply reducing emissions of global warming gases from cars and trucks over the next 11 years.

title: Poison Politics in Ukraine
description: Think this year's presidential campaign in the United States is nasty? Take a look at politics Ukrainian style. On Sept. 6 the leading opposition candidate in the presidential election disappeared from the campaign trail. The first news of Viktor Yushchenko came a week later: he had been in Austria, recovering from what aides initially thought was acute food poisoning but subsequently said was an attempt on his life. They quoted doctors in Vienna as saying his illness was due to "chemical substances not normally found in food products." At a rally upon his return to Kiev a week ago, Radio Free Europe reported, Mr. Yushchenko's face was swollen and half-paralyzed; he had difficulty reading his text and was salivating excessively.

title: Twisting Dr. Nuke's Arm
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan - President Bush has been searching vainly for Osama bin Laden for three years now, so I've decided to help him out. I'm traveling through Pakistan and Afghanistan to see whether I can find Osama, bring him back in my luggage and claim that $25 million reward.

title: Despite Strife at Home, Iraqi Leader Expresses Optimism on U.S. Tour
description: With numerous appearances in New York and Washington this week, President Bush and Iraq's interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi, painted a relentlessly optimistic picture, asserting unheralded advances against a vicious Iraqi insurgency and in the global war on terror.

title: KERRY ATTACKED ON GAY MARRIAGES
description: A political fund-raising group founded by Gary L. Bauer, the Christian conservative who ran for the 2000 Republican presidential nomination, is spending about $500,000 to run television commercials in Michigan and Pennsylvania that try to link Senator John Kerry to the push for same-sex marriage. The 30-second advertisement, by Americans United for the Protection of Marriage, says, "As a U.S. senator, John Kerry voted against the Defense of Marriage Act, which defined marriage as between a man and a woman." Phil Singer, a spokesman for the Kerry campaign, called the ad misleading, saying the senator "thinks marriage is between a man and a woman." A statement from Mr. Kerry campaign's said he had voted against the legislation, which permits states to refuse recognition of gay marriages performed in other states, because he believed it was "unnecessarily divisive." David D. Kirkpatrick

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELIAS, ELI
description: ELIAS--Eli. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed Charter and Honorary Member, Eli Elias. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Ted Tashlik, President

title: Hepatitis Outbreak Laid to Water and Sewage Failures
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 24 - A virulent form of hepatitis that is especially lethal for pregnant women has broken out in two of Iraq's most troubled districts, Iraqi Health Ministry officials said in interviews here this week, and they warned that a collapse of water and sewage systems in the continuing violence in the country is probably at the root of the outbreak. The disease, called hepatitis E, is caused by a virus that is often spread by sewage-contaminated drinking water. The officials said they had equipment to test only a limited number of people showing symptoms, suggesting that only a fraction of the actual cases have been firmly diagnosed. In Sadr City, a Baghdad slum that for months has been convulsed by gun battles between a local militia and American troops, the officials said as many as 155 cases had turned up.

title: Corrections

It is a special statute of the general trademark law, not the copyright law. title: NEXT GENERATION OF DVD'S TO HAVE DOLBY AUDIO
description: The two biggest developers of next-generation DVD's have chosen audio technology from Dolby Technologies to be incorporated into their products. The DVD Forum selected Dolby Digital Plus and MLP Lossless as audio formats for high-definition DVD products being developed by Toshiba and NEC. The rival Blu-ray Disc Association, which includes Sony, Panasonic and Samsung, have Dolby Digital as part of the format for their Blu-ray Discs. Both sides are rushing to develop the standards for discs and video players, which will be able to play and record programs and movies with the enhanced video and audio of high-definition technology. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: Judge Settles Long Family Feud Over Jimi Hendrix's Estate
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 24 - Ending one chapter in a long and bitter family feud over the estate of the rock legend Jimi Hendrix, a judge here ruled Friday that Mr. Hendrix's stepsister and her cousin had mismanaged his estate.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Thrown Object Fells Prime Minister
description: Ukraine's rollicking presidential campaign took another strange turn when one of the leading candidates, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, left, was hospitalized after being hit in the head with an object during a campaign swing in Ivano-Frankivsk, in western Ukraine. His press secretary, Hanna German, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Yanukovich fell to the ground but was not seriously injured. A protester who hurled the object -- variously described as an egg or a stone or piece of metal -- was arrested. Mr. Yanukovich's leading opponent, Viktor A. Yushchenko, was also hospitalized this month, following what he said was an attempt to poison him. The election is Oct. 31. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,039 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Nigel Nicolson, 87, Bloomsbury Group Biographer and Heir, Dies

He was 87.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Agency Promises Measures To Protect Children
description: The state's Child Protective Services office will hire 123 additional caseworkers and use more aggressive legal procedures in suspected instances of child abuse, a spokesman for the Texas Health and Human Services Commission said. The action follows the death on Sunday of a 2-year-old boy in Dallas whose case had been closed months earlier when his mother refused to cooperate with a state investigator. Gov. Rick Perry ordered a review of the office in July after a county grand jury indictment accused the commission of negligence in the case of a 2-year-old girl who was beaten to death two weeks after being returned to her family from state custody. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Vagrant Is Left To Die
description: South Africa's health minister assailed what he called the appalling conduct of two Johannesburg paramedics who were videotaped by security cameras on Tuesday as they refused to treat a homeless man who had collapsed in a downtown street gutter. The man was found dead the next morning. The paramedics had propped him against a wall after reportedly telling security guards that he was too dirty to ride in their ambulance. The health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, called for an inquiry, saying the government "should ensure that such an incident never happens again in this country." A police spokesman said the unidentified man had died of natural causes but declined to elaborate. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chess Championship Under Way
description: A 14-game world chess championship match between Vladimir Kramnik, 29, of Russia, and Peter Leko, 24, of Hungary, begins today in Brissago, Switzerland. It has a prize of $800,000. Mr. Kramnik, the title holder, beat Garry Kasparov, the former world champion, in 2000. But Mr. Leko is not seen by all as his legitimate challenger. He won the right to face Mr. Kramnik in 2002, when he beat out seven other challengers in a match tournament that was boycotted by some of the world's top players. They said that tournament, a sort of round-robin, was not a legitimate way to select a challenger. Dylan Loeb McClain (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOOCOCK, GLENN WINNETT
description: BOOCOCK--Glenn Winnett, 95, died peacefully at home in Santa Fe, NM on September 23rd, 2004. Born in Santa Monica, California, "Dougie" was the daughter of P.G. Winnett and Helen Hutton Winnett. Her husband, Kenyon, died in 1961. She was a graduate of the Marlborough School in Los Angeles and Miss Bennett's in Millbrook, NY. Loving mother of Susanna Weld of Essex, MA and Leslie Barclay of Santa Fe, NM. She is also survived by seven devoted grandchildren: Linzee Weld of North Yarmouth, ME, Amory Weld of Tiverton, RI: Minot Weld of Bernardsville, NJ: Kate Howard of Nantucket, MA: Rufo di Carpegna of San Anselmo, CA, Guelfo di Carpegna of New York and Allegra Castellini Baldissera of Gstaad, Switzerland and nine great-grandchildren. Formerly of New York City and Fishers Island, NY, she was a member of the Colony Club and the Fishers Island Club. She was a managing director of the Metropolitan Opera from 1976-1985. In 1987 she was awarded the Belmont Medal for distinguished service to the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Services will be private. Donations in her memory, to the Henry L. Ferguson Museum, Fishers Island, NY 06390 would be greatly appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bonus For Ad Executive
description: The WPP Group, the advertising agency, paid its chief executive, Martin Sorrell, left, a bonus of 16.7 million ($30 million) in cash and shares this week. Mr. Sorrell was awarded 6.7 million in shares and 10 million in cash under an incentive plan started in 1999, WPP said in a statement. The cash award, given to Mr. Sorrell's company, JMS Financial Services, was reinvested in 1.9 million newly issued shares at a price of 519 pence a share, the company said. Mr. Sorrell retained the stock component of the award, 1.3 million shares, WPP said.

description: OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 21 - To the many ways Americans can honor the remains of the dearly departed -- blasting their ashes into space or freezing the remains or simply sealing the body in a coffin, among others -- add one more option: mixing the cremation ashes with marine-grade concrete and forming an artificial reef, a home for the fish and the coral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, CAROL (NEE SACKHEIM)
description: MARCUS--Carol (nee Sackheim) of Purchase, NY on September 22, 2004. Cherished wife of Steven. Loving mother of Ari and Kim, Belinda and Tony. Adoring grandmother of Madeline Sarah. Devoted sister of Harvey (Judy) Sackheim and Thelma Lindner. Proud aunt to all her nieces and nephews. An educator supreme who guided the hundreds of teachers she collaborated with and the thousands of students and parents whose lives she touched. She will be remembered as a stylish lady and a defender of excellence. Funeral services will be Sunday, September 26 at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY, 914-664-6800. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Ovarian Cancer Centers at Memorial Sloan-Kettering; University of Connecticut Health Center at Farmington; New York University Hospital or the American Cancer Society.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - House Republican leaders introduced a long-awaited bill Friday that would grant more limited powers to a new national intelligence director than those recommended by the Sept. 11 commission or called for in a companion bill in the Senate.

description: When Paul Marciano, the creative director of Guess, decided he wanted Paris Hilton to be the Guess model -- the one featured in all the coming advertisements -- he called her agent, who quoted what Mr. Marciano called "an astronomical fee."

title: In Hartford, Rowland's Associates Plead Not Guilty to Federal Racketeering Charges
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 24 - The three men indicted this week on charges of using the office of former Gov. John G. Rowland as a racketeering enterprise pleaded not guilty Friday in federal court to charges that they swapped lucrative state contracts for money, business deals, trips to Walt Disney World and other benefits.

title: Floodwaters Recede From Haitian City, but Hunger Does Not
description: GONAVES, Haiti, Sept. 24 - Floodwaters receded Friday in this city where flooding from a tropical storm took more than 1,000 lives, leaving behind thousands of tired and hungry people who labored to clear the mud and debris from what was left of their homes.

title: As With Other Chip Makers, Sales Begin to Stall at Philips
description: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 24 - Signaling a possible wider slowdown in the semiconductor industry, Royal Philips Electronics on Friday became the latest company to say that its chip sales had begun to stall, at least temporarily.

title: A Crossover Moment for an Old World Game
description: The old Italian-American men in Carroll Park rise with old-men efforts from their plastic chairs to see over the low concrete wall into the narrow clay court where red and green balls bounce and roll and knock about. Their game taxes the same skills as any child's play, a lot of hand-eye coordination and a little strategy, but it is their game.

title: '60 Minutes' Delays Report Questioning Reasons for Iraq War
description: CBS News said yesterday that it had postponed a "60 Minutes" segment that questioned Bush administration rationales for going to war in Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Recall Challenge Rejected
description: In the latest setback to a fragmented opposition movement, Venezuela's electoral board has voted to reject a petition calling for the recall referendum won by President Hugo Chvez last month to be overturned. Stunned by Mr. Chvez's victory, the opposition has repeatedly issued claims of fraud. The Organization of American States and the Carter Center in Atlanta, monitors of the vote, have endorsed his victory. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Kerry Promises to Refocus U.S. on Terror War
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 - Escalating his critique of President Bush as commander in chief, Senator John Kerry declared here Friday that the invasion of Iraq was "a profound diversion from the battle against our greatest enemy, Al Qaeda," and asserted that he would refocus the nation's energies on "the real war on terror."

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Government Posts Surplus
description: Brazil posted a larger-than-expected primary budget surplus of 10.9 billion reais ($3.8 billion) in August, up from 4.96 billion reais a year earlier, the central bank said yesterday. So far this year the government has run up a primary surplus, which excludes interest payments on debt, of 63.73 billion reais, putting it on track to meet fiscal targets in a $14 billion loan deal with the International Monetary Fund. Under the loan agreement, Brazil agreed to a year-end surplus of 75.1 billion reais, or 4.25 percent of gross domestic product. Earlier in the week, however, the government raised its surplus target for 2004 to 4.5 percent of gross domestic product, saying it intended to use a windfall in tax receipts to pay off more of its debt. The rising surplus helped Brazil reduce its net public sector debt to 54.1 percent of gross domestic product by the end of August Todd Benson (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR ENDS FLAT. The dollar ended flat against the euro in volatile trading after falling to a one-month low, as dealers focused on durable goods orders. The dollar closed at $1.2268 yesterday from $1.2314 on Thursday.

title: 3 Commandos Charged With Beating of Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - In a growing scandal within a scandal, three more members of the Navy Seals have been charged with abusing Iraqi detainees, two of whom died in American custody in Iraq after they were beaten, Navy officials said Friday. One detainee died at Abu Ghraib prison and the other at an Army base near Mosul.

description: Baseball bright and baseball dark each make appearances this weekend -- in "Clubhouse," CBS's new fall drama, and "Hustle," an ESPN biopic. "Clubhouse" is about a sad-eyed, fatherless teenager looking for meaning and valor as a major league bat boy. "Hustle" is about Pete Rose. I'll leave you to guess which story is heartwarming and which is warped and pathetic.

title: ViewPoints:RATE CREEP
Today's Top Games
description: Iowa (2-1) at No. 18 Michigan (2-1) 3:30 p.m., ABC (Regional) Iowa fell out of the top 25 after being routed, 44-7, by Arizona State and hopes to avoid losing two in a row. After falling to Notre Dame, Michigan held on for a 24-21 victory over San Diego State. But quarterback Chad Henne threw three interceptions in that game. An early conference loss would be a lot for either team to bounce back from. Despite being favored at home, Michigan looks vulnerable and has struggled with Iowa in the past.

title: F.T.C. APPROVES LUXOTTICA'S BID FOR COLE NATIONAL
description: Luxottica, the world's largest maker of eye wear, won Federal Trade Commission approval of its $495 million bid for the Cole National Corporation, improving the company's access to the eyeglasses market in the United States. Luxottica, based in Milan, is growing through acquisitions and licensing deals. The company bought the OPSM Group, Australia's biggest eyewear retailer, in September 2003, and last month added a five-year licensing agreement with Donna Karan International. The purchase of Cole National, based in Twinsburg, Ohio, is scheduled to close on Oct. 4. Under the agreement's terms, Cole's stock will be converted into the right to receive $27.72 a share at the transaction's completion.

The Episcopal bishop of New York had dismissed a senior aide -- a female priest -- at Grace Episcopal Church for what he said was misappropriation of tens of thousands of dollars in church funds. The aide's job was given to another female priest, an associate of the bishop's.

title: At Center of Connecticut Case, a Man Who Exuded Power
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 24 - From the moment former Gov. John G. Rowland made him his co-chief of staff in the fall of 1997, Peter N. Ellef let everyone know he was the man to see on matters ranging from state contracts to the governor's personal affairs.

title: Balance Sheet : A matter of survival
World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Reject Talks
description: Maoist rebels rejected a government call to resume peace talks to end an eight-year rebellion that has claimed 10,000 lives. They said they would take part only if the United Nations or an international rights group were involved. Dhruba Adhikary (NYT)

title: The Two Brazils Combine for Night at Carnegie Hall
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 20 - Marcelo Bratke, 44, an award-winning classical pianist, comes from a family of architects long prominent here in Brazil's largest city. Alex Santos, 17, a resident of a violent slum neighborhood, plays in casual samba bands on weekends and sees a career as a professional musician as his best chance to escape poverty.

title: Garciaparra Content as a Cub and Playing for a Contender
description: While the Red Sox and the Yankees dueled four hours north before an overflow crowd at Fenway Park, Nomar Garciaparra took his spot at shortstop for the Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium last night before a crowd that could hardly fill a Boston watering hole.

title: TOMMY HILFIGER USA UNDER FEDERAL INVESTIGATION
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, the clothing maker, said yesterday that it was being investigated by federal authorities regarding commissions paid to an overseas purchasing unit for the last 14 years. The company's Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A. unit received a grand jury subpoena Thursday from the United States attorney's office for the Southern District of New York, seeking documents dating to 1990. Subpoenas also were given to some current and former employees, the company said. Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A. pays "buying-office commissions" to the offshore unit for services including product development, sourcing, production scheduling and quality control. Tommy Hilfiger, based in Hong Kong and run from New York, said it was turning over the requested documents.

title: Cemex to Buy Britain's RMC Group

The deal is set to be announced on Monday, these people said. RMC, the world's largest supplier of ready mix concrete, has been cutting costs and closing plants.

title: The U.S. Has a Favorite in Afghanistan. That's a Problem.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan - TALIBAN attacks aside, a huge question looms over Afghanistan's first-ever presidential election on Oct. 9. Will the country's hopeful electorate see it as an exercise in democracy, or an exercise in American political theater?

title: Subletting an Apartment in a Condo
description: Q. I own a condo in Manhattan. I have signed a lease agreement with a prospective tenant and sent the completed application package to the managing agent for board approval. The board has the right of first refusal. Under the condo bylaws, if the board does not exercise its right of first refusal within 14 days of receipt of application, the owner can proceed with the lease. The managing agent took seven days to process the application and send it to the board. Is the time it takes for the managing agent to process the application considered time with the board? . . . Carol Braun, Manhattan.

title: Greetings From Flint: Moore Says Camden Is His Kind of Town
description: CAMDEN - MICHAEL MOORE, self-described lovable communist and leftist gadfly, came to Rutgers-Camden last week as part of his new, multicampus "Slacker Uprising Tour," which is aimed at getting at least 5 percent of the 50 percent of the population that doesn't vote -- some of whom may be college students, he believes -- to the polls in November.

title: Iraq's Disappearing Election
description: Iraq's interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi, acknowledges that those elections he and President Bush have vowed would take place next January "may not be perfect." Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld acknowledges that they may not be held at all in 20 to 25 percent of Iraq because of continuing violence. Meanwhile, as The Times's Dexter Filkins reports from Baghdad, Iraq's most influential cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, is increasingly concerned that even where voting does take place, the choices will be rigged in advance in ways that underrepresent the country's Shiite majority and thwart democratic choice.

title: A Great Forecaster. Too Bad He Can't Reach the Map.
description: IN a roomy first-floor loft in Park Slope resides Brooklyn's answer to Punxsutawney Phil, the famous groundhog prognosticator. Hoover the Tortoise, who lives with a choreographer and a lawyer on Union Street, has an uncanny ability to inform his devotees when spring has arrived for good, or when summer has truly given way to fall. Perky during the summer months (as perky as a tortoise gets), Hoover slows down markedly in autumn, until he finally disappears for the winter into his hiding place behind a radiator.

title: An Eye on Albany
description: The State Assembly met briefly in Albany last week and accomplished almost nothing. That's a dog-bites-man headline if we ever heard one. One vote short of the number needed to override any of Gov. George Pataki's budget vetoes, the Democratic majority staged a series of purely symbolic votes and went home. For want of that one member (three Democrats stayed away, presumably to curry favor with Mr. Pataki), the Assembly was deprived of the chance to actually pass the overrides, which then would have become purely symbolic in the absence of any action by the Republican State Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLLIER, REGINALD B.
description: COLLIER--Reginald B. Reg Collier, businessman, philanthropist, horse lover, and owner died on September 15, 2004 in New York City. Mr. Collier was founder and Chairman of Research Systems Corporation, an Evansville based advertising research organization known across the world a The ARS Group. "Reg believed in what we wanted to accomplish in the marketing industry, and championed our cause with everything he and his wife Lois had. We will miss his passion and his guidance," said Meg Blair, longtime partner and RSC co-founder. Reg went to Evansville in 1961 as a product management director for Mead Johnson & Co, became President and CEO of PAR in 1963, and, in 1974, founded Research Systems Corporation. He was an avid and successful investor in addition to his business pursuits. In 1987, the Colliers built their winter residence, Highgate Farm, where the couple has raised and raced thoroughbreds. Reg fell in love with every foal born. The Colliers have been major supporters of the New York City Trickle Up Program, The Salvation Army, and Bryn Mawr College in Pennsylvania, where they endowed the Lois and Reginald Collier Science Library. They made possible the Roberts Road Project to transform historic houses in facilities for student activities through their extraordinary lead gift. Harvard Business School and Habitat for Humanity were also among their favorite charities, as was The Boys & Girls Club of Evansville. Reg attended Andover Academy, Haverford College, Harvard Business School, and was a US Marine. Reg leaves his wife, Lois Collier, of 54 years, son Mark Collier of Jacksonville, Florida, daughter Brynn Helms of Pine Bush, New York, and four grandchildren.

description: Kim Marie Krikorian and Dr. Marco Andrew Harmaty were married yesterday at St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in Summit, N.J. Msgr. John E. Hart performed the ceremony.

title: Fear and Laptops on the Campaign Trail
description: Nine blocks north of Madison Square Garden, next door to the Emerging Artists Theater, where posters advertised "The Gay Naked Play" ("Now With More Nudity"), the bloggers were up and running. It was Republican National Convention week in New York City, and they had taken over a performance space called the Tank. A homeless guy sat at the entrance with a bag of cans at his feet, a crocheted cap on his head and his chin in his hand. To reach the Tank, you had to cross a crummy little courtyard with white plastic patio furniture and half a motorcycle strung with lights and strewn with flowers, beneath a plywood sign that said, "Ronald Reagan Memorial Fountain."

title: Perennial Summer, With Turkish Treats

Walls awash in the blues, greens and, yes, turquoise of the Mediterranean convey a sense of perennial summer. The menu also lists dishes from that region, particularly Turkey.

title: On the Waterfront

Developers plan 128 units of housing on 30 acres and 250,000 square feet of new office and commercial space.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Society thinks we are monsters. The police want us dead. That's why we do this. If we do not take off these tattoos, we will never be able to live in peace."

title: Forget It?
description: Here's a thought to help assuage Kirn's feelings on his friend's being "over it": To my knowledge, this is the only country in the world with real political clout that had previously experienced virtually no terrorist activity. We're a physically vast nation, buffered by friendly nations on two sides and by oceans on the other two. Every other major power -- with the possible exception of Russia -- is easily accessible and therefore highly vulnerable, as evidenced by centuries of bombings and other malicious activity. The World Trade Center attack was unspeakably sad and will always be so, but it's simply a painful coming of age for a very young country; it just took a long time for anyone to figure out how to get here and do damage.

title: Shakespeare's Leap
description: Our sense that Shakespeare knew a lot about life's realities is an illusion, a trick of his incomparable skill as a dramatist and poet. The most common metaphor in Shakespeare is that the world is a stage and the stage is a world. In being able to convince us that they are one and the same lies the basis of Shakespeare's art and his supremacy as a poet and playwright.

title: Getting to Average

The fantasy isn't that inequality vanishes; it's that inequality in black America catches up with inequality in white America. And, for the moment, a fantasy is all it is. Since the 1968 assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., the black middle class has increased significantly, yet the percentage of black children living in poverty has hovered between 30 and 40 percent.

Diaphanous stoles by Margaret Loves Peter come in light blue or truffle brown ($140 at Cashmere New York, 212-744-3500). Banana Republic has a white wool and silk wrap ($98). title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNES, EDWARD LARRABEE
description: BARNES--Edward Larrabee. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of our Trustee Edward Larrabee Barnes. Ed was of a generation of architects who were steeped in modernism at Harvard and inspired by Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer. He is often first identified with the museums he designed-The Walker Art Center, the Sarah Scaife Gallery at Carnegie Mellon, the Dallas Museum of Art, and the Armand Hammer chief among them. He created beautiful, light-infused spaces in which architecture never upstages art, and through which visitors can flow easily. He also was one of the first modernist to bring a sensitivity to the local and the regional in his work, utilizing indigenous stone or wood to articulate his spare vocabulary. This tenet is perhaps most evident in his Haystack Mountain School of Arts and Crafts on Deer Isle, Maine. This country is filled with lasting monuments to Ed's genius, from huge projects like the IBM headquarters in New York, to private commissions done on a domestic scale. We especially extend our sympathies to his wife, Mary, who was our colleague in MoMA's Department of Architecture and Design in the 1940s, as well as to his son, his grandaughters, and the entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terence Riley, The Philip Johnson Chief Curator of Architecture and Design The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

title: An Eye on Albany
description: The State Assembly met briefly in Albany last week and accomplished almost nothing. That's a dog-bites-man headline if we ever heard one. One vote short of the number needed to override any of Gov. George Pataki's budget vetoes, the Democratic majority staged a series of symbolic votes and went home. For want of that one member (three Democrats stayed away, presumably in an effort to curry favor with Mr. Pataki), the Assembly was deprived of the chance to actually pass the overrides, which would also have been purely symbolic in the absence of any action by the Republican Senate.

title: Fiction: Fire-Eaters, Flying Cats and Joseph Conrad
description: VAMPIRES, pirates and lusty French socialites: now that's a recipe for a good time. These are just some of the characters in a new novel called HAWKES HARBOR (Tor/Tom Doherty, $21.95), a tale of monstrous men and the long, tricky road to redemption, mostly set in the 1950's and 60's. What's also exciting, and surprising, about this book is that it's written by an author familiar to many readers not because of her predilection for the fantastical but because of her timeless, gritty stories of teenage life. Ponyboy, anyone?

title: For Some Local Lubavitchers, Mum's the Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Voting Worth the Trouble?
description: Why does voting in a presidential election feel at the same time both terribly important and utterly pointless? There is a paradox here, and it is not easy to make it go away. On the one hand, casting a ballot on Election Day strikes us as a kind of civic obligation; neglecting to do so is perhaps not so serious as neglecting to file a tax return, but it is still something you feel guilty about. On the other hand, nearly half of those Americans who are eligible to vote evidently don't think that it's worth the bother. And, in a sense, they're right.

title: In Warren, a Big 'For Sale' Sign
description: IT was the same sort of inspiration that prompted the actress Kim Basinger to buy the town of Braselton, Ga., in 1989 for $20 million. Joe Cicio saw such potential in the tiny town of Warren in Litchfield County that he figured his best bet would be to just buy the whole commercial district and fix it the way he wanted.

title: 'American Dream'
description: The Pledge:Washington and Milwaukee, 1991

title: Mary Ellen Evolo, Milton Hsu
description: Dr. Mary Ellen Evolo and Dr. Milton Hsu were married yesterday in New Orleans. The Rev. Edgar J. Tiblier performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Jesuit Church.

title: Groh Is Comfortable in Virginia, and Cavs Are Getting Used to Winning
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 - When lunch and dinner are brought into the University of Virginia football office on Sunday afternoons, Mike Groh will catch his father peeking at N.F.L. games.

title: Saddam, the Bomb and Me
description: While the final report from Charles A. Duelfer, the top American inspector of Iraq's covert weapons programs, won't be released for a few weeks, the portions that have already been made public touch on many of the experiences I had while working as the head of Saddam Hussein's nuclear centrifuge program. Now that I am living in the United States, I hope to answer some of the most important questions that remain.

title: The Priciest Room You'll Never Use
description: Correction Appended

title: The Paper Not Used
description: To the Editor:

title: Before the Leaves Drop
description: Summer may have ended, but the outdoor dining season continues. There's still time to celebrate harvest in these restaurant gardens.

title: Broadway Bares the Human Voice
description: WHAT did music on Broadway sound like before the microphone invaded the stage? One answer may be heard tomorrow evening when "Broadway Unplugged," an all-star concert at Town Hall, will feature 20 Broadway performers singing their favorite show tunes, without the help of amplification. Among the singers scheduled to perform are Euan Morton, who played Boy George in "Taboo"; Marc Kudisch, the heroic baritone from "Thoroughly Modern Millie"; Michael Cerveris, the scary John Wilkes Booth in "Assassins"; and Cady Huffman, the blonde bombshell in "The Producers."

title: Nancy Sinatra, Rock Goddess
description: LOS ANGELES - "ROCK," Nancy Sinatra said, "is a business for young people. It's not for people who care about things like hair and makeup. And sleep." Ms. Sinatra was drinking iced tea in the garden bar of a West Hollywood hotel on a sultry September afternoon. On her right wrist, she wore a toy bracelet with imitation diamond-studded letters that spelled the word "rock." "It's one of those play bracelets -- you put whatever letters you want on it," she said. "I should probably put a 'C' in front of the 'R.' That might be more accurate."

title: Vegetarian Resort Adds Chicken and Tuna
description: After more than 30 years with a strictly vegetarian menu, Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health, a leading yoga retreat in the Berkshires in Lenox, Mass., has introduced chicken and fish to its daily buffet. The additions are modest: chicken and tuna salads made with celery and vegetarian mayonnaise. "We're not serving chicken cordon bleu," said Cathy Husid, a Kripalu spokeswoman.

title: Stepping Into a Battle for Survival
description: AGNES WHITE first appears as a silhouette, framed in the doorway of a dark, ratty motel room. The smoke from her cigarette wafts through the beams of passing headlights into her disheveled hair. Wine glass in hand, she's watching the cars go by. You can tell she's been in this desolate part of the country outside Oklahoma City -- specifically, in this grim little room with nothing for company but the radio -- for a long, long time.

title: Page Two: Sept. 19-25; INDICT THE OLD BOSS
description: What may prove to be the last of the Enron-era wave of big corporate-crime cases reached the most senior levels of Computer Associates, the Long Island-based software giant, last week. On Wednesday, a grand jury indicted Sanjay Kumar, the company's former chairman and chief executive, on charges of securities fraud and obstruction of justice. Stephen Richards, a former executive vice president, was also indicted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGER, MAXINE MIRIAM
description: BERGER--Maxine Miriam. Of Virginia Beach, VA, and Palm Beach, FL. Born in Far Rockaway, NY. Passed away September 23, 2004, at age 84. Daughter of the late David and Bess Goldrich. Pre-deceased by her husband Leslie Berger of 52 years. Maxine is survived by her children Gail Carol Berger and Bill (Gail S.), grandchildren Dani Pariser (Seth), Allison Weinger (Benjamin), great-grandchildren Jacob and Matthew Pariser, brother Lawrence J. Goldrich (Jan). In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Berger-Goldrich Home at Beth Sholom Village, 6401 Auburn Dr., Virginia Beach, VA 23464. All correspondence can be sent to Bill and Gail Berger, 4801 Ocean Front Ave, Virginia Beach, VA 23451, and Gail Carol Berger, 3140 South Ocean Blvd, Palm Beach, FL 33480.

title: New Jersey: Home Sales Drop, and Then Go Up
description: THERE were some seesaw dramatics concerning the pace of house sales during the last two months of summer -- down in July, up again in August -- according to fresh numbers on signed contracts in the state's 18 largest counties.

title: Two Hands, and Three Executives, Are Better Than One
description: IN the late 1980's, PolyGram (now Universal), the recording conglomerate, had three young and idealistic vice presidents in charge of its prestigious classical music labels: Lisa Altman at Philips, Gregory Barbero at London and Albert Imperato at Deutsche Grammophon. These ambitious executives shared marketing and sales teams at PolyGram's New York offices and plotted overall strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, ROBERTA (NEE LAZARUS)
description: HIRSCH--Roberta (nee Lazarus). On September 24, at age 62. Beloved wife of Jack. Mother of Janet and Josh, and mother-in-law of Dara. Adoring grandmother of Michaela. Passed peacefully at her home after courageously facing cancer. She will be missed dearly by her family and friends who meant so much to her. Her kindness, humor and warmth touched countless lives. Roberta was a compassionate person; her memory may be honored by supporting the Democrats this Novmeber.

title: Staying Fit Between Flights
description: ON a recent trip to New York, I was marooned at Detroit Metropolitan Airport with a long layover. My muscles ached from my flight's first leg, but as I strode through the waiting area's shop-lined corridor, I spotted an airport amenity I'd read about and had wanted to sample -- a compact spa offering massages, manicures and an opportunity to kill time therapeutically, albeit for a fee.

title: A Call for Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAUSHAR, ABRAHAM
description: KRAUSHAR--Abraham. On September 23, 2004. Beloved husband of Pearl, devoted brother of Harold and Sam, loving father of Rachel Gila, Rona, Mordecai and their spouses. Cherished grandfather of Ariel, Eitan, Yehuda, Naomi, Dana and Jodi. Proud marine veteran, active member of the Jewish community and a true friend to all. Funeral service 10AM Sunday at Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTON, RICHARD S., M.D.
description: MARTON--Richard S., M.D. On September 23, 2004 at age 86. Beloved husband of Natalie for 58 years. Loving father of Renee and Gary. Adoring grandfather of Simone and Danielle. Devoted brother of Edwin and Howard. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Sunday, October 17th, 4PM.

title: An Upset on Staten Island, in an Upset Republican Party
description: It is not often that an incumbent with 24 years in office loses a primary.

title: Giants Face Quarterback Who Broke Their Hearts
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 24 - Part of the reason anybody believes in quarterback Jeff Garcia's ability to revive the Cleveland Browns stems from a game 21 long months ago.

title: A Boulevard of Dreams, Unfolding Step by Step
description: A year ago at the Atlantic Antic, the huge annual street fair on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, representatives from a consortium of civic groups announced a far-reaching master plan to mold the street's westernmost end into the grand urban boulevard of their imagination.

title: The Peculiar Institution
description: WHY MARRIAGE MATTERS America, Equality, and Gay People's Right to Marry. By Evan Wolfson. 242 pp. Simon & Schuster. $22.

description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 - When lunch and dinner are brought into the University of Virginia football office on Sunday afternoons, Mike Groh will catch his father peeking at N.F.L. games.

title: Whitney Renwick, Michael Carlson
description: Whitney Vreeland Renwick, the daughter of Meryl S. Renwick and John P. Renwick III of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Christopher Carlson, a son of M. Lynne Carlson and Paul R. Carlson of Delmar, N.Y. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Rilo Kiley: Hot on Their Own Terms
description: LOS ANGELES - BLAKE Sennett, the guitarist and singer in the indie-rock band Rilo Kiley, sat on the front patio of the Edendale Grill in Silver Lake, with his band mates, who were doing paperwork. "We're filling out forms for our new bank accounts," he said with a smile. "To put all our money in."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERL, SIMONE (NEE LEVY)
description: PERL--Simone (nee Levy), granddaughter of renowned Captain Alfred Dreyfus, has died in Paris. Mme Perl, Member of the Order of the French Family, an Officer of Arts and Letters, served in the Resistance during World War II. In a final message of farewell, she asked for all to retain the memory of her grandparents. Lorraine Beitler, Curator Dreyfus Exhibition

title: Norwalk Ponders Drug Tests Concerning Public Housing
description: Norwalk is studying an idea that would require first-time applicants for public housing to test negative for illegal drugs, said Curtis O. Law, executive director of the city's housing authority.

title: A Shifting Menu With an Asian Twist
description: WITH a menu that changes daily, it may not be so surprising to find eel listed as an appetizer at Thomas Moran's Petite Syrah in New Preston, but it is the first time in Connecticut that I have seen eel served any place other than a Japanese restaurant.

title: Centerport Approves Firehouse Expansion
description: Centerport residents finally approved a hotly debated $2 million bond issue to expand the local firehouse. The turnout for the 761-to-590 vote on Monday was the largest of any of the five fire district votes on the expansion, which had failed all four times previously.

title: Ann Marie Elliott, Rudiger Breitenecker Jr.
description: Ann Marie Elliott and Rudiger Leopold Breitenecker Jr. were married yesterday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Park McD. Bodie, an Episcopal priest, conducted the ceremony.

title: With a Raceway, China Motors Toward the Modern Age
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 25 - What does a city with the world's fastest trains, some of Asia's most spectacular buildings and China's best-dressed people do for an encore?

title: Emotional Scars Linger
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care Costs Are a Killer, but Maybe That's a Plus
description: THE nation's health care bill is high and headed higher. Yet most hospitals lose money or barely break even. Doctors complain they are getting squeezed. Employers bemoan rising health care costs as a threat to global competitiveness.

title: A Classical Guide
description: To the Editor: "Fully Booked on Any Day of the Trip," by Vanessa Hartmann (Sept. 5), described my family's travels in Europe.

title: Wilpon Needs to Go
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, LEILA (EIDLIN)
description: STERN--Leila (Eidlin). On September 22, 2004 in her 100th year. Loving wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Marilyn and Joe Dukoff, Hubert and Marilyn Stern and Dr. Richard and Joan Stern. Proud grandmother of Dr. Amy and Helmer Toro, Patricia and Jeffrey Vallon, Wendy Stern, Dr. Peter and Tracy Stern, David and Sharyn Dukoff, Dr. Ruth and Alan Birnbaum, Roger and Beth Stern, Jordan and Erika Stern and Dr. Joshua Stern. Loving great-grandmother of sixteen. Donations to the Max and Leila Stern Fund, Weill Cornell Medical School, 525 E. 68th Street, NY, NY 10021 would be appreciated.

title: Climbing Down from the S.U.V., and Liking the View
description: WHEN Stafford Coakley went shopping for a new vehicle a year ago, he knew exactly what he didn't want: another sport utility vehicle. After driving a 1999 Nissan Pathfinder for three years, he said, he had had enough of the high cost of filling it with gasoline and what he considered an uncomfortable ride on his commute. And he had come to realize that there was not much more space in his Pathfinder than there was in many sedans.

title: Heather Austin, Brian Teta
description: Heather Anne Austin and Brian Fredrick Teta were married yesterday at the Country Club of Hilton Head on Hilton Head Island in South Carolina. The Rev. Dr. Fred Austin, a retired Methodist minister who is the bride's paternal grandfather, officiated.

title: Mary Jo Dunnington, James Doughty
description: Mary Jo Dunnington and James Patrick Doughty were married yesterday at the West Park Winery in West Park, N.Y. The Rev. Bardet Wardell, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Fashion Returns to Upper West Side
description: HILA FEIL, a writer, stood chatting with friends last Thursday, her pewter-gray curls set off by a black V-neck T-shirt worn over a denim skirt. On her hand was a kumquat-size turquoise, on her ankle a dark tattoo of an Edward Gorey bat. Her quasi-bohemian look was difficult to place: not the Village, exactly, and not Park Slope. More than anything, she seemed to embody the low-key chic of the Upper West Side of 15 or 20 years ago.

title: Prehistoric Caves
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed "Into Prehistory in the Dordogne," by Elaine Sciolino (Sept. 5), but neither the Combarelles nor Font-de-Gaume caves had English-speaking guides when we visited two years ago.

title: IN THE REGION/Long Island; 'Affordable' Housing for the Elderly
description: IN Hempstead, a town where more than 22 percent of the residents are age 62 or older and many more are approaching that threshold, a number of projects are aiming to provide mature adults with housing that is at the low end of the price range.

title: A Shampoo Vacation
description: Conventional wisdom holds that daily shampooings (not to mention blow-drying and ironing) are the enemy of healthy hair. For those wishing to give their locks a rest, beauty companies have come up with products to keep hair smelling fresh for days at a time.

title: A Drumroll, Again, for Interest Rates
description: THE mug's game of the day is predicting interest rates. Even quoting forecasts for longer-term interest rates can be embarrassing.

title: Bittersweet Taste of Change
description: Any reluctance to change on the part of Sergio Zyman would be understandable. Yet Mr. Zyman, who managed one of the most ill-fated marketing moves ever, the introduction of New Coke, remains a relentless proselytizer of repositioning the images of products and services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOOCOCK, GLENN WINNETT
description: BOOCOCK--Glenn Winnett, 95, died peacefully at home in Santa Fe, NM on September 23rd, 2004. Born in Santa Monica, California, "Dougie" was the daughter of P.G. Winnett and Helen Hutton Winnett. Her husband, Kenyon, died in 1961. She was a graduate of the Marlborough School in Los Angeles and Miss Bennett's in Millbrook, NY. Loving mother of Susanna Weld of Essex, MA and Leslie Barclay of Santa Fe, NM. She is also survived by seven devoted grandchildren: Linzee Weld of North Yarmouth, ME, Amory Weld of Tiverton, RI: Minot Weld of Bernardsville, NJ: Kate Howard of Nantucket, MA: Rufo di Carpegna of San Anselmo, CA, Guelfo di Carpegna of New York and Allegra Castellini Baldissera of Gstaad, Switzerland and nine great-grandchildren. Formerly of New York City and Fishers Island, NY, she was a member of the Colony Club and the Fishers Island Club. She was a managing director of the Metropolitan Opera from 1976-1985. In 1987 she was awarded the Belmont Medal for distinguished service to the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Services will be private. Donations in her memory, to the Henry L. Ferguson Museum, Fishers Island, NY 06390 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, MONROE
description: LERNER--Monroe, 81, formerly of Roslyn Heights, died on September 14, 2004. Beloved husband of Julia for 58 years. Devoted father of Cynthia Franken and Lynne Lerner. Proud grandfather of Jascha and Lily Havermans. Respected father-in-law of Richard Franken and Jos Havermans. A memorial will be held on Sunday, October 17th, 2004 at 3 P.M., at the Ethical Humanist Society, 38 Old Country Road, Garden City, NY. Phone 516-741-7304.

title: The Genesis Project
description: One morning, a little more than a year from now, a group of scientists, members of what is known as the Stardust mission, will be standing around on a remote stretch of salt flat in the Utah desert, eagerly awaiting the arrival of a very special package. It will, if all goes as planned, enter our atmosphere much like a meteorite, plunging earthward until the final stage of re-entry, when a small parachute will open. The object, about the size and overall appearance of a large metal cephalopod mollusk, better known as the nautilus, will drift harmlessly to the ground, its belly filled with the dust and debris gathered from the comet Wild 2, which scientists now expect may offer significant clues about life's origins here on earth.

description: BASEBALL

title: Rats, Reconsidered
description: To the Editor:

title: The 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE NOMINEE; Kerry as the Boss: Always More Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 - For 15 minutes in Milwaukee the other day, Senator John Kerry pummeled his staff with questions about an attack on President Bush, planned for later that morning, that accused the White House of hiding a huge Medicare premium increase.

description: It's heartwarming, really.

They were in parks throughout the city, not in Park Avenue medians.

description: THE FLAWED ARCHITECT Henry Kissinger and American Foreign Policy. By Jussi Hanhimaki. Illustrated. 554 pp. Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Corrections

description: TESTED: Lincoln LS Ultimate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUNWALD, FREDERIC J.
description: GRUNWALD--Frederic J., 85, of Franklin Lakes on September 22, 2004. Born in Vienna, Austria, he lived in Hillsdale before moving to Franklin Lakes 34 years ago. He was a decorated World War II Veteran of the United States Army Intelligence and was a member of the 10th Mountain Division. He was founder and co-owner of Crazy Horse, a well known women's apparel company out of New York City and Paterson, New Jersey, prior to his retirement in 1982. He remained an avid skier and mountaineer into his early 80's. From Snowbird, Utah to helicopter skiing millions of feet in British Columbia, he was renowned in the skiing world sharing that passion with family and friends. He was also a member of the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club, a bridge club in Spring Valley, New York, enjoyed sailing, windsurfing and classical music, especially opera. In his later years he devoted a great deal of effort pursuing recovery of his family's Nazi looted Art Collection. These efforts resulted in the restitution of two well known works, Egon Schiele's portrait of his father, Karl Grunwald and Gustav Klimt's "The Embrace". Beloved husband of Ilse Grunwald (nee Deutsch). Devoted father of Cory Pollack of Scottsdale, Arizona and Debbie Cooper of Upper Saddle River. Loving grandfather of Jason Pollack, Jessica Pollack, Alison Cooper and Michele Cooper. Dear brother of Hannah Beamt of Vienna, Austria. The family will be holding a Memorial Service on Sunday, October 3, 2004 at their residence in Franklin Lakes. Friends may gather at 12:00 noon and the Service will be at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made in Mr. Grunwald's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, New York, New York 10021 or Valley Hospice, 15 Essex Road, Paramus, New Jersey 07652.

title: Search and Destroy
description: EARLIER this month, New York State made its first halting effort to slow the abuse of eminent domain power when Gov. George Pataki signed a law requiring the government to tell home and business owners in a timely manner of its plans to take over their property, giving them sufficient time to challenge the condemnation.

title: Paperback Fiction
Questions for Ted Kooser
description: I don't know Ted Kooser (Deborah Solomon, Sept. 12). I have not read his poetry. But as an Ohioan who grew up in Nebraska, I'd say you treated the nation's new poet laureate in the way you do most interesting folk from the Midwest: like some country bumpkin who wouldn't know a good poem if it bit him in his bibbed overalls. Your profile, while heavy on Big City cynicism, failed to tell readers much about Kooser the man or Kooser the poet.

title: The Dancer WhoDefected Twice
description: LI Cunxin became a ballet dancer the old-fashioned way, not for love of art but for love of food The sixth of seven sons, Mr. Li grew up on a commune in rural China at the tail end of Mao Zedong's disastrous "Great Leap Forward." In 1972, Mr. Li was one of 44 children chosen to attend Madame Mao's dance academy in Beijing.

title: Cerro Wire Tower Falls; Retail Complex Planned
description: The Cerro Wire Water Tower was razed last Tuesday, marking the end of an era for the 39-acre site in Syosset. More than 50 people gathered to watch the 150-foot tower crumble on the land whose future has become a source of heated controversy. Once a productive workplace of 600 people, the project site was vacated by the Cerro Wire Company in 1986 and has stood unused ever since.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Formula One Paves a New Road
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 25 - The drivers' title has been won, and the team title has been decided, but that seems almost beside the point as Formula One conducts the first Chinese Grand Prix here Sunday.

title: Exit the Bayman
description: EARLY last Monday morning, Dan King got into his car with his wife, Marsha, and his mother-in-law, Sarah Wethy, and drove out of East Hampton, the town that had been home to him and his ancestors since the late 1600's. The Kings were bound for North Carolina. Their house in Springs had been rented out, and their remaining belongings were traveling with them. For Mr. King, 55, one of the last full-time baymen in East Hampton, there could be no looking back.

title: New Jersey, A to Z
description: Those for whom grade school is a distant memory may be tempted to concoct a slightly less optimistic letter code -- "S is for Sopranos," say, or "L is for lame-duck governor" -- but Eileen Cameron, author of the recently published "G Is for Garden State" (Sleeping Bear Press, $17.95), does an admirable job of summing up New Jersey's cultural and historical bragging points from A to Z for 5-to 10-year-olds and anybody else reluctant to own up to the state's seedier side.

title: Welcome to the Campaign That Makes 'Selling' a President Look Good
description: Richard Nixon sat on a New York soundstage in October 1968 and pondered how to avoid looking shifty-eyed on television. The answer, he concluded, was removing everyone from his line of sight who did not have to be there. Once the room was cleared, he shot targeted commercials: one for upstate New York that included the latest Buffalo crime statistics; another for the South that argued against wasting a vote on George Wallace, the third-party candidate.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Rosabeth Moss Kanter, the author and Harvard Business School professor, misstated the name of the town on Martha's Vineyard where she has a home. It is Edgartown, not Edgarton.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOCHHAUSER, MARSHALL
description: HOCHHAUSER--Marshall. At this very special time of the year, we remember the joy of our years together; how very much you remain a part of our lives and our love that never fades. May Marshall, Mae, Sophie and Emily follow in the steps of your honored path. Love, Joyce, David, Scott and Beth

description: Ciroc The online magazine Slate recently conducted a taste test of "premium" vodkas. More interesting than which offering won (a Polish brand called Chopin, which goes for about $30 a bottle) was which one was disqualified.

description: The New York Department of Motor Vehicles is reviewing a proposal for a limited "Immigrant Driver Permit" that could allow hundreds of thousands of drivers now facing license suspension to stay on the road legally.

description: EVER since man conceived the wheel 5,000 or 6,000 years ago, he has comforted himself with the thought that design is rolling forward, from the cart to the train to the car, like an ideal cog wheeling dead-straight into the future.

description: Kelli Jo Farwell and Shana Erin Lory affirmed their partnership yesterday at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture. John Pullos, a Universal Life Church minister, led the commitment ceremony.

title: City's Odoriferous Woes Linger Long After Storm
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 24 - Heavy rains, strong winds and a storm surge could be expected, but the bubbling black sludge five days after the hurricane came as a total surprise.

description: A man shot and killed his wife in the Highland Park section of Brooklyn last night and died in a car crash about 10 minutes later, the police said.

title: QUICK BITE/Bergenfield; Laptops and Lattes
description: At the Wired Coffeehouse in Bergenfield you face a decision at the door -- to go wired or wireless. The owners, Kim and Curt Mason of Paramus, are happy to help either way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, CY
description: BLOCK--Cy, 85, passed away on September 22, 2004. Dearest husband and sweetheart of Harriet. Devoted father of Bette and Larry Gerber, Margy and Larry Bauman and Nancy and Les Perlson. Adoring grandpa of Julie, Tracy, Shaun, Erica, Ryan, Aaron & Keith. Loving great-grandfather of Jessica and Sam. Services were held on Friday.

title: John Cassavetes, Laughing Last
description: IN 1968, when he was 38 years old, the filmmaker John Cassavetes received the first of the three Academy Award nominations he would earn during his lifetime. As it happens, the nomination wasn't for any of the extraordinary personal films Cassavetes wrote and directed, but for his performance in the entertainingly crude studio bagatelle "The Dirty Dozen." In that guns-and-guts blowout, a World War II pulp fiction directed by Robert Aldrich, Cassavetes plays a gangster turned soldier whose independence provokes brutal beatings from his costars -- Lee Marvin, Charles Bronson and Jim Brown. Even when he played the Hollywood game, Cassavetes took it on the chin.

title: Suffolk Anger Rises Over Tourism Group
description: SOUTHAMPTON - AS the Suffolk County district attorney's office continues to investigate allegations that the former Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau president was living large on the taxpayers' tab, some motel and resort operators from the Island's busiest tourist destination, Montauk, have urged that Suffolk secede from the tourism agency.

title: Social Security: Paths and Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: DataBank; Stocks Decline on Weak Outlook for Earnings
description: All three main stock gauges fell last week after several companies downgraded earnings outlooks, the price of crude oil climbed back to near $50 a barrel and the Federal Reserve raised its benchmark short-term interest rate by a quarter-point for the third time since June.

title: 3-Bedrooms Soar as New York Nests
description: Correction Appended

title: Governor-in-Waiting Picks a Battle
description: Newark - IF Richard J. Codey has his way, the financing for the prosecutor's offices in four of the state's busiest counties will shift from those counties to Trenton.

description: The perfect game. It's one of baseball's most elusive events. It means that a pitcher faces 27 batters who return to the dugout without ever reaching first base. Since Cy Young had one in 1904, it has happened only 16 times.

title: At Cole Pond, Nostalgia Is Overcome by Reality
description: ENFIELD, N.H. - Responding to a nostalgic urge to revisit Cole Pond this month, I was chagrined to discover that the steep, rocky, winding trail to it, which is less than a mile long, was much more challenging than I had remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARL, LEONARD P.
description: PEARL--Leonard P., 82, advertising executive, artist. Leonard Pearl died at home on September 18. He was President of Leonard Pearl, Inc., an advertising agency in Manhattan, whose clients included Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall. Immediately after graduating from CCNY in 1942, Leonard enlisted in the army in World War II, serving in the Pacific. His creativity emerged at CCNY, where, near completion of a chemical engineering degree he decided to pursue his studies in art, ultimately graduating with a fine arts degree. A renaissance man, Mr. Pearl's artistic talents extended to building fine furniture, but, always modest about his extraordinary skills, he built it only for his family's personal use. Later in life he discovered his passion for sailing and became a Commodore of the Hempstead Sailing Club, racing his sailboat until his health no longer permitted. Survived by his wife Claudia, daughter Alison Edelman, son Steven Pearl, a comedian in Los Angeles, and sister Rhoda Lubalin. Leonard's pride and joy was his only grandchild, David Edelman, 13.

title: Florida Braces For Strike 4 As 2 Million Are Told to Go
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Sept. 25 - With a fury familiar to millions of Floridians but no less terrifying, Hurricane Jeanne came ashore Saturday night, bending palm trees in the sideways rain, exploding transformers in showers of blue and white sparks and turning pieces of homes into road-skipping debris.

title: Reading Fannie Mae's Scary Cookbook
description: A SHOCKING expos hit the Street last week about one of the best-loved all-American companies: Fannie Mae, the mortgage and financial services giant. The report, written by the company's regulator, the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, offered a litany of accounting improprieties at the company. You might call it "In the Kitchen With Fannie: How to Cook the Books for Fun and Profit."

title: What if America Just Pulled Out?
description: EVEN by its own disturbing standards, this was a hallucinatory week in Iraq. Beheadings, kidnappings, bombings, outbreaks of deadly disease and everyday mayhem were accompanied by interim Prime Minister Ayad Allawi's upbeat statement to Congress: "We are succeeding in Iraq."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AQUILONE, PETER N.
description: AQUILONE--Peter N. On September 22, 2004, at age 34. Beloved son of Carmen and Edward, brother of Edward and Matthew. A life of good works unfinished. He joins his brothers Michael and Vincent; another star in Heaven. A graduate of Bishop Ford High School, Fordham University and Benjamin Cardozo School of Law. A first rate track athlete in high school and college who developed into a first class golfer. An attorney, he worked with the National Hockey League. Served as New York City Regional Director of the Empire State Games; gave generously of his time to Special Olympics and Habitat for Humanity. He is missed by a legion of family, friends and colleagues. Services: Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Brooklyn, Sunday and Monday, September 26 and 27, from 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Mass of the Resurrection: Tuesday, September 28, 9:30 am, Our Lady Help of Christians R.C. Church, E. 28 St and Ave M in Brooklyn. Family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to Special Olympics New York, 211 E. 43 St., NY, NY 10017.

title: An Eye on Albany
description: The State Assembly met briefly in Albany last week and accomplished almost nothing. That's a dog-bites-man headline if we ever heard one. One vote short of the number needed to override any of Gov. George Pataki's budget vetoes, the Democratic majority staged a series of purely symbolic votes and went home. For want of that one member (three Democrats stayed away, presumably in an effort to curry favor with Mr. Pataki), the Assembly was deprived of the chance to actually pass the overrides, which then would have become purely symbolic in the absence of any action by the Republican State Senate.

title: How Hong Kong Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Martial Arts
description: THE delirious and often dazzling cinema of Hong Kong has picked up more than its share of Western admirers in the last 15 or 20 years, and to most of us latter-day fans in the mysterious Occident these movies -- films like Tsui Hark's "Peking Opera Blues" (1986) and John Woo's "Better Tomorrow" (1986) -- seemed to come out of nowhere. But they didn't. As a sidebar to the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is mounting a 12-movie retrospective (beginning Saturday) devoted to the productions of the Shaw Brothers -- Runde, Runme and Run Run -- whose studio once dominated Hong Kong's film industry. The earliest movie in the series dates from 1958; the most recent came out in 1976. What we have, then, is a tasting menu of Hong Kong cinema in a time before Tsui Hark and John Woo and Wong Kar-wai. And while you may not want to order most of these dishes again, they're all worth sampling once.

title: Windsurfers Ride Out a Political Tempest

More recently the ultra-rad sport of kite-boarding has cut into windsurfing's appeal. But no single period has been as difficult for windsurfing enthusiasts as the last few weeks, when critics of the Democratic presidential candidate, Senator John Kerry, an avid windsurfer, have used the sport to deride him.

title: The Executive
description: As the senior corporate vice president of Este Lauder Companies and the founder and chairman of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Evelyn H. Lauder exudes power. But her clothes reveal a playful side. "I'm happiest wearing things that clash," she said. "I have a light-blue suit that I wear with a poison-green T-shirt, and the colors just sing." Other favorite pairings include a studded Oscar de la Renta biker jacket with a pink chiffon skirt. "I don't wear beige," said Mrs. Lauder, who is married to the late Este Lauder's son Leonard. "My husband says it doesn't do much for me. The closest I get to beige is camel."

title: Questions for Ted Kooser
description: Does it matter whether or not Ted Kooser has read contemporary European poets or if he's been to London or Paris? Hey, your own magazine called Shakespeare "the son of a provincial glovemaker." Maybe not everyone needs to be world-traveled and New York urbane to have something worthwhile to say.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHAPIRO, ELSIE
description: SHAPIRO--Elsie. September 27, 1992. Remembered forever with love.

title: A Thin Blue Lie, Admitted at Last
description: It was the coldest of cold cases. Twenty years had passed without an arrest in the killing of Officer Ronald S. Stapleton, who was found shot twice in the stomach with his own revolver, his right eye gouged out, in the parking lot of a Brooklyn bar in 1977. The police investigation had stalled; private detectives hired by his family were stymied, and their $5,000 reward for information went unclaimed.

title: Trumpologies
description: What is appealing about Donald J. Trump is his innocence and neediness (James Traub, Sept. 12). His brashness is that of a child in a playground, fists clenched, voice overly loud, desperately wanting friends yet driving them away by his very demands for their attention. "Look at me, watch me, love me," he seems to be saying. "Look at my TV show, look at my deals, look at my buildings."

title: What Can and Can't Be Done About North Korea and Iran
description: WASHINGTON - FOR weeks now, while American television screens have been tuned to bombings and beheadings in Iraq, an alternate set of high-definition images from spy satellites have been popping up on the monitors at the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, LYNN GORDON, JR.
description: BAILEY--Lynn Gordon, Jr. ("Gordie") of Dallas, TX died tragically in his sleep the morning of September 17, 2004, at 18 years of age in Boulder, CO where he had recently enrolled as a freshman at the University of Colorado, Leeds School of Business. In his short time at the University, Gordie had been named to the club lacrosse team and had become a pledge at Chi Psi Fraternity. Gordie went to Colorado after three years at Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, MA where he excelled in athletics and drama. In his senior year he was co-captain of the varsity football team. He also started at defense on the school's New England championship lacrosse team. At graduation he received the Class of 2004 Award of Excellence in Drama. Gordie mentored younger students as a Proctor in an underclass dormitory. Prior to Deerfield, Gordie attended St. Marks School of Texas in Dallas where he developed his love for football and lacrosse. He especially enjoyed his time in Sun Valley, ID visiting his father where he loved to snowboard, fly fish, hike and play golf. He also vacationed frequently in Jamaica and was a huge fan of its Reggae music. Gordie taught himself to play the guitar, which had become a passion. The many people whose lives he touched remember Gordie for his intelligence, leadership, compassion, humor, happiness and an uplifting attitude towards everyone and everything he encountered. All who knew him felt his joy for life. His goal to be a positive role model was enabled by his gift of putting a smile on everyone's face. At Deerfield, Gordie and some friends started the "Hug Club," just one of the many legendary "Gordieisms." Gordie cherished his special relationship with his closest friend, Lily. Gordie is survived by his extended family including his mother, Leslie Herrlinger Lanahan; father, Lynn Gordon Bailey; step-mother Claire Bailey; step-father, Michael Lanahan; sisters Bibb Bailey and Lily Lanahan; grandparents Marcia and Richard Rorick; Kim and Edward F. Herrlinger; W. Wallace Lanahan, Jr. and greatgrandmother, Ruth Mills Van Every. Gordie also has four step-brothers, five uncles, five aunts, nine first cousins and a nephew. There will be a memorial gathering at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA on Sunday, September 26th at 1:00pm. A memorial service was held in Dallas at St. Mark's School of Texas. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to the newly established Gordie Bailey Memorial Fund, Deerfield, MA, 01342

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, ROBERT
description: LEWIS--Robert. On September 24, 2004. Beloved husband of Edith Lewis. Dear brother of Jerri (Jonas Greenfield) Wachtell and brother George Wachtell. Services Monday, September 27, 1:00 PM "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Lessons of Classroom 506
description: Lisa Belkin's stunning article (Sept. 12) about Thomas Ellenson and his loving parents seems to be the kind of contribution that could change laws and lives. Belkin's ability to meld sensitive observations with clear explanations of complex public policy and educational issues made the piece feel complete. I imagine it will be read by many, in schools throughout America and perhaps the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTSCHALK, PAULA
description: GOTTSCHALK -- Paula. 59, passed away September 21, 2004 following years of battling recurrent, progressive brain tumors. She worked in a variety of positions with CBS Radio and CBS Inc. from 1971 through 1982, most notably as Vice President, Corporate Information, CBS Inc., from 1979 through 1982.

title: Urge to Surge
description: 'Support for Kerry-Edwards Surges Across the Country" read a July press release from Kerry-Edwards campaign headquarters. President Bush, too, likes the urgent verb; he told a veterans' convention in August of his plans to move troops to new locations outside Europe, "so they can surge quickly to deal with unexpected threats." This military usage has become a favorite at the Pentagon; Douglas Feith, under secretary of defense for policy, wrote in The Washington Post about troops "that can be 'surged' in quickly."

title: Editors' Note; Note to Readers
description: What's your favorite hardware store, fish market, luncheonette? Readers are invited to submit their choices for the crme de la crme of Long Island shops -- stores found along a Main Street or in a downtown area -- in whatever category comes to mind: pub, card store, ice cream parlor. Suggestions will be sifted for an article scheduled to appear in the "Long Island at Its Best" special section in November. E-mail: lishops@nytimes .com.

title: How to Insure a Co-op Apartment
description: Q A group of neighbors in our co-op recently received insurance renewal notices, and we are discussing whether to increase our coverage. Is it enough to insure for an amount that covers the contents of the apartment or is it better to insure for the market value of the apartment? . . . Gerald A. Koval, Manhattan.

description: WHILE living in Tokyo in the early 1990's with her journalist husband and their two young children, Roberta Beary practiced law during the day and the art of haiku at night.

description: PROFESSIONAL investors have often found Continental Europe to be an inhospitable place for their money. Heavy regulation and bloated staffing, they say, have limited corporate profitability and growth potential, leaving them unwilling to wait for the overhauls in economic policy that governments have long promised.

description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 25 - Robby Gordon plans to join the oil spills, the tire chunks, the sharp pieces of debris and the other typical racetrack hazards on Sunday.

title: Corrections

They were in parks throughout the city, not in Park Avenue medians.
