description: NEMET--Susan Rory. An inspiration to many. Curator of education at Westmoreland Museum of Art. Beloved aunt, sister, sister-in-law and friend. Passed September 23rd after a valiant struggle with cancer.

Cherished brother of Ellen Epstein and Barbara Blum. Life Member of SAE & AMS. "Bud's impact on the Aerospace Industry will be a lasting legacy." Bud's musical genius will never be forgotten.

title: They're Coming Through the Vents! Attack of the Subway Cellphones
description: A middle-aged businessman in a gray suit clicked open his cellphone on a recent morning and started talking. "Yes. Uh-huh. O.K. Tell Bill I'll call him as soon as I get to the office." He was completing a simple procedure that plays out countless times each day in New York. But with one noticeable difference: the man was riding the No. 9 train from Chambers Street to Franklin Street.

title: The Arsenal
description: Most people get through life with only three or four recipes. But why not be able to make more than just a handful of dishes? The world is filled with recipes; what it needs is someone to toss out the clunkers and whittle the other possibilities down, creating an arsenal of dishes that amount to a true cooking repertory -- everything from seasonal dishes to time-honored classics to the oddball concoction that feeds a cook's desire for an occasional moment of whimsy.

title: Cindy Rajkov, Adeo Ressi
description: Cindy Cica Rajkov and Adeo Gregory Ressi di Cervia were married yesterday on a bluff overlooking the Napeague Bay in East Hampton, N.Y. Shawn Gold, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: In Newark, Cory Booker Reloads
description: NEWARK - SEATED on a bench outside the housing complex he calls home, Cory Booker was looking away, his sentences fading. Suddenly he stopped.

title: Sex Books: The Elements of Sexual Style
description: SEX books come in as wide a variety as sex itself: some are educational but too technical, some are purely entertaining but hold little long-lasting value, while others have enticing premises but ultimately prove to be numbingly dull. These books are usually tucked away in poorly lighted sections in the back of bookshops, like triple-X videos, forcing embarrassed readers to wander all the aisles. Yet the journey can be worthwhile. There is no magical combination of tricks to turn any of us into champion lovers, but we can't help hoping. As Woody Allen put it, "Love is the answer, but while you're waiting for the answer, sex raises some pretty interesting questions."

title: No. 1 Southern Cal Absorbs the Blows, Then Battles Back
description: STANFORD, Calif., Sept. 25 - An upset is all about timing. Stanford had dominant plays from its wide receivers, a fake field goal and a long touchdown run with time running out against No. 1 Southern California Saturday evening. But the Cardinal needed all those plays in the fourth quarter, not in the second.

title: Colette Bonnard, R. Scott Edmonds
description: Colette Bonnard and R. Scott Edmonds, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Forget It?
description: What's interesting about the 9/11 griefathon is the political choreography that has turned a national tragedy into a Pavlovian exercise: politician invokes 9/11; audience obediently bursts into tears. At the same time, the continued loss of American soldiers in Iraq is sloughed off with glib platitudes like "Freedom isn't free."

title: 'Why Marriage Matters'
description: Depending on which linguistic expert you ask,there are anywhere from two thousand to seventhousand different languages spoken in the worldtoday. That's a huge number to put your mindaround - even for someone who lives inManhattan, where seemingly hundreds of thoselanguages can be heard on the subway on anygiven day. Still, I'm willing to bet that eachof these languages has something in common withthe others: a word that means marriage.

title: Storm Warning on Home Insurance Front
description: HOME insurers are facing damage claims that may run into the billions in hurricane-wracked Florida, but insurance experts and regulators said last week that home insurance premiums and wind deductibles on hurricane-prone Long Island would be unaffected, at least for the foreseeable future.

title: 'Just Enough Liebling'

title: The Director's Director
description: Late one night in March of last year, in a crumbling area on the island of Macao off Hong Kong, a film crew milled around in the street, awaiting the arrival of Wong Kar-wai. In life as in art, Wong tends to make you acutely aware of time. His films are filled with clocks and calendars. He is also notorious for keeping people waiting: waiting for his films to go into production, waiting for the shooting day to begin and waiting for a recognizable story and structure to emerge from his long, uncertain process. This particular night, the crew was setting up to shoot scenes from Wong's eighth film, "2046," an ambitious, star-studded, futuristic drama. (Its title refers to the 49th year after the 1997 British handover of Hong Kong.) There was nothing futuristic about the location: a dilapidated block bathed in a latticework of shadows and artificial golden light, it resembled the 1960's Hong Kong the director conjured for his previous film, the acclaimed "In the Mood for Love."

title: Bringing Up Me
description: Six months ago, my girlfriend and I decided to look for a house. As expeditions go, this was an arduous, some would say crazy, undertaking, since over the last 10 years London real estate, already among the world's most expensive, has tripled in value. Still, because we're both writers, dreamers by definition, we pooled our resources and entered the scrabbling mud fight. Two months ago, miraculously, we found a Victorian terraced house in the run-down borough of Hackney, with a garden and three bedrooms, looking out over a greensward the locals call a conservation area. We fought tooth and nail against another buyer, until our offer was accepted. Then, last week, two weeks before we would own it, there was a hitch. Over a cup of Earl Grey tea, my girlfriend sweetly told me that she wanted kids.

title: David B. Pall, 90, Invented Filters for Blood, Is Dead
description: Dr. David B. Pall, a chemist who invented dozens of sophisticated filters, most notably for purifying blood for transfusions, died Tuesday at his home in Roslyn Estates, N.Y. He was 90.

description: MALLER--Jane Kotzen, 4/4/33--9/23/2000 Time passes but love remains forever.

title: The Big Airline Profit Margins? Look at Regionals
description: If you want to travel a popular 2,000-mile route -- especially if it's served by one of those low-cost airlines that are such thorns in the wings of old-line carriers -- the competition is so fierce that the airlines will practically pay you to hop aboard.

title: The Lessons of Classroom 506
description: From the late 1970's into the 1990's, we were part of a tenacious team of parents who collaborated with our school system to design an inclusive education model for five children with significant disabilities. In 1997, these kids graduated with their friends (typically developing peers) from their local high school. Today, our daughter (who has Down syndrome) maintains her own apartment, takes public transportation to her receptionist job at the Y.M.C.A. and is a contributing and respected member of her community. How sad that after 25 years shaping inclusive education policy is still dependent on the parents who are most vocal and persistent. Our message to the Ellensons is, No matter how difficult the journey, stay the course.

title: Nicole Micco, Keith Garwood
description: Nicole LaFleur Micco, the daughter of Nancy-Ellen Micco of New York and Dr. David J. Micco Jr. of Manville, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Keith Matthew Garwood, the son of Ann M. Garwood of Glastonbury, Conn., and the late Dr. Gary J. Garwood. The Rev. Jon Walton officiated at the First Presbyterian Church of New York. The Rev. Ian Alexander, another Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: The U.S. Race in Arabic Newspapers
description: THAT the Arab Middle East should be interested in the American presidential election is no surprise. What may be surprising is the degree to which support in the Arabic language press is split between President Bush and Senator John Kerry.

title: Striper Madness
description: All but a few of the great North American wildlife migrations are history. Thundering oceans of buffalo no longer darken the Plains. There still are birds, of course, and butterflies, and salmon out West. But to signal the change of seasons, we in the suburbs can no longer rely on mass movements of large and hungry vertebrates. Instead, we take note of the changing quality of sunlight, and the late-summer Halloween ads.

title: A New 'Tanner' Joins the Race
description: THERE are few things as totally over as a failed presidential candidate. Think Michael Dukakis and Jack Kemp. So why were so many bigwigs at the Democratic convention in Boston running over each other to see Jack Tanner? Tom Brokaw descends from his NBC skybox to chat him up on the floor of the Fleet Center. Dick Gephardt seems to mean it when he says he missed him on the trail in Iowa. Even the new Democratic It Boy, Ron Reagan, whose anti-Bush stem cell speech was one of the convention's highlights, eagerly clears his schedule for him.

title: Can Biotech Crops Be Good Neighbors?
description: TOIVO LAHTI grows papaya on the Big Island of Hawaii. Over the last few years, he watched other growers start planting trees that were genetically engineered to resist a devastating virus. But Mr. Lahti stuck to conventional varieties for his organic orchard, and thought it would remain free of biotechnology, which he opposes.

title: League's Best Relievers Lift Rangers Back Into Pennant Race
description: SEVENTEEN days ago the Texas Rangers dropped six games from first place in the American League West and seemed to have come to the end of their magical ride. No division championship for them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLATT, RHODA
description: PLATT--Rhoda. 90, died September 17, 2004. Cherished by daughter Judith Trepp Dubs, grandchildren Selina and Donner Trepp, brother Julian and sister Eleanor. Contributions to Fine Arts Work Center, Provincetown, MA 06257.

description: BIG DANCE THEATER A "Plan B." Dance Theater Workshop, 219 W. 19th St. (212) 924-0077. Thur.-Sat., 7:30. Through Oct. 9.

title: Introduction
description: Readers were riveted by Lisa Belkin's account of the "inclusion" of a disabled boy in a public-school kindergarten class. Many called the efforts of his father heroic, though some said his advocacy insured special treatment. Other letter writers weighed in on the pros and cons of "getting over" 9/11.

title: Schrder's Opponents Get 2nd Setback in 2 Weeks
description: BERLIN, Sept. 26 A Chancellor Gerhard SchrAder's Social Democrats were celebrating today after voters in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's most populous state, punished Angela Merkel's opposition conservative Christian Democrats and gave her party its second big election setback in two weeks.

title: Al Qaeda Tries to Upset Afghan Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 25 - Al Qaeda is present along the border region of Pakistan and Afghanistan and is encouraging Afghan insurgents to disrupt presidential elections scheduled in just two weeks, on Oct. 9, the commander of American forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David Barno, said Saturday.

title: Kindness (Ugh!) of Strangers
description: The first-class cabin on the American Airlines flight leaving Heathrow in July was suitably hushed. Then along came my flight attendant, who remarked, when I ordered a second champagne, "Partying tonight, huh?" When she found out that I was a writer from Manhattan, she asked if I could get her an advance copy of a novel by her favorite author, which she was absolutely dying to read.

title: The Lessons of Classroom 506
description: As the parent of a 25-year-old man with developmental disabilities, I read Belkin's article with great interest. Each night we go to bed knowing that we have done what we can do. Some days are better than others. The Ellensons' battle to make their son truly feel part of a community has only begun. This journey will continue past educational settings into the world of adult services. This is the world that I now find myself in as we help our son create a life of true self-determination.

title: Failing the Grade System
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg reignited the social promotion debate this month by announcing that fifth graders who do poorly on standardized tests will not be promoted to the sixth grade.

title: How the Modern Said 'Cheese' for Almost 3 Years
description: MICHAEL WESELY first began taking photographs of the Museum of Modern Art in New York in the summer of 2001 and finished only a few months ago. In the intervening years, he maintained a constant, if subtle, presence in midtown Manhattan. Over the course of the museum's transformation, Mr. Wesely photographed the construction site between West 53rd Street and West 54th Street 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. And when he finally stopped, he found his thousands of hours of shooting had yielded successful pictures. Five, to be exact.

I can see Riverside Church shadowing public housing buildings. I can also see New Jersey, sometimes watching the sky darken long before the sun has called it a day, the rain tapping across the Hudson River, ultimately dancing on my windows.

description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION/Connecticut; Where Casinos Flourish, Condos Follow
description: GRISWOLD - DEANNA AND JEAN DENIS run an auction house in Jewett City, a borough of Griswold, Conn., where they have both lived all their lives. But the housing market is so strong in their town that they have decided to seek to convert a 3.5-acre parcel behind their business into a 39-unit condominium complex.

title: A Journey to the Center of the Earth, or So It Seems
description: As the environmental program director of the Urban Divers Estuary Conservancy, an environmental group committed to restoring, protecting and promoting New York's waterways, Ludger Balan has spent years studying the Gowanus Canal. Yet the murky, heavily polluted channel that cuts through South Brooklyn still has the potential to confound, as it did recently when Mr. Balan dove to extract a core sample of white material from the bottom, but found instead that there seemingly was no bottom.

title: Launching the Newest Ships
description: The shipbuilding surge that has lasted more than a decade has finally slowed. According to the Cruise Lines International Association, Its members will probably have no more than six major cruise liners entering service through the end of next year, compared with 13 in 2003. But the trend toward more luxurious accommodations continues, particularly the addition of private balconies for mini-suites as well as large suites and larger spas. With persistent concerns about terrorism, cruise lines have adjusted itineraries, most notably bypassing the Suez Canal. But at least one company, Crystal Cruises, has decided to use the canal on its next world cruise in January.

It was again six months ago, when a violent uprising against his increasingly authoritarian rule drove Mr. Aristide from power.

title: Women in Bikinis? Turn Off That Evil TV
description: Call it subtraction by, yes, subtraction. Skimpier bathing suits and a skimpier show added up to skimpier television ratings for the Miss America pageant last Saturday night.

title: Why Wait? Here's a Pre-Debate Quiz
description: Instructions for candidates: Pretend each question is coming from Jim Lehrer, the moderator of the debate, and choose the one answer most likely to please swing voters watching on television on Thursday night. Do not assume that voters want to hear your innermost feelings, let alone the truth.

title: Engines of Change
description: Have seen a new Toyota Prius up close. I have touched it and smelled it and, without even needing to pull the key or "fob" from my pocket, where the car can sense it just fine, pushed its gigantic iBook-like starter button and driven it for miles and miles, fast and slow. I have been awed by the dreamy blue-green digital dashboard gauges, which seem so very far away from the steering wheel as to be reachable by only an N.B.A. player. I have, in one trip, with the two back seats down, easily hauled two air-conditioners and a 37-pound bag of dog food in the hatchback, The Prius isn't small, the way it used to be.

title: Getting Parenthood a Place on Rsums
description: BECOMING a parent can make you a better worker. That was the simple message of my last column. Far from simple, however, is making this message an accepted truth of the workplace, so that being a parent is seen by employers as a solid credential.

title: 7 Iraqi Guard Applicants, 4 U.S. Marines and a Soldier Are Killed
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 25 - Seven Iraqi men applying for jobs with the Iraqi National Guard were ambushed and killed in western Baghdad on Saturday morning, while the United States military said four marines and a soldier had been killed over 24 hours.

title: A SURPRISE IN THE POLLS
description: A few weeks ago, conventional wisdom had it that New Jersey was John Kerry's for the asking. He had a double-digit lead in a state that voted overwhelmingly for Al Gore in 2000 and has no Republicans in statewide office. A new poll by Quinnipiac University in Hamden, Conn., however, indicates that New Jersey is no longer a Democratic slam dunk. The survey, released last week, shows that Mr. Kerry and President Bush are neck and neck in the state. Both took 48 percent of those surveyed; Ralph Nader accounted for 2 percent. Among registered voters, Mr. Kerry had a small lead, 47 to 43 percent. The results square with other polls with similarly bad news for Mr. Kerry. A recent Star-Ledger/Eagleton Institute poll had Mr. Kerry ahead by just 4 points; he had been ahead by 20 points in August. "What this suggests is that the Republicans may spend a little time stirring the pot in New Jersey, and the Democrats may have to play defense in a state where they didn't think they'd have to do that," said Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute. "Does this mean that New Jersey all of a sudden is a battleground state? Most politicians would probably say no, but you never know. One thing is for sure: If Bush looks like he'll carry New Jersey, it's a signal that this thing is over." Terry Golway

title: Hardcover Highlights
Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the 'listed at' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Facing an Armada of Patatas in Spain
description: MY girlfriend, Wendy, and I were strolling along a street in Madrid, trying to find the Palacio Real when a snack bar marquee caught my eye: "Churros y Patatas."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROTH, IDA
description: ROTH--Ida, Sept. 26, 2000. Our beloved Granny, four years in a world without you. Forever in our hearts. Diane and Larry

title: A Campus Awakens In a Corner of Camden
description: CAMDEN - ASK the provost of the Rutgers campus here about this troubled city's long-awaited reawakening, and he'll show you the door. And the trim around the ceiling. And the newly restored floor.

title: Turkish Currency Loses Six Zeros
description: As of Jan. 1, the cost of a cup of coffee in Turkey will no longer run into the millions. As of that date, the old Turkish lira will be divested of six zeros and the new Turkish lira, or YTL, will be circulated as bank notes in denominations of 1, 5, 10, 20, 50 and 100.

title: The Airport as Flight Boutique
description: NORTH CASTLE - GONE are the days when the Westchester County Airport operated from a ramshackle Quonset hut -- when lines snaked out the door and cars were parked at all angles on grassy embankments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIDSON, RICHARD
description: DAVIDSON -- Richard, 87, Ridgefield Park, NJ, September 11, 2004. Loving husband to Marguerite and father of Denise. Grandfather of George and Caroline. US Air Force WWII. Market Manager, McLean Trucking, retired 1982. Textile Square Club, the Les Amis du Vin. Memorial service planned.

title: A Continuing Shame
description: Native Americans came in great numbers to Washington last week, partly to celebrate, partly to correct a historic injustice. The occasion was the opening of the National Museum of the American Indian on the National Mall -- a vivid reminder of the profound cultural and symbolic legacy of America's indigenous peoples. In the background, however, was a continuing lawsuit, whose purpose is to restore to the Indians assets and revenues that are rightfully theirs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANSELMI, JOSE L.
description: ANSELMI--Jose L. November 29, 1949-September 11, 2004. Born in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico. Jose moved to New York City in 1969 and attended FIT. Jose worked his entire professional life as a respected and much loved hair designer for Jeniette's, Seventh Heaven, Bluni Rea, and Barney's NY, among others. Jose leaves partner and best friend, Bernard C. Durham; friend, Burt Lazarin; cousins, Carmen Monclova of San Juan, P.R., Wilmer Velez of NYC, and many other relatives in the United States and Puerto Rico, as well as numerous other friends and countless grateful clients. Jose lived a very happy and full life and he brought joy into the lives of everyone he met. He will be sorely missed by all. Contributions in Jose's name may be made to God's Love We Deliver and to the New York City Opera. Funeral Mass is to be held at Stella Maris R.C. Church in San Juan, P.R., at 6:00 PM, September 30, 2004. Memorial in Jose's honor is to be held on October 24, 2004, from 1PM to 3PM at Identity House, 39 W. 14 Street, 2nd Floor, NYC.

title: A Big Increase of New Voters in Swing States
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio - A sweeping voter registration campaign in heavily Democratic areas has added tens of thousands of new voters to the rolls in the swing states of Ohio and Florida, a surge that has far exceeded the efforts of Republicans in both states, a review of registration data shows.

title: Education Is Paramount
description: To the Editor:

title: Relievers Are Lucky the Yankees Didn't Need This Game
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 - Joe Torre had used his best setup man for two innings on Friday, bringing an October strategy to a game the Yankees needed in September.

title: Corrections: Eccentric, Essential and Ready for an Upgrade
description: FEW things irritate (or amuse) readers of The Times more than the corrections that appear daily on Page A2. The runic syntax, the elliptic references, the straight-faced earnestness of a prose style that has acquired the gloss of self-parody -- they may offer their own eccentric delights, but they don't necessarily give readers, or bruised story subjects, what they want.

description: SENATOR JOHN KERRY and President Bush tried to focus the nation's attention on two totally different countries last week, and both of them were Iraq.

title: Forget It?
description: Walter Kirn's attitude does not only seem "blasphemously insensitive"; it is dangerous. We endured a first attack on the World Trade Center in 1993 and the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole prior to 9/11. Too many people with his attitude treated those incidents by burying them in a spot which only they could locate. Look at the consequences of that kind of denial. Keep watching MTV.

title: Corrections
description: A "Scene Stealers" article in the New Season issue on Sept. 12 about Gerard Butler, star of the film musical "Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Phantom of the Opera," misidentified the lyricists. They are Charles Hart and Richard Stilgoe, not Lord Lloyd Webber.

title: Police Say Drunken Driver Hit Car, Killing Four Teenagers
description: Four teenagers celebrating a 17-year-old friend's birthday died in a fiery car accident on Long Island early yesterday morning when a drunken driver crashed into their Honda sedan, the Nassau County police said. After being struck on its side, the Honda smashed into a telephone pole and exploded.

description: He founded easyJet, the low-fare European airline, then branched off into easyCar auto rentals, easyHotel lodging and easyPizza delivery. Now the entrepreneur Stelios Haji-Ioannou is bringing his no-frills approach to corporate governance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, CECELIA
description: SHAPIRO--Cecelia. Of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn and Howard Beach. Died at 87 on September 23, 2004. Brooklyn College Class of 1939. Worked side by side with her beloved husband Joe (deceased) in their deli at Hegeman & Amboy in Brownsville. Enlightened and energetic, she was president of the parents' association of P.S. 165 and started the Girl Scouts in her community. In the early 60's she became a New York City school teacher. Survived by devoted daughters Abbe DiMatteo (Bernie) and Michele TrontzGrossman (Bill). She was a second mother to grandchildren Robert (Natalya), David (Francesca) and Jennifer DiMatteo and Ian (Jennifer) and Larry Trontz. She was blessed with two great-grandchildren: Esme Trontz, who loved and adored her, and Jason DiMatteo, newly arrived. Her love for her family was boundless and we will always miss her. She was an exceptional woman. Also survived by brother Ben Rabinowitz and sisters-in-law Laura Shapiro and Sylvette Goldwert and nieces and nephews. Graveside service 11 a.m. Monday at (Old) Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Blvd., Queens.

description: To the Editor:

title: When Employees Are Sick, Absenteeism Can Be a Virtue
description: Correction Appended

title: How Green Is Our Energy
description: Americans have come to understand that there is a price for depending on fossil fuels as the main source of electrical power. The particulates and other pollution produced by coal-fired -- and, to a lesser extent, gas-fired -- power plants damage air, water and soil and contribute to asthma and other health problems.

title: Page Two: Sept. 19-25; SINGER NON GRATA
description: The Department of Homeland Security diverted a London-to-Washington flight to Bangor, Me., last week to detain one passenger -- Yusuf Islam, the former pop star once known as Cat Stevens (and, before that, as Steven Demetre Georgiou). Officials said that the singer's charitable contributions may have made their way to terrorist groups and that he should not have been allowed on the plane in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KARP, LEONARD DAVID
description: KARP--Leonard David. 9/26/24--10/15/68 Happy 80th Birthday! You left 36 years ago. I wish we shared more than 10 years. You are in my heart, soul and eyes forever. I will never forget you. Your daughter, Carolyn

title: Applying Politics to U.S.-Europe Relations
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 25 - With its bewildering bureaucracy, the European Union often seems like the array of councils, commissions and commissariats that once prompted Henry Kissinger to say that he wanted to talk to Europe but did not know whom to call.

title: Designs for Living
description: Q: Your new exhibition on the future of design, "Massive Change," is opening at the Vancouver Art Gallery this Friday. Isn't it a conflict of interest for a designer to curate a survey of contemporary design?

title: Misplaced Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: MY favorite scene in Todd Graff's CAMP (2003), about teenagers at a special summer camp for aspiring stage stars, belongs to Anna Kendrick as sweet, humble Fritzi. Furious with her witchy blond friend Jill (Alana Allen), for good reason, Fritzi feeds her Woolite. When Jill begins throwing up onstage while trying to sing "Ladies Who Lunch," the hardened-broad anthem from "Company," there's Fritzi in the wings, in wig, makeup and costume, ready to go on for her, which she does, brilliantly. You probably have to love Broadway musicals to forgive this film its flaws. Or to get a kick out of adolescents singing the poignant "Losing My Mind" from "Follies." But if you do, you'll be as thrilled as the campers are by the surprise cameo near the end. Daniel Letterle plays the only straight boy at camp, and Robin de Jesus is the boy who worships him -- Friday at 4:30 p.m. on Starz.

title: First, So Close. Now, So Far.
description: Six years ago, when he was an executive vice president at General Motors, Louis R. Hughes was in the running to be the next chief executive of United Airlines. In the end, though, the job went to James E. Goodwin.

title: Visions of an Another Trendy Enclave
description: PENNSAUKEN - A swampy river smell rises up from the weed-choked banks of the Delaware River. Oil tanks loom over the New Jersey shoreline and across the river in Philadelphia. Freight trains and 18 wheelers rumble in and out of warehouses set along the industrial waterfront.

title: Chipping Away at Harlem
description: In many ways, New York still embodies the "two Americas." Even with Harlem's second renaissance under way, for many life remains as unequal as ever. And although Harlem is one of the city's leading tourist destinations, visitors hoping to see the fabled Harlem of yore instead find a disenchanting vista of parking lots and forgettable buildings standing where the Cotton Club, the Lafayette and Audubon Theaters, Small's Paradise and the Savoy used to be.

title: Indian Sales of Tobacco Face New Pressure
description: IRVING, N.Y. - Many people would love to put Larry Ballagh out of business. All antismoking groups, for instance. The National Association of Convenience Stores, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEDY, OTTO W.
description: KENNEDY--Otto W., 98. Born Vienna, Austria, November 14, 1905, died August 12, 2004. A lawyer, like his father, Dr. Julius Knopfmacher, Otto left Vienna in 1938 after the Nazi invasion. He fled to England, then New York City,and retired to Los Angeles, Ca. He served in the US Air Force during WWII. Married 34 years to his beloved wife, Eva Kennedy. Brilliant and charming, he will be missed by his sister-in-law Lily, nieces Lilo and Ines and their children and grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, GERTRUDE
description: DIAMOND -- Gertrude. Be loved wife of Teddy. Devoted mother of Maryann Monte. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave (East 10th St.).

title: Don't Worry, Be Happy (Even if Earnings Go Soft)
description: IN the long run, the two main drivers of a stock price are the profits the company produces and the amount that investors are willing to pay for them. So whenever investors turn cautious, as they have recently, and price-to-earnings ratios flatten out or fall, attention turns naturally to the other driver: the profits themselves.

title: Another Variation on That Good Ol' 'Fixin' to Die Rag'
description: Princeton - PRESIDENTIAL aspirants can't get over it, so why should we expect more of playwrights?

title: The Man Who Was Raised by a Movie Camera
description: WHEN he was 11, Jonathan Caouette started using a camera to create a protective force field. He needed one. His mother was a schizophrenic. The grandparents he lived with were eccentric. He was a gay boy growing up in Texas. Borrowing a neighbor's camera, Jonathan, pouting and tossing his head back, filmed himself playing an abused woman: "I wear too much makeup," she says to the camera. "It makes me look like a whore." At 13, Jonathan was hanging out at a gay club, disguising himself as a Goth girl, making friends with older boys who called themselves Spooky, Stacey and Bam Bam. He filmed them, too. Now, 20 years of videotaping later, he's edited his home movies into a bizarre, astonishing film called "Tarnation."

description: Erika Morgan Irish and Frank Brown Jr. were married yesterday in Rockleigh, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Shirley B. Cathie, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club.

description: To the Editor: "Emerging From the Mist," by Herbert Buchsbaum (Sept. 5), was particularly appreciated because it put traveling to Chiapas in context of the politics of the region.

description: Julie Hamilton Blair, the daughter of Connie Cutrer Blair and Joseph T. Blair of Groton, Conn., was married yesterday in Mystic, Conn., to Patrick Dennis Terrell, the son of Jane Ware Terrell and A. Dennis Terrell of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Ratmeyer, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Mystic Congregational Church.

description: BERGER--Charles, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Highland Park, IL died peacefully September 22, 2004 following a long illness. Decorated WWII veteran. Preceded in death by his wife Thelma (nee Goldsmith). Survived by his children Susan and Philip. Services private. Memorials to SUNY College of Environmental Sciences at Syracuse University.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: Cruise lines often discount the fares listed in their brochures, sometimes for early booking, sometimes for holidays. Whatever the reason, the ships come in all sizes:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about following Vice President Dick Cheney on the campaign trail referred incorrectly to the aircraft he usually uses. It is a modified Boeing 757, not a wide-body jet.

title: My, What Pretty Claws
description: MILES away from the orchestrated spectacle that was New York Fashion Week this month, Tyra Banks was tucked away in a mansion in Mahwah, N.J., making a commercial for Victoria's Secret. Her low-rise jeans were strategically unbuttoned, her famed bosom was nestled into a $10 million bra made of diamonds, and Ms. Banks, who moments earlier had worn a crimson thong and a matching push-up number, was delivering lines to the camera. "Delight me, dazzle me, excite me," she purred. "Bring me to my knees."

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Ideas & Trends; The House Electric: Cozy but Voracious
description: GADGETS and appliances make life easier, more entertaining and more comfortable. But they come with a cost: They use energy.

title: So Very Modern, So Very Forgotten
description: Montclair - OF all the early modernists who labored to make art that both captured the American experience, yet could mix it with the best of the European innovators, few succeeded. But this does not make their attempts less important, for through their efforts modern art developed roots in this country, later to score a stunning, homegrown success with the advent of Abstract Expressionism.

title: Kristina Rodrguez, Rawson Gamage
description: Kristina Joan Rodrguez, a daughter of Katherine Ilovar-Rodrguez and Juan Rodrguez-Muoz of New York, was married yesterday to Rawson Nathaniel Gamage, the son of Gay and Alvin Gamage of Saratoga, N.Y. The Rev. Allison Read performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Sensing End, Williams Savors Time With Yanks
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 - Bernie Williams spent Friday afternoon in his hotel room here preparing to play the Red Sox by composing some music. Williams brings his guitar on every Yankee trip, so it was no surprise that he was relaxing by working on some new songs.

title: Searle Hopes Lightning Will Strike for the Fifth Time
description: THE women's apparel retailer Searle is preparing to open its largest store in Manhattan this week: a three-level 12,000-square-foot space on the east side of Madison Avenue, just north of 59th Street. It will be the company's fifth store on Madison in a 26-block stretch of the avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVITT, STACY
description: LEVITT--Stacy. It's 16 years since we parted in the dentist's office. Miss you sweetie. Love, Mommy & Michael

title: Catching the M7
description: A few weeks ago, I caught an early-morning through train down from the northern end of the Harlem Line. I'm an indifferent rider, or so I thought -- an occasional commuter who knows the crew on my line by sight but not by name. That train has an excellent conductor. At Grand Central, he stands beside the head car and welcomes us as we leave the platform. That day, as another train slid alongside us in the Bronx, he came on the intercom. He announced that the cars on the train next to us were the new M7's being introduced by Metro-North.

title: In Desert Town, Training for'Terror Attacks'
description: PLAYAS, N.M., Sept. 20 - The Phelps Dodge mining company pictured a suburban utopia with a Southwestern flavor when it built this town for its employees from scratch in the early 1970's. It incorporated a six-lane bowling alley, a rodeo ring, a helicopter pad, a shooting range and a swimming pool into the community of 259 ranch-style homes.

title: Throwing Curves
description: I am in my month's trial membership at the fitness chain Curves, and I love it. I must decide whether to sign up for a year, and I've learned that the owner of the company financially supports pro-life efforts, whereas I am pro-choice. Do I have a duty to give up my Curves membership? Louise Dustrude, Friday Harbor, Wash. It depends: which do you value more, your reproductive rights or your figure? If the former, clean out your locker. You won't be alone. I've received queries from many women who are similarly conflicted. They love that Curves offers a great workout in a woman-friendly setting, and that many owner-operators of individual Curves centers are women, but they don't like seeing their payments used to support abstinence programs and what many regard as pro-life organizations.

title: Social Security: Paths and Perils (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Apostle to the Gentiles
description: PAUL His Story. By Jerome Murphy-O'Connor. 259 pp. Oxford University Press. $TK.

title: Now, an Advance Look at Those Big Paychecks
description: WHEN it comes to disclosing how senior executives are paid, American corporations have traditionally handed their shareholders a rear-view mirror. A few months into a new fiscal year, most public companies divulge how much they paid their top managers in the previous one. Occasionally, an irate investor attends the annual meeting to rail against the excesses, but by then the checks have been cut and cashed.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 26, 2004
description: Weeks

title: Of Greens and Greens
description: ACCORDING to a group called the Anarchist Golfing Association, "grass, like industrial culture, is invasive and permeates every aspect of our lives." The group is especially concerned about the Frankenstein variety -- genetically modified grasses designed for golf courses -- and tried to stomp it out a few years ago by breaking into two greenhouses owned by the Pure Seed company, destroying $500,000 worth of grass plants and leaving behind golf balls bearing its logo.

title: PHOTO-OP
You Only Sell Thrice
description: LAS VEGAS - ALEX YEMENIDJIAN, the chairman and chief executive of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was sitting at his private pool outside his high-roller villa at the Bellagio Hotel and Casino here last Monday. He had just struck a $5 billion deal to sell MGM, the Hollywood studio famous for its roaring-lion mascot and film franchises including James Bond, to Sony and a group of investors after an agonizingly long auction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEITSTEIN, SHIRLEY
description: LEITSTEIN--Shirley. Age 97, of Belvedere, CA., formerly of Yonkers, N.Y., passed away September 21, 2004. Loving wife of the late Jack Leitstein. Beloved mother of Bruce Leitstein, and Alex and Bob Leitstein. Cherished grandmother of Eric and Justin Leitstein, aunt of Richard Mescon and Jane Ryffel, Michael and Miriam Mescon and great aunt of Andrew, Jennie, David, Daniel and Hannah Mescon. Her love of life and the many friendships she shared will long remain an inspiration to the many lives she touched.

title: An Old Journey Forged in Pain; A Remembrance Born to Heal
description: ON a visit to Israel, the Rev. Dr. Johnny Ray Youngblood stopped at the Western Wall and was moved by the weeping and praying of thousands of Jews who went there to mourn their great catastrophe, the destruction of the second temple in Jerusalem by the Romans.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Park Slope Town House $849,000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, STEPHEN
description: BAKER--Stephen, age 83, died September 17, 2004. Advertising Executive. Author of 22 books including two bestsellers with over 200,000 copies sold: "How to Live with a Neurotic Dog" and "How to Play Golf in the low 120s". Twice nominated as Art Director of the Year by the National Society of Art Directors, recipient of approximately 60 citations and awards for creativity in advertising, including 6 Art Director Gold Medals. Monthly columnist for Art Direction Magazine for 9 years and Advertising Age Magazine for 14 years, creator of the "Let your Fingers do the Walking" advertising campaign for the AT&T Yellow Pages. Vice President and Creative Director of Cunningham and Walsh for 14 years. President of his own agency, Baker & Hartel, for 11 years. Consultant to government committees on the Metric System, American English; consultant to the Republican party, Walt Disney Entertainment, Barnum & Bailey, McGraw Hill. Taught at New York University, School of Visual Arts, Learning Annex, etc. Published over 200 articles, in Cosmopolitan, New York Times, Parade, Writer's Digest, Nature, etc. He was working on a nondenominational children's book, "Who is God?" with his son, Scott Baker. Services will be held at the Gannon Funeral Home, 28th Street between Third and Lexington at 2PM Saturday, October 2.

title: Law Changes Notification In Eminent Domain Cases
description: Municipalities preparing to seize private property must notify the landowner of the pending action either in person or by registered mail, under a bill signed last week by Gov. George E. Pataki authorizing changes in the state's eminent domain procedure.

title: Shakespeare's Leap
description: In his analysis of Shakespeare, Stephen Greenblatt (Sept. 12) makes the assumption that Shakespeare was unlikely to have personally known any Jews, since they had been expelled from England some 300 years earlier. Yet distinguished Jewish historians of the Tudor period, like Cecil Roth, Lucien Wolf and David S. Katz, have all confirmed that there was a lively converso community in Shakespeare's part of London during his lifetime. Conversos were Jews whose families had been coerced or forced to convert decades earlier on the Iberian Peninsula. Many were known to have kept up their Jewish practice in secret and were still immersed in their Jewish identity, albeit covertly.

title: Back to the Simple Things, Like Mud Stew
description: J.D. ROTH holds these truths to be self-evident: That malls and cellphones have replaced nature as entertainment for teenagers. That talking has become a lost art. That children will become more creative when left to their own devices. And that regardless of the obstacles placed before them, if they want something badly enough, they'll hang tight to their dreams for as long as they can.

title: The Show That Tanks Every Night
description: FROM the seats of Stage 5 at Dodger Stages, Basil Twist's puppet show, "Symphonie Fantastique," seems to proceed in serene, psychedelic slo-mo. In a 1,000-gallon water tank that hovers mid-stage like a plasma screen, blossoms of bright color appear, then float, dart and swirl in aquatic accompaniment to Berlioz's five-part symphony, which he composed in a mad, three-week dash in 1830 after falling under the spell of an Irish actress named Harriett. Color blots gather like squeezed dabs of oil paint on an artist's palette -- cadmium blue, geranium red, jade green, sun gold -- then shimmy and disperse as if they were alive.

title: SAVING SCHOLARS
description: For someone once known as "Dr. Doom," Henry Kaufman spreads a lot of cheer. His latest dose came last week, when he wrote a $10 million check to the nonprofit Institute of International Education, which runs the Fulbright Fellowship program for the State Department.

title: Indian Culture Clash: Classical or Pop?
description: EVERY Wednesday evening for eight years, Shreya Parvathi Subramani, 14, of Old Westbury took a lesson in bharata natyam, a form of Indian classical dance. She learned to master its rhythms, nuances and detailed movements for her arangetram -- a Tamil word that literally means ascending the stage. The gala $15,000 coming-of-age affair, held at the Hindu Temple in Flushing, Queens, last weekend, included prayers, family speeches, a buffet dinner for 400 and lots of presents.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Wordstock

title: Shuttling Between Nations, Latino Gangs Confound the Law
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras - Christin Antnez chokes back a scream as the nurse sticks a needle above his left eyebrow. "Ay, Mam!" he shouts. "It really hurts."

title: With Planning, Stadiums Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting the Iraq Vote in Perspective: Florida Wasn't Perfect Either
description: When it comes to troubled elections, Gen. John Abizaid, the United States commander in Iraq, evidently sees some similarities between Tikrit and Tallahassee.

title: Susan Kim, Martin Marren
description: Susan Marie Kim and Martin James William Marren are to be married today by the Rev. Ben H. Smith, an Episcopal priest, at the Engineers Club in Baltimore.

title: Never Ready for Their Close-Up
description: FOR Cathline Marshall, it began innocuously enough with a posting in her mailroom announcing that a film crew was searching for a modern, spacious apartment. Ms. Marshall, a computer science professor who relocated to the Upper East Side from Tokyo several years earlier, thought that her apartment would fit the bill.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AMERICA'S WOMEN: Four Hundred Years of Dolls, Drudges, Helpmates, and Heroines, by Gail Collins. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.95.) From Eleanor Dare and the lost colony of Roanoke to Betty Friedan and the feminist rebellion of the 1970's, this sweeping social history revolves around entertaining profiles of women who shaped the nation and were shaped in turn by what it means to be female in America. Collins, the editorial page editor of The Times, "is a master of the effortless glide from the individual to the collective experience and back again," Stacy Schiff wrote in the Book Review in 2003.

title: For Croton, an Award For Keeping Things Green
description: The Village of Croton-on-Hudson has received the first annual state-sponsored Greenway Visions in Planning Award, which recognizes a municipal project in the Hudson River Valley.

title: Police Sawed Through Locks and Seized Bikes, Riders Say
description: Although about 1,000 bicyclists on a mass ride moved peacefully through Manhattan on Friday night with just a small number of arrests, riders complained yesterday that the police had seized about 40 bicycles at one location after sawing through locks securing them to sign posts and light poles.

title: Sarah Hand, Gavin McAleer
description: Sarah Howard Hand, a designer, and Gavin Stevens Hyde McAleer, a chef, were married yesterday in Chicago at the home of Ann and Elbert O. Hand III, the bride's stepmother and father. Anne O'Laughlin Scott, a retired judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County in Rolling Meadows, Ill., officiated.

title: The New Silicon Valley: A Dog-Eat-Dog World
description: MAY I buy your beloved pet dog, just so I can take him around back and shoot him? That's how the chief executive of PeopleSoft, Craig Conway, described the Oracle Corporation's hostile bid for his company, which Oracle intends to use to move PeopleSoft customers to its own software.

title: I Thought of Jake
description: I HOPE this is not going to get me my nose slit open. But you never know where a drink will end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WULWICK, SAMUEL
description: WULWICK--Samuel. Devoted husband to Cynthia and Ronne Wohl Wulwick. Loving father to Joan and Kenneth Kastin, Kenneth and Ronnie Wulwick, and Dr. Robert and Doreen Wulwick. Caring grandfather to David and Abby, Lynn, Billy and Berta, Jennifer, Leslie, Amy, Stefanie and Emily. Adoring greatgrandfather to Daniel and Julia. A generous and compassionate man who made life more enjoyable to those around him. He will be sorely missed. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I., Sunday, 10:30.

title: At Elite Tournament in India, A Brilliant, Complex Attack
description: The Pune International Tournament in India, held Sept. 2 to 12, ended in a tie for first place between Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania and Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan. Each scored 6-3 in the all-play-all grandmaster event, the strongest ever held in India. Penteala Harikrishna of India came in third with a 5-4 tally.

title: Airline's Dispatchers Weather a Storm
description: Airline dispatchers, hardy souls who are employed by airlines to make daily operational decisions, have a reputation for being unflappable under stress.

title: Social Security: Paths and Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: The Other Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Continuing Care Housing Planned for Briarcliff Manor
description: Classic Residence by Hyatt has agreed to buy a 59-acre parcel in Briarcliff Manor, on the former campus of Kings College, for a luxury continuing-care retirement community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASTAGNETTA, LUIGI, PH.D.
description: CASTAGNETTA--Luigi, Ph.D. We were saddened to learn of the death in Palermo (September 16, 2004) of Prof. Luigi Castagnetta, renowned biomedical scientist. Our sympathy to his wife Maria and daughter Michela. Dr. and Mrs. H. Leon Bradlow

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FELD, ISABEL
description: FELD--Isabel. 1/23/2000. My darling & unforgettable, precious wife and lover for more than 60 years, I love you and miss you. Not a day goes by that I don't think of you and cry for you and for me. Harold Feld

title: Long Beach's Manager Submits Resignation
description: The Long Beach city manager, who was hired eight months ago after a change in leadership on the City Council, resigned on Monday, indicating that a medical condition required him to retire.

title: President Lindbergh In 2004
description: PHILIP ROTH is one of America's great novelists, but you don't expect him to be barreling up the best-seller list with a book that hasn't even been published yet. "Literary fiction," as it is now stigmatized in the cultural marketplace, no longer flies off the shelves unless struck by the TV lightning of Oprah or the "Today" show. And yet there was "The Plot Against America" in the top 25 at amazon.com last week, at one point the only serious contemporary American novel on the list, sandwiched between Clay Aiken's memoir and "The South Beach Diet." It had ascended without benefit of a single author's interview on TV or anywhere else and with only the first few reviews, not all of them ecstatic.

title: Lower the Drinking Age But Raise the Voting Age
description: Evan Baehr realizes that he may be swimming against the political tide in his adopted town of Princeton. Mr. Baehr, a senior at the local Ivy League university and the head of the campus Republicans, is running for a seat on the Borough Council.

title: 'American Soldier'
description: WYNNEWOOD, OKLAHOMAJUNE 1950

title: Page Two: Sept. 19-25; ALL IN THE TIMING
description: If there was a lesson in last week's Congressional vote to extend President Bush's tax cuts for another four to six years, it was that no political compromise is permanent.

title: The Lessons of Classroom 506
description: I was deeply ambivalent about Belkin's article. On the one hand, I was moved by the energy, time and love that the Ellensons have invested in their child's education, and I was heartened that Thomas's first year in school went well. On the other, his story is another reminder of the inequities in our cash-strapped educational system. I am, however, encouraged that the Ellensons are insisting that those involved in this experiment develop a template so that others can replicate the inclusion model they have gone to such great lengths to test.

title: Putting Her Money Where Her Music Video Is
description: GREEN DAY -- Before pop-punk devolves completely into bratty teen comedy, Green Day reclaims punk's ambition with "American Idiot" (Reprise). It's nothing less than a rock opera about a "Jesus of Suburbia" adrift in an America that's brainwashed by mass media, debased by materialism and facing Armageddon. The music connects buzzsaw punk to British rock from Merseybeat to glam -- including two nine-minute, five-part suites -- and Green Day trumps any pretension with melody and sheer fervor.

title: Britain Offering to Pay Off 10% of Third World Debt
description: LONDON, Sept. 25 - Britain is planning a new effort to help poor countries reduce their huge debts by offering to pay off 10 percent of the total owed to international agencies and challenging other nations to follow suit, said Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer.

title: Found Treasures from All Over to Adorn Redone Town Houses
description: BOB AND CORTNEY NOVOGRATZ are world-class scavengers. Husband-and-wife real estate developers with an eye for the unusual, they scour the flea markets, antiques stores and demolition sites of New York, Paris, southern France, Mexico and the southern United States (often with their four children in tow), searching for architectural castoffs: a limestone fountain, stained-glass windows, industrial lighting fixtures, decorative tiles. They bring their finds home and use them in their construction projects.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in SundayBusiness today about the possibility of diminished air service to some cities misattributes an estimate of the flights US Airways will have each day at Pittsburgh International Airport by year-end. The estimate -- half the number of flights scheduled in 1997 -- is by Michael Allen, an industry consultant, not Kent George, the airport's executive director.

title: The Price of Admission Is on the Rise
description: PARENTS of Connecticut college underclassmen looking forward to the various parents weekends this autumn may have an urgent question for the administration when they arrive on campus: Will tuition and fees keep surging?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOENE, BURKHARD
description: HOENE--Burkhard. 46, beloved son, brother, and adored friend of many, died peacefully at home on September 21, 2004 of pancreatic cancer. Born on December 10, 1957, he was raised in New Hampshire. In 1981, he graduated from UVM and began his career in fashion at Brooks Brothers. He was founder and designer of the Espionage clothing label and also helped establish the denim division of Harley Davidson. He founded Digital Fashion in 1993 to deliver expertise in pioneering digital media technologies in fashion. In 1995, he founded Fashion Planet Inc., as a joint venture between Digital Fashion and Digital Planet. His extraordinary photographic work that enriches humanity's visual journey, together with his beautiful and inspiring poetry, are his greatest achievements. He will be missed by all who love him. He is survived by his mother Ursula R. Hoene, siblings Eberhard, Barbara, Christina, Max, and their families. Donations may be made in memory of Burkhard Hoene, Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, research of Dr. G. Abu-Alfa, PO Box 27106, NY, NY 10087. Services at the Riverside Church, September 29, at 3:00 PM.

title: Sept. 19-25
description: IRAQ, AS TRIUMPH OR DISASTER, TAKES CENTER STAGE Senator John Kerry and President Bush tried to focus the nation's attention on two totally different countries last week, and both of them were Iraq.

title: Going Way Off-Road
description: The world has never been kind to flying-car dreamers like Henry Smolinski, who died in 1973 when his Ford Pinto with the welded-on Cessna wings crashed; or Paul Moller, who balances work on his multiengine Batmobile with life-extension experiments so he will still be alive when Skycars fill the skies over Los Angeles; or Rafi Yoeli, who built CityHawk in the living room of his second-floor apartment and had to remove a wall to get it out.

title: It's Another Closing, and Another Fee
description: IF Benjamin Franklin were around today, he might add something to his old bromide that nothing is certain but death and taxes. That something is closing costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELIAS, ELI
description: ELIAS--Eli. Beloved husband of Sara. Loving father of Roslyn Hazan, Allan and Richard. Adored grandfather to nine and great grandfather to ten. He was the beloved patriarch of our family and will be deeply missed. Services today, 10AM "Boulevard-Riverside Chapels", 1450 Bdwy, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WUNDERLICH, RUDOLF G.
description: WUNDERLICH -- Rudolf G. The staff of the Gerald Peters Gallery is deeply saddened by the passing of Rudolf G. Wunderlich on September 22. A preeminent dealer in American Art, Rudy was a great friend and mentor. We will sincerely miss his wisdom and laughter. Our most heartfelt sympathies to his family. Gerald P. Peters III Gerald Peters Gallery

title: PHOTO-OP
Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENSTOCK, ROBERT
description: ROSENSTOCK--Robert. International lawyer, legal advisor to the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, member of the International Law Commission, died of natural causes on September 20. Mr. Rosenstock is survived by his wife of 34 years, Gerda Michorl Rosenstock, daughter Elizabeth Rosenstock-Siller, son-in-law Michael Siller, grandson Phillip Siller and sons Thomas and Nicholas. The memorial will be private. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be sent to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NYC 10032.

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
South American Palette
description: HOBOKEN - WHEN I left Cucharamama after my second visit under standard practice, my last -- I felt a sharp pang of regret. I had dined amazingly well. But I had failed to order the fabada de horno, described so fetchingly on the menu as "a Latin cassoulet of white beans, sausages, smoked bacon and kale, slow-cooked in the wood-burning oven." There was nothing to do but come back a third time.

title: Letters
description: Readers were riveted by Lisa Belkin's account of the ''inclusion'' of a disabled boy in a public-school kindergarten class. Many called the efforts of his father heroic, though some said his advocacy insured special treatment. Other letter writers weighed in on the pros and cons of ''getting over'' 9/11.

title: Shared Trainers
description: Gymgoers who want guided workouts generally have two options: crowded classes or expensive personal trainers. Two clubs have found healthy compromises. The Gym, at 11 East 26th Street, (212) 889-3003, offers Pickup Workouts with a trainer and up to four people. At Equinox (equinoxfitness.com), members pair up in small classes, above. "You're working with someone," said Marcelo Ehrhardt, the Equinox instructor who came up with the idea. "There's no room to daydream." JENNIFER TUNG

title: A Place to Remember Marian Anderson
description: The newly renovated practice studio once used by Marian Anderson, which was originally built for her by her husband, the architect Orpheus Fisher, is now open to visitors in Danbury, Conn.

title: Magic Gold From a Blend
description: Hugel et Fils's dry whites set a gold standard in Alsace year after year. The aromatic, tangy 2003 Gentil ($10) is a feat of blending: equal parts of gewrztraminer, muscat, pinot gris, riesling and sylvaner. It works as aperitif and with fish dishes, salads (hold the vinegar) and pork. The bold, litchi-flavored 2002 gewrztraminer ($20) is magical with ginger-accented Chinese cuisine. Both are found at 67 Wine, 179 Columbus Avenue (68th Street). HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, STANTON L.
description: ROSENBERG--Stanton L. Age 48, on September 17, 2004, in his home in Morristown, NJ, after a long illness. Born in NYC. Owned and operated printing company Chameleon Editions. Attended Kansas University, BA degree 1980. Survived by wife, Roberta Duty, mother Josephine Rosenberg, sister Maria Minneci and brother Will Blackburn.

title: Difficult Choices
description: Medical advances are forcing more patients and families to confront ever more grueling choices about living and dying.

title: Your Insurance Agent, Along for the Ride
description: IF you can prove to your insurance agent that you always drive safely, will you get better rates? Some drivers are getting a chance to find out.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Rochelle: Woman Dies Of Gun Wounds
description: A Westchester County woman who was hospitalized after a shooting that left her half-sister dead has also died, her family said yesterday. The woman, Candice Rampersad, 18, of Mount Vernon, died on Friday at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle and will be buried on Wednesday in Mount Vernon, family members said. Ms. Rampersad and her half-sister, Michelle Bonner, 30, were shot by Ms. Bonner's estranged husband, Clifford Bonner, during a dispute on Sept. 18 in a Mamaroneck park. Mr. Bonner, 41, then fled the park with his three children, ages 7, 9 and 12, who witnessed the shootings. As dozens of police officers searched for him, Mr. Bonner left his children with a relative on Sept. 19, then shot himself to death. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Agencies Postpone Issuing New RulesUntil After Election
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - After a case of mad cow disease surfaced in Washington State late last year, federal regulators vowed to move swiftly to adopt rules to reduce the risks of further problems and restore confidence in the nation's meat industry.

title: He's Got a Thing or Two to Say About the World
description: Tommy Tiernan comes from Ireland. He's got the gift of gab. And a good thing that is for New Yorkers who make their way to the Village Theater between now and Oct. 9 while the 90 intermissionless minutes of standup comedy he calls "Cracked" are here to provide laughs mined from a sorry world.

title: Turkey Revises Its Penal Code in Bid to Join the European Union
description: ISTANBUL, Sept. 26 - The Turkish Parliament on Sunday approved a sweeping revision of the country's penal code to bring it closer to European Union norms, a step aimed at enhancing the prospect of Turkish membership in the 25-nation bloc.

title: Driver in Fatal Crash Tells Police Light Was Green, Lawyer Says
description: The man charged with drunken driving in a fiery car crash that killed four teenagers on Long Island this weekend has told the police that he was going through a green light at the intersection where the accident occurred, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Brown Suffers Rocky Return in Feisty Finale
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 - There was Kevin Brown at his worst, Curt Schilling at his best and baseball's most bitter rivalry at its end -- for now, anyway.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stabbing Victim Dies
description: A man who had been stabbed several times in the chest and back collapsed in a Lower Manhattan subway station after stepping off the N train yesterday morning, the police said. He was pronounced dead at 5 a.m. at New York University Downtown Hospital. It was unclear whether he had been stabbed on the train or before he boarded. Witnesses saw him step off the northbound train at the Rector Street stop at 4:40 a.m., stagger through the turnstile and collapse. The police did not identify the man, described as Hispanic and in his 30's. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Miscellany
description: MDC Partners, Toronto, secured a $100 million, three-year revolving credit line from banks led by J.P. Morgan Chase as part of efforts to improve its financial structure and pave the way for further acquisitions. MDC has bought majority or minority interests in advertising and design agencies including Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York; Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami; the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network, New York; Bruce Mau Design, Toronto; and VitroRobertson, San Diego.

title: Learning how less equals more
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about Bank of America's conversion of Fleet branches in New York misstated Citigroup's ranking among operators of bank branches in the New York area. It is the third largest, not second; J.P. Morgan Chase is No.2. A chart with the article used an erroneous figure from the US Bancorp Web site for the number of that bank's branches. It is 2,344, not 2,100.

title: Spoiled Again: Cubs Humbled by Mets
description: Clinging to a half-game lead in the race for the National League wild card, the Cubs sent Kerry Wood to the mound at Shea Stadium yesterday, needing to shake off a sudden and shocking defeat a day earlier.

title: U.S. Military Arrests an Iraqi Commander
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 26 - The American military said Sunday that it had arrested a senior commander of the nascent Iraqi National Guard, raising concerns about the loyalty and reliability of the new security forces just months before general elections are scheduled across the embattled country.

title: 7 Younger Executives Selected for Honor
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington will induct seven people into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives in marketing and the media who are 40 and younger.

title: Six Sigma: A Hollywood Studio Learns the G.E. Way
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 - On a morning in February, more than 40 executives huddled around a U-shaped table on the eighth floor of Universal Pictures headquarters here to discuss the marketing for their coming spring lineup. Among them was Bob Wright, who found himself debating a television commercial for the remake of "Dawn of the Dead" and critiquing the press junket for "Chronicles of Riddick."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Police Wound Man
description: Police officers shot and wounded a man who was shooting at them during a chase in Astoria shortly after 1 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The man, identified as Jelon Smith, 19, of Astoria, was shot in the knee after he fired three shots at the officers while running east on Astoria Boulevard, the police said. The shots did not strike the officers. The police said Mr. Smith had been carrying a 9-millimeter pistol. He was in stable condition yesterday at Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. He was charged with attempted murder, reckless endangerment, menacing and a weapons charge. The officers were responding to a call about men fighting in the street at 14th Street and 30th Avenue, the police said. The officers, whose names were not released, were treated for trauma at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Thailand Investigates Possible Bird Flu
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 27 - Officials in Thailand announced today that a 32-year-old woman had been hospitalized with avian influenza and that two of her family members had already died of a flu-like illness, raising the possibility that these might be among the first case of human-to-human transmission.

title: Future of Illinois Farm May Lie in Swampy Past
description: HAVANA, Ill, Sept. 20 - Every autumn for more than 80 years, a sprawling farm beside the Illinois River has yielded a rich bounty of corn and other crops. Now it is being turned back into a swamp.

title: Army May Reduce Length of Tours in Combat Zones
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 - Fearing a sharp decline in recruiting and troop retention, the Army is considering cutting the length of its 12-month combat tours in Iraq and Afghanistan, senior Army officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONRAD, MARTIN L.
description: CONRAD--Martin L. On September 25, 2004. Beloved husband of Harriet, father of David and Donna, stepfather of Lane and Stacey, grandfather of Zakery, Rebecca, Alex and Logan. Adored brother of Herbert and brother-in-law of Judith. Services Monday, 11:30 am, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Maker of Palm Software to Unveil Operating System for Smart Phones
description: PARIS - PalmSource, the maker of the Palm operating system for hand-held devices, plans to announce tomorrow its first operating system designed specifically for smart phones -- mobile phones that can run programs more typically found on desktop computers.

description: Merck Obtains Rights For Anti-Obesity Drug Merck & Company has obtained rights to license an experimental anti-obesity drug that has generated scientific interest because it is based on a hormone the body uses to signal that it has eaten enough.

description: It was just this past spring that the Metropolitan Opera under the conductor James Levine presented three complete accounts of Wagner's "Ring," with a couple of extra performances of "Die Walkre," the second of the cycle's four operas, thrown in. So why offer another "Die Walkre," which returned to the house on Saturday night, so soon in the new season?

Vikings Limp Away With a Victory in the Bandage Bowl
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 26 - Chicago Bears Coach Lovie Smith walked briskly down a Metrodome hallway toward the team bus when a sudden commotion made him stop and step to the side Sunday. He watched in silence as Bears quarterback Rex Grossman passed on the back of a flatbed cart, a black knee brace clamped over the right leg of his dark blue suit pants.

title: Red Sox Lose the Hand, but Still Hold the Ace
description: BOSTON - FOR seven sobering innings yesterday, the Yankees' offense against Curt Schilling consisted of a routine ground-ball single up the middle by Jorge Posada. Two runs scored on the play, but that was the result of Schilling's having loaded the bases on three straight walks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Three Public Servants Arrested
description: An off-duty police officer and an off-duty firefighter were arrested yesterday in separate instances and charged with driving while intoxicated, while a schoolteacher was charged with possession of marijuana, the police said. The police officer, Anthony Rosser, 41, of the Brooklyn North Task Force, was involved in a minor traffic accident before his arrest at 5 a.m. in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn. The firefighter, Thomas Cappelli, 25, was stopped on the Gowanus Expressway at Hicks Street in Brooklyn shortly after midnight Saturday, the police said. The teacher, Adam Calemmo, 25, was arrested on 26th Street in Chelsea at 8:35 p.m. Saturday and charged with possession of a controlled substance, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Before the Fall Theater Rush, a Festival Full of Song
description: It may be a quiet fall for new Broadway musicals, but not far from the big street people have been singing their heads off of late. The New York Musical Theater Festival, an ambitious three weeks of musicals at theaters in Midtown and other parts of the city, began Sept. 13 and continues through next Sunday.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 27  A senior Iraqi judge said today that he had closed a case brought against Ahmad Chalabi, the former exile once backed by the Pentagon, who had been suspected of involvement in a counterfeiting operation.

title: Conan O'Brien to Succeed Jay Leno in 2009, NBC Announces
description: NBC announced today that Conan O'Brien will succeed Jay Leno as host of the "Tonight" show when Mr. Leno's contract expires in 2009, cutting off early efforts by competitors to steal away Mr. O'Brien.

title: Big Juniors Program Nurtures Poland's Young Card Sharks
description: Where is the most effective bridge program for junior players? Many would guess a country in Western Europe, perhaps the Netherlands. But the right answer is surely Poland, which has had multiple successes at the international level.

title: Taliban Fighter Who Was Freed From Guantnamo Prison Is Killed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 26 - A senior Taliban commander who had been released from the American detention center in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, was killed Saturday in Uruzgan Province, Afghan officials reported Sunday.

title: Powell, Then and Now
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell, discussing the Iraq war during an appearance at The Times on Friday, did not have the crisp certitude of the general who assured us in 1991 that the first gulf war was going almost precisely as planned.

title: A Graphic Film of Protest, and Cries of Blasphemy
description: AMSTERDAM - As she begins to pray, the woman looks heavily veiled, showing her eyes only, but her long black chador turns out to be transparent. Beneath it, painted on her chest and stomach, are verses from the Koran.

title: Correction
Paid Notice: Deaths   BLASENHEIM, PAUL
description: BLASENHEIM--Paul. On September 24, 2004, at the age of 80, of Lambertville, NJ. Beloved husband of his beautiful wife of 59 years, Gloria. Best father of all time to his daughters, Lois, Laura, Joanne and Beth. Adored grandfather of Max and Alex. "Pinny" to his family and friends in the Bronx. "Blitz" to his WWII band of brothers and "Chef Paul" to the multitudes he fed through the years. He never gave up and he will never be forgotten. Graveside services on Wednesday, September 29, at 12 noon, at the Rose Hill/King David Cemetery, 101 Mill St, Putnam Valley, NY 10579.

title: The Secret Trade Courts
description: In Ecuador, residents of the country's eastern rainforest are suing ChevronTexaco. They say that the methods Texaco used to drill for oil in the 1970's and 1980's caused billions of dollars in environmental damage and health problems that continue today. ChevronTexaco, which stands a good chance of losing the lawsuit, has now demanded that the government-owned Ecuadorean oil company pay whatever damages are imposed and the costs of cleanup. On this issue ChevronTexaco has a good chance of winning. The reason is that its demand will be heard by arbitrators, not by a court, and arbitration greatly favors corporations.

title: Another Hurricane Roars Across Mid-Florida
description: BAREFOOT BAY, Fla., Sept. 26 - Hurricane Jeanne delivered walls of stinging rain and winds of up to 120 miles an hour as it spun across Florida on Sunday, making landfall almost exactly where Hurricane Frances did over Labor Day weekend and waging the third assault in six weeks on the state's sodden midsection.

title: Creative Tension, Until the Next Time

description: MARTON--Richard, M.D. The Board of Trustees, Department of Medicine and the entire staff of Lenox Hill Hospital express their deep sorrow at the death of Richard Marton, M.D., a distinguished member of our staff for over 54 years. Dr. Marton was a dedicated physician who was greatly admired by his patients and colleagues. The Lenox Hill Hospital family honors his memory and mourns his loss. We extend our sincere sympathies to the Marton family. William O. Hiltz, Chairman Board of Trustees Gladys George President and CEO James J. Richter, M.D., Ph.D. President, Medical Board Robert A. Phillips, M.D., Ph.D., Chairman, Department of Medicine

title: Around the World and Into the Psyche
description: In 1966, the fourth year of the New York Film Festival's existence, a correspondent for Cahiers du Cinma wrote that the festival had "proved itself incontestably one of the cultural ornaments of this city." By bringing the French New Wave (via Jean-Luc Godard), the Czech New Wave (Milos Forman and Ivan Passer) and some Hollywood dazzle (a documentary about Marlon Brando) to New York, the festival had drawn a following, as well as the contempt of some of the city's reviewers, including the chief film critic of The New York Times.

title: As a Life Ebbs, the Ultimate Family Quarrel
description: LANCASTER, Mass. - Geraldine Reardon's medical nightmare sneaked up like a cruel and crippling ambush. Mrs. Reardon, an otherwise healthy 66-year-old, went to the hospital last October for a routine hernia operation. Days later, a ravaging infection set in. It corroded her fingers and toes with gangrene and forced doctors to medicate her into a coma to spare her unbearable pain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDONAGH, WINIFRED JANE
description: McDONAGH--Winifred Jane. Passed away in her sleep on Friday, September 24, 2004, in NYC, age 105. An Irish immigrant, born Winifred Tierney in Lisdoonvarna, County Clare, she and her late husband, Francis McDonagh, opened the first Irish tavern in Morningside Heights, the Moylan Tavern, immortalized as the setting of the television comedy "The George Carlin Show." Before leaving Ireland, she was an active member of the Dublin Branch of the Irish Union of Distributive Workers and Clerks, and later reported to them about working conditions in New York. She worked for the Fifth Avenue department stores Altmans and Best & Co., where she was a hat model and sales associate. A devout member of Corpus Christi Parish, she was also a longtime volunteer at the Bellevue Hospital Center. She is survived by her beloved son Donald, granddaughters Maitland, Ruth, Rachel and Amy, and greatgrandchildren William, Ian and Alison, John and Grace, and Dakota and Taina. She will be interred at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY.

Pioneering founder of Cramer Products Co., Crambruck Press, and the Wine Museum, manufacturer of the first successful instant baking mix on the US market ("Joy"), innovative creator of vibration-free wine storage coolers, and holder of numerous patents. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, DAVID ANTHONY III
description: WILSON--David Anthony III. Age twenty-one, died on Wednesday, September 22, 2004, in the Adirondack Park near Wells, NY. Majoring in computer science, David was a senior at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, NY. David attended the Episcopal School and Trinity School in New York City. After three years at Brunswick School in Greenwich, CT, he attended Gould Academy in Bethel, Maine. He graduated high school from The Pomfret School in Pomfret, CT. David was an expert skier, and an avid photographer. He enjoyed all types of music and loved movies. Dave educated himself on topics such as artificial intelligence, economics, and politics by reading, research, and debate. He was an ardent Apple Computer proponent. His favorite author was Noam Chomsky. He is survived by his parents, Ann and David A. Wilson, Jr. of New Canaan, CT, his sister, Elizabeth R. Wilson of New York City, maternal grandparents Lt. Col. George W. Gaumond, USAF (retired), and Madeline R. Gaumond of Bradenton, FL, and paternal grandfather David A. Wilson of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan on September 30th at 3 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: American Civil Liberties Union (www. aclu.org) or Heifer International (www.heifer.org).
