title: INJURED AND OUT
description: Diahann Carroll out; Leslie Uggams in. The Kennedy Center in Washington has announced that Ms. Carroll, who was to star with James Earl Jones in its new production of Ernest Thompson's "On Golden Pond," has withdrawn from the play for medical reasons. Ms. Carroll fell last week at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, where she herniated a disk and strained muscles in her back and hip, the show's producer, Jeffrey Finn, said. Ms. Uggams, left, a Tony Award winner, will replace Ms. Carroll. Directed by Leonard Foglia, "On Golden Pond" will play for three weeks, as previously scheduled, from tomorrow through Oct. 17 in the center's Eisenhower Theater. JOHN FILES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELIAS, ELI
description: ELIAS--Eli. The officers and members of the New York Skirt & Sportswear Association, Inc. record with profound sorrow the passing of Eli Elias, retired President and Executive Director of the Association. For many decades, he devoted his energy and ability to the advancement of the interests of all association members and of the entire apparel industry and to the maintenance of harmonious management-labor relations. He served with distinction on the Boards of the Federation of Apparel Manufacturers, the Garment Industry Development Corporation, the Educational Foundation of the Fashion Institute of Technology, the High School of Fashion Industries and the Council for American Fashion. He was a long-time management trustee of many union benefit funds. He was truly a giant in the apparel industry and his leadership, integrity, creativity and dedication will be sorely missed. We express our heartfelt condolences to the Elias family. New York Skirt & Sportswear Association, Inc. Jack Glauberman, Exec Dir Counsel

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot On Street
description: An early morning shootout in Park Slope left one man badly wounded in the street, the police said yesterday. The victim, who is 22, was shot once in the chest, twice in the back and once in the leg, and was in critical condition at New York Methodist Hospital, the police said. His name was not released. Witnesses said a loud argument between two men broke the quiet on the block of Second Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues about 4 a.m. yesterday. Kyung Cho, a college professor, said he woke up to see one man begin walking away from the other, and then heard gunshots. Professor Cho said he then saw the gunman return to his car and drive away. Michael Wilson (NYT)

description: When the Justice Department opened an investigation a year ago into the question of how Robert Novak obtained the name of a covert Central Intelligence Agency operative for publication in his syndicated column, we expressed two basic concerns. The first was the need for an independent inquiry led by someone without Attorney General John Ashcroft's ultra-close ties to the White House. That was addressed belatedly with the naming of a special prosecutor, Patrick Fitzgerald, to pursue the accusations that unnamed Bush administration officials illegally leaked the woman's undercover role in an effort to stifle criticism of Iraq policy by her husband, former ambassador Joseph Wilson IV.

Boyle stands at a lectern at Barnes & Noble in Union Square in Manhattan, strange, thinning reddish-brown hair swept up and sprayed into a pompadour, eyebrows moving like inverted V's, beard coming to a devilish point. He's preparing to read from his new novel, "The Inner Circle" (Viking), about the sex researcher Alfred C. Kinsey. "I'm not mincing words," he tells the audience of some 400 people. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Three Men Shot
description: Three men were shot in the back last night, and two of them critically injured, during an argument between a group of men playing cards behind a Bronx apartment building and another group who disrupted the game, the police said. The shooting occurred around 7:30 p.m. in a courtyard behind the building at 844 East 230th Street, in Wakefield, after one group of men pulled up in a red S.U.V. and started an argument with the cardplayers. The police had made no arrests as of late last night and did not release the names of the victims. It was unclear whether the men who were shot were the cardplayers or the men who climbed out of the S.U.V. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: If Hockey Is Out, Best Thing on Ice May Be a Computer Game
description: Crestfallen hockey fans worried about filling the hours during the National Hockey League's labor dispute may now have a place to turn. Beginning Oct. 13, the cable channel G4techTV plans to resurrect each of the 1,230 regular-season games listed on the league's defunct 2004-2005 schedule by setting them in motion on a video game console. All 30 teams will face off in "computer only" mode, meaning that the computer will control both teams, and the resulting scores, stats and highlights will be shown on the network's sports program, "Sweat."

title: The Buzz From the Paris Auto Show: Monospace
description: PARIS -- When Jacques Chirac, the president of France, visited the 2004 Mondial de lAAutomobile last Friday, he found dozens of hostesses from the automaker CitroAn lined up in a single rank, resplendent in tailored pantsuits, waiting to be reviewed like troops. The president did the task with a dignity worthy of reviewing a French Foreign Legion regiment.

title: Avoiding Distractions
description: The outlines are barely set for Congress's landmark attempt to overhaul the failed American intelligence system, yet House Republicans are already trying to turn this week's debate into a pre-election brawl aimed more at scoring phony patriotic points than at passing meaningful laws. The House bill relegates intelligence reform to a bit part in a partisan hodgepodge of seamy proposals to crimp civil liberties in the name of preventing terrorism. Fortunately, in the Senate, a commendably bipartisan effort has produced a clean bill to empower a national intelligence director and counterterrorism center and straighten out the 15 intelligence agencies now stumbling at cross-purposes.

title: OPERA PASSIONS
description: At La Scala in Milan, they are calling it artistic integrity. At Covent Garden in London, they say it has all the air of a prima donna's behavior. Riccardo Muti has pulled out of a Royal Opera production of "La Forza del Destino," scheduled to open Oct. 16, in a disagreement over the set, spoiling his long-awaited return 20 years after last conducting at the house. The production is by La Scala and designed by Hugo de Ana. Several set walls taken to London were too heavy for the Covent Garden stage, so Covent Garden said it tried to win Mr. de Ana's approval for what it called minor changes. But he refused to agree, and Mr. Muti stepped aside in support, a Covent Garden spokesman, Christopher Millard, said Friday. The opera house's music director, Antonio Pappano, and its management said that they were "totally perplexed" by Mr. Muti's decision and that Mr. de Ana showed "no spirit of collaboration." La Scala, where Mr. Muti is music director, responded by saying the Covent Garden production is faithless to the original. The decision by Mr. Muti and Mr. de Ana to withdraw "upholds the tradition of La Scala that any restaging correspond absolutely to the original production," La Scala said. Mr. Pappano will take over, canceling concerts with the Chicago Symphony, a recording project and a concert in Mr. Muti's city, with the Giuseppe Verdi Symphony Orchestra of Milan. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Cheney Crowds Would Like More on Kitchen-Table Issues
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept 24 - For Vice President Dick Cheney's weeklong campaign swing, little was left to chance. Or so it seemed.

title: Penn Station Fire Disrupts Commute for Tens of Thousands
description: Tens of thousands of commuters were scrambling to find a way home from New York City tonight after Pennsylvania Station was shut down and briefly evacuated just before the evening rush because of fires in a transformer beneath the East River and on the tracks near a terminal entrance, the authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Stabbed In Hospital
description: A man was stabbed in the back early yesterday during a fight in the emergency room waiting area of St. Vincent's Staten Island Hospital in the Randall Manor neighborhood, the police said. The fight began when two men in the waiting area were harassing a woman waiting for treatment for a lip injury, the police said. The woman went outside and complained about the men to a friend, who went inside the waiting area and stabbed one of them and fled, the police said. The victim, whom the police did not identify, was in stable condition yesterday. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Judge Questions Pinochet About Killings Under His Rule

Augusto Pinochet, Chile's dictator from 1973 to 1990, failed to stave off an investigating judge's questions, the general was officially interrogated Saturday about his involvement in a coordinated effort by six South American military governments to hunt down and kill exiled political opponents in the 1970's.

But there is one more shared experience, if readers can bear another ramble down the byways of Yale, which is of no small relevance in a week when the two presidential candidates face off in their first debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEILL, JOHN T.
description: O'NEILL--John T. Of Chatham Township on September 24, 2004. Mr. O'Neill is survived by his beloved wife, Jane Byrnes O'Neill and seven children: John O'Neill of Austin, TX, Nancy Brooks of Duxbury, MA, Peter O'Neill of Millburn, NJ, Stephen O'Neill of Ponte Vedra, FL, Susan Guiliano of Basking Ridge, NJ, Michael O'Neill of Morristown, NJ, Mary Jo Gagliardi of Brooklyn, NY; two brothers: James O'Neill of Winchester, MA, Robert O'Neill of Lexington, MA and sister, Julie O'Neill of Medford, MA, and 11 grandchildren. Mr. O'Neill is also survived by five step-children: Shaun Byrnes of Basking Ridge, NJ, Brian Byrnes of Richmond, VA, Kerry Dario of Mill Valley, CA, Megan Hatt of Natick, MA, Timothy Byrnes of New York, NY, and 11 stepgrandchildren. Mr. O'Neill's first wife, Ruth Ann Gavagan O'Neill, pre-deceased him in 1987. Services were private. Donations in John's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Greater New Jersey Chapter, 400 Morris Avenue, Suite 251, Denville, New Jersey 07834-1365 or Tufts University Athletics Department, Attn: Eric Johnson, Medford, MA, 02155. To send condolences or for further information www.bradleyfuneralhomes .com

But when a black-corsetted Joyce Van Patten shows up to deliver a smutty song in the New York premiere of "The Oldest Profession," an early play by Paula Vogel, it is not an occasion for wincing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEUER, WALTER
description: SCHEUER -- Walter. The Swarthmore College community mourns the loss of its distinguished and beloved alumnus Walter Scheuer. Wally, individual connection by individual connection, helped build a global world and, through education, business, music, dance, and film, succeeded in bridging difference on a world scale. He was a philanthropist not only of resources but of confidence, courage, personal engagement, shared vision, and delight, who helped free Swarthmore and so many institutions to be their best selves. In 1998, fifty years after his graduation from Swarthmore, Wally honored the College by accepting an honorary degree. He spoke to the graduates of the grand adventures to come. He asked them to carry with them their hopes, their dreams, and the goodwill of their families and classmates. He charged them to be happy, to be loving, to keep their sense of humor, and always, always to be free. He urged them to make a difference, to engage life, to be messengers of peace. Experiencing the impact of his genius to connect and to empower, the graduates rose to salute Wally with one of the rare standing ovations in the history of Swarthmore commence ments--and then went off to infect the world with the powers Wally had so lovingly released in them.

title: National Briefing | West: California: A Call To Drain Yosemite Reservoir
description: A study released in Oakland by the advocacy group Environmental Defense suggests that the Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park, flooded in the 1920's as a reservoir for San Francisco, could be restored without jeopardizing most water and hydroelectric power supplies. The study proposes shifting water at Hetch Hetchy to reservoirs outside the park and to aquifers. Additional water, when needed, could be bought from farmers. A spokesman for the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission called the study "a very rosy scenario." Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said adopting the plan would be "a terrible mistake." Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Italy Rejoices at Release of Aid Workers in Iraq
description: ROME, Sept. 28  Italy rejoiced tonight at the safe release of the young Italian aid workers known here as "the two Simonas," whose three weeks in captivity wrenched the nation and stamped real faces on the rising dangers of the war in Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Slips
description: German business confidence fell for a fourth month in five in September, held down by stagnant consumer spending. The Ifo institute's confidence index, based on a survey of 7,000 companies, declined to 95.2 from 95.3 in August. The index touched a three-year high of 97.5 in January. German companies expect a "slight weakening" in global demand, Ifo said. Without exports, Germany's economy would not have grown in the first half. Spending by households, hampered by rising unemployment, barely rose in the second quarter after stagnating or declining in the previous year. Ifo said an index tracking the assessment of companies' current business rose to 94.8 from 94.7, and a measure of future expectations dropped to 95.7 from a revised 95.9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRY, EDYTHE ''PENNY'' (NEE ATKINSON)
description: BARRY -- Edythe "Penny" (nee Atkinson) On September 25, 2004. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of William, John and Lisa Pilla. Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Billy, T.J., Tricia, Sean and Kyle. Reposing Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 A.M. at St. Gabriel's Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Red Cross would be greatly appreciated.

title: Thais Suspect Human Spread of Bird Flu
description: BANGKOK, Tuesday, Sept. 28 - Two members of a Thai family have fallen ill with avian influenza, and a third probably died of it, the Thai health ministry announced Tuesday morning, saying that human-to-human transmission of the deadly illness had probably occurred for the first time this year.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Perot Systems Increases 3rd-Quarter Forecasts
description: The Perot Systems Corporation, the computer-services company founded by the billionaire Ross Perot, increased its third-quarter sales and profit forecasts as customers spent more on consulting. The shares rose as much as 12 percent. Profit will rise to 21 cents to 23 cents a share on sales of $448 million to $460 million, Perot Systems said. In August, the company forecast earnings of 17 cents or 18 cents a share on sales of $430 million to $445 million. Customers are investing more in their computer systems, bolstering revenue from technology advice, installation of software and networks and the combining of systems, said Perot Systems, based in Plano, Tex. Lower tax expenses will account for 3 cents of the profit increase. The company earned 14 cents a share on sales of $371.3 million in last year's third quarter. Analysts expected a profit of 18 cents a share in the current quarter, the average of 11 estimates in a survey by Thomson First Call. Analysts predicted sales of $438.8 million. Perot Systems will report third-quarter results on Nov. 2. Shares of Perot Systems rose $1, to $14.71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASSAN, SANDRA
description: KASSAN--Sandra. Of Westport, CT, died Saturday night, September 25, 2004, at her home on her 58th birthday. She is survived by her husband, Alan Kassan, her sons, Matthew and Andrew, three grandchildren Madison, Taylor and Sydney, her brother, Mark, and her sister, Joan. She will be remembered as a loving wife, mother, sister, friend and lover of life. Donations can be made on her behalf to The Lustgarten Foundation For Pancreatic Cancer Research at 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY, 11714, Phone: 516-803-2304.

title: Jordan's King Says 'Chaos' in Iraq Rules Out January Vote

By the time he died in 1989, leaving hundreds of signed sheets of paper to spawn a fake Dal industry, many in the art world had turned against him.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Diamond Caper
description: Two diamonds worth more than $14 million were stolen at the Antique Dealers Biennale at the Carrousel du Louvre, in the Louvre Museum complex in Paris. The thieves broke into a display case of the Geneva-based jeweler Chopard when employees stepped away for a few minutes. The police said the case containing the 47- and 30-carat diamonds did not have an alarm system. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: PLAYTEX SELLS WOOLITE TO BISSELL FOR $62 MILLION
description: Playtex Products, the maker of consumer and personal products, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Woolite rug- and upholstery-cleaning business to the closely held Bissell for about $62 million. The transaction was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter, and the proceeds may be used to repay debt or reinvest in the company's main businesses, Playtex said. The company, based in Westport, Conn., said it sold Woolite because it was the only household product the company offered. Bissell, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., makes home cleaning products.

title: Drugs to Help Smokers and Block Heart Attacks Show Promise
description: Two experimental drugs developed by biotechnology companies -- one to prevent heart attacks and the other to help people quit smoking -- have shown promising preliminary results, executives said.

F.D.A. DENIES APPROVAL OF ALLERGANS PSORIASIS CAPSULES
description: Allergan, the maker of Botox, said that the Food and Drug Administration had rejected its application to treat psoriasis with tazarotene capsules. The F.D.A. asked the company for a study that showed the drug was not inferior to other treatments for severe psoriasis. The agency also asked for a more comprehensive plan for making sure that tazarotene was not widely used for less serious conditions like acne and for improvements to the manufacturing of the capsules. Allergan, based in Irvine, Calif., already sells a tazarotene gel and cream for treating psoriasis and acne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, DEBRA E.
description: GOLDMAN--Debra E. Beloved wife of twenty-three years of Leonard Ellis. Cherished sister of Karen Goldman. Devoted daughter of the late Harold and Min Goldman. Adored daughter-in-law of Kenneth Ellis and the late Phyllis Ellis. Loving sister-inlaw of Andrew Ellis and Emily Segal and bemused aunt to Dana, Henry and Rebecca and dedicated friend to Jim Scholfield, Bertelle Selig, Phil Swaboda, Alison Fahey, Ida Steinberg and her daughter Debra Goldman who died at age 52 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Born in St. Louis, she graduated from the University of Michigan and moved immediately to New York City where she filled her life and those who shared it with her passions for theatre, literature, opera, ballet, travel and a constant stream of intelligent, usually hilarious conversation. She will be long remembered and deeply missed by all to whom she gave so much. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday, September 29 at 11:30AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: An Early Retirement Plan
description: About 1,000 members of the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union at Bell Canada, Canada's No. 1 phone company, accepted early retirement packages as part of a cost-cutting plan, the union said. Employees 60 or older or with at least 30 years of service at Bell Canada, a unit of BCE, were eligible, said Joel Carr, administrative vice president in Ontario for the union. France Poulin, a spokeswoman for BCE, would not comment on the figures but said that details would be released about the time BCE reports its third-quarter results. Workers from other unions and nonunion employees were also eligible for the packages.

description: Teams of sharpshooters have been dispatched with dart guns to inoculate wildlife against anthrax after a major outbreak killed at least 1,500 animals in the country's southeast corner, the chief of Zimbabwe veterinary services said. The region, which abuts Mozambique and South Africa's Kruger National Park, has been repeatedly hit with animal disease outbreaks since early this decade, when supporters of President Robert Mugabe's ZANU-PF party, seizing land for themselves, began tearing down park boundary fences. His doctor suggested switching medications, but Mr. Szymanski, wary of side effects, decided to try something he had always wondered about: acupuncture.

Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Jury Selected In East Hampton Case
description: After more than three weeks, lawyers finished selecting a jury yesterday to try Daniel Pelosi on charges that he murdered the millionaire Ted Ammon in his East Hampton home nearly three years ago. When the jury of nine women and three men plus four alternates was finally culled from a pool of around 300 potential jurors in county court, Mr. Pelosi, 41, whispered, "Yes! Finally." A woman who had already been selected as a juror was excused after telling the court that she had panic attacks because friends identified her as a juror from press accounts. Peter C. Beller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Stake In Can Maker Acquired
description: Rexam, the world's largest maker of beverage cans, has bought the 50 percent of Vitro-American National Can it did not own from Vitro for $26.5 million to expand further in Latin America. The business, known as VanCan, has one plant in Quertaro, Mexico. It had sales of $70 million last year and employs about 140 people, said David Yates, a spokesman for Rexam. Rexam won regulatory approval last month to buy Alcoa's Latasa unit, a can maker based in So Paulo, Brazil, with interests in Brazil, Argentina and Chile. Rexam, which is based in London, gets about 80 percent of its revenue from selling cans.

title: How I Ordered a Pilot to Land

title: School Worker Strip-Searched 4 Boys, Suit Says
description: When a teacher's aide reported that her ring was missing, four fourth-grade boys say, they were taken out of class one morning in April and led to an empty room in another part of their Bronx elementary school. There, behind a closed door, the boys say, a male employee threatened to send them to jail, ordered their clothes off, made them jump around in their underwear and searched them for a ring that was never found.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MORFORD, GORDON NADAL
description: MORFORD--Gordon Nadal, of Southampton and Palm Beach, died on September 22. Beloved husband of Elizabeth M. Morford and the late Mari R. Morford. Father of Christopher Peter. Service will be held on October 3 at 2pm at St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton.

title: Corrections

Nassau County's Credit Ratings Back in 'A' Range
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 27 - The Nassau County government, whose wayward finances flirted with insolvency even during the booming 1990's, has regained its A-range rating from all three major credit rating agencies for the first time in a dozen years.

title: Inquiry on Medicare Finds Improper Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - Federal investigators said Monday that the Bush administration had improperly allowed some private health plans to limit Medicare patients' choice of health care providers, including doctors, nursing homes and home care agencies.

title: Geoffrey Beene, Innovator of American Fashion, Dies at 77
description: Geoffrey Beene, a single-minded innovator who put fashion above commerce yet succeeded in making a business from originality, died today at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 77.

title: When to Go In: Sudan and the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo To Revise Home Page
description: Yahoo is preparing to renovate its home page -- Yahoo.com -- and its My Yahoo personalized news and information service. Yahoo.com is the most visited single page on the Internet, with 66 million users in the United States last month. It is mainly getting a cosmetic makeover, which reduces the size of Yahoo's directory of Web sites -- its original service -- and increases the emphasis on Web search and entertainment news. My Yahoo, which was used by 20 million people last month, is undergoing a more radical change that will allow users to put information from more than 150,000 sources on their custom pages. Until now, My Yahoo offered users a choice of news headlines, sports scores and financial information drawn from several hundred sources. These included Yahoo services and companies having business arrangements with Yahoo. Now Yahoo will use emerging technology known as really simple syndication, or R.S.S., a format that allows publishers of Web pages to make their content available to software that can read it and present it in different formats. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Growth In Exports
description: Hong Kong's exports rose at the fastest pace in six months as the city's ports handled more components bound for China and Chinese-made toys, clothes and computers en route to the United States, Europe and Japan. Exports in August rose 21 percent from a year ago, to 182.7 billion Hong Kong dollars ($23.4 billion), after climbing 16.5 percent in July, the government said. Trade with China has helped drive an economic rebound in Hong Kong in the last year. Goods made in China and shipped through Hong Kong account for more than 90 percent of the city's overseas sales.

title: The Wealth of the Season
description: The merest touch of frost the other morning brought down the potatoes in the lower garden. It seemed all the more surprising because the vines had been so rank with growth. Suddenly all the green was gone, and I could see the lumps where the new spuds -- ready to be gathered -- lay hidden under the straw. I began lifting potatoes. Wherever I pulled a plant, I found earthworms thriving in the borderland between straw and soil, writhing in their sudden exposure as though being threaded on a fishhook. The potatoes looked overexposed, too, still thin-skinned, their brilliant white flesh visible through their jackets.

title: 60-Story Building Is Proposed Near Nassau Coliseum
description: The co-owner of the New York Islanders hockey team is proposing a 60-story tower in the center of Nassau County -- more than triple the height of the tallest existing building on Long Island.

title: MOLSON EXPECTS TO CLOSE COORS DEAL NEAR YEAREND
description: Molson, the big Canadian brewer that is facing shareholder opposition and a potential lawsuit over its planned $3.4 billion merger with the Adolph Coors Company, said that it expected the transaction to close the week of Dec. 27. Molson said that it would put the stock swap to a shareholder vote the week of Dec. 13. The votes of two-thirds of each of Molson's Class A and Class B shareholders are needed to approve the transaction. Opposition to the combination has grown since Sept. 17, when Molson said in a regulatory filing that it intended to give company stock options, mostly held by Molson executives, the same voting rights as the Class A shares. Coors is based in Golden, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   B00C0CK, GLENN WINNETT
description: B00C0CK -- Glenn Winnett. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Glenn Winnett Boocock, an Honorary Director and a great friend to our company. "Dougie" Boocock was a member of The Metropolitan Opera Board of Directors from 1967 until 1976, when she was elected to The Met's first group of Managing Directors. She was named Honorary Director in 1985. Over many years, she was a graceful, gracious and always welcome presence in this house. We extend our condolences to her daughters, Susanna and Leslie, to her grandchildren and to her many friends. Beverly Sills, Chairman of the Board Mrs. Ezra K. Zilkha, Vice Chairman of the Board William C. Morris, President Joseph Volpe, General Manager

title: Lights, Camera, Action, Now Censor
description: SEATTLE - I'm a bit of a crank when it comes to watching movies on something other than a proper screen on which the actual film is projected the way the director meant it to be seen. If I put a movie on the television and hear Jack Nicholson saying, "Gosh darn," I'm clicking the remote on to Comedy Central. I know some shadowy censor has edited the script and hired a mimic to voice-over the offensive words, and that the rest of the movie is going to be a hash.

description: MARTIN--Polly D. Age 47, on September 24th, 2004, following an heroic struggle. Cherished and beloved sister of Liz Martin and Cecilia and John Ford. Adored and devoted aunt to Kate White, Eliza Ford and Clementine Ford. Memorial service, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St and 5th Ave, Friday, October 1st at 11AM.

description: Barely recognized by a crowd that might not have been on the block if he hadn't been there first, the man who Disneyfied Times Square walked across 42nd Street yesterday to take in a decade's worth of change. And express a passing regret or two.

He is Ashraf Jehangir Qazi, not Ashfar.

title: U.S. Voices Concern on Chinese Detainee

title: Japan's Leader Shuffles Cabinet to Push Economic Reforms
description: TOKYO Sept. 27 - With Japan's banking crisis coming under control, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi shifted his economic repairman on Monday to Japan's next gargantuan task: privatizing the world's largest bank.

title: A Hemingway story
Swagger vs. Substance
description: Let's face it: whatever happens in Thursday's debate, cable news will proclaim President Bush the winner. This will reflect the political bias so evident during the party conventions. It will also reflect the undoubted fact that Mr. Bush does a pretty good Clint Eastwood imitation.

title: Scientists Begin a Campaign to Oppose President's Policies
description: While Bruce Springsteen, Dave Matthews and other rock stars sing on a "Vote for Change" concert tour, another disgruntled group -- this one of scientists -- will crisscross the well-worn landscape of battleground states over the next month, giving lectures that will argue that the Bush administration has ignored and misused science.

title: Moist Nose Shows Promise in Tracking Down Cancers
description: British researchers have trained dogs to detect bladder cancer by sniffing human urine, opening up the possibility that dogs -- or electronic noses modeled on their snouts -- may one day be used to detect the disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITMAN, JANET RUSSELL
description: WHITMAN--Janet Russell on September 25, 2004 at age 85 after a long battle with cancer. Widow of NY Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman, Jr. who died in 2002. Mother of Charles S. Whitman, III, John R. Whitman and Janet Whitman and grandmother of Kate Annis, Taylor Whitman and Elizabeth Whitman. Mrs. Whitman served for many years as a director and officer of charities and patriotic societies in New York and Watch Hill, Rhode Island, among them Sheltering Arms Childrens Service (president and chairman), The Society for the Relief of Women and Children, The Daughters of the Cincinnati (president), the Stony Wold-Herbert Fund, The Colonial Dames of America and the Watch Hill Village Improvement Society (president). A memorial service will be held at 4:30pm on October 14, 2004 at St. James Church, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Sheltering Arms Childrens Service, 129 West 27th Street, New York, NY 10001, or Watch Hill Chapel Society POB 173 Westerly, RI 02891.

title: Upcoming: Heated U.S. presidential debates
Paid Notice: Deaths   BOOCOCK, GLENN
description: BOOCOCK -- Glenn. The Board of Directors of The Metropolitan Opera Guild mourns the death of its beloved Board member, Glenn Winnett Boocock. Dougie, as she was affectionately known, joined our Board in 1948, and served with great distinction as a Vice President and on our Executive, Membership, Special Events and Nominating Committees, all of which she chaired at various times. She was passionately devoted to opera and to The Met, and in April 1987, was awarded The Guild's highest honor, our Eleanor Robson Belmont Medal. We will miss her candor, good humor and friendship, and extend our sympathies to her daughters, Susanna and Leslie. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Susan S. Braddock, Pres. David A. Dik, Managing Dir.

title: CARDINAL HEALTH DELAYS EARNINGS REPORT FOR 3RD TIME
description: Cardinal Health, a drug distributor being investigated by federal regulators, said that it would delay reporting financial results for fiscal 2004 a third time to give the company's audit committee time to finish a review. Cardinal said that it planned to file the results with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the end of October. The delay would not change a June 30 forecast that 2004 profit would rise 11 percent, the company said. The S.E.C. and the United States attorney's office for the Southern District of New York are investigating the company's accounting. Cardinal will report fourth-quarter results at the same time as fiscal 2004 results, a Cardinal spokesman, Jim Mazzola, said.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Protest Suit Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday threw out a lawsuit against New York City by eight firefighters who claimed that their constitutional rights were violated when they were arrested at a protest at ground zero on Nov. 2, 2001. The firefighters, including Michael Carter, a vice president of the Uniformed Firefighters' Association, joined a march that day to protest orders from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to cut back on police officers and firefighters searching for victims' remains in the ruins of the World Trade Center. All charges against people arrested at the protest were dropped a month later. Judge Richard J. Holwell ruled that the firefighters' arrests were not malicious because it was clear they were not authorized to march to the trade center site. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: In Party Speech, Blair Admits Political Cost of Iraq Mistakes
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 28 A Prime Minister Tony Blair acknowledged today that there had been a decline of public trust in his government over the military campaign in Iraq and he offered the assembled delegates of his governing Labor Party a qualified apology for some of the judgments he had made in taking the country to war.

She is survived by her cherished family-daughter Susan and partner Sandy; son David, daughter-in-law Marisa and granddaughter Donielle; daughter Lori; son Andrew; and her beloved dog Sweetie. Gravesite service will be held at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ on September 28 at 2pm.

description: There was a time not too long ago when political strategists were uncertain whether candidates would even be able to use the threat of terror or the Sept. 11 attacks in their campaigns. The emotions were thought to be too raw, the trauma too real. The thinking was that voters might recoil at the use of the terror attacks for political purposes.

description: The voice on the other end of the telephone is alluring, and the image in your mind is too. But can you hear what a person looks like? Maybe so.

title: Palestinian Premier Urges New Way on Intifada Anniversary
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 A On the fourth anniversary of the Palestinian uprising, Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei urged both Palestinians and Israelis today to reassess strategies they have adopted during the grinding conflict.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on July 20 with an article about the sale of insurance and mutual funds on military bases misstated the basic death benefit provided by a life insurance policy sold to marines at Camp Pendleton, Calif., by the American Amicable Life Insurance Company of Waco, Tex. It is $44,000, in addition to any cash value, not $44,306. The company reported the error on Sept. 15, and this correction was further delayed for checking.

title: For the Splendidly Dressed Man, Web Sites to Match
description: One afternoon last week, a member of Styleforum.net, a Web site devoted to the discussion of men's clothing and lifestyle, asked fellow members about a shoe that had aroused his curiosity. The shoe, a cap-toe lace-up from the British cobbler Poulsen Skone, was not the sort of thing one finds at Brooks Brothers. Costing $1,500, it was made of Russian reindeer hide salvaged from a shipwrecked Danish brigantine -- the Catherina von Flensburg -- that had sunk off the coast of Cornwall in 1786.

title: New Jersey, Overlooked No Longer, Gets a Visit From Edwards
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28 - Promising to "crush" Al Qaeda and protect the country, Senator John Edwards on Tuesday night made the Democratic presidential campaign's first foray into a state where 9/11 resonates deeply and that until recently was considered solidly Democratic turf.Mr. Edwards, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, attacked a television commercial by a group supporting President Bush that uses images of Osama bin Laden and the World Trade Center and questions whether Senator John Kerry would be aggressive in rooting out terrorists.

title: Under Pressure, HUD Ends Shift on Home-Aid Formula
description: Bowing to strong bipartisan pressure, the Bush administration said last night that it would retreat from a housing proposal that critics said would have forced thousands of poor people in urban areas, especially in the Northeast, to pay more money to stay in their apartments, or else move into shoddier neighborhoods.

England, who became the face of the Abu Ghraib prison abuse scandal in photographs that were beamed around the world showing her holding a leash around the neck of a crawling and naked Iraqi detainee.

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: DNA Links Inmate To Rape Of Child
description: A jail inmate was charged in the rape of a 9-year-old girl on a Harlem rooftop last summer after DNA evidence linked him to the crime, the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. Ernest Jones, 27, pleaded not guilty to charges of rape, sodomy, endangering the welfare of a child and sexual abuse. He was already in jail for a July 31 assault of a 21-year-old woman in Harlem, for which he was charged yesterday. A blood sample taken Aug. 6 matched DNA evidence collected after the little girl's attack on Malcolm X. Boulevard in July 2003, the authorities said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday, and a front-page contents entry, about allegations that an English playwright plagiarized the work of others for her Tony-nominated drama "Frozen" misspelled her given name in some copies. She is Bryony Lavery, not Byrony.

title: Complaints Had Been Made About Operator of Day Care
description: A woman who ran a Queens day care center where a 7-month-old boy was suffocated by toys had been the source of two complaints filed by parents -- one concerning the licensed center where the infant later died, and the other about an unlicensed center that the woman operated across the street, officials said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Guilty Plea In Border Case
description: Farida Goolam Mahomed Ahmed, a resident of Johannesburg, pleaded guilty in federal court in Houston to violating immigration laws by altering her passport and making a false statement to a Border Patrol officer. Ms. Ahmed, 48, has been in custody since her arrest on July 19 as she tried to board a flight to New York at the McAllen-Miller International Airport. Her itinerary indicated that she had traveled from South Africa to Mexico by way of Dubai and London before entering the United States without a visa, wading across the Rio Grande. The case heightened concern that terrorists could easily enter the country through Mexico. Ms. Ahmed will remain in custody until she is sentenced in January. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Treasury Being Sued for Curbs on Editing
description: Treasury Department regulations against editing manuscripts from Cuba, Iran and other countries under American economic sanctions violate the First Amendment of the Constitution and should be overturned, a group of American publishers said in a federal lawsuit filed yesterday.

title: Intimate, mammoth Mikhailov
City of Fishermen in Pakistan Becomes Strategic Port
description: GWADAR, Pakistan - This city of mostly poor fishermen and their families sits on an isthmus between two picturesque bays, its most distinctive feature a flat-topped mountain of rock that extends into the sea like a fortress wall.

title: People
description: Joe Sciara was named senior vice president and director for marketing at Barkley Evergreen & Partners, Kansas City, Mo. He will be responsible for business development. He assumes those duties from Knox Duncan, senior vice president and director for planning, who had handled them temporarily since last year. Mr. Sciara had been co-president at Three Wide, Kansas City, Mo., which is majority-owned by Barkley Evergreen.

title: F.B.I. Said to Lag onTranslating Terror Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - Three years after the Sept. 11 attacks, more than 120,000 hours of potentially valuable terrorism-related recordings have not yet been translated by linguists at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and computer problems may have led the bureau to systematically erase some Qaeda recordings, according to a declassified summary of a Justice Department investigation that was released on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THALER, ANNA (HENYA)
description: THALER--Anna (Henya) Dolgin, of Brooklyn, New York, on September 27, 2004. b. Olevsk, Russia, 1910, immigrated to the US in 1929. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Solomon Thaler. Adored by her children Rena Thaler Rauch, Stuart Rauch, and Dr. Alvin Thaler; beloved grandmother of Benjamin Rauch, Meredith Rauch-Broxmeyer, Adam Thaler, Jonathan Thaler; great-grandmother of Dalia Margolis Thaler. A published author, she will be remembered for her powerful persona and intellect, her language, narrative and linguistic skills, her devotion to social service, vocational and educational programs in Israel, and especially for the profound impact she had on her children and her children's children. Funeral at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI, on Wednesday, September 29th at 11:15am. Shiva will be observed at 2500 Eileen Road, Oceanside, NY 11572. He is Allan Oliver, not Alan. A picture caption gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a league member who visited two women in their damaged home in Orlando. He was Jourdan Haynes, not Hayes.

description: O'NEILL--John, 75, of Chatham Township, on September 24, 2004. John O'Neill is survived by his wife, Jane Byrnes O'Neill, seven children; sons, John, Peter, Stephen, Michael; daughters Nancy Brooks, Susan Giuliano, Mary - Jo Gagliardi. Two brothers, James and Robert and a sister, Julie O'Neill, and 11 grandchildren. Mr. O'Neill is also survived by five stepchildren, Shaun Byrnes, Brian Byrnes, Kerry Dario, Megan Hatt, and Timothy Byrnes, and 11 step-grandchildren. title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Orders Immigration Document Disclosed
description: A federal judge ordered the Justice Department to release by Oct. 12 a document that describes its legal rationale for a policy shift two years ago, when it authorized state law enforcement officers to arrest illegal immigrants suspected in national security cases. The ruling by Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan came in a freedom of information suit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union and two other groups, which contend that state authorities should not enforce federal immigration laws. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Massachusetts Is Getting New Speaker
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 - The speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives, Thomas M. Finneran, who is under federal investigation in a redistricting case, said Monday that he would resign his position effective Tuesday afternoon.

title: Time Warner and Comcast Discuss Bid for Adelphia
description: The Comcast Corporation, the cable giant, said yesterday that it was in talks with Time Warner Inc. to make a joint bid for Adelphia Communications, which has been operating under bankruptcy protection.

title: Annie Herron, 50, an Art Dealer, Is Dead
description: Annie Herron, an art dealer and curator in the East Village of Manhattan in the early 1980's who opened the first commercial gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, died in the Bronx on Friday. She was 50.

Director of Anesthesiology, Maimonides Medical Center, New York, 1966-1986. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91 St., N.Y., 10AM Wednesday, September 29th. title: Trading Charges Over Iraq While Preparing for Debate
description: WEST CHESTER, Ohio, Sept. 27 - Trying out themes for their debate on Thursday, the presidential candidates swung at each other over Iraq on Monday, with President Bush mocking Senator John Kerry as indecisive under pressure and Mr. Kerry accusing him of "refusing to come clean with the American people."

title: A Political Activist to Make a Mother Proud
description: AS he applies to colleges this fall, Richard Prins, 17, has credentials like those of thousands of overachieving, bright, well-educated and well-to-do seniors. High grades, high SAT's; track team, president of two clubs; winner of Scholastic poetry awards and a citywide contest. He's given dozens of poetry readings, written a 100,000-word unpublished novel. He studies Spanish, Greek and Latin at Trinity School, a top private school a block from his family's duplex penthouse, and Swahili at Columbia. (He taught English this summer in Kenya, at a school he helped to build for the Free the Children Foundation, whose board he is joining.)

title: Man With Pistol Is Shot and Killed by Police

title: Cendant Nears Deal to Buy Orbitz Travel Site
description: The Cendant Corporation, which owns Avis car rental and the Days Inn hotel chain, is near a deal to buy Orbitz, the online travel service controlled by a consortium of airlines, for about $1.2 billion in cash, executives close to the talks said.

title: Manufacturer and Airline Dispute Cause of 2001 Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - During the long investigation into the November 2001 crash of an American Airlines jetliner in Queens that killed 265 people, the airline and the plane's manufacturer have engaged in an unusually public dispute about what happened. Now the National Transportation Safety Board is poised to conclude that actions by a pilot were the main cause.

title: Paleontologists Put Ancient Long-Necked Monster in Its Place
description: Giraffes evolved long necks to browse in trees high above the competition. That is as plain as the explanation the wolf in granny clothing gave Little Red Riding Hood for his big teeth: "The better to eat you with, my dear."

title: Tunnel Fire Snarls Evening Rush at Penn Station
description: A fire deep underground in one of the tunnels that feed into Pennsylvania Station halted train traffic for hours yesterday and briefly shut down the terminal, causing confusion and long delays for more than 100,000 riders trying to get home for the evening.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jet Purchase
description: Air Canada has agreed to buy 30 regional aircraft from Bombardier Aerospace. The airline, which will end a period under bankruptcy protection on Thursday, will pay $821 million for the aircraft, which will be used by Air Canada Jazz, its wholly owned regional operating unit. The order announced yesterday is for 15 aircraft with 70 seats and 15 others that carry 50 passengers. Options and conditional orders placed by Air Canada, which is also based in Montreal, could mean that it ultimately buys 90 planes from Bombardier. This week's announcement, however, falls short of an "agreement in principle" announced by the two companies last December. Under its terms, Air Canada would have placed an initial order for 45 aircraft. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALISBURY, NANCY, SR.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Restaurant At J.F.K. Airport Is Robbed
description: A man armed with a gun robbed a restaurant at Kennedy Airport shortly after midnight yesterday, the authorities said. The man did not go through the passenger checkpoint with the gun, said Lou Martinez, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He entered a "safe room," containing money from the restaurant Deep Blue, in an area restricted to employees, Mr. Martinez said, but it is possible to walk from there to the secure boarding area through the restaurant. The man tied up a female employee and stole thousands of dollars, the authorities said; the woman was unharmed. Shaila Dewan (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Publisher Sells Unit

They attacked the National Palace, staged highway assaults that cut the nation in two and blew up schools that were to be polling places.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cisco And Bank Of America To Announce Phone Venture
description: Cisco Systems has won a contract to deploy 180,000 Internet-based telephones into Bank of America branches over the next three years, the companies plan to announce today. The companies did not disclose the amount of the deal. The Cisco-made phones have a list price of $130 to $695 -- depending on features -- though they typically are sold at a considerable discount on big volume deals. Bank of America said it would deploy the phones in nearly 6,000 branches and office locations in order to consolidate its existing phone system, which includes several hundred different vendors and technologies. The Internet-based phones function like standard phones. However, because the voice stream information travels as data, the phones can offer companies added flexibility, according to Cisco. Matt Richtel (NYT)

description: As Florida was cleaning up yesterday from its fourth hurricane in six weeks, insurance executives and analysts said they expected the cost of coverage to rise sharply for millions of homes and businesses in the state.

title: Mysteries of Life, Time and Space (and Green Slime)
description: Thanks to "Origins," a brainy but accommodating series on PBS's "Nova," viewers can see what textbooks can't fully depict. The Earth once had a red sky and green oceans. The Moon loomed larger in a tighter orbit, just after its collision with Earth tilted our planet's axis. And hundreds of millions of years later, after single-cell bacteria led to a carnivorous food chain, a plummeting asteroid zapped the dominant dinosaurs, handing an evolutionary opportunity to mammals.

title: Trans-Atlantic Fare Cut
description: TRANS-ATLANTIC FARE CUT -- Jack Foley, the executive vice president of Aer Lingus-North America, concedes that he speaks heresy, if not outright apostasy. Yesterday, figuring that it can lure away business travelers exasperated by trans-Atlantic round-trip fares of $6,000 and up for business class, Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, announced sharply reduced fares in both business class and economy. The fare structure has been simplified and the need eliminated for round-trip purchases and Saturday night stayovers to obtain the best fare. Fares in business class have been permanently cut by 50 percent or more, and those in economy reduced by 20 to 30 percent. "The strategy is basically to say, the low-fare concept is coming to the Atlantic routes," Mr. Foley said yesterday. Some examples: Unrestricted nonstop one-way business-class fares between Los Angeles and Dublin are now $3,695, a 60 percent cut from previous fares. New York to Dublin is $1,504, a 43 percent reduction. Trans-Atlantic routes have long been plagued by high capacity and high fares. Aer Lingus uses seven Airbus A330's, with 24 business class seats in each, on about 47 round trips a week between the United States and Europe.

title: They Don't Call It the 'Iconoclast' for Nothin'
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Sept. 28 A No wonder President Bush doesn't much like the news media. He woke up at his ranch here today to find that the hometown newspaper, a 1,000-circulation weekly called the Lone Star Iconoclast, was endorsing his opponent, Senator John Kerry.

title: Oil Nears $50 as Gulf Storms Curtail Output
