title: Kerry Pins Hopes in Iowa on Big Vote From Absentees
description: DES MOINES, Sept. 26 - They're off and voting in Iowa, even before all the corn has been harvested.

title: Connecticut Sues 7 Tied to Rowland for Damages
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 27 - Attorney General Richard Blumenthal sued seven associates of former Gov. John G. Rowland on Monday, along with four companies, in connection with what he called "unscrupulous self-dealing at the highest levels of state government." The action adds a civil suit to federal criminal charges filed last week alleging corruption in Mr. Rowland's office.

title: Warehouses for Refugees
description: The starvation and disease stalking the refugee camps near the Darfur region of Sudan are a reminder that for many refugees, conditions where they land are not much better than the conditions they flee. The world has 12 million refugees, and 7.4 million of them have been living in camps or settlements for more than 10 years. Many are prohibited from traveling or working, confined to crowded, squalid tents, at the mercy of marauding gangs, and utterly dependent on handouts of food insufficient to ward off hunger and on health care that does not prevent cholera and dysentery. Some people have lived in such camps for generations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: New Ferry To Join Fleet
description: It is customary to name water vessels after dead people, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg waived that rule yesterday in anointing the latest addition to the Staten Island ferry fleet for a fellow Republican and a former borough president, Guy V. Molinari. "When it came to naming this, it was a no-brainer," he said at a ceremony to accept delivery of the boat at the St. George Ferry Terminal on Staten Island. The $40 million boat is to begin operating next year and is one of several that will replace three boats that have been running for 40 years between Lower Manhattan and Staten Island. Larger and spiffier than its predecessors, it can carry up to 4,500 passengers and has an open upper deck where passengers can sit outside and enjoy the view. It will feature an artwork commissioned by the German artist Werner Klotz called "The Middle of the World," a multimedia installation with a portal in the bridge deck through which passengers can view a video of the ocean floor. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Corrections Officers Stage Rally for 12% Annual Pay Raises
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27 - State law enforcement officers rallied in Trenton on Monday for a new contract that would include 12 percent annual pay raises and continued out-of-network medical benefits. As part of the protest, more than 1,000 corrections officers called in sick to attend the rally, according to state and labor officials.

title: 2 Abducted Italian Women Freed in Iraq After 3 Weeks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 28 A Two Italian aid workers kidnapped earlier this month in an audacious daylight raid on their home were freed today, the prime minister of Italy said. Two Iraqi aid workers abducted with the women were also freed.

title: A Crammed and Confused Evening Rush
description: At 2 p.m., they were curious. At 4 p.m., they were confused. By 6 p.m., they were angry.

title: Eddie Adams, war photographer
Truths Worth Telling
description: Kensington, Calif. - On a tape recording made in the Oval Office on June 14, 1971, H.R. Haldeman, Richard Nixon's chief of staff, can be heard citing Donald Rumsfeld, then a White House aide, on the effect of the Pentagon Papers, news of which had been published on the front page of that morning's newspaper:

title: The Yankees' Rotation Leaves Heads Spinning
description: Since the turn of the 20th century, 89 teams have won 100 games in a season. All of them -- from the 1902 Pittsburgh Pirates to this year's St. Louis Cardinals -- have something in common. Somewhere on their roster is at least one pitcher with 15 victories.

title: Delta Expected to Announce More Moves to Reduce Costs
description: Delta Air Lines, which is striving to avoid a bankruptcy filing, is expected to announce more internal cost cuts, including changes to employee benefits, as soon as today.

title: How Young Is Too Young to Have a Nose Job and Breast Implants?
description: Thanks in part to television shows like "I Want a Famous Face" on MTV, "The Swan" on Fox and "Extreme Makeover" on ABC, cosmetic surgery is more popular than ever. And children and teenagers are not immune to the trend.

title: Mayor's Promotion Standards Are Approved for Fifth Grade
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last night easily won approval of new promotion rules for fifth graders, with none of the fireworks that accompanied the vote on his third-grade promotion plan in March, when he fired two members of the Panel for Educational Policy who had vowed to oppose him.

title: Sales of New Homes Soar; Gain Is Largest in 4 Years
description: Sales of new homes jumped 9.4 percent in August, higher than economists had expected and the biggest gain since the end of 2000, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Manslaughter Charges In Car Crash
description: A 32-year-old Manhattan man already charged with drunken driving in a car crash that killed four teenagers was charged yesterday with four counts of second-degree manslaughter, the Nassau County district attorney's office said. The driver, Gerrard Ganz, has pleaded guilty to one charge of driving while intoxicated and is expected to be arraigned on the new charges this morning. The crash occurred early Saturday morning in Westbury, when a Dodge Magnum driven by Mr. Ganz collided with a Honda sedan carrying five teenagers. The Honda then struck a telephone pole and exploded, killing everyone except the 17-year-old driver. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: BRIEFLY:ASIA/PACIFIC:PARIS : Doctors tell Anwar to focus on recuperation
Technology Briefing | Communications: Nortel Names Marketing Chief
description: Clent Richardson, a former marketing executive at Apple Computer and T-Mobile, was named yesterday as Nortel Networks' chief marketing officer, a position that has been vacant for almost three years. William Owens, president and chief executive of Nortel, the telecommunications equipment maker, has repeatedly said that Nortel's engineering skills have not been matched by its marketing and sales efforts. In a statement, he called the appointment "a pivotal first step toward transforming Nortel Networks into a marketing-led organization." Mr. Richardson, 43, joined Nortel in April to lead the marketing operations of a group that makes products for corporations. Previously he was T-Mobile's chief sales and marketing officer. Most of Mr. Richardson's time at Apple was spent in developing partnerships with, among others, Microsoft and I.B.M. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Of Mice, Men and 'Magic' Diet Supplements
description: With ephedra off the shelves and low-fat and low-carb diets getting you nowhere, you might be tempted to turn to a supplement called conjugated linoleic acid, or C.L.A., that has received an increasing amount of attention both in scientific and lay circles in recent years.

title: Q & A
description: Primitive Gilding

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Sports Ceremony Canceled After Fatalities
description: The festive portions of the closing ceremony of the Greek Paralympics in Athens were canceled after seven students were killed in a bus crash on their way to the event. The authorities said the bus carrying 37 students and 4 teachers was traveling from Farkadona, in northern Greece, to Athens when it hit a truck. State schools were ordered to close Wednesday in mourning. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKELL, MARCIA R.
description: MARKELL--Marcia R. Died September 27, 2004. Born January 9, 1928 in Boston. Wife of Elliot. Mother of Jonathan, Jane, Alyson and the late David Markell. Grandmother of David, James and Emily. Graveside service at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, on Wednesday at 1 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Technology Briefing | Communications: Leucadia Sells Stake In MCI
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, the investment group that had expressed an interest in taking a large stake in MCI, said yesterday that it had sold all its common stock in the company. In a filing with regulators, Leucadia said the sale of its MCI stock generated a pretax gain of about $20 million. In August, Leucadia said it owned 15,738,100 shares of MCI worth approximately $245.9 million. Despite the sale of its MCI stock, Leucadia said it had not ruled out acquiring MCI in the future. MCI, which has been struggling in the long-distance business, has hired three investment banks to help it field bids from potential buyers. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: On the Trail, Taking the Low Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Toonology: Scientists Try to Find Out What's So Funny About Humor
description: So this group of scientists is setting out to study humor, and they wire up their research subjects and -- hang on. Is this a New Yorker cartoon?

title: EU nominee defends business record, promising to be impartial
World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Turmoil In Peace Talks
description: Negotiations between the government and right-wing paramilitary commanders are at a breaking point, with the two sides arguing vehemently and one important paramilitary commander boycotting the talks, according to transcripts of secret audiotapes published by Semana magazine. The tapes also show the government pledging that paramilitaries who disarm will not be extradited to face drug-trafficking charges in the United States. But the talks were thrown into further disarray when the government announced that one paramilitary commander, Juan Carlos Sierra, was not considered a negotiator in the talks and would be arrested, opening the door to his extradition. The paramilitaries control much of Colombia's drug trafficking and have considerable influence in regional government and the military. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: On the Trail, Taking the Low Road (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rules Against Europe's Antitrust Chief in MCI Case
description: RUSSELS, Sept. 28 - The European Commission was wrong to block the proposed $120 billion merger four years ago between MCI WorldCom and Sprint, a European court ruled today.

title: Wielding a Keen Eraser for a Troubled Memory
description: 'Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind'

title: ULTRALIFE MISSES FORECAST AS ARMY BUYS FEWER BATTERIES
description: Ultralife Batteries said that third-quarter revenue missed its forecast because the United States Army, its largest customer, bought fewer batteries. The news set off a 30 percent decline in the company's share price. Revenue in the quarter, which ended Sept. 25, was $24 million, the company said. Profit figures were not available, Ultralife's chief financial officer, Robert Fishback, said. The company has asked the military to rework the battery contract, hoping for a higher per-unit price since volume was lower than anticipated. Ultralife, based in Newark, N.Y., employs 750 people but said it might have to lay off 250 workers if sales do not increase. The company's stock price fell $4.25, to $9.80 a share.

title: Microsoft Weighs Resuming Negotiations With Europe
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the world's largest software maker, said yesterday that it might restart settlement talks with European Union regulators after Europe's second-highest court ruled on whether penalties should be suspended.

title: Sikh Group Finds Calling in Homeland Security
description: ESPANOLA, N.M. - At the end of a dusty road, behind a barbed-wire fence, is the Sikh Dharma of New Mexico, a religious compound with a golden temple of worship, a collection of trailers used for business and a quiet group of people wandering the grounds wearing flowing white robes and turbans.

title: All Is Not Sweet at the Home Base of Coca-Cola
description: In late June, just a few weeks after coming out of retirement to become the Coca-Cola Company's latest chief executive, E. Neville Isdell visited Coke's regional managers in China. He remembers one in particular, a young woman named Lily, on the job less than three years and radiating zeal and spunk. "She reminded me of myself at her age, just full of enthusiasm for the business and the brand," Mr. Isdell, 61, said.

title: World Briefings
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Barriers to Student Voting
description: Correction Appended

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TIFFANY & CO., New York, the retailer of luxury jewelry, said that it would open a store in Shanghai, its second in China.

title: Voters in 10 States Likely to Ban Gay Marriages
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Messier Appeals Bond Ruling
description: Jean-Marie Messier, the former chief executive of Vivendi Universal, left, filed an appeal with France's highest court to have his bail reduced after a Paris court rejected his appeal earlier this month, his lawyer, Olivier Metzner, said. Mr. Messier, who is under investigation for share-price manipulation, improper insider trading and fraud while he was the chief of Vivendi, argued that he was unable to pay the 1.35 million euro ($1.65 million) bail. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Turkey, key to the Mideast : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Solving a Riddle Written in Silver
description: The words are among the most familiar and ecumenical in the liturgies of Judaism and Christianity. At the close of a worship service, the rabbi, priest or pastor delivers, with only slight variations, the comforting and fortifying benediction:

title: Iraqi Judge Closes Case Against Ahmad Chalabi
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 27 - A senior Iraqi judge said Monday that he had closed a case brought against Ahmad Chalabi, the former exile leader once backed by the Pentagon, for suspected involvement in a counterfeiting operation.

title: DNA Bar Coding Uncovers Secrets of Costa Rican Butterfly
description: In one of the first uses of DNA bar coding, a new technique for cataloging the planet's species, researchers have uncovered an unexpected richness in the complexity of nature. A long-known butterfly has turned out to be not a single species but 10 different species that live in overlapping territories without interbreeding.

title: BJ's Names Six in Account Review
description: BJ's Wholesale Club in Natick, Mass., named six agencies yesterday to take part in a review for its account, which had been handled on a project basis. BJ's spent an estimated $8.3 million last year to advertise in major media, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: Bias Suit Delayed Against Wal-Mart
description: A federal district judge in San Francisco halted a discrimination lawsuit yesterday against Wal-Mart Stores until an appeals court reviews a ruling that allows 1.6 million female workers to sue as a group.

title: Iraqi parties born in exile turning secular for votes
Beene's Innovations
description: Geoffrey Beene was a single-minded innovator who put fashion above commerce yet succeeded in making a business from originality.

title: Stop Me If Youve Heard This One
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Baseball in Washington
description: Washington hasn't had a Major League Baseball team since the Senators left for Texas and became the Rangers after the 1971 season.

title: Italian, From the Region Near Whimsy
description: WHEN I walked into Petrosino about a month ago, I was suspicious. A friend had described it as a straightforward restaurant with hearty Italian fare, and I had made assumptions and extrapolations, filling in and rounding out that vague picture. I foresaw lighting that was too bright or too dark, generic dcor and an unabashed emphasis on the frumpy over the faddish.

title: Graham Legacy, on the Stage Again
description: When the sensuous, athletic dancers of the Martha Graham Dance Company take the stage at New York City Center tonight to perform Graham's classic "Embattled Garden," they will almost certainly reach a new generation of enthusiasts for the woman who defined contemporary American dance. The company is performing the 1958 ballet as part of a six-night, $10-a-ticket dance festival featuring the work of 30 dance companies.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: APCO Worldwide, Washington, completed a management buyout from the Grey Global Group, New York, for undisclosed terms. Margery Kraus continues as president and chief executive. Grey Global, which acquired majority ownership in APCO in 1991, disclosed plans to sell it last September.

title: New Hughes Research Center to Shift Focus
description: Hoping to emulate the past successes of two world-famous laboratories, the medical institute built from Howard Hughes's fortune is spending $500 million to build a research center that will seek to attract top scientists and encourage them to do hands-on creative work.

title: After a Broadway Opening, Crumbs
description: When Georgia's Bake Shop opened last week at 2418 Broadway (89th Street), Basil Pologianis, an owner and a pastry chef, had trouble keeping up with the opening-day demand. The neighborhood, which had been watching and waiting for weeks, could at last buy the shop's earthy breads and corn muffins with corn kernels and glazed tops. There are also delicate buttery croissants and other French pastries, and tarts including Earl Grey ganache, citrus, lattice pear and macadamia nut. Most of the pastries are $2.50 to $4.50. Mr. Pologianis's partner is Georgia Stamoulis, who is also an owner of Silver Moon uptown. Alain Roudiere, who was at the Castle at Tarrytown, N.Y., creates the pastries.

title: With Oil Near $50 a Barrel, Gas Prices Start to Inch Up
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 28 - As the price of crude oil flirts with $50 a barrel, gasoline prices are heading up again, ending an unusual period in which gasoline prices were falling even as oil prices rose.

title: Anti-Bush Billionaire to Give More
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist who has given $18 million to Democratic advocacy groups to defeat President Bush, is preparing to spend millions more because he fears that Senator John Kerry might lose.

title: Bush, Kerry and a Debate That Isn't (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORKPLACE : Europe narrows the job gap
Blair Offers an Apology, of Sorts, Over Iraq
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 28 - Prime Minister Tony Blair offered his governing Labor Party a qualified apology on Tuesday that the evidence on which he had taken Britain to war in Iraq had proved wrong.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an agreement over accounting between Fannie Mae and its regulator referred incorrectly to legislative efforts in Congress aimed at the company. Lawmakers have pressed for tighter regulation of Fannie Mae, not for full privatization.

title: Parcells Dusts Off Old Strategy to Win Old Rivalry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - It seemed appropriate that the game ended with a Redskins offensive player slamming his helmet to the ground, inches from the sideline and seconds too late for his team to attempt a game-winning field goal.

title: A Bad August Worsens Airline Financial Woes
description: The nation's airlines are seeing their hopes of a decent fall season blow away like a lawn chair on an Orlando patio. Record oil prices, on top of four hurricanes in six weeks that snarled traffic in the all-important Florida market, and a seemingly unending stream of bad financial news are prompting trade groups and analysts to predict that industry losses will approach $5 billion this year.

title: The Quiet Ones Can Surprise You
description: OF all the wine grapes in the world, none are as underrated and under-respected as chenin blanc. Some people may leap to argue the case for riesling, a grape that deserves plenty of accolades. But that only underscores my point, because who out there ever champions the juicy, complex pleasures of chenin blanc?

title: Court Backs Higher Valuation of HealthSouth Investors' Loss
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta has upheld the valuation by prosecutors of $328 million in losses by investors in HealthSouth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about political advertising in the presidential campaign, including a commercial that accused John Kerry of having "secretly met with the enemy" in Paris in the 1970's, misidentified the parties with whom Mr. Kerry said he had met at the Vietnam peace talks. (The error was repeated in articles on Friday and Saturday.) The parties were the two Communist delegations -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government -- with whom he discussed the status of war prisoners. He did not say he had met with "both sides."

title: Gardner Botsford, 87, Dies; Editor at The New Yorker
description: Correction Appended

title: Sentenced to Be Raped
description: MEERWALA, Pakistan - I'm still trying to help out President Bush by tracking down Osama bin Laden. After poking through remote parts of Pakistan, asking for a tall Arab with a beard, I can't say I've earned that $25 million reward.

title: New President of Baruch College Draws Some Hefty Alumni Donations
description: Kathleen M. Waldron has been the president of Baruch College at City University for less than two months. But at a dinner last night, she announced $54 million in new gifts, including a $25 million gift from William and Anita Newman that is one of the largest donations to a public college in New York State.

title: The Young Artists Of the Make-Believe
description: To the Editor:

title: Engineers Studying Vanderbilt (Amy, Not the Commodore)
description: Not too long ago, in the stories of John Cheever or maybe television's "Bewitched," the business meal seemed easy. Everyone knew the rules, and spontaneity had its time and its place.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: More Opposition To Ban On Same-Sex Marriages
description: Breaking ranks from other top Ohio Republicans, Attorney General Jim Petro said he opposed a proposed amendment to the State Constitution to ban same-sex marriages. Mr. Petro said on Monday that the language of the proposal was too sweeping, seeking to bar any type of civil unions and deny the legal standing of marriage to any unmarried couple, and that it would probably hurt the state's economy. Opponents of the proposal, which is on the Nov. 2 ballot, say one consequence of passage would be to deny health benefits to domestic partners of unmarried workers. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Troubled Mets Turn to Minaya
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 - A Mets season marked by disappointing play and questionable trades is ending with the firing of the manager and a drastic restructuring of the front office.

title: Justices Agree to Hear Property Rights Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - The Supreme Court added an important property rights case to its docket on Tuesday, beating the calendar to fill in its schedule for the new term that begins Oct. 4, the traditional first Monday in October.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid For Pub Owner
description: Newbridge Capital offered 1.1 billion Australian dollars ($788 million) for the Australian Leisure and Hospitality Group, the country's biggest owner of pubs, topping an earlier bid made by the Australian retailer Woolworths. Australian Leisure recommended that its shareholders accept the latest offer, but analysts said that Woolworths might raise its bid as it battles a rival, Coles Myer, for a larger share of the market in take-home liquor. Newbridge, which acquires undervalued companies and then tries to improve their performance, offered 3.05 Australian dollars for each share of Australian Leisure. Woolworths bid 2.685 Australian dollars ($1.93) a share. Newbridge is a joint venture between Blum Capital Partners and the Texas Pacific Group. A spokesman for Woolworths said that the company had no immediate comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNTER, PAUL
description: MUNTER--Paul. Sincere condolences and heartfelt sorrow to Beverly, his beloved wife and soul mate of 50 years, and to his dear children and grandchildren Rick, Holly, Cindy, Andrew, Lyndsey, Brian and Lauren. They were the center of his universe. Paul was a gentle giant who led an exemplary life of grace, wisdom and dignity. Jules & Linda Lane & Family MUNTER -- Paul. Deepest sympathy to Beverly our dear friend and co-worker on the passing of her beloved husband Paul. We will miss his warmth, kindness, intellect and generosity. The Officers & Employees of American Medical & Life Insurance Company American Dental Centers

title: Bush, Kerry and a Debate That Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
A Lothario Lawyer Meets His Match
description: The components of "Kevin Hill," which starts tonight on UPN -- the womanizer clichs, the prig nanny, the contrived you-must-file-the-Smith-motion lawyer talk -- are unpromising. But the sum is a profoundly pleasing hour, a show that literalizes the problem faced by ambitious New Yorkers who have migrated from out of town: what are their responsibilities to the past and to the families they left behind?

title: The Senate's Chance on Drug Costs
description: If Dr. Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader, knows what's good for the body politic, he will allow a quick floor vote on the drug reimportation bill he has been bottling up for the benefit of President Bush and the pharmaceutical industry. A large majority -- up to 75 members, by some estimates -- would easily pass the bill and delight the organized older voters who have been clamoring for lower-priced Canadian drugs. American consumers are increasingly aware that their average drug prices are 67 percent higher than what Canadians pay for comparable prescriptions. Bipartisan Senate pressure is growing on Dr. Frist, along with threats of the sort of floor rebellion that saw the Republican House rise up last year to pass a drug reimportation plan over Mr. Bush's opposition.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts In Ferry Service
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, Britain's largest ferry and port operator, plans to cut 1,200 jobs and shut routes to stem losses in the cross-channel ferries business. P.&O. will close 4 of its 13 routes, including Portsmouth, England, to Cherbourg, Caen and LeHavre, France. It will sell or reassign 8 of 31 ferries. The cuts will result in a one-time cost of 240 million ($435 million) this year and will increase operating profit by 55 million annually, the chief executive, Robert Woods, said in a conference call.

title: Sudan Conflict Reaches U.S. Immigration Courts
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 28 - The immigration judge called the case, and the asylum seeker from Africa took his seat in the courtroom here. After raising his right hand and swearing to tell the truth, he began a methodical account of his suffering at the hands of the Arab militias that have killed and maimed thousands of black Africans in the Darfur region of Sudan. The man, Fadl Ibrahim Mohammed, presented the scars on his body as evidence.

title: Rockets Kill 2 Israelis and Prompt Deadly Gaza Clashes
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 A A Palestinian rocket attack today killed two Israeli children, ages 2 and 4, and Israeli soldiers killed five Palestinians as bloodshed claimed young lives on both sides of the Gaza Strip's northern border.

title: Edwards Says Bush Administration of Botching Iraq Plans
description: WEIRTON, W. Va., Sept. 29 A Seizing on a published report that Vice President Dick Cheney had warned of getting "bogged down" in Iraq 12 years ago, Senator John Edwards today accused the Bush administration of botching plans for occupying Iraq and made clear it would be a topic during presidential debates.

title: Ecological protest turns 'waste' into a fashion statement
Nixon as Manipulator and a Feral Child as Victim
description: A bizarre mix of ingredients makes up "Plan B," a new work by Big Dance Theater that opened on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop. This theater-dance piece, which will play through Oct. 9, was inspired largely by President Richard M. Nixon's Watergate tapes and a diary written late in life by Kaspar Hauser, the 19th-century feral child who wandered away from the German forest in which he had been raised.

title: For a Complex Savennire, a Sweet and Simple Taste of the Sea
description: OF the two white-wine varietals commonly cultivated in the Loire Valley, chenin blanc and sauvignon blanc, chenin blanc is more challenging when it comes to food pairings. Unlike grassy, straightforward sauvignon blancs, which are magical with goat cheese, chenin blancs, notably Savennires, do not demand a particular dish. Savennires are complex customers, sometimes borderline sweet, and hinting of tropical fruits, toast and citrus.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about political advertising in the presidential campaign, including a commercial that accused John Kerry of having "secretly met with the enemy" in Paris in the 1970's, misidentified the parties with whom Mr. Kerry said he had met at the Vietnam peace talks. (The error was repeated in articles on Friday and Saturday.) The parties were the two Communist delegations -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government -- with whom he discussed the status of war prisoners. He did not say he had met with "both sides."

title: Guggenheim Family Says Bidder in Lukoil Auction Is Not Related
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 - No member of the prominent Guggenheim family of New York is taking part in the auction for a stake in the Russian oil giant Lukoil, a spokesman for the Guggenheim Brothers family investment firm said Tuesday.

title: Condominiums for Businesses Fill a Niche in California
description: ALAMEDA, Calif. - The dot-com collapse in Silicon Valley and beyond has given new prominence to a previously obscure class of office building: commercial condominiums. These are multi-user developments divided into small units where occupants buy their spaces, rather than renting them.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO MAKE PAYMENT TO 401(k) ACCOUNTS
description: Boston Scientific will make a special cash payment to its workers' 401(k) retirement savings accounts, resulting in a third-quarter charge of $110 million. The company, which employs 15,500, also plans to increase the percentage of employee contributions that it matches to 6 percent of pay from 4 percent. Sales of Boston Scientific's Taxus drug-coated stent, a device used to prop open arteries cleared during angioplasty, made the payment affordable, said Paul Donovan, a company spokesman. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said on Sept. 1 that it had regained the market share it lost after recalling 100,000 stents in July and August.

title: A 6-Pound, 1,040-Page Cookbook, With Big Ambitions to Match
description: "OUR goal was to give you a book with every recipe you would ever want." These strong words are emblazoned on the back cover of "The Gourmet Cookbook," which is a canary yellow befitting the cockeyed optimism of the tome it encases. And I do mean tome.

title: Fannie Mae Crisis Raises Concerns on Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - Testifying two years ago about the debacle at Enron, Franklin D. Raines, the chairman and chief executive of Fannie Mae, told lawmakers that one of the biggest lessons he had learned was that it was unacceptable to hide behind claims of ignorance.

title: The Light at the End of the Alley
description: HOUSED in a tiny space at the dead end of an alley off Rivington Street, Freeman's may be in the least likely spot for a restaurant. A chop shop? Sure. Mob hideout? It would almost be too obvious.

title: Lolita's Chapter 2: Motherhood and Memoirs
description: GET ready to feel old: the Long Island Lolita just turned 30.

title: Alaska Weighs Relaxing Rules of Exploration
description: Alaska's governor told oil industry officials last week that he expected to relax the rules for heavy equipment on the state's tundra, opening the central North Slope to exploration convoys three or four weeks earlier than in recent years.

title: Subways Remain Vulnerable to Flooding
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRASS, RALPH L.
description: BRASS--Ralph L. All the members of the Board of Directors of the Friars Foundation mourn the passing of their esteemed longtime Board member, Ralph L. Brass. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Services will be held on Wednesday, September 29, at 11:00 A.M. in the BernheimApter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey. Leo Greenland, Chairman of the Board Cy Leslie, President BRASS--Ralph L. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club are deeply saddened by the passing of their esteemed member, Ralph Brass. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Services will be held Wednesday, September 29, 11:00 AM in the BernheimApter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, New Jersey. Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Nomad designers:always on a fast plane, to the office
Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITMAN, JANET RUSSELL
description: WHITMAN--Janet Russell on September 25, 2004 at age 85 after a long battle with cancer. Widow of NY Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman, Jr. who died in 2002. Mother of Charles S. Whitman, III, John R. Whitman and Janet Whitman and grandmother of Kate Annis, Taylor Whitman and Elizabeth Whitman. Mrs. Whitman served for many years as a director and officer of charities and patriotic societies in New York and Watch Hill, Rhode Island, among them Sheltering Arms Childrens Service (president and chairman), The Society for the Relief of Women and Children, The Daughters of the Cincinnati (president), the Stony Wold-Herbert Fund, The Colonial Dames of America and the Watch Hill Village Improvement Society (president). A memorial service will be held at 4:30pm on October 14, 2004 at St. James Church, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Sheltering Arms Childrens Service, 129 West 27th Street, New York, NY 10001, or Watch Hill Chapel Society POB 173 Westerly, RI 02891.

title: Pretty Serene, Pretty Successful
description: MILAN, Sept. 28 - Pretty can be an insult in the rag trade. It's often the sort of adjective employed either to dismiss or damn with faint praise. As hard as fashionable women work at remaining youthful, they seem to set no particular premium on appearing juvenile, hence pretty.

title: ConocoPhillips Buys $2 Billion Stake in Lukoil
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 A ConocoPhillips, the American energy conern, paid nearly $2 billion at auction today for the Russian government's stake in the oil giant Lukoil, a purchase the two companies said sets the stage for potentially huge oil drilling projects in both northern Russia and Iraq.

title: Kerry Sees Debate as Chance to Shed 'Flip-Flop' Label
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 A Senator John Kerry, who hopes to use the first of three presidential debates to assure voters that he is strong and consistent on foreign policy, conceded today that the Bush campaign had been "particularly successful" in portraying him as wobbly.

title: Some Swing States Appear to Be Swinging to President
description: Correction Appended

title: Reports Suggest That Newark Housing Agency Had a History of Troubles
description: Mayor Sharpe James often tells people that Harold Lucas "took the Newark Housing Authority from worst to first" during his tenure as executive director of the agency from 1992 to 1998. By building town houses to replace the city's demolished public high-rises, Mr. Lucas helped the authority move from a federal list of troubled housing authorities to a category of high performers.

title: KarstadtQuelle to sell 77 of its stores
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Identify Stabbing Victim
description: The police have identified a man who was found fatally stabbed in a Lower Manhattan subway station on Sunday morning as Cidronio Ruiz-Hernandez, 45, of Paterson, N.J. Mr. Ruiz-Hernandez, who was stabbed several times in the chest and back, collapsed in the Rector Street station on the N line about 4:40 a.m., the police said. They said they were unsure whether he had been stabbed on the train or before he boarded. Witnesses saw him step off the northbound train, stagger through the turnstile and collapse. He was pronounced dead at New York University Downtown Hospital. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Just Don't Ask Us to Go Fishing
description: Just Don't Ask Us To Go Fishing

title: Reforming the UN : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
SAP stays cool as rivals near a merger
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Fitch Raises a Rating
description: Fitch Ratings, the credit rating agency, raised Brazil's sovereign debt rating to BB- from B+, saying that strong exports and sound macroeconomic policies had reduced the country's dependence on external financing. The move, which puts Brazil three levels below investment grade and should help reduce the country's borrowing costs abroad, followed similar upgrades in recent weeks by other credit agencies including Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's. Fitch praised the Brazilian government for reducing the volatility of its debt burden, noting that only 27 percent of public-sector debt is now linked to foreign currencies, versus more than 40 percent in 2002. The agency warned that Brazil needs to make more policy changes, like a new bankruptcy law. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Europe's Airlines Dreading the Winter
description: LONDON, Sept. 28 - When European airline executives look across the Atlantic at the industry's woes in the United States, they see a reflection of their own problems, but it is not an identical image. They have some troubles that are all their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRITTON, ROY
description: BRITTON--Roy, 75, on September 25th at home after a short illness. Attained rank of Acting Major in Royal Horse Artillery. Retired as a Board Director of Conde Nast Publications London. Wrote plays, children's books, poetry and composed music. Beloved husband of Sarah Ann Britton, father of Caroline, Clive and Michael and grandfather of five. Memorial service St. Matthews Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY, October 2 at 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WUNDERLICH, RUDOLF G.
description: WUNDERLICH -- Rudolf G. Art dealer and stamp collector passed away peacefully on September 22, 2004. Born in Tarrytown, NY in 1920, Rudy graduated from Hackley School in Tarrytown, and then proceeded into the family art business. As president of Kennedy Galleries, Rudolf Wunderlich was a leading art dealer in American art for over 50 years. He advised many of the foremost collectors of his day. He was a leading authority in Western Americana-the art of Frederic Remington and Charles M. Russell. In 1985, he moved to Chicago and became president of Mongerson-Wunderlich Galleries. Rudy Wunderlich was a collector of nineteenth century American stamps, and formed one of the foremost collections of proofs and essays. He served on the board of the Philatelic Foundation and won the Grand Award at Aripex in 1982. He is survived by his wife, Susan, and his sister Roberta Chamberlain. He is also survived by his children, Gerold, Theodore and John; his step-children, Tyler, Tina, and Lindsey, nine grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for a future date.

title: New York Story: Local Garlic Makes Good
description: WHAT is it about garlic that would drive people to hang cloves from their ears, sing songs about it and wear T-shirts that read, "This bulb's for you"? Carrots don't have fans like that. Neither do eggplants or cucumbers.

title: Analysts Expect Market to Seek New Level
description: PARIS, Sept. 28 - Oil prices, which have been rising for the last two years, briefly broke through the $50-a-barrel mark on Tuesday, reaching a new milestone, as some analysts warned that there is nothing to stop them from going higher.

title: A Windfall of Modern Poetry for Scholars
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 23 - More than four decades ago, when Raymond Danowski was an unhappy teenager in the Bronx, he worked after school shelving books in the Burgess-Carpenter Library at Columbia University.

title: Feeding-Tube Posturing Struck Down
description: Gov. Jeb Bush and the Florida Legislature were justly rebuked last week when the Florida Supreme Court declared unconstitutional their ghoulish efforts to require continued nutritional support for a severely brain-damaged woman who has been in a persistent vegetative state for more than a decade. The patient is Theresa Schiavo, who suffered a heart attack in 1990 that deprived her brain of oxygen. She has been kept alive with feeding and hydration tubes ever since.

title: News Analysis: Why MakeLeno a Lame Duck?
description: After NBC's surprise announcement Monday of the unusual deal that secured Conan O'Brien as the next host of the "Tonight" show at the end of a five-year transition period, the question facing the network's executives yesterday was one the current host, Jay Leno, once memorably asked:

title: Catchers Go to Bat for Yankees' Pitchers
description: The men behind the masks have heard the doubts about the pitchers they catch with the Yankees, and they have heard about the uncertainty that is complicating postseason plans more than at any other time in Joe Torre's nine seasons as manager.

title: Elections cannot uproot entrenched corruption
Paid Notice: Deaths   BOLAND, MARIAN WALSH
description: BOLAND--Marian Walsh, age 88, wife of the late James Boland, previously of Middle Village, Queens, died September 25, 2004, in Connecticut. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, 9:15 AM, in the Lesko Funeral Home, 1209 Post Road, Fairfield, CT. and 10 AM in St. Thomas Church, Fairfield. Calling hours are today from 5-8 PM. For more information, please visit www.leskofuneralhome.com.

title: MEANWHILE : We all need role models  gay or straight
Mets Enjoy Playing the Spoiler's Role
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 28 - The Mets have rescued themselves from the humdrum finish of a season gone bad. They have won five of their last seven games and are causing havoc with the playoff plans of the Cubs and the Braves.

title: As Season Is Setting, Dodgers Continue to Rise in the West
description: Correction Appended

title: Annual Inspections of Electrical Hazards Required
description: Consolidated Edison will be required to inspect its equipment annually to protect against stray voltage, and to publish the results, under a safety law passed by the City Council yesterday.

title: Jews Trying to Avert Protestant Divestment
description: Leaders of Jewish organizations said yesterday that they were reaching out to Protestant groups to pre-empt the spread of a recent initiative by the Presbyterian Church to divest selectively from companies doing business in Israel.

title: Black Suggests Trust to Control Hollinger Stock
description: Conrad M. Black, the embattled chief executive of Hollinger Inc., offered yesterday to create a trust that would control the Hollinger shares that are owned by him or by his holding company, the Ravelston Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Wednesday with an article about New York City street vendors referred incorrectly to the flavor of chicharrones, the fried snacks sold by Zoila Orellana in McCarren Park in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They are savory, not sweet.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL MLB--Suspended San Francisco RHP Dustin Hermanson three games and fined him an undisclosed amount for intentionally hitting Houston's Jeff Kent in a Sept. 23 game. Suspended Boston RHP Pedro Astacio and New York Yankees LHP Brad Halsey three games each and fined them an undisclosed amount for intentionally throwing at batters in a Sept. 26 game.

title: CENTENE TO ACQUIRE TWO HEALTH PLANS FOR $93 MILLION
description: The Centene Corporation, a managed care company, agreed to buy two health plans for about $93 million to gain Medicaid patients in Kansas and Missouri. The acquisitions, from the closely held Swope Community Enterprises, will add as much as $260 million in revenue and 34 cents a share to earnings in 2005, Centene said. Michael Neidorff, Centene's chief executive, said in a statement that the purchase of the health plans in the Medicaid-mandated states would add 136,000 patients and two states to the company's 533,300 patients in Indiana, Ohio, Wisconsin, Texas and New Jersey. Stock in Centene, which is based in St. Louis, rose $4.81, to $43.51 a share.

title: Bridges on Their Last Legs Pose Problems for Trains
description: NIANTIC, Conn., Sept. 28 - Passengers riding the rails in the Northeast hardly notice the three busy drawbridges they cross in southeastern Connecticut. But Amtrak engineers say the bridges are in such dire condition that they threaten to sever service between New York and Boston and curtail access to three rivers.

title: Liberty Survives Shock as Donaphin Beats Clock
description: The ball was in Becky Hammon's hands, right where the Liberty wanted it, with the game clock winding down, the score tied and a spot in the W.N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals on the line.

title: School Workers Are to Be Fired Over Strip Search
description: A teacher and another school employee will face termination proceedings in connection with the strip search of four fourth-grade boys at a Bronx elementary school, the city's Department of Education said yesterday.

title: Hernndez's Shoulder Worries Yanks
description: The Yankees' game against the Minnesota Twins was rained out last night, but Orlando Hernndez, the Yankees' scheduled starter, would not have pitched anyway.

title: Swinging to Shanghai and Points East
description: MILAN, Sept. 28 - Thirty years ago, before designers started sucking on globalism's big thumb, Geoffrey Beene brought his clothes here. It was a bold move for an American designer without a backer, whose name was not substantiated by handbags and other totems of chic. But Mr. Beene, who died Tuesday, recognized that Seventh Avenue was a village, once you went north of 39th Street; and that if you were any good, you belonged out in the world.

title: Jordan's King Voices Doubts on Iraq Election Schedule
description: PARIS, Sept. 28 - King Abdullah II of Jordan, one of the United States' closest Middle East allies, has expressed extreme pessimism about the prospect of free and fair elections being held in Iraq in January, as scheduled, saying in an interview published here Tuesday that the current level of instability in Iraq makes legitimate elections impossible.

title: EU Commission hearings offer a test for Barroso
Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, POLLY D.
description: MARTIN--Polly D. Age 47, on September 24th, 2004, following an heroic struggle. Cherished and beloved sister of Liz Martin and Cecilia and John Ford. Adored and devoted aunt to Kate White, Eliza Ford and Clementine Ford. Memorial service, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St and 5th Ave, Friday, October 1st at 11AM.

title: Red Sox Win Again, But Try to Think Ahead
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 28 - The Boston Red Sox have five pitchers in double digits for victories for the first time since 1979, yet the closer they move to the playoffs, the more evident it becomes that there is a big drop-off in consistency after their first two options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARDULLO, JUNE MOORE, M.D.
description: CARDULLO -- June Moore, M.D. Died suddenly on September 22, 2004, from injuries sustained when she was struck by an automobile while walking in her hometown of Pompton Plains, New Jersey. Born June 19, 1927 in Bayonne, New Jersey, she graduated from Barnard College in 1947 and received her medical degree from New York University in 1951. Dr. Cardullo interned in pediatrics at Bellevue Hospital and completed her residency at St. Vincent's Hospital, in New York City. She was a fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics and a member of the American Medical Association. Married to Hugo M. Cardullo, also a pediatrician, the two were in private practice in Pompton Plains for nearly 40 years. "Dr. June" as she was affectionately known, continued to practice part-time after the death of her husband in 1996. Most recently she was the medical director of the Wanaque Health Department. In her spare time, she continued to take CME courses, as well as classes in arts and literature at NYU and Barnard College. Dr. June also traveled widely and gardened enthusiastically. Her son, Mark, predeceased Dr. Cardullo in 2001. She is survived by three daughters: Alice Cardullo, M.D. of New York City, Lauren Cardullo Thompson, V.M.D. of Armonk, N.Y. and Susan Cardullo Topping, Esq., of Lincoln Park, N.J. She had four grandchildren, Natalie, Nicholas, Kevin and Christopher. A memorial service will be held on October 9, 2004 at the Holy Spirit R.C. Church in Pequannock, N.J. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Salvation Army-Wanaque Health Dept. Unit, Barnard College or the National Shrine of St. Jude, Chicago, IL.

title: Euro Disney Secures Plan To Ward Off Bankruptcy
description: Euro Disney, owner of struggling theme parks near Paris that have never been able to bring in enough business to pay their debts, secured a new restructuring plan yesterday, once again managing to stave off bankruptcy.

title: MCI Ruling Overturned; Court Cites Technicality
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 28 - The European Commission had no grounds to block the proposed $120 billion merger of MCI WorldCom and Sprint four years ago, a European court said Tuesday, basing its decision solely on a technicality.

title: A Fish Market Opens in Stock Market Country
description: Coast, a seafood restaurant that opened last week at 110 Liberty Street (Church Street), has given its financial-district neighborhood a much needed fish market. The market, right, which is in the front of the restaurant, is stocked with the same fine seafood that Coast uses (some seasoned and ready to cook). Coast and its siblings, Fresh and Shore in TriBeCa, are owned by Eric Tevrow and Daniel Angerer, the chef who oversees the kitchens. Mr. Tevrow is also an owner of Early Morning Seafood, a wholesale supplier of top restaurants.

title: British Hostage in Iraq Pleads With Blair in Tape
description: A sobbing Kenneth Bigley, the British engineer held hostage in Iraq, was shown in a videotape broadcast today by the Arab satellite station Al-Jazeera pleading with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to work harder for his release.

title: Globalist : Between U.S. and Iran, no relations, but a need
SOCCER : United keeps agents rich
Negotiator in Russia School Hostage Case Warns Revenge Could Ignite Regional Violence
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 - The official sent by the Kremlin to negotiate with hostage takers in Beslan earlier this month warned Tuesday that violence could explode after the traditional 40-day mourning period for the victims of the Sept. 1 school attack that could cause the Caucasus region of southern Russia to "go up in flames."

title: PEPSI BOTTLING'S QUARTERLY EARNINGS RISE 4.4%
description: The Pepsi Bottling Group said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter rose 4.4 percent on increased sales of Tropicana juices and lower interest expenses. Net income climbed to $191 million, or 73 cents a share, from $183 million, or 67 cents, in the period a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales at Pepsi Bottling, based in Somers, N.Y., increased 4.4 percent, to $2.93 billion. Earnings in the quarter, which ended Sept. 4, were a penny more than the 70-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The per-share earnings included a gain of 2 cents from the settlement of international tax audits.

title: New Office From Cramer-Krasselt
description: AFTER years of seeking to acquire an agency in New York to get a foothold in the biggest, most challenging advertising market in America, Cramer-Krasselt has decided, in effect, that if you can't buy 'em, start 'em.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Bid For Web Concern
description: Denmark's largest phone company, TDC, raised its bid for the Swedish Internet company Song Networks Holding to 4.7 billion Swedish kronor ($637 million), topping an offer by Tele2. TDC raised its offer 18 percent, to 82.5 Swedish kronor per Song Networks share, from the 70 kronor offered on Sept. 14, it said. The bid is 3.1 percent more than the closing price of Song Networks on Monday. Tele2 bid 75 kronor per share last week. Song Networks is attracting interest because of its position in the Nordic broadband Internet access market for businesses.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about prewar intelligence assessments on Iraq misidentified the television program on which Secretary of State Colin L. Powell discussed them on Sunday. It was ABC's ''This Week," not ''Fox News Sunday," on which he appeared the same day. (Go to Article)

title: Salaries Cut 10% at Delta in Bid to Remain Solvent
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it was cutting the pay of executives and other salaried workers by 10 percent and making other changes meant to help it avoid a bankruptcy filing. As part of the effort, the chief executive, Gerald A. Grinstein, said he would not draw a salary for the rest of 2004.

title: Graham Legacy, on the Stage Again
description: When the sensuous, athletic dancers of the Martha Graham Dance Company take the stage at New York City Center tonight to perform Graham's classic "Embattled Garden," they will almost certainly reach a new generation of enthusiasts for the woman who defined contemporary American dance. The company is performing the 1958 ballet as part of a six-night, $10-a-ticket dance festival featuring the work of 30 dance companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHERTOFF, PHILIP
description: CHERTOFF--Philip. On September 27th, 2004, beloved husband of Leonora, loving father of Andrew, Jane and Jeffrey and father-in-law of Faith and Dan. Cherished grandfather of Anne & David, Torey and Scott, Elizabeth, Samantha & David. Devoted brother of Daniel and the late Evelyn. Services today, 10AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J), Brooklyn. Donations may be made to American Diabetes Association.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Fatal Bombing
description: One person was killed and at least four were wounded when a bomb exploded in the southwestern city of Quetta, the capital of Baluchistan Province, the state-run media reported. The bomb was planted on a bicycle parked by a busy road, according to police officials. No one claimed responsibility for the explosion.But local nationalists, demanding more autonomy and a greater share of the province's natural wealth, have been blamed for a spate of attacks on government installations and workers in the region. Salman Masood (NYT)

World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Tourists Held In Coca Protest Freed
description: Twenty foreign tourists held by protesting coca farmers inside a 17th-century church built on the foundations of an Inca temple were freed by the riot police using gas canisters and swinging riot sticks, Peruvian authorities said. The coca growers, demanding to meet with government officials to press for an end to American-financed drug-eradication efforts, took over the Koricancha site, which was first a temple and later became the foundation of a Spanish Catholic Church in the southern city of Cuzco. A police spokesman told Reuters that 7 of the 70 coca growers had been detained. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: At Heart, Gorgeously Gooey
description: Woodhouse, a new chocolatier in St. Helena, Calif., takes the Whitman Sampler approach to an exquisite level, right. You can select peanut croquant made with peanut gianduja, the wild cherry in ganache, the spiced chocolate quatre-epices or the white chocolate Champagne truffle, among many others. Descriptions are enclosed. Woodhouse Chocolate sells its confections for $1.25 a piece or for $26 a pound. The chocolates can be ordered from (800) 966-3468 or www.woodhousechocolate.com.

description: A Memphis jury said yesterday that the medical equipment maker Medtronic must pay nearly $159 million to an inventor of spinal surgical devices for violating its licensing and royalty agreements with him.

description: NETTER--Arthur B. Died September 28, 2004. Survived by his son Andrew Netter and daughter Lisa Kelly, brothers Richard and Edward Netter. Funeral private on October 1.

title: Last of Hurricane Jeanne Brings Flooding and a Tornado to the Region
description: The remnants of Hurricane Jeanne drenched a broad swath of the New York region yesterday, as a tornado touched down in Cherry Hill, N.J., damaging several buildings, rainfall set records across New York City, and numerous roads were flooded.

description: There is no reason to suggest that ABC's "Monday Night Football" should maintain a pristine landscape and never change its formula.

title: Bush, Kerry and a Debate That Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: NO FREE RIDE IN CRAWFORD
description: The Lone Star Iconoclast, a weekly newspaper in Crawford, Tex., where President Bush has his ranch, endorsed his opponent, Senator John Kerry, saying that Mr. Bush "let us down." The 1,000-circulation newspaper began publishing after the 2000 election; its sister publications endorsed Mr. Bush that year. W. Leon Smith, a Democrat who is the paper's editor and publisher (and the mayor of nearby Clifton, Tex.) said in the Kerry endorsement that the "part-time president" had spent too much time vacationing at his ranch. The 1,800-word editorial, headlined "Kerry Will Restore American Dignity," focused on four items: Social Security, "the deteriorating state of the American economy," "a dangerous shift away from the basic freedoms established by our founding fathers" and Mr. Bush's "continuous mistakes regarding terrorism and Iraq." Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola To Cut 1,000 Jobs Worldwide
description: Motorola said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,000 jobs globally and take a $50 million charge to pay for the workers' severance benefits, according to a filing with securities regulators. The cuts stem from Motorola's decision to spin off its semiconductor division, Freescale Semiconductor, in July. Additionally, Motorola said in the filing that it raised about $218 million by selling some of its shares in Nextel Communications and Nextel Partners. Motorola now owns 6.9 percent of Nextel, the country's sixth-largest cellphone provider, down from 7.5 percent. Motorola's share of Nextel Partners has fallen to 0.5 percent, from 2.3 percent before the sale. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, IRVING BROOKS
description: HARRIS--Irving Brooks. A beloved gentle giant, a hero for our times. He chose to champion the cause of those who have no voice -- babies, young children and their families, especially those in poverty. With his passion, curiosity, brilliance, tireless advocacy and generosity, Irving Harris rallied others to help create the "Zero to Three" field where previously there was none. A visionary, it took Irving Harris to discern the effectiveness of our model programs and invest in them. He always gave with trusting respect, a model for the field itself. His passing leaves a painful gap, but his light lives on in us, in countless babies, children, parents, workers, clinicians, researchers, and programs across North America, Israel, and beyond. We send deepest sympathies to Irving's loving wife, Joan, and to his entire family of children, grandchildren and great grandchildren, each of whom were so precious to him. Rebecca Shahmoon Shanok, LCSW, Ph.D., Director Renee Ward, Chair, Leadership Council Maureen Cogan, Chair-elect, Institute for Infants, Children & Families Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services HARRIS--Irving B. The American Jewish Committee mourns the passing of Irving B. Harris, one of our most devoted leaders and generous benefactors for more than half a century. Irving was a member of AJC's National Leadership Council, President's Cabinet and was a Founder of AJC's Institute on American Jewish-Israeli Relations. In his local Chicago Chapter, he served on the Advisory Council for 35 years and co-chaired its Major Gifts Event for nearly as long. He was awarded our prestigious Human Rights Medallion for his longstanding work to battle anti-Semitism and promote positive intergroup relations. Irving was a wise and gentle man with an abiding love for the Jewish people and all the world's children. He will be sorely missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife Joan, his children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. E. Robert Goodkind, Pres David A. Harris, Exec Dir HARRIS--Irving B. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of longtime friend and supporter, Irving B. Harris. A member of the Institute's Board of Governors, he provided generous support, including the creation of the Irving B. Harris Fund for Brain Research. He was twice honored, along with his wife Joan Harris, by the Chicago Region ACWIS, and earlier this year was the recipient of the Weizmann Award in the Sciences and Humanities. We express our deepest sympathies to his beloved family. Robert B. Machinist, Chair, American Committee Dr. Albert Willner, Pres., American Committee Martin S. Kraar, Exec. V.P., American Committee Stuart Eizenstat, Chair, Weizmann Institute Prof. Ilan Chet, Pres., Weizmann Institute HARRIS--Irving Brooks. The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledges with great sadness the death of Irving Harris. He pioneered state - of - the - art programs for at risk children. He inspired and guided the creation of the JBFCS Institute for Infants, Children & Families, now a national leader in the training of practitioners working with young children and their families. He deeply believed in the Institute and its mission, and we are so grateful to him for his extraordinary vision and support. The Irving Brooks Harris Lecture will serve as a lasting reminder of his commitment to bettering the lives of young children. Our condolences to his entire family. Jean L. Troubh, President Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Exec. VP and CEO HARRIS -- Irving. Zero to Three expresses profound sorrow on the passing of a true champion of babies and toddlers. Without Irving's passion and vision, society's youngest children would not be as well understood or supported. His leadership and generosity helped to create and sustain the Ounce of Prevention Fund, the Yale Child Study Center, Erikson Institute and Zero to Three, among others. Joan, Bill and the entire family have our deepest sympathies. The Board and Staff of Zero to Three

title: Pilot Says Private Rocket 'Flew Like a Dream'
description: MOJAVE, Calif., Sept. 29 A A test pilot returned successfully to earth today after a foray into space that was marked by a white-knuckle ascent in which the rocket ship began an unexpected series of rolls as it roared toward the top of its arc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BESHEER, HASNA AZIZI
description: BESHEER--Hasna Azizi, 95, Papal Lady. Wife of the late Simon. Cherished daughter of the late Boutros and Salma Dahdah Azizi. Devoted mother of Salma Besheer Vahdat and the late Sahid. Loving sister of Eva, Dumit and Diana. Proud grandmother of six and great grandmother of eight. Reposing at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10AM, Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSBORNE, CHRISTIAN
description: OSBORNE -- Christian, for merly of New York, died September 18, 2004 in Los Angeles just after midnight. East Coast memorial to be held by Norman Isaacs & Tessa Marquis. For details, leave contact information at osborne@newstandardinstitute.com.

description: LERMAN--Pearl (Kleinman). Loving wife of the late Herbert for 65 yrs, cherished mother of Toby and Steven Appel, David, Karen and Roy, proud grandmother of nine, beloved great-grandmother of six. We will miss you always. Services and intermemt Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, September 29, 10:30 AM.

title: STARBUCKS TO RAISE COFFEE PRICES BY 11 CENTS A CUP
description: The Starbucks Corporation, the coffee shop operator, said it planned to raise its average price per cup by 11 cents in North America to cover the higher cost of ingredients. The increase, the first since August 2000, will take effect Oct. 6, the company said. Starbucks, which operates more than 8,000 stores, said earlier this month that it would increase drink prices by the end of the year. Sales at outlets open at least 13 months gained 8 percent in August, the smallest increase in 10 months.

title: Met Picks New Voice for Opera Broadcasts
description: There are voices at the Metropolitan Opera, and then there is The Voice.

title: Is Missouri Still a Swing State?
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 A Is Missouri a swing state that has already swung? So it seems to many people here on the eve of the first presidential debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEDERMAN, DONALD E.
description: LIEDERMAN--Donald E. 83, died September 23, Beverly Hills, CA, from complications connected with diabetes. Born in Chicago, he attended St. John's Military Academy, graduated from the Wharton School, and in 1943 entered the Navy where he commanded a minesweeper in the Pacific and won numerous medals. After the war, he earned a Master's degree in Education at Columbia University and went on to own and operate children's camps and schools on Long Island, in Westchester and Pennsylvania. In his later career, he turned his many talents to investment banking and was Chairman of The National Sugar Company, National Hospital, Heritage, and other public companies. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Judith (nee Ellis) and his three children from former marriages David, William and Ann, two stepdaughters Melissa Castle and Madeleine Jolton and seven grandchildren. Services October 9 at 2PM at Hillside Memorial Park, 6001 Centenella Ave, Culver City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THALER, ANNA (HENYA) DOLGIN
description: THALER--Anna (Henya) Dolgin, of Brooklyn, New York, on September 27, 2004. b. Olevsk, Russia, 1910, immigrated to the US in 1929. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Solomon Thaler. Adored by her children, Rena Thaler Rauch, Stuart Rauch, and Dr. Alvin Thaler; beloved grandmother of Benjamin Rauch, Meredith Rauch-Broxmeyer, Adam Thaler, Jonathan Thaler; great-grandmother of Dalia Margolis Thaler, and devoted sister of Shirley Baron. A published author, she will be remembered for her powerful persona and intellect, her language, narrative and linguistic skills, her devotion to social service, vocational and educational programs in Israel, and especially for the profound impact she had on her children and her children's children. Funeral at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI, on Wednesday, September 29th at 11:15am. Shiva will be observed at 2500 Eileen Road, Oceanside, NY 11572. In lieu of flowers please make donations to NA'AMAT USA, 350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 4700, New York, New York 10118.

title: Talks should include 'all forces in Iraq' : France seeks to put pullout on agenda
How to Debate George Bush
description: This year, as usual, the dominance of attack advertisements on television has made it hard to get a clear picture of where the candidates stand. But the same media revolution that brought us the 30-second commercial also brought us televised presidential debates -- and ever since the first of them 44 years ago, they have played a crucial role in shaping voters' opinions of the candidates.

title: Tsai Wan-lin, the Richest Man in Taiwan, Dies
description: Tsai Wan-lin, a financier and the wealthiest man in Taiwan, died on Monday in Taipei, his family told Agence France-Presse. His age was variously reported as 79, 80 and 81.

title: A Peach . . . No, a Honey of a Farmers' Market
description: MADISON, Wis. - ON Saturday, Sept. 30, 1972, 11 produce vendors set up shop in a street near Wisconsin's majestic white granite capitol. Customers quickly exhausted their meager stocks. A week later 85 fruit and vegetable sellers turned up, their stalls filling much of Capitol Square, to be mobbed by several thousand eager consumers.

title: Geoffrey Beene, Innovator of American Fashion, Dies at 77
description: Geoffrey Beene, a single-minded innovator who put fashion above commerce yet succeeded in making a business from originality, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Vetting Those Foreign College Applications
description: Peggy O'Neill has seen her share of foreign diplomas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUMP, JACOB E., JR., M.D.
description: STUMP--Jacob E., Jr., M.D., on September 25. Psychiatrist, graduate of NY Psychoanalytic Institute '57', Life Fellow of Am. Psychiatric Assoc., Past Pres of NJ Psychoanalytic Society (78-80), and Medical Director of MidBergen Community Mental Health Center in Paramus, NJ. Beloved husband of Margaret (Watkins) Stump, father of David & Daniel Stump & Susan Storm, brother of Dora Herold & grandfather of four. Services will be on Saturday, October 2 at 11:00 AM at Shrewsbury Episcopal Church in Kennedyville, MD. www.fhnfuneralhome.com

title: Bush, Kerry and a Debate That Isn't
