title: Hazy Sunshine, Vivid Memory
description: FIFTY years ago today, Willie Mays made one of the great catches in the history of the World Series, tracking down a rocket hit by Vic Wertz to deepest right-center field of an eccentric oval known as the Polo Grounds.

title: Russians Arrest 2 Men in Killing of U.S. Editor
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 - The police announced the arrest of two men on Tuesday in connection with the killing of a prominent American journalist. But officials provided few details about the men or their motive, and Russia's chief prosecutor later suggested the arrests had been disclosed prematurely.

title: American Taliban Soldier Seeks Less Prison Time
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 - John Walker Lindh, the American captured in Afghanistan after he had joined the Taliban, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to reduce his 20-year prison sentence after hearing news that another captured man was being released, his parents and lawyers said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC and Bellsouth Debt Ratings Cut
description: Standard & Poor's cut the long-term debt ratings one notch for SBC Communications, BellSouth and their joint venture, Cingular Wireless, citing the difficulty that Cingular will face in absorbing AT&T Wireless. SBC and BellSouth now have A ratings with negative outlooks; they had been rated A+. Cingular is awaiting government approval of its $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Off the Menu
description: GAVIN CITRON, left, who has cooked at Aleutia, Aja and Celadon, among other New York restaurants, finally has a place of his own. CITRON, with a 45-seat dining room done in soft greens and golds, anchors a busy intersection at 228 Bleecker Street (Avenue of the Americas). The menu is seasonal American, with wine and sake pairings for each course.

title: A Third Graduate Is Killed, and Another Plaque Is About to Go Up at Brentwood High
description: BRENTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 27 - The wall of honor is easy to miss. It is nothing more than a little space in the lobby of Brentwood High School, decorated with two plaques. But these days, people look at the wall and wish it were still blank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOTSFORD, GARDNER
description: BOTSFORD -- Gardner. On September 27, 2004. Survived by wife, Janet Malcolm, daughters Susan Workum and Margot Botsford, stepdaughter Anne Malcolm, four grandchildren and one great grandchild. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Countributions in his memory may be made to Planned Parenthood of NYC, 26 Bleecker St., NY, NY 10012.

title: A Request to Partisans: Don't Shoot the Pollster
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - There has been no shortage of targets for partisans of all persuasions this election season. But one group has come under fire from all sides: pollsters, who in these polarized times have become the political equivalent of lawyers.

title: Bush, Kerry and a Debate That Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rich Vision of Life Filled With Love and Housework
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 23 - The term "romantic comedy" has been bleached of meaning by decades of overuse. Nowadays, it may be most frequently applied to movies starring teenagers you've never heard of. But "The Clean House," a fresh, funny new play by a talented young playwright, Sarah Ruhl, breathes a little life into the epithet.

title: Retirement Vistas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINK, JAMES C.
description: LINK--James C. Of Greenwich, CT. passed away suddenly on September 9, 2004 at the age of 48. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen. Memorial services will be private. Memorial donations may be made to American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARZELAY, BATYA
description: BARZELAY -- Batya. The Board of Directors and staff of the JCC on the Palisades mourn the loss of Batya Barzelay, who has been a loved and creative staff member of the JCC. Her devotion to our Senior Adult Department made our center a "home away from home" for hundreds of seniors, and under her leadership, the JCC Israeli Club flourished. We send our sincerest condolences to her devoted husband Avraham, her sons Ami and Ifar, her daughter-in-law Alix, and her beloved grandson Wiley. She was deeply loved and treasured by the JCC family. May her memory be for a blessing. Daniel Rubin, President Avi A. Lewinson, Exec. Dir.

title: Politics Aside, a School's Real Success
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga. - IN the late summer of 2003, a few weeks into his first year as principal of Gainesville Elementary School here, Shawn Arevalo McCollough identified 125 pupils who were lagging a grade or two behind in reading and math. He could surmise that most were poor and nonwhite, because virtually his entire student body was poor and nonwhite. More precisely, most of these children were new immigrants from Mexico whose parents had been drawn to this small city by the exhausting but ample jobs in its chicken-processing plants.

title: Baseball Returns to Washington as Expos Move From Montreal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Back in the days when the Washington Senators were losers, which was often, there was a saying: "First in war, first in peace, and last in the American League."

title: Two Sentenced to Death in Yemen for Bombing U.S.S. Cole
description: CAIRO, Sept. 29 A A judge in Yemen sentenced two men to death and four others to prison terms up to 10 years for the deadly attack in 2000 against the warship U.S.S. Cole. The convictions today are the first stemming from the water-borne suicide bombing that provided an early glimpse of the brazen nature of Osama bin Laden's global terror network.

title: Palestinian Premier Urges Both Sides in Uprising to Rethink Tactics
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 - On the fourth anniversary of the Palestinian uprising, Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei on Tuesday urged both Palestinians and Israelis to reassess strategies they have adopted during the grinding conflict.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: In Any Town, Wilder's Mirror Reflects Angst
description: Haworth, N.J. - NOT to be too self-referential, but the "One Book/One Community" celebration going on in this tiny Bergen County town raises a good question -- how much can any community in New York and its environs in 2004 have in common with the world of Thornton Wilder's famous play about small-town life a century ago?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRY, JAMES W.
description: FRY--James W., 81, in Westport, CT. Member of the New York Stock Exchange. Husband of the late Barbara Leavitt Fry. Father of Daniel, Margaret, Elizabeth, Victoria and Jennifer. Brother of Joan, and grandfather of four. Memorial service Friday, 11:00 A.M., at the Unitarian Church of Westport.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Ulysses Grant Makeover
description: The Treasury Department is circulating a redesigned $50 bill in an effort to make counterfeiting more difficult. The Bureau of Engraving and Printing, which is responsible for paper currency, said 140 million bills had been printed. The new bill is the same size and still features Ulysses S. Grant, but has red and blue background colors and includes embedded threads that glow when exposed to ultraviolet light and ink that changes from a copper color to green when the bill is tilted. Because counterfeiting techniques change quickly, the government intends to change the design of some bills every 7 to 10 years. John Files (NYT)

title: Edwards Accuses Bush Administration of Botching Iraq Plans
description: WEIRTON, W. Va., Sept. 29 A Seizing on a published report that Vice President Dick Cheney had warned of getting "bogged down" in Iraq 12 years ago, Senator John Edwards today accused the Bush administration of botching plans for occupying Iraq and made clear it would be a topic during presidential debates.

title: Iraq Study Sees Rebels' Attacks as Widespread
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 28 - Over the past 30 days, more than 2,300 attacks by insurgents have been directed against civilians and military targets in Iraq, in a pattern that sprawls over nearly every major population center outside the Kurdish north, according to comprehensive data compiled by a private security company with access to military intelligence reports and its own network of Iraqi informants.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Plans Coffeehouse Venture
description: Sprint and the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia said they planned to announce today that they had reached an agreement for the company to provide Internet and telephone service to a new chain of coffeehouses owned by the federation. Under the deal, Sprint said it would provide telecommunications services to around 30 Juan Valdez coffeehouses, which are scheduled to open in the United States over the next six months. Sprint said coffeehouse customers would ultimately be able to buy wireless Internet access for $9.95 a day. Sprint and the federation did not provide financial details. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Lawyer's Jury Hears Offer to Halt Attacks
description: An Egyptian militant with ties to Osama bin Laden sought to negotiate with United States authorities after the bombing of the destroyer Cole in October 2000, offering to halt such attacks in exchange for the release of a fundamentalist Muslim cleric held in an American prison, according to evidence presented in federal court yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 13 with an article about absentee voting fraud reversed the requirements of Wisconsin and West Virginia for a restriction on absentee ballot submissions. Wisconsin requires a witness to sign, and West Virginia does not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOTT, ELIZABETH, PH.D.
description: LOTT--Elizabeth, Ph.D. On September 24. Associate Professor of Economics & Department Chair at Pace University. She authored many economic publications. Age 67 of Wayne, NJ. Mother of Joseph, Virginia and the late Helena Ava Liotta. For more information go to: www.festamemorial.com

title: Building a fire wall against the 'human factor'
Romance Turns to Wreckage, in Tune and Out
description: Eleven years and six albums into their career, the Old 97's still sounded like a scrappy bar band when they performed on Friday night at Irving Plaza, finishing a two-night stand.

description: RONIN--Rosalind. Wife, mother, nanny. Always loved, forever missed. Harold, Bonnie & Jeff, Judy & Marc, Robert, Andrew, Jennifer, Jon, and Liz

title: Announcement Seen Wednesday on Expos' Move
description: The D.C. Sports and Entertainment Commission has called a news conference for today, apparently to announce that the Montreal Expos will be moving to Washington, said an executive involved in the negotiations with Major League Baseball.

title: Rocco DiSpirito Is Out at Union Pacific
description: ROCCO DiSPIRITO famously opened his namesake restaurant in a reality show last summer and was famously thrown out by his partners in July. Now he has been removed from a second restaurant, Union Pacific, once the jewel in his crown, which will close at the end of the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about political humor misidentified the recipient of money raised by Concerts for Change, which sponsors concerts and comedy events. The money goes to a political action committee called Running for Change, which distributes it to the Democratic National Committee and to closely contested Democratic campaigns. John Kerry's presidential campaign is not a direct recipient.

LOST AND FOUND
description: Disaster struck the Lost Bayou Ramblers, an up-and-coming zydeco group, before a performance in Denver this month. On the morning of Sept. 12 the Ramblers emerged from their lodgings to find that their van had been stolen. Inside were their instruments, sheet music and sound system, as well as compact disks and cases of hot sauce, which they sell at concerts. The only thing the Ramblers had left was their accordion, which they had taken inside. For Louis Michot, 25, the group's leader and a third-generation musician, the loss was particularly devastating. Among the stolen instruments was his fiddle, a 1925 Stradivarius copy given to him by his grandfather. Friends and fans in Denver found them instruments and took up a collection so the Ramblers, who include Mr. Michot's brother, Andre, 28, could rent a minivan for the drive home to Lafayette, La. Upon arriving, the Ramblers, whose members are all 30 or younger, were stunned to find that news of the theft, aided by the Internet, had spread throughout the Cajun music community. As a result, the group was flooded with offers of "fiddles, basses, guitars, standup basses, drums, amplifiers" and a complete sound system, Mr. Michot said. A local merchant invited him to pick out any violin in his shop. "It's really mind-blowing," Mr. Michot said by telephone from Lafayette. "First you're destroyed and devastated, then you have all this help, and you wonder how it's happening." The loans will allow the Ramblers to keep their dates on Saturday and Sunday at the Chile Pepper Fiesta, running from noon to 5:30 pm. at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. MICHELINE MAYNARD ARTS BRIEFING: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Italian schools expand horizons
After Dark, the Stuffed Animals Turn Creepy
description: Correction Appended

title: ConocoPhillips Buys $2 Billion Stake in Lukoil
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28  ConocoPhillips, the American energy conern, paid nearly $2 billion at auction today for the Russian government's stake in the oil giant Lukoil, a purchase the two companies said sets the stage for potentially huge oil drilling projects in both northern Russia and Iraq.

title: Canada's Prophets of Pessimism (Is It the Weather?)
description: TORONTO, Sept. 28 - As one of Canada's pre-eminent historians, David Bercuson of the University of Calgary is not your average couch potato. But with beer in hand and feet up on the sofa, he watched the Olympics on television last month to cheer on the world champion hurdler Perdita Flicien to win a gold medal for Canada.

title: Where Did All the Jobs Go? Nowhere
description: CHICAGO - John Kerry is making the outsourcing of jobs by American companies a centerpiece of his campaign, telling audiences that "because of George Bush's wrong choices, this country is continuing to ship good jobs overseas." President Bush's team has in turn accused the senator of hypocrisy, noting that many of Mr. Kerry's supporters in the business world run companies that are sending jobs offshore. Yet as each side angles for votes, neither is addressing the real issue: is the outsourcing of jobs a problem? The answer, surprisingly, is no.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRICE, AUBREY STUART
description: PRICE--Aubrey Stuart. Died on September 25, 2004, age 79 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Liv for 51 years and father of Helen and Eric. Grandfather of Alistair, Amanda, Kate, Victoria and Jessica. Was vice president and director of Vlasov Group, Inc., president of V. Ships (USA) Inc, chairman of the board and a director of Liberian Shipping Council, member of the Society of Maritime Arbitrators, Lt. RAF. Memorial service October 3, 5 PM, Unitarian Church, Summit. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to Seton Hall Internal Medicine Residency Program at Trinitas Hospital, 225 Williamson St, Elizabeth, NJ 07207, Attn: Dr. Ernest Federici.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about the auction of the Russian government's stake in Lukoil referred incorrectly to a bidder, Dabir International. While the company is led by a man named David Guggenheim, he is not an heir to the fortune of the famous family. A brief report on Dabir appears on Page C2.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Slovenia And Croatia: Calls For Calm
description: Prime Minister Anton Rop of Slovenia backed away from his threats to block Croatia's bid to enter the European Union over a border dispute, as the union's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, called for dialogue to resolve differences. The border has been a source of friction since the states broke away from Yugoslavia in 1991. Last week, Croatian border guards arrested a group of Slovenians, including an opposition member of Parliament, in a disputed area after they refused to show their identity cards. Slovenia entered the European Union in May, and Croatia hopes to begin accession talks next year. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: CONVENTION FUND-RAISING
description: The host committee for the Democratic National Convention raised more than $54 million and spent roughly $48 million in the last two years, a finance disclosure form filed this week showed. The conventions -- unlike political parties or candidates -- are allowed to collect unlimited "soft money" contributions from corporations, labor unions and individuals. The Democratic event in Boston drew dozens of donors between July of 2002 and mid-September of this year, according to PoliticalMoneyLine, which tracks campaign finance. Among those that gave at least $1 million were Blue Cross Blue Shield, Citizens Bank, Fidelity Investments, Liberty Mutual Group, the Service Employees International Union and the State Street Corporation. Bank of America gave almost $1.4 million and the Gillette Company almost $1.6 million, while I.B.M., John Hancock Financial Services and Verizon Communications each gave more than $2 million. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Accuses 4 in Golden State Deal
description: Federal regulators have accused four people of insider trading violations in connection with the $4.9 billion purchase of the Golden State Bancorp by Citigroup in 2002.

title: Ending Editorial Oversight at Treasury
description: This week, a group of American publishers filed suit against the Treasury secretary and the Office of Foreign Assets Control at the Treasury Department concerning an issue percolating since last September: the editing of books and manuscripts from countries, like Iran and Sudan, that are the targets of sanctions. Last year, the office issued a ruling that allowed the publication of finished works from those countries but made it illegal for Americans to edit them or consult with an author about editorial changes. The ostensible goal was to deny economic benefits to hostile foreign countries. The actual result was to impair the principle of freedom of information, a cornerstone of American democracy.

title: Showdown Likely on Intelligence Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - The debate over restructuring the nation's intelligence operations is turning into an unexpected referendum of sorts on the antiterrorism powers granted to the federal government under the USA Patriot Act, with a Congressional showdown in the struggle expected on Wednesday.

title: Dodgers' Bradley Ejected for Throwing Bottle
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 - Milton Bradley became the latest Major League Baseball player to go after the people who pay to see him perform.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Governor Approves Election Changes
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed laws to change voting. One bill returns the state's presidential primary to June in 2008. The primary was shifted to March in 1996, but that did not add influence in the nomination process. A law on electronic voting systems requires them to include paper records in 2006, something the secretary of state had already directed, and absentee voters living temporarily overseas will be allowed to vote by fax. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Rogers Doubles His Gold as Cycling's Time Trial Champion
description: BARDOLINO, Italy, Sept. 29 A Michael Rogers, a 24-year-old Australian, received two gold medals today at the bicycling road world championships.

title: 2 Aid Workers Are Freed After 3 Weeks in Captivity
description: Correction Appended

title: Bird Flu Deaths in Thailand Raise New Fears
description: BANGKOK, Sept. 28 - A 26-year-old woman who cradled her dying daughter in her arms for 10 hours at a hospital in northwestern Thailand, and later fell sick and died herself, has become the subject of a hurried medical investigation across several continents.

title: The Runaway Prosecutor
description: The fundamental right of Americans, through our free press, to penetrate and criticize the workings of our government is under attack as never before.

title: CATERPILLAR RAISES SALES FORECASTS FOR 2004 AND 2005
description: Caterpillar, the world's biggest maker of earthmoving equipment, raised its sales forecast for this year and said revenue for next year would rise another 10 percent on growing demand. Sales this year are expected to rise 25 percent to 30 percent compared with a year earlier, up from the company's July forecast of 25 percent growth. The company, based in Peoria, Ill., had sales of $22.8 billion last year. James Owens, Caterpillar's chief executive, told analysts at the MINExpo mining industry convention yesterday in Las Vegas that the company expected to increase production by 40 percent in the second half of this year, helped by demand from China, India and Russia. The company did not change its profit forecast.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oil Prices Hit $50 a Barrel, Then Decrease Slightly Oil prices briefly broke through the $50-a-barrel mark, reaching a new milestone as some analysts warned there is nothing to stop them from going higher.

title: A Sticky Trivet
description: No, it's not the world's largest refrigerator magnet, though storing this magnetic trivet on the refrigerator would not be a bad idea. Place a steel or cast-iron pan or casserole on the trivet, and the trivet will travel with the pot to the table. The trivets are $24 and $30, depending on size, at www.factorydirect2you.com; a set of two is $50. By Kuhn Rikon, they have nonskid red and black feet. Williams-Sonoma also sells a Kuhn Rikon magnetic trivet, but in gray and white, for $24.

title: Italian, From the Region Near Whimsy
description: WHEN I walked into Petrosino about a month ago, I was suspicious. A friend had described it as a straightforward restaurant with hearty Italian fare, and I had made assumptions and extrapolations, filling in and rounding out that vague picture. I foresaw lighting that was too bright or too dark, generic dcor and an unabashed emphasis on the frumpy over the faddish.

title: White House Generally Backs Senate Intelligence Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - The White House on Tuesday endorsed the intelligence reorganization measure under consideration in the Senate, warning lawmakers that it would oppose efforts to dilute powers that the bill seeks for a proposed national intelligence director.

title: The Latest Reality Show Twist: Take My Wife, Please
description: The revolution known as reality television has reached its Thermidor: pathos, verging on bathos, is the ruling fashion.

title: Law to Rein In HospitalErrors Is Seen as Abused
description: Hospitals routinely violate a New York State law requiring that they tell the state promptly about medical errors that harm patients, an audit released yesterday said. The audit found that hospitals often delay for weeks or months reports that might be critical to a timely investigation, and sometimes never report the mistakes at all.

title: IT managers are putting security at top of their wish list
CARNIVAL SAYS HURRICANE REFUNDS TO CURB PROFITS
description: The Carnival Corporation, the world's biggest cruise line, said refunds prompted by Hurricane Jeanne would cut net income by 2 cents a share in the fourth quarter. The profit reduction is in addition to the 3 cents to 4 cents lost because of Hurricane Frances and other recent storms. The company, based in Miami, expects profit in the current quarter to rise to 28 cents to 30 cents a share, from 26 cents a year earlier. Carnival cut short six trips after Jeanne forced the closing of several Florida ports.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Iron Contract Expanded
description: The Australian min-ing company BHP Billiton said it had won a $3.2 billion deal to double its iron ore shipments to four Chinese steel mills over the next decade. Jiangsu Shagang, Maanshan Iron and Steel, Tanshan Iron and Steel and Wuhan Iron and Steel agreed in March to buy 12 million metric tons of iron ore from BHP Billiton for the next 25 years, a contract estimated to be worth $9 billion. Under the new deal, the four mills agreed to buy an additional 12 million metric tons of iron ore a year for the next 10 years. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, GERALDINE G.L. (AKA JAUNDINE)
description: MOORE--Geraldine G.L. (aka Jaundine), September 24, 2004. Beloved daughter of the late Geraldine (nee Griffin) and William A. Moore. Attended Loretto Academy, Chicago, graduated from St. Catherine's Academy and Katherine Gibbs, NYC. B.S. degree Fordham, M.A. and professional diploma Teachers College, Columbia. A high school English teacher, NYC, over 23 years. She taught at Bay Ridge H.S., Brooklyn, NY and George Washington H.S., Manhattan. Before teaching she was Asst. Prod. Mgr., Swertfager Ad Agency, Prod. Asst. Parade Magazine, Asst. Legal Ad Mgr. American Banker. Please omit flowers, Mass cards preferred. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of the Resurrection Thursday, September 30, 10:30AM, Esperanza Church, 624 West 156 Street, NYC. title: Hurdles Remain for American Voters Who Live Overseas
description: Four years after overseas voting became a battleground in the presidential election in Florida, millions of civilians and soldiers living abroad still face a bewildering and unwieldy system of absentee balloting that could prevent their votes from being counted.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SALISBURY, NANCY, RSCJ.
description: SALISBURY -- Nancy, rscj. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff, Students, Parents and Alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional leader, gifted teacher and treasured friend. An advocate for the importance of faith and spirit in the lives of children, she inspired countless women with her compassion and purpose as she led our school as Head Mistress from 1980 until her retirement in 2000. She left an indelible mark on thousands of Sacred Heart students in New York and in many other Network schools with her profound spirituality, her emphasis on academic rigor and her openness to new approaches in education. Memorial gifts may be made to the Society of the Sacred Heart Retirement Fund, 4389 West Pine Boulevard, St. Louis, MO. 63108. Mary Blake, Ed.D, Head Mistress Laurette M. Bryan, Chair, Board of Trustees Convent of the Sacred Heart New York City

title: Council Agrees on Deal to Put Water Plant in Bronx Park
description: At a raucous session, the City Council signed off yesterday on an agreement between city and state officials under which a $1.3 billion water filtration plant would be built in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. In return, the borough would get more than $200 million for parks projects.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retailer Selling Assets
description: Europe's largest department store operator, KarstadtQuelle, plans to raise 1.6 billion euros ($1.97 billion) by selling shares and assets, including almost half of its department stores, as sales fell for the third consecutive year. The company will cut jobs and pay no dividend over two years, the chief executive, Christoph Achenbach, above, said at a meeting near the company's headquarters in Essen, Germany. The company named Harald Pinger as chief financial officer to help with the overhaul, which will lead to a loss of up to 1.34 billion euros before tax and good will this year. The post had been vacant since July 2003. Mr. Achenbach, who took over in June, said he would cut back ventures formed under his predecessor, but that the company was unlikely to post a profit before 2006.

title: From India, Banana Leaf Optional
description: ITALY may have given us pesto, but it has no monopoly on herb pastes. You find them all over the world, and all they have in common is green. Among my favorites is a spicy cilantro-coconut paste whose flavor dominates the classic banquet dish of the Parsees of India, called patra ni machi, pomfret steamed in banana leaves.

title: CAMPAIGN 2004: As debate nears, Bush keeps lead over Kerry
Paid Notice: Deaths   BOROWITZ, ESTELLE, DR.
description: BOROWITZ -- Estelle, Dr. Whose grace, wisdom and depth of soul made her widely beloved, died Monday, September 27. One of the first graduates of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies, she served on its faculty and on its journal editorial board. She was a founder and Dean of Curriculum for the Long Island Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies. The devoted soulmate of Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz for 57 years, she was the loving mother of Lisa, Drucy and Phil Glick, and Nan and Andy Langowitz, and grandmother to Zoey, Zack, Noah, Emily and Joshua. Services are at 1:30 PM, Wednesday September 29 at Temple Sinai, Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Sinai. The family will be at home Sunday from 2-5PM for friends who wish to pay their respects.

title: INSIDE
description: Geoffrey Beene Dies at 77 The couturier, shown in his 57th Street office in 1991, succeeded by putting fashion above commerce. He avoided fads as well as the highfalutin, and from the 1970's on, he offered designs that showed an evolving interest in constructing clothes with a greater appearance of lightness. PAGE A23

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,048 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Martha Stewart to Serve Time in West Virginia
description: Martha Stewart's prison stay for lying about a stock sale will take her to West Virginia, farther from home for the holidays, she said today, than she had hoped.

title: Long Trail of Dubious Voter Registration Emerges in Queens
description: A review of voter registration records shows that a pattern of suspicious registrations in an Assembly district in Queens extends back to the 2002 election, when almost 100 new voters gave home addresses that turned out to be businesses like restaurants, hair salons and a plumbing supply store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURCO, ANTHONY M.
description: TURCO--Anthony M., 86, of Babylon, LI on September 28, 2004. Beloved husband of Annabella. Loving father of Mark and the late Arthur Turco. Devoted grandfather of Jessica Wilson and Bucky Turco. Dear brother of Fred Turco. Friends may visit Thursday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 P.M., at the Claude R. BoydSpencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main Street, Babylon. Funeral Friday, 12:30 P.M., from the funeral home. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The cellphone is not for her convenience. It's for her security. It's for my peace of mind."

title: Year After Assaults, Play Begins but Pain Never Ends
description: BELLMORE, N.Y., Sept. 23 - Football is back at Mepham High after a brutal hazing and a canceled season. There is an ache for comforting ritual: the peppy exhorting of cheerleaders, the hard slap of leather and plastic, a band's brassy geometry, the luxuriant smell of a grass field lined and mowed for autumn.

title: Sudan Official Calls Darfur a 'Smoke Screen' for Plotters
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, Sept. 28 - A senior Sudanese official on Tuesday called the Darfur crisis a "smoke screen" to hoodwink the international community into aiding political opponents who seek to overthrow the government. He warned that disarming pro-government militias, if done hastily and carelessly, could cause a violent ethnic war.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO ACQUIRE FLORIDA BANK
description: Colonial BancGroup Inc., based in Alabama, agreed to buy the Union Bank of Florida for about $233 million to add 18 branches in Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties. Colonial will pay $174.8 million in cash and $58.3 million in stock, according to a regulatory filing. Colonial, based in Montgomery, said it had bought 19 banks in Florida since 1996 to expand beyond Alabama. The purchase increases its deposits in Florida by 13 percent. Union Bank, based in Sunrise, Fla., had $1.1 billion in assets and $687 million in deposits as of June 30. Colonial has made acquisitions in Florida, Nevada, Texas and Georgia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allegheny Energy Inc., Greensburg, Pa., said it had agreed to sell an Illinois power plant to ArcLight Capital Partners, Boston, an investment firm, for about $173 million, and that it would sell plants in Indiana and Tennessee.

title: PFIZER APPEALS REVOCATION OF VIAGRA PATENT BY CHINA
description: Pfizer has appealed the revocation of its patent on Viagra by China in a case that may test that nation's commitment to intellectual property rights. Pfizer, which is based in New York, filed an appeal of the decision made by the patent office in July, said Wang Xunbiao, Beijing spokesman for the company. The filing was made in the Beijing First Intermediate People's Court. The Chinese patent on Viagra, an impotence treatment, was originally due to expire in 2014. Viagra generated $1.88 billion in sales for Pfizer last year, with $776 million coming from outside the United States. Sales in China were limited because only hospitals could sell the drug. Pfizer said that it had won approval from China to expand the sale of Viagra to pharmacies.

title: Calendar
description: Going Dutch

title: In the Expectations Game, the Bush Camp Plays Hard
description: By the time the presidential debate expectations game is played out Thursday night, it will be a wonder if the public expects President Bush to get a coherent sentence out.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: At Heart, Gorgeously Gooey
description: Woodhouse, a new chocolatier in St. Helena, Calif., takes the Whitman Sampler approach to an exquisite level, left. You can select peanut croquant made with peanut gianduja, the wild cherry in ganache, the spiced chocolate quatre-epices or the white chocolate Champagne truffle, among many others. Descriptions are enclosed. Woodhouse Chocolate sells its confections for $1.25 a piece or for $26 a pound. The chocolates can be ordered from (800) 966-3468 or www.woodhousechocolate.com.

title: Chemical Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Medtronic Ordered to Pay Inventor
description: The agency in charge of the federal Medicare program has proposed broadening its coverage for implantable devices that electrically shock the heart to restore a normal heartbeat. If the new rule takes effect, it could make tens of thousands of additional Medicare enrollees eligible for the potentially life-saving benefit.

title: New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: CENTRICA OF BRITAIN BUYS SERVICES COMPANY IN OHIO
description: Centrica, a British natural gas distributor, said it bought the Residential Services Group for $150 million. Residential Services provides plumbing, heating and air-conditioning services in Texas and Ohio, where Centrica has one million energy customers. Centrica has five million customers in the United States and Canada, which account for 12 percent of the company's profit. Residential Services, based in Dayton, Ohio, employs about 2,000 people and posted sales of $309 million in the year ended July 31. Earnings before interest, taxes, amortization and depreciation were $24 million, Centrica said.

title: I.B.M. Supercomputer Sets World Record for Speed
description: An I.B.M. machine has reclaimed the title of world's fastest supercomputer, overtaking a Japanese computer that had caused shock waves at United States government agencies when it set a computing speed record in 2002.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about political advertising in the presidential campaign, including a commercial that accused John Kerry of having "secretly met with the enemy" in Paris in the 1970's, misidentified the parties with whom Mr. Kerry said he had met at the Vietnam peace talks. (The error was repeated in articles on Friday and Saturday.) The parties were the two Communist delegations -- North Vietnam and the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government -- with whom he discussed the status of war prisoners. He did not say he had met with "both sides."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORENSTEIN, MILTON C.
description: BORENSTEIN--Milton C., of Brookline, Massachusetts entered into rest September 23, 2004. Husband of the late Anne (Shapiro) Borenstein. Devoted father of Roberta Borenstein of Wilton, CT and Jeffrey Borenstein of West Newton. Brother of Shirley Bloom of Brookline. Cherished grandfather of three. Services at Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1668 Beacon St, Brookline, MA on Wednesday, September 29 at 11 AM. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to Congregation Kehillath Israel, Brookline, MA., or to Boston College, Chestnut Hill, MA.

title: One Nation Indivisible, but Some of It Invisible
description: Correction Appended

title: At House Hearing, Quips, Insults and Some Official Business
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 A The House committee hearing began as a serious discussion about the coming elections in Afghanistan. It ended in insults, so partisan and personal that the committee chairman expressed relief upon adjournment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, JULES IRVING
description: SCHWARTZ -- Jules Irving. Beloved husband of Emily and the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Barbara Herz and Kenneth and Beth. Loving grandfather of Adam, Jonathan, and Ilana. Dear brother of Bernard and the late Harold. Cherished stepfather of Dr. Alan and Linda Fuhr and Michael and Joyce Fuhr and their children. Services Wednesday, at 1:30 PM, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Russia's medicine : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Corrections
description: A program listing, highlight entry and picture caption in the Wednesday pages of the Television section on Sunday for the new CBS series "Center of the Universe" have become outdated. The series will have its premiere on Oct. 20; an episode of CSI will be shown tonight at 9, replacing both "King of Queens" and "Center of the Universe."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEVER, RAYMOND
description: SIEVER--Raymond. Died Friday, September 24, in Cambridge, MA, age 81. Husband of Doris (Fisher) Siever. Father of Larry Siever and his wife Lissa Weinstein of Irvington, NY, and Michael Siever of San Francisco, CA. Grandfather of David Siever and Daniel Siever of Irvington, New York. Memorial to be determined.

title: Feeling a Link to the Spiritual Unknown
description: "The Cloud of Unknowing" is a digital-media experiment posing as a ghost story. It would probably not exist were it not for Hal Hartley, the darling of the independent film world, whose new company, Possible Films, produced and is distributing it. His company, Mr. Hartley has said, deals in films that are "extremely difficult to market theatrically in a conventional way."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, DEBRA E.
description: GOLDMAN--Debra E. Beloved wife of twenty-three years of Leonard Ellis. Cherished sister of Karen Goldman. Devoted daughter of the late Harold and Min Goldman. Adored daughter-in-law of Kenneth Ellis and the late Phyllis Ellis. Loving sister-inlaw of Andrew Ellis and Emily Segal and bemused aunt to Dana, Henry and Rebecca and dedicated friend to Jim Scholfield, Bertelle Selig, Phil Swaboda, Alison Fahey, Ida Steinberg and her daughter Debra Goldman who died at age 52 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Born in St. Louis, she graduated from the University of Michigan and moved immediately to New York City where she filled her life and those who shared it with her passions for theatre, literature, opera, ballet, travel and a constant stream of intelligent, usually hilarious conversation. She will be long remembered and deeply missed by all to whom she gave so much. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Wednesday, September 29 at 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOSLINER, BERTRAM J., MD
description: GOSLINER--Bertram J., MD, 89 of NYC. Prominent psychoanalyst. Beloved husband of Julia Gosliner; father of Kathy Gosliner and Denise Gosliner Orenstein; grandfather of Brendan, Laura, Jennifer, and Lisa. Brotherin-law Joseph Kotler; sistersin-law, Barbara Kotler and Jean Erdheim. Born November 12, 1914 in San Francisco. Graduate of University of California Berkeley, Creighton Medical School, Captain US Army, residency in psychiatry Bellevue Hospital, further trained in psychiatry at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute where he was a training and supervising analyst. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Thursday September 30th, 3pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Parkinsons Foundation, 1501 Northwest 9th Avenue, Miami, FL 33136. GOSLINER--Bertram, M.D. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of our esteemed former colleague. He was a Training and Supervising Analyst at The New York Psychoanalytic Institute and a member of The New York Psychoanalytic Society for over fifty years. Paul Rosenbaum, M.D., Pres. The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute

title: Dissidents at Disney Say They've Won
description: Two dissident shareholders of the Walt Disney Company, Roy E. Disney and Stanley P. Gold, who have called for the ouster of the chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, said their campaign had been successful and praised the board's decision to hire a search firm to find a successor by June 2005.

title: Rivals' Foreign Policy Stances Show Few Clear Distinctions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - It is an axiom of the two presidential campaigns that their candidates offer a stark choice about America's role in the world.

title: Schools Relax CellphoneBans, Nodding to Trend
description: LANSING, Mich. - Sitting in his second-period computer class at Eastern High School, Gray Taylor, 15, felt his cellphone vibrate. To avoid being caught by the teacher, he answered quietly -- and discovered an unexpected caller.

title: Fire in Commuter Train Tunnel Is Traced to a Wire in Queens
description: Correction Appended

title: Cendant Is Close to Acquiring Orbitz for $1.1 Billion
description: The Cendant Corporation, which owns Avis car rental and the Days Inn hotel chain, is close to a deal to buy Orbitz, the online travel service controlled by an alliance of airlines, for about $1.1 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Times Sues Prosecutor on Phone Records
description: The New York Times filed a lawsuit yesterday in federal court in Manhattan to stop a federal prosecutor from inspecting telephone records of two Times reporters. The suit contends that the records are covered by the reporters' privilege, a legal doctrine that allows reporters to protect their sources in some circumstances.

title: EU nominee defends business record, promising to be impartial
CAMPAIGN 2004: As debate nears, Bush keeps lead over Kerry
Doing Business : Swank and style merge in Melbourne
2 Agencies Get HUD Grants to Fight Housing Bias
description: The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday that it would award two groups working in tandem more than $1 million to help combat housing discrimination in New York City.

title: Wachovia Says S.E.C. May Act in Mutual Fund Trading Case
description: The Wachovia Corporation said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission may recommend enforcement action against its brokerage unit, Wachovia Securities, on charges of improper mutual fund trading.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Power Authority Plans Cable Projects
description: The Long Island Power Authority is embarking on two major cable projects, helping to replace a broken set of electric lines to Connecticut and laying a new cable to New Jersey, authority officials said yesterday. The projects, which are expected to be approved by the agency's board today, are intended to supply Long Island's growing demand for electricity, to curb prices by importing cheaper energy, and to bolster the power grid against wide blackouts. The New Jersey cable will stretch 67 miles under the Atlantic Ocean floor between Sayreville, N.J., and Wantagh, N.Y., where it will burrow under Jones Beach and then run along the Wantagh Parkway to a converter station. The other project will replace the 300-megawatt group of seven cables running 11 miles between Northport, N.Y., and Norwalk, Conn. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about New Jersey schools where people can learn to make wine misstated the location of Unico National, an Italian-American service organization where one winemaker recruited students. It is Fairfield in New Jersey, not Connecticut.

title: Italians Unite, for a Time, in Joy at Release of 'the 2 Simonas'
description: Correction Appended

title: Warnings on Warming
description: One wonders what it will take to bestir the Bush administration on the subject of global warming. Everywhere one looks nowadays -- London, Moscow, even the odd precinct on Capitol Hill -- there is evidence of mounting impatience with Washington's refusal to face up to the threat. While the links between global warming and Florida's serial hurricanes are largely theoretical, even the weather seems to be telling the politicians that it is time to start paying attention.

title: So a Purist Goes in a Bar and Starts to Pour Art
description: FLATIRON LOUNGE, a dim, year-old sanctum of red leatherette and cobalt blue mirrors, shares a certain retro cigarette-holder chic with many of the city's newer bars and lounges. But unlike most it does not serve a fruit bowl of slushy margaritas.

title: In Florida, Hopes for One Final Storm Recovery
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 28 - Schools and courts have closed for weeks on end. Roads, bridges, restaurants and hotels are in tatters, crops laid to waste and polling places for the coming election destroyed. Four back-to-back hurricanes have made normalcy ever more elusive in Florida, where intensive relief efforts cannot get traction helping people and whole industries cope.

title: WORD OF MOUTH
description: Oprah Winfrey (below) has done it again. "He's Just Not That Into You," a relationship-advice book by Greg Behrendt and Liz Tuccillo, has flown out of bookstores since Ms. Winfrey interviewed the authors on her show a week ago. The book's title is taken from a chilling riposte dreamed up by Mr. Behrendt and featured in the final season of "Sex and the City," the HBO television series where they worked as writers. Since their Oprah appearance, the book has occupied the No. 1 spot on both the Amazon.com and Barnes & Noble.com best-seller lists, and both online retailers are in need of books, warning of one-to-three-week shipping schedules. Simon Spotlight Entertainment, the new imprint from Simon & Schuster that features books for readers from 18 to 35, just raised the book's expected printing to 410,000, up from a first printing of 30,000, said Tracy van Straaten, executive director of publicity for the imprint. "We have books arriving from the printer every day this week," she said, "and they are going back out the door immediately." EDWARD WYATT

title: Riding a Crimson Tide Over the South
description: Rammer Jammer Yellow Hammer A Journey Into the Heart of Fan Mania By Warren St. John 275 pages. Crown. $24.

title: Victim of Domestic Abuse Gets City Job Back
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ruled that a woman who said she was unfairly fired from her job as a probation officer with the City Department of Correction must be reinstated. The decision came in the first case using a city law passed in 2000 that protects domestic violence victims from discrimination at work.

title: In Ellsberg's Footsteps
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about a Pentagon office's involvement in deliberations over United States policy toward Iran -- at the same time one of its employees was suspected of passing secrets to Israel, which was interested in some Iran issues -- misidentified the country on which Pentagon officials wanted to keep pressure. It was Iran, not Iraq. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the given name of an expert on Iran who was interviewed by the F.B.I. He is Keith Weissman, not Kenneth.

title: A Fast Finisher's Reputation Now Faces the Ultimate Test
description: In 1996, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts was struggling to keep his job in the face of a stiff challenge by his state's popular, aw-shucks Republican governor, William F. Weld, when midway through a series of televised debates, he began a confession that suddenly became a boast.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about prewar intelligence assessments on Iraq misidentified the television program on which Secretary of State Colin L. Powell discussed them on Sunday. It was ABC's "This Week," not "Fox News Sunday," on which he appeared the same day.

title: Brazilian Pianistic Classicism, Both Alloyed and Pure
description: Classical musicians are on the lookout these days for programming ideas that let them combine their own repertory with music that either is more broadly appealing or will attract the curious. The master is the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, who has turned his Silk Road project into several years of programs and recordings. Mostly Mozart gave this approach a try with a program last month that brought together Middle Eastern music and the Mozart Requiem.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision To Spin Off Unit In 4th Quarter
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the country's sixth-largest cable provider, said yesterday that it would spin off its Rainbow Media Enterprises division during the fourth quarter, according to a filing with regulators. The company had previously said it would complete the spinoff in the third quarter. The company, however, is still awaiting approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission and its own board. In August, Cablevision completed the financing plan for Rainbow Media, which includes several television networks and a high-definition satellite provider called Voom. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sentencing In 1991 Attack On Jews
description: A court sentenced Andrea Klump, linked to the left-wing terrorist group Red Army Faction, to 12 years in prison for a car bomb attack in 1991 on Soviet Jewish migrs in Budapest. Ms. Klump, 47, was found guilty of 33 counts of accessory to attempted murder on behalf of a radical Palestinian group. Six people were wounded in the attack on a bus carrying the emigrants to Budapest's airport. Ms. Klump was already serving a nine-year sentence for attempted murder, blackmail and hostage-taking during a failed attack in 1998 on a Spanish disco frequented by American military personnel. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Judge Voids Suit On Ten Commandments Monument
description: A Montgomery County Circuit Court judge dismissed a suit by 10 residents who want former Chief Justice Roy S. Moore to reimburse $550,000 in legal fees that the state paid groups that sued to have his Ten Commandments monument removed from the State Judicial Building. Mr. Moore's lawyers argued that the taxpayers lacked legal standing. Judge Tracy McCooey agreed, lawyers in the case said. Mr. Moore has said the state was wrong to pay the fees and maintains that the monument was illegally removed and that he was illegally removed from office. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ribbon Cut For Rejuvenated Park
description: One of 13 parks being created or rejuvenated through a $24.6 million program of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has officially opened. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg cut the ribbon on Monday for four reconstructed ball fields -- two natural grass and two synthetic -- in John V. Lindsay East River Park. The project, the fifth of the 13 to be completed, cost $4.6 million. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Why a Duck? Because It's Simple Yet Still Grand
description: MY family teases me that whenever they call me while I'm cooking and ask what I'm making, I answer, "Roast chicken." Personally, I don't get the joke. I really do believe most people would want to eat roast chicken for dinner, given a choice. And the dish certainly represents the best ratio of reward to effort in the kitchen that I can think of.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKWITH, LEO
description: BECKWITH--Leo. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Leo Beckwith. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jerold L. Zaro, President Harvey L. York, Secretary

title: F.E.C. to Fight Judge's Ruling on Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - The Federal Election Commission will appeal a judge's ruling last week that the agency must write tougher rules to regulate how millions of dollars are spent on campaigns.

title: Court Rules in Vendors' Favor, Declaring a Fine Increase Illegal
description: They filed into the high-ceilinged courtroom yesterday with weary, worried faces, more than 50 immigrant street vendors who had learned the hard way that the city could quadruple the fines on their sidewalk businesses without warning.

title: Women and the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Hits California 11 Years Late
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 - More than 11 years after scientists predicted it would occur, a strong earthquake rocked the Central California town of Parkfield on Tuesday morning, triggering almost 200 aftershocks and sending emergency crews scrambling in a radius of several hundred miles.

title: Corrections
description: A credit in the special Small Business section on Sept. 21 for a comic strip about one independent artist's career path in the comics industry misstated the author's name. He is Brian Michael Bendis, not Michael Bendis Smith.

title: Of Amulets and Scrolls
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Currents
description: On Sept. 23, Lisa Mahar opened Kid O, a shop in Greenwich Village that sells modernist toys,  furniture and books for children.

title: Set Design
description: David Rockwell's maniacal backdrops set the stage for the darkly comic vision of "Team America."

title: Spreading Scandinavian Genes, Without Viking Boats
description: ARHUS, Denmark - If, suddenly, children in some pockets of the world look blonder and taller, if they feel oddly at ease on a bicycle or juggling three languages, there may be an explanation: Arhus and its university men.

title: Ex-Officer Is Found Fit for Trial in Subway Blast
description: A former New York City police officer charged with setting off an explosive in a Times Square subway station has been determined mentally fit to stand trial, despite his lawyer's claims that he remains deeply traumatized from the explosion and the events of Sept. 11.

title: And Now, a Few Words From the Urinal
description: ISLIP, N.Y. - RICHARD DEUTSCH, an electrical engineer and former chiropractor, has come up with an invention that looks like a hockey puck with mesh wings, is sensitive to changes in light and has a tendency to go off with even the slightest bit of movement, which can prompt red flashing lights, crunchy guitar chords and a commercial announcement.

title: Tonight's the Night: Bush and Kerry, Head to Head
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
Climb Behind the Wheel, No Driver's License Required
description: Fans of video racing sometimes try to heighten a game's realism by replacing the game controller with a steering wheel peripheral. With a wheel in your hands and gas and brake pedals at your feet, you can almost feel as though you are driving a car, although the experience is somewhat diluted by the need to hold the wheel base between your knees or clamp it to a table.

title: Asian Immigrants Become Political Force in Flushing
description: Dr. Kent Chin, a Chinese immigrant who lives in Flushing, Queens, became an American citizen last year and on Sept. 14 voted in his first American election: the Democratic primary for State Assembly.

title: The Tricky Art of the Stew
description: Unexpected ingredients can sometimes be tossed into tasty stews. But at other times, combining bits of this with morsels of that produces only a hodgepodge, as when the Laura Ward/Octavia Cup Dance Theater presented Ms. Ward's new "Enredaderas: Entanglements" on Sunday at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: He Sings, He Dances, He Parts the Red Sea
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 - It's tempting to let the phrase that has been used as the advertising tag for "The Ten Commandments," the pop opera that opened here this week, stand as its critical epitaph. To wit: "Val Kilmer Is Moses."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Southampton: Police Officer Suspended
description: A Southampton Town police lieutenant accused of perjury in a hit-and-run trial this year has been suspended without pay for a month. The town board approved the penalty on Monday at the request of Police Chief Fred Overton. The lieutenant, William Armstrong, has eight days to answer disciplinary charges and could face dismissal, said Vincent Toomey, a lawyer for the town. Suffolk County investigators concluded that Lieutenant Armstrong, head of the detective squad, never went to the scene of a 2002 crash in Sagaponack that killed a pedestrian, as he had testified at the trial of Leslie Jennemann. She was convicted of manslaughter in the crash and is serving two to six years in prison. Peter C. Beller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOOPER, AL
description: KOOPER--Al. On September 28, 2004, at the age of 102, in West Palm Beach, FL. Holocaust survivor, entrepreneur, philanthropist. Husband of Jean, of Forest Hills, NY and Lake Worth, FL. Father of Larry and Mary Beth, of NY, and Fae and Jim Hamilton, of Redwood City, CA. Grandfather of Max. Services on Sunday, October 3 at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Contributions may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC, www.ushmm.org.

title: Pentagon Spends Without Bids, a Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - More than 40 percent of Pentagon business, a total of $362 billion, has been awarded on a no-bid basis over the last six years, according to a report issued Wednesday that showed that the biggest companies won the bulk of their contracts without going through a competitive process.

title: City Mails Tax Rebates as Mayor Collects the Credit
description: This time, the check really is in the mail.

title: The Return of Joe Hardy
description: In the first decade of the 20th century, a sportswriter named Charles Dryden, bemused by the stumbling Washington Senators of the new American League, took some liberty with Henry Lee's famed funeral oration in tribute of George Washington -- "First in War, First in Peace, and First in the Hearts of His Countrymen." Dryden placed an enduring stamp on the Senators with an often-quoted line: "Washington -- First in War, First in Peace, and Last in the American League."

title: Bush and Kerry Clash Over Iraq in Their First Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 - President Bush and Senator John Kerry clashed over national security on Thursday night in the opening minutes of the first presidential debate, with the president saying he had acted aggressively to protect the country and his Democratic challenger saying Mr. Bush had made a "colossal error" of judgment in his handling of the war in Iraq.

title: Ex-Mayor of Hoboken Admits He Accepted $5,000 in Bribes
description: NEWARK, Sept. 29 - Anthony J. Russo, the former mayor of Hoboken, pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to accepting $5,000 in bribes from the owner of an accounting firm in exchange for his help in securing city contracts.

title: Our Civilized Neighbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dallas Publisher to Cut 3% of Its Workers
description: Continuing its efforts to restore the confidence of investors and advertisers after the discovery of exaggerated circulation figures at The Dallas Morning News, the Belo Corporation said yesterday that it would pare the company's work force by about 3 percent before year's end.

title: Tonight's the Night: Bush and Kerry, Head to Head
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: New Order For Embraer
description: Air Canada placed an order worth $1.35 billion for 45 passenger jets from Empresa Brasileira de Aeronutica, the Brazilian aircraft manufacturer known as Embraer. Air Canada also has the option to buy an additional 45 planes, which could raise the total value of the deal to more than $2.7 billion if all options are exercised. Deliveries are scheduled to start in November 2005. Air Canada, which is expected to emerge from bankruptcy protection today, is seeking to renew its fleet with smaller regional jets like the Embraer 190, which seats up to 106 passengers. The deal comes just two days after Air Canada said it would buy $821 million worth of jets from the Canadian plane maker Bombardier for its regional operating unit, Air Canada Jazz. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, IRVING B.
description: HARRIS--Irving B. A courageous champion of young children and families, an articulate and uncompromising social critic, a compassionate pragmatist. His convictions inspired the work of four generations of practitioners and researchers in the field of child development and early care and education. He made of his life a quest to repair the world. In his passionate desire to see, to integrate, to serve, and to heal, he embodied the highest role of humanity. He was our founder, our friend, our mentor, and our benefactor. His lively intelligence and keen insights will be missed, but his voice will never fall silent and his spark will illuminate for generations to come. Our deepest sympathy to his loving wife and strongest ally, Joan, and to his children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren, of whom he was so proud. Samuel J. Meisels, Ed.D., President, and the entire Board of Trustees, faculty, staff and student body of Erikson Institute, a graduate school in child development, Irving B. Harris, Founder HARRIS--Irving B. Sarah Lawrence College mourns the passing of our former trustee ('50-'59)--a visionary dedicated to bettering the lives of children. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Joan, and his entire family, including his son, William Harris, also a trustee ('78-'82), and his daughters, who were alumnae of the College, Virginia Polsky and Roxanne Frank. Robert M. Riggs, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Michele Tolela Myers, President

title: Global Warming Is Expected to Raise Hurricane Intensity
description: Global warming is likely to produce a significant increase in the intensity and rainfall of hurricanes in coming decades, according to the most comprehensive computer analysis done so far.

title: WAL-MART TO BUY BACK $10 BILLION IN STOCK
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that it would repurchase as much as $10 billion in stock, the company's biggest proposed buyback in at least a decade. The repurchases would be made as more shares of the company trade because of weighting changes in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Wal-Mart's representation was expected to decline after a change in the benchmark index's methodology. Changes in the index could lead to the sale of about $8.4 billion in Wal-Mart shares, a Smith Barney analyst, Deborah Weinswig, wrote in a report. Wal-Mart is based in Bentonville, Ark.

Their school was also damaged and is still closed. Government officials and aid workers said clean drinking water and food were still scarce on much of the island, and most residents still lack electricity and telephone lines. PAGE A3

MORE FAME FOR THE FAMOUS
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center is to announce today the induction of the first 14 musicians into its Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame in the organization's new home in the Time Warner Building at Columbus Circle. The first inductees are Louis Armstrong, left, Sidney Bechet, Bix Beiderbecke, John Coltrane, Miles Davis, Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie, Coleman Hawkins, Billie Holiday, Thelonious Monk, Jelly Roll Morton, Charlie Parker, Art Tatum and Lester Young. Relatives and friends of the inductees will accept the awards, to be given by musicians including Herbie Hancock, Hank Jones, Clark Terry, Randy Weston and Jazz at Lincoln Center's artistic director, Wynton Marsalis. The hall of fame is a gift of Ahmet Ertegun -- a Jazz at Lincoln Center board member and a founding chairman of Atlantic Records -- and his wife, Mica. They have named it in honor of Nesuhi Ertegun, Ahmet's late brother, another initial partner in Atlantic records and an important advocate for jazz in journalism, education and recordings. "Originally, I thought it would be nice to have a space where people could see and hear the great pioneers of jazz, a place depicting the history," Mr. Ertegun said in an interview. "But our board said that in America, a hall of fame is a draw for the public, especially for non-New Yorkers, and I agreed with them. This is a small space, but it will celebrate the great people of jazz, and give jazz fans a locus." The musicians were chosen by a 72-member panel of educators, musicians and scholars. The Hall of Fame, which will be free and opens to the public on Oct. 21, includes interactive kiosks, touch-activated virtual plaques and a video wall, all centered on changing exhibitions. BEN RATLIFF

title: Walter Scheuer, 82, Investor and a Supporter of the Arts, Dies
description: Walter Scheuer, a New York investor and patron of the arts who produced the Oscar-winning documentary "From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China" among other films, died on Sept. 20 at his home in Manhattan, his family announced. He was 82.

title: Headphones That Make the World Go Away
description: TAKE a listen to the lullaby of Broadway these days and you will probably hear a lot more than the rumble of the subway train and the rattle of the taxi. Add a few squealing buses and the usual chorus of car horns, and you have a cacophonic symphony in your ears.

title: A Nuclear Iraq
description: The new International Criminal Court has gained the support of many European nations. In a recent statement to the American Bar Association, you asserted that the Bush administration has been "ham-handed" in its approach to the court and has "needlessly alienated" allies on the issue. But you don't say much else -- merely that you would "carefully consider the full range of U.S. interests at stake with respect to the court as we review our policy and fashion a more constructive approach."

title: In London, Dissent Roils Design Museum
description: LONDON - WHEN the Design Museum opened here in 1989, its founder, Sir Terence Conran, described it as a place to showcase manufactured products, delve into engineering and explore industrial design. But in recent years the museum, under the direction of Alice Rawsthorn, has strayed from that vision, offering whimsical exhibitions on Manolo Blahnik shoes and Saul Bass film posters. On Monday, after an exhibition opened on Constance Spry flower arrangements, James Dyson, the prominent inventor who has been chairman of the museum for the past five years, resigned, saying he disagreed with its direction.

title: House Votes to Repeal Ban on Handguns in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Two weeks after the Republican leadership in Congress allowed the federal assault weapons ban to expire, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to repeal the District of Columbia's 27-year-old ban on certain firearms, one of the strictest gun laws in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRYANT, MARTHA T.
description: BRYANT--Martha T., 87. Died in her Manhattan home on September 19th. She retired from government service in 1962 and the Presbyterian Church USA in 1988. She is survived by her husband of 51 years, William Bryant.

title: The UN and Darfur : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
GOLDEN ANNIVERSARY
description: George Jones will celebrate his half-century as a recording artist in a unique way. Mr. Jones, arguably country's greatest living singer, will release a three-CD compilation that features one song from each year of his 50-year career. "George Jones -- 50 Years of Hits" (Bandit Records) will be in stores on Nov. 9. It begins with his classic 1955 Starday release, "Why Baby Why." Since then, he has had more than 160 songs on the charts, including the 1980 tune many consider the finest country song ever, "He Stopped Loving Her Today." In a statement, Mr. Jones, 73, said: "It's hard to believe that it's been 50 years. I have to admit I'm a bit shocked by it all." PHIL SWEETLAND

title: A Chip Off the Old Park
description: By the time you have found a perch on the storybook hill, stumbled through the boggy marsh, ascended the glistening wall of craggy bluestone, scuttled through a notch in the limestone boulders and -- attention, first graders! -- slid into the sand pit, you will be amazed that you have covered only 1.9 acres.

description: "This is a great day for Washington. After 30 years of waiting and waiting, lots of hard work, and more than a few prayers, there will be baseball in Washington in 2005."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Food Workers Unionize
description: New York City's restaurant workers' union announced yesterday that it had unionized 117 food service workers at four Merrill Lynch sites in Manhattan. Amanda Ream, an organizer with Unite-Here, said workers at Merrill Lynch's executive dining room, cafeterias and trading floors had signed cards saying they wanted to join the union. They are employed by Sodexho, a French company that works as Merrill's food contractor. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: In a rock era thick with divas, Melissa Auf der Maur has some significant credentials. She is classically beautiful, she knows her way around a clothing rack, and as a former member of Hole and Smashing Pumpkins, she has seen bad behavior at its best.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Debt Swap For Trade Concern
description: A Japanese trading company, Sojitz Holdings, will receive 370 billion yen ($3.34 billion) in aid from UFJ Holdings and other lenders as part of a bailout approved by its shareholders. UFJ, which is based in Osaka, will swap debt owed by Sojitz for 330 billion yen of preferred shares in the company on Oct. 29, it said. Sojitz, based in Tokyo, is among several companies that are struggling to repay UFJ and are reorganizing their operations to bolster their finances. UFJ needs to cut bad loans to meet a target set by regulators and to prepare for a merger.

title: Judge Releases I.B.F. From Federal Supervision
description: The International Boxing Federation, the ranking organization that has been overseen by a court-appointed monitor for nearly five years after its founder was indicted on charges of racketeering and soliciting bribes, was released from that supervision yesterday.

title: Trouble With Anemia Drug Is Reduced, but Issues Remain
description: The incidence of a rare but serious side effect associated with Eprex, an anemia drug from Johnson & Johnson that is sold overseas, has been sharply reduced by changes in the packaging and administration of the drug, two teams of scientists said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Number Of Poor Children Rises
description: The number of poor children living in New Jersey's cities is rising, while state efforts to support them are falling, according to a report released by the Association for Children of New Jersey, a child advocacy organization. The report found that the 535,000 children living in New Jersey's 25 largest cities fell well below statewide averages in 20 of 26 indicators. Children in urban areas, who made up 26 percent of the state's total child population in the 2000 census, were more likely to suffer from health problems, abuse and neglect. Jessica Bruder (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Minorities Protest Program
description: More than 30 people marched in front of city hall in Detroit on Tuesday to protest an economic development plan that would benefit African-Americans and exclude other minorities. The plan is a result of a consultant's report that said other minority groups had taken jobs, resources and opportunities from African-Americans. Latino, Asian-American and Arab-American civic leaders sought repeal of the plan and an apology. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Playing With the Election Rules
description: One of the lessons of the election mess in Florida in 2000 was that a secretary of state can deprive a large number of people of the right to vote by small manipulations of the rules. This year in Ohio and Colorado, two key battlegrounds, the secretaries of state have been interpreting the rules in ways that could prevent thousands of eligible Americans from voting. In both states, the courts should step in.

title: Prosecutors Seek to Drop a Tyco Charge
description: Manhattan prosecutors want to drop a charge that accuses L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, the former executives of Tyco International, of running the company as a criminal enterprise when the two men are retried in January.

title: I.M.F. Asks China to Free Its Currency From Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - The International Monetary Fund added its voice on Wednesday to the growing calls for China to float its currency immediately, a move that supporters say would help reduce the United States trade deficit and strengthen the global economy.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Alcan Begins Spinoff
description: Alcan, the Montreal-based aluminum producer, formally moved to spin off its rolled-products business to shareholders by filing a prospectus with regulators late Tuesday. The new company, which will be known as Novelis, will be the world's largest producer of rolled-products, with an 18 percent market share and revenue of $6.2 billion, based on 2003. The spinoff was announced in May and is largely intended to counter antitrust concerns that developed in Europe and in the United States after Alcan acquired Pechiney last year. Ian Austen (NYT)

Richard A. Gephardt, a former Democratic presidential contender and a diehard St. Louis Cardinals fan, is for it, enthusiastically -- if it does not fatten the Cardinals' loss column.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Unit Introduces Wireless Technologies
description: Linksys, a division of Cisco Systems focused on consumer networking products, yesterday introduced new wireless technologies to help home users easily connect home entertainment and computing devices. Linksys, based in Irvine, Calif., also announced that Verizon would sell Linksys's phone adapter to customers who sign up for its Internet-based phone service. The new wireless products include a line of routers and adapters for connecting computers, music systems and televisions wirelessly throughout the house, using multiple wireless standards to eliminate compatibility problems. The products also include an upgraded wireless Internet video camera that lets users view live video streams over the Internet. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 20 Indicted In Robbery Ring
description: A federal indictment unsealed yesterday in Manhattan federal court charges 20 people from the Bronx with taking part in a robbery ring that focused on drug dealers and commercial establishments in the Bronx, Queens and Mount Vernon, actions that led to one homicide. Most of the robberies occurred from 2001 to 2003, with about half at the homes of narcotics dealers where the defendants stole drugs to sell, said Joseph G. Green, senior special agent at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. They were charged with robbery, firearms and narcotics offenses; three were also charged with the murder of Elvis Gonzalez, who was shot in August 2002 during an attempted robbery. Andrea Elliott (NYT)

description: NISANIT, Gaza Strip, Sept. 30  In the bloodiest day in more than two years, 28 Palestinians and 3 Israelis were killed today as Israeli troops pushed into a densely packed refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip and battled militants darting among the narrow alleys.

title: Time on a Chip: The Incredible Shrinking Atomic Clock
description: PEOPLE who are pressed for time often complain that clocks rule their lives. But for most electronic devices, the claim is absolutely true. Vibrations from tiny quartz crystals act like a metronome, producing precise time pulses that, among other things, keep the various operations of microchips in step.

title: Comptroller Agrees to Audit Finances of Yonkers
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29 - Responding to requests by six legislators who represent Yonkers, State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi agreed on Wednesday to conduct an audit of the city's troubled finances.

title: How Tony Blair Handled It
description: Watching Tony Blair is always instructive for Americans, and sometimes the source of envy. He faces much the same political conundrum as President Bush -- a war gone wrong in a charged political season -- with the added fillip that he followed Mr. Bush's lead into Iraq. But Prime Minister Blair has acknowledged the validity of the criticism he faces, and he is also not pretending that things in Iraq are humming along on schedule. "I entirely understand why many disagree," he said at the annual meeting of his Labor Party on Tuesday.

title: Dropout Aid Centers Are Shut by the City
description: The New York City Education Department has shut down dozens of sites used by dropouts to prepare for the high school equivalency exam, bewildering staff members and creating a chaotic situation for young people already at risk of abandoning their studies.

description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 - The doors are spinning again for the Mets. title: CYTOGEN SETTLES PATENT SUIT WITH IMMUNOMEDICS
description: The Cytogen Corporation, which makes products to help detect cancer, said that it made a payment to settle a patent infringement suit with Immunomedics over a method for diagnosing cancerous tumors. Immunomedics, which develops cancer therapies, sued Cytogen in 2000, claiming Cytogen's ProstaScint imaging agent for detecting prostate cancer violated its United States patent. Cytogen, based in Princeton, N.J., said it did not admit fault or liability in the claim. The payment size was not disclosed. Immunomedics is based in Morris Plains, N.J.
