title: WORDS ON OIL
description: After crude oil prices reached $50 a barrel on Tuesday and held at that price yesterday, Senator John Kerry accused President Bush of breaking a vow that oil from Iraq would lower oil prices to $28 a barrel. "The president promised us the oil would pay for the war, but we know that those oil pipes are being blown up," Mr. Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, said in Madison, Wis. "We know that $50 a barrel isn't as bad as it might get because analysts are now telling us that the price may go up to $60." He added, "The average American is going to feel this pain. Haliburton's not feeling the pain. The people in Saudi Arabia, the Middle East, who get the money aren't feeling the pain." In response to similar comments by Senator John Edwards, Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, on Tuesday said the rising oil prices reflected a failure of Senate Democrats to approve the president's energy plan, and on the recent hurricanes, brushing off the notion of the Iraq war's influence. "What happens here is that we go through this year after year because we manage through patchwork crisis management instead of passing comprehensive solutions," Mr. McClellan said.

title: City Center Kicks Off Free-Form Festival
description: City Center built it and they came, on Tuesday night, for the opening of the theater's first Fall for Dance Festival. There was even a downpour, courtesy of Hurricane Jeanne, that was worthy of the storms that added extra excitement to the outdoor Delacorte Dance Festival in the 1960's and 70's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEENE, GEOFFREY
description: BEENE--Geoffrey. We note with sorrow the passing of our esteemed client, Geoffrey Beene. Mr. Beene was a perennially elegant fixture in the fashion industry for 50 years, the consummate gentleman and a timeless classic. We extend our condolences to the entire Geoffrey Beene family. Eisikovic & Kane, LLP BEENE -- Geoffrey. The Board of Directors and members of the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA) mourn the loss of the remarkable Geoffrey Beenea creative leader in the industry, a role model and inspiration to so many. BEENE--Geoffrey. The Randa family offers their condolences to the Geoffrey Beene organization on the loss of their great leader. The fashon industry will miss his unique talent. Randa Corp. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron Posts 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Micron Technology, the maker of computer-memory chips, reported a second consecutive quarterly profit as sales jumped 34 percent. Net income was $93.5 million, or 14 cents a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter, compared with a net loss of $123.2 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales rose to $1.19 billion in the period that ended Sept. 2, from $888.5 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Commission Leader Chosen

Alvarado would serve as executive director of a 13-member commission to study how city schools should use money gained in a court order mandating an increase in state education financing. Mr. Alvarado was chancellor from May 1983 to May 1984 but stepped down amid allegations of financial improprieties. From 1998 to 2003, he was the top instructional official in the San Diego public schools and most recently worked as a consultant. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

Windows: Design vs. Safety
description: BILL Ryall, a Manhattan architect, is about to build an addition to a client's house on Shelter Island, at the east end of Long Island. In the living room, a series of sliding glass panels, each eight feet wide, will disappear into a wall. "The effect," he said, "will be dramatic."

title: F.D.A. MAY SUSPEND WORK AT STAAR SURGICAL PLANT
description: The Staar Surgical Company, which makes devices used in eye surgery, said the Food and Drug Administration might suspend operations at its Monrovia, Calif., plant because of flaws in the company's surgically implanted contact lens. Staar's shares fell 38 percent yesterday. After inspecting the plant, the F.D.A. said that the company was not adhering to the agency's regulatory requirements, Staar said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Staar, which is based in Monrovia, said in a written response to the F.D.A. that it had taken corrective actions aimed at resolving the agency's concerns.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Alcohol Machines Banned
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has voted to ban the sale, purchase or use of so-called Alcohol Without Liquid, or AWOL, machines that mix vaporized liquor with oxygen for inhalation. Legislator Jon Cooper, a Democrat from Huntington who introduced the bill that was approved unanimously on Tuesday, said users of the device risked brain damage and addiction and were likely to drive drunk. John Rather (NYT)

title: 1904:Desert Car Trip : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
More Shows Less The Door
description: IT started at the home furnishings fairs in Paris and in Milan: a softening of late-century modernism, with its notoriously hard surfaces and sharp edges. As international design trends trickle into the American retail market, the Lucite lamp becomes not boxy but baroque, with curvy lines and a crinkled see-through shade, and textiles, once studiously neutral, are going shrill with patterns and color.

title: A Little Problem With Authority in the West End
description: LONDON - Daddy is a pedophile. The judge is a crook and a rapist. The general is a murderer of innocent girls. The head nurse is a spirit-squelching fascist. As for the president of the United States, he's really spooky: a havoc-wreaking, self-defined instrument of divine vengeance who has a personal pawn in the British prime minister. As is indicated by this bleak and by no means complete list of power-abusing characters casting their shadows from the stages of the West End here, authority figures aren't getting much respect in London theaters.

title: Religion and U.S. politics : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Experts Confront Hurdlesin Containing Bird Flu
description: BANGKOK, Sept. 29 - With Thai and international experts confirming the first probable human-to-human transmission of a virulent strain of avian influenza in this country, public health officials around the world are facing major hurdles as they try to prepare for a possible pandemic.

title: Question Time: What to Ask John Kerry; Spread Democracy
description: How might you explain the apparent abrupt change in policy of Libya; the unexpected removal of Abdul Qadeer Khan, the father of Pakistan's atomic bomb; and the about-face in Saudi Arabia -- and what precise plans do you have to induce similar such positive changes in attitude in Iran, Lebanon and Syria?

title: Federal Hate Crimes Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Sukkot, the Jewish festival of the harvest, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: 1929:Priest Fights Night Life : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Changing Places
description: "How do you spell 'rat,"' my father would ask me during a lull in one of his many bid whist card games with his buddies from the paper mill. "R-a-t," I'd respond dutifully, with all of the preschool pride that I could muster. "Not that mousy kind of a rat," he'd say. "I mean like 'rat now."' His buddies would howl as my perplexity grew.

title: Martha Stewart Assigned to Prison in West Virginia
description: She wanted Connecticut. She would have settled for Florida. But yesterday, Martha Stewart drew the short straw. She was assigned to serve her sentence at a federal women's prison in Alderson, W.Va., the very facility she had hoped would not be chosen.

title: No Time for Congress to Tinker
description: The White House has sent a much-needed message to the House Republicans who are intent on making a political football out of the overriding need to overhaul the nation's tattered intelligence system. The administration has explicitly endorsed the Senate's far stronger, and bipartisan, reform bill, and it has promised to oppose the reams of House attachments that are more anti-immigrant and anti-civil-rights than anti-terrorist.

title: Sleek and Small, a Camera With an Innovative Eye for Close-Ups
description: The fact that something is smaller does not mean it is less powerful. Casio is hoping to prove that point with the latest addition to its Exilim line of digital cameras, the Exilim Card EX-S100.

title: A Crime Fighter Who Has Never Carried a Gun
description: HE'S not a registered pacifist, but Jeremy Travis, the new, fourth and understatedly patrician president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice, has never carried a gun, much less taken aim and fired one. His preferred weapon is research, something that kept him employed in Washington for the last decade and something that he says is indispensable in the fight against terrorism.

title: Newark Mayor Proposes Panel to Oversee Housing Agency
description: NEWARK, Sept. 29 - Mayor Sharpe James said on Wednesday that he would appoint a nine-member committee to monitor the Newark Housing Authority's role in the proposed $310 million downtown arena if the project wins approval by the Newark City Council.

title: The Workshops of Florence Meet Downtown Manhattan
description: Starting tomorrow, the inner workings of Florentine artisan studios will be on display at the World Financial Center's Winter Garden (220 Vesey Street), for the Splendor of Florence festival. The festival also includes concerts, lectures, wine tastings and an exhibition of paintings from the Uffizi Gallery. Eight teams of artisans will be on hand, etching crystal and silverware and carving architectural ornaments, among other things.

title: New Yorkers Are Taking the Political Fight Elsewhere
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 - Jeffrey Anderson, a paralegal from Brooklyn, took three vacation days and more than $600 out of his bank account to canvass this city this week, registering voters in the hopes of defeating President Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NETTER, ARTHUR B.
description: NETTER--Arthur B. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Arthur B. Netter, beloved brother of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Richard Netter, a member of the Continuum and Beth Israel Boards of Trustees. To Richard, his nephew, Andrew Netter, his niece Lisa Kelly, his brother Edward, the entire Netter family and all of his late brother's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum Thomas Killip, MD Interim President and CEO Beth Israel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WYATT, HOPE JOHNSTON
description: WYATT--Hope Johnston, widow of the late Judge Inzer B. Wyatt, Jr. Died in New York on September 26, 2004. Burial in Maple Hill Cemetery, Huntsville, Alabama, October 2nd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALISBURY, NANCY, RSCJ.
description: SALISBURY -- Nancy, rscj. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff, Students, Parents and Alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional leader, gifted teacher and treasured friend. An advocate for the importance of faith and spirit in the lives of children, she inspired countless women with her compassion and purpose as she led our school as Head Mistress from 1980 until her retirement in 2000. She left an indelible mark on thousands of Sacred Heart students in New York and in many other Network schools with her profound spirituality, her emphasis on academic rigor and her openness to new approaches in education. Memorial gifts may be made to the Society of the Sacred Heart Retirement Fund, 4389 West Pine Boulevard, St. Louis, MO. 63108. Mary Blake, Ed.D, Head Mistress Laurette M. Bryan, Chair, Board of Trustees Convent of the Sacred Heart New York City

title: Players' Tempers Burn in the Land of Playoff Fever
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 - In baseball's battleground state, where every game is a turf war and a test of survival, pennant fever has boiled into rage.

title: Hostages in Iraq:For Europe, it's personal
New Indictment for Ex-Chief of HealthSouth
description: Richard M. Scrushy, the founder and former chief executive of the HealthSouth Corporation, faces new federal charges of perjury and obstruction of justice in a revised indictment by a grand jury, Alice H. Martin, the United States attorney in Birmingham, Ala., announced yesterday.

title: Computer Associates to Make Cuts
description: A week after settling federal charges of accounting fraud, Computer Associates International said yesterday that it would dismiss 800 workers and reduce the number of software products it sells to save $70 million a year.

title: Poncho Panache: One Style Fits All
description: CONSIDER the poncho.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBINSTEIN, IRENE S
description: RUBINSTEIN--Irene S, died on September 29th, in her 92nd year, after a long and fulfilling life. She is survived by her sons, Laurence, Peter and John in whom she took enormous pride; their wives, Robin, Kerry and Blair who gave her love and devotion; her grandchildren, Mara and Jeff Tanzman, Eve and John Papernick, Michael and Nicola Rubinstein, Noah, James, Jill and Adam, and her great grandson, Noah Tanzman, all of whom lightened and enlivened her life. For over 65 years, she was the devoted wife of Dr. Benjamin Rubinstein who pre-deceased her. She shared his interests and loyalties with unstinting vigor and intensity. Services will be at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 10 AM on Friday, October 1. RUBINSTEIN--Irene. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Irene Rubinstein, mother of our beloved Senior Rabbi Peter J. and Kerry Rubinstein, Rabbi Laurence and Robin Rubinstein, Dr. John and Blair Rubinstein and grandmother of Noah and Michael Rubinstein. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Sarah H. Reines, Rabbi Ruth A. Zlotnick, Rabbi Ida Rae Cahana, Cantor Alfred Youngwood, President

title: CONTINENTAL CLOSING TIRE PLANT IN KENTUCKY
description: Continental, the tire maker, said that it would close a Mayfield, Ky., plant by the end of the year, eliminating 985 jobs, after failing to win sufficient union cost cuts. Continental would keep some mixing work and warehousing operations at the site, the company said. The company said that it decided to go ahead with the closing after reviewing a Sept. 17 proposal from the United Steelworkers of America. Continental, based in Hanover, Germany, has been cutting costs by moving production of tires and car parts to countries where wages are lower.

title: Merchants Pay (and Pay) for Right to Use Credit Cards
description: The challenges that face business start-ups are familiar enough: scraping together start-up capital, hiring talent, fighting government red tape, recruiting customers. But pity small retail shops. For them, and other small businesses that rely on foot traffic or the Internet, a big frustration is getting a credit card terminal up and running.

title: Gods Are Catty to the Swamp's Miss Piggy
description: If there is some degree of cruelty in all comedy, there is more than some in "Plate," Jean-Philippe Rameau's comdie-lyrique from 1745 about an amphibian-like marsh nymph who has appointed herself the grande dame of the swamp where she lives.

title: Venezuela's New Campaign
description: WHEN countries advertise, they usually plug balmy weather or low taxes, all the better to lure tourist dollars or big-spending companies searching for investment opportunities.

title: On The Move : Screening program takes hold in the U.S.
To the Patio and Beyond: Speakers Without Wires
description: FALL is in the air!

title: The Division Is Almost in the Yankees' Hands
description: The big, blue bullpen door swung open yesterday, and Minnesota reliever Grant Balfour chugged onto the field. He lugged a navy jacket -- and hope for the Yankees. The Twins' relievers were much less confounding than the Minnesota ace, Johan Santana, and the Yankees managed a 5-3 victory in the first game of a doubleheader at Yankee Stadium.

title: Scott Muni, 74, a Radio D.J. of FM Rock Programming, Dies
description: Scott Muni, a disc jockey whose deep, leisurely, fogbound voice was a regular companion to New York City rock fans for nearly 50 years, died on Tuesday in New York. He was 74 and had not returned to the air after suffering a stroke in January.

title: Captive Briton in Iraq Implores Blair to Do More to Free Him
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 29 - Caged and shackled, a British engineer kidnapped here two weeks ago appeared Wednesday in a video and beseeched his government to work harder for his release.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the impact of Hurricane Charley on Historic Bok Sanctuary in Lake Wales, Fla., attributed a distinction to the sanctuary erroneously. It is not the highest point in the state; that is Britton Hill, in Lakewood Park in Walton County, 345 feet above sea level.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Sell Cheaper Windows In India
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would sell a cheaper version of Windows software in India to make it more affordable there. The cheaper Windows XP Starter Edition will start selling in India by early next year, Rajiv Kaul, managing director of Microsoft's India unit, told reporters in New Delhi. He declined to give the price of the software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLORAN, LEO A.
description: HALLORAN--Leo A., former vice-president of General Electric and chief financial officer at GE Capital who pioneered a wave of innovative financing structures throughout the 1980's, died from cancer on Tuesday at his home in Guilford, CT. Born on April 2, 1931 in Schenectady, NY, Mr. Halloran was a graduate of Union College and served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. His wife, Marilyn Gobeli Halloran, daughter Patricia Garvey, sons Michael Halloran and Kevin Halloran and five grandchildren survive Mr. Halloran. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 9:00 A.M. Saturday, Oct. 2nd at the Saint George Catholic Church in Guilford, CT. Mr. Halloran will be buried at the Most Holy Redeemer in Schenectady, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Carolyn Frye Halloran Memorial, Massachusetts General Hospital Development Office, 100 Charles River Place, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114-2792.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRY, JAMES W.
description: FRY--James W., 81, in Westport, CT. Member of the American Stock Exchange. Husband of the late Barbara Leavitt Fry. Father of Daniel, Margaret, Elizabeth, Victoria and Jennifer. Brother of Joan, and grandfather of four. Memorial service on Friday, 11:00 A.M., at the Unitarian Church of Westport.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATES DELPHI DEALINGS WITH ELECTRONIC DATA
description: The Delphi Corporation, the auto-parts maker, said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating $86.5 million of the company's transactions with the computer services provider, Electronic Data Systems. In a filing with the S.E.C., Delphi said that the agency sent it a subpoena in late July and a notice of an investigation in August. Delphi, based in Troy, Mich., said it was cooperating with the S.E.C. Delphi said the agency was investigating $46 million the company received from E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., in 2000 and 2001, and $40.5 million Delphi paid to E.D.S. in 2002 and 2003.

title: New Corrections Policy
description: Starting tomorrow, corrections on Page A2 will be published in two groupings. Substantive errors -- those that have materially affected the reader's understanding of a news development -- will be addressed under the traditional heading, "Corrections." Narrower errors -- those involving spelling, for example, or dates and historical references -- will be corrected under a second heading, "For the Record."

title: Corrections
Connecticut Man Charged in Extortion by Mob
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29 - After a flurry of early-morning arrests, federal prosecutors investigating organized crime unsealed indictments on Wednesday against 18 people, including a Stamford, Conn., man they say has been serving as the underboss of the Gambino crime family for two and a half years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Higher Bid For Song
description: Tele2, Sweden's second-largest telephone company, raised its bid for the Internet access provider Song Networks Holding to 4.95 billion kronor ($673 million), topping an offer by TDC of Denmark for a second time. Tele2, which is based in Stockholm, offered 85 kronor for each share of Song Networks, the company said. That compares with Tele2's first bid of 75 kronor and the TDC offer of 82.5 kronor that was made Tuesday. TDC and Tele2 are battling for control of Song Networks to gain access to the company's Nordic business customers for broadband Internet access. The chief executive Tele2, Lars-Johan Jarnheimer, above, said that TDC and Tele2 might collaborate on a wholesale deal if one of them acquires Song.

title: Choice of Losing Custody of Child or Returning to New York
description: When Janice Vega describes the trajectory of her life, it starts out as one of those scrappy, boot-strappy kind of stories, followed by a nearly fairy-tale twist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITMAN, JANET RUSSELL
description: WHITMAN -- Janet Russell. The Society for the Relief of Women and Children mourns the death of Janet Russell Whitman, who served on our Board for over 50 years. Her dedication, generosity and lively spirit will be deeply missed. Elizabeth Jacks Scott President WHITMAN--Janet R. The Board of Directors extends its heartfelt sympathy to the Whitman family on the passing of Janet R. Whitman, our past President. She had been a very active Board member over the past 35 years and will be greatly missed. Stony Wold-Herbert Fund

title: National Briefing | Washington: Language Problem Delays Asylum Case
description: A decision in the case of an asylum seeker who says he fled the killings in Darfur, Sudan, was delayed when the court-appointed interpreter told the judge that she was struggling to understand a Sudanese witness. The immigration judge in Elizabeth, N.J., rescheduled the hearing for next month. Lawyers believe that the asylum seeker, Fadl Ibrahim Mohammed, is among the first to seek refuge in the United States because of the violence in Darfur. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: In Australia, Tug of War Over Privatizing Phone Giant
description: His name will not be on any ballot, but when Australians go to the polls on Oct. 9, they may determine the future of a man widely known as Ziggy: the chief executive of Telstra, Zygmunt E. Switkowski.

title: Jury-Tampering Claim Halts L.I. Murder Trial
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Sept. 29 - It was a moment three years in the making as the Long Island electrician accused of killing the Manhattan financier R. Theodore Ammon strode into court here, winked at his family and sat down with his lawyers, ready to begin his murder trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOGARTY, JAMES E., ESQ.
description: FOGARTY--James E., Esq. Reiss Corp. mourns the death of its Director Jim Fogarty, and acknowledges with deep appreciation his enormous contribution to every aspect of the corporation and to the Reiss family. Jim joined Reiss as in-house counsel in 1947 and remained a Director until his death. His advice and friendship will be sorely missed. Theodore and Carl Reiss

title: Principal Faces Firing in Hazing
description: The Department of Education is moving to fire a former principal of the Street Academy High School in Brooklyn after investigators said he mishandled a student's allegations that he had been assaulted in a fraternity hazing incident.

title: Senate Bill Aims at Makers of File-Sharing Software
description: Just over a year ago, the recording industry unleashed its first barrage of lawsuits against people who share music online -- a move that appeared to curtail illegal file swapping briefly. But in the months since, activity on file-sharing networks has recovered and grown, prompting the music and movie industries to try legislating the file-sharing beast into submission.

title: Kerry Says Flip-Flop Image 'Doesn't Reflect the Truth'
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 29 - On the eve of his first debate with President Bush, Senator John Kerry acknowledged Wednesday that the Bush campaign had succeeded in defining him as changing his mind too often -- in part because he has had "inarticulate moments" -- but said that the portrayal "doesn't reflect the truth."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, MICHAEL
description: STRAUSS--Michael. Service Guild of Long Island Jewish Medical Center mourns the passing of Michael Strauss. He is survived by his wife, Anne, longtime board member, and his two sons Dr. Richard Strauss and Mr. Robert Strauss. Our sincere condolences to the family.

title: Decrease in Oil Prices Helps Send Share Prices Higher
description: Stocks rose yesterday as the price of oil declined and a government report showed that the economy grew faster in the second quarter than previously reported.

title: 3 Weeks After Hurricane, Grenada's Life Is Still in Ruins
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Sept. 29 - Alfred Morain could hardly summon the words to describe what he experiences when he looks at his land filled with dead nutmeg trees, which Hurricane Ivan felled as it swept over this island three weeks ago, blowing away Mr. Morain's livelihood with it.

title: Surakiart Emerges as Favorite to Succeed Annan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 30 A Thailand's foreign minister, Surakiart Sathirathai, a Harvard-educated lawyer with a background in politics, finance and international economics, has emerged as an early favorite to succeed Kofi Annan as secretary general when his term ends in 2006.

title: On TV, Dwell Magazine Puts the Warm Into Modern
description: Dwell, the San Francisco-based magazine, has been spun off into a television series, which makes its debut on Sunday at 7 p.m. on the Fine Living Network. Each episode includes in-depth looks at two modern residences, as well as segments on home products. The second show in the series features a restored Joseph Eichler house in Marin County, Calif., bottom, while the eighth looks at a glass house built on a ranch near Austin, Tex., below. "There's a conception that modern is cold and sterile," said Gabriella Messina, the show's executive producer. "But we're trying to highlight that there's so much diversity to what modern can be." For more information, www.fineliving.com.

title: A New-Style Indian Village Rises From the Dust
description: WINNEBAGO, Neb. - PROGRESS has a way of backfiring on the Winnebago tribe of Nebraska. Over the past decade tribal businesses have flourished where poverty had long been the rule. Many of the 2,600 people living amid the rolling green and tan fields of the 120,000-acre Winnebago Indian Reservation have found jobs and begun to make decent money. But some of those same people, finding that their higher incomes made them ineligible for public housing, ended up leaving the reservation because there was no place else there for them to live.

title: Changing Direction
description: You say that we are winning in Iraq. Senator Chuck Hagel, a Republican, says, "We're in deep trouble." Gen. John P. Abizaid is asking for more troops. Secretary of State Colin Powell admits the insurgency is getting worse. The C.I.A. is pessimistic. Billions of dollars that were earmarked for reconstruction have been diverted for security. Insurgent attacks have quadrupled. Deaths of coalition troops are up. Significant chunks of Iraq are under enemy control. You have no viable military plan to make sure the January elections proceed peacefully and no political plan to reconcile competing factions. Your argument for re-election is that this is too dangerous a time to change direction. But since the direction is obviously wrong, don't we at least need to change drivers?

title: Knicks' Houston Proceeding With Caution
description: Allan Houston could have gone the bravado route, proclaimed himself fit and guaranteed a full 82-game season for his much-scrutinized knees. For an antsy Knicks fan base, and a hopeful front office, those would have been welcome assurances.

title: In Debate on Foreign Policy, Wide Gulf or Splitting Hairs?
description: Correction Appended

title: Iraqis Look With Hope to School Openings Twice Delayed by Violence
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - In this second school year since the United States deposed Saddam Hussein, Iraqi education officials have twice put off the start of classes, citing instability in the provinces.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 about Joan E. Mahon-Powell, a former New York City schools official who admitted that she had used false credentials to rise through the ranks, misidentified the location of Junior High School 292, where she was promoted to principal in 1997. It is in the East New York section of Brooklyn, not Bushwick. The article also misidentified the neighborhood primarily covered by Community School District 19, where she was named acting superintendent in 1999. It is East New York, not Bushwick.

title: 400 Kindergartners Get a Key to the Future
description: Tiffany Hedges, 24, arrived at the Apollo Theater yesterday morning expecting some kind of education announcement. What she learned was that her son Tyrell, 5, would be one of 400 Harlem kindergartners to receive a free college education.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stop-Gap Bill on Spending Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Acknowledging that Congress will not finish almost all of its required spending bills on time, the House and Senate adopted a stopgap measure on Wednesday to keep federal agencies running through Nov. 20.

title: French Utility Seizes Chance to Sell Oil Stock at a Profit
description: PARIS, Sept. 29 - Electricit de France, the government-owned power utility, said Wednesday that it had sold its 2.34 percent stake in the oil company Total, raising $3.2 billion in an effort to burnish its financial position ahead of a partial privatization.

title: Memories of Roger Straus by Writers He Championed
description: Writers, editors and friends -- among them some of the talents whom Roger W. Straus Jr. nurtured, fed (literally) and helped make famous -- gathered yesterday afternoon in Manhattan to remember the man who was known to the literary world as the last of the great independent publishers.

title: Hu takes charge
Learning ABC's and Sowing Seeds
description: THE current edition of Green Teacher, a magazine devoted to schoolyard gardening, suggests the following exercise: ask children to list their favorite brand names on a sheet of paper and draw the corresponding logos. Then ask them to list types of trees and draw their leaves.

title: Judge Strikes Down Section of Patriot Act Allowing Secret Subpoenas of Internet Data
description: Correction Appended

title: Strike Deadline Approaches for Office Building Janitors
description: The owners and managers of more than 1,000 office buildings in New York City were rushing to make final preparations yesterday for a possible strike at 12:01 a.m. tomorrow by 25,000 janitors and other building-service workers.

title: Merck Pulls Vioxx Painkiller From Market, and Stock Plunges
description: Merck & Company announced today that it was immediately pulling its arthritis and acute pain medication Vioxx from the worldwide market after data from a clinical trial showed that the drug produces an increased risk for heart attacks and strokes.

title: CVS TO CLOSE 160 ECKERD STORES WITH LAGGING SALES
description: The CVS Corporation, operator of the CVS chain of drugstores, said that it planned to close 160 Eckerd stores this year, or about one-eighth of those acquired from the J.C. Penney Company, to eliminate the least profitable outlets. The company expected to complete converting 1,100 Eckerd stores to CVS locations by July, the chief executive, Tom Ryan, said at a meeting with analysts and investors in New York. He did not say how many jobs would be lost. CVS, based in Woonsocket, R.I., said before it completed the $2.15 billion Eckerd purchase in July that it might close as many as 225 stores where sales lagged.

title: Elizabeth Eakins Takes Fabrics Back to the Past
description: Today, Elizabeth Eakins, a Manhattan company known for muted hand-woven rugs, will introduce its first fabric collection, Toiles Indiennes, 54 hand-printed linen-cotton-blend designs. Most of them are based on 18th- and 19th-century French and English work. Sanchi, below, is an adaptation of a 19th-century Irish linen. The designs sell for $108 a yard to architects and designers at the John Rosselli showroom, 979 Third Avenue (59th Street), (212) 593-2060. ELAINE LOUIE

title: World Bank meeting : Ending poverty is the key to stability
Mulk Raj Anand, 99, Famed Indian Writer, Dies
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 - Mulk Raj Anand, a renowned figure among Indian writers in English whose works depicted the lives of people in India's traditional society, an art critic and an educator, died at Jehandir hospital in Pune on Tuesday.

title: A New Phone and Techie Controversy at Verizon
description: Last week on "The Amazing Race for the Perfect Phone," Verizon Wireless announced that it was emerging from its cocoon of technological backwardness.

title: Arts Briefing
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Complaints Yield Change In Road Name
description: The Fort Bend County Commission voted unanimously to change the name of a rural route 45 miles east of Houston from Jap Road to Moore Branch Road. In August, the Jefferson County Commission made a similar change for a road near Beaumont after complaints about the name, which came about because of a Japanese farmer who lived in the area 80 years ago. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Conoco Wins Lukoil Bid, a Window on Iraq
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 - ConocoPhillips paid nearly $2 billion at auction on Wednesday for the Russian government's stake in Lukoil, a purchase that could allow Conoco to become the first Western company to return to Iraq's oil fields.

title: Giants and Favre Want to Create Amid Chaos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 29 - For the past two weeks, the Giants have been unveiling their defensive philosophy, and it is not for the faint of heart.

title: A Trio's Transformation Into a Quartet
description: The pianist Brad Mehldau is revealing a new band this week in the cold light of the Village Vanguard, and the project has a ways to go.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about gains President Bush is making in swing states that he lost in 2000 gave an erroneous total for the electoral votes Senator John Kerry might win based on states that are now supporting him or leaning his way. It is 185, not 177.

title: SOCCER : Rooney is dazzling in his United debut
Help Sites for Dropouts Are Closed
description: The New York City Education Department has shut down dozens of sites used by dropouts to prepare for the high school equivalency exam, bewildering staff members and creating a chaotic situation for young people already at risk of abandoning their studies.

title: Blair and the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Investors Buy Stake in a Big Hollywood Agency
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 - One of Hollywood's leading talent management companies, the Firm, has sold a minority stake to two private equity investors, Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital, the companies said Wednesday.

title: Russian Government Backs U.N. Accord on Global Warming
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30 A After years of unusually public infighting, the Russian cabinet approved the Kyoto Protocol on global warming today and prepared to send it to parliament, where its expected approval would allow the long-delayed climate change treaty to come into force around the world.

title: Martnez Loses 4th Straight as Red Sox Finally Fade
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 29 - Since Pedro Martnez was pitching at Tropicana Field, not Yankee Stadium, it took until the third batter before he was reminded of the memorable, despondent words that spilled out of his mouth about the Yankees five days ago.

title: Former Chief of Royal Ahold Facing Charges
description: AMSTERDAM, Sept. 29 - Once considered a captain of the Dutch corporate world, Cees van der Hoeven, the former chief executive of Royal Ahold, disclosed on Wednesday that he was facing charges by prosecutors here in connection with the $1.2 billion accounting scandal that nearly destroyed the international food company he helped create.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about nighttime activities in the American Museum of Natural History in New York misattributed a comment from a security guard who said he sometimes thought he heard ceremonial chanting from an American Indian display. The speaker was Frank Saunders, not William Anderson Jr., the guard pictured.

title: A New Way to DescribeComputer Muscle Power
description: Q. The way computer processor speed is listed has changed, but what does it all mean? How can I find out how fast the chip is supposed to be if the gigahertz speed is not listed?

title: New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sept. 14 about the Bush administration's record on environmental issues referred incorrectly to a regulation adopted this year to control emissions from off-road diesel engines. The regulation tightened existing standards; it was not the first federal effort to control emissions from most diesel engines. Highway vehicles have been regulated since 1988 and some off-road engines have been regulated since 1996.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: To Fans, Expos' Goodbye Is More Bitter Than Sweet
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 29 - With flashbulbs firing all around him and cheers ringing in his ears, Terrmel Sledge of the Montreal Expos batted with two outs in the ninth inning and his team trailing the Florida Marlins by 9-1 Wednesday night.

title: Torre Is Hoping to Use Hernndez
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre said yesterday that he hoped that Orlando Hernndez would be able to start tomorrow in Toronto against the Blue Jays.

title: Children on Both Sides Killed on Northern Border of Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 - A Palestinian rocket attack killed two Israeli children, ages 2 and 4, and Israeli soldiers killed five Palestinians on Wednesday in bloodshed that claimed young lives on both sides of the Gaza Strip's northern border.

title: Ex-Pastor Charged in Theft From a Church
description: For more than 30 years, the Rev. Charles E. Betts Sr. helped build the Morning Star Missionary Baptist Church in Jamaica, Queens, into a formidable center of political, religious and community activity. It became a must-stop for national politicians campaigning in New York, where they would invariably be introduced by the pastor.

title: Tonight's the Night: Bush and Kerry, Head to Head (10 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 7th journalist is slain in Philippines
ABN Amro Raises Guard on Money Laundering
description: AMSTERDAM, Sept. 29 - ABN Amro Holding N.V., the biggest Dutch bank by assets, is improving measures to help prevent money laundering after regulators in the United States said the company's New York branch had inadequate internal controls.

title: Euro Disney avoids collapse with debt deal
Death Sentences in Attack on Cole
description: CAIRO, Sept. 29 - A judge in Yemen sentenced two men to death and four others to prison terms of up to 10 years on Wednesday for the deadly attack in 2000 against the American destroyer Cole. The convictions were the first ones stemming from the maritime suicide bombing, which provided an early glimpse of the brazen nature of Osama bin Laden's global terror network.

title: Luxury Living in a Hyperactive Building
description: ST. LOUIS - WHEN Bob Cassilly made a bid to buy the International Shoe Company building in 1993, he half hoped he would be turned down. "It was just so big and intimidating," he said of the 10-story, 670,000-square-foot building. "I made this ridiculously low offer. But it was accepted."

title: Private Craft Rockets Past Edge of Space
description: MOJAVE, Calif., Sept. 29 - Completing the first leg of a quest for a $10 million prize, a test pilot took a privately financed plane past the cusp of space on Wednesday morning in a flight that had equal measures of white-knuckle moments and triumph.

title: Bush Returns to Florida, Storm Rent but Vote Rich
description: Correction Appended

title: Washington: The City of Broken Promises
description: YOU wouldn't want to stake your life savings on the strength of Bud Selig's word.

title: Baseball Is Back in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Back in the days when the Washington Senators were losers, which was often, there was a saying: "First in war, first in peace, and last in the American League."

title: Congolese Roots Now Helped by Hip-Hop
description: Leave it to Marie Daulne, the leader of Zap Mama, to come up with something new in audience participation. On Tuesday night at Irving Plaza, after she had gotten the crowd to sing along in African-style two-part counterpoint, she urged, "Shake your keys!" Soon the room filled with metallic tinkling.

title: Hate-Crime Accuser Charged With Arson
description: McALLEN, Tex., Sept. 29 - The owner of a Middle Eastern meat market who had said he was the victim of a hate crime in this border town was arrested and arraigned Tuesday on a felony arson charge that he set fire to his own business.

title: New Company Starts Up a Challenge to Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 - Google executives have long conceded that one of their great fears is to be overtaken by a more advanced Internet search technology. Vivisimo, a company founded by three former Carnegie Mellon University computer scientists, is hoping to prove that Google's worries are well founded.

title: A Canap Lures an Opponent Into a Suit With a Bad Split
description: At the dawn of contract bridge, about 70 years ago, some French experts developed the canap principle: a short suit is bid first, with a longer suit in reserve. This idea is still popular in France, Italy and other parts of Europe, but since it implies four-card major openings, it is rarely encountered in North America.

title: A 178-Foot Surprise Rises Over Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Those who live and work in this fortified city woke up Wednesday to find a 178-foot white blimp floating in highly restricted airspace about 1,000 feet above some of the most visible symbols of American democracy and military strength -- the White House, the Capitol and the Pentagon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Commissioner Leaves Office
description: Christopher O. Ward, left, commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection, is leaving to become president and chief executive of American Stevedoring, a port operator, city officials said yesterday. "All New Yorkers owe Chris Ward a debt of gratitude," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said in a statement. "Each day, millions of New Yorkers turn on the tap and flush the toilets without giving it a thought. It's a small miracle that Chris Ward has helped perform every day." American Stevedoring is awaiting approval of a renewal lease from the Port Authority -- where Mr. Ward was chief of planning and external affairs before joining the city -- to operate a port along the Brooklyn waterfront. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: All Over the Living Room, An Acoustic Sweet Spot
description: One nice thing about a new home theater is all the new friends you get along with it. But for the guests seated in the corners, the viewing and listening experience can be less than optimal. The screen may look dimmer and the sound quality deteriorates.

title: Question Time: What to Ask George Bush; The Iran Threat
description: There are reports coming out of Iraq that your administration plans to conduct military crackdowns on insurgent areas after the election in the United States, to regain control before the Iraqi elections in January. Is that your plan, and do you think that attacking Iraqi cities, as we have done in Falluja and Najaf, is in the long-term interest of the United States?

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Man Accused Of War Crimes
description: A man who federal prosecutors say was a member of a military unit that killed hundreds of Muslims in the former Yugoslavia was indicted on charges that he lied about his past affiliation with the group. The man, Marko Boskic, 40, of Peabody, is charged with four counts of immigration document fraud for not revealing his entire military history, and one false statements count. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Pair of Car Bombs in Iraq Kill Dozens, Including Many Children
description: AGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 30 - In one of the most horrific attacks here since the fall of Saddam Hussein, a pair of car bombs tore through a street celebration today at the opening of a new government-built sewer plant, killing 41 Iraqi civilians, at least 34 of them children, and wounding 139 people.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Radio Broadcaster Acquired
description: Capital Radio, Britain's biggest commercial radio broadcaster, agreed to buy another broadcaster, the GWR Group, for about 341 million ($618 million) to reduce costs and to increase advertising revenue. Capital Radio shareholders will own 52 percent of the combined company, and GWR's shareholders will own the rest. The companies have not yet picked a name for the new business, GWR's chairman, Ralph Bernard, said in a conference call with analysts. Combining GWR and Capital Radio will save at least 7.5 million ($13.6 million) annually, the companies said. It may give them more power in negotiations with advertisers and reduce Capital Radio's dependence on its flagship station, 95.8 FM. The station is battling with Heart 106.2 of the Chrysalis Group to remain London's most popular station and to attract the highest ad rates.

title: Who Says Design Is Just for Adults? In This Toy Store Style Counts
description: Finally, a design store for the preschool set. On Sept. 23, Lisa Mahar opened Kid O, a shop in Greenwich Village that sells modernist toys, furniture and books for children. "As a mom and as an architect, I was frustrated that I couldn't find well-made toys with both style and substance," Ms. Mahar said. She decided to open the store last winter after a friend gave Emmett, her son (left, with Ms. Mahar), a sleek wooden car by the designer Ulf Hanses. Within two weeks, she was scouting for products in Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RUDTKE, HELGA
description: RUDTKE--Helga. A year has passed and you are missed and loved by all your friends. Gl

title: Leaders Say Senate Can Act on 9/11 Bills Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 - Senate leaders promised Wednesday that they would act within days to reorganize the way the Senate provides oversight on intelligence and domestic security, a response to criticism by the Sept. 11 commission that Congressional oversight was dysfunctional.

title: Grants Will Preserve Paperless Bits of History
description: THE Library of Congress is giving $15 million to eight institutions to preserve a range of electronic material, including Web sites relating to the 2003 California gubernatorial recall election, digital maps, sound recordings and decades' worth of social science data.

title: A.I.G. Is Focus of Federal Inquiry
description: The American International Group, one of the world's largest insurance companies, said yesterday that the Justice Department had begun a criminal investigation of one of its units over possible violations of federal securities laws.

title: Spinning a high-tech web of innovation
A Little Bit of Elsewhere, at Elsewares
description: Elsewares, a Web catalog of objects for the home that are not available at big stores, offers place mats, left, with photographs of roadside diners, $18 for 48; a vase whose color changes with room temperature, $89; and other unpredictable designs. At www.elsewares.com or (866) 578-0730. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Forstmann Said to Make Deal for Talent Agency
description: Correction Appended

title: A Transfusion of Fresh Power for an IPod on Its Last Legs
description: Music may last forever, but batteries do not. The battery life -- and life expectancy -- of Apple's iPod has been a hot topic among the faithful since the earliest models began to reach an advanced age.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: M.T.A. Offers Capital Plan
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board approved a $27.8 billion proposed capital program yesterday, but questions loom about how it will be paid for. The board sent the proposal to Albany, where lawmakers will haggle over the amount of the appropriation and where financing will come from. The five-year program includes $17 billion for basic upkeep, modernizing equipment and rehabilitating stations, as well as billions more for security improvements and expansion projects, including the Second Avenue subway line and connecting the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal. The authority had to pay for much of its last rebuilding program by itself by issuing bonds. Payments coming due on that debt, however, have produced yawning budget deficits. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Question Time: What to Ask George Bush; Of God and War
description: Do you really believe that there are fewer terrorists plotting against America today than there were before you began the invasion of Iraq?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,050 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: U.S. Gives Europe a Fresh Look At the Last Century
description: European furniture dealers are increasingly looking to the United States for surprising 20th-century design, and the work of two lesser-known Americans is now on display in Paris. Paul Evans (1931-87) created one-of-a-kind sculptural furnishings with finishes in bronze, copper, pewter and aluminum. They are at Galerie Patrick Fourtin until Oct. 30; 6, place Valois, 011-33-1-42-60-12-63. The work of James Mont (1904-78), whose settee is shown above, will be at Eric Philippe until Oct. 20; 25, galerie Vero-Dodat, 011-33-1-42-33-28-26. Mr. Mont mixed contemporary lines with Asian and ancient Greek references for his Hollywood clients, who included Lana Turner and John Barrymore. MALLERY ROBERTS LANE

title: Corrections
The Travels of a Bioengineered Gene
description: A study showing that genes from a type of genetically engineered grass migrated much farther than anyone had thought possible virtually demands a careful reassessment of how such plants are regulated. We must ensure that the genes from genetically engineered plants do not escape into the wild and wreak havoc in natural ecosystems.

title: Ukraine adds to debate on 'transit' camps
Elusive Last Out in 9th Haunts Cubs Again
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29 - The silence was unearthly, as if 38,190 people were sitting in the Wrigley Field stands Wednesday afternoon bound and gagged. The Cubs are in a mad chase for the wild card in the National League playoffs, and on Wednesday, for the second time in five days, they lost a game they were within one strike of winning.

title: Construction Worker Dies in Fall at Trade Center Site
description: A construction worker at a 52-story skyscraper being built near ground zero fell down an elevator shaft to his death yesterday. It was the first death reported during reconstruction at the World Trade Center site since Sept. 11, 2001.

title: New Runoff System in San Francisco Has the Rival Candidates Cooperating
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 - Eugene C. Wong is running for an office that typically does not draw the national spotlight. Yet Mr. Wong and the 64 others seeking seats on the County Board of Supervisors here are being closely watched by advocates for election reform around the country.

title: Planning Iraq's future : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Sorry Seems to Be the Hardest Word
description: Maybe sorry really is the hardest word.

title: Where to tune in on debates
Dr. John E. Mack, Psychiatrist, Dies at 74
description: Dr. John E. Mack, a Pulitzer Prize winner and Harvard psychiatrist who studied people who said they had encounters with alien beings, died in London on Monday. He was 74 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ASML And Zeiss To Pay Nikon $145 Million To Settle Suit
description: The Nikon Corporation, the world's biggest maker of equipment used to etch computer chip circuits onto silicon wafers, said yesterday it would get $87 million from its European rival ASML Holding to settle a patent suit dating back to 2001. Nikon, based in Tokyo, will also receive $58 million from Carl Zeiss SMT in relation to the lawsuit. The companies announced the agreement earlier this month without giving financial details.

title: Florida Sunshine In Pillows and Duvets
description: "A huge part of our relationship is projects," said Jennifer Subrin, who started a business with her husband, Dennis Witnauer, making couch pillows, duvet covers and pillowcases using vintage fabrics. "I'm an actress, and Dennis is a painter," she added. "I go on the fly, and he has pretty specific ideas of how things fit together."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOSSITER, BERNARD D.
description: NOSSITER--Bernard D. On September 27, 2004. Adored brother of Elayne N. Boros and Suzanne Gordon; a gentleman and a gentle man.

description: Paintings and drawings by Elizabeth Peyton.

title: Patron Sweethearts
description: Think of them as thoroughly modern Medicis. They're the ladies who plan the galas and buy the art.

description: Tips for your next public reading.

description: By BONNIE TSUI Back in the studio after a long summer at the beach? Here's the latest gear to renew your practice.

title: Through the Glass, Quickly
description: These are some of the faces and places that Senator John Kerry saw over the last two months if he happened to look out the window as his campaign motorcade rolled by.
